headline: Hens, Unbound
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Factory Farming', 'Chickens', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Referendums', 'Pigs']
abstract: A new law is a significant step forward in animal welfare.
lead_paragraph: The most significant animal welfare law in recent history — California’s Prop 2 — takes effect today. The measure, which passed by a landslide vote in 2008, requires egg and some meat producers to confine their animals in far more humane conditions than they did before. No longer will baby calves (veal) or gestational pigs be kept in crates so small they cannot turn around and, perhaps more significantly, egg-laying hens may not be held in “battery” cages that prevent them from spreading their wings.

Gen. David M. Rodriguez, the top general for American missions in Africa, rushed from his headquarters here to help the commanders in the crisis.

headline: New C.D.C. Job Overseeing Laboratory Safety
keywords: ['Ebola Virus', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: A new job title — chief of laboratory safety — will be created at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the agency announced Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A new job title — chief of laboratory safety — will be created at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the agency said Wednesday. The move follows a series of lab accidents, the most recent of which may have exposed a scientist to the Ebola virus. Applicants are being recruited, and a spokeswoman said that whoever filled the post would report directly to the C.D.C.'s director, currently Dr. Thomas R. Frieden. Each of the agency’s divisions had handled lab safety separately. In the past year, different high-security C.D.C. labs shipped out samples of anthrax, H5N1 bird flu and Ebola that had not been properly killed. Thus far, there have been no injuries and no spread of the pathogens, but the agency’s procedures have been heavily criticized as sloppy.

headline: Massachusetts: New Effort to Move Bombings Trial
abstract: Lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the defendant in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, made a last-ditch effort late Wednesday to move the trial out of Boston.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the defendant in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, made a last-ditch effort late Wednesday to move the trial out of Boston. In a 32-page filing, they asked a federal appeals court to grant a change of venue, or at a minimum to order the trial judge, George A. O’Toole Jr., to hold a hearing on moving the trial. They also asked Judge O’Toole to delay the start of jury selection, which is scheduled for Monday, while the appeals court considers its request. Judge O’Toole has twice denied the request, most recently earlier Wednesday, saying the jury selection process could find impartial jurors. But Mr. Tsarnaev’s lawyers insisted that would be impossible, arguing that virtually everyone in the Boston region has a connection to the marathon and is, “in effect, an actual victim.” Government prosecutors have until 5 p.m. Thursday to respond.

headline: Ben Ammi Ben-Israel Dies at 75: Led Black Americans in Migration to Israel
abstract: Mr. Ben-Israel, a former metal worker from Chicago, became known as a holy father to members of the African Hebrew Israelites of Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: Ben Ammi Ben-Israel, a former Chicago metal worker who led a migration of hundreds of fellow black Americans to what they consider their ancestral homeland, Israel, died on Saturday in a hospital in Beersheba, Israel. He was 75.

headline: Central Park, After Hours
abstract: At 4 a.m., in the city that never sleeps, it’s just me and the raccoons.
lead_paragraph: It’s not yet 4 a.m. and I’m out walking at a healthy clip. The moon is bright. In the distance, a subway train toots its horn, breaking the silence. A pair of ducks waddle through the mist across my path. Rounding the bend, I detect movement among the trees and notice a shadow lurching. I quicken my step, but then stop to see two large raccoons locked in a mating embrace. They give me a startled stare but then get back to business.

lead_paragraph: It was a confounding year in global financial markets. Not because it was a disaster for most investors; American stocks and bonds both rose in value. It was confounding because of some major moves that defied expert consensus this time a year ago — not only what was predicted, but what was even thought plausible.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11 A.M. (HGTV) ROSE PARADE 2015 The new year is once again coming up roses for HGTV, which heralds 2015 from its traditional perch at this 126th annual parade. Louis Zamperini, the Olympic runner turned World War II bombardier of “Unbroken” fame, who died in July, will be honored as the grand marshal as nearly 40 floats inch their way down Colorado Boulevard in Pasadena, Calif. The floats, adorned with more botanical elements than the average florist might go through in year, are based on inspirational stories. The “Property Brothers” — Drew and Jonathan Scott — and Nancy O’Dell will provide play-by-play. (The parade will also be broadcast on ABC, NBC and the Hallmark Channel. The University of Oregon will take on Florida State in the Rose Bowl game at 5 p.m. on ESPN.) The HGTV programming moves into prime time at 8 with a tour of the latest “Dream Home” giveaway: a 3,200-square-foot, three-bedroom Cape Cod-style vacation house on Martha’s Vineyard. The property includes soaring ceilings, patios off each sleeping area, a bike rack and a doggy dream home. The winner also gets furnishings from Ethan Allen, a GMC Acadia Denali and $250,000.

lead_paragraph: Minutes before midnight on New Year’s Eve at Madison Square Garden, the dance party paused for a video montage. As a look back on the year that was, it was a bit random, mixing hints of hellishness with small victories: Robin Williams’s death, Ebola and Ferguson, Mo., but also Derek Jeter’s farewell to Yankee Stadium, a goal by Clint Dempsey in the World Cup and footage from Burning Man of the night’s headlining D.J.s, Diplo and Skrillex.

headline: Your Next Lesson: St.-Joseph
abstract: The best combination of value and distinctiveness is found in St.-Joseph, a region that follows the sinuous north-south twists of the Rhône River.
lead_paragraph: I tend not to think of wines seasonally. The convention of reds in cold weather, and whites and rosés in warm, doesn’t make much sense to me, as food dictates the choice of a wine more than the temperature. Yet certain exceptions present themselves: namely, the red wines of the northern Rhône Valley of France, which I seem to crave especially in the fall and winter.

headline: Days of Remembrance
abstract: Celebrate some of our national holidays this month.
lead_paragraph: TIMES INSIDER — Happy New Year! Baby, it’s cold outside, and a person could develop cabin fever during a month like January. The holidays are over and the decorations have hopefully been put away. Or if they haven’t, no worries; we don’t judge. But we need something to keep us occupied until the spring thaw.

headline: Ten Tips for Happiness, on a Postcard From the Past
abstract: Advice from a stack of postcards hidden in a closet years ago: Encourage your children in what they want, not what you want. Also, keep a good figure.
lead_paragraph: When Michelle Grewe was going through some boxes in her grandfather’s house, she found a cache of writing by her grandmother, Eleanor Virginia Webster. Among other things, she’d written out her “Ten Tips to Happiness” on a series of 20 postcards, sometime during the war in Vietnam. No one in her family had seen the postcards, or realized that Eleanor, who died in 1998, was a closet writer. Michelle and I both thought “all of you young people” would appreciate her grandmother’s words. — KJ Dell’Antonia

lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — At least 25 civilians were believed to have died in southern Afghanistan after shelling amid fierce fighting struck a wedding party, Afghan officials said Thursday.

headline: Where Big Stars and Space Heaters Mix
abstract: Why Classic Stage Company continues to draw big-name actors to perform in a 199-seat space in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: “This obviously isn’t for money or glory, so come and do it if you want.”

headline: T’s Top 10 Travel Stories of 2014
abstract: These 10 travel stories explore exotic destinations, a black market and even the journey itself.
lead_paragraph: These 10 travel stories explore exotic destinations, a black market and even the journey itself. More…

headline: Upshot Highlights, 2014
abstract: What Do Fruit, Robots and Celebrity Deaths Have in Common?
lead_paragraph: You may have read the list of the articles that the readers of The Upshot liked the most. This is the list of Upshot features that the writers, photo editors and graphics editors most liked doing for you:

headline: New York City’s Pedestrian Fatalities Lowest on Record in 2014
abstract: The reduction came as the city began to put into effect Mayor Bill de Blasio’s Vision Zero plan to try to eliminate all traffic deaths by 2024.
lead_paragraph: Pedestrian deaths in New York City fell to a historic low last year after a push by the city to make streets less dangerous.

headline: Abandoning Doubt in Sedona, Arizona
abstract: A couple choose to celebrate their love with a leap of faith in a mystical land.
lead_paragraph: While the idea of renewing your vows on a tropical beach at sunset like a pair of histrionic telenovela stars may sound romantic to some, my husband, Sacha, and I found the idea of celebrating our anniversary that way, well, boring.

headline: A Midtown Apartment Offers a Change of Pace
abstract: Brian and Stephanie Cashin decided to switch from a walk-up to a high-rise.
lead_paragraph: After their wedding and honeymoon in September, Brian and Stephanie Cashin turned their attention to an apartment hunt.

headline: 8 Ways to Save on Travel in 2015
abstract: Tips on how to save money by better using tools you already know.
lead_paragraph: Interested in 37 newfangled apps that will save you 0.01 percent on travel for the coming year? I didn’t think so. At some point, you have to stop trying to find every new tool for and shortcut to bargains as they appear and just wait to see which ones stick. By now, you surely know some basics: You probably use meta-search sites to compare airfare and hotel prices; you’ve either tried or consciously avoided “sharing economy” services like Uber; you know that most domestic car rental reservations can be canceled with no penalty should you find a better rate even on the day of the trip.

headline: Bob Hall, Harlem Globetrotter Who Relished the Showman Role, Dies at 87
abstract: A dazzling ball handler who was built like a Sherman tank, Hall would launch one-handed, no-look, behind-the-back passes that mesmerized universal crowds, even in the Soviet Union.
lead_paragraph: Bob Hall, a key showman for the Harlem Globetrotters, basketball’s barnstorming comedy troupe, from the late 1940s until the mid-1970s, died on Dec. 24 near his home in Detroit. He was 87.

headline: 1907-8 | The Times Drops the Ball
abstract: The marriage of The Times and New Year’s Eve began Dec. 31, 1904, when the newspaper moved from Lower Manhattan into a 24-story tower in the newly named Times Square.
lead_paragraph: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

headline: A Kanye West-Paul McCartney Single Drops Just Before the Ball
abstract: Just before midnight on New Year’s Eve, Kanye West released a new single featuring Paul McCartney.
lead_paragraph: It turns out 2014 wasn’t a Kanye-less year after all. Before midnight on Wednesday, Mr. West released a new single titled “Only One,” featuring Paul McCartney, on his website and iTunes.

headline: Andrew Cuomo Puts Bigger Challenges on His 2nd-Term Agenda
abstract: Beginning his second term only hours before the death of his father, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo in his inaugural address promised to confront issues of economic mobility and fairness in the justice system.
lead_paragraph: Beginning his second term only hours before the death of his father, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday promised to confront some of the most deep-rooted challenges facing New York and the nation: unfairness in the criminal justice system, an eroded economic mobility and the distortion of the public education system from a “great equalizer” during his father’s youth into a “great discriminator” for children born into poverty today.

headline: 1914: Christmas at the Front
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1914: Christmas in the trenches.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — ‘‘Eye-Witness,’’ in his latest descriptive account sent from General Headquarters, tells, as follows, how the soldiers passed Christmas at the front: ‘‘Christmas has come and gone, but it has brought no modification of the situation. On Christmas Eve a hard frost set in, and Dec. 25 was very cold, though it was not bright, for a mist hung over the countryside.

headline: Real Estate Chief Fears Troubled Sibling Has New Weapon: TV
abstract: Douglas Durst, a man of few words, great wealth and dynastic power over Manhattan real estate, has said virtually nothing in public about his older brother, Robert. Until now.
lead_paragraph: Douglas Durst recalled the last time he saw and spoke with his troubled older brother, Robert.

headline: Recent History in One Chart
abstract: Twin peaks and the valley of despond.
lead_paragraph: A number of people have been putting up candidates for chart of the year. For me, the big chart of 2014 wasn’t actually from 2014 — it was from earlier work (pdf) by Branko Milanovic, which I somehow didn’t see until a few months ago. It shows income growth since 1988 by percentiles of the world income distribution (as opposed to national distributions):

headline: Proulx Says She Regrets ‘Brokeback Mountain’
abstract: “I wish I’d never written the story,” Annie Proulx says of “Brokeback Mountain.”
lead_paragraph: Regrets, Annie Proulx has had a few, starting with “Brokeback Mountain.” That 1997 story about two gay cowboys may have won wide acclaim and been turned into an Oscar-winning movie, but in a 2009 interview with The Paris Review, which drew renewed attention this week, Ms. Proulx said she wished she could take it back.

headline: 3 Die in Queens Fire; City Records First Killing of 2015
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The blaze began in a ninth-floor kitchen apartment in LeFrak City and killed a married couple and their 37-year-old niece.
lead_paragraph: Just minutes before the New Year’s Eve ball dropped in Times Square, three members of a family in Queens died in a fire that started in the kitchen of their ninth-floor apartment in the LeFrak City housing complex, officials said on Thursday.

headline: Government Spending, Edging Up, Is a Stimulus
keywords: ['States (US)', 'Local Government', 'United States Economy', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: State and local governments are spending on projects that were stalled — like an effort in Naples, Fla., to prevent pelicans from entangling fishing lines — and even some federal spending is rising.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Fla. — For a long stretch, government spending cutbacks at all levels were a substantial drag on economic growth. Now, finally, relief is in sight.

headline: Digital Tax Increase to Take Effect in Europe
keywords: ['Sales and Excise Taxes', 'E-Commerce', 'E-Books and Readers', 'Mobile Applications', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Taxation', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: New rules are coming into force for services like movie streaming and content like e-books on Thursday, but who will foot most of the bill remains unclear.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Europe’s tax showdown could be headed straight to people’s wallets.

headline: Syria Deaths Hit New High in 2014, Observer Group Says
abstract: Figures compiled by the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights showed that 76,021 people had died in the Syria conflict last year.
lead_paragraph: More than 76,000 people died in Syria’s civil war in 2014, including more than 3,500 children, a monitoring group reported on Thursday. The figures would make last year the deadliest in Syria since the conflict began in March 2011.

headline: ‘A Shared Legacy: Folk Art in America’
abstract: A look at the new show at the American Folk Art Museum.
lead_paragraph: A look at the new show at the American Folk Art Museum.

headline: Pride in Success of Saban Resounds Across Alabama
abstract: Since Saban became the team’s coach after the 2006 season, the Crimson Tide have gone 91-16, a dynasty that has benefited fans, radio hosts, entrepreneurs and the university itself.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — On Oct. 6, Phyllis Chapple-Perkins called in to Paul Finebaum’s daily radio show, the pre-eminent Southeastern Conference talkfest, and let loose.

headline: Simple, but Oh, What Depths
abstract: “A Shared Legacy: Folk Art in America,” at the American Folk Art Museum, includes more than 60 choice objects made between 1800 and 1920.
lead_paragraph: In a letter he wrote in 1825, the American painter John Vanderlyn said that paintings by the itinerant portraitist Ammi Phillips were “... cheap and slight, for the mass of folks can’t judge of the merits of a well-finished picture.” Vanderlyn had gone to France for academic training. His masterpiece, “Ariadne Asleep on the Island of Naxos” (1809-14), a suavely erotic, neo-Classical vision of a nude woman dozing in a pastoral landscape, is one of the gems of the collection of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts. But a discerning viewer today might well prefer Phillips. His “Girl in Red Dress With Cat and Dog” (1830-35) is one of the loveliest paintings by any American artist.

headline: Turkish Police Thwart Attack on Prime Minister’s Office in Istanbul
abstract: The police arrested a man who tried to attack a palace complex close to the prime minister’s office in Istanbul, throwing two homemade grenades that failed to detonate.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Turkish police arrested an armed man on Thursday after he tried to attack a palace complex near the prime minister’s office in Istanbul.

headline: Dark Times Ahead for Two Major Paris Theaters
abstract: The Théâtre de la Ville and the Théâtre du Châtelet in Paris will close for extensive renovations after the 2016 season.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Théâtre de la Ville and the Théâtre du Châtelet, two of the most important theaters in Paris, will close for extensive renovations at the end of the 2016 season, darkening the houses for one and a half to two years.

headline: Piketty Turns Down the Legion of Honor
abstract: Thomas Piketty, the author of “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” says he does not think “it is the government’s role to decide who is honorable.”
lead_paragraph: The economist Thomas Piketty, the author of the surprise best-seller “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” has turned down the Legion of Honor, the highest decoration offered by the French government.

headline: ‘Painting as Process, Painting as Life’
abstract: A look at the Guggenheim Museum’s new retrospective of the 20th-century Indian modernist V.S. Gaitonde.
lead_paragraph: A look at the Guggenheim Museum’s new retrospective of the 20th-century Indian modernist V.S. Gaitonde.

headline: An Indian Modernist With a Global Gaze
abstract: A legend in Indian art, V. S. Gaitonde looked westward, eastward, homeward and inward to create an intensely personalized version of transculturalism.
lead_paragraph: Many Western abstract painters in the early 20th century — Albers, Kandinsky, Mondrian — were deeply influenced by Asian art and philosophy, though no one dismissed them as Orientalists. Their cosmopolitanism was a point in their favor, and proof of Modernism’s wide embrace. By contrast, if Asian artists showed signs of absorbing Western models, their work was disdained as derivative, inauthentic and evidence that Western Modernism was the only true one, the source that supplied the world.

headline: ‘Selma’ to Be Screened Free in Selma
abstract: Paramount Pictures will show the film free at Selma’s Walton Theater beginning Jan. 9 as part of the movie’s national release.
lead_paragraph: “Selma,” Ava DuVernay’s film about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s 1965 civil rights marches in that small Alabama town, is making the rounds among Oscar voters, who began casting ballots this week.

headline: Frank Lampard Lifts Manchester City as Fans in New York Fume
abstract: Frank Lampard’s goal for Manchester City highlighted his value to the club but exposed a deep wedge between him and American soccer fans who had expected to see him in New York this year.
lead_paragraph: Frank Lampard came off the bench to score the winning goal in Manchester City’s 3-2 victory over Sunderland on Thursday. The goal highlighted Lampard’s value to City, which moved into a tie for the Premier League lead when Chelsea lost to Tottenham later in the day, but it also exposed a deep wedge between Lampard and American soccer fans who had expected to see him play in New York this spring.

headline: Talking (and Talking) About Love
abstract: A new production of “The Merry Widow,” directed and choreographed by Susan Stroman, underlines the challenges of presenting spoken dialogue in the vast Metropolitan Opera hall.
lead_paragraph: Opening a new production of Franz Lehar’s enduring operetta “The Merry Widow” as a New Year’s Eve gala at the Metropolitan Opera seemed a promising idea. Here is a light comedy with a rich, tuneful score and plenty of opportunities for dancing. And, in its way, the story, which centers on an attractive widow from a Balkan land, now living in Paris, whose husband left her a fortune, touches on wistful emotions that often well up with the coming of a new year: the byways of romantic attachment, the passing of time, the difficulty of amending lost opportunities.

headline: A Creative Vision, So Down to Earth
abstract: “Jean Dubuffet: Soul of the Underground,” at the Museum of Modern Art, presents works made with sand, dirt and gravel from this Art Brut founder.
lead_paragraph: One of the smallest but most salient works in “Jean Dubuffet: Soul of the Underground,” at the Museum of Modern Art, is a sketchbook page covered with tiny contour drawings of footprints. Made during one of Dubuffet’s late-1940s sojourns in El Goléa, a Saharan oasis, it hints at the inspiration he would find under his soles over the next couple of decades.

headline: Communing With Mr. Turner
abstract: An assortment of works by J. M. W. Turner, including some featured in Mike Leigh’s new film about the artist, are on view at museums in New York or within a day’s journey from the city.
lead_paragraph: The Tate Britain in London houses the world’s largest collection of paintings by J. M. W. Turner, but Americans don’t need a passport to see his works in person. Below is a list of institutions in Manhattan or within a day’s journey from the city that own pieces prominently featured in Mike Leigh’s film “Mr. Turner,” followed by several museums with Turner’s work in their collections.

headline: Plotlines? Brush Strokes Are Enough
abstract: The art critic Roberta Smith watched 2014’s films about art — “Mr. Turner,” “Big Eyes” and others — with much emotional investment.
lead_paragraph: I tend to be a sucker for movies about art and artists. It almost doesn’t matter whether these films are good, bad or middling. Watching them is like watching sports or maybe a game show. You keep score. How much is right, how much seems off, how much is so inaccurate it makes you squirm. And, yes, there’s also a certain know-it-all satisfaction in catching mistakes.

headline: The Best Sports Films Often Take a Dark Turn
abstract: “Foxcatcher” brought to mind another sweaty, award-winning movie, “Raging Bull.”
lead_paragraph: The sports film is imbued with the impulse to inspire, or at least to make the moviegoer feel good. Think of the familiar blueprint: an underdog high school basketball team in “Hoosiers” or the aging ballplayer Roy Hobbs in “The Natural” battles the odds to emerge with a victory.

headline: Richard Sandomir’s Top 10 Sports Films
abstract: Three boxing movies in the top five? What would Adrian say?
lead_paragraph: 1. “Raging Bull”: A brilliantly directed epic about misanthropy that is propelled by a great story, more-than-credible action and fascinating, doomed relationships. And Robert De Niro won an Oscar as best actor.

headline: New Year’s Day Bowl Games
abstract: Images from Thursday’s college football bowl games, including the College Football Playoff’s two semifinal games: the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif.; and the Sugar Bowl in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: Images from Thursday’s college football bowl games, including the College Football Playoff’s two semifinal games: the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif.; and the Sugar Bowl in New Orleans.

headline: John I. Goodlad, Progressive Educator, Dies at 94
abstract: Many of the views put forth by Professor Goodlad, whose study of American public schools involved more than 27,000 students, remain central to educational improvement efforts.
lead_paragraph: John I. Goodlad, an influential educator whose study of more than 27,000 students, teachers and administrators in the late 1970s and early ’80s documented the problems plaguing American public schools, died on Nov. 29 in Seattle. He was 94.

headline: How the Civil War Created College Football
abstract: Veterans of the conflict saw the gridiron as a perfect training ground for soldier-scholars.
lead_paragraph: At a ceremony in Cambridge, Mass., on June 10, 1890, the philanthropist Henry Lee Higginson declared, “I ask to make [Soldiers Field] a memorial to some dear friends who gave their lives … to their country and to their fellow men in the hour of great need — the War of the Rebellion.” The 31 acres of marshlands and pasture that Higginson donated to Harvard College, his alma mater, would serve as the site of the country’s oldest concrete football arena, Harvard Stadium, built over a decade later in 1903. As he memorialized the Civil War dead, the Union veteran addressed a group of 400 male students and alumni, most of whom were too young to have experienced and learned from the horrors of battle during the nation’s bloodiest war. Like Higginson, however, many late-19th-century Americans saw a deep connection between the battlefield and the athletic field, believing that collegiate athletics, including football, could teach the next generation their “own duties as men and citizens of the Republic” and train them to manage “the burden of carrying on this country in the best way.”

headline: After a Remake for American Viewers, Back to Understatement
abstract: The second season of the Scandinavian series “The Bridge,” online at Hulu on Friday, begins with a cargo ship mysteriously veering off course.
lead_paragraph: The police drama “The Bridge,” in both its original (Scandinavian) and American versions, took its title from its evocative opening gimmick: A body is found on a bridge that crosses an international border, lying half in one country and half in the other. The result is an unlikely partnership between detectives from two countries, Sweden and Denmark in the original, the United States and Mexico in the remake.

headline: Recalling Blind Tom, an Autistic Pianist Born to Slavery
abstract: A collection featuring items from the pianist Blind Tom will be up for auction, as will a stock photo agency’s inventory.
lead_paragraph: The pianist Blind Tom began drawing crowds to his performances as a child in the 1850s. His black family and various white guardians fought for rights to earn money from his career until his death in 1908. Blind Tom himself, who was born into slavery and given a series of last names over the years, was autistic and unable to fathom the legal battles.

headline: Society’s Flaws and Foibles, Etched for Posterity
abstract: An edition of Goya’s “Los Caprichos,” owned by the artist Robert Henri and long overlooked, is coming to the National Arts Club.
lead_paragraph: THE registrar at the National Arts Club in Manhattan decided last summer to impose some order on a donated collection of books that once belonged to the Ashcan artist Robert Henri.

abstract: The MELT method claims to address a host of middle-age complaints: chronic pain, aching joints, weight gain, stress, wrinkles, digestive problems, low energy and insomnia.
lead_paragraph: THE MELT method — a kind of body work that has been the subject of gym classes and a best-selling book — claims to address a host of middle-age complaints: chronic pain, aching joints, weight gain, stress, wrinkles, digestive problems, low energy and insomnia.

headline: Where Have All the Cod Gone?
keywords: ['Cod (Fish)', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Recent drops in fish stocks are the latest in a long history of decline.
lead_paragraph: PORTSMOUTH, N.H. — IN November, regulators from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration shut down recreational and commercial cod fishing in the Gulf of Maine, that enchanting arm of the coastal sea stretching east-northeast from Cape Cod. They did not have much choice: Federal law requires action to rebuild fish stocks when they are depleted, and recent surveys revealed cod populations to be at record lows, despite decades of regulations intended to restore them.

headline: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
abstract: A look back at the first Academy Award-winning performances by the actress Luise Rainer, who died this week at 104.
lead_paragraph: 79 YEARS AGO

headline: Teach Congress a Lesson
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Why House members should have to attend ethics training sessions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — OVER the last decade, Congress’s approval ratings have gone from bad to worse to outright terrible, dropping from about 40 percent at the end of 2004 to a meager 15 percent today, according to Gallup. The American people are frustrated with the gridlock and hyperpartisan atmosphere in Washington, but a large part of the problem is the perception that lawmakers believe the rules don’t apply to them.

headline: As Bubbly as a Midnight Glass of Champagne
abstract: The New York Philharmonic, led by Bramwell Tovey, was joined by Norm Lewis and Dianne Reeves for a program of Gershwin on New Year’s Eve.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic’s New Year’s Eve concert at Avery Fisher Hall offered cleverness and good spirits aplenty. That much was all but guaranteed in a program celebrating the Gershwin brothers: the composer George and the lyricist Ira.

headline: Mortality and its Discontents
abstract: The summits no longer have the same pull; a beer and a brat on the 40-yard line are as enticing as looking down at cloud cover from Mount Rainier’s apex.
lead_paragraph: ESTES PARK, Colo. — On the first day of the new year, as on the last day of the old year, I slip outside at dusk and try to run away from my problems. There is no better way to make sense of the daily clutter of inchoate thoughts than bouncing along a trail, immortality in every stride.

lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: In the Sweet Shop, Happily Sampling New Concoctions
abstract: New York City Ballet’s seasonal “Nutcracker” run, in which dancers continually shuffle into new roles, is an education for young and adult performers alike.
lead_paragraph: “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker” is a marvelous holiday entertainment, but it is also an education for the young. The children in the production try out adult dances and formal courtesies. The child heroine, Marie, and the hero, Drosselmeier’s nephew (who becomes the Nutcracker Prince), battle mice and imagine the independence of maturity. The children in the audience learn how to watch ballet.

headline: 20 Shows to Watch
abstract: The winter is high season for the serious TV watcher, from a “Breaking Bad” spinoff, to the return of “Broadchurch,” to the final season of “Justified.”
lead_paragraph: When did winter become the season of television’s most distinguished content? The fall season, with its organized and heavily publicized broadcast-network premieres, still gets the attention, but a greater number of interesting shows now arrive on cable, broadcast and online in the first quarter of the year.

headline: Alas, the Indignity: Murder Victims Entombed in Cows
abstract: Bruno Dumont’s “Li’l Quinquin” unfolds in a French countryside filled with racist children and bizarre killings.
lead_paragraph: The French filmmaker Bruno Dumont has described his mesmerizing 197-minute murder mystery, “Li’l Quinquin,” as a comedy. The term fits that definition only if you understand that he means the human comedy in all its grotesque and happy-sad variations. As in most of his films, Mr. Dumont assumes the aesthetic and moral stance of a semidetached, some would say pitiless, observer of the human condition. “Li’l Quinquin” is a quasi-epic farce that mostly wears a poker face as it elaborates his continuing obsession with the collision of humankind’s bestial and spiritual impulses.

headline: Cops and Crime Versus Crumpets: Two Shows Reveal Two Britains
abstract: The grittiness of the police thriller “Line of Duty” is in stark contrast to the glamour of “Downton Abbey.”
lead_paragraph: There is an antidote to “Downton Abbey.”

headline: Stopping Goals, and Opening Up
abstract: In “The Keeper,” the goalie Tim Howard describes how he overcame obstacles to become one of the world’s best soccer players.
lead_paragraph: If you want to know what one of his spectacular crashes feels like, Evel Knievel once told a reporter, strap on a helmet and sit on the hood of a car. Have someone get that car up to 90 miles per hour. “Then you hold your nose and fall off,” he said.

headline: Jeb Bush Resigns From Board Seats, Possibly Edging Closer to Presidential Run
abstract: Mr. Bush gave up positions at an online education firm and his own education foundation this week, the latest nonpolitical commitments from which he has detached himself as he looks toward 2016.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida has resigned from each of his corporate and nonprofit board positions, an aide confirmed Thursday, the latest indication that he is moving toward starting a presidential campaign.

headline: Doing Close-Ups With No Camera
abstract: Mariano Pensotti’s “Cineastas,” part of the Under the Radar festival, tells eight stories at once, depicting four filmmakers and the four movies they’re creating.
lead_paragraph: Video projections, once the sole province of technologically precocious companies like the Wooster Group, have become standard fare for theater artists. A GoPro camera and a relatively flat surface can now transform the humblest of stages instantly.

abstract: Nebraskans and others respond to an Op-Ed article by Mary Pipher.

headline: Dancer’s Homage to a Kindred Soul
abstract: In “Night Light Bright Light,” the dancer and choreographer Jack Ferver draws inspiration from the dancer and choreographer Fred Herko.
lead_paragraph: The story of how the dancer, actor and choreographer Fred Herko died is mythic in avant-garde circles: He took a bath, danced around his friend’s Cornelia Street loft to Mozart’s “Coronation” Mass and leapt out of a window in a grand jeté. It was Oct. 27, 1964.

headline: Keeping Up With the Visuals
abstract: The Finnish aerialist Ilona Jantti is scheduled to perform in “Muualla/Elsewhere” as part of the Circus Now festival.
lead_paragraph: Circus performers are used to a bit of competition for the audience’s attention, whether from cream-pie-wielding clowns, befezzed elephants or popcorn-selling vendors.

headline: By ‘Editing’ Plant Genes, Companies Avoid Regulation
keywords: ['Genetic Engineering', 'Biotechnology and Bioengineering', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Defoliants and Herbicides', 'Corn']
abstract: Critics of bioengineered crops are concerned that a technical loophole could lead to the release of plants that could have unintended effects on the environment.
lead_paragraph: Its first attempt to develop genetically engineered grass ended disastrously for the Scotts Miracle-Gro Company. The grass escaped into the wild from test plots in Oregon in 2003, dooming the chances that the government would approve the product for commercial use.

headline: A Cold Month Is No Longer Dark
keywords: ['Theater', 'Innovation', 'Under the Radar Festival', 'Coil Festival', 'American Realness Festival']
abstract: January, once a quiet time for downtown theater, is now busy with stage festivals, among them Coil, Prototype, Under the Radar and American Realness.
lead_paragraph: MOST of us abandon our New Year’s resolutions. But if you vowed to see more live art in 2015, you can start keeping that one right away. A decade ago, January was a performance doldrums. No more.

abstract: The New York Propane Gas Association discusses the importance of propane for residents and farmers.

headline: Add Coffee to Subway Evils
abstract: Michael Ginsburg, a reader, adds spilled coffee to the list of offenses against subway etiquette.

headline: An All-Gyllenhaal Weekend, Anyone?
abstract: It’s not often that the stars align this way. But the cosmic event here concerns the sibling actors Gyllenhaal, Maggie and Jake.
lead_paragraph: It’s not often that the stars align this way. But the cosmic event here concerns the sibling actors Gyllenhaal, Maggie and Jake. She stars in a play on Broadway that will close on Sunday (Tom Stoppard’s “The Real Thing,” second from right). He stars in a play on Broadway now in previews that will open in a little more than a week (Nick Payne’s “Constellations,” far right). And they are both getting awards-season attention for their current screen work. She has been nominated for a Golden Globe for her performance in the summer TV mini-series “The Honorable Woman” (far left), which you can view now on Sundance.tv. And he is suddenly being mentioned everywhere for his creepy role in the film “Nightcrawler” (second from left), still in theaters. Binge away.

headline: A Ghost With a Grudge (Watch Out, Kids!)
abstract: In “The Woman in Black 2: Angel of Death,” a ghost with a vendetta against the young leaves behind the Edwardian setting of its predecessor for 1941.
lead_paragraph: THE WOMAN IN BLACK 2

headline: To Rescue Economy, Japan Turns to Supermom
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe pledged to make it easier for women who have children to continue careers, rather than leaving the work force.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — When she was pregnant with the first of her three sons, Chiaki Kitajima, an advertising executive here, said her bosses were shocked that rather than accept reduced hours and a demotion after maternity leave, she made a presentation on why the company should subsidize child care.

headline: Boston Marathon Bombing: What We Know
abstract: A recap of the events of April 15, 2013, and their aftermath, as jury selection for the trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev gets underway.
lead_paragraph: At 2:49 p.m. on April 15, 2013, two explosions occurred near the finish line at the Boston Marathon, killing three people and wounding more than 260. The trial for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, now 21, who is accused in the bombing, started on Monday in Boston.

headline: Finding Meaning in a Dish
abstract: Ian Cheney’s documentary “The Search for General Tso” is about history, heritage and struggle as much as about a certain chicken dish popular in Chinese restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday

headline: Despite Thaw, American Base at Guantánamo Still Stings for Cubans
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']
abstract: The Castros have long pointed to the base as a symbol of American imperialism, and it remains a sore point for Cubans.
lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO, Cuba — At a military checkpoint on the road that approaches the American naval base here, one of three along the way, four Cuban soldiers in pea-green fatigues, without guns, stood on duty last Sunday laughing over a joke in the shade of an almond tree, beside a neatly cultivated flower bed. A large sign declared the site “the first anti-imperialist trench.”

headline: Theater Listings for Jan. 2-8
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A Year of Columns, a Memorable Trove of Characters
abstract: A columnist meets many characters in the course of a year’s work. Here are a few featured in Common Sense who stood out.
lead_paragraph: HANGING OVER HIS FUTURE For Zachary Warren, the 30-year-old magna cum laude graduate of Georgetown Law School caught up in the 2012 collapse of the big law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf, probably the best thing that can be said about 2014 is that it’s over.

headline: Ditch the Persona, Then Move a Piano
abstract: Courtney Love’s latest and thoroughly unexpected gig is the music-theater piece “Kansas City Choir Boy.”
lead_paragraph: Singer, songwriter, punk-rocker, actress, fashionista, tabloid bonanza and ... piano mover? That’s part of Courtney Love’s latest and thoroughly unexpected gig. The performer who made her name in the 1990s with her primal rasp and confrontational, straight-from-the-id songs will play the lead in “Kansas City Choir Boy,” a music-theater piece she’s performing with its songwriter, Todd Almond, in the 84-seat South Village performance space Here from Jan. 8-17.

headline: Top 2 Thruway Authority Executives Quit Without Warning
abstract: The agency’s executive director, Thomas J. Madison, and its chief operating and financial officer, John M. Bryan, resigned on New Year’s Eve, the latest sign of turmoil at the agency.
lead_paragraph: The top two executives of the New York State Thruway Authority abruptly quit this week, the latest sign of turmoil at the agency as it faces a deep budget shortfall and difficulty financing the construction of a new Tappan Zee Bridge.

headline: Web Freedom Is Seen as a Growing Global Issue
keywords: ['Censorship', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Social Media']
abstract: The new year promises further attempts at online censorship, as the web increasingly serves as a platform for civil rights efforts.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Government censorship of the Internet is a cat-and-mouse game. And despite more aggressive tactics in recent months, the cats have been largely frustrated while the mice wriggle away.

headline: Deal Makers Notched Nearly $3.5 Trillion Worth in ’14, Best in 7 Years
abstract: Deals worth nearly $3.5 trillion were announced, a performance favored by low interest rates and high stock prices.
lead_paragraph: By almost every measure, 2014 was a time for deal makers to pop the corks of their Champagne bottles.

headline: Is the Modern American Dream Attainable?
abstract: According to recent studies, more than half of Americans believe that the prospect of a good job and a home with a "white picket fence" is gone, never existed or unachievable.

headline: Mario Cuomo, Ex-New York Governor and Liberal Beacon, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Cuomo, a spellbinding orator and colorful personality who flirted with running for the presidency, lived to see his son Andrew follow in his footsteps as governor.
lead_paragraph: Mario M. Cuomo, the three-term governor of New York who commanded the attention of the country with a compelling public presence, a forceful defense of liberalism and his exhaustive ruminations about whether to run for president, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

headline: Hope for the Homeless
abstract: Though homeless encampments elsewhere in the country have been dismantled by the authorities, officials in Las Cruces, N.M. have funneled money and services to Camp Hope.
lead_paragraph: Though homeless encampments elsewhere in the country have been dismantled by the authorities, officials in Las Cruces, N.M. have funneled money and services to Camp Hope.

headline: In New Mexico Tent City, a Glimmer of Hope
abstract: Officials in Las Cruces, N.M., transformed an encampment in a dangerous part of the city into a hub of services for homeless people.
lead_paragraph: LAS CRUCES, N.M. — On a dusty lot in a rough stretch of this city, homeless people have pitched dozens of tents, some nearly empty and others so packed with possessions that their residents are practically entombed inside. There is no electricity, and the unrelenting winds batter the tents so badly that duct tape, used for repairs, is coveted like gold.

headline: A Voice for American Liberalism
abstract: Mario M. Cuomo, a three-term governor of New York, was a liberal beacon in a conservative age and several times flirted with a presidential run.
lead_paragraph: Mario M. Cuomo, a three-term governor of New York, was a liberal beacon in a conservative age and several times flirted with a presidential run.

headline: Mario Cuomo Is Dead at 82
abstract: Mario M. Cuomo, a three-term governor of New York, was a major voice for American liberalism in a conservative age and several times flirted with a presidential run.
lead_paragraph: Mario M. Cuomo, a three-term governor of New York, was a major voice for American liberalism in a conservative age and several times flirted with a presidential run.

headline: Georgia Police Chief on Leave After Shooting of His Wife
abstract: William E. McCollom of Peachtree City was placed on administrative leave after calling in the shooting of his wife, Margaret, who is in critical condition and has not yet been questioned.
lead_paragraph: The police chief of an Atlanta suburb shot his wife early on New Year’s Day, telling 911 operators that it was an accident, officials said. The victim, Margaret McCollom, 58, was in critical condition, and the chief, William E. McCollom, was placed on administrative leave.

headline: Joining International Criminal Court Wouldn’t Guarantee Palestinians a War Crimes Case
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Even if the Palestinian Authority becomes a member of the court, the cases it plans to bring over the Gaza war last summer would face many hurdles.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The political fallout from the Palestinian move Wednesday to join the International Criminal Court is likely to be swift and profound.

headline: A Vital Nuclear Agreement, at Risk
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Treaties', 'Editorials', 'United States International Relations', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: Russia needs to know that defiance of arms control treaties will come at a cost.
lead_paragraph: There’s much more to the deeply troubled Russian-American relationship than Ukraine. Under the radar, tensions have also been brewing over compliance with a number of arms control treaties that for decades have been vital to keeping the peace between the two nuclear powers and setting an example for other countries.

headline: An Enemy of Reform in New York Jails
abstract: The leader of the correction officers’ union has a record of bullying and shielding abusive officers, so federal oversight might be needed to do the job.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department’s decision in December to join a class-action suit against New York City’s Correction Department has prepared the way for reforms proposed by Mayor Bill de Blasio to root out corruption and brutality at the notorious Rikers Island jail complex. Success depends heavily on the cooperation of Norman Seabrook, the president of the politically powerful correction officers’ union and a longtime supporter of the disastrous status quo.

headline: What’s Happening to New York’s Skyline?
abstract: Get used to the rise of the “pencil towers” across the city.
lead_paragraph: It’s not a tourist attraction yet, but when hard-hatted construction workers journey down from the summit of 432 Park Avenue at 57th Street they proudly rattle off-sky-high statistics — 1,396 feet and 96 stories tall — that now make the luxury condominium tower in Midtown the tallest habitable building in the city.

headline: Ducks Reach Title Game, in a Blur
abstract: Oregon, led by the Heisman Trophy-winning quarterback Marcus Mariota, ended Florida State’s 29-game winning streak with a big victory in the Rose Bowl.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — As Jameis Winston moved forward, looking for another improbable outcome, then circled counterclockwise in desperation, Florida State’s comeback magic came unraveled in spectacular fashion.

headline: Cuomo at the 1984 Democratic Convention
abstract: At the 1984 Democratic National Convention, then Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York delivered his famous “tale of two cities” keynote address.
lead_paragraph: At the 1984 Democratic National Convention, then Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York delivered his famous “tale of two cities” keynote address.

headline: The Age of Bibi
abstract: Bellicose in words yet cautious in action, Benjamin Netanyahu is a man of contrasts, and he is subtly reshaping Israel.
lead_paragraph: METULA, Israel — If I were a political novelist, I’d try to write a novel about Benjamin Netanyahu, the prime minister of Israel.

headline: Cuba Again Arrests Artist Seeking Dissidents’ Release
keywords: ['Art', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: Tania Bruguera, who advocates free speech in her native country, was arrested for the third time in two days.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A performance artist advocating free speech in Cuba was arrested for the third time in two days on Thursday, her supporters said, along with several dissidents after they went to a jail demanding the release of government opponents rounded up in a crackdown this week.

headline: Twin Peaks Planet
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Income', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Our current global setup isn’t working for everyone. What consequences from that are ahead if we don’t do something about it?
lead_paragraph: In 2014, soaring inequality in advanced nations finally received the attention it deserved, as Thomas Piketty’s “Capital in the Twenty-First Century” became a surprise (and deserving) best seller. The usual suspects are still in well-paid denial, but, to everyone else, it is now obvious that income and wealth are more concentrated at the very top than they have been since the Gilded Age — and the trend shows no sign of letting up.

headline: Man Threatened to Kill Officers, Authorities Say
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Threats and Threatening Messages', 'Nine-One-One (911) (Emergency Phone Number)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The case brought to 21 the number of people arrested in connection with threats against the police since two New York City officers were fatally shot in their patrol car on Dec. 20.
lead_paragraph: Emergency dispatchers were jarred by a string of predawn calls on Tuesday: A man’s voice, the police said, asked that officers be sent to his location so he could shoot them when they arrived.

headline: Boston Is Eager to Begin Marathon Bombing Trial, and to End It
abstract: Not since Sept. 11, 2001, has an act of terrorism wreaked such havoc on an American city. Now, the trial of alleged Boston Marathon bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev is set to begin as the nation watches.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The blood has long since been scrubbed from the finish line. The memorials have vanished, and the fund that raised money for victims has closed.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Battling Sun’s Glare at Ballpark, the Capitals Deliver a Final Bit of Brilliance
abstract: The Washington Capitals defeated the Chicago Blackhawks in the seventh edition of the Winter Classic on a goal by Troy Brouwer with 12.9 seconds remaining.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Under a national spotlight, there was no avoiding the glare.

headline: Vanguard of Syria’s Uprising, Now on the Run From ISIS, Weighs a Bleak Future
abstract: Syrian fighters and activists who once gathered in southern Turkey to plan a revolution are now marooned, their hopes rapidly deflating.
lead_paragraph: ANTAKYA, Turkey — The cigarette smoke in the hotel room grew as thick as the cottony fog outside in this Turkish border town, as Syrian men, night after night, told their war stories. Their memories veered from exhilaration to black humor to terror, but mostly they told of what they had lost: Friends. A fiancée. An arm. A country. None were out of their mid-20s.

headline: Ebola Doctors Are Divided on IV Therapy in Africa
abstract: Doctors seeking to stem the Ebola epidemic disagree on whether most patients in West Africa should, or can, be given intravenous hydration, a standard therapy in developed countries.
lead_paragraph: Medical experts seeking to stem the Ebola epidemic are sharply divided over whether most patients in West Africa should, or can, be given intravenous hydration, a therapy that is standard in developed countries. Some argue that more aggressive treatment with IV fluids is medically possible and a moral obligation. But others counsel caution, saying that pushing too hard would put overworked doctors and nurses in danger and that the treatment, if given carelessly, could even kill patients.

headline: Burning Sensation
abstract: Starting our 2015 themelesses off right, with David Steinberg.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — It’s always weird when you have New Year’s Eve in the middle of the week. We started off our solving year with a terrific themed puzzle by Jill Denny and Jeff Chen, and next, bam! Right into the crunchy, themeless part of our week we go. If you were hoping to start out the New Year with a nice, easy Monday, you’re out of luck.

headline: Mother’s Courage Helps Daughter Change Course Amid Illness
abstract: Rosemary Bruno was already going through a difficult time when she learned she had cancer. Watching her mother fight her own way back to health has helped Ms. Bruno persevere.
lead_paragraph: There was little doubt that she would win her battle with breast cancer, Nora Zenteno said, because she was filled with faith that God would heal her.

headline: Ferret Fanciers, Ruffled by Ban, Are Eager for New York City to Lift It
abstract: Disparaged as “little weasels” by Rudolph W. Giuliani in 1999, the furry pets are supported by Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration. The Board of Health will consider a proposal to legalize them this month.
lead_paragraph: Since a bizarre incident in which Rudolph W. Giuliani verbally abused a ferret enthusiast on the radio a decade and a half ago, New York City’s ferret owners have been dealing with two major problems.

headline: Soothing the Aged With Verse, a Lawyer Takes a Road Less Traveled
abstract: Marvin Wexler, a commercial litigator, also cultivates another side of himself, reading poetry to a room full of elderly and disabled residents at a nursing home.
lead_paragraph: On the public stage, Marvin Wexler is a hard-boiled commercial litigator, skilled at defending the unpopular: the actress Vanessa Redgrave, for instance, when she was cut from a role for supporting the Palestine Liberation Organization in the 1980s; more recently a New York City hospital, against accusations that it pressed Huguette Clark, the copper heiress and a longtime patient, to donate lavishly from her fortune.

headline: A Contentious Source of Income Is Set to Dry Up
abstract: Third-party ownership, the practice of selling shares of players in exchange for part of future transfer fees, is a large part of many clubs’ operations, but FIFA is banning the practice starting in May.
lead_paragraph: Soccer’s hot stove league — the winter transfer window — fired up again Thursday, beginning a monthlong frenzy in which some of Europe’s best-known teams will buy and sell the rights to some of the world’s best players.

headline: ‘The Family of New York’: Cuomo’s Inaugural Address
abstract: A transcript of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s inaugural address on Thursday, as recorded by The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s inaugural address on Thursday, as recorded by The New York Times.

headline: Oh, the Places We’ve Been
abstract: In 2014, Metro stories took photographers to places most New Yorkers rarely see, from rooftop water tanks to abandoned islands.
lead_paragraph: In 2014, Metro stories took photographers to places most New Yorkers rarely see, from rooftop water tanks to abandoned islands.

headline: A Different Sort of Santa Suit
abstract: Dick Shea braved the icy waters off Brooklyn during the Coney Island Polar Bear Club’s annual plunge on New Year’s Day.

headline: Doug Marrone Is Among Jets’ Candidates
abstract: The team plans to speak next week with Marrone, who opted out as coach of the Buffalo Bills on Wednesday, but no interview has been scheduled yet, said a person with knowledge of the team’s thinking.
lead_paragraph: Make Doug Marrone the Jets’ seventh confirmed coaching candidate. The team plans to speak next week with Marrone, who opted out as coach of the Buffalo Bills on Wednesday, but no interview has been scheduled yet, said a person with knowledge of the team’s thinking.

headline: Yankees Trade Former Top Prospect to Braves
abstract: After years of waiting for the left-hander Manny Banuelos to fulfill his potential, the Yankees traded him to Atlanta for the right-handed pitcher David Carpenter and the left-hander Chasen Shreve.
lead_paragraph: After years of waiting for the left-hander Manny Banuelos to fulfill his potential, the Yankees gave up on him, trading him to the Atlanta Braves for the right-handed pitcher David Carpenter and the left-hander Chasen Shreve. Banuelos joined the Yankees organization in 2008 but never reached the major leagues despite his promising ability.

headline: Where There’s a Drink, There’s a Whey
abstract: The cloudy liquid runoff from cheese- and yogurt-making can be a delicious ingredient in its own right. Here, the recipe for El Rey Luncheonette’s fennel-flavored “El Whey” beverage.
lead_paragraph: Whey, the cloudy liquid runoff of ricotta, mozzarella and yogurt usually destined for the sink drain, is finding new uses among creative chefs who are salvaging the tart, calcium-rich fluid for sodas and beverages. Though it’s essentially a byproduct of cheese production, whey can be a delicious ingredient in its own right.

headline: A Bright Classic With a Radiant Finish
abstract: The Capitals edged the Blackhawks with 12.9 seconds remaining to win the Winter Classic at Nationals Park.
lead_paragraph: The Capitals edged the Blackhawks with 12.9 seconds remaining to win the Winter Classic at Nationals Park.

headline: What’s On TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) BILLY JOEL: THE LIBRARY OF CONGRESS GERSHWIN PRIZE Mr. Joel adds this lifetime achievement prize — which honors living songwriters whose work, according to the library, exemplifies “the standard of excellence associated with George and Ira Gershwin” — to his 33 Top 40 hits and 23 Grammy nominations. Justice Sonia Sotomayor of the Supreme Court and Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, were among those who bestowed the award on Mr. Joel on Nov. 19 at Constitution Hall in Washington. That celebration, presented here, features Tony Bennett performing “New York State of Mind,” LeAnn Rimes singing “Lullabye (Goodnight, My Angel),” Josh Groban rendering “Always a Woman” and John Mellencamp covering “Allentown.” Then it’s Mr. Joel’s turn with renditions of “Movin’ Out,” “Vienna,” “You May Be Right” and, with Kevin Spacey, “Piano Man.”

headline: A No. 3 Quarterback Topples No. 1 Alabama
abstract: Led by the third-string quarterback Cardale Jones, the Buckeyes pulled off an upset in New Orleans in the semifinals of the inaugural College Football Playoff.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Nick Saban walked slowly down the sideline Thursday night, barely picking up his head as Ohio State running back Ezekiel Elliott sprinted toward the end zone with a trail of Alabama defenders helplessly chasing him.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 2, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “There’s no doubt in my mind that if he had the opportunity to kill me, he would.”

headline: No Corrections: January 2, 2015
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Friday, January 2, 2015.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: Traffickers Set Freighter on a Course for Italy and Flee, Leaving Migrants Aboard
abstract: The Italian Coast Guard said the cargo ship, carrying about 450 migrants, was being towed toward the southeastern coast after running out of fuel.
lead_paragraph: VERBANIA, Italy — For the second time in three days, the Italian authorities found themselves racing on Friday to rescue hundreds of migrants from an aging freighter that traffickers had pointed toward Italy and then abandoned, leaving the ship to plow through wintry seas at top speed with no one at the helm, heading straight for the coastline.

headline: Hairstyles That Ascend, and Aspire, in Nigeria
abstract: In Nigeria, J.D. ’Okhai Ojeikere captured fleeting hairstyles that he came to see as embodying beauty, knowledge and art.
lead_paragraph: In Nigeria, it’s not just hair.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: European Central Bank Hints of Stimulus as Euro Falls Against Dollar
abstract: Mario Draghi, the bank’s president, told a German newspaper that the risk of deflation must be tackled.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — A strong indication on Friday that the European Central Bank is on the verge of aggressive action to stimulate the economy, just as the Federal Reserve is dialing back its stimulus, helped push the euro to its lowest level against the dollar since 2010.

headline: New York Today: Words About Pictures
abstract: Friday: New York loses a political icon; cool weather today, snow and rain tomorrow; and Times photographers recount their adventures.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this chilly Friday.

headline: Teenagers in the Times | December 2014
abstract: We ring in the New Year with the December edition of Teenagers in the Times.
lead_paragraph: We ring in the New Year with the December edition of Teenagers in the Times, a feature that presents almost everything published in The Times about young people during the prior month.

headline: Bono Fears He May Never Play the Guitar Again
abstract: In a personal roundup of 2014 on U2’s website, the singer said that recovery from a cycling accident in November had been more difficult than he had expected.
lead_paragraph: Bono, the lead singer of U2, has announced on the band’s website that he may never play the guitar again because of injuries sustained in a cycling accident in New York.

headline: Morning Agenda: Looking Back on a Year of Deals
abstract: Deal makers notched $3.5 trillion worth of deals in 2014. | Stock markets ended the year on a high note. | DealBook’s annual “Closing Dinner.”
lead_paragraph: LOOKING BACK ON A YEAR OF DEALS | The holidays are over, but a final toast is still in order.

headline: A Historical Drama Shows Too Much Cleavage for China’s Censors
abstract: “The Empress of China” was pulled briefly from the air, but when it returned it was clear that the show’s aesthetic had undergone a major transformation: The ample chests that once filled the screen were nowhere to be seen.
lead_paragraph: In “The Empress of China,” Fan Bingbing portrays Wu Zetian, the only woman in Chinese history to rule in her own right. When the highly anticipated television show “The Empress of China” was abruptly pulled from Chinese airwaves just days after its premiere on Dec. 21, many speculated that the reason might have had less to do with technical problems, as the show’s producers claimed on its official microblog account, than with one aspect of the show that was, well, impossible to miss: the plunging necklines and tightly squeezed bosoms.

headline: A Day With Apple Pay
abstract: The success of Apple Pay will in part be determined lies in the hands of the people behind retailers’ counters. How are those people doing two months after the service was introduced?
lead_paragraph: For years, payments industry insiders have been skeptical of the rise of the mobile wallet, a vision of the future where customers eschew wallets for credit cards stored on their smartphones.

headline: Jeb Bush, and Two Myths About Shifting to the Right
abstract: A study suggests he doesn’t need to move to the right in the primary but won’t be punished in the general election if he does.
lead_paragraph: Even before Jeb Bush announced he was exploring a run for the presidency in 2016, the question emerged: Could Mr. Bush win the nomination without pandering to the Republican party’s conservative base in the primaries? The answer from many strategists was an uncomfortable no.

headline: Time to Assess Your Financial Fitness
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Savings', 'Retirement', 'Disability Insurance', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: To track your financial progress, here are some personal markers you can turn to this year, and every year.
lead_paragraph: When the Dow Jones industrial average closed above 18,000 for the first time late last month, you could practically hear the champagne corks popping. Traders wore hats celebrating the occasion, and email news alerts were followed by dutiful articles.

headline: Kenyan Court Suspends Part of New Antiterrorism Law
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Law and Legislation', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The court blocked some of the law’s contentious restrictions on media organizations and provisions on refugees until further hearings could be held.
lead_paragraph: A Kenyan court on Friday suspended some of the most contentious provisions of a new security law that detractors have said would undermine democracy.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Dying in the E.R., and on TV Without His Family’s Consent
abstract: Months after her husband was hit by a truck, Anita Chanko watched him die again on “NY Med,” a medical series. But she hadn’t given permission for those moments to be aired.
lead_paragraph: Anita Chanko could not sleep. At 4 a.m., on an August night in 2012, she settled onto the couch in her Yorkville living room with her dog, Daisy, and her parrot, Elliott, and flipped on the DVR. On came the prior night’s episode of “NY Med,” the popular real-life medical series set at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, starring Dr. Mehmet Oz. Mrs. Chanko, 75, was a fan of the show and others like it.

headline: A Ringtone Gets an Encore
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: When a woman’s cellphone rang at a diner with a march from “Aida,” delighted patrons asked her, not to turn it off, but to play it again.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Four Big Pieces of AirAsia Jet Are Found; Search Crews Have Recovered 46 Bodies
abstract: Officials said that they had identified three of the bodies, but that stormy seas had prevented them from deploying sophisticated sonar equipment.
lead_paragraph: SURABAYA, Indonesia — An Indonesian official said four major pieces of the Airbus A320-200 jetliner that plunged into the Java Sea last Sunday had been found. The wreckage was located by sonar equipment, but divers had not yet been able to examine it because of high waves and perilous currents, according to the National Search and Rescue Agency.

headline: Panda Bear on the Books, Films and Music That Inspire Him
abstract: The Animal Collective musician shares some influences with T in anticipation of the Jan. 13 release of his new album, “Panda Bear Meets the Grim Reaper.”
lead_paragraph: A name is just a name, even the not-so-vaguely menacing title “Panda Bear Meets the Grim Reaper.” In fact, the fifth album from Panda Bear – the singer-songwriter also known as Noah Lennox – shows the Animal Collective member’s purported encounter with the afterlife to have been quite productive. As was the case with Lennox’s 2011 release “Tomboy,” the new album transforms experimental techniques into moody yet uplifting pop music that somehow evokes both a dank basement rave and the sunny sounds of the Beach Boys.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Stuff We Liked: Clever Data Visualization and a Year in Outrage
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Interesting reads and charts from around the web, including a Dude Map and another look at Christmas music.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the things we liked elsewhere on the web:

headline: The Films of Hayao Miyazaki
abstract: Images of the director’s work.
lead_paragraph: Images of the director’s work.

headline: A Master of Childhood Dreams
abstract: Hayao Miyazaki has received an honorary Academy Award after a career of animated films including “Princess Mononoke,” “Spirited Away” and “The Wind Rises.”
lead_paragraph: The nominations won’t be announced until Jan. 15, but it’s safe to say that the greatest filmmaker associated with the 2015 Academy Awards has already received his Oscar, delivered a modest but revealing acceptance speech and flown home to Japan and, perhaps, retirement.

headline: Mike Nichols Told Him Not to Do It
abstract: Alejandro G. Iñárritu made some unorthodox choices as director and a writer of “Birdman.” They appear to have paid off.
lead_paragraph: Audiences could get vertigo following the meta-narrative of “Birdman,” Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s film about a washed-up action star, Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton), trying to regain a little prestige by doing a Broadway play — contending with showboating actors playing showboating actors — and losing track of reality in the process.

headline: It’s Her Freak Show Right Now
abstract: The current season of “American Horror Story” is almost too apt a metaphor for Hollywood, where older actresses (the freaks) take refuge in television (the sideshow).
lead_paragraph: In a silky, beguiling whisper, Elsa Mars, the Marlene Dietrich manquée played by Jessica Lange on “American Horror Story: Freak Show,” tells a new employee why she won’t allow matinees. Audiences, she says, want to watch these kinds of acts only at night, “when darkness moves in and speaks of mystery and the unknown, when logic loosens its vise grip and the imagination comes out to play.”

headline: Tim Burton Narrates a Scene From ‘Big Eyes’
abstract: In Anatomy of a Scene, the director Tim Burton discusses his process.
lead_paragraph: In this video, the director Tim Burton discusses a sequence from his film “Big Eyes,” based on the life of the artist Margaret Keane (Amy Adams) and her husband, Walter (Christoph Waltz), who takes credit for her artwork. Some of the look of the scene, Mr. Burton said, was inspired by the films of the Italian director Mario Bava. He also discusses the quiet, internal performance given by Ms. Adams.

headline: Daily Report: Web Freedom Is Seen as a Growing Global Issue
keywords: ['Censorship', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Privacy']
abstract: The new year promises further attempts at online censorship, as the web increasingly serves as a platform for civil rights efforts.
lead_paragraph: Government censorship of the Internet is a cat-and-mouse game. And despite more aggressive tactics in recent months, the cats have been largely frustrated while the mice wriggle away, Vindu Goel and Andrew E. Kramer report.

headline: Letter From the Editor: About Writing What We Wished to Read
abstract: A look at the genesis of four particularly satisfying projects.
lead_paragraph: Some of the most satisfying work I’ve done has stemmed from a bit of dissatisfaction I’ve had as a reader: Why haven’t I been able to read that before?

headline: Indian Officials Seek 2 Police Officers Accused of Raping Girl, 14
abstract: The two officers, who were in charge of patrolling the girl’s village, were suspended and are now missing, according a police official.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Indian police said on Friday that they were searching for two officers in the Budaun district of Uttar Pradesh after a 14-year-old girl from a local village accused them of raping her.

headline: Private Letters Untangle Mysterious Death of Oscar Wilde’s Wife
abstract: In roughly 130 pieces of correspondence to her brother, Constance Wilde described pains, exhaustion and partial facial paralysis, symptoms that are often associated with multiple sclerosis.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Multiple sclerosis may have contributed to the mysterious early death of Constance Wilde, the wife of the Irish playwright Oscar Wilde, according to a paper published on Friday in the medical journal The Lancet.

headline: (Yet Another) Brand-New Me
abstract: The fate of unfulfilled New Year’s resolutions.
lead_paragraph: The fate of unfulfilled New Year’s resolutions.

headline: The Split-Screen Marriage
abstract: In a time when couples overshare, we could use some cautionary tales about all that they miss.
lead_paragraph: The other day, just off the train, I pulled out my phone and texted my wife: “just off the train.” A few minutes later, standing in line at the grocery store, I decided that this moment, too, was not without import, and so out came my phone again: “in line at store.” My wife, throughout the day, contributed reporting of her own: “heading into gym”; “forgot my umbrella”; “wait, have umbrella.” When we reunited that evening, we were — like so many couples who spend their days smiling faintly at their phones — as well informed of each other’s doings as if we had each hired a private investigator to trail the other.

headline: Brain Freeze
keywords: ['Voice and Speech', 'Paralysis', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Medicine and Health', 'Language and Languages']
abstract: They didn’t know what was wrong with me. What if I never got better?
lead_paragraph: I was wheeled into a room full of doctors ready to pry and poke, clipboards in hand. I counted more than seven and fewer than 15 — I couldn’t tell, because it was hard to turn my neck. All I could think about was how bad I smelled. God, how I must have smelled. I hadn’t washed myself in juvenile protest of my symptoms, which arrived with no notice and, I convinced myself, would surely depart as quickly. Help me, I thought while trying not to slump in my wheelchair, but please forgive me for reeking.

headline: The Complicated Origins of ‘Having It All’
abstract: The feminist mantra that never was.
lead_paragraph: A woman sits on the edge of a desk, a spray of pink daisies to her left and floral paper on the walls. The desk bears the gentle clutter of somebody busy but not overwhelmed: a leaning stack of papers, a cup filled with too many pencils, a tangle of paper clips. The woman wears a plum-brown dress, cinched at the waist and unbuttoned at the collar, large button-pearl earrings and still more pearls looped around her neck, along with a gold pendant chain. With her hands clasped loosely in her lap, she smiles, her mouth curved into a languid grin.

headline: Reply All: The 12.21.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: WHEN MARISSA MAYER TRIED TO BE STEVE JOBS

headline: D-List Doppelgänger
keywords: ['Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Celebrities', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Traffic and Parking Violations', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: Sign? Dine? Fine?
lead_paragraph: I share a highly uncommon name with a very minor celebrity who hasn’t worked much in decades. A fan, mistaking me for the celebrity, sent me a note offering praise for his fine work several decades ago and asked for an autograph on an enclosed publicity photo. I’ve had a few such misunderstandings over the years and have come to learn that the celebrity is impossible to locate. The fan’s note was quite endearing, and I am tempted to simply sign the photo and thank the fan for the support. I’d be claiming to be someone I’m not, which is deceitful, but the fan would probably be happier with that than with the truth. Does the charity of such an act outweigh the deception? NAME WITHHELD

headline: What’s On This Week Around the World
abstract: An exhibition on Ukiyo-e in Tokyo, Mats Ek’s reworking of ‘‘Romeo and Juliet’’ in Paris and multidisciplinary events in Australia and Chile.
lead_paragraph: Santiago, Chile

headline: 1940: Whereabouts of Unity Mitford
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Whereabouts of Unity Mitford, Hitler’s friend.
lead_paragraph: London — Mystery more obscure than London in a black-out surrounded the whereabouts of Miss Unity Freeman-Mitford, 25-year-old daughter of Lord Redesdale and a friend of Hitler, who is reported to be seriously ill with a revolver wound in her head, en route to her home in England either in a special hospital train or an airplane. Since the first report this morning that Hitler had supplied the hospital train from Munich, where Miss Mitford was reported to be hovering between life and death, the mystery has been complete.

headline: Exclusive | 775 Park Avenue
abstract: An elegant Park Avenue penthouse is poised to enter the market for the first time in 26 years.
