lead_paragraph: An elegant Park Avenue penthouse is poised to enter the market for the first time in 26 years.

headline: Harry Reid Is Hospitalized After Exercise Accident
abstract: Senator Harry Reid had a painful New Year’s Day, breaking ribs and bones in his face after falling off a piece of exercise equipment in his home.
lead_paragraph: Senator Harry Reid had a painful New Year’s Day, breaking ribs and bones in his face after falling while exercising at his home in Nevada.

headline: An Outsider’s Borough Shaped a Politician Who Helped Shape It
abstract: Mario Cuomo, who died Thursday, was an unassuming lawyer from Queens who emerged as the Great Compromiser after the columnist Jimmy Breslin lionized him as a local hero.
lead_paragraph: When a parochial fight over a school field projected Mario M. Cuomo beyond the obscurity of Queens into a national figure nearly 50 years ago, his home borough was already reverberating with the shocks of tectonic demographic change.

headline: A Decline in Problem Mortgages
abstract: Nationally, foreclosures and serious delinquencies have dropped significantly from a year ago, but many major markets have a much longer way to go.
lead_paragraph: While the lingering effects of the housing-market collapse continued to recede last year, millions of homeowners will still struggle in 2015 and beyond.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Steven Brill, whose new book is “America’s Bitter Pill,” once reviewed a John Grisham novel for the Book Review.
lead_paragraph: Grishamstyle: “Thrillers thrive on villains and heroes, and usually these characters are not overly complicated; writers don’t want to confuse or slow the plot.” That was Steven Brill — whose book about the health care system, “America’s Bitter Pill,” is reviewed in next week’s Book Review — writing in 2008, in these pages, about John Grisham’s novel “The Appeal.” Brill is best known as a media mogul and entrepreneur: He founded The American Lawyer magazine in 1979, followed a decade later by Court TV and then by the short-lived magazine Brill’s Content. (“I believe in journalism,” he told the National Press Club in 1998. “I believe deeply in journalism.” Apparently he still does; his latest venture is a partnership with The Times’s former executive editor Jill Abramson to promote articles too long for a magazine and too short for a book.) But Brill also has personal experience with the best-seller list: In 1978 he hit the nonfiction list with his first book, “The Teamsters” — “the whole squalid story meticulously researched,” according to the Book Review back then — while in 2011 he spent a few weeks on the extended list with “Class Warfare,” a look at education in America. Reviewing Grisham’s novel, Brill had some kind words for its political observations, although he didn’t think much of what he called “Grishamstyle”: “At times,” he wrote, “his weakness with words is painful to watch, . . . as if someone new to English decided to mimic ‘The Bonfire of the Vanities.’ ”

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: A Sobering Perspective on a Looming Retirement Crisis
abstract: “Falling Short” details the whats and whys of an impending retirement crisis and provides a number of reasonable sounding alternative paths to avoiding financial Armageddon, writes Jonathan A. Knee in a Book Entry review.
lead_paragraph: Feeling pleased that I had survived another year and the annual predictions of the apocalypse, I made the mistake of picking up  “Falling Short: The Coming Retirement Crisis and What to Do About It”  (Oxford University Press).

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Charles D’Ambrosio’s ‘Loitering’
abstract: This week, Phillip Lopate discusses Charles D’Ambrosio’s “Loitering”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Sven Beckert talks about “Empire of Cotton”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Parul Sehgal is the host, filling in for Pamela Paul.
lead_paragraph: This week, Phillip Lopate discusses Charles D’Ambrosio’s “Loitering”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Sven Beckert talks about “Empire of Cotton”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Parul Sehgal is the host, filling in for Pamela Paul.

headline: How Dick Cheney and Marvin Gaye Inspired ‘A Most Violent Year’
abstract: Jessica Chastain says she modeled her ambitious wife on the vice president, while Oscar Isaac says his businessman husband is based on a particular performance by the singer.
lead_paragraph: While the title “A Most Violent Year” suggests, as Vanity Fair’s Richard Lawson put it, “a picturesque orgy of gangster violence,” the film instead tells a quieter story about a heating oil (!) salesman with bourgeois aspirations and industry enemies.

headline: Year of the Condo in New York City
abstract: Twice as many new condominium units will hit the Manhattan market this year as in 2014.
lead_paragraph: At least twice as many new condominium units are scheduled to hit the Manhattan market this year as in 2014, the most since 2007. That means more choice for buyers and some welcome competition among developers.

headline: In Miami, a New Outpost for Fashion-Forward Fine Jewelry
abstract: Alchemist, which carries pieces from top avant-garde designers, is opening its third and largest store in the city’s design district and launching a private label.
lead_paragraph: Rattling off a list of top avant-garde jewelry brands, Roma Cohen — the owner, with his wife, Erika, of Miami’s Alchemist boutiques — says, “Though we’ve always been able to represent these people, a lot of times, we haven’t had the space to give them a proper presentation.” Now, the roll call that includes such fine-jewelry designers as Lydia Courteille, Abraxas Rex, Stephen Webster, Garrard and many others will have room to shine in Alchemist’s spacious new third outpost, opening in the Palm Court complex in the city’s Design District.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Charles D’Ambrosio’s ‘Loitering’
abstract: This week, Phillip Lopate and Sven Beckert.
lead_paragraph: This week, Phillip Lopate and Sven Beckert.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s houses include a five-bedroom in Mount Laurel, N.J., and a three-bedroom on an island in Yorktown, N.Y..
lead_paragraph: This week’s houses include a five-bedroom in Mount Laurel, N.J., and a three-bedroom on an island in Yorktown, N.Y..

headline: Advice for the 114th Congress
abstract: Four departing members of Congress, including Senator Saxby Chambliss, Republican of Georgia, give advice to freshman lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: Four departing members of Congress, including Senator Saxby Chambliss, Republican of Georgia, give advice to freshman lawmakers.

headline: ‘Loitering,’ Essays by Charles D’Ambrosio
abstract: From J. D. Salinger to the complexities of suicide, Charles D’Ambrosio’s essays search for long-forgotten ideals.
lead_paragraph: The great promise of essays is the freedom they offer to explore, digress, acknowledge uncertainty; to evade dogmatism and embrace ambivalence and contradiction; to engage in intimate conversation with one’s readers and literary forebears; and to uncover some unexpected truth, preferably via a sparkling literary style. In the preface to “Loitering,” his new and collected essays, Charles D’Ambrosio presents himself as a true believer in the form. Having digested “all of Joan Didion and George Orwell, all of Susan Sontag and Samuel Johnson, all of Edward Abbey and Hunter Thompson and James Baldwin,” he saw essays as “fast friends”: “I must have needed that sort of close attachment, that guidance, the voice holding steady in the face of doubt, the flawed man revealing his flaws, the outspoken woman simply saying, the brother and the sister — for essays were never a father to me, nor a mother.”

headline: Maotanchang: Study City
abstract: Chinese students hope this no-nonsense town will transform them into test-taking machines.
lead_paragraph: Chinese students hope this no-nonsense town will transform them into test-taking machines.

headline: Departing Lawmakers Bemoan the Decline of Compromise
abstract: As the 114th Congress prepares to convene on Tuesday, some senior members who will not be returning offered advice to Capitol Hill newcomers: Partisanship is easy, governing is hard.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With more than 120 years in the House and Senate among them, four lawmakers offered a bit of parting wisdom to Capitol Hill newcomers: Partisanship is easy, governing is hard.

headline: Bodies Recovered From AirAsia Crash
abstract: Bambang Soelistyo, Indonesia’s National Search and Rescue Agency chief, said on Tuesday that 30 bodies have been recovered from the wreck of Flight 8501.
lead_paragraph: Bambang Soelistyo, Indonesia’s National Search and Rescue Agency chief, said on Tuesday that 30 bodies have been recovered from the wreck of Flight 8501.

headline: Corky Pollan: Supershopper, and Now, Cookbook Author
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Cooking and Cookbooks']
abstract: A home visit with Corky Pollan, New York magazine’s weekly former Best Bets columnist.
lead_paragraph: For a generation of New Yorkers, Corky Pollan was the city’s premier shopping maven. Beginning in 1981 and continuing for about two decades, Ms. Pollan wrote and produced New York magazine’s weekly Best Bets column, whose tagline was “the best of all possible things to buy, see and do in the best of all possible cities.”

headline: Style-Minded Oregon Shows Its Substance
abstract: Moving beyond the gimmicky apparel that helped put them on the football map, the Ducks made a roaring statement by dismantling Florida State and advancing to the title game.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — On a big day for college football, the national semifinal game between Oregon and Florida State was as much a morality play as a matchup of two of the country’s best teams.

headline: The Year in Pop Feuds, Charted
abstract: The musical tiffs that fed Twitter and the tabloids this year, as charted by Andrew Kuo.

headline: ‘Us,’ by David Nicholls
abstract: In this novel, a British couple on the verge of divorce and their unpleasant son trek around Europe.
lead_paragraph: David Nicholls’s “Us,” which had yet to be published when it was selected for the longlist of the Man Booker prize last summer, was widely regarded as the judges’ nod to popular taste, a kind of token cute blonde candidate for an award often criticized as quirky and elitist. Nicholls’s previous novel was the best-selling “One Day,” which served as the basis for a movie starring Anne Hathaway and Jim Sturgess. Like its predecessor, this new offering charts the path of an unlikely love affair over the course of decades.

headline: ‘Mermaids in Paradise,’ by Lydia Millet
abstract: Lydia Millet satirizes our rapacious culture in this novel of mermaids, mercenaries and a Caribbean honeymoon gone awry.
lead_paragraph: It’s a bold move to make mermaids the center of a grown-up story, even in a novel as hilariously funny as this one. But Lydia Millet’s novels raise the bar for boldness. Through the window of the unlikeliest events or plot twists, she poses the questions many contemporary writers shy away from, or simply skirt: What’s going to happen to the earth? How do we know what to believe? What are the costs of irony?

headline: Fiction in Translation
abstract: New books by Javier Cercas, Eric-Emmanuel Schmitt and Alina Bronsky.
lead_paragraph: OUTLAWS

headline: Eve of Destruction
abstract: Charles Todd’s latest historical mystery opens on the day the Austrian archduke and his wife are assassinated in Sarajevo.
lead_paragraph: Picking up one of Charles Todd’s post-World War I historical mysteries is like starting off on an uncertain journey. In each book, Inspector Ian Rutledge of Scotland Yard, a shellshocked veteran of the Great War, makes his solitary way to some provincial English town, ostensibly to assist the local constabulary with a baffling crime but also to bear witness to the incalculable devastation brought about by the fighting. In 16 previous novels, the authors (a mother and son who write under a pen name) have sent their haunted hero all over the country, taking stock of the terrible desolation he sees everywhere and knowing that true justice is beyond his powers.

headline: ‘The Bully of Order,’ by Brian Hart
abstract: In a logging town on the Pacific Coast, a family grapples with violence and tragedy at the turn of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: From the opening pages of his second novel, “The Bully of Order,” Brian Hart warns the reader of the harshness to come. “This is war but bloodier,” one voice tells another. “Nah,” the other replies, “I seen war and this is darling compared.” Those brave enough to forge ahead are soon faced with a fond recollection of a sexual act with a steer’s heart and a story that culminates in a dog’s hanging itself, among other atrocities. On Hart’s late-19th-century Pacific Coast, nothing stays clean for long, literally or spiritually: “White here is brave and temporary, steam in the windows, ice in the pan.” Violence is a way to pass the time, and time is just counting down to death. Hopes, when a character dares to have any, are shattered into pieces, those pieces burned and the ashes tossed into the ocean.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: DYING EVERY DAY: Seneca at the Court of Nero,  by James Romm. (Vintage, $17.95.) Romm adeptly unravels the enigma of the great Stoic philosopher Seneca, who watched his student Nero spiral into madness as Roman emperor — a descent that saw family murders, the apocalyptic fire of A.D. 64 and a savage purging of the supreme minds of the Imperial Senate’s golden age.

headline: New Books for the New Year
abstract: A look ahead to new novels by Toni Morrison, Jonathan Franzen and others.
lead_paragraph: For those who can’t face living in the present, the end of all the retrospective 2014 lists doesn’t have to spell doom. It’s time for year-ahead lists. So what does 2015 promise for readers?

headline: Letters: Who but a Psychopath?
abstract: Readers respond to a recent review of Phil Zuckerman’s “Living the Secular Life” and a question posed by Dick Cavett.
lead_paragraph: Who but a Psychopath?

headline: ‘To Make Men Free,’ by Heather Cox Richardson
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: What is the proper role of government? A history of the Republican Party traces its responses to that question.
lead_paragraph: America does not have a broken political system. It has a broken political party: the Republicans.

headline: ‘The Happiest People in the World,’ by Brock Clarke
abstract: Spies, terrorism, adultery, guns — Brock Clarke’s novel sets this combustible mix in remote upstate New York.
lead_paragraph: At the center of this new novel from the author of “An Arsonist’s Guide to Writers’ Homes in New England” and “Exley” is a high school guidance counselor named Henry. Well, not really. His name isn’t Henry, it’s Jens, and he isn’t a high school guidance counselor, he’s a Danish cartoonist on the run from terrorists. But he’s not one of the Danish cartoonists you’re thinking of, the ones who satirized the Muslim world with their representations of Muhammad. Rather, he’s a different Danish cartoonist, one who drew a cartoon about the other cartoonists, and whose cartoonist cartoon proves to be just as controversial as the original cartoonists’ cartoons. Anyway, for the purposes of this paragraph, let’s just say he’s a high school guidance counselor in Broomeville, N.Y., a cold and isolated upstate town. Although, really, he’s one of two guidance counselors there. The first one has been fired for being a drunk, but actually she’s been fired so that the principal of the school, Matty, who is sort of the protagonist — well, wait, he’s not really the protagonist, per se, he’s one of several people who function, at various times, as protagonists — but as I was saying, Matty has fired the original guidance counselor in order to do a favor for his ex-lover, the wildlife researcher, which is to hire Henry, who is actually Jens. Because the ex-lover, whose name is Locs but really it’s Lorraine, isn’t a wildlife researcher anymore, she’s a C.I.A. agent. And she is trying to protect the cartoonist-of-cartoonists-cum-guidance-counselor by hiding him in Broomeville from the terrorists, who are actually, it turns out, just this one guy, who, it also turns out, is not really a terrorist. But, it further turns out, she’s just trying to find a way to get Matty (whom she calls Matthew) back, though she never really had him in the first place.

headline: ‘A Tale of Two Plantations,’ by Richard S. Dunn
abstract: The lives and experiences of three generations of slaves on a Caribbean sugar estate and a Southern plantation.
lead_paragraph: For enslaved peoples in the New World, it was always the worst of times. Whether captured in Africa or born into bondage in the Americas, slaves suffered unimaginable torments and indignities. Yet the specific form their miseries took, as the historian Richard S. Dunn shows in his painstakingly researched “A Tale of Two Plantations: Slave Life and Labor in Jamaica and Virginia,” depended on whether one was a slave in the British Caribbean or in the United States. The contrasts between the two slave societies were many, covering family life, religious beliefs and labor practices. But one difference overrode all others. In the Caribbean, white masters treated the slaves like “disposable cogs in a machine,” working them to death on sugar plantations and then replacing them with fresh stock from Africa. In the United States, white masters treated their slaves like the machine itself — a breeding machine.

headline: ‘The Ploughmen,’ by Kim Zupan
abstract: Two hardened men — a Montana deputy and a killer awaiting trial — forge an uneasy friendship in this debut novel.
lead_paragraph: Some protagonists crave a perch in history. Others hope merely to survive with dignity. The lead characters of Kim Zupan’s first novel, “The Ploughmen,” occupy opposite ends of this spectrum, but share two critical traits: They cannot sleep, and the source of their insomnia is their terrible familiarity with death.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: SUSPENDED SENTENCES: Three Novellas,  by Patrick Modiano. Translated by Mark Polizzotti. (Yale University, paper, $16.) These novellas offer as good a place as any to enter the long, slow-moving river of the French Nobelist’s fiction.

headline: ‘Citizen Coke,’ by Bartow J. Elmore
abstract: A historian portrays Coca-Cola as an international public health burden, profiting from other nations’ infrastructures.
lead_paragraph: Halfway into “Citizen Coke,” Bartow J. Elmore describes taking a treacherous journey through an Indian jungle in 2010. He was searching for a Coke bottling plant that had been shut down six years earlier after villagers claimed it had parched their wells and polluted their streams, causing skin and stomach diseases. Thirsty and tired, he stumbled upon a restaurant in a secluded village where the only safe thing to drink was . . . Coca-Cola. “It seemed I had become trapped in the history I had come to investigate,” he writes.

headline: Jane Gardam’s ‘Hollow Land’
abstract: A powerful friendship between two lads illuminates family and community ties in Jane Gardam’s linked stories.
lead_paragraph: Just as devotees of certain television shows dream of finding lost episodes and Beatles fans imagine opening a box and fishing out recordings of forgotten studio sessions, so readers long for ways to extend the pleasure they receive from beloved writers. In this regard Jane Gardam has been more than accommodating. After American readers began to embrace the British writer’s novel “Old Filth,” released here in 2006, they learned that Gardam had been publishing fine fiction regularly since the 1970s. Her backlist is extraordinary and deep, populated by titles published only in Britain as well as ones that also appeared in America but had essentially been hiding in plain sight, the way books sometimes do when they don’t find their audience.

headline: ‘Noontide Toll,’ by Romesh Gunesekera
abstract: Foreign visitors in Sri Lanka unhesitantly spill their secrets in front of a minivan driver.
lead_paragraph: This collection of linked stories, set in post-civil-war, post-tsunami Sri Lanka, is narrated by a retired clerk who has sunk his savings into a minibus and now hires himself out as a driver. Each story traces a different journey, with passengers that include three Russians on their way to a new luxury spa; a Roman Catholic priest and his acolyte pursuing a kind of detective mission; a Czech couple who share a walk on a beach with a night watchman whose entire family perished, along with more than 30,000 other Sri Lankans, in the 2004 tsunami; a delegation of Chinese businessmen appraising vast “junk fields” of military scrap; and a Sri Lankan general (also a renowned ballroom dancer) en route to a meeting with a woman whose family he has all but destroyed. The 14 stories in “Noontide Toll” function like the stages of a tour through a place that’s trying to emerge from the ruins, yet is still “trapped by the past despite the prospects ahead.”

headline: Oil Price Slump May Spur European Oil and Gas Deal-Making
abstract: In the short term, the drop in the oil prices will make it harder to get deals done. But if low prices persist, financial stress may make small players vulnerable, Fiona Maharg-Bravo of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: There was $383 billion in mergers and acquisitions in the oil and gas sector last year, as of Dec. 11. Yet Europe has largely missed out: About three-quarters of the targets have been in North America, according to Thomson Reuters data. Shale has played a big role. In 2015, oil and gas bankers in Europe will get a bigger slice of the action.

headline: Fight on Guns Is Being Taken to State Ballots
abstract: The gun control movement, facing mounting losses in federal elections, is tweaking its name, refining its goals and using the gay-marriage movement as a model.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The gun control movement, blocked in Congress and facing mounting losses in federal elections, is tweaking its name, refining its goals and using the same-sex marriage movement as a model to take the fight to voters on the state level.

headline: The Year in Jazz 2014
abstract: Jon Pareles, Nate Chinen and Ben Ratliff discuss the movements of jazz in 2014.
lead_paragraph: [Listen in iTunes | Download the MP3]

headline: Facts & Figures: Government Leadership Worries Americans Most
abstract: Eighteen percent said government leadership was the nation’s most important problem.
lead_paragraph: A poll released on Friday found that Americans were more worried about the country’s political leadership and political conflict than any other issue.

headline: Clothes and Character: ‘Annie’
abstract: The challenge for the “Annie” costume designer: making that iconic red dress feel contemporary.
lead_paragraph: The central character has been popular with children and adults alike since the 1920s, and the score is based on the catchy tunes of a 1980s musical. But for the new adaptation of “Annie,” about a precocious orphan in search of her family, the director Will Gluck’s goal was to be sure the film felt modern.

headline: A Stress Test for Mario Draghi and the European Central Bank
abstract: In doing “whatever it takes” to save the eurozone, the head of the European Central Bank now risks dividing it.
lead_paragraph: Mario Draghi indulged the photographers and their rapid-fire shutters for a few moments, making his first appearance for the news media in the European Central Bank’s ostentatious new high-rise headquarters in Frankfurt.

headline: Sharing Flickr Photos Privately
abstract: You can adjust your settings so that only certain people can see your images. Also, syncing files between Macs and PCs.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties include a Greenwich Village one-bedroom; a Hell’s Kitchen two-bedroom; and a Brooklyn house with two units.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a Greenwich Village one-bedroom; a Hell’s Kitchen two-bedroom; and a Brooklyn house with two units.

headline: Humble Leeks Can Add Brightness to Winter
abstract: A thoroughly rinsed leek, kept from overcooking, can offer a pleasant surprise for winter meals.
lead_paragraph: In my experience, leeks are usually terribly overcooked or strangely undercooked. Either way, it’s a sad situation: It’s so easy to get them right, and results can be sublime.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties include a Greenwich Village one-bedroom; a Hell’s Kitchen two-bedroom; and a Brooklyn house with two units.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York York City:

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s houses include a five-bedroom in Mount Laurel, N.J., and a three-bedroom on an island in Yorktown, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York York region:

headline: Book Review Podcast: Charles D’Ambrosio’s ‘Loitering’
abstract: Phillip Lopate talks about “Loitering,” and Sven Beckert discusses “Empire of Cotton.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Phillip Lopate reviews Charles D’Ambrosio’s “Loitering: New and Collected Essays.” Mr. Lopate writes:

headline: A Royal Ride in Portugal
abstract: A luxury vessel built for the queen of England is now cruising the Douro River in Portugal.
lead_paragraph: Tom Harper River Journeys’ new 12-day tour explores Portugal on a luxury vessel built for the queen of England to lead the diamond jubilee pageant on the Thames in 2012 in London.

headline: Chocolate Factory in Brooklyn Asks: What, Us? Gentrifiers?
abstract: Li-Lac Chocolates, priced out of Manhattan, has met resistance in its new home in a complex in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: If the wind is right, the scent of chocolate will waft up 35th Street in Brooklyn from the waterfront toward the commercial strip of Sunset Park, winding past pornography shops, liquor wholesalers and building-supply warehouses. Once you pass under the Gowanus Expressway, there is no mistaking it, even amid the exhaust of the 18-wheelers jockeying for position on the cobblestone streets in front of the loading docks of Industry City.

headline: Easing Into Leisure, One Step at a Time
abstract: A growing number of Americans are downsizing and retiring in multiple steps, continuing to work at least part time and moving more than once.
lead_paragraph: At 54, Jack M. Guttentag decided to downsize. His children had grown, and he and his wife thought they should prepare for the future and move from their townhouse in Philadelphia to something countrified, a few dozen miles west in Valley Forge, Pa.

headline: For Bond Investors, Ignoring Expert Advice Has Been Profitable
abstract: But will the trend continue in 2015? Strategists offer their predictions.
lead_paragraph: OVER the last three or four Januarys, the advice for investing in bonds has been remarkably consistent. It’s gone something like this: Beware of them, because inflation is going to rise, interest rates are going to spike and bond holders are going to lose enormous amounts of money. When it came to losses, comparisons were made to what happened to equities in 2008.

headline: Jared Leto’s Oscar Selfie Update
abstract: This week’s popular Oscar retweets included an animated Jared Leto.
lead_paragraph: Among this week’s most retweeted Oscar-related messages was one from Jared Leto, the actor-musician who was on the edge of the original Oscar selfie  but got a do-over courtesy of “The Simpsons”:

headline: Saudi King, 90, Hospitalized; Pneumonia Is Diagnosed
abstract: The king’s health is scrutinized for any hint of a leadership change in Saudi Arabia, a top oil producer and American ally.
lead_paragraph: Uncertainty about the longevity of Saudi Arabia’s king intensified on Friday with the announcement that he was battling pneumonia and needed temporary help from a breathing tube.

headline: American Cinema Editors Release Their Nominees
abstract: A tie results in six nominees for best edited drama.
lead_paragraph: The American Cinema Editors have announced their Eddie Award nominations. A tie resulted in six nominees for best edited drama. The complete list, including television nominees, is here.

headline: PJ Harvey Turns Her Album Into an Art Installation
abstract: Three times a week over four weeks, the public will be invited to watch, through a one-way mirror, PJ Harvey and her bandmates write and arrange their tracks in a makeshift studio.
lead_paragraph: Bringing a touch of Marina Abramovic to the music industry, the musician PJ Harvey is turning her next album into a public art installation. This month, Ms. Harvey, the Mercury-award winning British songwriter and vocalist, will record her ninth album behind a one-way mirror at Somerset House, a cultural center in London.

headline: How Times Reporters Unraveled the Ebola Epidemic
abstract: A team of New York Times reporters spent the past two months gathering facts for a first draft of the early history of an epidemic that began in the forests of Guinea a year ago.
lead_paragraph: Celia W. Dugger, deputy science editor for health, has helped to coordinate the Times’s coverage of Ebola. She edited a feature published Tuesday on the origin of this year’s Ebola outbreak, and shares how the story came together after months of reporting.

headline: A Closer Look at the Colorado Senate Race
abstract: How turnout and shifting loyalties affected one of the closest Senate races of 2014.
lead_paragraph: Colorado was the state that got away from Republicans in 2010 when Michael Bennet, the Democrat, won a come-from-behind victory. Yet if any Republican Senate win in 2014 was symbolic of the completeness of that party’s victory on Nov. 4, it was Cory Gardner’s in Colorado.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
abstract: Joe makes predictions for the financial headlines that will shape 2015.
lead_paragraph: The champagne has been popped and the Times Square confetti (mercifully) cleared away. Yet as we say goodbye to 2014, it seems too early to tell if the past 12 months set the stage for strong economic growth in 2015 or were merely a momentary burst of activity before a global slowdown. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar take a look at some of the major events and storylines of the past year and make predictions for tomorrow’s financial headlines. Plus, a dive into the rumored tech bubble.

headline: Jim Harrison: A Prairie Prologue in Nebraska
abstract: The author Jim Harrison recalls a teenage trip to the Sand Hills, which foretold the novels he would write years later.
lead_paragraph: In 1954, as an impetuous, irascible 16-year-old, I got my first view quite by accident of Nebraska’s Sand Hills. In my sophomore year of high school it had occurred to me that the lakes and forests of Michigan were too small for my burgeoning personality. I was an athlete of sorts, a student leader, but also an addict of Faulkner and James Joyce. Throw in Rimbaud and Dostoyevsky and I was an absurdly premature powder keg and felt I should look in a far field.

headline: More Sanctions on North Korea After Sony Case
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare', 'Movies', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Obama administration doubled down on its allegation that North Korea’s leadership was behind the hacking of Sony Pictures.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration doubled down on Friday on its allegation that North Korea’s leadership was behind the hacking of Sony Pictures, announcing new, if largely symbolic, economic sanctions against 10 senior North Korean officials and the intelligence agency it said was the source of “many of North Korea’s major cyberoperations.”

headline: Funeral for Mario Cuomo Is Set for Tuesday
abstract: The private service for Mr. Cuomo, who died Thursday, will be held at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The funeral for Mario M. Cuomo, the former governor, will be held at 11 a.m. on Tuesday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola on the Upper East Side.

headline: Britain’s Success Story
abstract: Not quite as advertised.
lead_paragraph: Simon Wren-Lewis asks how good British economic recovery — which is being touted as a wonderful success story — really has been. Not very, he says. Indeed. Here’s a comparison of the UK with two other major economies since 2007:

headline: Departing Members Urge Congress to Govern
abstract: Partisanship is easy, four lawmakers who are leaving Congress said, governing is the hard part.
lead_paragraph: Partisanship is easy; governing is the hard part.

headline: Lines to Speak and to Savor
abstract: Hollywood players are always saying how a good screenplay is hard to find. In these excerpts, we see just how one is written.
lead_paragraph: Birdman

headline: A First at the Garden Earns an Encore
abstract: Queens College and Immaculata, the first women’s teams to play at the arena, will meet in the Maggie Dixon Classic on Sunday to commemorate the 40th anniversary of their historic game.
lead_paragraph: The game is a distant but shining beacon, its significance magnified across four decades of growth. But the first women’s college basketball game at Madison Square Garden was initially just a showdown between fierce rivals, producing a winner, a loser and acute memories of how the result came about.

headline: Park Avenue Penthouse in a Rosario Candela Building
abstract: An elegant home at 775 Park Avenue, lovingly restored in homage to the building’s architect, is poised to enter the market for the first time in 26 years.
lead_paragraph: An elegant three-level penthouse with two terraces at 775 Park Avenue that has been lovingly restored in homage to the building’s original architect, Rosario Candela, is poised to enter the market at $40 million.

headline: Palestinians Submit Papers to U.N. to Join International Criminal Court
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'International Relations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The court could potentially investigate serious crimes on Palestinian lands committed by either side in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The Palestinian ambassador to the United Nations, Riyad H. Mansour, formally submitted papers for the Palestinians to join the treaty creating the International Criminal Court, paving the way for the tribunal to potentially investigate serious crimes on Palestinian lands committed by either side in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

headline: Big Bang to Be Investigated From Balloon in Antarctica
abstract: A set of six telescopes known as Spider will circle the continent for the next 20 days, observing a haze of faint microwave radio waves that are thought to be the fading Big Bang remnants.
lead_paragraph: Cosmologists celebrated the new year by launching a new experiment on a balloon in Antarctica to investigate the Big Bang.

headline: Brahms From Different Batons
abstract: Two conductors, both leading German orchestras, have released sets of Brahms’s symphonies within a year of each other. What’s the difference?
lead_paragraph: Over the last few years, Riccardo Chailly and Christian Thielemann have been engaged in a quiet, almost implicit battle for the soul of the orchestral repertoire. Both pursue a markedly different style of conducting. Both relate to tradition in conflicting ways, even as they work with some of the oldest orchestras. And both, as if to confound the stories told about the industry today, have their recordings lavishly presented by major record labels.

headline: The Olden Days, With Nymphs and Trolls
abstract: The Royal Danish Ballet will perform the work of the 19th-century Romantic August Bournonville in a program of excerpts at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: For more than half a century, Americans have felt a kind of fascination for Danish dancers. The attraction dates at least to the 1950s, when a small group from the Royal Danish Ballet traveled to the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., for the first time. At those performances, audiences and critics were charmed by the company’s buoyant dancing, amiable stage manner and seemingly natural acting abilities. The most celebrated ballets were by August Bournonville, a 19th-century choreographer in the Romantic vein who has come to define the Danish style. An ensemble of 13 dancers from the company, led by the principal dancer Ulrik Birkkjaer, will perform a program of Bournonville excerpts at the Joyce Theater in Manhattan from Jan. 13 to 18.

headline: Children at Weddings Don’t Forever Hold Their Peace
abstract: Schools of thought on allowing kids at weddings include adorable, awful and plenty in between.
lead_paragraph: The scene: A little flower girl at a wedding is given the cue to begin walking up the aisle and drop the rose petals in her basket, one by one, along the way. The wrinkle: She forgets about the rose petals until she reaches the top of the aisle, at which point she takes the basket, upends it and dumps all the petals in a heap on the floor.

headline: Wait, You Need to Suffer Some More
abstract: Musicians discuss whether suffering and world experience are needed to play pieces from Beethoven and other masterworks.
lead_paragraph: “Which master managed, as Beethoven did in his late music, to weld together present, past and future, the sublime and the profane?” Alfred Brendel wrote in his recent book for piano aficionados, “A Pianist’s A-Z” — aptly describing music whose depth prompts even the most expressive virtuosos to delay performing it, saying, “I’m not ready.”

headline: A Crash Course in Airbnb
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Road Trips']
abstract: Tired of generic motels, a family tried the vacation-rental website during their road trip and had memorable, if not always cozy, experiences.
lead_paragraph: When the 1962 Ford Galaxie convertible cruised up the hill, my car-crazy son Caleb, 15, was behind the wheel, a giddy smile on his face.

headline: Playing Jams
abstract: Ricardo Steak House is an unapologetic party spot, attracting people of all walks, races and ages.
lead_paragraph: Ricardo Steak House is an unapologetic party spot, attracting people of all walks, races and ages.

headline: At Ricardo Steak House, They’re Gonna Party Like It’s Your Birthday
abstract: Ricardo Steak House, in East Harlem, is an unapologetic party spot, attracting people of all walks, races and ages.
lead_paragraph: Just north of 110th Street, on a stretch of Second Avenue with a pawnshop, a laundromat and a couple of bodegas, a single velvet rope at No. 2145 signals something out of the ordinary. On a recent cold night, a bouncer kept a watchful eye while two hostesses, wearing short dresses despite the temperature, swiped their tablets’ touch screens, trying to free up space inside.

headline: A Full Floor at One57 for $52.9 Million
abstract: A four-bedroom, five and a half bath apartment was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A full-floor apartment on the 84th floor of the glass-sheathed One57 tower, with panoramic water, park and city vistas, sold for $52,952,500 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: A Primer in House Sitting
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: House sitters, aided by websites that connect them with strangers who are planning vacations, find that a vagabond lifestyle isn’t so bad.
lead_paragraph: I am living the life of the rich and famous, although I am neither.

headline: Gay Marriage Prompts Call for Clergy to Shun Civil Ceremonies
keywords: ['Religion-State Relations', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Religion and Belief', 'Clergy', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: A pledge taken by some pastors not to sign state marriage licenses has stirred a debate in the conservative Christian world over the church’s connection to culture and government.
lead_paragraph: If you read wedding announcements, you may have noticed that members of the clergy do not matter as much as they used to. More and more people are married by judges, or justices of the peace, or friends who get officiating privileges from the state. Others use what we might call “clergy lite,” ordained by online services like the Universal Life Church, which has but two tenets — “To promote freedom of religion” and “To do that which is right” — and requires only your name and email address and a promise that you are “over the age of 13.”

headline: Rocking a Speedo and a Spatula
abstract: Ebon Moss-Bachrach on the secret to winning his role on “Girls.”
lead_paragraph: The actor Ebon Moss-Bachrach has been kicking around Brooklyn for 15 years, since just after college at Columbia University. So a few years ago, when he heard about an HBO pilot called “Girls,” chronicling post-collegiate life in the borough, it seemed like the perfect fit. “I was begging my agents to get me an audition, and they couldn’t,” he recalled.

headline: Home Exchange 101
abstract: Lending your home in exchange for someone else’s is kind to your budget and offers a chance to act like a local.
lead_paragraph: The offers pop into my inbox: Come stay in my villa in Tuscany. Bordeaux is beautiful in the spring, and our country house has a pool. Wouldn’t you like to come to Rio and use my place at the beach? Each one ignites its own little fantasy: drinking coffee in the garden of a French chateau from a big, chipped cup, so chic it doesn’t have to be perfect. Waving to George and Amal in their speedboat on Lake Como. Coming home at night to cocktails on the terrace of my cutting-edge London apartment.

headline: There’s No Place Like Homes
abstract: Intrepid travelers are forgoing hotels to stay on couches, in chic apartments or even on a bus. These veterans offer an idea of what to expect.
lead_paragraph: Have you heard of Airbnb? Of course you have. Have you used it to book your vacation lodging? Probably not.

headline: Roaring Down an Unlikely Path to Romance
abstract: They were happily single for years. Then came a sensual motorcycle ride.
lead_paragraph: Margie Goldsmith is known for her firecracker energy and a keen sense of adventure. One friend recalled that the lithe Ms. Goldsmith entered a triathlon in Cuba so that she could explore the country on an athlete’s visa. Another remembered that after she learned the rudiments of playing blues harp, she would perform exuberantly on her harmonica at every opportunity — with Pygmies in Uganda, at a pub in Ireland, at a bar in New York.

headline: All Aboard
abstract: A group want to bring rides to the Bronx and New York City as a way to repurpose stretches of little-used or abandoned railroad tracks for recreational use.
lead_paragraph: A group want to bring rides to the Bronx and New York City as a way to repurpose stretches of little-used or abandoned railroad tracks for recreational use.

headline: In the Bronx, Test-Driving a Plan to Open Railroad Tracks to the Public
keywords: ['Railroads', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: A group of Bronx residents, train enthusiasts, historians and others want to repurpose stretches of little-used or abandoned railroad tracks for recreational use.
lead_paragraph: The three-minute ride was just long enough to give a taste of what could be.

headline: A Kingdom of Jousting, Kidnapping and Some Saucy Singing, Too
abstract: “Galavant,” an eight-episode comic series, features devious damsels and men in armor.
lead_paragraph: Television sure is eager to appropriate the stage musical form lately, and ABC makes a saucy, silly attempt on Sunday with “Galavant,” an eight-episode comic series featuring men in armor and devious damsels. Despite some amusing bits and clever songs, it’s only occasionally as much fun as it ought to be.

headline: Unruly Factions Hurt Taliban’s Bid to Capture Afghan Hearts, and Territory
abstract: Factions of the movement have hardened, while others are involved in kidnappings, robberies and the opium trade — damaging the Taliban’s efforts to win over the Afghan population.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A series of kidnappings and robberies struck northern Helmand Province this summer, paralyzing residents and embarrassing the Taliban leaders who controlled the area.

headline: On, or Just Near, the Ice at Brookfield Place
abstract: For a few months of the winter, Brookfield Place, the riverfront development formerly known as the World Financial Center, has this attraction: one of the least-crowded skating rinks in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Brookfield Place, the riverfront development formerly known as the World Financial Center, offers views to the east of Santiago Calatrava’s massively over-budget PATH station; to the west, the sun setting over the Hudson River; and to the middle, Hudson Eats, a food court that has the rare good taste not to blast bad music.

headline: Argentina Agrees to Extradite American Who Sought Asylum
abstract: Kurt Sonnenfeld claims that he is being framed for his wife’s death to discredit his theories about government foreknowledge of the Sept. 11 attacks.
lead_paragraph: INTENDENTE ALVEAR, Argentina — An American who sought refuge in Argentina after he was accused of killing his wife in 2002 should be sent back to the United States, Argentina’s Supreme Court announced this week.

headline: Sharon Isbin: Seeking Out Serenity
abstract: Ms. Isbin, a classical guitarist, has been a trailblazer both for female musicians and for the guitar’s place in the classical music world.
lead_paragraph: Sharon Isbin’s living room is decorated with two Grammy Awards and a keepsake from her time performing in the Amazon: a handcrafted poison-dart gun. (It does not work.) She lives on the Upper West Side with a view of the Hudson River and of a statue of her heroine, Eleanor Roosevelt. Ms. Isbin, a 58-year-old classical guitarist, has been a trailblazer both for female musicians and for the guitar’s place in the classical music world. She is the director of guitar programs at the Juilliard School and at the Aspen Music Festival, and will tour again this spring. A documentary on public television, “Sharon Isbin: Troubadour,” explores her musical beginnings in Italy, her teenage years in Minnesota and her lifelong collaborations with composers.

headline: Steven Gerrard Will Leave Liverpool, Perhaps for M.L.S.
abstract: Gerrard, Liverpool’s longtime captain, ruled out joining any club that might see him line up against the Reds.
lead_paragraph: Steven Gerrard, the longtime Liverpool captain, announced Friday that he would leave the club that he has supported and played for since he was a boy when his contract expires at the end of the season.

headline: India Says Men on Pakistani Boat Set Off Explosion in Arabian Sea
abstract: Pakistan denies the Indian Defense Ministry’s account of intercepting a suspicious Pakistan-based boat in the Arabian Sea.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India said on Friday that its coast guard had intercepted a suspicious Pakistan-based fishing boat at sea late on New Year’s Eve, but that when Indian officers approached the vessel to investigate, four men aboard the boat set off an “explosion and major fire” that completely destroyed the vessel.

headline: At the Racetrack
abstract: Theo Zierock photographed bettors at Aqueduct Racetrack in Queens, where they “gamble for gambling’s sake,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Theo Zierock photographed bettors at Aqueduct Racetrack in Queens, where they “gamble for gambling’s sake,” he said.

headline: Photographs at Aqueduct Racetrack: Where Horses Race, but No One Wins
abstract: When the photographer Theo Zierock looked beyond the excitement of horse racing at Aqueduct Racetrack in Queens, he found a building populated by lonely old men.
lead_paragraph: Thoroughbred horse racing provides one of the great American spectacles: the magnificently chiseled athletes, the elemental contest of speed and power, the libidinal rush of personal fortunes won or lost by the margins of a split second.

headline: The Paradox of the Free-Market Liberal
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'United States Economy', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: Why personality and politics don’t always align.
lead_paragraph: IN American politics, personality is, supposedly, destiny: Having a conservative personality makes us conservative on economic and social policy, and vice versa for liberals. Think of the stereotypes: the free-spending, libertine liberal; the rock-ribbed, free-market conservative.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Sweden and Elsewhere
abstract: Sweden and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Sweden and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Pictures of the Day — Jan. 2, 2015
abstract: Photos from Sweden, Indonesia, Italy and the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Sweden, Indonesia, Italy and the Philippines.

headline: Five-Alarm Obsession: A Fire Truck Buff Custom-Builds Models
abstract: Tom Eve, 63, has not lost his boyish enthusiasm for fire trucks, custom building models for clients who request replicas of pumpers and ladder trucks.
lead_paragraph: Tom Eve, 63, still remembers the day in 1958 that the firehouse on his South Bronx block got its new pumper: a gleaming new Mack whose cab could fit five firefighters.

headline: Who Will Replace Michael Grimm?
abstract: The congressman is stepping down because he cheated on his taxes.
lead_paragraph: Congressman Michael Grimm, who pleaded guilty on Dec. 23 to cheating on his taxes when he ran a health food restaurant, has finally realized that he can no longer represent his New York City district “100 per cent.” The Republican from Staten Island announced earlier this week that he would resign from Congress on Jan. 5 because it is time for him “to start the next chapter of my life.”

headline: For Writer, Talent Finally Succeeds Where Chance Failed
abstract: The writer Edith Pearlman is enjoying a commercial breakthrough at 78, with her first story collection to be published by a major house.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLINE, Mass. — On a recent drizzly afternoon, the short-story writer Edith Pearlman sat reminiscing in the living room of her apartment here with her best friend, Sandy Siler, a retired psychoanalyst.

headline: Next Men Up? Cardinals
abstract: Helped by a new stadium, the Cardinals have grown into a consistent contender since 2007, when Michael Bidwill took over operations of the club. The N.F.L. has rewarded him with a higher profile within the league.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Two hours before the Cardinals played perhaps their biggest regular-season home game in their 27 years in Arizona, Michael Bidwill raced around University of Phoenix Stadium trying to pump up the crowd.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Global Debutantes
abstract: The debutantes resembled orchids in their dresses, which echoed the influence of a recent Charles James exhibition.
lead_paragraph: The debutantes resembled orchids in their dresses, which echoed the influence of a recent Charles James exhibition.

headline: What We’re Reading: Great Reads From the Editors of NYT Now
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Bill Cunningham | Global Debutantes
keywords: ['International Debutante Ball', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Parties (Social)', 'Debutantes', 'High Society and Socialites']
abstract: The debutantes resembled orchids in their dresses, which echoed the influence of a recent Charles James exhibition.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 29, the 60th annual International Debutante Ball, which benefited the Soldiers’, Sailors’, Marines’, Coast Guard and Airmen’s Club, invited young women from Europe, the United States and Asia to the Waldorf-Astoria in New York. The debutantes resembled orchids in their dresses, which echoed the influence of a recent Charles James exhibition. Actual orchids, designed by Anthony and Joseph Silva, set the atmosphere.

headline: Evening Hours | Midnight Song
abstract: An opening at the opera on New Year’s Eve.
lead_paragraph: An opening at the opera on New Year’s Eve.

headline: In Georgia, a Weekend of TV Highlights
abstract: The Cloister at Sea Island in Georgia will have a Classic TV Weekend, with Jerry Mathers as the Beaver.
lead_paragraph: The Cloister at Sea Island is celebrating “30 years of TV” (rooms there didn’t have television sets until 1985) with a trip to the broadcast past.

headline: Of Witches, the Forest and Field Hockey
abstract: The work of the playwright and director Tina Satter, whose “Ancient Lives” opens at the Kitchen on Wednesday, blends coziness and estrangement, weirdness and familiarity.
lead_paragraph: “Fun is not enough,” said the playwright and director Tina Satter, one of downtown theater’s most meticulous yet reliably entertaining artists.

headline: Ferran Adrià Feeds the Hungry Mind
abstract: Ferran Adrià, a groundbreaking Spanish chef whose El Bulli was one of the world’s top restaurants before he closed it, is now on an idiosyncratic quest for knowledge and creativity.
lead_paragraph: One day in November, Ferran Adrià, the Spanish chef who turned foods into foams and pioneered a new era in gastronomic innovation while running one of the world’s most popular restaurants, bounced through a loft space in Barcelona. He peered at pencil-sketched mind maps tacked to plastic foam bulletin boards and examined books jammed on narrow shelves — until he reached the end of a display table featuring a variety of Asian soup spoons. Then he stopped.

headline: A Craigslist ‘Missed Connection’ Lure (Updated With Podcast)
abstract: Before social media made it easy to find out about someone, I fell for a mysterious stranger I met via Craiglist.
lead_paragraph: UPDATED: You can now listen to our Modern Love podcast, featuring Broadway actress Lauren Molina reading this column and a conversation with the writer. Look for the “play” button below.

headline: Paying for Peace
abstract: Questions about a money issue between siblings, false advertising on social media, an old debt, and an old area code.
lead_paragraph: Our daughter and son-in-law, a certified 1 percenter, moved to suburbia with their children. They need a second car because he won’t take the train to work. Our son lent them his pristine vintage Mercedes, and our daughter got into an accident with it, causing $6,000 of damage. So far, our son-in-law has balked at all estimates for repair and told my son to submit an insurance claim. But our son doesn’t want to because his premiums may increase. Harsh words were spoken. Who is right?

headline: Literature of India, Enshrined in a Series
abstract: In a complex undertaking, Harvard University Press is publishing translations of important Indian texts in a series called the Murty Classical Library.
lead_paragraph: When the Loeb Classical Library was founded in 1911, it was hailed as a much-needed effort to make the glories of the Greek and Roman classics available to general readers.

headline: Selfies Get a Little Help
abstract: Visitors to Times Square and Rockefeller Center made use of a popular tool for taking self-portraits.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to Times Square and Rockefeller Center made use of a popular tool for taking self-portraits.

headline: Fusillades Piercing a Fog of Dementia
abstract: Barney Norris’s play “Visitors” has returned to London for a weeklong run at the Bush Theater.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For Edie and Arthur, an English couple who have lived together on a farm for some 40 years, life’s final horizon seems to have reared up with an alarming suddenness. The days and years have passed by uneventfully for this contented and very settled pair, for whom even holidays were rare events. But now Edie’s mind has begun to falter. She can’t move very well, but more distressingly, words don’t come as easily as they once did, and when they do, they may not be the ones intended.

headline: A Deal From the SportAccord World Mind Games
abstract: The winners of the women’s pairs were Marion Michielsen and Meike Wortel from the Netherlands.
lead_paragraph: At the fourth SportAccord World Mind Games last month in Beijing, two pair events followed the team competitions.

headline: The Selfie Stick Takes Manhattan
abstract: Selfie sticks help you keep your distance, and your arm out of the requisite photo.
lead_paragraph: If the throngs of tourists who congregate each December in Times Square and Rockefeller Plaza were not conspicuous enough, the selfie stick took matters to new heights this holiday season. On the last day of the year, you could barely walk through New York’s most touristy areas without getting poked or prodded by the latest craze in digital accessories.

headline: Bitcoin Foundation Parts Ways With Its Global Policy Counsel
keywords: ['Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The dismissal of Jim Harper comes as the Bitcoin Foundation is shifting its focus, from policy advocacy to Bitcoin technology and infrastructure development.
lead_paragraph: Jim Harper, whose appointment as the Bitcoin Foundation’s global policy counsel last March was viewed as a sign that the advocacy group was taking digital currency regulation seriously, has been dismissed from the foundation.

headline: Virgin Conceives; Network Profits
abstract: The Golden Globe nominations for the screwball comedy “Jane the Virgin” has helped lift its home, the CW network, which is in the midst of a transformation.
lead_paragraph: It is the tale of a 23-year-old named Jane, a virgin, who becomes pregnant after she is artificially inseminated — accidentally.

headline: Oscars 2015: Stephen Holden’s Picks
abstract: The critic makes his choice of films he would like to see on the Academy Awards ballot.
lead_paragraph: For the major categories of the Oscars, the New York Times film critics composed a list of films they would like to see nominated. Stephen Holden’s choices are below. Manohla Dargis’s choices are here and A. O. Scott’s choices are here.

headline: Oscars 2015: A. O. Scott’s Picks
abstract: The critic makes his choice of films he would like to see on the Academy Awards ballot.
lead_paragraph: For the major categories of the Oscars, the New York Times film critics composed a list of films they would like to see nominated. A. O. Scott’s choices are below. Manohla Dargis’s choices are here and Stephen Holden’s choices are here.

headline: Oscars 2015: Manohla Dargis’s Picks
abstract: The critic makes her choice of films she’d like to see on the Academy Awards ballot.
lead_paragraph: For the major categories of the Oscars, the New York Times film critics composed a list of films they would like to see nominated. Manohla Dargis’s choices are below. A. O. Scott’s choices are here and Stephen Holden’s choices are here.

headline: The Team Behind the N.F.L.’s ‘No More’ Campaign
abstract: A small group helped the football organization with the “No More” public-service announcements against domestic abuse.
lead_paragraph: This National Football League season got off to a disastrous off-the-field start. In early September, TMZ published a video of Baltimore Ravens running back Ray Rice punching his fiancée (and now wife), Janay Palmer, in an elevator. Days later, Minnesota Vikings running back Adrian Peterson was charged with child abuse for striking his son with a tree branch. The Associated Press named the N.F.L.’s domestic violence problem the top sports story of 2014, ahead of Donald Sterling’s racist comments and LeBron James’s return to Cleveland.

headline: The Unending Anxiety of an ICYMI World
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'News and News Media', 'Television', 'Movies', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The “in case you missed it” sentiment has a way of haunting us. In the Internet age, there is simply too much readable, viewable and listenable data for anyone to stay abreast of.
lead_paragraph: In case you missed it, the initials ICYMI stand for the first five words of this sentence. In the event you have, indeed, missed it (ITEYH, I, MI has not taken off yet for some reason), it’s most likely because you’re not on the Internet much, particularly Twitter, where individuals and outlets deploy it every few seconds to bring links to the attention of others who may not have seen them. The New York Times now even has a section at the bottom of its app called “In Case You Missed It” with articles from previous days.

headline: What Isn’t There an App For?
abstract: A writer spent three weeks trying to improve his life through apps.
lead_paragraph: I am afraid of the Machine. Expose me to banner ads or anticipatory marketing and I am instantly reminded of the inexorable rise of the android; hand me a pair of Google Glass and I am convinced that “RoboCop” was a documentary.

headline: Katherine Waterston’s Red Carpet Looks
abstract: The actress has drawn the fashion world’s attention with her style.
lead_paragraph: The actress has drawn the fashion world’s attention with her style.

headline: Katherine Waterston of ‘Inherent Vice’ Shyly Captivates the Fashion World
abstract: Ms. Waterston became fashion’s “one to watch” this red carpet season.
lead_paragraph: Opacity is Katherine Waterston’s stock in trade. On screen, her disarmingly childlike features are as hard to read as the fine print on a lease, a quality that has set her apart in a string of film roles, most recently that of Shasta Fay Hepworth, the oddly inscrutable temptress of Paul Thomas Anderson’s “Inherent Vice.”

headline: How My Mom Got Hacked
abstract: Navigating the nefarious, shadowy world of ransomware criminals.
lead_paragraph: MY mother received the ransomnote on the Tuesday before Thanksgiving. It popped up on her computer screen soon after she’d discovered that all of her files had been locked. “Your files are encrypted,” it announced. “To get the key to decrypt files you have to pay 500 USD.” If my mother failed to pay within a week, the price would go up to $1,000. After that, her decryption key would be destroyed and any chance of accessing the 5,726 files on her PC — all of her data — would be lost forever.

headline: Suicides Spread Through a Brazilian Tribe
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Indigenous People', 'ABORIGINES', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: After losing their way of life, some indigenous people lose hope.
lead_paragraph: FRIENDS and family gathered around the limp body of a 15-year-old boy laid out on a bed in a thatched hut near the Brazilian town of Iguatemi, close to the border with Paraguay. A shaman shook a small wooden rattle while chanting and dancing — final rites for yet another victim of a suicide epidemic that has plagued the Guaraní Indians of the western Brazilian state of Mato Grosso do Sul.

headline: Thai Cuisine, by Way of Laos
abstract: Along with standard Thai fare, Green Papaya Thai Restaurant, in Canton, offers a handful of dishes based on Laotian cuisine.
lead_paragraph: Among the colorful textiles and Buddhist temple rubbings that decorate the walls of Green Papaya Thai Restaurant, in Canton, hangs a Hmong story cloth that depicts the flight of refugees from Laos into Thailand. This blue fabric, stitched with images of helicopter gunships and people swimming across the Mekong River, is a subtle clue that Green Papaya is not your run-of-the-mill Thai place.

headline: Hairstyles That Ascend, and Aspire, in Nigeria
abstract: J.D. ’Okhai Ojeikere captured fleeting hairstyles that he came to see as embodying beauty, knowledge and art.
lead_paragraph: J.D. ’Okhai Ojeikere captured fleeting hairstyles that he came to see as embodying beauty, knowledge and art.

headline: Gasoline-Tax Increase Finds Little Support
abstract: Advocates like Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee find it tough to penetrate Washington’s antitax mood, even as gas prices fall and federal transportation funds face huge deficits.
lead_paragraph: When gasoline topped $4 a gallon, opponents of an increase in the gas tax argued that prices were already too high.

headline: A Time for Traitors
abstract: Israelis and Palestinians need bold leaders to carry out “a fair divorce.”
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Here is Amos Oz on writing a novel: “It is like reconstructing the whole of Paris from Lego bricks. It’s about three-quarters-of-a-million small decisions. It’s not about who will live and who will die and who will go to bed with whom. Those are the easy ones. It’s about choosing adjectives and adverbs and punctuation. These are molecular decisions that you have to take and nobody will appreciate, for the same reason that nobody ever pays attention to a single note in a symphony in a concert hall, except when the note is false. So you have to work very hard in order for your readers not to note a single false note. That is the business of three-quarters-of-a-million decisions.”

headline: New Zealand Glaciers Ebb and Tour Guides Play Catch-Up
abstract: With winter weather more unpredictable in many parts of the world, companies offering tours through ice and snow find an uneven effect on business.
lead_paragraph: FOX GLACIER, New Zealand — This town of about 300 residents trades on its namesake: a giant slab of ice and snow a short drive from the main street. Guided glacier hiking began here in 1928 and is a main reason for the area’s popularity as a destination for international travelers.

headline: Friday Night Music: The Boys of Sumer
abstract: Golden oldies — really old.
lead_paragraph: The girls too. And yes, I mean Sumer. As I understand it, this is a (seriously) informed guess at what ancient Sumerian and Babylonian music sounded like. And it’s quite haunting:

headline: Combining Funk and Sophistication
abstract: There are lots of influences at work — Cajun, Italian, Japanese and more — at the Hudson Room, a former five-and-dime storefront that opened in August in the heart of Peekskill, but also a lovely local feel.
lead_paragraph: Does fried avocado sound like a good idea to you? It didn’t to me either. But at the Hudson Room, a happening new space in the heart of Peekskill, it somehow worked. Part of a “shrimp and avocado fry” that included expertly fried Gulf shrimp and chunks of avocado with a side of spicy mustard rémoulade, vegetables and brown rice, the bowl captured the feel of the restaurant: Funky meets sophisticated.

headline: Rikers Inmate Found Dead Despite Suicide-Watch Alert
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: According to jail policy, Fabian Cruz, 35, should have been on round-the-clock observation, called for by a mental-health clinician 24 hours earlier.
lead_paragraph: The warning was sent at 4:45 p.m. on New Year’s Eve: A Rikers Island inmate, distraught over an imminent prison sentence, was threatening to harm himself and was possibly suicidal.

headline: Where the Pho Cures All
abstract: Every element of a steaming bowl of pho at Viet Ai, which opened in 2006, in Florham Park is purifying.
lead_paragraph: Never have I had a holiday-induced ailment that a steaming bowl of pho at Viet Ai in Florham Park could not cure. Every element of this soup is purifying, from the star-anise-scented broth made from beef bones (paleos should love this) to the sprigs of fresh basil served on the side so that you, the diner, may add them, thus minimizing wilt time. Delicate rice noodles swim in the fragrant broth. They amaze me every time I eat them because in this one rendition, they actually taste like rice.

headline: Euro Falls Lower as Central Bank Hints at Increase in Stimulus Plan
abstract: Statements by Mario Draghi, president of the European Central Bank, led investors to conclude that the bank would soon buy large quantities of eurobonds.
lead_paragraph: Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, may be pushing hard for a weaker euro to spur growth in Europe, but his central bank peers seem to be several steps ahead of him.

headline: The Décor and Menu: Elegant but Casual
abstract: The owners of Swallow have overhauled the Huntington restaurant and the result is a welcoming, attractive space.
lead_paragraph: Since its opening about three years ago, the Paramount Theater in Huntington has added sparkle to the community. Some of that stardust has drifted to neighboring enterprises like Swallow.

headline: Cuba: Performance Artist Is Freed
abstract: The Cuban performance artist Tania Bruguera was released from custody on Friday after her third arrest this week related to her efforts to push for freedom of expression.
lead_paragraph: The Cuban performance artist Tania Bruguera was released from custody on Friday after her third arrest this week related to her efforts to push for freedom of expression. Her #YoTambienExijo (I also demand) support group said she returned to her mother’s house after being released from a police station, though the authorities had not returned her passport. They told Ms. Bruguera, who divides her time between Cuba, New York and France, that she could not leave the country while “resistance and public disorder” charges were pending. Several activists among about 50 government opponents detained Tuesday were also released. The crackdown, condemned by the State Department and 1,000 artists who signed a letter on Friday to President Raúl Castro, was the largest since the diplomatic thaw between the United States and Cuba was announced Dec. 17.

headline: A Glamorous Spa Day for Little Girls
abstract: The Seriously Spoiled spa in Dix Hills, N.Y., is one of an increasing number of spas that cater to children. A birthday party celebration includes hairstyling, manicures and pizza.
lead_paragraph: The Seriously Spoiled spa in Dix Hills, N.Y., is one of an increasing number of spas that cater to children. A birthday party celebration includes hairstyling, manicures and pizza.

headline: After a Spa Day, Looking Years Younger (O.K., They’re Only 7)
abstract: The spa industry is going way beyond mother-daughter manicures to offer a range of massages, facials and other treatments for young girls (and sometimes boys).
lead_paragraph: AURORA, Colo. — It was a day out at the spa for Paige Ehresman and her closest friends. Manicures. Hairdos. Makeup. And some gossip — about second grade.

headline: John W. Hinckley Jr. Won’t Face Charges in James Brady’s Death
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: The verdict that said Mr. Hinckley was not guilty by reason of insanity in the 1981 shooting of President Ronald Reagan still legally applies, though Mr. Brady’s death last summer was ruled a homicide.
lead_paragraph: John W. Hinckley Jr., who shot and wounded President Ronald Reagan and three others in 1981, will not face charges in the death last summer of James S. Brady, the former White House press secretary, federal prosecutors said Friday.

headline: A Doctor Who Denies He’s a Kingpin
abstract: Dr. Moshe B. Mirilashvili, 66, was charged in federal court with writing over 10,000 medically unnecessary prescriptions for oxycodone from his Manhattan office.
lead_paragraph: “Good afternoon. Doctor speaking.”

headline: A Republican Ruse to Make Tax Cuts Look Good
keywords: ['Taxation', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: “Dynamic scoring” is the wrong way to estimate government revenues.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — AS Republicans take control of Congress this month, at the top of their to-do list is changing how the government measures the impact of tax cuts on federal revenue: namely, to switch from so-called static scoring to “dynamic” scoring. While seemingly arcane, the change could have significant, negative consequences for enacting sustainable, long-term fiscal policies.

headline: When Celebrity Fortunetellers Talk, the Lebanese Listen
abstract: In a region where many governments criminalize divination, Lebanon stands apart for featuring its star soothsayers on New Year’s Eve, when they make predictions in TV specials.
lead_paragraph: ADMA, Lebanon — As the clock ticked toward midnight on New Year’s Eve, Leila Abdel Latif, a Lebanese fortuneteller, sat under the glaring lights of a television studio here and unveiled to viewers across the Arab world what 2015 held in store.

headline: Betting on Default
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Hedge Funds', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Recession and Depression', 'Credit Default Swaps', 'United States Economy', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)']
abstract: Speculation with derivatives is back, the kind of risky behavior that led to the last financial crisis. And Congress is enabling it by weakening Dodd-Frank.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a lender demanding that you miss a payment. That is the situation described in a recent article in The Wall Street Journal. In 2013, GSO Capital Partners, the debt-investing arm of the private equity firm the Blackstone Group, refused to renew a $122.3 million loan to the Spanish gambling company Codere unless it delayed paying interest on other existing debt. Why? It turns out that GSO had placed a bet that Codere’s existing debt would not be paid on time. When, lo and behold, the payment was late, GSO collected on its bet.

headline: Win for ESPN, but Title Game Is the Real Test
abstract: Ohio State’s 42-35 upset of Alabama in the Sugar Bowl attracted 28.27 million viewers, making it the most-watched event in cable TV history, but now comes Part B for ESPN: Ohio State versus Oregon.
lead_paragraph: For the $7.3 billion it is pouring into the new College Football Playoff over 12 years, ESPN surely wants a spectacular payoff. The return on investment was to begin with big viewership for the semifinal games on New Year’s Day, followed by even more viewers for the title game on Jan. 12.

headline: From the Band’s Music, the Weight Builds a Future
abstract: The guitarist Jim Weider, a longtime collaborator of Levon Helm’s, and other surviving members of the Helm inner circle have formed the Weight, an ensemble dedicated to playing the Band’s songs — and keeping the spirit alive.
lead_paragraph: Gamely traversing his native Woodstock on a rainy weekday recently, the guitarist Jim Weider pointed out its onetime cultural hot spots, ending at Levon Helm Studios, which stands as a wooden shrine to its creator, the co-founder of the Band and a latter-day link to Woodstock’s post-festival heyday.

headline: A Calligrapher Brings an Elegant Touch to an Officer’s Funeral
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Chinese-Americans', 'Art']
abstract: Zhao Ru, a famed Chinese calligrapher and Bensonhurst resident, created two scrolls, one for the wake and one for the funeral of Officer Wenjian Liu.
lead_paragraph: The man placed a hand on the paper as gently as a doctor feeling for a pulse. With his other hand he dipped a bamboo brush into a bowl of ink, turning the thirsty bristles black, then brought its tip to the paper’s surface.

headline: Seat of Boston’s Catholic Power Gives Way to Other Pursuits
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Priests']
abstract: The Catholic Church in Boston sold property in its headquarters to pay settlements to sexual abuse victims, a 10-year process that has altered familiar symbols in “Little Rome.”
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The house on the rise has long been a symbol of Catholicism in Boston. When it was built, its grandeur demonstrated the wherewithal of the city’s newly powerful Roman Catholic community. When it was sold, the transaction reflected the straits of a once-powerful archdiocese brought low by scandal.

headline: In Sweden, the Land of the Open Door, Anti-Muslim Sentiment Finds a Foothold
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'ARSON', 'Mosques', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Hate Crimes', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Amid the relentless stream of migrants to Europe that has fueled a backlash against immigrants, directed most viciously at Muslims, arson is suspected at mosques in three Swedish cities over the last 10 days.
lead_paragraph: ESKILSTUNA, Sweden — As Khalif Samantar knelt for afternoon prayers at the Eskilstuna Islamic Dawa Center on Christmas Day, he sensed a growing heat and a low, rushing sound coming from a nearby hallway. He focused his mind on the ritual, only to realize seconds later that someone was shouting, “The mosque is on fire!”

headline: Donna Douglas, the Fairest ‘Beverly Hillbilly,’ Dies at 82
abstract: Ms. Douglas played the shapely daughter of the mountaineer Jed Clampett on the wildly popular television sitcom “The Beverly Hillbillies.”
lead_paragraph: Donna Douglas, who played the shapely, blue-eyed daughter of the suddenly wealthy mountaineer Jed Clampett on “The Beverly Hillbillies,” the wildly popular television sitcom of a half-century ago, died on Thursday in Baton Rouge, La.

headline: As Refugee Tide Swells, Lebanon Plans a Visa Requirement for Syrians
abstract: Some 1.1 million Syrians are said to have sought refuge in Lebanon, a nation of four million people.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For the first time since colonial powers carved Syria and Lebanon into separate countries, Syrians will soon need visas to enter Lebanon, the latest and most significant in a series of new measures by Syria’s neighbors to try to control an overwhelming flow of refugees that appears unlikely to end any time soon.

headline: Mario Cuomo’s Life in Public Service
abstract: The former governor of New York was an eloquent champion of the plights and hopes of ordinary citizens and had a passion for the potential of government.
lead_paragraph: Mario Cuomo, the former governor of New York, came on the political scene with a surpassing idealism about the potential of government and a passion for defending its power to address the plights and hopes of ordinary citizens. Well before his three terms ended, he had become an eloquent champion of those values for the entire country.

headline: Hong Kong Slaughters Chickens After an Outbreak of Bird Flu
abstract: Hong Kong health officials have slaughtered thousands of chickens from mainland China and closed markets, after tests found some birds were infected with a strain of bird flu.
