lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hong Kong health officials have slaughtered thousands of chickens from mainland China, closed one wholesale market and banned imports of live poultry after tests found some birds were infected with a strain of bird flu.

headline: One Last Confluence for Mario and Andrew Cuomo, Proud Rivals
abstract: On the day of Andrew Cuomo’s inauguration for his second term as governor of New York, his father, Mario Cuomo, died, commanding the state’s attention.
lead_paragraph: New Year’s Day was to be a day of triumph and celebration for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo. He was being sworn in for a second term not once but twice, in Manhattan and in Buffalo, with a stirring speech that heralded the accomplishments of his first term and laid out an aggressive agenda for the next four years.

headline: Science Fuels the Writing, and Faith, of a Nicaraguan Poet
abstract: To honor the long life of Ernesto Cardenal, a Roman Catholic priest and a revolutionary, the writer Sergio Ramírez compiled an anthology of Father Cardenal’s poems: “Ninety at Ninety.”
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — ERNESTO CARDENAL is a poet and a priest, a revolutionary and a mystic. His poetry speaks of Marilyn Monroe and Charles Darwin, of Spanish conquistadors and pre-Columbian gods. Science saturates his writing.

headline: N.F.L. Playoffs, as Seen From Below .500
abstract: Through the quirks of the N.F.L. postseason format, Carolina (7-8-1), as a division winner, will have home field advantage over the 11-5 Arizona Cardinals in Saturday’s wild-card matchup.
lead_paragraph: Many roads can lead to the N.F.L. playoffs. Some teams get there with offense, others with defense or special teams. Some have depth, while others ride a superstar through the regular season.

headline: New Jersey Schoolgirl Samplers, Like a Stitch Out of Time
abstract: An exhibition in Princeton focuses on samplers stitched by young girls in the 18th and 19th centuries.
lead_paragraph: By today’s academic standards, the schoolwork stitched onto the 151 samplers that comprise the “Hail Specimen of Female Art! New Jersey Schoolgirl Needlework, 1726-1860” exhibition at Morven Museum and Garden here might not be A-plus-worthy.

headline: Jimmy Dickens, an Outsize Country Singer, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. Dickens, who was small in stature but had a big voice, sang about rural life.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Little Jimmy Dickens, the diminutive but big-voiced country singer best known for his novelty recordings and his self-deprecating sense of humor, died on Friday at a hospital here. He was 94.

headline: Albany Lawmakers and Their Secret Incomes
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'State Legislatures', 'Income']
abstract: State ethics laws are incredibly feeble, and penalties for violations can be little more than a tap on the wrist.
lead_paragraph: It has taken far too long, but federal authorities are finally asking the right questions about how New York’s part-time lawmakers make money apart from their legislative salaries. The Times reported Tuesday that investigators are examining “substantial” secret payments from a small law firm to one of New York’s most powerful politicians, Speaker Sheldon Silver of the Assembly. So far, there has been no real explanation from Mr. Silver.

headline: Dazing SEC Titans, Big Ten Lives Up to Its Adjective
abstract: With its teams winning three bowl games on New Year’s Day and Michigan landing Jim Harbaugh as coach, the Big Ten may be challenging the SEC for college football dominance.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — With less than two minutes left in the Sugar Bowl on Thursday night, Ohio State, ahead by 7 points and having just recovered an onside kick by Alabama, tried a deep pass along the left sideline — Ohio State’s sideline.

headline: Many Identities of New York Officers’ Killer in a Life of Wrong Turns
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Ismaaiyl Brinsley, who killed two police officers in New York last month, seemed to be a grandstander at the end of his tether, homeless, jobless and hopeless.
lead_paragraph: His entire life, Ismaaiyl Brinsley tried on identities as if they were new clothes. He was a bad boy with a gun, a fashionable man in Gucci and Cartier, a T-shirt maker, a film director, a screenwriter, a devout Muslim, a rap producer.

headline: Domestic Discombobulation in an Odd Kitchen
abstract: In an exhibition at the New Britain Museum of American Art, John O’Donnell, a multidisciplinary artist, has transformed a small space into a fantastical kitchen.
lead_paragraph: One sunny morning, John O’Donnell was making coffee when, from the corner of his eye, he was diverted by a ray of light glinting off a pan in his dish drainer. “I was shocked,” he said. “I spent more time than I ever had looking at my dish rack.”

headline: A Ring Sparks Speculation That North Korean Leader’s Sister Has Married
abstract: A photograph in a North Korean newspaper of Kim Jong-un’s younger sister wearing what may be a wedding ring has prompted suggestions that she recently married the son of one of Mr. Kim’s close aides.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The younger sister of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, was shown in the North Korean media wearing a ring on her left ring finger on Friday, prompting speculation that she may have recently married.

headline: Helping Holocaust Artifacts Tell Their Stories
abstract: “Objects of Witness: Testimony From Holocaust Artifacts” features items donated to the Holocaust Memorial and Tolerance Center of Nassau County, in Glen Cove, and gives them personal context.
lead_paragraph: A shoe. A light bulb. A beer stein. An accordion. A concentration camp uniform.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 2, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Eschewing a Higher Calling
abstract: Take a walk with me through Sam Ezersky’s wonderful Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Have you ever traveled to a new town with no real plan for exploring and just meandered along the streets, taking in the sights as you go? I love doing that, because it’s the best way to stumble upon the hidden jewels that a town has to offer. That’s precisely how solving Sam Ezersky’s fine puzzle felt to me. I wandered around his grid, laughing and learning as I went, and that is the best possible outcome one can hope for on a Saturday.

headline: Hillary Versus History
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: With only 55 weeks until the New Hampshire primary and seven months until the Iowa straw poll, there is much presidential history to contemplate.
lead_paragraph: When Hillary Clinton thinks about running for president, do you think she contemplates the fact that no Democrat has been elected to succeed another Democrat since James Buchanan in 1856?

headline: The Legion of Honor? Thomas Piketty Refuses
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Income Inequality', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Why Thomas Piketty doesn’t want an award — at least not from the French government.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes an award means more to the giver than the recipient. That is probably the case with the French government’s decision to give the Legion of Honor to Thomas Piketty, the economist and author of the critically acclaimed book about inequality, “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” who says he doesn’t want the award.

headline: New York City Requiring Flu Shots for Preschoolers
abstract: The new rule applies to about 150,000 children in city-licensed day cares and preschools, covering those from 6 months to 5 years of age.
lead_paragraph: New York City preschoolers will be heading back to class next week with memories of new holiday toys, vacation adventures, and, health officials hope, a flu shot.

headline: A.F.C. Wild-Card Matchup: Baltimore Ravens vs. Pittsburgh Steelers
abstract: Baltimore has typically not performed well in playoff games at Pittsburgh, but an injury to the Steelers’ Le’Veon Bell could help the Ravens.
lead_paragraph: Ravens (10-6) at Steelers (11-5)

headline: N.F.C. Wild-Card Matchup: Arizona Cardinals vs. Carolina Panthers
abstract: Arizona has been slumping and will host Carolina, which has been one of the league’s hottest teams in the last month despite its losing record.
lead_paragraph: Cardinals (11-5) at Panthers (7-8-1)

headline: The Abortion Stereotype
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'ABORTION', 'Religion and Belief', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Think of it less as a “war on women,” and more as a war among them.
lead_paragraph: DAVIS, Calif. — IT’S been widely observed that in recent elections men have leaned Republican and women Democratic. A key element of that gender gap is often assumed to be a difference in attitudes to women’s reproductive rights.

headline: No Turned Backs at Officer Liu’s Funeral, Bratton Asks
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton urged New York City officers not to demonstrate antagonism when Mayor Bill de Blasio appears at the service for an officer who was killed on duty.
lead_paragraph: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton urged New York City police officers on Friday not to turn their backs when Mayor Bill de Blasio appears on Sunday at the funeral of an officer who was killed on duty in Brooklyn last month.

headline: Miller Williams, Plain-Spoken Arkansas Poet, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Williams, the father of the singer Lucinda Williams, was a man of economical speech whose admirers included Richard Yates and Flannery O’Connor.
lead_paragraph: Miller Williams, a poet who championed the power of everyday language and who delivered a poem at the Capitol for President Bill Clinton’s second inauguration, died on Thursday in Fayetteville, Ark. He was 84.

headline: Mario Cuomo: The Liberal Idealist
abstract: Readers react to the death of the former New York governor.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: After an Attack, a Man’s Options Slowly Fade
abstract: Modesto Miranda, 60, of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., is slowly going blind after being stabbed multiple times during a robbery in 2008.
lead_paragraph: Along Main Street in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., the occasional landmark was a backdrop to commuting cyclists, bundled against an early December chill. A few men leaned against mull posts outside storefronts with boarded-up windows. Where the glass remained unbroken, hand-lettered signs hung outside family-owned businesses: “Tenemos pan!” one read.

headline: Serge Hochar, Producer of Lebanese Wines, Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Hochar made his Chateau Musar much admired, in part for having operated even as civil war raged in Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: Serge Hochar, who navigated Chateau Musar, his family’s winery in Lebanon, through 15 years of civil war as Musar became one of the most admired wine producers in the world, died on Wednesday in Acapulco, Mexico. He was 75.

headline: The Trouble With Common Core Standards
abstract: Teachers, current and former, respond to a Sunday Review article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The South’s Newcomers
abstract: Readers explain the appeal of a fast-growing region.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Rajon Rondo Stars in Boston, Wearing Blue This Time
abstract: In an unremarkable season, honoring the team’s former stars has become a highlight, and Dallas’s Rajon Rondo was the latest to benefit.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Reunions represent the high point of the Celtics’ schedule these days. The team does not win much — it is 11-19 — but it has learned during the past few seasons how to pay tribute to its former players and coaches.

headline: A Toddler and a Gun
abstract: Readers react to the accidental shooting of a mother by a toddler who reached into her purse containing a gun.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Denied Entry to Egypt
abstract: The Egyptian ambassador says an American scholar was turned away because she lacked the required visa, not for political reasons.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Knicks, Desperate for Points and Bodies, Fall Again
abstract: The injury-depleted Knicks lost for the 20th time in 21 games as the struggling Pistons easily sent them to their ninth straight home loss.
lead_paragraph: Before the Knicks heard resounding boos in the second quarter, missed their first 11 shots in the third and fell behind by 30 points in the fourth, before all of this on Friday, Coach Derek Fisher’s pregame question-and-answer session veered into the absurd.

headline: Girl, 7, Survives Kentucky Plane Crash That Killed 4, Police Say
abstract: The girl, who was injured, showed up at a resident’s home after a twin-engine plane crashed Friday, killing the pilot and three passengers, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A 7-year-old girl walked away from a small-plane crash on Friday that killed four people, including two children, in southwest Kentucky, according to the authorities.

headline: China’s Crime-Free Crime Films
keywords: ['Movies', 'Censorship', 'Writing and Writers', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: Can any good movie make it past the censors?
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A FEW years back I got a call from a film director based in China who had read one of my detective novels. “Can you help me write a screenplay for a crime story?” he asked. “The tricky thing is that it’s set in Beijing, so no crime can be involved.”

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 3:40 P.M. (HBO Signature) THE TRUTH ABOUT CHARLIE (2002) In Jonathan Demme’s remake of the 1963 comic thriller “Charade,” Thandie Newton steps into the Audrey Hepburn role as a new wife who returns to her Paris apartment to break it off with her art-dealing husband, Charlie, only to find the place ransacked. She soon discovers that nothing is as it seems. Mark Wahlberg, in the role originated by Cary Grant, portrays the charming stranger eager to help; Tim Robbins is the man she turns to at the United States Embassy. “The sensual, butter-voiced” Ms. Newton is “so good that when she’s on screen, the movie works — or at least you think it does,” Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times. “It’s a spot-specific case of alchemy.”

headline: Corrections: January 3, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, January 3, 2015.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 3, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “They do deserve something special. I don’t want them to feel that my saying ‘no’ means that I don’t love them.”

headline: Qaeda Suspect Facing Trial in New York Over Africa Embassy Bombings Dies
abstract: A suspected leader of Al Qaeda, Nazih Abdul-Hamed al-Ruqai, who was to be tried this month in the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in East Africa, died in government custody after suffering from liver cancer.
lead_paragraph: A Libyan suspected of being an operative for Al Qaeda who was captured by United States commandos in Libya in 2013 and brought to New York to face trial died in government custody on Friday night after complications from longstanding medical problems, prosecutors said.

headline: Five Arrested in India Rape Case
abstract: A Japanese woman said that she had been lured to the Gaya district in Bihar by a man posing as a tour guide and raped, the police said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Five men have been arrested in connection with the alleged abduction and rape of a Japanese woman who said she was held captive for 12 days, the Indian police said Saturday.

headline: Penn Station: A Place That Once Made Travelers Feel Important
abstract: The loss of the old Pennsylvania Station, an architectural and civic gem of New York, was a story of desperation and indifference.
lead_paragraph: If you don’t enjoy arriving in or departing from New York City through the squalid cavern known as Pennsylvania Station, you can blame — at least for a start — the desperate executives, short on public spirit, who tried to prop up the money-losing Pennsylvania Railroad in the 1950s.

headline: If You Want to Meet That Deadline, Play a Trick on Your Mind
abstract: By tweaking our perception of time, research shows, we can more easily attain a goal — or meet a New Year’s resolution.
lead_paragraph: It’s just a few days into the new year. How are you doing on your resolutions? Wait: Have you even started on them yet?

headline: Learning a Foreign Language Called Public Relations
abstract: Despite being utterly clueless about the business world, a hired writer soon won over a start-up company’s team.
lead_paragraph: It was an odd phone call, a request out of the blue to ghostwrite a book for a man who’d read a magazine column of mine.

headline: Racial Bias, Even When We Have Good Intentions
abstract: Dozens of researchers have documented discrimination that is outside of our awareness.
lead_paragraph: The deaths of African-Americans at the hands of the police in Ferguson, Mo., in Cleveland and on Staten Island have reignited a debate about race. Some argue that these events are isolated and that racism is a thing of the past. Others contend that they are merely the tip of the iceberg, highlighting that skin color still has a huge effect on how people are treated.

headline: Maynard Webb, Yahoo’s Chairman: Even the Best Teams Can Be Better
abstract: A veteran tech executive says that in general, companies spend too much time on poor performers and not enough on making “A-plus” employees better.
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Maynard Webb, a veteran technology executive whose current roles include serving as chairman of Yahoo, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Whole Foods’ High Hurdle for Investors
abstract: Whole Foods Market got the S.E.C.’s permission to exclude from its proxy a shareholder proposal on director nominations, and 10 other companies now want to do the same.
lead_paragraph: Shareholders own the companies they invest in, but they have long been largely shut out of any role in naming the people who are supposed to represent them: corporate directors.

headline: Maintaining Rent-Stabilized Status
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Cooperatives', 'Home Appliances']
abstract: This week’s topics include the maintenance of rent-stabilized status; a co-op Energy Star appliance rule; and questions about a board president’s apartment purchase.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Variety: Takeaway
abstract: Matt Ginsberg takes away our letters in this fun Variety puzzle.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — The Variety puzzles are a lovely breath of fresh air from our daily crosswords, unless they make your brain hurt. It took me a few tries to get into Matt Ginsberg’s Takeaway puzzle, but get into it I did. Once my brain stopped hurting.

headline: Resolving to Create a New You
abstract: Don’t just do what you should be doing. Reflect on the person you can be.
lead_paragraph: THE annual ritual of the New Year’s resolution — I’ll lose 10 pounds, get my finances in order, be more patient with my family, feel more grateful — misses the point. We try to steel our wills to do what we already know we should be doing. Kick-in-the-pants reminders, however stern, are missed opportunities for genuine self-renewal. (Not to mention that the shelf life of any motivational juice we generate in January tends to expire in February.)

headline: Obama Plans 3-Day Tour to Preview State of the Union
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama plans a three-day, three-state tour promoting different themes as a prelude to his State of the Union speech, White House officials said.
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — President Obama plans to spend the weeks leading up to his State of the Union speech traveling across the country to promote different themes from it, a new approach by the commander in chief to the annual address to Congress.

headline: The Liberation of Growing Old
abstract: Ageism has been described as prejudice against one’s future self.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — WHY do we have such punitive attitudes toward old people? Granted, the ancients did hideous things to elders who were unable to work but still needed food and care, but in more recent times, that had changed: In 18th-century New England, it was common for people to make themselves seem older by adding years to their real age, rather than subtracting them.

headline: Healthy and Hungry Again
abstract: After a period of pain and reflection, Victoria Azarenka, the former No. 1 tennis player in the world, is primed for the opening of a new season.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was almost 2015, and Victoria Azarenka was parked in her sleek sport utility vehicle on a Beverly Hills street with the rain drumming on the windshield as she spoke about how it felt to no longer be above the rest, to be ranked No. 31 instead of No. 1.

headline: Heavyweight Response to Local Fracking Bans
keywords: ['Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Natural Gas', 'Local Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The oil and gas industry has responded aggressively to a wave of local, citizen-led bans on hydraulic fracturing, arguing in court that only state officials can impose such rules.
lead_paragraph: LONGMONT, Colo. — This northern Colorado city vaulted onto the front lines of the battle over oil and gas drilling two years ago, when residents voted to ban hydraulic fracturing from their grassy open spaces and a snow-fed reservoir where anglers catch smallmouth bass.

headline: Confessions of a Columnist
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Police', 'Ebola Virus', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Here is the annual inventory of mistakes and bad predictions.
lead_paragraph: IN the new year, it goes without saying that we should all eat more vegetables, exercise more often, tweet or text a little less and pray a little more. But for the professional pundit, there’s really only one resolution that matters: Be less wrong.

headline: Islanders Enjoy a Raucous Advantage in Their Soon-to-Be Former Home
abstract: Many of the singing, chanting fans in Section 329 of Nassau Coliseum are too young to remember the Islanders’ last victorious playoff series, in 1993.
lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — As the Islanders’ final home game of 2014 began, Tom LoFaso stood poised in the next-to-last row of Section 329 surrounded by dozens of his orange-and-blue-clad brethren.

headline: Radical Islam, Nihilist Rage
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Terrorism', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks']
abstract: Jihadism fills the void left by failed political ideologies.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — FACED with a horror like the slaughter of 148 schoolchildren and school staff members by the Taliban in Pakistan, it is tempting to describe the act as “inhuman” or “medieval.” What made the massacre particularly chilling, though, is that it was neither. The killings were all too human and of our time.

headline: After Killing of Gaza Teenager, Calls for Egyptian Inquiry
abstract: Palestinian officials are demanding that the Egyptian government investigate the fatal shooting of a 16-year-old boy from Gaza who they say was killed by Egyptian soldiers.
lead_paragraph: GAZA — Palestinian officials are demanding that the Egyptian government investigate the fatal shooting of a 16-year-old boy from Gaza who they say was killed by Egyptian soldiers, condemning what the officials called excessive force against a teenager who had been crossing the frontier to find work.

headline: The Strip
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'New Year', 'Comic Books and Strips']
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Indian and Pakistani Guards Trade Fire on Disputed Border
abstract: The exchange of fire across the northern border in the state of Jammu and Kashmir left at least two people dead and at least one other wounded, officials said Saturday.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Indian and Pakistani border guards exchanged fire along the disputed northern border in the state of Jammu and Kashmir, leaving at least two people dead and at least one other wounded, officials said Saturday.

headline: Anthony Doerr
abstract: The novelist on Joseph Campbell’s monomyth argument, the power of wool and the LeBron James narrative.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Doerr is a fiction writer living in Boise, Idaho, whose most recent novel is “All the Light We Cannot See.”

headline: Obama Is the Nation’s Private Golfer in Chief
abstract: While little is known about President Obama’s game, his own hints (and golfers who have played with him) describe a dedicated and gradually improving player.
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — President Obama’s drives were consistently short. It often took him one shot too many to get his ball on the green. And when he finally took out his putter, he struggled with his touch.

headline: Filling Garden With Misery and, at Least for Now, Fans
abstract: The Knicks’ season has given fans little to cheer about, but Madison Square Garden continues to sell out and attract its share of celebrities.
lead_paragraph: Milton and Anthony Tembelis, cousins from Queens, were eating pastrami and turkey sandwiches at a table for two Friday night in a concourse at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Playing Dumb on Climate Change
abstract: Scientists practice a form of self-denial, denying themselves the right to believe anything that has not passed a very high bar.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — SCIENTISTS have often been accused of exaggerating the threat of climate change, but it’s becoming increasingly clear that they ought to be more emphatic about the risk. The year just concluded is about to be declared the hottest one on record, and across the globe climate change is happening faster than scientists predicted.

headline: Two Stars Don’t Start, and the Nets Thrive
abstract: With Brook Lopez and Deron Williams coming off the bench, Brooklyn has won six of seven games in its annual midseason turnaround.
lead_paragraph: In the last few seasons, the Nets have developed a habit of making midseason turnarounds after making major personnel changes. Two seasons ago, they went 35-19 after Avery Johnson was fired as coach. Last season, they closed the season with a 34-17 record after adjusting to the loss of Brook Lopez. Having defeated the Magic in Orlando on Friday night, the Nets have won six of their last seven games.

headline: Faces of Worship
abstract: Readers discuss an essay about religious practices that don’t center on a belief in God.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss an essay about religious practices that don’t center on a belief in God.

headline: Turkey’s President Traces a New Internal Threat: The Way He’s Drawn
abstract: Editorial cartoonists have long been a staple of Turkish politics, but President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is not amused, and is using the courts to crack down on them.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — In the cartoon, an image of Recep Tayyip Erdogan stands watch while two thieves empty a safe full of cash. “No need to rush,” one of the thieves says with a grin. “We have a holographic watchman,” he adds.

headline: The Afghan President’s Overreach
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Politics and Government', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)']
abstract: A demand that a United Nations agency relinquish responsibility for a security fund does not instill much confidence.
lead_paragraph: President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan is known for occasionally being hot-tempered. But it was nonetheless baffling to Western diplomats when, in recent days, he abruptly demanded that the United Nations Development Program, the agency that manages hundreds of millions of dollars provided by Western donors to run the police force, relinquish responsibility for the fund within six months.

headline: A Weary Greece Considers Its Options
abstract: Voters, battered by misguided austerity policies, are looking beyond mainstream political parties.
lead_paragraph: The human toll of the economic crisis in Greece has been significant: Rates of hunger, suicide and unemployment have increased sharply, thanks to years of misguided austerity policies. So it is hardly shocking that polls are showing that voters are likely to give control of Parliament to the leftist political party Syriza in an election later this month.

headline: Brazen Attempts by Hotels to Block Wi-Fi
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Wireless Communications', 'Editorials', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission should not allow Marriott and others to prevent guests from using their own wireless Internet devices.
lead_paragraph: Some large hotel chains want to  block guests from using their own wireless Internet devices. It’s a blatant attempt to limit customer choice, and the Federal Communications Commission should say no.

headline: F.B.I. Employees With Ties Abroad See Security Bias
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Terrorism']
abstract: An F.B.I. program aimed at reducing internal threats is said to be penalizing employees hired for their foreign language skills by subjecting them to higher scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. is subjecting hundreds of its employees who were born overseas or have relatives or friends there to an aggressive internal surveillance program that started after Sept. 11, 2001, to prevent foreign spies from coercing newly hired linguists but that has been greatly expanded since then.

headline: Are Two Dynasties Our Destiny?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The prematurely anointed frontrunners for the White House have miles to go and many liabilities.
lead_paragraph: JEB and Hillary. Hillary and Jeb. It’s getting to the point where a mention of one yields a reference to the other, where they’re semantically inseparable, presidentially conjoined. Should we just go the extra step, save ourselves some syllables and keystrokes? The 2016 matchup as envisioned by many: Jebary. Or, more economically still, Heb.

headline: Stanislaw Baranczak, 68, Polish Underground Poet, Dies
abstract: Mr. Baranczak defied state censors to write about living under Communist oppression and later emigrated to the United States, where he taught at Harvard.
lead_paragraph: Stanislaw Baranczak, a Polish poet and essayist who defied state censors to write about living under Communist oppression and who later emigrated to the United States, where he taught at Harvard, wrote in English about living in exile and translated Polish masters into English and English masters into Polish, died on Dec. 26 at his home in Newton, Mass. He was 68.

headline: Making the Case for Don Mattingly on His Last Chance for Cooperstown
abstract: Mattingly likely will not make it into the Hall of Fame in his last year of eligibility, a sad prospect for one fan who watched him in his peak years.
lead_paragraph: Don Mattingly is the author of one of baseball’s most preposterous statistical anomalies. In 1987, he set the major league record (it has since been tied) for most grand slams in a season — six — and those were the only ones he ever hit.

headline: Healthy Body, Unhealthy Mind
abstract: I gave up Big Macs and started exercising. But I was neglecting my inner life.
lead_paragraph: MANY of my friends were shocked some years ago when I cut down on my junk-food intake. Even my wise old physician was a little put out. He had more or less given me the green light to the “golden arches” a few years before when, one afternoon, following my annual checkup, he’d asked me what I consumed every day. “A Big Mac, medium fries and Coke for lunch,” I answered, “and frozen pizza from the convenience store for dinner.”

headline: As Dallas Cowboys Hit Stride, Tony Romo Pursues His Legacy
abstract: Romo, the Cowboys quarterback, had one of his finest seasons, but he has missed the last four postseasons and has yet to win a Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: IRVING, Tex. — At 34, Tony Romo stands at a crossroads of his career and his legacy. There is only one criterion by which to judge what he has accomplished as quarterback of the Dallas Cowboys: Super Bowl appearances.

headline: Emotions Flip From Note to Note
abstract: Almost from the outset of his tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic, Alan Gilbert has championed the music of the Danish composer Carl Nielsen.
lead_paragraph: Almost from the outset of his tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic, Alan Gilbert has championed the music of the Danish composer Carl Nielsen. This week he conducts performances of Nielsen’s Clarinet Concerto with the orchestra’s new principal clarinetist, Anthony McGill, taking on the solo part that flips through emotions ranging from sardonic humor to deep melancholy. The program also includes Ravel’s “Valses nobles et sentimentales” and selections from Tchaikovsky’s “Swan Lake.” (Thursday, Friday and Saturday, Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, nyphil.org.)

headline: New to New York, but Not to Music
abstract: How could it be possible that Neneh Cherry has never performed in New York before?
lead_paragraph: How could it be possible that Neneh Cherry has never performed in New York before? The song she is most famous for — “Buffalo Stance,” from the album “Raw Like Sushi” — was full of self-conscious hip-hop style and smart, joyous, Madonna-like pop, an almost perfect 1989 New York radio record, even if made by a Swedish-British bohemian with meaningful roots outside of the mainstream. (Her stepfather was the jazz trumpeter Don Cherry, and she had already been a member of the important English post-punk bands Rip, Rig + Panic, and the Slits.)

headline: There’s More Than Movement
abstract: Bodytraffic and Doug Elkins Choreography, Etc. are sharing the Joyce this week.
lead_paragraph: Although only one of the two groups sharing the Joyce this week has “etc.” in its name, both Bodytraffic and Doug Elkins Choreography, Etc. could be called et cetera companies. In their productions, a range of dance and musical forms are added to one another in theatrically rich mixtures.

headline: ‘Life Itself,’ a Documentary
abstract: “Life Itself,” a documentary about the film critic Roger Ebert, who died in 2013, has its television premiere on Sunday night on CNN.
lead_paragraph: A simple biography of the film critic Roger Ebert would have made for a full documentary, but the director Steve James set the bar much higher with “Life Itself.” The film, receiving its television premiere Sunday night on CNN, covers the life and career of Mr. Ebert, who died in 2013, but it also chronicles the final months of his battle with cancer, his philosophy of criticism, the influence he had on filmmakers and more.

headline: The Pains of War, Long After Battle
abstract: John Huston made his 1946 documentary, “Let There Be Light,” about soldiers with “neuropsychiatric disorders” — what we now call post-traumatic stress disorder — for the Army.
lead_paragraph: John Huston made his 1946 documentary, “Let There Be Light,” about soldiers with “neuropsychiatric disorders” — what we now call post-traumatic stress disorder — for the Army. But the Army banned the film for 35 years. What did it fear? Presumably the power of the soldiers’ pain and of Huston’s movie, which follows a group of soldiers from admission to a hospital through treatment (talk therapy, hypnosis) and rehabilitation to release.

headline: Where Housing Is Cheapest
abstract: Data shows that the least affordable areas lean blue politically.
lead_paragraph: Data shows that the least affordable areas lean blue politically.

headline: Black History, Told by Works
abstract: The Philadelphia Museum of Art will present “Represent: 200 Years of African American Art,” an exhibition of about 75 works by more than 50 artists from the museum’s holdings.
lead_paragraph: The first work by a black American artist to be acquired by an American museum was Henry Ossawa Tanner’s luminous “The Annunciation” (1898), in which the angel Gabriel in the form of a burst of pure light appears to Mary in her humble, typically Middle Eastern bedroom — it entered the collection of the Philadelphia Museum of Art in 1899. The museum has since collected much more art by black Americans. On Jan. 10, it will open “Represent: 200 Years of African American Art,” an exhibition of about 75 works by more than 50 artists from the museum’s holdings. The show will include works made by free and enslaved pre-Civil War artists and artisans; early Modernists like William Henry Johnson and Jacob Lawrence; and self-taught artists like William Edmondson, Horace Pippin and Bill Traylor. Glenn Ligon, Martin Puryear, Carrie Mae Weems and other contemporary artists will bring up to date what promises to be an enlightening, kaleidoscopic reflection of black American history and experience. (Through April 5, philamuseum.org.)

headline: Is Life Better in America’s Red States?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'States (US)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Income Inequality', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Liberal regions are richer, but they create fewer jobs.
lead_paragraph: THE new Congress that starts work this week is the latest reminder of America’s stark political divisions: The parties in Washington are more polarized than they have been in decades, the partisanship gap between rural Republicans and urban Democrats has grown, and the battle for suburban voters keeps intensifying. Much less is said, however, about the equally significant economic division between conservative “red states” and liberal “blue states.”

headline: Indianapolis Colts’ Offensive Line Remains Fluid
abstract: Indianapolis, plagued by injuries, will use its 11th offensive-line starting combination of the season in its playoff opener on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Anthony Castonzo has been a rock on an ever-shifting beach.

headline: When Prisoners Are Patients
abstract: Should convicted felons receive free health care?
lead_paragraph: It’s an odd thing, to take care of someone who is chained to a bed, guarded 24/7 by bored corrections officers idling away time with TV and card games, who cannot receive visitors or even phone calls. But it happens when prison inmates are sick enough that they need care that only a hospital can provide.

headline: Tensions Mount as Israel Freezes Revenue Meant for Palestinians
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'Israeli Settlements', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Taxation', 'International Relations']
abstract: It is the first of an expected series of punitive measures in response to a push by the Palestinians to prosecute Israeli officials for war crimes during the battle with militants in the Gaza Strip last summer.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel is withholding $127 million in tax revenue it collects for the Palestinian Authority in response to its move last week to join the International Criminal Court, further escalating tensions with a step that could have serious repercussions for both sides.

headline: The Next Battle for Ukraine
abstract: A new activist generation seeks a shift in the way society and the state interact.
lead_paragraph: CAN a group of young reformers fix a broken country?

headline: Me, Me, Me and My Therapist
abstract: Would he continue to exist if we couldn’t see him?
lead_paragraph: “Just because I go someplace doesn’t mean you lost me,” Jeffery, my therapist, said. Crouched on the floor, my back to him, I tried not to listen. “It’s true I do other things, but that doesn’t mean I forget you.”

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest Sports headlines.
lead_paragraph: Rethinking Business Of College Football

headline: With Knicks Crumbling, Maybe Carmelo Anthony Can Heal
abstract: The Knicks’ sole solace this season may be a prime position in the draft lottery, so it may be a good time to shut down Anthony so his sore knee can heal.
lead_paragraph: Carmelo Anthony did not miss a shot against the Detroit Pistons on Friday night. He did not commit a turnover. He was neither outrebounded for putbacks nor caught flat-footed on backdoor cuts. Instead, he occupied a seat behind the bench and watched his teammates do everything wrong without him.

headline: Mourners Pay Respects to Wenjian Liu, Officer Slain in Brooklyn
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A blue line of police officers stretched for blocks outside a funeral home in Brooklyn on Saturday at the wake for Officer Liu, who was fatally shot along with his partner, Officer Rafael Ramos, on Dec. 20.
lead_paragraph: A cold rain pelted the long, blue line of police officers that stretched for blocks outside the Aievoli Funeral Home in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn on Saturday.

headline: The Economics (and Nostalgia) of Dead Malls
keywords: ['Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: High-end shopping malls are thriving across the country, but as midtier retailers like Sears and J. C. Penney flounder, they are also dragging down their malls.
lead_paragraph: OWINGS MILLS, Md. — Inside the gleaming mall here on the Sunday before Christmas, just one thing was missing: shoppers.

headline: Edward W. Brooke III, 95, Senate Pioneer, Is Dead
abstract: A liberal Republican from Massachusetts, Mr. Brooke in 1966 became the first African-American popularly elected to the Senate.
lead_paragraph: Edward W. Brooke III, who in 1966 became the first African-American elected to the United States Senate by popular vote, winning as a Republican in overwhelmingly Democratic Massachusetts, died on Saturday at his home in Coral Gables, Fla. He was 95.

headline: N.F.L. Coaches Now Reach for Next Level: College
abstract: In the N.F.L. players can outrank coaches, while in college, the head coach frequently has more power than the star quarterback, the athletic director and the university president.
lead_paragraph: In the early days of his first season in the N.F.L. as the Tennessee Titans’ offensive coordinator, Norm Chow was in a meeting in which, he recalled, coaches and players were bantering with a rookie, chiding him to pay closer attention. When Chow joined in, the rookie, a recent high draft pick, responded that he had a direct line to the owner.

headline: N.F.C. Wild-Card Matchup: Detroit Lions at Dallas Cowboys

Yanukovych hesitated, shaking his pen above the text placed before him in the chandeliered hall. Then, under the unsmiling gaze of European diplomats and his political enemies, the beleaguered Ukrainian president scrawled his signature, sealing a deal that he believed would keep him in power, at least for a few more months.

headline: For the Indie Writers of Amazon, It’s Publish or Perish
keywords: ['Amazon Kindle', 'Books and Literature', 'E-Books and Readers', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Amazon’s “all you can eat” reading service, Kindle Unlimited, is driving down prices even as it boosts sales. For self-published authors, that’s a cause for concern.
lead_paragraph: One big argument for “all you can eat” music, video and book services is that they encourage people to sample new artists and ultimately develop a deeper relationship with a few of them. You listen to songs you have never heard before because there is no additional cost, and then maybe you go to the concert and, perhaps, buy a T-shirt. Artists are rewarded at the end of the process, not in the beginning the way they used to be.

headline: In Fervent Support of the ‘Gap Year’
abstract: I worried that my daughter’s decision to take a gap year would mean she’d never go to college. I shouldn’t have.
lead_paragraph: I wasn’t enthusiastic when my daughter first floated her plan to take a “gap year” before college. As someone who couldn’t wait to matriculate, I didn’t see the point of delaying that great intellectual awakening. I felt vaguely disappointed that she wasn’t more eager to embrace all those books and ideas and late-night conversations about the cosmos. And what if her gap year turned into a permanent crevasse and she never earned a degree?

headline: 1940: British Shipping to Be Operated by Government
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Britain announced it would take control of British and colonial shipping in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The government will take over full control of British and colonial shipping beginning February 1 to obtain more tonnage for national use, the Ministry of Shipping announced tonight [Jan. 4]. All ships of United Kingdom and colonial registry, with the exception of vessels of Indian and Burman registry, will be taken over when they discharge their first cargo in Great Britain after that date. The scheme, identical to the one employed successfully during the World War, will make it possible to operate ships more efficiently and economically because of the community of interests of the British Dominions, it was explained. Such a control system, it was stated, will result in a regular execution of the shipping program for the efficient conduct of the war. The companies will continue to manage and operate their ships as though carrying on their own business but will receive instructions as to the cargoes to be carried and the routes to be followed. They will maintain their organizations in Britain and abroad but will keep an account of costs for the Ministry. Operating profits and losses are to be treated as on government account. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 5, 1940

headline: Another Silent Protest of Mayor de Blasio as Officer Liu Is Laid to Rest
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']

And for the second time, hundreds of those officers made a silent show of protest against Mayor Bill de Blasio.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) DOWNTON ABBEY The times are a-changin’ at Downton as Season 5 of this soapy “Masterpiece” drama picks up in 1924. Upstairs, Lord Grantham stews about the first Labour Government under Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald and what he perceives as its anti-aristocracy stance. Downstairs, the servants think that someone in charge might finally understand the concept of hard work. Lady Edith, meanwhile, turns to the tenant farmer Mr. Drewe and his unsuspecting wife to secret away Marigold, her illegitimate daughter with her married lover, Michael Gregson, still missing in Germany. Lady Mary finds herself inundated by dashing suitors. And when the committee in charge of creating a World War I memorial comes knocking, it isn’t Lord Grantham they want, but rather Mr. Carson, the butler. In “The Manners of Downton Abbey,” at 10:15, Alastair Bruce, an expert on royal ceremony and custom who serves as the show’s historical adviser, discusses the code of conduct that governed Britain in the early 20th century and how he goes about tutoring the actors in speaking, sitting, dressing and keeping an appropriately stiff upper lip. Hugh Bonneville, Elizabeth McGovern, Michelle Dockery (above, with Allen Leech), Laura Carmichael, Brendan Coyle, Joanne Froggatt and Lily James chime in.

headline: 1965: T. S. Eliot, 76, Dies
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: T.S. Eliot dies in 1965.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — T. S. Eliot, 76, American-born poet, critic and dramatist, died at his London home tonight [Jan. 4]. Thomas Stearns Eliot’s best known poems include ‘‘The Waste Land’’, ‘‘The Love Song of J. Arthur Prufrock,’’ and ‘‘Four Quartets,’’ and his plays: ‘‘The Cocktail Party’’ and ‘‘Murder in the Cathedral.’’ Born in St. Louis. Mo., of a Colonial Boston family, he was a naturalized British subject and held the highest civilian honors of both Britain and the United States. He was given the U.S. Presidential Medal of Freedom last September, and received the Order of Merit in Britain; as well as the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1948. France also made him an Officer of the Legion of Honor. Mr. Eliot was acknowledged as one of the most important creators of poetic style in the 20th century. He found in the cultural tradition of Europe a source of renewal for English poetry. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 5, 1965

headline: ‘The Hobbit: The Battle of Five Armies’ Reigns at the Box Office
abstract: “The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies” (Warner Bros.) continued to lead the North American box office, taking in an estimated $21.9 million, for a three-week total of $220.8 million.
lead_paragraph: As expected, “The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies” (Warner Bros.) continued to lead the North American box office, taking in an estimated $21.9 million, for a three-week total of $220.8 million. But the two films hot on its tail – Rob Marshall’s “Into the Woods” and Angelina Jolie’s “Unbroken” – were the reason Hollywood started the year smiling: Each release is a prime example of a type of film that supposedly can no longer succeed in theaters.

headline: National Pride at a Steep Price
abstract: The debate over an Olympic stadium to be built for the 2020 Summer Games illustrates how the structures have become potent symbols of architectural prowess and economic pride.

But many others deplore it, with one prominent Japanese architect saying it reminded him of a turtle. Another likened the $1.37 billion building, already projected to be the most expensive Olympic stadium in recent history, to another kind of animal.

lead_paragraph: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif. — The tip of El Capitan, 3,000 feet above its base, glowed in late-day sunlight while a full moon rose at the other end of the Yosemite Valley on Saturday. lead_paragraph: By just about any measure, the International Consumer Electronics Show is big. The event, held in Las Vegas, attracts more than 150,000 visitors. It occupies two million square feet, the equivalent of about 35 football fields, of exhibition space. More than 3,500 companies come to show their wares.

lead_paragraph: In 1994, the guitarist Peter Bernstein made the record “Signs of Life” for the Dutch label Criss Cross Jazz, with the pianist Brad Mehldau, the bassist Christian McBride and the drummer Greg Hutchinson. Almost exactly 20 years later, starting on Friday, Mr. Bernstein assembled the same band — all of them among the most respected players in jazz — for a three-night run at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola.

headline: Virtuosity Isolated, but Running Free
abstract: “Music for a Prince: The Esterhazy Orchestra,” a concert by the ensemble Artek, focused on pieces that Haydn composed for an aristocratic family.
lead_paragraph: It’s telling that Haydn’s name does not feature in the title “Music for a Prince: The Esterhazy Orchestra,” an all-Haydn concert presented by the period-instrument ensemble Artek at Immanuel Lutheran Church on the Upper East Side on Saturday. The fruitful relationship between Haydn and the aristocratic Esterhazy family, in whose employ Haydn created the bulk of his vast output, is well known. But Artek’s delightful performance served as a reminder that within the much-cited isolation of the Esterhazy country estate — where Haydn said he was “forced to become original” — the most direct influence on his music was the small band of highly talented court musicians.

lead_paragraph: The Broadway production of Ayad Akhtar’s “Disgraced” will close on March 1, producers announced on Sunday. That Pulitzer Prize-winning play first came to New York in 2012 and was warmly received by critics after opening at the Lyceum Theater in October. The play, directed by Kimberly Senior, stars Hari Dhillon and Gretchen Mol as a couple whose dinner party becomes a verbal joust over religion and politics. It will have had 149 performances and 27 previews when it closes.

headline: An Algerian Author Fights Back Against a Fatwa
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: There are elements of the absurd about the plight of Kamel Daoud, whose debut novel reaped glowing reviews, literary honors and then, suddenly, demands for his execution.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — There are elements of the absurd about the plight of Kamel Daoud, an Algerian writer whose debut novel reaped glowing international reviews, literary honors and then, suddenly, demands for his public execution.

headline: Another Girl Gone in a Tale of Betrayal
abstract: “The Girl on the Train” by Paula Hawkins is a tight, suspenseful chiller with a dubious narrator, who tries to solve the mystery of a woman’s disappearance.
lead_paragraph: “The Girl on the Train” has more fun with unreliable narration than any chiller since “Gone Girl,” the book still entrenched on best-seller lists two and a half years after publication because nothing better has come along. “The Girl on the Train” has “Gone Girl”-type fun with unreliable spouses, too. Its author, Paula Hawkins, isn’t as clever or swift as Gillian Flynn, the author of “Gone Girl,” but she’s no slouch when it comes to trickery or malice. So “The Girl on the Train” is liable to draw a large, bedazzled readership too.

headline: An Unhinged King’s Downfall, in a Chapel Setting

headline: An Exuberant Array of Sweets Closes the Holiday Rush
abstract: Despite performing “The Nutcracker” nearly 50 times since the day after Thanksgiving, New York City Ballet dancers showed little fatigue and finished the run with verve.
lead_paragraph: Between the day after Thanksgiving and the first weekend of the new year, New York City Ballet gave nearly 50 performances of “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker.” That’s a lot, but if the dancers were suffering from “Nutcracker” fatigue (a common seasonal condition) on Friday afternoon at the David H. Koch Theater, it didn’t show. If anything, many seemed to summon extra verve and abandon to carry them through the homestretch of the run.

headline: A Battle of Bandits and Wits in Civil War Era China
abstract: “The Taking of Tiger Mountain” is a protracted, oddly proportioned Chinese war picture from the action director Tsui Hark, adapted from the novel “Tracks in the Snowy Forest.”

headline: Spoleto Festival Announces Lineup
abstract: The 39th annual event will include more than 150 performances of opera, dance, theater and music.
lead_paragraph: Organizers of Spoleto Festival USA have announced the lineup for the 39th annual event, including more than 150 performances of opera, dance, theater and music. Highlights of the 17-day festival include the world premiere of “Paradise Interrupted,” a contemporary opera composed by Huang Ruo and designed and directed by Jennifer Wen Ma, whose visual installations were used in the opening and closing ceremonies of the 2008 Beijing Olympics. Also making world debuts will be “What Moves You,” by the dancer Lil Buck and the cellist Ashley Bathgate, as well as the Spoleto-commissioned performance of Francesco Cavalli’s opera “Veremonda l’amazzone di Aragona.” Other festival highlights will include a new production of “Romeo and Juliet” by Shakespeare’s Globe theater company, the Carlo Colla and Sons Marionette Company performing “Sleeping Beauty,” and the Casus Circus of Australia. Featured dance performances will include Trisha Brown Dance Company, Shen Wei Dance Arts, and Scottish Ballet’s adaptation of the Tennessee Williams play “A Streetcar Named Desire.” In the musical category, highlights include performances by the Westminster Choir, Emmylou Harris and Rodney Crowell. Spoleto Festival USA runs May 22 through June 7 in Charleston, S.C. Schedules and more information are at spoletousa.org.

abstract: The fourth SportAccord World Mind Games in Beijing last month ended with two individual events.
lead_paragraph: The fourth SportAccord World Mind Games in Beijing last month ended with two individual events. These are always enjoyed by top players. Although it can be frustrating not to have a finely tuned bidding system, it is fun partnering so many experts from around the globe.

And they have taken down professors, journalists and others deemed disloyal to Communist Party orthodoxy.

Mr. Abbas has now announced that he will turn to the International Criminal Court — a move that will produce Palestinian charges and Israeli countercharges but not alter the reality on the ground.

Mr. Clinton’s decision not to grant clemency to Mr. Rector, who had been sentenced to death for killing a police officer, was widely seen as an attempt to fend off the familiar charge that Democrats were soft on crime.

headline: In Madrid, a New Restaurant Features a Rotating Cast of Regional Chefs
abstract: The Table By, located in the Hotel Urso, showcases the riches of Spanish regional cooking and produce.
lead_paragraph: In Madrid, an ingenious new pop-up restaurant is putting Spain’s culinary talent on display by showcasing a different chef from the country’s provinces each month. The Table By, which is located in the Hotel Urso and debuted with a soft opening in late 2014, changes completely with the arrival of each new chef, down to the wine list. The visiting chef also gets free rein to redecorate the dining room in the style of his or her restaurant. “The project is fantastic because in a homogenizing world, it champions the riches of Spanish regional cooking and produce,” says Marcos Cerqueiro, whose Abastos 2.0, a restaurant in Santiago de Compostela in Galicia, served as The Table By’s debut offering.

headline: Limiting Rest Is Found to Help Young Concussion Patients
abstract: Researchers found the opposite of what they had expected: Patients who stayed at home for two days or less had fewer remaining symptoms when returning to normal activity than those who were secluded for five days.
lead_paragraph: Experts recommend that young people who have suffered a concussion get one or two days of rest at home, until symptoms start resolving, before gradually returning to school and physical activity.
