headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10:30 A.M. (Showtime) THE DIVING BELL AND THE BUTTERFLY (2007) Jean-Dominique Bauby, a 43-year-old French magazine editor and something of a playboy, had a stroke in 1995 that left him with a condition in which he retained vision, hearing and a functioning mind but was almost completely paralyzed. He told his story in a book that he dictated to an assistant by blinking. In this film from the artist Julian Schnabel, Mr. Bauby is played by Mathieu Amalric, above at right with Max von Sydow; Emmanuelle Seigner is Céline, the longtime partner he has recently left and the mother of his three children; and Marie-Josée Croze is a speech therapist who teaches him to use his left eyelid to communicate. “The phrase ‘triumph of the human spirit’ hovers over ‘The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,’ along with a swarm of other empty, uplifting clichés,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “But Mr. Schnabel and the screenwriter, Ronald Harwood, have other themes in mind” — among them, limitation, constraint and incarceration — Mr. Scott said. (Both men were nominated for Oscars.) “Their common subject, however, is freedom, the self-willed liberation of a difficult, defiant individual,” he added, noting that Mr. Schnabel demonstrated this with “imaginative freedom in every frame and sequence, dispensing with narrative and expository conventions in favor of a wild, intuitive honesty.”

headline: Taiwan’s Ex-Leader Released From Prison on Medical Parole
abstract: Chen Shui-bian, the former president of Taiwan who was sentenced to 20 years in prison, suffers from a series of medical conditions including depression, brain atrophy and Parkinsonism.
lead_paragraph: Chen Shui-bian, the imprisoned former president of Taiwan, was released on medical parole on Monday, after Justice Ministry officials accepted the recommendation of a panel of medical experts that his failing health could be better treated at home.

headline: Graft Offensive May Expose Something More Vile in China: Factions
abstract: A recent burst of official Chinese commentaries asserting that corruption scandals have exposed a “culture of cliques” points to the deeper tremors detonated by President Xi Jinping’s campaign to clean house.
lead_paragraph: Since Mao Zedong’s time, few sins have been more repugnant to the Chinese Communist Party than forming factions. And under President Xi Jinping, that abhorrence has resurfaced.

headline: Test Yourself | The Selfie Stick
abstract: Here are the first several paragraphs from a Jan. 2 Style section article, “The Selfie Stick Takes Manhattan.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are the first several paragraphs from a Jan. 2 Style section article, “The Selfie Stick Takes Manhattan.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Sportscaster Stuart Scott Dies at 49
abstract: How did Stuart Scott use his non-sports passions to contribute to his work as a sports broadcaster?
lead_paragraph: In the obituary “ESPN’s Stuart Scott Dies at 49,” Richard Sandomir writes about the life and contributions of sportscaster Stuart Scott, who died of cancer on Sunday.

headline: A Photo Book for Its Subjects
abstract: Kosuke Okahara wanted viewers of his photo project about self-injury to connect with its subjects. So he sent copies of the book around the world, collecting greetings.
lead_paragraph: The little square book arrived in a FedEx box, buried in packing peanuts.

headline: What Changes Would You Like 2015 to Bring?
abstract: How can you contribute to the changes you want to see in your life and in the larger world in 2015?
lead_paragraph: We are just a few days into 2015. People are getting back to school and to their normal routines, ideally feeling refreshed and ready to start again.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: Watching The Police Turn Away
abstract: Monday: A photographer describes back-turning, a cold front blows in, and Eric Garner’s daughter leads a protest.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this windy Monday.

headline: Daily Report: Connectivity at the Consumer Electronics Show
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'International Consumer Electronics Show', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: Household devices like door locks and light switches that link together through the web are likely to energize this year’s International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: By just about any measure, the International Consumer Electronics Show is big. But something has been lacking in recent years: big excitement, Molly Wood reports.

headline: Judge Gives Rules at Start of Boston Marathon Bombing Trial
abstract: The trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev began as prosecutors and defense lawyers seek 12 jurors and six alternates to be part of one of the most high-profile trials in U.S. history.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, 21, thin and pale, arrived in court Monday looking like the college student he was before he was accused of bombing the Boston Marathon.

headline: Do No Harm? It May Be Hard to Avoid With Health Law’s Medicare Cuts
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals', 'Medicare', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: Hundreds of billions of dollars may be saved, but research suggests those cuts hurt patients.
lead_paragraph: The Affordable Care Act made changes to government payments for Medicare services that are expected to save tens to hundreds of billions of dollars per year. This sounds like a good thing — and it very well may be — but only if those spending cuts don’t cause harm. Research suggests they just might.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 5, 2014
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why. A live discussion is offered from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Jan. 6, 2015

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: Can the Republican leadership hold fractious lawmakers together to effectively exert their new power?
lead_paragraph: Republicans Have Something to Prove as New Congress Opens

headline: In Invoking Shanghai Stampede, College Stirs Outrage
abstract: The university in Xi’an, which had banned Christmas celebrations, published a statement titled, “The unfortunate Shanghai holiday stampede tragedy confirms that our school’s position on holiday management is indisputably correct.”
lead_paragraph: A Chinese college that banned Christmas festivities has stirred up a new controversy with its assertion that the New Year’s Eve stampede in Shanghai that left at least 36 people dead has vindicated  its restrictions on merrymaking.

headline: Morning Agenda: Banner Year for Fund-Raising
abstract: Last year was a good one for the business of raising money. | Euro falls lower as central bank hints at stimulus. | A stress test for Mario Draghi. | Bitcoin Foundation parts ways with global policy counsel.
lead_paragraph: By any measure, last year was a good one for the business of raising money, in either the public or the private markets, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. Some 1,205 issuers raised nearly $249 billion globally, according to data from Thomson Reuters, making 2014 one of the busiest since 2010 for companies seeking to list on the stock markets. Such enthusiasm has prompted comparisons to the dot-com boom and bust of 1999-2000.

headline: China Issues Complaint After North Korean Defector Is Said to Kill 4
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Defectors (Political)']
abstract: A soldier fleeing the North killed the Chinese citizens in late December during a robbery attempt, according to a Chinese official and various reports.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China has made a formal diplomatic complaint to North Korea after a soldier fleeing the North killed four Chinese citizens in late December during a robbery attempt, according to a statement on Monday from a Chinese official and news reports from China and South Korea.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Obamas Are Back in Washington
‘Cabaret’ to Close March 29, and Emma Stone Extends Her Run
abstract: “Cabaret” will close on March 29, and Emma Stone has extended her run in the show by two weeks, to Feb. 15.
lead_paragraph: The lights at the Kit Kat Club will dim for good this spring, but at least one of the beautiful people is sticking around slightly longer than expected. Producers are set to announce on Monday that the Roundabout Theater’s production of “Cabaret” at Studio 54 will close March 29, a little more than a year after it opened for an initial 24-week engagement. Additionally, Emma Stone will continue her role as Sally Bowles through Feb. 15, extending her run by two weeks.

headline: DealBook’s Most Popular Stories of 2014
abstract: Investors fleeing emerging markets, Facebook’s deal for WhatsApp and @GSElevator were some of the most popular articles on DealBook in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Investors fleeing emerging markets, Facebook’s deal for WhatsApp and @GSElevator were some of the most popular stories on DealBook in 2014.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Mark Schultz Apologizes, Sort of, as Campaigns Heat Up
abstract: The wrestler, who is the subject of “Foxcatcher,” had lashed out at the film’s director.
lead_paragraph: Happy Monday! Awards campaigning is kicking back into high gear this week. The Oscar nomination ballots are due Thursday by 5 p.m. P.S.T. And the Golden Globes, the premiere pre-Oscar preening event, take place on Sunday.

headline: Meet Jessica Pratt, 2015’s Folk Singer-Songwriter to Watch
abstract: The Californian’s forthcoming album, “On Your Own Love Again,” brings to mind everyone from Judy Collins to Joanna Newsom, but has a spirit all its own.
lead_paragraph: The Californian singer-songwriter Jessica Pratt tends to be classified under the term “freak-folk.” Yet on “Strange Melody,” the third track from her forthcoming second album, “On Your Own Love Again” (out Jan. 27 from Drag City), she accidentally evokes a familiar ’80s New Wave tune. “I noticed there was a similar vocal melody to Duran Duran’s ‘Hungry Like the Wolf’ right when I was recording it,” Pratt says by phone from San Francisco in the midst of a biblical downpour. “I like those strange references that happen sometimes in music, so I just left it in there.” A similar spirit of serendipity also informs the rest of the album, a collection of eloquent, lingering acoustic songs that brings to mind everyone from the chanteuse Judy Collins to Joanna Newsom. The first single, “Back, Baby,” appears below.

headline: Here’s How Lack of Competition Can Hurt Consumers
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Interest Rates', 'Credit and Debt', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'United States Economy', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: A study of one corner of the mortgage market shows how a small change in rules had a big effect on profits.
lead_paragraph: Businesses are forever insisting that a little less competition won’t lead to higher prices. What’s one more merger? What’s one more barrier to entry?

headline: Question Christie’s Cowboys Love? Brother Says ‘Get a Life’
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie was gleefully cheering for his beloved Dallas Cowboys on Sunday night, celebrating with the team’s owners in their luxury box.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie was gleefully cheering for his beloved Dallas Cowboys on Sunday night, celebrating with the team’s owners in their luxury box.

headline: What to Watch For in 2015: Galliano and Gucci, Elections and Apple
abstract: It’s time to take note of what lies at the top of the fashion agenda for 2015.
lead_paragraph: It is officially the first full week of the new year, and you know what that means: time to take note of what to watch for in 2015. I think it’s going to be a doozy. Why? Well, here’s what I have at the top of my agenda:

headline: Four Opposition Activists Die in Clashes in Bangladesh
abstract: The deaths occurred despite a nationwide tightening of security in anticipation of violence on the first anniversary of the governing party’s re-election.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Four activists from the opposition Bangladesh Nationalist Party were killed on Monday during clashes with supporters of the governing party and security forces.

headline: After Ban on Beef From Europe, U.S. Gives Green Light to Ireland
keywords: ['Meat', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Beef', 'Mad Cow Disease (Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy)', 'Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning']
abstract: Ireland has met American safety rules, becoming the first European country to come off a ban that was imposed after an outbreak of mad cow disease in the late 1990s.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Irish beef will be the first from Europe to be sold in the United States in almost 16 years, after the lifting of a ban that had stemmed from an outbreak of mad cow disease in the late 1990s.

headline: Former Governor Spoke Willingly of His Religion and Politics
abstract: Like few other elected officials, Mario Cuomo sought publicly to reconcile his religious beliefs with his political ideals, while challenging public figures who claimed a moral monopoly.
lead_paragraph: “It’s always been safer not to talk about religious beliefs because religious beliefs are so personal that they tend to antagonize,” Mario M. Cuomo once cautioned. Never one to dodge a debate, though, he predictably, and dramatically, rejected his own advice and tackled the issue.

headline: Club Med Shares Fall as Battle for Resort Operator Ends
abstract: Andrea C. Bonomi, an Italian businessman who had been battling for control of the vacation resort operator, conceded to his rival, the Chinese conglomerate Fosun International.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Shares of Club Méditerranée fell on Monday, after an Italian businessman who had been battling for control of the vacation resort operator conceded to his rival, the Chinese conglomerate Fosun International.

headline: 1940: Paris Welcomes Hitler’s Coffee
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1940: Coffee is to the French what tea is to the English.
lead_paragraph: Following an announcement that 4,000 tons of coffee seized on a German freighter are to be distributed shortly in France, Parisians are hoping that some of this amount, which is enough to supply national consumption for ten days, will come to their particular groceries. As French newspapers announced it yesterday morning, ‘‘Our coffee for the next ten days will be on Adolf Hitler.’’ For some time Frenchmen, who remember that during the last war there was always an adequate supply of coffee, have been asking themselves why is there a shortage. Coffee is to the French what tea is to the English. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 6, 1940

headline: Heroin’s Growing Scourge in Myanmar
abstract: The New York Times video journalist Jonah M. Kessel discusses the revival of heroin production and use in the Golden Triangle.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times video journalist Jonah M. Kessel discusses the revival of heroin production and use in the Golden Triangle.

headline: How Can Democrats Take Back the States?
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Governors (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'State Legislatures', 'States (US)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: Not since the Jazz Age have Democrats been in such a poor position in the states. Some worry that it might hurt the party nationally as well.
lead_paragraph: Of all the depressing results for Democrats in the midterm elections, the ones at the state level might be the most grim — as in, not since the Jazz Age grim.

headline: Talk Turns to Inequality at Annual Meeting of Economists
abstract: As the economic recovery is picking up, the talk is shifting away from concerns about unemployment.
lead_paragraph: The big annual gabfest for academic economists, currently underway in Boston, provides a useful signal of how the field is evolving. Consider this a dispatch from the pleated khaki-clad trenches. The clearest theme so far is a renewed interest in inequality.

headline: AirAsia Jet Was Cleared to Take Off Without All Permits in Order, Officials Say
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AirAsia Flight 8501', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: The Indonesian Transportation Ministry said it was suspending several officials for allowing Flight 8501, which crashed in the Java Sea, to fly.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — AirAsia Flight 8501, which crashed in the Java Sea on Dec. 28, was allowed to take off from Surabaya, Indonesia, even though it did not have all the required clearances from regulators to fly that day, the Indonesian Transportation Ministry said on Monday.

headline: Decks Tilting, Crew Grounded Ship Off Southern England to Save It
abstract: The 57,000-ton Hoegh Osaka was run aground on Bramble Bank, a well-marked sandbank off the port of Southampton, to prevent it from capsizing after it began to list.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Seen from some angles, tilting at a crazy angle in shallow water, it might almost resemble a huge plaything discarded by capricious giants.

headline: Art Directors Pick Their Nominees for Best Production Design
abstract: The guild divides its picks into period, fantasy and contemporary categories.
lead_paragraph: The Art Directors Guild has announced its nominees for production design, divided into period, fantasy and contemporary categories.

headline: Inside Myanmar’s Opium Fields
abstract: A video journalist spent four days in the front seat of a pickup traveling through valley after valley filled with opium poppies.
lead_paragraph: Jonah M. Kessel’s video “Relapse in the Golden Triangle” explored the resurgence of poppy and opium production in Myanmar, where he reported the story with Thomas Fuller. Here, Mr. Kessel’s behind the scenes video shows what went in to putting the story together. Mr. Fuller also tells of what surprised him about reporting in the region, where so many are dependent on harvesting the drug.

headline: Like Advice From a Friend
abstract: A cookbook for new cooks, for uncertain cooks, for good cooks looking for simple inspiration.
lead_paragraph: Cookbooks today fall largely into two camps. There is glossy art-house food erotica assembled by chefs eager to set down markers of regional pride, of particular aesthetic technique, of gastronomic genius. Cooking from those books is like making a paint-by-numbers Ingres or Hockney. You get the shape and the color and the line. But the dish is never really art.

headline: A Grand Hotel, a Miniature Design
abstract: In the production design for “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” Plan A involved helicopters in the Alps. Plan B called for replicas and stop-motion animation. Plan B won out.
lead_paragraph: With its candy-colored dollhouse sets, miniaturized funicular and post-Weimar-era grandeur, “The Grand Budapest Hotel” offered moviegoers one of the most visually sumptuous confections of 2014.

headline: 19 Years Later, Article by Kagan Echoes at the Supreme Court
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: As a law professor, Justice Elena Kagan wrote an article about the First Amendment that has become a touchstone in recent cases.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — What is the best way for a scholar to influence the Supreme Court through a law review article? Join the court.

headline: Harvard Ideas on Health Care Hit Home, Hard
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: While Harvard professors oppose changes that will raise their health care costs, the university says the increases are in part a result of the Affordable Care Act, which many Harvard experts championed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years, Harvard’s experts on health economics and policy have advised presidents and Congress on how to provide health benefits to the nation at a reasonable cost. But those remedies will now be applied to the Harvard faculty, and the professors are in an uproar.

headline: Border Clash With Iraqis Kills Seven, Saudis Say
abstract: Four assailants fired automatic weapons and detonated suicide belts in a confrontation that left them and three Saudi border guards dead.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Four heavily armed men from Iraq attacked a Saudi border patrol early Monday, firing automatic weapons and detonating suicide belts in a confrontation that left three guards and all the assailants dead, Saudi officials said.

headline: Keshia Knight Pulliam Ousted From ‘Celebrity Apprentice’ Over Refusal to Contact Bill Cosby
abstract: The episode was taped in March but broadcast on Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: The season premiere of NBC’s “Celebrity Apprentice” resulted in an awkward juxtaposition of reality television and actual reality when one of its contestants, the “Cosby Show” star Keshia Knight Pulliam, was ejected from the program by host Donald Trump for not seeking assistance from Bill Cosby, the comedian and actor who has been accused of sexually assaulting several women.

headline: Protests Turn Violent in Bangladesh
abstract: Fighting broke out in Dhaka between supporters of the ruling party, the Awami League, and the Bangladesh Nationalist Party. Protests were timed with the first anniversary of controversial elections.
lead_paragraph: Fighting broke out in Dhaka between supporters of the ruling party, the Awami League, and the Bangladesh Nationalist Party. Protests were timed with the first anniversary of controversial elections.

headline: Penelope Casas’ Final Lessons
abstract: A comprehensive Spanish cookbook, trends in gin, lentil crisps for snacking and more.
lead_paragraph: To Learn: All You Need to Know About Spanish Cooking

headline: CES: Sensors Rule From the Start
abstract: The unofficial theme of the trade show seemed to be: Put a sensor in it.
lead_paragraph: With virtually no preamble, the 2015 International Consumer Electronics Show, which opens to the public on Tuesday, jumped directly into a flurry of press events and even a little news on Sunday night.

headline: Keeping Older Pedestrians Safe
abstract: Older adults account for a disproportionate number of pedestrian deaths, so they need to make sure they have enough time to cross a street.
lead_paragraph: Too many older adults put their lives at the mercy of two- and four-wheeled vehicles when performing an activity that they are repeatedly advised to do: walking.

headline: The Latest to Defect From Boehner: Cantor’s Replacement
abstract: Dave Brat says he will vote against Speaker John A. Boehner.
lead_paragraph: Speaker John A. Boehner and former Representative Eric Cantor occasionally had their differences, but Mr. Cantor’s replacement in the House, Dave Brat, has taken his opposition to a new level.

headline: No Comment Necessary: The Obama Economy
abstract: A C.E.O. who threatened “less opportunity for everyone” if President Obama were re-elected is now giving raises.
lead_paragraph: The C.E.O. of Westgate Resorts, a Florida-based timeshare company, told his employees in 2012 that if President Obama were re-elected, that would mean “fewer jobs, less benefits and certainly less opportunity for everyone.” Two years in to the president’s second term, that same C.E.O. is giving raises.

headline: Morgan Stanley Breach Put Client Data Up for Sale on Pastebin, an Online Site
abstract: Morgan Stanley traced the leak to Galen Marsh, a young financial adviser, but said he did not share the data or use it for financial gain.
lead_paragraph: In mid-December, a posting appeared on the Internet site Pastebin offering six million account records, including passwords and login data for clients of Morgan Stanley.

headline: The Chess Master
abstract: A chess master prepares. Can you crack this challenge by Marco Moriconi?
lead_paragraph: We start off the new year with a puzzle suggestion by Marco Moriconi, a regular Numberplay contributor and professor of physics at the Universidade Federal Fluminense, in Niteroi, Rio de Janeiro. (Dr. Moriconi also writes a monthly math column for the Brazilian national science magazine, Ciência Hoje (Science Today), called Qual o Problema, or “What’s the Problem?”).

headline: Boehner Challenger’s Website Goes Up, Then Comes Down
abstract: Representative Louie Gohmert, the Republican Tea Party favorite from Texas, said on Sunday that he is launching a challenge to take the House speakership from John A. Boehner, launched a campaign website to lay out his platform as a “true conservative” and said that it was time for the current leadership regime to move on.
lead_paragraph: Representative Louie Gohmert, the Tea Party favorite from Texas, said on Sunday that he was launching a challenge to take the House speakership from John A. Boehner, put up a campaign website to lay out his platform as a “true conservative,” and made a case that it was time for the current leadership to move on.

headline: Ferrying the Dead of Both Sides in a Cruel Afghan War
abstract: Malik Abdul Hakim, who has lost two sons, is revered for collecting and returning the bodies of both Taliban and government casualties.
lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — On the brindled plains of southern Afghanistan, Malik Abdul Hakim is death’s ferryman.

headline: Bess Myerson, New Yorker of Beauty, Wit, Service and Scandal, Dies at 90
abstract: Ms. Myerson, the only Jewish Miss America, was one of a select group of American figures to parlay pop culture celebrity into positions of influence in government.
lead_paragraph: Bess Myerson, a New York favorite daughter who basked in the public eye for decades — as Miss America in 1945, as a television personality, as a force in public affairs and finally as a player in a shattering municipal scandal — died on Dec. 14 at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 90.

headline: Apps Everywhere, but No Unifying Link
abstract: As people spend more time using apps, their Internet has taken a step backward, becoming more isolated — more like the web before search engines.
lead_paragraph: Navigating the Internet used to mean painstakingly typing the exact address you wanted into your computer. The web browser and the search engine simplified that, giving us the Internet we take for granted today.

headline: Anti-Immigration Rallies in Germany Defy Calls to Desist
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Foreign Workers']
abstract: Despite the calls from Chancellor Angela Merkel appealing to Germans to avoid the marches and their organizers, demonstrators gathered against “economic refugees.”
lead_paragraph: DRESDEN, Germany — Defying appeals from an array of German institutions to stay away from anti-immigration rallies, some 18,000 people took part in a protest here on Monday, parading against what they call the Islamization of Europe and putting pressure on the authorities to defuse social tensions.

headline: 1915: Plot to Smuggle Opium Foiled
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1915: Plot to Smuggle Opium into Britain Foiled.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The American Embassy here, with the assistance of the Home Office, has succeeded in nipping in the bud a plot to smuggle huge supplies of opium into England from America. The first installment of the drug, contained in three large trunks in charge of Sophie Ghee, wife of a Chinese, was confiscated upon the arrival of the Baltic here on Friday, and the woman was sent back to New York on board the Philadelphia on Saturday. Mr. Horace Lee Washington, the American Consul at Liverpool, by getting in touch with the Baltic’s officers by wireless, enabled them to have everything ready for the woman’s detention when the liner reached port. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 6, 1915

headline: Capturing Manhattan’s Waterfront
abstract: A collection of Barbara Mensch’s photography from her South Street series and Brooklyn Bridge work.
lead_paragraph: A collection of Barbara Mensch’s photography from her South Street series and Brooklyn Bridge work.

headline: Finding Glamour, Not Grit, at South Street Seaport
abstract: As the seaport poises for yet another transformation, with plans for a new mall and apartment tower, an artist recalls the neighborhood she documented decades ago.
lead_paragraph: Looking as tough as gangsters, which some of their bosses were, the fishmongers are lined up against a wall at the South Street Seaport in Manhattan, menacing any stranger who passes by. Vinny smiles through his cigarette, handsome as Brando. Jake the Snake, after decades on the docks, looks as swollen as an octopus. Big John has drawn his tiny pistol, a joke and a threat.

headline: Pick Me! Four American Cities Put Best Olympic Foot Forward
abstract: Reporters in Boston, Los Angeles, Washington and San Francisco describe the local mind-set as the U.S.O.C. decides which finalist to back as a potential host city. The Games will be awarded in 2017.

headline: Patient, Heal Thyself
abstract: A book that emphasizes gathering data over having a caring provider.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Eric Topol and I appear to practice medicine on two different planets. This fact makes it difficult for me to comment sensibly on his books, let alone critique them. Instead, I read along with mouth slightly agape, marveling at this missive from a far-off place whose atmosphere, physical laws and inhabitants bear no resemblance to the ones I know.

headline: Discovery, Guided by Morality
abstract: In 2012, Ann Lam and Elan Ohayon founded the Green Neuroscience Laboratory. The focus is on using environmentally clean methods and looking at the reasons behind an assignment.
lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, CALIF. — Ann Lam delicately places a laboratory slide holding a slice of brain from a living human onto a small platform in a room the size of a walk-in refrigerator. She closes a heavy door and turns to a row of computers to monitor her experiments.

headline: War and Gorillas and Other Hazards of Documentary Filmmaking
abstract: The director Orlando von Einsiedel explains what went into making “Virunga,” his Oscar-shortlisted documentary about a national park in the Democratic Republic of Congo that has been besieged by poachers and armed rebels.
lead_paragraph: “Virunga,” one of 15 candidates shortlisted for the best documentary Oscar, is a nature film with an edge.

headline: Who Is a Whistle-Blower? The Courts Weigh In
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Sarbanes-Oxley Act', 'Whistle-Blowers']
abstract: The vagaries of the Dodd-Frank Act have left it to the courts to sort out whether a whistle-blower is protected from retaliation, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: The 19th-century German leader Otto von Bismarck once remarked that “laws are like sausages, it is better not to see them being made.” Figuring what a law means can be no less problematic.

headline: TPG Investors Pay Twice for Work on Chobani Deal
keywords: ['Executive Compensation', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Clients of TPG are paying management fees and a separate fee for a partner’s work for the yogurt maker Chobani, which borrowed $750 million from TPG last year.
lead_paragraph: The senior partners of Wall Street’s private equity firms typically draw their salaries from management fees paid by clients, including the nation’s biggest pension funds, whose capital they invest.

headline: Son Is Charged With Murder in Death of Manhattan Hedge Fund Manager
abstract: Thomas Gilbert Jr., 30, was taken into police custody after the shooting on Sunday of his father, Thomas Gilbert, on the East Side.
lead_paragraph: The son of a wealthy Manhattan hedge fund manager was arrested on a murder charge on Monday after shooting his father at his parents’ home, the police said.

headline: Right Price for Oil? Not the Current One
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Taxation']
abstract: In an ideal world, the price of oil for producers would be lower and more stable, while the average price for consumers would be higher and more stable, Edward Hadas of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: The price of oil is still too high, often too low and much too volatile. In other words, this is a market that doesn’t work well for anyone.

headline: Aleksei Navalny, Defying Kremlin Again, Declares End to House Arrest
abstract: Mr. Navalny, the Russian political opposition leader, removed the electronic bracelet used to monitor his whereabouts, raising the possibility that the authorities would punish him.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Taunting the Kremlin yet again, the Russian political opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny on Monday snipped the electronic bracelet used by the authorities to monitor his whereabouts and personally declared an end to his more than 10 months of house arrest.

headline: Witnesses on Capsized Ship Near Scotland
abstract: Passengers of a nearby ferry described the search-and-rescue operation for a Cyprus-registered cement carrier, the Cemfjord, which overturned off the coast of Scotland.
lead_paragraph: Passengers of a nearby ferry described the search-and-rescue operation for a Cyprus-registered cement carrier, the Cemfjord, which overturned off the coast of Scotland.

headline: Signs of a McConnell Senate on the Cafeteria Menu
abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell officially takes over as Senate majority leader tomorrow, but traces of the senator’s Kentucky influences are already popping up on Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell officially takes over as Senate majority leader tomorrow, but traces of the senator’s Kentucky influences are already popping up on Capitol Hill.

headline: For Second Week, Arrests Plunge in New York City
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Traffic and Parking Violations', 'Police']
abstract: The declines, which follow a decrease that began shortly after the murders of two patrol officers in Brooklyn, may present a new challenge for Mayor Bill de Blasio and Police Commissioner William J. Bratton.
lead_paragraph: For two straight weeks, New York City police officers have sharply cut back on making arrests and issuing summonses throughout the five boroughs, magnifying the growing divide between the city’s police force and its mayor, Bill de Blasio.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: A Challenge to America
abstract: A writer says America is failing in comparison with European countries in promoting the well-being of the populace. Readers are invited to respond.

headline: French Leader Urges End to Sanctions Against Russia Over Ukraine
abstract: Backing Vladimir V. Putin into a corner will not work, President François Hollande of France said, reflecting sanctions fatigue among European officials.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Western nations should stop threatening Russia with new sanctions and instead offer to ease off on existing restrictions in exchange for progress in the peace process in Ukraine, President François Hollande of France said in an interview on Monday.

headline: Producers Surprise With Nominations for ‘Nightcrawler,’ ‘Whiplash’
abstract: Most of the nominees were expected but the snubs include “Selma” and “Unbroken.”
lead_paragraph: The Producers Guild of America has unveiled its feature nominees. They are:

headline: Dish Network Unveils Sling TV, a Streaming Service to Rival Cable (and It Has ESPN)
abstract: The service will include popular networks and cost $20 a month, with no contract, installation, equipment or credit check required.
lead_paragraph: Dish Network, the satellite provider, is trying to lure younger viewers back to paying for television with the start of a web-based offering that includes ESPN and a number of other popular networks for $20 a month, about a fifth the cost of the average household bill for cable and satellite service.

headline: Working Extra Hours for No Extra Pay
abstract: The salary threshold that defines a white-collar job under federal rules has barely budged since 1975.
lead_paragraph: It has been nearly 10 months since President Obama ordered the Labor Department to revamp the outdated federal rules on overtime pay, but the department has yet to propose new rules.

headline: Congress More Devout Than Most of America
abstract: When it comes to religion, Congress appears to be much more devout than the rest of America.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to religion, Congress appears to be much more devout than the rest of the country.

headline: Europe’s Trap
abstract: Japanification has already happened.
lead_paragraph: There are many risks in the world economy right now — a possible Chinese hard landing (local governments depend heavily on land sales for revenue? Oh, boy), a financial crisis in Russia and other oil exporters, etc.. But one thing is not a risk, because it has already happened: the euro area has entered a Japan-style deflationary trap.

headline: Defiant on Witness Stand, Times Reporter Says Little
keywords: ['News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: James Risen of The New York Times took the stand but did not answer any questions that could help the Justice Department identify his confidential sources.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — After losing a seven-year legal battle, James Risen, a reporter for The New York Times, reluctantly took the witness stand in federal court here on Monday, but refused to answer any questions that could help the Justice Department identify his confidential sources.

headline: Oil’s Fall Continues Into 2015, and Stock Markets Shudder
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: West Texas crude oil dipped below $50, and the Dow Jones industrial average was down more than 300 points on a day of volatility.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Oil prices tumbled below $50 a barrel on Monday, spooking global financial markets and signaling that the remarkable 50 percent price drop since June was continuing this year and even quickening.

headline: White House Says Elevating Scalise Reflects G.O.P. Values
abstract: President Obama was far away in Hawaii last week while the firestorm surrounding Representative Steve Scalise was gathering pace, but the White House was clearly watching.
lead_paragraph: President Obama was far away in Hawaii last week while the firestorm surrounding Representative Steve Scalise was gathering pace, but the White House was clearly watching.

headline: Judge Sets Date to Consider Release of Eric Garner Grand Jury Records
abstract: A Staten Island judge ruled that he would hear arguments on Jan. 29 over whether to release transcripts from a grand jury that declined to bring criminal charges in the death of Mr. Garner.
lead_paragraph: A Staten Island judge ruled on Monday that he would hear arguments this month over whether to release grand jury transcripts in the case of Eric Garner, the man who died after being placed in a chokehold by a police officer.

headline: Not Invented Here Macroeconomics
abstract: Of balance sheets and monetary policy.
lead_paragraph: Martin Wolf writes sympathetically about Richard Koo’s latest; let me be a bit less sympathetic.

headline: Yeovil’s Big Moment
abstract: Images from Yeovil, England, where in the third round of the F.A. Cup on Sunday, Yeovil Town, which plays two divisions below the Premier League, drew mighty Manchester United to its tiny stadium.
lead_paragraph: Images from Yeovil, England, where in the third round of the F.A. Cup on Sunday, Yeovil Town, which plays two divisions below the Premier League, drew mighty Manchester United to its tiny stadium.

headline: 2014 Auto Sales Jump in U.S., Even With Recalls
abstract: Fiat Chrysler and General Motors reported strong gains for December and for 2014, but Ford’s sales were weak.
lead_paragraph: When the history of the contemporary auto industry is written, 2014 will go down as a year of contrasts. Deluged by safety recalls, auto manufacturers faced the ire of regulators and consumers. Yet, buyers did not stay away and instead gave the American auto industry its best sales year in nearly a decade.

headline: Leon Wieseltier Joins The Atlantic
abstract: Mr. Wieseltier will join The Atlantic as a contributing editor and critic.
lead_paragraph: Leon Wieseltier, the former literary editor of The New Republic, will be joining The Atlantic as a contributing editor and critic, writing for both the print magazine and the website on “his customary wide range of subjects,” according to a news release.

headline: Two Ways Infrared Cameras Have Boosted the Case for E.P.A. Rules Cutting Methane Leaks
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Cameras', 'Environment', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Methane', 'Natural Gas', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Infrared cameras have boosted the case for methane rules in two ways – making leak inspections cheap and building public concern.
lead_paragraph: I first realized the enormous value of infrared imagery in pollution detection in 2009, when I co-wrote “Curbing Emissions by Sealing Gas Leaks” with Clifford Krauss. In the related Dot Earth post, I included some remarkable video shot for the Environmental Protection Agency showing the difference between looking at an oil or gas facility with a standard camera and one tuned to the infrared wavelengths absorbed by gases like methane — the main constituent of natural gas:

headline: Grand Juror in Ferguson Sues to End Silence Rule
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Jury System', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The juror, bound to secrecy under Missouri law, says in a federal lawsuit that the public’s impression of the grand jury’s work in the Michael Brown case is “not entirely accurate.”
lead_paragraph: A member of the grand jury that did not indict a white police officer in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager in Ferguson, Mo., sued the county prosecutor on Monday, seeking to speak out because the public’s impression of the grand jury’s work was “not entirely accurate.”

headline: The Bloom Is On for Maple Syrup
keywords: ['Trees and Shrubs', 'Maple Syrup and Sugar', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Sugar']
abstract: Sugar makers have historically relied solely on the weather to predict good and bad syrup years. But research suggests that seed production is a key indicator of what is set to flow from the trees and onto your pancakes.
lead_paragraph: Pancake lovers, take heart. In the coming weeks, maple farmers throughout Quebec, Vermont and elsewhere in the syrup belt will dust off their metal spiles for another harvest season, and some scientists are predicting that the sugary sap will flow even more freely than usual.

headline: Allie Sherman Dies at 91; Led Giants to Title Games
abstract: Mr. Sherman, an early master of the T-formation, led the Giants to N.F.L. title games in his first three seasons as coach. He played quarterback for Brooklyn College and the Philadelphia Eagles.
lead_paragraph: Allie Sherman, who possessed a dubious football pedigree as a left-handed quarterback at Brooklyn College but went on to take the New York Giants to National Football League title games in his first three seasons as their coach, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.

headline: When Leaves Fail to Fall
abstract: Why are shriveled leaves remaining on a Japanese maple?
lead_paragraph: Q. Why are the leaves still clinging to my Japanese maple this winter, shriveled and brown, rather than falling to form a vermilion carpet as usual?

headline: Illusions Fool Even the Blind
abstract: In an experiment, blind people using echolocation misjudged objects in the way those with vision did.
lead_paragraph: That bats use echolocation to navigate and to find food is well known. But some blind people use the technique, too, clicking their tongues and snapping fingers to help identify objects.

headline: Ask Well: Blockages in the Heart and Brain
abstract: A reader asks: Why do people get blockages in the arteries of the heart and brain, but rarely in other organs?
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Fit for the Job, Even in an Ill-Fitting Suit
abstract: The president of Hope Family Wines enjoys working the vineyards, but when work called for formal attire, a luggage problem called for quick thinking.
lead_paragraph: IT seems that I’ve been in an airplane most of my life. When I was younger I raced professionally in motocross. I did the national circuit and we traveled all over the country. My family started planting grapes in 1978. I remember getting into a little trouble at school once and my dad said if I didn’t shape up he was going to make me work the vineyards. I thought working on the land was the coolest thing ever, which probably wasn’t the reaction he wanted. But there is a great joy to be found when you’re working a vineyard and seeing grapes develop and grow. I don’t know how I did it, but somehow I managed to get my college degree in fruit science from California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo. Now I’m president and winemaker for our business, Hope Family Wines, including Treana, and I’m still traveling all the time.

headline: Euro Countries Take Tough Line Toward Greece
abstract: A caustic campaign in Greece is reviving fears that the country could leave the eurozone, while European officials are taking an increasingly hard line toward Athens.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As a caustic election campaign in Greece revives fears that the country could leave the euro, European officials are taking an increasingly hard line toward Athens, saying they want to keep Greece in the single currency, though not at any cost.

headline: Where Security Fails: Airport Worker Access
abstract: A recent gun-smuggling case highlights a dangerous loophole that allows employees at airports to bypass the stringent security screenings passengers undergo.
lead_paragraph: AS business travel resumes robustly this week, frequent fliers could reasonably be asking questions about security. Do we in fact have a serious problem with guns in our airports and, if so, is there anything to be done about it?

headline: For One New Member of Congress, Twitter Silence
abstract: Among the fresh faces joining Congress, only one, Representative-elect Dan Newhouse, a farmer from Washington State, is not on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: A new Congress means a new freshman class — 71 members are scheduled to be sworn in for the first time on Tuesday. For political obsessives like us at First Draft, though, it also means updating our Twitter feeds to keep track of the newcomers.

headline: Grace Helbig Gets E! Talk Show
abstract: The YouTube star will star in a series shown in prime time.
lead_paragraph: With female faces becoming an increasing rarity on TV talk shows that are shown after sundown – currently none of the major late-night shows are hosted by women – the E! network is continuing to do its part to reverse that trend.

headline: Philharmonic Names a New Fundraiser
abstract: Lisa Mantone will begin to raise hundreds of millions of dollars to renovate Avery Fisher Hall whil also trying to double the New York Philharmonic’s endowment fund.
lead_paragraph: It is a daunting task: raising hundreds of millions of dollars to renovate Avery Fisher Hall while simultaneously doubling the New York Philharmonic’s endowment fund. Now that task will be assigned to Lisa Mantone, who has been appointed to the new position of the orchestra’s senior vice president of institutional advancement, the Philharmonic announced on Monday.

headline: Chadwick Boseman and His James Brown Exorcism
abstract: The actor, who starred in the biopic “Get On Up,” said he had to work hard to shed the character after shooting wrapped.
lead_paragraph: Chadwick Boseman was heaped with plaudit upon plaudit for his portrayal of James Brown in last summer’s “Get On Up.” From the dancing to the smoothness to the PCP-fueled meltdowns, Mr. Boseman, who rose to fame with his portrait of Jackie Robinson in “42,” was heralded for singularly channeling the Godfather of Soul.

headline: Fueled by Rotten Eggs, an Annual Mock Coup Mirrors Spain’s Mood
abstract: The playful political upheaval is held in Ibi every year, but the satire has been imbued with outsize significance amid scores of fraud scandals around Spain.
lead_paragraph: IBI, Spain — Wearing a top hat and surrounded by supporters mostly dressed in outlandish military uniforms, Vicente Candela stormed the town hall here briefly last month and proclaimed himself mayor of Ibi’s 24,000 residents.

headline: Rare Frogs Give Birth to Live Tadpoles
abstract: The newly described species, Limnonectes larvaepartus, was discovered in the rain forests of Indonesia’s Sulawesi Island.
lead_paragraph: A tiny frog discovered in the rain forests of Indonesia’s Sulawesi Island is the only frog known to give birth to live tadpoles.

headline: How It Happens | Volcanic Eruptions
abstract: The eruption of a volcano can be one of the planet’s most destructive events — spewing huge amounts of rock, gas and ash that can kill people. Henry Fountain explains how a volcano can blow its top.
lead_paragraph: The eruption of a volcano can be one of the planet’s most destructive events — spewing huge amounts of rock, gas and ash that can kill people. Henry Fountain explains how a volcano can blow its top.

headline: Pressure, and Mystery, on the Rise
abstract: Volcanic eruptions are among the earth’s most cataclysmic events, but scientists are often reduced to analyzing possibilities within possibilities when making forecasts.
lead_paragraph: SKAFTAFELL, Iceland — Just north of here, on the far side of the impenetrable Vatnajokull ice sheet, lava is spewing from a crack in the earth on the flanks of Bardarbunga, one of Iceland’s largest volcanoes.

headline: Sneak Peek at the G.O.P. 2016 Field
abstract: With the next presidential election a mere 22 months away, it’s high time for speculation.
lead_paragraph: With the next presidential election a mere 22 months away, it’s high time for speculation — informed, ill-informed and just plain wild — about who will be running for the nominations of the two major parties.

headline: Sanford Rubenstein Will Not Face Rape Charges
abstract: After a three-month investigation into rape allegations against Mr. Rubenstein, a prominent lawyer, the Manhattan district attorney’s office said there was insufficient evidence to press charges.
lead_paragraph: After spending more than three months investigating rape allegations against the prominent lawyer Sanford A. Rubenstein, the Manhattan district attorney’s office announced on Monday that it would not bring charges against him.

headline: Next Year in Havana
abstract: The Cuba you can look forward to.
lead_paragraph: The Cuba you can look forward to.

headline: Money From Merce Cunningham Trust Goes to Two Arts Groups
abstract: The Merce Cunningham Trust will give $250,000 to the Baryshnikov Arts Center and $375,000 to the Foundation for Contemporary Arts.
lead_paragraph: The Merce Cunningham Trust, established in 2000 to further the choreographer’s legacy, has announced an award of $250,000 to the Baryshnikov Arts Center and of $375,000 to the Foundation for Contemporary Arts. Both organizations, said Allan Sperling, a trustee, were crucial to Cunningham, who died in 2009.

headline: Documentaries in Focus at Miami Jewish Film Festival
abstract: The 18th annual Miami Jewish Film Festival will offer 74 films, including feature-length documentaries.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Spielberg said she knew that her older brother, Steven, and others had toyed with the idea of making a film about the foreign volunteers, or the Machal, who played a crucial role in Israel’s War of Independence in 1948, but she feared the story would never fully be told.

headline: Perceptions of Race at a Glance
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Minorities', 'Racial Profiling', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Capital Punishment', 'Police', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: A professor tries to unearth biases to aid criminal justice.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer L. Eberhardt, 49, an associate professor of psychology at Stanford University, studies the effect of unconscious ideas about race on the workings of the criminal justice system. She was one of 21 winners of 2014 MacArthur “genius” grants.

headline: 6-Year-Olds at the Spa: Understandable, Not Laudable
abstract: Those spas for little girls aren’t really about little girls at all. They’re about parents looking for something special in a world where very little is “special” anymore.
lead_paragraph: There is something about the image of toddler girls and their not-too-much older counterparts engulfed in pink fake fur and trying on tiaras at a day spa that makes me want to begin muttering dire things about bread and circuses and tossing around end-of-days imagery. I’m like a windup baseball batter: Throw the “Seriously Spoiled Salon and Spa” at me, and I’ll swing.

headline: African Nations Can Help More on AIDS, Study Says
abstract: The 12 African countries that receive most of the American taxpayer dollars spent fighting AIDS could do much more to pay their own way, according to a study published in The Lancet.
lead_paragraph: The 12 African countries that receive most of the American taxpayer dollars spent fighting AIDS could do much more to pay their own way, according to a new study.

headline: Drinking In a New Year (and Lifestyle)
abstract: Two new books and a Bobbi-Brown-endorsed greens supplement make for a sound mind in a sound body for 2015.
lead_paragraph: In his new book “The New Health Rules” (out Jan. 6 from Artisan, $20), Dr. Frank Lipman, the founder and director of the Eleven Eleven Wellness Center in New York City and a regular contributor to Gwyneth Paltrow’s lifestyle website Goop, offers his secrets to feeling our best. He prescribes a new lifestyle, not a diet, which he breaks down into five categories: eating (“eat till you’re only 80 percent full”), moving (“stop if it hurts”), boosting (“spend lots of time with people you love”), healing (“wander barefoot”) and living (“lose the mainstream deodorant”). It’s a handy little collection of healthy habits, endorsed with book-jacket blurbs by prominent multitaskers including Paltrow, Arianna Huffington and the makeup artist Bobbi Brown.

headline: Jury Selection Begins in Patz Murder Case
abstract: Pedro Hernandez is accused of killing the 6-year-old Etan Patz in 1979. Opening statements are expected to start on Jan. 20.
lead_paragraph: Jury selection began on Monday in the trial of a man accused of murdering 6-year-old Etan Patz, and the judge warned potential jurors the proceedings could take more than two months.

headline: Scrutiny for Laxatives as a Childhood Remedy
abstract: An ingredient used in adult laxatives like Miralax that are routinely given to children, sometimes daily for years, will be examined more closely by a team of scientists.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has raised new questions about the safety of an adult laxative routinely given to constipated children, sometimes daily for years.

headline: The ‘Inherent Vice’ Bus Tour (Cough, Cough)
abstract: Paul Thomas Anderson is inviting 25 people on a “hazy bus adventure” to see a screening of the film. Draw your own conclusions.
lead_paragraph: “Everybody must get stoned,” Bob Dylan sang, and the director Paul Thomas Anderson is apparently taking that maxim to heart.

headline: Biotech Company Moderna Raises $450 Million
abstract: Moderna Therapeutics said the financing brought the funds it had raised from investors and corporate partners to more than $950 million, a remarkable figure for a company that does not have an experimental drug in clinical trials.
lead_paragraph: Moderna Therapeutics, a four-year-old company with a promising but unproven technology for developing drugs, said on Monday that it had raised $450 million in its latest round of financing, a figure that could be the largest ever in a single round for a private biotechnology company.

headline: Enter Huckabee
abstract: He could have been a contender, but probably not this time around.
lead_paragraph: In Sunday’s column, my first of the new year, I looked back on some of my mistakes and oversights in the old one, starting with my underestimation of Jeb Bush’s belly-fire: I didn’t think he’d actually run for president, and my analysis of the 2016 G.O.P. field last year mostly reflected that assumption, but in the last month he’s looked much more like an actual, all-in candidate than I expected.

headline: Turkey Will Help Train Moderate Syrian Rebels, Diplomat Says
abstract: The training is scheduled to start in March and is expected to involve 15,000 rebels as part of the American-led effort to combat ISIS, the official said.
lead_paragraph: MUGLA, Turkey — Turkey is ready to conclude an agreement this month to train and equip moderate Syrian rebels as part of the American-led effort to combat Islamic State fighters, a senior Turkish diplomat said Monday.

headline: Cancer’s Random Assault
abstract: Spontaneous genetic mutations may be more often to blame than heredity or environment, according to a new study.
lead_paragraph: It may sound flippant to say that many cases of cancer are caused by bad luck, but that is what two scientists suggested in an article published last week in the journal Science. The bad luck comes in the form of random genetic mistakes, or mutations, that happen when healthy cells divide.

headline: At the Bottom of the Ballot, One Last Shutout
abstract: Among the 34 players on this year’s Hall of Fame ballot, the candidates for joining the zero-vote club include Aaron Boone, Eddie Guardado, Rich Aurilia and Tony Clark.
lead_paragraph: As debates rage about the Hall of Fame worthiness of players like Mike Mussina, Curt Schilling and John Smoltz ahead of Tuesday’s announcement of the class of 2015, no one is bothering to argue the case for Aaron Boone.

headline: CES: New Options for Networked Speakers
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'International Consumer Electronics Show', 'Speakers (Audio)']
abstract: Home theater systems have declined in popularity as most consumers chose simpler setups like soundbars. But that doesn’t mean we don’t want our music to follow us.
lead_paragraph: Since streaming music has become more popular, it should come as no surprise that home stereo systems are starting to get a connected makeover. This could be the year that Sonos, the longtime leader in this field, gets some competition.

headline: Scott Walker, Starting Second Term as Wisconsin Governor, Resists New Union Battle
abstract: The governor has indicated that he does not want to expand the fight with labor that defined his first term, but fellow Republicans seem determined to challenge the power of unions.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, who rose to national prominence in the Republican Party by cutting the collective bargaining rights of most public sector unions, strongly indicated in the final days of his re-election campaign that he had no plans to expand the battle with labor unions that defined his first term.

headline: Profit at Point72, Cohen’s New Firm, Outshines Many a Hedge Fund’s
abstract: Had the family office been operating as a hedge fund, it would have been one of the industry’s most profitable in 2014.
lead_paragraph: If Steven A. Cohen’s investment firm were operating as a hedge fund, it would have been one of the industry’s most profitable in 2014.

headline: Gohmert Doesn’t Talk Like a Speaker, or Donate Money Like One
keywords: ['Political Action Committees', 'Campaign Finance', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Texas Republican challenging John Boehner for Speaker of the House doesn’t deviate from the party line much but stands out for how he uses his PAC.
lead_paragraph: Louie Gohmert, the Texas Republican challenging John Boehner for Speaker of the House, doesn’t talk like the G.O.P. leadership.

headline: Falling Euro Fans Fears of a Regional Slowdown
abstract: The euro's continued plunge, to a nine-year low against the dollar, came on the same day that global oil prices also resumed their descent.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The value of the euro fell to its lowest level in years on Monday, prompting sharp declines in European stocks and creating uneasiness about whether the region is on the verge of a new economic and financial crisis.

headline: N.F.L.’s Underdogs Have Reasons for Optimism
abstract: The home teams were favored in the upcoming divisional round, but there were reasons for optimism among the visitors.
lead_paragraph: In 1990, the N.F.L. switched to its current playoff format, featuring six teams from each conference, with the top two seeds earning first-round byes.

headline: Thinking About International Bond Yields
abstract: Currencies matter.
lead_paragraph: One of the occupational hazards of being a professional economist writing for a broader audience is that sometimes you lose track of what is and isn’t obvious to smart people who haven’t spent their lives immersed in your field. (Actually, the same problem arises in teaching undergraduates.) So I welcome it when people ask questions in an open-minded spirit, and reveal that there is some bit of stuff that I’ve been taking for granted as obvious, but isn’t.

headline: Gov. Jerry Brown Begins Last Term With a Bold Energy Plan
abstract: The California governor issued a call to slash gas consumption by cars and trucks by as much as 50 percent as part of a campaign to battle global warming.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Gov. Jerry Brown began his fourth and final term on Monday proposing a broad reduction in California’s energy consumption over the next 15 years — including a call to slash gas consumption by cars and trucks by as much as 50 percent — as part of what he said would be a sweeping campaign to heighten the state’s role in the fight against global warming.

headline: From the Upshot: Gohmert’s Leadership PAC

headline: Famous Faces in Oscar de la Renta
abstract: Since the designer’s death in October, his brand has been among the best represented at high-profile events.
lead_paragraph: Since the designer’s death in October, his brand has been among the best represented at high-profile events.

headline: Kaleidoscopic Naturalist Collages, a European Collective’s American Debut and More From the Art Calendar
abstract: Plus, the desert sculptor Alma Allen’s first L.A. solo show, a retrospective from the Turkish tour de force Mehmet Guleryuz and more happenings to see in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: T’s list of happenings worth visiting in the week ahead.

headline: Mugler
abstract: The prefall collection included a tailored suit with grommets details and lots of leather.
lead_paragraph: The prefall collection included a tailored suit with grommets details and lots of leather.

headline: A Banner Week for Broadway
abstract: Broadway musicals and plays grossed $42.8 million, the highest total ever for a week’s worth of performances, according to box-office data released on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Coming off a hugely profitable run of performances during Christmas week, Broadway musicals and plays did even better last week over the New Year holiday, grossing the highest amount ever – $42.8 million – for a week’s worth of performances, according to box-office data released on Monday by the Broadway League.

headline: An Unlikely and Tumultuous Pair, Making History in Avant-Garde Theater
abstract: Pamela Katz’s “The Partnership: Brecht, Weill, Three Women, and Germany on the Brink” is an account of “The Threepenny Opera” collaborators Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brecht.
lead_paragraph: Rehearsals for Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brecht’s “The Threepenny Opera” ended near dawn on Aug. 31, 1928, the day of its premiere. They had not gone well.

headline: Creating a New Mission Statement
abstract: By creating a mission statement people can begin to identify the underlying causes of behaviors, as well as what truly motivates them to make changes.
lead_paragraph: Forget the New Year’s resolution. This year, try creating a personal mission statement instead.

lead_paragraph: Afghanistan and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day

headline: Hanging Out 1,200 Feet Up (Yes, Downtime)
abstract: How do the two men free-climbing El Capitan charge their cellphones, and where and how do they sleep and eat and post to the Internet?
lead_paragraph: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif. — The two men attempting to free climb the daunting 3,000-foot Dawn Wall route of El Capitan spent much of Monday morning in their tents, hanging 1,200 feet above the valley floor.

headline: Debt Dispute Between Hedge Funds and Argentina at Impasse
abstract: Argentina made an informal offer to settle a debt dispute with a group of New York hedge funds, but the country is still asking the bondholders to accept less than they are seeking.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — The hopes of easing a debt dispute between Argentina and a group of New York hedge funds seemed to be dashed on Monday after the country’s economy minister made an offer that appeared to fall well short of what the investors were seeking.

headline: Still Music to the Ears, but From Odd Sources
abstract: Works by James Nyoraku Schlefer and others were part of a Winter Festival program on Sunday at Bargemusic.
lead_paragraph: You never know what might inspire a composer to write a piece. On Sunday afternoon, for a Winter Festival program in the Here and Now contemporary-music series at Bargemusic in Brooklyn, several of the extremely diverse works derived from unusual sources.

headline: Shots Beat Pills for Knee Arthritis Relief
abstract: The most effective treatment for the pain of knee osteoarthritis may be an injection of hyaluronic acid or corticosteroids, and the least effective may be Tylenol or Celebrex pills.
lead_paragraph: The most effective treatment for the pain of knee osteoarthritis may be an injection of hyaluronic acid or corticosteroids, and the least effective may be Tylenol or Celebrex pills, a review of studies concludes.

headline: In Performance | Courtney Love
abstract: Ms. Love performs the song “All I Ever Wanted” from “Kansas City Choir Boy,” with the show’s composer, Todd Almond, on piano, and Eric Allen on cello. The show is at Here Arts Center from Jan. 8-17.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Love performs the song “All I Ever Wanted” from “Kansas City Choir Boy,” with the show’s composer, Todd Almond, on piano, and Eric Allen on cello. The show is at Here Arts Center from Jan. 8-17.

headline: For a Trailblazer, Odd Was the Norm
abstract: “Ripley: Believe It or Not” profiles Robert L. Ripley and how he fed the public’s hunger for oddities and curiosities.
lead_paragraph: The odd has become commonplace these days. Do you have anatomical malformations or enjoy looking at them? Pinterest has a board for you. Does your collection of mustard bottles number in the thousands? A reality TV show will be calling shortly.

headline: Jeb Bush Strikes Conciliatory Note on Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: As gay couples began to wed in Florida, Jeb Bush, long an opponent of same-sex marriages, struck a conciliatory note on Monday, saying that “regardless of our disagreements, we have to respect the rule of law.”
lead_paragraph: As gay couples began to wed in Florida after a court ruling, Jeb Bush, the state’s former governor and long an opponent of same-sex marriages, struck a conciliatory note on Monday, telling The New York Times that “regardless of our disagreements, we have to respect the rule of law.”

headline: A Furor in France Over the Final Resting Place for a Roma Child
abstract: The mayor of Champlan, about 10 miles southwest of Paris, is accused of refusing to grant burial space in the municipal cemetery for a Roma infant.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A 2-month-old Roma infant was buried on Monday in a town south of Paris amid accusations that the mayor of the nearby town where the baby died had refused burial space in the local cemetery. The episode has prompted antidiscrimination investigations by local prosecutors and France’s human rights ombudsman.

headline: Life After Captain America
abstract: In “Marvel’s Agent Carter,” Peggy Carter, Captain America’s former girlfriend, forges her own career as a spy.
lead_paragraph: The title “Marvel’s Agent Carter” may create a misleading impression for a show set in 1946 New York and featuring automats and fedoras. This latest product of the Marvel comics-adventure factory, an eight-episode series starting on Tuesday, has less in common with its sister ABC show, “Marvel’s Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.,” than it does with some of the more active British mysteries on PBS. Viewers with long memories may even be reminded of “Remember WENN,” the serving of World War II-era schmaltz that was AMC’s first scripted show.

headline: Official Says Crucial Call Was Missed by Referees
abstract: Dean Blandino, the vice president for officiating for the N.F.L., said the Cowboys should have been penalized during a key point in the fourth quarter.
lead_paragraph: The Dallas Cowboys are set to head to Green Bay to play the Packers on Sunday in the divisional round of the N.F.L. playoffs, but the Cowboys’ victory over the Detroit Lions on Sunday is still being picked over.

headline: Two in U.S. Face Charges After Coup Attempt Fails in Gambia
abstract: The two were accused in federal court of conspiracy to violate the Neutrality Act in connection with a botched attempt to depose the Gambian president.
lead_paragraph: A botched coup attempt in the tiny West African nation of Gambia last week reached into the American heartland on Monday with criminal charges against two United States citizens, accused in federal court of helping to finance, lead and arm the plotters.

headline: Albums From Art Hirahara and Death Grips
abstract: Mr. Hirahara’s “Libations & Meditations” is thoughtfully assured; Death Grips teaches you to listen with your defenses up.
lead_paragraph: ART HIRAHARA

headline: Ally of Deposed Leader Is Nominated to Be Premier of Tunisia
abstract: Habib Essid served in a variety of government positions under the autocratic President Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, who was ousted in 2011.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A former government official of the dictatorship in Tunisia, Habib Essid, was nominated Monday to be prime minister and charged with forming a new government.

headline: Discounted Tickets: A Test for the Metropolitan Opera
abstract: The Met discount ticket program is a lesson in the difficulties of giving something away for almost nothing.
lead_paragraph: One of the first measures Peter Gelb instituted when he arrived as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera in 2006 was to introduce a rush ticket program, which offers up to 100 or so $25 tickets in prime seating locations for each performance. Surprisingly, people are still grumbling.

headline: Racially Ignited, a Magical World Is Uncanny
keywords: ['Television', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: “The Wizard of Watts,” an animated musical coming to Adult Swim on Saturday, takes on greater weight as a national debate over race and overzealous policing is underway.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “The Wizard of Watts,” a coming animated television musical, was conceived two years ago as a big, fat gob of raucous entertainment wrapped around a nugget of racial commentary.

headline: Grilling and Being Grilled
abstract: The process of elimination can be painful on children’s reality TV competitions, including the Tuesday night shows “MasterChef Junior” and “Child Genius.”
lead_paragraph: When a child chef is eliminated on “MasterChef Junior,” two things happen. First, the unbearable: The child cries. This is almost always the case: Competitors range in age from 8 to 13, and by and large don’t have the backbone to endure being told they didn’t succeed. It’s agonizing, of course, or maybe heartening, if you’re the sort of person who appreciates emotional transparency.

headline: What Would MacGyver Do?
abstract: “Hack My Life,” on TruTV, serves up improvised solutions for a barbecue crisis and other emergencies.
lead_paragraph: What idiot forgets to buy charcoal for a barbecue but has a large sack of potato chips, another of nacho chips and, for some reason, another of marshmallows?

keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Uniforms', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Flight Attendants', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Business Travel']
abstract: Domestic airlines have steadily pared back trendsetting designer looks in favor of uniforms that resemble today’s more utilitarian flying experience.
lead_paragraph: If it is indeed true that you are what you wear, then consider the statement American Airlines recently made when, as part of its postmerger rebranding, it unveiled prototype uniforms for its flight attendants and other employees.

abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Miami-Dade became the first county in Florida to allow gay couples to wed after a state judge lifted a temporary ban.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Ending a drawn-out battle over same-sex marriage in Florida, Miami-Dade on Monday became the first county in the state to allow gay couples to wed after a state judge lifted a temporary ban on the nuptials.

headline: Telling Stories in a Tennessee Coal Town
abstract: Since 1993, Robert Heller’s advanced photography students at the University of Tennessee have documented life in LaFollette, which has seen better days.
lead_paragraph: Since 1993, Robert Heller’s advanced photography students at the University of Tennessee have documented life in LaFollette, which has seen better days.
