keywords: ['Americans Abroad', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Philanthropy']
abstract: This short documentary profiles a Kenyan activist who asks American student volunteers: “Why do you want to help us? Help your own country.”
lead_paragraph: This short documentary profiles a Kenyan activist who asks American student volunteers: “Why do you want to help us? Help your own country.”

headline: ‘An African’s Message for America’
keywords: ['Americans Abroad', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Philanthropy']
abstract: This short documentary profiles a Kenyan activist who asks American student volunteers: “Why do you want to help us? Help your own country.”
lead_paragraph: A volunteer trip abroad has become almost a rite of passage for a certain set of Americans, particularly students. This Op-Doc video profiles a Kenyan activist who has one simple question for them: “Why?”

headline: Illinois Introduces Automatic Retirement Savings Program, a First for the Nation
keywords: ['Individual Retirement Accounts', 'Savings', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Starting in 2017, most state residents lacking a retirement plan at work will have money taken out of their paychecks and put toward an I.R.A.
lead_paragraph: Illinois is taking a novel approach to getting its residents to save for retirement. Starting in 2017, most state residents with jobs who don’t already have a retirement plan at work will be automatically enrolled in individual retirement accounts, funded through a 3 percent deduction from their paychecks.

headline: Bess Myerson Dies at 90
abstract: Ms. Myerson was a favorite daughter of New York who basked in the public eye for decades.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Myerson was a favorite daughter of New York who basked in the public eye for decades.

headline: Walkabout: Olympic Stadiums — Some Iconic, Others in Ruins
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Faster, Higher, Stronger Olympic stadiums have become potent symbols of architectural prowess and national pride. A look back at arenas and forward to the one designed for the 2020 Summer Games in Tokyo. (The New York Times)

headline: An Ambitious Plan to Boost American Playwrights
abstract: Second Stage is seeking $58 million to purchase the Helen Hayes Theater in an effort to join the small ranks of nonprofit theaters with a Broadway berth.
lead_paragraph: Brother, or sister, can you spare $58 million?

headline: What a Stronger Dollar Means for the Economy
keywords: ['US Dollar (Currency)', 'Euro (Currency)', 'United States Economy', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The seemingly inexorable rise of the dollar versus the euro and most other currencies has broad implications this year and beyond.
lead_paragraph: It just might be time to book that vacation in Paris you’ve been thinking about.

headline: Man Killed by San Francisco Police Had Air Gun and Suicide Motive, They Say
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'BB and Airsoft Guns']
abstract: The police said a man who left suicide notes had reached for a gun that did not have the orange handle that would identify it as a toy.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco police shot and killed a man outside a police station on Sunday night after a brief confrontation in which he brandished a weapon that turned out to be an air gun.

headline: Stop Subsidizing Big Pharma
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Research', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Biotechnology and Bioengineering', 'Royalties']
abstract: Venture philanthropy risks benefiting companies, not patients.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — ROBERT J. BEALL, the president and chief executive of the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, called his recent decision to sell the royalty rights to his organization’s research a “game changer.” Indeed: Deals like this, in which an investment company paid the foundation $3.3 billion for its future royalties from several cystic fibrosis drugs it helped finance, could revolutionize the way medical research is funded. Rather than the staid model of government-funded institutions handing out grants to academic research facilities, a new breed of “venture philanthropies” like the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation could corral private investment into developing lifesaving drugs quickly and cheaply.

headline: The Path to Closing Guantánamo
keywords: ['Detainees', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Three misconceptions are holding up the end of this stain on America.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — WHEN I began as the State Department’s envoy for closing the detention facility at Guantánamo Bay, many people advised me that progress was impossible. They were wrong.

headline: Boehner Facing Dissent and Defections in Vote to Remain Speaker of House
abstract: Tuesday’s vote for speaker represents a reach for relevance by some rank-and-file conservative Republicans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner is all but assured of re-election to the top House leadership post when his colleagues vote on Tuesday, but the new term also could serve up the embarrassment of a potentially record number of his own Republican conference voting against him as speaker.

headline: Ambush Unfolds on Video as Pennsylvania Sets Trial for Eric Frein in Killing of State Trooper
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Eric M. Frein, accused of killing a Pennsylvania trooper, was ordered to be tried in a state court, at a hearing at which surveillance video of the attack was shown.
lead_paragraph: MILFORD, Pa. — Eric M. Frein, a self-described survivalist accused of an ambush that killed a Pennsylvania state trooper and wounded another, sat motionless during a preliminary hearing in a Pike County courtroom on Monday, his eyes riveted on a surveillance video.

headline: Blood and Politics
abstract: Are dynasties bad for American democracy, or simply inevitable? How do they affect political power?

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s Expanded Horizons
abstract: In his second inaugural address, the governor of New York touched on some of the high points while laying out an ambitious agenda.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York gave a politically important speech last week that got lost in the news that his father, former Gov. Mario Cuomo, had died that same afternoon. The speech — his second inaugural address — touched on some of the high points of his first term while laying out an ambitious agenda for his next four years.

headline: CES: A Push for Higher Resolution and Better-Looking TVs
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'International Consumer Electronics Show', 'Television Sets and Media Devices']
abstract: The big TV makers, including Samsung and Sony, showed off giant screens with sky-high display resolutions, and in a bid to push ultrahigh definition into the mainstream, several are teaming up with each other and content makers like Netflix.
lead_paragraph: The International CES took a turn toward the familiar on Monday: televisions.

headline: Migrant Deaths on the Mediterranean
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Smuggling', 'Drownings', 'International Relations', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: European governments should create more legal avenues for refugees seeking safety.
lead_paragraph: Well-organized criminal gangs are increasing the pressure on Europe to deal with illegal migration across the Mediterranean by using a terrible new tactic: Sending rusty old freighters filled with refugees hurtling full throttle toward Italy’s shores and certain disaster. It’s a game of chicken, and the smugglers know that Europe has no moral option but to rescue the ships’ human cargo.

headline: Obama Nears Goal for Guantánamo With Faster Pace of Releases
abstract: A series of secret nighttime flights over the last two months has brought the administration closer to meeting the president’s promise to empty the military prison in Cuba.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a series of secret nighttime flights in the last two months, the Obama administration made more progress toward the president’s goal of emptying the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, than it had since 2009. The accelerated pace came after an era of political infighting and long bureaucratic delays.

headline: Egypt’s Appalling Crackdown on Gays
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Editorials', 'Discrimination', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The Egyptian government has persecuted gay men with varying degrees of intensity in the past, but the trial of 26 men now underway is especially harsh.
lead_paragraph: Even if they were acquitted on the ludicrous charge of “debauchery,” the 26 Egyptian men on trial in the government’s latest crackdown on gays are likely to suffer a lifetime of public scorn.

headline: Feistier de Blasio Appears, Uncowed by Police Unions
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: After two weeks of cautious, sometimes halting remarks, Mayor Bill de Blasio blasted the language of police unions and those who turned their backs on him at two officers’ funerals.
lead_paragraph: This time, Mayor Bill de Blasio came out swinging.

headline: Aces’ Obstacle on Way to Hall: A Modest Hitter
abstract: Over 11 seasons, Mickey Morandini batted .268, but he hit a combined .352 off three pitchers likely to be named to the Hall of Fame on Tuesday: Randy Johnson, Pedro Martinez and John Smoltz.
lead_paragraph: The newest members of the Baseball Hall of Fame will be revealed on Tuesday, and three overpowering aces of the 1990s — Randy Johnson, Pedro Martinez and John Smoltz — seem certain to be cast in bronze in Cooperstown.

headline: Mourners Pay Their Respects to Mario Cuomo
abstract: New Yorkers, both the famous and the ordinary, lined up outside the Frank E. Campbell funeral home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan to attend the former governor’s wake.
lead_paragraph: They waited in the bitter cold, in some cases for more than two hours, drawn to pay their respects to a gifted politician they admired. Many came from the highest ranks of New York’s political world.

headline: The Problem With Meaning
abstract: Our fuzzy modern idea of “meaning” is a poor substitute for real moral architecture.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, a friend sent me a speech that the great civic leader John Gardner gave to the Stanford Alumni Association 61 years after he graduated from that college. The speech is chock-full of practical wisdom. I especially liked this passage:

headline: Resistance From Right Slows G.O.P. Press to Redefine Full-Time Worker
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Working Hours', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The legislative priority for the new Republican Congress would change the definition of a full workweek, under the Affordable Care Act, to 40 hours, rather than 30.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of the new Republican Congress’s first legislative priorities — redefining a full-time worker under the Affordable Care Act — is gaining opposition just days before passage from a surprising group: conservatives.

headline: Gilead Strikes Hepatitis Drug Deal With CVS Health
abstract: The agreement partly offsets a similar pact between the pharmacy benefit manager Express Scripts and AbbVie, another maker of a costly hepatitis C drug.
lead_paragraph: Gilead Sciences struck back on Monday against its rival AbbVie in a budding marketing war over costly hepatitis C drugs, winning exclusive access to many patients whose prescriptions are managed by CVS Health.

headline: Martin Anderson, White House Adviser to Reagan, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Anderson, a conservative economist, served three other presidents in addition to Reagan.
lead_paragraph: Martin Anderson, a conservative economist who helped shape American economic policy in the 1980s as a top adviser to President Ronald Reagan, died on Saturday at his home in Portola Valley, Calif. He was 78.

headline: Hezbollah Appears to Acknowledge a Spy at the Top
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: Remarks were taken as confirmation of reports that a senior Hezbollah operative had been caught spying for Israel, disrupting several assassination plots abroad.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The admission from Hezbollah’s deputy chief was startling. The group, he said over the weekend, is “battling espionage within its ranks” and has uncovered “some major infiltrations.”

headline: Rams Owner Stan Kroenke Reveals Plan for Field in Los Angeles Area
abstract: Stan Kroenke announced plans to build an 80,000-seat stadium that would rise in proximity to a city that has been without an N.F.L. team for two decades.
lead_paragraph: The owner Stan Kroenke of the St. Louis Rams on Monday announced plans to build an 80,000-seat football stadium in Inglewood, Calif., about 10 miles from downtown Los Angeles.

headline: When Mark Zuckerberg Likes a Book, Sales Soar
abstract: The chief of Facebook has created a new book club, setting off a torrent of orders for its first selection, “The End of Power” by Moises Naim.
lead_paragraph: The Facebook chief executive Mark Zuckerberg made a New Year’s resolution to read two books a month in 2015, and he’s inviting his 31 million Facebook friends to join him.

headline: Not Embracing Christie’s Love of the Dallas Cowboys
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie’s televised hug with the team’s owner, Jerry Jones, struck a nerve in New Jersey, where football loyalties are split among the Giants, the Jets and the Eagles.
lead_paragraph: Embracing President Obama was one thing. But hugging Jerry Jones?

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 5, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: The Moral of the Kulluk
keywords: ['Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Why is Shell drilling for oil in the most inhospitable place on earth?
lead_paragraph: The cover story of The New York Times Magazine on Sunday, “The Wreck of the Kulluk,” by McKenzie Funk, is one of those articles that you can’t put down even though you know how it turns out. The Kulluk was an offshore exploratory drilling rig, owned by Royal Dutch Shell, which, in December 2012, ran aground in some of the most inhospitable waters in the world.

headline: Q. and A. on Palestinian Statehood
abstract: Answers about the principles of statehood and how they might apply to the Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: Q. What determines statehood?

headline: Palestinians Seen Gaining Momentum in Quest for Statehood
abstract: Palestinians have begun to translate a series of symbolic steps made outside of negotiations into a strategy that has increased pressure on Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — When the Palestinians sought statehood at the United Nations in 2011, it was widely dismissed as a symbolic gambit to skirt negotiations with Israel and Washington’s influence over the long-running conflict. But the Palestinians have begun to translate a series of such symbolic steps, culminating in last week’s move to join the International Criminal Court, into a strategy that has begun to create pressure on Israel.

headline: An Unusual Boardroom Battle, in Academia
abstract: A paper by Daniel M. Gallagher and Joseph A. Grundfest takes aim at Lucian A. Bebchuk of Harvard, an advocate for changing policies that prevent shareholders from electing, or overthrowing, an entire board at once.
lead_paragraph: A normally academic question about corporate governance has erupted into a nasty, often personal battle among elite professors, regulators and white-shoe lawyers that has raised the suggestion of securities fraud on one side and abuse of authority on the other.

headline: At 5-32, Knicks Look to the Future by Trading Smith and Shumpert
abstract: J. R. Smith and Iman Shumpert were on their way to Cleveland as part of a three-team trade, and Samuel Dalembert was waived.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks, in their continuing quest to shed salaries and reshape the franchise, were involved in a major, three-team trade on Monday night, sending J. R. Smith and Iman Shumpert to the Cleveland Cavaliers in exchange for several players with nonguaranteed contracts and a future draft pick.

headline: Justice Dept. Sues Doctor Paid Richly by Medicare
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Whistle-Blowers']
abstract: The lawsuits accuse Dr. Asad Qamar of billing Medicare for unnecessary operations, and paying kickbacks to patients by waiving their bills.
lead_paragraph: One of the nation’s top-billing doctors, a cardiologist who collected more than $18 million in payments from Medicare in 2012, has been accused by the federal government of performing unnecessary procedures on patients.

headline: Sound Investments
abstract: Joel Fagliano gets down to a molecular level.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE —The curvaceous black-square pattern going down the center of the grid tipped me off that something was going on in Joel Fagliano’s grid. I wasn’t sure what that might be until I got to the revealer at 62 Down, when I realized it was meant to invoke the sinewy nature of DNA strands. It was clever to hold out until the last Down entry, although, personally, I don’t feel that the gray squares do much for the solving experience.

headline: Sacvan Bercovitch, Scholar Who Traced America’s Self-Image, Dies at 81
abstract: Dr. Bercovitch argued that the Puritans regarded New England not as an extension of European societies but as something new and exceptional.
lead_paragraph: Sacvan Bercovitch, a distinguished literary scholar who traced America’s self-image of “exceptionalism” to the rhetoric of the colonial Puritans of New England, died on Dec. 9 at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 81.

headline: After His Ex-Wife’s Death, a Struggle to Raise His Daughters
abstract: Yefim Ulitskiy, 55, has relied on his mother’s help, including housing and after-school pickups, with his two young daughters after their mother died in January 2014.
lead_paragraph: Yefim Ulitskiy, 55, did not know how to tell his two young daughters that their mother, his ex-wife, had died.

headline: Leo Tindemans, 92, Dies; Belgian Prime Minister and Voice for European Unity
abstract: Mr. Tindemans saw European integration and a single currency as a means of overcoming the virulent nationalism of the past.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Leo Tindemans, a former prime minister of Belgium who pushed for greater European integration and helped set the stage for the introduction of the European Union’s single currency, the euro, died on Dec. 26 in Edegem, in the Flemish province of Antwerp. He was 92.

headline: In Memphis, Knicks Can Only Watch Marc Gasol and Wish He Were One of Them
abstract: Gasol, one of the best centers in the N.B.A. and a free agent after the season, helped the Grizzlies send the Knicks to their 12th straight defeat.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — As the Knicks were trying to complete a major three-team trade on Monday — a deal that sent J. R. Smith and Iman Shumpert to the Cleveland Cavaliers in exchange for several players with nonguaranteed contracts and a future draft pick — Jose Calderon was going through a pregame drill.

headline: Rysheed Jordan Returns for St. John’s in Time to Play Villanova
abstract: As the Red Storm prepared to face the Wildcats in a Big East matchup, the team’s second-leading scorer, Jordan, was back after missing a weekend loss.
lead_paragraph: The puzzling disappearance of the sophomore guard Rysheed Jordan from the St. John’s lineup this past weekend was resolved at least somewhat on Monday afternoon, when the program announced that Jordan would return for Tuesday’s crucial home contest against Villanova.

headline: Chris Christie Supports Cowboys Owner, but Not Eagles Fans
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey recounted his time with Jerry Jones, owner of the Dallas Cowboys, after a recent win over the almost-hometown Philadelphia Eagles.
lead_paragraph: Chris Christie relishes his proximity to the owner of the Dallas Cowboys, Jerry Jones, whose friendship has caused the New Jersey governor a new round of headaches this week.

headline: Bronx School Ousts Priest After Admissions of Abuse
abstract: The Rev. Robert Harrison, a Capuchin priest who was an assistant principal at the Bronx school, said the abuse of 10 minors occurred in the 1970s and 1980s, authorities from his religious order said.
lead_paragraph: An assistant principal at Cardinal Hayes High School in the Bronx has been dismissed after admitting just before the Christmas break that he sexually abused 10 minors in the 1970s and 1980s, authorities from his religious order said on Monday.

headline: Conviction to Be Cleared in 1991 Brooklyn Murder Case
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Kenneth P. Thompson, the Brooklyn district attorney, said on Monday that he would move to clear the conviction of Derrick Hamilton, who spent years in prison for a 1991 murder in Bedford-Stuyvesant.
lead_paragraph: Saying the sole eyewitness at a murder trial gave “patently false” testimony, the Brooklyn district attorney said on Monday that he would move to clear the conviction of Derrick Hamilton, who spent about two decades in prison for a 1991 murder.

headline: Nets Make It Interesting but Wither in Overtime
abstract: The Nets made 16 shots in the first quarter and only 16 more in the rest of regulationen route to a 96-88 overtime loss to the Mavericks.
lead_paragraph: Consider the Nets’ statistics in the first quarter of their game Monday night against the Dallas Mavericks: 35 points, 61.5 percent shooting, 13 team assists and no turnovers.

headline: Two Plainclothes Officers Are Shot in the Bronx
abstract: The officers appeared to have been investigating a robbery, a police official said; the injuries did not appear to be life-threatening.
lead_paragraph: Two plainclothes New York City police officers were shot in the Bronx on Monday night while they were investigating an armed robbery at a grocery store, the police said.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Takes a Trailer of Its New Season to Imax
abstract: The move, the first time a TV series has shown on Imax screens, continues the blurring of lines between platforms, from tiny mobile phones to movie theaters.
lead_paragraph: The dragons, dire wolves, White Walkers and power-hungry political factions in HBO’s fantasy epic “Game of Thrones” will invade movie theaters later this month — on the big, big screen. An exclusive trailer for the coming season along with the final two episodes of the previous season will be shown in 150 Imax theaters across the country.

headline: Word of the Day | spat
abstract: This word has appeared in 136 New York Times articles in the past year.

headline: Real Estate in Manhattan Set Sales Records in 2014
abstract: Ending the year on a high note, the fourth quarter saw triple the number of closings on units costing $10 million or more compared with the same quarter of 2013.
lead_paragraph: It was a banner year for Manhattan real estate. In 2014, buoyed by sales of ultraluxury apartments in new developments, the real estate market rebounded to surpass its previous peak, reached in 2008, when the financial crisis hit, according to Jonathan J. Miller, the president of the appraisal firm Miller Samuel.

headline: Holding Off Russia, Canada Wins First Title in 6 Years
abstract: Canada had last reached the final of the World Junior Championship in 2011, losing a heartbreaker to Russia.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — With Canada’s prime minister on hand and fans clad in the red and white of the national flag rocking Air Canada Centre, Canada scored on its first two shots and held on to defeat Russia, 5-4, on Monday and win the gold medal at the World Junior Championship.

headline: How Nonemployed Americans Spend Their Weekdays: Men vs. Women
abstract: An interactive comparison of a day in the life of 147 men and 147 women without jobs.
lead_paragraph: An interactive comparison of a day in the life of 147 men and 147 women without jobs.

headline: Where Working Women Are Most Common
abstract: Female employment rates have continued rising in most rich countries, but they have been falling in the United States since 2000.
lead_paragraph: Female employment rates have continued rising in most rich countries, but they have been falling in the United States since 2000.

headline: ‘Last Ship’ to Close on Broadway
abstract: Despite herculean efforts by Sting, the show’s star composer, to promote the musical, an audience did not materialize.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway musical “The Last Ship” will close on Jan. 24 despite an unusual attempt by Sting, its composer, to try to increase ticket sales and spread word about the show by joining its cast last month. Two of the musical’s producers, Jeffrey Seller and Kathryn Schenker, shared the news in an email on Monday night to members of the production and other supporters of “The Last Ship.”

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6:30 P.M. (HBO Signature) THE GREAT GATSBY (2013) Leonardo DiCaprio stars as the enigmatic millionaire Jay Gatsby and Carey Mulligan portrays Daisy Buchanan, the object of his obsession. Tobey Maguire is Nick Carraway, the Yale graduate — and, conveniently, Daisy’s cousin — renting the cottage next to Gatsby’s colossal Long Island mansion in Baz Luhrmann’s stylized musical take on this F. Scott Fitzgerald novel. “Despite what you may have heard, it is an eminently enjoyable movie,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this film, which won Oscars for best costume and production design. Still, is the tale “a credible love story?” he asked. “Fitzgerald himself was not sure, but Mr. Luhrmann, Mr. DiCaprio and Ms. Mulligan make it an effective one.”

headline: Telling Stories in a Tennessee Coal Town
abstract: Since 1993, Robert Heller’s advanced photography students have documented life in LaFollette, Tenn., an old coal town that has seen better days.
lead_paragraph: Robert Heller felt out of place when he first arrived in Knoxville to teach photography at the University of Tennessee in 1986. Mr. Heller — who had been raised on Long Island, N.Y., by second-generation Russian-Jewish immigrant parents — had never been to Tennessee and didn’t know much about the state other than it is a center of country and bluegrass music (so much so that it has at least five official state songs, including “Tennessee Waltz” and “Rocky Top”).

headline: University in Xi’an Opens School of Cyberengineering
abstract: The move by Xidian University, with more than 30,000 students on two campuses, was a sign that cybersecurity had become an increasingly important academic discipline for the Chinese government and military.
lead_paragraph: Xidian University, with more than 30,000 students on two campuses in the ancient city of Xi’an, has a storied history. The original academy was personally established by Mao Zedong in 1931, when the Communist Party and Red Army were leading an insurgent movement to overthrow the Kuomintang government. Based in Jiangxi Province, where the Communists had their headquarters for a period, the school’s mission was to train radio operators for the military. Mao had set it up in his role as head of the party’s Central Military Commission.

headline: Morning Agenda: Data Leak at Morgan Stanley

lead_paragraph: After account records for clients of Morgan Stanley were put up for sale last month on the information-sharing site Pastebin, the bank traced the breach to a financial adviser working out of its New York offices, a 30-year-old named Galen Marsh, Nathaniel Popper writes in DealBook, citing a person involved in the investigation. Mr. Marsh, who had been with Morgan Stanley since 2008, was quickly fired and is currently the subject of a criminal investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, a person briefed on the investigation said. The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority is also examining the matter.

Ms. Love, the lead singer of the band Hole, is accompanied on piano by Todd Almond, her co-star and the show’s songwriter, and the cellist Eric Allen. The piece runs at the performance space Here from Thursday to Jan. 17 as part of Prototype, the annual music and theater festival.

headline: Long a Walled-Off Secret, the Paris Mint Transforms Into a Dining and Art Destination
abstract: The grand Monnaie de Paris — which still produces commemorative coins — is undergoing a face-lift, hosting exhibits and Guy Savoy’s forthcoming flagship restaurant.
lead_paragraph: The three-Michelin-starred chef Guy Savoy is impatient. A 4,300-square-foot space at the top of the Monnaie de Paris — one of the city’s most beautiful buildings — is scheduled to open this spring as the reincarnation of his flagship restaurant on the other side of town. But the kitchen has no refrigerators and only partial electrical and heating systems. Buckets of water and cans of paint line the floors. Some of the light fixtures have not been installed. Paintings have not been hung.

headline: About That French Time Bomb
abstract: So hopeless that it can borrow at 0.8 percent.
lead_paragraph: I’ve written often about the remarkable track record of U.S. debt-and-inflation doomsayers, who have warned again and again that we’re about to turn into Greece if not Zimbabwe, and are now completely unwilling to admit that they were wrong, or even that their model of how the world works needs some revision. But as interest rates plunge almost everywhere, let’s look back at the bad-mouthing of another economy, which looks equally wrong-headed if not more so.

headline: Coach Is Buying Stuart Weitzman: Why It Matters
abstract: Coach can use some help in the footwear department, and presumably the Weitzman acquisition, along with its know-how, can help.
lead_paragraph: Coach, the accessible luxury company long rumored to be a possible acquisition target for a big group, and in the midst of a revamp of its stores and image under the creative director Stuart Vevers, has turned the tables. It announced Tuesday that it was acquiring the shoe brand Stuart Weitzman from Sycamore Partners in a deal that values the company at $574 million.

headline: Daily Report: Getting the Apps to Talk to Each Other
abstract: As people spend more time using apps, their Internet has taken a step backward, becoming more isolated — more like the web before search engines.
lead_paragraph: Navigating the Internet used to mean painstakingly typing the exact address you wanted into your computer. The web browser and the search engine simplified that, giving us the Internet we take for granted today.

lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Nearly a week after a stampede killed at least 36 people and injured 49 others during an outdoor New Year’s Eve gathering in one of this city’s most popular tourist spots, a solemn memorial service was held here Tuesday morning.

headline: Paying for the TV Shows You Want
abstract: The new streaming service from Dish Network bundles 12 channels together for $20 a month.
lead_paragraph: The new streaming TV service from Dish Network is not going to kill the cable bundle—at least not in its current form. But the service, which Dish is calling Sling TV, should help some people save money by allowing them to pay only for the TV shows that they actually want to watch.

headline: National Portrait Gallery Names New Director

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Nicholas Cullinan, who has been the curator of modern and contemporary art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York for the last two years, has been appointed the new director of the National Portrait Gallery here, the gallery announced on Tuesday.

headline: Resolutions for a Year of Change in a Military Family
keywords: ['New Year', 'Parenting', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: With deployment hanging over our heads, 2015 will come with incredible challenges for our marriage, our children and ourselves. I’m resolving to take care of myself as well as my children, accept help when we need it, give it where we can and appreciate our beautiful mess.
lead_paragraph: I’ve never cared much for New Year’s resolutions. Mostly, I subscribe to the mentality that if you want to make a change in your life, you don’t need a specific date to do it. This year, however, I’m giving it a chance, hoping that “if I write it down,” I’ll be more inclined to commit.

headline: Everything Must Go! Knicks Start Over, Again

headline: Jeb Bush’s Mission Statement, in Translation
abstract: First Draft reads between the lines of the mission statement for Jeb Bush’s new PAC, “Right to Rise.”
lead_paragraph: In which First Draft reads between the lines of the mission statement for Jeb Bush’s new PAC, Right to Rise.We believe passionately that the Right to Rise — to move up the income ladder based on merit, hard work and earned success — is the central moral promise of American economic life.Besides paying homage to Paul Ryan, who coined the phrase “right to rise,” Mr. Bush is playing to the G.O.P.’s linguistic foundation, with words like “earned” and “merit” to telegraph a message of personal responsibility, rather than government help.

lead_paragraph: In the end there were the words, and the words were the son’s, and the words were about his father, former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

headline: Newport Panel Approves Visitor Center for the Breakers
abstract: A new visitor center at the Breakers mansion in Newport, R.I., cleared a near final hurdle on Monday when the zoning authorities there gave their approval to the plan.
lead_paragraph: A controversial visitor center proposed for the grounds of the Gilded Age Vanderbilt mansion, the Breakers, was approved by the Newport, R.I., Zoning Board of Review on Monday.

headline: Detroit Institute of Arts Meets Bankruptcy Plan Fund-Raising Goal
abstract: The museum announced that it had secured pledges from donors to meet its fund-raising obligation as part of an agreement under Detroit’s federal bankruptcy plan.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit Institute of Arts – whose world-class collection was saved last year in an agreement that kept it intact under Detroit’s federal bankruptcy plan – announced Monday that it had secured enough pledges from donors to meet a $100-million obligation as its part of the agreement, known as the “grand bargain.”

headline: Have You Noticed the Decline in Arrests and Tickets in New York City?
abstract: We’re looking for stories of how the drop in police activity has affected the people and neighborhoods of New York City. If you’ve noticed the decline, please share your stories.
lead_paragraph: The number of arrests and tickets has fallen sharply in New York City for the second straight week, J. David Goodman and Al Baker reported. Police statistics showed that some precincts recorded not even a single parking ticket, traffic summons or ticket for a low-level crime like public urination or drinking.

headline: Boehner Fends Off Dissent as G.O.P. Takes the Reins
abstract: Representative John A. Boehner beat back a challenge to his speakership from aggrieved conservatives as Republicans assumed control of both houses of Congress, pledging to restore function and civility.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative John A. Boehner beat back an embarrassing challenge to his speakership from aggrieved conservatives on Tuesday as Republicans assumed control of both houses of Congress, pledging to restore function and civility to a body that has become a symbol of disorder for most Americans.

headline: How Amy Adams Overcame Her Resistance to ‘Big Eyes’
abstract: The actress was looking to play tough, confident characters, and that didn’t seem to describe Margaret Keane, the real-life artist at the center of the story.
lead_paragraph: Amy Adams has played the real-life aspiring culinarist Julie Powell in “Julie & Julia” (2009); Charlene Fleming, another real person, in “The Fighter” (2010); and Sydney Prosser, who is based on the Englishwoman Evelyn Knight, in “American Hustle” (2013).

headline: Suicide Bomber in Istanbul Kills Officer at Police Station
abstract: In the second attack on the police in the city in a week, a woman killed one officer and wounded another after detonating explosives under her coat.

headline: Wanted: Better Basketball for a Beleaguered Reporter
abstract: It is only merciful to give The Times’s Knicks beat writer, Scott Cacciola, a break from such a woeful team. But where should he be sent to write about good hoops?
lead_paragraph: The Knicks, in an effort to rebuild through the N.B.A. draft and free agency, appear to have officially given up on this season. They’re an unthinkable 5-32, and on Monday night they traded away J. R. Smith and Iman Shumpert, leaving a roster that might struggle against an N.B.A. Development League team.

headline: Long a College Town, Worcester Now Looks the Part
abstract: Local colleges and universities have both spurred and assisted in the redevelopment of central Worcester, Mass.
lead_paragraph: WORCESTER, Mass. — Although College of the Holy Cross was founded here in 1843, and eight other prominent institutions of higher learning followed, it has taken most of the last two centuries for this sizable New England city to consider itself a college town.

headline: Same-Sex Pairs in Florida Say Jubilant ‘I Dos’
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Only six years ago, Florida passed a constitutional amendment ban on gay marriage, garnering 62 percent of the vote.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Wedding ceremonies began and ended in the middle of the night in Fort Lauderdale and Key West, and hundreds of other marriages played out under blue skies in Miami Beach and Orlando, as Florida completed its long, arduous journey Tuesday to become the 36th state to legalize same-sex marriage.

headline: Jitters After Bitcoin Exchange Suspends Services
keywords: ['Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: Bitstamp, a popular Bitcoin exchange, said on Tuesday that some of its virtual wallets were compromised on Sunday and that it had lost roughly 19,000 Bitcoins, worth about $5 million.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest Bitcoin exchanges suspended services on Tuesday, prompting unease in a virtual currency industry already scarred by the collapse last year of Mt. Gox, once its most prominent exchange.

headline: Same-Sex Couples Marry in Florida
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Now the nation’s third largest state, Florida became the 36th state to allow same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: Now the nation’s third largest state, Florida became the 36th state to allow same-sex marriage.

headline: 1965: Congo May Hire African Troops
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Congo planned to hire African troops in 1965.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congolese Premier Moise Tshombe is considering hiring African soldiers dismissed from the French Army, it was reported today. Authoritative sources said the Africans, if hired, would replace the white mercenaries employed by Mr. Tshombe in his fight against Congolese rebels. The Africans Mr. Tshombe reportedly is considering hiring are well-trained, disciplined men who have been without jobs since the reduction of French forces in Africa. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 7, 1965

headline: The Jeb Bush Optimism Challenge
abstract: His new mission statement is positive, negative and confusing about the state of the American Dream.
lead_paragraph: In preparation for his 2016 attempt to become the third of his name in the White House, former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush has launched a new PAC called “Right to Rise.” Michael Barbaro has ably “translated” Mr. Bush’s mission statement on First Draft, but I wanted to call attention to an apparent contradiction.

headline: The Child-Averse Sperm Donor
abstract: I could lose a finger or two and still count on one hand the number of kids I’ve had more than a passing conversation with in my life. What if I can’t connect with children, even those that share my biological imprint?
lead_paragraph: I hadn’t even fastened my seatbelt before the woman next to me tapped me on my shoulder. “I just have to show you something!” she exclaimed. Just my luck, I thought. Not only was I stuck in the middle seat on a five-hour red-eye, but now I also had to deal with Chatty Cathy here the whole flight home.

headline: Obama’s Choice for Fed Is a Nod to Smaller Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Pressed by the community banking industry, the White House chose a former chief of Bank of Hawaii to join the Fed’s Board of Governors.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said on Tuesday that he would nominate Allan R. Landon, the former chief executive of one of the largest banks in Hawaii, to a seat on the Federal Reserve’s Board of Governors.

headline: With Desks Shuffled, a New G.O.P. Senate Is Seated
abstract: The new Senate was seated with the usual ceremony just after noon today as 13 new members were sworn in and Senator Mitch McConnell assumed the majority leader position.
lead_paragraph: The new Senate was seated with the usual ceremony just after noon today as 13 new members were sworn in and Senator Mitch McConnell assumed the majority leader position.

headline: So Many Earth-Like Planets, So Few Telescopes
keywords: ['Planets', 'Telescopes and Observatories', 'Kepler Space Telescope', 'Space and Astronomy']
abstract: Scientists have found more new planets orbiting their stars that look a lot like Earth. The next question: how to study them more closely.
lead_paragraph: It’s a big universe, but it’s full of small planets.

headline: Alcohol Poisoning Kills 6 Americans a Day, a Federal Report Finds
abstract: The report by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found that the death rates were highest among middle-aged men, Native Americans and Native Alaskans.
lead_paragraph: Six Americans die from alcohol poisoning daily on average, and mortality rates are highest among middle-aged men, federal health authorities reported on Tuesday.

headline: A Final Tribute to Mario Cuomo
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York spoke at the funeral service for his father, which was held at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York spoke at the funeral service for his father, which was held at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan.

headline: Fear Spread Through Ranks as Officers’ Shootings Seemed Like an Ambush
abstract: Before the complete story emerged, a police shooting in the Bronx on Monday stoked fears in a department still shaken by the December killings of two officers.
lead_paragraph: Word spread in a flurry of messages across the Police Department: two officers shot, conditions unknown.

headline: The Year in Market Doublespeak
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Executive Compensation', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The last 12 months saw above-average creativity in saying one thing and meaning another. John Foley and Rob Cox of Reuters Breakingviews offer 10 euphemisms they would most like to disappear.
lead_paragraph: As the market perpetually shifts, so do the rhetorical stylings its players use to talk their way out of problems. The past year saw above-average creativity when it came to saying one thing and meaning another. Here, Reuters Breakingviews offers 10 euphemisms we’d most like to see disappear.

headline: Recipe for a Small Planet
abstract: Astronomers have found a recipe for rocky, Earth-like planets orbiting other stars.
lead_paragraph: Astronomers have found a recipe for rocky, Earth-like planets orbiting other stars.

headline: The Record of Austerity
abstract: Stuff happens, but the world looks Keynesian.
lead_paragraph: Let me jump right in here. How many people, I wonder — even among economists who have eagerly taken sides in the austerity debate — have a sense of what the overall picture looks like since the great turn to austerity in 2010? I don’t mean what happened in country X in year Y, which you imagine supports your position; I mean the overall shape of events across many countries and multiple years.

headline: Where Will Americans Travel in 2015?
abstract: Industry forecasters predict Mexico, Canada and Britain as top choices.
lead_paragraph: Americans today are taking less vacation time than at any point in nearly 40 years, according to an October report for the U.S. Travel Association by Oxford Economics. So where and how will we be spending our precious leisure time in 2015?

headline: Obama Invites Congressional Leaders to White House
abstract: President Obama has invited the bipartisan leadership of Congress to a meeting next Tuesday to discuss his legislative agenda for 2015.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has invited the bipartisan leadership of Congress to a meeting next Tuesday to discuss his legislative agenda for 2015 and to update congressional leaders on international issues, White House officials said.

headline: White House Says Obama Would Veto Keystone Pipeline Bill
abstract: President Obama will veto a bill authorizing construction of the Keystone XL oil pipeline if it passes Congress, his spokesman said on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: President Obama will veto a bill authorizing the construction of the Keystone XL oil pipeline if it passes Congress, his spokesman said on Tuesday, setting up a clash between the White House and the new Republican-led Congress.

headline: Forget the Cowboys. This Is Why Chris Christie Needs Texas.
abstract: Although the governor of New Jersey was widely mocked for his joy over a Dallas Cowboys victory, his actions make financial sense.
lead_paragraph: The social media reaction to Chris Christie's jubilation over a Dallas Cowboys playoff victory Sunday may be harsh and unforgiving. But there may be a political upside to Mr. Christie’s devotion to the Cowboys: campaign cash.

headline: Rocky Start in Senate as Democrats Slow G.O.P. Pipeline Plan
abstract: Relations in the new Senate got off to a rough start Tuesday as Democrats at least temporarily blocked Republican plans to convene a hearing Wednesday on the Keystone XL pipeline, the new majority’s first legislative priority.
lead_paragraph: Relations in the new Senate got off to a rough start Tuesday as Democrats at least temporarily blocked Republican plans to convene a hearing Wednesday on the Keystone XL pipeline, the new majority’s first legislative priority.

headline: A Veteran Who Captured Imaginations on D-Day Anniversary Dies at 90
abstract: Bernard Jordan became known as the “Great Escaper” after he disappeared from his nursing home and caught a ferry to France to attend the celebrations of the 70th anniversary of D-Day.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A veteran of World War II who slipped away from a nursing home in England last year to attend the celebrations of the 70th anniversary of D-Day in France has died at the age of 90.

headline: House Re-elects Boehner as Speaker
abstract: Fending off a challenge from the right wing of his party, Speaker John A. Boehner was re-elected as the top Republican in the House.
lead_paragraph: Fending off a challenge from the right wing of his party, Speaker John A. Boehner was re-elected on Tuesday as the top Republican in the House.

headline: N.B.A.’s Futility Record Seems Safe, Even From These Knicks and 76ers
abstract: The 76ers, the Timberwolves and the Knicks have managed only five wins each, spurring talk that one might break the N.B.A.’s futility mark, 9-73 by the 1972-73 Sixers.
lead_paragraph: It is already January, and three teams in the N.B.A., the Philadelphia 76ers, the Minnesota Timberwolves and the Knicks, have managed only five wins each. These teams are so woeful that there has been talk that one (or more) might break the league’s futility mark, the legendary 9-73 record of the 1972-73 Sixers.

headline: Oh, Mr. Vice President
abstract: A quip from the president.

headline: Palestinian Gets 3 Life Sentences in Killing of Israeli Teenagers
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: A court imposed the maximum penalty on a man described as logistics commander in the abduction of Eyal Yifrach, Gilad Shaar and Naftali Fraenkel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — An Israeli military court on Tuesday sentenced a Palestinian man to three life terms for his role as logistics commander in the abduction and murder of three Israeli teenagers in the occupied West Bank in June, a crucial chapter in last year’s deterioration of Israeli-Palestinian relations.

headline: Baseball Writers Elect Three Aces and a Doubles Machine
abstract: Randy Johnson, Pedro Martinez, John Smoltz and Craig Biggio were chosen for the Hall of Fame, which could help clear the logjam on the ballot.
lead_paragraph: Three ace pitchers and one durable doubles machine achieved baseball’s highest honor on Tuesday. Randy Johnson, Pedro Martinez, John Smoltz and Craig Biggio were elected to the Hall of Fame. It was the first time in 60 years that the baseball writers chose four players in the same class.

headline: Transport Group’s New Season to Feature Jackie Hoffman and John ‘Lypsinka’ Epperson in ‘Once Upon a Mattress’
abstract: The season will also include the premiere of the musical “The Blonde Streak.”
lead_paragraph: Jackie Hoffman and John “Lypsinka” Epperson will star in a Transport Group revival of the musical “Once Upon a Mattress,” the company announced on Tuesday. Ms. Hoffman will play Princess Winnifred and Mr. Epperson (whose alter ego is the drag persona Lypsinka) will be Queen Aggravain in the comic retelling of the story “The Princess and the Pea.” (Carol Burnett and Jane White played the roles in the original Broadway production in 1959.) Ms. Hoffman and Mr. Epperson will reprise their roles from a concert version of the show that Transport Group mounted in 2013 (above). The new production is set to run Nov. 29 through Jan. 3, 2016, at the Abrons Arts Center.

headline: Wall Street Regulator Plans to Scrutinize Electronic Bond Trading
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, known as Finra, said it would scrutinize whether firms that offer electronic bond trading are able to ensure they are achieving the best price for their customers.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s self-regulator plans to take a closer look at electronic trading in bonds this year, as part of an expanded review of fixed-income markets.

headline: Bone Broth
abstract: Spurred on by the popularity of the Paleo diet, bone broth is replacing chai on the morning commute.
lead_paragraph: Spurred on by the popularity of the Paleo diet, bone broth is replacing chai on the morning commute.

headline: Bones, Broth, Bliss
abstract: Nourishing stock is popping up on restaurant menus and replacing caffeine in the cups of Americans on the run.
lead_paragraph: When Michelle Tam was growing up in Menlo Park, Calif., in the 1980s, her family sipped broth with dinner every single night.

headline: Drake, AC/DC and Jack White Headline Coachella
abstract: The 2015 Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival boasts an eclectic and generation-spanning lineup.
lead_paragraph: Spanning generations, AC/DC, Jack White, and Drake will headline the 16th annual Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival across two weekends, April 10 through 12 and 17 through 19, in Indio, Calif., its organizers announced on Tuesday via Twitter.

headline: From The Upshot: One Upside to Christie’s Far-Flung Fandom
abstract: There may be a political upside to Gov. Chris Christie’s devotion to the Cowboys: campaign cash.
lead_paragraph: Forget the Cowboys. This Is Why Chris Christie Needs Texas.

abstract: The sequin-striped look the actress-writer wore at the “Girls” premiere was a typically eccentric choice.
lead_paragraph: The Star: Lena Dunham

headline: Police in India Say Politician’s Wife Was Murdered
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: The Delhi Police said Sunanda Pushkar, the wife of Shashi Tharoor, who was found dead last year in a hotel, had been poisoned, but did not identify a suspect.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Almost a year after the shocking death of Sunanda Pushkar, the glamorous wife of a well-known South Indian member of Parliament, the Delhi Police have finally decided what to call it: murder.

headline: A Secret Hidden in the Mediterranean
abstract: The people of Malta drink almost all their country’s modest wine output. A trickle makes it to England and Italy, and none is shipped to the United States.
lead_paragraph: Even the most adventuresome wine drinkers have probably never tasted a Maltese wine. How could they? The Maltese themselves drink almost all that their handful of wineries produce. A mere trickle of the country’s modest output makes it to England and Italy, and none is shipped to the United States.

abstract: The Cronut creator has plans for a bakery in SoHo with everything made to order; a place to sip craft beers in Chelsea; and more restaurant openings.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Dynastic, in a Hip-Hop Sort of Way
abstract: “Empire” is a classic ’80s-era nighttime soap opera retrofitted for the age of Jay Z and Beyoncé.
lead_paragraph: The president of the United States has extended an invitation to a state dinner. Lucious Lyon (Terrence Howard), a music industry kingpin, looks put upon. “O.K.,” he instructs his assistant, “tell Barack that, yes, but this is the last one for the next few months.” Lucious strides on, busy as a head of state with the final details for taking his record company, Empire Entertainment, public.

headline: For Freshman Lawmakers, Even the Small Stuff Is Cool
keywords: ['Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Capitol Building (Washington, DC)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It was the question echoing through the Capitol halls on Tuesday: Where’s the restroom?
lead_paragraph: It was the question echoing through the Capitol halls on Tuesday: Where’s the restroom?

headline: Farm Dinners, Winter Edition
abstract: The series Outstanding in the Field will offer farm dinners in January in Louisiana, Florida and Hawaii.
lead_paragraph: Annually, from May through early November, Jim Denevan organizes farm-based dinners in more than 30 states and Canadian provinces through his traveling pop-up party Outstanding in the Field.

headline: Jeb Bush Begins Wooing Donors for a 2016 Bid
abstract: The former Florida governor laid out a campaign rationale and opened a fund-raising apparatus for a possible presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush on Tuesday delivered a powerful message about two of the most vital ingredients in a presidential campaign, money and ideas, transforming himself from a figure who once seemed paralyzed by ambivalence over a White House run into the most forceful presence within the emerging Republican field.

headline: John Boehner’s Back
abstract: The speaker beat back a challenge.
lead_paragraph: At first blush, it might seem like a positive sign that two dozen Republicans voted against giving John Boehner another term as Speaker of the House. Congressional approval levels are at all-time lows, so it makes sense that at least that many members of Mr. Boehner’s own party thought better of giving him yet another opportunity to lead.

headline: N.C.A.A. to Allow Family Travel Aid for Top Title Games
abstract: Players’ families will be reimbursed for some travel expenses for the College Football Playoff’s title game and the men’s and women’s basketball Final Fours, the N.C.A.A. said.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Ohio State Coach Urban Meyer reiterated a theme on Tuesday that he had sounded loudly after the Buckeyes secured a spot opposite Oregon in the first College Football Playoff title game, to be played Monday. Players’ families, he said, should not have to pay to travel to Arlington, Tex., to watch those players compete for a championship.

headline: CES: F.T.C. Chairwoman Notes Concerns Raised by Connected Devices
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Privacy']
abstract: Edith Ramirez seemed to be directing her remarks at the start-ups that are making most of the products driving the so-called Internet of Things.
lead_paragraph: The head of the Federal Trade Commission on Tuesday offered a prescription for protecting consumer data collected by Internet-connected gadgets like wearable fitness trackers and “smart home” devices, previewing themes of a coming report by the agency on Internet privacy and security.

headline: CES: Visions of Cars on Autopilot
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'International Consumer Electronics Show']
abstract: A number of automakers at CES were touting their plans for self-driving cars, with some executives predicting that a completely autonomous vehicle would be manufactured within five years.
lead_paragraph: No more dancing around it: The major automakers now see a world of completely self-driving cars.

headline: Ernst Given Special Plaque by New Senate Colleagues
abstract: Senator Joni Ernst of Iowa came to national prominence last year with a bold commercial promoting her pig castrating credentials and promising to make Washington’s big spenders squeal.
lead_paragraph: Joni Ernst, the newly sworn-in Republican senator from Iowa, came to national prominence last year with a bold commercial promoting her pig castrating credentials and promising to make Washington’s big spenders squeal.

headline: What Rising Airline Fees Tell Us About the Cable Industry
keywords: ['Television', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Cable Television', 'Customer Relations', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Unbundling sounds promising, but more choice and the possibility of paying less do not necessarily translate into consumer satisfaction.
lead_paragraph: The day when people are no longer forced to pay for dozens of cable channels they never watch seems to be coming nearer. But subscribers may want to be careful what they wish for.

abstract: Stuart Weitzman, whose products are regularly on the feet of celebrities, offers Coach a chance to jazz up its reputation, Stephanie Rogan writes in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: There can be no clearer admission that Coach has exhausted the growth opportunities of its core brand than the $574 million purchase of the luxury shoemaker Stuart Weitzman.

lead_paragraph: Drawing from a mostly neutral palette, The Row’s prefall collection included long tunics and capelike jackets.

headline: Cavaliers Are a Case of Missing Identity
abstract: Cleveland, which took a pummeling Monday night, was pressed into a roster remake to pump up a record that has the team closer to being out of a playoff position than to first place.
lead_paragraph: When LeBron James was last in New York with the Cleveland Cavaliers, during an eight-game winning streak, he referred to his team as a work in progress. One month later, with the Cavaliers battered by injury and bloodied by six losses in eight games, the temptation is to call them a withering mess.

headline: Alan Dershowitz Denies Suit’s Allegations of Sex With a Minor
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Prostitution']
abstract: Mr. Dershowitz, a criminal defense lawyer who was accused along with Prince Andrew, also asked that his name be removed from the case.
lead_paragraph: A well-known criminal defense lawyer, who along with Prince Andrew has been accused of having sex with an under-age girl, has denied the allegations in a federal court filing and asked that his name be removed from the case.

headline: Video of Armed Robbery in Bronx Store
keywords: ['Robberies and Thefts', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Surveillance video shows two armed men robbing a grocery store, Yemen Deli, in the Bronx on Monday night. Two police officers were later shot nearby.
lead_paragraph: Surveillance video shows two armed men robbing a grocery store, Yemen Deli, in the Bronx on Monday night. Two police officers were later shot nearby.

headline: Producers Struggle to Fathom the Fall of Sting’s ‘The Last Ship’
abstract: The show, which will not recoup its producers’ $15 million investment, strained to attract more female theatergoers and Sting fans.
lead_paragraph: Why do some serious-minded Broadway shows flourish and others flop? Monday night’s announcement that the new musical “The Last Ship” will close on Jan. 24 after a meager four-month run, despite unusual efforts by Sting, its composer, to increase ticket sales, raises that question more than most other foundering musicals in recent years.

abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Jason Stallman, Diantha Parker and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Lawmakers in Pakistan Approve Military Tribunals
abstract: A constitutional amendment significantly expanded the army’s power during a period of political unrest in the civilian government.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s Parliament passed a constitutional amendment on Tuesday that allows a parallel system of military courts to try Islamist militants, significantly enlarging the army’s power during a period of political unrest in the civilian government.

headline: Anna Kendrick’s Beauty Routine, Complete With ‘Schmancy-Schmancy’ Lip Cream
abstract: Ms. Kendrick, who plays Cinderella in the musical film “Into the Woods,” buys fragrance for the special times in her life and dreams of Keira Knightley’s eyebrows.
lead_paragraph: An Academy Award and Tony Award nominee, Anna Kendrick is known for her roles in film (“Up in the Air,” “Pitch Perfect” and the “Twilight Saga” movies) and theater (“High Society”). She is also quite the Twitter star, issuing pithy pronouncements — “I’m so humble it’s crazy. I’m like the Kanye West of humility” — to her three million followers. She plays Cinderella in the musical film “Into the Woods,” which is nominated for a Golden Globe in the best motion picture, musical or comedy category. A native of Portland, Me., Ms. Kendrick, 29, lives in Los Angeles. BEE SHAPIRO

headline: Boehner and Pelosi Embrace
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: John A. Boehner of Ohio, the re-elected Speaker of the House, and Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, as the new Republican-led Congress convened.
lead_paragraph: John A. Boehner of Ohio, the re-elected Speaker of the House, and Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, as the new Republican-led Congress convened.

headline: Meet Norway’s Bernhoft, the Year’s Most Unlikely Grammy Nominee
abstract: The Norwegian ex-rocker earned a Best R&B album nod for “Islander,” becoming the first non-American to be nominated in the category’s 20-year history.
lead_paragraph: With his oversize Buddy Holly glasses, trim suits and carefully coiffed hair, 38-year-old Jarle Bernhoft certainly looks the part of fledgling R&B star. The rest of his story, however, is more unexpected. Before breaking through last year with the release of “Islander,” a silky-smooth mash-up of disco grooves and soaring falsetto melodies that gracefully picks up the neo-soul torch Robin Thicke so clumsily dropped last year, the Oslo native toiled in Norway for years as the frontman for the rock bands Explicit Lyrics and Span. After a string of successes with the latter — “It wasn’t massive, but we were pretty big in Norway,” he says — the singer was left to rethink his path after the band dissolved in 2005.

headline: A Sublime Touch, From Head to Heel
abstract: Three Indian dancers exemplify the qualities that have often made Odissi seem the most sensuously poetic of all dance idioms.
lead_paragraph: CHENNAI, India — Who are the greatest dancers in the world today? Most of the contenders considered in the West for this category are the roving international stars of ballet. But many of today’s finest dance artists have been performing here at the Music Academy’s weeklong dance festival, which ends on Friday. Some — all women — have touched on the sublime.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
abstract: New York and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: New York and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Pictures of the Day — Jan. 6, 2015
abstract: Photos from New York, China, Afghanistan and Bulgaria.
lead_paragraph: Photos from New York, China, Afghanistan and Bulgaria.

headline: Greenhill Hires Energy Lawyer as Vice Chairman
abstract: Joseph C. Dilg, a longtime deal maker for the energy sector, was the managing partner of the law firm Vinson & Elkins from 2002 until 2011.
lead_paragraph: The investment banking firm Greenhill & Company said on Tuesday that it had hired Joseph C. Dilg, a veteran deal maker in the energy industry, as a vice chairman in its Houston office.

headline: A Message to New York City From Mario Cuomo, Through His Son
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo said his father would have asked the city to come together and stop the negative energy.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo gave one of the more poignant speeches of his career Tuesday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan, a eulogy for his father, former Gov. Mario Cuomo. It was full of humanity, wit and self-deprecation — qualities not always on display with this intensely political governor.

headline: Oh, to Have the ’90s, and All Those Bad Judgment Calls, Back
abstract: In “Hindsight,” a new series on VH1, Laura Ramsey plays a woman who wakes up in 1995 with a sure sense of how to fix her life.
lead_paragraph: “Hindsight,” a clever, affecting and sly new show about bad choices begetting worse ones, begins somewhere near the intersection of romance and horror. On the eve of her second wedding, to a onetime childhood friend turned midlife paramour, Becca (Laura Ramsey) blacks out in a New York elevator and wakes up back in 1995, on the eve of her first wedding, to a set of oily abdominals named Sean (Craig Horner). Sean has an appealing Australian accent, and looks like an extra from “Singles”: He is, of course, a tortured artist. The new guy is, of course, neither of those things.

headline: Streit’s Matzo Factory, a Piece of Lower East Side History, Is Moving On
keywords: ['Kosher Foods and Products', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Passover', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Family Business', 'Matzoh']
abstract: Streit’s has been an anchor in the neighborhood, but aging equipment and competition mean another longstanding outlet of Jewish food will disappear.
lead_paragraph: The grandchildren and great-grandchildren of the people who abandoned the squalor of the Lower East Side tenements have been moving back into those very same buildings, paying sums like $3,000 to rent apartments that a few decades before went for under $50, turning the neighborhood into one of New York City’s hippest.

headline: A Beach House on Ambergris Caye
abstract: On the Caribbean coast of Belize’s largest island, this five-bedroom home is on the market for $995,000.
lead_paragraph: On the Caribbean coast of Belize’s largest island, this five-bedroom home is on the market for $995,000.

headline: Mexico’s Leader, Peña Nieto, Praises Obama on Immigration
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Deportation', 'Mexican-Americans', 'United States International Relations', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Visiting the White House, President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico said President Obama’s plan to shield immigrants from deportation was “an act of justice.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mexico’s president, Enrique Peña Nieto, on Tuesday praised the steps President Obama has taken to shield millions of unauthorized immigrants from deportation, describing them as “an act of justice” after meeting with Mr. Obama at the White House.

headline: Why McDonald’s Isn’t Shake Shack and Probably Shouldn’t Be
abstract: Wall Street wants McDonald’s to be more like Shake Shack, which has filed for an I.P.O., but the burger chains are not the same and serve different types of customers.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street wants McDonald’s to be more like Shake Shack, the hamburger purveyor in New York that just filed for an initial public offering that could value it at a billion dollars. But perhaps instead, Wall Street should let McDonald’s be McDonald’s and be careful about whether Shake Shack is a burger bubble.

headline: Taking Time to Mine Portraits
abstract: Sean Hawkey figured out a way to distinguish himself, making portraits of miners using silver they mined themselves.
lead_paragraph: Sean Hawkey figured out a way to distinguish himself, making portraits of miners using silver they mined themselves.

headline: Gates Foundation Uses Art to Encourage Vaccination
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Art', 'Philanthropy', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Artists are collaborating on a Gates Foundation project to raise awareness, and money, for an effort to vaccinate children in undeveloped countries.
lead_paragraph: Artists, it’s fair to say, usually don’t know much about bacteria. Vik Muniz is an exception. Mr. Muniz, the Brazilian-born photographer known for his unorthodox materials, has been working with the M.I.T. bioengineer and designer Tal Danino on a series of trompe l’oeil images of microscopic organisms: cancer cells, healthy cells and bacteria.

headline: The Symbiotic Evolution of ‘Partita’ and Ensemble
abstract: Seven of Roomful of Teeth’s members have sung or still sing in Julian Wachner’s Choir of Trinity Wall Street, so the concert was both a homecoming and a demonstration of possibilities.
lead_paragraph: There aren’t many words among the sighs, belts and purrs of Caroline Shaw’s vocal octet “Partita” (2009-12), and at first hearing they sound like gibberish. Take these, purloined from Sol LeWitt’s “Wall Drawing 305”: “The eighty-sixth, eighty-seventh and eighty-eighth points are located symmetrically across the central vertical axis of the wall.” It’s about lines and connections, words that in Ms. Shaw’s “Passacaglia” movement disappear into a thicket of nonsensical sibilance as eight speakers overlap.

headline: Fleeting Sweetness, and Pits
abstract: Mary Testa shows she can belt à la Ethel Merman and intertwine the music of devastation with that of utter joy.
lead_paragraph: A gentle reminder to hedge fund managers everywhere: “The sweet things in life to you were just loaned/So how can you lose what you never owned.” These words from “Life Is Just a Bowl of Cherries” have never sounded more pertinent than in our new gilded age. This breezy but profound standard was introduced by Ethel Merman in 1931, and it was a latter-day Merman, the brass-knuckled belter Mary Testa, who punched it out as the opening salvo of her terrific show, “Have Faith,” at the Laurie Beechman Theater on Monday evening.

abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: A Conversation With Daniel Miller, President of Fundrise
abstract: Mr. Miller, 27, started Fundrise, a real estate crowdfunding website, with his brother, who serves as the chief executive.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Miller, 27, is the president of Fundrise, a real estate crowdfunding website that he founded with his brother Benjamin, the chief executive. Fundrise has its headquarters in Washington; Mr. Miller works out of the company’s New York office.

headline: No Justice, No Police
abstract: Call this what it is: a reckless, coordinated escalation of a war between the police unions and Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio has been in office barely a year, and already forces of entropy are roaming the streets, turning their backs on the law, defying civil authority and trying to unravel the social fabric.

lead_paragraph: Every day, Aida Mizquiri and her children contend with numerous limitations. Fear, she said, will no longer be one of them.

abstract: The long-sought shift to “dynamic scoring” is widely seen as a way for Republican leaders to set new ground rules for an overhaul of the entire tax code.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After the drama of electing a new speaker of the House and the changing of control in the Senate, the House on Tuesday approved an obscure but significant rule change requiring the economic effects of legislation to be included in a bill’s official cost to the Treasury.

headline: How to Save Your Life
abstract: Transgender teenagers need faith in the future.
lead_paragraph: THEY placed an unlit candle in my hands. Hundreds of people sat quietly in chairs. This was at the L.G.B.T. Community Center in Greenwich Village in November, at an event called the Transgender Day of Remembrance.

headline: On Patz Juror Questionnaire, Queries About TV Shows and Mental Health History
abstract: The 22-page questionnaire is the first step in the effort to find 12 jurors for the trial of Pedro Hernandez, who is accused of killing the 6-year-old Etan Patz in 1979.
lead_paragraph: The questionnaire is longer than most job applications: 109 questions covering everything from where one attended elementary school to whether one had ever seen a psychiatrist.

abstract: Pimco has removed the quarterly investment reports of two large mutual funds from its website. The funds were managed by William H. Gross before he was forced to leave the firm last year.
lead_paragraph: The bond giant Pimco has removed from its website the quarterly investment reports of two large mutual funds that were managed by William H. Gross before he was forced to leave the firm last year.

headline: The Man or the Moment
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The architect of the Great Society wasn’t anything like the current president. But a new book suggests that their times, not their talents, tell the real story.
lead_paragraph: We measure our presidents against not only our hopes for the present, which are sometimes unreasonable, but also our understanding of the past, which can be just as flawed.

headline: As Vote Nears, Astrologer for Sri Lanka’s President Faces Ultimate Test of His Skills
abstract: President Mahinda Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka faces a serious election challenge, and his astrologer, who acts as spiritual adviser and political consultant, is wary of bad results.
lead_paragraph: GALLE, Sri Lanka — Few people will be watching this week’s presidential election in Sri Lanka with more pointed interest than a balding, prosperous-looking man wearing a gold amulet under his shirt, who claims the title of “royal astrologer.”
