headline: Atlanta Ousts Fire Chief Who Has Antigay Views
abstract: Kelvin Cochran wrote and gave workers copies of his book, in which he wrote that homosexuality was among “vile, vulgar and inappropriate” activities.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Mayor Kasim Reed announced Tuesday that he had fired the chief of the city’s Fire Rescue Department, Kelvin Cochran, after Mr. Cochran gave workers a religious book he wrote containing passages that condemn homosexuality.

headline: Utah: Rope-Swinging on Rock Arches Is Banned
abstract: Federal land officials on Tuesday announced new restrictions on rope-swinging from giant natural rock arches in the desert canyonlands outside Moab.
lead_paragraph: Federal land officials on Tuesday announced new restrictions on the daredevil pursuit of rope-swinging from giant natural rock arches in the desert canyonlands outside the tourist destination of Moab. The Bureau of Land Management placed a two-year ban on activities including zip-lining, rope-swinging and rappelling. The move came after a handful of serious accidents and dozens of complaints from hikers and tourists, who said that the screams and whoops of swinging adrenaline junkies were ruining a tranquil natural setting.

headline: Climatologists Balk as Brazil Picks Skeptic for Key Post
abstract: The appointment comes as Brazil is seeking to assert leadership in global talks and as scientists are questioning the nation’s commitment to reducing deforestation.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Calling Aldo Rebelo a climate-change skeptic would be putting it mildly. In his days as a fiery legislator in the Communist Party of Brazil, he railed against those who say human activity is warming the globe and called the international environmental movement “nothing less, in its geopolitical essence, than the bridgehead of imperialism.”

headline: Missouri: Tear Gas Restrictions Extended
abstract: A judge in St. Louis granted a 45-day extension to an order barring the police from using tear gas unless they provide a warning, give peaceful demonstrators time to leave and try to minimize the impact of the tear gas.
lead_paragraph: A judge in St. Louis granted a 45-day extension to an order she issued in December that bars the police from using tear gas unless they provide a warning, give peaceful demonstrators time to leave and try to minimize the impact of the tear gas. Judge Carol. E. Jackson of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri took the action Tuesday after lawyers for protesters and law enforcement said they needed more time to negotiate policy changes regarding the gas. The issue arose during unrest after the shooting in August of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer in Ferguson.

headline: Soaring Bond Prices May Sound an Economic Warning
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Government Bonds', 'Interest Rates', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The bond market is flashing warning signs as higher prices create lower yields.
lead_paragraph: The United States economy is accelerating, unemployment is falling and wages are even beginning to creep higher.

headline: Mike Piazza’s Turn for Election Could Be Next
abstract: Piazza, a former Dodgers and Mets catcher in his third year on the Hall ballot, finished fifth in the voting results disclosed on Tuesday, just short of being chosen.
lead_paragraph: Now on deck for the Hall of Fame is Mike Piazza, who finished a strong fifth in the voting results disclosed on Tuesday, with the support of nearly 70 percent of the baseball writers who submitted ballots.

headline: Intel Allocates $300 Million for Workplace Diversity
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Minorities', 'Women and Girls', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The fund is intended to help attract more women and minorities to the technology field and make the industry more hospitable to them once they get there.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the last year, Apple, Google and other big technology companies have faced mounting criticism by civil rights leaders about the lack of diversity in their work forces, which are populated mostly by white and Asian men.

headline: Mercedes to Move U.S. Headquarters From New Jersey to Georgia
abstract: The German automaker said on Tuesday that it would move its headquarters to Georgia from Montvale, N.J., marking another corporate employer to leave Bergen County for the South.
lead_paragraph: In the latest blow to New Jersey, which is still staggering from the recession, Mercedes-Benz USA said on Tuesday that it would move its headquarters to Georgia from Montvale, N.J.

headline: The 114th Congress Brushes Off the Snow and Gets Its Bearings
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: The 114th Congress began its first day with receptions, ceremonies, some joking and even some moments of actual government work.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As members of the 114th Congress trudged to work Tuesday amid wet white flurries and congressional formalities, the Capitol felt both like the first day of school and a potential snow day.

headline: Fighter Defects, Citing Ties to the Fugitive African Warlord Joseph Kony
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Officials are trying to confirm the identity of a man who claims to be a senior commander in the Lord’s Resistance Army, which is led by Joseph Kony in central Africa.
lead_paragraph: A man claiming to be a senior commander in the Lord’s Resistance Army, the ruthless renegade guerrilla organization in central Africa led by Joseph Kony, the fugitive warlord, has surrendered to a joint military task force of the United States and the African Union, a State Department spokeswoman said Tuesday in Washington.

headline: Anti-Immigration Movement in Germany Reignites Debate Over National Identity
abstract: The marches in Dresden have galvanized both proponents and opponents in Germany and raised anew a question the country has long grappled with: Who is German?
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The appearance of thousands of anti-immigrant marchers in Dresden has galvanized both sides of the immigration debate in Germany and reignited a discussion about national identity.

headline: Life in New York City, Where Arrests Are Down and Tickets Are Rarities
abstract: With the police arresting half as many people and giving more than 90 percent fewer tickets, some residents were relieved while others feared for their safety.
lead_paragraph: In a city of more than eight million people and 33 million subway rides a week, police officers arrested or ticketed just 22 people for jumping the turnstile last week. In the same period a year ago, nearly 1,400 fare-beaters were caught.

headline: Florida Joins the Wave on Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Now that more than 70 percent of Americans live in places that have legalized marriage equality, the Supreme Court needs to decide whether to make it legal nationally.
lead_paragraph: Now that Florida has become the 36th state to allow same-sex couples to marry, more than 70 percent of Americans live in jurisdictions that permit such unions. What’s made this possible is a string of supportive federal court rulings following the Supreme Court’s pivotal 2013 decision striking down provisions of the Defense of Marriage Act — the 1996 federal law that denied federal benefits to lawfully married same-sex couples.

headline: Ban on Cellphones in New York City Schools to Be Lifted
abstract: The policy, which has been inconsistently enforced, has been unpopular among parents, who worry about not being able to reach their children.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s Department of Education plans to announce on Wednesday that it will lift the ban on cellphones in schools, a person familiar with the decision said Tuesday.

headline: To Gov. Jerry Brown, a Legacy Project; to Critics, a Runaway Train
abstract: The California governor attended a decidedly ceremonial groundbreaking for his high-speed train, a defiant and defining act for Mr. Brown as he enters his final term.
lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif. — One day after being sworn in to a final term as governor, Jerry Brown, a chief executive who tends to disdain the trappings of political ceremony, came to this Central Valley city on Tuesday for a decidedly ceremonial groundbreaking for his Los Angeles-to-San Francisco high-speed train — a defiant and defining act for Mr. Brown as he enters his final stretch in public life.

headline: New Hall of Fame Class Is the Biggest in 60 Years
abstract: The last time four baseball players were inducted in a year was 1955. This year’s crop is partly the result of the eligibility of a group of stars who retired at the same time.
lead_paragraph: When writers elected Randy Johnson, Pedro Martinez, John Smoltz and Craig Biggio to the Baseball Hall of Fame on Tuesday, it was only the third time a four-man class was created.

headline: Time for a Pause
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Books and Literature', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: Rising cybercrime is roiling and reshaping today’s world before we’ve learned to adjust. How does anyone adapt?
lead_paragraph: You could easily write a book, or, better yet, make a movie about the drama that engulfed Sony Pictures and “The Interview,” Sony’s own movie about the fictionalized assassination of North Korea’s real-life dictator. The whole saga reflects so many of the changes that are roiling and reshaping today’s world before we’ve learned to adjust to them.

headline: Losing the Tea Party Baggage
abstract: Senator Cory Gardner’s successful campaign in Colorado provides a template for the Republican future.
lead_paragraph: With the demographic composition of the electorate rapidly changing, what is the best way for Republicans in diverse states to campaign? The election in November of Senator Cory Gardner of Colorado provides a template for the party on how to succeed in a battleground state with two ascendant constituencies: well-educated social liberals and increasingly assertive Hispanic voters.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 6, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Do Immigrants Take Jobs From American-Born Workers?
abstract: Do immigrants take  jobs away from lower-paid working-class natives or has that threat to  economic stability been exaggerated?

headline: Hank Peters, 90, Dies; Built Baseball Winners in Baltimore and Cleveland
abstract: Mr. Peters won a World Series as general manager of the Baltimore Orioles and helped rejuvenate the Cleveland Indians.
lead_paragraph: Hank Peters, a longtime baseball executive who won two pennants and a World Series as general manager of the Baltimore Orioles before helping to rejuvenate the Cleveland Indians franchise, died on Sunday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 90.

headline: With Veto Threat, Obama and Congress Head for Collision Over Keystone Pipeline
keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'Pipelines', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Vetoes (US)']
abstract: The White House on Tuesday made it clear that President Obama would veto a bill authorizing construction of the Keystone XL oil pipeline, setting up a clash with Republicans just as they assume control of Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House on Tuesday made it clear that President Obama would veto a bill authorizing construction of the Keystone XL oil pipeline, setting up an immediate clash with Republicans just as they assume control of Congress.

headline: Effort on Ebola Hurt W.H.O. Chief
abstract: Critics of Margaret Chan have said she lets governments around the world steer the W.H.O. to fit their own needs, instead of firmly taking the helm as the world’s doctor in chief.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Under a stormy sky, on a boat to a G-8 summit meeting, a media-savvy Hong Kong pediatrician named Margaret Chan first met her country’s president, Hu Jintao. In a preview of the political maneuvering to come, he told her privately that China was considering backing her for the top post at the World Health Organization.

headline: As Power in Congress Shifts to G.O.P., Lives of Freshmen in Transition
abstract: The new Congress members arrived eager and optimistic, even though some had not found places to live and were having challenges finding where they needed to go in the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three hours after he was sworn in as a new member of Congress on Tuesday, Representative Ted Lieu, Democrat of California, stood outside the House chamber looking bewildered as a colleague breezed past him, asking, “Where’s Nancy’s thing?” — a reference to the opening day open house of Nancy Pelosi, the Democratic leader.

headline: Friendship Frays, a Topic at a Time
abstract: “Winners and Losers,” at Soho Rep, is a frisky theatrical symposium in which two friends categorize all manner of people and things.
lead_paragraph: Americans are often accused of having a mania for competition, of seeing the world through a prism of success and failure. But “Winners and Losers,” a frisky theatrical symposium in which all manner of people and things are categorized as one or the other, is created and performed by — what’s this? — two Canadians.

headline: Maze Runner
abstract: Run through Greg Johnson’s twisty puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Win Valuable Prizes Alert! “The Enigma Variations” is a puzzle suite contest being run by George Barany and friends, which includes multiple fun prizes. Solve the suite and you can win puzzle books (some autographed) and subscriptions, and if you put everything together and successfully solve the meta that ties the suite together, you might win a paid registration to the 2015 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament. This contest ends on January 11 at midnight, P.S.T., so get solving.

headline: Postal Chief Says Congress and Unions Block Progress
abstract: Patrick R. Donahoe’s comments drew a heated response from postal union leaders, who said he was responsible for continuing financial problems.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Critical changes needed to turn around the financially troubled United States Postal Service have been held up by Congress and by opposition from postal labor unions that want to preserve jobs and benefits, the postmaster general said Tuesday.

headline: Reports of Civilian Deaths Prompt Inquiry Into Strikes Against ISIS
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The United States military has begun looking into two instances in which coalition airstrikes against the Sunni militancy known as the Islamic State may have inadvertently hit civilians.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States military is investigating reports of civilian casualties that may have occurred as part of the American-led fight against the Sunni militancy known as the Islamic State, a senior Pentagon official said Tuesday.

headline: North Korea Has Made ‘Significant’ Advances in Nuclear Arms Program, South Says
abstract: According to a Defense Ministry white paper, North Korea appears to have made progress toward making a nuclear warhead small enough to fit onto a missile capable of reaching the West Coast.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The Defense Ministry of South Korea said Tuesday that North Korea appeared to have made a “significant” advance toward making a nuclear warhead small enough to fit onto a long-range missile capable of reaching the West Coast of the United States. The ministry, which included the assessment in its latest white paper, also suggested that the North now had a missile that could fly that far.

headline: Knicks Bet Firmly on the Future, Which Is Anything but Firm
abstract: With this season’s monumental collapse, rebuilding through free agency and the draft may become the team’s new mantra.
lead_paragraph: On a Friday afternoon in late September, Phil Jackson sat on a dais at the Knicks’ training site in Greenburgh, N.Y. He wore a gray suit and a smile as he answered questions from reporters about the season ahead. It was a time for cautious optimism and quiet expectations.

headline: Rangers Find Top Form, but a Tough Trip Looms
abstract: Winners of 10 of their last 11 games, the Rangers are confident as they head west to play in three arenas that haunted them last season.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Winners of 10 of their past 11 games, the Rangers are a confident group heading west to play in three arenas that haunted them last season.

headline: Egyptian Leader Visits Coptic Christmas Eve Service
abstract: The state news media declared President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi the first Egyptian president to attend such a service.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi on Tuesday visited the main Coptic Christian cathedral during its Christmas Eve Mass, and the Egyptian state news media declared him the first Egyptian president to attend such a service.

headline: New York State Legislature Will Convene Amid a Changed Political Landscape
abstract: One issue lawmakers could be confronted with has been bubbling up from New York City: balancing the need for criminal-justice reform with safeguarding the police.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Clouds of controversy, intraparty sniping, the pall of the passing of an iconic leader: The 2015 New York State legislative session has everything a pessimist could ever want.

headline: Fans of Liberty State Park Leery of Proposed Agency
abstract: A plan to create a Meadowlands Regional Commission that would take final control over development from the state’s environmental department has generated concerns.
lead_paragraph: When Liberty State Park opened in 1976, it was said to be New Jersey’s bicentennial gift to the United States. Sitting at the southeastern end of Jersey City, it stretches along the Hudson River for 1,200 acres, offering a collection of stunning vistas: The Statue of Liberty seems almost within reach, and Ellis Island beckons. The waters of the Verrazano Straits and New York Harbor stretch east; the Manhattan skyline shimmers in the distance.

headline: Death of Infant Boy in East Harlem Is Ruled a Homicide
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The infant, Deion McNeil, was found on Jan. 2 on the living room floor of his family’s apartment, unconscious and bleeding from a gash on his forehead.
lead_paragraph: The death of a 23-day-old boy in East Harlem last week has been ruled a homicide, the police said on Tuesday.

headline: Revealing a Slowly Changing Cuba
abstract: Little ideology, much decay and an awakening of business were on display during a drive across the island.
lead_paragraph: Little ideology, much decay and an awakening of business were on display during a drive across the island.

headline: James Hester, 90, Dies; Guided N.Y.U. to Become a Major University
abstract: Dr. Hester steered New York University through campus unrest in the 1960s and helped chart its evolution from a commuter school on the brink of bankruptcy to a highly selective institution with national academic stature.
lead_paragraph: James M. Hester, who steered New York University through campus unrest in the 1960s and helped chart its evolution from a commuter school on the brink of bankruptcy to a highly selective institution with national academic stature, died on Dec. 31 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 90.

headline: On the Open Road, Signs of a Changing Cuba
abstract: A road trip across the island revealed a slowly changing Cuba — beautiful, tired and looking ahead.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — The signs of the times speak loudly in Cuba, sometimes through their silence.

headline: Yankees Are Said to Be Close to a Deal With Stephen Drew
abstract: The Yankees and infielder Stephen Drew were very close to finalizing a one-year, $5 million deal with incentives, according to a baseball executive with knowledge of the negotiations.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees and infielder Stephen Drew were very close to finalizing a one-year, $5 million deal with incentives Tuesday, according to a baseball executive with knowledge of the negotiations. Drew is expected to play mostly second base in 2015, as the Yankees continue to groom the prospects Jose Pirela and Rob Refsnyder.

headline: When Courtney Love Wears (and Serenades) Zac Posen
abstract: For the final number in her first opera, which opens tomorrow in New York, the iconic singer handpicked a dramatic number from the designer’s fall 2014 collection.
lead_paragraph: When the fashion designer Zac Posen first met Courtney Love in the summer of 1997, he realized that “with her, nothing is what it seems.” That couldn’t ring any truer today, as the grunge music icon prepares to star in “Kansas City Choir Boy” a provocative new opera love story about a singer and her musician boyfriend which was written by Todd Almond and opens tomorrow. And for her dramatic finale on stage, she’ll be wearing an equally spectacular number that she handpicked from Posen’s fall 2014 collection: a voluminous ball gown in black taffeta jacquard and duchesse satin (the performance space is so small that the gown balloons out over much of the floor). It’s a far cry from the baby-doll and slip dresses that make up the singer’s personal wardrobe. “I thought it was really important to do something that felt transformative for her,” Posen explains. “The first dress I had designed and draped didn’t feel right, and it just wasn’t surprising enough.”

headline: In D.C., a Vibrant New Restaurant From the Obamas’ Favorite Local Chef
abstract: China Chilcano serves dishes inspired by Asian communities in Peru in an industrial-chic, East-meets-West setting.
lead_paragraph: In the District of Columbia’s historic Penn Quarter, the newly opened China Chilcano is a departure from the usual Spanish sprawl of José Andrés, the tapas pioneer (and arguably the city’s most famous chef) who runs a mini-empire of restaurants, frequented by Barack and Michelle Obama, in the city.

headline: For Super Bowl, Anheuser-Busch Aims at Younger Crowd
abstract: Anheuser-Busch is preparing three 60-second commercials, with corresponding digital campaigns, to promote its Budweiser and Bud Light brands during this year’s game.
lead_paragraph: The Super Bowl attracts more than 100 million viewers every year. Anheuser-Busch is trying to connect with the texting and Snapchat- and Instagram-using millennials among them.

headline: ‘Whiplash’ and Those Bleeding Hands
abstract: The writer-director of the film was himself a drummer whose hands did bleed.
lead_paragraph: At 29, the New Jersey native Damien Chazelle has entered the Oscar fray with the much lauded feature he wrote and directed, “Whiplash.” Starring Miles Teller as a music-school drumming student terrorized by his sadistic teacher, played by J.K. Simmons, the film is loosely based on Mr. Chazelle’s own experience as a high school drummer. (He confirmed that as is the case of Mr. Teller’s character, his hands did bleed in those years.)

headline: How Exercise Keeps Us Young
abstract: Active older people resemble much younger people physiologically, according to a new study of the effects of exercise on aging.
lead_paragraph: Active older people resemble much younger people physiologically, according to a new study of the effects of exercise on aging. The findings suggest that many of our expectations about the inevitability of physical decline with advancing years may be incorrect and that how we age is, to a large degree, up to us.

headline: Word of the Day | subsidiary
abstract: This word has appeared in 921 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: subsidiary •\səb-ˈsi-de-ˌer-e, -ˈsi-də-re\• adjective and noun

headline: Big East Struggles of St. John’s Provide Unwelcome Reminder of Last Year
abstract: No. 8 Villanova handed the Red Storm their third straight loss and sent St. John’s to the bottom of the conference standings.
lead_paragraph: It was a hole that St. John’s proved unable to dig itself out from: five straight losses to open Big East Conference play, a lesson that players said they never wanted to repeat.

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE TALENTED MR. RIPLEY (1999) Starting with the loan of a jacket with a Princeton insignia, Tom Ripley, a New York men’s room attendant played by Matt Damon, begins his ascent of the social ladder — then murders his way up the rest of the rungs — in Anthony Minghella’s adaptation of the Patricia Highsmith thriller. Jude Law (above right, with Mr. Damon, center, and Rosario Fiorello) is Dickie Greenleaf, the scion of a rich American family, whose father has hired Tom to bring him back to the United States from Italy; Gwyneth Paltrow is Marge, who must share Dickie’s affections with his new friend. And Philip Seymour Hoffman is Freddie, who isn’t buying Tom’s act. Writing in The New York Times, Janet Maslin said the film “offers diabolically smart surprises wherever you care to look.”

abstract: The bond market may be sounding an economic warning. | Why McDonald’s isn’t Shake Shack and shouldn’t be. | Coach adds celebrity cachet with acquisition of Stuart Weitzman. | Bitcoin exchange Bitstamp suspends services after breach.
lead_paragraph: Despite signs that the United States economy is accelerating, a huge bond market with a strong track record for predicting economic problems may be sounding a warning, DealBook’s Peter Eavis reports. As they do in times of stress, investors are seeking the safety of government bonds. In turn, the prices of government bonds are rallying, pushing their yields to lows. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note, for instance, fell to 1.94 percent on Tuesday. In Europe, yields are even lower.

headline: A Young Private, Killed in World War II, Still Leaps Off the Page
keywords: ['Cemeteries', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Families and Family Life', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Grandparents', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Pvt. Richard Halvey’s death in North Africa in 1943 was a loss his family never got over, but his great-niece, Kiley Bense, has sought him out through family stories and a scrapbook containing some ephemera of his short life, including his letters home.
lead_paragraph: Pvt. Richard Halvey scribbled his last letter home in the passenger seat of an Army radio vehicle rumbling somewhere through North Africa in February 1943. He wrote on the desk built into the front of the car while his friend Ryan drove, passing across chocolate bars and sticks of gum. He complained about his warts (“I even have an idea they are bringing friends”). He asked after his driver’s license and his brother, Bob. He spoke of regret that he had to shave his mustache without taking a photo first (“Beards aren’t permitted in this company and mustache was starting to strain coffee etc so rather than have it dry cleaned I decided to dispense with it”). The last letter addressed to my grandmother, Patricia, his sister, was just a quick note about a $30 money order, later carefully pressed flat; his mistake in dating the top delicately corrected in Pat’s spindly hand.

headline: C. Wonder’s Demise: A Teachable Moment
abstract: High expectations and expensive initial investment seems to put some new brands in trouble before they have the chance to really start.
lead_paragraph: The news on Tuesday that C. Wonder, the accessibly priced, bright-’n’-busy women’s lifestyle brand started by J. Christopher Burch in 2011, had ceased operations, closing its stores, firing employees and starting to “evaluate its best alternative to maintain the C. Wonder experience for its customers,” according to an official statement (whatever that means in this context), has caused much gleeful commentary among fashion watchers about the problems with “revenge retail.”

headline: The Search for Petr Khokhlov
abstract: His brother and his girlfriend had no idea why he disappeared — or why he turned up in an online video being questioned by Ukraine’s internal security service.
lead_paragraph: After their father died and their mother fell into drink, Petr Khokhlov and his brother, Sergey, were sent to an orphanage in Novouzensk, a small, dusty town of low-slung Soviet-era apartment blocks on Russia’s border with Kazakhstan. The two boys had only each other. Petr was quiet and well behaved, scolding other students at the orphanage when they addressed their teachers with the familiar ty, rather than the more formal vy. He played the balalaika in music class and carried himself as a little gentleman, with any number of pretty girls in tow. As they grew up, Petr would consult with his older brother on just about every decision, down to what T-shirts he should buy. When Sergey was courting the woman who would later become his wife, Petr — just two years Sergey’s junior, but with a soft, boyish face that made him look even younger — would tag along on their dates to the movies and fall asleep in the back seat on the drive home.

headline: Sorrowful Quest of an Empty Kettle

lead_paragraph: L. Frank Baum’s novel “The Wonderful Wizard of Oz” (1900) certainly has dark elements, like those creepy flying monkeys, but the story is just one part of Baum’s Oz series. In 1918, he wrote the even darker back story of one character in “The Tin Woodsman of Oz.”

headline: Rachel Cusk’s ‘Outline’
abstract: The British memoirist and novelist Rachel Cusk “skews the boundary between autobiography and fiction.”
lead_paragraph: I was out to dinner recently with a man who observed of a mutual friend: “He’s a cipher. He just stands there and doesn’t speak.” He felt our friend did not pull his weight in social situations. I countered that there were participatory ways of saying nothing; that I experienced our friend’s silence as encouragement to display, for his appreciation and scrutiny, the more typically hidden parts of myself.

headline: Reaching for Beauty
abstract: Picture-book biographies of the painter Benny Andrews and the soprano Leontyne Price trace their paths from African-American childhoods in the segregated South to international acclaim.
lead_paragraph: The world has no shortage of interesting people who make a big impact without ever quite becoming household names, and lately we’ve seen a plentiful crop of picture-book biographies about some of them. Among several good recent examples are Jen Bryant and Melissa Sweet’s “The Right Word: Roget and His Thesaurus” and Jeanette Winter’s “Mr. Cornell’s Dream Boxes.” Both found a whimsical, child-friendly charm in the eccentricities of subjects few would have called ideal picture-book material: the neurotic Victorian Peter Mark Roget, who came up with the idea for the thesaurus, and the reclusive avant-garde artist Joseph Cornell, who innovated with assemblage. Two new ones are particularly welcome additions to the genre, for both their beautiful illustrations and their stirring stories: Each takes up the life of a 20th-century artist whose accomplishments are no doubt too rarefied to be already familiar to the average elementary schooler; but the subjects’ experiences growing up African-American in the segregated South, then making their ways through civil-rights-era America, give a natural storybook feel to their life trajectories.

The prince is a German submarine officer, now at Kiel, but has received a few days’ leave and will visit his fiancée. Miss Rogers is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Rogers, of Washington, D.C. Miss Rogers, who made her début in Washington three years ago, first met the prince in Cairo. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 8, 1915

headline: ‘America’s Bitter Pill,’ by Steven Brill
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Zephyr Teachout reviews Steven Brill’s new book, a guide to the maze of issues in American health care and health care reform.
lead_paragraph: Steven Brill is not easily intimidated. The founder of Court TV and Brill’s Content, among many other ventures, Brill likes to dive deeply and quickly into complicated national policy issues — public education, health care — that he, by his own admission, knows relatively little about when he begins. This is his great appeal and can be a great frustration. It makes him vulnerable to the charisma of his sources, as was apparent in his 2011 book, “Class Warfare,” in which he seemed dazzled by individuals involved in privatizing public education, while he largely ignored the existing research.

headline: Hearing Oscar Buzz In Genre-Busting Scores

headline: The Rich Tradition of Filipino Embutido
abstract: Learning to cook the rustic meatloaf in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Before she showed me how to make the egg-stuffed, raisin-speckled meatloaf of her Filipino youth, Emma Phojanakong took me to the curiously named Johnny Air Mart. It’s a Filipino store on the East Side of Manhattan near her home in Stuyvesant Town, its shelves crammed with instant Pinoy comforts: just-add-water noodle bowls with “artificial bone marrow flavor,” sugary breads folded around electric swaths of purple yam and, prominently, rows of canned meats: Pop the top, heat and eat. Nostalgia, I figured, is a hunger that wants to be fed now.

headline: Did Mitch McConnell Just Take Credit for the Economic Recovery?
abstract: The new Senate majority leader said “the uptick appears to coincide” with “the expectation of a new Republican Congress.”
lead_paragraph: The new Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell, suggested earlier today that the Republican Party deserves credit for recent data showing that the economic recovery has picked up speed. As ridiculous as that statement is, at least it is intellectually consistent with the party’s past statements. After the financial crisis, Republicans said President Obama had hurt the economy by (occasionally) criticizing Wall Street bankers for their misdeeds. Now, Mr. McConnell is claiming credit for a recovery based solely on the fact that Republicans have just taken control of both houses of Congress, even though the year has barely begun and they have not yet passed any bills.Here’s what Mr. McConnell said on the floor this morning:

headline: Among the Disrupted
abstract: Leon Wieseltier on the state of culture in the digital age.
lead_paragraph: Amid the bacchanal of disruption, let us pause to honor the disrupted. The streets of American cities are haunted by the ghosts of bookstores and record stores, which have been destroyed by the greatest thugs in the history of the culture industry. Writers hover between a decent poverty and an indecent one; they are expected to render the fruits of their labors for little and even for nothing, and all the miracles of electronic dissemination somehow do not suffice for compensation, either of the fiscal or the spiritual kind. Everybody talks frantically about media, a second-order subject if ever there was one, as content disappears into “content.” What does the understanding of media contribute to the understanding of life? Journalistic institutions slowly transform themselves into silent sweatshops in which words cannot wait for thoughts, and first responses are promoted into best responses, and patience is a professional liability. As the frequency of expression grows, the force of expression diminishes: Digital expectations of alacrity and terseness confer the highest prestige upon the twittering cacophony of one-liners and promotional announcements. It was always the case that all things must pass, but this is ridiculous.

headline: Bringing Time-Lapse Photo Studies Into Real Time, Online
abstract: The Library of Congress is putting photographs by Camilo José Vergara online, and will update the archive as he continues his time-lapse studies of sites in certain cities.
lead_paragraph: Camilo José Vergara, the Chilean-born photographer who has documented the street culture and the changing face of America’s inner cities for 40 years, agreed to place his entire photographic archive with the Library of Congress in 2013, and now more than 400 images have been digitized and put on the library’s website. This is the first step toward making more than 10,000 works available to the public.

headline: Ava DuVernay Defends the History in ‘Selma’
abstract: The filmmaker and others respond to criticism of Johnson’s portrayal.
lead_paragraph: Defenders of the historical accuracy of “Selma,” which has been questioned by assorted scholars and ex-politicos for weeks, stepped forward this week.

headline: Public Reading to Mark Release of Guantánamo Detainee’s Diary
abstract: Michael Cunningham and Lili Taylor are among those who will read from Mohamedou Ould Slahi’s “Guantánamo Diary” at the Culture Project on Jan. 26.
lead_paragraph: Michael Cunningham, Joshua Ferris, Nicole Krauss and Lili Taylor will be among the participants at a reading in New York on Jan. 26 in honor of the publication of “Guantánamo Diary,” described as the first and only diary written by a still-detained prisoner at Guantánamo Bay to be publicly released.

headline: Remembering the Lost
abstract: At many nursing homes and assisted living places, a resident’s passing may be hardly noted.
lead_paragraph: You may have noticed the discreet way in which many nursing homes and assisted living places acknowledge a resident’s death: A bud vase on the mantle or at the reception desk. A single rose. A card announcing the deceased’s name.

headline: Games Played by the Laws of Physics (Though Bent a Little in Some Cases)
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Games', 'Physics', 'Gravitation and Gravity']
abstract: While games like Angry Birds may seem to have little to do with physics, many make use of the laws of motion, materials science and gravity.
lead_paragraph: LONG before I wrote about apps for a living, I spent many years at university learning to be a physicist, and I worked as a professional scientist for a while. So I get an extra-special kick out of all the physics-based games that can be played on a smartphone.

headline: Parenting in the Age of Online Pornography
abstract: Discussing a child’s exposure to what seems unavoidable.
lead_paragraph: It had been another long day for Eliza, a 41-year-old stay-at-home mother who lives in Los Angeles with her two sons. She had taken the boys, 10 and 13 at the time, to school, taken care of the house, and after putting them to bed, planned to relax in front of her computer.

headline: When GoFundMe Is the Safety Net
abstract: Families and parents using GoFundMe for what should be small setbacks like car repairs and rent increases have been all over my social media of late.
lead_paragraph: Families and parents struggling to get out of a financial hole and hoping to use GoFundMe to help have been all over my social media of late. The single mother who graduated from high school with a baby and is now hoping to graduate from college with a 7-year-old. The military family with the broken-down car and no money for repairs, or anything else.

lead_paragraph: Whenever Republicans start talking about protecting Social Security, warning bells go off in my head.

lead_paragraph: The assault on the Paris offices of Charlie Hebdo, a French newspaper that has repeatedly satirized religion, was one of the deadliest in a history of violent responses and threats against the news media over the mockery of Islam.

headline: Many ‘Healthy Obese’ Don’t Stay Healthy
abstract: A small study challenges the notion that you can be obese and healthy in the long run.
lead_paragraph: The idea of “healthy obesity” — that there are obese people who are nevertheless in good health, with normal cholesterol levels, blood pressure and other metabolic risk factors — has gained traction in recent years. But a small study suggests this apparently healthy state of affairs does not last.

headline: 1965: Gunman Caught After Chase
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1965: Gunman, John Marson, caught after chase.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Unarmed police captured a dangerous gunman last night [Jan. 7] after cornering him in a basement club and felling him with a barrage of stones, bottles and chairs. But before being captured, the gunman injured two policemen and killed an Alsatian police dog. The gunman, identified as John Marson, a 22-year-old jailbreaker, was charged today with attempted murder. His capture last night took place after he had forced a restaurant owner into a white Mercedes sportscar and led 14 London police cars and motorcycles on a 100-mile-per-hour chase back and forth across the bridges over the River Thames.— New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 8, 1965

headline: 36 Hours in Milan
abstract: New energy courses through cosmopolitan Milan, site of this year’s World Expo, with new bars, shops, restaurants and cultural centers adding to the allure of this most international of Italian cities.
lead_paragraph: New energy courses through cosmopolitan Milan, site of this year’s World Expo, with new bars, shops, restaurants and cultural centers adding to the allure of this most international of Italian cities.

headline: Classical Playlist: Beethoven, Brahms, John Luther Adams and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: BEETHOVEN, BRAHMS, WEBER Jon Manasse, clarinetist; Jon Nakamatsu, pianist; Clive Greensmith, cellist (Harmonia Mundi) The clarinetist Jon Manasse, the pianist Jon Nakamatsu and the cellist Clive Greensmith open this disc with Beethoven’s Trio in B flat (Op. 11), Mr. Nakamatsu’s fleet-fingered clarity enhancing the vivacious outer movements and all three playing with deep expression in the Adagio. Mr. Manasse demonstrates a lovely, limpid tone throughout, such as in the second movement of Weber’s Grand Duo Concertant in E flat (Op. 48). Also included on the disc is a passionate rendition of Brahms’s autumnal Trio in A minor (Op. 114). (Vivien Schweitzer)

headline: For First Time, F.D.A. Panel Approves Generic Copy of Costly Biologic Drug
abstract: The group of experts endorsed a close version of the cancer drug Neupogen, which could open the door to more such biosimilar medicines.
lead_paragraph: SILVER SPRING, Md. — An expert panel unanimously recommended on Wednesday that the Food and Drug Administration approve a cheaper copy of a special drug used in cancer therapy, paving the way for alternatives to an entire class of complex and costly drugs to enter the United States market.

headline: 36 Hours in Milan
abstract: The new energy coursing through the city can be enjoyed even before this year’s World Expo.
lead_paragraph: If it’s been a few years since you last visited Milan (our top choice for 52 Places to Go in 2015), you’re in for a pleasant shock. Yes, the preparations for the World Expo being held here this year (May through October) turned large swaths of the city into construction zones, many of which are still in progress. But alongside these urban development projects, a more organic wave of rejuvenation has swept through the city. Old structures of various stripes — among them a sawmill, a foundry, a bank and a farmhouse — have recently been repurposed as bars, shops, restaurants and cultural centers worthy of this most international of Italian cities. Put simply, there’s new energy coursing through cosmopolitan Milan, and it’s likely to last long after the Expo.

headline: New Antibiotic Stirs Hope Against Resistant Bacteria
abstract: Researchers reported that a new drug, extracted from a soil sample, easily cured infections in mice, with no side effects.
lead_paragraph: An unusual method for producing antibiotics may help solve an urgent global problem: the rise in infections that resist treatment with commonly used drugs, and the lack of new antibiotics to replace ones that no longer work.

headline: From the Director John Waters, a Kiddie-Friendly “Pink Flamingos”
abstract: For a new multimedia show at Marianne Boesky Gallery, the perennially tongue-in-cheek provocateur reimagined his X-rated 1972 cult classic with a cast of children.
lead_paragraph: In 1972, John Waters raised eyebrows with the X-rated film “Pink Flamingos,” the story of Divine, played by the drag queen of the same name, a criminal hiding under the moniker Babs Johnson in a pink trailer with two plastic flamingos at the front. Waters filled it with the types of raunchy, lewd acts that turned his movies into cult favorites. More than four decades later, Waters has reinvented “Pink Flamingos” as video art for his new exhibition “Beverly Hills John,” on view at Marianne Boesky Gallery’s Chelsea location through February 14. “I’ve become my own worst enemy and rewrote the script so that it’s G-rated,” explains Waters, who hired a cast full of children — most, he says, were friends’ kids — to do a costumed table reading that was filmed over the course of one day. The 72-minute video, titled “Kiddie Flamingos,” pokes fun at the original; an exclusive preview runs here. “I see it as a new kind of perversity not to ever make an X-rated thing again,” he said.

headline: Patti Smith’s Cinematic Lullaby
abstract: Patti Smith, the “godmother of punk,” crossed a new frontier when she wrote an original song for the movie “Noah,” based on the biblical flood.
lead_paragraph: Patti Smith, the “godmother of punk,” crossed a new frontier when she wrote an original song for the movie “Noah,” based on the biblical flood.

headline: Writers Guild Gives ‘Nightcrawler,’ ‘Whiplash’ More Momentum
abstract: Screenplay nominations went largely to expected titles, though “Guardians of the Galaxy,” an adaptation, could be considered a surprise.
lead_paragraph: The debate this week over whether “Whiplash” was an original screenplay or an adaptation (as the Academy has designated it) didn’t hurt the movie with the Writers Guild. That organization has announced its nominees, and the film, written and directed by Damien Chazelle, is among the contenders.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Reiterates Faith in Phil Jackson as the Knicks Look to the Long Term

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Carmelo Anthony said his decision to sign a new, five-year deal with the Knicks last summer was based partly on his trust that Phil Jackson, the team’s new president, would know how to turn the club’s fortunes around.

headline: First Draft Focus: Democratic Women Bundle Up and Smile

keywords: ['Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Magazines', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Muslim Americans', 'Muslims and Islam']

headline: Methodology of Calculating Company Payments to Doctors
abstract: The pharmaceutical and medical device industries have not made it easy to track their expenditures on doctors and teaching hospitals.
lead_paragraph: The pharmaceutical and medical device industries, even when required by the federal government, have not made it easy to track their expenditures on doctors and teaching hospitals.

headline: The Drugs That Companies Promote to Doctors Are Rarely Breakthroughs
abstract: The money spent to influence doctors tends to be in the service of newer drugs that are “fairly redundant.”
lead_paragraph: For more than five decades, the blood thinner Coumadin was the only option for millions of patients at risk for life-threatening blood clots. But now, a furious battle is underway among the makers of three newer competitors for the prescription pads of doctors across the country.

lead_paragraph: Sienna Miller will be the next and final actress to play Sally Bowles in the Broadway revival of “Cabaret,” starting Feb. 17 and running through the production’s scheduled closing date of March 29, Roundabout Theater Company announced on Wednesday.

headline: To Lift Market, Obama Will Lower Mortgage-Insurance Cost
abstract: The Obama administration, struggling to get the housing market running again for low-income and first-time homebuyers, will lower the premium that the Federal Housing Administration charges on mortgage insurance, administration officials said Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration, struggling to get the housing market running again for low-income and first-time home buyers, will lower the premium that the Federal Housing Administration charges on mortgage insurance, officials said Wednesday.

headline: Fed Committee Hopeful, but Wary at Last Session
abstract: Minutes of the December session show that Federal Reserve policy makers were encouraged about the economy but determined not to act too quickly on interest rates.

lead_paragraph: When Vogue, a former employer of the esteemed writer Joan Didion, announced on Tuesday that she was starring in Céline’s latest ad campaign, with a photograph featuring her in black shirt, oversize gold pendant and dark sunglasses, the fashion Internet quivered in a way it hasn’t at least since Kim Kardashian stripped nude for Paper magazine two months ago.

headline: In Assessing 2015 Goals, Be Wary of ‘Risk Creep’
abstract: A small risk seems easy to take when things are going well, but remembering the lessons of the past can rein in the attraction, a financial planner writes.

headline: How Cold Is It? As Cold as  ________

headline: Yale Library Acquires Paula Vogel Archive
abstract: Ms. Vogel’s archive will join those of other playwrights, including Eugene O’Neill and Thornton Wilder, in the Yale Collection of American Literature.
lead_paragraph: The Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library at Yale has acquired the literary archive of Paula Vogel, whose play “How I Learned to Drive” won the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 1998. Ms. Vogel, who has taught at the Yale School of Drama since 2008 and is a playwright in residence at Yale Repertory Theater, is the first female playwright to be included in the library’s Yale Collection of American Literature, a repository that includes the papers of Eugene O’Neill, Thornton Wilder. A. R. Gurney and John Guare.

headline: Reports of Army Deployment in Sri Lanka Investigated Ahead of Election
abstract: The Sri Lankan election commissioner said he had received complaints about the deployment of troops in the former conflict zones in the north and east of the country.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — The Sri Lankan election authorities are investigating reports that the military has troops standing by, ready to deploy during the presidential election Thursday, the country’s election commissioner said on Wednesday.

headline: John Travolta to Play Lawyer in O.J. Simpson Mini-Series
abstract: The film actor is returning to the small screen in the role of Robert Shapiro.
lead_paragraph: It’s, like, so weird: despite a decades-long acting career that includes the films “Grease,” “Saturday Night Fever” and “Pulp Fiction,” John Travolta has played relatively few television roles. He’s been Vinnie Barbarino on four seasons of “Welcome Back, Kotter”; the title character in TV movies like “The Boy in the Plastic Bubble”; and a creative enunciator of names on the Academy Awards.

headline: Paris Assault Examined for Qaeda and ISIS Methods
abstract: While the attack seemed to be inspired by the Islamic State’s call for lone-wolf action, some analysts said the killers seemed to have Qaeda training.
lead_paragraph: Wednesday’s attack on a satirical newspaper in Paris prompted speculation about the involvement of an organized terrorist group, possibly the Islamic State, whose leaders have called for sympathizers to carry out assaults wherever they can. These “lone wolf” attacks have included the siege of a cafe in Sydney, Australia, last month; an attack on the Jewish Museum in Brussels in May; and a gunman’s rampage through the Parliament building in Ottawa in October.

headline: Fashion’s Two-Faced Relationship With Age
abstract: Fashion is celebrating the older woman, but how much does it really love her?
lead_paragraph: For the last three years at about this time — which is to say, in the nascent days of the new year, when the calendar lies clear and the sense of possibility is at its apex — Selfridges, the British department store, has dedicated its windows, all 13 of them, to a new class of Bright Young Things: dozens of up-and-coming stars of fashion and art, including names like Simone Rocha, Christopher Shannon and Maarten van der Horst, who it thinks will shape what we wear and how we shop in the year to come.

headline: Jack O’Connell in Sharp, Casual Separates
abstract: With a cleaned-up haircut and his choice not to wear a layer underneath the knit, the actor is surely on the verge of becoming Hollywood’s next English heartthrob.

headline: ‘Redshirting’ Kindergarten-Age Kids Can Lead to Regrets
abstract: Because wealthier, better educated parents ‘redshirt’ while others don’t, a kindergarten classroom can include 4-year-olds who have never been to preschool and can’t sit still, and 6-year-olds who are fluently reading chapter books and ready for advanced math.
lead_paragraph: Last week we had our 4-year-old’s parent-teacher conference. She’s in pre-K, turning 5 next summer, and so one of her teacher’s first questions for us was, “What are you thinking about kindergarten?”

headline: Cuban Road Trip: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: The reporter William Neuman reflects on his 17-hour road trip across Cuba.
lead_paragraph: The reporter William Neuman wrote a front-page article about his 17-hour road trip, in a 1956 Ford Fairlane, across Cuba. Here he reflects on the trip and ideas of modern and new.

headline: ‘Dangerous Moment’ for Europe, as Fear and Resentment Grow
abstract: The strike against the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo seems certain to accelerate the growth of anti-Islamic sentiment in Europe.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The sophisticated, military-style strike Wednesday on a French newspaper known for satirizing Islam staggered a continent already seething with anti-immigrant sentiments in some quarters, feeding far-right nationalist parties like France’s National Front.

headline: Texas Abortion Clinic Rules Tested in Appeals Court
abstract: The rules could force more than half the remaining abortion providers in Texas to close.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Lawyers for abortion clinics squared off with Texas state attorneys in a federal appeals court here on Wednesday, arguing over the constitutionality of stringent abortion clinic rules that would force more than half the remaining abortion providers in Texas to close.

headline: For January, Cooking the Pantry (and Freezer, and Fridge) Dry
abstract: In keeping with the frugal spirit of January, this month, we’ll be buying little, and using up a lot.
lead_paragraph: It started when my husband bought me a new appliance for Christmas. (An air fryer. It’s very entertaining if not exactly necessary.)

headline: A New Retrospective of Jesús Rafael Soto Debuts on Both Sides of the Atlantic
abstract: The late midcentury artist is the subject of an exhibition at Emmanuel Perrotin’s galleries in New York and Paris.
lead_paragraph: “Jesús Rafael Soto is not a forgotten master,” says the curator Matthieu Poirier. That term has lately has been tossed around in art circles as frequently as the very same names being put up at auction. But Poirier may, in fact, have an informed perspective on the matter. After all, he wrote the book (or rather, the catalogue) on Soto, the late Venezuelan-born midcentury artist who pioneered the practice known as kinetic art. Poirier, an art history lecturer at the Sorbonne, curated “Dynamo: A Century of Light and Movement in Art 1913–2013″ last year at the Galeries Nationales du Grand Palais, which he says “tried to demonstrate, with 143 artists’ contribution, that Soto’s context and influence goes much beyond the South American historical and geographic borders within which he is regularly considered.”

headline: The Blasphemy We Need
keywords: ['Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: On Charlie Hebdo, and why offenses that provoke violence are the ones most worth defending.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the vicious murders at the offices of the satirical French newspaper Charlie Hebdo today, let me offer three tentative premises about blasphemy in a free society.

headline: F.B.I. Says Little Doubt North Korea Hit Sony
abstract: Instead of routing their attacks through decoy servers, the hackers sent them directly from web addresses in North Korea, the F.B.I. said. But some skeptics still wanted to see the agency’s evidence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I.’s director, James B. Comey, said on Wednesday that the United States had concluded that North Korea was behind the destructive attacks on Sony Pictures partly because the hackers failed to mask their location when they broke into the company’s servers.

headline: G.O.P. Leaders Question Obama’s Intent
abstract: Republican leaders, now in control of both houses of Congress, said the onus for bipartisan cooperation was on President Obama and questioned whether he would seriously pursue it.
lead_paragraph: Republican leaders, now in control of both houses of Congress, said the onus for bipartisan cooperation was on President Obama and questioned whether he would seriously pursue it.

headline: Gearing Up for Re-election, Reid Said to Shake Up Staff
abstract: David Krone, the, um, lightning rod to Harry Reid, will be replaced by Drew Willison, the Senate’s former sergeant-at-arms, according to a source familiar with the personnel change.
lead_paragraph: David Krone, Senator Harry Reid’s lightning rod — or chief of staff — will be replaced by Drew Willison, the Senate’s former sergeant-at-arms, according to a source familiar with the personnel change.

headline: Abduction. Lost Finger. Now, a Rock Climber’s Tallest Hurdle.
abstract: That Tommy Caldwell would spend a decade trying to figure out how to free climb El Capitan’s Dawn Wall came as no surprise to those who know him as an untiring goal-setter.
lead_paragraph: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif. — Whatever part inside of Tommy Caldwell that made him attempt the seemingly impossible — a free climb of El Capitan’s Dawn Wall — might have been born in 2000 when he and three others were kidnapped by militants while climbing in the Pamir-Alai range of Kyrgyzstan. They escaped after six days on the run when Caldwell shoved an armed guard over a cliff.

headline: Taylor Swift’s Reign Continues in 2015
abstract: Her album “1989” earned an eighth week at No. 1.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift had the best-selling album of 2014, and she is starting off the new year on top, as her hit “1989” notches an eighth week as Billboard’s No. 1 album.

headline: Hollande Pledges to Defend Freedom
abstract: President François Hollande of France declared Thursday a national day of mourning after a terror attack on the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo left 12 dead.
lead_paragraph: President François Hollande of France declared Thursday a national day of mourning after a terror attack on the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo left 12 dead.

headline: Barnes Foundation Recruits Director From Miami
abstract: Thomas Collins, who has led the Pérez Art Museum Miami through a capital building program, has been named executive director of the Barnes Foundation in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: The Barnes Foundation — now in its third year in its gleaming new home in downtown Philadelphia after a contentious relocation — announced on Wednesday that it had chosen Thomas Collins, a longtime museum leader and curator, to become its new executive director and president after a search of almost a year.

headline: A New Resort for Nevis
abstract: A new resort is scheduled to open in January on Paradise Beach in Nevis.
lead_paragraph: While St. Kitts has been the focus of development with the recent opening of Belle Mont Farm and an anticipated Park Hyatt, Nevis, the smaller sibling in the Caribbean nation of St. Kitts and Nevis, will get a new villa resort Jan. 15 when Paradise Beach Nevis opens.

headline: A Visceral Slide Into Darkness
abstract: “Toxic Psalms,” the latest production by the vocal ensemble Carmina Slovenica, is a meditation on a collective’s ethical choices.
lead_paragraph: The members of the chorus pace restlessly around the stage, periodically halting in ominous formations. Sometimes they sing at one another in a whisper, but using megaphones. The floor is littered with lemons, and the lighting is stark. Some of the performers wear elaborate, antiquated black gowns, as if mourners at a Victorian funeral. Some don combat boots.

headline: The Charlie Hebdo Massacre in Paris
abstract: A terrorist attack on the French satirical weekly is an assault on freedom everywhere.
lead_paragraph: The brutal terrorist attack on the French satirical weekly Charlie Hebdo in Paris on Wednesday has badly shaken France. But the French have reacted with a fierce determination to defend their freedoms. President François Hollande, speaking from outside the magazine’s office a couple of hours after the murder of 12 people, was crystal clear: This was an assault, he said, on “the expression of freedom” that is the “spirit of the republic.”

headline: Is Islam to Blame for the Shooting at Charlie Hebdo in Paris?
abstract: Let’s speak up about terrorism in the Islamic world, but let’s not respond with our own brand of intolerance.
lead_paragraph: The French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo skewers people of all faiths and backgrounds. One cartoon showed rolls of toilet paper marked “Bible,” “Torah” and “Quran,” and the explanation: “In the toilet, all religions.”

headline: A Wide Range of Works, With Some Sexiness Thrown Into the Mix
abstract: The Los Angeles troupe Bodytraffic brings its dance to the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: For Bodytraffic, a Los Angeles repertory company formed in 2007, variety counts for much and a dose of sexy never hurts. Still, the four choreographers featured in its latest program, shown Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, shared some similar sensibilities. Along with jolts of speed contrasted with slowness, there was the frequent use of the spotlight and, as usual in a certain strain of contemporary dance, plenty of gestures gone wild.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
abstract: France and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: France and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: First Draft Focus: Mustang Barry
abstract: President Obama gets in a new Ford Mustang during a tour of the company’s assembly plant in Wayne, Mich., on Wednesday.

headline: A Tense Paris After Charlie Hebdo Attack
abstract: Parisians discussed what the terrorist attack in the heart of the city could mean for France and its large Muslim population.
lead_paragraph: Parisians discussed what the terrorist attack in the heart of the city could mean for France and its large Muslim population.

headline: Tensions Between Mayor and the Police
abstract: Readers react to the work slowdown by police officers in New York City.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Sotheby’s and Christie’s Return to Guaranteeing Art Prices
abstract: Minimum price guarantees to sellers of coveted art, which wounded auction houses a few years ago, are in resurgence.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps it’s a mark of confidence in the art market. Or a sign that profit margins are thin. Or simply another big gamble, like the ones taken in 2008.

headline: Paper-and-Scissors Game Is Now a Designer’s Métier
abstract: Kiki van Eijk’s Paper Cut light fixtures were inspired by a child’s game.
lead_paragraph: Kiki van Eijk’s Paper Cut light fixtures were inspired by the child’s game of cutting out objects from double-folded scraps, a pastime she enjoyed as a child.

headline: Japanese Masters at Play
abstract: “Shiro Kuramata and Hiroshi Sugimoto: Works From the Absent Past” at the Wright gallery in New York.
lead_paragraph: Time is arrested in an auction preview of art pieces by two Japanese masters. “Shiro Kuramata and Hiroshi Sugimoto: Works From the Absent Past” displays limited-edition furniture by Mr. Kuramata (1934-1991) alongside photographic seascapes by Mr. Sugimoto. The show is at Wright’s New York gallery, 980 Madison Avenue (East 77th Street).

headline: G.O.P. vs. Obama Agenda
abstract: Ellen Shire, a reader, faults “a party that cares more about blocking the president than taking care of its fellow citizens.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hard-Luck Heroes on Streets and the Set
abstract: In “The Martini Shot,” featuring seven short stories and a novella, George Pelecanos covers his usual milieu but dips into the television world as well.
lead_paragraph: It’s well known that George Pelecanos has a terrific ear for street talk, and that his crime novels, populated mostly by black characters in tougher parts of Washington, sound as credible and unforced as they do cutting-edge. But the novella in this short-story collection, Mr. Pelecanos’s first, shows that his ear for movie-set argot is just as good. He has named both the novella and the book “The Martini Shot.” That’s industry talk for the last shot, the one after which work ends and night life begins — the idea being that the next shot will be coming out of a glass.

headline: Careful, Eve. This One Is Crystal.
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Maison Et Objet (Trade Show)']
abstract: Martyn Lawrence Bullard designs crystal fit for Eden.
lead_paragraph: In his first collection for Daum, the French crystal manufacturer, Martyn Lawrence Bullard put an artful twist on a Garden of Eden theme. The infamous apple assumes three forms: a paperweight ($675); a candleholder ($1,470) with a niche for an LED candle; and the centerpiece of a chandelier with pale green leaves and a gilded serpent (price upon request). All are made using the company’s technique of pâte de cristal, a modern refinement of pâte de verre, the ancient Egyptian glass-casting method, which results in the bold, saturated color evident in the ruby red of the apple. They will be introduced at the Maison et Objet home furnishings show in Paris on Jan. 23.

headline: White House Digital Project
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Matt Levinson, the author of “From Fear to Facebook,” writes that President Obama’s technology adviser needs to “keep in mind the human side of change.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Big Barrel Is Refilled
abstract: In Los Angeles, a renovation brings the Idle Hour back to life.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles was once lousy with fanciful buildings made to look like other things: The Brown Derby restaurants are an example. Most are gone or living out a shabby old age.

headline: Cultivating a More Youthful Orchestra
abstract: American orchestras and major music institutions are chasing youth with ever more ambitious programs to reach, and teach, the next generation of players.
lead_paragraph: Despite the graying of the classical music audience — or perhaps because of it — American orchestras and major music institutions are chasing youth with ever more ambitious programs to reach, and teach, the next generation of players.

headline: Suicide Among Native Peoples
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Indigenous People']
abstract: Richard K. Reed, an anthropologist, writes that “many more die from the casual violence that targets minorities.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Jarring Reality, Doused With Humor
abstract: The British series “Babylon,” a darkly satirical comedy about law enforcement and its discontents, is starting on the Sundance Channel.
lead_paragraph: The British series “Babylon,” a complicated and darkly satirical comedy about law enforcement and its discontents that runs on the Sundance Channel starting Thursday, is eerily timely for American viewers. It touches on issues from pensions to prison privatization, but the story is built around two questionable police shootings. One, of a young black man, leads to riots that escalate because aggrieved police officers refuse to leave their stations.

headline: Brick by Tiny Brick
abstract: Using Legos, Adam Reed Tucker has built a model of Frank Lloyd Wright’s Taliesin West.
lead_paragraph: ­It took Adam Reed Tucker several exhausting months to build what he considers the masterwork of his career, up to this point. In fact, what he built was the masterwork of Frank Lloyd Wright’s career, only with tiny plastic bricks.

headline: What to Do About Chipped Tiles in the Bathroom?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Brick and Tile']
abstract: When your bathroom floor has chipped or cracked tiles, it’s wise to take action before listing your home for sale.

headline: Tax Returns Complicated by Health Care Law and I.R.S. Staff Cuts
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The Affordable Care Act adds a major twist for some tax filers, and budget cuts might mean long wait times when phoning the Internal Revenue Service.
lead_paragraph: The filing season for tax year 2014 starts in less than two weeks. While some people won’t have all the forms needed to file their returns until the beginning of next month, there’s good reason to start gearing up now — whether you prepare your own taxes, or pay someone to do it for you.

headline: Testing Out a Twilight Stir of Melody, Before Heading to the Studio
abstract: A concert by Matt Mitchell doubled as preparation for a recording session.
lead_paragraph: The moments of clarity came scattered throughout Matt Mitchell’s first set at the Jazz Gallery on Tuesday night, each making a distinct impression before receding into the churn. One such moment was an improvised piano interlude, played by Mr. Mitchell in a two-handed, crab-scuttling counterpoint, on a composition wryly titled “Numb Trudge.”

headline: Galvanized Near the Gowanus
abstract: An architect’s dream home coexists with its industrial surroundings.
lead_paragraph: An architect’s dream home coexists with its industrial surroundings.

headline: New York City Taxi Medallion Prices Keep Falling, Now Down About 25 Percent
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: While prices have decreased in New York, medallions are barely selling at all in Chicago and Boston.
lead_paragraph: Taxi medallion prices continue to fall under pressure from new taxi competitors, including Uber. New York City individual taxi medallions, whose owners must drive a taxi for at least part of the year, fell to $805,000, down 23 percent from 2013’s peak of $1.05 million. Corporate medallions, which may be owned in fleets, traded on average at $950,000, down 28 percent from their peak.

headline: Padding the Edge
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: An architect’s dream home coexists with industrial surroundings.
lead_paragraph: The lot was on the edge of the residential neighborhood of Carroll Gardens in Brooklyn, near a concrete plant and the Gowanus Canal, and it had an old garage on it. To many people, it wouldn’t have seemed like an obvious place to build a dream home. But when Philippe Baumann and Lisa Sardinas saw the property, they knew they wanted it.

headline: A Deal From the World Mind Games in Beijing
abstract: At the fourth SportAccord World Mind Games in Beijing last month, two Americans won a pair of medals.
lead_paragraph: At the fourth SportAccord World Mind Games in Beijing last month, two Americans won a pair of medals: Justin Lall of Plano, Tex., and Roger Lee of Las Vegas. They were third in both the open teams and the open pairs. They said nothing noteworthy happened to them, so let’s look at a deal that occurred during the concluding individual event.

headline: Proud to Offend, Charlie Hebdo Carries Torch of Political Provocation
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Newspapers', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The struggling satirical paper was once firebombed, but it continued to amuse and horrify, taking pride in offending one and all.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In 2012, when Charlie Hebdo editors defied the government’s advice and published crude caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad naked and in sexual poses, the French authorities shut down embassies, cultural centers and schools in about 20 countries.

headline: Where Being in Denial Is Right at Home
abstract: In “My Husband’s Not Gay,” a special on TLC, Mormon men acknowledge having a same-sex attraction.
lead_paragraph: If you’re fishing for reality-TV viewers, you want to start the year off with something attention-getting, and normally a show about men with a fetish for dressing in latex suits that make them look like giant female dolls would do the trick. But for TLC, the network that loves to make itself hateable, guys-as-dolls (Wednesday night’s Season 6 premiere of “My Strange Addiction”) was only an appetizer.

headline: Pick a Country, Any Country
abstract: Behomm, a home-exchange website, lets you inhabit magazine-perfect residences, but only if you qualify.
lead_paragraph: Behomm, a home-exchange website, lets you inhabit magazine-perfect residences, but only if you qualify.

headline: Brazil’s Former Sports Minister is Moved to Science Post Despite Rejection of Global Warming Science
keywords: ['Carbon Dioxide', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Global Warming', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Brazil’s president picks a former sports minister who rejects global warming science as her new science minister.
lead_paragraph: For the president in any democracy, compromises are often necessary in assembling a cabinet that satisfies a range of constituencies. But even with that in mind, it’s really hard to understand how President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil, who has repeatedly pressed for strong global action to curb climate change, could possibly justify her choice of Aldo Rebelo as her new minister of science, technology and innovation.

headline: Shopping With Anna Rabinowicz
keywords: ['Toothbrushes and Toothpaste', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Even a toothbrush can be a collectible. At the very least, it can make you smile in the morning.
lead_paragraph: Even a toothbrush can be a collectible. At the very least, it can make you smile in the morning.

headline: Adventurous Offerings in San Francisco Opera Season
abstract: San Francisco Opera’s 2015-16 season will be the last under its transformative general director, David Gockley, who plans to retire.
lead_paragraph: Rising young singers, a mix of old and new works, star directors and a new, intimate theater will all be features of the San Francisco Opera’s 2015-16 season, the last under its transformative general director, David Gockley, the company announced Wednesday.

headline: Toothbrushes: Saying ‘Ah’ (and ‘Ooh’)
keywords: ['Toothbrushes and Toothpaste', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Even a toothbrush can be a collectible. At the very least, it can make you smile in the morning.
lead_paragraph: It all began with a kiss: Dr. Kiss, the toothbrush designed by Philippe Starck for Alessi in 1996, which looks something like a pen curving out of an inkwell.

headline: Pictures of the Day — Jan. 7, 2015
abstract: Photos from France, Yemen, England and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from France, Yemen, England and the United States.

headline: Trading Places, in Style
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Barter']
abstract: A new home-exchange website lets you inhabit magazine-perfect residences, but only if you qualify.
lead_paragraph: Sara Frisk never thought about traveling to Mexico City until a stranger named Pilar Muñoz invited her. Ms. Muñoz, a publicist for designers, lives in a 4,300-square-foot penthouse apartment with glass walls and luscious green views. The home has richly grained wood floors, trim modern sofas and a kitchen island you could sacrifice an ox on.

headline: Following T-Mobile, AT&T Allows Some Customers to Roll Over Unused Data
abstract: AT&T said on Wednesday that customers that have subscribed to its shared data plans would be able to roll over unused data from month to month.
lead_paragraph: T-Mobile USA is the small fry among the big American phone carriers, but its moves continue to influence its competitors. Just a few weeks after T-Mobile said it would allow phone customers to roll over their unused data month after month, AT&T said it would provide a similar offering.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
