abstract: Paris Attack Slideshow
lead_paragraph: Paris Attack Slideshow

headline: Sales at Ankasa, Gracious Home, Jayson Home and the MoMA Design Store
abstract: Discounts on bedding, lighting, furniture and accessories for the home.
lead_paragraph: Ankasa is discounting duvets and coverlets by 30 percent and sheets by 20 percent through Jan. 15 (a queen-size Bonne Terre duvet, originally $625, is about $437); 424 Broome Street (Crosby Street), 212-226-8002, and 1200 Madison Avenue (East 88th Street), 212-996-5200.

headline: Emma Stone
abstract: Ms. Stone’s outfits seem to be synced partly with her chameleonic changes of coiffure.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Stone’s outfits seem to be synced partly with her chameleonic changes of coiffure.

headline: ‘Sleepy Hollow’ Recap: What Was That Winged Creature?
abstract: And a character, thought dead, returns.
lead_paragraph: Season 2, Episode 12: “Paradise Lost”

headline: Learn, Baby, Learn
abstract: Winter is fire season, but many homeowners are woefully unprepared for the worst.
lead_paragraph: Last July, Jeremy Slutskin and his neighbors in a four-story condo building in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, experienced a reverse miracle: A fire broke out in a top-floor apartment due to — wait for it — spontaneous combustion of chemicals.

headline: China Wants Taxes Paid by Citizens Living Afar
abstract: A longtime law, widely ignored, requires individuals and companies to pay domestic taxes on income earned outside the country.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As Chinese individuals and companies head overseas in greater numbers, the country’s tax authorities are starting to follow.

headline: The Soft Sway of Suede
abstract: A suede skirt could be the first investment you consider for the new year.
lead_paragraph: A suede skirt could be the first investment you consider for the new year.

headline: Iran’s Supreme Leader Is Skeptical of Nuclear Talks With U.S.
abstract: Saying that the United States could not be trusted to lift sanctions, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said that Iran should find internal solutions to economic problems.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s supreme leader said on Wednesday that his country should find internal solutions for dealing with economic sanctions and that the United States could not be trusted to lift sanctions in the event that a nuclear agreement is reached.

headline: Inhofe Says He Would Consider a Gas Tax Increase
abstract: Add Senator James Inhofe, the conservative Republican from Oklahoma, to a small but growing list of senators who would consider backing an increase in the gasoline tax. Just don’t call it a tax.
lead_paragraph: Add Senator James Inhofe, the conservative Republican from Oklahoma, to a small but growing list of senators who would consider backing an increase in the gasoline tax. Just don’t call it a tax.

headline: CES: Security Risks From the Smart Home
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Electronics', 'International Consumer Electronics Show']
abstract: Security experts are warning that things like Internet-connected cameras and household appliances are a threat to security and privacy.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — THE Internet of Things arrived in force at this year’s International CES, the huge trade show here. But while manufacturers at the event painted a rosy picture of connected grills, coffee makers, refrigerators and door locks, security experts and regulators warned that the Internet of Things could be a threat to both security and privacy.

headline: Our Doctors May Be Listening, but ...
keywords: ['Doctors', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: A doctor, a nurse and a psychotherapist respond to an Op-Ed article, “Doctor, Shut Up and Listen.”

headline: Why We’re So Mad at de Blasio
abstract: For me and my fellow police officers, it’s a matter of respect.
lead_paragraph: ON Sunday, at the funeral of the slain New York City police officer Wenjian Liu, his grieving father described how his son would call him at the end of each day’s tour of duty, just to let him know he was O.K.

headline: Hollywood’s Leading Men Embrace Fashion
abstract: Male actors, such as Benedict Cumberbatch and Bradley Cooper, are suddenly appearing everywhere, always looking like a million bucks.
lead_paragraph: Male actors, such as Benedict Cumberbatch and Bradley Cooper, are suddenly appearing everywhere, always looking like a million bucks.

headline: Deadly Attack in Paris
abstract: Masked gunman opened fire Wednesday at the Paris offices of Charlie Hebdo, a satirical weekly newspaper.
lead_paragraph: Masked gunman opened fire Wednesday at the Paris offices of Charlie Hebdo, a satirical weekly newspaper.

headline: Spring Fashion: What to Get Excited About Now
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Leather and Leather Goods']
abstract: Here’s to a stylish new year, with inspiration from the indulgent ’70s.
lead_paragraph: In these first days of 2015, resolve to have a stylish new year. Designers have already done most of the deep thinking, looking ahead by looking back to the 1970s, the indulgent decade that dominated the spring runways. The jewelry will be bigger, the platforms higher, the denim more statement-making. And there’s more suede in the shops than at a Topanga Canyon love-in. It’s time to get started. Happy New Year!

headline: A Race to the Front Row
abstract: Like fashion shows, gyms have their status-symbol front rows, too, and the scramble is on for those coveted spots.
lead_paragraph: Greccia Clausen, a Manhattan accountant, approaches her quest for a front-row bike at SoulCycle like the numbers game it is. Every Monday at noon, when the booking window opens, she and a friend each try to grab two front-row bikes. Then they compare notes and choose the two best placed, preferably front and center.

headline: French Humor, Turned Into Tragedy
abstract: Charlie Hebdo’s editors started as aggressively secular youth rebels.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — IN September 2012, the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, defying the advice of the French government, published several lewd caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad.

headline: CES: A Fitness Watch, Smart Light Bulbs and a Self-Watering Flower Pot
keywords: ['International Consumer Electronics Show', 'Electric Light Bulbs', 'Watches and Clocks', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Electronics', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: A few devices that stuck out at the International CES trade show this year.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — AT the International CES, tens of thousands of gadgets from thousands of manufacturers are on display. And yet, each year, a few rise to the surface.

headline: It’s All Right With Sam
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Eighth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: To the political right, Supreme Court Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. is a rock star.
lead_paragraph: Samuel A. Alito Jr. may be the least recognizable of Supreme Court justices. I doubt if one American in a thousand could pick him out of a lineup. Those who do know the name, if not the face, of the 64-year-old justice most likely lump him with the other conservatives who as a bloc dominate the Roberts court.

headline: How Stylish Male Actors Have Upped the Red Carpet Game
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Movies', 'Celebrities', 'Men and Boys', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES']
abstract: Male Hollywood stars, who once disdained fashion, have learned that looking good now comes with the territory.
lead_paragraph: By the time awards season rolls around each year, the inbox of anyone covering style fills up with so much pressing fashion minutiae that trepanation can suddenly seem like a desirable option.

headline: Shopping Sales and Events in New York City
abstract: A collection of shopping suggestions and sales.
lead_paragraph: ­For those returning to the nest after holiday journeys, Dover Street Market has a temporary Rick Owens Maison/Objet installation featuring a selection of furniture, tableware and flatware, including an “Urnette” bronze vase ($6,300), which is displayed across a black plinth with mural artwork by Mr. Owens’s stepdaughter, Scarlett Rouge. At 160 Lexington Avenue. ­

headline: Plan for Offshore Wind Farm in Nantucket Sound Hits a Snag
abstract: The two largest utilities in Massachusetts, which had agreed to buy three-fourths of the wind farm’s power, said they were canceling their contracts because Cape Wind had failed to meet a Dec. 31 deadline.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Cape Wind, a massive wind farm proposed in Nantucket Sound, has been dealt a setback that threatens its finances and throws into doubt whether it will become the nation’s first such offshore project.

headline: At Tomas Maier, a Vision of the Closet as Toolbox
abstract: On Madison Avenue, well-made clothes that you shouldn’t have to replace very often.
lead_paragraph: The best way to experience a Tomas Maier store is to emerge from the No. 6 train like a gremlin, brushing subway grime from your coat and scraping your shoe against the ground to remove a spilled slushie that you and 50 other passengers stepped in on the way out. These are conditions that contrast optimally with the new store on Madison Avenue, which is among the cleanest and brightest-lit vendors of luxury goods on its Upper East Side block. It’s the kind of environment you wander into and think, “If I lived in a place like this, I’d never be filthy again.”

headline: From Caretaker to Computer Analyst Via a Nonprofit Technology School
abstract: Sydney Almorales deferred his future after high school to tend to his dying stepfather, and then could not afford the subway trip to technology classes.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, Sydney Almorales was wrapping up his senior year at Brownsville Academy High School, plotting his course to college. But by the middle of the year, his future as a student was abruptly overtaken by a more immediate duty: caretaker.

headline: Professors, Politicians, and Moments of Truth
abstract: When does being wrong matter?
lead_paragraph: Simon Wren-Lewis offers a clever way to think about whether US growth despite sequestration is a huge problem for Keynesians — he shows that under a hypothetical in which the US maintained spending at 2009 levels, a Keynesian analysis says that growth would have been higher — but not enormously higher. Another way of saying this is that US austerity, while real and destructive, hasn’t been world-class, and is well within the range that is consistent with some growth.

headline: A Bus Takes a Local Route to Fighting Mexican Corruption
abstract: Born through a mix of frustration, satire and savvy, the Corruptour is a free one-hour ride led by young activists hoping to stir a political awakening with five trips per weekend.
lead_paragraph: MONTERREY, Mexico — Inside a large, open-air bus, a corrupt politician quarrels over the loudspeakers with a fed-up citizen who tells the passengers about the millions of pesos lost in a series of corruption scandals.

headline: Two Mississippi Men Plead Guilty to Hate Crimes
keywords: ['Hate Crimes', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The two were the last of 10 defendants who have pleaded guilty in racially motivated attacks on African-Americans in Jackson in 2011.
lead_paragraph: The two remaining defendants among a group of young white Mississippians charged with carrying out racially motivated attacks on African-Americans in Jackson in 2011 pleaded guilty Wednesday to violations of the federal hate-crime law, with one of them admitting his role in the killing of a 47-year-old man.

headline: It’s Plastic Foam Packaging, Not the Food, That’s to Go Under a New York Rule
keywords: ['Containers and Packaging', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Foam', 'Street Vendors (Non-Food)']
abstract: The de Blasio administration is expected to announce on Thursday that a ban on the material used to make many food containers will take effect in July.
lead_paragraph: The proposed mayoral ban — swift, decisive, stirring in the moment — does not always take.

headline: For Fashion Week This Fall: Location, Location, Location
abstract: New York Fashion Week will be without Lincoln Center and a big sponsor this fall.
lead_paragraph: This fall, the leaves will change, the days will grow short and Fashion Week, that autumn perennial, will head downtown.

headline: Iraq Veteran, Now a West Point Professor, Seeks to Rein In Disability Pay
abstract: Lt. Col. Daniel Gade is traveling the country to urge a shift toward work incentives for disabled veterans, but some find his message misguided.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — Nearly 200 sick and wounded soldiers in a gym at Fort Carson last month listened silently as Lt. Col. Daniel Gade offered a surprising warning: The disability checks designed to help troops like them after they leave the service might actually be harmful.

headline: Good Room, a New Nightclub in Greenpoint, Brooklyn
abstract: As Greenpoint’s only full-fledged nightclub, Good Room is luring not only the neighborhood’s G train riders, but also partiers from other burgs.
lead_paragraph: In the demographic battle for Greenpoint, Brooklyn, Club Europa was a symbolic stronghold for Polish tough guys who still live with their parents against the invasion of real-life “Girls” characters who still live off their parents. But with the recent opening of Good Room in Europa’s surrendered hull, it’s not hard to imagine a shirtless Hannah Horvath hoisting her victory banner over Greenpoint, perhaps once and for all.

headline: Weather Makes Bad Situation Worse for Syrian Refugees
abstract: A fierce winter storm has compounded the misery of the millions of Syrians displaced by their country’s civil war and left the organizations that seek to help them scrambling to keep up.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A fierce winter storm that has unleashed barrages of rain and snow on parts of the Middle East this week has compounded the misery of the millions of Syrians displaced by their country’s civil war and left the organizations that seek to help them scrambling to keep up.

headline: Pakistan: Court Condemns American’s Kidnapper to Death
abstract: An Antiterrorism Court in Lahore sentenced Hafiz Imran to death on Wednesday in the kidnapping of the American aid worker Warren Weinstein.
lead_paragraph: An Antiterrorism Court in Lahore sentenced Hafiz Imran to death on Wednesday in the kidnapping of the American aid worker Warren Weinstein. Prosecutors said that Mr. Imran was among the men who seized Mr. Weinstein at his home in Lahore in 2011, and that he now joined a growing list of men scheduled to be executed since the reinstatement of capital punishment in Pakistan last month. Mr. Weinstein, 73, has been shown in hostage videos released by Al Qaeda, which claims to be holding him. Mr. Weinstein had been working in Pakistan for a development consulting company based in Arlington, Va.

headline: U.S. Oil Producers Cut Rigs as Price Declines
abstract: Falling oil prices have prompted producers to slash the number of drilling rigs around the country.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — With oil prices plunging at an ever-quickening rate, producers are beginning to slash the number of drilling rigs around the country.

headline: F.A.A. Orders Airlines to Devise Plans to Identify Risks
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration said airlines would have until 2018 to adopt new programs to help identify potential hazards and prevent accidents.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators said on Wednesday that airlines would be required to develop new safety management programs by 2018 to help identify potential hazards and prevent accidents.

headline: Back to the Future
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Keystone Pipeline System']
abstract: The new Congress is back in Washington and already hard at work in aiming for “bipartisan achievement.”
lead_paragraph: It’s a new year in Washington, and I cannot tell you how harmonious things are looking.

headline: Massachusetts: Prospective Jurors Screened for Trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev
abstract: The first phase of jury selection in the trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev in the Boston Marathon bombing ended Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The first phase of jury selection in the trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev in the Boston Marathon bombing ended Wednesday as the last of more than 1,350 prospective jurors filled out questionnaires intended to help lawyers and the court find 12 jurors and six alternates for the capital case. For the third day, several hundred prospective jurors were introduced by Judge George O’Toole to the defendant, who is accused of killing three people and injuring more than 260. One of those injured, Jaymi Cohen, a college student, watched the proceedings alongside Carmen Ortiz, the United States attorney for the District of Massachusetts. The questionnaires will be reviewed, and some of the prospective jurors will be summoned for further questioning.

headline: Who Should Apologize in Police Conflict?
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Racial Profiling', 'Search and Seizure', 'Apologies', 'Minorities', 'Discrimination', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Both sides will have to give a little, a matter of politics more than principle. Everyone will have to swallow as much contrition as they can stomach.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Lynch, the president of New York City’s largest police union, has once again called on Mayor Bill de Blasio to apologize to the police officers.

headline: Jenni Kayne
abstract: The prefall collection included plaid pants and all-white ensembles.
lead_paragraph: The prefall collection included plaid pants and all-white ensembles.

headline: Preen
abstract: The prefall collection included a sweatshirt with lace insets and sequin skirts.
lead_paragraph: The prefall collection included a sweatshirt with lace insets and sequin skirts.

headline: When a Local Jury Won't Do
abstract: How should courts decide when a trial like the Boston bombing case needs to be moved beyond where the crime occurred?

headline: Challenged by Upstarts, Lenders Try New Strategy: Cooperation
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit Cards', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Rather than play defense, financial services firms are taking time to engage engaging their rivals, as disruptive businesses are being taken more seriously.
lead_paragraph: Employees at MasterCard thought they saw a drop-off in credit card volume last spring at one of their merchants, a legal services provider. Checking further, they found they had a new competitor, Behalf, a start-up small-business lender backed by two venture capital firms that makes credit decisions in just a few seconds.

headline: More Life at the Javits Center
keywords: ['Editorials', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Sustainable Living', 'Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED)', 'Birds']
abstract: The living green roof and new populations of insects, birds and bats are testament to the success of the eco-friendly renovation.
lead_paragraph: For all the complaints about the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center over the years — it’s too small, too outdated, too gloomy — it never reported a bat invasion until its ambitious eco-friendly renovation was completed. The center now features a 6.75-acre living green roof, bird protective glass and a new population of insects that bats can’t resist. Five species of bats have unexpectedly been attracted to this new urban habitat on the West Side along with a flurry of bird species like foraging American kestrels, according to delighted watchers at the New York City Audubon Society.

headline: California: Ban on Foie Gras Is Ended
abstract: A federal judge on Wednesday struck down a state law barring sale of foie gras, ending a ban of the fatty duck liver that had lasted more than two years.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Wednesday struck down a state law barring sale of foie gras, ending a ban of the fatty duck liver that had lasted more than two years. Animal rights groups have long condemned foie gras, which has traditionally been produced by force-feeding ducks and geese, as inhumane. Many chefs across the state, who had lamented the loss of a favored ingredient, were elated by the ruling. “The person who buys our foie gras called us from the courthouse crying with happiness,” said Jon Shook, one of the chef-owners of Animal in Los Angeles. The judge ruled the ban unconstitutional because it attempted to override existing federal law regulating poultry products. The state can appeal the decision, and animal rights groups warned that restaurants that serve it could face protests. “Foie gras is French for ‘fatty liver,’ and ‘fathead’ is the American word for the shameless chefs who actually need a law to make them stop serving the swollen, near-bursting organ of a cruelly force-fed bird,” Ingrid E. Newkirk, the president of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, said in an email.

headline: Spring Rush at the University of Virginia
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Fraternities and Sororities', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: An encouraging and realistic agreement by student and school leaders to crack down on binge drinking and partying abuses is worthy of being copied elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Before it was discredited, a coed’s sensational story alleging gang rape at the University of Virginia prompted the university’s president, Teresa Sullivan, to suspend fraternity and sorority activities on campus so that underlying problems of frat-house excesses could be addressed. The result, announced Tuesday, is an encouraging and realistic agreement by student and university leaders to crack down on the sort of binge drinking and partying abuses that have given frat-house behavior a notorious reputation on campuses across the nation.

headline: Ruth Popkin Dies at 101; Hadassah Leader Worked to Resettle Refugees
abstract: Ms. Popkin, the former president of Hadassah, the Jewish National Fund and the World Zionist Congress, assisted immigrants and environmental projects in Israel.
lead_paragraph: Ruth Popkin, who emerged from a secular background to lead two major Jewish organizations, Hadassah and the Jewish National Fund, in work that benefited Israelis and refugees in the 1980s and ’90s, died on Jan. 2 at her home in Manhattan. She was 101.

headline: Texas: Fort Bliss Shooter and Victim Identified
abstract: Authorities in El Paso on Wednesday released the names of two men who died in a shooting at a Department of Veterans Affairs mental health clinic at Fort Bliss on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Authorities in El Paso on Wednesday released the names of two men who died in a shooting at a Department of Veterans Affairs mental health clinic at Fort Bliss on Tuesday. An Army veteran, Jerrry Serrato, 48, killed a psychologist, Timothy Fjordbak, 63, before shooting himself, the authorities said. Mr. Serrato worked at the clinic in 2013 as a scheduling clerk. At the time, according to an F.B.I. spokesman, he made verbal threats to Mr. Fjordbak at a local supermarket. The F.B.I. spokesman, who said Mr. Fjordbak did not recognize Mr. Serrato, paraphrased the threat as, “I know what you did and I will take care of it.” The agency has not established that the two men had a professional relationship. The clinic will remain closed Thursday.

headline: For States That Don’t File Carbon-Cutting Plans, E.P.A. Will Impose ‘Model Rule’
abstract: Republicans and the coal industry were quick to criticize the move, which is meant to pre-empt states that refuse to submit plans of their own.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency will force states to comply with a federal “model rule” to cut their carbon emissions if the states do not submit customized plans under the Obama administration’s new climate change regulations, a senior official said Wednesday.

headline: A Lifelong Packers Fan Chuckles as Fame Tugs
abstract: Jeremy Wilcox cannot go anywhere in Wisconsin without being recognized as the guy with the nine-inch-long beard pulled by Aaron Rodgers during Green Bay’s regular-season finale.
lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY, Wis. — The man with the most famous red beard in Wisconsin was three bites into his chicken sandwich Tuesday night when someone approached his table at Kroll’s West, a bar and restaurant across the street from Lambeau Field, with a small placard and a Sharpie.

headline: Violence Grows in Yemen as Al Qaeda Tries to Fight Its Way Back
abstract: Houthi fighters seized control of the Yemeni capital of Sana in September, promising radical political reforms, but Sunni extremists have retaliated with growing ferocity.
lead_paragraph: RADA CITY, Yemen — When Houthi fighters swept into this town and broke the grip of Al Qaeda, they were greeted by grateful residents, relieved that a months-long ordeal of bombings and assassinations by the militants might be coming to an end.

headline: Judge Overturns California Ban on Foie Gras
abstract: A federal judge struck down a state law barring sale of the fatty duck or goose liver, ending a ban that had lasted more than two years.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Foie gras is back on the menu in California. A federal judge on Wednesday struck down a state law barring sale of the fatty duck or goose liver, ending a ban that had lasted more than two years.

headline: New Research Links Scores of Earthquakes to Fracking Wells Near a Fault in Ohio
abstract: The study indicates that fracking built up subterranean pressures that repeatedly caused slippage in an existing fault as close as a half-mile beneath wells in Ohio.
lead_paragraph: Not long after two mild earthquakes jolted the normally steady terrain outside Youngstown, Ohio, last March, geologists quickly decided that hydraulic fracturing operations at new oil-and-gas wells in the area had set off the tremors.

headline: In Paris, Solidarity Against Terrorism
abstract: Hours after the deadly attacks on Charlie Hebdo in Paris, thousands gathered in the Place de la République to show support for free speech.
lead_paragraph: Hours after the deadly attacks on Charlie Hebdo in Paris, thousands gathered in the Place de la République to show support for free speech.

headline: Obama to Outline Proposals to Bolster a Lagging Housing Sector
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: President Obama will seek to address the disappointing housing sector Thursday, lowering insurance rates on federally issued mortgages to first-time home buyers, minorities and struggling Americans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The job market is stirring, gas prices are plunging and stocks are near record levels, but a housing sector that dragged the nation into the worst recession since the Depression remains the black spot in an otherwise resurgent economy.

headline: An Industry Will Vanish, Along With a Cellphone Ban in New York City Schools
abstract: Starting March 2, students will be allowed to carry the devices into public schools, and the phone storage business — provided by trucks, vans and other local vendors — will no longer be necessary.
lead_paragraph: For every hour of light on Wednesday, Dorinne Concepcion sat on a folding chair in a drafty box truck, in front of a propane heater, wrapped in a blanket.

headline: Deadly Attack in Paris
abstract: Masked gunmen opened fire Wednesday at the Paris offices of Charlie Hebdo, a satirical weekly newspaper.
lead_paragraph: Masked gunmen opened fire Wednesday at the Paris offices of Charlie Hebdo, a satirical weekly newspaper.

headline: Two Paths to Cooperstown Are Tinged With Black and Blue
abstract: Nobody alive has been hit by more major league pitches than Craig Biggio, and nobody alive has hit more major league batters than Randy Johnson, another new Hall of Famer.
lead_paragraph: Few people know the feeling of a baseball thrown 95 miles an hour thumping into their flesh. Few understand the panic of unleashing such a pitch and watching it veer toward a head, instead of a glove or a bat. In that way, we are lucky.

headline: How to Raise Wages in New York
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Minimum Wage', 'Wages and Salaries', 'State Legislatures', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo does not need the State Legislature to act in order to increase the minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: New York is one of 29 states with a minimum wage that exceeds the meager federal minimum of $7.25 an hour. But, with an hourly minimum of $8.75, rising to $9 next year, it still lags nine states — including California, Connecticut, Maryland, Massachusetts, Oregon and Washington — and the District of Columbia, which have or soon will have hourly minimums higher than $9.

headline: Numerous Injuries in Brooklyn Bus Crash
abstract: Six people were seriously injured and 19 others suffered minor injuries in a crash in Brooklyn on Wednesday involving two vehicles and a Metropolitan Transportation Authority bus, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Four men were critically injured and more than a dozen others suffered minor injuries on Wednesday in Brooklyn after a BMW struck a Nissan Altima on Utica Avenue, causing the BMW to hit a Metropolitan Transportation Authority bus, the police said.

headline: Samsung Predicts Big Drop in Its End-of-Year Quarter
abstract: The report signals the fifth consecutive quarter of decline in operating profit and reflects continuing troubles for the company’s mobile division.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Samsung, the world’s No. 1 maker of smartphones, had a tough end to 2014: On Thursday, the South Korean company said its operating profit and revenue probably fell almost 40 percent in the quarter ending in December compared with the same period in 2013.

headline: Clickbait Has a New Address
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The address of a website, or URL, can be a place where writers on the Internet can poke fun at themselves.
lead_paragraph: Some of the most popular reading material on the Internet, at least among the meta-humor-loving tech-industry types, is now being provided by URLs. You know, the name of the website you are perusing, plus the string of words, numbers and dashes that follow.

headline: Other Teams Have Designs on Dan Quinn, Seahawks’ Defensive Wizard
abstract: Quinn, Seattle’s defensive coordinator, has met with five of the N.F.L. teams with head coaching vacancies, not surprising given his squad’s performance the past two seasons.
lead_paragraph: RENTON, Wash. — The night before a recent Seahawks game, about 90 minutes after the team’s final meeting, defensive end Cliff Avril walked past a room he presumed was empty.

headline: Years of Repetition Help Sharpshooter Equal a Record
abstract: With help from her stepfather, Kaleena Mosqueda-Lewis, who matched Connecticut’s record for 3-pointers, began when she was young to work toward a goal of taking 500 shots per day.
lead_paragraph: As Kaleena Mosqueda-Lewis took aim at one of the most significant scoring records in women’s basketball at Connecticut, perhaps the most meaningful assist had nothing to do with any teammate.

headline: In G.O.P., a Divide of Ideology and Age
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: As Mike Huckabee and Jeb Bush consider seeking the Republican nomination for president, they face challenges in their party over their past departures from conservative orthodoxy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three years before he ran for president in 2008, a newly slim Mike Huckabee peddled a book with a title that doubled as a lecture: “Quit Digging Your Grave With a Knife and Fork.” Now, as he considers a second White House run, he has written another book with a decidedly different but equally direct title: “God, Guns, Grits and Gravy.”

headline: A Small Sign of Progress? The Knicks Lose by Only 10
abstract: With a raggedy loss to the Washington Wizards, the Knicks fell to 5-33, but they had lost their previous five games by an average of 18.8 points.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Knicks have 44 games left.

headline: Merkel’s Visit to Britain Sets New Tone After E.U. Rift
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron hoped that Chancellor Angela Merkel would help him mollify those in his party who clamor for an exit from the European Union, something both leaders said they are eager to avoid.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The first thing Prime Minister David Cameron did when Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany arrived Wednesday for a half-day visit here was to take her to a German history exhibition at the British Museum.

headline: Prof. Philip E. Converse, Expert on How Voters Decide, Dies at 86
abstract: Professor Converse, in “The American Voter,” concluded with three co-authors in 1960 that most voters were remarkably uninformed and based their preferences largely on party affiliation.
lead_paragraph: “You have the vote of every thinking person,” a woman assured Adlai E. Stevenson during one of his presidential campaigns. To which Stevenson, so the story goes, replied skeptically: “That’s not enough, madam — we need a majority!”

headline: Inadequate Effort
abstract: In which Jacob Stulberg makes me feel inadequate.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — All together now: Deb probably had trouble with this one because it was a rebus. Even more so, because, technically, it was a double rebus, with two rebus entries in each theme entry. And because, if we as a group could take an educated guess, Deb has never heard of a measurement called a GILL. Also, Deb was not warned that there would be math that required that she cleave her brain in two. So she tanked on this one.

headline: Lee Israel, a Writer Proudest of Her Literary Forgeries, Dies at 75
abstract: Ms. Israel composed and sold hundreds of letters that she said had been written by Dorothy Parker, Noël Coward, Lillian Hellman and others.
lead_paragraph: In a rented storage locker on Manhattan’s Upper West Side, the writer Lee Israel kept a cache of antique typewriters: Remingtons and Royals, Adlers and Olympias. Each was tenderly curated, hung with a tag whose carefully lettered names — Edna, Dorothy, Noël, Eugene O’Neill, Hellman, Bogart, Louise Brooks — hinted at the felonious intimacy for which the machines were used.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 7, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: As Police Go Idle, So Do New York City Courts
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The New York courts, usually bustling with arraignments, have taken on an unusual tranquility after a steep decline in arrests.
lead_paragraph: One arraignment courtroom instead of two. Clerks watching “Batman” on their computer screens and playing with their cellphones as they wait for something to happen. And Manhattan’s night court shutting down an hour early because there are no more cases to call.

headline: New York Vaccine Requirement Is Lawful, a 2nd Court Says
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Children and Childhood', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Education']

lead_paragraph: New York State’s requirement that children be vaccinated before attending public school does not violate their constitutional rights, a federal appeals court in Manhattan said on Wednesday.

headline: After 2 Deaths, New York City Adopts New Strategy to Protect Homeless Children
abstract: In an effort to spot problems, social workers are looking at histories and providing support for families in which children are considered at high risk for abuse and neglect.
lead_paragraph: There were no complaints of child abuse or domestic violence that would warrant a closer look at the young family staying at a homeless shelter in Brooklyn.

headline: New York Officers on Even Higher Alert After Paris Attack
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Already on high alert after the ambush killings of two officers last month, the New York Police Department on Wednesday urged its patrol force to take further precautions.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department, already on high alert after the ambush killings of two officers last month, issued a call for further precautions in the wake of a deadly attack in Paris, including telling its patrol force not to sit in pairs in squad cars when at a fixed post.

headline: Police Shooting Suspect Was Seen as Defiant or Gentle
abstract: With about 20 police officers looking on, Jason Polanco and Joshua Kemp were arraigned in Bronx Criminal Court on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: Jason Polanco, who was known to stride out of his local deli with food that he had not always paid for, stepped into a nearby bodega in the Bronx on Monday night with more grandiose plans, according to the police.

headline: Making a Meal With Mission Chinese Food’s (Really Cool) Executive Chef
abstract: In this short documentary, Angela Dimayuga discusses her creative process and takes us into downtown Manhattan’s buzziest, recently reopened restaurant.
lead_paragraph: “‘Craveable’ is something that’s really important to me because that’s why I go back to certain restaurants for maybe a singular dish,” explains Angela Dimayuga, executive chef of Mission Chinese Food New York, in the above video. In October 2013, much to the dismay of Manhattan’s foodie set, the original Lower East Side location of Danny Bowien’s buzzy downtown joint was shut down by the city’s health department for sanitary violations. But as New Yorkers recently toasted the end of 2014, they celebrated, too, the much-anticipated reopening of Mission Chinese Food.

headline: The Artist Devin Troy Strother Turns to Michael Jordan — and Joan Miró
abstract: The Los Angeles-based artist’s new show at Marlborough Chelsea, “Space Jam,” combines commentary on other artists’ practices with basketball iconography.
lead_paragraph: When the gallery Marlborough Chelsea called the Los Angeles-based artist Devin Troy Strother in September to ask whether he’d like to do a show with them this winter, he initially misunderstood the request: he thought they were asking him to have new work ready by December 2015. When he called back, he learned he had only a few months to conceive of an entire exhibition. For inspiration, he turned to the movie that was still queued up on his computer: the 1996 Michael Jordan vehicle “Space Jam.” The play on words proved too good to resist. “My initial thought was the idea of ‘Space Jam’ — I had to fill this huge space in a short amount of time and work very quickly,” Strother says.

headline: Military-Inspired Looks From the Resort Collections
abstract: Designers are once again exploring such motifs as gabardine twill, cargo pockets and olive-drab hues.
lead_paragraph: Military style has been a recurring theme in fashion ever since Burberry invented the trench coat. And for the resort 2015 season, designers once again explored such motifs as gabardine twill, cargo pockets and olive-drab hues. Valentino, for instance showed embroidered cargo pants and a camouflage dress, while Michael Kors incorporated such covetable items as a knee-length green trench coat that doubles as a utility cape. Since the big designers always seem to revisit the theme, it’s safe to say that this small army of styles — available in stores now — will always be on-trend.

headline: Health Premiums Rise More Slowly, but Workers Shoulder More of Cost
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: In part because of wage stagnation, even smaller rises in health care costs are less affordable, a study by the Commonwealth Fund said.
lead_paragraph: When Charlotte Alger, 25, was working at a Home Depot just outside Boston last year, she said she earned $10.75 an hour working on the sales floor in the woodworking department. She chose one of the more comprehensive health insurance plans offered, but it came with a whopping $3,000 deductible.

headline: Study Finds Reading to Children of All Ages Grooms Them to Read More on Their Own
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Books and Literature', 'Parenting']
abstract: A study by Scholastic points to ways that parents can encourage kids to read for fun.
lead_paragraph: Cue the hand-wringing about digital distraction: Fewer children are reading books frequently for fun, according to a new report released Thursday by Scholastic, the children’s book publisher.

headline: Word of the Day | sacrilegious
abstract: This word has appeared in 21 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: sacrilegious •\ˈsa-krə-lij-əs\• adjective

headline: Two Brothers Suspected in Killings Were Known to French Intelligence Services
abstract: The slaughter raised questions about how Chérif Kouachi, so well-known to the police for so many years, and Said, his brother, managed to conceal their intentions.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When Chérif Kouachi first came to the attention of the French authorities as a possible terrorist a decade ago, he was in his early 20s and, according to testimony during a 2008 Paris trial, had dreamed of attacking Jewish targets in France. Under the influence of a radical Paris preacher, however, he decided that fighting American troops in Iraq presented a better outlet for his commitment to jihad.

headline: China: North Korean Soldier Dies
abstract: A North Korean soldier who fled into China and killed four Chinese citizens in late December has died after being injured during an arrest attempt by Chinese security forces, according to reports by Chinese state news organizations.
lead_paragraph: A North Korean soldier who fled into China and killed four Chinese citizens in late December has died after being injured during an arrest attempt by Chinese security forces, according to reports by Chinese state news organizations. An article published Wednesday by Xinhua, the state news agency, cited a foreign ministry spokesman discussing the soldier’s death. “Chinese police immediately arrested him after the incident,” the spokesman, Hong Lei, said, according to Xinhua. “The runaway was injured during the process and died after treatment failed.” Mr. Hong said the murders by the soldier, which took place in northeast China near the North Korean border, were an individual criminal case. Earlier this week, Chinese officials said they had lodged a formal diplomatic complaint with the North Korean government.

headline: The Men Behind the Cartoons at Charlie Hebdo
abstract: According to those who knew them and followed their work, the four cartoonists who were killed Wednesday represented a radical, crude and vital strain of French culture.
lead_paragraph: The four cartoonists killed in the offices of Charlie Hebdo, the satirical French newspaper, represented a radical, crude and vital strain of that nation’s culture, according to those who knew them and followed their work.

headline: Study Finds More Reasons to Get and Stay Married
abstract: Even as fewer people are marrying, the disadvantages of remaining single have broad implications.
lead_paragraph: A new economics paper has some old-fashioned advice for people navigating the stresses of life: Find a spouse who is also your best friend.

headline: A Rhode Island Rule on Health Enrollment Offers a Consumer Experiment
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The federal government opted to automatically re-enroll health insurance customers at the end of 2014; Rhode Island decided to make them shop again.
lead_paragraph: Millions of people signed up for Obamacare health plans in 2014. But states and the federal government faced a quandary when it came to keeping them enrolled for 2015.

headline: Taking On Politicians on the Cover of Charlie Hebdo
abstract: French political leaders were among those skewered by cartoonists in recent editions of the Paris newspaper.
lead_paragraph: French political leaders were among those skewered by cartoonists in recent editions of the Paris newspaper.

headline: Police Hunt for Suspects in Paris Attack as Nation Mourns
abstract: As French citizens mourned their dead, the authorities were carrying out an intense search for the brothers suspected of attacking a Paris newspaper.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As France mourned, thousands of law enforcement agents mobilized on Thursday in an extensive manhunt for two brothers suspected of killing 12 people, including two police officers, at the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo in Paris.

headline: U.S. Charter Airline Cited for Neglecting Cargo of Macaques From China

lead_paragraph: An American charter airline has been accused by the United States Department of Agriculture of violating an animal protection law while shipping monkeys to laboratories in the United States from China.

headline: Standard Chartered to Close Equity Sales and Research Business
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: The bank announced that it would cut about 200 jobs in the unprofitable unit. The move is in addition to the previously announced elimination of 4,000 jobs.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Standard Chartered said Thursday it would close its unprofitable equity sales and research business, eliminating about 200 jobs in an effort to cut about $100 million in annual costs by 2016.

headline: Test Yourself | New York City Ferrets

headline: Panoramic Photos Show the Decisive Minute
abstract: Chuy Benitez makes sweeping panoramas of everyday scenes, turning a moment into a minute.
lead_paragraph: Panoramas make sense to Chuy Benitez, even if they don’t to some editors. He grew up in El Paso, where sprawling murals cover city walls. He’s also devoted to Diego Rivera, whose works set in specific communities layer every available inch to create full scenes. So it’s no mystery why the wide format struck him while he was exploring uncharted aesthetics in art school.

headline: Chinese Official Is Removed From Post and, Again, Salacious Details Flow

lead_paragraph: The announcement on Thursday that the Communist Party chief of the city of Nanjing had been removed from his post gave little explanation, save for a line about “serious discipline and law violations,” a phrase that generally refers to corruption.

abstract: Whether you live in a big city or a small town, we’re all annoyed by public rudeness. What behavior drives you most crazy? Why?

lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — After a startling upset in Sri Lanka’s presidential election, President Mahinda Rajapaksa conceded defeat on Friday morning, bringing an abrupt end to a larger-than-life, increasingly controlling presidency that he had hoped to extend into a third six-year term.

lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said on Thursday that the crisis in Ukraine could be eased only if Russia made tangible progress on all 12 points of a four-month-old agreement and that sanctions imposed on Moscow for its actions in eastern Ukraine could be lifted only if that overall progress was made.

headline: Jazz & Colors Will Head Indoors, to the Met
abstract: The third installment of this jazz series will be held inside the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Jan. 30, after two years in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: Jazz & Colors, which has twice presented a bounty of jazz ensembles at picturesque locations all over Central Park, will return this year. But the festival is moving indoors — to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, according to an announcement scheduled to be made today. “Jazz & Colors: The Masterworks Edition,” as it’s being called, will be held on Friday, Jan. 30, with sets at 6 and 7:30 p.m. It will be free with museum admission.

headline: Daily Report: F.B.I. Offers More Evidence Linking North Korea to Attack on Sony
abstract: Instead of routing their attacks through decoy servers, the hackers sent them directly from web addresses in North Korea, the F.B.I. said. But some skeptics still wanted to see the agency’s evidence.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I.’s director, James B. Comey, said on Wednesday that the United States had concluded that North Korea was behind the destructive attacks on Sony Pictures partly because the hackers failed to mask their location when they broke into the company’s servers, Michael S. Schmidt, Nicole Perlroth and Matthew Goldstein report.

headline: Morning Agenda: Fed Shows Signs of Optimism
abstract: Fed officials are encouraged by the strength of the economy. | Lenders are engaging with upstart rivals. | Standard Chartered will close its equities business. | William H. Gross helps fuel his new fund with his own cash.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials were encouraged by the strength of the economy at the December meeting of the Fed’s policy-making committee, according to an official account published on Wednesday. But the signs of optimism were tempered by concern that the weakness of the global economy, and the weak response of foreign governments, could weigh on domestic growth, Binyamin Appelbaum reports in The New York Times. As a result, the account of the meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee made clear that Fed officials were determined not to act too quickly on raising interest rates.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Showtime) FINDING VIVIAN MAIER (2014) In 2007, John Maloof bought a box of negatives — nearly 40,000, taken from the 1950s to the ’70s — at a Chicago auction for about $400. He was told they were by Vivian Maier, but a Google search revealed no information about her. Eventually he mounted some of the works on Flickr, which led to a story in the British newspaper The Independent and an exhibition at the Chicago Cultural Center about Ms. Maier, a nanny and amateur street photographer who died in 2009. This film, which Mr. Maloof directed with Charlie Siskel, documents his search for the woman behind the images while serving as a sort of feature-length advertisement for the work he owns, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “It’s no surprise that Maier is now the subject of a documentary, given the quality of her work, the nominal exoticism of her life and the secrets that still drift around her,” Ms. Dargis said. “She’s a terrific story — part Mary Poppins, part Weegee — who was at once emancipated and in service.” Still, she added, “time and professional pronouncements will decide if she was an outsider artist or just an unorthodox one who, as a single 20th-century woman, found freedom, her voice and her own private bohemia while under cover of other people’s bourgeois domesticity.” The documentary has been shortlisted as an Oscar contender.

headline: She’s About a Lot More Than That Bass
abstract: The singer-songwriter Meghan Trainor made a splash with the bouncy “All About That Bass,” but she has no intention of being a one-hit wonder.

headline: A Literary Triumvirate of Love and Lust
abstract: “Beloved Sisters” imagines a fraught ménage à trois among the German poet and dramatist Friedrich Schiller and the sisters Charlotte von Lengefeld and Caroline von Lengefeld.
lead_paragraph: A frail, handsome artistic genius and the women who fuss and fight over him: That not-so-novel concept powers the German director Dominik Graf’s sumptuous, soaked-in-suds costume drama, “Beloved Sisters.” The movie, Germany’s candidate for the best foreign-language Oscar, imagines a fraught ménage à trois of the German poet and dramatist Friedrich Schiller (Florian Stetter) and two sisters.

abstract: One day soon, we may be able to quickly scan a patient’s brain, check his brain activity “fingerprint” and select an antidepressant or psychotherapy accordingly.

headline: Intel Takes Wearables Beyond the Wrist and Dares Fashion to Have a New Idea
abstract: The new Curie is a low-power Bluetooth device the size of a suit button with computing, motion sensor and battery-charging abilities.
lead_paragraph: I admit it, among the shows I have been most excited about recently is one that is not a fashion show at all, but the Consumer Electronics Show, and if my fashion travel schedule weren’t so horrendous, I’d be in Las Vegas right now. As it is, I’ve had to survive on live streams and a constant check-in with the Twitterati. And at this stage, the news that has most piqued my interest, because I think it has the greatest potential to affect the fashion wearables market, is the introduction of Intel’s button-sized computer.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Stéphane Charbonnier was perched, as was his habit every Wednesday morning, at a U-shaped wooden table on the second floor of the light-filled Parisian offices of Charlie Hebdo, the French satirical newspaper he headed. An array of papers was spread before him.

headline: Dick’s Sporting Goods Is an Attractive Candidate for Private Equity Firms
abstract: The financial health of Dick’s Sporting Goods suggests that there is ample room for a new private equity owner to generate a nice return, Kevin Allison writes in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Dick’s Sporting Goods may become the next private equity plaything. The vendor, whose stock is valued at more than $6 billion, is contemplating a leveraged buyout, according to a Reuters report on Wednesday. A relatively clean balance sheet means there is an opportunity to make money. It would, however, require healthy growth assumptions for the company at a time when stiff online competition is challenging many retailers.

headline: A Softer Side of Loathing
abstract: The comedian Louis CK treated the Madison Square Garden audience to willfully eccentric and delightfully illogical new jokes in his stand-up act.
lead_paragraph: No comic moves from premise to punch line as unpredictably as Louis CK.

headline: Sebastian Seung’s Quest to Map the Human Brain
abstract: Using crowdsourcing and artificial intelligence, a Princeton neuroscientist is hoping to map the intricate wiring of the human brain. If he succeeds, could we live forever as data?
lead_paragraph: In 2005, Sebastian Seung suffered the academic equivalent of an existential crisis. More than a decade earlier, with a Ph.D. in theoretical physics from Harvard, Seung made a dramatic career switch into neuroscience, a gamble that seemed to be paying off. He had earned tenure from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology a year faster than the norm and was immediately named a full professor, an unusual move that reflected the sense that Seung was something of a superstar. His lab was underwritten with generous funding by the elite Howard Hughes Medical Institute. He was a popular teacher who traveled the world — Zurich; Seoul, South Korea; Palo Alto, Calif. — delivering lectures on his mathematical theories of how neurons might be wired together to form the engines of thought.

headline: Yankees Are Banking on Stephen Drew to Regain His Form at the Plate
abstract: Drew, who has agreed to a one-year, $5 million deal, hit far below his career average last year after missing spring training and the first two months of the season.
lead_paragraph: During the final week of the 2014 regular season, when almost every microphone and camera lens at Yankees games was pointed in Derek Jeter’s direction, Stephen Drew was quietly finishing his worst year in the major leagues.

headline: An Artistic Video from the Hot Chip Spinoff New Build
abstract: For their sophomore album’s title single, “Pour It On,” the band approached the filmmaker Richard Heslop, who offered up a video starring the performance artist Rachel Gomme.
lead_paragraph: “We had no real desire to release a video for this song unless we found something we really liked,” says the British synthesizer artist and programmer Felix Martin of “Pour It On,” the new single from his band New Build. It was serendipity, then, when the band received an entrancing, unreleased video by the filmmaker Richard Heslop, known for his work with the Smiths and the Cure, which fit perfectly with the atmospheric track. “I had seen a show reel of his work, and I really liked his approach to editing, as well as the way he worked with sound footage and different kinds of textures,” Martin says. The band approached Heslop, who offered up the footage that would eventually become the video for “Pour It On.” It stars the British performance artist Rachel Gomme, who walks the beach while continuously filling her dress up with stones as a personal test of endurance.

headline: Singing Oscar’s Tune
abstract: Unexpected musical names are coming up this awards season, including Patti Smith, who said she felt a responsibility when it came to composing a ballad for “Noah.”
lead_paragraph: For even the most established musician, composing for film can be terrifying. As Patti Smith, the “godmother of punk” who wrote the lullaby “Mercy Is” for “Noah,” told the Bagger: “There’s nothing worse than when you’re watching a movie and one of the characters takes you out and you no longer believe the atmosphere. The same thing can happen with the wrong piece of music, so I felt a responsibility.”

headline: Next Year in Havana
abstract: The Cuba you can look forward to.
lead_paragraph: Cuba is the idiosyncratic sister of the Caribbean, and a large part of its idiosyncrasy stems from having watched as the last half-century passed it by. What was once a cultural hotbed moldered under Communism. Still, there is an embattled dignity in Havana’s dilapidated architecture, whether colonial style or Art Deco or even the midcentury classics; nowhere else does the traveler find this peculiar marriage between the contemporary and the antiquated, with its incongruous traces of the space age, of Spanish flair and Soviet flotsam. There is, too, a unique resilience among Cubans themselves, whose talent for improvisation, for making do with what’s at hand, is legendary. The feeling of living in frozen time is one of Cuba’s most frustrating realities and its most powerful allure. To imagine Cuba without it evokes an almost existential question.

headline: 1915: Wedding Party Travels in Punts
keywords: ['Social Conditions and Trends', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'World War I (1914-18)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives:1915 Heavy Flooding Forces Wedding Party to Travel in Punts.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As a result of the floods there was a romantic military wedding at Bray yesterday.The bride, bridegroom and the guests had to travel part of the way to the church in punts. The bridegroom was Captain Forbes Adams, of the Indian army, who only arrived here last night straight from the trenches on a week’s leave. The bride was Miss Pitman, the second daughter of Mr. F. Pitman, the well-known Cambridge ‘‘Blue.’’ Every arrangement had been made by Mr. Pitman to enable the wedding party to get to and from the church, for his house, Bray Mead, is completely surrounded by water. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 8, 1915

headline: Mapping Out a Holiday With the Family
abstract: A long title is only the beginning of the brashness in “A Beautiful Day in November on the Banks of the Greatest of the Great Lakes.”
lead_paragraph: If you want to see true collaboration between a playwright and a director, check out the floor of the performing space at City Center Stage II. It’s a mass of painted lines that suggests what you’d get if a football-play diagram and an astrological chart had a baby. And it was the key that allowed a young director to take an intriguing but formless play by a new writer and make a startlingly entertaining theatrical experience out of it.

headline: An Upper East Side Apartment Convenient to Work

headline: Clothes and Character: Colleen Atwood on ‘Into the Woods’ and ‘Big Eyes’
abstract: The designer explains the thinking behind the costumes in two of her projects, which ended up being released on the same day.
lead_paragraph: Having two projects released on the same day was a surprise for Colleen Atwood, the costume designer for both “Big Eyes,” Tim Burton’s biopic about the artist Margaret Keane, and “Into the Woods,” Rob Marshall’s adaptation of the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical. Both films hit theaters on Dec. 25, one of the most competitive box office dates of the year.

lead_paragraph: The composer John Luther Adams continues to ride the wave. Mr. Adams, who won a Pulitzer Prize last year for his mesmerizing,environmentally aware orchestral work “Become Ocean,” will be awarded the $50,000 William Schuman Award this fall, Columbia University’s School of the Arts announced on Thursday.

On a recent Sunday afternoon inside a Midtown Manhattan high-rise, where the teenage Sevian had been invited for a training session with the chess champion Garry Kasparov, he recalled a recent game with enormous stakes.
