headline: Always on His Own Terms
abstract: Ray Johnson, who drowned 20 years ago this week, has become an inspiration to a new generation of younger artists.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago next week, the artist Ray Johnson jumped off a low bridge in Sag Harbor, N.Y., and backstroked placidly out to sea. Two teenage girls saw him plunge into the frigid water and tried to alert the police, but when they found the station closed they went to see a movie instead, a detail many of Mr. Johnson’s friends said would have delighted him.

headline: 1956 | ‘The Voice of a Free Press’
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Self-Incrimination', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: David W. Dunlap writes of a 1956 Times editorial titled “The Voice of a Free Press,” which challenged the Eastland committee’s prejudice against members of the Communist Party.
lead_paragraph: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

headline: How Keystone XL Got (So) Political
abstract: As Washington debates Keystone XL, here’s how the 1,179-mile pipeline became so political.
lead_paragraph: As Washington debates Keystone XL, here’s how the 1,179-mile pipeline became so political.

headline: Experts Say That Battle on Keystone Pipeline Is Over Politics, Not Facts
keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The bill, which President Obama has said he would veto, was sent along for consideration by the full Senate the day before the House was expected to approve its own version of the bill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2009, the Obama administration approved a 986-mile pipeline to bring 400,000 barrels of oil sands petroleum a day from western Canada to the United States. Almost no one paid attention. Construction on the pipeline, called the Alberta Clipper, was quietly completed last year.

headline: Spineless? A Squish? The Words Do Sting, Boehner Says
abstract: Two days after surviving a minor coup attempt, Speaker John A. Boehner on Thursday took a stab at answering the question that has been nagging him for his entire speakership: Why do Tea Party conservatives hate him so much?
lead_paragraph: Two days after surviving a minor coup attempt, Speaker John A. Boehner on Thursday took a stab at answering the question that has been nagging him for his entire speakership: Why do Tea Party conservatives hate him so much?

headline: Honda Fined for Violations of Safety Law
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration fined Honda $35 million in each of two civil penalties, the most levied against a carmaker at a time.
lead_paragraph: In a sharp escalation of penalties against automakers that skirt safety laws, the nation’s top auto safety agency has fined Honda Motor a record $70 million for grossly underreporting fatal accidents and injuries to the government, regulators said on Thursday.

headline: 1965: Actress Still a U.S. Citizen
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1965: Elizabeth Taylor Decides Not To Renounce Her U.S. Citizenship.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Elizabeth Taylor tried to renounce her U.S. citizenship but failed because she could not bring herself to disavow ‘‘all allegiance and fidelity’’ to the United States, the State Department said today. The London-born film star reportedly said the United States had been good to her and that she did not want to imply that she bore it ill will by using such language. Miss Taylor’s New York spokesman said she decided to renounce her citizenship because she wanted to have the same citizenship as her husband, British actor Richard Burton. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 8, 1965

headline: A Foreign Film Coincidence, Two Years in a Row
abstract: Like last year when the Israeli and Palestinian entries followed similar plots, this year’s Oscar entries from Estonia and Georgia tell nearly the same story, though in very different ways.
lead_paragraph: In last year’s competition for the Oscar for best foreign-language film, something seemingly odd, the apparent product of coincidence, happened: the Israeli and Palestinian submissions dealt with the same story. Both Yuval Adler’s “Bethlehem” and Hany Abu-Assad’s “Omar,” which eventually received a nomination, focused on the relationship between a young Palestinian informer and his control agent in Israeli intelligence, and the two movies even ended the same way, with the mole turning on his handler.

headline: In Vermont, Election Is Held on Nov. 4, and Governor Is Chosen on Jan. 8
abstract: The election had to be decided by the Legislature after the front-runner, Gov. Peter Shumlin, a Democrat, failed to win 50 percent of the vote in November.
lead_paragraph: MONTPELIER, Vt. — November came and went, and even until Thursday, Vermonters did not know who would be inaugurated as governor. They seemed to take this uncertainty in stride, much as they ignored the record-breaking low temperature of minus 20 degrees that encased the gray granite statehouse here in a brittle air.

headline: Washington Power Lunch
abstract: Equinox, a downtown D.C. restaurant, saw a particularly power-packed crowd visit for lunch on Thursday.

headline: Uber Tests a Cargo Delivery Service in Hong Kong
abstract: The ride-hailing start-up experiments with a new courier service.
lead_paragraph: Uber has made millions offering quick, convenient rides to customers. Its ambitions are much larger.

headline: First Draft Focus: And I Had On These Bright Blue Slippers!
abstract: President Obama surprised a woman in Phoenix.

headline: Peaks and Valleys of Nero d’Avola
abstract: The wine panel explores the red grape of Sicily.
lead_paragraph: For a decade now, Sicily has been among the most exciting wine regions in the world. I’ve fallen in love with reds and whites, wines full of freshness and vitality, complexity and a sense of place, from both Mount Etna in the east and the region centering on Vittoria in the southeast.

headline: A Georgian Competing on Estonia’s Behalf
abstract: The director of “Tangerines,” on the shortlist for the foreign-language film Oscar, knew little about Estonia — and didn’t speak the language — when he started this project.
lead_paragraph: It is 1992, shortly after the breakup of the Soviet Union, and the newly independent republic of Georgia is embroiled in a war with a Russian proxy army supporting the breakaway province of Abkhazia. From the Caucasus Mountains to the Black Sea, villagers have fled, but in one remote settlement a pair of old men, Ivo and Margus, have stubbornly remained behind, hoping to harvest a crop of tangerines.

headline: Paris Terror Suspect Shown in 2005 Film
abstract: Chérif Kouachi, one of the suspects in the Charlie Hebdo shootings in Paris, appeared in a 2005 investigative documentary about jihadism that aired on French television.
lead_paragraph: Chérif Kouachi, one of the suspects in the Charlie Hebdo shootings in Paris, appeared in a 2005 investigative documentary about jihadism that aired on French television.

headline: General Motors Chief Pledges to Move Beyond Recalls
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'North American International Auto Show']
abstract: “It was a year of great disappointment, but also great progress,” Mary T. Barra said, after a year in which the company issued a record number of recalls in the United States.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In her first year as chief executive of General Motors, Mary T. Barra was engulfed by the gravest safety crisis in the company’s history.

headline: Caesars Gets More Support for Restructuring Plan, With Sale by BlackRock
abstract: With about a week remaining before its operating unit expects to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, Caesars is trying to rally support among bondholders for a plan to streamline the bankruptcy process.
lead_paragraph: Some of Wall Street’s largest investors are playing a game of high-stakes poker in preparation for a big casino company bankruptcy.

headline: The Stumbling, Tumbling Euro
keywords: ['Euro (Currency)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Editorials', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The currency markets have a message: European leaders are not doing enough.
lead_paragraph: European leaders and central bankers have been saying for years that their economic policies would soon revive the economies of the eurozone. It seems that investors have finally stopped believing those fairy tales.

headline: First Build an Island, Then Make a Film
abstract: “Corn Island,” Georgia’s entry for the foreign-language film Oscar, has few characters and little dialogue, so it seemed like production would not be difficult. Until the filmmakers realized that the setting needed to be created from scratch.
lead_paragraph: The Georgian filmmaker George Ovashvili, director and co-writer of “Corn Island,” says he is living a dream these days. He was 13 when he decided he wanted to direct movies, but his first feature, “The Other Bank,” was released only when he was 45, after years of political turmoil in his homeland and decades of personal struggle and sacrifice.

headline: When Dynasties Roamed
abstract: Once upon a time, it was common for teams to advance to the Super Bowl two years in a row.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, it was common for teams to advance to the Super Bowl two years in a row.

headline: Alongside ‘Je Suis Charlie,’ Slain Officer Inspires His Own Social Media Refrain
abstract: Along with “I Am Charlie,” protesters adopted a slogan to pay tribute to Ahmed Merabet, the officer killed outside the Charlie Hebdo office, whose parents were from North Africa.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In an amateur video that was widely circulated online after the shooting Wednesday at the Charlie Hebdo newspaper offices in Paris, two gunmen could be seen killing a police officer as he lay wounded on the ground.

headline: Tenderloin Artists Unite
abstract: As a tech boom reshapes San Francisco, a nonprofit group is searching for and cataloging the artists of the Tenderloin, arguably the central city’s last working-class neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: As a tech boom reshapes San Francisco, a nonprofit group is searching for and cataloging the artists of the Tenderloin, arguably the central city’s last working-class neighborhood.

headline: A Different ‘Lion’ to Stalk the Stage
abstract: Complicité, a troupe known for haunting experimental work, brings “Lionboy,” its first full-fledged family production, to the New Victory.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A length of rubber tubing becomes a bucket of squirming eels. Aluminum ladders are transformed into the cage-like walls of a sinister pharmaceutical company. Boxes and ropes evoke the crowded, bustling streets of London or a ship peopled by an itinerant circus troupe.

headline: A Close Call on Publication of Charlie Hebdo Cartoons
abstract: The executive editor changed his mind twice before deciding the cartoons did not meet Times standards
lead_paragraph: Was The Times cowardly and lacking in journalistic solidarity when it decided not to publish the images from the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo that precipitated the execution of French journalists?

headline: In Ray Rice Case, N.F.L. Chose Not to Ask Many Questions
abstract: Robert S. Mueller III said that the league had not seen the video of Mr. Rice punching his fiancée before it was made public, but that it did not seek additional information aggressively.
lead_paragraph: An investigation into how the N.F.L. handled a domestic abuse case involving the former Baltimore Ravens running back Ray Rice determined that the league was aware of the nature of the altercation but chose not to aggressively pursue additional information.

headline: Top Bankers in Europe Making Big Bonuses, According to Latest Data
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bonuses', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Figures recently released show that Goldman Sachs paid, on average, $4.7 million to 121 people classified as “material risk takers” in 2013.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The public is getting its annual peek at the top earners in Europe at major banks.

headline: Teaching ‘The Kite Runner’ With The New York Times
abstract: Five ways to use New York Times content to approach this novel with students.
lead_paragraph: In the original Times review of “The Kite Runner,” published in 2003, Edward Hower describes the novel as telling “a story of fierce cruelty and fierce yet redeeming love.” He goes on to write, “Both transform the life of Amir, Khaled Hosseini’s privileged young narrator, who comes of age during the last peaceful days of the monarchy, just before his country’s revolution and its invasion by Russian forces.”

headline: Police Department Slowdown? A Parker’s Paradise and a Reporter’s Challenge
abstract: The Metro reporter Vivian Yee wrote about the effects of an apparent police slowdown in New York City and the challenge of covering the absence of events.
lead_paragraph: This week, the Metro reporter Vivian Yee wrote  about the visible effects of an apparent slowdown in arrests and ticketing by the New York Police Department. Here, Ms. Yee describes the reportorial oddity of covering events that are NOT occurring.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | A Most Violent Year
abstract: The writer and director J.C. Chandor narrates a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: The writer and director J.C. Chandor narrates a sequence from his film.

headline: Santander Finally Gets the Message on Capital
abstract: The Spanish lender had resisted raising equity. Now the new executive chairwoman, Ana Patricia Botín, has shown that she can decisively break with her father’s legacy, says Fiona Maharg-Bravo of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Ana Patricia Botín is grabbing the bull by the horns. The new executive chairwoman of Banco Santander is seeking 7.5 billion euros of fresh equity in a speedy share sale and slashing the dividend. The Spanish bank has long resisted raising capital or touching its outsize payout. The moves may be overdue and including pre-emption rights would have been fairer on shareholders. But Santander is getting capital now without the challenge of a drawn-out rights issue during a critical Greek election.

headline: Obama, in Bid to Ease Home Buying, Cuts Mortgage Insurance Rate
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'United States Economy', 'Mortgages', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama said the reduction, which could cut $900 in costs for home buyers, would make purchasing a home cheaper for hundreds of thousands of people.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — President Obama announced on Thursday new measures to try to assist a still-sluggish housing market, even as he hailed an economic recovery that he said was finally roaring ahead.

headline: Documentary on Russell Brand to Open South by Southwest Film Festival
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: “Brand: A Second Coming,” directed by Ondi Timoner, will open the festival on March 13.
lead_paragraph: Russell Brand, the comedian, actor, author and activist, will take the spotlight at the South by Southwest Film Festival: he’s the subject of the opening-night film, “Brand: A Second Coming,”  organizers announced Thursday. The documentary, directed by Ondi Timoner (“We Live in Public”), offers an intimate look at the British entertainer, whose  film credits    include  “Get Him to the Greek,” “Forgetting Sarah Marshall” and, in the title role,  the remake of the 1981 comedy “Arthur.”

headline: Congress Passes Measure to Cover Terrorism Risk
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Insurance', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: The legislation passed the Senate after addition of a measure to ease some regulations on financial derivatives.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday gave overwhelming final congressional approval to a revamped federal backstop to terrorism insurance, just eight days after lawmakers allowed it to lapse. Businesses had pleaded for the bill, saying it was necessary to avoid losing some important investments.

headline: Robert S. Mueller III's Report on Ray Rice Domestic Violence Case
abstract: The report by Robert S. Mueller III, the former F.B.I. director chosen by the N.F.L. to determine how the league handled its investigation of a domestic abuse case involving the former Baltimore Ravens running back Ray Rice.
lead_paragraph: The report by Robert S. Mueller III, the former F.B.I. director chosen by the N.F.L. to determine how the league handled its investigation of a domestic abuse case involving the former Baltimore Ravens running back Ray Rice.

headline: Talking to Your Teenager About Online Pornography
abstract: Start here: “We need to talk about Internet pornography; there are a few things I want to be sure you know,” and continue to the things your family considers the most important.
lead_paragraph: If “Parenting in the Age of Online Pornography” has you worried, take heart. Encountering pornography on the Internet, intentionally or inadvertently, may be a near-guarantee for the modern teenager, but the parents of those teenagers don’t need to feel helpless in the anticipation of the event, or in its discovery.

headline: The Recruiter From Another Planet
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: A job seeker wonders about the unorthodox approach of an ostensible recruiter.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago I received an email from someone using a Gmail address, claiming to be a headhunter representing Fortune 500-level companies. The person asked about my interest in a position at an unnamed firm, and requested a résumé. I responded positively, but became suspicious when a follow-up asked for my salary information and the reason I’d left the last company I worked for.

headline: Whose Baby Is ‘Boyhood’?
abstract: Two producers of “Boyhood,” a leading contender in the Oscar race, have found themselves cut out by the Producers Guild of America.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In early September 2001, Barack Obama was a state senator. The World Trade Center still stood. And the director Richard Linklater was sitting in a restaurant in Venice, pondering a very personal film idea.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: marriage, youth and exercise and alcohol poisoning. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: marriage, youth and exercise and alcohol poisoning. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Obama Announces Housing Plan in Arizona
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Homeowner Affordability and Stability Plan', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Insurance', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president visited Arizona to herald gains in the recovering housing market and announced a housing initiative to lower annual mortgage insurance premiums.
lead_paragraph: The president visited Arizona to herald gains in the recovering housing market and announced a housing initiative to lower annual mortgage insurance premiums.

headline: Chita Rivera and Roger Rees to Star in ‘The Visit’ on Broadway
abstract: “The Visit,” directed by John Doyle, will open at the Lyceum Theater on April 23, the eligibility deadline for 2015 Tony nominations.
lead_paragraph: The Tony Award winners Chita Rivera and Roger Rees will star on Broadway this spring in “The Visit,” a darkly romantic musical that has been evolving over the last 15 years; its creators are the acclaimed theatrical songwriters John Kander and Fred Ebb (“Chicago,” “Cabaret”) and their frequent collaborator, Terrence McNally. The producers announced on Thursday that “The Visit,” directed by the Tony winner John Doyle (the 2005 Broadway revival of “Sweeney Todd”), will begin performances March 26 at the Lyceum Theater and open on April 23 – the eligibility deadline for 2015 Tony nominations.

headline: Inside Helmut Lang’s New Art Show
abstract: The former fashion designer’s first solo exhibition in New York opens tonight at Sperone Westwater.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, Helmut Lang sold his stake in his eponymous label and shifted focus to making art at his studio in East Hampton. Tonight, he opens his first New York City solo gallery show at Sperone Westwater in SoHo, presenting a body of sculptural works from 2010 to 2014. Some include repurposed materials from his past vocation, while other, more recent, works comment on the passage of time in a less narrative and more metaphysical way.

headline: The Risk of ‘Material Parenting’
abstract: Does dangling goods in front of children as a reward for good behavior or yanking them away as a form of punishment contribute to materialism when those kids grow up?
lead_paragraph: As a parent and scholar who has studied materialism for much of her professional life, Marsha Richins had long pondered the following question: Does dangling goods in front of children as a reward for good behavior or yanking them away as a form of punishment contribute to materialism when those kids grow up?

headline: Man Convicted of Environmental Terrorism Is Freed
abstract: The man, Eric McDavid, 37, was convicted in 2007 of conspiring to bomb several targets near Sacramento, Calif., as part of a radical environmental campaign.
lead_paragraph: A man serving a 19-year prison sentence for environmental terrorism won an early release from prison on Thursday, with a California judge approving a settlement between defense lawyers and prosecutors that acknowledged that the authorities had withheld documents during his criminal trial.

headline: Honda Motors Fined a Record Amount, but It’s Still Just a Rounding Error
abstract: The $70 million penalty is nothing in comparison with the company’s $1.5 billion operating profit for July through September.
lead_paragraph: After a year filled with news about the negligence of automakers, federal regulators are getting tougher on car companies. But the penalties still seem modest.

headline: New Clues on Google’s Plans for Insurance
keywords: ['Automobile Insurance and Liability', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: A Forrester analyst has speculated that Google is on the cusp of launching a U.S. insurance-shopping site.
lead_paragraph: The insurance industry takes it for granted that Google will soon introduce its Google Compare auto insurance shopping site — available in Britain for two years — in the United States.

headline: Unraveling the Key to a Cold Virus’s Effectiveness
abstract: New research suggests that lower temperatures help rhinoviruses get past the immune system.
lead_paragraph: If there is a champion among contagions, it may well be the lowly rhinovirus, responsible for many of the coughs and sniffles that trouble us this time of year. Rhinoviruses are spectacularly effective at infecting humans. Americans suffer one billion colds a year, and rhinoviruses are the leading cause of these infections.

headline: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar to Publish a Novel About Sherlock Holmes’s Brother Mycroft
abstract: Mr. Abdul-Jabbar will release his first novel this fall: “Mycroft Holmes,” starring Sherlock Holmes’ brainy older brother.
lead_paragraph: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar’s first novel, “Mycroft Holmes,” which stars Sherlock Holmes’ brainy older brother, will be published this fall by Titan Books.

headline: Trove of Still Lifes on the Auction Block
abstract: An assemblage of Dutch and Flemish master paintings collected by Henry and June Weldon will be sold at Sotheby’s on April.
lead_paragraph: Until recently, Henry and June Weldon’s Park Avenue apartment reflected a kind of passionate, obsessive collecting of a bygone era. Wood-paneled rooms featured cabinets stuffed with rare English pottery and 17th-century Dutch and Flemish paintings hung cheek by jowl on every available wall. Asian sculptures were also scattered around the place.

headline: What I Love | Angus McIndoe
abstract: The restaurateur parks his sneakers far from the Broadway crowd.
lead_paragraph: The restaurateur parks his sneakers far from the Broadway crowd.

headline: Barbara Boxer and the Rise of Democratic Partisan Discipline
abstract: The California senator voted with her colleagues 98 percent of the time in the last two years. She was part of a trend.
lead_paragraph: It might seem unremarkable that Senator Barbara Boxer of California, who announced on Thursday that she would not seek re-election, voted with a majority of her Democratic colleagues 98 percent of the time during the past two years.

headline: Shamans on Call for Rites Near Machu Picchu
abstract: Luxury hotels are calling on Andean shamans to spiritually cleanse their guests, renew wedding vows and lead ceremonies to offer gratitude to Mother Earth.
lead_paragraph: In the highlands surrounding Machu Picchu in Peru, luxury hotels are calling on Andean shamans to spiritually cleanse their guests, renew wedding vows and lead ceremonies to offer gratitude to Mother Earth.

headline: The One-Word Resolution
abstract: “A word can’t be broken. It serves as a reminder; a filter. It’s who you want to be instead of what you regret.”
lead_paragraph: I love this idea. For New Year’s, instead of a resolution (and it’s not too late for resolutions, the month is still fresh), why not boil all your bubbling good intentions down into a single word? It came first from a Facebook post from Lisa Belkin, in which she credits the author Laura Lippman for the inspiration:

headline: Former Georgia Tech Engineering Professor Indicted on Racketeering Charges
abstract: Dr. Joy Laskar, once a high-profile electrical engineering professor, has been indicted on racketeering charges, nearly five years after his career at the Georgia Institute of Technology collapsed over a wireless chip start-up he founded.
lead_paragraph: A former high-profile electrical engineering professor has been indicted on racketeering charges, nearly five years after his career at the Georgia Institute of Technology collapsed over a wireless chip start-up he founded.

headline: Tracing a World Awash in Lies
abstract: The Chinese artist Sun Xun’s exhibition at Sean Kelly Gallery reflects his simultaneous fascination with and distrust of history.
lead_paragraph: Sun Xun was in residence at Sean Kelly in December, working in an ad hoc studio on the lower level of the gallery with his assistants and adding paintings and drawings to the exhibition upstairs as he went along. The news release for the show says, “Questions and dialogue with the artist will be encouraged,” so I obliged.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
abstract: France and More – Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: France and More – Pictures of the Day

headline: Raising the Profile of Columbia’s Art
abstract: An art historian at Columbia has made it his mission to get more people to notice thousands of objects on campus.
lead_paragraph: Columbia University owns thousands of antiquities, antiques and paintings, but it has no major display spaces and no comprehensive database. So the works largely go unnoticed even by some staff members. Roberto C. Ferrari, an art historian and librarian who became Columbia’s curator of art properties in 2013, has set out to raise the profile of the 10,000 objects on campus.

headline: Times Readers on the Charlie Hebdo Massacre
abstract: Many wondered why The Times had not printed the cartoons.
lead_paragraph: Readers responding to a Times editorial on the Charlie Hebdo killings seemed most keen to discuss what wasn’t in the editorial: Reproductions of Charlie Hebdo cartoons.  A Times spokesperson has explained that the paper does “not normally publish images or other material deliberately intended to offend religious sensibilities.” But many readers said that was a cop out.

headline: J. C. Chandor Narrates a Scene From ‘A Most Violent Year’
abstract: The writer and director discusses his film.
lead_paragraph: In this video, the writer and director J. C. Chandor narrates a sequence from his film, featuring Oscar Isaac as the intimidating owner of a heating oil company.

headline: More on the Complex Tax-Minded Deal That Starboard Doesn’t Want Yahoo to Do
abstract: Yahoo isn’t a stranger to the complex deal structure known as a “cash-rich split-off” that could be used to sell off its stakes in its Japanese affiliate and Alibaba Group.
lead_paragraph: The activist hedge fund Starboard Value fretted on Thursday that Yahoo might employ a type of complicated transaction to dispose its minority stakes in the Chinese Internet giant Alibaba Group and in the publicly traded Yahoo Japan.

headline: From Czarist Rubble, a Russian Autocrat Rises
abstract: “Stalin: Paradoxes of Power” is the first of three volumes that, in Stephen Kotkin’s explanation, tell “the story of Russia’s power in the world and Stalin’s power in Russia.”
lead_paragraph: Readers plunging into Stephen Kotkin’s “Stalin: Paradoxes of Power” expecting a detailed dissection of the cobbler’s son and seminarian from Georgia who evolved into the monster called Stalin may be disconcerted to find that, as a boy called Iosif Dzhugashvili (Jughashvili in this book), he plays a relatively minor role in early chapters.

headline: Rudy Burckhardt: ‘Subterranean Monuments: A Centenary Celebration’
abstract: “Subterranean Monuments,” a retrospective at Tibor de Nagy, celebrates the work of Rudy Burckhardt.
lead_paragraph: Rarer than the artist’s artist is the poet’s artist, and Rudy Burckhardt was one. Born in Switzerland in 1914 into a family of scholars and businessmen, he picked up photography early and, after meeting the American poet and critic Edwin Denby, came to New York in 1935. Creating art and living in an aesthetic milieu seemed, initially at least, to have about equal weight for him. Mr. Burckhardt tended to speak of himself as a committed amateur in the sense of being someone who does what he does for love, not glory or pay. In his case, that love embraced several mediums, all represented in a small museum-ready survey called “Rudy Burckhardt: Subterranean Monuments: A Centenary Celebration” at Tibor de Nagy.

headline: Those Who Nailed 2014 See Volatility This Year
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: A survey of investment professionals whose forecasts proved accurate in 2014 indicates a roller-coaster ride for stocks, bonds and oil prices.
lead_paragraph: Volatility will be the new normal in 2015.

headline: Takashi Murakami: ‘In the Land of the Dead, Stepping on the Tail of a Rainbow’
abstract: This show features art created in response to the 2011 earthquake in the Tohoku region of Japan.
lead_paragraph: In his exhibition at Gagosian, Takashi Murakami appears unintimidated by big historical and religious subjects but strangely cowed by his fellow artists. Working in response to the devastating earthquake and tsunami of 2011 in the Tohoku region of Japan, he has come up with a quasi-spiritual installation of paintings and sculptures surrounding a copy of the gates of a Buddhist temple. It invites us to meditate and heal from the trauma of natural disasters and to savor expensively fabricated art objects while worshiping Koons, Hirst and Warhol (as if we needed another place to do that).

headline: Entang Wiharso
abstract: This gaudy, overstuffed exhibition reveals an artist of extraordinary industry and canny versatility.
lead_paragraph: One of Indonesia’s most prominent contemporary artists, Entang Wiharso represented his country in the Venice Biennale of 2013. He has been included in other biennials and museum exhibitions from Tokyo to Rome. This gaudy, overstuffed exhibition reveals an artist of extraordinary industry and canny versatility. In near mural-scale paintings and in sculptures cast in aluminum, brass and resin, he mixes traditional Indonesian styles with Pop and Surrealism, creating allegories of psychic stress in a global economy.

headline: ‘Modern Photographs’
abstract: Photos from the new show at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the new show at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Cy Twombly: ‘Treatise on the Veil’
abstract: This show at the Morgan Library & Museum centers on a vast gray 1970 canvas with white-crayon elements.
lead_paragraph: “Cy Twombly: Treatise on the Veil” ostentatiously combines two museum trends: exhibitions built around one important painting, and the growing urge of museums of all kinds to feature modern and contemporary art. Here the yen for newness is lavishly advertised by a show centering on the billboard-size painting “Treatise on the Veil (Second Version),” a panoramic canvas measuring nearly 33 feet across that Cy Twombly (1928-2011) made in Rome in 1970.

headline: House Passes Bill to Alter Health Law’s Workweek Provision
abstract: The 114th Congress took up its first bill to impose changes to the Affordable Care Act on Thursday, with the House of Representatives passing legislation to expand the definition of a workweek to 40 hours, from 30.
lead_paragraph: The 114th Congress took up its first bill to impose changes to the Affordable Care Act on Thursday, with the House of Representatives passing legislation to expand the law’s definition of a workweek to 40 hours, from 30.

headline: Tamir Rice Shooting Aftermath
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The Cleveland Police Department released surveillance footage showing the aftermath of the shooting of 12-year-old Tamir Rice, in which his sister can be seen running toward him.
lead_paragraph: The Cleveland Police Department released surveillance footage showing the aftermath of the shooting of 12-year-old Tamir Rice, in which his sister can be seen running toward him.

headline: Police Gave Boy No Aid After Shooting in Cleveland
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: After one officer shot Tamir Rice, 12, he and another officer stood by and did not help the wounded boy. An officer also tackled the boy’s sister.
lead_paragraph: The two Cleveland police officers involved in the fatal shooting of Tamir Rice, a 12-year-old boy who was carrying a pellet gun, stood by without rendering medical aid as the boy lay wounded next to their patrol car, a newly released extended surveillance video shows.

headline: ‘For a Love of His People’
abstract: A new show at the National Museum of the American Indian features the work of the photographer Horace Poolaw.
lead_paragraph: A new show at the National Museum of the American Indian features the work of the photographer Horace Poolaw.

headline: Black and White and Accessible All Over
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art’s new exhibition of 20th-century photography from the Walther Collection is enhanced by information tools that give it scope and depth.
lead_paragraph: Overflowing with prints by Berenice Abbott, Andre Kertesz, Edward Weston and other luminaries from the first half of the 20th century, “Modern Photographs: The Thomas Walther Collection, 1909-1949,” at the Museum of Modern Art, would seem to be a straightforward look at photography’s past. But the show, packaged with a book, a symposium and an engrossing interactive website, is really a bold attempt to visualize the future of photography inside the museum as it reckons with the unwieldy, image-saturated culture outside the galleries.

headline: Going Mainstream on Their Own Terms
abstract: Horace Poolaw’s photographs at the National Museum of the American Indian in Lower Manhattan show Native Americans inventively fusing past and present.
lead_paragraph: A 2001 exhibition called “Spirit Capture: Native Americans and the Photographic Image,” at the National Museum of the American Indian in Lower Manhattan, remains one of the most moving photography shows I’ve seen in New York in two decades. Culled from the museum’s permanent collection, it wasn’t about formal perfection or a singular sensibility. It was an archival look at a group of people as they were historically portrayed through a visual medium they didn’t invent and, until recently, rarely used. Indeed, it was a show about how that medium invented and used them, or rather stereotyped images of them — the recalcitrant savage, the timeless primitive, the vanishing race — to create an official American saga from a victor’s point of view.

headline: A Kaleidoscope of Meaning on a Single Surface
abstract: Devin Powers’s kaleidoscopic new paintings at Lesley Heller Workspace muster an elaborate physicality while corralling references to various cultures, mediums and artifacts.
lead_paragraph: Devin Powers’s kaleidoscopic new paintings muster an elaborate physicality while corralling a profusion of references to different cultures, mediums and artifacts within their irregular borders. They might more logically be called painted reliefs, but they confuse matters by being so clearly derived from a single surface on which a mongrel process of drawing, painting and chiseling has run a bit rampant. And nothing is quite as rampant as the unhinged geometric patterns, defined first by automatist drawing and then by divots painted with contrasting colors, which give the best works a writhing, billowing energy.

headline: G.O.P. Faces Push From Right to Be Bolder
abstract: The Heritage Foundation is holding a two-day policy conference next week that is aimed at nudging Republicans toward a more aggressive agenda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Heritage Foundation, long known as a font of conservative ideas, is planning a two-day policy conference next week aimed at nudging Republicans toward a more aggressive agenda, just days before House and Senate Republicans are set to hold a joint retreat.

headline: As San Francisco Booms, So Does its Gallery Scene
abstract: As members of the newly well-heeled tech elite look to invest their money, the city’s small but thriving gallery scene is finding itself the recipient of their attention.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco, as has been well documented, is undergoing seismic cultural shifts. The second technology boom has brought an influx of wealth, investors and start-up prospectors to the city, drawing parallels with the gold rush of 1849. Now, as members of the newly well-heeled tech elite look to invest their money, the city’s small but thriving gallery scene is finding itself the recipient of their attention.

headline: Before Paris Shooting, Authors Tapped Into Mood of a France ‘Homesick at Home’
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Even before the attack on Charlie Hebdo, a futuristic novel and a nostalgic essay had set off intense debate.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The cover of this week’s Charlie Hebdo, the French satirical newspaper that was the target of a massacre on Wednesday by masked gunmen, featured a cartoon depicting Michel Houellebecq, whose polemical — some say prophetic — new novel, “Submission,” imagines a Muslim becoming president of France in 2022.

headline: Passengers’ Accounts of Rescue From Burning Ferry Differ Sharply
keywords: ['Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Ferries', 'Rescues', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Evacuations and Evacuees']
abstract: One passenger rescued in waters off Greece last week told of “chaos.” Another said “everything worked.”
lead_paragraph: VERBANIA, Italy — Leonidha Ndreu was one of the first of nearly 450 passengers to leave the Norman Atlantic, the ill-fated ferryboat that caught fire en route from Greece to Italy early last week, killing at least 11 passengers. Zoran Koron was one of the last.

headline: ‘The Thing and the Thing-in-Itself’
abstract: This exhibition in Chelsea derives from a distinction posited by Immanuel Kant.
lead_paragraph: This spare, thought-provoking exhibition’s title derives from a distinction posited by Immanuel Kant. That is, a thing can be known by a human being only from his or her unique perspective. What the thing is, in and of itself, independent of any perceiver’s view of it, isn’t fully knowable. Organized by the art historian Robert Hobbs, the exhibition presents seven things, which he introduces as “works that pit people’s sight and insight against the limits of what they are able to comprehend.”

headline: Music Emanating From a Box
abstract: In “My Voice Has an Echo in It,” by the Temporary Distortion multimedia theater company, four band members play for six hours in a room-size box walled by mirrors.
lead_paragraph: Temporary Distortion’s durational installation “My Voice Has an Echo in It,” part of the Coil festival, has the feeling of a happening in which not much actually happens. The company drew notice with a trilogy of plays — “Welcome to Nowhere,” “Americana Kamikaze” and “Newyorkland” — that juxtaposed skillful video sequences with less compelling live ones. The video sprawled and soared and dazzled. The stage actors hunched in viselike shadow boxes.

headline: North Korea Seems to Be Closer to Missile-Launching Submarine
keywords: ['Submarines and Submersibles', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: A research group that focuses on North Korea said satellite imagery showed what appeared to be launching tubes on a North Korean submarine.
lead_paragraph: North Korea has displayed its cyberattack capabilities and advances toward making nuclear warheads, the country’s adversaries say. Now, the North appears to have shown progress in fitting submarines with missile launchers.

headline: After Six Years of Homelessness, Taking Comfort in an Apartment of Her Own
abstract: Elisa Byard, 58, who makes $10 an hour as a home health aide, has had trouble paying the rent. She stayed with friends and family and then entered the shelter system, but now has an apartment.
lead_paragraph: After six years without a home, Elisa Byard had no choice but to enter New York City’s shelter system in 2012.

headline: Al Qaeda Trained Suspect in Paris Terror Attack, Official Says
abstract: Saïd Kouachi, 34, one of the two brothers suspected of killing 12 people at a newspaper, spent “a few months” with an Al Qaeda affiliate in Yemen, a U.S. official said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of the two brothers suspected of killing 12 people at a satirical newspaper in Paris traveled to Yemen in 2011 and received terrorist training from Al Qaeda’s affiliate there before returning to France, a senior American official said Thursday.

lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

lead_paragraph: Photos from France, Lebanon, India and the United States.

lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: A Trans-Atlantic View of Modernism
abstract: “Reimagining Modernism: 1900-1950,” an ambitious reinstallation of art from the Met’s permanent collection, offers a view of modernism that is rare for New York museums.
lead_paragraph: At the Metropolitan Museum of Art, lots of works of early European and American modernism are now sharing the same galleries. This shouldn’t be radical. It is. At least for New York.

headline: Boehner vs. the Far Right
abstract: Paul Bloustein, a reader, writes that the “silent majority” does not share the views of far-right Republicans.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Theater Listings for Jan. 9-15
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: When Traveling Through Time, Pack a Change of Identities
abstract: Based on a short story by the science-fiction writer Robert A. Heinlein, “Predestination” tracks the journeys of a Temporal Agent assigned to right wrongs before they happen.
lead_paragraph: Jumping across time and space is tough, thankless business in “Predestination,” a slab of science-fiction speculation draped in old-fashioned detective story crepe. The story centers on a temporal agent, a futuristic enforcer (he tries to right wrongs before they happen) nicely played by Ethan Hawke with a hungry, hangdog look that suggests that his character has spent long nights howling in the wasteland, often without either a scrap or a prayer. Whether slinking through 1985 or another vintage year (usually while chasing down a bomber), the temporal agent looks like a classic lone wolf.

headline: Helping the Transgendered
abstract: A reader pays tribute to her brother’s courage in his transition and his work on health care rights for others like him.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Latter-Day Chaplin, Pining for Romance
abstract: Doug Elkins’s troupe is presenting the clownish “Hapless Bizarre” at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: In recent years the choreographer Doug Elkins has been consumed by stories and the music behind them. His entertaining “Fräulein Maria,” created in 2006, is a Bessie Award-winning sendup of “The Sound of Music.” Six years later Mr. Elkins returned to an early distillation of “Othello,” using a Motown-inspired score and B-boy moves, in his wildly popular “Mo(or)town/Redux.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Weekend Entertainments from the Archives of The New York Times
abstract: Decades before “Downton Abbey” there was “Upstairs, Downstairs,” another imported Edwardian drama and the subject of a gently scolding letter by a reader of The Times in 1974.
lead_paragraph: 41 YEARS AGO

headline: Visual Beauty and History in Hartford
abstract: Hartford bears the scars, and reaps the benefits, of the urban renewal and social upheaval of mid-20th century America. Yet for a small city, it boasts extraordinary ethnic diversity and fluidity.
lead_paragraph: Hartford bears the scars, and reaps the benefits, of the urban renewal and social upheaval of mid-20th century America. Yet for a small city, it boasts extraordinary ethnic diversity and fluidity.

lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Moving Toward Internet Fairness
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission is getting closer to issuing strong rules on broadband service.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Communications Commission is moving closer to issuing strong rules that would stop cable and phone companies from establishing fast lanes and slow lanes on the Internet. Such arrangements would discriminate against smaller companies that have a tough enough time as it is competing against big content providers like Amazon and Netflix.

abstract: A selected, critical guide to the visual arts in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Stigma of Ebola Customer Is Too Much for Bridal Shop
abstract: The store in Akron, Ohio, became known as “the Ebola store” after a Dallas nurse who had visited later tested positive for the virus.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Unable to shake its reputation as “the Ebola store,” an Ohio bridal shop visited by a woman who later tested positive for the virus will close this year, the store’s manager said Thursday.

headline: Gene-Modified Grass
abstract: Jim Hagedorn of Scotts Miracle-Gro Company takes issue with a Business Day article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Seeking Solace Elsewhere, Before Encountering It at Home
abstract: “Valley of Saints” tells the story of two men whose plans are disrupted by a military curfew and whose friendship is threatened by a shared love interest.
lead_paragraph: Dal Lake, the setting of Musa Syeed’s small glowing film “Valley of Saints,” is a picturesque body of water in the Kashmir region where tourists flock to have boatmen take them to sites with names like Floating Garden and Lotus Lake. The water is dotted with small man-made islands.

abstract: A selected, critical guide to classical music performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: The Birth of Civil War Reenacting
abstract: Long before the war ended, soldiers and civilians were putting on sham battles around the country.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of Feb. 22, 1864 in Hillsborough, Ohio, a crowd gathered for a celebration of Washington’s Birthday. “The usual monotony of our peaceful and quiet town was agreeably broken,” wrote the local newspaper, the Highland Weekly News, when three cavalry companies forming the 24th Battalion of the Ohio Volunteer Cavalry, armed and equipped with sabres and carbines, paraded in front of the public square. No one but the officers knew what would happen. In short time, “the 4-pounder known as ‘Old Red’ was brought out, and a gun-squad formed of a number of veteran volunteers.” Then the cavalry galloped off to the outskirts of town, the artillery took position and the infantry began building breastworks.

headline: Challenging Corruption in the Niger Delta
abstract: “Black November,” a blood-for-oil drama directed by Jeta Amata, follows a Nigerian activist who mobilized opposition after a deadly explosion.
lead_paragraph: There are no half-measures in the Nigerian brand of moviemaking called Nollywood: “Black November,” a blood-for-oil drama directed by Jeta Amata, with a mix of Nigerian and American actors, opens with a hostage crisis in a Los Angeles tunnel. It unfolds in flashbacks to corruption and protests in the oil-rich Niger Delta, where Mr. Amata stages as many face-offs and tirades as he can, bringing a full-on pulp style and speechifying to a fraught subject.

headline: High-Ranking Editor to Leave Bloomberg News
abstract: Michael Bloomberg, who recently returned to running the company, said in a note to staff that the departure of Laurie Hays, a senior executive editor, was amicable.
lead_paragraph: Laurie Hays, a senior executive editor at Bloomberg News, is leaving the company, people with knowledge of the matter said on Thursday.

headline: U.S.O.C. Chooses Boston as Candidate for 2024 Summer Olympics
abstract: The United States Olympic Committee on Thursday chose Boston as the American bid city for the 2024 Summer Games, over Los Angeles, San Francisco and Washington.
lead_paragraph: Boston, which stages a celebrated marathon and has a rich history of professional championships in basketball, football, baseball and hockey, will now swing for the fences in international sport as it seeks to host the 2024 Summer Olympics.

headline: Captive, and Not Just to the Internet
abstract: In “Dark Summer,” a teenager becomes the victim of his online obsession.
lead_paragraph: There is something profoundly draining and suffocatingly incestuous about watching a film that’s dedicated to watching a computer screen. It’s as if directors hoped to lure audiences away from their hand-held and desktop devices by focusing on characters who are glued to their own. All they’re likely to end up with, however, are movies that hardly ever move.

headline: Skip Your Annual Physical
keywords: ['Preventive Medicine', 'Medicine and Health', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Doctors', 'Research']
abstract: They cost the country billions, but they don’t save lives.
lead_paragraph: WE all make resolutions and promises to live healthier and better lives, to make the world a better place. Not having my annual physical is one small way I can help reduce health care costs — and save myself time, worry and a worthless exam.

headline: Reading The Times With Meghan Daum
abstract: Writer Meghan Daum reads The New York Times, January 8, 2015.
lead_paragraph: Meghan Daum is an op-ed columnist for The Los Angeles Times and the author, most recently, of “The Unspeakable: And Other Subjects of Discussion.”

headline: In Intimate Quarrels, Deciphering What’s Unsaid
abstract: Corneliu Porumboiu’s ”When Evening Falls on Bucharest or Metabolism” consists of only 17 shots, and the truth in each scene remains ambiguous.
lead_paragraph: Corneliu Porumboiu makes films in which talk leads to obfuscation. “12:08 East of Bucharest” hinges on a debate over whether revolutionary action took place in a small Romanian city in 1989. “Police, Adjective” climaxes with an argument over how literally the law should apply to an insignificant hashish bust.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Jan. 9-15
abstract: A selected guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Winter Blast

headline: DuPont Finds Itself a Target of Activist Nelson Peltz
abstract: The activist investor has nominated four director candidates, escalating his campaign to break up the chemical maker.
lead_paragraph: DuPont is about to face one of the biggest challenges in its two centuries as an industrial powerhouse: a fight with one of Wall Street’s most prominent activist investors over its board.

headline: Spare Times for Jan. 9-15
abstract: A selected guide to readings, discussions, exhibitions and other cultural events in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Around Town

headline: Apple’s Cut From App Sales Reached $4.5 Billion in 2014
abstract: Google’s app store is the largest in the world, but still makes far less money than the Apple App Store.
lead_paragraph: Apple continues to make billions of dollars from mobile apps sold in its App Store. The company said on Thursday that in 2014, billings from app sales rose 50 percent from the previous year, which results in roughly $15 billion in revenue for app developers and a $4.5 billion cut for Apple.

headline: A Family Fractured by the Holocaust
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: In “Farewell Herr Schwarz,” Yael Reuveny follows the trail of relatives who were torn apart.
lead_paragraph: Interweaving multiple perspectives and three generations of family memories, Yael Reuveny’s “Farewell Herr Schwarz” traces a Holocaust mystery with stumbling curiosity and endearing sincerity.

headline: In Cat-Kicking Case, Judge Dismisses Most Serious Charge
abstract: A Brooklyn judge ruled there was no proof that the stray kicked by Andre Robinson, in a notorious video posted on Facebook, had been injured.
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn man whose cat-kicking case infuriated animal activists had his most serious charge dismissed on Thursday, after a State Supreme Court judge ruled that the prosecution had not shown that the cat had been injured.

headline: On the Dawn Wall, Climbing and Tweeting
abstract: Strength, tenacity and maybe a little insanity on a 3,000-foot rock wall.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, N.H. — A LITTLE before noon on Nov. 18, 1970, a blood-flecked hand pawed the top of the southeast face of El Capitan, the massive, 3,000-foot vertical wall in Yosemite National Park known to climbers as the Dawn Wall. A bearded, wild-eyed man eventually pulled himself up and stumbled back into the realm of horizontal existence after 26 nights lashed to the cliff. Approximately 70 reporters and well-wishers rushed forward to greet him. A dozen TV cameras whirred.

headline: Death Watch on a Dutch Farm
abstract: In Nanouk Leopold’s “It’s All So Quiet,” a middle-aged farmer waits on his bedridden father while making plans for when he dies.
lead_paragraph: In “It’s All So Quiet,” the Dutch filmmaker Nanouk Leopold brings us close to a middle-aged farmer who’s looking after his bedridden father, and looking ahead to the changes that are likely to occur when the old man dies.

headline: Searching for Family Along a River of Tears
abstract: JK Youn’s “Ode to My Father” has an obsessive hero seeking relatives lost in the Korean War.
lead_paragraph: Little more than an archipelago of historical set pieces linked by a syrupy causeway of sentiment, JK Youn’s “Ode to My Father” may have slain them in South Korea, but its packaged pain and bullet-point structure are likely to leave Western audiences cold.

headline: N.F.L. Dynasties, on the Decline
abstract: The Super Bowl has become more accessible, to more teams, in recent years, as our dynasty index and accessibility index show.
lead_paragraph: With the Broncos and the Seahawks — last year’s Super Bowl contestants — hosting playoffs games this weekend, the N.F.L. may seem like a closed club, with the same few teams winning every year. Actually, that has never been less true than now.

headline: Where Deer Aren’t the Only Trophies
abstract: In Christopher Denham’s “Preservation,” a hunting party finds itself pursued.
lead_paragraph: A young money manager, his bored wife and his brother, a war veteran, head into the woods to hunt deer in “Preservation,” and as the venerable movie trailer cliché has it, the hunters become the hunted. That’s assured from the opening sequence, which patiently tails their truck at a respectful stalker-cam distance down winding country roads.

headline: Finding Her Way Back in Small, Slow Steps
abstract: In “Something, Anything,” a young newlywed disrupts her closest relationships as she tries to put her life back together after a traumatic loss.
lead_paragraph: The carmine nail polish that Peggy (Ashley Shelton), a young real estate agent in Knoxville, Tenn., applies so carefully at the beginning of “Something, Anything” isn’t the film’s only facade. Before the opening credits have faded, Peggy has married a handsome go-getter (Bryce Johnson), become pregnant and settled in an enviable starter home. But there’s something adrift in her expression, and when a personal tragedy slaps her into awareness, she suspects that the life she has passively accepted may not be the one she wants.

headline: Coca-Cola to Cut Up to 1,800 Jobs
abstract: The company said in the fall that it would eliminate jobs to reduce costs but did not say how many until Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Coca-Cola said on Thursday that it was cutting 1,600 to 1,800 jobs globally as part of $3 billion in costs it hopes to pare over the next several years.

headline: Egypt Moves to Eradicate Town Near Gaza Strip
abstract: Egypt began evacuating hundreds of families from Rafah on Thursday after a senior official acknowledged that the military was eliminating the town to complete a security zone.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt began evacuating hundreds of families from a town bordering the Gaza Strip on Thursday after a senior official acknowledged that the military was eradicating the town in order to complete a security zone abutting the Palestinian territory.

headline: Tripping Over the Hazy Line Between Fiction and Reality
abstract: Raya Martin and Mark Peranson’s “La Última Película” is a goofy, dazzling riff on Dennis Hopper’s ambitious if flawed picture, “The Last Movie.”
lead_paragraph: In 1971, the actor-director Dennis Hopper, flush with success from his directorial debut, “Easy Rider,” made “The Last Movie,” ostensibly a final, definitive statement about the medium but a notorious box office bomb. About a stuntman (Mr. Hopper) who leaves a film production in Peru to live among the locals, the movie, in its ragged, druggy way, aimed to be both a comment on Hollywood cultural imperialism and an apocalyptic examination of fiction versus reality.

headline: Obama Plan Would Help Many Go to Community College Free
keywords: ['Community Colleges', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Income Inequality', 'Tuition', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president’s initiative, which would expand educational opportunities for millions, is another attempt to address persistent income inequality.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Thursday that he would propose a government program to make community college tuition-free for millions of students, an ambitious plan that would expand educational opportunities across the United States.

headline: Codes and Vendettas, Frozen in Time
abstract: A Civil War legacy cascades through the backwoods of North Carolina in the 1970s in “The World Made Straight,” an overcooked adaptation of a Ron Rash novel.
lead_paragraph: A Civil War legacy cascades through the backwoods of North Carolina in the 1970s in “The World Made Straight,” an overcooked adaptation of a novel by Ron Rash.

headline: In Weather Fit for Hibernation, Central Park Grizzly Bears Debut
abstract: On a day when the temperature reached only 21 degrees, two bears, Betty and Veronica, were introduced to the news media.
lead_paragraph: As the city shivered around her, a 20-something blonde, new to this part of town, stood in the middle of Central Park, the wind ruffling her fur coat, and took in her surroundings.

headline: This Week’s Movies | Jan. 9, 2015
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Unbroken,” “A Most Violent Year” and “Into the Woods.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Unbroken,” “A Most Violent Year” and “Into the Woods.”

headline: De Blasio and Police Both Blamed for a Feud That Few Like
abstract: Interviews with New Yorkers about the current strife between Mayor Bill de Blasio and the city’s police officers found plenty of criticism to go around, and an overall sense of frustration.
lead_paragraph: It is understandable that New Yorkers might think they are witnessing something scripted for a grade school playground. In the stubborn showdown between the police and Mayor Bill de Blasio — turned backs, forgiven infractions — many citizens can only watch with sentiments that flow from bemusement to revulsion, if not a mixture of both.

headline: Voodoo Time Machine
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Global Warming', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Leaders in the Republican Party seem to be wrong on everything that counts, but no amount of contrary evidence will get them to change their minds.
lead_paragraph: Many of us in the econ biz were wondering how the new leaders of Congress would respond to the sharp increase in American economic growth that, we now know, began last spring. After years of insisting that President Obama is responsible for a weak economy, they couldn’t say the truth — that short-run economic performance has very little to do with who holds the White House. So what would they say?

headline: The News We Need to Hear
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Journalism Schools', 'News and News Media', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Journalism is good at reporting problems. But society also needs to know how those problems get solved.
lead_paragraph: Happy 2015, our fifth year of Fixes.

headline: Drug Switch May Delay Executions in Ohio
abstract: The state will stop administering the lethal drugs used in a botched execution last year, but the effort to find alternatives could delay future executions.
lead_paragraph: The state of Ohio said Thursday that it might delay several executions as it changes its lethal-drug protocol after a convicted man choked, gasped and clenched his fists for more than 20 minutes during his execution last year.

headline: U.S. Consolidates Forces in Europe to Save Money
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'F-35 Airplane']
abstract: Defense officials said that more American troops would be stationed in Germany and Italy as the United States sought to counter a more aggressive Russia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Defense Department is consolidating American forces in Europe to save what Pentagon officials say will be about $500 million a year while not reducing the number of American military personnel — some 67,000 — who are currently there.

headline: I Am Not Charlie Hebdo
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Terrorism', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Censorship']
abstract: The attack in France reminds us to look closely at our own speech codes, and to remember that offensive speech should be discouraged socially but never legally.
lead_paragraph: The journalists at Charlie Hebdo are now rightly being celebrated as martyrs on behalf of freedom of expression, but let’s face it: If they had tried to publish their satirical newspaper on any American university campus over the last two decades it wouldn’t have lasted 30 seconds. Student and faculty groups would have accused them of hate speech. The administration would have cut financing and shut them down.

headline: Federal Grand Jury to Look at Brownback Loans
abstract: A subpoena asks Carol E. Williams, the executive director of the Kansas Governmental Ethics Commission, to provide documents regarding loans made in 2013 and 2014 to the campaign of Gov. Sam Brownback.
lead_paragraph: Federal grand jurors are scheduled to hear testimony next week about loans made to the re-election campaign of Gov. Sam Brownback of Kansas, a subpoena of a state ethics official shows.

headline: Bombardier’s CSeries Gamble Is Facing Longer Odds
abstract: The company is making an innovative smaller airliner that has been plagued by so many delays that competitors have had time to create similar versions.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — If all had gone according to plan, Bombardier’s direct challenge to the Boeing 737, the world’s best-selling commercial plane, would be approaching its second year in service. Instead, Bombardier’s grand plan for a new plane, the CSeries airliner, has faced myriad delays.

headline: Arch Moore, Trailblazing West Virginia Governor, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Moore was the only governor of the state to serve three four-year terms, and the first sitting governor to be formally charged with a crime.
lead_paragraph: Arch A. Moore Jr., the only West Virginia governor to serve three four-year terms, beginning in 1969, and the first sitting governor of the state to be formally charged with a crime, for which he later served time in federal prison, died on Wednesday in Charleston, W.Va. He was 91.

headline: Voices Join Greek Left’s Call for a New Deal on Debt
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Government Bonds']
abstract: One view about Greece is that a restructuring, as advocated by the leader of a left-of-center coalition, would not be as radical a step as investors fear.

headline: A Welcome Ban on Forever Foam
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Plastics', 'Editorials', 'Foam', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: People haven’t agreed with all of the Bloomberg and de Blasio administrations’ crusades, but those takeout containers are truly noxious.
lead_paragraph: Score another victory for the sustainable city. New York is broadly banning expanded polystyrene, the all but unavoidable, near-everlasting plastic foam used in drink cups, food trays, packing peanuts and many, many other things.

headline: Gun-Running in the Jet Age
abstract: The smuggling of firearms by a Delta baggage handler should shock anyone who has spent time in an airport security line.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has spent time waiting shoeless on an airport check-in line — in fact, anyone who flies — should pay serious attention to the recent revelation that an airline baggage handler was allegedly able to smuggle 153 firearms in an accomplice’s carry-on bag on 17 Delta flights from Atlanta to New York during a seven-month period. The reason, shocking in its simplicity, is that most back-room airport workers are not required to pass through metal detectors on the way to the job.

headline: Debt Buyer Faces Fine and Loss of Thousands of Court Judgments
abstract: A company that buys consumer debt is expected to vacate 4,500 court judgments over concerns that its debt collection lawsuits were riddled with errors and fabrications.
lead_paragraph: In courtrooms across New York State, lawsuits poured in by the hundreds as if manufactured on an assembly line. Some included generic testimony, others relied on bogus affidavits, churned out so rapidly that they were seldom viewed for accuracy.

headline: From Sergeant-at-Arms to Canadian Ambassador, After Ottawa Attack
abstract: Kevin Vickers, the sergeant-at-arms of Canada’s House of Commons, rose from relative obscurity when his role in ending an attack on Parliament was revealed.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Vickers, the sergeant-at-arms of Canada’s House of Commons who became a national hero in October after an armed attack on Parliament, was appointed the ambassador to Ireland on Thursday.

headline: Struck by Bench in School Gym, New Jersey Boy, 7, Dies
abstract: A second grader at a soccer practice died after being struck by a fold-up bench that fell from a wall to which it was believed to be secured, officials said.
lead_paragraph: NEW MILFORD, N.J. — The soccer practice in the Berkley Street Elementary School gym was about to begin on Wednesday evening, and when a ball was kicked toward a wall in the building, Brendan Jordan, 7, a second grader from nearby Bertram F. Gibbs Elementary School, chased after it, officials said. But as he tried to retrieve the ball, they said, a heavy fold-up bench inexplicably fell from a wall where it was thought to have been secured, striking him in the head and killing him.

lead_paragraph: Ty Hensley, the Yankees’ top draft pick in 2012, was severely beaten and was hospitalized on Dec. 28 after a former college football player assaulted him in the town of The Village, Okla., according to a report by the Oklahoma County district attorney.

headline: Peru: Jailed Ex-President Is Convicted of Corruption
abstract: Former President Alberto Fujimori on Thursday was convicted of using public money to influence newspaper coverage during his 2000 re-election campaign.
lead_paragraph: Former President Alberto Fujimori on Thursday was convicted of using public money to influence newspaper coverage during his 2000 re-election campaign. Mr. Fujimori is already serving a 25-year sentence, handed down in 2009, for ordering the killings of 25 people during a war with leftist guerrillas. On Thursday, he was sentenced to eight years to be served concurrently with his earlier sentence so it will not add to his time in jail. Mr. Fujimori, who was president from 1990 to 2000, was also ordered to pay restitution of about $1 million. Local news media reported that evidence showed that a representative of Mr. Fujimori paid newspapers up to $3,000 for articles smearing his opponents. The verdict could affect the political prospects of his daughter, Keiko Fujimori, a probable candidate for president next year.

headline: South Carolina: Former Police Chief’s Defense Begins
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Lawyers for Richard J. Combs, the former Eutawville, S.C., police chief, say he fired his weapon because his life was in jeopardy as he was fighting Bernard Bailey, an unarmed black man, in 2011.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors on Thursday rested their case in the murder trial of a former police chief accused of killing Bernard Bailey, an unarmed black man, in 2011. Lawyers for Richard J. Combs, the former Eutawville, S.C., police chief, immediately began their defense before the jury in Orangeburg County. Prosecutors say Mr. Combs was reckless when he tried to serve an arrest warrant on Mr. Bailey, but Mr. Combs’s lawyers say the chief fired his weapon because his life was in jeopardy when the two men fought. Jurors on Thursday heard from six witnesses, including Brittany Dantzler, a former Eutawville official who saw the shooting and said she thought Mr. Combs was at risk of being “run over” by Mr. Bailey’s truck. Mr. Combs is expected to testify as soon as Friday. The United States Department of Justice investigated the shooting but did not file any charges. Last year, the town agreed to a $400,000 settlement in a lawsuit related to the shooting.

headline: Cuba Is Reported to Release 26 Dissidents
abstract: Some of the prisoners were believed to be among 53 that Cuba had agreed to free last month as part of a thaw with the United States.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — After a flurry of arrests in recent weeks raised questions about its human rights record, Cuba on Thursday released more than two dozen dissidents, some of them believed to be among 53 it had agreed to free last month as the United States and Cuba decided to normalize diplomatic relations.

headline: Robots May Get an Emotional Upgrade, but Humans Are Also Up for Retooling
abstract: “Sorry Robot” at the New Ohio Theater is a gleeful, ramshackle tale of a not-too-distant future in which machines are both our best friends and mortal enemies.
lead_paragraph: Though it is a tale told by an automaton, there is nothing remotely inhuman about “Sorry Robot,” which opened at the New Ohio Theater on Thursday night as part of the 2015 Coil festival of experimental theater. On the contrary, this gleeful, ramshackle tale of a not-too-distant future in which machines are our very best friends and our mortal enemies (or has that day already arrived?) is only and all too human.

headline: Outside the Spotlight, Bill de Blasio Wages a War on Inequality
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Income Inequality', 'Affordable Housing', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: In his first year as New York City’s mayor, Mr. de Blasio has taken steps to close the economic gap between the rich and poor.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, just days into his tenure as New York City’s 109th mayor, Bill de Blasio fell under criticism for his approach to eating pizza, one that depended on cutlery. That this minor peculiarity became a matter of mass media interest — Jon Stewart, Time magazine, The Guardian all weighed in obsessively — only confirmed Mr. de Blasio’s status as a national celebrity. He had been elected by a wide margin, promising to rectify the imbalances of an ever more economically divided city. On the right were predictions that Mr. de Blasio’s progressive commitments would return the city to the anarchy of the 1970s; elsewhere was the concern that we were now to be led by someone dull and dismissible. And yet we haven’t ended up in an era of another Abe Beame.

headline: A New Jersey Town Faces Scrutiny on Police Hiring
abstract: Wayne R. Kubs, 38, a top ranking civil-service veteran, is the second person to file suit against the town of Rutherford, alleging that he was bypassed for a police opening because of favoritism.
lead_paragraph: When Wayne R. Kubs, a former Navy corpsman who spent years deployed in the Middle East, applied to the police force in his hometown in New Jersey, he thought his chances were good. He had grown up in Rutherford, a working-class borough of 18,000 people and about eight miles from Manhattan. He was a volunteer firefighter and a tactical paramedic for the largest hospital in the state, sometimes part of a SWAT team.

headline: Indonesia: Teams Detect Pings at AirAsia Flight 8501 Site
abstract: Indonesian officials said Friday that search and rescue teams had detected pinging from the black box recorders of AirAsia Flight 8501, which crashed into the Java Sea on Dec. 28 with 162 people aboard.
lead_paragraph: Indonesian officials said Friday that search and rescue teams had detected pinging from the black box recorders of AirAsia Flight 8501, which crashed into the Java Sea on Dec. 28 with 162 people aboard. Tatang Zainuddin, deputy chief of operations for the National Search and Rescue Agency, said a research ship from Indonesia’s Agency for Assessment and Application of Technology had picked up pinging from the plane’s flight data and cockpit voice recorders on Thursday afternoon. He said that the Sampson, an American Navy destroyer, had also detected the pinging. He said the authorities had not yet determined the exact coordinates of the black boxes. The bodies of 45 victims had been reovered as of Thursday.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Showtime) PHILOMENA (2013) With the help of a former political journalist (Steve Coogan), an Irish Roman Catholic woman (Judi Dench, in an Oscar-nominated performance) seeks the son who was taken from her 50 years earlier, when she became pregnant as a teenager and was forced to live in a convent, in this drama directed by Stephen Frears. Their sleuthing takes them to Washington after they discover that the boy — sold for 1,000 pounds — was adopted by an American couple and worked for the Reagan administration as an adult. “Ms. Dench’s Philomena Lee glows with the radiance of someone serene in her faith despite inhumane treatment by the church,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “That she makes you believe her character has the capacity to forgive provides the movie with a solid moral center.” Her dignified performance and the screenplay — adapted by Mr. Coogan and Jeff Pope from Martin Sixsmith’s 2009 nonfiction book, “The Lost Child of Philomena Lee” — “stabilize a volatile blend of ingredients,” he added. “In less confident hands, the film could have been a mawkish, rambling tear-jerker.”

headline: Visual Beauty and History in Hartford
abstract: Hartford bears the scars, and reaps the benefits, of the urban renewal and social upheaval of mid-20th century America. Yet for a small city, it boasts extraordinary ethnic diversity and fluidity.
lead_paragraph: Even before I had moved to the area, I had heard all the warnings. Hartford, once the insurance capital of the world and one of the country’s most prosperous cities in the 19th century, had degenerated into one of its poorest. There was little of interest beyond the historical landmarks of its Yankee past. Major highways ran through the city — making for an easy escape to the cultural meccas of New York and Boston. Even real-estate agents eager to sell me a house told me as much: “The good thing about Hartford is how easy it is to leave.”
