headline: Ireland’s XL Group Agrees to Buy the Bermuda Insurer Catlin for $4.2 Billion
abstract: The deal, if approved by shareholders, would bolster XL’s property and casualty insurance and reinsurance portfolio, and create a combined company worth more than $12 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Ireland-based insurer XL Group said on Friday that it had agreed to acquire the Catlin Group in a deal that values the Bermuda insurer at about 2.79 billion pounds, or about $4.2 billion.

headline: Morning Agenda: Proxy Fight at DuPont
abstract: Nelson Peltz’s firm nominates four director candidates to the board of DuPont. | Encore Capital faces a fine and the loss of thousands of court judgments. | Voices join Greek left’s call for a new deal on debt. | Santander plans a capital increase.
lead_paragraph: PELTZ IGNITES PROXY FIGHT AT DUPONT | Trian Fund Management, the investment firm run by Nelson Peltz, announced on Thursday that it had nominated four director candidates to the board of DuPont, escalating its campaign to break up the $67.5 billion chemical maker, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced and Andrew Ross Sorkin report. The proxy fight, the first major challenge by an activist investor in 2015, would be one of the biggest tests in DuPont’s two centuries as an industrial powerhouse. DuPont is one of the biggest companies ever to face a proxy battle.

headline: Turning a New Year’s Resolution Into Action With the Facts
abstract: Much of what we know — or think we know — about keeping self-improvement promises is wrong, experts say. Here are seven common myths about habits.
lead_paragraph: DESPITE the best intentions for the new year, the reality is that by next month, gym memberships will lapse, chocolate will replace carrots and Candy Crush will edge out Moby Dick.

headline: Theater Games: Our Contribution to ‘Kids’ Night on Broadway’
abstract: Since Kids’ Night on Broadway is presented in New York City by The New York Times, The Learning Network helped out this year by creating two games to go into the program.
lead_paragraph: Kids’ Night on Broadway— this year Jan. 9-15 — is a program of The Broadway League, the national trade association for the Broadway theater industry. Created in 1996 by the League and Theatre Development Fund, its goal is to “introduce young people to the magic of live theater and make Broadway accessible to a new generation of theatergoers in New York and across the U.S.”

headline: Box, a Data Storage Provider, Seeks Up to $162.5 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: Box said that it planned to price its shares at $11 to $13. At the midpoint of that range, the company would be valued at about $1.4 billion.
lead_paragraph: After months of delay, Box is finally close to making its stock market debut.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: In Britain, Spy Chief Calls for More Power for Agency
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The move by the director general of MI5 was a sign that the attack on a satirical newspaper in Paris was likely to sharpen the security-versus-privacy debate in the West.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s domestic intelligence chief has demanded greater authority for spies to help fight the threat of Islamist extremism, a sign that the attack on a satirical newspaper in Paris is likely to sharpen the security-versus-privacy debate in Western countries.

headline: Politics Helpline: The 114th Congress, Part 1
abstract: Our congressional team answered selected questions on the 114th Congress. Here is their first batch of answers.
lead_paragraph: We’re taking questions and answering them as fast as we can as part of our continuous political helpline. On Friday, our congressional team answers select questions about the 114th Congress. Here is their first batch of answers. We will post more as the day goes on.

headline: For China, a New Leader in Sri Lanka May Herald a Change in Ties
abstract: Beijing is likely to be watching with some unease to see if the surprise victor in Sri Lanka’s election follows through on a promise to scrap a major Chinese investment project.
lead_paragraph: Last January, Sri Lanka’s health minister, Maithripala Sirisena, joined his colleagues in toasting the Chinese New Year at a red-lantern-festooned gala featuring performances of the songs “Love My China” and “Mother Sri Lanka” and hosted by the Chinese Embassy in Colombo, the capital.

headline: Celebrities to Watch at the Golden Globes: Handicapping the Fashion Winners
abstract: It may be the year’s hottest red carpet, with both movie and TV actresses dressing their best — and only a couple tethered to specific brands.
lead_paragraph: Given that every movie critic I know is busy handicapping the winners of the Golden Globes on Sunday, I thought I might as well chime in, fashionwise. After all, the pool of well-dressed actresses at this event is, perhaps, the greatest of any awards show, given the best-actress-trifecta of stars in dramatic films, comedy/musical films and TV shows. Arguably, it’s a bigger fashion event than the Oscars, at least when it comes to frocks and frippery.

headline: How We Chose Our List
abstract: To add some clarity to the process, we’ve decided to answer some frequently asked questions about how we chose our 52 Places to Go in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Each January, the editors of the Travel section publish our Places to Go issue. And each year after we do, readers wonder why their favorite destination was overlooked or why their least favorite made the top 10. To add some clarity to the process, we’ve decided to answer some frequently asked questions about how we chose our 52 Places to Go in 2015.

headline: Show Me the Money
abstract: Where are the wages?
lead_paragraph: Another good employment report — and another triumph for future Republican policies (hahahahaha) — and there will be many voices calling on the Fed to accelerate its tightening.

headline: Time Warp, 56th and Broadway
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: The sight of a longhaired young woman running in Midtown, coffee in hand, took an observer back to a summer and a heartthrob long ago.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Theories of Everything
abstract: Fun, but beware.
lead_paragraph: I’ve worked on a lot of interesting things over the course of my career, but I surely had the most intellectual fun working on economic geography. The models were nifty, the stories seemed to shed a lot of light on history. And maybe too much light — the temptation to claim universal explanatory power was strong. I can certainly see why Noah Smith likes to suggest that the New Economic Geography may be a theory of everything. But here’s what Tony Venables and I wrote in the paper (pdf) that comes closest to what Noah is saying:

headline: When Autocorrect Goes Wrong (And So, So Right)
abstract: The changing complexities, and constant follies, of our autocorrected life.
lead_paragraph: There were a few things that were sweetly grandmotherly about Patricia Duncan Moran’s Facebook post to her great-granddaughter Devyn on her birthday. For starters, Ms. Moran had posted it to her own wall instead of Devyn’s. She named but did not tag her great-granddaughter. But most striking was the signer.

abstract: A reader asks: What’s the best way to create a habit of exercising?
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: On His Best Behavior and Hoping to Fit In
abstract: “Paddington,” a new film based on the children’s books by Michael Bond, prepares to open in the United States.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — He is an illegal immigrant, small, brown and different-looking, lonely and unwelcome in a metropolis in which people try hard not to notice other people’s problems. Carrying a battered suitcase that contains very little, he encounters hostility, rudeness and indifference, and must battle prejudice and enmity.

headline: What’s On This Week Around the World
abstract: An eclectic music festival in Tasmania, an opera at a pop music venue in London and a Whistler retrospective in Yokohama.
lead_paragraph: Kochi, India

headline: Big-Budget Effects Without the Budget
abstract: Art-house auteurs are increasingly turning to digital tricks to enhance their dramas.
lead_paragraph: Special effects are usually considered the province of Spider-Men and guardians of galaxies. But for a while now, visual effects have quietly become part of small films in ways you might not expect. Hidden away in art-house movies, including a recent crop of dramas, are digital tricks that reduce the cost of potentially expensive shots or, more subtly, help filmmakers heighten the visual impact of seemingly naturalistic tales.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Romantic Fancy in French Flavors
abstract: A pair of Gallic meditations on love come to DVD: one fantastical (“Mood Indigo”), the other observational (“A Summer’s Tale”).
lead_paragraph: “Mood Indigo,” the retro-futurist folly fashioned by Michel Gondry from “L'Écume des Jours” (“The Foam of the Days”), written in the heady aftermath of World War II by the French novelist, jazz critic, musician and Saint-Germain-des-Prés scene-maker Boris Vian (1920-1959), is an evident labor of love. It is often labored but sometimes lovely, particularly in the longer version included on Drafthouse’s DVD and Blu-ray edition.

headline: Carlyle Reports Declines in Energy Investments
abstract: A group of the private equity firm’s energy funds fell 17 percent in the quarter as publicly traded investments in that portfolio declined because of the collapse in oil prices.
lead_paragraph: With the collapse in oil prices weighing on the energy sector, the Carlyle Group suffered declines in its energy investments in the fourth quarter of 2014.

headline: Job Growth Looks Great; Wage Growth, Less So
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Unemployment']
abstract: There’s a lot of good news in the latest numbers, but also disappointment, particularly about the seeming lack of upward pressure on wages.
lead_paragraph: The last few weeks have been a time of, dare we say it, buoyant optimism about the United States economy. The long winter slumber may be over, or so it has seemed after news of a 5 percent G.D.P. third-quarter growth rate and a November jobs report showing the strongest gains in years.

headline: Daily Report: Box Seeks to Raise up to $162.5 Million in I.P.O.

lead_paragraph: After months of delay, Box is finally close to making its stock market debut, Michael J. de la Merced reports.

abstract: New books include four Elmore Leonard novels from the Library of America, a collection of Donald Westlake’s nonfiction and more.
lead_paragraph: FOUR NOVELS OF THE 1970S

headline: Back to the Studio, With Hits in Hand
abstract: Mark Ronson, the club D.J. turned in-demand producer, teamed up with an array of artists for “Uptown Special,” his fourth solo album.
lead_paragraph: “I remember this couch,” Mark Ronson said, eyeing a brown suede number in the basement of Electric Lady, the storied recording studio in the West Village. It was here that Mr. Ronson, the club D.J. turned in-demand producer, made his first proper album, for the singer Nikka Costa.

headline: Placing Bets on How Many Takes Fincher Will Need
abstract: Carrie Coon, who made her big-screen debut in “Gone Girl,” says the cast put money on how many times the director would shoot one scene.
lead_paragraph: The character of Margo Dunne – better known as Go, sister to Ben Affleck’s Nick in the smash hit adaptation “Gone Girl” – was a critical one in the film. In the vicious tale of a presumed-dead wife and a husband under suspicion, Margo provided a much-needed voice of reason for the audience, illuminating the unsavoriness of the wife, Amy, and allowing the husband, Nick, to seem less like a monster when all evidence points to him.

headline: Americans Use More Online Social Networks
abstract: More than half of American Internet users log onto at least two social networks regularly, according a new research survey. While Facebook remains the dominant network, other networks like Instagram and Pinterest are growing in popularity.
lead_paragraph: Teenagers may be spending more time on messaging services like Snapchat, but American adults are still increasing their use of social networks, according to a new survey released Friday by the Pew Research Center.

headline: For Republicans, Jobs Report Offers Little Help
abstract: The hot debate among Republicans over how to respond to economic improvement got little clarity from a December jobs report that gave ammunition to those Republicans who want to claim credit for the recovery and those who want to keep bashing it.
lead_paragraph: The hot debate among Republicans over how to respond to economic improvement got little clarity on Friday from a December jobs report that gave ammunition to those Republicans who want to claim credit for the recovery and those who want to keep bashing it.

headline: McDonald’s Runs Out of Fries in Venezuela
abstract: Political leaders there suggested the shortage was part of an economic war.
lead_paragraph: In most countries, McDonald’s running out of fries would be seen as an inconvenience. (Or a blessing, if your New Year’s resolution is to eat healthier)

headline: Blocked In
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Parking Garages and Lots', 'Gifts']
abstract: Questions about parking disputes, relationships, unwanted gifts and declining a Facebook invitation.
lead_paragraph: I live in a town that is notoriously difficult for parking. After years of circling blocks for spaces, I found an apartment with a garage. Then a business moved in, and one of its employees started parking in front of my garage every day. I only use my car occasionally, but when I do, I have to ask her to move hers. She does it right away, but it’s still annoying. The other day I told her it had to stop. She was furious and called me selfish (because I use the car infrequently). Was I wrong?

headline: Sleep’s Marketing Problem: You ‘Have To’ Go to Bed.
abstract: Sleep needs a new ad campaign, and parents need to sell it. Why don’t we remind our children of how good it feels, and how good it is for us, instead of the way we tend to insist on it?
lead_paragraph: It’s 7 p.m. My children should be winding down for sleep, but my 6-year-old cannot fathom leaving his Lego X-Wing Fighter incomplete. My 3-year-old won’t brush her teeth. When she finally does, she decides she “must” change her pajamas again.

headline: Obama Facing Rising Pressure on Keystone Oil Pipeline
abstract: After the Nebraska Supreme Court cleared the way for construction of the Keystone XL pipeline, the House voted, 266 to 153, approving of the project.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama came under new pressure on Friday to make a decision on the Keystone XL oil pipeline as the Nebraska Supreme Court cleared the way for its construction through the state and the House passed a bill to approve the project.

headline: Retrograde Beliefs
abstract: In defense of magical thinking.
lead_paragraph: The planet Mercury is small, not much larger than our moon, but dense, mostly a molten iron core with hardly any crust or atmosphere. It flies fast, orbiting the sun once every 87.97 earth days, and spins slowly, rotating only 1.5 times every trip around. During those long nights and days, temperatures drop to minus 280 degrees Fahrenheit and rise to 800 degrees. The poles, surprisingly, contain deposits of ice, but the rest of Mercury’s surface is rough ground, a record of the early years of the solar system, when the planet was pummeled by asteroids and meteors.

headline: Need for (Reduced) Speed
abstract: Confronting my fear of winter driving.
lead_paragraph: I didn’t go to Colorado to ski. I went because my father, to help me conquer my longstanding fear of driving, talked me into attending a two-day class at the Bridgestone Winter Driving School in Steamboat Springs.

headline: The Cannabis Queen of Beverly Hills
abstract: Marijuana is becoming increasingly legal. Cheryl Shuman wants to make it increasingly glamorous.
lead_paragraph: Cheryl Shuman, founder of the Beverly Hills Cannabis Club, arrived at the Perennial Holistic Wellness Center, an upmarket medical-marijuana dispensary in Los Angeles, in a red 2010 Ferrari California, a gift, she said, from a friend. She had come to get supplies for a “mansion party” that she was hosting the following evening, one of the semiregular events she organizes with her daughter, Aimee, to promote their marijuana enterprises. Shuman, a tall 54-year-old blonde with the unflagging cheer of someone accustomed to being noticed, handed the keys to Perennial’s valets with a Mae West-inflected “Careful, boys.” She headed inside to present her state-issued Medical Marijuana Identification Card.

headline: The Case for Throwback Baseball Uniforms
abstract: Right to wear?
lead_paragraph: Some Major League Baseball teams wear retro uniforms as alternates, allowing for increased opportunities to market jerseys to fans. I’ve seen some teams wearing Negro league jerseys as retro alternates. Ostensibly, they’re celebrating the tradition of Negro league baseball — but it’s an odd premise, given that Major League Baseball is the same organization that didn’t allow black players until after World War II. Is it ethical for M.L.B. teams to wear Negro league uniforms and potentially reap profits by selling them? PETE TOSIELLO, NEW YORK

headline: Reply All: The 12.28.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: When I glanced at the cover of the Lives They Lived issue, I knew immediately that it was a tribute to Massimo Vignelli. I worked with Vignelli as the first design director for Unimark in Chicago. Vignelli’s passion for design was constant. He was a very soft-spoken and wonderful guy with a desire to make communication minimalist and beautiful. I first thought that he was nuts when he said you only need five great typefaces, but I soon came to understand what he meant. Massimo touched many designers in his life, and all of us are better because of it. Thank you so much for this issue, which was beautifully written and designed. JIM LIENHART, Tucson

headline: Death by Robot
keywords: ['Robots and Robotics', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles']
abstract: Automated machines may soon care for the sick and fight in wars. Can they learn to make moral choices?
lead_paragraph: Imagine it’s a Sunday in the not-too-distant future. An elderly woman named Sylvia is confined to bed and in pain after breaking two ribs in a fall. She is being tended by a helper robot; let’s call it Fabulon. Sylvia calls out to Fabulon asking for a dose of painkiller. What should Fabulon do?

headline: When Judging Financial Advisers, Look Beyond the Annual Return
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Financial Planners', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)']
abstract: Many advisers can offer more than asset allocation services and advice, but needs are often particular to the investor.
lead_paragraph: ANY day now, financial advisers will start sending clients their annual reviews and outlooks along with year-end account statements. Both will probably look pretty good.

headline: Well Into Adulthood, but Still Trying to Figure It Out
abstract: “Togetherness,” a new comedy joining “Girls” on HBO, is set in Hollywood and centers on its characters’ struggles with relationships and other issues.
lead_paragraph: “Togetherness,” a beguiling new comedy beginning Sunday on HBO, is an intimate, bittersweet look at the travails of a clique of disaffected middle-class friends. So, of course, is “Girls,” which returns the same night for a fourth season, and so is “Looking,” which begins its second season.

headline: Charlie Hebdo Attack Chills Satirists and Prompts a Debate
keywords: ['Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Discrimination', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The killings at the French newspaper Charlie Hebdo have forced cartoonists to reconsider how far to go when skewering a target.
lead_paragraph: The killing of a dozen people in Wednesday’s attack on the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo has prompted an outpouring of tributes from cartoonists around the world, who have flooded the Internet with images ranging from the elegiac to the scabrously rude.

headline: 1915: Anger Over Garibaldi’s Death
abstract: Highlights from The International Herald Tribune archives: 1915: Anger Over The Death of Garibaldi’s Grandson.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Feeling against the Austrians, and against the Germans who are supporting them, is growing daily more intense, and it now seems that the nation has been fired to a hatred ripe for action, the death of Lieutenant Bruno Garibaldi having supplied the necessary spark. The death of Costante Garibaldi added fuel to the fire. All Rome mourns Garibaldi’s grandson ‘‘tué à l’ennemi,’’ as the simple but eloquent inscription on Bruno’s coffin read. As I telegraphed to you yesterday [Jan. 8], no funeral ever drew so vast a crowd, and General Ricciotti Garibaldi’s heartfelt words over his son’s grave, foreshadowing Italy’s speedy avenging of the lieutenant’s death, stirred the blood of the whole nation. There was, at the beginning of the European war, a great outburst on the part of the Italian people. War against Austria appeared inevitable, as a consequence of the aggressive action against Servia, which action, in case it proved successful, would have profoundly affected the Balkanic equilibrium. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 10, 1915

headline: Lentil Salad With Roasted Vegetables
abstract: Melissa Clark makes a bright lentil salad with roasted root vegetables and sherry vinaigrette.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark makes a bright lentil salad with roasted root vegetables and sherry vinaigrette.

headline: The Webster and Le Bon Marché Join Forces for an All-White Series of Designer Collaborations
abstract: Following the Parisian department store’s January tradition, labels such as Dior and Céline have created alabaster items to be sold at the two shops.
lead_paragraph: Last September, the Miami retail-scene mainstay the Webster and the Parisian department store Le Bon Marché Rive Gauche approached more than 50 brands with a carte blanche of sorts: the opportunity to design an item for a limited-edition collection to launch in 2015. The (appropriate) caveat? Each contribution had to be rendered in white, as part of “le mois du blanc” (“the month of white”), a Bon Marché tradition since January 1873, when the store’s founder Aristide Boucicaut stocked a selection of snow-hued garments to fill his shelves following the holiday shopping season.

headline: Looking for the ‘Most Recent’ Facebook Posts
abstract: Facebook eventually reverts to the “Top Stories” view of its news feed even if “Most Recent” is chosen, but there are ways around this.
lead_paragraph: Q. When I use Facebook on my computer, I want to see the most current posts in my news feed, and not the “Top Stories,” which always seem to be older. When I change the view to “Most Recent,” it always reverts back to “Top Stories” after a while. Why won’t it stay on “Most Recent”?

headline: Teaching Islam’s ‘Forgotten’ Side as Germany Changes
abstract: At a time of fear and loathing for Muslims and non-Muslims in Europe, Prof. Mouhanad Khorchide preaches tolerance and understanding at the University of Münster.
lead_paragraph: MÜNSTER, Germany — AT a time of fear and loathing for Muslims and non-Muslims in Europe, Mouhanad Khorchide, professor of Islamic pedagogy at the venerable university in this town near the Dutch border, preaches and teaches a course of tolerance and understanding.

headline: Why Reams of Intelligence Did Not Thwart the Paris Attacks
abstract: The government faced gaping questions over its failure to thwart a brazen assault on the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, as well as a double hostage situation two days later.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The bloody denouement on Friday of two hostage crises at different ends of a traumatized Paris means attention will now shift to the gaping question facing the French government: How did several jihadists — and possibly a larger cell of co-conspirators — manage to evade surveillance and execute a bold attack despite being well known to the country’s police and intelligence services?

headline: A Stand-Up Antipasto of Crunchy Bites
abstract: The concept of fritto misto (assorted fried things) can yield a satisfying first course of bite-size morsels.
lead_paragraph: Every culture does fried food, but Italian cooks do it especially well. In Italy, whether it’s artichokes, lamb chops or shrimp, the result is bound to be crisp and golden. Eaten with a just a sprinkle of salt and a squeeze of lemon, a well-fried morsel is supremely satisfying.

headline: London Men’s Wear Designers on Where to Savor a Sunday Roast
abstract: On the eve of the fall 2015 shows, T spoke to five designers about their favorite pubs for the traditional British meal.
lead_paragraph: With another round of London’s men’s collections kicking off today, weary showgoers shuttling around town will need sustenance. Though the U.K.’s gastronomic tradition can’t match those of the other men’s wear capitals, Italy and France, one particular meal is inarguably owned by the Brits. The Sunday roast, a weekend meal with friends and family, can be enjoyed at home or at one of the countless pubs dotted around the capital. Choose between lamb, chicken or beef (or the veggie options) and you’ll be served generously with roasted potatoes, cooked vegetables, gravy and an oversized Yorkshire pudding.

headline: Port Agency’s Reorganization to Start With Exit of Executive Christie Picked
abstract: The departure of Deborah Gramiccioni will be the start of the restructuring of the authority’s management after the lane-closing affair that entangled Gov. Chris Christie and several of his allies.
lead_paragraph: A year after her predecessor resigned over his role in the shutting of traffic lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge, Gov. Chris Christie’s top executive appointee at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is stepping down.

headline: The Art Forger Who Wasn’t in It for Money
abstract: The Oscar-shortlisted documentary “Art and Craft” examines the case of Mark Landis, who copied everything from Picassos to “Peanuts” panels and then donated them to museums.
lead_paragraph: Even in the shadowy world of art forgery, Mark Landis seemed an aberration. From the 1980s on, he copied all kinds of paintings and drawings, from Picassos and Monets to panels from “Peanuts” and illustrations from “The Cat in the Hat.” But instead of selling his counterfeits, he assumed the role of a philanthropist, sometimes disguising himself as a priest, and donated his fake masterpieces to unsuspecting museums.

headline: F.H.A. Loans More Affordable
abstract: The Federal Housing Administration’s plan to lower its annual insurance premiums could make buying a first home possible for a quarter-million more borrowers.
lead_paragraph: An announcement by the Obama administration that the Federal Housing Administration would lower its annual insurance premiums by 0.5 percentage point could make it possible for a quarter-million more borrowers to buy their first homes, according to the agency’s estimates.

headline: Despite Pipeline Ruling, White House Renews Veto Threat
abstract: Nebraska’s highest court gave its blessing today to construction of the Keystone XL pipeline, but its ruling hasn’t swayed President Obama.
lead_paragraph: Nebraska’s highest court gave its blessing today to construction of the Keystone XL pipeline, but its ruling hasn’t swayed President Obama.

headline: Trader With a Taste for Bubbly Convicted in $7.5 Million Investment Scam in Britain
abstract: The Financial Conduct Authority said that Alex Hope, who reportedly spent more than $300,000 in champagne during a single night out, promised large returns for investors but suffered heavy losses.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – A trader who reportedly once spent more than $188,000 on a single bottle of Champagne was convicted of fraud on Friday in an investment scam that authorities say took in 5 million pounds, or about $7.54 million, from investors.

headline: ‘Charlie Hebdo, Before the Massacre’
abstract: In this short documentary filmed at Charlie Hebdo in 2006, cartoonists and editors design a satirical front page image of Muhammad.
lead_paragraph: In February 2006 the editors of the French magazine Charlie Hebdo met to discuss a matter of what turned out to be deadly consequence: Would they publish a satirical image of Muhammad on their cover? We were making a documentary about Jean Cabut, known as Cabu, one of the most famous cartoonists in France. So we were there, filming his conversation with his colleagues as they chose the cover. The issue that came out of this meeting — with a Cabu cartoon on the cover and the images they discussed here — turned out to be one of the most popular in the magazine’s history. Almost nine years later, gunmen stormed this very meeting and killed 10 editors and cartoonists, including three of the people in this film: Cabu, Bernard Verlhac (known as Tignous) and Georges Wolinski.

headline: ‘My Heart Is a Drunken Compass,’ by Domingo Martinez
abstract: The author heads for a breakdown as his world implodes.
lead_paragraph: The memoirist Domingo Martinez is irreverent, judgmental and unapologetic. At its best, his writing calls to mind the bravado of Junot Díaz, another foul-mouthed son of contemporary literature. Like “The Boy Kings of Texas” — Martinez’s first memoir, which was a 2012 finalist for the National Book Award and was recently optioned for an HBO series — his latest, “My Heart Is a Drunken Compass,” is a tragic comedy filled with wit and cultural insight.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: HONEYDEW: Stories,  by Edith Pearlman. (Little, Brown, $25.) With simultaneous intimacy and distance, the tales in Pearlman’s majestic collection excel at capturing the complex and surprising turns in seemingly ordinary lives.

headline: ‘Vanessa and Her Sister,’ by Priya Parmar
abstract: A novel of Vanessa Bell and Virginia Woolf includes invented letters and diary entries.
lead_paragraph: Rarely do you encounter a woman who commands as much admiration as does the painter Vanessa Bell in Priya Parmar’s multilayered, subtly shaded novel, “Vanessa and Her Sister.” The sister of the title is, of course, Virginia Woolf, who understood how hard it is for a novelist to capture a character. “Few catch the phantom,” Woolf said in a lecture at Cambridge in 1924, the year before the publication of “Mrs. Dalloway.” “Most have to be content with a scrap of her dress or a wisp of her hair.” Parmar’s portrait brings Vanessa out of the shadows, into fully realized, shining visibility. The world remembers Virginia better than her enigmatic older sister: Parmar restores the symmetry of their relationship in the familial landscape, showing how essential Vanessa’s steadying force was to Virginia’s precarious balance.

headline: Please Look After This Bear
abstract: The stories of Paddington’s adventures bounce along with a Wodehousian lightness and consistency.
lead_paragraph: When Paddington Bear landed in London in 1958, it was still quite a provincial place. Safe, settled, a little gray — no sign of the Beatles or the swinging ’60s yet — it upheld the ceremonial proprieties immortalized in “Brief Encounter” and “84, Charing Cross Road.” Men wore ties to dinner, women skirts; the post-nuclear nightmares and beatnik explosions of America were barely visible on occasional television screens. Yes, the likes of the Trinidad-born novelist Samuel Selvon were beginning to give voice to other realities in works like “The Lonely Londoners,” but if a British family’s name was Brown, you could be fairly sure its skin was not.

headline: ‘China 1945,’ by Richard Bernstein
abstract: With the defeat of Japan, the United States hoped to prevent civil war in China.
lead_paragraph: “To err is human. To blame someone else is politics.” Hubert H. Humphrey’s aphorism came to mind as I was reading “China 1945,” Richard Bernstein’s excellent history of United States policy toward China at the end of World War II. The comment is particularly apt when intractable problems provide myriad paths to failure but no clear right answer — and the civil war in China after Japan’s surrender was just such a problem. (Today, think of Syria.) The debates over China policy were acrimonious and personal, and this was several years before Joseph McCarthy lent his name to sneering political assassination.

headline: ‘It Will End With Us,’ by Sam Savage
abstract: Sam Savage’s novel of a South Carolina family in decline is constructed from a daughter’s scattered memories.
lead_paragraph: “I wasn’t going to begin again, having stopped, apparently, and started up again, foolishly, too many times already.” So protests Eve Taggart, the narrator of Sam Savage’s fifth novel, “It Will End With Us.” Like the first-person narrators of Savage’s earlier work, Eve begins with the intention, or at least the possibility, of ending in mind. This awareness that the narrative may be abandoned gives the book the feel of being cobweb-slight. It seems arbitrary, almost incidental; yet the text’s fragility reads as purity of a kind.

headline: ‘American Queen,’ by John Oller
abstract: A biography of the socialite Kate Chase Sprague, daughter of a cabinet minister, wife of a governor, mistress of a senator.
lead_paragraph: In the prelude to her great novel “Middlemarch,” George Eliot meditates on the fate of heroic women “who found for themselves no epic life” equal to their passion and intellect, but instead “only a life of mistakes, the offspring of a certain spiritual grandeur ill-matched with the meanness of opportunity.” One wonders what Eliot would have made of Kate Chase Sprague — daughter of a Civil War-era American cabinet minister, wife of a governor, mistress of a senator — whose career as a ­behind-the-scenes kingmaker is chronicled in John Oller’s “American Queen.” Beautiful, wealthy and clever, she could dazzle a Washington salon or (said one historian) “scheme like a cigar-­chewing convention rigger.” But her horizons were limited by the same constraints that tied Eliot’s heroine Dorothea Brooke, and the results for her bordered on the tragic.

headline: ‘My Life as a Foreign Country,’ by Brian Turner
abstract: A poet and Army veteran presents vignettes that draw on his family history and his deployments, especially in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: There’s a persistent idea in our culture that what we experience is “true,” while what we imagine is “untrue.” But without exploring the possibility of imagination in nonfiction, we leave out a fundamental part of the human experience — digressive wanderings, the chaotic interior self and, most important, our empathy. Empathy, after all, starts as an act of fiction. We must think ourselves into the lives of others.

headline: ‘Cowardice: A Brief History,’ by Chris Walsh
abstract: A study of cowardice, and of how it’s been understood and misunderstood through history.
lead_paragraph: “Cowardice” is not quite one of those words, like “honor,” whose meaning was once understood by everyone but is now understood by almost no one. Yet its meaning has lately become more elusive. Are suicide bombers “cowardly,” as we are so often assured they are, or insanely courageous? Is it more cowardly to refuse to fight or to fight for fear of being called a coward for not fighting? Some people claim to have the answers to such questions about this once familiar and unproblematic subject, but they tend to disagree. There is no consensus as to who is a coward and who is not — or even about whether the question is one of any importance. Cowardice, whatever it means, must seem a matter of individual choice, like everything else, and the implied judgment made by the term probably requires that we decline to use it at all.

headline: ‘All Eyes Are Upon Us,’ by Jason Sokol
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Northerners applauded individual high-achieving African-Americans but opposed collective civil rights agendas.
lead_paragraph: If, as many believe, America’s experiment in postracialism is over, then “All Eyes Are Upon Us” is a prescient book that offers a great deal to explain a national self-deception of stunning brevity. According to Jason Sokol, whose anecdotally rich first book, “There Goes My Everything,” tracked white Southerners variously coping in the civil rights era, historians have paid insufficient attention to the Janus-faced ­responses of white Northerners to the struggles of black Americans. To be sure, monographs by James Goodman and Thomas Sugrue have explored the dark side of Northern race relations. They found that although the dominant racial philosophies of whites in the North and South were antithetical, opportunity for a majority of black men and women in the North was not very different from what it was in the South.

headline: ‘Tell,’ by Frances Itani
abstract: Two couples are left rudderless in the aftermath of World War I in Frances Itani’s novel.
lead_paragraph: Here be dragons. There are the stories we tell our friends, the versions we tell our partners and, most important, the stories we tell ourselves in order to keep on living.

headline: Health Care as High Drama
abstract: Reporters at The Times recommend books about health care.
lead_paragraph: With “America’s Bitter Pill,” Steven Brill’s new book, on this week’s cover, we asked reporters at The Times with experience covering health care to name a favorite book on the subject.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE BROKEN ROAD: From the Iron Gates to Mount Athos, by Patrick Leigh Fermor. Edited By Colin Thubron and Artemis Cooper. (New York Review Books, $17.95.) In 1933, an 18-year-old Leigh Fermor set out on a walk across Europe, from Holland to Istanbul. Decades later, he recounted that life-changing journey in “A Time of Gifts” (1977) and “Between the Woods and the Water” (1986). “The Broken Road,” posthumously published last year, covers the final leg of his travels, through Bulgaria, Romania and Greece. In her absorbing biography Patrick Leigh Fermor: An Adventure (New York Review Books, $18.95), Artemis Cooper adds further details and intrigue to the British wayfarer’s life, including his heroic efforts in occupied Crete during World War II.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Tess Gerritsen, whose “Die Again” is No. 5 on the hardcover fiction list, briefly assumed a new role last winter: organic farmer.
lead_paragraph: Home to Roost: Fans of the doctor-turned-romance-novelist-turned-thriller-writer Tess Gerritsen (whose latest Rizzoli and Isles mystery, “Die Again,” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 5) may not know that last winter she briefly assumed yet another role: organic farmer. When Gerritsen’s son wanted a vacation from the farm he and his partner own in Maine, his parents agreed to take over for two weeks. “There’s a comforting rhythm to farming,” Gerritsen wrote on her blog. “Every morning, the cows stand eagerly at the fence, excited to see us bringing hay, and the sheep come stam­peding like hungry children. . . . I’ve found out that I love hanging out with chickens. I’ve learned which hen leaves the flock every morning to hide out with the sheep, and which hen sneaks away to spend time with the outcast rooster. I’ve learned the secret places where those two lay their eggs. I’ve learned that the alpha rooster can be brutal with hens (and I’m going to talk to my son about turning him into coq au vin).” The wry sadism of that last sentence won’t surprise Gerritsen’s readers — in the opening pages of “Die Again,” a murdered taxidermist is discovered “hung and dressed like game” in his garage, with organs discarded in a nearby trash can. The inspiration for the organs, at least, may have come from the farm. “Thanks to my son,” Gerritsen wrote when her stint was done, “I’ve also been blessed with a bountiful supply of free-range eggs and chicken livers. Will all this turn up in a book some day? Trust me, I’m thinking about it.”

headline: ‘Lives in Ruins,’ by Marilyn Johnson
abstract: Exploring the world of archaeology, with tips for making ancient alcoholic drinks and fashioning a butcher blade from obsidian.
lead_paragraph: The past has a way of suddenly speaking to us. When images appear, for example, of human hands that archaeologists say were stenciled 40,000 years ago, a haunted feeling of connection and perspective quickly emerges. But many archaeologists themselves seem to experience this sense of connection more or less continuously. As Marilyn Johnson suggests in “Lives in Ruins,” her lively survey of archaeology and the people who practice it, it fuels their dedication to the job, which they desperately need because the actual work and the challenges involved are pretty continuous as well.

headline: Letters: Found in Translation
abstract: Readers respond to a recent review of Tolstoy’s “Anna Karenina” and more.
lead_paragraph: Found in Translation

headline: ‘Sailing the Forest: Selected Poems,’ by Robin Robertson
abstract: A career-spanning collection of poems from one of Scotland’s most intriguing literary voices.
lead_paragraph: It’s impossible to talk about the poetry of Robin Robertson without talking about sex, but to do so is to slip into perilous waters. And by “waters” I mean a hot tub. Because you can’t bring up sexy poetry without thinking of Roger and Virginia Klarvin, the randy and dithyrambic professors (played by Will Ferrell and Rachel Dratch) who always seemed to be in the middle of a steamy soak on “Saturday Night Live.” If even the most masterly fiction writers botch the job of describing the erotic act, it’s more challenging still for poets. One false move and they run the risk of sounding like Mr. Klarvin, the grandiloquent scholar and “love-ah” who proclaimed, in one episode, that “beneath the surface of these very waters a virtual ant farm of activity is taking place.”

headline: Robert Bausch’s ‘Far as the Eye Can See’
abstract: A Civil War veteran finds violence and love along the Western frontier in Robert Bausch’s novel.
lead_paragraph: Bobby Hale, the hero of Robert Bausch’s new novel, is a frontier hustler with a heart of gold. A Civil War veteran with a sketchy past, Hale heads west in 1869 simply because it seems like a good idea: “Everybody said it was the place to be — with free land and open skies.” What everybody doesn’t say is that it’s also a land of treachery, deception, double-dealing, torture, warfare and death.

headline: The Bishop, the Cyclist and a Death on the Road
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Hit-and-Run Drivers', 'Bicycles and Bicycling']
abstract: Maryland’s attorney for Baltimore City announced charges against Suffragan Bishop Heather Cook, a high-ranking Episcopal official, in the death of a cyclist in late December.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Two days after Christmas, Thomas Palermo took advantage of a rare moment of free time to do what he loved most: ride his bike up a busy road popular with cyclists for its challenging hill and wide bike lanes, the afternoon sun warming his face. About the same time, the police say, an Episcopal bishop got into her car, her blood-alcohol level far above the legal limit, and drove toward him.

headline: Rod Taylor, Star of ‘The Birds’ and ‘The Time Machine,’ Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Taylor made more than 50 films, including “The Birds” and “The Time Machine,” and acted alongside Debbie Reynolds, Elizabeth Taylor, Maggie Smith and Jane Fonda.
lead_paragraph: Rod Taylor, the ruggedly handsome Australian-born actor who fended off attacks from above in Alfred Hitchcock’s revered horror film “The Birds” and helped an 8,000th-century people escape a monster race in the film version of the science-fiction classic “The Time Machine,” died on Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 84.

headline: MAN: Fall 2015 Menswear
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Explosions After Kouachi Brothers’ Siege
abstract: Explosions and gunfire were heard at a printing plant outside Paris where the two brothers suspected in the Charlie Hebdo attacks were killed.
lead_paragraph: Explosions and gunfire were heard at a printing plant outside Paris where the two brothers suspected in the Charlie Hebdo attacks were killed.

headline: What a Great Place to Work Ought to Look Like
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Living Wage', 'Minimum Wage', 'Paid Time Off', 'Productivity', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: In the Life@Work column, Tony Schwartz provides a step-by-step guide to how employers can invest more in their employees so they feel motivated to invest more of themselves at work.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a workplace that you truly look forward to arriving at every day — one that meets your most important needs so that you feel freed and inspired to bring your best to work.

headline: 1940: Chamberlain Speaks on War
abstract: Highlights from The International Herald Tribune archives: 1940: Chamberlain Speaks on the Course of the War.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a fifty-five-minute address to an enthusiastic gathering of notables in the Mansion House, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain reviewed the course of the war, affirming once again Britain’s determination, with the aid of ‘‘our dauntless French Allies’’ to bring it to a successful conclusion, but warning his listeners that the road ahead might be a long one and most certainly hard.

headline: State of the Art Museums in New Report
abstract: “Museums invest a lot in their visitors and in their communities,” Christine Anagnos said.
lead_paragraph: A new report from the Association of Art Museum Directors compiled from a survey of its 236 members offers a sometimes surprising snapshot of the state of the museum ecosystem.

headline: Letter From the Editor: Marriage, and When Liberals Are Wrong
abstract: A new study on marriage offers a reminder that the evidence suggests family structure really does matter.
lead_paragraph: One of today’s more intriguing social-science debates is whether changes in family structure have helped cause the rise in economic inequality — or are merely an effect of that rising inequality.

headline: Stuff We Liked: Happiness in America
abstract: Also, some surprising conclusions about tips for taxi drivers, the problem of female poverty, a dynamic flu map and more.
lead_paragraph: If this is not proof of American exceptionalism, I am not sure what is. When Pew Research Center’s Global Attitudes survey asked people around the world how their day was going, it found that people in poor countries were often more likely than those in rich ones to report having a good day. But in America, where the pursuit of happiness ranks with life and liberty, the data shows we are pretty happy.

headline: Warming Up for Winter Jazzfest
abstract: This weekend’s festival offers a relentless profusion of music, overwhelming by design.
lead_paragraph: When the Winter Jazzfest celebrated its 10th anniversary last year, it stretched out to five days of programming, from the customary two. This year’s edition isn’t quite so big, but it’s still plenty big enough, officially kicking off Thursday night with “Blue Note Now!” — a lineup of bands from the current Blue Note Records roster — and “Jazz Legends for Disability Pride,” an all-star concert that raised funds for the first annual Disability Pride NYC Parade.

headline: On Snowy Day, Late Reprieve on Alternate-Side Rules Doesn’t Ease Drivers’ Ire
abstract: New York car owners were incredulous on Friday morning that the parking regulations were being enforced despite the weather, and complaints continued after the decision was reversed.
lead_paragraph: No words are sweeter to the ears of New York City’s car owners than these: “Alternate-side parking regulations are suspended.”

headline: The “Punk Ballerina” Karole Armitage Brings Together Lacroix, Gaultier, Koons and More
abstract: A new exhibition at Mana Contemporary, curated by Jeffrey Deitch, highlights the choreographer’s many collaborations with key art and fashion figures.
lead_paragraph: A new exhibition at Mana Contemporary, curated by Jeffrey Deitch, highlights the choreographer’s many collaborations with key art and fashion figures.

headline: Sebastiaan Pieter Debuts His Fall/Winter 2015 Men’s Collection in an Eerie New Video
abstract: The 26-year-old created a voyeuristic look at the new line, which features a cool merging of activewear with unconventional tailoring and knitwear.
lead_paragraph: “I wanted to make a video to place the clothes, the Pieter guy, more in a ‘reality’ context,” says Sebastiaan Pieter, the 26-year-old Dutch designer who will present the fall/winter 2015 collection of his nascent line, Pieter, on Saturday in London. Collaborating with Max Pearmain, the stylist and editor of fashion magazine Arena Homme Plus, as well as the art director Jonathan Baron, Pieter created a voyeuristic look at the new collection, which features a cool merging of activewear with unconventional tailoring and knitwear: athletic tights layered under knit tops with slashed openings (inspired by Lucio Fontana paintings) and unstructured outerwear made from fabrics typically used for uniforms of the Royal Guard. Filmed in a bleak office environment with expansive views of London’s Financial District and composed of grainy time-stamped clips mimicking security footage, the video, which will run on loop during the presentation, “grounds the clothes,” says the young designer (albeit rather eerily). For this new season, as with his previous two collections, Pieter, who worked both in publishing (Fantastic Man) and design (for Jil Sander under Raf Simons) before launching his own line in early 2014, explores the loosening and blurring of men’s sartorial norms through more feminine cuts and roomier silhouettes. “There’s a dark twisted way of sexuality,” Pieter says, “that I’m always thinking about.”

headline: Life Sentence for British Cleric Who Helped Plan 1998 Kidnappings in Yemen
abstract: Mostafa Kamel Mostafa, 56, a former imam in North London, had been convicted of 11 terrorism-related charges.
lead_paragraph: A fiery British cleric who was convicted last year of 11 terrorism-related charges, including helping to orchestrate the violent 1998 kidnappings of 16 American, British and other tourists in Yemen, was sentenced in Manhattan on Friday to life in prison.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Black Box Pings Detected in AirAsia Hunt
abstract: Supriyadi, operational officer at Indonesia’s National Search and Rescue Agency, said his team detected pings in their efforts to find the black box flight recorders from AirAsia Flight 8501.
lead_paragraph: Supriyadi, operational officer at Indonesia’s National Search and Rescue Agency, said his team detected pings in their efforts to find the black box flight recorders from AirAsia Flight 8501.

headline: Obama’s College Proposal Is Also a Bid to Rev the Economy
abstract: Rising education levels were a crucial factor in America’s economic growth. The president hopes they can be again.
lead_paragraph: Economic history provides the broader context for understanding President Obama’s proposal to make community college available free.

headline: All About Meghan Trainor
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Joe Coscarelli discuss Ms. Trainor as surprise, as a formula, as contrivance and as a product of Nantucket, hip-hop and Nashville.
lead_paragraph: Ben Ratliff and Joe Coscarelli discuss Ms. Trainor as surprise, as a formula, as contrivance and as a product of Nantucket, hip-hop and Nashville.
