abstract: An eco-friendly mansion on nearly four waterfront acres is poised to enter the market at $38 million.
lead_paragraph: An eco-friendly mansion on nearly four waterfront acres is poised to enter the market at $38 million.

headline: Readers Respond: On Islam and the Charlie Hebdo Shootings
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Mosques', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Muslim Americans', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Terrorism']
abstract: In comments, readers were responsive, substantive and civil in reaction to Nicholas Kristof’s column “Is Islam to Blame for the Shooting at Charlie Hebdo in Paris?”
lead_paragraph: Muslim voices from the United States and around the world joined with thousands of others to provide a kaleidoscope of straightforward, anguished and angry replies to the question posed in Nicholas Kristof’s column “Is Islam to Blame for the Shooting at Charlie Hebdo in Paris?”

headline: Kerry to Meet Iranian Counterpart Next Week Before Nuclear Talks Resume
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry and Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif will confer in Geneva on Wednesday, a day before the talks resume.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry plans to meet with his Iranian counterpart next week in Geneva to try to advance the negotiations over Iran’s nuclear program, the State Department said on Friday.

headline: Views From Every Room
abstract: A postmodern, eco-friendly mansion on nearly four waterfront acres in the affluent village of Sands Point, N.Y., is poised to enter the market at $38 million.
lead_paragraph: A nearly new, postmodern, eco-friendly mansion on almost four waterfront acres in Sands Point, N.Y., an affluent village on the North Shore of Long Island, is poised to enter the market at $38 million.

headline: House Passes Pipeline Bill, Adding to Pressure on Obama
abstract: Legislation to authorize the controversial Keystone XL pipeline project is moving on to the Senate.
lead_paragraph: Legislation to authorize the Keystone XL pipeline project is moving on to the Senate.

headline: Worker Fatally Struck by Elevator in Upper West Side Building
abstract: The 30-year-old man was working at 75 West End Avenue, a residential building near 66th Street, when an elevator struck him.
lead_paragraph: A 30-year-old worker was killed on Friday morning while working on the elevators at a building on the Upper West Side, the authorities said.

headline: Hostages Flee Kosher Store in Paris
abstract: Video shows people fleeing a kosher supermarket in Paris after the police stormed the building where an armed man held several hostages on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Video shows people fleeing a kosher supermarket in Paris after the police stormed the building where an armed man held several hostages on Friday.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week: Topman Fall/Winter 2015
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: Cosby Makes a Joke About Drinking Around Him
abstract: Bill Cosby, whose lawyers have denied the accusations of many women that he spiked their drinks and sexually assaulted them, jokes about the subject at a performance in Canada.
lead_paragraph: As the number of women accusing Bill Cosby of spiking their drinks before sexually assaulting them continues to grow, the comedian has not commented on the allegations, except obliquely. But on Thursday night during a performance in London, Ontario, Mr. Cosby did make a joke about them.

headline: Joan Didion’s Céline Ad, Cara’s Side-Shave and So Much Bieber
abstract: Plus, Jared Leto’s fanny packs, the fashion dads of Instagram and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: At Cuomo’s Request, Panel May Again Weigh Casino Bids for Southern Tier of New York
abstract: Two state boards announced they were considering opening a new round of bidding for a fourth casino license in the Southern Tier, after urging from Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.
lead_paragraph: What a difference a governor’s letter makes.

headline: Expansive House G.O.P. Immigration Bill Undercuts the President
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals']
abstract: The House plan went further than expected, not only trying to block President Obama’s recent executive actions, but also seeking to undo a protected status for young immigrants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans introduced legislation Friday that would roll back President Obama’s executive actions on immigration, undoing a provision that would allow five million undocumented immigrants to remain in the country and one that protects young people brought to the United States illegally by a parent.

headline: Popcast: All About Meghan Trainor
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Joe Coscarelli discuss Ms. Trainor as surprise, as a formula, as contrivance and as a product of Nantucket, hip-hop and Nashville.
lead_paragraph: Meghan Trainor’s first single, “All About That Bass,” the cheeky ’50s-style self-empowerment anthem, spent eight weeks in all at No. 1 on Billboard’s Hot 100 chart last year. (That’s more weeks than Michael Jackson’s “Billie Jean” spent at number one — an astonishing statistic — but fewer weeks than Lorde’s “Royals” or Pharrell’s “Happy.”) And much about the story is odd: Ms. Trainor, now 21, is a young songwriter from Nantucket with no pop star training, but an apprenticeship in Nashville writing songs for Rascal Flatts, Sabrina Carpenter, and others.

headline: Why You Should Be More Optimistic About Wage Growth
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Productivity', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Unemployment']
abstract: Weak growth in nominal wages can still yield moderate growth in real wages. The big unknown is how far we can reduce joblessness.
lead_paragraph: Commentary on this month’s employment report has focused on what’s happening to wage growth. Throughout the recovery, wage growth has been disappointing, barely keeping pace with inflation.

headline: European Official Criticizes Russian Law Banning Transgender Drivers
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Drivers Licenses', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The Council of Europe’s human rights commissioner, Nils Muiznieks, called the new law “ridiculous.”
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — One of Europe’s most senior human rights officials, the Council of Europe’s human rights commissioner, Nils Muiznieks, has criticized as “ridiculous” a new Russian law on road safety that prohibits transgender people from obtaining a driver’s license.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Unbroken, ‘A Most Violent Year’ and ‘Into the Woods’
abstract: Times critics review “Unbroken,” “A Most Violent Year” and “Into the Woods.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Unbroken,” “A Most Violent Year” and “Into the Woods.”

headline: Start Paying Attention: What’s Happening Now in G.O.P. Matters for 2016
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The “invisible primary” — a battle for the resources, attention and credibility needed to win the presidential nomination — has already started.
lead_paragraph: If you want to be a savvy political reader, it’s time to start paying attention to the flurry of articles about the so-called invisible primary: the behind-the-scenes competition for the support of elected officials, donors, party leaders and political operatives.

headline: The Story Behind Joaquin Phoenix’s “Inherent Vice” Style
abstract: Mark Bridges, the film’s costume designer, took style cues for the 1970s crime comedy (out today) from musicians of that era.
lead_paragraph: Watching “Inherent Vice,” the new Paul Thomas Anderson film based on Thomas Pynchon’s novel about a surfer/stoner private eye, is like being taken on a joyride through the very best of late 1960s and 1970s SoCal fashion. There’s the orange crochet minidress worn by one character, the Rudi Gernreich-style bikini on another, the wacky purple suit of a square dentist trying to be hip. The movie, out today with an all-star cast (Joaquin Phoenix, Josh Brolin, Benicio Del Toro, Owen Wilson, Reese Witherspoon and the promising newcomer Katherine Waterston), follows the sandal-wearing gumshoe Larry “Doc” Sportello (Phoenix) around Los Angeles as clues pile up in a shaggy-dog mystery. But Phoenix’s character is more hippie fashion plate than noir tough guy in his green army coat, navy turtleneck, jean jacket and slew of vintage flannel shirts. And it’s all thanks to Mark Bridges, the film’s costume designer, who has worked with Anderson since before “Boogie Nights.”

headline: Bronx Man Surrenders and Is Charged in a Fatal Hit and Run
abstract: Guler Ugur-Yaacobi, 44, was struck and killed by the man, Prezidor Porbeni, while she was crossing Amsterdam Avenue on West 113th Street in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: A Bronx man was arrested and charged in a hit-and-run accident on New Year’s Eve in Manhattan that killed a 44-year-old woman, the authorities said on Thursday.

headline: A Bad Flu Season Hits the Halfway Mark, C.D.C. Says
abstract: The dominant flu strain this year is not very vulnerable to the vaccine and the agency is urging anyone with flu symptoms to take antiviral medicines.
lead_paragraph: The nation is halfway through a bad flu season, dominated by a viral strain that is not very vulnerable to this year’s vaccine, federal health officials said on Friday.

headline: When Outside Factors Dictate Retirement Age
abstract: Some older workers consider life expectancy, changes in technology at work and potential age bias when deciding to retire.
lead_paragraph: FOR many, deciding to retire can be as straightforward as reaching Social Security eligibility age or amassing a solid nest egg. But for others mulling over when to stop work, there are other powerful, if less measurable, considerations like life expectancy, changing technological demands of the workplace and fear that age bias will limit continued employment.

headline: From The Upshot: Community College and the Economy
abstract: Economic history provides the broader context for understanding President Obama’s proposal to make community college available free.
lead_paragraph: Obama’s College Proposal Is Also a Bid to Rev the Economy

headline: The Dress Is Temporary, the Memories Forever
abstract: Practical brides take to renting or selling their gowns.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie Grimes Cornman coveted the designer wedding dress she had ogled in fashion spreads. But the price kept it out of reach — that is, until she embraced the idea that a dress, unlike a spouse, is not to have and to hold forever.

headline: DuPont’s Main Defense Against Nelson Peltz: Performance
abstract: In arguing against Nelson Peltz, the chemical maker has repeatedly cited what may be its strongest defense: its stock price performance and return of capital to shareholders.
lead_paragraph: Nelson Peltz has kicked off only his second proxy fight by seeking four board seats at DuPont. But the chemical maker is an unusual target for a shareholder activism campaign — in part because the company appears to already be performing well.

headline: CES: Everything Old Is New Again
abstract: The biggest trends at International CES were actually technological concepts that have been around for decades, if not centuries.
lead_paragraph: Friday is the last official day of International CES, the giant technology trade show in Las Vegas. It is also, as it happens, the eighth anniversary of the introduction of the original iPhone.

headline: In Africa, a Decline in New Ebola Cases Complicates Vaccine Development
abstract: Clinical trials in Africa are being pushed by a sense of urgency as fewer new cases occur, making it more difficult to determine how effective the drugs are.
lead_paragraph: As authorities and drug companies hurriedly prepare to begin testing Ebola vaccines in West Africa, they are starting to contemplate a new challenge: whether an ebbing of the outbreak could make it more difficult to determine if the experimental vaccines are effective.

headline: Pursuing Games, Boston Jumps In With One Foot
abstract: While many business interests supported hosting the Summer Games in 2024, not everybody was celebrating the idea or sold on its benefits.
lead_paragraph: Christmas has come and gone, but a holiday spirit lingers in Boston. Not the holly-jolly kind, but the quizzical kind where you unwrap a glitzy present and immediately wonder if it ought to be returned.

headline: A Proxy Fight as Much About Nelson Peltz’s Firm as About DuPont
abstract: Flexing muscle sends a message to other stubborn targets, like PepsiCo, writes Kevin Allison of Reuters Breakingviews. It also gives Mr. Peltz’s potential successors at Trian experience in the trenches.
lead_paragraph: Nelson Peltz’s latest proxy fight will resonate beyond its immediate target, DuPont. The billionaire activist’s Trian Partners is seeking four director seats at the venerable chemicals group, its first public battle since squeezing onto Heinz’s board nine years ago. Flexing muscle sends a message to other stubborn targets, like PepsiCo. It also gives Mr. Peltz’s potential successors experience in the trenches.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week: Topman Fall/Winter 2015
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: Behold the Republican Immigration Strategy: Mass Deportation
abstract: The party wants to undo several executive actions.
lead_paragraph: It’s a new year, with a new Congress, but the same old Republican Party hard line on immigration. Harder, actually.

headline: Sizing Up Seismic Activity of Football Fans
abstract: The noise of the famously raucous Seahawks fans, who caused a temblor in 2011, will be monitored by scientists during their game against the Carolina Panthers.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — What if the Big One happens during the Big Game?

headline: 2 Entrepreneurs Know the Value in Serendipity
abstract: Two entrepreneurs from the South marry, just as the psychic hairdresser predicted.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Moskowitz had no interest in peering into a crystal ball. She was the type who knew where she was going, the girl who took first prize in statewide oratory contests, snagged the lead in school plays, and was admitted to Brown University. Fortunes were to be made, she believed, not told.

headline: Of a Feather, but a Flock Apart
abstract: Four leading dancers of the Mariinsky Ballet of St. Petersburg, soon to perform at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, discuss what it’s like to portray Odette-Odile.
lead_paragraph: Yekaterina Kondaurova, the elegant, flame-haired principal of the Mariinsky Ballet, appeared in “Swan Lake” during her first year with the St. Petersburg company in 2001. “I was in the last row of the corps of swans,” she recalled in an email interview. “At the time I thought it was the most frightening thing there could be in life. My arms and legs were shaking so much. It was even hard to stand on my two feet.”

headline: So Nice, They Do It Twice
abstract: For classical musicians, encores can be a shock-and-awe routine or a chance for the technically flawless to prove their artistic bona fides.
lead_paragraph: They are demanded, they delight and then they’re over, rarely to be remembered like the big concerto, sonata or symphony to which they form brief codas.

headline: Storm Adds to Misery of Gaza’s Most Vulnerable
abstract: A baby in Gaza, where thousands of residents’ homes were destroyed or damaged last summer, was among the cold weather’s victims.
lead_paragraph: GAZA — As a winter storm continued to pound the Middle East, thousands of Gaza residents whose homes were destroyed or damaged in last summer’s war with Israel struggled with the harsh weather for a third day, and a 4-month-old baby from the southern part of the territory died on Friday from complications caused by the bitter cold, Palestinian health officials and relatives said.

headline: A Reporter Treads Carefully When Writing About Religion and Violence
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The Cairo bureau chief for The Times, David D. Kirkpatrick, discussed writing about questions within Islam.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the attack at the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo in Paris, The Times’ Cairo bureau chief, David D. Kirkpatrick, wrote a front-page article about debates over the connection between violence and Islam. Here he describes the care involved in writing about an inherently fraught subject and why it seemed important to address the questions.

headline: A New Direction
abstract: The blog is ending, but our coverage of caregiving and aging is not. The New Old Age will run as a twice-monthly column by Paula Span on nytimes.com and frequently in Science Times.
lead_paragraph: As some readers have already discovered, The Times is discontinuing publication of The New Old Age blog. I join many of you in disappointment — but, to paraphrase Mark Twain, reports of its death have been exaggerated.

headline: A Propulsive Leap Forward and a Nod to Late Blooms
abstract: From the kora duets of Toumani and Sidiki to the paranoid nightmares of Gazelle Twin, a look at new albums as well as some from last year that attracted recent attention.
lead_paragraph: Out with the old? Not quite yet. Before the year fully gears up, this Playlist lingers over some albums from 2014 that earned some belated notice — and welcomes some 2015 albums that defy the January doldrums.

headline: Live Coverage: Golden Globes 2015
abstract: Interviews and photos from the red carpet, reports from backstage, telecast commentary and more.
lead_paragraph: The Times covered the 72nd Golden Globe Awards live, with interviews and photos from the red carpet, reports from backstage, commentary during the telecast from Dave Itzkoff and Jon Caramanica, and more.

headline: From Vertigo to Tinnitus, Ear Ailments Are New Focus for Drugs
abstract: In search of an alternative to hearing aids or implants, some report success in early trials for drugs to improve hearing or silence tinnitus.
lead_paragraph: Driving to a meeting in 2008, Jay Lichter, a venture capitalist, suddenly became so dizzy he had to pull over and call a friend to take him to the emergency room.

headline: Obama, in Tennessee, Begins Selling His Community College Tuition Plan
keywords: ['Community Colleges', 'Tuition', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Pell Grants']
abstract: The president urged Congress to allocate an estimated $60 billion over 10 years for an initiative that would be based in part on a Tennessee program.
lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — In California, community college tuition and fees average less than $1,500 a year, the lowest in the nation, and with government grants, most students pay nothing. In Florida and Michigan, the cost is over $3,000, yet poorer students still attend free. But in Vermont and New Hampshire, prices are around $7,000, well over what government grants cover.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week: MAN Fall/Winter 2015
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Christopher Shannon: Fall 2015 Menswear
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Easily Channeling a Vulnerable Vicar
abstract: James Norton says he feels an easy kinship with the conflicted clergyman he plays in “Grantchester,” coming to “Masterpiece Mystery!” on PBS.
lead_paragraph: With his model looks, plummy British elocution and bad-boy twinkle, James Norton gives the impression of having the acting world on a string. But his first film role — a few seconds in Lone Scherfig’s “An Education,” stealthily undertaken in defiance of institutional rules while a student at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art — didn’t exactly portend a star in the making.

headline: Cameras and the Tricks They Play
abstract: Two productions in the Under the Radar festival, “Cineastas” and “O Jardim,” consider the gulf between images and the truths they obscure.
lead_paragraph: Though it’s not for want of trying, we can never fit real life into a frame. That’s the premise, both sobering and invigorating, that animates two affectingly inventive works from South America at the Under the Radar festival of experimental theater this weekend, ruefully sentimental plays about the deceptions of sentimental journeys.

headline: Israelis Link Attacks to Their Own Struggles
abstract: For many Israelis, any terrorism by Islamic extremists bolsters the view that their conflict with the Palestinians is part of a larger clash of civilizations.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Like leaders around the world, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was quick to condemn the attack that killed 12 people in Paris on Wednesday at the offices of a satirical newspaper, Charlie Hebdo. The next day, Mr. Netanyahu sent a letter of condolence and outrage to the French president and declared after a meeting with Norway’s foreign minister, “Israel is being attacked by the very same forces that attack Europe.”

headline: Stormy Waters Decide a Family’s Fate
abstract: “The Scarlet Ibis,” a new chamber opera, is based on a James Hurst short story published in The Atlantic in 1960.
lead_paragraph: The tools that contemporary composers, conductors and directors are using to expand the spectacle of music can sometimes seem like unnecessary embellishments, whether video projections, acrobatics or reflecting pools of water. So the great achievement of “The Scarlet Ibis” — an outstanding new chamber opera by the composer Stefan Weisman and the librettist David Cote that opened the Prototype festival at Here on Thursday night — is not only that it’s a moving, intense and dignified creation, but also that it adds puppetry to opera’s basic elements in a completely organic way.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
abstract: A snowy landing and more in the Week in Politics slideshow.
lead_paragraph: A snowy landing and more in the Week in Politics slideshow.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
abstract: A snowy landing and more in the Week in Politics slideshow.

headline: The “Punk Ballerina” Karole Armitage Brings Together Lacroix, Gaultier, Koons and More
abstract: A new exhibition at Mana Contemporary, curated by Jeffrey Deitch, highlights the choreographer’s many collaborations with key art and fashion figures.
lead_paragraph: Nearly four decades ago, in 1978, a twentysomething dancer and choreographer named Karole Armitage tapped Christian Marclay, then a budding artist studying at Cooper Union, to create the set and costumes for her production “Ne.” “It was kind of like ‘Ne’ was destroying all that there was before, that jubilation, that you can remake the world in your own way,” Armitage remembers. The piece was originally supposed to debut in an East Village squat. “There was no heat, which is why we decided to have bright, fluorescent, fake-fur pants — because we just wanted to keep the dancers warm,” Armitage explains. The squatters changed their minds, so “Ne” eventually premiered at a gymnasium in Chelsea.

headline: A Memorial for a Jazz Great
abstract: A few dozen musicians will gather to pay respects to Charlie Haden in words and music, at Town Hall.
lead_paragraph: The bassist Charlie Haden, who died last year at 76, was a generous collaborator throughout his expansive jazz career, sowing seeds of deep melody and pliable rapport among several generations of fellow musicians. A few dozen of them will gather to pay respects, in words and music, at his memorial celebration on Tuesday at Town Hall. Organized by his widow, Ruth Cameron, the service will include two of his flagship ensembles: the Liberation Music Orchestra, featuring the composer Carla Bley and, for this occasion, the bassist Steve Swallow; and Quartet West, with Scott Colley on bass. Members of Mr. Haden’s musical family — his son, the singer-songwriter Josh Haden, and his daughters, known as the Haden Triplets — will appear.

headline: Piano and Strings, or Mahler
abstract: Morton Feldman’s work will be performed at Spectrum on Sunday, a night that also brings Argento Chamber Ensemble’s Mahler as New York Contemporary series.
lead_paragraph: This week night offers a couple of strong concert choices. On Sunday, you can head to Spectrum, a very cozy space on the Lower East Side, for Morton Feldman’s late, visionary Piano and String Quartet, featuring the pianist Joseph Branciforte and string players drawn from several ensembles: Christopher Otto, Pauline Kim Harris, John Pickford Richards and Mariel Roberts. (9 p.m., 121 Ludlow Street, second floor, spectrumnyc.com.)

headline: When Spite Trumps the Nielsen Ratings
abstract: Season 4 of Showtime’s Emmy-nominated “Episodes” starts Sunday.
lead_paragraph: When last we saw Beverly and Sean Lincoln, the fictional creators of a British TV hit made unrecognizable by a Hollywood studio, they’d been swept out of fantasyland and back to reality with the cancellation — finally — of “Pucks!”

headline: The Uphill Push to Save a Bike-Share Pioneer
abstract: A Canadian investor takes a chance on a pace-setting system that lost its way.
lead_paragraph: The typical origin story for a tech company includes a paper napkin and a garage. But the company that powers the bike-sharing programs in New York, London, Chicago and a dozen other cities started much differently: It began with a municipal parking authority, wound through bankruptcy court and got another shot at corporate viability off the Madagascar coast during the annual hatching of the green sea turtles.

headline: Scenes of France, Sketched in Oil
abstract: Oil sketches are the Twitter of 18th-century painting. The Morgan Library & Museum will focus on the history of the practice in “Exploring France: Oil Sketches From the Thaw Collection.”
lead_paragraph: Oil sketches are the Twitter of 18th-century painting, dashed off sometimes in mere minutes to capture a fleeting idea or a quality of light that would be gone forever with the next cloud bank. Their power is not only in their immediacy but also in how they prefigure outdoor painters who elevated landscape as a genre. Starting Tuesday, the Morgan Library & Museum will focus on the history of the practice in “Exploring France: Oil Sketches From the Thaw Collection.” The collector Eugene V. Thaw and his wife, Clare, benefactors of the Morgan and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, have donated 135 oil sketches to the two institutions, in addition to giving hundreds of old master and 19th-century drawings to the Morgan. Mr. Thaw has described the sketches as “the most wonderful, fresh, free pieces on paper” — work that mattered to him because it mattered to the artists, who considered them much more than disposable studies: “They traded them amongst each other, and they preserved them.” (Through Oct. 4, 225 Madison Avenue, at 36th Street, 212-685-0008, themorgan.org.)

headline: Uncovering Secrets
abstract: Patrick Stewart stars in the film version of Stephen Belber’s play “Match,” stepping into the role that earned Frank Langella a Tony nomination.
lead_paragraph: In the film version of “Match,” Stephen Belber’s play about choices, regrets and long-hidden secrets, Patrick Stewart takes on the role brought to Broadway by Frank Langella in 2004. The movie, adapted and directed by Mr. Belber, opens on Wednesday at the IFC Center (323 Avenue of the Americas, at Third Street, Greenwich Village). Mr. Stewart plays Tobias Powell, a dance teacher and former performer whose long career is supposedly the reason Lisa (Carla Gugino) and her husband, Mike (Matthew Lillard), have come to interview him. But that is just a pretense; they are really interested in a piece of his past he has long buried. It’s a three-hander that’s also a showcase for the actor playing Tobias. What does Mr. Stewart have to live up to?

headline: West Village Townhouse for $21 Million
abstract: A fully renovated townhouse in the West Village that was converted back to a single residence from 10 apartments was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A meticulously renovated townhouse in the West Village, with ample outdoor space that includes a two-tiered patio and a paved roof deck offering a wide range of cityscape and river views, sold for $21,000,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Gesture, Genetics and Other Fare
abstract: Michelle Ellsworth’s “Preparation for the Obsolescence of the Y Chromosome” is one of 23 productions presented by American Realness, an 11-day festival of contemporary performance.
lead_paragraph: Are we on our way to becoming a single-sex species? In “Preparation for the Obsolescence of the Y Chromosome,” the choreographer Michelle Ellsworth considers the possibility, building on her body of jubilantly absurd yet pragmatically minded work. (Her past projects include an online inventory of pseudospiritual paraphernalia and a video archive of motivational talks.) “Preparation,” which draws inspiration from the folklorist Alan Lomax and recent genetic research, digests cultural lore through gestural choreography, a “male gaze simulator” and other witty devices.

headline: Obama’s Community-College Plan: A Reading List
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Community Colleges', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'United States Economy', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: A guide to the debate over President Obama’s plan to make community college free for many students — and the local programs that have already done so.
lead_paragraph: President Obama is in Tennessee on Friday, along with the state’s Republican governor and two Republican senators, to lay out his plan for free community college. The plan — which would require congressional approval — would apply to students attending a two-year college, including part time, so long as the college offered credits that could transfer to a four-year college or provided training that led to jobs.

headline: Christie to Pay His Way to Watch Cowboys Play
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is shrugging off controversy over his football loyalties — and his acceptance of flights and tickets from the owner of the Dallas Cowboys — opting to pay his own way to attend this weekend’s playoff game in Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: Showing that his loyalty to the Dallas Cowboys has no limits, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is shrugging off controversy over his football loyalties — and his acceptance of flights and tickets from the team’s owner, Jerry Jones — opting to pay his own way to attend this weekend’s playoff game in Wisconsin.

headline: George Washington Fought — and Lost — Here
abstract: The history of the Revolutionary War’s bloody Battle of Brooklyn is on display at the Old Stone House in Park Slope.
lead_paragraph: The history of the Revolutionary War’s bloody Battle of Brooklyn is on display at the Old Stone House in Park Slope.

headline: Where George Washington Lost a Battle in Brooklyn, a Museum Dedicated to Its History Sits
abstract: The Old Stone House museum in Park Slope is dedicated to the history of the Revolutionary War’s bloody Battle of Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: A tumult of children play soccer and skateboard around a Dutch Colonial farmhouse in Park Slope, oblivious to the site’s brutal, blood-drenched past. The Battle of Brooklyn, the Revolutionary War’s biggest conflict, was waged around the OLD STONE HOUSE, a museum dedicated to the chaos that unfolded on Aug. 27, 1776, less than two months after the Declaration of Independence.

headline: After Taking His Bows, a Super Bowl Star Takes a Seat
abstract: Malcolm Smith was named Super Bowl M.V.P. last season, but in Seattle’s meritocracy, he now finds himself playing behind three durable and dominant linebackers.
lead_paragraph: RENTON, Wash. — The morning after his life changed forever, Malcolm Smith boarded a private jet bound for Florida. A waiter catered to his and his girlfriend’s every need, recharging Smith for the parade that awaited him when he landed.

headline: Bitcoin Exchange Bitstamp Resumes Services
abstract: Bitstamp said it had adopted new security measures and protocols to prevent future breaches. The company had suspended its services after some virtual wallets were compromised.
lead_paragraph: Bitstamp, the prominent Bitcoin exchange that suspended its services this week after a security breach, has resumed operations, capping a period of uncertainty in the virtual currency industry.

headline: Blast Kills at Least 7 People at Mosque in Pakistan
abstract: Witnesses said that a suicide bomber detonated his explosives outside a Shiite mosque in Rawalpindi, near Pakistan’s capital.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — At least seven people were killed and 18 were wounded Friday when a suicide bomber detonated his explosives outside a Shiite mosque in Rawalpindi, police officials said.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week: MAN Fall/Winter 2015
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week', 'Men and Boys', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: How ‘Places to Go’ Gets Done
abstract: Monica Drake, the Travel editor, and Dan Saltzstein, an assistant editor and point person for Places to Go, talk about the selection process, how the list has evolved over a decade and what cities they’re most excited about.
lead_paragraph: Everyone wants to visit Rome. But have you considered Cleveland? The Travel section’s 10th annual “52 Places to Go” feature is live, and there are destinations that some may find surprising.

headline: After Workout Accident, Reid Says Regaining Full Vision Is No Slam Dunk
abstract: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada said Friday that he might not regain the vision in his right eye after suffering a nasty fall in which he broke four ribs and some bones around his eye.
lead_paragraph: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada said Friday that he might not regain the vision in his right eye after suffering a nasty fall in which he broke four ribs and some bones around his eye.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
abstract: France and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: France and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day

headline: Pictures of the Day — Jan. 9, 2015
abstract: Photos from France, Manila, India and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from France, Manila, India and the United States.

headline: Target-Date Funds Can Pose Complexities
keywords: ['Mutual Funds', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Funds whose investment strategies reflect an employee’s projected retirement date are surging in popularity but investors should be aware of the various levels of risk.
lead_paragraph: Deborah L. Lemmerman, vice president for human resources at Hebrew SeniorLife in Boston, believes in the benefits of target-date retirement funds. Over the last 15 years, in her current post and in previous ones, she has seen employees embrace these investments.

headline: For U.S. Stocks, at Least, a Solid Finish
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Mutual Funds', 'United States Economy', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Domestic economic strength overshadowed weakness abroad, though plunging oil prices pose global uncertainty for the new year.
lead_paragraph: Stocks ended the fourth quarter of 2014 near record highs, but they traveled a circuitous route to get there — falling, then soaring, then falling again before making a strong late run. Bonds went in either direction, depending on the quality of the vehicle used for the trip. And in the quarter’s biggest surprise, oil headed due south.

headline: Trying to Capitalize on Lower Oil Prices, Through E.T.F.s
keywords: ['Mutual Funds', 'Exchange Traded Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Oil’s price plunge hurt energy funds, but investors may still be able to make good bets by focusing on specific pieces of the industry.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the biggest events in an eventful fourth quarter of 2014 may have been something that didn’t happen.

headline: The Rise of Trading in the Dark
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mutual Funds', 'United States Economy']
abstract: So-called dark trading — when computers serve as matchmakers and bid-and-ask quotations aren’t displayed to all participants — now accounts for almost half of daily trading volume in the United States, a report finds.
lead_paragraph: JUDGING solely by the name, stock trading in so-called dark pools may conjure up images of mysterious deals cut beyond public view. Also called simply “dark trading,” it happens when computers serve as matchmakers and bid-and-ask quotations aren’t displayed to all participants. What’s surprising is just how big the dark-trading market has become.

headline: Gauging Funds’ Emergency Preparedness
keywords: ['Mutual Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: How liquid are mutual funds’ investments? Regulators are considering the question as they examine the industry for several areas of risk.
lead_paragraph: WHENEVER markets are hot, mutual fund companies tend to go far off the beaten track in their hunt for better returns.

headline: For Bond Investors, That Other Shoe Still Didn’t Drop
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Credit and Debt', 'Government Bonds', 'Interest Rates']
abstract: In the fixed-income market, 2014 was frustrating only for bond bears who have been waiting since 2009 for interest rates to rise.
lead_paragraph: BONDS confounded conventional wisdom in 2014 with a much-better-than-expected return.

headline: A Day of Calm for Kathryn Garcia
abstract: Ms. Garcia, the New York City sanitation commissioner, has been savoring her non-snowy Sundays.
lead_paragraph: Kathryn Garcia remembers having just four snow days when she was a student in Park Slope in the 1970s. Growing up, she would listen to the radio for the announcements. “They’d go through a laundry list of suburban schools,” Ms. Garcia said. " ‘Mount Vernon, Montclair schools are closed, New York public schools are ...open.’ ” Sigh. Now, as the New York City sanitation commissioner, Ms. Garcia, 44, is the one who advises the Education Department as to whether to call a snow day, consulting with the city’s meteorologists and with three weather services. With the city not seeing its first accumulation until Tuesday, Ms. Garcia has been savoring her non-snowy Sundays. She does not venture far from the Park Slope home she shares with her husband, Jerry Garcia, 45 (he does not play guitar), and their daughter, Anna, 16. Their son, Alex, 18, is a freshman at the University of Pennsylvania.

headline: Suddenly, BRIC Markets Are on a Shakier Foundation
keywords: ['Third World and Developing Countries', 'Exchange Traded Funds', 'Mutual Funds', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Commodities']
abstract: Investing in the BRIC countries — Brazil, Russia, India and China — once was a prudent way to benefit from emerging-market growth. But experts say times have changed.
lead_paragraph: Investing in rapidly developing economies is an inherently risky proposition. That is why more than a decade ago, investors embraced what seemed a prudent approach: focusing on the BRIC countries — Brazil, Russia, India and China — which have the largest and most liquid stock markets in the emerging-market world.

headline: An Instrumental Force in the Face of Darkness
abstract: A response to the killings at Charlie Hebdo, the French satirical newspaper, was woven into the New York Philharmonic’s program on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: For the New York Philharmonic’s first subscription series program of 2015, Alan Gilbert, the music director, had chosen some “joyous music for the New Year,” he told the audience at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night. But while the orchestra was preparing this concert, he said, the “horrific massacre” took place at the offices of the newspaper Charlie Hebdo, in Paris.

headline: Two Schools of Thought, Adding Up to Success
abstract: Three funds that were among the top performers of the fourth quarter of 2014 combined elements of both growth and value investing.
lead_paragraph: GROWTH and value styles of investing are often described as opposites, but managers of three of the better-performing funds of the fourth quarter of 2014 don’t see it that way.

headline: Feeding the Beast With Ever-Cheaper Oil
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Automobiles', 'Gasoline Tax (US)']
abstract: Lower gasoline prices have proved at least one thing: the guzzle lust of many American consumers.
lead_paragraph: GOOD news! Oil prices have dropped through the floor.

headline: Investment Strategies for Resolution Breakers
abstract: Two new personal-finance books sympathize with the plight of the weak-willed, offering upbeat advice on how to spend less and save more in the new year.
lead_paragraph: THE problem with most New Year’s resolutions is that they aren’t any fun. Sure, many of us should eat less — and healthier. And of course, more exercise would be a good thing. But actually doing these things can be hard.

headline: ‘If/Then’ to Close on Broadway
abstract: “If/Then,” a star vehicle for the Tony Award winner Idina Menzel, will close on March 22, when her run ends.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway musical “If/Then,” a star vehicle for the Tony Award winner Idina Menzel that portrays the implications of career and romantic choices on a modern-day New Yorker, will close on March 22 at the conclusion of Ms. Menzel’s run in the show, the producers announced on Friday.

headline: The Freewheeling Event That’s Part Performance Art, Part Dance Party
abstract: This weekend, the beer-fueled experimental happening stages its 66th iteration, which will include an interpretation of Chekhov and a Whitney Houston mash-up.
lead_paragraph: High rents and branded, well, everything may loom over the arts in New York City — but some grassroots culture organizations still manage to tough out the mean streets of the metropolis without compromising their homespun ethics. On Jan. 10, the whirlwind, ball-of-wax performance showcase Catch stages its 66th iteration — a feat for a sui generis arts project. The secret to its fancy-free success for over a decade? “Beer,” deadpans Caleb Hammons, one-third of Catch’s advisory team. As it says on the flyer, “$20 gets you in and gets you drinking.” As Hammons explains, “It signals that it’s okay to enjoy yourself.”

headline: An Escape Artist, Unlocking Door After Door
abstract: In what borders on a conceptual art project, Miranda July is marketing items online that relate to passages in her debut novel, “The First Bad Man.” The proceeds go to charity.
lead_paragraph: The objects for sale on Miranda July’s website seem entirely ordinary and even deliberately random. A pink hairbrush. An envelope. A painted vase. A bag of popcorn.

headline: Keeping the Laughs on Track
abstract: The sitcom “Last Man Standing” features lots of experienced writers behind the scenes.
lead_paragraph: STUDIO CITY, CALIF. — When the writers of the ABC sitcom “Last Man Standing” broke for lunch one recent Friday, five of them took their food to Ed Yeager’s office on the lot here.

headline: Before Dying, French Suspects Speak
abstract: Shortly before being killed in police shootouts, Chérif Kouachi and a man believed to have killed a police officer spoke on the phone with a French television station.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before being killed in police shootouts, Chérif Kouachi and a man believed to have killed a police officer spoke on the phone with a French television station.

abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: Saudis Begin Public Caning to Punish a Blogger
abstract: Raif Badawi was sentenced to 1,000 blows, 10 years in prison and a fine for starting a website critical of the country’s religious establishment.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The authorities in Saudi Arabia on Friday began the public flogging of a blogger who was sentenced to 1,000 blows, 10 years in prison and a large fine for starting a website that featured content critical of the country’s religious establishment, the rights group Amnesty International reported.

headline: What We’re Reading
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Ebola Virus', 'News and News Media', 'Pulitzer Prizes', 'Social Media']
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Nick Bilton, Quentin Hardy and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: The Duet as a Physical Sculpture, Unburdened by Noise or Clothing
abstract: “Rude World” is performed without words, and largely without clothes, by its choreographers Molly Lieber and Eleanor Smith as part of PS122’s Coil festival.
lead_paragraph: “Rude World,” the title of a new duet choreographed and performed by Molly Lieber and Eleanor Smith, might refer to all that the dance appears at first to exclude. The walls of the tiny Chocolate Factory theater, where the work was performed on Thursday as part of PS 122’s Coil festival, have been draped in black, the floor covered in black vinyl. The two women, entirely silent and naked most of the time, could be alone, dancing only for each other. Dancing with each other, they intertwine, skin to skin. Their world seems self-contained.

headline: Stop Checking Email So Often
abstract: When it comes to visiting your inbox, less might be more.
lead_paragraph: IS email overload bad for you?

headline: Hooting, Hissing and Ululating to Protest Man’s Inhumanity
abstract: The vocal ensemble Carmina Slovenica presents the American premiere of “Toxic Psalms,” an intense meditation on repressive violence and other forms of subjugation, at St. Ann’s Warehouse.
lead_paragraph: Much of “Toxic Psalms,” a striking new work by the rabidly talented Slovenian female vocal ensemble Carmina Slovenica, is dark. Literally: Enveloped in shadow, the vast stage of St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn, where the piece runs through Sunday, has rarely looked as forlorn as it did on opening night on Thursday.

headline: Jeb and Hillary Have Some Work to Do, a Pollster Finds
abstract: The political classes may be embracing the inevitability of a Jeb Bush-Hillary Clinton clash in 2016, but some voters are not sold.
lead_paragraph: The political classes may be embracing the inevitability of a Bush-Clinton clash in 2016, but some voters are not sold.

headline: Help Unravel a Gordon Parks Southern Mystery
abstract: A Gordon Parks photo from 1956 raises tantalizing questions about race and class in the Jim Crow South. Now, Lens is asking readers to help uncover the identities of the people in the picture.
lead_paragraph: A Gordon Parks photo from 1956 raises tantalizing questions about race and class in the Jim Crow South. Now, Lens is asking readers to help uncover the identities of the people in the picture.

keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week', 'Men and Boys', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: Cocktails, Karaoke and Occasional Cringing
abstract: “The Blind Date Project,” an improv piece in the Coil festival, is a new take on first encounters.
lead_paragraph: Schadenfreude is perhaps a natural reaction to “The Blind Date Project,” an improvisational theater piece presented as part of this year’s Coil festival that allows you to be a voyeur at the first meeting between two strangers. Admit that there’s something sneakily appealing in the prospect of watching other people navigate the jittery horrors of that initial encounter, a grueling rite of passage pretty much everyone has endured, and often regretted.

headline: In New York, a Hotel by Baccarat
abstract: The French crystal company Baccarat will open a hotel in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The venerable French crystal company Baccarat is venturing into hotel business for the first time with the Baccarat Hotel & Residences New York in a glass tower in Midtown Manhattan across the street from the Museum of Modern Art. While the 60 residences have been open since December, the hotel will make its debut in March.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Informative Auction at World Mind Games in Beijing
abstract: At this event last month, Vincent Demuy of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., found a great opening lead in the open pair event.
lead_paragraph: At the fourth SportAccord World Mind Games in Beijing last month, Vincent Demuy of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., found a great opening lead in the open pair event. Admittedly, he was helped by the very informative auction of his opponents, Fulvio Fantoni (North) and Claudio Nunes (South) from Monaco.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘America’s Bitter Pill’
abstract: Steven Brill discusses his new book about health care in America, and Heidi Julavits talks about Rachel Cusk’s new novel, “Outline.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Zephyr Teachout reviews Steven Brill’s “America’s Bitter Pill: Money, Politics, Backroom Deals, and the Fight to Fix Our Broken Healthcare System.” Ms. Teachout writes:

headline: Koons, Murakami and Other Artists Donate Works for Childhood Education
abstract: Jeff Koons and Takashi Murakami are among the artists donating work to benefit the 1 in 11 campaign, which aims to improve education for children.
lead_paragraph: London — Jeff Koons, Damien Hirst, Cai Guo Qiang, Jenny Holzer, Takashi Murakami, Richard Serra and Luc Tuymans are among the 17 major artists who have donated works for auction to benefit 1 in 11, a new campaign to improve education for children.

headline: Another Avenging Rampage
abstract: Liam Neeson returns as the retired government agent Bryan Mills in “Taken 3.”
lead_paragraph: After “Non-Stop,” “Unknown” and three installments of the “Taken” thrillers, I’m not sure that Liam Neeson’s signature avengers are actually good people to know. On the plus side, they’ll use any means necessary to rescue you from kidnappers and killers. But if you’ve been kidnapped or are facing death, it’s probably directly related to knowing Mr. Neeson’s character in the first place, or just being nearby.

headline: Staten Island Prosecutor to Run for Grimm’s House Seat
abstract: The Staten Island district attorney, Daniel M. Donovan Jr., a Republican, announced that he was seeking to replace former Representative Michael G. Grimm in a special election.
lead_paragraph: The race to succeed former Representative Michael G. Grimm has officially begun.

headline: Boston Bombing Trial, Week by Week
abstract: A synopsis of the trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who is accused of killing three people and injuring more than 260 in the bombing at the Boston Marathon in 2013. Mr. Tsarnaev is facing 30 federal charges, 17 of which carry the death penalty. He has pleaded not guilty.
lead_paragraph: A synopsis of the trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who is accused of killing three people and injuring more than 260 in the bombing at the Boston Marathon in 2013. Mr. Tsarnaev is facing 30 federal charges, 17 of which carry the death penalty. He has pleaded not guilty.

headline: ‘Vessel,’ Directed by Diana Whitten
abstract: The debates over access to abortion often invoke personal rights. “Vessel” concerns the intersection of those rights with national sovereignty.
lead_paragraph: The debates over access to abortion often invoke personal rights. “Vessel” concerns the intersection of those rights with national sovereignty. The movie follows the work of Dr. Rebecca Gomperts, a physician from the Netherlands who founded Women on Waves, an organization whose goal was to provide medical abortions in international waters to women from countries where the procedure was illegal. She later started Women on Web, a telemedicine support service. (Emily Bazelon covered Dr. Gomperts’s efforts at length in The New York Times Magazine last year.)

headline: F.B.I. and Justice Dept. Said to Seek Charges for Petraeus
abstract: The F.B.I. and Justice Department prosecutors suggested bringing felony charges against the retired general for providing classified information to his former mistress while he was director of the C.I.A., officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. and Justice Department prosecutors have recommended bringing felony charges against David H. Petraeus, contending that he provided classified information to a lover while he was director of the C.I.A., officials said, and leaving Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. to decide whether to seek an indictment that could send the pre-eminent military officer of his generation to prison.

headline: Wrongly Convicted Man Was His Own Best Advocate
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: More than two decades of filing motions, sending letters and securing affidavits arguing his innocence in a murder case ended on Friday, when Derrick Hamilton was vindicated.
lead_paragraph: They would meet every week in the law library, researching legal databases, discussing United States Supreme Court decisions and reviewing copies of Justice Denied, a magazine for the wrongfully convicted.

headline: If at First You Don’t Succeed, Try Scaling Back Your Dream
abstract: Jeremy Chess, the producer of “Soul Doctor,” hopes for success as the play moves to an Off Broadway stage.
lead_paragraph: It was just last season that the bio-musical “Soul Doctor” opened and quickly closed on Broadway, a box-office failure with a price tag of at least $5 million.

headline: The Battle to Belong
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Electroshock Therapy']
abstract: My mother suffered as an immigrant, as a Jew set adrift.
lead_paragraph: NEVER before have so many people been on the move. New opportunity, like a bright star, draws immigrants across the world. In every one of the past four generations my family has moved, hopping from Lithuania to what is now South Africa and on to Britain, Israel and the United States. Sometimes they have found success and happiness. But the other side of displacement, its black sun, is loss.

headline: Who Will Be America’s Next Top Mentor?
keywords: ['Mentors', 'Women and Girls', 'Careers and Professions', 'Social Media', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Powerful women like Diane von Furstenberg and Sophia Amoruso add mentoring to their portfolio.
lead_paragraph: The January issues of fashion magazines usually contain extra lashings of diet and exercise advice (and the fewest ads of the year), but this month’s Elle, with Nicole Kidman on the cover, offers something new. To celebrate its third decade, the magazine announced, it is convening “a board of 43 female powerhouses who are joining forces to improve the lives of women — that’s you! — for the next 30 years.”

headline: Users Say TurboTax Deluxe Is Less Deluxe Than It Used to Be
abstract: To get the program’s full question-and-answer help to complete some tax schedules, customers must upgrade and pay an extra $30 to $40.
lead_paragraph: TAXPAYERS buying commercial software to prepare and electronically file their 2014 income tax returns should double-check that the version they are purchasing fits their needs.

headline: Where Fabric and Trinkets Are Found
abstract: Broadway Silk Store has been an anchor in Astoria, Queens, since the Depression.
lead_paragraph: Broadway Silk Store has been an anchor in Astoria, Queens, since the Depression.

headline: Where Elmo’s People Shop: Broadway Silk Store in Astoria
abstract: A purveyor of fabric and costume jewelry, Broadway Silk Store, in Astoria, Queens, has been an anchor in the neighborhood since the Depression.
lead_paragraph: Is it a coincidence that Broadway Silk Store, a Queens purveyor of fabric and costume jewelry, sits across the street from the Greater Astoria Historical Society? The store has been an anchor in the neighborhood since the Depression. It is two blocks from Kaufman Astoria Studios and has furnished costuming for an array of productions over its 80-year history, including “Sesame Street,” “Men in Black 3” and “The Good Wife.” And as with other multigenerational, family-owned institutions, it has an oral history so rich that it can be hard to distinguish fact from fiction.

headline: The Fury Over Chirlane McCray’s Trousers
abstract: As New York City’s first lady has found out, public figures have to consider what they wear as a piece of communication.
lead_paragraph: The firestorm of social media accusation and response that blew up around the question of what New York City’s first lady, Chirlane McCray, did, or did not, wear to the slain police officer Wenjian Liu’s funeral last Sunday may seem a silly distraction in the greater, more urgent story of fraying relations between City Hall and the police force, but it is also a powerful reminder of the power clothes have, for both good and ill.

headline: To Fall in Love With Anyone, Do This
abstract: What happens if you decide that falling in love is not something that happens to you, but something that you do?
lead_paragraph: More than 20 years ago, the psychologist Arthur Aron succeeded in making two strangers fall in love in his laboratory. Last summer, I applied his technique in my own life, which is how I found myself standing on a bridge at midnight, staring into a man’s eyes for exactly four minutes.

headline: The 36 Questions That Lead to Love
abstract: A series of personal questions used by the psychologist Arthur Aron to explore the idea of fostering closeness through mutual vulnerability.

headline: Mitt Romney Says He’s Considering a 2016 Presidential Run
abstract: Mr. Romney, the 2012 Republican nominee, told about 30 donors in New York on Friday that he was “thinking about” a third campaign for the White House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney, the 2012 Republican presidential nominee, told a group of donors in New York on Friday that he was considering running for president again next year, sending a signal to the party’s financiers that they should not yet commit to Jeb Bush.

headline: Piano Tuner Is Known as a Pro, and a Scold
abstract: Customers who neglect their pianos and call Zinovy Pritsker to tune them will get an expert job, and very likely a piece of his mind.
lead_paragraph: “Between you and me, a job like this is a pain in the neck,” the piano tuner said, surveying the aging Baldwin spinet before him.

headline: Amid Urban Debris, the Snowy Owl Is a Wintertime Ghost
abstract: The snowy owl is a rare visitor from the north, but last year’s superabundance drew the attention of bird-watchers and the uninitiated equally.
lead_paragraph: The first snowy owl I ever saw turned out to be a Clorox bleach bottle, perched on the crest of a dune in the Rockaways. Three friends and I spent a half-hour stalking its glowering, yellow cap, which, at least at a distance, made for a passable yellow eye in what seemed like an accurate white silhouette. Lesson 1: Not all bumps on a dune in New York City are snowy owls.

headline: Uber Cuts Fares in 48 Cities, Raising Some Concern Among Drivers
abstract: Uber said the fare cuts would help drivers “beat the winter slump” by generating business in the months after the busy holiday season.
lead_paragraph: Uber, the popular ride-hailing start-up, has enticed millions of new customers with a simple promise: The experience will be better and cheaper than taking a taxi.

headline: Police Efforts to Free the Hostages
abstract: The police moved on two sites in France where suspects were said to be holding hostages.
lead_paragraph: The police moved on two sites in France where suspects were said to be holding hostages.

headline: At A.F.I. Lunch, an Award for Everyone
abstract: The annual event also acts as a welcome respite from the glare of the Globes.
lead_paragraph: The formation of hierarchies seems an indubitable part of human nature, which is perhaps why the American Film Institute awards luncheon on Friday came off, to your Bagger’s new-to-all-of-this eyes, as a little flat.

headline: Remembering Bess Myerson’s Turbulent Public Life
abstract: Friends, colleagues and journalists recall the life of the first and only Jewish Miss America.
lead_paragraph: For the first 70 years of her life, Bess Myerson barely breathed without making headlines.

headline: Books About ‘Sodom by the Sea’ and the Bronx
abstract: “A Coney Island Reader” includes writing by Stephen Crane and Isaac Bashevis Singer; and four books discuss different aspects of the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: “It’s the nature of Coney Island to confuse,” Kevin Baker writes in his foreword to “A Coney Island Reader: Through Dizzy Gates of Illusion” (Columbia University Press), by Louis J. Parascandola and John Parascandola, an overdue anthology that vividly paints Brooklyn’s seaside playground in psychedelic prose and poetry.

headline: New Mexico: Deal Would Restore Doctor’s License
abstract: An obstetrician/gynecologist in Hobbs has been ordered to undergo evaluation for sex addiction as a condition of returning to work.
lead_paragraph: An obstetrician/gynecologist in Hobbs whose medical license was suspended over accusations that he had sex with patients, drank on the job and was unavailable as his patients went into labor has been ordered to undergo evaluation for sex addiction as a condition of returning to work. The doctor, Christopher S. Driskill, one of the few obstetrician-gynecologists in Hobbs and president-elect of the New Mexico Medical Society, had his license suspended in November by state medical officials. In December, he reached a settlement with state Medical Board prosecutors to restore his license. The settlement was approved Thursday by the board, which required that he “submit to a comprehensive inpatient evaluation” within the next three months by the Sexual Recovery Institute in Los Angeles.

headline: Friday Night Music: Nickel Creek
abstract: A bit of perfect harmony, in all senses.
lead_paragraph: How is it that I missed this band? Some simple joy after a week of terrible headlines:

headline: At Princeton, a Student of Sports Leadership Successfully Applies Her Research
abstract: Courtney Banghart, a former Dartmouth star who did a master’s project on sports leadership, has led the Tigers to a national ranking.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J. — As a women’s basketball assistant at Dartmouth in 2007, Courtney Banghart juggled her coaching duties with requirements for a master’s degree in writing and leadership development. For her final project, she conducted in-person interviews with accomplished coaches, including the North Carolina women’s soccer coach, Anson Dorrance, and the Connecticut women’s basketball coach, Geno Auriemma.

headline: Dozens Said to Die in Boko Haram Attack
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']

lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Refugees in northeast Nigeria fleeing an attack by the Islamist group Boko Haram have spoken of dozens of civilian deaths and scores of houses destroyed in an already hard-hit fishing village near Lake Chad.

headline: Julio Scherer García, Investigative Journalist in Mexico, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Scherer, the founder of the magazine Proceso, created a school of critical journalism that unmasked political corruption in Mexico and helped lay the groundwork for its democratic transition.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Julio Scherer García, a newspaper and magazine editor who created a school of critical journalism that unmasked Mexico’s political corruption and helped lay the groundwork for the country’s democratic transition, died here on Jan. 7. He was 88.

headline: A License to Say Anything?
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Automobile Registration and License Plates', 'ABORTION', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia']
abstract: Specialty license plates are a new frontier in debates over freedom of speech.
lead_paragraph: SPECIALTY license plates — which bear the logo of a college or a sports team, or a slogan like “Save Our Seas” or “Stop Child Abuse” — bring in lots of money for state governments, as well as the schools, nonprofit groups, professional organizations and other entities that sponsor them. But these vehicular tags have also become a new frontier in debates over freedom of speech.

headline: Windfall for Taxpayers Coming to an End
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Economy', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: The Fed turns over most of its profits from a bond-buying campaign to the Treasury Department, helping people buy cars and refinance mortgages. But the earnings are set to decrease.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s bond-buying campaign continues to produce one clear benefit: a windfall for taxpayers.

headline: A Pop-Punk Singer and the Blurred Line Between Digital Fan Mail and Trouble
abstract: Jake Mcelfresh, 23, a pop-punk singer-songwriter also known as Front Porch Step, has faced accusations by underage fans on Tumblr and Change.org.
lead_paragraph: As technology has eroded the traditional barriers between musicians and their admirers, the old-fashioned methods of connection — sending fan letters into the record label ether, sneaking backstage at a concert for a photo — have given way to new forms of interaction: Twitter, Instagram, Facebook. Online, artists are closer to their public than ever.

headline: Ex-Police Chief Tells South Carolina Jury Why He Shot Unarmed Black Man
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Richard J. Combs, the former police chief of Eutawville, S.C., faces possible life imprisonment for shooting an unarmed black man, Bernard Bailey.
lead_paragraph: ORANGEBURG, S.C. — For much of the week, Richard J. Combs, a former police chief in the small town of Eutawville, sat in silence at his murder trial while jurors heard how he killed an unarmed black man.

headline: Chicago Man Is Indicted on Charge of Trying to Aid ISIS
abstract: Mohammed Hamzah Khan, a 19-year-old Muslim, was charged with trying to travel to Syria in October to join the terrorist army trying to overthrow governments in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: A 19-year-old man from the Chicago suburbs has been indicted by a federal grand jury on charges that he tried to provide support to a terrorist group in his effort to travel to Syria with his younger sister and brother.

headline: At Ramen Shops in Westchester, Broth and Noodles Harmonize
abstract: Roc-N-Ramen, in New Rochelle; Ramenesque, in Peekskill; Dumpling+Noodle, in Bronxville; Fujinoya, in Hartsdale; and Ichiro and Noodle Plus, both in White Plains, serve ramen dishes.
lead_paragraph: So many places to eat ramen, so little time. Ramen seems to be the food of the moment. And why not? These noodle soups are clean, hearty, filling and cheap, just the bracing, nourishing meal needed to get on with your day.

headline: Easing the Rules on Home Schooling
abstract: Two educators and two parents whose children are home-schooled discuss whether some children can learn better outside traditional classrooms.

headline: Turkey: Leftists Retract Their Claim About an Attack
abstract: A Marxist extremist group that took responsibility for a suicide bombing in Istanbul this week retracted its claim on Friday, saying that it had made a mistake.
lead_paragraph: A Marxist extremist group that took responsibility for a suicide bombing in Istanbul this week retracted its claim on Friday, saying that it had made a mistake. On Tuesday, a woman detonated explosives in a police station in Istanbul’s tourist district, Sultanahmet, and blew herself up. One police officer died in the attack and another was wounded. The outlawed Revolutionary People’s Liberation Party claimed responsibility and identified the suicide bomber as Elif Sultan Kalsen. But Ms. Kalsen’s family said that the body that was shown to them was not their daughter. On Friday, the group retracted its claim that it carried out the bombing. It said it had made a mistake because the bombing corresponded with an attack it had planned in the same area. It did not offer details about its planned attack. The Turkish news media has reported that the bomber was a Russian citizen of Chechen descent. An investigation is underway, the Interior Ministry said.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After years of finding the dark lining in every silver economic cloud, Republicans are facing a political quandary that is dividing their leadership even as it buoys the nation: The economy appears to be achieving liftoff.

headline: Reaching Outside C.I.A., Obama Picks Treasury Official to Become Agency’s No. 2
abstract: President Obama has chosen David S. Cohen, who has directed the effort to cut off funding of the Islamic State and impose economic sanctions on Syria, Russia and Iran, to become the C.I.A.’s deputy director.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has chosen the Treasury Department official who has directed the effort to cut off funding of the Islamic State and impose economic sanctions on Syria, Russia and Iran to become the C.I.A.’s deputy director, the agency announced on Friday.

headline: Four Oklahoma Inmates Seek Delay in Executions
abstract: Lawyers for prisoners who are scheduled for lethal injections this winter filed an emergency appeal with a federal circuit court, claiming that a sedative the state plans to use is unpredictable.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for four Oklahoma inmates who are scheduled for lethal injection this winter filed an emergency request for a delay with a federal appeals court on Friday, claiming that a sedative the state plans to use cannot reliably induce the deep coma needed for a humane execution and that its use “constitutes human experimentation.”

headline: Court Could Move Quickly on Israeli-Palestinian Case

abstract: The International Criminal Court’s chief prosecutor can immediately start a preliminary examination of war crimes allegations stemming from the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court could start looking into allegations of war crimes and crimes against humanity on Palestinian lands even before Israelis go to the polls in March, according to the court.
