headline: How to Stop Currency Manipulation
keywords: ['Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'Currency', 'United States Economy', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Protectionism (Trade)']
abstract: Restrict it through the Trans-Pacific Partnership.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — IF the new Congress can agree on anything this year, it may well be the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a trade deal between the United States and 11 other countries throughout the Asia-Pacific region. Passions run high when it comes to trade deals these days, and the Obama administration is working hard to sell it to labor unions, which roundly oppose it.

headline: Students in Maryland Test Civic Participation and Win Right to Vote
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'City Councils', 'Local Government']
abstract: The City Council in Hyattsville, Md., approved giving 16- and 17-year-olds a voice in local government.
lead_paragraph: HYATTSVILLE, Md. — Sarah Leonard, 15, joined a group of local teenagers here recently as they lobbied the City Council to grant them more power. Wearing a black “I am Hyattsville” T-shirt, she stood in front of a standing-room-only crowd, sounding confident as she addressed the lawmakers.

headline: To Keep Rams in St. Louis, City Unveils Stadium Plan
abstract: The Rams’ owner, Stan Kroenke, has announced plans to build an 80,000-seat football stadium in California, but St. Louis responded on Friday with a plan for an outdoor stadium along the Mississippi River.
lead_paragraph: In a bid to keep the Rams from moving to Southern California, civic leaders in St. Louis on Friday unveiled plans to build a 64,000-seat outdoor stadium along the Mississippi River.

headline: Growing Up on Easy Street Has Its Own Dangers
keywords: ['High Net Worth Individuals', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Alcohol Abuse']
abstract: An emerging body of research suggests that adolescents in wealthy families are more likely to suffer from depression, anxiety, substance abuse problems and other ailments than their less-well-off peers.
lead_paragraph: When Thomas Gilbert Jr. was arrested on Monday and charged with killing his wealthy father with a gunshot to the head, the rubbernecking and tut-tutting began almost immediately.

headline: An Attitude Forecast: Bitter and Nasty
abstract: The Patriots-Ravens divisional matchup on Saturday should be a bit of a throwback to an era when the playoffs involved more snarling.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Thirty years ago, when restricted free agency kept N.F.L. rosters unchanged and parity was not the goal of the game schedule, it was customary for powerhouse teams to meet in the postseason year after year.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Fashion’s Deep Freeze
abstract: While no one was turning blue from the cold, several fashionable women wore blue coats, and one young man appeared in a silk, quilted coat.
lead_paragraph: While no one was turning blue from the cold, several fashionable women wore blue coats, and one young man appeared in a silk, quilted coat.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Fashion’s Deep Freeze
abstract: A surprise was the sight of many capes and ponchos, which are not very practical in the cold.
lead_paragraph: All the drama of winter cold arrived just as the last holiday tourist throngs left the city on Monday. In Bryant Park, on the Sixth Avenue side, the fountain was covered in icicles. By Friday, the fountain was no longer visible. Members of the usually politically correct fashion crowd pulled out their fur coats. Cellphones disappeared, and hands clutched hot cups of coffee instead. The few visitors to the city who were left after the cold set in still had breakfast at Tiffany & Co., even as their teeth chattered. A surprise was the sight of many capes and ponchos, which are not very practical in the cold. More practical were the belted coats. And while no one was turning blue from the cold, several fashionable women wore blue coats, and one young man appeared in a silk, quilted coat.

headline: Extremists Harming Islam, Leader of Hezbollah Says
abstract: Hassan Nasrallah said in a televised address that extremists’ beheadings and massacres hurt the Prophet Muhammad more than mocking him in books, films or drawings.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The leader of Hezbollah declared on Friday that extremists claiming to act in the name of Islam did more harm to the religion than any cartoon.

headline: Bratton Tells New York Police Officers It’s Time to Get Back to Work
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Traffic and Parking Violations', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton ordered the department’s top commanders to do what they could to end the slowdown.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to end more than two weeks of a precipitous drop in police activity, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton said on Friday that he had instructed top commanders to do what they could to reverse the trend.

headline: Boston, in Old College Try, Uses Campuses in 2024 Olympic Bid
abstract: Boston, which was chosen Thursday as the American bid city for the 2024 Olympics, is relying heavily on using the existing facilities at many of the region’s dozens of colleges and universities.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The odds were against James B. Connolly. He was born in South Boston in 1868, one of 12 children of poor Irish immigrants. But he schooled himself and managed to get into Harvard.

headline: The Labor Picture in December
abstract: Employers added 252,000 jobs in December as the labor market closed out a breakout year on a strong note, the Labor Department said Friday. The unemployment rate fell from 5.8% to 5.6%, lowest since June 2008. The rate plunged just over a full percentage point between 2013 and 2014, the largest decline since 1984.
lead_paragraph: Employers added 252,000 jobs in December as the labor market closed out a breakout year on a strong note, the Labor Department said Friday. The unemployment rate fell from 5.8% to 5.6%, lowest since June 2008. The rate plunged just over a full percentage point between 2013 and 2014, the largest decline since 1984.

headline: Days of Sirens, Fear and Blood: ‘France Is Turned Upside Down’
abstract: Friday was a day, like the previous two, of violence in and around Paris, one that ended with France unsure whether this drama is now truly over or a predictor of more cultural, religious and political violence to come.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It was a day of sirens, helicopters in the air, frantic news bulletins; of police cordons and anxious crowds; of young children led away from schools to safety. It was a day, like the previous two, of blood and horror in and around Paris, one that ended with France unsure whether this drama is now truly over or a predictor of more cultural, religious and political violence to come.

headline: Connecticut Teenager With Cancer Loses Court Fight to Refuse Chemotherapy
abstract: The state Supreme Court ruled that the girl, who is 17, was not competent to make her own medical decisions and could not choose to forgo the treatment for Hodgkin’s lymphoma.
lead_paragraph: The police were banging on the doors and the windows of her home while she cowered in the closet, a 17-year-old girl recounted. She remembered clutching her phone, crying, calling her mother.

headline: They Don’t Rebuild. They Replace.
abstract: The Emporia State Lady Hornets, a perennial power from Emporia, Kan., are ranked No. 1 in Division II this season despite having seven new players.
lead_paragraph: ST. JOSEPH, Mo. — The Lady Hornets of Emporia State, 130 miles from home, had gone scoreless in their first two possessions against Missouri Western on Thursday night when the freshman point guard Addie Lackey cradled the basketball near midcourt and turned to her coach, Jory Collins, for instruction.

headline: New President in Sri Lanka Puts China’s Plans in Check
abstract: President Mahinda Rajapaksa was voted out of office in a startling upset, throwing Sri Lanka’s growing alliance with China into question.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — On a Sunday four months ago, a vessel pulled unannounced into Sri Lanka’s Colombo harbor: the Chinese Navy submarine Great Wall No. 329, which is designed to carry torpedoes, a cruise missile and a 360-pound warhead.

headline: Gov. Christie’s Cowboy Connection
abstract: The governor may have followed the letter of the law, but he took thousands of dollars’ worth of hospitality from a powerful magnate.
lead_paragraph: The video of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey clumsily trying to high-five Dallas Cowboys executives went viral days ago. But apart from causing a good deal of merriment, the awkward embrace between Mr. Christie and the Cowboys’ owner, Jerry Jones, after the team’s comeback win Sunday over the Detroit Lions, has drawn attention to a potentially more troubling connection between two powerful friends.

headline: On Duty for the Chris Christie Hug Watch
abstract: What will Chris Christie do if the Dallas Cowboys win the big game this weekend?
lead_paragraph: As we move into a big football weekend, one exciting question uniting fans and nonfans alike is: What will Chris Christie do if Dallas wins?

headline: Measuring Football Fans’ Seismic Effects
abstract: Scientists from the Pacific Northwest Seismic Network set up earthquake trackers ahead of a playoff game in Seattle on Saturday to capture the ground-shaking effects of about 67,000 people.
lead_paragraph: Scientists from the Pacific Northwest Seismic Network set up earthquake trackers ahead of a playoff game in Seattle on Saturday to capture the ground-shaking effects of about 67,000 people.

headline: A Groundbreaking Game Remembered
abstract: Fifty years ago, Father Ryan High’s integrated basketball team played Pearl High’s team, which because of segregation was entirely black, in Nashville.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago, Father Ryan High’s integrated basketball team played Pearl High’s team, which because of segregation was entirely black, in Nashville.

headline: Tense Scene on Basketball Court 50 Years Ago Recalls Catholic Role in Civil Rights
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Basketball', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Interscholastic Athletics', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: A contest that broke a sports color line in Nashville in 1965 was played without violence breaking out, and is now a landmark in local history.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — In the locker room beneath the packed bleachers of the Municipal Auditorium here, Bill Derrick gathered the basketball players he coached at Father Ryan High School. They recited “The Lord’s Prayer” and said a “Hail Mary,” as they always did before tipoff. Then, with unusual emphasis, Mr. Derrick intoned two or three times, “Lady of victory, pray for us.”

headline: After Brutal Traverse, Climber Looks Upward
abstract: The climber Kevin Jorgeson made it across a brutally difficult pitch that had stymied his efforts for six days and held up his climbing partner, Tommy Caldwell, in their effort to complete one of the hardest rock climbs in the world.
lead_paragraph: About 200 miles away from Yosemite Valley and El Capitan, Jacqui Becker got a text message and a photo from her boyfriend, the climber Kevin Jorgeson. The photo was of him smiling in front of a wall of granite. The text announced that he was not stopping now.

headline: Is Pakistan Worth America’s Investment?
keywords: ['Foreign Aid', 'Editorials', 'Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Cutting aid precipitously would be unwise, but a managed decrease is in order.
lead_paragraph: It doesn’t take much to stir controversy over America’s relationship with Pakistan. The latest dust-up involves $532 million in economic assistance that the United States expects to provide later this year. Last week, Pakistani officials jumped the gun by suggesting the money is closer to being disbursed than it is; the news annoyed India, which doesn’t think the aid is merited.

headline: For Author of ‘Younger’ Novel, It’s Showtime
abstract: As Pamela Redmond Satran’s “Younger” novel becomes a comedy series on TV Land, she’s considering her options.
lead_paragraph: The author Pamela Redmond Satran recently read the comedian Amy Poehler’s memoir, “Yes, Please,” and found a few things within that resonated.

headline: Racial Isolation in Public Schools
abstract: The problem is especially urgent in Buffalo, where federal officials are promoting minority access to the better parts of a dysfunctional system.
lead_paragraph: New York’s schools are the most segregated in the nation, and the state needs remedies right away. That was the message delivered to the governor and the Legislature last week by the chancellor of the State Board of Regents. Minority children are disproportionately trapped in schools that lack the teaching talent, course offerings and resources needed to prepare them for college and success in the new economy.

headline: Riddle of the Pyramids: What Is Herbalife?
abstract: Is Herbalife a successful marketer of protein shakes or something more terrible than a Ponzi scheme?
lead_paragraph: “We’re doing God’s work,” said William Ackman, the hedge fund manager, on CNBC this week. He was referring to his $1 billion bet against Herbalife, the company that he accuses of being an illegal pyramid scheme.

headline: M.T.A. Officers Bid Farewell to Comrade Who Was Struck on the Verrazano in 2013
abstract: Officers for the Bridges and Tunnels agency of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority gathered to remember one of their own: Officer Thomas Choi, 62, who died from his injuries on Dec. 29.
lead_paragraph: The mayor and the governor did not attend. The sea of pressed blue shirts often seen outside police funerals appeared more like a stream. The buzz of uniformed officers’ radios told not of crime and distress but of eastbound traffic on the lower level of a bridge.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 9, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Four at the Fore
abstract: Saturday in the grid with Joe Krozel.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Well, I’ve gotta tell you, it’s been a heck of a week for New York Times crossword puzzles. There was a strong reaction to the puzzles over the past few days (Patrick Berry’s puzzle may be the exception), and rightfully so. The consensus, both here and on social media, is that the level of arcane knowledge needed to solve some of the puzzles, especially Wednesday’s, was excessive.

headline: For the College Playoff, Super-Size Ads
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Television', 'Super Bowl', 'Bowl Games', 'College Football Playoff National Championship']
abstract: While it isn’t quite the Super Bowl, Monday’s College Football Playoff championship is expected to attract a massive audience, giving advertisers a fresh opportunity.
lead_paragraph: When commercials for advertisers such as Allstate and AT&T made their debuts during the Rose and Sugar Bowls on New Year’s Day, it was reasonable to assume that some marketers saw the College Football Playoff as an event with Super Bowl-like power to reach a massive audience.

headline: A Statue of Muhammad on a New York Courthouse, Taken Down Years Ago
abstract: It seems unlikely that the designers of the courthouse that included statues of historical lawgivers intended offense to anyone. The intent was to instruct and inspire viewers.
lead_paragraph: It would have given great offense, had anyone known it was there.

headline: Down an Unlikely Path, a Culinary Hideaway
abstract: To get to Farm Country Kitchen in Riverhead, you drive down an industrial road. The restaurant is marked only by a chalkboard easel and has a B.Y.O.B. policy, but it’s worth it.
lead_paragraph: The first impressions of Farm Country Kitchen in Riverhead are not promising. To get there, you drive down an industrial road full of car dealerships and auto body shops. Then you will invariably drive past the place, since there is no sign except for a chalkboard easel sitting inconspicuously outside, the restaurant itself hidden behind a tall line of bushes.

headline: Conquering Her Fears While Learning Job Skills and Moving Toward Independence
abstract: After being bullied, having depression and worrying about being alone, Alba Ramos is realizing that she can learn the skills she needs to find a job.
lead_paragraph: All her life, Alba Ramos has been haunted by a single question, one she posed to Ydalia Gomez constantly.

headline: 11 Are Injured, Two Critically, in Bronx Fire
abstract: The fire broke out just before 5 p.m. on the third floor of a six-story building near the south side of Van Cortlandt Park, according to the Fire Department.
lead_paragraph: A two-alarm fire in a Bronx apartment building on Friday injured 11 people, two of them critically, and left dozens of families seeking shelter, the authorities said.

headline: Samuel Goldwyn Jr., 88, Dies; Hollywood Scion and Film Influence
abstract: Mr. Goldwyn was an early champion of stylized independent films that most major studios thought would never sell a ticket.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Samuel Goldwyn Jr., an urbane, soft-spoken scion of a Hollywood dynasty who became an influential movie executive in his own right, supporting promising young directors and advancing the independent film movement, died here on Friday. He was 88.

headline: Staying Close to Home
abstract: Harvest, in Greenwich, one of five restaurants owned by a three-sibling team, has a highly creative menu.
lead_paragraph: Greenwich Avenue, the long, long main shopping street in affluent Greenwich, is not the sort of area where you can expect to dine on the cheap. That’s why finding the two-year-old Harvest was such a pleasant surprise.

headline: He Zhenliang Dies at 85; China’s Olympic Crusader
abstract: The sports executive was credited with making the communist nation more accessible to the world after politics interrupted its participation in the Games for nearly 30 years.
lead_paragraph: He Zhenliang, a key figure in returning China to the Olympics in the 1980s after an absence of almost three decades and in securing the 2008 Summer Games for Beijing, died on Jan. 4 in Beijing. He was 85.

headline: David H. Marlowe Dies at 83; Helped Army Nurture Bands of Brothers
abstract: His studies among soldiers drove home the importance of group cohesion in combat and led to changes in how the military disciplines, organizes and cares for its troops.
lead_paragraph: David H. Marlowe, an anthropologist whose immersive studies among soldiers drove home the importance of group cohesion in combat and helped prompt enduring changes in how the military disciplines, organizes and cares for its troops, died on Dec. 27 at a retirement community in Silver Spring, Md. He was 83.

headline: A Resurgent Harvard Will Confront Yale at the Garden
abstract: Harvard, which is enjoying a turnaround season, leads the overall series against Yale, but has not beaten the Bulldogs since 2012.
lead_paragraph: For the past two seasons, the Harvard men’s hockey team had to look up at its archrival Yale.

headline: The Links Among the Paris Terror Suspects and Their Connections to Jihad
abstract: Where their lives intersected and what may have influenced them.
lead_paragraph: Where their lives intersected and what may have influenced them.

headline: Andraé Crouch, 72, Who Infused Gospel With Soul, Dies
abstract: Mr. Crouch won seven Grammys for his mix of faith and pop genres, and was nominated for an Oscar for his work on “The Color Purple” score.
lead_paragraph: Andraé Crouch, a singer and songwriter whose plaintive, passionate gospel songs knitted religious music to rhythm and blues, soul and contemporary balladeering and found their way into mainstream pop music, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 72.

headline: Faces of a Small Southern Town: ‘Becoming Disfarmer,’ at the Neuberger Museum of Art
abstract: An exhibition in Purchase, N.Y. features the work of the commercial photographer who was born Mike Meyer, changed his name to Mike Disfarmer and shot postcard-size portraits in Heber Springs, Ark.
lead_paragraph: A visitor could spend hours studying the faces on display in “Becoming Disfarmer,” an exhibition of photographic portraits at the Neuberger Museum of Art. Couples, families, men dressed in military uniforms, pretty young women in lipstick and barrettes: They peer out from the walls and up from the glass cases. Some of the faces are freckled, others weathered and lined. A few smile, but most are grave. All stare intently into the camera’s lens.

headline: Baltimore Ravens at New England Patriots: Saturday’s A.F.C. Divisional-Round Matchup
abstract: Joe Flacco, who has won a record seven postseason games on the road, leads the Ravens to Gillette Stadium to face the Patriots.
lead_paragraph: Ravens at Patriots

abstract: The Seahawks, who have won six consecutive games, host the Panthers, the N.F.L.’s second sub-.500 division winner.

headline: Old Belts and Fishing Tackle Transformed
abstract: Two exhibitions in Water Mill feature Midwestern artists who have morphed ordinary objects into high art.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes wildly different exhibitions connect through kindred approaches to the artistic process. That synergy has “Alan Shields: In Motion” conversing with “Steven and William Ladd: Mary Queen of the Universe” at the Parrish Art Museum. Visit, and you will see two generations of artists born in the Midwest who have transformed ordinary stuff — from fishing tackle to Miss Piggy sheets — into high art. A meandering line through Kansas, Missouri and New York reveals a moral compass pointing to a shared American heartland ethic: Waste not. Improvise. Do what you love.

headline: The Dawn Wall: El Capitan’s Most Unwelcoming Route
abstract: A graphic tracks an attempt by Tommy Caldwell and Kevin Jorgeson to free-climb the 3,000-foot Dawn Wall, a vertical sheet of mostly smooth granite that many believe is the hardest climb in the world.
lead_paragraph: A graphic tracks an attempt by Tommy Caldwell and Kevin Jorgeson to free-climb the 3,000-foot Dawn Wall, a vertical sheet of mostly smooth granite that many believe is the hardest climb in the world.

headline: Big City Book Club
abstract: The Big City Book Club returns for 2015, and we’re getting things rolling with Bernard Malamud’s classic New York novel “The Assistant.” Join us for the online discussion of the novel on Thursday, Feb. 12, at 6:30 p.m.
lead_paragraph: The Big City Book Club returns for 2015, and we’re getting things rolling with Bernard Malamud’s classic New York novel “The Assistant.” Set in Brooklyn in the 1950s, the novel has it all: the clash of immigrant cultures, the threats of modernization to old shopkeeping ways, crime and illicit love. Join us for the online discussion of the novel on Thursday, Feb. 12, at 6:30 p.m. on The New York Times’s City Room blog.

headline: Maher Hathout, a Powerful Voice for American Muslims, Dies at 79
abstract: Dr. Hathout, who helped found the Islamic Center of Southern California, called on American Muslims to embrace their dual identity, and preached interfaith comity and understanding in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Maher Hathout, an Egyptian-born cardiologist who became an influential American Muslim leader, preaching interfaith comity and helping to sustain the Muslim faithful in the United States against the backlash after the Sept. 11 attacks, died on Jan. 3 in Duarte, Calif. He was 79.

headline: With Fans in Tow, Islanders Edge Devils to Land in First
abstract: With a highly anticipated game against the Rangers looming, the Islanders defeated the Devils in overtime to move into first place in the Metropolitan Division.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — At the midway point of their farewell season at Nassau Coliseum, the Islanders have surprisingly entrenched themselves as a contender for the Metropolitan Division title.

abstract: With Aaron Rodgers perhaps not playing at 100 percent because of a left calf injury, the Packers will host the Cowboys in a rematch of the so-called Ice Bowl.

abstract: Indianapolis and Andrew Luck take on Denver’s formidable defense, which has one of the most effective pass-rushing combinations with Von Miller and DeMarcus Ware.
lead_paragraph: Colts at Broncos

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (CUNY) ONE DAY YOU’LL UNDERSTAND (2008) As the 1987 trial of the Nazi war criminal Klaus Barbie unfolds on television, a Frenchman, Victor Bastien (Hippolyte Girardot), pores over old family documents and finds an “Aryan declaration” written by his deceased father — a discovery that upends his concept of his history. His mother, Rivka (Jeanne Moreau), a Jewish woman living an elegant life, evades Victor’s questions. “Rivka’s embrace of that life can look like a form of denial, but as Ms. Moreau’s performance unfolds, the character’s courage and resilience emerge more pointedly into view,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this meditation on memory, identity and reconciliation from the Israeli director Amos Gitai based on a book by Jérôme Clément. She “gives a master class in how to be regal without vanity and how to use the hard-won charisma of a movie star to illuminate the dignity of an ordinary person.” The film “contains no great revelations or surprises, but rather is suffused with a quiet glow of sympathy and enlightenment,” he added.

headline: Haiti: Judge Throws Out Cholera Suit Against U.N.
abstract: Victims of Haiti’s cholera epidemic seeking to hold the United Nations responsible were set back on Friday by a federal judge in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan dealt a set back on Friday to victims of Haiti’s cholera epidemic who have been seeking to hold the United Nations responsible. Judge J. Paul Oetken dismissed a class-action lawsuit by Haitians against the United Nations, deeming the organization immune because of treaties. Lawyers for the plaintiffs vowed to appeal. “The court’s decision implies that the U.N. can operate with impunity,” said Beatrice Lindstrom, a lawyer with the Institute for Justice and Democracy in Haiti, which helped file the lawsuit in October 2013. Two other lawsuits filed by Haitian cholera victims are still pending in American courts. The cholera epidemic, which has killed 8,700 people in Haiti since 2010, has been traced to infected United Nations peacekeepers who were then assigned to the country.

headline: French Premier Declares ‘War’ on Radical Islam as Paris Girds for Rally
abstract: Law enforcement officials appealed to the public to help find Hayat Boumeddiene, the girlfriend of Amedy Coulibaly, who took hostages at a kosher supermarket.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Prime Minister Manuel Valls declared Saturday that France was at war with radical Islam after the harrowing sieges that led to the deaths of three gunmen and four hostages the day before. New details emerged about the bloody final confrontations, and security forces remained on high alert.

headline: AirAsia Jet’s Tail Retrieved; Data Recorders Still Missing
abstract: After being thwarted for days by severe currents and low visibility, Indonesian Navy divers were finally able to tie special lifting balloons to the tail.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — An Indonesian search team on Saturday pulled the tail section of the AirAsia plane that crashed last month from the Java Sea, but the aircraft’s data recorders were not inside, officials said.

headline: South Korea Deports American Over Warm Words for Trips to North
abstract: Shin Eun-mi, a South Korean-born American, faced an outcry from conservatives who accused her of sympathizing with the government in Pyongyang.

headline: Deflation As Betrayal
abstract: Changing the rules on the south.
lead_paragraph: Ambrose Evans-Pritchard writes that Europe’s slide toward deflation amounts to a “betrayal” of Southern Europe. This sounds over the top, but it is the simple truth. So let me elaborate with a picture I find illuminating.

lead_paragraph: London

headline: How to Make Yourself Go to the Gym
keywords: ['Exercise', 'Health Clubs', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Motivation and Incentive Programs']
abstract: The principle of pay-now, work-out-later is great for gyms, but less so for their customers. Economists look at other ways to encourage exercise.
lead_paragraph: If you’re like a lot of Americans, one of your New Year’s resolutions is to work out more. If you’re like a lot of Americans, you’ll join a gym this January as part of that plan. And if you’re like a lot of Americans, you won’t go very much.

headline: Marla Malcolm Beck’s Three Keys to Hiring: Skill, Will and Fit
abstract: The chief executive of Bluemercury says she looks for three main qualities in job candidates. “If you’re hungry to get somewhere, that means you want to learn,” she says. “And if you want to learn, you can do any job.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Marla Malcolm Beck, chief executive of Bluemercury, a beauty products and spa services retailer, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: The Depression’s Unheeded Lessons
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Recession and Depression', "Great Depression (1930's)", 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Economic leaders made the 2008 financial crisis worse through a combination of misinterpreted history and missed opportunities, a new book argues.
lead_paragraph: The global economy stood on the precipice, making the possibility of a descent into the horrors of the Great Depression — the despair our grandparents told us about — all too real. Then some brave leaders with a knowledge of history and names like Bernanke, Geithner and Paulson (or if you have an international bent, Trichet, King and Darling) stepped in, applied the lessons of that brutal period and pulled us back from the abyss.

headline: When the Parking Space Becomes a Park
keywords: ['Urban Areas', 'Parking', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Small Business']
abstract: Often commissioned by small businesses hoping to attract customers, “parklets” can brighten streetscapes and create community gathering spaces.
lead_paragraph: The three parking spots on the street directly in front of Tony’s Pizza Napoletana, in the North Beach neighborhood of San Francisco, have been the site of a rap-music video, poetry readings, a fashion photo shoot and jazz mini-concerts.

headline: Watching Their Every Step
abstract: Stacy Steffen, a biomechanist at the Brooks Running Company, studies athletes’ motion and physiology to build a better running shoe.
lead_paragraph: Stacy Steffen, 31, is a biomechanist at the Brooks Running Company in Seattle.

headline: Staying Up to Speed
abstract: From her office window, Michelle Kumbier, a Harley-Davidson executive, can see the seasons change — and watch the company’s motorcycles zooming around the test track.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Kumbier is senior vice president for motorcycle operations at the Harley-Davidson Motor Company, Milwaukee.

headline: Orthodoxy, Heterodoxy, and Ideology
abstract: No, mainstream economics didn’t justify austerity.
lead_paragraph: Many economists responded badly to the economic crisis. And there’s a lot wrong with mainstream economic analysis. But how closely are these two assertions related? Not as much as you might think. So I’m very much in accord with Simon Wren-Lewis on the remarkable unhelpfulness of recent heterodox assaults on the field. Not that there’s anything wrong with being heterodox in general; but a lot of what we’ve been seeing misidentifies the problem, and if anything gives aid and comfort to the wrong people.

headline: Kicking Dodd-Frank in the Teeth
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Private Equity']
abstract: New legislation, promoted as making only technical changes in a financial regulation law, could end up gutting some of its provisions.
lead_paragraph: The 114th Congress has been at work for less than a week, but a goal for many of its members is already evident: a further rollback of regulations put in place to keep markets and Main Street safe from reckless Wall Street practices.

headline: 1890: Canonization of Jeanne d’Arc
abstract: Highlights from The International Herald Tribune archives: A monsignor is called upon to investigate the life of Joan of Arc as cardinals discuss her canonization.
lead_paragraph: The cause for the canonization of Jeanne d’Arc will, as soon as the documents relating to her life are ready, be discussed by the Cardinals belonging to the Sacred Congregation of Rites. Every minute particular relating to her life is being looked into with the greatest care by Mgr. Caprara, a learned advocate, who is employed by the Vatican always in matters concerning beatifications and canonizations.

headline: Dialect Society Names Its Word of the Year: #blacklivesmatter
abstract: Other candidates: bae, columbusing and manspreading.
lead_paragraph: The American Dialect Society has overwhelmingly voted to name #blacklivesmatter its word of the year for 2014, marking the first time that the group has chosen a Twitter hashtag in its annual vote.

headline: Writing Off the Warhol Next Door
keywords: ['Art', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Museums', 'Philanthropy', 'Collectors and Collections']
abstract: Wealthy art collectors are benefiting from tax breaks when they build museums with limited public access, often near their homes.
lead_paragraph: The Brant Foundation Art Study Center — a picturesque gallery space inside a converted 1902 stone barn — is just down the road from the Greenwich, Conn., estate of its creator, Peter M. Brant, the newsprint magnate and avid art collector. There are no identifying signs for the center, whether at the turnoff on North Street, at the security gate or on the building itself, though the location is known to the art-world cognoscenti and celebrities who attend the twice-a-year gala openings, held at the private polo club next door that Mr. Brant also founded. Visits to the center itself are by appointment only.

headline: Agi & Sam: Fall 2015 Menswear
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Dealing With Hyperactive Upstairs Neighbors
abstract: This week, questions about noisy neighbors, co-op fees for name changes and secondhand smoke from outdoors are answered.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Should Schools Teach Personality?
keywords: ['Charter Schools', 'Education', 'Education (K-12)', 'Intelligence and Intelligence Tests (IQ)', 'Research', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: Traits like “grit,” more associated with personality than with intelligence per se, are capturing the attention of educators. But can they really be taught?
lead_paragraph: Self-control, curiosity, “grit” — these qualities may seem more personal than academic, but at some schools, they’re now part of the regular curriculum. Some researchers say personality could be even more important than intelligence when it comes to students’ success in school. But critics worry that the increasing focus on qualities like grit will distract policy makers from problems with schools.

headline: After Terrorist Attacks, Many French Muslims Wonder: What Now?
abstract: France’s Muslim population — the largest in Europe — seems braced for a potential backlash, both political and personal, after the terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Last week’s terrorist attacks without doubt set all of France on edge, but the sense of wariness, even siege, has grown increasingly profound among France’s Muslim population — the largest in Europe — which seems braced for a potential backlash, both political and personal.

headline: When Satire Cuts Both Ways
abstract: Can satirists sometimes be too provocative and outrageous? Should they hold themselves back?

headline: Race, the Police and the Propaganda
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Attacks on Police', 'Racial Profiling']
abstract: Ending the impunity that fuels unequal law enforcement.
lead_paragraph: WELCOME visitors to New York City! This has been the best time ever to urinate on a street, sneak onto the subway or run a red light, for the police force has been on a virtual strike.

headline: Variety: A Childish Acrostic
abstract: A rather childish acrostic, by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY — I need to brush up on my vocabulary. Did this acrostic make you feel that way?

headline: Moshe Safdie
abstract: The modernist architect on the importance of drawing with a pen.
lead_paragraph: Moshe Safdie is an Israeli-born architect and protégé of Louis Kahn’s whose modernist designs emphasize locale, geography and culture.

headline: Your God and My Dignity
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Faith warrants respect, but it shouldn’t earn anyone an exemption from laws or permission to discriminate.
lead_paragraph: I’VE been called many unpleasant things in my life, and I’ve deserved no small number of them. But I chafe at this latest label:

headline: The Backlash Against African Women
keywords: ['Women and Girls', "Women's Rights", 'Sexual Harassment', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: They are powerful in government, but harassed on the street.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — A FEW weeks ago, as I was leaving my office, I stopped at a traffic light and watched a young woman cross the street in front of me. She wore a pair of jean shorts cut fashionably high, and I could see the crease of her left buttock extend each time she took a step. She wouldn’t have been out of place in London or New York or Tokyo. Except that this was Johannesburg, the biggest city in a country known for its high levels of violence against women. As I pulled away, I worried that she might be assaulted.

headline: Obama to Announce Cybersecurity Plans in State of the Union Preview
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'Cyberwarfare', 'Identity Theft', 'Privacy', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Speeches in the coming week will address identity theft, privacy, protections for government and company computers, and high-speed broadband access.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will announce new initiatives next week designed to bolster online security and improve access to cyberspace, White House officials said Saturday.

headline: Is the War Crimes Court Still Relevant?
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations']
abstract: The Palestinian situation is only the latest challenge.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Fatou Bensouda, chief prosecutor for the International Criminal Court, is about to face her toughest trial yet: to demonstrate that the court has enough muscle to tackle the gravest human rights cases, even if it means confronting the world’s most powerful countries.

headline: Old Nazis Never Die
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'International Relations', 'Nineteen Hundred Fifties']
abstract: A lasting influence in the Mideast, in life and in death.
lead_paragraph: AS the decades roll by, there are fewer and fewer Nazi war criminals left alive to track down. Which made the recent reports suggesting that Alois Brunner, the top lieutenant to Adolf Eichmann, may have died as recently as a few years ago in his late 90s all the more surprising.

headline: In New Era of Terrorism, Voice From Yemen Echoes
abstract: Anwar al-Awlaki, an American who joined Al Qaeda but was killed by a C.I.A. drone strike in 2011, has remained a leading influence on jihadists, and there is evidence that Yemen’s Al Qaeda branch, and Mr. Awlaki, had a role in preparations for the deadly assault in Paris.
lead_paragraph: For more than five years now, as Western terrorism investigators have searched for critical influences behind the latest jihadist plot, one name has surfaced again and again.

headline: When Will the North Face Its Racism?
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The protests against police shootings are a referendum on the black condition since the Great Migration.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — THE groundswell of protests over police brutality in the closing days of 2014, when people dropped to the marble floor of Grand Central Terminal and shut down the Brooklyn Bridge, blocked Lake Shore Drive in Chicago and chanted “I Can’t Breathe” from Boston to Oakland, summoned ghosts not only of the marches of the civil rights era but of the larger forces that led to the arrival of so many African-Americans in the big cities of the North and West in the first place.

headline: North Korea Offers U.S. Deal to Halt Nuclear Test
abstract: North Korea said it had told the United States that it would impose a temporary moratorium on nuclear tests if Washington canceled its joint annual military exercises with South Korea.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said Saturday that it had told the United States that it would impose a temporary moratorium on nuclear tests if Washington canceled its joint annual military exercises with South Korea to help promote dialogue on the divided Korean Peninsula.

headline: Getting Grief Right
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Grief (Emotion)', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: Don’t believe what you hear about closure and “stages” of mourning.
lead_paragraph: By the time Mary came to see me, six months after losing her daughter to sudden infant death syndrome, she had hired and fired two other therapists. She was trying to get her grief right.

headline: Saving the Nuclear Deal With Iran
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: An agreement would carry risks, but a bigger risk would be squandering this moment.
lead_paragraph: Twice recently, Iran’s president, Hassan Rouhani, has acted boldly in support of his biggest political gamble, pursuit of a nuclear agreement with the major powers. In a speech last Sunday on Iran’s troubled economy, he argued that Iran will never enjoy sustained growth if it is isolated from the rest of the world. Three weeks earlier, he made clear that he would confront Iran’s hard-liners in his efforts to clinch a deal in which Iran would agree never to produce a nuclear weapon in return for the lifting of crippling international sanctions.

headline: Raise the Gas Tax to Fix America’s Roads
keywords: ['Gasoline Tax (US)', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Editorials', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Sales and Excise Taxes']
abstract: Now that drivers have seen the cost of fuel fall so much and so quickly, a modest increase would hardly be noticeable.
lead_paragraph: Gasoline prices have fallen more than 40 percent since the end of June thanks to the collapse of global oil prices. That makes this the perfect time for Congress to overcome its longstanding terror of offending the nation’s motorists and raise the tax on gasoline and diesel fuel. The results could only be beneficial: for the nation’s roads, bridges and transit systems, which badly need repair; for the budget; and, to the extent that higher taxes encourage greater fuel efficiency, for the climate.

headline: Gun Rights, From Holsters to Bras
abstract: The open-carry debate in Texas is the latest barometer of America’s firearm culture, as it veers somewhere between eerie and lethal.
lead_paragraph: For all the clichés about pistol-packing Texas, the state is one of the few that has not yet succumbed to the gun lobby’s big push to let citizens carry handguns at the hip wherever they go. That may be about to change as the State Legislature convenes next week with open carry a top priority of the Republican majority and with Governor-elect Greg Abbott pledging to sign it into law. The result could produce a far from reassuring civic tableau if even a modest number of the 800,000 Texans who have concealed-carry licenses choose to strap their weapons on in public.

headline: Team Has Golden Moments but Lacks a Halo in Bronze
abstract: Angels have won Most Valuable Player and Cy Young awards, but none have entered the Hall of Fame as members of the franchise.
lead_paragraph: Tim Mead was 12 years old when his family moved from Virginia to California. The family drove, arriving at its new home in Highland ahead of its furniture. Mead, who had brought a transistor radio, sat on the floor of his family’s new kitchen, turned the dial and found an Angels game. He was hooked on a team not much younger than he was.

headline: In Illinois, New Governor’s Campaign Promises Are About to Meet Budget Realities
abstract: Bruce Rauner, a Republican businessman who has never held elective office, has called for tax cuts in a state that received the worst credit rating in the country.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — As Bruce Rauner swept out the Democratic governor of this Democratic-leaning state, he made one absolute pledge: He would shake up Illinois. Mr. Rauner, a multimillionaire who has never held elective office, said the state needed, at long last, to put its finances in order. He has said the state ought to lower income taxes, reduce regulations on businesses and devote more money to education.

headline: The Deano Chronicles, Continued
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: Inside the head of the tanned, rested and ready Speaker Boehner after the tumultuous first week of the 114th Congress.
lead_paragraph: KISSING the sun. Swilling merlot. Plotting revenge.

headline: France, the Crucible of Europe
abstract: It is increasingly clear that the Continent’s future will be determined by the French.
lead_paragraph: THE France that endured a vicious terrorist attack last week is a France that has suffered, for decades and centuries, from anxieties about its own decline. And for good reason: Since the 18th century, when it bestrode Europe and seemed poised to dominate the globe, France has seen its relative power diminish, suffering defeats and humiliations at the hands of rival forces, from Britain’s navies to Germany’s jackboots to the invading might of American popular culture.

headline: In the Era of N.F.L. Blackouts, Giants Nation Put Its Lead Foot Down
abstract: To watch their beloved team, they used to travel to motels and bars located outside the 75-mile exclusion zone.
lead_paragraph: One day in late October 1962, when the Giants were playing the Washington Redskins at Yankee Stadium, 500 fans were watching the game at a motel in Stratford, Conn.

headline: Seizing Assets in Crimea, From Shipyard to Film Studio
abstract: Since Russia annexed the Black Sea peninsula 10 months ago, more than $1 billion in assets and real estate have been stripped from their owners and claimed by the Crimean government.
lead_paragraph: YALTA, Crimea — In the scramble for Crimea’s spoils, armed forces have raided myriad enterprises across the peninsula, expelling the owners and claiming the property for the Crimean government.

headline: College Football Is Powerful: The Proof Is in the Alcohol
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'College Athletics', 'College Football Playoff National Championship']
abstract: By allowing alcohol sales at Monday’s title game and approving travel reimbursements for players’ families, college football is once again showing its dominance.
lead_paragraph: Spectators at the men’s basketball Final Four last April at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Tex., could buy burgers, sodas and even Texas-shaped waffles. But they could not buy alcohol. The N.C.A.A. does not permit alcohol sales — or even its advertising — at the 89 championships it administers.

headline: This Time, Forecast in Green Bay Is a Balmy 20 Degrees
abstract: Sunday’s playoff game between the Packers and Cowboys has been called Ice Bowl II, a reference to the last time these teams met at Lambeau Field in the postseason in 1967.
lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY, Wis. — The N.F.L. loves to trumpet that its players can overcome anything, including subzero temperatures and howling winds. So it is no surprise that the divisional playoff game between the Packers and Cowboys here has been called Ice Bowl II, a reference to the last time these teams met at Lambeau Field in the postseason in 1967.

headline: An Uneasy Mix of News and Opinion
abstract: The Times needs to do a better job of helping readers tell news articles from opinion pieces.
lead_paragraph: RACHEL SWARNS feels free to use the word “I” in her weekly column, “The Working Life.” But as a longtime news reporter, who made the transition to columnist about a year ago, she prefers to tell other people’s stories, not her own.

headline: Hearing Is Believing
keywords: ['Audiobooks', 'Books and Literature', 'Podcasts', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'E-Books and Readers']
abstract: The newest old art form: Riveting tales, told aloud, as audiobooks.
lead_paragraph: THE thriller writer Jeffery Deaver has released an original work called “The Starling Project” as an audiobook — only it’s not what we think of as an audiobook: a printed book read aloud that you can listen to on your laptop or phone. Featuring 29 actors in more than 80 speaking roles combined with “state-of-the-art sound and music design,” Mr. Deaver’s “book” was conceived as an audio drama for Audible. There are no plans to turn it into a traditional text-based book, either on paper or digitally.

headline: America, Falling Short
keywords: ['Minimum Wage', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Income Inequality', 'Family Leaves']
abstract: Readers discuss whether America should adopt European-style policies for caring for the populace.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss whether America should adopt European-style policies for caring for the populace.

headline: In Nigeria, New Boko Haram Suicide Bomber Tactic: ‘It’s a Little Girl’
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Women and Girls', 'Children and Childhood', 'Terrorism', 'Child Soldiers']
abstract: Witnesses said a bomb carried by a girl who appeared no older than 10 had killed at least 20 people in a northern Nigeria market.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — A girl perhaps no more than 10 years old detonated powerful explosives concealed under her veil at a crowded northern Nigeria market on Saturday, killing as many as 20 people and wounding many more.

headline: Health-Law Suit Hints at G.O.P. Divide
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Relatively few Republican state officials are signing on to briefs in a case challenging subsidies, which may reflect a more pragmatic view of the law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After President Obama’s Affordable Care Act was enacted in 2010, Republicans at both the state and federal levels seemed to speak with one voice in flatly rejecting it.

headline: For Jeb Bush, Evolving Views Over 2 Decades
abstract: Allies say the former governor of Florida, a possible Republican contender for the presidency in 2016, has tried to present himself as less harsh than in the past.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush once called for building prisons and emphasizing “punishment over therapy” for juvenile offenders. Today, he supports reforming the criminal justice system, arguing that incarceration can harden low-level lawbreakers into career criminals.

lead_paragraph: London

headline: What We’re Watching: Sunday Shows
abstract: The terrorist attacks in France this week will dominate conversation on the Sunday shows.
lead_paragraph: Terror gripped France after gunmen attacked a satirical newspaper office and held hostages at a kosher supermarket, leaving at least 20 dead, including the three terrorists.

headline: Where Are The Friedmans Of Yesteryear?
abstract: Try looking at the demand side.
lead_paragraph: I never got around to commenting on the infamous Economist list of influential economists; they’ve been given plenty of deserved grief, to which I needn’t add. But I think I might have something useful to say about a fact that is really unmistakable when you look at a list corrected by removing central bankers, or make a more subjective judgment: these days, the economist as public intellectual is overwhelmingly likely to be a liberal.

headline: In Baltimore, Fighting an Incinerator
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Air Pollution']
abstract: Students from Benjamin Franklin high school in Baltimore, Md., are fighting the construction of a proposed waste-to-energy incinerator plant in their already highly toxic neighborhood, Curtis Bay.
lead_paragraph: Students from Benjamin Franklin high school in Baltimore, Md., are fighting the construction of a proposed waste-to-energy incinerator plant in their already highly toxic neighborhood, Curtis Bay.

headline: George Zimmerman Is Charged With Assault in Florida
abstract: Mr. Zimmerman, who was acquitted in the Trayvon Martin killing two years ago, was charged with throwing a wine bottle at a woman at his home this week, according to the police in Lake Mary, Fla.
lead_paragraph: George Zimmerman, who was acquitted less than two years ago in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager, was arrested in Florida on Friday night and charged with aggravated assault, officials said.

headline: Gophers Lose a Leader but Find a New Resolve
abstract: When Rachel Banham tore her A.C.L. on Dec. 10, Minnesota could have folded. Instead, it reeled off five straight wins and is now tied for the Big Ten lead.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The Minnesota players watched Rachel Banham, their leader, collapse in pain during a Dec. 10 game at North Dakota. But Coach Marlene Stollings missed it. Stollings had turned to say something to one of her reserves while Banham, a senior guard and the preseason pick as Big Ten player of the year, drove to the basket.

headline: Garbage Incinerators Make Comeback, Kindling Both Garbage and Debate
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Air Pollution', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Environment']
abstract: With the country’s record-setting trash output unyielding, new waste-to-energy plants are being considered, raising concerns about emissions.
lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — Rising from a denuded landscape not far from this area’s famed beaches, the nation’s first new commercial garbage incinerator in 20 years is about to be fired up, ready to blast up to 3,000 tons of trash a day into electricity for thousands of houses.

headline: Ohio State Receiver Capitalizes on Skills Transferable Across Two Sports
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Track and Field', 'College Football Playoff National Championship']
abstract: Ohio State wide receiver Devin Smith, who is expected to lead the Buckeyes’ receiving corps in the national championship game, is also a track and field standout.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — On a Sunday night in late November, Ohio State wide receiver Devin Smith, like millions of other Americans, was watching “Sunday Night Football” when the Giants’ Odell Beckham Jr. made a leaping, one-handed catch for a touchdown against the Dallas Cowboys.

headline: New Courts Offer Pakistan’s Generals the Power They Used to Seize
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The government of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif is hanging on, extending a nearly seven-year stretch of nominal civilian rule, but otherwise, the military is back in the driver’s seat.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After Taliban gunmen massacred dozens of schoolchildren in Peshawar last month, Pakistan’s two most powerful men convened an emergency meeting at army headquarters. Their body language, captured in a government-released photo, was revealing: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif looked glum and ill at ease, while the man beside him, Gen. Raheel Sharif, the army chief, lectured confidently.

headline: Sibling: Fall 2015 Menswear
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: When Art Is Dangerous (or Not)
keywords: ['Art', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Terrorism', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Censorship']
abstract: Could a cartoon really alarm anyone in the United States?
lead_paragraph: THE only time art ever seems to make news here in the West anymore is when a Pollock or Warhol sells for a sum commensurate with the budget of a “Transformers” film. It seems bizarre, then, to find ourselves grappling with international crises in which art is the issue: the imbroglio involving the Sony movie “The Interview,” the massacre at Charlie Hebdo in Paris. The incomprehension, whether bemused or horrified, that we feel toward people who take up arms against the creators of cartoons or comedies is a chastening reminder that there are still cultures in which art is not a harmless diversion or commodity, but something real and volatile, a potential threat to be violently suppressed. These attacks are, in a way, a savage, atavistic show of respect.

headline: Phil Jackson Takes Blame Before Yet Another Knicks Loss
abstract: Phil Jackson took responsibility for the Knicks’ terrible season before the team went on to lose its 15th game in a row, a team record.
lead_paragraph: This is a mea culpa, Phil Jackson said, his tall frame leaning slightly against a lectern Saturday. In 30 minutes, his hapless Knicks were due to tip off against the Charlotte Hornets. Jackson had lost sleep, he said, and it was evident. He wore a black suit and a black-and-gray tie, but none of the 13 N.B.A. championship rings he had won over the years.

headline: Buckeyes Are Beloved in Oregon (Not That One)
abstract: The mayor of Oregon, Ohio, was surprised by the amount of email and social media chatter clamoring for his city to temporarily change its name.
lead_paragraph: Michael J. Seferian is the mayor of Oregon, Ohio.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest Sports headlines.
lead_paragraph: Tough Climb Has Its Comforts

headline: Broncos Have a Void That’s Difficult to Fill
abstract: Pat Bowlen has owned the Broncos since 1984, but his familiar presence has been missed this season as he battles Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: ENGLEWOOD, Colo. — The Denver Broncos are like the perky family whose holiday card is the picture of beatitude. Outwardly, it looks as if all is well. What others fail to see, but what is glaring to the Broncos, is the shadow darkening this season’s group portrait.

headline: Jeff Golub, a Guitarist at Home in Several Genres, Dies at 59
abstract: Mr. Golub worked with Rod Stewart and Billy Squier and had a genre-crossing solo career as well.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Golub, a guitarist who worked with rock stars like Rod Stewart and Billy Squier and for the last two decades had a successful genre-crossing solo career, died on Jan. 1 at his home in Manhattan. He was 59.

headline: Two Ducks Are Out After Positive Drug Tests
abstract: Oregon will have to face Ohio State in Monday’s title game without wide receiver Darren Carrington and running back Ayele Forde.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Oregon Coach Mark Helfrich said Saturday that wide receiver Darren Carrington and running back Ayele Forde would not play in Monday night’s College Football Playoff championship game against Ohio State after positive drug tests, a violation of N.C.A.A. rules.

headline: Carl N. Degler, Scholarly Champion of the Oppressed in America, Dies at 93
abstract: Professor Degler, a Stanford historian, was a Pulitzer Prize-winning author who illuminated the role of women, the poor and minorities in the nation’s evolution.
lead_paragraph: For four decades, as a Stanford University scholar, a Pulitzer Prize-winning author and a commentator who envisioned a future that did not repeat the mistakes of the past, Carl N. Degler endeavored to remedy American myopia.

headline: Cleveland Reaches for the Unteachable
abstract: The Cavaliers paid a steep price in trading for Timofey Mozgov because seven-footers with respectable statistics are a relative rarity in the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: Red Auerbach won nine N.B.A. titles as coach of the Boston Celtics and seven more as an executive. He was known for, among other things, lighting victory cigars and having an aversion to cheerleaders. One of his most enduring quotations referred to virtually any player who stands 7 feet or taller: “You can’t teach height.”

headline: Personal Statements
abstract: A personal statement from Peter A. Collins.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — You might have noticed that there is a style rule here at The New York Times that says that even a name that ends with the letter S must have an apostrophe-S if it is possessive, as opposed to just the apostrophe. It’s not something I did naturally when I was hired but, like most things in life, I adjusted and now I apostrophe-S my S-ending names like a boss. That will come in handy with today’s puzzle by Peter A. Collins.

headline: Elevating the Humble Bird
abstract: Le Bon Choix, in downtown Ridgewood, specializes in flavorful and affordable rotisserie chicken.
lead_paragraph: Rotisserie chicken has become something of a food-world darling over the last few years, with renowned chefs like Marcus Samuelsson taking an interest in the once-humble weeknight dinner staple. Some trendy restaurants are even stuffing their birds with foie gras.

headline: Triangle Offense Baffles a Second Group of Lowly and Anemic Knicks
abstract: The offense of the Westchester Knicks of the N.B.A. Development League has also struggled as the team learns Phil Jackson’s system.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — Although the Knicks trailed by 18 late in the second quarter, with nine turnovers by the time they hit their first nine field goals, nobody at Westchester County Center on Friday seemed ready to boo, or storm out, or don a paper bag mask in mock protest, a common gesture these days at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Muslim Employee of Kosher Market in Paris Praised for Hiding Customers From Gunman
abstract: A Muslim employee, credited with saving the lives of customers at a kosher market in Paris on Friday, was praised online for his efforts.
lead_paragraph: As the authorities in France worked on Saturday to piece together the sequence of events at a kosher supermarket in Paris where a gunman and four hostages were killed on Friday, there was an outpouring of praise online for a young employee credited with saving the lives of some customers by hiding them in a cold-storage room.

headline: In Jerry Jones, Dallas Cowboys Have a Lightning Rod Made of Mettle
abstract: Jerry Jones, the N.F.L.’s most irrepressible salesman, dreamer and entrepreneur, has worked to turn Dallas into the center of the sports world and AT&T Stadium into a magnet for what he calls “iconic events.”
lead_paragraph: IRVING, Tex. — It was 72 hours after the Dallas Cowboys had won a thrilling playoff game against the Detroit Lions, and Jerry Jones, the team’s owner, president, general manager and chief cheerleader, was beaming. Tired, but beaming.

headline: No Moon Suits, Just Trunks and the Healing Surf
abstract: As Ebola gnaws through Sierra Leone, those at Bureh Beach Surf Club teach and feed tourists, eking out a living seemingly determined to pursue their passion as a way to cope.
lead_paragraph: BUREH BEACH, Sierra Leone — There is at least one place in this country, along a quiet, palm-fringed cove, where nobody is talking about viral loads or death rates, treatment centers or protective suits.

headline: Jihadists and Supporters Take to Social Media to Praise Attack on Charlie Hebdo
abstract: For jihadists from North Africa to Pakistan, the attack in Paris was a justified blow against a country perceived as an enemy of Islam.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Within hours of the deadly attack on the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, Islamic extremists and their supporters were praising the killings and lauding the attackers on social media under hashtags like #we_avenged_the_prophet and #lone_wolves.

headline: Patients Seek ‘Right to Try’ New Drugs
abstract: The critically ill want access to experimental drugs not yet approved by the Food and Drug Administration.
lead_paragraph: LYONS, Colo. — Since May, a string of states have passed laws that give critically ill patients the right to try medications that have not been approved by the Food and Drug Administration.

headline: Ex-Leader’s Trial Details Union Coercion
abstract: The former boss of a Philadelphia ironworkers’ union local charged in a campaign of violence against nonunion projects heard the testimony of members who have become witnesses for the government.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — A former union boss is fighting accusations that he led a campaign of violence, extortion and vandalism at local construction sites in an effort to force nonunion contractors to hire his members.

headline: Warning: That Tan Could Be Hazardous
keywords: ['Suntan', 'Skin Cancer', 'Women and Girls', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'States (US)', 'Melanomas', 'Ultraviolet Light']
abstract: Tanning salons dot strip malls across the country, promising prettiness and, in some cases, better health, despite a growing body of evidence that links indoor tanning to skin cancer.
lead_paragraph: TEQUESTA, Fla. — On their way home from an SAT tutoring session, the Van Dresser twins, Alexandra and Samantha, 17, popped into Tan Fever & Spa, a small family-owned salon tucked into a strip mall between a bar and a supermarket.

headline: French Police Say Suspect in Attack Evolved From Petty Criminal to Terrorist
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Amedy Coulibaly, who had a long criminal record, presented himself as a model employee and transformed, in plain sight, into a hardened jihadist.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When French police raided the home of Amedy Coulibaly, a suspected Islamic extremist, in May 2010, they found his computer crammed with religious texts, holiday pictures of himself with a veiled female companion and photographs of a “pedo-pornographic character,” according to an official record of the search. They also found 240 gun cartridges for a Kalashnikov automatic rifle.

headline: Receiver’s Pass Does Trick for Patriots
abstract: In a tense game with frequent grappling and sneering after the whistle, Tom Brady led a rally with help from a receiver’s pass in New England’s win over Baltimore in the divisional playoff game.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Pro football plays in the modern era usually have lengthy, byzantine names designed to make them almost incomprehensible to anyone outside the team. But the play that turned around the A.F.C. divisional playoff game between the Baltimore Ravens and the New England Patriots on Saturday was just the opposite.

headline: Turning His Life Around to Gain Custody of His Child
abstract: David Rodriguez, a single parent, overcame many obstacles and broke old habits to gain custody of his daughter.
lead_paragraph: The seventh birthday of Jada Rodriguez — queen of their block in the West Bronx, her father, David, said — was always going to be a princess party.

headline: The Jets’ Chris Johnson Is Arrested
abstract: Johnson was arrested Friday in Orlando, Fla., on misdemeanor weapons charges, the police said. He was charged with open carrying of weapons/firearms, a second-degree misdemeanor in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Jets running back Chris Johnson was arrested Friday in Orlando, Fla., on misdemeanor weapons charges, the police said. Johnson was charged with open carrying of weapons/firearms, a second-degree misdemeanor in Florida.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 11, 2015
lead_paragraph: When you’re inside the water, you shouldn’t be thinking about anything, not Ebola, not nothing, just the waves.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 10, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Robert Stone, Novelist of the Vietnam Era and Beyond, Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. Stone’s novels grappled with the spiritual as well as with modern history and mores.
lead_paragraph: Robert Stone, who wrote ambitious, award-winning novels about errant Americans in dangerous circumstances or on existential quests — or both — as commentary on an unruly, wayward nation in the Vietnam era and beyond, died on Saturday at his home in Key West, Fla. He was 77.

headline: A Sigh of Relief as the Ravens Fade From View
abstract: With Baltimore eliminated from the playoffs, Roger Goodell can now look forward to a Super Bowl week without fresh echoes of his botched handling of the Ray Rice case ringing in his ears.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Here on the dark side of the A.F.C. postseason draw, the New England Patriots gave Roger Goodell, the N.F.L. commissioner, what he most needed and presumably wanted as he shivered in the stands Saturday evening at a frigid Gillette Stadium among the rabid riffraff.

headline: Kerry Lays Groundwork for Obama’s Visit to India
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry was in India on Sunday to set the stage for a visit by President Obama this month.
lead_paragraph: AHMEDABAD, India — Secretary of State John Kerry met with Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Sunday to promote economic ties with India and set the stage for President Obama’s visit later this month.

headline: Jacqueline Korenthal, Brian Swanson
abstract: A management consultant and an investment banker are married at the Pierre in New York.
lead_paragraph: Jacqueline Paige Korenthal and Brian Ober Swanson were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Roger Ross at the Pierre in New York.

Lindvall, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the home of the bride’s parents.

lead_paragraph: Jade Petra Frampton, the daughter of Barbara A. Frampton of Bal Harbour, Fla., and the guitarist Peter Frampton of Nashville, was married Saturday evening to Samuel David Homburger, the son of Louise C. Homburger and Jeffrey E. Homburger of New York. Rabbi David Gelfand officiated at the Harold Pratt House, an event space in New York.

headline: Candice Hebden, William Osnato
abstract: A lawyer for an electronic games company marries a former commodities trader.
lead_paragraph: Candice Brooke Hebden and William Peter Osnato were married Saturday at the Sofitel Philadelphia hotel. The couple were joined under Pennsylvania’s self-uniting marriage statute.

headline: Risa Staszewski, Marc Zegen
abstract: A teacher and a real estate executive married in Old Westbury, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Risa Levine Staszewski and Marc Joseph Zegen were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Alan B. Lucas at the Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation in Old Westbury, N.Y. Cantor Ofer Barnoy assisted.

headline: Winning in a Runaway, Seattle Takes a Step Toward Another Title
abstract: The defending Super Bowl champion Seattle turned a tight game into a rout by forcing turnovers and bullying Carolina at the line of scrimmage.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The chants of “Seahawks, Seahawks” cascaded from the stands at CenturyLink Field, where the playoffs returned on Saturday evening, and not a day too soon.

headline: Yale Topples Harvard (Again) in Matchup at Garden
abstract: Against a traditional nemesis, the Crimson’s seven-game winning streak came to an end.
lead_paragraph: Yale picked up where it left off against Harvard, scoring twice in the first period on the way to a 4-1 victory at Madison Square Garden on Saturday.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (NBC) THE 72ND ANNUAL GOLDEN GLOBE AWARDS Tina Fey and Amy Poehler host these awards — often considered predictors of the Oscars — sponsored by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association and broadcast live from the Beverly Hilton in Beverly Hills, Calif. In the motion picture drama division, the nominees for best picture are “Boyhood,” “Foxcatcher,” “The Imitation Game,” “Selma” and “The Theory of Everything”; for best actress, Jennifer Aniston, Felicity Jones, Julianne Moore, Rosamund Pike and Reese Witherspoon; and for best actor, Steve Carell, Benedict Cumberbatch, Jake Gyllenhaal, David Oyelowo and Eddie Redmayne. In the comedy or musical division, the nominees for best picture are “Birdman,” “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” “Into the Woods,” “Pride” and “St. Vincent”; for best actress, Amy Adams, Emily Blunt, Helen Mirren, Julianne Moore and Quvenzhané Wallis; and for best actor, Ralph Fiennes, Michael Keaton, Bill Murray, Joaquin Phoenix and Christoph Waltz. Awards will also be handed out for television work. Red carpet coverage begins at 7.

headline: A Chronicler of an America Without a Path
abstract: Robert Stone, who died on Saturday at 77, explored the underside of American life in books populated with pilgrims, agitators and crackpots in search of salvation, or what he called “the numinous.”
lead_paragraph: Robert Stone was one of the few writers to capture the apocalyptic madness of America in the 1960s and ’70s, as the country lurched deeper into the jungles of Vietnam and the counterculture party at home turned increasingly nihilistic, as Woodstock gave way to Altamont and as violence — propagated by the likes of both Charles Manson and the Weather Underground — rocked the home front.

headline: Huge Show of Solidarity in Paris Against Terrorism
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: More than one million people marched through the French capital with world leaders, who linked arms, in a defiant rally after deadly terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — More than a million people joined over 40 presidents and prime ministers on the streets of Paris on Sunday in the most striking show of solidarity in the West against the threat of Islamic extremism since the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: An Eternal Dilemma in the Golden Triangle
abstract: Efforts to stop opium cultivation and heroin production have been stymied by poor farmers who have few alternative to support their families.
lead_paragraph: For more than 40 years, opium poppies have been cultivated and processed into heroin in the Golden Triangle, a mountainous area that straddles the borders of Myanmar, Laos and Thailand. Along with Afghanistan, it has supplied most of the world’s heroin.

headline: Coach and Public School Add a U.S. Flair to London Collections: Men
abstract: The men’s wear shows, newly expanded to four days, kick off the fall 2015 season.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — New Year’s Eve is barely a faded memory by the time the January men’s wear runway circuit grinds into gear. Christmas is still within spitting distance. For those whose job it is to make or follow men’s clothing, who gather with back-to-school regularity, the post-holiday precipice is steep. When the troops gathered in London last week for the newly expanded London Collections: Men shows, many still sported tans.

headline: Scores Killed After Bus Collides With Oil Tanker in Pakistan
abstract: Rescue workers said the bus, operating in Sindh Province, was carrying 62 passengers inside and 10 on the roof.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — At least 62 people were killed on Sunday when a passenger bus crashed into an oil tanker on the outskirts of Karachi.

headline: Language Translation Tech Starts to Deliver on Its Promise
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', 'Software', 'Translation and Interpreters']
abstract: It may sound like the stuff of science fiction, but translation tools are improving enough to imagine a day when a Spanish speaker and an English speaker can easily chat.
lead_paragraph: The tech industry is doing its best to topple the Tower of Babel.

headline: Anita Ekberg, International Screen Beauty, Dies at 83
abstract: The Swedish actress, best known for her role in “La Dolce Vita,” was frequently quoted as saying that it was Federico Fellini, the director, who owed his success to her, and not the other way around.
lead_paragraph: Anita Ekberg, who became an international symbol of lush beauty and unbridled sensuality in the 1960 Federico Fellini film “La Dolce Vita,” died on Sunday in Rocca di Papa, southeast of Rome. She was 83.

headline: Paris March Draws More Than 1 Million Into the Streets
abstract: World leaders and hundreds of thousands of people attend a rally and march under extraordinary security in Paris on Sunday after a series of terrorist attacks in the city.
lead_paragraph: More than one million people joined world leaders on the streets of Paris on Sunday for a rally and march under extraordinary security after a series of terrorist attacks in the city. Elsewhere in France, and around the world, hundreds of thousands of people showed their support for freedom of expression and to honor the 17 people killed last week in Paris.

headline: 1915: Russian Columns Advancing Into Transylvania
abstract: Highlights from The International Herald Tribune archives: Russians inflict heavy losses on Germans.
lead_paragraph: PETROGRAD — Only skirmishing actions are reported in the latest official communiqués from the Polish and Caucasian fronts. Grand Duke Nicholas remains intentionally vague about the movements in Galicia and Bukowina. To-day’s [Jan. 11] statement from the Great General Staff says that on the left bank of the Vistula the Germans attempted yesterday and during the night to attack the Russian front at several points, but were repulsed by artillery fire. In an attack near the village of Sarnice, east of Skierniewice, the Germans reached the barbed wire protecting the Russian trenches and shouted: “Don’t fire on your own men!” The Russians, however, failed to be taken in by this worn-out ruse and replied with a murderous fire and inflicted heavy losses on the enemy.— The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 12, 1915
