headline: Video Shows a Paris Gunman Declaring His Loyalty to the Islamic State
abstract: In a recording that appeared online on Sunday, two days after his death, Amedy Coulibaly appeared below the flag of the militant group.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Amedy Coulibaly, one of three gunmen killed by the police on Friday after carrying out France’s worst terrorist attacks in more than half a century, spoke from the grave on Sunday in a slickly produced video, declaring allegiance to the Islamic State militant group, describing his role in what he called a coordinated offensive to defend Islam, and urging young French Muslims to take up the fight.

headline: Deaths of East Harlem’s Cultural Leaders Put a Legacy in Flux
abstract: Fernando Salicrup is the fifth member of New York’s Puerto Rican artist-activist community to die in just over a year, raising questions about who will carry the mantle.
lead_paragraph: The strains of “Ave Maria” resounded through the pristine East Harlem community room where Fernando Salicrup lay in state on Tuesday night. A huge Puerto Rican flag hung behind his open coffin, a reminder that Mr. Salicrup — an artist and activist — had helped to carve out a cultural space that defined Puerto Ricans in New York City.

headline: ‘Taken 3’ Tops Box Office
abstract: Liam Neeson’s franchise of vengeance raked in $40 million in its opening weekend, one of the best results on record for January.
lead_paragraph: The weekend box office provided a primer on why Hollywood spends more time pumping out sequels than it does attempting to make meaty, well-reviewed original movies. “Taken 3,” starring Liam Neeson and receiving a paltry 12 percent positive score on the review-aggregation site RottenTomatoes, was a huge No. 1 at North American multiplexes, taking in an estimated $40.4 million – one of the best opening results on record for January.

abstract: A look at the lives of those who died in the attacks at Charlie Hebdo and elsewhere in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Among the 12 people who were killed in the attack Wednesday on the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo were cartoonists, a proofreader, a maintenance worker and two police officers. A police officer was killed the next day in a Paris suburb, and four hostages were killed at a kosher supermarket in eastern Paris on Friday.

headline: ‘Hereeeee’s Ikechukwu!’ (Complete With Sidekick and Fake Cityscape)
abstract: “Ike at Night,” a sendup of an old-school late-night talk starring Ikechukwu Ufomadu, is part of the Under the Radar festival.
lead_paragraph: Maybe some things that happen in Brooklyn should stay in Brooklyn. And before you assail me for my highfalutin Manhattan attitude, admit that we now have a reverse-snobbery situation, where Brooklyn dwellers sniff in umbrage at the interlopers who clog the L train in a frantic clamor to visit the latest white-hot restaurant in Williamsburg.

headline: A Bruising Love Throbs Anew
abstract: In “Kansas City Choir Boy,” starring Courtney Love and Todd Almond at HERE Arts Center, a musician reflects painfully on a former relationship.
lead_paragraph: A glamorously tarnished rock goddess, Courtney Love, plays an elusive muse named after the deity Athena in “Kansas City Choir Boy,” a music-theater piece by Todd Almond being presented as part of the Prototype festival of new opera and musical theater. Ms. Love, looking trim and intense, her long blond hair caught in a tangled ponytail, portrays the onetime love of a dream-bound musician in Mr. Almond’s dramatically blurry but musically inviting work, which is being presented in a small underground space at HERE Arts Center.

headline: Crouched Behind a Barricade, Until a Crude Stranger Barges In
abstract: In Miranda July’s first novel, “The First Bad Man,” the arrival of an interloper upends the life of a depressed and solitary woman.
lead_paragraph: The first novel by the filmmaker and artist Miranda July is like one of those strange mythological creatures that are part one thing, part another — a griffin or a chimera, perhaps, or a sphinx. The novel starts off tentatively, veers into derivative and willfully sensational theater-of-the-absurd drama — part Pinter, part Genet — and then mutates, miraculously, into an immensely moving portrait of motherhood and what it means to take care of a child.

headline: European Central Bank Policy Makers Remain Divided on Bond Purchases
abstract: The E.C.B. is under pressure to interrupt a decline in consumer prices that could undermine corporate profits and lead to a surge in unemployment.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Top officials of the European Central Bank offered dueling views over the weekend on how to deal with the risk of a downward price spiral in the eurozone, a sign that internal debate continues ahead of a crucial meeting next week.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the annual music festival.

headline: A Canvas for Mystery and Unabashed Lewdness
abstract: “Kein Applaus” and “Sister” pushed the envelope of contemporary choreography at the American Realness festival.
lead_paragraph: For those who think American Realness 2015, a festival of dance and performance, is about promoting one kind of art, two recent shows, seen Friday at Abrons Arts Center, presented two sides of contemporary choreography. One was by a brash young duo from Europe; the other, an experienced New York formalist.

headline: Dryly Shattering Taboos
abstract: Ivo Dimchev’s “Fest” and Keith Hennessey’s “Bear/Skin” had premieres at Abrons Arts Center on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The American Realness festival can be a cliquish affair in which the performers seem to be interested mainly in one another. But with the participation of the Bulgarian-born provocateur Ivo Dimchev, this genre-crossing series has at least acquired a saving sense of humor about itself.

headline: For Cowboys, It’s Overturned and Out
abstract: Aaron Rodgers’s tender left calf had not fully healed, but he engineered a stirring comeback. Dallas was involved in another controversial call, this one on a pass to Dez Bryant that went against them.
lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY, Wis. — By all accounts, Cowboys quarterback Tony Romo threw a perfect, arcing pass on a fourth down with the game on the line. Dallas’s star receiver, Dez Bryant, leapt high in the air and made a fabulous grab, landing a yard short of the goal line.

headline: Kravitz to Join  Super Bowl Show
abstract: The Grammy award-winning artist Lenny Kravitz will join Katy Perry at the Super Bowl halftime show.
lead_paragraph: The Grammy award-winning artist Lenny Kravitz will join Katy Perry (both above) at the Super Bowl halftime show. Ms. Perry made the announcement on Saturday during NBC’s broadcast of the playoff game between the New England Patriots and Baltimore Ravens. “My first special guest is going to be an incredible rock ’n’ roll icon, a guitar god,” Ms. Perry said, adding that other artists would be added. “He’s going to make me so much cooler that day,” she said. The Super Bowl takes place on Feb. 1 in Glendale, Ariz. Ms. Perry, 30, is currently on a world tour in support of her 2013 album, “Prism.”  Mr. Kravitz, 50, will begin the second leg of his international “Strut” tour in March.

headline: $5 Million to Benefit New York Dance
abstract: The Harkness Foundation for Dance announced that it would distribute $5 million in grants over the next decade to five organizations that support dance.
lead_paragraph: The Harkness Foundation for Dance announced on Sunday that it would distribute $5 million in grants over the next decade to five organizations that support dance. The recipients are the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Joyce Theater, City Center, the 92nd Street Y and the NYU Langone Medical Center’s Hospital for Joint Diseases, which houses the Harkness Center for Dance Injuries. Each organization will receive $1 million, making this the foundation’s largest grant to date. Plans for the funding include support for dance presentation at the academy; a new performance series at the Joyce; renovations at City Center; a new residency program at the 92Y; a new boardroom at the Hospital for Joint Diseases; and the development of online courses about dance injuries and treatment.

abstract: Cara Buckley reports from the red carpet of the Golden Globes.

headline: When Ordinary Words Sprout Wings and Fly
abstract: Target Margin Theater’s “Reread Another,” an adaptation of a 1921 play by Gertrude Stein, finds the fun — and the meaning — in Stein’s seeming nonsense.
lead_paragraph: Words seem to be plucked from the air, with great care and wonder, in “Reread Another,” a charming palate-teaser of an opener for the Target Margin Theater’s season devoted to the writings of Gertrude Stein at the Bushwick Starr in Brooklyn. They are simple words, said with savor and, occasionally, apprehension.

headline: Egyptian Authorities Release a Morsi Adviser
abstract: Khaled al-Qazzaz, who was the foreign relations secretary and a top adviser of the Muslim Brotherhood, had been held without charges for 558 days.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egyptian authorities on Sunday released, for the first time, one of the advisers to ousted President Mohamed Morsi who were detained with him at the time of the military takeover on July 3, 2013.

headline: French Gunman Speaks
abstract: The French police confirmed that this is Amedy Coulibaly, one of three men suspected in the deadly terrorist attacks in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The French police confirmed that this is Amedy Coulibaly, one of three men suspected in the deadly terrorist attacks in Paris.

headline: Highly Confident in His Own Catalog
abstract: Robin Schulz focused about half of his 90-minute set at Webster Hall on Saturday on his own catalog, leaving him less freedom than the resident D.J.s.
lead_paragraph: At around 3 in the morning on Saturday, near the end of Robin Schulz’s 90-minute set at Webster Hall, he looked, more or less, like the archetypical superstar D.J. aspirant. He had stepped out from behind his turntable setup to assess the crowd. There was a video camera attached to an elaborate contraption that dangled it in front of his face. He was holding a bottle of champagne. A cluster of red balloons dropped from the ceiling, and he perfunctorily sprayed the champagne out over the crowd.

headline: Reaction to Dez Bryant Call Includes Plenty of Head Shaking
abstract: A controversial call in an N.F.L. game can certainly get Twitter buzzing.
lead_paragraph: A controversial call in an N.F.L. game can certainly get Twitter buzzing. Sunday’s replay reversal on a seemingly key catch in the Dallas-Green Bay game by the Cowboys’ Dez Bryant was no exception, as people inside and outside the game were left questioning the rules governing pass receptions.

headline: A Sense of Frenetic Energy in a Hardscrabble World
abstract: The Winter Jazzfest marathon marked its 11th year with performances around the city.
lead_paragraph: Maybe the code-orange, brain-overload feeling produced by the Winter Jazzfest, this year in particular, can be explained by a formula.

headline: Striding Back Into the Limelight With Heady, Hip-Swiveling Glee
abstract: Neneh Cherry, best known for her 1980s hit “Buffalo Stance,” performed in her first New York show as a solo artist.
lead_paragraph: Neneh Cherry had international hits in the late 1980s and early 1990s, when she was a sassy young woman in her 20s, immersed in London’s overlapping post-punk, hip-hop and club cultures. She fused them in songs like “Buffalo Stance,” in 1988, rapping and singing about pimping, poverty, dancing and love. Now 50, she was just as bold in her New York City solo debut on Friday night at the Highline Ballroom. “It’s kind of a deep thing that this is actually at last happening,” she said. “It’s about the now, right here, right now.”

headline: Reweaving a Tapestry From Charpentier’s Threads
abstract: The Green Mountain Project performed a de facto Charpentier Vespers at St. Joseph’s Church that blended the composer’s works with chants and sonatas.
lead_paragraph: The French Baroque composer Marc-Antoine Charpentier never wrote an elaborate choral work in the manner of Monteverdi’s 90-minute “Vespro della Beata Vergine.” But that has not stopped Scott Metcalfe, the early-music violinist and music director of the Green Mountain Project, from piecing together a Vespers score on Charpentier’s behalf.

headline: Who Is Solving This Puzzle
abstract: A smooth Monday puzzle by Jason Flinn. Just what we needed.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Ah, that’s better. There’s nothing like a nice, easy, smooth Monday to restore one’s sense of puzzle-solving self-worth.

headline: Catch Is Ruled a Bobble as Dallas’s Good Fortune Turns to Agony
abstract: A seemingly spectacular catch on fourth down late in the game by the Cowboys’ Dez Bryant was overturned, helping to seal the Packers’ 26-21 victory on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY, Wis. — More than three decades ago, the Dallas Cowboys lost an N.F.C. championship game to the San Francisco 49ers because of a 6-yard touchdown pass from Joe Montana to Dwight Clark that has become known as the Catch.

headline: A Swarm in ‘Dead City’
abstract: At 14, I tried to run away. But millions of molting cicadas, and a mother who loved me, came between me and my freedom.
lead_paragraph: I was 14 and desolate, living in a place so unlike the vibrant home I’d left behind that I named it “Dead City.” Determined to return to civilization, I planned to hitchhike to O’Hare Airport and buy a ticket back to New York. There was just one hurdle. Outside my grandmother’s suburban front door was a plague of cicadas.

headline: Silicon Valley Turns Its Eye to Education
abstract: Educational technology companies are latecomers to exploiting the potential of the Internet, but venture capitalists seem to believe their time has come.
lead_paragraph: The education technology business is chock-full of fledgling companies whose innovative ideas have not yet proved effective — or profitable. But that is not slowing investors, who are pouring money into ventures as diverse as free classroom-management apps for teachers and foreign language lessons for adult learners.

headline: Tony Award for Teachers
keywords: ['Theater', 'Tony Awards (Theater Awards)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Education (K-12)', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: A new Tony Award will be given annually to a theater teacher who has made a “monumental impact” on the lives of students.
lead_paragraph: A new Tony Award will be given annually to a theater teacher who has made a “monumental impact” on the lives of students, executives who oversee the Tonys and officials at Carnegie Mellon University announced on Sunday. The honor is intended to reflect the appreciation that many Tony winners — actors, writers, directors — have expressed for drama teachers who guided or inspired them. The award is the first new Tony since 2009. Through March 31, anyone can nominate a teacher for the new Excellence in Theater Education Award. Nominees must be current teachers at an accredited elementary, middle or high school or community theater organization in the United States. (College professors and retired teachers are not eligible.) A panel of judges comprising members of the American Theater Wing and the Broadway League, which oversee the Tonys, and Carnegie Mellon officials and theater industry executives will choose the winner, who will receive the award onstage at the annual Tonys ceremony in June.

headline: For the Love of Carbon
keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Unemployment', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Environment']
abstract: Building Keystone XL is about creating jobs, Republicans say — but it’s really about creating a richer fossil fuel industry.
lead_paragraph: It should come as no surprise that the very first move of the new Republican Senate is an attempt to push President Obama into approving the Keystone XL pipeline, which would carry oil from Canadian tar sands. After all, debts must be paid, and the oil and gas industry — which gave 87 percent of its 2014 campaign contributions to the G.O.P. — expects to be rewarded for its support.

headline: United in Outrage
abstract: By turning out in vast numbers, the marchers in Paris made an eloquent statement in support of the fundamental right of free expression.
lead_paragraph: The solidarity march of more than one million people in Paris on Sunday was rich in placards and symbols but appropriately devoid of speeches. Like many in the vast throng that filled the broad boulevards between Place de la République and Place de la Nation, the world leaders who marched a portion of the route with President François Hollande locked arms and embraced. But there was no podium, no pulpit, only ubiquitous signs reading “Je suis Charlie.” For the moment, that said it all.

headline: The Two Faces of Azerbaijan’s Mr. Aliyev
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The nation’s president is “pro-Western,” with ample supplies of oil and gas. He is also hugely corrupt and authoritarian.
lead_paragraph: President Ilham Aliyev of Azerbaijan does a masterful political Jekyll and Hyde. A cable from the American ambassador to Baku released on WikiLeaks described him as a Michael Corleone-Sonny Corleone figure — referring, respectively, to the coolly calculating and the impetuously violent brothers of the “Godfather” mafia family. Mr. Aliyev is “pro-Western” in many of the ways the West admires: He is suave, well dressed and well spoken in English; he is ready to send his country’s ample supplies of oil and gas to Europe and to Israel; his Islam is moderate and modern; and he hosts lavish international events like the Eurovision Song Contest in 2012 and the European Games to be held next June.

headline: Jihadism Born in a Paris Park and Fueled in the Prison Yard

headline: Rebuilding 3 Lives After Family Loses a Husband and a Provider to Cancer
abstract: When Yaresly Cosme-Alicea’s husband, Jean Carlos Ocasio, died of leukemia, she had to learn how to support their two children.
lead_paragraph: Leukemia took Jean Carlos Ocasio in November, but the apartment he shared with his wife, Yaresly Cosme-Alicea, and their children still vibrates with his presence. It is in the walls he painted in warm earth tones, the steel kitchen shelves he custom made, the dividing wall he built in the apartment’s one bedroom, which is only half-finished, beams and Spackle still visible.

headline: Justice Department Declassifies Additional Portions of Inspector General Reports on Using Patriot Act Section 215 for Business Records Collection
keywords: ['Freedom of Information Act', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'USA PATRIOT Act']
abstract: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by The New York Times, the Justice Department has declassified additional portions of these two inspector general reports about the government’s use of Section 215 of the Patriot Act, which is the legal basis for the once-secret National Security Agency program that systematically collects records in bulk about Americans’ domestic and international phone calls.
lead_paragraph: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by The New York Times, the Justice Department has declassified additional portions of these two inspector general reports about the government’s use of Section 215 of the Patriot Act, which is the legal basis for the once-secret National Security Agency program that systematically collects records in bulk about Americans’ domestic and international phone calls.

headline: Yankees’ Coaching Plans
abstract: The Yankees are close to naming three new coaches, including a head hitting coach and an assistant who will share the duties, a first for the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees are close to naming three new coaches, including a head hitting coach and an assistant who will share the duties, a first for the Yankees. Jeff Pentland will be the principal hitting instructor, according to a person familiar with the matter, and Alan Cockrell will be the assistant. Both have extensive major league experience.

headline: Newcastle Brown Ale Calls for Other Brands to Join a Sly Super Bowl Ad Campaign
abstract: Newcastle Brown Ale is looking to incorporate 20 to 30 other companies into a commercial to be shown online and in local TV markets during the game.
lead_paragraph: Crowning itself the Robin Hood of the Super Bowl, the beer brand Newcastle Brown Ale is trying to steal the buzz from the world’s richest advertising event and give it to dozens of other marketers that aren’t paying $4.5 million for 30 seconds of commercial time during the game.

headline: Some New York Police Officers Were Quick to Resort to Chokeholds, Inspector General Finds
abstract: The first investigation by the city’s newly created police inspector general’s office found that little or no punishment has been given to officers who used the banned maneuver.
lead_paragraph: The first investigation by New York City’s police inspector general includes the finding that in several cases where officers were found to have used a chokehold, the banned maneuver was the officer’s initial physical response to verbal resistance.

Stringer, has agreed to pay $17 million to settle three more claims based on wrongful criminal convictions, his office said on Sunday, part of an emerging strategy to resolve civil rights cases before they are formally filed as lawsuits in court.

headline: Skewers, Serious and Silly

headline: Harry V. Jaffa, Conservative Scholar and Goldwater Muse, Dies at 96
abstract: Dr. Jaffa, a prolific author, helped shape modern politics by suggesting two lines about extremism and moderation at the 1964 Republican National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Harry V. Jaffa, who explored America’s founding in many books, but shifted modern politics with two speech lines that cast Senator Barry M. Goldwater as an extremist, abetting his landslide defeat in the 1964 presidential race and the birth of a zealous new conservatism, died on Saturday in Pomona, Calif. He was 96.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9:15 A.M. (IFC) IGBY GOES DOWN (2002) Kieran Culkin portrays Igby, a 17-year-old military school runaway who camps out in a New York loft as he rebels against his preppy older brother (Ryan Phillippe) and high-strung mother (Susan Sarandon), in this sarcastic comedy written and directed by Burt Steers. Amanda Peet, above with Mr. Culkin, is the heroin-addicted choreographer and trophy girlfriend of Igby’s wealthy godfather and benefactor (Jeff Goldblum) with whom Igby finds solace; Bill Pullman is Igby’s father, in a mental hospital after a schizophrenic breakdown. “Even though the movie drifts uneasily between satire and realism, and its visions of military school and bohemia feel secondhand, it maintains a ruthless emotional honesty,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “Ultimately, it gets at something that no other recent American movie has captured quite so acutely: a resentful, lurking disappointment in the good life.”

headline: South Korean Leader Urges North to ‘Stop Hesitating’ on Talks

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — President Park Geun-hye urged North Korea on Monday to come to the negotiating table to discuss projects of reconciliation on the divided Korean Peninsula, like reunions of families separated during the Korean War.

lead_paragraph: The Swiss pharmaceutical giant Roche said on Monday that it would acquire a majority stake in the tumor-testing company Foundation Medicine for more than $1 billion, in a deal aimed at improving both cancer treatment and drug development.

headline: First Black Box Is Recovered From AirAsia Plane
keywords: ['AirAsia Flight 8501', 'Recording Equipment', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']
abstract: The flight data recorder from Flight 8501 was retrieved on Monday morning, and divers have also pinpointed the location of the cockpit voice recorder.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesian Navy divers on Monday retrieved one of the so-called black boxes from the AirAsia plane that crashed into the Java Sea late last month and were trying to recover the other one amid strong underwater currents and limited visibility, officials said.

headline: Q. and A.: Jimmy Lai on the Democracy Movement in Hong Kong
abstract: Jimmy Lai, who has come under attack for his anti-Communist views, speaks about his role in the Occupy Central protests, why he is distancing himself from his media company and the challenges that lie ahead.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Lai, profiled in Monday’s New York Times, is the founder and owner and was until recently the chairman of Next Media, which publishes the Apple Daily newspaper and Next Magazine in Hong Kong and Taiwan. He was a central figure in the pro-democracy Occupy Central protests, in which demonstrators closed major streets in three sections of Hong Kong between late September and mid-December. Now, officials in Hong Kong are weighing bringing formal charges against scores of people they have identified as key members of the protests. On Friday, Mr. Lai, 66, was instructed to report to police headquarters on Jan. 21.

abstract: The authorities said that they would bolster security to protect potential targets of terrorism, putting in place one of the country’s biggest peacetime security operations.

headline: Golden Globes: Which Brand Won the Night?
abstract: Versace had a banner night but, over all, lots of brands were worn by lots of celebrities.
lead_paragraph: The brand/celebrity equation has had its ups and downs — once upon a time, a single brand could dominate awards nights, outfitting multiple stars and making a major splash (Armani, anyone?), a situation that gave way to the one-brand, one-woman approach. But interestingly, if the Golden Globes on Sunday night are anything to go by, fashion seems to be leaning back toward the dress-as-many-as-possible technique.

headline: The Best-Positioned Rival to Jeb Bush May Not Be the Best Known

lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush had a good month. He struck first in the invisible primary — the behind-the-scenes competition for the support of donors, officials and operatives. And for all of the talk about the depth of the Republican field, the opposition to Mr. Bush remains unclear and underwhelming.

headline: Reaganomics Undefended
abstract: A very weird attack on yours truly.
lead_paragraph: OK, I’m accustomed to getting attacked — if what I write doesn’t induce some hysterical backlash, I’ve wasted the space. And it’s kind of flattering when people devote whole print columns to attacking yours truly; it’s kind of a compliment, a tribute to their sense of my malign influence.

headline: Kerry Vows Aid for Displaced Pakistanis
abstract: The secretary of state announced effort $250 million package those who fled during the Pakistani military’s campaign against militant groups.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The United States plans to provide $250 million in emergency aid to help resettle and sustain civilians displaced by the Pakistani military’s campaign against militant groups, senior American officials said Monday night after the first day of a visit by Secretary of State John Kerry.

headline: Morning Agenda: Shire’s Deal for NPS
abstract: Shire agrees to buy NPS Pharmaceuticals for $5.2 billion. | Banks brace for a jolt as the price of oil falls. | Kicking Dodd-Frank in the teeth. | David A. O’Neil, a federal prosecutor, is joining the law firm Debevoise & Plimpton.
lead_paragraph: The Irish drug maker Shire has agreed to acquire NPS Pharmaceuticals for $5.2 billion, the first big corporate acquisition of the year, DealBook’s David Gelles reports. Shire, based in Dublin, said on Sunday that it would pay $46 a share for NPS, which is based in New Jersey and specializes in drugs for gastrointestinal disorders. That represents a 51 percent increase over NPS’s share price on Dec. 16, before rumors of the deal first surfaced. Shire will pay for NPS using all cash.

headline: Doing More for Patients Often Does No Good
abstract: When options are available, it’s tempting to go for the maximum treatment. But that doesn’t necessarily lead to better outcomes.
lead_paragraph: Given the remarkable advances that have been made in the last 50 or so years in pharmaceuticals, medical devices and surgical procedures, it’s not a surprise that people want more, and more invasive, care than they have had in the past. Just as it’s hard to do nothing when you’re ill, it’s sometimes hard to do less than the maximum when there are different treatments to choose from.

headline: History and Policy Failure
abstract: None of this should have come as a surprise.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been having a hard time reading Barry Eichengreen’s Hall of Mirrors, about how the lessons of the Great Depression were ignored after 2008. It’s not that it’s a bad book; so far, it seems to be a very good book, with a lot about the 1930s that I didn’t know. But the recent history is painful, because I was watching in real time, warning desperately that what did happen, would happen.

headline: What the Globes Say About the Oscars (and ‘Grand Budapest’)

headline: When Diabetes Treatment Goes Too Far
abstract: Plunging blood sugar levels put older patients at risk.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — ONE of my elderly patients has Type 2 diabetes and heart disease. He takes a number of medications, including insulin to control his blood sugar levels. A few years ago, he was driving when his blood sugar suddenly dropped. He felt lightheaded for a moment, and then ran into a tree.

abstract: The orchestra’s plan to record all seven Sibelius symphonies was interrupted by a 16-month lockout.

headline: Access and How to Get It: Congressional Reporter’s Notebook
keywords: ['Capitol Building (Washington, DC)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Jeremy Peters, a congressional reporter for The Times, describes the reporter’s abiding concern with access and the question of how to get past handlers and other hurdles.
lead_paragraph: Congress is back in session, and though it remains to be seen how the new Republican majority will affect legislation, some things almost never change. Jeremy W. Peters, a congressional reporter for The Times, describes the reporter’s abiding concern with access and the question of how to get past handlers and other hurdles.

headline: The 10 Best Dressed on the Golden Globe Awards Red Carpet
abstract: From Amal Clooney’s opera gloves to Felicity Jones’s demure Dior, the stars turned it out at last night’s event.
lead_paragraph: From old-Hollywood glamour to red-carpet rebels, the stars turned it out at last night’s Golden Globe Awards. Several trends emerged on the red carpet, such as silver-embellished gowns that shined like disco balls, worn by Julianne Moore and Dakota Johnson, and suiting and separates, as seen on Emma Stone and Lorde. Only a brave few took risks, but they did so successfully: Last year’s award winner Lupita Nyong’o stood out in one of the night’s only prints; the most anticipated guest of the evening, Amal Clooney, sported white opera gloves; and the nominee Felicity Jones wore demure, high-necked Dior, proving amidst all the cleavage and cutouts that being covered up can make just as much of an impression. Last but not least, there were the ladies who wore true fashion and wore it well: Claire Danes in Valentino, a pregnant Keira Knightley in Chanel and Sienna Miller in Miu Miu. All in all, it was an exciting kick-off to 2015’s awards season.

headline: The Sony Hack and the Gender Pay Gap
abstract: Female stars were paid less than their male counterparts.
lead_paragraph: It’s rare to see such clear evidence of women making less pay for equal work. Among other unflattering details revealed by the Sony Pictures Entertainment hack (presumably sponsored by North Korea in retaliation for the film The Interview) was that Chris Hemsworth had secured higher compensation than his co-star Charlize Theron for the upcoming movie “The Huntsman.”

headline: 1915: A Battle Royal in the Sky
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'World War I (1914-18)']
abstract: Highlights from The International Herald Tribune archives: 1915: A battle royal in the sky at an altitude of 9,000ft.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A thrilling sequel to the German aerial raid on Dunkirk, a battle royal 9,000 feet above the ground between two Belgian aeroplanes and seven enemy machines, has become known here. As shrapnel and rifle bullets from the anti-aircraft guns were pattering down on houses, two plucky Belgian aviators took to the air and engaged seven foes. Rapidly outmaneuvering the hostile pilots, the Belgians ascended, and half hidden by the thin gray clouds, they poured a hail of bullets from their machine-guns. As fast as the remaining German planes rose, the Belgians climbed more swiftly, until the final phase of the duel was decided at an altitude of 9,000ft. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 13, 1915

headline: Daniel Finkel and the Balance Problem
abstract: A twist on the classic coin-scale problem by math educator Daniel Finkel.
lead_paragraph: Our puzzle this week was proposed by regular contributor Daniel Finkel, part of the Seattle-based Math for Love duo committed to revitalizing grade- and high-school math education. “I think I’ve just concocted a novel coin-balance problem,” he wrote in a recent email. “To the best of my knowledge, it is totally original.”

headline: A Killing Spree Ignored for Decades
abstract: “Tales of the Grim Sleeper,” shortlisted for the Oscar for documentary feature, argues that hundreds of women may have died.
lead_paragraph: Nobody knows how many women may have been killed during a spree in Los Angeles that began in the 1980s and ended with the arrest in 2010 of Lonnie Franklin Jr. He has been charged in 10 cases, but in “Tales of the Grim Sleeper,” one of 15 films shortlisted for the Oscar for best documentary feature, the British director Nick Broomfield argues that a more realistic count would have to be in the hundreds.

headline: The Skinny on Moving Under Sand
abstract: A study showed that the long, slender shape of a snake was able to move more efficiently than that of a lizard.

headline: Celebrating King in Atlanta, Memphis and Boston
abstract: A guide to events celebrating the anniversary of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s birth.
lead_paragraph: In Atlanta, where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was born and raised, his holiday, coming up on Jan. 19, feels both somber and celebratory, said Kim Severson, a domestic correspondent for The New York Times based there. “You definitely feel like it’s a special day when you’re in Atlanta, probably more so than in other cities.”

headline: Monochrome Men’s Looks at the Golden Globes
abstract: The actors William H. Macy and Adrien Brody and the musician Common buttoned up dark layers beneath their navy tuxedos.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when wearing a navy tuxedo during awards season seemed a revolutionary choice for men. But after last night’s Golden Globes, it’s safe to say what was once a risky move has nowadays become commonplace. Plenty of navy tuxedos walked down the red carpet yesterday evening; however, the above men took it a step further. The actors William H. Macy and Adrien Brody and the musician Common — who won the award for Best Original Song for the film “Selma” — opted against the traditional crisp white shirt that actors are wont to wear with their evening suits and instead buttoned up dark layers beneath, creating dapper monochromatic looks that were just a bit more exciting than the basic navy tux.

headline: Harsh Critics in Public Spaces, Judging Only What They See
abstract: Strangers like to tell me what I’m doing wrong as a parent, or at least give me hard, critical looks, all the time. But there’s a big part of our story they often don’t know.
lead_paragraph: The last time it happened was in the grocery store. A scowling woman closed in on me and my son, Nico, in the produce section. Glaring, she waved at my son’s face and said, “His nose!” And then she mimed wiping with furious gestures. I sighed and pulled a tissue from my pocket. She harrumphed slightly and walked away. I offered Nico the tissue.

headline: Despite Scrutiny, Police Chokeholds Persist in New York City
abstract: Since a police chokehold contributed to a Staten Island man’s death in July, the tactic and its 20-year-old prohibition in New York City have come under intense review.
lead_paragraph: Before pepper spray, Tasers, expandable batons and portable radios, New York police officers facing resistance from a criminal suspect had another option: the chokehold. By 1993, though, the New York Police Department had joined departments in other large cities by banning the chokehold with an order that amounted to, in the words of former Chief of Department John F. Timoney: “Stay the hell away from the neck.”

headline: Emerging Markets After The Tantrum
abstract: Making rupee.

headline: Getting Over Cold Feet: The Case for Impulse Buying
abstract: We can’t always make the best decisions, but we can quickly make ones that are good enough and that will free us to move on to other important things.
lead_paragraph: I live in a part of the country where we take skiing pretty seriously. It’s common for people to ski a few times a week since there are three great resorts right in our town. Our family is no exception. We ski a lot, but as my wife and I have gotten older, we discovered a painful reality: Our feet get colder faster.

He immediately thought of Mr. Legend, who sent him the composition three days later.

headline: 1965: Burch to Quit as GOP Leader
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Dean Burch resigns as president of the Republican Party in 1965.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Dean Burch battle has ended, and with it the brief reign of Barry Goldwater over the Republican party. Today [Jan. 12], less than six months after his triumphant nomination for the presidency, the Arizona conservative announced that Mr. Burch, his choice for national chairman, would step down from the top party post April 1 in favor of Ohio state chairman Ray C. Bliss. It was hailed by most leaders of the GOP as a harbinger of a new era of harmony within the faction-ridden party. — The New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 13, 1965

headline: Plunging Teenage Angst Deeper Into the Woods
abstract: Tina Satter’s “Ancient Lives” sort of follows the format of Grimm’s fairy tales, but don’t expect to find Rapunzel and Cinderella and their respective princes in residence.
lead_paragraph: A lively squadron of archetypes, long familiar to fans of popular myths, wanders into a mysterious forest. Uncanny and unsettling things happen there, including encounters with a witch. Songs are sung, lessons are learned, and by the end all these explorers have grown just a bit in their knowledge of life’s uncertainties.

headline: Meet Martine Rose, London’s Rising Men’s Wear Provocateur (and Rihanna’s Go-To Label)
abstract: The men’s wear label is attracting notice for its outrageous subculture-inspired silhouettes.
lead_paragraph: Since her debut collection in 2007, the London-based men’s wear designer Martine Rose has searched for and celebrated what she calls “an awkwardness that is beautiful in its entirety.” The punk, skinhead, ’90s raver and ’70s S-and-M scenes, to name a few, provide references for her odd proportions (outrageously oversize trousers paired with super-cropped or tight tops) and unexpected fabric combinations. The fashion world has taken notice; so, too, has Rihanna, who has worn Rose’s designs on multiple occasions.

headline: Galliano’s Back, on Tiptoes
abstract: The start of the rest of John Galliano’s fashion life had its own hashtag, #MargielaMonday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The klieg lights went up on Act III of John Galliano’s career on a rainy Monday here, on the fourth floor of a brand-new eco-sensitive glass and steel office tower just around the corner from New Scotland Yard and behind Buckingham Palace. In case you missed it: new building, new businesslike beginning.

headline: Manhattan Clinic That Treated Joan Rivers Will Lose Federal Funding
abstract: Yorkville Endoscopy has failed to correct the deficiencies implicated in Ms. Rivers’s death, according to a letter from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan clinic where Joan Rivers went into cardiac arrest while being treated for a voice problem has failed to correct deficiencies implicated in her death and will be prohibited from having its services paid for by Medicare and Medicaid funds, according to a letter released on Monday from the federal agency that oversees those two programs.

headline: Lane Departs and Sales Sag for ‘It’s Only a Play’ on Broadway
abstract: Sales softened considerably for “It’s Only a Play” after Nathan Lane was replaced by Martin Short.
lead_paragraph: Call it the Nathan Lane effect. A two-time Tony Award winner and one of theater’s biggest box-office draws, Mr. Lane recently departed the Broadway hit comedy “It’s Only a Play” – and ticket sales promptly slid without him last week, just as they did when he left earlier Broadway shows like “The Addams Family” and “The Producers.”

headline: A Computer That Knows When to Hold ’Em
abstract: Scientists have developed an algorithm that guarantees at least a draw in one variation of poker.
lead_paragraph: It has been eight years since a computer program “solved” checkers, calculating a strategy so optimal that it guaranteed at least a draw. Now, an algorithm has done the same for poker, producing a winning strategy that researchers say no human can beat in a single lifetime.

headline: Rivalry’s Edict: Drub Thy Neighbor
abstract: Hope College and Calvin College, Division III rivals in Michigan, play in one of the biggest rivalries in college basketball. After Calvin’s win on Saturday, it trailed in the 95-year series, 98-91.
lead_paragraph: HOLLAND, Mich. — As much as he emphasizes the twin concepts of consistency and continuity, Kevin Vande Streek dabbled in the unconventional when his players gathered for practice Friday.

headline: Egyptian Court Acquits 26 Men Accused of Debauchery
abstract: The men were charged in December after the police raided a bathhouse in a case seen as evidence of an intensifying crackdown on gay men by the government.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A Cairo court on Monday acquitted 26 men accused of “debauchery” in a case that was seen as evidence of an intensifying crackdown on gay men by the government of President Abdel-Fattah el-Sisi.

headline: Regulators Again Reject Doral Financial’s Capital Plan
abstract: The troubled Puerto Rico bank warns of possible “additional regulatory enforcement actions up to and including the appointment of a receiver or conservator for the bank.”
lead_paragraph: Doral Financial, the troubled Puerto Rico bank with offices that were raided by the F.B.I. last month, has run afoul with banking regulators over its plans to restore its depleted capital levels.

headline: Deviating From the Modern, to Fresh Effect
abstract: Johnny Gandelsman’s show at Bargemusic bore the fruits of a 2013 performance of the Chaconne from the second Partita, which he played on gut strings with a Baroque bow.
lead_paragraph: Not every career has a watershed moment. But the violinist Johnny Gandelsman, who gave a mesmerizing performance of Bach’s sonatas and partitas for unaccompanied violin at Bargemusic on Saturday, recalled the pivotal experience that forever changed his approach to this music.

headline: White House Admits Misstep
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'United States International Relations', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, said that the United States should have sent a higher ranking official than the ambassador to France to attend Sunday’s peace march in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, said that the United States should have sent a higher ranking official than the ambassador to France to attend Sunday’s peace march in Paris.

headline: Women Run 30 Percent of All Businesses, but Only 5 Percent of the Biggest, Study Shows
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Gender']
abstract: A report by the International Labor Organization said “there is a long way to go before we achieve true gender equality in the workplace.”
lead_paragraph: Women own or manage more than 30 percent of all businesses but 5 percent or less of the biggest enterprises, the United Nations said in a report published Monday.

headline: Arrests and Summonses Rise in New York City, but Fall Short of Pre-Slowdown Levels
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Traffic and Parking Violations']
abstract: After largely ignoring many minor offenses for two weeks, the Police Department’s rank and file began to reverse a severe slowdown that began after two officers were killed.
lead_paragraph: The shift could be seen across New York City. Orange parking tickets again fluttered on windshields; turnstile jumpers again faced a summons or arrest; and drivers encountered more traffic checkpoints.

headline: Your Letters: Cancer’s Luck, Earth-Like Planets and Protecting Pedestrians
abstract: Letters to the Editor.
lead_paragraph: Cosmology

headline: Celebrating 2 Broadway Powerhouses, Bit by Bit
abstract: David Loud conducts an erudite survey of collaborations by Stephen Sondheim and Harold Prince.
lead_paragraph: When David Loud auditioned for the ill-fated original Broadway production of the 1981 Stephen Sondheim-George Furth musical, “Merrily We Roll Along,” he was just a college student. After many callbacks, he joined the cast of a production that closed after only 16 performances, thus ending the string of remarkable collaborations between Mr. Sondheim and the director and producer Harold Prince; they reunited in 2003 for “Bounce.”

headline: Thermal Imaging Allows for Picturing the Invisible
abstract: Thermal imaging, once limited to the police and the military, is becoming a mainstream technology.
lead_paragraph: The thermal imaging systems used by the French police to find the two brothers suspected in the Charlie Hebdo massacre last week are based on a rapidly evolving technology now turning up in hospitals, airports, and even smartphones.

headline: Murdoch and Fox News Mocked on Twitter for Claims About Muslims
abstract: This cannot have been a quiet weekend for anyone at 21st Century Fox responsible for cultivating the image of Rupert Murdoch or his Fox News Channel.
lead_paragraph: This cannot have been an enjoyable weekend for anyone at 21st Century Fox responsible for cultivating the image of either Rupert Murdoch or his Fox News Channel.

headline: An Ambassador for Physics Is Shifting His Mission
abstract: Rolf-Dieter Heuer, who as director led CERN from a dark period and declared the finding of the Higgs boson, is in the final year of his term.
lead_paragraph: Rolf-Dieter Heuer, a crinkly-eyed German with a snowy goatee, showed up at the Four Seasons, the perennial Manhattan power lunch spot, dressed like the physicist he is — in a sweater and baggy jeans for the red-eye to Geneva — rather than the diplomat he had just been playing.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week: Burberry Prorsum Fall/Winter 2015
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.

headline: Justices Seem Unsettled by Ordinance Restricting Arizona Town’s Signs
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Signs and Signage', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: Most of the Supreme Court justices seemed uncomfortable with the ordinance in Gilbert, Ariz., which restricts signs based on based on the messages they convey.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An Arizona town ordinance that places strict limits on some religious signs appeared to be in trouble on Monday at the Supreme Court.

headline: First Draft Focus: Obama Adds to His Jersey Collection
abstract: President Obama welcomed the San Antonio Spurs, last season’s N.B.A. champions, to the White House on Monday.

headline: Clown Shoes and Other Surprising Travel Necessities
abstract: The chief executive of Integreon says he wears big shoes to speed through security and likes the contents of airlines’ free toiletry bags — usually.
lead_paragraph: I RUN a global outsourcing company, Integreon, that provides legal, document, research and business support to law firms, financial institutions and multinationals. My job as chief executive means I’m kind of like a casting director, making sure we have the right people at the right place at the right time. That involves an incredible amount of travel helping clients.

headline: Child With Symptoms? App Lets You Text Doctors, With No Guarantees
abstract: A variety of apps and online services put you in touch with medical providers, but users should be aware of who they’re talking to (or texting with).
lead_paragraph: It’s happened to nearly every parent: the child with the borderline temperature and the amorphous symptoms, prompting the classic should-we-or-shouldn’t-we dilemma. Does this call for a visit to the pediatrician, or not?

headline: At the Golden Globes, Beauty Looks Got Matchy-Matchy
keywords: ['Celebrities', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Golden Globes (Awards)', 'Hair', 'Nails (Body Part)']
abstract: A few celebrities embraced what might be considered a faux pas — coordinating their hair, makeup and nails to their fashion choices.
lead_paragraph: At last night’s 2015 Golden Globe Awards, the stars seemed to be feeling riskier than ever when it came to hair and makeup. And a few celebrities even embraced what might be considered a faux pas — coordinating the colors of their hair, makeup and nails to their fashion choices. The “Homeland” actress Claire Danes reproduced the palette of her Valentino gown with an off-pink nude lip and a soft royal-blue eyeshadow (which also matched her earrings). Jessica Chastain chose the exact metallic bronze color of her Versace dress for her nails, while Zosia Mamet wore a gray dress and silver jewelry to echo her dyed gray hair.

headline: A Gallery of Tenacious Survivors
abstract: Rachel Sussman spent nearly 10 years and traveled to all seven continents to create striking images of organisms that are at least 2,000 years old.
lead_paragraph: Some people are accused of living in the past. The photographer Rachel Sussman is captivated by the past living in the present.

headline: Age and the Shingles Vaccine
keywords: ['Shingles (Disease)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Elderly', 'Chicken Pox']
abstract: Why do many health insurers pay for the vaccine only for those are who 60 and older?
lead_paragraph: Q. Why do many health insurers pay for the shingles vaccine only for people who are 60 or older?

headline: Sparrows Don’t Just Sing Same Old Song
abstract: The birds can convey vastly different meanings by varying the length and context of their whistles and trills, researchers find.
lead_paragraph: A sparrow’s song may sound simple, consisting of little more than whistles and trills. But to the sparrows, those few noises can take on vastly different meanings depending on small variations in context and repetition, researchers have found.

headline: Former Oregon Quarterback Laments What He Lost
abstract: Masoli, the former Ducks quarterback whose career went off track after an arrest, is still trying to attract the attention of N.F.L. teams at age 26.
lead_paragraph: MILLBRAE, Calif. — The last time Oregon played Ohio State was at the Rose Bowl five years ago. Jeremiah Masoli and Terrelle Pryor were the quarterbacks. Ohio State won, 26-17, and Masoli lingered on the field afterward, watching as the Buckeyes celebrated. He vowed to work harder the next season.

headline: PC Market Exited 2014 With a Whimper
abstract: Many people and businesses haven’t found compelling reasons to buy new personal computers in recent years, and PC companies didn’t discover any new gimmicks to change their minds over the holidays.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Many people and businesses haven’t found compelling reasons to buy new personal computers in recent years, and PC companies didn’t discover any new gimmicks to change their minds over the holidays.

headline: At Museum, New Front in Guinea Worm Fight
abstract: Former President Jimmy Carter cited a 15-percent drop in cases last year as he helped open an exhibition on diseases at the American Museum of Natural History.
lead_paragraph: There were only 126 cases of Guinea worm reported in the world last year, a 15 percent drop from the year before, according to former President Jimmy Carter, who has fought for decades to eradicate the debilitating disease, which once affected millions.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week: Burberry Prorsum Fall/Winter 2015
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week', 'Men and Boys', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.

headline: 2015 Detroit Auto Show
abstract: The auto industry, after reporting a strong 2014 a week ago, gathered in Detroit to show off its new models.
lead_paragraph: The auto industry, after reporting a strong 2014 a week ago, gathered in Detroit to show off its new models.

headline: Paul Ryan Announces He Will Not Run for President
abstract: As potential Republican presidential candidates continue to jockey for position before official announcements are made, one prominent Republican is withdrawing his name before the rumors even begin.
lead_paragraph: As potential presidential candidates continue to jockey for position before official announcements are made, one prominent Republican is withdrawing his name before the rumors even begin.

headline: In Performance | Slotnick and Wilson
abstract: Joey Slotnick and C.J. Wilson in a scene from Moira Buffini’s dark comedy “Dying for It,” an adaptation of Nikolai Erdman’s 1928 play “The Suicide.” The show is at the Atlantic Theater through Jan.18.
lead_paragraph: Joey Slotnick and C.J. Wilson in a scene from Moira Buffini’s dark comedy “Dying for It,” an adaptation of Nikolai Erdman’s 1928 play “The Suicide.” The show is at the Atlantic Theater through Jan.18.

headline: Parents Challenge President to Dig Deeper on Ed Tech
abstract: While President Obama endorsed a voluntary student privacy effort by ed tech companies, some parents seek more comprehensive legislation.
lead_paragraph: Education technology companies that have pledged not to exploit student data they collect for marketing purposes welcomed President Obama’s endorsement on Monday of the industry’s effort to limit its use of classroom data.

headline: Albuquerque Officers Are Charged With Murder in Death of Homeless Man
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The shooting last March came after a standoff in which the police said the homeless man had two knives, but in a video recorded by a police officer’s camera, he appeared to be turning away as he was shot.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — Prosecutors here said Monday that they would pursue murder charges against two police officers who were involved in the fatal shooting last year of a homeless man with a history of mental illness, a case that led to protests and a federal criminal investigation and that is likely to be among the first to rely on evidence obtained by a camera worn by an officer.

headline: Walkabout: New Scrutiny for U.S. Visa-Waiver Program
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: High Alert  Sen. Dianne Feinstein criticized the nascent visa-waiver program, which helps travelers from 38 countries to enter the United States visa-free for fewer than 90 days. The program may come under new scrutiny, following increasing terrorist threats and the latest attacks in Paris. (Skift)

headline: Mawmaw, The Dwarf Mammoth and M&Ms
abstract: Thomas Pierce’s “Hall of Small Mammals” includes short stories about a cloned mammoth, a corpse that may be a biological weapon, marriage and the multiverse.
lead_paragraph: If Thomas Pierce’s first book, “Hall of Small Mammals,” makes him sought after on the interview circuit, he will be asked the same thing over and over: “Where do your ideas come from?” Usually, that’s a silly question, but it’s unavoidable for a writer whose short-story collection opens with “Shirley Temple Three,” about a man’s bringing a waist-high, supposedly extinct Bread Island Dwarf Mammoth home to his mother.

headline: Amid Seeming Progress, a Vicious Backlash
abstract: “Klansville U.S.A.,” a documentary about the third wave of Ku Klux Klan activity, which came in the 1960s in response to the civil-rights movement, debuts on PBS on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: “Klansville U.S.A.” is a documentary about the Ku Klux Klan, but it’s short on images of terrorists on horseback and bodies hanging from trees. It more often resembles home movies of a Sunday outing: picnics, dancing, cooking a pig. And much of it looks like the civil rights rallies and marches that were taking place at the same time, except for the white robes and the occasional 60-foot burning cross.

headline: If Mitt Romney Challenges Jeb Bush, Rand Paul Stands to Gain
abstract: It’s still not clear whether Mitt Romney will run for president again. But if he mounts a credible campaign, he will help shape the field.
lead_paragraph: It is still not a sure thing that Mitt Romney will run for president. No losing nominee has done so in decades. But it now seems more likely. The Washington Post reported on Monday that he was reassembling his campaign apparatus, and even told one Republican he “almost certainly will run.”

headline: New Releases From Justin Townes Earle, Liam Hayes and Justin Kauflin
abstract: Reviews of Justin Townes Earle’s “Absent Fathers,” Liam Hayes’s “Slurrup” and Justin Kauflin’s “Dedication.”
lead_paragraph: JUSTIN TOWNES EARLE

headline: Now Onstage: Steady and Evolving
abstract: The soprano Angela Meade and the baritone Nicholas Pallesen shared the program during a George London Foundation event at the Morgan Library & Museum.
lead_paragraph: There was a telling moment in her recital on Sunday afternoon at the Morgan Library & Museum when the soprano Angela Meade’s voice did something surprising: It didn’t do what she wanted it to. She was finishing the recitative that leads into “Non mi dir,” one of Donna Anna’s arias from Mozart’s “Don Giovanni,” and she sent up a floating high note, like a gymnast launching herself into the air.

headline: Stillness and Motion and Voluptuous Curves, in a Temple Setting
abstract: The Temple of Dendur at the Metropolitan Museum can be a risky setting for a classical Indian dance, but not in the case of two performers from the Nrityagram ensemble on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: In India, ancient temples teem with sculptures of dancing figures, testifying to the spiritual origins and importance of dance. To see a performance of a classical Indian dance in such a setting must be revelatory, an experience impossible for an Indian dance troupe to reproduce for North American audiences. But New York got the next-best thing on Saturday, as the Nrityagram Dance Ensemble performed in the Temple of Dendur at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Climber Yearns for the Summit, and a Shower
abstract: As he and Tommy Caldwell near their goal of free climbing El Capitan’s Dawn Wall, Kevin Jorgeson is eager to return to Santa Rosa, Calif., where he first demonstrated his unusual skill.
lead_paragraph: SANTA ROSA, Calif. — Inside Kevin Jorgeson’s living room, his smiling, bearded face popped up on the screen. His hair, two weeks since a shampoo, stuck straight up.

headline: Where Terrorism is Normal (Nigeria) and News (France)
abstract: Where terror is normal (Nigeria) and news (France).
lead_paragraph: It’s heartening to see a growing discussion of the lack of attention that’s been paid in recent days to the latest atrocities committed in Nigeria by what The Times recently described and mapped as “Boko Haram, the other Islamic State.”

headline: Oil Prices Fall to Lowest Since 2009
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: International banks predict that prices will drop even lower because of an oversupplied global crude oil market.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Oil prices took another sharp turn downward on Monday to levels not seen since the depths of the 2009 recession. Several international banks predicted even lower prices later this year because of an oversupplied global crude market.

headline: No Time for Bats to Rest Easy
abstract: White-nose syndrome, a disease contracted in hibernation, is threatening a resilient, helpful marvel.
lead_paragraph: LEWISBURG, PA. — The 10 hibernating little brown bats hang from a corner of their tailor-made refrigeration chamber at Bucknell University like a clump of old potato skins, only less animated. In torpor, bats become one with their wintry surroundings, their body temperatures falling to just above freezing, their heart rates slowing to one or two beats a minute, their breathing virtually undetectable.

headline: Equipped to Body Slam, or Embalm, if Necessary
abstract: “Wrestling With Death” follows an Arkansas family’s mortuary and pro wrestling businesses.
lead_paragraph: WGN America got off to a strong start last year in its effort to build a national profile, introducing two decent scripted dramas, “Salem” and “Manhattan.” How does its latest series, “Wrestling With Death,” fit into the channel’s emergent strategy? Perfectly, if that strategy is “Let’s squander our tidbit of hard-won credibility by serving up a spectacularly idiotic reality show.”

headline: Brooklyn District Attorney Affirms Conviction in 2003 Killing of Student
abstract: The district attorney said after a review that he would not seek to overturn the conviction of John Giuca in the death of a student athlete at Fairfield University.
lead_paragraph: After an examination by his Conviction Review Unit, the Brooklyn district attorney said on Monday that he would stand by a conviction in the 2003 murder of a popular Fairfield University student athlete.

headline: Worlds and Rhythms Meet, in Euphoric Result
abstract: The Nile Project performed as part of Globalfest, the annual world-music showcase, on Sunday night at Webster Hall.
lead_paragraph: To a traditionalist, the Nile Project might look like an ungainly mélange: a gathering of musicians from the 11 countries of the Nile basin, playing instruments that weren’t made to share a stage or a song. They included an Egyptian wooden flute, an oud, African harps, a thumb piano, a saxophone. But at Globalfest, the annual world-music showcase on Sunday night at Webster Hall, the Nile Project was a committed, euphoric international coalition.

headline: Performing at Globalfest
abstract: Images of some of the performers at the world-music showcase Globalfest.
lead_paragraph: Images of some of the performers at the world-music showcase Globalfest.

headline: Fidelity Introduces Location-Based Stock-Picking App, for Some Reason
abstract: Stocks Nearby takes the strategy of “buy what you know” literally — perhaps a bit too literally.
lead_paragraph: It’s Grindr, but for stocks.

headline: With Win, Amazon Shakes Up Yet Another Industry
abstract: A nemesis for publishers, Amazon collected a Golden Globe for “Transparent,” becoming the first digital streaming service to win one for best TV series.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Among the usual names invoked during the acceptance speeches at Sunday’s Golden Globes — Harvey Weinstein, Scott Rudin, Les Moonves — was an unusual one: the tech billionaire Jeff Bezos, founder and chief executive of Amazon.

headline: Facing Opposition, Nominee for Treasury Under Secretary Withdraws
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Antonio Weiss withdrew his name from consideration in the face of liberal opposition, and will instead serve as a counselor to the secretary of the Treasury.
lead_paragraph: Antonio Weiss, a senior investment banker at Lazard, withdrew his name from consideration to be a senior Treasury Department official in the face of liberal opposition Monday, and will instead serve as a counselor to the secretary of the Treasury, Jacob J. Lew.

abstract: A reader is “mortified” that no high-level American official attended the French march against terrorism.

abstract: Members of Congress hold a lot of the power in America and, a new report shows, plenty of wealth. In fact, more than half of them are millionaires.
lead_paragraph: Members of Congress hold a lot of the power in America and, a new report shows, plenty of wealth. In fact, more than half of them are millionaires.

headline: Ratings Suggest Drop for Globes
abstract: Preliminary numbers for the Golden Globes gave it a 12.6 rating in 56 markets, down from 14.1 the year before.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Meaningful ratings data for the 72nd Golden Globes was hard to come by on Monday, as Nielsen worked through technical difficulties. But early information suggested a decline.

headline: An Unsettled Chapter in Martin Luther King’s Legacy
keywords: ['Wills and Estates', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Nobel Prizes']
abstract: The children of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. continue to fight in court over, among other things, his Bible and Nobel Peace Prize medal.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. seems to be everywhere these days with the success of the film “Selma,” which begins with his being awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.

headline: Getting From Here to There, but Not in a Straight Line
abstract: Three performers express themselves in various circuitous ways in Alexandra Bachzetsis’s “A to B via C.”
lead_paragraph: The title of Alexandra Bachzetsis’s “A to B via C” suggests a series of scrambled steps, a beginning and an end linked by a roundabout middle. On Sunday at the Swiss Institute, in its United States premiere, this coolly disarming work revealed many such convoluted structures, favoring switchbacks, detours and double exposures over any linear route.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
abstract: France and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: France and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day

headline: Coachella Organizers in Deal With Hangout Music Festival
abstract: Goldenvoice, the organizer of the annual Coachella music festival in California, has entered into a joint venture with the Hangout festival in Alabama.
lead_paragraph: Since it started in the Southern California desert in 1999, Coachella has become the premier name in pop festivals. Now it is extending its reach to the Alabama coast through a deal with a smaller festival.

headline: Silky and Shivery Tones, With Flickers of Heat
abstract: Presenting trios by Beethoven and Kodaly and the “American” quintet by Dvorak, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center offered a Sunday afternoon of exceptional playing.
lead_paragraph: The concert by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday featured no timpani jolts or cymbal crashes. These were works for strings, after all: trios by Beethoven and Kodaly and the “American” Quintet by Dvorak. But give these works to fiercely temperamental players, and they’ll still find ways to make you jump out of your skin.

headline: Quandary: When Cousins Aren’t Friends
abstract: How do you help a child navigate continuing, but always fluctuating, family relationships — or should you just resolutely stay out of the way?
lead_paragraph: In our parenting Quandaries, we pull from the comments, the weekly open thread or email a question that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You — the readers — provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family?

headline: A Threat to Unionize, and Then Benefits Trickle In for Players
abstract: Everyone except the players, it seems, is making money in college football, where even the players’ scholarships come with compromises.
lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo. — College football has gone on a roll that would bring a giggle to the lips of King Midas.

headline: Pictures of the Day — Jan. 12, 2015
abstract: Photos from France, Syria, Haiti and the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: Photos from France, Syria, Haiti and the Philippines.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Ohio State Wins National Championship
abstract: Follow live updates of the inaugural College Football Playoff championship game between Oregon and Ohio State.
lead_paragraph: Couldn’t get to a television? Want to discuss the result with other fans? See how the inaugural College Football Playoff championship game between Oregon and Ohio State happened in real time.

headline: Choke First, Ask Questions Later
abstract: A new report suggests that this disavowed tactic has never gone away and sometimes officers use it as a first, not last, resort.
lead_paragraph: The policy couldn’t be clearer: “Members of the New York City Police Department will NOT use chokeholds,” says section 203-11 of the department’s Patrol Guide. But as last July’s fatal police assault on Eric Garner showed, reality is messier than the rule book — and more dangerous for civilians.

headline: Docker, a Software Start-Up, Sees a Future in Containers of Code
abstract: The start-up is in the forefront of a move to package applications much as shipping containers hold physical goods.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A tech start-up called DotCloud was on its last legs in 2012. Now called Docker, its software has been downloaded 70 million times.

headline: Senate to Debate Keystone XL, Setting Stage for More Energy Battles
keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Debates (Political)', 'Vetoes (US)']
abstract: A measure that would force approval of the oil pipeline appears certain to pass, in a preview of clashes to come between President Obama and the new Republican Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted Monday to take up a bill that would force approval of the Keystone XL pipeline, opening a debate on energy and climate change that will preview other clashes to come between President Obama and the new Republican Congress. It will also set the stage for the energy and climate battles of the presidential election next year.

headline: A Mine Erodes an Andean City
abstract: High in the Andes, a smoldering mine eats away at residents whose rich traditions sustained them for generations.
lead_paragraph: High in the Andes, a smoldering mine eats away at residents whose rich traditions sustained them for generations.

headline: Times Reporter Will Not Be Called to Testify in Leak Case
abstract: A seven-year legal fight ended between the Justice Department and James Risen of The New York Times over reporting on a botched C.I.A. operation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — James Risen, a New York Times reporter, will not be called to testify at a leak trial scheduled to begin this week, lawyers said Monday, ending a seven-year legal fight over whether he could be forced to identify his confidential sources.

lead_paragraph: Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, lit a candle outside the kosher supermarket where four Jewish hostages were killed in a terrorist attack on Friday.

headline: A Musician’s Lament? Carrying On the Instrument
abstract: In March, airlines will be required to treat musical instruments like other passenger luggage, first come first served in the baggage bins.
lead_paragraph: BASEBALL cap turned backward, Zachary De Pue stands on the tarmac by the boarding steps of a US Airways Express regional jet in Charlotte, N.C., furiously fiddling the prelude to the Partita No. 3 in E by J.S. Bach on his 250-year-old violin.

headline: For French Muslims, a Moment of Truth
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Politics and Government', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Suburbs']
abstract: The government must do more for alienated youths. So must imams, teachers and parents.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On Friday, after prayers at the Grand Mosque here, the faithful emerged holding banners saying, against the background of the French flag, “Touche pas à mon pays,” or “Hands off my country” — echoing the slogan of the French anti-discrimination association SOS Racisme: “Touche pas à mon pote,” or “Hands off my buddy.” Other signs proclaimed that the terrorists who killed the journalists at Charlie Hebdo and the customers of a kosher supermarket last week were not true Muslims — as the family of Ahmed Merabet, the Muslim police officer who was killed trying to protect Charlie Hebdo, has poignantly noted.

headline: West Virginia Revisits Science Standards
abstract: Members of the West Virginia Board of Education will take up the teaching of climate science after accusations that the curriculum had been revamped to appease the state’s fossil fuel industry.
lead_paragraph: West Virginia joined 25 other states several years ago to help develop a set of standards for teaching science across the United States. Among other topics, the standards acknowledge the overwhelming scientific consensus that climate change is real and has been profoundly affected by human activity.

headline: Letter From the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services Ending Federal Benefits to Yorkville Endoscopy
abstract: Yorkville Endoscopy, the Manhattan clinic where Joan Rivers went into cardiac arrest while being treated for a voice problem, will lose those benefits effective on Jan. 31, the letter said.
lead_paragraph: Yorkville Endoscopy, the Manhattan clinic where Joan Rivers went into cardiac arrest while being treated for a voice problem, will lose those benefits effective on Jan. 31, the letter said.

headline: After Stabilizing, Overdose Deaths Rose in 2013
abstract: Deaths from drug overdoses rose by 6 percent in 2013 from 2012, the federal government said Monday.
lead_paragraph: Deaths from drug overdoses rose by 6 percent in 2013 from 2012, the federal government said Monday, reversing progress made in 2012, when the national rate, which had long been increasing, appeared to have stabilized. The 2013 increase was driven in part by a 39 percent jump in heroin deaths, the third consecutive year of increases for that drug. Deaths from opioid pain relievers — the biggest cause of drug overdose deaths — were up by about 1 percent in 2013. In 2012, such deaths declined by 5 percent, the first drop since the late 1990s. That decline helped level out drug overdose deaths overall, for an increase of less than 1 percent from 2011 to 2012.

headline: Ethical Questions of Investing in Pot
abstract: The injection of venture capital money into the cannabis industry will put pressure on some emerging fault lines.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the venture capital firm run by Peter Thiel — a co-founder of PayPal and an early investor in Facebook, SpaceX and Spotify — invested millions of dollars in a marijuana company.
