lead_paragraph: On television and in the courtroom, Standard & Poor’s has waged war against a Justice Department lawsuit. But behind the scenes, the giant bond-rating agency wants nothing more than to buy peace.

headline: Interpol Calls for Arrest of Yanukovych and Other Former Ukrainian Officials
abstract: The directive, called a red notice, does not compel any nation to arrest the officials, but declares them to be wanted in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Interpol issued a worldwide directive on Monday seeking the arrest of Viktor F. Yanukovych, the former president of Ukraine, and other former senior officials including Mykola Azarov, who was prime minister, on charges of embezzlement and misappropriation of public funds.

headline: Oklahoma: Request to Delay Four Executions Is Denied
abstract: A federal appeals court on Monday denied the request by four prisoners in Oklahoma to delay their executions, rejecting their claim that the drugs to be used could result in unconstitutional pain and suffering.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Monday denied the request by four prisoners in Oklahoma to delay their executions, now scheduled for this winter, rejecting their claim that the drugs to be used are unreliable and could result in unconstitutional pain and suffering. The decision in the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit, in Denver, appeared to clear the way for the execution on Thursday of Charles F. Warren, which would be the state’s first since the botched lethal injection of Clayton D. Lockett in April. Defense lawyers argued that the sedative used in Mr. Lockett’s case and planned for Mr. Warner, midazolam, has unpredictable effects. But the state said it would multiply the dosage, and has refined procedures to ensure that the drug is properly administered. While defense lawyers said they would appeal to the Supreme Court, legal experts said there was little chance of success.

headline: In China, Projects to Make Great Wall Feel Small
abstract: Despite economic choppiness, the country that built the Great Wall is attaining new superlatives in bridges, tunnels, rail links and other projects of immense size — and expense.
lead_paragraph: DALIAN, China — The plan here seems far-fetched — a $36 billion tunnel that would run twice the length of the one under the English Channel, and bore deep into one of Asia’s active earthquake zones. When completed, it would be the world’s longest underwater tunnel, creating a rail link between two northern port cities.

headline: Paris Attacks Expected to Influence Boston Trial
abstract: A grim reminder of a global struggle adds to the challenge of selecting a jury for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the defendant in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombing, analysts said.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — A pair of brothers viewed as homegrown Islamic terrorists. Horrible acts of violence. Manhunts that forced the lockdown of entire neighborhoods.

headline: Libyan Militants Aligned With Islamic State Claim Kidnapping of 21 Egyptian Christians
abstract: The group claiming to have seized the hostages identified itself as the Tripolitania Province of the Islamic State, named for the region around the capital, Tripoli, in western Libya.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Libyan militants calling themselves part of the Islamic State said on Monday that they were holding captive 21 Egyptian Christians, raising new fears about the extremist group’s spreading influence beyond the battlegrounds of Syria and Iraq.

headline: What’s Wrong With ‘All Lives Matter’?
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Philosophy', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The philosopher Judith Butler argues that we risk missing the fact that black people have not yet been included in the idea of “all lives.”
lead_paragraph: This is the fifth in a series of interviews with philosophers on race that I am conducting for The Stone. This week’s conversation is with Judith Butler, Maxine Elliot Professor in the department of comparative literature and the program of critical theory at the University of California, Berkeley. She is the author of numerous influential books, including “Dispossession: The Performative in the Political,” which she co-authored with Athena Athanasiou. She will publish a book on public assemblies with Harvard University Press this year. — George Yancy

headline: Stellar Passers, Sure, but That May Not Be Enough
abstract: The Packers’ Aaron Rodgers and the Colts’ Andrew Luck are central to their teams’ successes, but they will meet well-rounded opponents in the conference championships.
lead_paragraph: At Stanford, Andrew Luck was immensely hyped as the next great quarterback prospect. The Indianapolis Colts selected him with the first overall pick in 2012, and remarkably, Luck has managed to meet even the highest of expectations. After helping turn a 2-14 team in 2011 into a playoff team in 2012, Luck won his first playoff game during the 2013 season and has now guided the Indianapolis Colts to the A.F.C. championship game.

lead_paragraph: Francesco Rosi, a filmmaker who was fascinated with power, poverty and politics, and whose commitment to social issues made him a direct heir to the traditions of Italian neorealist cinema of the postwar years, died on Saturday in Rome. He was 92.

There were the police encounters, the school visits, the fraught hospital trips — all negotiated without the bureaucratic lubricant of local identification.

After almost two decades on the air with WABC-AM, Seton Hall’s games moved to WMTR-AM — a 7,000-watt station based in Morristown, N.J. But fans were finding only static.

keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Mobile Applications', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The pricing policies of Uber and other car-service apps, like Lyft, were at issue at a transportation committee hearing, where legislation to cap “surge pricing” was introduced.
lead_paragraph: Hypothetically, if there were no traffic on a journey from Times Square to La Guardia Airport, the price of a ride from a car-service app like Uber would be around $41.88. If the journey were to occur around 6 p.m. on a rainy Monday in January, the trip could cost more than twice as much, because Uber increases rates to give drivers incentives to work during peak times.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One woman aboard a subway train died and 83 other people were taken to hospitals here Monday after a downtown Metrorail tunnel filled with smoke during the late afternoon rush, National Transportation Safety Board officials said. Two of the injured were reported to be in critical condition.

headline: Echoes of ’83-84: New York Rivalry Stirs Again

lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — A game against the first-place Islanders is not familiar territory for the Rangers, or any team for that matter. That makes Tuesday night’s clash at Madison Square Garden that much more meaningful.

headline: Obama Assures Netanyahu That U.S. Opposes Palestinians’ Bid to Join Court
abstract: President Obama told Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Monday that the United States opposed the Palestinian Authority’s bid to join the International Criminal Court, the White House said.
lead_paragraph: President Obama told Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Monday that the United States opposed the Palestinian Authority’s bid to join the International Criminal Court, the White House said. Mr. Obama, in a telephone call with Mr. Netanyahu, “reiterated the United States’ position that the Palestinian Authority does not yet constitute a state, and is therefore not eligible” to join the court, the administration said in a statement. President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority moved to join the court last month as part of a strategic shift by the Palestinians to pursue statehood on their own after decades of failed negotiations with Israel brokered by the United States.  Mr. Obama also told Mr. Netanyahu that Washington wanted a comprehensive deal that would prevent Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon, the White House said.

headline: Joan Peters, Journalist Who Wrote on Israeli-Palestinian Conflict, Dies at 78
abstract: In a 1984 book, both widely hailed and criticized, she cited historical documents showing that Arab settlers had flocked to Palestine beginning in the late 1800s; they had not, she wrote, inhabited the land “from time immemorial.”
lead_paragraph: Joan Peters, a journalist whose 1984 book, “From Time Immemorial: The Origins of the Arab-Jewish Conflict Over Palestine,” drew accolades and outrage by arguing that claims of a historical Palestinian homeland in Israel were invented, died on Jan. 5 at her home in Chicago. She was 78.

headline: A Scottish Distillery Celebrates 200 Years by Changing Absolutely Nothing
abstract: In this video, see the making of Laphroaig’s smoky whisky on the rainswept island of Islay.
lead_paragraph: Though whisky experts are divided on whether the spirit has a terroir like wine (flavors reminiscent of the place it was made), one sip of any whisky produced on the Scottish island of Islay is enough to suggest that, yes, indeed it does. The salty sea air and characteristic peat infuse aging casks there with a signature brininess and smokiness — and fierce sense of origin. Large-scale distilleries have inhabited the small Hebridean island since 1779, when Bowmore settled in; a new one called Gartbreck is set to open there this spring. And this year Laphroaig, arguably the smokiest of the distilleries on Islay, celebrates its 200th anniversary.

Elliott looked exhausted, having carried Ohio State to the brink of the inaugural College Football Playoff championship, and it was the least they could do.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (TLC) MY BIG FAT FABULOUS LIFE After Whitney Thore received a diagnosis of polycystic ovarian syndrome, this once slender dancer quickly gained more than 200 pounds. Struggling with self-doubt but still eager to dance for all to see, she posted a performance piece on YouTube last January — and it became a viral hit. Eventually she founded the No Body Shame Campaign, a movement created to promote body acceptance, centered on the motto “Love yourself. Live fully. No excuses. No shame.” This new series follows Ms. Thore as she tries to find happiness through teaching and performing, confronting online bullies, dating and even wearing a bikini on the beach for the first time in a decade.

headline: Anger at Officials’ Expensive Meal Before Deadly Shanghai Stampede
abstract: Public outrage is mounting amid reports that local leaders dined at an expensive Japanese restaurant as 36 people died on New Year’s Eve amid lax security and crowd control.
lead_paragraph: A cover story in the latest issue of Caixin New Century Weekly, a Chinese business magazine, includes important details about the deadly stampede in Shanghai on Dec. 31: how few police officers were on duty, what preceded the sudden crush that killed 36 people and how emergency vehicles were slowed by the huge crowds that had gathered along the city’s famous riverfront to celebrate.

headline: The Point of Order
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: How a 19th-century document still influences the N.Y.P.D. — for better and for worse.
lead_paragraph: The question of whom the police serve, and whose order they impose, is once again up for debate. But it is as old as policing itself. A political cartoon by Charles Jameson Grant, sold for a penny or two on the streets of London around 1834, depicts the British secretary of state addressing members of London’s recently formed Metropolitan Police Force. “My lads,” he says, “you are always justified in breaking the heads of the public when you consider it absolutely necessary for the maintenance of the public peace.” The assembled constables, a rough-looking crew, appear perfectly capable of such a task. “By Jasus I wish your honor would give us a few throats to cut,” one says, “for we have had enough of breaking heads.”

headline: Could Following These Directions Make You Fall in Love With a Stranger?
abstract: What makes two people fall in love?
lead_paragraph: Is there only one, or a small handful, of special someones out there for each of us? Does fate, or perhaps chemistry, make us fall in love?

headline: A Mine Erodes an Andean City
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'Mines and Mining', 'Photography']
abstract: High in the Andes, a smoldering mine eats away at residents whose rich traditions sustained them for generations.
lead_paragraph: In the heart of Cerro de Pasco, a Peruvian city perched 14,000 feet in the Andes, a mile-wide mine pit smolders. For residents, the growls of heavy machinery are background noise. Just as ever-present is the hazardous cocktail of smoke and lead that seeps into their air and water. “As the mine grows in diameter, it eats away at the city and its residents little by little,” said the photographer Paccarik Orue.

headline: Egyptian Judge Voids Mubarak’s Last Standing Conviction and Orders Retrial
abstract: But even before the ruling, former President Hosni Mubarak had already spent enough time in detention to allow his release for time served.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Former President Hosni Mubarak embezzled $17.5 million for personal expenses during his last eight years in power, according to billing statements cited as evidence in his only criminal conviction still standing: $5,455 for four La-Z-Boy recliners, $6,336 on a marble mosaic for a son’s bathroom, $2,018 for a chess set, and hundreds of other items.

headline: Emotion Mixes With Politics as 4 Killed at Paris Market Are Buried in Jerusalem
abstract: Thousands of Israelis, many of them recent immigrants from France, gathered to bury the men, who were killed in a hostage-taking last week.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — They were buried Tuesday not in the land where they had made their homes but in what was described as their homeland. The funeral for the four Jews killed Friday in a terrorist attack on a kosher market in Paris was at once emotional and political, underscoring the tension roiling in recent days between a call for mass immigration to Israel and a demand to protect diaspora communities.

headline: Burberry, McQueen and Others Puncture the Fashion Bubble
abstract: Collections range from escape hatches, like Casely-Hayford, to the fantasy mountain men at Moschino.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The most telling cameo at the four-day men’s wear shows here, the kickoff of the fall 2015 multicity men’s fashion circuit, was not from the three-piece-suited David Gandy, the male model better recognized in his Dolce & Gabbana-ad skivvies; the visiting designers of the American labels Public School and Coach in town to show their wares; or any of the unplaceable Brit rockers at Burberry. It was by the most unlikely guest star of all: the plastic bag, making arguably its most prominent cultural appearance since “American Beauty.”

headline: Inflation in Britain Falls to Lowest Rate in 15 Years
abstract: The decline to 0.5 percent, attributed partly to cheaper gas and stable food prices, is far below the Bank of England’s 2 percent target.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Driven by drastically falling oil prices and lower food prices, British inflation fell to 0.5 percent in December, a steeper drop than was expected and the lowest rate recorded in the past 15 years.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: Flash Your ID
abstract: Tuesday: The no-questions-asked city identification card debuts, temperatures will fall, and the police slowdown is ending.
lead_paragraph: Greetings on this raw Tuesday morning.

headline: Daily Report: Software Start-Up Builds Future on Containers of Code
abstract: A software start-up is in the forefront of a move to package applications much as shipping containers hold physical goods.
lead_paragraph: A tech start-up called DotCloud was on its last legs in 2012. Now called Docker, its software has been downloaded 70 million times, Quentin Hardy reports.

headline: Maison Martin Margiela Changed Its Name, and No One Noticed
abstract: The fashion house’s stealth approach seems to be a master class in how to rebrand under the radar.
lead_paragraph: Yes, I include myself in the above statement, at least initially (might as well get that out of the way early on). Of all the changes that took place on Monday in London as John Galliano unveiled his new look for the house of Margiela (which was mostly an oldish runway look) and a new look for himself (which involved his take on the Margiela uniform: no makeup — or, most likely, no-makeup makeup — hair pulled back in a low ponytail, dark suit under white lab coat), the new look of the brand’s name passed almost unnoticed.

headline: France Mourns Attack Victims and Takes Steps Against Further Terrorism
abstract: Three coffins draped in the French tricolor were laid out in Paris as tribute was paid to the officers who died. In Jerusalem, four other victims were buried.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On a day of mourning and defiance, brave words and choking sadness, funerals were held Tuesday in Israel and France for some of those who died in the attacks in Paris last week, and French leaders sought to prevent further attacks while reaffirming the values that their country regards as its defining strengths.

headline: 1940: Newsie in Paris Jumps to Death
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Paris’ only American news vendor committed suicide in 1940.
lead_paragraph: Ike Meltzer, 41 years old, who brought a Broadway accent and the American style of selling papers to the ‘‘world’s most famous corner’’ — Place de l’Opéra on the Café de la Paix angle — jumped out of the fifth-floor window of a building in the Rue Caumartin Friday noon. He died three hours later in a hospital from injuries sustained in crashing through the skylight on the rear courtyard. The war cut off his supply of American dailies but, even more important, it kept thousands of tourists, who had been his customers, out of the combat zone. Moreover the news-vendor’s wife was seriously ill in London. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 14, 1940

headline: The News From France
abstract: The far-right National Front has made gains following the attack on the offices of Charlie Hebdo.
lead_paragraph: The far-right National Front has made gains following the attack on the offices of Charlie Hebdo.

headline: Today in Politics
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama and congressional leaders will sit down on Tuesday for their first meeting since the Republicans took over Congress.
lead_paragraph: Can’t We All Get Along? Obama and Republicans Give It Another Try

headline: Oil Output Seen Rising, Despite Fall in Its Price
abstract: The Energy Information Administration forecast oil production in the United States of 9.3 million barrels a day in 2015, up from last year, and rising to 9.5 million in 2016.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Even with oil prices continuing to plummet and oil companies decommissioning drilling rigs every day, the Energy Department on Tuesday projected that domestic crude production would continue to rise in 2015, although growth would slow.

headline: Morning Agenda: S.&P. Seeks Peace
abstract: S.&P. is nearing a settlement with the Justice Department over inflated ratings. | Antonio Weiss withdraws from consideration to be a Treasury under secretary. | Oil prices plunge. | Ethical questions of investing in pot.
lead_paragraph: Standard & Poor’s has publicly fought a Justice Department lawsuit, but behind the scenes, the bond-ratings agency now wants peace, Ben Protess reports in DealBook. “After S.&P. mounted a two-year campaign to defeat civil fraud charges ‒ portraying them as retaliation for cutting the credit rating of the United States ‒ the ratings agency is now negotiating with the Justice Department to settle the case, according to people briefed on the matter,” he writes.

headline: MetLife Sues Over Being Named  Too Big to Fail
abstract: The designation is meant to identify big players who could gridlock markets. But MetLife’s chief said the insurer was “simply not that interconnected” to other financial firms.
lead_paragraph: MetLife sued a panel of regulators led by the Treasury secretary on Tuesday to fight its designation as “systemically important,” making it the first financial company to go to court over the issue since the government started singling out so-called too-big-to-fail institutions in an effort to stem any future financial crises.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Jan. 6-12, 2015
abstract: Have you been following the news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more, and look for a new edition each week on Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: Have you been following the news?

headline: Facebook Will Push Amber Alerts to Users’ News Feeds
abstract: Facebook will use its geographic targeting technology to spread the word about abducted children through the news feeds of its American users.
lead_paragraph: Amber Alerts, which already buzz your cellphone, light up highway billboards and appear on television and radio broadcasts, will now start showing up in your Facebook feed, too.

headline: When Spell-Check Can’t Help
abstract: Here’s the latest batch of sound-alike mix-ups, featuring old standbys and new twists. Put them on your watch list.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the latest batch of sound-alike mix-ups, featuring old standbys and new twists.

headline: Christie Speech Points to a Presidential Path
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Elections, Governors', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Property Taxes', 'State of the State Message (NJ)']
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie’s State of the State speech will provide a framework for a potential presidential race.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey will hint at the framework for a potential presidential run in his State of the State speech on Tuesday afternoon by highlighting “just how bad things were” when he won office five years ago and arguing that he “brought New Jersey back from the brink” of financial and political crisis, aides said.

headline: In Performance: Joey Slotnick and C.J. Wilson of ‘Dying for It’
abstract: A scene from Moira Buffini’s dark comedy adapted from Nikolai Erdman’s 1928 play “The Suicide.”
lead_paragraph: This week’s video features the actors Joey Slotnick and C.J. Wilson in a scene from the dark comedy “Dying for It,” an adaptation by the playwright Moira Buffini of Nikolai Erdman’s 1928 play “The Suicide.” Set in Moscow in 1929 over a decade after the Russian revolution, the play tells the story of Semyon Semyonovich (played by Mr. Slotnik), who cannot find a job or any meaning in his life and decides to end it all. In this scene, Semyon discovers that his friend Alexander (Mr. Wilson) is exploiting his proposed suicide for money. The show, directed by Neil Pepe for the Atlantic Theater Company, is at the Linda Gross Theater through Jan. 18.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Years After Aurora Theater Rampage, Colorado Braces for the Trial
keywords: ['Aurora, Colo, Shooting (2012)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Jury System']
abstract: After multiple delays, jury selection is set to begin Jan. 20 in the trial of James E. Holmes, charged with killing 12 people in a movie theater in July 2012.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — To choose a jury in the trial of the man charged with killing 12 people in a packed Colorado movie theater, court officials mailed notices to 9,000 people in suburban Arapahoe County, casting such a wide net that residents ran about a one-in-50 chance of being tapped as potential jurors. An uncle, a father, husbands and friends of people who work in the prosecutor’s office received jury summonses. So did 12 people who are slated to be prosecution witnesses.

headline: Bootleg Liquor Kills at Least 23 in India
abstract: An additional 200 people were seriously sickened after drinking contaminated moonshine in the state of Uttar Pradesh, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — At least 23 people died and 200 others were seriously sickened after drinking contaminated moonshine in the northern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh, the authorities said on Tuesday.

headline: Ascap Names Elizabeth Matthews as Its Chief
abstract: Ms. Matthews, the music licensing agency’s general counsel, succeeds John LoFrumento, who retired in December.
lead_paragraph: Ascap, the giant music licensing agency, has appointed Elizabeth Matthews as its new chief executive, a generational shift as the century-old organization adapts to the digital age.

headline: All Raving, No Working
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A Hasidic man found an unlikely savior early one morning in an ex-partygoer who was still wearing wings.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Honoring Victims of the Attacks
abstract: Hundreds gathered in Jerusalem to bury the four men who were killed last week at a kosher market in Paris, and three slain police officers were honored in France.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds gathered in Jerusalem to bury the four men who were killed last week at a kosher market in Paris, and three slain police officers were honored in France.

headline: Meal Deliveries Endorsed by Lena Dunham and the Like
abstract: In lieu of juice cleanses, more sustainable (and fulfilling) detox plans are finally in vogue — and easy to order.
lead_paragraph: Marissa Lippert, a registered dietician and owner-chef at Nourish Kitchen + Table in New York, offers a little perspective to those hoping to reset in 2015: “The new year gives us the opportunity to set intentions, rather than unattainable resolutions. Diving into a restrictive detox isn’t sustainable, and it’s certainly not any fun.” These four NYC-based meal services, including Lippert’s own, are designed for a less punishing post-holiday recovery than juicing alone. And for those strictly shopping for a little motivation (or not within delivery range), each company below has its own blog full of inspiring meal plans and recipes.

headline: Angelina Jolie on How Japan May View ‘Unbroken’
abstract: The country is still wrestling with its wartime past and there have been calls for a boycott of the film.
lead_paragraph: We’ll know early Thursday whether Angelina Jolie’s “Unbroken,” which, after months of anticipatory hoopla, was toasted by the American Film Institute but received no Golden Globes love, will land one of the Academy’s best picture nominations. Another place where “Unbroken’s” reception remains unknown is Japan, where the book on which the film is based has not been translated and the country’s wartime past is the subject of debate. Though the film has yet to open there, there have been reports of outrage.

headline: Selective Voodoo
abstract: Yay tax cuts, never mind positive effects of spending.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans have passed a measure demanding that the Congressional Budget Office use “dynamic scoring” in its revenue projections — taking into account the supposed positive growth effects of tax cuts. It remains to be seen how much damage this rule will actually cause. The reality is that there is no evidence for the large effects that are central to right-wing ideology, so the question is whether CBO will be forced to accept supply-side fantasies.

headline: Obama Calls for New Laws to Bolster Cybersecurity
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Cyberwarfare', 'Computer Security', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: The president’s effort comes in the wake of a series of high-profile computer breaches, the most recent involving the military’s Central Command.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday called on Congress to pass broad legislation to bolster cybersecurity across the United States government and private industry, working to capitalize on concern about recent high-profile computer breaches to counter an escalating threat.

headline: Ryanair Expects Revised I.A.G. Bid for Irish Airline Aer Lingus
abstract: Ryanair said it would be prepared to consider an offer between 2.50 and 2.70 euros a share from the parent of British Airways.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Ryanair, the largest shareholder of the Irish airline Aer Lingus, said on Tuesday that it expected the parent of British Airways to make another takeover bid for Aer Lingus as soon as this week.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Hitler and Obama
abstract: A Texas congressman compared the president to the Nazi leader.
lead_paragraph: Randy Weber is a U.S. Representative from Texas. His tweet below contains a very important parenthetical.

headline: Museum of Fine Arts, Houston Unveils Expansion Design
abstract: The museum has revealed designs for a redevelopment of its 14-acre campus, including a 164,000-square-foot-building and a new home for the Glassell School of Art.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Fine Arts, Houston on Tuesday is to reveal designs by Steven Holl Architects for a redevelopment of its 14-acre campus, including a master plan; a 164,000-square-foot-building for 20th- and 21st-century art; and a new, 80,000-square-foot home for the Glassell School of Art.

headline: Amazon Signs Woody Allen to Write and Direct TV Series
abstract: Woody Allen will make his first television series, a full season of half-hour episodes, available only on Amazon’s Prime streaming service.
lead_paragraph: After more than four decades of making films, Woody Allen is coming to television — streaming television.

headline: Why Are We Obsessed With the Great American Novel?
abstract: Cheryl Strayed and Adam Kirsch try to get to the bottom of our long-running obsession with the Great American Novel.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Cheryl Strayed and Adam Kirsch try to get to the bottom of our long-running obsession with the Great American Novel.

headline: Pakistan Executes Terrorism Convicts During a Visit by Kerry
abstract: Pakistan lifted a six-year moratorium on executions after the Taliban assault on a school in Peshawar on Dec. 16 that killed 150 people, most of them children.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan executed seven prisoners on Tuesday, including one who had been convicted of taking part in an attack on an American Consulate, as part of a broader crackdown on militancy after last month’s school massacre in Peshawar.

headline: Want to Be Happy? Join a Union
keywords: ['Collective Bargaining', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Organized Labor', 'Productivity', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Research', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: The institution may be at a historic low in size, but a new study suggests that membership has psychological benefits.
lead_paragraph: Fewer and fewer Americans belong to a union. Membership is down to a historic low of 11.2 percent of the work force, and only 6.7 percent of workers in the private sector.

headline: For G.O.P., Precedent to Cooperate and Shed Its ‘Party of No’ Label
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: After midterm elections in 1986 and 2006, the White House and Congress cooperated on bills to expand Medicare and the minimum wage. Now the parties in power are reversed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Shelley Moore Capito’s optimism about winning a seat in the Senate is tempered by another reality.

headline: Share Your Experiences After the Paris Attacks
abstract: The New York Times would like to hear from Europeans, particularly Muslims, about their experiences.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times would like to hear from Europeans, particularly Muslims, about their experiences.

headline: 1965: Good Skiing Near Madrid
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: skiing was growing popular near Madrid in 1965.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — ‘‘Skiing in Spain’’ exclaim some with more than a hint of disbelief. Yes, indeed. After only an hour’s drive from Madrid it’s possible to be on the snow-covered slopes of the Guadarrama mountains schussing and slaloming. Skiing is not new to Spain or Spaniards. Navacerrada, the ski center near this capital, has been in existence since before the Spanish Civil War. But it is since the war that it has really developed. If there is any doubt that Spaniards like to ski, figures show that on an average Sunday as many as 12,000 of them appear at Navacerrada. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 14, 1965

headline: Suburban Poverty, Hidden on Tree-Lined Streets
abstract: Maybe, back when we had so much more of it, I left enough money in a coat pocket to buy the gallon of milk I can’t afford now.
lead_paragraph: Sticking my hands between the cushions, I blindly dig through the maze of lint and mashed-up cracker pieces. Coming up empty handed, I start to pick at the thin layer of dust that has collected beneath my fingernails. Nervously, I start on my cuticles as well, as I often do when I am stressed.

headline: Rikers to Ban Isolation for Inmates 21 and Younger
abstract: The plan, which would take effect next January, would be highly unusual and would place Rikers at the forefront of national jail reform efforts.
lead_paragraph: New York City officials agreed on Tuesday to a plan that would eliminate the use of solitary confinement for all inmates 21 and younger, a move that would place the long-troubled Rikers Island complex at the forefront of national jail reform efforts.

headline: Eric Church, Ariana Grande and Madonna Among Grammy Performers
abstract: The performances at the 57th annual Grammy Awards on Feb. 8 will cover the pop landscape.
lead_paragraph: The performances at the 57th annual Grammy Awards next month will cover the pop landscape from self-proclaimed country outsider Eric Church, who has four nominations, to the next-generation diva Ariana Grande, who has two, the Recording Academy said on Tuesday.

headline: At 78, McCain Savors a New Dream Job in the Senate
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: John McCain, who is certain that he would have made a better commander in chief than President Obama, takes the reins of the Senate Armed Services Committee.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One by one, Senator John McCain’s fellow prisoners from the Vietnam War have been dying, and at 78, he said, he is aware more than ever that his time will come, too. “Every single day,” he mused in an interview, “is a day less that I am going to be able to serve in the Senate.”

headline: Verbatim: Boehner on 2016
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner responded “May the best person win,” when asked if Mitt Romney deserves a third chance at running for president.
lead_paragraph: — Speaker John A. Boehner, when asked if Mitt Romney deserves a third chance at running for president.

headline: New Bronx Senior Center Aims to Provide a More Welcoming Atmosphere
abstract: The space, which will offer programs and hot lunches, is part of a $1.5 million expansion of services for older lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people.
lead_paragraph: Tom Esola has become a regular at a senior center in Midtown Manhattan, where he drops by two to three times a week to see friends, sit down to shepherd’s pie dinners, volunteer in the computer room and even try a tango lesson.

headline: Quarterback Is a Work in Progress, but Oh, What Progress
abstract: Ohio State’s Cardale Jones went from serving as a backup to winning a title in four games, but the greatest measure of his growth may be his new understanding of the game and his role in it.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Cardale Jones was not the most valuable player of college football’s national championship game Monday night. That honor went to the sensational sophomore running back Ezekiel Elliott, his Ohio State teammate, who alternated between safety net and battering ram in the Buckeyes’ 42-20 pulverizing of Oregon.

headline: Spring for Music Festival to Be Reborn in Washington
abstract: Shift: A Festival of American Orchestras, will bring four or five North American orchestras to Washington, for performances at the Kennedy Center and community outreach and education.
lead_paragraph: It turns out that spring will come again after all, or at least something like it.

headline: Kamala Harris Announces Senate Bid in California
abstract: Kamala Harris, the California attorney general, announced on Tuesday she is running for the Senate seat that is opening up with Barbara Boxer’s retirement at the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — No exploratory committees here. Kamala D. Harris, the California attorney general, announced on Tuesday that she was running for the Senate seat that is opening up with Barbara Boxer’s impending retirement.

headline: A Lost City Haunted by Crooks and Nazis
abstract: Three Patrick Modiano novellas, newly translated from the French, summon up an older version of his native city.
lead_paragraph: There are many adjectives you can use to describe the fiction of the French novelist Patrick Modiano, winner of the 2014 Nobel Prize in Literature. “Elusive” is often among them. “Timely” rarely is.

headline: Jazz Festivals in New Orleans and Newport Name Lineups
keywords: ['Jazz', 'Music', 'New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival', 'Newport Jazz Festival']
abstract: Elton John, the Who and the new partnership of Tony Bennett and Lady Gaga will headline in New Orleans; Newport will include Dr. John and Arturo O’Farrill’s Latin Jazz Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: Two of the country’s most significant summer jazz festivals have announced their lineups: the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival and the Newport Jazz Festival.

headline: Many Who Take a Daily Aspirin Don’t Need It
abstract: Many healthy people take a daily aspirin to reduce the risk of heart disease and stroke, but a new study has found that more than 11 percent of them should not be doing so.
lead_paragraph: Many healthy people take a daily aspirin to reduce the risk of heart disease and stroke, but a new study has found that more than 11 percent of them should not be doing so.

headline: Charlie Hebdo’s Defiant Muhammad Cover Fuels Debate on Free Speech
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Newspapers', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists']
abstract: Six days after the attack on Charlie Hebdo, Muslim groups in France, Egypt and elsewhere said the newspaper’s new cover would exacerbate tensions.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Immediately upon unveiling its new cover — a depiction of Muhammad — the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo on Tuesday reignited the debate pitting free speech against religious sensitivities that has embroiled Europe since 12 people were killed during an attack on its Paris offices by Muslim extremists a week ago.

headline: New Report Urges Less Intervention in Births
abstract: “If overtreatment is defined as instances in which an individual may have fared as well or better with less or perhaps no intervention,” says a new report, “then modern obstetric care has landed in a deep quagmire.”
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, Britain’s national health service advised healthy women that it was safer to have their babies at home, or in a birth center, than in a hospital. For low-risk mothers-to-be, giving birth in a traditional maternity ward increased the chances of surgical intervention.

headline: Pope Francis’ Remarks in Sri Lanka
abstract: Pope Francis addressed an interfaith audience in Sri Lanka, calling for healing and unity after the country’s civil war.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis addressed an interfaith audience in Sri Lanka, calling for healing and unity after the country’s civil war.

headline: Alibaba Will Help Curb Export of Recalled Items
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The Chinese e-commerce group has agreed to prevent the export of dangerous items recalled by the Consumer Product Safety Commission.
lead_paragraph: Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce company, has a new partner in rooting out products deemed unsafe for American consumers, but the cooperation could also bring it more headaches.

headline: One Democrat Announces While Others Ponder a Race for the Senate in California
abstract: The attorney general, Kamala D. Harris, plans to run for the Senate seat opening up with Barbara Boxer’s retirement. Tom Steyer, the billionaire environmentalist, said he was also considering a run.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — No exploratory committees here: Kamala D. Harris, the California attorney general, announced on Tuesday that she was running for the Senate seat that is opening up with Barbara Boxer’s retirement.

headline: For Li Na, Retirement Has Been a Busy Time
abstract: Li, who won the Australian Open last year, retired in September, but has maintained many commitments in the tennis and business worlds.
lead_paragraph: Uncertainty abounds heading into the Australian Open, the first Grand Slam event of the season, which begins next week in Melbourne. But one thing is for sure: There will be a different champion on the women’s side. Li Na, who won the Australian Open last year after being runner-up in 2011 and 2013, retired in September because of persistent knee problems. Li, who became the first Grand Slam singles champion from Asia when she won the French Open in 2011, reached a career high of No. 2 last year.

headline: Verbatim: United by Football
abstract: President Obama met with congressional leaders on Tuesday in the Cabinet Room of the White House.
lead_paragraph: — President Obama to Speaker John A. Boehner during a meeting with congressional leaders on Tuesday. Mr. Boehner is from Ohio and is a fan of Ohio State, which won last night’s championship game against Oregon, 42-20.

headline: Seeing Beauty in ‘Talking Heads’
abstract: The filmmaker behind the shortlisted documentary “The Kill Team” argues that we shouldn’t dismiss this closeup as it says so much about the characters in a story.
lead_paragraph: At the core of “The Kill Team,” one of 15 films shortlisted for the best documentary Oscar, is a moral dilemma with life-and-death consequences.

headline: New Analysis Challenges Arguments for Repealing Tax on Medical Devices
keywords: ['Medical Devices', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: A report by the Congressional Research Service found that many concerns among medical device manufacturers about a tax under the Affordable Care Act were unfounded.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A tax on medical devices, imposed by the Affordable Care Act, has become a prime target for Republicans, some Democrats and a small army of lobbyists for the industry. But a new report from the Congressional Research Service challenges economic arguments that are being made to justify repealing the tax.

headline: Upland
abstract: Classic California cuisine on Park Avenue South
lead_paragraph: Classic California cuisine on Park Avenue South

headline: Restaurant Review: Upland on Park Avenue South
abstract: A large space and vast menu cannot overshadow Justin Smillie’s classic California cuisine at Upland.
lead_paragraph: “Go to Upland” is my current answer to anybody who asks for a good new place to eat in Manhattan. It will probably remain my answer for some time. The recommendation is the same for fetishists who unwind by reconstructing recipes from the court of Catherine de Medici as for parishioners in the Church of St. Rachael. It holds for drinkers who are on the lookout for unexplored grapes and for those who call all white wine chardonnay. The only diners I would not send to Upland are the ones who categorically refuse to take any meals along Park Avenue South. Their loss.

headline: Mix Diskerud Signs With New York City F.C.
abstract: Diskerud, 24, bolsters a midfield — and a club — trying to regain its footing since the announcement that another of the team’s high-profile signings would not arrive until July.
lead_paragraph: New York City F.C. completed the signing of midfielder Mix Diskerud on Tuesday, bolstering a midfield — and a club — trying to regain its footing since the recent announcement that another of its high-profile signings would not arrive in time for the start of the team’s inaugural season.

headline: Rage and Reaganolatry
abstract: Defending the legend, no matter what.
lead_paragraph: A bit more on the curious back and forth between myself and Robert Samuelson. It started when I made the commonplace point that normally the Fed, not the White House, is responsible for managing booms and busts, and that the great disinflation of the 1980s was basically a story of a Fed-imposed recession, and had little if anything to do with Reagan’s supply-side tax cuts.

Putin of Russia will not be attending the 70th anniversary commemoration of the liberation of the Auschwitz concentration camps, his spokesman told a Moscow radio station on Tuesday. The spokesman said that the president’s schedule was too packed and that he was not invited.

Chris Christie delivered his State of the State address on Tuesday, it sounded less like the valedictory of a presidential hopeful on his way to bigger and better things than a defensive move by a politician anticipating the shots that could be leveled against him.

headline: MetLife’s Decision to Challenge Regulators May Backfire
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: MetLife’s stance to challenge the decision to designate it a “systemically important financial institution” carries risks, writes Rob Cox of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Challenging regulators can often come back to bite you. JPMorgan Chase proved this by publicly questioning the reforms of the Dodd-Frank Act and then privately failing to rein in some particularly problematic behavior by some of its traders. That’s what makes MetLife’s decision to take its watchdogs to court so surprising.

headline: Supreme Court Takes Broad View on Hostage-Taker’s Penalty
abstract: Bank robbers are subject to mandatory 10-year sentence increases if they force others to accompany them for even very short distances, the Supreme Court ruled.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday unanimously ruled that bank robbers are subject to mandatory 10-year sentences if they force others to accompany them, even for very short distances.

headline: A Vintage-Inspired New Video From the Singer-Songwriter Tom Brosseau
abstract: “Roll Along”‘s retro vibe complements the singer’s narrative-style folk sound.
lead_paragraph: “I have all these cinematic ideas, but when it comes to filming it’s all Greek to me,” says Tom Brosseau about “Roll Along with Me,” the first single and video from his forthcoming album, “Perfect Abandon.” Luckily, Brosseau found a kindred spirit and co-conspirator in the director Andrew van Baal early on in his career. The two met in San Diego in the early 2000s, and since then, van Baal has directed a number of music videos for Brosseau, as well as casting him as the lead in van Baal’s 2012 short film, “Wonder Valley.”

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An incident Monday in which one passenger was killed and scores were hurt when smoke filled a Washington Metro car during a chaotic rush hour commute has raised new concerns about Washington’s aging, troubled transit system.

headline: Three Signs Pointing to Bigger Raises in 2015
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Small Business', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: New data suggests pay raises may become more commonplace, providing workers — who have endured years of stagnant wages — with some relief.
lead_paragraph: All eyes are on wages. For workers who have faced six years of stagnant pay, Federal Reserve officials trying to decide when they can safely raise interest rates, or anyone who wants the United States economy to experience a truly robust recovery, the single biggest question about the economy in 2015 is whether pay raises will become more commonplace.

headline: MoMA to Sell a Monet in London
abstract: Monet’s “Les Peupliers à Giverny” is estimated to sell for $13.8 million to $18.4 million; the proceeds will benefit the Museum of Modern Art’s acquisitions fund.
lead_paragraph: The cover of Sotheby’s London Impressionist and modern art sale catalog features “Les Peupliers à Giverny,’’ one of Monet’s depictions of poplar trees in the fields at the edge of his property in Giverny. Painted in 1887, it captures the sunset of early autumn. Sotheby’s is auctioning the work on Feb. 3; it is estimated to sell for $13.8 million to $18.4 million.

headline: Richard Branson Enters the City Hotel Scene
abstract: The billionaire British entrepreneur is introducing Virgin Hotels in the United States, with the first set to open in Chicago on Jan. 15.
lead_paragraph: Sir Richard Branson, the billionaire British entrepreneur, has created hundreds of enterprises, from airlines to mobile phone businesses to a cruise line, and oversees more than 50,000 employees. One of his most recent ventures, the space tourism company Virgin Galactic, had a significant setback in November: a pilot was killed in a flight test accident just months before commercial service was to begin. (“We continue to be excited by the challenge of space — and make no mistake it is a huge challenge,” Mr. Branson said. “I am extremely proud of the team in Mojave who are driving our program forward.”)

headline: Restaurant Report: Café ArtScience in Cambridge, Mass.
abstract: A Harvard bioengineering professor opens his latest venture, which aims to blend a French-American menu with palatable technology.
lead_paragraph: If David Edwards was ever told as a child not to play with his food, he didn’t listen. The Harvard bioengineering professor and founder of the design center Le Laboratoire in Paris has invented, among other things, WikiPearl, edible, skinlike packaging for everything from ice cream to water, and Le Whaf, which turns things like cocktails and soup into inhalable vapor. Both are available at his latest venture, Café ArtScience, which opened in October near M.I.T. alongside the first stateside version of Le Laboratoire — and aims to blend a French-American menu with palatable technology.

headline: Verbatim: Exploring All Options
abstract: John McCain encouraged Lindsey Graham to consider running for president.
lead_paragraph: — Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, encouraged his friend Mr. Graham, of South Carolina, to consider a bid for president after being asked about Mitt Romney’s announcement that he may run for a third time.

headline: Covering the Knicks: A Reporter’s Dilemma
abstract: Scott Cacciola is taking a sabbatical from covering his usual beat: the New York Knicks. Jason Stallman, his editor, explains why.
lead_paragraph: Last week, basketball fans may have noticed that The Times’s dedicated Knicks reporter, Scott Cacciola, was writing about something different: an undefeated women’s college basketball team from Kansas playing in Missouri. On Monday, he reported on a Division III college basketball rivalry in Michigan.

headline: Audra McDonald and Alan Cumming in a Reading of ‘Kiss of the Spider Woman’
abstract: A multiday reading of the show, with Ms. McDonald, Mr. Cumming and Steven Pasquale, suggests a stage revival could be in the works.
lead_paragraph: Could a Broadway revival of the acclaimed musical “Kiss of the Spider Woman” be on the horizon? A multiday reading of the show, the 1993 Tony Award winner for best musical, was held last week with three big theater names playing the major roles: Audra McDonald as the title character, Alan Cumming as the gay prisoner Molina, and Steven Pasquale as the Marxist revolutionary Valentin. The Tony-winning director John Tiffany (“Once”) oversaw the reading, which was organized by the producer Tom Kirdahy (“It’s Only a Play”). Mr. Kirdahy is married to the show’s book writer, Terrence McNally, and is working with the “Spider Woman” composer, John Kander, on this spring’s Broadway revival of “The Visit.” (“Spider Woman” has lyrics by Fred Ebb.)

headline: The Met’s Groundbreaking “Henry’s Show” Gets a Reprise
abstract: “The New York School, 1969: Henry Geldzahler at the Metropolitan Museum of Art,” includes many works curated by Geldzahler in his trailblazing contemporary exhibition.
lead_paragraph: “I’m Henry — just Henry.” Indeed, that sensibility served Henry Geldzahler well. The charismatic curator, short in stature and large in vitality, in 1969 convinced that stodgiest of institutions — the Metropolitan Museum of Art — to, for a blockbuster exhibition, swap its Rembrandts and Renoirs for Rosenquists and Rauschenbergs. Formally titled “New York Painting and Sculpture: 1940-1970,” the exhibition was colloquially dubbed “Henry’s Show,” which stuck in the history books as its proper name. That show contained nearly 410 works by more than 40 artists — the very catalysts of contemporary art whose fabled exploits, fueled by creativity, community and feuds, composed the history of the New York School. And many of these artists counted Geldzahler as a close personal friend. Frank Stella famously said, “The thing about Henry was that he lived with us. Other curators don’t live with artists.” Another thing about Geldzahler, according to David Hockney: “Henry had a fantastic eye. He wasn’t wrong about anything. He was always right.”

headline: Bill de Blasio and the N.Y.P.D.: Everyone Calls for an Apology
abstract: Whose hurt feelings matter most?
lead_paragraph: In New York City, a former mayor, Rudy Giuliani, is demanding that the current mayor, Bill de Blasio, apologize to the New York Police Department for hurting its feelings. The head of the police union, Patrick Lynch, and former Police Commissioner, Raymond Kelly, are saying the same thing — that all the bitterness between Mr. de Blasio and the police would evaporate, and everything would be O.K., if only the mayor would say he was sorry.

headline: Obama Is Planning New Rules on Oil and Gas Industry’s Methane Emissions
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Methane', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Executive Privilege, Doctrine of', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The president will use his executive authority to issue the first federal regulations to target emissions of the powerful greenhouse gas, according to a person familiar with the plans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In President Obama’s latest move using executive authority to tackle climate change, White House officials on Wednesday announced plans to impose new regulations on the oil and gas industry’s emissions of methane, a powerful greenhouse gas. The administration’s goal is to cut methane emissions from oil and gas production by up to 45 percent by 2025 from the levels recorded in 2012.

headline: A Reason to Believe in the Buckeyes
abstract: Ezekiel Elliott, the title game’s most valuable player, had 246 yards on 36 carries against Oregon — and 696 yards and eight touchdowns in his last three games over all.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — With 28 seconds left in the national championship game, Ohio State running back Ezekiel Elliott scored his fourth and final touchdown. After celebrating in the end zone, he ran to the sideline, where he slapped hands with one of the most famous athletes in the world, LeBron James, who banged Elliott’s helmet with pride as Elliott jogged off to be with his teammates.

headline: In Search for Love, Pitfalls Prevail
abstract: “Man Seeking Woman,” on FXX, created by Simon Rich, follows an Everyman as he navigates the dating world.
lead_paragraph: “Man Seeking Woman,” a wispily surreal anti-romantic comedy beginning on Wednesday on FXX, has an all-star team of writing and directing talent working to keep it airborne. Lorne Michaels of “Saturday Night Live” is an executive producer, and other key players include Ian Maxtone-Graham (“The Simpsons”), Jonathan Krisel (“Portlandia,” “Kroll Show”), Robert Padnick (“The Office”) and Dan Mirk (“Onion News Network”).

abstract: Athletes at the 2014 Winter Games barrel down an icy chute at 80 miles per hour and fly more than the length of a football field off a jump, among other physical feats. In these videos, learn their tricks and techniques — and then see how they used them to take home the gold.

lead_paragraph: For members of the press, Harold Holzer has been as much a staple of the Metropolitan Museum of Art as the Arms and Armor wing. He seemed to try to move on before — in 2005, when he was given additional responsibility for visitor services and the Multicultural Audience Development Initiative, and in 2013, when he assumed the new title of senior vice president for public affairs.

headline: Preparing for a Life Without the Male Gaze
abstract: Two shows by Michelle Ellsworth and Jeremy Wade at the American Realness festival dealt with disappearance and decline.
lead_paragraph: If you wanted to spend some time contemplating death — your own, other people’s — Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side was a good place to be on Monday night. As part of the American Realness festival, two very different shows — Michelle Ellsworth’s cheerfully wacky “Preparation for the Obsolescence of the Y Chromosome” and a much darker work by Jeremy Wade with an obscenity in its title — grappled with disappearance, decline and the thin line between being here and being gone.

headline: From the Prosaic, Evoking a Sadness Under the Surface
abstract: The American Realness dance and performance festival presented four premieres at the Abrons Arts Center on Monday, including works by Miguel Gutierrez and Tere O’Connor.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Benjamin Snapp Pryor is the producer of American Realness, a dance and performance festival that he founded in 2010. He is also the manager of several artists. His main client is Miguel Gutierrez, who has appeared at American Realness every year. At the Abrons Arts Center on Monday, the festival presented four premieres. One was by the excellent Tere O’Connor. One was Mr. Gutierrez’s latest work, “Age & Beauty Part 2: Asian Beauty @ the Werq Meeting or The Choreographer & Her Muse or &:@&.”

headline: 10 Are Killed in Ukraine as Diplomacy Hits a Wall

headline: ‘France Without Jews Is Not France’
abstract: Feeling insecure and isolated, some French Jews are asking themselves if they have a future in France.
lead_paragraph: Long before Chérif Kouachi burst into the offices of Charlie Hebdo last Wednesday with his brother Saïd to assassinate the journalists and cartoonists gathered at the satirical magazine’s weekly editorial meeting, he had a dream. Mr. Kouachi wanted, according to testimony given at a 2008 court hearing, to “burn synagogues,” “vandalize Jewish stores in Paris” and “terrorize the Jews.” We know that dream was shared by Amedy Coulibaly, the gunman who laid siege to a kosher supermarket in Paris on Friday and killed four of the terrified hostages — Yoav Hattab, Yohan Cohen, Philippe Braham and François-Michel Saada — for one reason: They were Jews.

headline: Revisiting a Soviet Ballet That Was Banned in 1931
abstract: The exhibition “Bolt” at the Gallery for Russian Arts and Design in London gives vivid life to a ballet and to the way it exemplified a cultural moment in postrevolutionary Soviet Russia.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For most in the West, ballet history moves from the establishment of classicism in Russia in the 19th century (“Swan Lake,” “Sleeping Beauty”) to the early-20th-century innovations of Diaghilev’s Ballets Russes, which shifted the center of balletic gravity to the West. But while the radical propositions of Fokine, Nijinsky and Balanchine were playing out under the Ballets Russes banner in Paris and London during the first decades of the 20th century, an entirely different current and aesthetic — almost completely unknown and unseen outside of Russia — was flourishing under Soviet rule.

headline: After Moguls Come Life’s Bumps
abstract: Hannah Kearney, a former Olympic champion and a World Cup mainstay who is set to retire, is headed back to school to aid in her transition to life after sports.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — On a dais with eight other members of the United States national ski and snowboarding team, Hannah Kearney, owner of Olympic gold and bronze medals in freestyle moguls, was asked last week if a recent World Cup victory — the 43rd of her career — gave her reason to reconsider her retirement at season’s end.

headline: A Concert Hall in Paris Aims to Bridge Divides
abstract: The Philharmonie de Paris, a concert hall designed by Jean Nouvel, finally opens on Wednesday after seven years and long delays.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The new concert hall here, the Philharmonie de Paris, rises like a flight of doves, its sprawling waves of concrete and steel designed by the star architect Jean Nouvel to symbolize the end of the “eternal ostracism” of the struggling neighborhoods nearby.

headline: Ruben Ostlund’s ‘Involuntary,’ ‘Play’ and ‘The Guitar Mongoloid’
abstract: The Film Society of Lincoln Center is holding a retrospective of Ruben Ostlund’s movies through Jan. 22.
lead_paragraph: Ruben Ostlund achieved a modest breakthrough with his fourth feature, “Force Majeure,” Sweden’s submission for the Oscars, but his interest in social expectations and machismo is hardly new. The Film Society of Lincoln Center is holding a retrospective of Mr. Ostlund’s movies through Jan. 22. The series, titled In Case of No Emergency: The Films of Ruben Ostlund, includes the three features that preceded “Force Majeure,” all receiving their first runs in New York.

headline: The Returned
abstract: A generation of adoptees brought up in America is moving back to South Korea — and raising soul-searching questions about international adoption.
lead_paragraph: A generation of adoptees brought up in America is moving back to South Korea — and raising soul-searching questions about international adoption.

headline: A History of Christianity, With No Strings Attached
abstract: Three cardinals take the place of the puppets in their traveling theater to teach the history of Christianity in “The Cardinals.”
lead_paragraph: The long, tumultuous history of Christianity reels by like a silly cartoon in “The Cardinals,” an uninspired and interminable show being presented as part of the Under the Radar festival. The concept behind the production, which comes from a theater troupe called Stan’s Cafe of Birmingham, England, posits that three cardinals are “on an evangelical mission to broaden knowledge of the Bible — through their traveling puppet theater,” according to a note on the Public Theater website. Alas, the puppets get lost in transit, so the cardinals must jump into the fray to enact famous scenes from the Old and New Testaments.

lead_paragraph: Mountain views in California, a colonial-style house in Massachusetts and a lakeside setting in Minnesota

headline: Songs of Experience and Songs of Affirmation
abstract: Dr. Dog, whose music unabashedly harks back to the LP era, has consolidated its own style.
lead_paragraph: Weariness, isolation, loneliness, futility, imminent collapse — those are situations Dr. Dog likes to sing about, in music that solidly contradicts any such sentiments. “What does it take to be lonesome? Nothing at all!,” band members sang, in hearty harmony over rowdy guitars, as they wound up their set at the Music Hall of Williamsburg on Monday night, a show that was webcast on Yahoo.

abstract: President Obama visited the National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center in Arlington, Va., on Tuesday, a day after hackers claiming to be working on behalf of the Sunni militant group known as the Islamic State took over the Twitter and YouTube accounts of the United States Central Command.

headline: As Bitcoin’s Price Slides, Signs of a Squeeze
abstract: Some miners of the virtual currency are starting to feel the effects of a sustained decline in prices.
lead_paragraph: The price of Bitcoin slid further on Tuesday, dipping to its lowest level since the spring of 2013.  The downward spiral, which began early last year, suggests that confidence in the virtual currency may be dwindling.

headline: A Dance Instructor Amid Twists and Reversals
abstract: In “Match,” Patrick Stewart plays a dance professor at Juilliard who becomes involved in a confrontation with a woman interviewing him for her dissertation and her husband.
lead_paragraph: It may be a tribute to Patrick Stewart’s performance in “Match” that it takes some time to be sure that it’s a good performance. As Tobi, a dance instructor at Juilliard, Mr. Stewart offers a study in self-protective vanity. The character — flamboyant, forever peppering his chatter with French phrases and far too insistent that his guests eat the party mix — is at once extroverted and antisocial, a combination easy to overplay.

headline: With Every Ankle’s Jingle, a Vibrant Blend of Grace and Precision
abstract: The Music Academy in Chennai featured some of India’s most distinguished dancers, as well as ones on the ascendance.
lead_paragraph: CHENNAI, India — The Tamil month of Margazhi runs from mid-December to mid-January. In this city, the capital of the state of Tamil Nadu, it abounds with dance festivals. Specialists in the classical dance forms of India fly in from around the world to perform — barefoot, wearing anklets laden with tiny bells, elaborate costumes, ornaments and jewels.

headline: At Scalise Event, Protesters Outnumber Reporters. Barely.
abstract: Despite some build-up by civil rights groups, just 11 protesters lined the sidewalk outside the Capitol Hill Club at an event for Representative Steve Scalise, under fire for appearing in front of white supremacists more than a decade ago.
lead_paragraph: Blame it on the wind chill or the midafternoon hour, but a demonstration Tuesday outside an event for Representative Steve Scalise, the Louisiana Republican who has been under fire for speaking to a group of white supremacists in 2002, drew only slightly more protesters than reporters.

headline: When Ambition, Privilege and Money Entangle Lives
abstract: “Human Capital,” directed by Paolo Virzì, tells a sociopolitical story through distinct chapters, each from a different point of view and in service of an overly neat-and-tidy moral.
lead_paragraph: A tale of two families and one ruinously divided country, “Human Capital” plunges a large spike into the heart of the Italian rich and its ravenous middle-class aspirants. Smoothly schematic and ferociously unsentimental, the movie has been separated into several alternating voices, but its overall trajectory mirrors the arc of the sweeping double staircase that fronts the wealthy family’s mansion. Each side of the staircase leads to the same luxurious entrance and all that shimmers and gleams beyond, except that not everyone manages the climb with equal success.

abstract: Solo had faced two counts of fourth-degree misdemeanor assault after what was described in court papers as an alcohol-fueled scuffle with her half-sister and her teenage nephew last June.
lead_paragraph: A judge dismissed misdemeanor assault charges against United States goalkeeper Hope Solo on Tuesday, most likely clearing the way for her to participate in the Women’s World Cup this summer in Canada.

headline: Christie to Announce PAC as Republicans Eye Donors
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie is preparing to take his first concrete step toward a presidential campaign by setting up a PAC as early as this month that could help finance travel and provide a fund-raising vehicle for would-be donors, according to three supporters involved in the discussions.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is preparing to take his first concrete steps toward a presidential bid by setting up a leadership political action committee as early as this month that could help pay for travel and provide a fund-raising vehicle for would-be donors, three supporters involved in the discussions said.

headline: Al Bendich, Defender of ‘Howl’ and Lenny Bruce’s Comedy, Is Dead at 85
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: As a young lawyer, Mr. Bendich argued the two landmark obscenity cases, providing the legal rationales for the judge to find in favor of the defense both times.
lead_paragraph: Al Bendich, a lawyer who successfully defended the right to free speech in two landmark midcentury obscenity cases — involving Allen Ginsberg’s poem “Howl” and Lenny Bruce’s nightclub act — died on Jan. 5 in Oakland, Calif. He was 85.

lead_paragraph: Two and a half years after stepping down as a co-anchor on NBC’s “Today” show, Ann Curry is leaving her full-time position at NBC News for a new role that will allow her to report for NBC and other outlets.

lead_paragraph: G. G. Michelson, who helped dismantle barriers for women as a longtime executive of R. H. Macy & Company, as an adviser to mayors and often as the only female member of corporate boards, died on Saturday at her home in Greenwich Village. She was 89.

She also became a professional tennis coach for the first time, agreeing to join the team of the Polish star Agnieszka Radwanska, who has entertained many with her large bag of tricks but has yet to win a Grand Slam title.

headline: Georgia: Fight Over King Legacy Is Closer to Trial
abstract: Lawyers for Bernice King, the daughter of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., squared off Tuesday against lawyers for Dr. King’s estate in an effort to resolve the disputed ownership of the slain civil rights leader’s Bible and Nobel Prize.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Bernice King, the daughter of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., squared off Tuesday against lawyers for Dr. King’s estate in an effort to resolve the disputed ownership of the slain civil rights leader’s Bible and Nobel Prize. But a Fulton County Superior Court judge declined to side with either party, raising the possibility of a February trial. Ms. King contends that the items do not belong to the Estate of Martin Luther King Jr. Inc. The estate’s three directors are Ms. King and her two brothers, Dexter King and Martin Luther King III. The brothers voted earlier to sell the items. Ms. King objects to a sale.

headline: In New Congress, Wall St. Pushes to Undermine Dodd-Frank Reform
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Law and Legislation', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The continuing assault on the 2010 Dodd-Frank law has achieved remarkable success, especially compared with the repeated failures of opponents of another 2010 law, the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the span of a month, the nation’s biggest banks and investment firms have twice won passage of measures to weaken regulations intended to help lessen the risk of another financial crisis, setting their sights on narrow, arcane provisions and greasing their efforts with a surge of lobbying and campaign contributions.

headline: Tesla Chief Asks Makers to Support Electric Cars
abstract: Elon Musk said high fuel prices could no longer be expected to drive consumers toward alternative vehicles.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Elon Musk, chief executive of the electric car company Tesla, urged traditional automakers to step up their efforts at electrifying automobiles, saying that with gasoline prices hovering in the $2-a-gallon range, high fuel prices can no longer be expected to drive consumers toward alternatives.

headline: Islam’s Problem With Blasphemy
abstract: Muslims should simply ignore insults to their faith, the Quran says.
lead_paragraph: WILL “moderate Muslims” finally “speak up” against their militant coreligionists? People around the world have asked (but, as in the past, have not all seriously examined) this question since last week’s horrific attacks on the French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo and on a kosher supermarket in Paris.

abstract: With a Republican majority in Congress looking to cut taxes and spend less, it is easy to forget that tightfisted government imposes real costs.

abstract: Detroit emerged late last year from emergency management and bankruptcy, but some officials worry that the woes of its public schools threaten to slow efforts to remake the city.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan appointed a new emergency manager on Tuesday to oversee the Detroit Public Schools, the fourth such state-assigned manager to lead the struggling system since it was deemed in serious financial trouble in 2009.

headline: We Need Another Giant Protest
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Terrorism', 'International Relations']
abstract: How about a million-person march by Muslims for Muslims?
lead_paragraph: President Obama was criticized for failing to attend, or send a proper surrogate to, the giant antiterrorism march in Paris on Sunday. That criticism was right. But it is typical of American politics today that we focus on this and not what would have really made the world feel the jihadist threat was finally being seriously confronted. And that would not be a march that our president helps to lead, but one in which he’s not involved at all. That would be a million-person march against the jihadists across the Arab-Muslim world, organized by Arabs and Muslims for Arabs and Muslims, without anyone in the West asking for it — not just because of what happened in Paris but because of the scores of Muslims recently murdered by jihadists in Pakistan, Yemen, Iraq, Libya, Nigeria and Syria.

headline: Can Jeb Bush Defy the Tea Party and Win?
abstract: Bill Clinton did something similar to the left wing of his party in 1992, but the depth of our political polarization makes the task much harder now.
lead_paragraph: Can Jeb Bush win the Republican presidential nomination while defying the most ideologically committed wing of his party?

headline: In a Safer Age, U.S. Rethinks Its ‘Tough on Crime’ System
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Democrats and Republicans alike are rethinking the vast, costly system of policing and incarceration that was born of a crime wave decades ago.
lead_paragraph: Bullets were flying in the cities. Crack wars trapped people in their homes. The year was 1994, and President Bill Clinton captured the grim national mood, declaring “gangs and drugs have taken over our streets” as he signed the most far-reaching crime bill in history.

lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Tuesday sharpened his opposition to a City Council bill that would criminalize the use of chokeholds by New York City police officers, promising to veto the proposed legislation if it reached his desk.

headline: Trial Begins for Former C.I.A. Official Accused of Breaching National Security
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Books and Literature', 'News and News Media', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']

headline: Residents Get a Chance to Put Their Own Stamp on a Bronx Park
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Playgrounds', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: Basketball courts, barbecues and grass are on the residents’ wish lists of things they’d like to see in the refurbished Lyons Square Playground.
lead_paragraph: Troy Faux, 36, wanted brighter lights and longer benches around the basketball courts. Jose Rodriguez dreamed of new and improved sprinklers to entertain his 2-year-old daughter on hot summer days. And Jahiem Mewborn-Dozier, 9, longed for a roof over the basketball courts, as well as cellphone charging stations and barbecues.

headline: Let Them Eat Foie Gras
keywords: ['Foie Gras', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Caviar', 'Truffles', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Meat', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: To single a tiny fraction of meat production and label it “cruel” is to miss the big picture: Almost all meat production in the United States is cruel.
lead_paragraph: The lifting of the California ban against selling foie gras (the hyperfattened liver of geese or ducks, brought about by overfeeding the live animals) is pretty much a nonissue, except to point out that as a nation we have little perspective on animal welfare. To single out the tiniest fraction of meat production and label it “cruel” is to miss the big picture, and the big picture is this: Almost all meat production in the United States is cruel.

headline: Washington Governor Seeks New Taxes as a Court Order Looms

lead_paragraph: OLYMPIA, Wash. — Gov. Jay Inslee, a Democrat, stepped to the rostrum in the ornate House chamber of the Capitol here on Tuesday and called for the biggest increase in new tax dollars in state history.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Wednesday will ask the Federal Communications Commission to pre-empt state laws that restrict communities’ ability to expand high-speed Internet access to underserved areas.

headline: A School Aide to the Disabled Sues New York City
abstract: Lawyers representing Debra Fisher, an occupational therapist, demanded that the Education Department overturn her suspension for helping raise funds for a boy with cerebral palsy.
lead_paragraph: Back in September, an occupational therapist ferociously devoted to disabled children in her public school was suspended for 30 days on charges so flagrantly trumped up that Vladimir V. Putin would blush to bring them. The therapist, Debra Fisher, has helped children to soar from wheelchairs.

headline: Driven to Push Past Her Disabilities and Achieve Independence
