headline: Bohemian Looks From the Resort Collections
abstract: Billowy silhouettes, fringed trim and paisley florals of the sort seen in the ’70s made repeat appearances on the runways.
lead_paragraph: Billowy silhouettes, fringed trim and paisley florals of the sort seen in the ’70s made repeat appearances in the resort and spring 2015 collections. In one of the strongest resort outings, at Miu Miu, Miuccia Prada’s girls slinked down the runway in psychedelic printed dresses and pantsuits. The following season, Hedi Slimane showed a free-spirited look for Saint Laurent featuring patchwork suede jackets and dresses that are sure to be in high demand come spring. But for those who can’t wait that long, these pieces from the resort collections — in stores now — are every bit as groovy.

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8:20 P.M. (Starz Cinema) HELLO I MUST BE GOING (2012) A divorced 30-something (Melanie Lynskey, above, now starring in HBO’s “Togetherness”) finds a haven from her adult problems in the suburban Connecticut home of her critical mother (Blythe Danner) and indulgent father (John Rubinstein) in this comedy written by Sarah Koskoff and directed by Todd Louiso. She also discovers sex and romance with a 19-year-old — the stepson (Christopher Abbott) of a potential client her father is desperate to impress — who has allowed his doting mother (Julie White) to believe he is gay. “Needless to say, there are complications, some farcical, some belonging more to the realm of therapeutic melodrama,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “This is ultimately a tale of affirmation, self-acceptance and second chances, and its lessons, while not unwelcome, are a bit too forced and neatly packaged to make it fully satisfying. But when Ms. Lynskey and Mr. Abbott are together, there are inklings of a wilder, riskier, less predictable movie — one you may wish the characters could escape into, even though you know they never will.”

headline: Thomas Graboys, Doctor Who Wrote of Parkinson’s Fight, Dies at 70

lead_paragraph: When he was just 5 years old, Thomas Graboys declared that he intended to become a doctor. As a young physician, he visited a nephew serving in the Peace Corps in Mauritania and remained for two months, treating dozens of patients a day.

He was 95.

headline: In Ensenada, Cheap Mexican Charms Await
abstract: Less than two hours from San Diego, the city is one of the easiest and safest places to experience Mexico on a budget.
lead_paragraph: For as long as I can remember, Ensenada has had a whiff of south-of-the-border excess and spring-break stigma. Less than two hours from San Diego, down the Baja California peninsula, it’s one of the easiest and safest places to experience Mexico on a budget — which makes it easy to think of this small coastal city and cruise line layover as a sort of Mexico for Beginners. But dismissing northwest Baja is a mistake. Beyond the souvenir shops selling sombreros, knockoff artesanía (handicrafts) and tacky T-shirts, there’s a college town, a port town and a budding culinary capital that invite exploration. While Ensenada and the surrounding area can require a bit of patience, its pleasures are worth the time it takes to find them — and all the more so because they can be had so affordably.

keywords: ['Editorials', 'States (US)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']

headline: I Owe It All to Community College
abstract: President Obama’s plan to expand free access to two-year schools deserves Congress’s support.
lead_paragraph: IN 1974, I graduated from Skyline High School in Oakland, Calif., an underachieving student with lousy SAT scores. Allowed to send my results to three colleges, I chose M.I.T. and Villanova, knowing such fine schools would never accept a student like me but hoping they’d toss some car stickers my way for taking a shot. I couldn’t afford tuition for college anyway. I sent my final set of stats to Chabot, a community college in nearby Hayward, Calif., which, because it accepted everyone and was free, would be my alma mater.

headline: Why a Generation of Adoptees Is Returning to South Korea
keywords: ['ADOPTIONS', 'Orphans and Orphanages', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Families and Family Life', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: A movement is raising soul-searching questions about international adoption.
lead_paragraph: Laura Klunder’s newest tattoo runs down the inside of her left forearm and reads “K85-160,” a number that dates to her infancy. Klunder was 9 months old when her South Korean mother left her at a police station in Seoul. The police brought her to Holt Children’s Services, a local adoption agency, where a worker assigned Klunder the case number K85-160. It was only two weeks into 1985, but she was already the 160th child to come to the agency that month, and she would go on to be one of 8,800 children sent overseas from South Korea that year. Klunder became part of the largest adoption exodus from one country in history: Over the past six decades, at least 200,000 Korean children — roughly the population of Des Moines — have been adopted into families in more than 15 countries, with a vast majority living in the United States.

headline: Finding Robert Frank, Online
abstract: A new online resource from the National Gallery allows viewers to explore its vast collection of Robert Frank’s work – from contact sheets to ephemera.
lead_paragraph: The cover image for the U.S. edition of “The Americans,” Robert Frank’s epochal book, spoke volumes about the state of the nation in the mid-1950s. The tightly-cropped photo shows passengers in the windows of a New Orleans trolley assuming their place in the social order of the Jim Crow South — progressing from a black woman in the rear to white children and adults up front (slide 4).

headline: An Artist Favored by the U.S. Embassy in Pakistan
abstract: Jennifer Nocon’s solo show “You See Ocean I See Sky” opens tomorrow and uses pattern to reflect human behavior — and the possibility of change.
lead_paragraph: Though plenty of ink is spilled about the intersection of politics and aesthetics, less is said about the artwork hanging in the rooms where statesmanship is actually conducted. Recently, one of the most geopolitically sensitive locations in the world, the U.S. embassy in Islamabad, Pakistan, reserved a multimedia wall piece and watercolors by the Los Angeles-based artist Jennifer Nocon, whose solo show “You See Ocean I See Sky” opens tomorrow in New York. Assembled from wool, clay and steel, standout pieces in the exhibition combine the artist’s signature motifs, branching tendrils and small scales, layered into a gathering storm of color.

headline: Westbury, N.Y., a ‘Melting Pot’ Village
abstract: The 2.37-square-mile Village of Westbury is known for its economic diversity, shopping convenience and choice of public and parochial schools.

They were then living in Hell’s Kitchen in Manhattan. “I kind of went kicking and screaming” on the house hunt, Mr. Moran said.

headline: In Salt Lake City, a Proposal to Link Ski Trails
abstract: Momentum is growing for a plan to combine seven ski resorts in Utah, but opposition from environmentalists also continues.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the biggest news lately in North American skiing has been the announcement in 2014 that seven ski resorts perched high above Salt Lake City hope to join hands to create the largest megaresort in North America. OneWasatch, as it’s being billed, would be a colossus, with one ski pass linking more than 100 lifts across Utah’s Wasatch Mountains, more than double the acreage of Whistler-Blackcomb in Canada, currently the continent’s largest ski resort. Its backers say OneWasatch would offer an experience akin to Europe’s linked valley-to-valley ski systems like Arlberg in Austria or Trois Vallées in France.

headline: 1890: The Rouble Takes a Drop
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1890: The rouble takes a drop following the budget announcement.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG — The Budget announcement has made a very unfavorable impression. The Finance Minister has himself admitted how real and widespread is the agricultural distress, and has publicly declared the opinion that there will be an immediate fall in the value of the rouble. Yet he has calmly augmented the expenditure by no less than 60,000,000 roubles. Probably the Minister could not help himself against the pressure of the war party. It is significant that most of the increase is due to the demands of the War Office. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 15, 1890

headline: Crazy All the Time
abstract: A new picture book from the cartoonist Roz Chast supplies a laugh for every hour of the day.
lead_paragraph: After reading aloud to my children virtually every night for over a decade — my daughter just turned 12, and my sons are 9 and 4 — I have, of course, many book recommendations, but I also have some strategic suggestions. The first is, if you can’t picture yourself reading a particular book nightly for, oh, two straight months, don’t even bring it into the house. Small children have a huge appetite for repetition, and you never know what will catch their interest. So be wary. I recently brought home “Hello Kitty Goes to Camp,” which comes with postcards to send home, thinking it would be an opportunity for “ironic” bonding with my frighteningly culturally sophisticated preteenage daughter. She didn’t bite. Then the 4-year-old found it and, fascinated by his sister’s two recent sleepaway camp disappearances, has demanded to hear it for many, many nights now.

headline: Inspired by Simón Bolívar and Gustavo Dudamel

lead_paragraph: In the United States, Simón Bolívar is remembered, vaguely, as a kind of George Washington of South America, commander of an army that freed a half-dozen countries, including his native Venezuela, from Spanish colonial rule. In Latin America, though, he is known simply as “The Liberator,” which happens to be the title of a biopic, by the Venezuelan director Alberto Arvelo, that is one of nine movies shortlisted for the Academy Award for best foreign-language film.

headline: Corduroy Gets a Luxurious Reboot at the London Men’s Wear Shows
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: One of the favored fabrics of the ’70s found its way onto the runways this week, but these weren’t the thrifty sort of cords one might expect.
lead_paragraph: It’s clear that ’70s nostalgia is the trend of the moment, with designers of both women’s and men’s fashion lately taking cues from the decade in their collections. So it comes as no surprise that one of the favored fabrics of the era, corduroy, found its way into the men’s shows in London this week. These weren’t the thrifty sort of cords one might expect, however. The new designer Alex Mullins, who debuted his collection in a fluorescent-lit room filled with empty cardboard boxes, featured Me Decade-inspired knits and denim as well as corduroy. One look referenced the classic professorial type (think Donald Sutherland in the 1978 comedy “Animal House”), but its slightly odd proportions — cropped and flared trousers with a fitted jacket — made the suit more eccentric than dowdy. J.W. Anderson incorporated the durable ridged fabric — in a very ’70s powder blue, to boot — into a short zipped jacket with a contrasting black collar. Styled with a pair of leather trousers on a model with slick hair, the jacket looked sharp, urbane and dangerously cool. And at Burberry Prorsum, the British fashion house’s traditional trench was fabricated in a larger-scaled corduroy, giving the coat a bit more heft and the retro cloth a much more modern vibe.

headline: Video: David Oyelowo Talks ‘Selma’ and ‘Overnight’ Success

We’ll know Thursday, but either way, 2014 was a breakout year for him, with a raved-about performance as the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in “Selma” and roles in “Interstellar” and “A Most Violent Year.” It’s well-known by now that he was a major force in getting “Selma” made after several abortive attempts. headline: 1915: Thousands Dead in Earthquake
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1915: Thousands dead in earthquake in Avezzano, Italy
lead_paragraph: ROME — Despatches which have arrived from the provinces last night and this morning show that yesterday’s earthquake is a disaster second only in extent to that which devastated Messina in 1908. Only the most general estimates can yet be made of the number of victims, and even these vary between 20,000 and 30,000. Two new shocks were felt this morning. The worst fears are confirmed with regard to the town of Avezzano and the surrounding district. As far as can be at present ascertained, only 800 inhabitants out of a population of 11,000 have escaped and the majority of these are injured. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 15, 1915

headline: 36 Hours in Memphis
abstract: Beyond blues, barbecue and Elvis, you can find zydeco and indie rock, newly vibrant neighborhoods and a refurbished civil rights museum.
lead_paragraph: Maybe even more Music City than its country cousin to the east, Memphis has strong affiliations with not one musical genre but three. It is the birthplace of rock ‘n’ roll, the cradle of soul and, though the blues weren’t born here (that distinction goes to the rural parts of the Mississippi Delta), it was the Memphis-based musician and “Father of the Blues,” W. C. Handy, who helped get those “lonesome songs” out into the world. But there is far more to Bluff City than blues and barbecue. A watermelon and feta salad can be found alongside great smokehouse meats; zydeco and indie rock are within earshot of soul; and up-and-coming areas like Cooper-Young are giving the city’s older haunts some stiff competition. For this short visit, leave out the Graceland juggernaut, though if Elvis is on your bucket list, head out any morning to Graceland’s Meditation Garden where the King is buried — it’s peaceful and free.

headline: Blasphemy Revisited
keywords: ['Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Censorship', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Easter and Holy Week', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Movies', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Religion and Belief', 'Violence (Media and Entertainment)']
abstract: Satire and self-censorship around religion, from Charlie Hebdo to The Book of Mormon.
lead_paragraph: My post last week in the immediate aftermath of the Charlie Hebdo murders received an unusual amount of favorable feedback from readers of varying persuasions, for which I’m grateful. It was also written in a mood that was perhaps not completely nuanced and reflective, so I want to return to the issues now in the hopes of both clarifying and qualifying certain elements of the argument. This will be the first of at least two posts trying to do just that.

headline: Envisioned for Decades, a Revival of a Manhattan Pier Is Complete
abstract: For the first time in many years, the public is welcome on Pier A, which will include restaurants and bars after being rehabilitated by the Battery Park City Authority.
lead_paragraph: Battery Park City was supposed to have obliterated the picturesque Pier A at the tip of Manhattan, whose clock tower — pealing the time in ship’s bells — is believed to have been the first permanent World War I memorial erected in the United States.

headline: Classical Playlist: Bach, Anders Koppel, Mahler and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: BACH: English Suites Nos. 1, 3 and 5Piotr Anderszewski, pianist(Warner Classics 0825646219391; one CD)The Polish-Hungarian pianist Piotr Anderszewski brings superb facility and probing musicianship to everything he plays. His deeply personal Bach performances are especially compelling. In this essential new recording of three of Bach’s English Suites (No. 3 in G minor, No. 1 in A, No. 5 in E minor), he uses the full tonal and colorist resources of the modern piano while vividly conveying Baroque style and sensibility. I particularly admire the way he combines articulate rhythmic vitality with lyrical treatment of inner voices. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Virginia Politician Serves 2 Terms: In Jail and in the State Legislature

lead_paragraph: To be clear, late-night votes might be a bit of a problem for Joseph Morrissey, the newly sworn-in Virginia House delegate who must report to his jail cell about 7:30 each evening.

headline: At the Fall 2015 London Men’s Collections, Designers Had a Few Words to Put on Their Chests
abstract: A number of runway looks were emblazoned with messages that ranged from the promotional to the polemical.
lead_paragraph: A handful of designers at the fall/winter 2015 London shows this week had something to say — so much so that their clothes came emblazoned with messages that ranged from the promotional to the polemical. Christopher Shannon, who has made it his signature to deconstruct and dissect active sportswear, used his designs as commentary on commercial industries and the economy. With slogans like “Thanks 4 Nothing,” “Save Me” and “Broke” knitted into brightly colored intarsia jumpers, the ostensibly humorous collection revealed a darker undercurrent. While Sarah Burton’s military-inspired collection for Alexander McQueen displayed a mastery of tailoring, the bold capitalized words “HONOUR,” “VALOUR” and “TRUTH” inscribed across blazers and coats made a bigger statement. And lastly, the American designer Shaun Samson, who returned with a runway show after two seasons away, brought a Southern California flair to the London scene with his collection of bold flannel plaids, Dickies-inspired chinos and aprons adorned with the phrases “DELUSIONAL RADICAL BLISS” and “GNARLY DANK DUDE.”

headline: A Calculated Look Behind the Lust
abstract: Peter Strickland, the director of “The Duke of Burgundy,” had some fanciful ideas behind the visuals for his film, which explores a couple’s sexual appetites.
lead_paragraph: In “The Duke of Burgundy,” due Jan. 23, a couple (Sidse Babett Knudsen and Chiara D’Anna) blend sadomasochism and role play into their lives. Viewers might think they know what a movie like this looks like. But the film’s director, Peter Strickland, has a more fanciful visual in mind. Rather than just leather and lace, the film is also about butterflies, capes and mansions. It’s often more Hans Christian Andersen than “Fifty Shades of Grey,” creating a melodramatic fantasia that seems to exist both in the real world and outside it.

headline: Savings Rates Are Anemic, but a Survey Shows They Are Less Paltry Online
abstract: GoBankingRates says nine of the 10 best savings rates are offered on web accounts, with several hitting 1 percent.
lead_paragraph: Americans are not known as great savers, and a tough economy, combined with anemic interest rates on savings, haven’t offered them much opportunity to change.

headline: Injustice Treated Like a Thriller
abstract: “Accused,” the Dutch film shortlisted for the foreign-language Oscar, takes on a notorious case in the Netherlands.
lead_paragraph: It’s not just the United States that has sensational criminal cases that mesmerize the tabloids. In “Accused,” one of nine films shortlisted for the Oscar for best foreign-language film, a Dutch nurse is falsely accused of murdering patients, demonized in the press as an “angel of death” and sentenced to life in prison, gaining her freedom only when a team of crusading lawyers establishes her innocence.

headline: Alexandra Fuller’s ‘Leaving Before the Rains Come’
abstract: After a divorce, Alexandra Fuller looks to her Zambian past for guidance in leading an independent life.
lead_paragraph: A memoir often takes one of two basic forms: In the first, the writer has an extraordinary story to tell; in the second, she has the ability to tell the common story in an extraordinary way. Sometimes — Mary McCarthy’s “Memories of a Catholic Girlhood” is an example, Paula Fox’s “Borrowed Finery” another — the two are conflated in events on whose extremity the artistic mind succeeds in imposing literary form. I once heard the writer Aharon Appelfeld, asked why he had underplayed the savagery of his Holocaust childhood in one of his books, give the answer that extremity, whether imaginary or real, is harmful to art. What he perhaps meant was that the artist’s aim is to represent truth, and that certain experiences — those that infringe or violate the common sense of reality — can never be made to seem true. Joan Didion dealt interestingly with this problem in “The Year of Magical Thinking,” making the surreality of her husband’s death at the dinner table a space the reader could philosophically inhabit. And likewise Alexandra Fuller, writing about her often tragically idiosyncratic African childhood in “Don’t Let’s Go to the Dogs Tonight,” brilliantly succeeded in retaining a child’s astonished objectivity at the unfolding of bizarre events.

headline: At Versailles, a Very French Response to Terrorist Attack
abstract: A rarely seen portrait of Voltaire, with a quotation about tolerance, are on display at Versailles.
lead_paragraph: The Château de Versailles has mounted its own response to the attack on Charlie Hebdo, placing a rarely seen portrait of Voltaire front and center in the main tourist circuit inside the palace.

headline: Getting Government Into the Broadband Internet Business
abstract: President Obama wants to make it easier for cities to compete with cable and telephone companies.

Despite years of trying, regulators and lawmakers have struggled to introduce more competition, which is why President Obama said on Wednesday that he wants to make it easier for local governments to get into the broadband business.

When I wrote about the test drive of a Tesla electric car, or Nate Silver’s offer to place a bet on his prognostications, hundreds of readers commented and emailed. When I wrote about coverage of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, readers certainly let me know what they thought.

headline: Bernie Sanders Forces Republicans to State Their Views on Climate Change

lead_paragraph: With Senate majority leader Mitch McConnell promising an open debate on the Keystone XL pipeline bill, Senator Bernie Sanders, the maverick Independent from Vermont, has crafted a beauty of an amendment. He plans to offer a “sense of Congress” resolution in the debate asking each senator if he or she agrees with “the opinion of virtually the entire worldwide scientific community” that climate change is a factually proven problem resulting in “devastating problems in the United States and around the world.”

headline: Je Suis Charlie et Ahmed: Teaching and Learning About the Charlie Hebdo Attacks
abstract: A series of reading, writing and discussion activities based on Times reporting and Opinion pieces that may help students think through some of the complex issues the Charlie Hebdo attacks have raised.
lead_paragraph: Overview |  Three days of bloodshed last week shook France, a nation struggling with Islamic extremists, and sent shock waves through Europe and beyond. On Jan. 7, a terrorist attack by masked gunmen on the newspaper Charlie Hebdo left 12 people dead. On Jan. 9, the French police killed three terrorists in raids at a printing plant and a kosher supermarket that left the gunmen and four Jewish hostages dead. In all, at least 17 French citizens were killed by terrorists in the chaos.

headline: Amazon Comes Out Swinging

It’s posting its latest batch of original pilots on Thursday, just a few days after winning a Golden Globe for one of the shows from the last batch, “Transparent.” Last week it was the supporting player of streaming video on demand; now it’s pushing Netflix for the lead role.

headline: A Crooner and a Belter All in One
abstract: Cheyenne Jackson was open and upbeat as he sang standards and contemporary material at Café Carlyle.
lead_paragraph: As Cheyenne Jackson closed his eyes and crooned “Falling Slowly” with an unwavering intensity on Tuesday evening at Café Carlyle, this great ballad from “Once” never sounded more profound and mysterious. For a moment, Mr. Jackson, who was joined on harmony vocal by his excellent musical director, Willy Beaman, transcended his wholesome image of a handsome, genial all-American boy from northeast Washington State who once played Elvis Presley on Broadway and went deep.

headline: Evocative Nudes That Allude to Matisse, Bonnard and Balthus
abstract: The painter Tal R’s “Alstadt Girl” series features a variety of women in states of repose — some of whom Tal R stops on the street to ask to pose.
lead_paragraph: Ever been stopped on the street and been asked to pose nude for a painting? “There are people you look at that you want to draw,” says Tal R, the figurative painter whose mysterious last initial hides as much as the whispers of his aspirated English. The Israeli-born artist — the R stands for Rosenzweig — specializes in florid canvases, especially his new series “Altstadt Girl”: naked women in all states of repose, vivid in red. One is a 16-year-old whose mother granted permission for her to model: “She was smoking in this beautiful arrogant way that you do when you are young because you own the world,” the artist says.

headline: Facing a Desert Plague of Poisonings
abstract: In “Fear the Darkness,” Becky Masterman’s second novel, the investigator Brigid Quinn returns.
lead_paragraph: Becky Masterman’s first book, “Rage Against the Dying” (2013), introduced a highly original heroine for a detective series. She was Brigid Quinn, an ex-F.B.I. agent old enough to be mistaken for a fragile granny by a sexual predator, who spied her out hiking one day and tried to shove her into his van. Boy, was that sexual predator ever sorry. At 59, Brigid had a white ponytail and a walking stick — but she also had 40 years’ worth of vigorous conditioning and a wicked way of fighting. That walking stick came equipped with a razor blade.

headline: Latest Witness Video of Gunmen Outside Charlie Hebdo Office Adds to Picture of Attack Aftermath
abstract: Video recorded just after the attack on the offices of the satirical weekly Charlie Hebdo last week in Paris shows the gunmen claiming responsibility.
lead_paragraph: Video recorded by a witness minutes after the deadly attack on the offices of the satirical weekly Charlie Hebdo last Wednesday in Paris offers the clearest images of the gunmen claiming responsibility, and linking the killings to cartoons mocking the Prophet Muhammad.

headline: Undetected Defense at Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional
abstract: The Truscott Board-a-Match Teams was won by a team of players from New York City and Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 30, the final day of the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan, the Truscott Board-a-Match Teams was won by Jared Lilienstein, Michael Polowan and Sam Lev of New York City, and Ron Smith of Las Vegas. They finished more than three boards ahead of Melanie Tucker, Radu Nistor and John Hurd of New York City, and John Kranyak of Las Vegas. Third were Dori Byrnes of Morris Plains, N.J.; Michael Kopera and Craig Ganzer of New York City; William Ehlers of Livingston, N.J.; and Robert Brady of McLean, Va.

headline: New Research May Solve Puzzle in Sea Level’s Rise
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Research', 'Floods', 'Coast Erosion']
abstract: Researchers have reported that the ocean did not rise quite as much as previously believed in the 20th century, possibly explaining a discrepancy in climate research.
lead_paragraph: A team of researchers reported Wednesday that the ocean did not rise quite as much as previously believed in the 20th century. They proposed a seemingly tiny adjustment that could make a big difference in scientific understanding of the looming problem of sea-level rise.

headline: The Other Detroit Auto Show

headline: The Other Auto Show in Detroit
abstract: Not far from the glamour of the auto show, vehicles that once were stars of the show now sit abandoned around the city.
lead_paragraph: Not far from the glamour of the Detroit International Auto Show this week, one photographer found an auto show of another sort — like in many cities, there were cars of yesterday, slowing rusting and rotting around town.

headline: Pursuing the Impossible, and Coming Out on Top
abstract: Tommy Caldwell and Kevin Jorgeson finished scaling the sheer face of the Dawn Wall rock formation at Yosemite on Wednesday. Some consider it the most difficult free climb ever achieved.
lead_paragraph: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif. — On the 19th day of their climb, Tommy Caldwell and Kevin Jorgeson, both now bearded, reached the summit of El Capitan’s Dawn Wall, completing a quest that included years of planning and that many considered the most challenging rock climb in the world.

headline: Justin Bieber for Calvin Klein: Seeing May Not Be Believing

lead_paragraph: After days of fevered speculation, charges of Photoshopping and retaliatory threats of legal action, as well as hundreds of tweets and retweets on the subject, Elle magazine sent out a news alert on Sunday afternoon that seemed designed to put the first big controversy of 2015 to rest:

headline: Focusing on the Margins of Society

headline: Inhabiting Wes Anderson’s Universe
abstract: Matt Zoller Seitz, a connoisseur of the idiosyncratic filmmaker’s oeuvre, has a new book on “The Grand Budapest Hotel.”
lead_paragraph: ­Matt Zoller Seitz is a film historian, TV critic (for New York magazine and Vulture.com), filmmaker and the editor of Roger­ebert.com. He is also a connoisseur of the oeuvre of the idiosyncratic filmmaker Wes Anderson and the creator of “The Wes Anderson Collection,” a medley of essays, interviews and illustrations in a coffee-table-size book published last year. It is as hyper-designed and meticulous as an Anderson film.

headline: The Uproar Over Amal Clooney’s White Gloves
abstract: For better or worse, Ms. Clooney pulled off a dubious feat by accenting her dramatic Dior dress with a pair of pristine opera gloves.
lead_paragraph: At the Golden Globes on Sunday night, the fastidious Amal Clooney made what passed for red carpet history, turning the proceedings at the Beverly Hilton hotel into something resembling an affair of state. For better or worse, depending on which critic one consults, she pulled off that dubious feat by accenting her dramatic one-shoulder Dior haute couture dress with a pair of pristine opera gloves.

abstract: The Washington saloniste has had epic triumphs and losses, including a fire that destroyed her art collection. Now she’s built it all back.

headline: Peggy Cooper Cafritz: Everything in a Big Way
abstract: The Washington saloniste has not let setbacks keep her from her passion: collecting African and African-American art.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was five years ago last August that Peggy Cooper Cafritz’s entire life was erased by a fire that tore through her elegant, art-filled house here.

headline: Sensory Overload Is Part of the Script
abstract: In Andrew Schneider’s inventive, astounding and inexplicably shirtless “Youarenowhere,” part of the Coil festival, digital marvels synchronize with analog dance and personal revelation.
lead_paragraph: You could say that the performer Andrew Schneider has tricks up his sleeve. Except he isn’t wearing any. In Mr. Schneider’s inventive, astounding and inexplicably shirtless “Youarenowhere,” part of the Coil festival, digital marvels synchronize with analog dance and personal revelation.

headline: ‘System Design: More Than 100 Years of Everyday Chaos’ Opens in Cologne
abstract: The exhibition at the Museum of Applied Arts spans almost every category of design, including fashion, graphics, furniture and electronics.
lead_paragraph: “System Design: More Than 100 Years of Everyday Chaos,” which opens Tuesday at the Museum of Applied Arts in Cologne, Germany, makes the case for the role of chaos as the principle governing our lives. The curator, René Spitz, believes that the systems seen in the design that surrounds us wage a fight against chaos, but that the systems inevitably lose.

headline: What Happened to Risk on the Red Carpet?
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Celebrities', 'Movies', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'Golden Globes (Awards)', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES']
abstract: Unspoken edicts continue to govern the dress at Hollywood events, calling forth nothing more daring than spangled variations on a conventional prom dress.
lead_paragraph: “Will that go off in a metal detector?” Ryan Seacrest asked as he greeted Emma Stone, who met his gaze with a coy smile and plenty of attitude.

headline: Eric Foner’s ‘Gateway to Freedom’
abstract: Mr. Foner’s new book about the Underground Railroad began with the notebook of an abolitionist newspaper editor.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Foner’s new book about the Underground Railroad began with the notebook of an abolitionist newspaper editor.

headline: Sleepy Thoughts
abstract: Easily mistaken for puffy wall art, Alessandra Baldereschi’s upholstered pieces are entirely functional and were created out of necessity.
lead_paragraph: Alessandra Baldereschi’s soft headboards could easily be mistaken for puffy wall art. Yet these upholstered pieces are entirely functional and were created out of necessity.

headline: From Deborah Bowness, Wallpaper That Mimics Walls Themselves
abstract: Deborah Bowness designs wallpaper that brings exterior scenes indoors.
lead_paragraph: For years, Deborah Bowness, a British wallpaper artist, has designed photographic murals showing the kinds of objects that sit against walls: things like bookcases, chairs and frames. Now she is producing wallpaper that displays the walls themselves. Her new digitally printed collection offers rusted corrugated tin siding, Russian graffiti, postings on a notice board in Hastings, England, and simple brick or cinder block.

headline: In Remote Thai Villages, Legacy of China’s Lost Army Endures
abstract: Dozens of villages in northern Thailand are home to veterans and descendants of a unit of the Nationalist Army, which lost to Mao in 1949.
lead_paragraph: BAN RAK THAI, Thailand — At night, traditional Chinese red lanterns illuminate the hotels, shop fronts and Yunnanese-style restaurants lining the main road in this highland village of just over 1,000 people. On one recent evening, as the mist rose off a nearby reservoir, the mellifluous voice of the popular Taiwanese singer Teresa Teng could be heard wafting out from one of the village’s several tea shops.

headline: What Would You Grab in a Fire?
abstract: My son — but also, my toothbrush, my computer and a knife.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — I was getting ready for bed when I heard sirens. No big deal in the city, right? We hear them all the time. I brushed my teeth — they got louder. Tossed my pants on the bathroom floor — louder, closer, and when I went into the living room I saw red lights slicing through the blinds.

headline: Words From the Past Illuminate a Station on the Way to Freedom
abstract: “Gateway to Freedom,” a book about the Underground Railroad by Eric Foner, began with the notebook of an abolitionist editor, Sydney Howard Gay.
lead_paragraph: Eric Foner has won a place in the front rank of American historians with books that seem to vacuum up all available sources to produce bold new interpretations of the country’s reckoning with the big questions of slavery and freedom.

headline: The ‘One-in-a-Million’ Farmhouse

keywords: ['Restoration and Renovation', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']

lead_paragraph: There is a lesson to be taken from how Christina Salway and her husband, John Moskowitz, came to buy a farmhouse near Callicoon, N.Y., in Sullivan County, a year and a half ago. The lesson, depending on your point of view, is either don’t peer into the windows of real estate offices or — if you do and find the country home you’ve always wanted — seize the opportunity.

lead_paragraph: The glazed ceramic Nola money box is an adult spin on the child’s piggy bank. Instead of coins, it holds bills.

headline: Fort Fisher II: Fiasco
abstract: The plan called for the army to go first, then the marines would advance, and after that the sailors. Instead, everyone charged.
lead_paragraph: After the failed attack on Fort Fisher in December 1864, General Grant, knowing the character of both General Butler and Admiral Porter, the co- commanders of the Union forces, had no doubt which man was at fault.

lead_paragraph: Readers in America clamoring for the latest copy of the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo will probably struggle to find one the next few days, its distributors and stores seeking the latest issue said Wednesday.

headline: Modern Red-Carpet Looks, in a Perfect World
abstract: Antonio Marras, Rosetta Getty and more designers sketch their hypothetical concepts for modern red carpet looks.
lead_paragraph: ­His scrollwork embroideries and sophisticated florals have yet to garner a reliable red-carpet following for Antonio Marras. No matter. The designer’s aims are lofty: Nothing less, he said, than “to try to defeat banality and platitudes in fashion.”

headline: Winter Wardrobe Refreshers
abstract: Crochet as a spring warm-up; ankle boots in winter white and shearling ear muffs and scarves with Scandinavian shapes.
lead_paragraph: Crochet, a prominent spring runway trend, has made an unexpected early showing on the red carpet. At a recent premiere in London, the Swedish actress Alicia Vikander wore an airy crochet number from Louis Vuitton (above right). Dakota Fanning and Kim Kardashian also got their hands on hot runway looks, Ms. Fanning in a crochet Proenza Schouler (right) and Ms. Kardashian in a revealing wide-mesh Balenciaga (above left). Day or evening, any of these dresses would be pretty fabulous to pack for a warmer place, where they could appropriately be worn over, say, just two pieces.

headline: Why Drugs Cost So Much
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: We perversely encourage high prices. It’s not that hard to fix.
lead_paragraph: ELI LILLY charges more than $13,000 a month for Cyramza, the newest drug to treat stomach cancer. The latest medicine for lung cancer, Novartis’s Zykadia, costs almost $14,000 a month. Amgen’s Blincyto, for leukemia, will cost $64,000 a month.

headline: The Jihadist in Our Family
abstract: Why would Mohd Lotfi Ariffin leave his wife and children behind in Malaysia in search of martyrdom in Syria?
lead_paragraph: Why would Mohd Lotfi Ariffin leave his wife and children behind in Malaysia in search of martyrdom in Syria?

headline: The Jihadist in Our Family
abstract: A video about one of several dozen Malaysians whose faith has led them to take up arms against President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.
lead_paragraph: KUALA KETIL, Malaysia — A year ago, Mohd Lotfi Ariffin bid his family goodbye and headed for Syria, where he intended to fulfill what he saw as his religious duty fighting President Bashar al-Assad. He left behind his wife, their six children and his job as a religious school teacher here to fight with his fellow Sunnis more than 4,000 miles away.

headline: The Complexity of Deadly Force
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Racial Profiling', 'Gun Control']
abstract: Police officers do dangerous work that few of us would sign up to do. But does the type of person they encounter warp their perception of citizens in general?
lead_paragraph: Another video in another police shooting emerged this week — and it shows yet another case that demands empathy, and an understanding of the fraught moments that can lead to such an outcome, and the complexity of the legal process that follows.

abstract: The implant is the first to generate an intermittent electrical pulse that blocks nerve signals from the brain to the stomach, reducing hunger pangs.

headline: Shopping Sales and Events in New York City
abstract: Dover Street Market to close for three days for a full-on “seasonal changeover” and sales this week.
lead_paragraph: ­It’s normal this time of year for stores to be making room for new merchandise, but leave it to Dover Street Market to close for three days for a full-on “seasonal changeover.” Reopening Saturday, the luxury emporium will debut several dedicated shop-in-shops and exclusive collections. On the third floor, look out for the first permanent United States retail space for Idea Books, the London distributor of rare art and fashion books and magazines — “4 x 4” by Richard Prince ($195) and Visionaire No. 20: Comme des Garçons ($1,750) may entice — and a new home for Miu Miu. In the DSM Showroom for emerging designers on the fourth floor, you’ll find an oversize V-neck mesh top ($1,530) and a neoprene and space-mesh skirt with bow ($930) designed by Andrea Jiapei Li, a recent graduate from the M.F.A. program at Parsons the New School of Design; and a conceptual taffeta party frock ($2,675) from the Central Saint Martins alumna Molly Goddard. At 160 Lexington Avenue. ­

headline: Fistfuls of Cash Spilled on Expressway Swirl in Young Imaginations Only
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Roads and Traffic', 'ARMORED CAR SERVICES']
abstract: Five teenage boys patrolled the Long Island Expressway on Wednesday, looking for $178,000 in cash that supposedly fell out of the back of an armored truck the day before.
lead_paragraph: Five teenage boys in Corona, Queens, awoke on Wednesday to the sort of question that can shape a young man’s future, dividing life into two sections: the part before that morning, and the part that followed.

headline: Flocking to Buy Charlie Hebdo, Citizens Signal Their Support of Free Speech
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: The sentiment that drove the sales probably had less to do with those messages and more to do with the impulse to preserve a world in which the speech of the many cannot be held hostage by a few.
lead_paragraph: For people who are supporters of not just free speech but newspapers, too, the images of Parisians queued up at dawn Wednesday to get their hands on a printed artifact was heartening. The French distributors of the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo said the latest issue’s initial printing of three million copies had been increased to perhaps five million, and there were reports that the now-precious editions were being auctioned on eBay for hundreds of dollars.

headline: Far Ahead of Curve, a 6-Year-Old Thrills a Nation
abstract: Rashid al-Dhaheri, who became enamored of motorsports after attending a Formula One race with his father, has been winning youth go-kart races and building a following in the United Arab Emirates.
lead_paragraph: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — On a sparkling morning here in December, I stepped into a red-and-black driving suit, slipped on a helmet and eased my car up to the start line alongside this country’s most famous motorsports star.

headline: Facebook Looks to the Workplace for Future Growth
abstract: The world’s largest social network of individuals is making a move into the corporate world, hoping to organize the workplace the way it has organized personal relationships.
lead_paragraph: Facebook doesn’t just want to be the world’s leading social network for people to communicate about their personal lives. It wants to host workplace chatter, too.

headline: Manhattan Judge Offers Deal to Driver Who Killed Girl, 4
abstract: Justice Gregory Carro offered Franklin Reyes Jr., accused of killing Ariel Russo last year while fleeing the police on the Upper West Side, a lighter sentence in exchange for a guilty plea.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan judge offered a plea deal on Wednesday to a troubled teenage driver accused of killing a 4-year-old girl while racing away from the police, putting forward a more lenient punishment than prosecutors proposed.

headline: Web Failure Slows New York City’s ID Program
abstract: The de Blasio administration’s issuance of municipal identification cards, to help undocumented immigrants, the homeless and others, was hampered by a broken scheduling website.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, the de Blasio administration introduced its municipal identification program, attracting long lines and waits as applicants strained to navigate the fledgling system.

headline: One Person Dies and Many Others Fall Ill After Saline Infusions
abstract: One person has died and many more were sickened after receiving infusions of a saline solution produced by Wallcur, a San Diego-based company, the Food and Drug Administration said Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: One person has died and many more were sickened after receiving infusions of a saline solution produced by Wallcur, a San Diego-based company, the Food and Drug Administration said Wednesday. The saline solution was meant for training purposes and was not sterile, officials said. It was shipped to medical clinics, surgical centers and urgent care facilities, some of which administered it to patients. More than 40 people are known to have received infusions, according to federal health officials. Many suffered fever, chills, tremors and headaches. So far cases have been reported in seven states: Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Louisiana, North Carolina, New York and Colorado.

headline: C.I.A. Officers Are Cleared in Senate Computer Search
keywords: ['Interrogations', 'Torture', 'Detainees', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The findings overturned the conclusions of the C.I.A. inspector general, who determined last year that five officers acted improperly when they searched files used by the Senate Intelligence Committee during its investigation of C.I.A. interrogations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The panel investigating the Central Intelligence Agency’s search of a computer network used by the Senate Intelligence Committee found that five agency officers had acted in good faith during an episode marked by confusion and poor communication, and should not be punished.

headline: Obama Plans to Push Paid Family and Sick Leave for Workers
keywords: ['Paid Time Off', 'Family Leaves', 'Government Employees', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama plans to urge Congress to pass a bill allowing workers to earn up to seven paid sick days a year and creating a fund to help states pay for family leave.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will announce Thursday that he is directing federal agencies to give their employees up to six weeks of paid leave after the birth or adoption of a child, a benefit he wants to extend to all American workers.

headline: ‘I Would Love for This to Open People’s Minds’
abstract: Minutes after reaching the top of El Capitan, after the hugs and the sprays of sparkling wine, Tommy Caldwell and Kevin Jorgeson spoke with John Branch of The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Minutes after reaching the top of El Capitan, after the hugs and the sprays of sparkling wine, the rock climbers Tommy Caldwell and Kevin Jorgeson spoke exclusively with John Branch of The New York Times.

lead_paragraph: A decommissioned missile silo 20 miles from downtown Roswell, N.M., is looking for a new occupant.

headline: As a Player, Todd Bowles Had the Aura of a Future Head Coach
abstract: Woody Johnson, the Jets’ owner, was the first person to test a widely held belief that Bowles had N.F.L. head coaching potential.
lead_paragraph: Woody Johnson was hardly alone in believing Todd Bowles possessed N.F.L. head coaching potential. But Johnson, the Jets’ owner, was the first person to test that conviction, hiring Bowles to lead the team at what Johnson has defined as a critical time in its history.

headline: An Islamic Reformer, Lashed
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: Let’s support moderates in the Islamic world who are pushing for change — and being punished for it.
lead_paragraph: As one group of Islamic militants was waging war in Paris, another was slaughtering vast numbers of civilians in Baga in northern Nigeria — as many as 2,000, according to Amnesty International; “only” 150, according to the Nigerian government.

headline: Dropouts and Politics and Cats
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Governors (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: How important do you think it is for a president to have a college degree?
lead_paragraph: Let’s talk about governors. Or college dropouts.

headline: Court Takes Paternity Suit Against Spain’s Ex-King
abstract: Juan Carlos’s abdication last year opened him to a paternity challenge.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The Spanish Supreme Court agreed Wednesday to examine a paternity suit against King Juan Carlos filed by a Belgian woman who claims he had an affair with her mother.

headline: Readers in Europe Respond to the Paris Attacks
abstract: The New York Times asked readers to share their experiences before and after the attacks on the Charlie Hebdo offices and a kosher grocery store last week.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the deadly terrorist attacks on the Charlie Hebdo offices and a kosher grocery store in Paris last week, anxieties in France, and elsewhere in Europe, have been high. Increased security in the country has recalled the situation in the United States after the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: President of New York City Police Union Faces Internal Opposition
abstract: Amid a rift among officers and Mayor Bill de Blasio, Patrick J. Lynch is beating back dissent within his Patrolmen’s Benevolent Association as he seeks a fifth term as president.
lead_paragraph: The head of the union for New York City’s police lieutenants laid out ideas for repairing a rift with Mayor Bill de Blasio. The leader of the sergeants union planned a trip to Texas to talk to black clergy members and offer suggestions for mending the police-civilian divide.

headline: After an Absence, NBC Agrees to a Ringside Seat
abstract: There is something old-fashioned about boxing’s returning to network TV with regularity, and NBC faces the challenge of resurrecting the heralded past.
lead_paragraph: To announce the return of boxing to network television, NBC staged a media event without bellowing promoters, snarling fighters, eccentric fight camp hangers-on or bitten ears. It was oddly civilized, with sushi for lunch.

headline: Put In for Extra Time
abstract: Herre Schouwerwou makes his debut with a punny puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial “Win Valuable Prizes” Alert! Registration is now open for the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament (which returns to its original home in Stamford, Connecticut this year), and, if you sign up before March 24, 2015, you can get $10 off the registration fee. There’s a Friday night interactive puzzle that can be solved in teams, as well as the usual conviviality and puzzle solving. Be there or be a whole bunch of tiny black and white squares.

headline: Attack Raises Questions on Roots of Muslim Objection to Image-Making
abstract: While many Muslims were upset by the caricatures of Muhammad in Charlie Hebdo, the origins of their objection to visual depictions of the prophet and holy persons of any faith are far from clear.
lead_paragraph: Many Muslims upset by the caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad published in Charlie Hebdo, the French satirical newspaper, argue that the issue is not free speech but the insult to a religious figure revered by roughly a quarter of the world’s population.

headline: A Business Collapse Froze His Income, and Then the Pharmacy Bills Came
abstract: Moshe Orlansky, a former doughnut maker at Donut Delite Baking and Processing Company, faced surprising bills after a medical crisis.
lead_paragraph: When you are glazing doughnuts, they have to be really warm, just moments out of the fryer, for the glaze to coat them properly.

headline: In Detroit, Google Makes a Case for Driverless Cars
keywords: ['Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Google hopes to have fully autonomous vehicles on the road by 2020, taking the driver out of the equation and handing the virtual wheel to software.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The automobile industry has spent the last century trying to forge a visceral connection between drivers and their cars. On Wednesday, the head of Google’s driverless-car program came here to declare much of that bond may soon be a thing of the past.

headline: Crisis in France Is Seen as Sign of Chronic Ills
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Terrorism', 'Suburbs', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: After the Paris attacks, appeals for unity have hardly penetrated the sense of isolation, even siege, felt in disaffected suburbs like Vaulx-en-Velin.
lead_paragraph: VAULX-EN-VELIN, France — France may have just hosted its biggest outpouring of solidarity since the end of World War II in response to the terrorist attacks last week in and around Paris that left 17 dead at the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo and a kosher supermarket.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 14, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Obama Announces Moves to Encourage Expansion of Public Broadband Networks
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'States (US)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: President Obama said allowing cities to provide high-speed Internet would lower the cost and help break what he called a near monopoly in some markets.
lead_paragraph: CEDAR FALLS, Iowa — President Obama announced executive actions on Wednesday to expand high-speed Internet access and make it more affordable, including an effort to spur the creation of municipal broadband networks that could challenge the nation’s large telecommunications companies.

headline: Republican Convention Set Earlier Next Year
abstract: The party’s presidential nominating convention in Cleveland will be held a month or more earlier than usual, giving the nominee more time to use general election money.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Republican National Committee announced Wednesday that it would hold next year’s presidential nominating convention from July 18-21, a month or more earlier than usual.

headline: Phil Africa, of Black-Liberation Group Move, Long in Prison, Dies at 59
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Mr. Africa, who was serving a 30- to 100-year sentence for killing a police officer, was in prison at the time of Move’s best-known episode, a 1985 siege that ended when the state police dropped a bomb, touching off the worst fire in Philadelphia’s history.
lead_paragraph: Phil Africa, a high-ranking member of the Philadelphia-based black-liberation group Move, who was serving a 30- to 100-year sentence in the 1978 fatal shooting of a police officer, died on Saturday at the state prison in Dallas, Pa., near Wilkes-Barre. He was 59.

headline: Iran Charges, and Will Try, Jason Rezaian, Washington Post Reporter
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Iranian-Americans', 'International Relations']
abstract: Iran’s official news agency said that Mr. Rezaian would be tried in a Revolutionary Court, although it did not specify the charges against him.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Post’s correspondent in Iran, who has been imprisoned since July for unspecified reasons, has been formally charged and will be tried in a Revolutionary Court, the country’s official Islamic Republic News Agency said Wednesday. It did not describe the charges or say when the trial would begin.

headline: Nets Put On Sleepy Show After Morning Workout
abstract: Lionel Hollins put the Nets through a morning shootaround on Wednesday, their first on the day of a home game this season. But they went on to their seventh straight loss, falling to Memphis.
lead_paragraph: Lionel Hollins summoned the Nets to the team’s practice center in East Rutherford, N.J., to go through a shootaround Wednesday morning before a night game against the Memphis Grizzlies.

headline: New York Attorney General Seeks Expanded Reports on Data Breaches
abstract: A planned bill would expand New York’s definition of what constitutes the type of private information whose breach would mandate a disclosure. It would cover email addresses and passwords.
lead_paragraph: Across much of the United States, companies are not required to report a data breach if it is limited to the theft of email addresses and passwords, even though many companies do so of their own volition.

headline: Under New Agreement, U.S. Will End Oversight of the Teamsters in Five Years
abstract: The federal government and the Teamsters union have agreed to replace a consent decree that has governed union affairs for more than a quarter-century with a settlement that would phase out court supervision of its activities, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: The federal government and the Teamsters union have agreed to replace a consent decree that has governed union affairs for more than a quarter-century with a settlement that would phase out court supervision of its activities after five years, prosecutors said on Wednesday.

headline: U.S. Moves Five Yemenis From Guantánamo
abstract: The transfers came one day after several Republican senators proposed legislation that would place a moratorium on the release of most of the prisoners held at Guantánamo.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States transferred five more detainees — all of them Yemenis — from the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, on Wednesday, the Defense Department announced. Their release intensified the dispute between the Obama administration and several Republican senators over President Obama’s recent flurry of transfers as he seeks to empty the American-run prison.

headline: Suddenly, India Cuts Interest Rates
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The central bank cut its benchmark short-term interest rates by a quarter percentage point as falling prices for oil and other commodities have helped control inflation.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — India’s central bank unexpectedly cut its benchmark short-term interest rates Thursday morning by a quarter percentage point as steeply falling prices for oil and other commodities have helped bring inflation under control and allowed the bank to focus more on allowing faster economic growth.

headline: Alternate-Side Parking Rules in New York in 2015
abstract: Following are the days on which alternate-side street-cleaning rules will be suspended in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Following are the days on which alternate-side street-cleaning rules will be suspended in 2015.

headline: New York City Education Department to Add or Expand 40 Dual-Language Programs
abstract: Carmen Fariña, the schools chancellor, said the programs for elementary, middle and high school levels would be created or expanded for the 2015-16 school year.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Education Department plans to expand dual-language programs offered in public schools, using the orchestra of local languages to spread bilingual little symphonies across the five boroughs — and perhaps to attract more middle-class families to poorer schools in the process.

headline: Police Slowdown Cost New York City an Estimated $5 Million in Lost Fines
abstract: Unwritten parking tickets over the last three weeks, when parking tickets dropped as much as 90 percent, accounted for about $3 million of the lost revenue.
lead_paragraph: Now that New York’s police force has returned to enforcing the laws at a pace closer to normal, city officials are calculating the costs of its protracted slowdown. Their best guess so far is that the tally will be no more than several million dollars.

headline: A Most Dangerous Profession
abstract: On the North Shore of Oahu, 42 full-time lifeguards patrol a stretch of beach that attracts both pro surfers and amateur swimmers seeking to tangle with massive swells.
lead_paragraph: On the North Shore of Oahu, 42 full-time lifeguards patrol a stretch of beach that attracts both pro surfers and amateur swimmers seeking to tangle with massive swells.

lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

abstract: Stepan was listed as day to day after sustaining what the team called an upper-body injury Tuesday night against the Islanders.
lead_paragraph: Rangers center Derek Stepan was listed as day to day after sustaining what the team called an upper-body injury Tuesday night against the Islanders.

abstract: A major goal of the Affordable Care Act was to improve the financial security of previously uninsured people. A new survey suggests this is happening.
lead_paragraph: After rising for a decade, the number of Americans experiencing financial distress from their medical bills has started to decline, a new survey has found.

abstract: Findings in the report, by the Department of Investigation, underscore the profound dysfunction at Rikers Island and help explain how a culture of violence and corruption has come to flourish in the city jails.

lead_paragraph: A recent applicant for a job as a correction officer at New York City jails had several friends who were gang members. Another had been arrested four times and had been fired from a job as a security guard for stealing from the business he was supposedly guarding.

keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Euro (Currency)', 'US Dollar (Currency)']

lead_paragraph: The strong dollar and threat of deflation may be wreaking havoc on European economies, but as an American consumer it has made me feel flush.

headline: Defense Contractor Scheduled to Change Plea in Navy Bribery Case
abstract: Leonard Glenn Francis is set to appear at a change-of-plea hearing on Thursday in federal court in San Diego. He previously pleaded not guilty to conspiracy in the case.
lead_paragraph: A Malaysian defense contractor awaiting trial on corruption charges is scheduled to change his plea in a multimillion dollar bribery scheme that led to the arrest of several high-ranking Navy officials.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10:15 P.M. (TMC) IN THE NAME OF THE FATHER (1993) Daniel Day-Lewis and Pete Postlethwaite star in Jim Sheridan’s adaptation of “Proved Innocent,” Gerry Conlon’s memoir about an Irishman whose coerced confession for an Irish Republican Army bombing he didn’t commit imprisons his father as well. Emma Thompson plays the lawyer who tries to free them. Writing in The New York Times, Janet Maslin called the film, which was nominated for seven Oscars, “scathingly brilliant” and Mr. Day-Lewis’s performance “dazzling.”

headline: Trying to Solve the Great Wage Slowdown
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Taxation', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: An international commission, describing income stagnation as a defining challenge, offers proposals meant to influence the political debate.
lead_paragraph: After almost 15 years of a disappointing economy, it’s easy to get pessimistic. Incomes for the middle class and poor have now been stagnating over a two-term Republican presidency and well into a two-term Democratic one. The great wage slowdown of the 21st century has frustrated Americans, polls show, and raised serious questions about what kind of policies, if any, might change the situation.

headline: Time to Test North Korea’s Intentions
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: Pyongyang’s offer to impose a moratorium on nuclear testing may suggest a new willingness to restart negotiations.
lead_paragraph: North Korea thrust itself back into the international limelight with its recent hacking of Sony Pictures. As always, however, the gravest danger from North Korea is the threat that its unpredictable leaders could one day unleash a nuclear weapon, either in anger or by mistake.

headline: How to Spend New York’s Spare $5 Billion
abstract: Albany’s treasury is fat with the state’s share of fines, which should go to carefully chosen, one-time investments. Here are a few ideas.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a scary thought: New York State’s politicians suddenly have an extra $5 billion to spend. Albany’s treasury is fat with the state’s share of fines paid by financial institutions for past misconduct. And in all but a few cases, there are no real strings attached. So the scrum has started, with virtually every politician and interest group and government entity scrambling for a share of the windfall.

headline: Expanding Community College Access
abstract: President Obama’s proposal to make community college tuition-free could be crucial in the information age. It needs to be taken seriously.
lead_paragraph: In the abstract, President Obama’s proposal for making community college tuition-free seems a reasonable response to a troublesome fact: The American work force is less educated than it needs to be at a time when most jobs in the new economy will require some college education. But for such an idea to work, states and localities that have been starving community colleges for decades will need to begin holding them to higher standards and commit to sustained financing instead of using the new federal money to dodge their own financial obligations.

headline: Test Yourself | In Case You Missed It …
abstract: Here are the first six paragraphs from a Jan. 2 article, “The Unending Anxiety of an ICYMI World.” Can you choose the best word or phrase for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are the first six paragraphs from a Jan. 2 article, “The Unending Anxiety of an ICYMI World.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Impossible Task? Climbers Come Out on Top
abstract: What challenge “long considered impossible” did two climbers complete on Jan. 14?
lead_paragraph: In “Impossible Task? Climbers Come Out on Top” John Branch writes about two men who just completed what is considered to be the most challenging rock climb in the world.

headline: Hired, Fired and Ready for a New Tennis Season
abstract: Stars and newcomers alike are making changes to their coaching staffs as the tennis year begins at the Australian Open in Melbourne.
lead_paragraph: As another tennis season begins in earnest with next week’s Australian Open, the cards may or may not have been reshuffled but the support staffs definitely have been.

headline: Should Newspapers Reprint Cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad That Some Deem Offensive?
abstract: Would being able to see the Charlie Hebdo cartoons help readers better understand an important news event? Are the cartoons deliberately offensive, and will republishing them likely offend reasonable readers?
lead_paragraph: Newspapers around the world had a choice this past week. They could republish cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad that originally ran in the French satirical paper Charlie Hebdo, which was attacked last week by terrorists. Or they could choose not to.

headline: Robert Frank, Telling It Like It Was
abstract: Robert Frank’s favorite image from “The Americans” captures the contradiction of racism in the liberal climes of mid-century San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: One of the most consequential images in Robert Frank’s “The Americans” is a raw, cinematic photograph of a black couple in San Francisco in 1956. Approaching them from behind as the pair relaxed on a grassy hill overlooking the city, Mr. Frank disrupted their solitude. Startled, they turned to acknowledge him. The woman was annoyed. The man crouched protectively. As his eyes locked on the photographer, his expression hardened into a scowl. The couple seemed determined to protect themselves and their dignity.

headline: German Economy Expanded 1.5% in 2014
abstract: The growth, in line with forecasts, was up from a rate of 0.1 percent a year earlier, as employment rose to record levels and consumers spent more.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Germany’s economy accelerated in the final quarter of 2014 as consumer spending picked up, according to data published on Thursday, a sign that the largest economy in the eurozone could perform moderately better than expected in 2015.

headline: Filipinos, Their Faith Strong but Shifting, Hail Pope
abstract: Pope Francis’ arrival Thursday marked the first papal visit in 20 years to a country whose Catholic Church is struggling with profound social and political change.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Cheering throngs greeted Pope Francis when he arrived in the deeply Catholic Philippines on Thursday evening, the first papal visit in 20 years to a country whose church is struggling with profound social changes and a decline in political power.

headline: In India, a Banker in Defense Mode
abstract: Raghuram G. Rajan, the governor of the Reserve Bank of India, has become the subject of a political struggle as he reduces a benchmark rate.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — Few central bankers in emerging markets have been as internationally lionized as Raghuram G. Rajan of India.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: Get-Rich-Quick Dreams
abstract: Thursday: The allure of spilled cash, slightly warmer weather, and tallying the cost of the police slowdown.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this somewhat warmer Thursday.

headline: Swiss Franc Soars After Central Bank Drops Cap
abstract: The Swiss central bank increased the amount it charges depositors to hold their cash, to little avail.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Switzerland stunned the markets on Thursday by abandoning a crucial part of its effort to hold down the value of its currency, concluding that the strategy was too risky and too costly given the enormous forces pushing in the other direction.

headline: Daily Report: Starring in Your Own Snapchat Story
abstract: Imagine a short and very personal TV show: directed, edited and starring you. It lasts 24 hours and then — poof! — it’s gone.
lead_paragraph: An original promise of social media was that it mimicked real life. Sites like Facebook, Twitter and Instagram offered places to capture and share your memories, but after using them for several years, I feel like someone who was sold a lemon by a used-car salesman, Nick Bilton writes in his Disruptions column.

headline: Oscar Nominations 2015: ‘Birdman’ and ‘Grand Budapest Hotel’ Lead the Pack
abstract: “Birdman” and “Grand Budapest Hotel’’ each received nine nominations for the 87th Academy Awards, which will take place Feb. 22. “Boyhood” also was confirmed as a best picture favorite.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES— Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s “Birdman” and Richard Linklater’s “Boyhood” were showered with honors on Thursday as the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences confirmed what’s been whispered for months: Those are the films to beat at the 87th Oscar show on Feb. 22.

headline: 1890: Moving Day in Paris
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: it was Moving Day in Paris in 1890.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The highways and byeways of the metropolis were disfigured yesterday from dawn till dark with countless furniture vans, which, laden down and creaking under the weight of beds, boxes, book cases, chairs, stoves, carpets, tables and all the thousand and one things which go to make up a home, crawled along with cracking whips and swearing drivers, bringing the penates of many an unsettled family to some new abiding place. It was the fifteenth of January, dreaded day when grinding landlords and landladies insist on having their quarter’s rent. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 16, 1890

headline: French Rein In Speech Backing Acts of Terror
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Muslims and Islam', 'ANTI-SEMITISM']
abstract: Recent court cases in Paris have raised accusations of a double standard on free speech with some pointing to a divide between cartoonists and statements made by Muslim supporters of the gunmen.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French authorities are moving aggressively to rein in speech supporting terrorism, employing a new law to mete out tough prison sentences in a crackdown that is stoking a free-speech debate after last week’s attacks in Paris.

headline: Caesars Unit Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: TPG and Apollo Global Management are hoping to use the bankruptcy to salvage as much as they can, but they are facing opposition from some of Wall Street’s biggest investors.
lead_paragraph: The casino operator Caesars Entertainment was locked in a bitter standoff with some creditors on Thursday after it put its largest unit into bankruptcy.

headline: Throwback Thursday | Cat People and Dog People
abstract: An 1872 editorial argues that “lunatics” often have an “excessive fondness for felines.”
lead_paragraph: It’s worth reading all of this 1872 editiorial (PDF), headlined “Cats and Craziness,” to follow the author’s full argument that “lunatics” often have an “excessive fondness for cats.”

headline: Oklahoma Executes First Inmate Since Slipshod Injection in April
abstract: A sharp dissent held that the drug combination being used in Oklahoma risked causing severe, unconstitutional suffering. But the other five justices voted without comment to deny the appeal for a stay.
lead_paragraph: McALESTER, Okla. — With a renovated death chamber, new training and a higher dose of drugs, Oklahoma on Thursday carried out its first execution since April, when the slipshod, prolonged killing of Clayton D. Lockett led the state to suspend lethal injections and change its procedures.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: While Republicans are holding a high profile retreat in Pennsylvania, Senate Democrats, two months removed from their bruising midterm losses, have quietly hunkered down in Baltimore for two days to lick their wounds.
lead_paragraph: Senate Democrats Regroup in Baltimore as G.O.P. Savors Victory

headline: Court Winnows Jury Pool in Boston Marathon Bombing Trial
abstract: Remaining candidates are expected to be questioned individually as jury selection resumes in the trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the defendant in the 2013 attack.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — One potential juror said his wife was an intensive care nurse who had treated victims of the Boston Marathon bombing. Another had posted comments on social media while his neighborhood was on lockdown during a manhunt for the suspects. Yet another said he could not imagine any evidence that would make him think the defendant was innocent — and his friends had told him it would be “cool” to impose the death sentence.

headline: Researchers Propose Earth’s ‘Anthropocene’ Age of Humans Began With Fallout and Plastics
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Earth', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Environment', 'Geology', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Nuclear Tests', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Plastics', 'Sustainable Living', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: A research team assessing whether and when a new geological age shaped by humans began has settled on the mid 20th century, with plastics and nuclear bombs as markers.
lead_paragraph: As many readers are aware, I’ve been writing since 1992 about the notion that we’ve left the Holocene behind — that’s the geological epoch since the end of the last ice age — and entered “a post-Holocene…geological age of our own making,” now best known as the Anthropocene.

headline: China Debates How to Manage Unruly Airline Passengers
abstract: A flier opened the emergency door of a plane taxiing in the southwestern city of Chongqing this week. It was the latest in a spate of passengers misbehaving, leading to calls for tougher punishment.
lead_paragraph: A spate of passengers opening the emergency doors of taxiing airplanes in China has led to calls for tougher punishment of unruly fliers.

headline: Bank of America’s Profit Falls 11%, Hurt by Consumer Loans and Investment Banking
abstract: The outstanding totals for every type of consumer loan fell at the bank in 2014, suggesting that lending to consumers remains lukewarm.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America on Thursday reported fourth-quarter results that fell short of expectations, sending a lackluster signal about the state of banking and the wider economy.

headline: A Dark Prince Steps Into the Light
abstract: At 46, Marilyn Manson, with a career as a best-selling goth rock star and agitator behind him, is facing a bit of an identity crisis.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — “We’re drinking wodka,” Marilyn Manson said, pronouncing the word like he was a fur-hatted Russian cartoon character, and filling a tumbler. Two tumblers: Like any peacocking musician, he knew that a drinking buddy makes for a ready audience.

headline: Cartoons Spoofing Corrupt Politicians in China Anger City
abstract: Dozens of images that made fun of the officials appeared on walls alongside a road in Changsha. Local authorities were not amused, and they have ordered that the cartoons be painted over.
lead_paragraph: President Xi Jinping of China has vowed that there will be no relenting in his sweeping crackdown on official corruption, but an artist in the central city of Changsha who mounted his own campaign is facing a government slap down.

headline: Morning Agenda: Profit Slides at Bank of America
abstract: Bank of America reports uninspiring fourth-quarter results. | New York’s attorney general seeks expanded reporting on data breaches. | A strategy in the fight over Dodd-Frank. | BlackBerry’s stock goes on a wild ride.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America reported uninspiring fourth-quarter results on Thursday, saying its earnings fell to $3.05 billion, or 25 cents a share, from $3.44 billion, or 29 cents a share, in the period a year earlier, DealBook’s Peter Eavis reports. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had forecast that the bank would earn 31 cents a share in the latest quarter.
