headline: France’s Jews Have No Choice but Israel
abstract: If the only way for Jews to live in France today is behind guards with guns, perhaps emigrating makes sense.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — There is great irony to Israel’s instinctive response to terror attacks on Jews in Europe — and the devastating attack last week on a kosher grocery store in Paris was no different.

headline: Citigroup Profit Plunges on Weak Trading and Legal Costs
abstract: The bank said profit fell to $350 million from $2.5 billion in the period a year earlier, weighed down by large legal charges and a greater than expected drop in trading revenue.
lead_paragraph: A steeper than expected trading slowdown dented Citigroup’s earnings in the fourth quarter, contributing to the bank’s failure to meet analysts’ profit expectations and raising a fresh round of questions about the future of the Wall Street trading machine.

lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — Secretary of State John Kerry said Thursday that the United States would help Bulgaria reduce its dependence on Russia for energy supplies.

abstract: More than 50 years of Rolling Stones images, collected.
lead_paragraph: More than 50 years of Rolling Stones images, collected.

headline: Jumpin’ Jack Flash Bulb
abstract: “The Rolling Stones,” a new book collecting more than 50 years of images of the band, contains previously uncirculated photographs from its own archives.
lead_paragraph: Last June, I experienced the Rolling Stones live like I never had in the past: four shows, four European cities, four countries — in a frenetic two-week stretch.

headline: BlackRock’s Profit Slips Despite Strong Flows Into Its Funds
abstract: BlackRock continued to benefit from strong investor flows in the fourth quarter, although the company’s growth was down slightly compared with results in the period a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: BlackRock, the world’s largest money manager, continued to benefit from strong investor inflows in the fourth quarter, although the company’s growth was down slightly compared with results in the period a year earlier.

headline: 2015 Oscar Nominations
abstract: Nominations for the 87th Academy Awards were announced on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Nominations for the 87th Academy Awards were announced on Thursday.

headline: Show Leigh Steinberg the Money (Again)
abstract: The original football superagent tries to pull off a fourth-quarter comeback.
lead_paragraph: Leigh Steinberg stepped onto the football field at Southern Methodist University under a cloudy Texas sky. At events he hosts — like his gigantic annual Super Bowl bash — Steinberg, a sports agent, is accustomed to parading around like a presidential candidate, working the crowd with a boyish smile and a pinstripe suit. On the Dallas campus last March, in his sweatshirt and baggy bluejeans, Steinberg looked more like a guy at the local horse track. He riffled through a booklet of notes and popped a stick of Nicorette into his mouth. His client, the quarterback Garrett Gilbert, was the one who had to put on a show in front of more than 30 N.F.L. scouts, but Steinberg’s own prospects were also being tested.

headline: Surf Is Fierce, but So Are They
abstract: The workers who patrol Oahu’s North Shore battle a force far greater than anything that technology can overcome: In 2013, they handled more than 1,000 ocean rescues and major medical cases.
lead_paragraph: HALEIWA, Hawaii — Dusk masked the approaching waves at Banzai Pipeline on the North Shore of Oahu as they climbed to 15 feet before pounding the shallow, jagged reef below. Adrift in the rapid current and foamy sea was a photographer, exhausted from battling the relentless waves and fighting for his life.

headline: An Upper East Side Apartment in a Hurry
abstract: With his lease expiring, Joseph Nawy searched for a one-bedroom apartment.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Nawy grew up on Manhattan’s Upper West Side. After his marriage, he lived first in Queens and then in New Jersey. When his two sons were grown, he and his wife moved to Tennessee for work. Shortly thereafter, his wife died.

headline: The Weird Science of Naming New Products
abstract: To find the perfect brand, leave no word unturned.
lead_paragraph: The announcement came in November with two names attached: one famous, one not, or at least not yet. The famous name was Paul McCartney. Anyone who wanted to try a virtual-reality experience starring the former Beatle — replicating the sensation of standing center stage with him as he sang “Live and Let Die” to 70,000 screaming fans — had only to download a special video file, put the file into an app for their Android phone and slip the phone into a cardboard headset designed by Google. The not-yet-famous name was of the virtual-reality production process that created this experience. Reviewers said it was “mind-­blowingly cool” and an “exciting preview of the future,” but it was also so novel that it had been hard to think of a word to label it. Its inventors had wanted a name that would lodge in the public consciousness the same way Dolby and Imax and Blu-ray had. A name that could become a verb as well as a noun. An iconic name. A name for the ages.

headline: In Southeast Ireland, a Culinary and Coastal Destination
abstract: Creative chefs are giving visitors another reason to go to West Waterford.
lead_paragraph: The West Waterford region on Ireland’s southeast coast is a favorite among the Irish for its idyllic beaches, picturesque villages and sprawling green fields blanketed with sheep. Now the area, an hour’s drive east from Cork, is fast becoming known for its epicurean culture, which includes new high-quality restaurants and food purveyors.

headline: Along the Niger River, the Beat of the Sahel
abstract: The Festival on the Niger, in Ségou, Mali, does much to cheer and calm a country recently torn by jihadists.
lead_paragraph: Down by the Niger River last February, a Tuareg street performer was warming up the crowd. The evening concert at the Festival on the Niger was about to begin, and the promenade inside the concert grounds was filled with early arrivals. Dozens had gathered in a circle around the elderly nomad, who was draped in a blue robe and a black veil. Robe flying, the toothless dervish hurled himself to the ground, flipped and twirled with the loose-limbed dexterity of a teenager. Two Tuareg women, seated cross-legged on the ground, served as his musical backups: One beat a calabash with a plastic sandal, the other played a tapered wood-and-goatskin drum known as a tendé.

headline: In Baton Rouge, They’re Still Singing the Blues
abstract: Decades after the Louisianan capital’s glory as a hub for the blues, a few authentic spots remain.
lead_paragraph: There was a time, around 40 years ago, when Baton Rouge was not only the blues capital of Louisiana but also one of the busiest blues hubs in the entire United States.

headline: Starting Friday, U.S. Will Ease Restrictions on Travel to Cuba
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: While ordinary tourism remains banned by law, new rules put in place by President Obama will make it easier for Americans to visit Cuba than it has been for most of the last 50 years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For decades, the aging tourist mecca of Havana beckoned, but the United States did not make it easy for Americans hoping to visit. They had to justify their trips to a government agency, apply for licenses, sign up with a company organizing “people to people” exchanges, or circumvent the law altogether by flying somewhere else first.

headline: Target’s Red Ink Runs Out in Canada
abstract: The company, which has made major management changes in the last year, is closing more than 100 Canadian stores less than two years after they opened.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Less than two years after opening in Canada, Target conceded defeat on Thursday and said it would shutter its 133 stores, bringing an infamously ill-managed northward foray by the American retail giant to an abrupt end.

headline: Publisher of Nature and Scientific American to Form Joint Venture
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity']
abstract: The joint venture will combine the majority of the Holtzbrinck Publishing Group’s Macmillan Science and Education division with Springer Science & Business Media.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The German publisher of Scientific American and Nature magazines has agreed to form a joint venture with the private-equity backed Springer Science & Business Media to create a global science and education publishing house.

headline: In Paris, a Music Hall Built for Unity Offers a Stirring First Act
abstract: A lot is riding on the success of the hotly debated Philharmonie, which opened with the Orchestre de Paris performing a challenging program.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For months, contentious debates and infighting played out in the international media. Could the Philharmonie de Paris, the new concert hall for the Orchestre de Paris and the final linchpin in a decades-long project to turn a park on the northeast rim of this city into a major cultural center, open on schedule? It seemed impossible.

headline: Beijing Moves to Halt Crime Spilling Out of North Korea
abstract: Authorities in China have organized civilian militias to help secure largely unprotected areas that are near the border of North Korea, a state-run publication has reported.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A jump in violent crime in Chinese towns near the border with North Korea has prompted the authorities in China to organize civilian militias to help secure the largely unprotected border, a state-run publication has reported.

headline: Terry Richardson Returns to Magazine Covers, Without a Fuss
abstract: Doesn’t the photographer’s reappearance in the magazine world undermine fashion’s role in women’s lives?
lead_paragraph: It’s been a big week for forgiveness in fashion: John Galliano made his reappearance on the runway under the aegis of Maison Margiela, and the American Harper’s Bazaar and Rolling Stone unveiled their latest covers, courtesy of the photographer Terry Richardson.

headline: CME Again Raises Offer for GFI Group After Increased Hostile Bid
abstract: The revised offer comes a day after BGC Partners raised its own bid to $5.60 a share in cash.
lead_paragraph: The CME Group said on Thursday that it had increased its offer to acquire the GFI Group, a New York brokerage and clearing house, as it tries to stave off a competing hostile bid by BGC Partners.

headline: Technology Has Made Life Different, but Not Necessarily More Stressful
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Sociology']
abstract: It is conventional wisdom that things like frequent email checking and heavy use of social media make people twitchy. But is it true?
lead_paragraph: Among New Year’s resolutions shared on Twitter, unplugging digitally came right after losing weight and quitting smoking. People are flocking to digital detoxes, screen-free bedrooms and apps that nudge you off your phone.

headline: A 12-Hour Window for a Healthy Weight
abstract: Eating only within a 12-hour period every day could make a big diet difference.
lead_paragraph: This article appeared in the January 18, 2015 issue of The New York Times Magazine.

headline: The Snubs (‘Lego Movie,’ Aniston) and the Semi-Surprises (Cotillard, Dern)
abstract: Did the Academy’s animation panel overlook “Lego” because it wasn’t hand-drawn or stop motion?
lead_paragraph: And lo it came to pass in the predawn hours of this Los Angeles morning that the fruits of millions of dollars spent in ad campaigns, watermarked screeners and other forms of Academy member wooing – along with creative blood, sweat and tears, were revealed with the Oscar nominations, listed here.

headline: Best Buy Outlook Overshadows Holiday Sales Gains
abstract: The electronics retailer said factors that buoyed end-of-year results were unlikely to endure, and its stock dropped sharply.
lead_paragraph: Best Buy said on Thursday that holiday-season sales in the United States grew by 2.6 percent as brisk sales of flat-screen TVs and smartphones offset limp demand for tablets. But the retailer said it expected electronics demand to wane in the new year.

headline: In Brooklyn, Fertile Ground for a Wind Turbine
keywords: ['Wind Power', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: Four years in the making, the new wind turbine in Sunset Park is expected to provide 4 percent of the power consumed by a recycling plant.
lead_paragraph: Modern-day Don Quixotes looking to tilt at wind turbines can see their latest fearsome foe from far and wide: Lower Manhattan; Red Hook, Brooklyn; or the Gowanus Expressway.

headline: In Gesture to Tamils, Sri Lanka Replaces Provincial Leader
abstract: Addressing a longtime complaint of Tamil leaders, President Maithripala Sirisena replaced a retired army commander with a retired diplomat.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — A week after taking office, Sri Lanka’s new president reached out to ethnic Tamils in the country’s north on Thursday by appointing a new governor for the Northern Province, replacing a retired army commander with a retired diplomat.

headline: The 2015 Academy Awards’ Top Nominees
abstract: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts president Cheryl Boone Isaacs and the actor Chris Pine announced the 2015 Oscar nominations for best director, best actress, best actor and best picture.
lead_paragraph: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts president Cheryl Boone Isaacs and the actor Chris Pine announced the 2015 Oscar nominations for best director, best actress, best actor and best picture.

headline: An Old Role, but New Tresses
abstract: John Cameron Mitchell stars in “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” on Broadway, in a part he has played elsewhere and in the movie.
lead_paragraph: Ghosts are all around John Cameron Mitchell, and not just those said to haunt Broadway’s Belasco Theater.

headline: Dollar General Admits to Long Odds in Pursuing Family Dollar
abstract: In highlighting the obstacles that it still faces — principally a disagreement over how many stores it would need to sell — Dollar General was seen by analysts as conceding defeat.
lead_paragraph: The monthslong race for Family Dollar appeared near an end on Thursday, as Dollar General pleaded for more time to complete its $9.1 billion hostile takeover bid amid steep regulatory hurdles.

headline: At Pitti Uomo in Florence, Put a Hat on It
abstract: The story of SuperDuper Hats is characteristic of the successes on display at the men’s fashion fair.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Italy — In December 1929, Irving Berlin published a song with an irresistible but notoriously complex rhythmic pattern and lyrics about the custom in Harlem of putting on one’s Sunday finery to parade up and down Lenox Avenue, “Spendin’ every dime/For a wonderful time.”

headline: Compliance Shake-Up at R.B.S. as General Counsel and 3 Others Leave Bank
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: John Collins, the bank’s deputy general counsel, has succeeded Chris Campbell, who retired as general counsel last month, and three other compliance staff members are joining other banks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Royal Bank of Scotland is experiencing a shake-up in its compliance staff, with its general counsel and three other staff members having left or preparing to leave the bank.

headline: 2016 Hopefuls Skirt Leaders of the G.O.P.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A kind of political free agency, surfacing before the new Senate has passed a single bill, poses an early test for the party as it looks to expand its power and prove it can govern.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Republican majority in Congress is barely a week old. Until just a few days ago, the new sign outside Senator Mitch McConnell’s office, freshly stenciled with the words “majority leader,” was not even screwed in properly. But an important group of Republicans has already decided that it is ready to move on.

headline: Turkey Casts Doubt on Chinese Account of Turks’ Arrests in Smuggling Plot
abstract: The Turkish Foreign Ministry confirmed that 10 Turks were under arrest in China but did not say they had been helping terrorism suspects, as a Chinese report asserted.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Turkish Foreign Ministry has confirmed that 10 Turkish citizens are under arrest in China on charges of trying to smuggle people out of the country, but it did not say they had been helping terrorism suspects, as a Chinese news report asserted.

headline: A Shock in the Foreign Language Category
abstract: “Force Majeure,” the Swedish entry, was widely thought to be a shoo-in, but was left off the list, which did include two favorites, “Leviathan” and “Ida.”
lead_paragraph: In the end, all the early buzz about Sweden’s “Force Majeure” came to naught. To the surprise of all the Oscarologists who had director Ruben Ostlund’s movie high on their lists, the film, a positively reviewed mixture of drama and dark comedy set in a ski resort, was not nominated Thursday for the Academy Award for best foreign-language film.

headline: Economic Lessons From Switzerland’s One-Day, 18 Percent Currency Rise
keywords: ['Euro (Currency)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Swiss Franc (Currency)']
abstract: The Swiss franc’s abrupt movement shows how the monetary activism of central banks, in this case the E.C.B., can have unintended consequences.
lead_paragraph: These are strange and unnerving times in global financial markets, and if Thursday’s jaw-dropping move in the Swiss currency didn’t prove it, nothing will.

headline: Rising Fears Among French Jews in Wake of Terror Attack: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Dan Bilefsky give Insiders a glimpse of how he reported and assembled his Page 1 article, “Fear on the Rise, Jews in France Weigh an Exit.”
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, the reporter Dan Bilefsky wrote a front-page article about French Jews contemplating emigration in the context of rising fear of anti-Semitism and attack. Here, he gives Insiders a glimpse of how he reported and assembled his story.

headline: Inside the Kitty Cafe
abstract: A tour of Meow Parlour, New York’s new cat cafe on the Lower East Side.
lead_paragraph: A tour of Meow Parlour, New York’s new cat cafe on the Lower East Side.

headline: Oscar Nominations 2015: Michael Keaton Plans to Spend the Day Smiling
abstract: An Academy Award nod caps off a week that started with a Golden Globe win.
lead_paragraph: Even though Michael Keaton was considered a lock in the best actor category this year, for his performance as Riggan Thomson in “Birdman,” finally getting the Academy’s nomination brought, he told the Bagger, a measure of relief.

headline: Cat Cafe Offers a Place to Snuggle, With Reservations
abstract: At Meow Parlour on the Lower East Side, cat lovers can get their fill (for a fee).
lead_paragraph: MADELINE WEINSTEIN was reaching for the top of the shelves at Meow Parlour, New York’s new cat cafe, going for the ultimate prize: Roger, the most antisocial animal in the place. Down below, on floor level, nine other cats roamed, batting at toys, leaping exuberantly, bumping heads affectionately against the outstretched hands of customers. Roger remained aloof.

headline: 1940: Montgomery’s Anti-Nazi Film
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Robert Montgomery visits France between shoots of an anti-Nazi film in 1940.
lead_paragraph: Wearing one of the only American raccoon coats extant, either off or on a college campus, Robert Montgomery, Hollywood’s sardonic but smiling screen star, and the first to arrive in the European war zone since hostilities began, is now visiting Paris for a few days, prior to returning to England to resume motion-picture work. The first screen shooting for the star at the Denham studios will be a film story of the life of Pastor Martin Niemoeller, the fighting German clergyman and former submarine commander, who is now in a concentration camp for opposing the Nazi regime. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 16, 1940

headline: Skipping School for Vacation: Good for Families, or Bad for Students?
abstract: I’m a parent. I have taken my children out of school for family events and other trips. I am also an educator, and I have seen the havoc these absences can wreak on students and their teachers.
lead_paragraph: In the article “Taking My Kid Out of School for a Family Vacation Shouldn’t Be ‘Illegal,’” Jeanne Sager recounts the time she took her daughter out of school for a family vacation, and the school responded by labeling those absences “illegal.” Ms. Sager wrote, “I hate my kid’s school and the state education department for making me feel ashamed of spending time with my daughter,” adding, “I think there’s something to be said for education outside of the classroom, and certainly something to be said for the value of family time.”

headline: Pitti Uomo: Hood by Air Fall/Winter 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Pitti Uomo photo diary of Piotr Niepsuj.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Pitti Uomo photo diary of Piotr Niepsuj.

headline: Pitti Uomo: Hood by Air Fall/Winter 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Pitti Uomo photo diary of Piotr Niepsuj.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Pitti Uomo photo diary of Piotr Niepsuj.

headline: Oscar Nominations 2015: #OscarsSoWhite Emerges as Response
abstract: Twitter users responded to a lack of Oscar nominees of color with a hashtag that was used thousands of times in the hours after the Academy made its announcement.
lead_paragraph: The 2015 Oscars nominations did not recognize any actors of color, nor did the director Ava DuVernay receive a nod for her work on “Selma” (which is up for best picture). And the omissions were widely noted online.

headline: OPEC Report Downgrades Demand for Its Oil as Prices Fall Again
abstract: The report said that demand for crude would fall to 28.8 million barrels per day this year, 100,000 barrels a day less than it forecast last month.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries issued a report on Thursday that downgraded demand for its crude for 2015, while also predicting slower oil-production growth in the United States.

headline: Oscar Nominations 2015: Academy Surprisingly Overlooks Ebert Film
abstract: What is it about the Academy and Steve James? It famously omitted his “Hoop Dreams” from nominations and now it has snubbed his Roger Ebert documentary, “Life Itself.”
lead_paragraph: The Oscar nominations for best documentary include a major snub in what most Academy voters regard as a minor category: Steve James’s “Life Itself,” about the esteemed film critic Roger Ebert, was left off the list. Most prognosticators had it down as a co-favorite with Laura Poitras’s “Citizenfour,” about the whistleblower Edward Snowden.

headline: In Boston Classes, It’s All About Entertaining
abstract: The Eastern Standard restaurant in Boston is offering classes focusing on entertaining, from craft cocktails to macarons.
lead_paragraph: Boston’s Eastern Standard restaurant, in the newly renovated Hotel Commonwealth, is offering a day of culinary classes focusing on the art of entertainment.

headline: Stevie Wonder’s Tour Will Take Him to States He Vowed to Avoid
abstract: Mr. Wonder will perform his classic 1976 album in 11 cities, including some in states with Stand Your Ground laws, which he said in 2013 he would avoid.
lead_paragraph: What was once a limited engagement is back by popular demand: Stevie Wonder has extended last year’s “Songs in the Key of Life” tour, and will bring performances of his classic 1976 album to 11 more cities this spring.

headline: Music Video | Tide: The Paradox Effect
abstract: A video featuring the music of Dawn Richard.
lead_paragraph: A video featuring the music of Dawn Richard.

headline: Oscar Nominations 2015: Laura Poitras on the Uncertainties Surrounding ‘Citizenfour’
abstract: The director said she was unsure how the film, which touches on raw nerves, would be received.
lead_paragraph: Laura Poitras’s “Citizenfour,” about Edward J. Snowden’s leak of National Security Agency documents, has long been seen as the front-runner for the best documentary Oscar. It plays out like a thriller while touching on one of the rawest nerves of our time – government surveillance of private citizens.

headline: A Photographic — and Romantic — Duo Creates Double Self-Portraits With a Sense of Humor
abstract: Leta Sobierajski and Wade Jeffree use everyday objects and bright, vivid palettes to create intimate, expressive photos that document their life as a couple.
lead_paragraph: Leta Sobierajski and Wade Jeffree use everyday objects and bright, vivid palettes to create intimate, expressive photos that document their life as a couple.

headline: Times and Other News Organizations to Test Use of Drones
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']
abstract: The companies, which include The New York Times and NBC Universal, have formed a partnership with Virginia Tech.
lead_paragraph: A coalition of 10 news organizations, including The New York Times, The Washington Post and NBCUniversal, has formed a partnership with Virginia Tech to test drones for news gathering, the companies said on Thursday.

headline: Plant Love House
abstract: Thai street food in Elmhurst, Queens.
lead_paragraph: Thai street food in Elmhurst, Queens.

headline: Answering the Call of Friends
abstract: At Plant Love House in Elmhurst, Queens, a mother and her daughters offer Thai street food with house rules that will have you grinning.
lead_paragraph: It’s only at the end that the blood is tipped in, just before the bowl of num tok — an opaque, nearly black Thai noodle soup — is brought to the table. This is time enough for the blood to disperse in the broth and lose its drawn-sword tang. What I tasted was more elliptical: salt, minerals, a distinctly animal sweetness.

headline: A Call to Better Track Police Use of Guns
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Attacks on Police', 'Police', 'Firearms', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. called for improved tracking of the number of times law enforcement officers are shot at or fire their weapons, as part of a trust-building effort.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said Thursday that the federal government needed to improve how it tracks the number of times law enforcement officers across the country are shot at or fire their weapons, as part of an effort to restore trust between the police and the public.

headline: Welcome to (Your Name Here) Medical School
abstract: A medical journal explored the implications of more medical schools being renamed after benefactors.
lead_paragraph: Medical journals are fairly dry reading, and it isn’t often that I come across an intriguing headline like “Green Eggs and Ham.” But there it was in a recent issue of Academic Medicine, with a story noting how Dartmouth’s medical school had been renamed in 2012 for one of the university’s most famous graduates, Theodor Geisel, or Dr. Seuss — a doctor, of course, of a different kind. Dartmouth Medical School had been rechristened the Audrey and Theodor Geisel School of Medicine, joining a growing list of medical schools that had been renamed after benefactors.

headline: Republicans Resist Obama’s Move to Dismantle Apparatus of Deportation
abstract: Republicans want to restore a program canceled by President Obama called Secure Communities that led to deportations for immigrants arrested on minor charges.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — For four years Arturo Hernández García, an immigrant from Mexico, tried every legal move to stop his deportation. As a last resort, he camped out in the basement of a church here, seeking sanctuary from federal agents trying to expel him.

headline: Looser Rules for Travel to Cuba, a Destination Already in Transition
abstract: Announcing new, more flexible regulations, American officials expect visitors to get a view of life on the island rather than sit poolside with a margarita.
lead_paragraph: Estelle Grush sliced cucumber and guava in the busy kitchen one recent evening at Cafe Laurent, a small, privately owned restaurant in a 1950s penthouse a few blocks from Havana’s sweeping seafront.

headline: Republicans’ Hershey Retreat May Crackle With Debate
abstract: Lawmakers began Thursday morning with breakout sessions on the new Congress, the House leadership team holding one for their members, and the Senate leadership team hosting one for their conference.
lead_paragraph: HERSHEY, Pa. — Congressional Republicans gathered here in chocolatey Hershey, Pa., on Thursday to try to pick up the pieces of last year’s dysfunctional Congress, and despite pledges of unity, it’s not expected to be all hugs and kisses. Sparks could fly over the issue of immigration, and a strategy for handling health care will be up for debate.

headline: A Stylish, Futuristic New Music Video From the R&B Singer Dawn Richard
abstract: The visuals for “Tide: The Paradox Effect,” the second single from Richard’s sophomore album, “Blackheart,” find Richard embodied by an animated, Joan of Arc-esque gladiator who battles galactic forces to reach the sun.
lead_paragraph: To create her second album, “Blackheart,” the R&B singer Dawn Richard put herself through the ultimate career-defining test: isolation. “I had to get away,” the 31-year-old singer-songwriter says. “I literally left everything I had just to lock myself in a cabin in the woods for months and complete this album. No phone, no nothing. I even deleted my Instagram.” After the abrupt collapse of her fame-making reality-show band, Danity Kane, in August, along with a cancer diagnosis for her father and the death of her grandmother, Richard found herself at a crossroads. “I didn’t know if I wanted to make music anymore,” she says. “It took a lot to come to this point, and this project is definitely the deepest, darkest place I’ve been. It became more than just an album when I decided to keep it going. It was my test. It was my therapy, and I had to go through it.”

headline: Mariah Carey Set for a Run in Las Vegas
abstract: Ms. Carey will begin a residency at the Colosseum, at Caesars Palace, on May 6.
lead_paragraph: In an ideal marriage of dazzle and camp, Mariah Carey will become the latest pop diva to bring her outsize presence to the Las Vegas Strip.

headline: Talking Band at 40
abstract: A look at the productions of this avant-garde theater company, which has preserved its methods and retained its members.
lead_paragraph: A look at the productions of this avant-garde theater company, which has preserved its methods and retained its members.

headline: The Experiment Must Go On
abstract: The Talking Band, a SoHo based avant-garde theater company that produced its first show 40 years ago, remains active and vital.
lead_paragraph: If you run a certain kind of scrappy theater company, opportunity can appear in some peculiar guises. Last year, when Loehmann’s department store closed, Paul Zimet of the Talking Band saw a chance to grab a half-dozen clothing racks, cheap.

headline: Killings Deepen Rift as Turks Accuse Netanyahu of ‘Crimes Against Humanity’
abstract: Israel’s response to the Charlie Hebdo attack has touched off a divisive new chapter in the war of words between allies turned rivals.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — If the Paris attacks unleashed a powerful demonstration of unity, with world leaders gathering to denounce terrorism, they also touched off a divisive new chapter in the war of words between Turkey and Israel, once stalwart allies but now bitter rivals.

headline: ‘A Voice Still Heard: Selected Essays of Irving Howe’
abstract: Irving Howe was one of the greatest critics of his generation, a perspicacious reader of difficult texts.
lead_paragraph: A voice still heard. What a sad, anxious assertion of the great critic’s relevance. Alas, the claim is not terribly true, not anymore. A generation ago, Irving Howe’s voice rattled around the brain of the American intellectual. When writers sat down to compose essays, they were already imagining the postcard of praise they might receive from Howe. A small legion of his enemies made careers of baiting him. Howe’s hot ire flowed easily, often in the form of elegant sarcasm that could bury alive.

headline: Houellebecq Provokes Again
abstract: Michel Houellebecq’s new novel imagines France in 2022, when a Muslim political party has won the presidency.
lead_paragraph: The French novelist Michel Houellebecq is a longtime friend of controversy, which has done at least as much as critical praise to sell his books. In the Book Review in 2000, Anthony Quinn called his novel “The Elementary Particles” a “bilious, hysterical and oddly juvenile” book, the tone of which “lurches unpleasantly between the salacious and the psychotic.”

headline: 20 Wines Under $20
abstract: Eric Asimov selects inexpensive bottles that won’t be found on the main highways of wine.
lead_paragraph: Eric Asimov selects inexpensive bottles that won’t be found on the main highways of wine.

headline: Worth the Search
abstract: A selection of inexpensive bottles that won’t be found on the main highways of wine.
lead_paragraph: The great intersection of quality and value in wine occurs in the $15- to $25-a-bottle range. Here, you can find wines that are not merely sound or decent but fascinating, without breaking the bank. Can you find these sorts of wines for less than $15? Possibly, but the choices rise exponentially if you can commit to paying just a little bit more.

headline: Oscar Nominations 2015: Bradley Cooper on His Third Nod in 3 Years
abstract: The actor says the film should be seen as a window into the plight of soldiers and their treatment.
lead_paragraph: Bradley Cooper, groggy after returning to New York late Wednesday night after touring a veterans’ hospital in San Antonio and the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, graciously deflected praise for what is his third Oscar nomination in three years.

headline: An Exclusive Backstage Look at Alexander McQueen Men’s Fall/Winter 2015
abstract: A video takes us behind the scenes at London Collections: Men.
lead_paragraph: [Watch the video.]

headline: Let’s Retire the Term ‘Oscar Worthy’
abstract: Why should we pretend that aesthetic merit has anything to do with the nomination process?
lead_paragraph: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences routinely dispenses Oscars to mediocre performances and snubs terrific ones; the catalog of egregious choices (“Forrest Gump” beat out “Pulp Fiction” for best picture in 1995, just for example) is long. Everyone knows that. It’s also widely acknowledged that roll-out and publicity, the quality of the campaign a studio runs, matters as much or more than the quality of a film. A good politician with a bad communications team probably can’t become president; a good actor with a bad communications team probably can’t win an Oscar.

headline: Two Italian Aid Workers Held Hostage in Syria Are Released
abstract: The women, who had been working in the northern city of Aleppo, were reported seized in August. It was not immediately clear why they were freed.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Two Italian women abducted by Islamist militants while doing aid work in northern Syria last year have been freed and are en route home, Italy’s government announced Thursday.

headline: Judge Dismisses Brooklyn Gun Case as Police Are Investigated
abstract: Jeffrey Herring asserted that officers had planted a gun on him and fabricated the circumstances of his 2013 arrest.
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn man who claimed the police manufactured gun-possession charges against him had his case dismissed on Thursday, amid two investigations into the practices of a group of police officers in the 67th Precinct in East Flatbush.

headline: Turkey and Israel Exchange Heated Words
abstract: The prime minister of Turkey compared the Israeli prime minister to the Paris terror attackers on Thursday after Israel’s foreign minister called President Erdogan of Turkey an “anti-Semitic bully.”
lead_paragraph: The prime minister of Turkey compared the Israeli prime minister to the Paris terror attackers on Thursday after Israel’s foreign minister called President Erdogan of Turkey an “anti-Semitic bully.”

headline: Wrong Responses to Charlie Hebdo
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Censorship', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Editorials', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: Some European leaders are proposing the kind of Internet censorship and surveillance that would do little to protect their citizens but do a lot to infringe on civil liberties.
lead_paragraph: Leaders in Europe are justifiably trying to figure out what they should be doing to prevent terrorist attacks like the recent massacre at the satirical French newspaper Charlie Hebdo. Regrettably, some politicians are proposing the kind of Internet censorship and surveillance that would do little to protect their citizens but do a lot to infringe on civil liberties.

headline: 2 Suspects Killed in Gun Battle in Belgian Antiterror Raid
abstract: The raid in eastern Belgium also left a third person gravely injured, as the authorities stepped up their efforts against extremists.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Police officers killed two men after coming under fire in one of several raids against suspected terrorists that unfolded across Belgium on Thursday, barely a week after the terrorist attacks in Paris.

headline: Satellite Images Show Ruin Left by Boko Haram, Groups Say
abstract: The militants stormed through northern Nigerian towns in recent days, according to an analysis of satellite images by human rights groups.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Thousands of buildings were burned, damaged or destroyed in northern Nigerian towns in recent days when Boko Haram militants stormed through, using scorched-earth tactics against civilians, according to a new analysis of satellite images by human rights groups.

headline: Ocean Life Faces Mass Extinction, Broad Study Says
keywords: ['Oceans and Seas', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Research']
abstract: Scientists find what they say are clear signs that humans are beginning to damage oceans on an unprecedented scale.
lead_paragraph: A team of scientists, in a groundbreaking analysis of data from hundreds of sources, has concluded that humans are on the verge of causing unprecedented damage to the oceans and the animals living in them.

headline: Pass to the Open Man! Not Him! The Other One!
abstract: Division II Bellarmine University has been among the top 10 shooting teams in seven consecutive seasons, employing a basketball philosophy used by the 1969-70 Knicks.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The hardest job at Knights Hall on Tuesday morning belonged to the student managers who were charting the points.

headline: Oscar Nominations 2015: Felicity Jones Has the Shoes for the Job
abstract: The actress has garnered many nominations this season for her performance in “The Theory of Everything,” and that has meant an “enormous amount of shoes” for the red carpet.
lead_paragraph: It was one of those too-scary-to-look moments, Felicity Jones said. Instead of watching the announcement of the Academy Award nominations live Thursday, the 31-year-old star of “The Theory of Everything” said, she waited in her pajamas by the phone in her Los Angeles hotel room.

headline: Hot Hands at Bellarmine University
abstract: Images of the Bellarmine University men’s basketball team, which has ranked among the top 10 in field goal percentage in each of the past seven seasons.
lead_paragraph: Images of the Bellarmine University men’s basketball team, which has ranked among the top 10 in field goal percentage in each of the past seven seasons.

headline: Mr. President, ‘vlogbrothers’ Has a Pressing Question
abstract: After his State of the Union address on Tuesday night, President Obama will sit down with three “social media celebrities” on YouTube for a live video interview from the White House.
lead_paragraph: The clout of the “social media celebrity” has reached a new height: interviewing the sitting president of the United States after the State of the Union address.

headline: UBS to Pay $14.5 Million in S.E.C. Settlement Over Dark Pool
keywords: ['High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: A subsidiary ran afoul of regulations by allowing traders to buy and sell stocks priced at increments smaller than a penny, the S.E.C. said.
lead_paragraph: UBS has agreed to pay $14.5 million to settle accusations by the Securities and Exchange Commission that a subsidiary violated federal securities laws in its operation of a private stock trading system known as a dark pool.

headline: Royal Ballet Adds Lincoln Center to Its American Tour
abstract: The Royal Ballet from London will perform at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center in June.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Ever since it was reported that the Royal Ballet would visit Washington and Chicago in 2015 rumors have been swirling about a New York stop. The rumors are true. The Royal Ballet and the Joyce Theater Foundation announced Thursday that the company would appear at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center from June 23 to 28, after performances at the Kennedy Center in Washington from June 9 to 14, and at the Auditorium Theater in Chicago from June 18 to 21. It will be the Royal Ballet’s first New York appearance since 2004.

headline: Mormon Church Threatens Critic With Excommunication
keywords: ['Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Excommunication', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The Mormon Church has moved against the prominent Utah-based founder of an online forum for doubting Mormons, charging him with apostasy.
lead_paragraph: Mormon leaders have moved to excommunicate the prominent founder of an online forum for questioning Mormons, charging him with apostasy for publicly supporting same-sex marriage and the ordination of women, and for challenging church teaching.

headline: Kerry to Give Paris a ‘Big Hug’
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said Thursday that he planned to give Paris a “big hug” on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry said Thursday that he planned to give Paris a “big hug” on Friday.

headline: Oscar Nominations 2015: ‘Foxcatcher’ Writers Plan Their Oscar Outfits
abstract: The two never worked in the same room and only got to know each other when it came time to promote the film.
lead_paragraph: It was a ho-hum day just like any other.

headline: Are Oscar Nominations Moving in the Wrong Direction?
keywords: ['Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Movies', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The Academy Awards failed to nominate a single actor or actress of color this year — and many find the relatively few nominations for “Selma” especially disturbing.
lead_paragraph: “Could white actors really take home all 20 Oscar nominee slots?” asked Kyle Buchanan at Vulture in September. On Thursday morning, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences delivered its answer: Yes.

headline: The Swiss Give a Scary Lesson on the Limits of Central Banks
abstract: The first lesson is never trust a central banker when he or she makes a commitment or gives guidance, writes Swaha Pattanaik of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Central bankers have to live up to high expectations. Investors and politicians expect them to control inflation, prevent deflation, promote growth and keep the financial system healthy. The Swiss National Bank, an above-average institution, has failed at two simpler tasks, keeping its word and preventing destabilizing currency moves. The lessons for the rest of the world are scary.

headline: First Draft Focus: It’s Lunchtime in Baltimore
abstract: President Obama had lunch with women in Baltimore.

headline: Thawing Relations: Teaching About Cuba and the U.S.
abstract: In this lesson we explore different facets of the historic relationship between Cuba and the United States and give students a chance to predict what might come next. In follow-up activities students can delve more deeply into the history, culture, economics and politics of the communist nation 90 miles south of Florida.
lead_paragraph: Overview | For more than half a century, the United States has feuded — sometimes to the edge of war — with the island nation of Cuba. Now that mutual hostility could be coming to an end with last month’s announcement that the two countries will resume diplomatic relations. How will life change for people in both countries?

headline: Rdio, a Streaming Music Service, to Open in India
abstract: The service, which has a catalog of more than 30 million songs for $2 a month, is beating its Western rivals into the populous country.
lead_paragraph: The streaming music wars have arrived in India.

headline: Senator Ernst, of Iowa, to Deliver State of the Union Response
abstract: In response to her selection, Ms. Ernst, the first woman elected to federal office from Iowa, said: “It’s a long way from Red Oak, Iowa, to Washington, D.C. But now that I am here, I am excited to get to work in order to craft and implement real solutions as we chart a new path forward for our great nation.”
lead_paragraph: In response to her selection, Ms. Ernst, the first woman elected to federal office from Iowa, said: “It’s a long way from Red Oak, Iowa, to Washington, D.C. But now that I am here, I am excited to get to work in order to craft and implement real solutions as we chart a new path forward for our great nation.”

headline: U.N. to Renew Syria Talks, Seeking Aleppo Cease-Fire
abstract: The United Nations hopes to negotiate a cease-fire around the northern city and restart a process “with a clear political horizon.” But diplomats see little sign of a breakthrough.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations will resume talks with the Syrian government next week in the hope of achieving a cease-fire around Aleppo, the largest city in the north, the special envoy for Syria said Thursday. But the specifics remained hazy.

headline: The Year in Movies
abstract: Some Oscar counterprogramming.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, Frank Bruni and I steered our latest movies-and-politics dialogue into the open water between the Golden Globes and the Oscar nominations, wrangling a little over some of the holiday releases, particularly “American Sniper,” which neither of us loved but whose politics (or lack of politics) I was more inclined to defend, while finding a little bit more common ground in the great-“Selma”-and-historical-accuracy debate. That common ground was mildly critical of the way “Selma” so explicitly black-hats Lyndon Johnson, but now that the Oscar nominations are out and neither the movie’s director nor its star earned a nomination I wish I’d muted my criticism even more, because if accuracy issues peeled off any support from the film it’s a pretty terrible to reason to have Ana DuVernay and David Oyelowo lose out to — well, basically anyone associated “Foxcatcher,” “The Theory of Everything,” and “The Imitation Game,” all of which are based-on-true-story movies that are just as vulnerable as “Selma” to historical-inaccuracy critiques, and none of which (despite various strengths) feature directing or acting that equals the work that DuVernay and Oyelowo turned in.

headline: Report Finds No Substitute for Mass Data Collection
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Terrorism', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: A federal study found that there was no reliable way to get at the communications of terrorism suspects without sweeping up records of every call in the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal study released on Thursday concluded that there was no effective alternative to the government’s “bulk collection” of basic information about every telephone call made in the United States, a practice that civil rights advocates call overly intrusive.

headline: Rachel Rossin’s Virtual-Reality Installation in Bushwick
abstract: Rachel Rossin’s “n=7/The Wake in Heat of Collapse,” an interactive installation, will be open to the public Friday at Signal.
lead_paragraph: The Miser, giving in to nostalgia, recently began playing a Nintendo 64 game in which he has 72 hours to defeat a masked menace before the moon falls on a fictional land. But the apocalypse is more like a reset button; “game over” is shorthand for “let’s try that again.”

headline: Woody Allen’s Early Stand-Up Years
abstract: A profile of Woody Allen and reviews in The New York Times from the early 1960s capture the rapport he forged with audiences in his early stand-up comedy routines.
lead_paragraph: 53 YEARS AGO

headline: How to Unit Test a RequireJS Application
abstract: Learn about how we’ve been unit testing a RequireJS application at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Adding unit tests to an existing application can be a challenge. If the application wasn’t developed with testing in mind, getting your source code into shape so that your components are isolated and testable is like adding a new character to a story after the book is already written. Significant refactoring must be done to decouple and test your code.

headline: Irrepressible Passion, Laced With Sadness
abstract: In Willy Decker’s production of Verdi’s “La Traviata” at the Metropolitan Opera, the soprano Sonya Yoncheva plays a Violetta full of vitality and sensuality.
lead_paragraph: In Willy Decker’s production of Verdi’s “La Traviata,” a painted backdrop of jewel-tone flowers looms over the second act. As Violetta’s hopes and prospects dim, the blooms’ color seems to slowly leach away, leaving an ashen field of gray.

headline: Coming to the Met’s Rooftop: A Pierre Huyghe Installation
abstract: The French conceptual artist Pierre Huyghe has been asked to create an installation for the roof of the Met.
lead_paragraph: The French conceptual artist Pierre Huyghe often plunges viewers into his own, fantastical universe. It can take a surprising number of forms. His creations can include film, performance, sculpture, magic, biology, even nature like insects. So when Sheena Wagstaff, the chairwoman of the Metropolitan Museum’s modern and contemporary art department, and Ian Alteveer, a Met associate curator, saw the beguiling environment Mr. Huyghe created at Documenta 13 in 2012 and the retrospective first at the Pompidou Center in Paris and now on view at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, they asked him to create a site-specific installation for the roof of the Met next spring. “His work is so captivating, and the way he thinks about the layers of a site, taking into account history, environment and science is so compelling, we thought he’d create something particularly interesting,” Mr. Alteveer said.

headline: The Many Faces of Brad
abstract: A male model in twilight.
lead_paragraph: A male model in twilight.

headline: Volatility Is the New Weather for Banks
abstract: Banks are blaming market ups and downs for hurting earnings. That’s rich after years of claiming conditions were too docile, writes Antony Currie of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Volatility is the new weather for the likes of Citigroup and Bank of America. The two mega-banks joined JPMorgan Chase in blaming market ups and downs for crimping trading revenue and thus hurting overall earnings. That’s rich after years of claiming conditions were too docile. It doesn’t mask the deeper problem the lenders have, either.

headline: Yasumasa Morimura
abstract: Mr. Morimura slyly inserts himself into Velázquez’s “Las Meninas,” among other Western masterpieces.
lead_paragraph: The sly re-enactor of art history Yasumasa Morimura is back with yet another of his witty, gender-bending attacks on Western masterpieces, and this time he’s set his sights inadvisably high. His target is Velázquez’s “Las Meninas,” one of the most famous paintings and a work already rich in intrigue and charisma. Fortunately, Mr. Morimura rises to the occasion with photographs that tease out the painting’s spatial layers and strange mirror effects (while playing his usual games with identity).

headline: 1974 | After Showing an Image of the Prophet, The Times Apologized
abstract: David W. Dunlap looks back at a note from Times editors that apologized for printing an image of the Prophet Muhammad.
lead_paragraph: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

headline: ‘David Weiss: Works, 1968-1979’
abstract: This exhibition focuses on the solo efforts of David Weiss, half of the Swiss art duo Fischli/Weiss.
lead_paragraph: The Swiss artist David Weiss (1946-2012) is best known for the sly, jokey photographs, sculptures and videos he made with Peter Fischli under the name Fischli/Weiss. Among these is the classic film “The Way Things Go” (1987), a Rube Goldberg lineup of everyday objects arranged into a flaming, foaming, combustible chain reaction.

headline: Enrico David
abstract: Mr. David presents evocative sculptures that look as if they could have been excavated from an ancient ruin.
lead_paragraph: From show to show, you never quite know where Enrico David is going to land, but it’s almost always in the vicinity of figures of a mystical or fantastical sort. Usually he also finds a patch of unlikely yet solid ground.

headline: Teaser: The Unplayed Notes Museum
abstract: A look at the work of Loris Gréaud, which will be on view at Dallas Contemporary.
lead_paragraph: A look at the work of Loris Gréaud, which will be on view at Dallas Contemporary.

headline: Snowden Filmmaker’s Earlier Works Exhibited
abstract: Documentaries by Laura Poitras, who released “Citizenfour” last fall, follow two men at the intersection of historical events in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Laura Poitras is the documentary filmmaker whom Edward J. Snowden asked to help make public classified information about domestic surveillance that he downloaded in his job as an analyst for the National Security Agency. “Citizenfour,” her film about him, was released last fall. Along with three shorter pieces, this exhibition presents two absorbing feature-length documentaries that she made before she became involved with Mr. Snowden. Each portrays an individual at the intersection of historical events in the Middle East.

headline: Playful, With a Joie de Vivre
abstract: Tyson Reeder’s “New Paintings” show at the Canada gallery includes informal pastel landscapes, playful nods to 1970s counterculture, and a soft spot for art history.
lead_paragraph: It can be hard to make art seem like a casual, fun activity, although Tyson Reeder has had plenty of practice. Along with his brother, the artist Scott Reeder, Mr. Reeder set up the General Store gallery, which sold paintings alongside Etsy-like knickknacks; helped to found the Dark Fair, an art fair (or meta-art fair) where works were viewed in near darkness; and helped establish another art fair in a Polish beer hall and bowling alley in Milwaukee.

headline: Lowell W. Paxson Dies at 79; Started Home Shopping Network
abstract: In addition to the network now called HSN, which grew out of a shopping feature on a Florida cable station, Mr. Paxson founded the broadcast network Ion.
lead_paragraph: Lowell W. Paxson, a media executive who turned bargain hunting and impulse buying into couch potato heaven when he started the Home Shopping Network, died on Jan. 9 in Kalispell, Mont. He was 79.

headline: Morgan Stanley Names 151 New Managing Directors
abstract: Women make up 22 percent of the latest class of managing directors at the Wall Street firm.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley said on Thursday said that it had promoted 151 employees to managing director, down slightly from 2014’s class of 153 managing directors.

headline: Quarterback Who Led Title Run Stays at Ohio State, Forgoing N.F.L. Draft
abstract: Cardale Jones, the quarterback who recently led the Buckeyes to the national championship, announced on Thursday that he would return instead of declaring for the N.F.L. draft.
lead_paragraph: Ohio State quarterback Cardale Jones, fresh off leading the Buckeyes to victory in the inaugural College Football Playoff national championship game, announced Thursday that he would return to the university instead of declaring for the N.F.L. draft.

headline: Facts & Figures: New Yorkers Not Happy With Police Behavior
abstract: City voters disapprove of police officers turning their backs on the mayor.
lead_paragraph: A new poll has found that New York City voters aren’t happy with recent behavior by the police or the president of the Patrolmen’s Benevolent Association, Patrick Lynch.

headline: Layers That Conceal and Reveal
abstract: The urban landscape offers Luis Mallo a chance to find layered, complex compositions that reveal his intent.
lead_paragraph: The urban landscape offers Luis Mallo a chance to find layered, complex compositions that reveal his intent.

headline: Belgian Official on Counterterror Raid
abstract: Eric Van der Sypt, a federal prosecutor’s spokesman in Belgium, said terror suspects opened fire on officers executing a search warrant and two were killed. Amateur video shows the scene.
lead_paragraph: Eric Van der Sypt, a federal prosecutor’s spokesman in Belgium, said terror suspects opened fire on officers executing a search warrant and two were killed. Amateur video shows the scene.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: blueberries and blood pressure, indoor tanning and one child’s paralysis. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: blueberries and blood pressure, indoor tanning and one child’s paralysis. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Intel Profit Rises 39%, but Losses in Mobile Devices Are Heavy
abstract: While Intel’s profit rose significantly, concerns remain about whether it can move beyond its focus on putting chips in personal computers and servers.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Intel ended 2014 on a high note, and appears confident that its momentum can continue. But the question is how much the company has to change to keep up the pace.

headline: Tough Love for Republicans From a Major Supporter
abstract: Americans for Prosperity may have spent big to help Republicans take control of Congress, but the group held a news conference Thursday to send a message to the party’s members: Don’t go back to the profligate ways of the Bush era.
lead_paragraph: Americans for Prosperity may have spent big to help Republicans take control of Congress, but the group held a news conference Thursday to send a message to the party’s members: Don’t go back to the profligate ways of the Bush era.

headline: Automakers Rethink Seats for Self-Driving Cars
keywords: ['Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Automobiles', 'Motion Sickness', 'North American International Auto Show']
abstract: As envisioned by some companies, self-driving cars will have front seats that can face each other so occupants, even the person in the driver’s seat, can chat face to face.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — As self-driving cars become increasingly real, automakers are already reimagining how passengers may actually ride in the cars, without the need to pay such close attention to the road.

headline: A Literary Life in Portrait Detail
abstract: Two new books, a collection and a biography, delve into the life and work of the publisher James Laughlin.
lead_paragraph: James Laughlin was tall, blue-eyed, athletic, vastly wealthy and, by many accounts, sexually mesmerizing. He could charm the pants off women and usually did. Sometimes he went home and wrote a terrible, simpering poem about the experience.

headline: Pin-Striped Pajama-Style Pants, as Seen on Sienna Miller
abstract: The actress’s day-after-the-Golden-Globes look offers a lesson in how to appear composed yet comfortable.
lead_paragraph: Sienna Miller’s day-after-the-Golden-Globes look offers a lesson in how to appear composed yet comfortable following a full night of parties. On Monday, the actress — who had already flown to New York from Los Angeles — looked casually chic in Belstaff’s pin-striped silk trousers paired with a simple navy cardigan and heeled sandals. These three all-season alternatives are equally versatile — especially since nautical stripes are right on trend for spring 2015.

headline: Can Humanity’s ‘Great Acceleration’ Be Managed and, If So, How?
keywords: ['Biology and Biochemistry', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Fertilizer', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Marine Biology', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: A revised set of planetary boundaries for human activities engenders fresh debates about how to manage our planet-changing growth spurt.
lead_paragraph: Through three-plus decades of reporting, I’ve been seeking ways to better mesh humanity’s infinite aspirations with life on a finite planet. (Do this Google search — “infinite aspirations” “finite planet” Revkin – to get the idea. Also read the 2002 special issue of Science Times titled “Managing Planet Earth.”)

headline: A Girl Turns 150, and Fans Take Note
abstract: Books and exhibitions on view for the 150th anniversary of Lewis Carroll’s “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland.”
lead_paragraph: Charles L. Dodgson wanted to be remembered for his mathematical innovations as an Oxford don rather than his colorful personal life and 1865 book, “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland,” but despite his efforts to hide behind the pen name Lewis Carroll, it was Alice who made him famous.

headline: Adventures of a Peruvian Immigrant (the Furry Variety)
abstract: The beloved bear of children’s books makes his big-screen debut in Paul King’s “Paddington.”
lead_paragraph: In stark contrast to their furry, blundering star, the makers of “Paddington” have colored so carefully inside the lines that any possibility of surprise or subversion is effectively throttled. Perhaps burdened by an excess of respect for Paddington Bear’s creator, the children’s author Michael Bond, or maybe just unwilling to deter the built-in market for the inevitable movie-related merchandising, the filmmakers have settled on safe.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and More
abstract: France and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: France and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: An Education on Camera and Behind It
abstract: College students helped make “Northern Borders,” a coming-of-age film set in Vermont.
lead_paragraph: A group of young people learned something about the movie business during the making of “Northern Borders.” One thing they presumably learned is that good intentions don’t guarantee a good movie.

headline: Bodies of French Gunmen Lie Unburied, and, It Appears, Mostly Unwanted
abstract: The burial of the three raises a difficult question for France, which in the past has offered a Muslim burial even to those who committed terrorist acts.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As France continued to reel from one of the bloodiest terrorist attacks in recent memory, the authorities were grappling with the question of what to do with the bodies of the three gunmen.

headline: A Family of Few Words in a Slow-Burn Disaster
abstract: In “Medeas,” Andrea Pallaoro depicts a troubled farm family on the verge of imploding.
lead_paragraph: A slow, mesmeric slide into heartbreak and horror, “Medeas,” the ravishing first feature from the Italian director Andrea Pallaoro, effortlessly conveys a family’s disintegration with few words and even fewer miscalculations.

headline: The New York Police, the Mayor and the Limits of Bullying
abstract: A new poll finds that New Yorkers don’t like cops turning their backs on the mayor.
lead_paragraph: A new poll from Quinnipiac University finds New Yorkers are siding with Mayor Bill de Blasio and Police Commissioner William Bratton in the mayor’s bitter standoff with the New York Police Department.

headline: One Man’s Journey Through Hell
keywords: ['Movies', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: “The Touch of an Angel,” about a Polish Holocaust survivor, mingles documentary with re-enactments.
lead_paragraph: As survivors of the Holocaust have reached the end of life, documentaries capturing their memories have become fairly common and, it sometimes seems, fairly formulaic. Give “The Touch of an Angel” credit for trying something new.

headline: Neue Galerie Extends Schiele Exhibition
abstract: It was to have closed on Jan. 19 but has now been extended three months, to be on view through April 20.
lead_paragraph: More than 80,000 visitors have been to see the Neue Galerie’s exhibition of Egon Schiele portraits since it opened in October, making it one of the Manhattan museum’s most popular exhibitions. It was to have closed on Jan. 19 but has now been extended three months, to be on view through April 20.

headline: When Did ‘Teaching Independence’ Become ‘Possible Neglect’?
abstract: Parents in Maryland are being investigated for allowing their children to walk home from a park unsupervised. When did we abandon this idea that our children should learn to move about in the world without our hovering presence, and what have we lost?
lead_paragraph: How young were you when you first walked home from school alone? Or from the park? When you first ventured to the nearby QuikTrip or its equivalent? I can’t answer any of those questions, because I can’t actually remember not being able to do those things. I do know that when I was 10, my mother let a friend and me take a city bus to the mall. We missed our stop, and wound up in downtown San Antonio, where I found a pay phone and called my mother, who came to get us.

headline: Ship-Supply Contractor and Navy Captain Plead Guilty in Scandal
keywords: ['Defense Contracts', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Ships and Shipping']
abstract: A fourth Navy official pleaded guilty on bribery charges for accepting free trips, meals and prostitutes from a contractor.
lead_paragraph: A Malaysian ship-supply contractor and a fourth Navy official pleaded guilty to federal charges on Thursday, in a decade-long conspiracy that the contractor said involved scores of Navy officials and millions of dollars in bribes and gifts.

headline: Knicks Cross Ocean to Get Nowhere
abstract: The game was played on a different continent, but the result was the same: The Knicks were hammered, falling to 5-36.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — About 90 minutes before the Knicks’ game against the Milwaukee Bucks here Thursday night, Coach Derek Fisher was asked a difficult question: If he could go back to the beginning of this season, a season that has been as wretched as the English winter weather, what would he change?

headline: Have Tux, Will Babysit Groom
abstract: In “The Wedding Ringer,” a comedy directed by Jeremy Garelick, Kevin Hart plays a professional best man for grooms who lack friends.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Callahan, the professional best man of “The Wedding Ringer,” warns his client more than once that theirs is strictly a business relationship. No actual friendship is intended or implied as Jimmy (Kevin Hart) fills the role of best bud for the self-described yutz Doug Harris (Josh Gad) before and during his wedding, for whom he also assembles a team of degenerate groomsmen.

headline: How I Came to Live in a Chair Emporium
keywords: ['Modern Love (Times Column)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'ANTIQUES', 'Families and Family Life', 'Friendship']
abstract: When you collect an inheritance of table and chairs, you realize it’s to help you stay connected to friends.
lead_paragraph: There are 16 chairs in the one-room apartment I share with my girlfriend, and 18 if you count the tiny ones my young daughters favor when drawing at the coffee table. We also have a love seat and an enormous sectional sofa — a crazy amount of seating for an abode with only one private space, the bathroom (just one seat in there, and it’s porcelain). Jessica, my girlfriend, jokingly calls our apartment “the chair emporium.”

headline: A Road to Nowhere
abstract: Answering questions of marital infidelity, wigs for a teenager, proper idioms and bathroom protocol.
lead_paragraph: I am ashamed to admit that I have cheated on my wife several times during our 10-year marriage. So far, she has not found out. Every time, I vow it will be the last time, but it never is. And opportunities for cheating keep presenting themselves. My wife nearly discovered my last affair, which I ended before the holidays. This makes me worry that I am growing careless. You are an odd place to turn for help, but I trust your advice, and my wife loves your column. What should I do?

headline: Questions and Worry in Eastern Connecticut as Numerous Small Quakes Strike Region
abstract: A top question: Are the tremors a signal of something worse? A scientist says the answer is almost certainly no.
lead_paragraph: PLAINFIELD, Conn. — Connecticut has been feeling a bit of stress lately.

headline: Magically 50 Years Younger, but Still Old at Heart
abstract: In Leste Chen’s “20 Once Again,” a septuagenarian grandmother turns into her much younger self after a visit to a very strange photography studio.
lead_paragraph: Like the 2014 Korean hit “Miss Granny,” Leste Chen’s “20 Once Again” belongs to the genre of stories that set up life lessons by miraculously reversing a character’s aging process. In this case, no bodies are switched à la “Freaky Friday”; instead, a nagging septuagenarian mother-in-law, Shen Mengjun, turns back into her 20-year-old self after visiting a mysterious photography studio.

headline: Jan. 15, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from France, Afghanistan, Armenia and the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: Photos from France, Afghanistan, Armenia and the Philippines.

headline: Vivid Visions, Unsettling Still
abstract: The Peter Blume retrospective at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts showcases that painter’s devotion to allegorical art.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — For many years one of the most memorable artworks displayed in the permanent collection galleries of the Museum of Modern Art was “The Eternal City” (1934-37) by Peter Blume. A weird, technically dazzling mix of Magic and Social Realism on which the artist worked for nearly three years, it offers a comically nightmarish view of Rome under the Fascist reign of Mussolini.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Airlines Address Security of Mileage Accounts
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Computer Security', 'Consumer Protection', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: American Airlines and United Air Lines are responding to the theft of user names and passwords of members of their frequent-flyer programs, including restoring miles that were stolen.
lead_paragraph: Thieves last month illegally acquired the user names and passwords of American AAdvantage and United MileagePlus frequent-flier program members, and then broke into their accounts to steal miles, which they used to book free travel and upgrades.

headline: ‘Vice,’ a Sci-Fi Thriller That Lacks Thrills
abstract: This android-on-the-loose caper with Bruce Willis and Thomas Jane has more bullets than brains.
lead_paragraph: Evidencing more bullets than brains, “Vice” — a bit of ephemeral science-fiction twaddle directed by Brian A. Miller — has absolutely nothing to recommend it. Not Bruce Willis, who navigates his few scenes as if fortified by megadoses of Ambien. Not Yaron Levy’s brittle cinematography, so devoid of richness and texture that even the actors not playing robots seem drained of life. And certainly not the plot, a thin and repetitive android-on-the-loose caper that might have been concocted by a precocious middle-schooler.

headline: ‘Freedom Journey 1965’
abstract: Photographs by Stephen Somerstein of the march from Selma to Montgomery, Ala., from the new exhibition at the New-York Historical Society.
lead_paragraph: Photographs by Stephen Somerstein of the march from Selma to Montgomery, Ala., from the new exhibition at the New-York Historical Society.

headline: When Mystery Keeps Works New
abstract: Two shows on the Upper East Side of Manhattan form a valuable exchange about the physical processes of making art and what they impart.
lead_paragraph: “Make it new” was Barnett Newman’s famous injunction to his fellow Abstract Expressionists. It has an idealistic, exhortatory urgency, but achieving newness is in some ways quite mundane: It involves doing something physical, usually with materials, that hasn’t been done before. This can include new twists on old techniques, like the tiny dots of oil paint with which the Post-Impressionist Georges Seurat formed his images; the introduction of nonart materials or objects, as with Cubist collage and Marcel Duchamp’s ready-mades; or the repurposing of a commercial technique or tool, like the silk-screen process or the portable video camera.

headline: A Long March Into History
abstract: “Freedom Journey 1965: Photographs of the Selma to Montgomery March by Stephen Somerstein” runs through April 19 at the New-York Historical Society.
lead_paragraph: Almost 50 years ago, the picture editor of a campus newspaper at City College of New York assigned himself a breaking story: coverage of what promised to be a massive, violence-threatened march in Alabama, led by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., to demand free-and-clear voting rights for African-Americans. On short notice, the editor, Stephen Somerstein, grabbed five cameras, climbed on a bus and headed south.

headline: Yosemite Climbers Talk About Ascent
abstract: Tommy Caldwell and Kevin Jorgeson spoke after their 19-day climb of the Dawn Wall on El Capitan in Yosemite National Park, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Tommy Caldwell and Kevin Jorgeson spoke after their 19-day climb of the Dawn Wall on El Capitan in Yosemite National Park, Calif.

headline: Pitti Uomo: Marni Fall/Winter 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Pitti Uomo photo diary of Melody Lieftink.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Pitti Uomo photo diary of Melody Lieftink.

headline: All for One and One Robot From All
abstract: In “Spare Parts,” George Lopez and Jamie Lee Curtis play educators who help four Mexican students build an underwater robot in a national competition.
lead_paragraph: “Spare Parts” should have been a slam dunk. Based on the true story of four remarkable teenage boys — all poor, undocumented immigrants from Mexico — who surmounted incalculable odds to enter a national underwater robotics competition, the movie’s setup has underdog appeal in spades.

headline: Comedy Listings for Jan. 16-22
abstract: A selected guide to improv, stand-up and other comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A Mysterious New Show in Dallas from a Young French Heavyweight
abstract: Loris Gréaud’s “The Unplayed Notes Museum,” modeled on a natural history museum, will occupy the entire 26,000-foot exhibition space at the Dallas Contemporary.
lead_paragraph: Loris Gréaud is one of the biggest names in the Parisian art world, but chances are you’ve never heard of him; the 35-year-old artist has rarely shown his work in the United States. Beginning his career with delicate projects probing the nature of the universe through collaborations with specialists in other fields — scientists, writers, engineers and sound designers, to name a few — by 2008 he had already pulled off an institutional coup, filling the entire Palais du Tokyo with a solo show, for the first time ever. Then, five years later in summer 2013, the Pompidou and the Louvre joined forces to present joint exhibitions by Gréaud, another first.

headline: Working on a Screenplay, One Distraction at a Time
abstract: “Loitering With Intent” follows two New York actors as they struggle to write a film script that they have already boasted about to a producer.
lead_paragraph: LOITERING WITH INTENT

headline: Theater Listings for Jan. 16-22
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Our Mascot Won’t Wear Wellies
abstract: Is there an animal or a character of some kind who stands for the city?
lead_paragraph: Here at Weekend Arts, we are always excited about new movies featuring anthropomorphized animals. As we waited for “Paddington” to arrive, some of us got to thinking. If a small, confused, marmalade-loving bear from Peru is an emblem of sorts for London, where is our mascot for New York? Is there an animal — or a character of some kind — who stands for our city? If not, should we make up our own?

headline: Movie Listings for Jan. 16-22
abstract: A critical guide to movies playing in theaters, as well as a selected overview of film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

abstract: A selected, critical guide to performances of rock, pop, cabaret and more in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

abstract: A selected, critical guide to performances of jazz in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A Family Bond Inspired by Music and Circumstance
abstract: “Life Inside Out” chronicles a mother-son musical partnership that grows from a family’s financial hardships.
lead_paragraph: LIFE INSIDE OUT
