abstract: A selected, critical guide to performances of classical music in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: In China’s Antigraft Campaign, Small Victories and Bigger Doubts
abstract: Two years into a far-reaching government campaign against official corruption, many ordinary Chinese remain deeply cynical about whether it can succeed.
lead_paragraph: BEIDAIHE, China — The daily cavalcade of government miscreants featured in the Chinese news media makes for lurid reading: the housing official caught on camera aggressively fondling women at a karaoke parlor; the 41 members of the Communist Party expelled for using heroin and crystal meth in Yunnan Province; the general manager of a state agricultural firm sentenced to death for pocketing $55 million in bribes.

headline: In a Mob Family, Blood Feuds Span Generations
abstract: The saga “Gangs of Wasseypur” is five hours — and then some — of gliding camera moves, brutal action and dizzying revenge plotting.
lead_paragraph: GANGS OF WASSEYPUR

lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Dance Listings for Jan. 16-22
abstract: A selected, critical guide to dance performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Rewinding the Clock to Stop a Killer Virus
abstract: A spinoff of “12 Monkeys,” in Syfy’s television series of the same name, has only a little in common with the original.
lead_paragraph: The last time we saw James Cole, he was Bruce Willis, and he was dying of a gunshot wound in an airport while his younger self looked on. Now he’s Aaron Stanford, and he isn’t dead after all. In the world of film and television, finality is a mutable concept.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Jan. 16
abstract: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include scenes from Central Park Zoo and the State of the State address by Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include scenes from Central Park Zoo and the State of the State address by Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.

headline: An Old Master’s Beauty With a Euphoric Lift
abstract: The Royal Danish Ballet’s six sequences at the Joyce Theater show a refreshing of the choreographer August Bournonville’s dance heart.
lead_paragraph: In dance after dance, the 19th-century Danish choreographer August Bournonville took innocent joy as his subject and made it intoxicating. His ballets also contain despair, jealousy and satire, but he confined those things to acting. He expressed delight by means of dances, made especially in terms of pure classical ballet. This week, principals and soloists of the Royal Danish Ballet perform six of those dance sequences at the Joyce Theater. The rush of happiness that keeps flooding the theater is so pure that it may well bring tears to the eyes; it did to mine, more than once Tuesday, the opening night.

headline: Anguish, Wackily Recalled
abstract: Jack Ferver invokes the 1964 suicide of the dancer Fred Herko in his new piece, “Night Light Bright Light.”
lead_paragraph: “Night Light Bright Light,” the latest work by the performance artist Jack Ferver, has been advertised as drawing inspiration from the dancer Fred Herko, best known for having committed suicide in 1964 by jumping out of a window in a grand jeté. But it’s foolish to expect a Jack Ferver piece to be about anyone other than Jack Ferver.

headline: A Vicar in a Fine Tradition
abstract: In the ITV mystery “Grantchester,” a village vicar solves crimes in the 1950s.
lead_paragraph: The British network ITV is a more important part of the American television diet than most viewers realize. It sends us both the sweet clotted cream of “Downton Abbey” and the greasy late-night doner kebab of “Broadchurch.” But just as important for some of us, it’s the leading source of that bland bangers-and-mash called cozy mysteries: Marple, Poirot, “Midsomer Murders,” “Foyle’s War,” “Lewis.” Its latest contribution is “Grantchester,” about a village vicar who solves crimes in the 1950s, and it’s the perfect distillation of the form.

headline: A Misbehaving Monk Recounts His Sins
abstract: The Mariinsky Theater and the conductor Valery Gergiev present “The Enchanted Wanderer” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: It’s always an event when the Russian star conductor Valery Gergiev comes to town. There’s the promise of polished music making and, these days, the guarantee of political protests by demonstrators calling attention to Mr. Gergiev’s ties to Russia’s president, Vladimir Putin; his reticence on anti-gay policies in Russia; and his support of that country’s annexation of Crimea. On Wednesday evening, a dozen or so demonstrators brandishing Ukrainian flags picketed the opening of the Mariinsky Theater’s residency at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. They might have reserved some of their ire for the program itself: Rodion Shchedrin’s “The Enchanted Wanderer” is a composition so lugubrious, clichéd and dull that Mr. Gergiev’s energetic championing of it might now be added to the rap sheet his detractors are compiling.

headline: Pitti Uomo: Marni Fall/Winter 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Pitti Uomo photo diary of Melody Lieftink.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Pitti Uomo photo diary of Melody Lieftink.

headline: Looser Credit for Home Buyers
abstract: Credit is becoming more available thanks to reduced F.H.A. insurance premiums and new programs from Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
lead_paragraph: The coming reduction in insurance premiums on mortgages backed by the Federal Housing Administration will make these loans more attractive to the most creditworthy, lower-risk borrowers, according to an analysis by the Urban Institute’s Housing Finance Policy Center.

headline: Fleeting Acts That Linger in the Mind
abstract: The Under the Radar theater festival at the Public Theater features Reggie Watt’s “Audio Abramovic” and Marie-Caroline Hominal’s “The Triumph of Fame.”
lead_paragraph: To reach Reggie Watts’s “Audio Abramovic,” you travel from the Public Theater’s brightly lit lobby down a dark hallway and into an equally dark room where Mr. Watts sits behind a table crowded with recording equipment. You can just make out his extraordinary hair, which looks as though someone jammed a Byzantine icon’s halo into an electric socket, and a few vivid threads of his sweatshirt. The piece is over before your eyes adjust.

headline: White House on Travel to Cuba
abstract: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, commented on the announcement that beginning Friday, the United States will ease restrictions on travel to Cuba.
lead_paragraph: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, commented on the announcement that beginning Friday, the United States will ease restrictions on travel to Cuba.

headline: Unshackled Hacker Dons a White Hat
abstract: In Michael Mann’s “Blackhat,” a hacker is provisionally released from prison to combat a cybercriminal who has sabotaged a nuclear plant and manipulated a financial market.
lead_paragraph: Michael Mann’s thriller “Blackhat,” a story about the intersection of bodies and machines, is a spectacular work of unhinged moviemaking. By turns brutal and sentimental, lovely and lurid, as serious as the grave and blissfully preposterous, it combines a truckload of plot with many of the obsessions, tropes, sights and sounds that distinguish his other movies, from kinetic gun battles to cool beauties gazing into the distance in sunglasses. Here those beauties are a pair of improbable computer savants, played by Chris Hemsworth and Tang Wei, who race, jet and furiously bang on keyboards across the globe while chasing villainy, lines of code and millions in loot.

headline: The Cruel Waste of America’s Tech Talent
keywords: ['Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Science and Technology', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Visas', 'Foreign Students (in US)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Scholarships and Fellowships']
abstract: The not-so-heartwarming story of four young immigrants.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — WHEN audiences watch the movie “Spare Parts” in theaters this month, they will see the kind of Hollywood ending that has eluded the immigration debate in Congress.

headline: A Mining Tragedy, With Veins of Earnest Drama
abstract: A calamity shatters the peace of a West Virginia mining town in “Little Accidents,” with Jacob Lofland, Chloë Sevigny and Boyd Holbrook.
lead_paragraph: The sympathetic young actor Jacob Lofland lights up the American independent movie “Little Accidents,” an earnest, schematic, pocket-size drama about three people struggling under the weight of a calamity. He plays Owen, the elder of two boys who’ve recently lost their father in a coal mining accident that has left 10 dead and upended a West Virginia town. Now, amid the region’s sweeping green mountains, its ominous mines and traumatized population, Owen tries with lurching uncertainty to ease back into normal, even as the writer and director Sara Colangelo clutters his path with enough obstacles to challenge the most heroically determined traveler.

headline: Your Free Speech, and Mine
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Women and Girls', 'Comedy and Humor']
abstract: An enlightened society should be able to take the punch of satire and ridicule, even coarse satire and savage ridicule.
lead_paragraph: Last Sunday, as lovers of free speech filled the streets of Paris, lovers of elegant English period soap opera were watching “Downton Abbey” in America. The episode featured a frisky Lady Mary, in 1924, asking her maid to purchase a contraceptive device for her in advance of a hookup with Lord Gillingham. She pointed to a section in a book, likely one of the pioneering sex manuals of the British botanist Marie Stopes, for guidance.

headline: Judge’s Ruling on Gulf Oil Spill Lowers Ceiling on the Fine BP Is Facing
keywords: ['Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Explosions (Accidental)', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The ruling puts the potential fine at several billion dollars less than feared, and estimates the size of the worst offshore spill in U.S. history at 3.19 million barrels.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge will hold BP responsible for spilling 3.19 million barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico in the 2010 Deepwater Horizon disaster — a finding that could lead to a penalty of nearly $14 billion.

headline: The Israeli Draft Resister, and His Critics
abstract: Readers, including from Israel, respond to an Op-Ed article, “Why I Won’t Serve Israel.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Under New Rules, Expect More Tony Nominees This Season
abstract: As many as seven performers may be eligible for Tony nominations in acting categories.
lead_paragraph: The number of Tony Award nominations for Broadway actors, directors and choreographers is set to grow under rules changes approved on Thursday, according to a statement released by the Tony administration committee that oversees the annual theater honors.

headline: A ‘Satanic Verses’ Lesson
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Martin Garbus, the First Amendment lawyer, urges the media to make joint decisions on publishing controversial materials.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Documentary Draws Ire From the Church of Scientology
keywords: ['Television', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: The church says there are journalistic lapses in a documentary by Alex Gibney and it will take out ads in newspapers to raise its concerns.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — If controversy sells, HBO may suddenly have a hit in Alex Gibney’s new documentary about Scientology and renegades who left it behind.

headline: Silent Reading in Class
abstract: Allen Berger, professor emeritus of reading and writing, says “it’s good to see the present catching up with the past.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hand In Your Cellphone
abstract: Michelle Vacchio, a reader, writes that restrictions on cellphone use should not be limited to schoolchildren.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 5 More Lives, and Counting
abstract: “The Adventures of Puss in Boots,” an animated series from Netflix, casts the character as the swashbuckling protector of an innocent city.
lead_paragraph: Animal Planet is preparing yet another “Puppy Bowl.” The Hallmark Channel is readying “Kitten Bowl II.” It’s good to see that at least one animal out there aspires to be something other than an insufferably cute ersatz football player.

headline: Aimless Adventures of a Hip Narcissist
abstract: “Appropriate Behavior” centers on a willful young bisexual woman in Brooklyn who embarks erratically on sexual adventures.
lead_paragraph: Because “Appropriate Behavior” is set in Brooklyn and focuses on the romantic confusion and misadventures of Shirin, a headstrong young Iranian-American woman adrift in hipsterland, this lively romantic comedy starring Desiree Akhavan, who wrote and directed, has inevitably been compared to “Girls.” Shirin’s brash, off-kilter attitude is not unlike that of Lena Dunham’s Hannah Horvath. Both are self-centered, impulsive and brusque. But there are few signs that Shirin possesses Hannah’s driving career ambition. When Shirin takes a job teaching filmmaking to kindergartners, the little tykes run her ragged.

headline: Hunts Point Market Workers Continue Talks to Avoid Strike
keywords: ['Strikes', 'Organized Labor', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: If wage and health insurance issues are not resolved, more than 1,200 workers and drivers at the Hunts Point Terminal Produce Market in the Bronx could go on strike as early as Sunday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: More than 1,200 workers and drivers who carry out day-to-day operations at the Hunts Point Terminal Produce Market in the Bronx could go on strike as early as Sunday afternoon if contract talks fail to resolve wage and health-care-contribution issues. The workers had been ready to strike on Friday morning, but the union leaders agreed to postpone taking action at the request of a federal mediator.

headline: Bombardier Plans Layoffs and $1.4 Billion Write-Down
abstract: The moves comes as a result of its decision to suspend development of the Learjet 85 business aircraft.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Bombardier, the Canadian aerospace and railway equipment maker, said on Thursday that it would lay off about 1,000 employees and post a $1.4 billion write-down as a result of its decision to suspend development of the Learjet 85 business aircraft.

headline: Viacom Chief’s Contract Extended Until 2018
abstract: Philippe Dauman, a lawyer, received $37.2 million in 2013 in salary, stock and options.
lead_paragraph: Viacom, the media group that includes MTV, Comedy Central and Nickelodeon as well as the Paramount film studio, has extended the contract of its chief executive and president, Philippe Dauman, until 2018, the company said Thursday. His contract was set to expire in 2016. Mr. Dauman, 60, a lawyer and deal maker, became chief in 2006, beating out rivals from the creative side of the company to install himself as the leading candidate to succeed the executive chairman and founder, Sumner M. Redstone, 91. Mr. Redstone said Mr. Dauman had “been an extraordinary C.E.O.” and “his strategic vision and creative leadership have delivered consistently outstanding operational and financial results.” Mr. Dauman received $37.2 million in 2013 in salary, stock and options. In the quarter that ended last September, ratings for Viacom’s networks dropped 15 percent, though Mr. Dauman pointed out that ratings failed to take account of other platforms.

headline: A Designated Mourner, Flirting Warily With Joy
abstract: In Uberto Pasolini’s “Still Life,” Eddie Marsan plays a Londoner who arranges for the burial of dead people whose bodies have not been claimed by relatives.
lead_paragraph: In Uberto Pasolini’s “Still Life,” the wonderful British character actor Eddie Marsan, barely moving his features, his watery eyes glistening slightly, infuses a remarkable depth of empathy into his character, John May, a dignified, solitary 44-year-old South Londoner. John works in a local council office where his job is to find the next of kin to recently deceased people in his borough whose bodies no one has claimed.

headline: Contrapuntal Hum of a Worker’s Hive
abstract: Denis Côté’s semi-documentary “Joy of Man’s Desiring” captures the humanity of factory workers as they encounter frustrations and the occasional moment of satisfaction.
lead_paragraph: Factories are a byword for drudgery, but they have a certain inherent drama: the mesmerizing and menacing machines, the vivid subjection of people to their labor, the fact that something (usually) is created at the end of the line. In the ruminative semi-fictional film “Joy of Man’s Desiring,” the Canadian director Denis Côté watches men and women on the factory floor with a documentary eye, before trickling in details and dialogue that seem to express the workers’ humanity.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘American Sniper’
abstract: Clint Eastwood narrates a sequence from “American Sniper,” featuring Bradley Cooper and Sienna Miller.
lead_paragraph: Clint Eastwood narrates a sequence from “American Sniper,” featuring Bradley Cooper and Sienna Miller.

headline: This Week’s Movies | Jan. 16, 2015
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Blackhat,” “Human Capital” and “Appropriate Behavior.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Blackhat,” “Human Capital” and “Appropriate Behavior.”

headline: BP Deepwater Horizon Ruling
abstract: The British oil giant will face a maximum fine of $13.7 billion related to the 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, a federal judge ruled on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The British oil giant will face a maximum fine of $13.7 billion related to the 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, a federal judge ruled on Thursday.

headline: A 3-D Printed Car, Ready for the Road
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'North American International Auto Show', '3-D Printers', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)']
abstract: Local Motors uses 3-D printing to simplify the way automobiles are produced.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — TUCKED away among the gleaming steel machines on display at the North American International Auto Show this week, an Arizona start-up was trying something new: manufacturing a car from scratch right on the convention floor.

headline: Saudi Arabia: U.N. Denounces Flogging of Blogger
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: The United Nations high commissioner for human rights, Prince Zeid Ra’ad Zeid al-Hussein of Jordan, publicly appealed to Saudi Arabia on Thursday to halt the flogging of a blogger.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations high commissioner for human rights, Prince Zeid Ra’ad Zeid al-Hussein of Jordan, publicly appealed to Saudi Arabia on Thursday to halt the flogging of a blogger sentenced to 1,000 blows, 10 years’ imprisonment and a large fine for creating a website that contained criticism of the country’s religious establishment. The first 50 blows were given to the blogger, Raif Badawi, last Friday. Prince Zeid made the appeal on the eve of the second in a series of floggings, which are to be administered every Friday until all 1,000 blows with a cane have been completed. “Flogging is, in my view, at the very least, a form of cruel and inhuman punishment,” Prince Zeid said in a statement on his office’s website. He reminded the Saudis that the United Nations considers flogging a form of torture. As of Thursday evening, there was no indication that the authorities planned to halt the punishment, which has been widely condemned around the world.

headline: Guardrail Falls 81 Stories at Park Avenue Tower Work Site
abstract: Construction of the 96-story condominium building, arguably New York City’s tallest, was briefly halted after the piece fell from a hoist.
lead_paragraph: Construction work was briefly halted at 432 Park Avenue in Midtown Manhattan this week after a section of guardrail fell from a hoist near the top of the building, which is arguably the tallest in New York City.

headline: Showers on Wheels
abstract: Design can’t solve homelessness, but a number of projects have emerged aiming to address the sanitation problems that can plague even rich cities.
lead_paragraph: This past fall, a project started called (Human) Wasteland, which maps reports of human waste throughout the city of San Francisco. Yes, a disproportionate amount of poop on the streets is not from dogs but from humans.

headline: Live From Death Row
abstract: Erik Eckholm describes waiting for an execution in Oklahoma.
lead_paragraph: Erik Eckholm, a national reporter, is in McAlester, Okla., to cover the execution of Charles Warner, whose death was delayed after the prison botched the execution scheduled just before his last April. Mr. Eckholm was in attendance that evening, and tells of the experience, as he awaits tonight’s outcome.

headline: How Vitamin D May Fight Colon Cancer
abstract: Vitamin D may interact with the immune system to prevent the growth of colorectal malignancies.
lead_paragraph: Higher levels of vitamin D have been associated with a reduced risk of colon cancer in many observational studies. A new analysis has found a possible reason.

headline: Google Glass to Leave ‘X’ Research Lab as Nest’s Tony Fadell Takes Over Project
abstract: The wearable device will soon be a lot harder to buy as the Glass Explorer program will shut as part of the shift.
lead_paragraph: Despite a lot of fanfare and news coverage, the Google Glass smart glasses have largely been the butt of a lot of good jokes.

headline: Colombia: President Hints at Shift on a Cease-Fire
abstract: President Juan Manuel Santos appeared to open a window this week to a bilateral cease-fire with the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia.
lead_paragraph: President Juan Manuel Santos appeared to open a window this week to a bilateral cease-fire with Colombia’s main rebel group, saying that while peace talks to end more than 50 years of war continue, “We are seeking to de-escalate the intensity of the conflict.” He said Wednesday night that negotiators in Havana had begun talking about how the group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, will eventually hand over its weapons, and he said he had told them to start discussions on an eventual armistice. Mr. Santos has previously said that he would not order a halt to fighting until a final peace deal was clinched, and he reiterated that view last month when the FARC declared a unilateral cease-fire. On Thursday Óscar Naranjo, a government minister involved in the peace process, clarified Mr. Santos’s remarks, saying that hostilities continued and that no order had been given to halt bombing raids against FARC targets.

headline: Sotomayor’s Dissent in Oklahoma Execution Case
abstract: As the Supreme Court refused to grant a stay in the execution of Charles F. Garner, paving the way for Oklahoma to resume lethal injections, a liberal justice issued a sharp dissent.
lead_paragraph: As the Supreme Court refused to grant a stay in the execution of Charles F. Garner, paving the way for Oklahoma to resume lethal injections, a liberal justice issued a sharp dissent.

headline: Governor of Michigan Vetoes Bill on Guns
abstract: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan, a Republican, on Thursday vetoed gun legislation that was supported by the N.R.A. because he said the package could expose domestic abuse victims to additional violence.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan on Thursday vetoed gun legislation that was supported by the National Rifle Association and approved by wide margins in the state’s Legislature, dominated in both chambers by Mr. Snyder’s fellow Republicans.

headline: Francs, Fear and Folly
keywords: ['Deflation (Economics)', 'Swiss Franc (Currency)', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Euro (Currency)']
abstract: Switzerland shows us how hard it is to fight the deflationary vortex that’s dragging down the world economy.
lead_paragraph: Ah, Switzerland, famed for cuckoo clocks and sound money. Other nations may experiment with radical economic policies, but with the Swiss you don’t get surprises.

headline: Jean-Claude Baker Dies at 71; Restaurateur Honored a Chanteuse
abstract: Mr. Baker created the Manhattan restaurant Chez Josephine in memory of Josephine Baker, who had befriended him as a child and whose biography he wrote.
lead_paragraph: Jean-Claude Baker, the flamboyant restaurateur who created the popular Manhattan nightspot Chez Josephine in memory of Josephine Baker, the exotically beautiful dancer and mesmerizing chanteuse who had cared for him as a lonely child in Paris and whose biography he published to acclaim in 1993, was found dead on Thursday at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 71.

headline: Condoleezza Rice Testifies on Urging The Times to Not Run Article
keywords: ['News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Books and Literature', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Ms. Rice, the former national security adviser, described how the White House successfully persuaded Times editors not to publish an article about a secret operation to disrupt Iran’s nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — White House officials favor two primary tactics when they want to kill a news article, Condoleezza Rice, the former national security adviser, testified Thursday: They can essentially confirm the report by arguing that it is too important to national security to be published, or they can say that the reporter has it wrong.

headline: Saks Treatment of Transgender Employees Is Investigated
abstract: New York’s attorney general takes issue with statements Saks lawyers made regarding a Houston-based employee’s treatment and dismissal.
lead_paragraph: New York’s attorney general is investigating Saks Fifth Avenue’s treatment of transgender employees after a former saleswoman said that the luxury retailer had harassed and dismissed her over her transgender identity.

headline: Trainers Cleared in Cruelty Case
abstract: The Kentucky Horse Racing Commission said Steve Asmussen and Scott Blasi did not abuse horses as the People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals had charged.
lead_paragraph: The Kentucky Horse Racing Commission said Steve Asmussen, one of the sport’s most accomplished trainers, and his top assistant, Scott Blasi, did not abuse the horses in their care as the People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals alleged last year.

headline: Rating the Republicans
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'State of the State Message (NJ)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: John Kasich is easily the most underestimated Republican this year, but Chris Christie is close behind.
lead_paragraph: If the Republican presidential campaign were “American Idol” or “The Voice,” this would be the out-of-town auditions phase. Governors across the country are giving State of the State addresses, unveiling their visions. Let’s spin the chairs and grade the contenders, to see who deserves a shot at the big show.

headline: Need Some Espionage Done? Hackers Are for Hire Online
abstract: No longer just the domain of intelligence agencies, “hacktivists” or criminal gangs, there is a growing cottage industry of ordinary people hiring hackers for much smaller acts of espionage.
lead_paragraph: A man in Sweden says he will pay up to $2,000 to anyone who can break into his landlord’s website. A woman in California says she will pay $500 for someone to hack into her boyfriend’s Facebook and Gmail accounts to see if he is cheating on her.

headline: Milton Hebald, Whose Sculptures Are in Plain View, Dies at 97
abstract: Though his name may not be familiar to many, Mr. Hebald’s work is — in Central Park and in other public spaces around the world.
lead_paragraph: Milton Hebald was “without doubt the most important living figure sculptor,” Anthony Burgess, the English novelist and literary critic, wrote in 1971, but he nonetheless predicted that few people, even among the cognoscenti, would remember his name.

headline: Amid Threats, Duke Moves Muslim Call to Prayer
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Prayers and Prayer Books']
abstract: The university canceled plans for Muslim students to deliver the traditional call from the school’s iconic chapel tower, and instead the call will be sounded from the quadrangle in front of it.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — Duke University has canceled plans for Muslim students to sound the traditional call to prayer from the school’s iconic chapel tower amid threats of violence and a backlash from anti-Muslim groups, conservatives and Christian leaders.

headline: Elaine Summers, Who Meshed Dance and Film, Dies at 89
abstract: Ms. Summers was a dancer, choreographer and multimedia artist whose work sought to blur the boundaries between dance and film.
lead_paragraph: Elaine Summers, a dancer, choreographer and multimedia artist whose work sought to blend dance and film into a seamless whole, died on Dec. 27 in Manhattan. She was 89.

headline: U.N. Says Meeting Is Set on Middle East
abstract: The United States, the European Union, Russia and the United Nations will convene to seek a resumption of Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations.
lead_paragraph: Confronting bleak prospects for any resumption of Israeli-Palestinian peace talks soon, the so-called Quartet group of powers will convene late this month in an attempt to find a way forward in the increasingly intractable-looking conflict, the United Nations said on Thursday.

headline: Man Seeks to Turn Tables on Officials in Voter Fraud
abstract: A political gadfly in Brooklyn who was convicted of voter fraud wants to have his conviction vacated on the grounds of selective prosecution.
lead_paragraph: John Kennedy O’Hara spent most of 2003 picking up garbage in city parks and cleaning public toilets as part of his sentence for illegal voting in Brooklyn. Also, he had to pay a fine and restitution amounting to $15,192. His supposed crime was that he registered to vote using the address of a girlfriend on 47th Street in Sunset Park, where he claimed to live part of the time. But he also maintained a residence 14 blocks away.

headline: Single Father Embraces His Role With Pride
abstract: Romaine Sweat may be struggling to raise four children on his own, but he swells with happiness when he talks about their accomplishments.
lead_paragraph: Along with all the demands and unpredictability of single fatherhood comes something else: all of the credit. And Romaine Sweat, 37, could not be prouder to take it.

headline: For Jews From France, a Sociable Landing Spot in Israel
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Terrorism', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: With safety issues growing after the terrorist attacks in Paris, the French economy struggling and an open invitation from Israel to relocate, French-Israeli Jews in Netanya await new arrivals.
lead_paragraph: NETANYA, Israel — At one end of Independence Square, by the dancing fountain, French speakers sat at tables outside La Brioche, a patisserie owned by native Israelis, drinking coffee one warm afternoon this week and ordering from a window display of éclairs, colorful macaroons and mille-feuilles.

headline: Perry Exits Texas Stage Making a Case for His Past, and His Future
abstract: As Gov. Rick Perry prepares to leave office and contemplates another run for the White House, his record in Texas will be closely scrutinized for what it says about him and the priorities he set.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Gov. Rick Perry leaves office here next week not so much as a man but as the face of an era — a 14-year reign in which he became the state’s longest-serving chief executive and was widely regarded as the most powerful governor in the history of modern Texas.

headline: After Health Scare, Bearcats Coach Yearns for the Sideline
abstract: Cincinnati’s Mick Cronin was told last month that he had an arterial dissection in his brain, but he hopes to return by the postseason.
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD — During the Cincinnati-Connecticut men’s basketball game on Saturday, Hep Cronin sat in the front row behind the Bearcats’ bench, just as he had done dozens of times. Cronin, a fixture at games and practices and on the team’s charter flights, has maintained his routine despite trying family circumstances.

headline: F.B.I. Chief Criticizes Times on Qaeda Source
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The F.B.I. director sharply criticized The Times on Thursday for anonymously quoting a member of a terrorist group in an article about the deadly attacks last week in France.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, sharply criticized The New York Times on Thursday for anonymously quoting a member of a terrorist group in an article about the deadly attacks last week in France.

headline: The Least Economically Diverse Top College, Seeking to Change
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Tuition', 'Pell Grants', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Washington University in St. Louis, with a small share of lower-income students, is announcing a major expansion of financial aid.
lead_paragraph: The leaders of Washington University in St. Louis have decided that it has a distinction they no longer want: the nation’s least economically diverse top college.

headline: Symbols With Supposed Magic Power
abstract: Friday fun with Michael Wiesenberg.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — This is Michael Wiesenberg’s third puzzle in The New York Times, and he continues his streak as a late-week constructor. (His other two puzzles are, in order of publication, a Saturday and another Friday.)

headline: What Happens in Vegas Comes to New York
abstract: The course of true love runs on parallel roller-coaster tracks in the new Broadway musical “Honeymoon in Vegas,” starring Tony Danza.
lead_paragraph: Wake up and smell the mai tais, New York. Las Vegas has come calling on you. And it’s on such good behavior, you’d be a churl not to embrace it as if it were a long-lost sibling.

headline: Cuomo Wants $1.5 Billion Contest for Upstate Revitalization Grants
abstract: Three winning regions would each be awarded $500 million to boost their economies if the New York Legislature approves the proposal.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — In his first four years in office, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has proffered all kinds of solutions for problems in upstate New York, including casinos, tax-free districts and municipal consolidation. But on Thursday, the governor seemed to embrace a more direct, Darwinian approach: cash, in the form of competition for $1.5 billion in grants.

headline: Russia: Opposition Protesters Are Arrested After Clash
abstract: Opposition protesters were arrested in Moscow on Thursday evening after scuffles broke out between supporters of President Vladimir V. Putin and Aleksei A. Navalny.
lead_paragraph: Around a dozen opposition protesters were arrested in Moscow on Thursday evening after scuffles broke out between supporters of President Vladimir V. Putin and Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s most prominent opposition politician. Thirteen anti-Putin protesters were detained at the rally under the walls of the Kremlin, according to OVD INFO, an opposition website that tallies protesters carted off in police vans. Most were released without charges late Thursday evening. Small scuffles broke out in the combined crowd of 500 between Mr. Navalny’s supporters and the so-called anti-Maidan, supporters of Mr. Putin’s hard-line policies in Ukraine.

headline: ‘Freedom Journey 1965’
abstract: Photographs by Stephen Somerstein of the march from Selma to Montgomery, Ala., from the new exhibition at the New-York Historical Society.
lead_paragraph: Photographs by Stephen Somerstein of the march from Selma to Montgomery, Ala., from the new exhibition at the New-York Historical Society.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 15, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbersfor New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Deserted by Devils, Nets and Profits, Izod Center in North Jersey Is to Close
abstract: The loss of the Izod Center, in the Meadowlands, will be a boon for the Prudential Center in Newark, the current home of the Devils.
lead_paragraph: The Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., home to innumerable Bruce Springsteen concerts as well as years of Nets and Devils games, is on life support.

headline: By Highlighting Gains in Affordable Housing, de Blasio Raises a Counting Question
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio said that his administration was on pace to meet his 10-year goal for creating or preserving affordable housing units, but his predecessor might take issue with his first-year tally.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Thursday that his administration had financed more than 17,300 affordable homes in its first year in office, a figure that he said put New York City on track to fulfill his pledge to preserve or create 200,000 affordable units over 10 years.

headline: Visions of New Era in College Sports Converge at N.C.A.A. Convention
abstract: The N.C.A.A.’s annual convention in Washington is debating how to treat the young athletes driving what has become a multibillion-dollar industry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Early Thursday morning, hours before the N.C.A.A.’s president, Mark Emmert, took the stage at his association’s annual convention, a group of college sports’ most prominent critics strode through the halls of Congress, fresh from a briefing they held for Senate staff members. Among them were Ramogi Huma, president of the College Athletes Players Association; Kain Colter, the former Northwestern quarterback who headed the union movement there; and Ed O’Bannon, the former U.C.L.A. basketball star who sued the N.C.A.A. for using his image in video games — and won.

headline: Focus Is on Bitcoin Trader at Trial Over Silk Road Black Market
abstract: A federal agent said he became convinced that the person behind the Silk Road black-market website was Mark Karpeles, operator of the world’s largest Bitcoin exchange.
lead_paragraph: The man accused of operating the online black-market bazaar Silk Road was not the person government investigators had focused on early in their hunt, new court testimony shows.

headline: Obama and Senator Robert Menendez Spar on How to Handle Iran
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: President Obama and Mr. Menendez traded sharp words on Thursday over whether Congress should impose new sanctions on Iran, according to two people who witnessed the exchange.
lead_paragraph: President Obama and Senator Robert Menendez traded sharp words on Thursday over whether Congress should vote to impose new sanctions on Iran while the administration is negotiating with Tehran about its nuclear program, according to two people who witnessed the exchange.

headline: Voters Disapprove of Police Officers’ Protests and Work Slowdown, Poll Finds
abstract: For Mayor Bill de Blasio, the results from the Quinnipiac University survey provided vindication as he seeks to address deep-seated tensions with the Police Department.
lead_paragraph: By overwhelming margins, New York City voters objected to the back-turning protests and work slowdown that have roiled the Police Department, an auspicious turn for Mayor Bill de Blasio as he seeks to end weeks of open tensions between officers and City Hall.

headline: Lively Morgue Tumblr 462 & 463
abstract: Lively Morgue Tumblr 462 & 463
lead_paragraph: Lively Morgue Tumblr 462 & 463

headline: Cuomo Selects Another Democrat for New York’s Highest Court
abstract: If confirmed by the State Senate, Justice Eugene M. Fahey, the fourth Democrat appointed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, would give the Court of Appeals a five-member liberal majority.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo selected a Democratic judge from western New York to fill the last open seat on the state’s highest court, continuing his effort to move the seven-judge panel to the left.

headline: The Kings Theater to Reopen in Brooklyn
abstract: A panoramic view of the Kings, which was completed by the Loew’s Corporation between 1929 and 1930, and is reopening on Feb. 3 following a $95 million renovation.
lead_paragraph: A panoramic view of the Kings, which was completed by the Loew’s Corporation between 1929 and 1930, and is reopening on Feb. 3 following a $95 million renovation.

headline: The Paradise Theater in the Bronx
abstract: A panoramic view of this former “Wonder Theater,” which was designed by John Eberson and modeled on a Venetian doge’s palace.
lead_paragraph: A panoramic view of this former “Wonder Theater,” which was designed by John Eberson and modeled on a Venetian doge’s palace.

headline: The Loew’s Jersey in Jersey City
abstract: A panoramic view of the mezzanine level of the lobby of the Loew’s Jersey, in Journal Square, a “Wonder Theater” that opened in 1929 and is now run by a nonprofit group.
lead_paragraph: A panoramic view of the mezzanine level of the lobby of the Loew’s Jersey, in Journal Square, a “Wonder Theater” that opened in 1929 and is now run by a nonprofit group.

headline: The Valencia in Jamaica, Queens
abstract: A panoramic view of the Valencia, opened by Loew’s Corporation in 1929. Designed by John Eberson, this “Wonder Theater” was modeled on a Spanish villa, and features a trompe-l’oeil of an Old World courtyard in the auditorium. This is just the lobby.
lead_paragraph: A panoramic view of the Valencia, opened by Loew’s Corporation in 1929. Designed by John Eberson, this “Wonder Theater” was modeled on a Spanish villa, and features a trompe-l’oeil of an Old World courtyard in the auditorium. This is just the lobby.

headline: The United Palace Theater, 175th Street in Manhattan
abstract: A panoramic view of the United Palace, a former “Wonder Theater” now run by a religious organization that has formed partnerships with an in-house booking agency for concerts and a community programming group.
lead_paragraph: A panoramic view of the United Palace, a former “Wonder Theater” now run by a religious organization that has formed partnerships with an in-house booking agency for concerts and a community programming group.

headline: Across the New York Area, Restoring ‘Wonder Theater’ Movie Palaces to Glory
abstract: Five majestic, ornate theaters built in 1929 and 1930 declined, but some are making a comeback.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 3, concertgoers will walk into a world of Jazz Age beauty at the newly renovated Kings Theater on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn. A grand lobby of walnut-paneled walls and Corinthian columns will be lit from above by massive Art Deco chandeliers, and almost 4,000 feet of newly woven gold and scarlet carpet — reconstructed from a remnant discovered beneath an old candy counter — will stretch underfoot. The theater’s grand reopening, 86 years after it was first introduced to the public, will feature a performance by Diana Ross.

headline: Group Urges New York City to End Credit Checks by Employers
keywords: ['Credit Scores', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Minorities', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: Proponents of a City Council bill that would end the practice say it disproportionately harms Hispanic and black people without accurately predicting fraud or poor job performance.
lead_paragraph: New York City employers use credit checks to screen applicants for all sorts of jobs, like dog-walking and janitorial work. A coalition of municipal labor leaders, liberal advocates and left-leaning City Council members is seeking to end that practice, saying it disproportionately harms blacks and Hispanics without accurately predicting fraud or poor job performance.

headline: Missing New Jersey Man Is Found Dead in the Trunk of His Car
abstract: Police officers patrolling in the Bronx discovered the car of Jordan Johnson, 24, who was last seen leaving his apartment in Fort Lee on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A northern New Jersey man who disappeared this week and was believed to have been kidnapped was found dead in the trunk of his car in the Bronx on Thursday, according to law enforcement officials.

headline: Letter From Coalition to de Blasio and City Council Pushing Ban on Credit Checks by Employers
abstract: The coalition said it wanted to ensure that “unjustified exemptions” were not written into a bill that would end the practice.
lead_paragraph: The coalition said it wanted to ensure that “unjustified exemptions” were not written into a bill that would end the practice.

headline: Bronx Stabbing Leaves One Dead and Another Hospitalized
abstract: A 34-year-old man was fatally stabbed in the neck and a 22-year-old man was slashed on his head during a dispute at a co-op building in the Allerton neighborhood, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A stabbing in the lobby of a co-op building in the Bronx on Thursday left one man dead and another hospitalized, the police said.

headline: F.D.A. Begins Inquiry After Death and Illnesses From Saline Bags Meant for Training
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Health authorities were scrambling to find out how hundreds of bags of unsterilized saline solution could have been used in real patients, killing one person and possibly causing dozens to fall ill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — How could hundreds of bags of intravenous saline solution meant for training health care workers have been given to real patients?

headline: Word of the Day | propulsive
abstract: This word has appeared in 92 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: propulsive •\prə-ˈpəl-siv\• adjective

headline: Chinese Anticorruption Agency Investigates a Security Official
abstract: China’s investigation of Vice Minister Ma Jian was the latest demonstration of President Xi Jinping’s drive to consolidate control of the levers of Communist Party power.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A senior official in China’s Ministry of State Security faces investigation by the Communist Party’s central anticorruption agency, the agency announced on Friday, breaching the wall of secrecy that usually protects the powerful ministry.

headline: Regime Change in Switzerland
abstract: Unfortunately in the wrong direction.
lead_paragraph: Blogging will be limited for the next few days, unless I can resolve the tech problems here in Delhi. But I did want to say something about the Swiss de-pegging, beyond what I put in the column.

headline: Swiss Move Prompts Fears of Sustained Market Tumult
abstract: The question now is whether the much larger players in the $5 trillion-a-day foreign exchange market might have been caught short in significant ways.
lead_paragraph: The Swiss central bank’s surprise decision to remove the cap on its currency has incited investor fears that a spate of bank and fund losses could lead to a sustained bout of market turmoil beyond the ability of central banks to ride yet again to the rescue.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE LUNCHBOX (2014) When a delivery service sends the lunch intended for her husband astray, a neglected Mumbai housewife (Nimrat Kaur) finds herself communicating through handwritten letters and home-cooked meals with a widowed office worker (Irrfan Khan) nearing retirement in this debut feature from Ritesh Batra. “This is not a new conceit,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, citing “You’ve Got Mail” and “The Shop Around the Corner.” “But the idea of two lonely souls connecting in a vast, modern metropolis, and remaining strangers even as their intimacy grows, has a durable charm. As do Mr. Khan and Ms. Kaur, islands of melancholy calm surrounded by silliness and noise. Their performances are not exactly subtle — nothing in ‘The Lunchbox’ is exactly subtle — but they are graceful and dignified in the manner of movie stars in an earlier, less aggressive age, ennobling the ordinary lives they explore. And Mr. Batra makes their story touching and credible, an urban fable of hope in the face of disappointment.”

headline: As Pope Francis Visits Philippines, Tensions Between Church and Government Surface
abstract: After meeting with the pope, President Benigno S. Aquino III said that church leaders in the Philippines had been overly critical of him.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Pope Francis’ first full day in the Philippines was filled with the pageantry befitting a country in which more than 80 percent of the people identify themselves as Roman Catholics. But the tensions that have roiled relations between the church and the country’s leaders in recent years was also on display.

headline: Press Freedom in Hong Kong Under Threat, Report Says
abstract: The report by the PEN American Center cites developments that it says amount to an alarming erosion of Hong Kong’s tradition of freewheeling news media.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Press freedom in Hong Kong, long an enclave of liberties in the shadow of mainland China, is increasingly threatened, with journalists assaulted, news organizations censoring stories and advertisers shunning publications that rile the authorities, a new report says.

headline: Amazon’s Tax Deal With Luxembourg May Break Rules, E.U. Regulator Says
abstract: In a 23-page letter, the European Commission described a “complex” arrangement involving Amazon subsidiaries and outlined why it is pursuing the case.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s antitrust office on Friday released a preliminary finding that a tax deal between Amazon and the Luxembourg government appears to amount to unfair state aid that may have enabled the company to underpay its taxes for a decade or more.

headline: Corrections: January 16, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, January 16, 2015.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 16, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “I see this as a call for action to close the gap between conservation on land and in the sea.”

headline: Kerry Travels to Paris to Show Solidarity After Terror Attacks
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry started a day of high-level meetings and wreath-layings to commemorate France’s struggle against terrorism.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Secretary of State John Kerry on Friday capped off a morning full of high-level meetings and wreath-laying to commemorate France’s struggle against terrorism by welcoming James Taylor at Paris’s ornate City Hall.

headline: As Europe Moves Aggressively Against Terrorism, New Challenges Emerge
abstract: A spate of police raids and arrested suspects showed the complexity of the challenge facing intelligence agencies and security services in confronting the expanding threat from radical jihadis.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — After a series of police raids and a deadly gun battle, arrests of terror suspects in Belgium, Germany and France late Thursday and Friday highlighted the scope and complexity of the challenge facing European intelligence agencies and security services in confronting the expanding threat from radical jihadists, many of them battle-hardened in Syria and Iraq.

headline: South Korean Journalists Acquitted on Charges of Defaming President’s Brother
abstract: The case against the two, who speculated that Park Geun-hye’s brother might have been involved in a murder, was seen by rights groups as a test of freedom of speech.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Two journalists who have been vocal critics of South Korea’s president were acquitted Friday on charges of defaming her brother, in a case that rights groups saw as a test of freedom of speech here.

headline: Myanmar Sweeps Up Copies of Film Mocking Kim Jong-un
abstract: DVD vendors said police officers were sometimes accompanied by North Korean officials as they visited shops to seize copies of the controversial film.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — Long before Sony Pictures released “The Interview,” a comedy about a fictitious C.I.A. plot to kill North Korea’s leader, Pyongyang had declared war against the movie. It has since been blamed for a cyberattack on Sony’s computers. Now, it appears that the country’s famously touchy diplomats have taken the dispute much farther afield: to the streets of Yangon, Myanmar.

headline: Gov. Cuomo on New York City’s Woes
abstract: The governor could play a useful role in the tensions between the city’s police and Mayor Bill de Blasio, but much depends on how he acts.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, Gov. Andrew Cuomo has repeatedly noted his concern about the unhealthy tensions in New York City between the police and Mayor Bill de Blasio. He also sees an alluring political vacuum tempting him to step forward as an impartial healer and arbitrator. “I think everybody in New York City knows that this situation is unsustainable,” he said on Wednesday morning.

headline: Standing Up to the N.R.A.
abstract: With a veto on Thursday, Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan stood as the rare Republican leader willing to buck the powerful gun lobby’s statehouse clout.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan rebuffed heavy lobbying by the National Rifle Association and vetoed a patently dangerous gun measure Thursday that would have compounded the risks for women caught in domestic abuse cases. The measure, quietly passed by the Republican Legislature at the behest of the gun lobby, would have allowed gun permits for abusers in domestic violence and stalking cases — even those under a court-issued restraining order — if judges neglected to issue an explicit ban.

keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Research', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: We need science and gold-standard evidence about what works to help us identify promising interventions, and save lives.
lead_paragraph: What causes young inner-city men to kill each other?

abstract: Why might prejudice be unconscious?
lead_paragraph: In “Racial Bias, Even When We Have Good Intentions,” a social scientist writes about how we discriminate unconsciously.

headline: Test Yourself | A Go-Kart Star Called Little Alonso
abstract: Below are nine paragraphs from a Jan. 14 article, “Far Ahead of Curve, a 6-Year-Old Thrills a Nation.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?

headline: Encouraging Women to Be Heard
abstract: Readers respond to an Op-Ed essay by Sheryl Sandberg and Adam Grant about women staying quiet at work.

headline: What Are Your Favorite Movies Ever?
abstract: What were the best movies you saw in the past year?
lead_paragraph: The nominations for this year’s Academy Awards were announced on Thursday, and the films “Birdman,” “Grand Budapest Hotel,” “The Imitation Game” and “Boyhood” earned the most nods.

headline: Layers That Conceal and Reveal
abstract: The urban landscape offers Luis Mallo a chance to find layered, complex compositions that reveal his intent.
lead_paragraph: Luis Mallo has a simple rule for his photos. “It’s all about composition,” he insists. He will spend 40 minutes on a single photograph, relying on the flexible bellows of his 4×5 view camera to align the scene and achieve that perfect composition before he loses the right light.

headline: Head of India’s Central Bank Criticizes Post-Crisis Efforts
abstract: Raghuram G. Rajan has been critical of central banks around the globe for focusing too much on their domestic issues.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Raghuram G. Rajan, the governor of the Reserve Bank of India, has a reputation for bluntness. A former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, he has criticized central banks around the globe for focusing too much on their domestic issues instead of considering the international ramifications of their decisions.

headline: Preaching Loneliness to a Packed House
abstract: The British pop star Sam Smith played Madison Square Garden with his repertoire of love songs and a few surprises that honored his humble roots.
lead_paragraph: The British singer and songwriter Sam Smith has made himself pop’s king of cling, its bard of dependence. He started his sold-out Madison Square Garden show on Thursday evening with a song that insisted, “You’re my life support,” and finished it with his million-selling hit “Stay With Me,” begging someone to do just that, if only for a one-night stand.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Obama Proposes Tapping Private Investors to Fund Infrastructure Projects
abstract: A tax proposal and administrative actions are an attempt to pay for roads, bridges, water systems and broadband networks without using any new federal money.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House unveiled a tax proposal and administrative actions on Friday that are aimed at promoting private investment in roads, bridges, water systems and broadband networks.

headline: New York Today: Where Empty Bottles Go
abstract: Friday and the long weekend: A peek inside a recycling plant, a mixed bag of weather, and the week in pictures.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this chilly pre-holiday Friday.

headline: Xi’s Selective Punishment
abstract: The Chinese leader’s anticorruption drive is more of a Stalinist purge than an attempt to clean up government.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A Chinese government official I know was put under shuanggui, the secretive system of internal Communist Party investigation in which victims are detained, questioned without counsel and sometimes tortured. He was held for several months last year, and he now awaits trial. This midlevel apparatchik in Yunnan Province was responsible for city planning and construction. I don’t know why they targeted him — shuanggui is so opaque. Friends think he was an able official who may have taken a few bribes. But the most probable reason for his travails with the authorities was that his political patron also got in trouble.

headline: Daily Report: Intel Posts a Profit, Despite Losses in Mobile Devices
abstract: While Intel’s profit rose significantly, concerns remain about whether it can move beyond its focus on putting chips in personal computers and servers.
lead_paragraph: Intel ended 2014 on a high note, and appears confident that its momentum can continue. But the question is how much the company has to change to keep up the pace, Quentin Hardy reports.

headline: European Auto Market Expanded Last Year for First Time Since 2007
abstract: Passenger car registrations increased 5.7 percent across the European Union last year, and analysts expect a modest increase in sales again in 2015.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The European auto market grew last year for the first time since before the global financial crisis began, industry data showed on Friday, as consumers replaced worn-out models, and analysts expect a modest upward trend again this year.

headline: Green Bay Packers at Seattle Seahawks: N.F.C. Championship Preview
abstract: Seattle will find it difficult but not impossible to keep its home playoff winning streak alive against Green Bay, thanks in part to CenturyLink Field.
lead_paragraph: Packers at Seahawks

abstract: The Patriots have seemingly reveled in showing that although the Colts’ Andrew Luck may be the N.F.L.’s future, Tom Brady is the league’s present.

headline: To End an Unjust Imprisonment
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'Editorials', 'News and News Media', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: Iran must dismiss charges against a reporter for The Washington Post and set him free.
lead_paragraph: As Iran’s unjustified and unexplained imprisonment of Jason Rezaian, The Washington Post’s bureau chief in Tehran, headed into a sixth month, the government news agency announced Wednesday that he had been indicted. But the mystery continued: No charges were cited, nor was there any sign that the Iranian-American reporter would be allowed to consult a lawyer and Western diplomatic officials for his defense.

headline: Disappointing Trading Results Hobble 4th-Quarter Revenue at Goldman Sachs

headline: Morning Agenda: Hackers for Hire
abstract: The business of hacking is an increasingly personal enterprise. | Currency traders are reeling from the appreciation in the Swiss franc. | A trading slowdown at Citigroup raised questions about the Wall Street trading machine. | Caesars is in a bitter standoff with creditors after putting a unit into bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: HACKERS FOR HIRE | The business of hacking, once thought to be the domain of intelligence agencies and international criminal gangs, is an increasingly personal enterprise, Matthew Goldstein reports in DealBook. While big attacks on companies like Sony and JPMorgan Chase grab headlines, less noticed is a growing cottage industry of ordinary people hiring hackers for smaller acts of espionage.

headline: In Portugal, a Land Finely Aged Like Wine
abstract: A road trip through the whitewashed villages of the Alentejo, the southern Portuguese wine country.
lead_paragraph: The surprising thing about touching down at Lisbon Airport is how fast, heading south in a car, you find yourself transported into deep countryside. I arrived on a mild October morning, was met there by my old friend Martin Earl, and within a few minutes was crossing the Vasco da Gama Bridge, longest in Europe, an affair of towers and cables that stretches like a single bolt of flung steel across more than 10 miles of the Tagus River estuary. Immediately thereafter we swerved off the highway and decelerated into the dreaming, older world of the Alentejo (the word literally means “beyond the Tejo” or Tagus).

headline: Morgan Collett of Saturdays Surf NYC on Where to Eat, Drink, Shop and Stay in Milan
abstract: As the fall 2015 men’s shows kick off, one insider offers up tips for visitors to the city.
lead_paragraph: The fall/winter 2015 men’s wear shows kick off in Milan tomorrow, and men of style from all continents are currently descending on the city. Among them is Morgan Collett, the co-founder of Saturdays Surf NYC — a versatile line that appeals to Rockaway beach bums and Milanese peacocks alike. “I have been hearing that more and more Italians enjoy surfing, which is fantastic,” he says. “Our brand has so much influence from the fashion industry and the many cultures that exist in New York that I think Italians can appreciate our collection as part of a larger lifestyle.” Collett has come to town twice annually for the past several years for sales appointments, and in that time has come to rely on a few standbys for shelter, sustenance and inspiration. Here, he shares his list of local hangouts — some chilled-out, others classic, all worth a visit.

headline: Soup Well
abstract: Five soups made from winter vegetables.
lead_paragraph: This week I was all set to work on quick winter soups when I remembered that I had some terrific giant white beans in my pantry that were begging to be used in a slow-simmering minestrone. So I changed my plan and made an array of warming soups, some quicker than others but all easy. The only one that requires much time on the stove (unsupervised) is the minestrone, the heartiest of the week’s recipes and a delicious vehicle not only for the beans but for winter squash, too.

headline: A New ‘Orfeo’ Steps Off the Pedestal
abstract: A new Royal Opera House production of Monteverdi’s “Orfeo,” directed by Michael Boyd, ventures out of Covent Garden.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A modern curiosity of opera is that we spend vast amounts on theaters customized with all the comforts and amenities the art form needs, only to get excited by the prospect of performances in train sheds. It is the thrill of living rough. And it explains why the operatic event of the moment in London is a new Covent Garden production of Monteverdi’s “Orfeo” that is not actually playing at Covent Garden but at the Roundhouse: a cavernous industrial building in North London’s edgy Camden Town that once held trains but now holds music, though not often music of this kind.

headline: TV’s New Girls’ Club
abstract: Great shows used to be about fallen masculinity. Now they’re about collaboration and resilience. What changed?
lead_paragraph: There is a moment in HBO’s “Doll & Em” when Em, a movie star, leaves her trailer to rehearse her lines alone. Doll, Em’s childhood best friend and now her assistant, stays behind. In an echo of “All About Eve,” Doll picks up her friend’s script and starts reading aloud. “ 'Why didn’t you call me?’ ‘I didn’t think it was my place,' ” she says, intoning both parts and knowing she’s overstepping. The script is terrible. It’s derivative. But it’s a transgressive moment for Doll and a distillation of her complicated envy toward Em. The sharp parody happening in that scene — of great films, of female friendship, of Hollywood’s idea of better roles for women — coexists with an air of unstudied sincerity that’s in fact subversive. It’s a mood typical of the show and bespeaks a broader sophistication that has finally found its way onto the small screen, over a decade into what we’ve so often heard is a TV renaissance.

headline: Happy Meals
keywords: ['Parenting', 'Personal Finances', 'Children and Childhood', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Education', 'Fast Food Industry']
abstract: By providing my children with a better life, was I also depriving them?
lead_paragraph: Tujunga is not one of those well-to-do Los Angeles suburbs. It does not have a quaint main street or rows of tidy houses with trim lawns or a view of the ocean. When I was growing up, there were boarded-up storefronts and chain-link fences surrounding monstrous pink apartment buildings. There were abandoned houses and empty lots overrun by weeds.

headline: Try This at Home!
abstract: Does life imitate art or does art reflect life?
lead_paragraph: I live and work in Hollywood. Some of my friends are screenwriters, and they tend to be politically progressive. They often criticize conservatives for ignoring scientific evidence when it conflicts with their politics. But when it comes to the negative effects of violence in the media, my friends dismiss the idea and insist that it is unfair to blame artists for societal issues. When confronted with scientific studies that point to media having an impact on violent behavior, most say that this is merely a reflection of what is already there. But if there is evidence of an effect, even nominal, is it unethical to write (or produce or direct) violent films and shows? NAME WITHHELD, LOS ANGELES

headline: Valery Gergiev: ‘Anyone Can Buy a Ticket’
abstract: The conductor on taking Putin’s Russia to Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The conductor talks with Andrew Meier about trying his best to keep his politics and music separate.

headline: The Jet Set Life of Karl Lagerfeld’s Favorite Male Model — for Now
abstract: Private planes, caviar lunches and Little League.
lead_paragraph: One Sunday last spring, Brad Kroenig and his 5-year-old son, Hudson, showed up at a private airport near Paris to meet Karl Lagerfeld, the fashion designer. “Karl will be here 1, 1:30 for takeoff,” announced a Frenchman in a black suit and tie. “O.K., cool,” Brad said. The man in the suit performed something like a bow and retreated. It was 12:45. Brad sank into an armchair by the window and surveyed the tarmac. He pointed out a large gray hawk of a plane that stood off to the side of the slighter, dovelike jets. “It’s the same one that Oprah has,” Brad said. “It’s the biggest one. It flies, like, the longest journey. A lot of private planes have to stop for gas.”

headline: 1940: Thousands Join Finnish Army
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Thousands of volunteers join the Finnish army.
lead_paragraph: WITH THE INTERNATIONAL BRIGADE IN THE FINNISH ARMY — Another group of Americans and even more Swedes, Norwegians and Danes reached the training center for volunteers late last night [Jan. 15] and early today to swell the number of fighting men in the International Brigade being formed in Finland. They have been coming in here every day now for four or five weeks, at first in groups of twenty to thirty, and then by hundreds. It is beginning to look as if the greatest International Column of all time will be fighting for Finland by spring. The backbone of this International Brigade will be the Swedish corps under General Eric Linder, a powerful force trained and equipped and paid for by Swedes. It will operate under the supreme command of the Finnish General Staff. Otherwise, it will resemble a private army. They are here to fight for a small country with a population about half that of the City of New York, into which a powerful neighbor has sent its armies and air force. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 17, 1940

headline: A Sleepy Ottawa Neighborhood Wakes Up
abstract: Chefs and entrepreneurs have reinvigorated the ByWard Market area, ushering in an era of hybrid establishments and must-try bars and restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Until recently, downtown Ottawa’s ByWard Market — the name for both one of Canada’s oldest farmers’ markets and the roughly four-block neighborhood that encompasses it — suffered from a common capital-city affliction: After hours, it turned notoriously sleepy. Lately, however, numerous chefs and entrepreneurs have reimagined and reinvigorated the area, ushering in a new era of one-of-a-kind shopping, hybrid establishments and must-try bars and restaurants.
