lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Consumer prices in the United States are rising at the slowest pace during a period of economic growth in the last half-century, a trend that could delay the Federal Reserve’s retreat from its stimulus campaign.

headline: $17 Million Home in Art Deco Chelsea Tower
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: An apartment claimed by one of the developers during the early stages of the Walker Tower’s conversion was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: Another apartment at Walker Tower that was claimed by one of the developers during the early stages of the Art Deco skyscraper’s conversion sold for $17,156,250 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records. The duplex aerie is now back on the market for almost double the purchase price.

headline: Lemon Bars With Olive Oil
abstract: Melissa Clark makes lemon bars sprinkled with flaky sea salt and confectioners’ sugar.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark makes lemon bars sprinkled with flaky sea salt and confectioners’ sugar.

headline: Lemon Bars With a Touch of the Tart and the Tangy
abstract: Olive oil and sea salt bring complexity and sophistication to this lemon bar recipe. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: My mother wasn’t a baker, but she did make some mean lemon bars when I was growing up, using a recipe straight out of a Charlie Brown cookbook.

headline: Aaron Rodgers Has a Strained Calf, and Everyone Has Advice
abstract: Rodgers’s injury diminishes his mobility as quarterback but has not hurt his effectiveness. That has not stopped Packers fans from offering their help.
lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY, Wis. — The fans mean well, Aaron Rodgers said. On his Tuesday radio show and again at a Wednesday news conference at Lambeau Field, Rodgers thanked those who called, emailed and texted various suggestions for speeding the healing of his strained left calf.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Leaving Before the Rains Come’
abstract: This week, Alexandra Fuller discusses her new memoir, “Leaving Before the Rains Come”; John Williams has news from the publishing world; Lauren Groff talks about Miranda July’s “The First Bad Man”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Alexandra Fuller discusses her new memoir, “Leaving Before the Rains Come”; John Williams has news from the publishing world; Lauren Groff talks about Miranda July’s “The First Bad Man”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Leaving Before the Rains Come’
abstract: This week, Alexandra Fuller and Lauren Groff.
lead_paragraph: This week, Alexandra Fuller and Lauren Groff.

headline: Critics’ Choice Awards
abstract: Perhaps relieved that the suspense of Oscar nominations was over, stars let their hair down Thursday night in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps relieved that the suspense of Oscar nominations was over, stars let their hair down Thursday night in Los Angeles.

headline: Clint Eastwood Narrates a Sequence From ‘American Sniper’
abstract: The director discusses a sequence from his film featuring Bradley Cooper and Sienna Miller.
lead_paragraph: In this video, the director Clint Eastwood discusses a scene from his Oscar-nominated film, in which Chris Kyle (Bradley Cooper) takes a moment in a bar to unwind after returning from an Iraq tour.

headline: Uber to Introduce Driver Background Checks in India
abstract: The ride-hailing start-up brings new screening policies to India after months of scrutiny from lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: Uber plans to introduce background check procedures for its drivers in India, the company said Thursday evening, in a move that comes weeks after a driver was charged with rape there. The episode prompted wider scrutiny of the ride-hailing service that is now banned in some parts of the country.

headline: The Trip Is Ending: Dead Will Play Final Shows in July
abstract: Three concerts in Chicago in July will be the Grateful Dead’s four surviving members’ final performances together.
lead_paragraph: Honoring a half-century of Grateful Dead music, the band’s four surviving members will reunite for three shows this summer in what is being billed as their final performance together.

headline: ‘I’m Glad I Did’ and ‘Scripted’
abstract: Two Y.A. novels consider the perks and the costs of celebrity and show business.
lead_paragraph: It’s never been easier to be a famous teenager, even if it’s never easy to be a teenager. Two new debut novels find similarly plucky, quietly ambitious 16-year-old heroines at the beginning stages of stardom. Though living on opposite sides of planet showbiz — “I’m Glad I Did” takes place in a “Mad Men”-era New York, while “Scripted” is set on an island where inhabitants’ lives are broadcast 24/7 — each girl comes to learn the same lesson: Where the lights are brightest, you’re bound to get burned.

headline: Experiencing the Chokehold Firsthand
abstract: Kirk Semple, a Metro reporter, describes being assigned to experience the much-debated police chokehold.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department banned the chokehold, a tactic that contributed to the death of Eric Garner, in 1993. But as a report revealed this week, the chokehold is still the “first act of physical force” that officers use, even facing “mere verbal confrontation.” To better understand the methods that the Police Department uses to subdue suspects, Kirk Semple, a reporter, was asked to experience them firsthand.

headline: Letter From the Editor: Calories, a Two-Step
abstract: Restaurants try to find ways to brag about nutrition while also bragging about portion size. Behold the “culinary monsterpiece.”
lead_paragraph: It’s fair to say that the people who run Chipotle did not love our recent feature on what 2,000 calories’ worth of food look like. We pointed out that a single generous meal at Chipotle, centered on a carnitas burrito, can deliver 2,000 calories, which happens to be the recommended intake for many adults over an entire day.

headline: A Political Challenge for the Navajo Nation
abstract: The tribe has inaugurated a new body of lawmakers, but does not have a president.
lead_paragraph: The tribe has inaugurated a new body of lawmakers, but does not have a president.

headline: A Navajo Inauguration, Minus a New Leader
abstract: After a popular candidate was rejected, critics said that a requirement that Navajo presidents be fluent in their native language had allowed tradition to trump progress.
lead_paragraph: FORT DEFIANCE, Ariz. — Crisp suits. A roaring band. Beaming first-term lawmakers. The inauguration held here this week for the newest government of the Navajo Nation held the trappings of a typical passage of power.

headline: Protests in Pakistan Over Charlie Hebdo
abstract: Demonstrations took place across Pakistan, including clashes between protesters and the police in Karachi, over the Muhammad cartoon published on the cover of the French newspaper Charlie Hebdo.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrations took place across Pakistan, including clashes between protesters and the police in Karachi, over the Muhammad cartoon published on the cover of the French newspaper Charlie Hebdo.

headline: Catch Her if You Can
abstract: In Rebecca Scherm’s first novel, “Unbecoming,” an art student reinvents herself.
lead_paragraph: The objets d’art produced in the Paris atelier of Zanuso et Filles by a young woman who calls herself Julie and claims to come from California are so lovely, it hardly seems fair to call them fakes. The same applies to Julie from California, who is really Grace from Garland, Tenn., and a first-class fraud.

headline: What to Look Out for at Men’s Fashion Week in Milan
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: Milan gets its turn in the spotlight, with Brioni making its return to the runway and the creative director of Jil Sander presenting his first men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — It’s gray and drizzly here, but the crowds are coming in anyway Friday, via their Freccia Rossas (the Italian high-speed train) from Florence, where Pitti Uomo has just wrapped up, or flying in from farther afield. The fall 2015 men’s wear season is well underway, with London and now Pitti complete, and the Milanese shows starting Friday night.

headline: Obama and Cameron Face the Press
abstract: President Obama and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain are holding a joint news conference at the White House.
lead_paragraph: President Obama and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain are set to hold a joint news conference at the White House. Previewing their meeting, The Times’s Michael D. Shear reported in First Draft this morning that domestic and international terrorism is at the top of their agenda today.

headline: An Artist’s ‘Meditation Nightclub’ on the Las Vegas Strip
abstract: Lia Chavez’s interactive show emulates the sights and sounds of a night out — based on visitors’ brainwaves (and without the dancing).
lead_paragraph: Artists’ residencies in Las Vegas tend to involve grand theater stages and bizarre ticketed performances, but at the Cosmopolitan hotel, the New York-based multimedia artist Lia Chavez has crafted an altogether different kind of spectacle. As the first in the annual lineup for the hotel’s P3Studio artist-in-residence program, Chavez has set up a surprisingly cerebral take on the notion of nightclubbing.

headline: Bookshelf: Snow Days
abstract: New picture books include Peter McCarty’s “First Snow” and Deirdre Gill’s “Outside.”
lead_paragraph: New picture books include Peter McCarty’s “First Snow” and Deirdre Gill’s “Outside.”

headline: ‘The Secret Wisdom of the Earth,’ by Christopher Scotton
abstract: A Kentucky town is roiled by conflict over aggressive mining in this first novel.
lead_paragraph: There’s a school of thought that believes the major chords are to be found in the familiar, and the great books are those that most readily suggest the well-known, well-loved classics. “The Secret Wisdom of the Earth,” the first novel from Christopher Scotton, brings a handful of favorite novels to mind, suggestive of several without being deeply indebted to any single one. That accounts, at least in part, for the great enthusiasm this novel has generated on its way to publication.

headline: Thrillers
abstract: New books by Harriet Lane, Tim Johnston, Tina Seskis and Nina Darnton.
lead_paragraph: HER  By Harriet Lane  Little, Brown, $26.

headline: J. Robert Lennon’s ‘See You in Paradise’
abstract: In these stories, common domestic dysfunction segues into fantasy.
lead_paragraph: In the first story of “See You in Paradise,” J. Robert Lennon’s funny and poignant new collection, a family discovers a “magic portal” in their backyard. The “oval, sort of man-sized, shimmering thing” not only transports them to other worlds; it also serves as the reader’s entree to the rest of the book, with its array of futuristic and surreal psychic landscapes. The breezy blend of realism and fantasy is characteristic: The narrator, a world-weary dad, describes the first giddy era of exploration, which soon declines into domestic dysfunction as his children hit puberty and his wife grows distant. The portal, mirroring this entropy, becomes “lopsided, with a sort of hernia in the lower left corner,” and the narrator is left bereft and aching, trying to find his way back to some semblance of enchantment.

headline: ‘The First Bad Man,’ by Miranda July
abstract: A perverse houseguest shakes the world of the initially passive protagonist of Miranda July’s first novel.
lead_paragraph: Cheryl Glickman has a psychosomatic lump in her throat that sometimes prevents her from swallowing. She also has a burning crush on a man named Phillip Bettelheim who wants her blessing before he consummates his love for an underage girl, and a karmic connection with a child she calls Kubelko Bondy, whose spirit continually appears to her in other people’s babies. Cheryl is the protagonist of Miranda July’s very funny debut novel, “The First Bad Man,” and she’s such an acute observer that her life is never as pathetic to the reader as it appears to the people around her. She has developed systems for everything, including a rigid housekeeping asceticism that helps her stave off the kind of debilitating sadness that, if left unchecked, can snowball from letting dirty dishes pile up in the sink to eating off said dirty dishes, to no longer bathing, to urinating in cups because they’re closer to the bed. Her ideal is unruffled contentment. When things really flow, she says, “my days become dreamlike, no edges anywhere, none of the snags and snafus that life is so famous for. After days and days alone it gets silky to the point where I can’t even feel myself anymore, it’s as if I don’t exist.”

headline: 1965: Swedes Report Soviet Blast
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1965: Swedes report Soviet nuclear blast
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — An underground atomic explosion deep in the Soviet Union has warned the Western world that the Russians may be stepping up development of their strategic nuclear weapons.

headline: What I Love | Jill Platner
abstract: A long-held loft has gone the distance with an artist, serving as home and workshop.
lead_paragraph: A long-held loft has gone the distance with an artist, serving as home and workshop.

headline: An Artist in Her Element, a Garret
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Art']
abstract: The jeweler and sculptor has lived in the same downtown loft since she was a student.
lead_paragraph: When she was a 21-year-old student at the Parsons School of Design, the sculptor and jewelry designer Jill Platner fell in love with a TriBeCa restaurateur. He put up a notice that they were looking for an apartment, and one of his regulars offered them a rental in NoHo: a loftlike fourth-floor walk-up with a wood-burning fireplace, a mezzanine and a peaked ceiling supported by timber beams.

headline: Letters: Retelling Joan’s Story
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Kathryn Harrison’s “Joan of Arc” and more.
lead_paragraph: Retelling Joan’s Story

headline: Tony Judt’s ‘When the Facts Change’
abstract: Written in the last 15 years of Tony Judt’s life, these essays confront the history, politics and ethical dilemmas that consumed him.
lead_paragraph: “The arc is down,” is how Jennifer Homans, the widow of Tony Judt and an eminent dance critic and historian, describes the age of cruel disappointment that followed the end of the Cold War. It was the era in which her husband was condemned to live out his last two decades before his untimely death at age 62 in 2010.

headline: Bitcoin Is a Victim of Disinflation
abstract: In a more ebullient and inflationary world, the novelty and limited supply of Bitcoins might appeal, Edward Hadas of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin is proving a big disappointment. The virtual currency is down 33 percent against the dollar in 2015, and 71 percent in the last year. There is almost certainly more bad news to come.

headline: Jane Bahk’s ‘Juna’s Jar,’ and More
abstract: With some help, these little ones are bouncing back from letdowns to find the beauty (and fun) in the world around them.
lead_paragraph: The great novels for young readers all explore the same question: How do we respond to an unfair world? For the picture book crowd, unfairness and injustice can be tough topics for discussion, but as three new books show, even the very young understand disappointment.

headline: ‘The Darkest Part of the Forest’ and ‘The Ghosts of Heaven’
abstract: Humans and fairies, cave men and astronauts: Two fantasy books for young adults move across boundaries.
lead_paragraph: As discerning readers are well aware, some of the most interesting fiction currently being written is published under the catchall category of young adult — a term that encompasses such a diversity of work as to be nearly meaningless, but that does suggest a book’s concerns will focus primarily on the doings of adolescent characters (though, as we shall see, even this definition does not always hold true). The young adult fiction ­powerhouses Holly Black and Marcus Sedgwick are masters of the genre, with well-deserved reputations for pushing it to its limits, and both writers’ newest books ably demonstrate that the line between young and adult is fluid indeed.

headline: Jennifer Niven’s ‘All the Bright Places’
abstract: In Jennifer Niven’s young adult debut, a suicidal teenager shows a grief-stricken girl how to live again.
lead_paragraph: In the opening moments of Jennifer Niven’s “All the Bright Places,” a 12th grader named Theodore Finch poses on the narrow sixth-story ledge of his school’s bell tower, arms extended, welcoming the spectators below to his death scene. And then he notices the popular Violet Markey on the same ledge, terrified, thinking about taking a leap of her own.

headline: India Film Censor Resigns, Complaining of Government Interference
abstract: The head of the Central Board of Film Certification said government ministers regularly telephoned board members to press them to change decisions.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — India’s chief film censor, Leela Samson, resigned this week, saying she could no longer tolerate the interference of high-ranking government officials in her work. A second member of the film certification board followed suit on Friday, also citing interference.

headline: Popcast: Sleater-Kinney Returns
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Jon Pareles are joined by Caryn Ganz, of RollingStone.com, to discuss “No Cities to Love,” the new album by Sleater-Kinney.
lead_paragraph: As of this writing, days before the release of its new album “No Cities to Love,” @Sleater_Kinney — an official band account on Twitter established in late October last year — has roughly 10,000 followers. But it’s fair to assume that many of those followers think Sleater-Kinney was the greatest rock band of the last 25 years.

headline: Patricia Arquette and Her Terrible, Horrible, Also Very Good Day
abstract: The actress tweets that her car was towed the same morning that she was nominated for an Oscar.
lead_paragraph: Patricia Arquette, the best supporting actress nominee for “Boyhood,” learned of the Academy honor on a busy morning:

lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil – The JetBlue founder David Neeleman has postponed plans for the third time to hold an initial public offering for the Brazilian airline company he founded, as Brazil’s stock market continued to be volatile.

headline: A Closer Look at the Global Warming Trend, Record Hot 2014 and What’s Ahead
keywords: ['Earth', 'El Nino Southern Oscillation', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Oceans and Seas']
abstract: Computer models range widely in assessing whether the record warmth of 2014 will be topped in 2015.
lead_paragraph: There’s plenty of news coverage, including in The Times, of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announcement that 2014 was the warmest year since careful record keeping began in 1880.

headline: Where Shiny Meets Gritty
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Leasing has begun at a glassy Dumbo rental complex, but critics call it an eyesore that obstructs historic views.
lead_paragraph: For renters looking for new construction in Dumbo, a Brooklyn neighborhood with scant space to build, 60 Water Street has begun leasing 232 market-rate apartments, many with stunning East River views. But for many residents, historians and preservationists, the glassy complex with a 17-story tower is an eyesore that obstructs historic views seen from the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Pierce Brown says his novel “Golden Son,” which is No. 6 on the hardcover fiction list, “echoes a lot of the dissatisfaction that many people feel” with the political system.
lead_paragraph: Bullies Are From Mars: “Golden Son,” the second novel in Pierce Brown’s Red Rising trilogy, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 6. The plot of these books — in which a charismatic hero makes his way from Mars’s oppressed underclass into the ruling elite, where he plans a secret insurrection — has reminded some critics of the Hunger Games series, while putting others (O.K., me) in mind of Arthur Krystal’s observation about pulp fiction: “Skilled genre writers know that a certain level of artificiality must prevail, lest the reasons we turn to their books evaporate.” But in an interview last year with the publishing trade magazine Kirkus, Brown, who is 26, suggested the series is less artificial than it seems, at least to the extent it reflects his generation’s distrust of the political system. “I’m not trying to make a statement,” he said; “I just think it echoes a lot of the dissatisfaction that many people feel with those who make the decisions based on their own self-interests, rather than what is in the best interests of society. It’s people being selfish.” In the same interview, Brown said his views of cliques and social structures had been shaped in part by his childhood experiences moving from state to state with his family. “A lot of times, I faced bullies — or the ‘big dogs’ at school. What I wanted ‘Red Rising’ to be is not necessarily an indictment on bullies, but it reflects my experiences and attitudes that I had with bullies growing up. A lot of times, you had to beat the bullies at their own game. But the difficulty is not becoming the bully yourself.”

headline: Bankruptcy Code Forces Rush of Empty Stores
abstract: An overhaul of Chapter 11 in 2005 imposes a tight time frame on handling commercial leases, complicating the process for retailers, Stephen J. Lubben writes in the In Debt column.
lead_paragraph: The bankruptcy filing on Friday by Wet Seal, the teen apparel retailer, and the all too obvious moves in the same direction by Radio Shack, illustrate how much Chapter 11 practice has changed since the bankruptcy code was overhauled in 2005. This is especially true for retail companies.

headline: Galliano for Margiela, the Royals Get Social and Leo and Rihanna?
abstract: Plus, Frida Giannini’s early departure, Terry Richardson’s return and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The database contains calls between the United States and abroad as part of an effort to catch drug traffickers — but data was collected on people not involved in criminal activity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department revealed on Thursday the existence of yet another database of American telephone records, adding new details to the disclosures in recent years about mass government surveillance.

headline: Australian Open: Players to Watch
abstract: Six tennis players who are positioned well to use the Australian Open, which begins on Monday, as a springboard to success in 2015.
lead_paragraph: The Australian Open, which begins Monday, can be a springboard to success in 2015. Here are some players who are poised for a strong showing in Melbourne.

headline: U.S. and Britain Present a United Front
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Obama and Prime Minister David Cameron, vowing new cooperation after the terrorist attacks in Paris, agreed to bolster cybersecurity and step up training of Iraqi forces to counter the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Friday that the United States and Britain have pledged new cooperation to bolster cybersecurity and an intensified effort against the Islamic State as the two nations work to confront a mounting threat from violent extremists across the globe in the wake of terrorist attacks in Paris.

headline: Stuff We Liked: Checking Out the Neighborhood
abstract: Our weekly look at web gems, including analysis of spending on diseases, educational test scores and the peak years of authors.
lead_paragraph: We found a wide variety of thought-provoking material on the web this week.

headline: The Rehabilitation of Joe Paterno, Back at No. 1
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A proposed N.C.A.A. settlement is one sign that the reputation of the former Penn State football coach may be rehabilitated after the Jerry Sandusky child-molestation scandal.
lead_paragraph: Amid the child-molesting scandal at Penn State, Joe Paterno lost his job, more than 100 victories as a coach and his reputation as a kind of football Renaissance man. Even a statue of him outside the university’s stadium was removed.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: AMERICA’S BITTER PILL: Money, Politics, Backroom Deals, and the Fight to Fix Our Broken Healthcare System,  by Steven Brill. (Random House, $28.) Brill’s fresh, outsider curiosity makes him a superb guide to the maze of issues here.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region

lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom house in Larchmont, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Stamford, Conn.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: FDR AND THE JEWS, by Richard Breitman and Allan J. Lichtman. (Belknap/Harvard University, $19.95.) What, exactly, did Franklin Roosevelt do during his presidency, from 1933 to 1945, to protect the Jews of Europe from Nazi genocide? This thorough revisiting of the record reveals a concerned leader whose efforts on behalf of Jews were significant yet whose moral role was tempered by the political realities of depression and war.

abstract: The Republican National Committee announced the initial schedule of presidential primary debates, beginning this August and spanning seven months.
lead_paragraph: The Republican National Committee has announced the initial schedule of presidential primary debates, beginning this August and spanning seven months.

headline: A French Town Linked to Jihad Asks Itself Why
abstract: In the wake of attacks in Paris, the southern town of Lunel, population 25,700, is trying to fathom how it became a source of recruits for fighting in Syria.
lead_paragraph: LUNEL, France — When this picturesque southern French town of just 25,700 people first learned late last year that six local Muslims had been killed fighting for Islam in Syria, accounting for 10 percent of the total number of French killed there, the right-wing mayor quietly asked the head of the local mosque for help.

headline: José Saramago’s ‘Skylight’
abstract: An early novel by José Saramago looks in on the humble residents of a Lisbon apartment building.
lead_paragraph: From outside a cobbler’s airy window, a little corner of Lisbon unfurls. Voyeurism is inescapable in José Saramago’s “new” novel, “Skylight,” which peeks in on a shabby apartment building in the 1940s and takes its epigraph from the Portuguese writer Raul Brandão: “In all souls, as in all houses, beyond the facade lies a hidden interior.” The interior at issue in this book is all the heartbreak and tepid dreams of the building’s humble residents, who are stuck in “the inquisitorial silence of the past observing us and the ironic silence of the future that awaits us.”

headline: Sundance London Festival Canceled
abstract: The London offshoot of the Sundance Film Festival has been canceled for this year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Sundance London, an offshoot of the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah, will not return in 2015, the website ScreenDaily reported Friday. The London edition has been held at the O2 Center, more usually home to large-scale pop concerts, since 2012 when Robert Redford, the chairman of the Sundance Festival, said that he hoped it would help “build a picture of our country that is broadly reflective of the diversity of voices not always seen in our cultural exports.”

headline: From Seminary to the Cemetery, Fascination Persists Over Pets and the Afterlife
keywords: ['Religion and Belief', 'Pets', 'Death and Dying', 'Cemeteries', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: A comment attributed incorrectly to Pope Francis has led to renewed interest in a longstanding theological discussion.
lead_paragraph: In December, Pope Francis got the attention of pet owners everywhere when he was quoted as saying, “Paradise is open to all of God’s creatures.” Alas, media outlets, including The New York Times, confused the remarks and the circumstances under which they were made. The pope had actually made a broader comment about heaven during an event in November. The quotation itself was reportedly taken from remarks made years ago by Pope Paul VI.

headline: SpaceX Founder Releases Photos of Rocket’s Crash Landing
keywords: ['Rocket Science and Propulsion', 'Private Spaceflight', 'Space and Astronomy']
abstract: Elon Musk posted pictures of a Falcon 9 rocket exploding on a floating platform in the Atlantic Ocean.
lead_paragraph: It came down with a crash and a flash.

headline: Paid Leave and America’s Family Values
abstract: President Obama wants better benefits for workers.
lead_paragraph: Continuing his post-midterm strategy of pushing good ideas that might actually appeal to a lot of people, President Obama on Thursday announced two family friendly proposals.

headline: Eccentricities, Classroom Steps and a Balcony Scene
abstract: New York Theater Ballet performs the latest installment of its Legends & Visionaries series at the 92nd Street Y.
lead_paragraph: New York Theater Ballet  may be small, but its repertory is mighty. For the latest installment of the Legends & Visionaries series, Diana Byer, the artistic director, dusted off some of the company’s amiable works by an array of accomplished choreographers. Leading off the program at the 92nd Street Y on Saturday was Pam Tanowitz’s “Short Memory,” created for the company in 2013 and set to music by Lou Harrison and Henry Cowell.

headline: Truman and His Degrees (All Honorary)
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Harry Truman has been the only United States president since 1901 without a bachelor’s degree,
lead_paragraph: Harry Truman has been the only United States president since 1901 without a bachelor’s degree,

headline: Insider Tips: Travel in 2015
abstract: Monica Drake, Travel editor, shares her top destinations for 2015.
lead_paragraph: As a special thanks to Insiders, Times editors and reporters are giving the gift of great recommendations for 2015. Monica Drake, Travel editor, shares the places she would like to visit in the coming year.

headline: Zach Blank: Outside the Great Indoors
abstract: Mr. Blank is the vice president of Paragon Sporting Goods, a quintessential store for New York athletes that is a family business.
lead_paragraph: Zach Blank grew up in an indoor playground; now he gets to work there. Mr. Blank, 31, is the vice president of Paragon Sporting Goods, a quintessential store for New York athletes — especially when it comes to winter sports like skiing, snowboarding and ice skating. The six-floor family business, on East 18th Street and Broadway in Manhattan, was founded in 1908 by Mr. Blank’s great-grandfather, Phil Blank, an émigré from Ukraine, and his father, Bruce, is the president and chief executive. Mr. Blank is studying for an M.B.A. at New York University’s Stern School of Business. He lives in Gramercy with his fiancée, Betsy Lawson, 30, a program manager at the KIPP Foundation, the charter school enterprise, and their dogs, Tristan, a rescue pit bull mix, and Archie, a goldendoodle.

headline: Co-Stars at Last!
abstract: Cast as an extra, the groom finds his princess making a Bollywood movie at Harvard.
lead_paragraph: Cast as an extra, the groom finds his princess making a Bollywood movie at Harvard.

headline: Marion Cotillard in Voluminous Dior Couture
abstract: The actress’s sculptural, white-as-snow gown made a strong statement at the 2015 Critics’ Choice Awards.
lead_paragraph: The Star: Marion Cotillard

headline: Readers Respond: On Tom Hanks and Community College
abstract: The Tom Hanks Op-Ed “I Owe It All to Community College” evoked readers’ youthful hopes — and their support of community colleges.
lead_paragraph: Like the boy who looked into a “magic” machine and wished to be “Big,” the actor and director Tom Hanks evoked readers’ youthful hopes as they recounted how they realized their ambitions through inexpensive community colleges like the one he attended in the 1970s.

abstract: President Obama and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said they would work together to thwart extremism and terrorism around the world.
lead_paragraph: President Obama and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said they would work together to thwart extremism and terrorism around the world.

lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: A Princess for a Make-Believe Prince
abstract: Cast as an extra, the groom finds his princess making a Bollywood movie at Harvard.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in the United States in the 1990s, Trisha Pasricha fell in love with Indian movies from the 1950s, ’60s and ’70s — a period known as the Golden Age of Bollywood. The glamour, the romance, the music and dancing: She loved it all. She watched and rewound the videotape of her favorite 1972 movie, “Pakeezah,” so many times, it broke.

headline: D’Angelo to Perform at the Apollo
abstract: The Feb. 7 show will be the reclusive soul singer’s first public appearance since the release of “Black Messiah,” his first album in 14 years.
lead_paragraph: After ending 2014 with the unexpected reveal of “Black Messiah,” his first album in almost 15 years, D’Angelo is keeping the surprises coming.

lead_paragraph: A look back at the week in politics, from the White House to Capitol Hill.

headline: Prince Andrew, Back in News, Faces Curse of the ‘Spare’
abstract: The resurgence of allegations that the prince had sex with a minor has raised anew the problem of carving out a life as a “spare” in Britain’s royal family.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It’s not easy being the spare, the second son trained for little except hanging around waiting for your older brother to die, or to have children who then outrank you. Being Prince Andrew, the Duke of York, is a lot like being the vice president of the United States — only for life.

headline: Rand Paul Gets a Gift Not Made in America
abstract: Senator Rand Paul is now the proud owner of the ultimate smoking jacket: a custom-made, navy blue hemp blazer.
lead_paragraph: Senator Rand Paul is now the proud owner of the ultimate smoking jacket: a custom-made, navy blue hemp blazer.

headline: A Journey Into the Mind, Beginning at the Ear
abstract: The composer Bora Yoon brings her “Sunken Cathedral,” a multimedia journey, to the Prototype festival.
lead_paragraph: The origin of sound is often concealed in a blur of fast-moving arms, fingers and bows — a thick tapestry of notes created by instruments clustered together and sometimes only partly visible to the audience. A crucial element of the Korean-American vocalist and composer Bora Yoon’s performance art is highlighting the tactile elements of sound production, as she does during her mesmerizing “Sunken Cathedral”: a soundscape blending electronic, acoustic and visual components that opened on Wednesday at La MaMa as part of the Prototype festival.

headline: Supreme Court to Decide Marriage Rights for Gay Couples Nationwide
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'States (US)']
abstract: The court, after declining to take up the issue in October, is now likely to resolve one of the great civil rights questions of the age before its current term ends in June.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to decide whether all 50 states must allow gay and lesbian couples to marry, positioning it to resolve one of the great civil rights questions in a generation before its current term ends in June.

lead_paragraph: Mel Gibson’s character got to explore one mystery of the universe in the movie “What Women Want,” but a far bigger enigma — as any parent who has tried to raise one knows — is what teenage girls want.

headline: An American Techno D.J. Beloved Overseas Comes to Brooklyn
abstract: Jeff Mills, who has been both canonized in Eminem lyrics and knighted Chevalier des Arts et des Lettres by the the French ministry of culture, makes a rare appearance in Williamsburg this Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Half an hour into Jeff Mills’s futuristic black-and-white film “Man From Tomorrow” there is a long, unfocused shot of people dancing in a dark space. The skin from their bodies catches the light at different angles, creating shimmering gray blurs that look like particles under a microscope or energy vibrating out in the cosmos. “That part of the film referenced the idea of what happens when a D.J. has been in that scenario for many, many years,” explains Mills, 51, who began D.J.ing on Detroit radio in the 1980s. After several prolific decades as a producer, label boss and artist, he has become the intellectual Jupiter in the techno solar system and certainly the only person to be both canonized in Eminem lyrics and knighted Chevalier des Arts et des Lettres by the the French ministry of culture. “You develop a certain type of alternative view of the audience as a collective, as a composite,” he says. “In most cases, I’m looking at the audience as a wave, or like when you go to the sea and you’re looking at the different levels of the water.”

headline: Percentage of Poor Students in Public Schools Rises
abstract: Just over 50 percent of students are eligible for free or reduced-price lunches, the Southern Education Foundation said.
lead_paragraph: Just over half of all students attending public schools in the United States are now eligible for free or reduced-price lunches, according to a new analysis of federal data.

keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'E-Mail', 'Industrial Espionage']

lead_paragraph: Hacker’s List, an online meeting place for hackers and people who want to hire them, spent a good part of Friday struggling to keep the upstart web service running.

headline: PepsiCo Reaches Truce With Nelson Peltz After 2 Years of Locking Horns
abstract: The settlement will most likely end a long-running campaign by Mr. Peltz to break up PepsiCo, who has said investors would benefit by spinning off the company’s beverage business.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two years of public saber-rattling between PepsiCo and the billionaire investor Nelson Peltz appeared to end on Friday, as the two announced a truce of sorts.

headline: As ‘Motown’ Nears Closing, the Hits and Dollars Keep Coming
abstract: “Motown: The Musical,” which closes Sunday, has recouped its backers’ $18 million investment.
lead_paragraph: “Motown: The Musical,” which ends its Broadway run on Sunday, recouped its $18 investment at the end of last year, its producers announced Friday. The show began performances at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater in March 2013. Only about 25 percent of shows on Broadway earn back their capitalization and turn a profit each year.

headline: Heralding New Music and Nurturing It
abstract: Joel Sachs, a professor at Juilliard, has been readying a weeklong survey of the post-1945 Japanese repertory for the school’s annual Focus! festival.
lead_paragraph: Alfred Schnittke’s String Trio, written in 1985, swerves from clamorous dissonance to almost unbearably poignant lyricism and back again. On a recent afternoon, three students at the Juilliard School were starting its slow second movement in a practice room high above 66th Street. Joel Sachs, a professor at the school, sat across the room on a slouchy yellow couch, following along with a score. After a few seconds, he stopped the music.

headline: City Ballet’s Fab Five (2015 Edition)
abstract: New York City Ballet’s new season will feature five ballerinas in top form.
lead_paragraph: The word “ballerina” simply means, in Italian, a female dancer. But in the Anglo-Saxon dance world, it means quite specifically a female practitioner of ballet — and not just any female practitioner, but one who has reached the summit of her art, who exemplifies the essential attributes of classical dance. (France and Italy still don’t use the word in this sense, although the Paris Opera Ballet gives us “étoiles” or stars.) What those attributes must be has probably changed from era to era. Today we value, indeed expect, absolute technical mastery from a top ballerina, and we want musicality, dramatic power, charm, assertiveness and radiance, too.

headline: Why Some Teams Are Smarter Than Others
abstract: It’s about listening, empathy and having more women.
lead_paragraph: ENDLESS meetings that do little but waste everyone’s time. Dysfunctional committees that take two steps back for every one forward. Project teams that engage in wishful groupthinking rather than honest analysis. Everyone who is part of an organization — a company, a nonprofit, a condo board — has experienced these and other pathologies that can occur when human beings try to work together in groups.

headline: In Milan for Fashion Week? Here’s What to Do
keywords: ['Milan Fashion Week', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: There’s more to do in Milan, Italy’s second largest, than gaze at models with chiseled cheekbones, in well-tailored suits. Here are our suggestions.
lead_paragraph: Fashion is always central to life in Milan, and never so much as during Fashion Week, which begins on Jan. 17 with the fall/winter 2015 men’s wear. But there is more to do in the city, Italy’s second largest, than gaze at models with chiseled cheekbones, in well-tailored suits (not to imply that activity ever becomes tiring, of course).

headline: The Best Way to Get Over a Breakup
abstract: Write about your feelings. But not too much.
lead_paragraph: Writing about your feelings, a practice long embraced by teenagers and folk singers, is now attracting attention as a path to good health. And a recent study suggests that reflecting on your emotions could help you get over a breakup. But, one of its authors says, journaling can have its downsides.

headline: Inspiration: Some Find It Alone, Others in Collaboration
abstract: Chris Potter, Ryan Bingham, Aaron Goldberg, Rob Mazurek and Tanya Tagaq release new music.
lead_paragraph: Chris Potter Underground Orchestra

headline: Robin Pecknold of Fleet Foxes Branches Out to the Stage
abstract: Pecknold’s latest project isn’t an album but a score — for “Wyoming,” an off-Broadway family drama written by his cousin Brian Watkins.
lead_paragraph: With a world’s worth of inspiration at a writer’s fingertips, real creativity often comes from constraints. That’s true at least for the musician Robin Pecknold, best known as the principal songwriter for Fleet Foxes, the pop-folk band that got a Grammy nomination and a top-five debut with its last album, “Helplessness Blues,” in 2012. “Too much freedom can be creatively paralyzing,” Pecknold says. He’s currently preparing for his musical return: the score for the off-Broadway play “Wyoming,” which he co-composed with Neal Morgan, who has been the drummer for Joanna Newsom and Bill Callahan. “With the score, I had the ability to play with genre without worrying about appropriation,” Pecknold says. “There is less of the self in it, compared to writing an album.”

headline: Cleaning Up the Mac’s Printers List
abstract: Tidying lists after a printer upgrade, and how to excise recently watched movies from Netflix’s list.
lead_paragraph: Q. I recently got a new printer for my Mac, but I still see my previous printer (which I got rid of) listed in the options when I go to print. How do I get the old model out of the list?

headline: Superyachts to the Rescue
abstract: In a remarkable economic comeback, La Ciotat has become Europe’s largest yacht-maintenance and refitting seaport.
lead_paragraph: LA CIOTAT, France — After scuba divers checked the supporting mounts, a massive submerged boat elevator slowly raised the 661-ton, 51-meter-long yacht M/Y Sky clear of the Mediterranean, gradually revealing its black matte hull.

headline: Photos: A Game of Juxtaposition
abstract: Using a Nikon 35-mm film camera, Cooper Neill created these double exposures at Monday night’s national championship college football game in Arlington, Tex.
lead_paragraph: Covering an event like college football’s national championship game is an exciting and challenging assignment. For the game Monday night between Ohio State and Oregon in Arlington, Tex., the wire services positioned photographers at all corners of the field and on the catwalks, and editors worked on-site and used card runners to make sure photos were promptly uploaded.

headline: At Hunts Point Market, Awaiting Word on Strike as Talks Continue
abstract: The union that represents over 1,200 workers at the produce market in the Bronx agreed to a federal mediator’s request to delay a potential work stoppage.
lead_paragraph: Metal barricades stood next to the entrance to the Hunts Point Terminal Produce Market in the Bronx on Friday, ready to be lined up if the more than 1,200 warehouse workers and drivers employed at the market went on strike.

headline: Hearing Set For Loretta Lynch, Attorney General Nominee
Dinner Is Also a Sport
abstract: “A Beautiful Day in November on the Banks of the Greatest of the Great Lakes,” a comedy by Kate Benson, transforms a Thanksgiving dinner into a competitive sport.
lead_paragraph: The holidays and all the fraught togetherness they can bring are now in the rearview mirror. But if you’re still smarting over that unkind word from a brother-in-law, or a passive-aggressive takedown from Mom or Dad, some solace may be found by attending a performance of “A Beautiful Day in November on the Banks of the Greatest of the Great Lakes,” a quirky comedy by Kate Benson that cleverly transforms an extended family’s Thanksgiving dinner into a fiercely fought competitive sport.

headline: Shaking the Rafters With the Thundering Chords of a Monumental Requiem
abstract: The New York Philharmonic, led by Alan Gilbert, performed Verdi’s powerful Requiem with the New York Choral Artists and a quartet of soloists.
lead_paragraph: Critics of Avery Fisher Hall and its acoustics usually agree that it is too big. But on Thursday evening, during the galvanic Dies Irae (Day of Wrath) in the New York Philharmonic’s performance of Verdi’s Requiem, it suddenly felt as if the hall were too small to contain such an explosion of sound. As the massed forces of the excellent New York Choral Artists invoked the Day of Judgment, shrieking piccolos pierced through the orchestral texture, and ear-shattering offbeats on the bass drum answered thundering orchestra chords. Trumpeters had been stationed on both sides of the second balcony, and the metallic bite of their salvos seemed to cut into the listener from all directions.

headline: Where Dvorak Puts Fleet Fingers to the Ultimate Test
abstract: The Orchestra of St. Luke’s program at Carnegie Hall included Dvorak’s difficult Piano Concerto in G minor.
lead_paragraph: When musicians describe a work as awkward to play, they are referring to the finger gymnastics necessary to render a particular passage smoothly, one that may sound simple and straightforward to the listener. That category includes Dvorak’s Piano Concerto in G minor, which the British pianist Stephen Hough has described as “a concerto for 10 thumbs,” alluding to the composer’s unidiomatic writing.

headline: A Deal From the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional
abstract: The main pair event was won by Alan Lechner and Elliot Sternlicht of New York City.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 27, the second day of the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan, the main pair event was won by Alan Lechner and Elliot Sternlicht of New York City. They were just over one board ahead of Cynthia Colin and Jeff Hand of New York City, with Beverly Perry of New York City and Ron Smith of Las Vegas third.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage Decision to Put Spotlight on Republicans
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: A Supreme Court ruling that recognizes a right to same-sex marriage in all 50 states would reverberate quickly through a Republican presidential field whose leading figures have not yet embraced such change and, in a few cases, have actively fought it.
lead_paragraph: A Supreme Court ruling recognizing a right to same-sex marriage in all 50 states would reverberate quickly through a Republican presidential field whose leading figures have not yet embraced such change and, in a few cases, have actively fought it.

headline: Love Here, Drugs There, Music and a Death
abstract: Lifetime’s movie “Whitney” cherry-picks incidents from Whitney Houston’s short life and presents Bobby Brown, her husband, as the sometimes heroic voice of reason.
lead_paragraph: We need a new term to describe the sort of history on offer in “Whitney,” the Whitney Houston biopic that airs Saturday on Lifetime. “Revisionist history” doesn’t quite capture it; that implies a cogently argued counternarrative, with some kind of ideological motivation. And “selective history” isn’t quite right either; that implies a narrative arc sandpapered down to cohesion in service of one idea about a person.

headline: After the Warmest Year on Record, West Virginia Feels the Heat
abstract: A member of the Board of Education tried (and at first succeeded in) altering new teaching standards to reflect his doubts about climate change.
lead_paragraph: Friday’s news that 2014 was the Earth’s hottest year on record could not have been timelier for West Virginia, where a dissident member of the Board of Education recently altered new teaching standards to reflect his personal doubts about climate change.

headline: Branching Out, but Never Far From Its Roots
abstract: Alison Chase, a founder of Pilobolus and Momix, presented four pieces in her company’s New York debut at the Miller Theater.
lead_paragraph: Pilobolus, the mix of acrobatics, dance and dreamlike theater that became famous under the name of a fungus, first germinated in a 1970s Dartmouth College dance class taught by Alison Chase. Ms. Chase joined the troupe, and though, in 1980, she helped found the offshoot Momix, she stuck with Pilobolus until an acrimonious parting in 2005. Four years later, she started another company, Alison Chase/Performance, and at the Miller Theater this weekend, this latest venture had its New York debut.

headline: The Perils of Odette, Retold in Brooklyn
abstract: The Mariinsky Ballet presented “Swan Lake” to open its two-week season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: How can a production as visually beautiful and stylish as the Mariinsky Ballet’s “Swan Lake” be so unmoving? The exquisitely medieval look of this staging, which this St. Petersburg company presented on Thursday to open its two-week season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is marvelously right, and other balletic felicities abound. But four central problems remain.

headline: The Supreme Court and Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Editorials']
abstract: It’s time to end the debate on same-sex marriage, once and for all.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in three terms, the Supreme Court has agreed to consider the constitutionality of same-sex marriage. The last time around, the justices declined to take up the broad question. This time, there is every reason for them to follow the logic of their own rulings over the past 12 years and end the debate once and for all.

keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The documentary “Our Terrible Country,” filmed amid Syria’s civil war, follows a dissident, disillusioned, into exile.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In the early scenes of the Syrian documentary “Our Terrible Country,” the leftist writer Yassin al-Haj Saleh explores the ruins of a rebellious Damascus suburb, his clean-shaven face, Lenin-style cap and pristine clothes marking him as a recent arrival from the mostly intact government-controlled downtown.

headline: Ex-Employees Accuse Health Firm of Fraud
abstract: Two former executives of NantHealth said that the company made fraudulent claims about the reliability of its system, and may have used company donations to attract federal funds so a hospital could buy its products.
lead_paragraph: Two former executives of the health technology firm NantHealth said in a lawsuit filed this week that the company made fraudulent claims about the reliability of its system, which links patient information gathered by different medical devices and pieces of hospital equipment.

headline: At the Super Bowl of Linguistics, May the Best Word Win
abstract: A dispatch from the place where the nation’s most well-regarded grammarians, etymologists and language enthusiasts gather to talk shop.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — “It is a solemn and important duty we have,” Allan Metcalf, a grandfatherly looking man, said into a microphone. He was standing in front of a crowd of the nation’s top linguists, many of whom were still flooding into the already packed room. The space was tight, Mr. Metcalf apologized, but the linguists had only an hour. They had to get started.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Stripes of all Sizes
abstract: Patterns and colors, particularly of the Native American variety, were an uplifting sight during the post-holiday slump.
lead_paragraph: Patterns and colors, particularly of the Native American variety, were an uplifting sight during the post-holiday slump. For example, the chevron-stripe coat on a woman crossing the street mimicked the stripes on the Louis Vuitton store. No one is predicting that these colorful coats will replace New York’s beloved all-black look, but they lift the spirits on a cold winter day. One artist took a novel approach to dressing warm and turned a Depression-era rug into a coat.

headline: The Dark Side of ‘Broken Windows’ Policing
abstract: If Police Commissioner William J. Bratton believes that the practice of “broken windows” policing is indispensable to keeping New York City safe — and perhaps it is — then he must retool and reframe it.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, New Yorkers have been watching a family drama unfold among an angry patriarch, the mayor, Bill de Blasio; his petulant charges in the Police Department, apparently as huffy as 12-year-olds told to stop texting; and a mother, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton, who, like mothers everywhere hoping to get Daddy to understand and the children to listen, has been trying to broker peace.

abstract: At Pitti Uomo, the designer Shayne Oliver fails to impress, but “Cloakroom” — a presentation by Olivier Saillard and featuring Tilda Swinton — was as compelling as it was strange.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Italy — Boredom, as Renata Adler once wrote, implies duration. By that standard, virtually every performance-art piece ever staged is inherently a bore. How not to think about tonight’s dinner, the dry cleaning, that overdue email response while spending seemingly interminable moments waiting for, oh, let’s say, the Hood by Air show to commence?

headline: Not Just Fried, but Double Fried
abstract: True to its name, Roosterspin, in Westfield, blends a Korean chicken dish with old rock music and jazz.
lead_paragraph: Because of Roosterspin, my most significant memory of the 2014 holiday season will be about chicken. Between our visits to the restaurant, strategically located next to the Westfield train station, all I could think about was its delicious double-fried signature dish. It didn’t matter whether I was spending time with family or enjoying a getaway in Cape May, all I wanted to do was eat that chicken one more time.

headline: The Thwock of Ball Against Wall

headline: In the Bronx, Paddle Ball All (Thwock!) Winter Long
abstract: Zerega Indoor Paddleball Courts in the Bronx has many veterans of the sport, but the new owners have attracted more young people by opening additional space to handball.
lead_paragraph: You can hear the chaotic soundtrack of Zerega even before you enter the building: the ping and thwock of rubber balls hitting cement walls, the distinctive squeak of sneakers stopping short on painted floors, and the ohhhhhhs that accompany the echo of a particularly good shot.

headline: Slippery Tips on Annuities From a Life Coach
abstract: Tony Robbins’s best-selling new book speaks highly of a certain type of annuity, but there may be less there than meets the eye.
lead_paragraph: By Page 418 of Tony Robbins’s new book “Money: Master the Game,” which promises on the cover that its seven steps to financial freedom will be “simple,” I was sort of ready to put it down.

headline: Obama Orders Panel to Study Police Equipment
keywords: ['Police', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: President Obama on Friday ordered the creation of a new federal working group to recommend tighter standards on providing military-style equipment to local police departments.
lead_paragraph: President Obama on Friday ordered the creation of a new federal working group to recommend tighter standards on providing military-style equipment to local police departments. The order was part of Mr. Obama’s response to racial unrest in Ferguson, Mo., that followed the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer, and the heavily militarized posture police used in the days afterward to confront riots and protests over the killing. In an executive order, Mr. Obama said the group would be jointly led by the secretary of defense, the attorney general and the secretary of homeland security. It is tasked with ensuring that law enforcement agencies that acquire the equipment — including firearms and tactical vehicles — are properly trained to use it, and that they comply with civil rights requirements.

headline: Caning of Saudi Blogger Is Delayed Amid Protests
keywords: ['Corporal Punishment', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Saudi Arabia delayed a second round of caning against a writer jailed for criticizing the religious establishment after a video of the first round appeared online and drew international condemnation.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A lawyer in Saudi Arabia who founded a human rights group was sentenced to 15 years in prison. His wife, a women’s advocate who won a courage award from the State Department, says she is barred from leaving the country. Her brother, a writer who ran a liberal online forum, is also in jail and was sentenced to be caned regularly in a public square over the next few months.

headline: The Other Pipeline You Should Worry About
abstract: In all the talk about Keystone XL, we’re overlooking Line 61.
lead_paragraph: WHILE the ire of environmental activists remains fixed on the Keystone XL pipeline, a potentially greater threat looms in the proposed expansion of Line 61, a pipeline running the length of Wisconsin carrying tar sands crude. The pipeline is owned by Enbridge, a $40 billion Canadian company, which has been responsible for several hundred spills in the past decade, including one in 2010 near Marshall, Mich., reportedly the largest and most expensive inland oil spill in American history.

headline: Shared Greatness
abstract: The talent of exceptional players rubs off on those around them: teammates and opponents.
lead_paragraph: Exploding sliders. Time-stopping change-ups. Three-thousand-hit machines. We expect to embrace such superlatives with any baseball Hall of Fame induction class, and 2015 was no different.

headline: Failures in Screening Rikers Jail Guards
keywords: ['Guards', 'Editorials', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers']
abstract: A new report underscores that the lawlessness at the jail complex cannot be fixed unless it reforms the selection of the guards who run the place.
lead_paragraph: New York’s notoriously corrupt and violent Rikers Island jail complex got that way after city officials let the correction officers’ union run the complex as it saw fit. The result was a system in which guards could beat up inmates for minor offenses, like talking back, without fear of being held accountable.

headline: Travel to Cuba Eases, but Airlines Will Miss Initial Rush
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The United States has relaxed some restrictions on going there, but letting carriers set up regular flights is another matter.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration this week lifted some travel and trade restrictions on Americans traveling to Cuba, but commercial airlines will not be flocking to Havana for at least another year, experts say.

headline: Forty Acres and a Mule
abstract: The origins, and failure, of Gen. William T. Sherman’s plan to resettle freed slaves.
lead_paragraph: In a Jan. 15, 1865 letter from Savannah, Maj. Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman reported to his wife, Ellen, that Secretary of War Edwin M. Stanton “has been here and is cured of that Negro nonsense” – namely, Stanton’s insistence that black regiments be included in his army, an idea Sherman steadfastly opposed. But if Sherman won that particular fight, he knew he faced a much larger challenge: his treatment of blacks during his triumphant campaign through Georgia.

headline: Pressed by Budget Squeeze, Gov. Sam Brownback of Kansas Pulls Back on Tax Cuts
keywords: ['Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Income Tax', 'Governors (US)', 'Taxation', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: The governor of Kansas, a supporter of shrinking government, on Friday proposed some higher sales taxes and slowing his plan to reduce state income taxes.
lead_paragraph: TOPEKA, Kan. — Gov. Sam Brownback, who made cutting taxes and shrinking government the centerpieces of his government, proposed on Friday to close a huge projected shortfall in the state budget by increasing some sales taxes and sharply slowing his plan to gradually reduce the state income tax.

headline: Jury Selection for Tsarnaev Trial in Boston Sees Emotions Come to Fore
abstract: The judge in the trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, accused in the Boston Marathon bombing case, has questioned prospective jurors, looking for bias.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — It was the first time during jury selection for the Boston Marathon bombing trial that someone had become emotional under questioning by the judge, but it was a sharp reminder of the loss that is at the heart of the case.

headline: Creating a Cozy Home for Her Children
abstract: A mother acquires much-needed furnishings with the help of the Neediest Cases Fund.
lead_paragraph: From the time she was 3 years old until she turned 21, Krystle Jackson lived in 13 different foster homes. So she was distraught when her own young children, Kayla and Isaiah, landed in foster care in 2012 when her daughter was seriously hurt while Ms. Jackson was at a job-training class. She fought hard to get her children back, working with New Alternatives for Children’s foster care program to meet the necessary requirements. She attended parenting class, kept appointments with the children twice a week and participated in therapy. In early 2014, she was reunited with Kayla and Isaiah.

headline: Car Market Shows Signs of Revival for Europe
abstract: Consumers replaced worn-out models and analysts said they expected a modest upward trend again this year.
lead_paragraph: The European auto market grew last year for the first time since before the global financial crisis began, industry data showed on Friday, as consumers replaced worn-out models and analysts said they expected a modest upward trend again this year. New passenger car registrations, a proxy for sales, rose 5.7 percent in the European Union last year, reaching about 12.6 million vehicles, the European Automobile Manufacturer’s Association reported from Brussels. It was the first annual expansion since 2007, when the market peaked at nearly 16 million new passenger cars. Spain led the major national markets in 2014, with government trade-in incentives helping to lift sales by more than 18 percent. Germany, Europe’s largest auto market, grew 2.9 percent. Still, the industry is not out of danger. The stagnant economy in most of Europe, as well as crushing unemployment in countries like Greece and Spain, will continue to weigh on the market. LMC Automotive, a market research firm, estimates that European sales will gain just 1.1 percent in 2015. Carlos Da Silva, who follows Europe’s car market at IHS Automotive, said in a research note that the 2014 recovery was welcome news, but that Europe was not yet “a fully cured patient.”

headline: Couple Ending a 3-Decade Journey in Travel Book Sales
abstract: The Complete Traveller Antiquarian Bookstore in Manhattan, after weathering intense competition and readers’ shift to online travel resources, will shut down Monday.
lead_paragraph: There is no villain in this story.

headline: A Nurse Decides to Get Hands-On in the Ebola Zone
keywords: ['Ebola Virus', 'Nursing and Nurses', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Epidemics', 'Emergency Medical Treatment']
abstract: While most accounts of American health workers have focused on the ones returning, Lindsey Hallen, an emergency room nurse in Manhattan, is heading to West Africa to fight an epidemic that has killed more than 8,000 people.
lead_paragraph: Lindsey Hallen is in the bug spray aisle at REI, the outdoor equipment emporium in SoHo, looking for exactly the right mosquito repellent to take to West Africa’s Ebola zone, when her phone rings. Three ascending tones, the personal anthem of an emergency room nurse, captured in a ringtone called “Summit.”

His parents were both master tailors, and he spent his first years wandering the floors of their shop in Harlem. He always loved the machines, he said, and one day, when his mother was away, he climbed up on one.

headline: Nigeria: 2 Regions Report New Outbreaks of Bird Flu
abstract: The health and veterinary authorities on Friday reported outbreaks of avian flu hundreds of miles apart on opposite ends of Nigeria.
lead_paragraph: The health and veterinary authorities on Friday reported outbreaks of avian flu hundreds of miles apart on opposite ends of Nigeria. In Lagos, the southern commercial center, 3,300 birds at a live bird market showing symptoms were culled, said Nigeria’s chief veterinary officer, Dr. Abdulganiyu Abubakar, in a report to the World Organization for Animal Health, an agency that tracks disease outbreaks. In Kano State, in northern Nigeria, an unspecified number of birds showing a high mortality rate were culled from a poultry farm. In both cases, blood samples tested positive for an H5 strain of avian influenza, officials quoted by Nigerian news media said. It was not immediately clear whether the birds were afflicted with H5N1, which is highly pathogenic and can infect humans. H5N1 first spread from Asia to Europe and Africa in the late 1990s and is a recurrent problem in domesticated bird populations. Nigeria was the first country in Africa to report H5N1 in poultry, in 2006, according to the World Health Organization.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (CUNY) ARMY OF CRIME (2009) The Armenian poet Missak Manouchian (Simon Abkarian) leads a heroic ragtag group of anti-Fascist partisans to sabotage the Nazi regime in occupied Paris in this biopic, directed by Robert Guédiguian, a Marseille-based filmmaker of German and Armenian parentage. Virginie Ledoyen portrays Missak’s beautiful, adoring French wife, Mélinée; Jean-Pierre Darroussin is a double-dealing inspector in the neighborhood where the Resistance is centered. “Was it all for naught?” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “Only weeks after the 23 partisans were arrested (and all but two promptly executed), Paris was liberated. ‘Army of Crime’ is a passionate act of remembrance.”

headline: Green-Energy Inspiration Off the Coast of Denmark
keywords: ['Islands', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Wind Power', 'Solar Energy', 'Geothermal Power']
abstract: Residents of islands off Maine’s coast seek to draw on the experiences of the Danish island Samso in an effort to explore alternative sources of light and heat.
lead_paragraph: Before dawn one morning in October, a handful of Americans gathered at a lonely pier on Samso, a small Danish island about four hours from Copenhagen. Bundled in layers of fleece and wool, the Americans, mostly from islands off the Maine coast, had come to get a closer look at a wind farm — 10 mighty turbines spinning in the Kattegat strait — that has helped make Samso a symbol for a greener future, one powered entirely by renewable energy.

abstract: Saïd Kouachi, one of the gunmen who killed 12 people at the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, was buried in Reims, a city in northeastern France, the mayor said.

headline: Before a Show, a Fireside Meal at the Black Mountain Wine House
abstract: On a recent chilly night, three women stopped by the Black Mountain Wine House in Brooklyn before the theater.
lead_paragraph: Around this time of year, when the holidays are over and the nighttime temperature descends to nostril-numbing levels, many heat-seeking residents of Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, spend their evenings at the Black Mountain Wine House at 415 Union Street. The quiet saloon, just blocks from busy Smith Street, exudes a rustic warmth: A fireplace crackles in the corner; agricultural bric-a-brac hangs from the walls. The only thing to dispel the impression that you’ve just walked into a farmhouse in Vermont is the aproned chef slicing and sautéing in the open-window kitchen. On Tuesday nights, Black Mountain offers a fondue special ($16), increasing its cold-weather allure, and this past Tuesday, in the after-work chill, the place was full of whispering couples, book-reading singles and three women: a mother, her daughter and her daughter-in-law, taking in a meal before the theater.

headline: An Open Office (No Names)
abstract: Memo is an app that wants to elevate water-cooler talk so that the good ideas and criticism of company practices are accessible to everyone in the company. It is an anonymous message board within specific workplaces.
lead_paragraph: Ryan Janssen, the founder of a new app called Memo, comes across as an idealist. He maintains that the state of the American professional classes is one of constant repression and hierarchical miscommunication. Or in less dramatic terms: People are scared to be themselves at work, and to tell their managers what they think about their companies.
