keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Children and Childhood', 'Equal Educational Opportunities', 'Education (Pre-School)', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Researchers have found that something as small as text message reminders can help children born into poor families close the gap with richer students.
lead_paragraph: There are enormous inequalities in education in the United States. A child born into a poor family has only a 9 percent chance of getting a college degree, but the odds are 54 percent for a child in a high-income family. These gaps open early, with poor children less prepared than their kindergarten classmates.

headline: This Cast Works Without a Script
abstract: Haven’t we already seen ride-along shows set in Louisiana?
lead_paragraph: Haven’t we already seen ride-along shows set in Louisiana? Yes, we have. So what’s different about “Nightwatch,” which begins Thursday on A&E and follows police, firefighters and ambulance workers on the overnight shift in New Orleans?

headline: Variety: A Restful Diagramless Puzzle
abstract: Fred Piscop provides a relaxing diagramless puzzle.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — One of the advantages of this job is having the answers at your disposal if they are absolutely needed. I normally don’t peek, but one of my weaknesses is remembering names. Today, one name in particular gave me trouble. I got hung up on Franz LEHAR as the composer of “The Merry Widow.”

headline: What’s So Bad About Cheap Oil?
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Shale', 'Gross National Product (GNP)']
abstract: The stock market is treating lower prices as bad news even though they will help consumers, many of the nation’s businesses and the economy.
lead_paragraph: The sharp drop in oil prices will benefit American consumers, many of the nation’s businesses and the economy as a whole. So why are stock market investors behaving as though oil under $50 a barrel and gasoline prices hovering around $2 a gallon are bad news?

headline: The Patio Furniture That Nobody Wanted
keywords: ['E-Commerce', 'Customer Relations', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A man who bought a lamp from an online furniture store got more than he bargained for, or ordered.
lead_paragraph: Let’s start with an update from our last episode, which you may recall concerned a battle between a monk and United Airlines. The confrontation between a tranquillity-seeking man and an immovable corporation proved irresistible to websites like Yahoo News, Gawker and Boing Boing, to name a few. And a reporter from a local TV station was dispatched to the Monastery of Christ in the Desert, in Abiquiu, N.M., where the monk, Brother Noah, was asked to repeat his not very hostile kiss-off to an unyielding United phone rep: “Thank you for speaking. God bless you. I will pray for you. But you have not been helpful.”

headline: Charlie Hebdo Attackers’ Path to Radicalization
abstract: Key moments in the lives of Chérif and Saïd Kouachi, based on accounts from thousands of pages of legal documents obtained by The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Key moments in the lives of Chérif and Saïd Kouachi, based on accounts from thousands of pages of legal documents obtained by The New York Times.

headline: From Amateur to Ruthless Jihadist in France
abstract: Documents reveal how Chérif Kouachi became a professional jihadist virtually under the noses of the French authorities and, with his brother, Saïd, carried out the attack on Charlie Hebdo.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In the year after the United States’ invasion of Iraq, a 22-year-old pizza delivery man here couldn’t take it anymore. Sickened by images of American soldiers humiliating Muslims at the Abu Ghraib prison, he made plans to go fight United States forces. He studied a virtual AK-47 on a website. Then he took lessons from a man, using a hand-drawn picture of a gun.

headline: Jil Sander: Fall 2015 Menswear
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Morocco Crushed Dissent Using a U.S. Interrogation Site, Rights Advocates Say
keywords: ['Torture', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Detainees', 'Extraordinary Rendition']
abstract: The authorities in Morocco denied allegations that they used the war against terrorism and harsh C.I.A. tactics as a cover to torture those who spoke out against them.
lead_paragraph: RABAT, Morocco — After landing at the Rabat airport in 2010, Zakaria Moumni, a former kickboxing world champion, was distressed when he was taken aside by security agents, arrested, blindfolded and taken on a ride under a blanket in the back seat of a car to a secret facility. He says he was held there for four days, during which he was deprived of food and water.

headline: Houthi Rebels Abduct Aide to Yemen’s President
abstract: Shiite Houthi rebels abducted the office director for Yemen’s president on Saturday in the capital in an effort to disrupt a meeting on a new constitution, which includes provisions to which the Houthis have strongly objected.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — Gunmen abducted a senior aide to Yemen’s president early Saturday, highlighting the frailty of the central government and the growing sense of lawlessness as Yemen suffers its most severe political crisis in years.

headline: Lower Oil Prices Provide Benefits to U.S. Workers
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'United States Economy', 'Heating', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Consumer Behavior']
abstract: Wall Street may be growing anxious about the negative impact of falling oil prices on energy producers, but the steep declines of recent weeks are delivering substantial benefits to American working-class families.
lead_paragraph: LEWISTON, Me. — Wall Street may be growing anxious about the negative impact of falling oil prices on energy producers, but the steep declines of recent weeks are delivering substantial benefits to American working-class families and retirees who have largely missed out on the fruits of the five-and-a-half-year economic recovery.

headline: Republicans Like Their 2016 Options, Assuming They Avoid Chaos
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: With so many appearing ready to enter the presidential fray, the party has already moved to streamline the nominating process, for example limiting the number of primary debates.
lead_paragraph: CORONADO, Calif. — At the end of the last Democratic presidential administration, Republicans hungry to recapture the White House rallied behind an all-but-anointed candidate to take on Bill Clinton’s heir apparent of that era.

headline: A Shakespearean Drama With Two Raging Heroes
abstract: To follow the Cavaliers as they clashed with the Clippers and the Lakers in the past week was to observe a near perfect cosmology of talent, ego and insecurity, rumor and anxiety.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — To go wheels down at LAX and travel the practice and game circuit with the Cleveland Cavaliers as they clashed with the Clippers and the Lakers in the past week was to observe a near perfect cosmology of talent, ego and insecurity, rumor and anxiety.

headline: Juan Martín del Potro Decides Wrist Isn’t Ready for Australian Open
abstract: Del Potro, out of action for nearly a year, announced his withdrawal from the Australian Open, saying his two-handed backhand continued to cause him pain and concern.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Out of action for nearly a year because of a wrist injury, Juan Martín del Potro will remain out of action for the Australian Open, too.

headline: By Many Measures, It’s a Quarterbacks’ League
abstract: Rules changes to protect quarterbacks and receivers have resulted in a further explosion in passing offense.
lead_paragraph: Rules changes to protect quarterbacks and receivers have resulted in a further explosion in passing offense.

headline: Restroom Ordinance Is Just One More Sign of a City’s Acceptance
keywords: ['Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Law and Legislation', 'Signs and Signage']
abstract: An ordinance has abolished the traditional designation of “Men” and “Women” on single-stall public restrooms, a bow to the requests of the sizable community of transgender people.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — This city was one of the first in the nation to pass a same-sex marriage law. It was one of the first communities viewed as a haven for gay people: When the city was incorporated in 1984, a majority of the City Council members were openly gay, helping earn West Hollywood the nickname the “Gay Camelot.” Even today, it has rainbow-colored crosswalks.

headline: Better Check the Beds, Edwardians
abstract: Everything you wanted to know about sex at “Downton Abbey” but were afraid to ask.
lead_paragraph: I was fascinated by “The Manners of Downton Abbey,” a special about Edwardian-era etiquette for highborn families that aired on PBS early this month.

headline: A Young Woman Tries Hard to Be the Kind of Mother That She Never Had
abstract: For Masicqua Andrews, talk of family does not conjure warm feelings. She wants to reverse that for her own son.
lead_paragraph: Masicqua Andrews scoffs at the mention of family, summoning a guttural sound to match the disdain and neglect she said her relatives had long shown her.

headline: Kristin Muhlner of NewBrand Analytics: The Upside of Being Replaceable
abstract: The chief executive of a social-media-monitoring company discusses how she learned not to need to be involved in everything.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Kristin Muhlner, chief executive of NewBrand Analytics, a social-media-monitoring company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: As Rules Protect Quarterbacks, N.F.L. Defenses Are on the Defensive
abstract: Through rules changes, stricter enforcement, and player fines and suspensions, the N.F.L. in recent years has sought to remove the most extreme violence from an inherently violent sport.
lead_paragraph: As Tony Romo, the Dallas Cowboys’ quarterback, dropped back to pass last Sunday in an N.F.L. playoff game, the Green Bay Packers’ Clay Matthews dashed past an offensive lineman and into the backfield.

headline: Belgium Deploys Troops After Foiling Possible Plot
abstract: Beefing up security around Jewish sites, embassies and other potential terrorist targets, Belgium deployed scores of heavily armed paratroopers on Saturday in Brussels and Antwerp.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Tightening security around Jewish sites, embassies and other potential terrorist targets, Belgium deployed scores of heavily armed paratroopers on Saturday in Brussels, the capital, and in the port city of Antwerp, a diamond-trading center with a large Orthodox Jewish population.

headline: Redefining Mental Illness
abstract: New research recognizes that diagnoses and drugs are not the only approach.
lead_paragraph: TWO months ago, the British Psychological Society released a remarkable document entitled “Understanding Psychosis and Schizophrenia.” Its authors say that hearing voices and feeling paranoid are common experiences, and are often a reaction to trauma, abuse or deprivation: “Calling them symptoms of mental illness, psychosis or schizophrenia is only one way of thinking about them, with advantages and disadvantages.”

headline: Howard S. Becker
abstract: The sociologist on jazz, push-ups and Charlie Hebdo.
lead_paragraph: Howard S. Becker is a sociologist known as much for his dry wit as for his groundbreaking work examining deviancy, art and music. His most recent book is “What About Mozart? What About Murder?”

headline: Not Just a Movie
abstract: The truth of the strategizing on civil rights between President Johnson and Dr. King was dramatic enough. Why twist it?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — I WENT Friday morning to see “Selma” and found myself watching it in a theater full of black teenagers.

headline: The Dangerous Erosion of Taxation
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Editorials', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Tax Evasion']
abstract: The new Congress is likely to deliver more hits to the Internal Revenue Service, a victim of the penny-wise and pound-foolish.
lead_paragraph: The obsession among House conservatives to hobble the Internal Revenue Service is about to pay off this tax season in foolhardy budget cuts to the agency that will cost the government an estimated $2 billion in lost revenue.

headline: How Mexicans Became Americans
abstract: Immigrants are now seeing California as home.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH GATE, Calif. — A FEW weeks ago, the City Council in this suburb southeast of Los Angeles appointed a Mexican immigrant to its advisory council. Jesus Miranda is from Michoacán and owns a taco restaurant here. He’ll advise the council on housing development and other issues.

headline: In Nigeria, the Terror Continues
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Fighting Boko Haram effectively requires a government willing and able to take on the security challenge.
lead_paragraph: They commanded global attention for a fleeting few days last spring. Across the world, millions prayed for and tweeted about the plight of the more than 200 Nigerian schoolgirls abducted in northeastern Nigeria by the vicious militant group Boko Haram. The first lady, Michelle Obama, joined the cause, posting a selfie looking downcast and demanding that the militants “#BringBackOurGirls.” The United States government hastily put together a task force of experts and dispatched drones to search for the hostages.

headline: Mark Wahlberg, Penance and Pardons
abstract: The actor wants his criminal record wiped clean. But what kind of message would that send?
lead_paragraph: EVERY time I read about the actor Mark Wahlberg’s bid to be pardoned by the state of Massachusetts for crimes he committed in his youth, I flash back to the days I spent with him for a Times magazine profile just before “Boogie Nights” came out. I remember a specific detail.

headline: Perpetuating Guantánamo’s Travesty
abstract: It is long past time to prosecute suspected terrorists in courtrooms and shut down a prison that has deservedly brought America international scorn.
lead_paragraph: Standing before the press last Tuesday on Capitol Hill, Senator Kelly Ayotte, Republican of New Hampshire, argued that this is no time to be releasing detainees from the military prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. Opportunistically, she cited the recent massacre in Paris and deteriorating security in Yemen, which she oddly described as “the wild, wild West for terrorists.” She warned that American officials suspect or know that roughly 30 percent of the men released from Guantánamo have returned to the fight.

headline: Your Annual Checkup
abstract: Doctors and patients debate an assertion that the yearly exam is “basically worthless.”
lead_paragraph: Doctors and patients debate an assertion that the yearly exam is “basically worthless.”

headline: Smart Guns Save Lives. So Where Are They?
abstract: We protect our cellphones with a PIN or a fingerprint, so why not do the same with firearms?
lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo. — JUST after Christmas, Veronica Rutledge of Blackfoot, Idaho, took her 2-year-old son to a Walmart store to spend holiday gift cards. As they strolled by the electronics section, according to news reports, the toddler reached into his mom’s purse and pulled out a handgun that she legally carried. He pulled the trigger once and killed her.

headline: Packing Heat at the Airport? Oops
abstract: With concealed-carry weapons permits becoming more common, travelers seem to forget they have firearms in their bags.
lead_paragraph: WHO hasn’t smacked their forehead at an airport security checkpoint because someone ahead in line had packed more than 3.4 ounces of shampoo or forgotten to take a laptop out of its case? Did they miss the big screaming signs?

headline: Mean Girls in the Retirement Home
abstract: I couldn’t believe people were shunning my 99-year-old Nanna.
lead_paragraph: ABOUT 18 months ago, my 97-year-old grandmother went out to dinner with some friends. As Nanna got out of the car, she tripped over her friend Shirley’s cane, fell to the pavement and came down hard on her elbow. Back at home, she headed to the kitchen to get some dessert — “and my left leg just crumpled.”

headline: Mitt the Insurgent
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A third Romney run is a bad idea, but it’s hard to see what harm it can do.
lead_paragraph: THE idea of yet a third Mitt Romney campaign for the presidency, once the idle dream of a few Romney bundlers and now apparently something embraced by the Man From Bain Capital himself, has been greeted by most Republicans with a mixture of horror, exhaustion and embarrassment. The polite ones sound like a girl before the senior prom who can’t believe that the stumblebum date who ruined her last school dance is in line first to ask her again: No, please, not this time. The rest sound like the characters in the third act of a horror movie, confronting a shambling revenant that just keeps coming: How do we kill this thing?

headline: Is a Climate Disaster Inevitable?
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Extraterrestrial Life', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Planets']
abstract: What astrobiology can tell us about the fate of the planet.
lead_paragraph: OUR galaxy, the Milky Way, is home to almost 300 billion stars, and over the last decade, astronomers have made a startling discovery — almost all those stars have planets. The fact that nearly every pinprick of light you see in the night sky hosts a family of worlds raises a powerful but simple question: “Where is everybody?” Hundreds of billions of planets translate into a lot of chances for evolving intelligent, technologically sophisticated species. So why don’t we see evidence for E.T.s everywhere?

headline: After PTSD, More Trauma
abstract: I was a veteran who needed therapy. What I got was another kind of battle.
lead_paragraph: Going in for therapy at a Veterans Affairs hospital is a lot like arriving at a large airport in a foreign country. You pass through a maze of confusing signage. Your documents are scrutinized. There are long lines you must stand in and a series of bureaucratic rituals that must be endured before anything resembling a human encounter occurs.

headline: An Opulent Bet on Housing
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: Jeff Greene’s Beverly Hills estate, listed at $195 million, is believed to be the most expensive public listing in the country.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Greene became a billionaire during the recession by betting that people would default on their mortgages. Now, happily ensconced in a 35,000-square-foot estate in Palm Beach, Fla., Mr. Greene has a more optimistic outlook about real estate, at least when it comes to the very rich.

headline: Replacing a Colts Legend, and Not Missing a Beat
abstract: Andrew Luck was chosen by the Colts as the heir to Peyton Manning, and so far, he has exceeded expectations.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — The owner Jim Irsay laid the foundation for a new beginning for the Indianapolis Colts on April 26, 2012.

headline: Prospect of Peace: Talking With the FARC
abstract: Two members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia talk about their goals and their accountability in five decades of armed conflict.
lead_paragraph: Two members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia talk about their goals and their accountability in five decades of armed conflict.

headline: Spacious, Gracious and Priced in the Nine Figures
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: Jeff Greene made a fortune on mortgage defaults. Now he sells to the extra-superrich. HIs estate in Beverly Hills is listed for $195 million.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Greene made a fortune on mortgage defaults. Now he sells to the extra-superrich. HIs estate in Beverly Hills is listed for $195 million.

headline: The Men Who Haunted Me as a Child in Colombia
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons']
abstract: The FARC kidnapped thousands of people, and now here were two of its members sipping drinks in the hotel bar.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — A VARIATION of the scene has played out in sporadic nightmares I began having as a child. A band of guerrilla fighters with scraggly beards, dirty camouflage uniforms and rifles slung over their shoulders walk toward me. Their glares are callous, their words gruff. I watch as black rubber boots caked with mud advance toward me. It is too late. I am cornered, trapped.

headline: Even as a Player, Butler’s Unlikely Coach Did Things His Own Way
abstract: Chris Holtmann has shed the interim tag as coach of Butler and now has a multiyear contract as the Bulldogs have rebounded from last year’s losing season.
lead_paragraph: Chris Holtmann had played horribly. Here was a senior guard for Taylor University, a small N.A.I.A. school in Upland, Ind., and his team had won the game, but that was not enough. Holtmann’s performance was beneath his standards, with turnovers, poor shot selection and porous defense. Teammates and coaches chalked it up to an off night.

headline: Neil Barrett: Fall 2015 Menswear
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: In Charge, and Sounding the Part
abstract: The more powerful you are, the more your voice reflects it, research suggests.
lead_paragraph: Science has not proved the trope that power changes everything. But it does suggest, at least, that it changes the vocal cords.

headline: What We’re Watching: Sunday Shows
abstract: Heightened concerns of terrorism threats in Western Europe following the attacks in Paris will dominate conversation on the Sunday shows.
lead_paragraph: Following the attacks in Paris, the arrest of terrorism suspects across Western Europe this week highlighted the challenges in preventing threats from radical jihadists. Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, who met with President Obama at the White House this week to discuss how to bolster cybersecurity, will talk about the terrorism threat in Europe on CBS’s “Face the Nation.”

headline: Decoding the Paradox of Rising Cable Stocks
keywords: ['Net Neutrality', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Wireless Communications', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Why, despite President Obama’s moves toward greater regulation of Internet providers, cable companies’ share prices have continued to go up.
lead_paragraph: The stock market is often an early indicator of major developments in finance, the economy and geopolitics. But sometimes that collective wisdom generates signals so difficult to decipher that they seem contradictory.

headline: Savoring the Sweet Taste of Acceptance
keywords: ['Translation and Interpreters', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: A Soviet Jew bound for the United States finds a way to make the most of a temporary job as a translator in Italy.
lead_paragraph: “Supposte,” the doctor said.

headline: Vernon B. Mountcastle, Brain Explorer, Dies at 96
abstract: At the dawn of modern neuroscience, Dr. Mountcastle showed how cylinders of neurons, dedicated to specific tasks, work together to process perception.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Vernon B. Mountcastle, whose studies of how brain cells conspire to process perceptions and movement laid the foundations of modern neuroscience, died last Sunday at his home in Baltimore. He was 96.

headline: U.S. Lawmakers in Cuba for 3-Day Visit
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The delegation, led by Senator Patrick Leahy, will discuss with Cuban officials greater cooperation and remaining areas of disagreement. Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York is also planning a trip.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A delegation of American legislators led by Senator Patrick J. Leahy arrived in Cuba on Saturday to discuss greater cooperation and remaining areas of disagreement, the first congressional delegation to visit the island nation since President Obama announced last month that he was restoring full diplomatic ties with it.

headline: Unselfish Hawks Resemble Winners, Namely, the Spurs
abstract: Atlanta, with the best record in the Eastern Conference, has no superstars, but like San Antonio, the Hawks have skilled, smart players committed to making the game easier for one another.
lead_paragraph: Only two teams in the N.B.A. rank in the top six in both offense and defense. One is the Golden State Warriors (31-5 entering Friday), a talented team with seven players who were drafted with lottery picks. The other is the Atlanta Hawks, who have only three such players, and one is the 35-year-old Elton Brand. Still, the Hawks are the hottest team in the league; entering Saturday, they were 32-8, had won 25 of their last 27 games and led the Eastern Conference by five games.

headline: Phil Jackson Confidant Studies Historically Bad Teams, Like Knicks
abstract: Charley Rosen, who has known Phil Jackson for 40 years, recently published a book about the 1972-73 Philadelphia 76ers, who went 9-73.
lead_paragraph: Over 40 years, Phil Jackson and Charley Rosen have coached and written books together, played hundreds of games of one-on-one, and discussed basketball philosophy as if Descartes equaled Holzman.

headline: On Long Island, Restaurants Offer Super Bowl Takeout
abstract: Whatever a Super Bowl crowd craves — beer, wings, or barbecue — restaurants can have it wrapped and ready.
lead_paragraph: Standout game-day cuisine, whether traditional Buffalo chicken wings or buckets of meatballs and growlers of beer to go, is easy to come by if you plan a bit in advance. Rick Ritacco, a co-owner of Wings Plus in Port Washington, advises booking a week before the Super Bowl. “Everyone wants their food at 5 p.m., and those pickup times book up fast,” he said, adding that most people prefer to eat and imbibe in one another’s homes for the big game. “It’s all about the house parties because it’s more relaxing, more fun and more communal.”

headline: On Long Island, Bookstores and Libraries Expand Their Offerings
keywords: ['Libraries and Librarians', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: While the number of independent bookstores is dwindling in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, those that remain are thriving by finding other ways to remain relevant.
lead_paragraph: When Marty Schwartz and Melinda Nasti take a vacation, they make a point of finding live-music venues.

headline: Two Unsigned Aces Play a Waiting Game
abstract: Max Scherzer and James Shields are two high-profile free-agent pitchers who have not yet signed with a new club, even though pitchers and catchers are scheduled to report Feb. 19.
lead_paragraph: In terms of travel expenses, Max Scherzer and James Shields may have reached the point of costing themselves money. The two aces remain unsigned, and with pitchers and catchers scheduled to report to spring training on Feb. 19, they have missed the 54-day advance purchase that a study of four million flights by CheapAir.com found was necessary to maximize savings.

headline: In One Act, a Troubled Life Recounted
abstract: Dael Orlandersmith’s solo show, “Forever,” at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, tells the story of her broken upbringing.
lead_paragraph: Not all the music lovers recalling the first time they heard the Doors song “Light My Fire” bother to mention Ray Manzarek’s organ solo. Dael Orlandersmith does in the opening moments of “Forever,” her brave and heartfelt new solo show at the Long Wharf Theater. She describes the sound as “something otherworldly,” which is a particularly apt comment because she is standing beside Jim Morrison’s grave at the time.

headline: As Baseball Games Drag On, Timelessness Becomes Less Than Sacred
abstract: With major league games taking longer than ever, baseball is changing rules in the minors this season in an attempt to force players to speed things along.
lead_paragraph: Every five games during the baseball season, Jerry Howarth gets to travel back in time. Howarth settles in behind his microphone in the Toronto Blue Jays’ radio booth and watches Mark Buehrle move briskly through the innings, the way the old guys did.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in Sports.
lead_paragraph: Inching Upward Toward a Dream

headline: Already a Hub for the Arts, New Brunswick Enters Its Jazz Age
abstract: Showcases at Tumulty’s Pub, the Hyatt and Hotoke have become staples, as New Brunswick’s profile as a destination for jazz grows.
lead_paragraph: This month’s cold snap did not deter the drummer Rudy Royston, a fixture on the New York jazz scene, from making his way to New Brunswick, where on a particularly frigid Thursday night, he could be found burning up the bandstand at Hotoke, a restaurant and lounge on George Street.

headline: Bob Boyd, Who Battled a Basketball Giant, Dies at 84
abstract: As basketball coach at Southern California, Boyd had a 216-131 record, with 11 winning teams in 13 seasons, but he went 2-25 against John Wooden’s U.C.L.A. teams.
lead_paragraph: Bob Boyd coached the University of Southern California to more than 200 basketball victories and three Top 20 national rankings in the 1960s and ’70s. But he was a victim of unfortunate timing.

headline: A Leader in Socially Conscious Architecture Is Closing Amid Financial Woes
abstract: Architecture for Humanity, a nonprofit design group specializing in socially conscious construction, has abruptly closed its San Francisco headquarters and plans to file for bankruptcy protection.
lead_paragraph: Architecture for Humanity, a nonprofit design group that sought to repair the world with socially conscious construction in places like Kosovo, Haiti and hurricane-ravaged Mississippi, has abruptly closed its San Francisco headquarters and plans to file for Chapter 7 bankruptcy protection.

headline: Both Were Born Hamilton Fish, but Their Paths Differed
abstract: A film being shown soon in Albany and Carmel traces the history of a serial killer and a Westchester politician who died a day apart in 1936.
lead_paragraph: When Hillary Fontana entered the black-box theater at the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art in Peekskill last fall for a screening of the film “The Lives of Hamilton Fish,” which also included a performance by its director, it was with a low-grade sense of anxiety.

headline: Unfamiliar Territory
abstract: As a player and coach, Phil Jackson is used to his teams being well above .500. But now as an executive, his Knicks are exploring unimagined depths.
lead_paragraph: As a player and coach, Phil Jackson is used to his teams being well above .500. But now as an executive, his Knicks are exploring unimagined depths.

abstract: Christine C. Quinn made her first appearance in her new role at a news conference on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Christine C. Quinn, the former New York City Council speaker and mayoral candidate, is now a special adviser to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline: Odd Byproduct of Legal Marijuana: Homes That Blow Up
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Explosions (Accidental)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Cities are trying to clamp down as some amateur alchemists who turn their kitchens and basements into labs end up blowing up their homes while using flammable chemicals to extract potent drops of a marijuana concentrate.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — When Colorado legalized marijuana two years ago, nobody was quite ready for the problem of exploding houses.

headline: A Multiethnic Movement Emerges in Guyana to Counter Politics-as-Usual
abstract: A few years ago, a gathering of members of Guyana’s two main ethnic groups — descendants of African slaves and indentured laborers from India — would have been unusual, but a new third party has changed that dynamic.
lead_paragraph: GEORGETOWN, Guyana — Swaying to the rhythms of Afro-Guyanese reggae, the protesters, descendants of African slaves and indentured laborers from India, gathered on the streets of Georgetown in a show of unity against the country’s president.

headline: 54 Miles And 5 Cameras
abstract: The New-York Historical Society is about to present images of the civil rights march to Montgomery captured by someone who was actually there.
lead_paragraph: Even as the film “Selma” has recreated the civil rights march to Montgomery for moviegoers, the New-York Historical Society is about to present images of the event captured by someone who was actually there. The exhibition, “Freedom Journey 1965,” features photographs by Stephen Somerstein, who traveled to Alabama to document the march as a student in City College of New York’s night school, where he was picture editor of his student newspaper.

headline: For Indonesians, President’s Political Outsider Status Loses Its Luster
abstract: The Indonesian president’s appointments have cast doubt on his reputation as a man of the people and his promises of a squeaky-clean government.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — When the political outsider Joko Widodo was sworn in as president of Indonesia, promising “people-centric politics” and a common touch, supporters hoped for miracles while opponents confidently predicted he would be destroyed politically within a year.

headline: A Young Star And a Master
abstract: This winter the dazzling young Russian pianist Daniil Trifonov has been almost in residence in New York.
lead_paragraph: This winter the dazzling young Russian pianist Daniil Trifonov has been almost in residence in New York. Mr. Trifonov, who won both the Arthur Rubinstein Competition in Tel Aviv and the Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow in 2011, played an acclaimed solo recital at Carnegie Hall in December. He then appeared with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall, exciting audiences in Rachmaninoff’s First Piano Concerto.

headline: Everyone Here Is Part of the Act
abstract: Every live theater event convenes an impromptu community in which artist and audience create a shared experience.
lead_paragraph: Every live theater event convenes an impromptu community in which artist and audience create a shared experience. The choreographer Moriah Evans examines this in much of her work, including “Social Dance 1-8: Index,” a new piece commissioned by the Issue Project Room.

headline: Unearthing Fear and Mistrust
abstract: The unsettling work of the Swedish filmmaker Ruben Ostlund, whose 2014 movie “Force Majeure” was one the year’s most acclaimed films, has been described as “Michael Haneke lite.”
lead_paragraph: The unsettling work of the Swedish filmmaker Ruben Ostlund, whose 2014 movie “Force Majeure” was one the year’s most acclaimed films, has been described as “Michael Haneke lite.” Like Mr. Haneke, Mr. Ostlund digs under the surface sheen of affluent bourgeois life to discern deep currents of fear and mistrust. His previous two features, “Play” (2011) and “Involuntary” (2008), both running through Thursday at the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center in Lincoln Center, are calculated to make you squirm.

headline: Rodeo, Rockabilly And Ample Mixing
abstract: For Sufjan Stevens, America is an expanse of history, myth, memory, fantasy, ideals and quirks, reflected in music that might be gently homespun, orchestral, jazz-tinged or electronic.
lead_paragraph: For Sufjan Stevens, America is an expanse of history, myth, memory, fantasy, ideals and quirks, reflected in music that might be gently homespun, orchestral, jazz-tinged or electronic. “Round-Up” takes on an institution that is a sport and a cultural touchstone: rodeo. It’s a live score for slow-motion footage from the Pendleton Round-Up; Mr. Stevens plays electronics with the ensemble Yarn/Wire. Maybe he’ll be glancing over his shoulder at Aaron Copland’s “Rodeo.” (Tuesday through Jan. 25 at 7:30 p.m., BAM Harvey Theater, bam.org)

headline: Changelings
abstract: Joe Krozel’s theme reminds me of a newspaper headline from long ago.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — On July 17, 1935, the entertainment industry newspaper Variety printed a headline that entered the lore of journalism for its creativity: “Sticks Nix Hick Pix” was meant to communicate that rural moviegoers did not necessarily want to see movies about country life, as the movie industry had assumed.

headline: Bench That Killed 7-Year-Old New Jersey Boy Wasn’t Secure
abstract: A fold-up bench that fell from a school wall and killed Brendan Jordan this month was not properly locked at the time, an investigation has found.
lead_paragraph: A fold-up bench that fell from a school wall and killed a 7-year-old New Jersey boy this month was not properly fastened at the time, an investigation into the cause of the fatal accident has found.

headline: Elena Obraztsova, Jewel of the Bolshoi Opera, Is Dead at 75
abstract: Ms. Obraztsova, a mezzo-soprano, survived the siege of Leningrad to become one of the Soviet Union’s greatest opera singers with theatrical triumphs around the world.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Elena Obraztsova, a mezzo-soprano who survived the siege of Leningrad to become one of the Soviet Union’s greatest opera singers and an international star during the Cold War, died on Jan. 12 at a clinic in Germany. She was 75.

headline: Opposites Day
abstract: And it’s not even April 1.
lead_paragraph: And, I’m back — for some reason the local internet access didn’t like the Times servers, leaving me unable to post. But I have found a workaround, so I can weigh in briefly on stuff that has been happening.

headline: The Bushes, as Distinct and Alike as Brothers Can Be
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: While loving and supportive of each other, George W. and Jeb Bush do not talk that often, according to family intimates, and they travel in different circles.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One day last fall, former President George W. Bush called Mel Sembler, a Republican donor from Florida who had served as his ambassador to Italy. Mr. Sembler had just had a pacemaker implanted into his chest, and his wife had also recently had surgery. Mr. Bush wanted to check on how they were faring.

headline: Obama Will Seek to Raise Taxes on Wealthy to Finance Cuts for Middle Class
keywords: ['Taxation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes']
abstract: President Obama will use his State of the Union address Tuesday to call on Congress to raise taxes and fees on the wealthiest taxpayers to finance the tax cuts, administration officials said on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will use his State of the Union address to call on Congress to raise taxes and fees on the wealthiest taxpayers and the largest financial firms to finance an array of tax cuts for the middle class, pressing to reshape the tax code to help working families, administration officials said on Saturday.

headline: Chicago No Longer Seems a Lock to Host Obama’s Library, and Many Are Alarmed
abstract: President Obama and his wife, Michelle, are said to have “major concerns” with Chicago’s bids to host the Barack Obama Presidential Library, increasing the likelihood it will be built in New York City or Hawaii.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — People who live in Chicago know a few things to be true about their city. Winters are brutal. The architecture is first-rate. The Cubs will lose.

headline: Top Conferences to Allow Aid for Athletes’ Full Bills
abstract: The five most prominent conferences in college sports voted to increase their scholarships to cover athletes’ full cost of attendance, which is typically several thousand dollars more than colleges currently provide.
lead_paragraph: OXON HILL, Md. — In a milestone, the five most prominent conferences in college sports voted on Saturday to increase their scholarships to cover athletes’ full cost of attendance, which is typically several thousand dollars more than colleges currently provide.

headline: Protesters Out to Reclaim King’s Legacy, but in Era That Defies Comparison
keywords: ['Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: On the eve of Martin Luther King’s Birthday, protesters mobilized by the shooting deaths of young blacks and angry about racial inequality are evoking his work, denouncing what they say is an attempt to sanitize his message.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of Martin Luther King’s Birthday, protesters mobilized by the shooting deaths of young blacks and outraged about racial inequality are evoking his work, denouncing what they say is an attempt to sanitize his message and using the hashtag #ReclaimMLK hoping to rekindle a new movement for social change.

headline: Tentative Deal to Avert Strike at Produce Market in Hunts Point
abstract: The union workers at the Hunts Point Terminal Produce Market will vote on Wednesday on the agreement, which gives raises in the next three years.
lead_paragraph: The Hunts Point Terminal Produce Market reached a tentative contract agreement on Saturday with more than 1,200 workers, averting a potential strike that could have disrupted the region’s supply of fresh fruits and vegetables.

headline: Cuomo to Offer Plan to Cut College Graduates’ Debt
abstract: Under the proposal, the state would cover two years of loan payments for graduates of New York State colleges who make less than $50,000 a year, continue to live in the state and are enrolled in a federal repayment program.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo will propose legislation to ease the debt burden of thousands of college graduates, an administration official said.

abstract: Herring, the secret to world domination.

headline: ‘That’s My Sister!’ Taking a Twin’s Gender Fluidity in Stride
abstract: One of my twins was born a boy but, for the moment at least, identifies a girl; wearing dresses, using the girls’ restroom, crying if referred to as “he.” Only one person has handled all of this with ease: her twin sister.
lead_paragraph: Do you have a sister? This is the “question of the day” that greets us as we enter my twins’ preschool class. My heart sinks. Question like these can be difficult to navigate in my family. Can we just say sibling?

headline: Prominent North Korean Defector Recants Parts of His Story of Captivity
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Books and Literature', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Shin Dong-hyuk became famous after speaking about his childhood in a prison camp. On Sunday, he said that elements of his harrowing tale were untrue.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — He was the poster boy for human rights atrocities in North Korea; a soft-spoken survivor of the North’s cruel gulags who eventually met such dignitaries as John Kerry in his campaign to focus attention on the North’s abuses. His harrowing tales of life in a prison camp — including being forced to watch his mother and brother being executed — stunned even those steeped in defectors’ stories and made him a star witness for an unprecedented United Nations’ investigation of abuses by the North’s rulers.

headline: 1890: Is John Ruskin Insane?
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The author John Ruskin is rumored to have suffered a breakdown in 1890.
lead_paragraph: The mental condition of Mr. John Ruskin, the great leader in English critical literature, is causing much sorrow among his friends. There has been a great deal of whispered talk in the upper art circles of London for months past concerning Mr. Ruskin’s state and the peculiar circumstances by which he is environed. There has been no public comment on the matter, because of the general desire, among his most intimate friends, Mr. Swinburne, Mr. Burne Jones and others, to have nothing said about it. Now, however, the removal of his publisher from Orpington to London, and the change in the sale of Mr. Buskin’s books from the no discount system, which he instituted, to the ordinary methods prevailing in the book trade, with other circumstances, make further secrecy impossible.

headline: Costume National and John Varvatos Reach for Rock ‘n’ Roll
abstract: Lots of designers say they are inspired by rockers, but few really seem to understand them.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — A recurring beef a person who writes about style and fashion might develop is the lazy reference designers inevitably make to rockers. Depending on who you’re consulting, rock ‘n’ roll has been around for a good 70 years. That’s a lot of music. When someone like Ennio Capasa of Costume National, a decent man and equally so a designer, cites rock musicians as his inspiration, a listener is often left to wonder which ones: the Rolling Stones, the Kills, the Pretenders, the White Stripes, Sleater-Kinney?

headline: Bien nommer la menace
abstract: Le terrorisme islamiste est le cancer de l’islam contre lequel les musulmans doivent eux-mêmes lutter à nos côtés.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — « Mal nommer les choses, c’est ajouter au malheur du monde. » Qu’Albert Camus l’ait prononcée ou non, cette phrase décrit étonnamment bien la situation dans laquelle se trouve l’actuel gouvernement de la France. En effet, le nom des choses, c’est ce que Laurent Fabius, ministre français des Affaires étrangères, n’ose même plus prononcer.

headline: 1940: French Are Seeking a Walt Disney, Artists Asked to Submit Work
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The French are seeking their own Walt Disney in 1940.
lead_paragraph: French motion-picture producers, pointing to the artistic triumphs and box-office successes of Walt Disney, have been casting about lately for Gallic talent to give Walt a little competition, and, incidentally, to capture some of the money flowing so copiously into the coffers of the creators of animated screen cartoons. Determined to find native counterparts of Mickey Mouse and Popeye, the Frenchmen have sent out an invitation to all artists, cartoonists and designers to submit their most fanciful brainchildren for study and possible adaptation. The invitation has been answered by scores of good, and — no doubt — bad and indifferent artists. At the Centrale de Coordination des Métiers, 5 Rue de Logelbach, one can see the results of the response in the form of drawings, silhouettes, cutouts and marionettes. Sergent Badu, ‘‘Poilu de l’Avant,’’ is the only war character. Should the war last, he might prove the most popular of the lot. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 19, 1940

headline: Eight Israeli Arab Men Are Charged With Aiding Islamic State

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — An Israeli helicopter strike in Syria killed five Hezbollah fighters on Sunday, including the son of the group’s slain military commander, Imad Mughniyeh, Hezbollah said as a member briefed on the episode described the attack as a provocative move by Israel.

lead_paragraph: Travis Kalanick, chief executive of the ride-hailing service Uber, wants to play nice with Europe.

headline: Louis CK Adds Another Show at Madison Square Garden
abstract: The comedian is adding a Jan. 27 show to his Madison Square Garden run.
lead_paragraph: On his television show “Louie,” Louis CK stars as a perpetual loser who repels most women and decent humans. But in real life — or at least in the comedy arena — he has recently been the opposite: someone who has barely enough time to accommodate all of his admirers. On Saturday, the comedian announced that he was adding a Jan. 27 show to his Madison Square Garden run — the fourth Garden appearance of his current tour.

headline: Dreaming of Fame, the Stage and Rainbows
abstract: Sam Harris stars in “Ham: A Musical Memoir,” based on his book “Ham: Slices of a Life,” at Theater 511 at Ars Nova.
lead_paragraph: I was worried going into “Ham: A Musical Memoir,” at Theater 511 at Ars Nova. Its star, Sam Harris, now in his 50s, was the male-vocalist champion on the very first season (1983-84) of “Star Search,” which was unique at the time as a television talent-competition series. How long ago was 1983? Ed McMahon was the show’s host.

headline: In Panama, a Burgeoning Jazz Hotbed
abstract: Danilo Pérez has made promoting musicianship in Panama — using music as a springboard, cultural unifier and teaching tool — his life’s work.
lead_paragraph: Danilo Pérez has made promoting musicianship in Panama — using music as a springboard, cultural unifier and teaching tool — his life’s work.

headline: Will the F.D.A. Kill Off E-Cigs?
keywords: ['E-Cigarettes', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Nicotine']
abstract: Government guidelines could clarify the benefits for smokers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — ELECTRONIC cigarettes, battery-powered devices that convert a solution of nicotine and other chemicals into a vapor that can be inhaled, or “vaped,” have the potential to wean a vast number of smokers off cigarettes. No burned tobacco leaves, no cancer-causing tar: a public health revolution in waiting.

headline: High Noon for the Gray Wolf
abstract: If the U.S. doesn’t act, these creatures will be slaughtered again.
lead_paragraph: TUCSON — IN December 2011, a wild gray wolf set foot in California, the first sighting in almost a century. He’d wandered in from Oregon, looking for a mate. In October 2014, for the first time in almost three-quarters of a century, a gray wolf was seen loping along the forested North Rim of the Grand Canyon, in Arizona. She had walked hundreds of miles, probably from Wyoming or Idaho.

headline: Aiming to Create a Jazz Capital
abstract: In his native Panama, the pianist Danilo Pérez spearheads a festival, a foundation and a jazz club, as well as musical opportunities for Panama’s youth.
lead_paragraph: PANAMA — In the wee hours of Friday morning, Danilo Pérez climbed onstage at his jazz club here to play a set. Mr. Pérez, the Panama-born pianist and composer who has for more than a decade been a member of Wayne Shorter’s acclaimed quartet, had already headlined shows for the Panama Jazz Festival, which he founded 12 years ago. There he had performed alongside the Puerto Rican saxophonist Miguel Zenón and his fellow Panamanian, the salsa singer Rubén Blades, and in the festival’s gala concert at the 106-year-old National Theater.

headline: A Hip-Hop ‘Spirit Guide’ and Online Taste Maker
abstract: ASAP Yams, who died on Jan. 18 at 26, exerted a prescient influence over hip-hop both online and through ASAP Worldwide records.
lead_paragraph: Hip-hop’s past is littered with secret histories, scenes and stories and sounds that never got their full hearing, remembered only by a few. Thanks to the Internet, though, secret histories aren’t so secret anymore. Those stories are now rescued, amplified and recontextualized by a new wave of agents who are fluent in the past, and who use it to build a more creative future.

headline: CBS Renews Its Thursday Football Deal
abstract: The network will carry the first eight Thursday night games of the 2015 season after a successful eight-game run this season.
lead_paragraph: CBS announced Sunday that it would carry Thursday night football games again in 2015, building on the games’ success during the 2014 season.

headline: ‘Sniper’ Rules Weekend Box Office
abstract: The big weekend totals by “American Sniper” give the Oscars the breakout hit that awards show was lacking in the best picture category.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood is prone to superlatives, but this one is truly jaw dropping: “American Sniper,” which arrived in wide release on Friday, is expected to sell about $105.2 million in tickets in North America over the four-day holiday weekend.

headline: Like Alpine Peaks
abstract: Solve Jean O’Conor’s cool puzzle with me.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — A timely grid for Jean O’Conor, even if there is no white stuff on the ground here right now. It’s cold enough, so I’m calling this a seasonal puzzle.

headline: Not From Here, Are You?
abstract: In “The Bubble,” a 1960s sci-fi film, a couple’s plane makes an emergency landing in a strange town.
lead_paragraph: Originally premiering in 1966, Arch Oboler’s 3-D science-fiction puzzler, “The Bubble,” gets a New York theatrical run to show off its Space-Vision technology in an extraordinary restoration. Mr. Oboler, a titan from radio days, predicted in 1967 “that in 20 years there will be no flat movies.” He was a little off, but not for lack of trying: This film thrusts not only a tray of beers but a cancan dancer’s high-kick at the audience.

headline: An Entitled Executive as Mozart May Have Imagined Him
abstract: A Paris National Opera production of “Don Giovanni” is set in a modern corporate office.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As the residents here continue to cope with the aftermath of the recent terrorist attacks, the performing arts institutions of this city clearly feel the need to make rallying artistic statements. So it was on Thursday night when the Paris National Opera opened a revival of its boldly contemporary 2006 production of Mozart’s “Don Giovanni” by the Austrian film director and screenwriter Michael Haneke.

headline: Hybridized Hip-Hop, Playing to the Kids
abstract: Illstyle and Peace Productions presented “IMpossible IZZpossible,” a program that blended hip-hop, tap, ballet and West African dance, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Peace, love and respect are excellent values for a theatrical production to promote, especially one directed at children. But it takes more than good intentions to make a good show, and Illstyle and Peace Productions’ “IMpossible IZZpossible,” which played over the weekend at BAM Fisher as part of the BAM Kids series, is an incoherent jumble.

headline: Seahawks Rally Past Packers in Overtime to Return to Super Bowl
abstract: Green Bay scored the first 16 points of the game and tied the score after Seattle took a late lead, but the Seahawks quickly drove for a touchdown in overtime, on a 35-yard pass to Jermaine Kearse.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The Seahawks huddled on their sideline Sunday afternoon, and inside the circle, their coach, Pete Carroll, pointed and shouted and waved. Above the din, in a stadium that two hours earlier had been stunned into silence, many players nodded along as he spoke.

headline: Something New to Follow Your Moment of Zen
abstract: “The Nightly Show” on Comedy Central has its premiere on Monday night, and its host, Larry Wilmore, is working hard to prepare while keeping his options open.
lead_paragraph: Seated at the head of the oblong table where he will preside over his new Comedy Central series, “The Nightly Show,” Larry Wilmore was moderating a vigorous, sometimes sincere, sometimes acerbic panel discussion about the attack on the French newspaper Charlie Hebdo.

headline: In Panama, a Burgeoning Jazz Hotbed
abstract: Danilo Pérez has made promoting musicianship in Panama — using music as a springboard, cultural unifier and teaching tool — his life’s work.
lead_paragraph: Danilo Pérez has made promoting musicianship in Panama — using music as a springboard, cultural unifier and teaching tool — his life’s work.

headline: For Musicians, a TV Series Underscores Diminishing Role
abstract: In a scene in “Mozart in the Jungle,” musicians are portrayed in a studio recording an over-the-top score for a low-budget film, a scene that verges on anachronistic.
lead_paragraph: Nestled among the zany plotlines of the Amazon series “Mozart in the Jungle” are scenes that many classical musicians will recognize of the struggles, and indignities, that they face as they try to make it in New York.

headline: Classical Music as ‘Jungle’ Rings True
abstract: “Mozart in the Jungle” is a sexed-up, druggy, daffy and fictional look inside a major symphony, but most surprising is how true its depiction of the classical music industry rings.
lead_paragraph: “Classical music has been losing money for people for 500 years,” an orchestra administrator tells her numbers-obsessed colleague in the new Amazon series “Mozart in the Jungle.” “It’s not a business.”

headline: Purgatory at Home In Wartime
abstract: “The Train to Crystal City” delves into the internment program that targeted Japanese residents in America during World War II.
lead_paragraph: The American government made no secret of the fact that it had rounded up Japanese residents of this country, even if they had been born here, and kept them in detention camps during World War II. At first glance, “The Train to Crystal City” appears to be about some version of that story, since the people depicted on its cover are Asian and some are being transported somewhere. But the facts Jan Jarboe Russell has unveiled are much thornier, more complex and terrible. The tale they tell is almost more than her mind-boggling but awkwardly organized book can handle.

headline: If Mahler Were Writing Now
abstract: The Argento Chamber Ensemble presented the second concert in its “Mahler as New York Contemporary” series at the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: Gustav Mahler, maker of gigantic symphonies, may seem an odd preoccupation for a chamber group. But preoccupation he is, this season, for the adventurous Argento Chamber Ensemble, which presented the second concert in its series Mahler as New York Contemporary on Thursday evening in the Board of Officers Room at the Park Avenue Armory.

headline: A Win for Sotheby’s in Dispute Over Painting
abstract: A British judge ruled last week that Sotheby’s had not been negligent in the case of a painting that the auction house sold for much less than it was worth.
lead_paragraph: A British judge ruled last week that Sotheby’s had not been negligent in the case of a painting that the auction house sold in 2006 for 42,000 pounds (about $63,600), only to be declared worth £10 million a year later, the Financial Times reported. Lancelot Thwaytes sued Sotheby’s for £11 million (about $16.7 million) in damages, claiming that the auctioneers had insufficiently researched his painting “The Cardsharps.” The auction house described the work, below, which depicts two hustlers trying to cheat another man in a card game, as a 17th-century copy of the original by the Italian master Caravaggio. The painting was purchased by a friend of the British collector Denis Mahon, who died in 2011 and who, after further analysis, declared it an authentic Caravaggio and valued the painting at £10 million. The Financial Times reported that Judge Vivien Rose dismissed Mr. Thwaytes’s claim, saying in her ruling that the auctioneers had examined the painting thoroughly, and reasonably concluded that the painting was not of high enough quality to be a Caravaggio. The disputed painting is currently on loan to the Museum of the Order of St John in London.

headline: Good Eggs
abstract: It wasn’t cuddly or strokable, but I had no choice in the matter: We were going to be sharing our apartment with a turtle.
lead_paragraph: When I left our Manhattan apartment for a short trip, everything was more or less normal. But when I returned, I saw the turtle tank — it had come in while I was away. Along with the tank came a turtle — a mature red-eared slider. My wife had bought the tank while I was in another city. Maybe she’d waited until I was traveling so I wouldn’t stop her.

headline: Alternate Possibilities at Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional
abstract: When tournament winners send in a deal, usually they have the analysis of the main line correct.
lead_paragraph: When tournament winners send in a deal, usually they have the analysis of the main line correct. But a columnist working against a deadline will feed the deal into William Bailey’s Deep Finesse software, both to check that analysis and to see if something important was overlooked.

abstract: This holiday does not fully belong in the most profound ways to many Americans, and to some, it does not belong at all.
lead_paragraph: I am very honored to be addressing you here today, though it is not without some trepidation.

abstract: Bullied by the balance-sheet bugaboo brigade.
lead_paragraph: OK, arrived in Hong Kong, and IT is working a lot better. So let me weigh in a bit more on the Swiss miss. Basically, my take is the same as Brad DeLong’s: what we have here is a central bank that let itself be bullied by the balance sheet bugaboo brigade.

headline: Microsoft Looks to Windows 10 for a Jolt in the Mobile Realm
abstract: Windows 10 is the biggest effort yet by Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s new chief, who has been able to lift the company’s stock to a nearly 15-year high.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Optimism is a renewable resource at Microsoft.

lead_paragraph: Because of Martin Luther King’s Birthday, the regulations will be suspended on Monday. Other rules remain in effect.

headline: Why the Oscars’ Omission of ‘Selma’ Matters
keywords: ['Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Movies', 'Women and Girls', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES']
abstract: In general, the film academy and the industry it mirrors manage diversity the same way that corporate America does, by ticking off boxes.
lead_paragraph: Monday is Martin Luther King Jr. Day and given the context, it is an interesting moment to ask whether it really matters that the motion picture academy failed to nominate the black director and the black lead actor of “Selma,” the King biopic, for Oscars.

headline: Nickelodeon Remixes Its Sitcom Formula to Adapt to Children’s Media Consumption
abstract: In an effort to counter ratings declines and children’s changing tastes, the network has introduced shows that have more nuance and sophistication.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Buffoonish parents. Voice-of-reason best friend. Laugh track. Extra-bright lighting. Nifty girl’s bedroom with window seat.

headline: Gay Marriage Case Offers G.O.P. Political Cover
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: If the Supreme Court resolves the issue as expected, it could largely neutralize a debate that a majority of Americans believe Republicans are on the wrong side of.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The news Friday that the Supreme Court will rule on same-sex marriage brought elation from gays and lesbians who are hopeful the justices will grant them the constitutional protections they have long sought.

headline: Economic Data From China, and Stimulus From the E.C.B.
abstract: China will release its fourth-quarter growth on Monday night, and on Thursday the European Central Bank is expected to start its bond-buying program; IBM and General Electric will report results.
lead_paragraph: CHINA WILL RELEASE FIGURES ON FOURTH-QUARTER GROWTH

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Jan. 19
abstract: The following tax-exempt, fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, which will be held Tuesday as the markets will be closed Monday in observance of Martin Luther King’s Birthday. The regular four-week bill auction will be moved to Wednesday.

headline: With Aerial Banners, Taking Grievances to the Skies
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Signs and Signage', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Football', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Instead of taking to the streets, two groups have used airplanes to make sure their political and sports-related points receive plenty of neck-craning attention.
lead_paragraph: Banner-toting airplanes, though sometimes loud, are usually not heavy on commentary; they are better known as a flashy way to propose marriage or promote happy hour at a local bar.

headline: Riding High, Biotech Firms Remain Wary
abstract: Soaring stock prices and major advances in fighting diseases have some saying the industry has turned a corner and others watching for a bursting bubble.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The biotechnology industry tends to be overshadowed by the razzle-dazzle of high-tech companies like Apple, Facebook and Google, particularly in the Bay Area.

headline: In Ferguson, Push for Criminal Justice Reform Draws Comparisons to ’60s Fight for Civil Rights
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Police', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: The Congressional Black Caucus was focusing its attention on a bill that would support President Obama’s plan to equip more police officers with body cameras.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — During the unrest here that followed the fatal shooting of Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager, by a white police officer, Wellspring United Methodist Church positioned itself as a haven for demonstrators seeking refuge from the chaos on the streets.

headline: History Buff, Buy Our Movie: Indie Film Team Tries the Direct Approach
abstract: A new film set in World War II, “Against the Sun,” is marketing itself in a way Hollywood has been slow to embrace: targeted digital sales to narrowly defined purchaser pools.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Take a quiz about your open-sea survival skills on Buzzfeed. Score maybe 7 of 10, marking you as the type who might make it through a midocean disaster. And up pops an offer of, say, 30 percent off the standard $15 price to buy “Against the Sun,” a new feature film about real Navy fliers who spent 34 days adrift on the Pacific during World War II.

headline: Cuomo to Propose 2 New Minimum Wages, for New York City and State
keywords: ['Minimum Wage', 'State Legislatures', 'State of the State Message (NYS)', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: The proposal, which Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo plans to announce in his State of the State address Wednesday, would raise the minimum wage to $11.50 in New York City and to $10.50 elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Flanked by a collection of liberal groups and labor leaders, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Sunday announced a raft of proposals on social issues, among them a plan that would raise the minimum wage to $11.50 an hour in New York City and $10.50 an hour in the rest of the state.

headline: ASAP Yams, Creative Force in Hip-Hop, Dies at 26
abstract: A New York City native, Yams, whose real name was Steven Rodriguez, was an owner of the ASAP Worldwide label and a founder of the ASAP Mob collective.
lead_paragraph: ASAP Yams, the hip-hop executive who helped start the career of ASAP Rocky, the popular Harlem rapper whose 2013 studio album, “Long.Live.ASAP,” debuted at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, has died. He was 26.

headline: So He Let 20 Goals Past Him? In His Sport, That’s a Great Game
abstract: As the world’s best handball goalkeeper, Thierry Omeyer of France has mastered one of the most frustrating and demanding positions in sports.
lead_paragraph: NANTES, France — Handball, virtually unknown in the United States as a team game, is one of the fastest-growing and most ostentatious sports in Europe, often drawing more fans than basketball. No one, though, loves it quite the way the French do.

headline: Yoko Nagae Ceschina, Countess and Fairy Godmother to the Arts, Dies at 82
abstract: Countess Ceschina was one of the world’s foremost patrons of classical music, if also one of the least publicly known.
lead_paragraph: A long, long time ago — more than half a century, to be exact — there lived a young woman who journeyed to Italy from her native Japan. She went there to study the harp, an instrument on which she possessed uncommon skill.

headline: N.S.A. Breached North Korean Networks Before Sony Attack, Officials Say
abstract: Evidence gathered by software hidden by the N.S.A. to monitor North Korean activities proved critical in persuading President Obama to accuse the government of ordering the cyberattack on Sony, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The trail that led American officials to blame North Korea for the destructive cyberattack on Sony Pictures Entertainment in November winds back to 2010, when the National Security Agency scrambled to break into the computer systems of a country considered one of the most impenetrable targets on earth.

headline: As Content Pours From Everywhere, New Network Shows Strive for Boldness
abstract: At a time when small-screen audiences have never had more viewing options, network executives are highlighting star turns and audacious themes as they aim to be heard above the din.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — Jesus, a pregnant lesbian, an Asian-American family. A hip-hop empire, cybercrime fighters and the last man on earth. Those are among the cast of characters broadcasters now are depending on to rescue them from a season of troubling ratings declines.

headline: Hating Good Government
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Global Warming', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Economy', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: Why do so many Americans hold views that are completely at odds with, and completely unaffected by, actual experience?
lead_paragraph: It’s now official: 2014 was the warmest year on record. You might expect this to be a politically important milestone. After all, climate change deniers have long used the blip of 1998 — an unusually hot year, mainly due to an upwelling of warm water in the Pacific — to claim that the planet has stopped warming. This claim involves a complete misunderstanding of how one goes about identifying underlying trends. (Hint: Don’t cherry-pick your observations.) But now even that bogus argument has collapsed. So will the deniers now concede that climate change is real?

headline: In N.C.A.A.’s Varied Landscape, Some Open Floodgates While Others Fear Drought
abstract: As new benefits flow to top conferences and sports, some involved in the less lucrative areas of the N.C.A.A. worry they will soon have even fewer resources.
lead_paragraph: OXON HILL, Md. — At the annual N.C.A.A. convention over the weekend, the trendiest color was black.

headline: Supreme Court to Review Bans on Solicitations in Judge Races
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Elections, Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Judges already routinely hear cases involving lawyers and litigants who have contributed to their campaigns, setting up possible conflicts of interest.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Almost five years to the day after the Citizens United decision reshaped American politics, the Supreme Court on Tuesday will turn its attention to judicial elections.

headline: How Expensive It Is to Be Poor
keywords: ['Poverty', 'Income Inequality', 'Credit and Debt', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Welfare (US)', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Income', 'Traffic and Parking Violations']
abstract: Most wealthy Americans believe “poor people today have it easy.” This view is infuriatingly obtuse.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the Pew Research Center released a study that found that most wealthy Americans believed “poor people today have it easy because they can get government benefits without doing anything in return.”

headline: Libya Militias Agree to Halt in Fighting, With Caveats
abstract: The cease-fire is the closest that international mediators have come to ending the violence in Libya since it began to escalate last summer with the breakdown into two rival national alliances of competing militias.
lead_paragraph: TOBRUK, Libya — The main factions fighting in Libya agreed to a provisional cease-fire on Sunday, apparently in response to pressure from the United Nations Security Council.

headline: After 36 Years, a New York Town Sifts Through Suspicions on a Fatal Fire
abstract: Law enforcement officials in Greece, N.Y., say they are close to seeking an indictment in connection with a 1978 blaze at a Holiday Inn that killed 10.
lead_paragraph: GREECE, N.Y. — No obvious traces remain of the fire that killed 10 people here in 1978, no monument to remind local residents of the arson at the Holiday Inn that left an entire town in tears. A Red Lobster now occupies the spot on a busy road where the motel once stood.

headline: As Playboy and Penthouse Fade, Newer Magazines Tilt Artistic
abstract: A newer breed of erotic publications are blending nudity with art, fashion and philosophy as traditional sex-themed magazines fall victim to the Internet and its boundless pornography.
lead_paragraph: Pornography used to mean Playboy or Penthouse or another of the hundreds of glossy magazines kept on high shelves and purchased furtively.

headline: Cubans Convicted in the U.S. Face New Fears of Deportation
abstract: A longstanding policy of permitting Cubans with criminal convictions to remain in the United States is suddenly on shakier ground.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — For Amaury Villa, who arrived here from Cuba more than 15 years ago and became a permanent resident, pleading guilty in 2012 to federal charges that he sold stolen prescription drugs was a difficult choice. But there was one positive aspect: Unlike most foreign citizens convicted of serious crimes, Mr. Villa stood next to no chance of being deported back to his home country.

headline: Banking Start-Ups Adopt New Tools for Lending
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Discrimination', 'Credit and Debt', 'Start-ups', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Consumer Protection', 'Credit Cards']
abstract: New software is expected to sharpen assessments of creditworthiness, but even proponents acknowledge the potential for inadvertent discrimination.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When bankers of the future decide whether to make a loan, they may look to see if potential customers use only capital letters when filling out forms, or at the amount of time they spend online reading terms and conditions — and not so much at credit history.

headline: Man Who Filmed Execution Is Arrested, Saudi Outlets Say
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Shariah (Islamic Law)', 'Capital Punishment', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Amid rising scrutiny over the local justice system, news outlets in Saudi Arabia reported that the authorities had arrested a man who had filmed a woman’s execution and planned to prosecute him.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In a recent video from Saudi Arabia, three uniformed security officers and a professional swordsman in a white gown struggled to placate a woman cloaked in black and sitting in the street. A Saudi court had convicted her of murder, but she was proclaiming her innocence.

headline: After an Unthinkable Crime, a Second Chance
abstract: Lora Pitoscia was imprisoned after letting her infant son starve to death while she was in jail for prostitution. Now released and working, she is trying to start over.
lead_paragraph: With its sloped lawns and dense shrubbery, its stately Colonials and svelte Corvettes, Watchung Road in Bound Brook, N.J., was a world apart from the cluttered street where Lora Pitoscia grew up nearby.

headline: Urban Poetry by Accident
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A driver looking for a parking space sent four text messages to his wife, and then realized that they worked well together.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Insurance via Internet Is Squeezing Agents
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Insurance', 'Homeowners Insurance', 'Automobile Insurance and Liability', "Renter's Insurance", 'Online Advertising', 'E-Commerce', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Technology start-ups with websites that sell many types of insurance and promise savings with comparison shopping are putting pressure on insurance agents, who collect commissions.
lead_paragraph: To the list of jobs threatened by the Internet, add one more: insurance agent.

headline: Team’s Mission: Beat the Boys (and Maybe Make Them Cry)
abstract: The Central Illinois Xpress basketball team is the only team of girls in a fifth-grade boys’ league. They have an 8-1 record and aren’t intimidated.
lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, Ill. — Tariq Toran, the coach of the Central Illinois Xpress basketball team, presented his players with matching mouth guards for Christmas. He had made sure they all came in fluorescent green.

headline: ‘Girls’ Recap: Hannah, the White Girl in the Room
abstract: Is Lena Dunham taking her critics seriously? Or is the show making fun of them?

headline: Lavish Malls Sprouting Up to Attract Iranian Elite

headline: Freedom for Yazidis, After Months of Torment
abstract: Nearly 200 members of the Yazidi religious minority in Iraq might have been released because Islamic State militants could no longer provide food and medicine for them, former captives and Iraqi officials said.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Nearly 200 members of the Yazidi religious minority in Iraq, held captive for months by Islamic State extremists and freed over the weekend, might have been released because the militants could no longer provide food and medicine for them, former captives and Iraqi officials said Sunday. The group of mostly elderly Yazidi hostages, many in poor health, were released on Saturday.

The warning about deepening global inequality comes just as the world’s business elite prepare to meet this week at the annual World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.
