headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TMC) STARRING SIDNEY POITIER Stanley Kramer’s “The Defiant Ones” (1958), about an uneducated black convict on a chain gang who goes on the lam with his “other half,” a white Southern bigot portrayed by Tony Curtis, above left, ushers in this tribute to Mr. Poitier, right (between them is Cara Williams). In 1964, Mr. Poitier became the first black person to win a best-actor Oscar and three years later was the nation’s top box-office draw. “In its candid presentment of racial conflict and resentment,” Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times, “it rips right into the subject with clawing ferocity and flails it about with merciless fury until all the viciousness in conflict is spent.” In James Clavell’s “To Sir, With Love” (1967), at 10, Mr. Poitier stars as Thackeray, an idealistic new teacher in London assigned to a school near the city’s docks, where his Cockney-accented students are ill mannered and insolent. Christian Roberts plays Denham, the arrogant teenager who incites Thackeray’s latest classroom edict: If the students want to be treated as the adults they are about to become, they must act like adults. “A nice air of gentility suffuses this pretty color film, and Mr. Poitier gives a quaint example of being proper and turning the other cheek,” Mr. Crowther wrote. And in Mr. Kramer’s “Guess Who’s Coming to Dinner” (1967), at midnight, the liberal principles of an aging couple (Spencer Tracy and Katharine Hepburn) are tested when their daughter (Katharine Houghton) announces her engagement to a black doctor (Mr. Poitier). Mr. Crowther called the movie “a most delightfully acted and gracefully entertaining film, fashioned much in the manner of a stage drawing-room comedy, that seems to be about something much more serious and challenging than it actually is.”

headline: Judges, With Hat in Hand
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Editorials', 'Elections, Courts and the Judiciary', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Supreme Courts (State)', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Even elected members of the judiciary are not lawmakers or political leaders, and they should not be put in the position of asking donors for money.
lead_paragraph: The Florida judiciary is no stranger to misconduct and corruption. During one tawdry stretch in the early 1970s, three of the state’s supreme court justices resigned over corruption scandals. One was caught on a gambling junket in Las Vegas that had been paid for by a greyhound track owner with a case pending before the court. Two others stepped down after trying to tamper with cases involving campaign supporters.

headline: A Modest Move on Methane
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Methane', 'Editorials', 'Global Warming', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Natural Gas', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Air Pollution']
abstract: The first federal effort to regulate the gas directly will put a dent in harmful emissions. But only a dent.
lead_paragraph: There is much to like in the Obama administration’s proposal, announced last Wednesday, to reduce harmful methane emissions from oil and gas drilling. The proposal — which calls for detailed rules to be unveiled in early summer — is the first federal effort to directly regulate methane, the main component of natural gas and a major contributor to climate change. The regulations will apply to all new oil and gas wells, and be national in scope, thus setting minimum standards for what is now a patchwork quilt of state laws.

headline: An Inclusive French Republic
abstract: Professed values must become a reality for the country’s many youths who feel marginalized.
lead_paragraph: The recent terrorist attacks in Paris prompted millions to take to the streets to show national solidarity and to pay tribute to the 17 people murdered. The attacks have also inspired a lot of soul-searching, as the French struggle to understand how three men, born and raised in France, could have trained the murderous intent of Al Qaeda and the Islamic State on their own countrymen. And the attacks have revealed a larger, existential threat to France: that its social compact may be torn apart by sectarian polarization.

headline: Suspicious Nonsense on Trade Agreements
abstract: What’s good for the US Chamber of Commerce is probably bad for America.
lead_paragraph: I am in general a free trader; there is, I’d argue, a tendency on the part of some people with whom I agree on many issues to demonize trade agreements, to make them responsible for evils that have other causes. And my take on both of the trade agreements currently under negotiation — Pacific and Atlantic — is that there’s much less there than meets the eye.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The chief executive of Allied Irish Banks, a nationalized lender, is leaving for a similar position at Clydesdale Bank, the Scottish arm of National Australia Bank.

headline: Video Review: The 2015 Yaris Is Toyota’s Bare-Bones Budget Car
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Many cars in this segment now offer luxuries like keyless ignition, rear-view cameras and heated leather seats. Don’t look for them in the Yaris.
lead_paragraph: AUTOMOTIVE engineers say the most difficult vehicle to produce is a budget subcompact. Certainly, luxury cars stuffed with tech are complex projects. But building a car that’s compelling, affordable, comfortable and — here’s the tricky part — profitable? That’s a black art of the highest order.

headline: Accountable Care Organizations: Like H.M.O.s, but Different
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: New payment models seek to put more responsibility for cost control and quality improvement on health providers, and more, but not all, of the risk.
lead_paragraph: In pursuit of greater efficiency in the United States health system, public programs and private insurers have begun to pay some hospitals and physicians differently. These new payment models take many forms, but they all impose greater responsibility for cost control and quality improvement on providers and bear some resemblance to failed health care financing arrangements from the 1990s. However, there are some distinctions that could make all the difference.

headline: Big Data Underwriting for Payday Loans
abstract: ZestFinance, a practitioner of big data underwriting, says it can reduce the risk of default on payday loans by 40 percent or more.
lead_paragraph: ZestFinance traces its origins to a phone call Douglas Merrill received one winter day from his sister-in-law, Victoria, who needed new snow tires to drive to work and was short of cash. When Mr. Merrill asked what she would have done had she not been able to reach him, she replied that she would have taken out a “payday loan.”

headline: 1915: Germans at Soissons
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1915: Germans at Soissons massing troops in the region.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As yet the Germans are doing nothing to follow up their ‘‘victory’’ on the Aisne, north east of Soissons, although they are believed to be massing troops in the region. The few meters of territory won was taken at so heavy a cost that the disposition is to render a verdict of ‘‘Victorious, but don’t do it again.’’ Many trains of wounded victims of the shrapnel fire of the French have arrived at Louvain, while the local hospitals in the towns behind the centre of the German line are filled with casualties too serious to permit their removal to Germany. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 20, 1915

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Iran confirmed Monday that one of its generals was among the dead in an Israeli airstrike that also killed several Hezbollah fighters in southern Syria on Sunday, an announcement that added to the tension and unpredictability in the region after the strike.

headline: Puzzling Death of a Prosecutor Grips Argentina
abstract: Alberto Nisman, a federal prosecutor who was found dead in his home, had accused top Argentine officials of conspiring with Iran to cover up responsibility for the 1994 bombing of a Jewish community center in Buenos Aires.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Police sentries guarded the federal prosecutor’s luxury high-rise building. His door on the 13th floor had been locked from the inside, and a gun with a spent cartridge was found on the floor near his body. There was no suicide note.

headline: Max Scherzer and Nationals Said to Reach Lucrative Agreement
abstract: The deal, said to be for seven years and more than $200 million, what would be the richest contract for a right-hander, would give the Nationals a powerful rotation.
lead_paragraph: The protracted free agency of Max Scherzer has reached a resolution at last. Scherzer, the former American League Cy Young Award winner, has an agreement with the Washington Nationals on a contract that will be the richest for a right-hander in baseball history.

headline: Charities That Inspire Kids: Kiva
abstract: Diana Williams, a teacher from Surrey, British Columbia, describes the value of making microloans from the classroom.
lead_paragraph: Between Christmas and New Year’s, we shared stories from children, teenagers and families about the charities that inspire them to give time, money and passion. Here’s one more. Diana Williams, a teacher, wrote in about making microloans through Kiva with her students and her own children.

headline: Study Suggests Way to Fight Asian Tiger Mosquito
abstract: The disease-carrying pest appears to spread along highways in Panama, suggesting that spraying cars and trucks could combat the mosquito.
lead_paragraph: The Asian tiger mosquito, which can carry the dengue and chikungunya viruses, appears to spread from place to place along highways, according to a study of its recent dispersal throughout Panama.

headline: On to Plan B as Oil Work Stalls in Texas
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Many residents of Midland, a community dependent on oil drilling, already have their backup plans in place as work starts to dry up.
lead_paragraph: MIDLAND, Tex. — With oil prices plummeting by more than 50 percent since June, the gleeful mood of recent years has turned glum here in West Texas as the frenzy of shale oil drilling has come to a screeching halt.

headline: Tom Brady Laughs at N.F.L. Inquiry Into Deflated Footballs
abstract: “I think I’ve heard it all,” quarterback Tom Brady said on Monday after learning that the N.F.L. was looking into whether the Patriots deflated footballs on Sunday to gain a competitive edge over the Colts.
lead_paragraph: Sunday night was a smooth joy ride for the New England Patriots, with a 45-7 pounding of the Indianapolis Colts that propelled them into another Super Bowl. But Monday morning was a good deal bumpier, with the disclosure that the N.F.L. was investigating whether the Patriots used deflated footballs to gain an unfair advantage in Sunday’s game.

headline: Movie Studio by Amazon for Screens Big and Small
abstract: The online retailing giant signaled its broader ambitions to revolutionize the traditional system used to shepherd movies from the theaters to home screens.
lead_paragraph: First the small screen, now the big screen. Amazon’s entertainment ambitions come in all sizes.

headline: Bernardo Recamán’s Marbles in Bags
abstract: Can you solve this marbles puzzle by Colombian educator Bernardo Recamán?
lead_paragraph: Our puzzle this week was suggested by Bernardo Recamán, a British-trained (Warwick University) Colombian mathematics teacher. We saw him some time ago with Primes in a Circle and it’s a pleasure having him back. Let’s try —

headline: Extreme Migration: Geese Hug the Himalayas
abstract: Scientists have discovered that bar-headed geese stay close to the terrain on their round trip, allowing them to avoid thin air.
lead_paragraph: It has been called the most extreme migration on Earth: Twice a year, bar-headed geese fly over the Himalayas between India and Central Asia. Now, after years of speculation, scientists say they have discovered how the birds manage the high-altitude journey.

headline: 1890: Electrical Executions
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1890: First tests on an apparatus for electrical execution.
lead_paragraph: The apparatus for electrical execution at Clinton Prison was tested yesterday in the presence of the State Commission. Mr. P. Brown, the New York electrical engineer, conducted the test.

headline: Complexities of Choosing an End Game for Dementia
keywords: ['Dementia', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies', 'Death and Dying', 'Elder Care', "Alzheimer's Disease"]
abstract: Some wonder if a directive to hasten death by withholding “ordinary means of nutrition and hydration” should apply to a person who can’t remember it.
lead_paragraph: DEDHAM, Mass. — Jerome Medalie keeps his advance directive hanging in a plastic sleeve in his front hall closet, as his retirement community recommends. That’s where the paramedics will look if someone calls 911.

headline: What a Rise in Obama’s Approval Rating Means for 2016
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: If the rating reaches 50 percent next year, it should be a hopeful sign for the Democratic presidential nominee.
lead_paragraph: After a difficult year, President Obama is enjoying a modest rebound ahead of State of the Union address Tuesday. His approval rating has increased to around 46 percent over the last month, according to an average of polls taken over the last month, up from 42 percent in the weeks after the decisive Republican victory in the midterm elections.

headline: U.S. Signals Shift on How to End Syrian Civil War
abstract: American support for two diplomatic initiatives in Syria underscores the West’s quiet retreat from its demand that Bashar al-Assad step down immediately.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — American support for a pair of diplomatic initiatives in Syria underscores the shifting views of how to end the civil war there and the West’s quiet retreat from its demand that the country’s president, Bashar al-Assad, step down immediately.

headline: Facebook Knows You Better Than Anyone Else
abstract: Researchers have developed a computer model that can judge someone’s personality more accurately than friends and family — using just the subject’s Facebook activity.
lead_paragraph: Think your friends know you well? Researchers have developed a computer model that can judge someone’s personality more accurately than their friends and family — using nothing but the subject’s Facebook activity.

headline: Founder of British Hedge Fund Convicted of Fraud
abstract: Magnus Peterson was convicted of fraud, forgery, false accounting and fraudulent trading related to the collapse of the Weavering Capital hedge fund during the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The founder of Weavering Capital was convicted on Monday of fraud, forgery and other criminal charges related to the collapse of the hedge fund in 2009, prosecutors said.

headline: The Bond of the Past: It’s Ended, Yet Unending
abstract: In Amir Reza Koohestani’s “Timeloss,” two actors, former lovers, rehash an argument that’s both scripted and real.
lead_paragraph: Two former lovers, sitting in a room, bickering: This is an argument they have had so many times, starting so many years ago, that they know it by heart.

headline: Too Close to a Patient for Comfort
abstract: A doctor’s objective eye, unclouded by a relationship, is a key to more effective medical care.
lead_paragraph: The new chief executive of our clinic was gung-ho on its mission and purpose, so much so that he was prepared to put his insurer’s money where his mouth was. He announced at a staff meeting that he would be transferring his own medical care to one of the doctors on staff.

headline: Food Detectives on a Tough Case
abstract: A lab is at the forefront of an effort to keep China from dodging United States tariffs on honey.
lead_paragraph: SAVANNAH, Ga. — Behind the immaculate gray walls of the Customs and Border Protection’s laboratory here stands a cabinet containing three plastic vials filled with a sticky, yellowish substance. Honey, or so an importer has claimed.

headline: Looking Ahead to October, Washington Banks on Pitching
abstract: The Nationals’ expected deal with Max Scherzer, what would be the richest for a right-handed pitcher, would give them an overpowering rotation.
lead_paragraph: A franchise can come a long way in a decade. Ten years ago, there had not been an official major league game played in Washington since 1971. Now, the team that plays there, the Nationals, has such high expectations that the regular season is only a prelude.

headline: Preparing for the Worst in the Heart of Texas Oil Country
abstract: With the price of oil plummeting, the residents and workers in Midland who depend on the industry are honing their backup plans as work dries up.
lead_paragraph: With the price of oil plummeting, the residents and workers in Midland who depend on the industry are honing their backup plans as work dries up.

headline: FX Picks Up a Pilot From Louis CK and Pamela Adlon

lead_paragraph: Pamela Adlon, who was recently the focus of a multi-episode plot arc on “Louie,” will star in her own show, FX has announced. The network picked up the pilot to “Better Things,” created by and starring Ms. Adlon and directed by Louis CK.

headline: Expansion Microscopy Stretches Limits of Conventional Microscopes
abstract: A new technique makes minute biological features, some just 70 nanometers wide, more visible through regular optical microscopes.
lead_paragraph: A new laboratory technique enables researchers to see minuscule biological features, such as individual neurons and synapses, at a nearly molecular scale through conventional optical microscopes.

headline: The Best Sellers: Filed Under Sports
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Athletics and Sports']

lead_paragraph: The best-selling sports books in December 2014, according to the New York Times best-seller list.

headline: Random Chance’s Role in Cancer
abstract: Though we long for control, chance plays a powerful role in the biology of cancer and the evolution of life.
lead_paragraph: Unlike Ebola, flu or polio, cancer is a disease that arises from within — a consequence of the mutations that inevitably occur when one of our 50 trillion cells divides and copies its DNA.

headline: Commemorating King’s Legacy and Invoking Change
abstract: Tributes around the country to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. spoke of persevering in spite of the deaths of black people last year.

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Armenians', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'News and News Media']

headline: Showcasing a Brother, and Giving a Sister Her Due
abstract: The Budapest Festival Orchestra played works by Felix Mendelssohn and his sister Fanny.
lead_paragraph: I wonder if an orchestra had ever played works by Fanny and Felix Mendelssohn on the same program before Ivan Fischer and his Budapest Festival Orchestra did so on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: 4 Killed in Clashes in Northeastern India
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Hinduism', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The fighting between Hindus and Muslims was apparently set off by rumors of an interfaith love affair.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — At least four people died in northeastern India over the weekend in an outbreak of religious violence that was set off by rumors of an interfaith love affair.

headline: Data Show New York Police Are Resuming Their Work
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Traffic and Parking Violations', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Arrests and tickets have yet to reach the same levels as in past years, but the rebound further indicates that a slowdown is over.
lead_paragraph: Police activity in New York City remained at a lower level last week than during the same period in past years, but continued its rise since enforcement came to a near standstill, the result of a citywide slowdown tied to the killings of two officers in December.

headline: Rising Above the Draft Class of 2012
abstract: By leading the Seahawks to two Super Bowls, Russell Wilson, a third-round selection, has set himself apart in a class whose top two picks were Andrew Luck and Robert Griffin III.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Before Muhammad Ali fought the imposing George Foreman in their Rumble in the Jungle in 1974, one of Ali’s trainers told him that there comes a point in every champion’s life when he has to go into the lion’s den and snatch the meat from the lion’s jaw.

headline: Millennials Set to Outnumber Baby Boomers
abstract: The total of millennials — those born from 1981 to 1997 — will reach 75.3 million, overtaking baby boomers (1946 to 1964) as the United States’ largest living generation.
lead_paragraph: 75 is the approximate number, in millions, of millennials that the United States will have this year. The total of millennials — those born from 1981 to 1997 — will reach 75.3 million, overtaking baby boomers (1946 to 1964) as the United States’ largest living generation.

headline: ScienceTake | Bats That Prey Together
abstract: For some bats eavesdropping is a way to find who is eating, and join them.
lead_paragraph: For some bats eavesdropping is a way to find who is eating, and join them.

headline: Amid the Clatter of Bats, a Call to Feed
abstract: When a greater mouse-tailed bat hears another bat hunting, it flies toward the sound, because it signals the presence of food, a study says.
lead_paragraph: Greater mouse-tailed bats live in crowded colonies in caves and also forage in groups, even though the noise from nearby bats can be distracting in using sonar to hunt prey.

headline: Electricity-Free Fountains
abstract: How did ornamental water fountains work before the availability of electricity or even steam engines to run the pumps?
lead_paragraph: Q. How did ornamental water fountains work before the availability of electricity or even steam engines to run the pumps?

headline: Growing Older, Not Happier
abstract: ‘Essays After Eighty’ is a frank collection from Donald Hall about the tarnish of the golden years amid a ‘ceremony of losses.’
lead_paragraph: In 2001, Donald Hall, just 70 and yet to be named the nation’s poet laureate or to receive the National Medal of Arts, published a poem titled “Affirmation” in The New Yorker. It began: “To grow old is to lose everything.”

headline: Do I Need Screen Time Rules for Other People’s Children, Too?
abstract: It’s my house and my rules, but I’m uncomfortable snatching away a prized possession a child brings over. I’m also uncomfortable with the recent sleepover in which every child spent the night buried in her own screen.
lead_paragraph: In our parenting Quandaries, we pull from the comments, the weekly open thread or email a question that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You, the readers, provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family?

keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']

lead_paragraph: In Atlanta, about 200 young demonstrators sat down in the middle of Peachtree Street, not far from the annual Martin Luther King's Birthday commemoration at Ebenezer Baptist Church, and briefly stopped the parade.

headline: A Ban Motivates Viktor Troicki to Return Even Stronger

lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — A year ago, Viktor Troicki was roughly halfway through a yearlong suspension for failing to provide a blood sample for a doping test.

abstract: Once again, photographers are invited to apply for a weekend of critiques and community, where they will meet with gallerists, editors and publishers. It’s free (and fun).
lead_paragraph: Once again, photographers are invited to apply for a weekend of critiques and community, where they will meet with gallerists, editors and publishers. It’s free (and fun).

headline: For D.J. Mick, a Diverted Flight Brings About a Blissful Train Ride
abstract: Mick Batyske, who performs worldwide, will do anything to get to a job on time, including taking an unexpected rail journey from Los Angeles to San Diego.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was young I didn’t fly a lot except to go see my grandparents in Naples, Fla., every summer. When I was in college I didn’t fly a lot, either. I was focused on school and on getting a good job. I used to D.J. as a hobby in the evenings to pay for graduate school. Now working as a D.J. is my career, and I fly more than 225,000 miles a year.

headline: State of the Union Speechwriter for Obama Draws on Various Inspirations
abstract: For Cody Keenan, the White House speechwriter President Obama has christened “Hemingway,” the toughest audience can be the man who will deliver the words.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One night last week Cody Keenan, the chief White House speechwriter President Obama has christened “Hemingway,” knew he needed help.

headline: Parenting Advice From ‘America’s Worst Mom’
abstract: A New York City mother embraces her leading role in a campaign to return to the days when children played and navigated through life without constant adult supervision.
lead_paragraph: Lenore Skenazy, a New York City mother of two, earned the sobriquet “America’s Worst Mom” after reporting in a newspaper column that she had allowed her younger son, then 9, to ride the subway alone.

headline: Dahesh Museum of Art, Homeless for 7 Years, Has a New Residence
abstract: The Dahesh Museum of Art will display its collection of academic European and American art from the 19th and 20th centuries at a townhouse on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: The 20-year-old Dahesh Museum of Art has a new home and a permanent exhibition space for the first time in seven years after the purchase of a townhouse at 178 East 64th Street.

headline: In Retort to Paris, Chechens Denounce ‘Permissiveness’
abstract: Tens of thousands of people marched on Monday through Grozny in a conservative retort to the mass demonstrations in France this month expressing solidarity with the victims of the terror attacks in Paris.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Tens of thousands of people marched on Monday through Grozny, the capital of the mainly Muslim Chechnya region of Russia, in a conservative retort to the mass demonstrations in France this month expressing solidarity with the victims of the terror attacks in Paris.

abstract: The attempt to reduce the value of the Danish krone is in anticipation of a policy shift by the European Central Bank that could weaken the euro.
lead_paragraph: The Danish monetary authorities lowered interest rates further into negative territory on Monday, seeking to reduce upward pressure on their currency, the krone, just days before a momentous meeting of the European Central Bank.

headline: An Age-Old Romantic Introduction, With Revitalizing Touches
abstract: The Mariinsky Ballet’s performance of “Cinderella” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music shows Alexei Ratmansky’s gifts for comic caricature but is uneven in its storytelling.
lead_paragraph: The differences between danced versions of Prokofiev’s “Romeo and Juliet” — a mainstay of ballet repertory — tend to be relatively subtle. The Capulets and the Montagues usually meet in Renaissance Verona, and the individuals tend to quarrel, laugh, fall in love and die at more or less the same passages in the music.

headline: Writing Your Way to Happiness
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Some researchers believe that by writing and then editing our own stories, we can change our perceptions of ourselves and identify obstacles that stand in the way of better health.
lead_paragraph: The scientific research on the benefits of so-called expressive writing is surprisingly vast. Studies have shown that writing about oneself and personal experiences can improve mood disorders, help reduce symptoms among cancer patients, improve a person’s health after a heart attack, reduce doctor visits and even boost memory.

headline: A Symphony and a Final Statement
abstract: The Los Angeles Philharmonic paid homage to Henryk Gorecki in a performance of his Fourth Symphony.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Henryk Gorecki’s Fourth Symphony has given me a bad rash of modernist guilt.

headline: In Paris, a New Music Hub Hums
abstract: The Philharmonie de Paris, a new concert hall, is part of a complex that officials hope will lure patrons away from their usual cultural haunts.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A crucial test for the Philharmonie de Paris, the new 2,400-seat concert hall that is now home to the Orchestre de Paris, came last Wednesday with the long-awaited and much-delayed official opening concert. But for the future of this ambitious project and, in a way, the future of classical music, the more revealing tryout came on Saturday. The Philharmonie presented a full day of free concerts, classes and workshops geared toward families in this gleaming and modern, if still unfinished complex, as well as the existing halls in what has become a de facto arts center near the northeast border of Paris.

headline: A Wry Comedy of Manners in Kentucky Coal Country
abstract: “Justified” returns to FX for its final season, and a last confrontation between the marshal and the crime boss may lie ahead.
lead_paragraph: “Justified” returns to FX on Tuesday night for a final season in the hamlets and hollers of southeastern Kentucky. It’s a show about guns, for one thing, and it’s a safe bet that the 13 episodes will build toward several O.K. Corral-style shootouts, and that these will be tense, compact and well choreographed.

headline: Make Forests Pay
keywords: ['Forests and Forestry', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Environment', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Global Warming', 'Logging Industry']
abstract: Tropical forests could be protected by selling their carbon reserves as offsets to greenhouse gas emitters.
lead_paragraph: IN the last 40 years, more than one billion acres of tropical forests have vanished, equivalent in size to over half of the continental United States. The rate of cutting, burning and clearing shows no signs of abating.

headline: A Poet’s Boyhood at the Burning Crossroads
abstract: In the wake of the deaths of James Byrd Jr. and Matthew Shepard, the process of writing poems felt like a reprieve.
lead_paragraph: The year I started writing poems, I dreamed about chains dragging along a dusty country road. It was June 1998, six months before my 13th birthday. Earlier that evening, my mother and I watched, encased in a heavy silence, as the local news station reported on the murder of James Byrd Jr. in Jasper, Tex.

headline: Stuck, but Trying to Leave
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art is screening two films by the Senegalese director Mati Diop: “Mille Soleils” and “Atlantiques.”
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of Mati Diop’s “Mille Soleils,” a man drives a herd of skinny long-horned cattle toward a slaughterhouse in a busy section of Dakar, Senegal, bringing car traffic to a halt. The incongruities within the image — animals mingling with machines, a pastoral activity in an urban setting — are intensified by the music, Tex Ritter’s “The Ballad of High Noon,” a solemn, stirring song of longing and vengeance.

headline: In the Midst of Uncertainty, Seizing the Moment in Song
abstract: Barbara Carroll extols living in the present in her latest show, in an open-ended run at Birdland.
lead_paragraph: The elegant jazz pianist Barbara Carroll opened her show at Birdland on Saturday evening with a lightly swinging performance of Irving Berlin’s “Let’s Face the Music and Dance,” a song that never loses its relevance as it seesaws between dread and exuberance. From its opening phrase, “There may be trouble ahead,” it addresses the age-old question: How is it possible to live happily in a world that often seems on the verge of collapse? The answer is the same today as it was 1936: Whenever possible, live in the moment.

headline: Indie Folk Polished to a Bright, Sly Sheen
abstract: The Decemberists, Hanni El Khatib and Duane Eubanks all have new albums out this week.
lead_paragraph: Colin Meloy, the grandiloquent bard at the heart of the Decemberists, plants his silver tongue firmly in cheek at the start of “What a Terrible World, What a Beautiful World,” the group’s new album. By way of a deadpan disclaimer titled “The Singer Addresses His Audience” — “We had to change some, you know, to belong to you,” he sings, briefing the fervent faithful — the album opens knowingly, making an end run around at least one line of critique.

headline: A Troubled Young Man Grapples With His Family’s Secrets
abstract: A young man journeys to a Brazilian beach town to confront his family’s past in Daniel Galera’s “Blood-Drenched Beard.”
lead_paragraph: Quién es más macho? The unnamed hero of Daniel Galera’s “Blood-Drenched Beard” es mas macho, in that universal phrase, at least in the scene that gives this novel its title.

headline: Fox News Becomes the Unwilling Star of a French TV Satire
abstract: Fox issued a correction and an apology after “Le Petit Journal,” a mock news program, satirized the American channel for reporting on “no-go zones” for non-Muslims.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Mockery is a national weapon in France, so when an American cable news channel raised false alarms about rampant lawlessness in some Paris neighborhoods — proclaiming them “no-go zones” for non-Muslims, avoided even by the police — a popular French television show rebutted the claims the way it best knew how: with satire, spoofs and a campaign of exaggeration and sarcasm.

headline: Shifting Politics of Net Neutrality Debate Ahead of F.C.C. Vote
keywords: ['Net Neutrality', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A simple fight over big government versus small has put Republicans in the awkward position of defending cable giants, one of the nation’s most maligned industries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last November, when President Obama proposed strict rules to prevent broadband companies from blocking or intentionally slowing down the web, Republicans pounced on what they called yet another heavy-handed liberal proposal. headline: Shock and Anger in Cambodian Village Struck With H.I.V.
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Hypodermic Needles and Syringes', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness']
abstract: More than 200 people who tested positive for H.I.V. in Roka appear to have one thing in common: an unlicensed doctor who was believed to reuse syringes.
lead_paragraph: ROKA, Cambodia — Frail and depressed after her diagnosis, Chem Mao decided to take her life by climbing a mango tree in her backyard, fastening one end of a rope around a sturdy branch and the other around her neck, and jumping. As she shuffled weakly beside her cinder-block house toward her family’s small orchard she saw her grandchildren playing nearby and relented, collapsing into tears.

The prize, which is given in six categories –– autobiography, biography, criticism, fiction, nonfiction and poetry – is one of the most prestigious American literary awards, and is judged by a panel of critics and book review editors.

headline: Support Our Students
abstract: President Obama’s well-intentioned plan on free community-college tuition misunderstands students’ genuine obstacles.
lead_paragraph: All college commencements are happy, but community-college commencements are the happiest of all. Many of the graduates are the first in their extended family to have earned degrees. When their name is read, big cheering sections erupt with horns and roars from the stands. Many students are older; you’ll see 50- or 60-year-old women grasping their diplomas awash in happy tears. The graduates often know exactly where they’re going to work; they walk with an extra sense of security as they head off campus.

Cuomo, never one to shy away from a round of gamesmanship with the Legislature, announced plans on Monday to establish a commission to study, and possibly raise, the pay of state politicians. The downside for the lawmakers: The same commission has been given the task of creating restrictions on the often lucrative outside income they earn.

headline: Canada: Troops Clash With ISIS in Iraq
abstract: Canadian soldiers exchanged fire with Islamic State fighters in Iraq over the past week, a commander said Monday.
lead_paragraph: Canadian soldiers exchanged fire with Islamic State fighters in Iraq over the past week, a commander said Monday. The officer, Brig. Gen. Michael Rouleau, the commander of Canadian special operations forces, said his troops were advising Iraqi officers “at the front lines” when the soldiers came under machine-gun and mortar fire. “That resulted in the immediate requirement to return fire,” he said. Canadian snipers, he said, then “neutralized” the fighters of the Islamic State group, also known as ISIS or ISIL. He did not say how many Canadians were involved nor did he say how many attackers were killed. As many as 69 Canadians are providing training and advice to Iraqis.

headline: China: W.H.O. Reports 3 Deaths Among Bird Flu Cases in Humans
abstract: The deaths were among serious cases of H7N9 avian flu in humans confirmed by China, the World Health Organization reported Monday.
lead_paragraph: China has confirmed 15 serious cases of H7N9 avian flu in humans, the World Health Organization reported Monday. All the people first reported symptoms in December; three have died, the rest are in critical condition. Their ages range from 20 to 78, with most over 50. All but one had a known history of exposure to live poultry. Human infections with this bird flu strain were first noticed in March 2013. Since then, there have been more than 450 cases, with the numbers spiking in winter and vanishing in summer. Thus far, the H7N9 strain has not been known to move easily between humans, although there have been some family clusters. There has been no known spread to health care workers. China has tried to fight outbreaks by shutting live poultry markets for cleaning, but legal and illegal markets continue to operate, the W.H.O. has said.

headline: Guatemala: Former Police Official Is Convicted in 1980 Embassy Siege
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The former police official was convicted of crimes against humanity and homicide in the 1980 siege of the Spanish Embassy that ended in a fire, killing 37 people.
lead_paragraph: A court on Monday convicted a former police official of crimes against humanity and homicide in the 1980 siege of the Spanish Embassy that ended in a fire, killing 37 people, including diplomats, Guatemalan politicians and student and rural activists. Among the dead was the father of the Nobel Peace laureate Rigoberta Menchú; he was a member of an indigenous group that seized the embassy to protest the military’s brutal campaign against Indian villages as part of its battle against leftist rebels. The three-judge tribunal ruled that the official, Pedro García Arredondo, 70, the leader of a special police investigative unit, cut off negotiations, ordered officers to attack the embassy and prevented anyone from leaving after the fire broke out. The cause of the fire has never been determined. Mr. García was sentenced to 90 years in prison for his actions in the embassy fire and the killing of two students at a subsequent mass funeral. He is already serving a 70-year prison sentence for his role in the 1981 disappearance of a student leader.

This one had a white dove flying across a blue background with a long red ribbon in its beak. To the dove’s left was a red flag with the hammer and sickle, the symbol of the Communist Party. headline: What’s On TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 4:30 P.M. (Starz Cinema) LAUREL CANYON (2003) Jane (Frances McDormand, above), an aging, hard-partying Los Angeles record producer, opens her California dwelling to her snobbish son (Christian Bale) and his fiancée (Kate Beckinsale), both Harvard Medical School graduates. Alessandro Nivola plays the lead singer of the rock band whose album is being overseen by Jane, who has a history of sleeping with the musicians she produces. This situation is no exception, and soon the entire family is led into temptation. “Having set up its domestic conflicts, the movie doesn’t know exactly where to go or how far, but when the inevitable emotional explosions erupt, the mutual recriminations carry a sharp sting,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this film, written and directed by Lisa Cholodenko, who said she was partly inspired by Joni Mitchell’s album “Ladies of the Canyon.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | They Don’t Need a League of Their Own
abstract: What sets the Central Illinois Xpress apart from other teams in its league?
lead_paragraph: In “Team’s Mission: Beat the Boys (and Maybe Make Them Cry),” Scott Cacciola writes about the Central Illinois Xpress, a basketball team that stands out in its fifth-grade league.

headline: What Would You Grab in a Fire?
abstract: How do you think you would react if you had to quickly evacuate your home?
lead_paragraph: People who have only a moment or two to safely grab their possessions before fleeing a fire often say they reached for sentimental items like photographs or things that once belonged to departed loved ones or things that would be costly or otherwise difficult to replace.

headline: Test Yourself | Hackers for Hire
abstract: Here are the first several paragraphs from a Jan. 15 article, “Need Some Espionage Done? Hackers Are for Hire Online.” Can you choose the best word or phrase for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Here are the first several paragraphs from a Jan. 15 article, “Need Some Espionage Done? Hackers Are for Hire Online.”

headline: North Korea Uses Defector’s Partial Retraction to Lash Out at Washington
abstract: Pyongyang said the United States should stop pressuring it over human rights, calling the defector’s reversal evidence that a United Nations report on its rights record was false.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea on Tuesday demanded that Washington stop pressuring it over human rights, citing a prominent North Korean defector’s partial recanting of his story as evidence that a United Nations report on its rights violations could not be trusted.

headline: Third Annual New York Portfolio Review
abstract: Once again, photographers are invited to apply for a weekend of critiques and community, where they will meet with gallerists, editors and publishers. It’s free (and fun).
lead_paragraph: We know how hard it is to be a photographer today and that every break counts. That’s why we are again putting together 150 photographers and 75 of the most influential editors, curators, gallerists and book publishers for two days of private photo critiques on April 11 and 12.

headline: Joel and Ethan Coen to Preside Over Cannes Film Festival
abstract: The brothers, who have a long history with the festival, will be the first co-presidents of the jury.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Joel and Ethan Coen will preside over the jury of the 68th annual Cannes International Film Festival in May, the festival announced on Tuesday.

headline: E.U. Official Urges Google to Offer Greater Concessions in Antitrust Inquiry
abstract: Günther Oettinger, the European Union’s digital economy commissioner, said that while he respected what Google’s founders had achieved, the company must honor European rules.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One of Europe’s top policy makers on Tuesday called on Google to offer more concessions in a long-standing antitrust investigation that the search giant is facing in the European Union.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Want to get the briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.

headline: Boston Mayor Says He Won’t Try to Block Referendum on Hosting 2024 Olympics
abstract: Mayor Martin J. Walsh of Boston, who still opposes holding a referendum on his city’s Olympic bid, appeared to bow to wide public support for such a vote.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Mayor Martin J. Walsh, who is not in favor of holding a referendum on Boston’s hosting the 2024 Summer Olympics, said Tuesday that he would not try to block one.

headline: As I Lay Lying: The Web Fixes Faulkner
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Computers and the Internet', 'English Language']
abstract: What to do with the most offensive word in English? The Internet has an answer: Make it disappear.
lead_paragraph: “The past is never dead,” William Faulkner wrote, rather famously. “It’s not even past.” But that was before the Internet, which can shed the past so smoothly that we don’t even notice.

headline: Nigeria’s Army of Psychopaths
abstract: The next president has to take on Boko Haram.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — Here in Nigeria’s commercial hub, it is tempting to regard Boko Haram, the Islamist terrorist group that for more than five years has waged war in the country’s far northeast, as a distant tragedy. We are, of course, aware of the fallout: the thousands of deaths, the hundreds of thousands of displaced persons, the destroyed infrastructure — schools, churches, mosques, homes, police stations — that will take years, and millions of dollars, to rebuild. But in southern Nigeria, it is easy to feel removed from the crisis.

headline: New York Today: The Airbnb Debate
abstract: Tuesday: Dueling rallies about short-term rentals, some sun, and the mayor is in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this tolerably cold Tuesday.

headline: Xi Gets a Raise, But Beijing Apartments Still Out of His Reach
abstract: Even after receiving a 62 percent raise on Tuesday, President Xi Jinping of China still makes less than the median United States wage. Fortunately for Mr. Xi, he does not have to live solely on his salary.
lead_paragraph: Xi Jinping, the leader of China, the world’s most populous country and soon to be (maybe) the planet’s biggest economy, draws a basic salary that is so low it could not cover the monthly rent at a modest Beijing apartment complex.

headline: Brioni, and a New Group of Front-Row Fans
abstract: Jack Huston, Max Irons and James Marsden are just some of the actors on the international show circuit.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — The common cry among fashion week attendees is a plaint of exhaustion and overexertion, but the most committed of front-row regulars has nothing on Jack Huston, the actor who is in “deep preproduction” in Rome for the title role in a remake of “Ben-Hur.”

headline: Daily Report: A G.O.P. About-Face in the Net Neutrality Debate
keywords: ['Cable Television', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Net Neutrality', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Republicans, who had sided with the cable giants in a fight with the president over net neutrality, are now seeking to prohibit the creation of paid “fast lanes” for Internet content providers.
lead_paragraph: Last November, when President Obama proposed strict rules to prevent broadband companies from blocking or intentionally slowing down the web, Republicans pounced on what they called yet another heavy-handed liberal proposal Jonathan Weisman reports.

headline: Shake Shack Sets Price Range for I.P.O.
abstract: The premium burger chain plans to sell five million Class A shares at $14 to $16 a share.
lead_paragraph: Moving a potential market debut further along the line, the premium burger chain Shake Shack on Tuesday priced the range of its initial public offering at $14 to $16 a share.

headline: The Ups and Downs of Tennis Doubles Who Go It Alone
abstract: The singles careers of Karolina Pliskova, who advanced to the second round of the Australian Open, and her identical twin, Kristyna, who lost in the qualifying tournament, have diverged.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Andy Murray’s appreciation for women’s tennis is not limited to his decision to hire Amélie Mauresmo as his coach; he also regularly watches the women’s game. Last week, Karolina Pliskova, a lanky Czech with torpid footwork but impeccable timing, caught his eye during her run to the final in Sydney.

headline: French Premier Says ‘Apartheid’ Is Leaving Minorities on the Fringe
abstract: Prime Minister Manuel Valls said that France, even while fighting terrorism, must address a deeply rooted divide that has stoked tensions in immigrant communities.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Prime Minister Manuel Valls of France on Tuesday cited a deep divide in the country, likening it to a state of “territorial, social, ethnic apartheid” that has left part of the population on the cultural fringe.

headline: Porch.com Raises $65 Million in Financing
keywords: ['Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Venture Capital']

lead_paragraph: Over its two years of existence, Porch.com has amassed huge amounts of data from customers who turn to the start-up to find home improvement professionals.

headline: Morning Agenda: Davos Takes Up Gay Rights
abstract: The issue of gay rights is on the formal agenda for Davos. | Regulatory actions in China hit shares. | PepsiCo and Nelson Peltz announce a truce. | The apparent murder of a hedge fund manager by his son and the price of privilege.
lead_paragraph: Anything related to gay and lesbian rights has long seemed to have been officially off limits at the World Economic Forum annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland. But this year, for the first time, the World Economic Forum is addressing the issue on the formal agenda for Davos. And while this may be a “good first step,” the topic nevertheless “looks buried on the Davos program,” Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook Column.

headline: Results Disappoint, but Profit at Morgan Stanley Increases
abstract: Legal expenses declined in the fourth quarter of 2014, but the bank struggled with difficult trading conditions.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley reported lower than expected quarterly profits on Tuesday, suggesting that the bank’s effort to rebuild itself into a more reliably profitable enterprise is going more slowly than expected.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Pays His Respects in Paris After Attacks
abstract: After a meeting with Jewish leaders in the French capital, Mayor Bill de Blasio said New York City and Paris both “understand what it is to fight back” against terror.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The bouquets lay beside the sprawling memorial at the Hyper Cacher grocery store in eastern Paris, labeled simply enough for any guest to understand.

headline: Beijing Investigating Detention of 100 Chinese in Myanmar
abstract: A spokesman for Beijing’s embassy in Myanmar said the Chinese nationals had been detained on suspicion that they entered the country to engage in logging.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese government is investigating the detention of more than 100 Chinese citizens by Myanmar on suspicion that they entered the country to engage in logging, a spokesman for the Chinese Embassy in Myanmar said Tuesday.

headline: In Performance: Tony Danza and Jason Robert Brown of ‘Honeymoon in Vegas’
abstract: Mr. Danza sings a musical number — and does some tap dancing — from the new Broadway musical, with the show’s composer, Jason Robert Brown, on piano.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Tony Danza sings the number “A Little Luck” from the new Broadway musical “Honeymoon in Vegas,” based on the 1992 film. The show’s composer, Jason Robert Brown, accompanies him on piano. And in a first for this series, Mr. Danza, who plays a high-stakes gambler in the show, performs some crackerjack tap dancing. “Honeymoon in Vegas,” directed by Gary Griffin, is at the Nederlander Theater.

headline: A Lineup of Missteps
abstract: An extra-large helping of lapses.
lead_paragraph: This week, an extra-large grab bag of grammar, style and other lapses, compiled with help from colleagues and readers.

headline: Twitter Acquires ZipDial, an Indian Start-Up
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Start-ups']

lead_paragraph: Twitter said on Tuesday that it had acquired ZipDial, a nearly five-year-old Indian start-up that aims to help businesses connect with customers in emerging markets who may not have access to the Internet.

headline: A Cover-Up, of Sorts, at a Tabloid in Britain
abstract: After more than 40 years of running pictures of topless women on Page 3, The Sun, Britain’s best-selling newspaper, has put some clothes on its models.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After more than 40 years of running a picture of a topless woman almost daily on its Page 3, The Sun, Britain’s raucous and best-selling newspaper, appears to have given in to changing social attitudes.

headline: Restaurant Report: Char in Singapore
abstract: Two brothers are quietly trying to revolutionize the island’s Chinese-style roast meat scene.
lead_paragraph: Along a sleepy stretch not far from the dark alleys of the often seedy Geylang neighborhood, two brothers are quietly trying to revolutionize Singapore’s roast meat scene. Char, a cozy 70-seater, opened last January with Chinese-style roast meats being the stars of the menu — specifically traditional meats like char siew (roast pork) and siew yoke (crispy roast pork belly), but done in somewhat untraditional ways.

headline: A Trot, Not a Gallop, Toward Renewal in Lexington, KY.
abstract: National Avenue has transformed into a walkable district for shopping, dining and even practicing yoga.
lead_paragraph: Residents of Mentelle, a neighborhood on the east side of Lexington, Ky., once drove right past National Avenue, a half-mile street hemmed in by railroad tracks and the hum of traffic on U.S. 60.

headline: In South Africa, Fine-Art Landscapes for Postcard Prices
abstract: Along Route 62 — popular with locals but virtually unknown to foreign visitors — there are plenty of towns with laid-back, eccentric states of mind and very reasonable prices.
lead_paragraph: Last month, driving along Route 62 through Montagu, in South Africa’s Western Cape province, my friend Sabiha and I spied a sign announcing a “car boot sale” — a sort of roadside flea market. We didn’t pause to confer: They had us at “sale.”

headline: Brawl Disrupts Drafting of Constitution in Nepal
abstract: Maoist opposition leaders threw chairs and microphones at members of the governing parties during negotiations, wounding about a dozen security guards.
lead_paragraph: KATMANDU, Nepal — Maoist opposition leaders in Nepal threw chairs and microphones at members of the governing parties on Tuesday at a meeting of lawmakers working to draft a Constitution on deadline. Three lawmakers and about a dozen security guards were wounded.

headline: ‘Koch Primary’ Tests Hopefuls In the G.O.P.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky went to Kansas last year to campaign for Gov. Sam Brownback, he quietly requested a private meeting with the oil billionaire Charles G. Koch in his Wichita headquarters.

keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shopping and Retail']

keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Charter Schools', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)']
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is expected to seek changes to teacher evaluations and charter school limits, putting him in direct conflict with teachers’ unions.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has been laying the groundwork for an aggressive education agenda as he begins his second term, signaling that he will seek several major changes that, atypically for a Democrat, will put him in direct conflict with teachers’ unions.

headline: Among Snowden Leaks, Details of Chinese Cyberespionage
abstract: Edward J. Snowden, who was lauded for leaking N.S.A. materials, may have lost a little of his shine among Chinese leaders after his latest revelations gave details of Beijing’s own misdeeds.
lead_paragraph: Edward J. Snowden, the former contractor for the National Security Agency whose revelations of American cyberspying were widely praised in China’s state media, may have lost a little of his shine among Chinese leaders after his latest revelations gave details of Beijing’s own cyberespionage.

headline: 1890: Prince Bismarck’s Policy
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1890: Prince Bismarck’s Policy towards Great Britain.
lead_paragraph: CONSTANTINOPLE — Some interesting information has been given me by a high official which throws a curious light on the tricks and manners of Prince Bismarck at this Court. In 1885, when war between Russia and Great Britain seemed to be imminent, Prince Bismarck’s hostility to Mr. Gladstone’s Government was so notorious that there is nothing surprising in the fact that Baron Radowitz, the Prussian Ambassador, received instructions at that time to press upon the Porte the imperative necessity of refusing the British fleet a free passage through the Dardanelles in the event of war between Russia and Great Britain. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 21, 1890

headline: Hong Kong Tycoon Li Ka-shing to Buy British Passenger Train Provider

lead_paragraph: LONDON – Li Ka-shing, Asia’s richest man, has added a major passenger train provider in Britain to his vast empire of corporate holdings, which includes ports, utilities and retail stores.

abstract: Kenyan officials said they were looking into the conduct of police officers who tear-gassed elementary schoolchildren at a protest over a playground.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Kenyan officials said Tuesday that they had opened a major internal investigation into the conduct of police officers who tear-gassed elementary schoolchildren during a protest over a playground, an episode that drew widespread condemnation.

headline: Texas’ New Governor Echoes the Plans of Perry
abstract: Greg Abbott, who served as state attorney general under Rick Perry, has championed and defended his conservative initiatives.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Greg Abbott, the first new governor of Texas in more than a decade, was sworn in here Tuesday as he prepared to lead the state at a time of economic anxiety, partisan divisions and shifting demographics, and he appeared poised to continue the policies of his predecessor, Rick Perry.

headline: ISIS Has Executed Scores in Iraq This Month, U.N. Says
abstract: Reports include the slaying of soldiers, doctors, lawyers, women and children in a reign of terror throughout regions under Islamic State control.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Islamic State extremists have carried out scores of execution-style killings in Iraq this month, the United Nations said on Tuesday, reporting “cruel and inhuman” punishment of men, women and children in areas under their control.

headline: First Draft Focus: Running Through Her Lines
abstract: Senator Joni Ernst, a freshman Republican from Iowa, rehearsed her response to the State of the Union address in the Russell Senate Office Building on Tuesday.

headline: At Ferragamo, Fendi and Etro: The Good Earth
abstract: The dirt and leaves of Milan’s runways are reflected in the fall men’s styles.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Pity the well-shod in Milan this week. Men’s wear editors and retailers — a population given to expensive shoes — have been confronted with runways unpaved and laid with all manner of sole-scuffing irritants. At Stefano Pilati’s show for Ermenegildo Zegna on Saturday, one tramped through dirt to arrive at a seat; at John Varvatos the next day, there was a damp blanket of fall leaves; at Salvatore Ferragamo the day after, more earth. One is an exception and two is a coincidence, but three, as the singsong saw goes, is a trend.

lead_paragraph: The Mercado Victoria in Cordoba, Spain, may be open from 9 a.m. every day, but if would-be diners arrive before noon, they may be eating solo.

headline: Unlocking Scrolls Preserved in Eruption of Vesuvius, Using X-Ray Beams
abstract: Researchers say that for the first time, they can read letters inside the scrolls without unrolling them, by using a laserlike beam of X-rays.
lead_paragraph: Researchers have found a key that may unlock the only library of classical antiquity to survive along with its documents, raising at least a possibility of recovering vanished works of ancient Greek and Roman authors such as the lost books of Livy’s history of Rome.

headline: Coup Fears Rise in Yemen as Rebels Storm Palace
abstract: The turmoil worries U.S. officials because Yemen is the base of Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, which claimed responsibility for the attack on the Charlie Hebdo newspaper in Paris.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — Houthi rebel militiamen seized control of the palace of Yemen’s president and clashed with guards outside his residence on Tuesday in an escalation of the violent crisis that has gripped the capital for days, raising fears of a coup in one of the Arab world’s most impoverished and insecure states.

headline: Justin Bieber Gets Comedy Central Roast
abstract: The pop star will headline the event.
lead_paragraph: Justin Bieber, the multiplatinum-selling singer and living public service announcement for why young men require powerful adult role models and high automobile insurance rates, does a pretty good job of making fun of himself. Even so, Comedy Central has determined that television viewers needed an event where this 20-year-old pop heartthrob would be made fun of to his face (and could laugh at himself), and has announced that Mr. Bieber will be the headliner and guest of honor at its next “Comedy Central Roast.”

lead_paragraph: Part 14: The stars of “The Theory of Everything” reveal the biggest thing that can go wrong for an actor on the first day of a film shoot.
