abstract: Part 11: The stars of “The Theory of Everything” explain the long-term effects that the physicality of Eddie Redmayne’s performance had on him.
lead_paragraph: Part 11: The stars of “The Theory of Everything” explain the long-term effects that the physicality of Eddie Redmayne’s performance had on him.

headline: Redmayne & Jones: You Just Cope With It
abstract: Part 13: The stars of “The Theory of Everything” reflect on what they learned about humor from A.L.S. patients.
lead_paragraph: Part 13: The stars of “The Theory of Everything” reflect on what they learned about humor from A.L.S. patients.

headline: Which Literary Figure Is Overdue for a Biography?
abstract: Thomas Mallon and Ayana Mathis on authors whose life stories should be told.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Thomas Mallon and Ayana Mathis on authors whose life stories should be told.

headline: After Frida Giannini’s Departure, a Brand-New Men’s Collection at Gucci
abstract: It took only about a week to change the clothes, the models and even the show's seating plan.
lead_paragraph: By all outward signs — the location, on Piazza Oberdan, the milling crowds of gawkers and photographers outside, even the champagne-bearing waiters in the lacquered black atrium within — there was nothing unusual about the Gucci men’s wear show Monday.

headline: Prosecutors in Poland Send Polanski Extradition Request to Court
abstract: The prosecutors’ office in Krakow says a request by the United States for the extradition of the director Roman Polanski can proceed.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Polish prosecutors on Tuesday forwarded a request for the extradition of the director Roman Polanski to the United States, over a 1977 conviction for having sex with a 13-year-old girl, to the district court in Krakow.

headline: An Epic, Space-Bound New Album from the L.A. Musician Jack Name
abstract: The subject matter on the artist’s new LP is inspired by werewolves, the moons of Jupiter and Name’s own cancer diagnosis and treatment.
lead_paragraph: “Maybe it’s a strange thing to be a concept album person, but it’s just the way my brain works. I like long, epic, ridiculous things,” says the Los Angeles-based musician Jack Name, a former member of the cult-favorite San Francisco psychedelic band White Fence whose latest LP, “Weird Moons,” is out today via Castle Face Records. On his last record, 2014’s “Light Show,” Name revealed a twisted battle between light and shadows, the subtext of which was a criticism of the use of prescription drugs to suppress children’s creativity. The concept of “Weird Moons” is even more eccentric: a posthumous space trip in which the album’s protagonists transform into werewolves and then shape-shift depending on their proximity to each of Jupiter’s 67 moons.

headline: Meeting the Baby, Becoming a Family
abstract: From the moment we met our daughter, weighing two-and-a-half pounds and wearing a red bow pasted on her head, we could tell she was the fighter and “rock star” we’d been told about.
lead_paragraph: I’ve never been a big believer in “signs from above” or cosmic signals or any of that flimflam. But the package I saw on my doorstep on Jan. 6 gave me pause: a free sample of Enfamil formula.

headline: 2 Wall Street Deal Makers Form an Activist Fund With a Twist
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Hedge Funds', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: Douglas L. Braunstein and James C. Woolery plan to work hand-in-hand with management and boards rather than threatening to wage proxy fights.
lead_paragraph: For years, Douglas L. Braunstein and James C. Woolery advised companies on how to defend themselves against activist investors. Now the two veteran Wall Street advisers plan to become shareholder activists themselves.

headline: 1915: Zeppelin Raid Targets Royals
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A German zeppelin bombards England’s King and Queen at their country home in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The long-talked of Zeppelin air raid upon England is an accomplished fact. German airships, probably starting from Cuxhaven, came up over the North Sea to strike coward blows at undefended towns in East Anglia, on their way to bombard England’s King and Queen, at Sandringham, their Norfolk country home. The raiders dropped bombs at Yarmouth, Sheringham, King’s Lynn, Beeston, Dersingham, Grimston and Snettisham, with the result that several persons were killed and several injured, women and children among the number. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 21, 1915

headline: Doctor Critically Wounded in Boston Hospital Shooting, Police Say
abstract: Officials said the gunman targeted a particular doctor at Boston’s Brigham and Women’s Hospital, then took his own life.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — A man walked into a prestigious Boston hospital on Tuesday, asked for a particular doctor and then shot him twice before taking his own life, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Analysis of Obama’s State of the Union Address
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama will deliver his State of the Union address Tuesday night, outlining his agenda in front of a joint session of Congress fully controlled by Republicans for the first time in his presidency.
lead_paragraph: President Obama delivered his State of the Union address on Tuesday night, outlining his agenda in front of a joint session of Congress, which is fully controlled by Republicans for the first time in his presidency.

headline: Ban on Prison Beards Violates Muslim Rights, Supreme Court Says
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Beards and Mustaches', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Freedom of Religion']
abstract: The justices unanimously rejected arguments by Arkansas prison officials that said allowing beards would make it easier for inmates to hide contraband.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday unanimously ruled that Arkansas corrections officials had violated the religious liberty rights of Muslim inmates by forbidding them to grow beards.

headline: A Counterculture Spirit Flourishes, Preserved Under Fiberglass Domes
abstract: A 1970s experiment in communal housing at the University of California, Davis, continues to draw students with its sustainable, grow-your-own ethos.
lead_paragraph: DAVIS, Calif. — The trill of panpipes from a yurt wafted across the mulch hillocks of the Domes, a 1970s experiment in communal housing in which students live in igloolike fiberglass domes and snuggle up in snow-white interiors of plastic foam.

headline: Cuomo Wants Elevated Train Link Built to Ill-Served La Guardia Airport
abstract: The train, which would connect with the No. 7 subway line and the Long Island Rail Road, would be the first mass transit link to the Queens airport.
lead_paragraph: It is a struggle known to generations of weary air travelers: the traffic-choked, anxiety-laden trip to La Guardia Airport, heartbeats and taxi meters rising in unison.

headline: Fallout Builds From Ruling on Insider Trading
abstract: A court’s reversal of two insider trading convictions has been the equivalent of dropping a big rock into a calm lake as the waves spread to other cases, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: An appeals court decision in December that reversed the insider trading convictions of two hedge fund managers has been the equivalent of dropping a big rock into a calm lake as the waves keep spreading to other cases. The Justice Department is fighting to minimize the impact of the opinion, which raised the bar on what the government must show to establish a violation for trading on confidential information.

headline: De Blasio Pays Tribute to Paris Victims
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York, honoring victims in Paris, said the recent terror attack in the city was a “turning point” like Sept. 11.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York, honoring victims in Paris, said the recent terror attack in the city was a “turning point” like Sept. 11.

headline: Insurgents Attack Yemeni President
abstract: The president of Yemen, Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi, was believed to be inside the presidential palace when it was attacked by insurgents. It was not immediately clear if he was safe.
lead_paragraph: The president of Yemen, Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi, was believed to be inside the presidential palace when it was attacked by insurgents. It was not immediately clear if he was safe.

headline: Japan Calls ISIS Acts ‘Unforgivable’
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan responded to the ISIS video showing two Japanese hostages, calling the Islamic State’s methods “unforgivable.”
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan responded to the ISIS video showing two Japanese hostages, calling the Islamic State’s methods “unforgivable.”

headline: Israeli Government Watchdog Investigates Military’s Conduct in Gaza War
abstract: The announcement by the state comptroller was Israel’s latest effort to head off an International Criminal Court inquiry into its actions in the war last summer with Hamas.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s government watchdog, the state comptroller, said on Tuesday that he had opened an investigation into decisions made by military and political leaders during last summer’s 50-day war with the Hamas militant group in Gaza.

headline: To Invest, or Not, as China Shifts
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Foreign Investments']
abstract: A slowdown in the pace of growth of China’s economy is leading foreign investors to reassess the country as a destination for their money.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — On a tour of central Henan Province in May of last year, China’s president, Xi Jinping, first raised the notion of the economy adjusting to a “new normal.” Eight months later, with the economy growing at its slowest pace in more than two decades, it is increasingly clear what this adjustment will mean for China.

headline: Tempering a Worldview With Freedom and Fairness
abstract: Free enterprise and globalization are the cornerstones of the worldview at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, but there should be a dose of fairness as well.
lead_paragraph: How is it possible to construct a free-market economy that is also fair? That should be the central question for this year’s annual gathering of the global elite at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

headline: Misha Nonoo’s Adventures in Beijing
abstract: The New York-based designer recently took an inspiration-seeking trip to the Chinese city. Here, she discusses what caught her eye.
lead_paragraph: As a designer in the CFDA Fashion Incubator, an initiative supported by W Hotels Worldwide that fosters young fashion brands, Misha Nonoo was given a round-trip ticket to travel abroad this winter to seek inspiration for her forthcoming resort and spring 2016 collections. She spun the globe and put her finger on Beijing. “I’ve always been fascinated by the Great Wall and the immense history of Beijing,” she says. “And now that China has the number-one economy, I was curious to see how it would change in the future.” Having grown up in Bahrain and London before moving to Paris and later New York, Nonoo has something of a gypsy spirit, which is often evident in her collections. For spring 2013, she nodded to Havana’s languid climes with crisp white silhouettes and colorful prints, while the following season she featured a palette of black-and-red fabrics and furry hats reminiscent of a trip to the Russian countryside.

headline: AirAsia Jet Climbed Too Fast, Inquiry Finds
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AirAsia Flight 8501', 'Recording Equipment']
abstract: The passenger jet, which normally ascends at 1,000 to 2,000 feet per minute, was climbing at about 6,000 feet per minute, Indonesian investigators said.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The AirAsia plane that crashed into the Java Sea last month had climbed at excessive speeds to an unusually high altitude before plunging and disappearing from radar, Indonesia’s top transportation official said Tuesday.

headline: The Art of Matching Actor and Role
abstract: Ellen Lewis, who is being honored by the Casting Society of America for her work on films like “Goodfellas” and “Forrest Gump,” talks about the changes she’s seen in her profession.
lead_paragraph: For almost three decades, the Casting Society of America’s annual Artios Awards, which recognize achievement in the often overlooked profession of casting, have been announced long after the Oscars, making the casting directors seem less relevant to the awards season conversation. But after the 2013 documentary “Casting By” questioned why there wasn’t a dedicated category at the Academy Awards, the society moved its ceremony, putting it in line with the similar events of guilds and other Hollywood organizations. The 30th Artios awards will take place Thursday, in both New York City (with Michael Urie as host) and Los Angeles (with Patton Oswalt doing the honors).

headline: Keeping a Lid on What Happens in Davos
abstract: Stung by past criticism, organizers of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, are making an effort to rein in opulent events.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — It was a parable in the unwritten rules of Davos party-giving.

headline: Who Are the Houthis of Yemen?
abstract: The Houthis are part of a Shiite rebel group from northwestern Yemen that has been battling U.S.-allied government and Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula.
lead_paragraph: The Houthis, an insurgent group based in northwestern Yemen, won major concessions from the country’s president Wednesday after its militiamen besieged the presidential palace in Sana. President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi’s accession to the group’s demands defused a violent standoff in the capital that raised fears about the stability of the government.

headline: Cross-Dressing in Pakistan
abstract: In a conservative Islamic nation, some Pakistanis attempt to balance two identities.
lead_paragraph: In a conservative Islamic nation, some Pakistanis attempt to balance two identities.

headline: Butter & Scotch Combines Cupcakes and Cocktails
abstract: Allison Kave and Keavy Blueher are collaborating on a retro-style cafe and bar; a kale and walnut pesto; black garlic; and more.
lead_paragraph: To Indulge: Cupcakes and Cocktails Are on the Menu

headline: Echoes of Piketty in Obama Proposal to Address Income Inequality
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Income Tax', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The White House proposal to tax gifts and bequests is carefully aimed at the top 1 percent, Victor Fleischer writes in the Standard Deduction column.
lead_paragraph: At the end of his book “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” Thomas Piketty proposes a global wealth tax to help address the problem of runaway income inequality. In contrast with the careful research that went into the book, the suggestion of a global wealth tax struck many tax policy veterans as naïve and unhelpful.

headline: Exposure Offers Clarity in the Risky World of Investing
abstract: By understanding and evaluating our exposure, we can gain valuable control over our lives when the world is seemingly out of control.
lead_paragraph: Last week, a conversation with a friend reminded me how easily we can confuse actual risk with our own exposure to that risk. My friend travels a lot for work, and I asked him where he planned to go this year. His answer surprised me. “I don’t know,” he replied. “With everything going on in the world, I’m not sure I want to travel as much.”

headline: Rival Suitor for New York Clearinghouse Raises Bid
abstract: The Howard Lutnick-led brokerage firm BGC Partners raises its bid to $6.10 a share for the GFI Group, seeking to block the CME Group.
lead_paragraph: BGC Partners has increased its offer for the GFI Group, the New York brokerage firm and clearinghouse, in an effort to wrest the company from the arms of its chosen suitor, the operator of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade.

headline: Stratford Festival Mainstay Will Be New Star of ‘Beautiful’ on Broadway
abstract: Chilina Kennedy will succeed Jessie Mueller, who won a Tony Award in the role of Carole King.
lead_paragraph: Chilina Kennedy, who previously starred on Broadway in “Jesus Christ Superstar,” will take over the title role of “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical” on March 7. Ms. Kennedy has big shoes to fill: she is replacing Jessie Mueller, who won a Tony Award in June for her performance as the seminal singer-songwriter.

headline: The State of the Union and the Minimum Wage
abstract: President Obama should abandon the $10.10 benchmark in favor of a bolder goal that is in keeping with economic and political realities — and with his promise to restore the middle class.
lead_paragraph: In his State of the Union speech on tonight, President Obama is expected to again call on Congress to raise the federal minimum wage. His case is unassailable. The minimum was last updated eight years ago, when lawmakers passed a plan to raise it in steps to $7.25 in 2009. That level was too low even back then. And with each passing year, its inadequacy becomes more apparent. The economic underclass is growing, the economy is becoming more unequal and taxpayers are being forced to subsidize low-wage employers by providing public aid to underpaid workers.

headline: In State of the Union, Obama Sets an Ambitious Agenda
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama defended an activist federal government and challenged Republicans to support him on education, child care and middle-class tax breaks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama claimed credit on Tuesday for an improving economy and defiantly told his Republican adversaries in Congress to “turn the page” by supporting an expensive domestic agenda aimed at improving the fortunes of the middle class.

headline: Christie’s Reports Strong Numbers for Postwar and Contemporary Art
abstract: The auction house’s total art sales in 2014 rose 12 percent over its 2013 sales.
lead_paragraph: The London-based auction house Christie’s said its 2014 art sales totaled 5.1 billion pounds, or about $7.7 billion, a 12 percent increase over 2013. Growth at Christie’s was led by postwar and contemporary art, which contributed £1.7 billion (about $2.6 billion) of the year’s £4.2 billion ($6.4 billion) in public sales.

headline: Brennan’s
abstract: The famed New Orleans restaurant gets new owners and a face-lift.
lead_paragraph: The famed New Orleans restaurant gets new owners and a face-lift.

headline: Brennan’s in New Orleans Walks the Tightrope of Tradition
abstract: The French Quarter restaurant, which was founded in 1946, is trying to overcome years of family dissent, and it starts with breakfast.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The busiest meal of the day is still breakfast, which for many customers still begins with a cocktail and ends with dessert. At tableside trolleys inside the many dining rooms, bananas still go up in flames every few minutes. The stucco facade on Royal Street in the French Quarter is still pink, although the paint manufacturer prefers to call it Tomato Cream Sauce. (The trim color is Mayonnaise.)

headline: Better but Still Troubled: Our Take on the State of the Union
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Global Warming', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Job growth is up, and the deficit is down. But incomes are not doing so well, and neither is the climate.
lead_paragraph: President Obama isn’t going to offer an objective overview of the country when he delivers his sixth annual address to Congress on Tuesday night. No president does so in a State of the Union. He will instead emphasize the positive, mostly elide the negative and take a few wry digs at the other political party.

headline: Life in the Domes
abstract: The counterculture still thrives at an alternative housing community at the University of California, Davis.
lead_paragraph: The counterculture still thrives at an alternative housing community at the University of California, Davis.

headline: Sororities Should Throw Parties
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Fraternities and Sororities', 'Women and Girls', 'Sex Crimes', 'Colleges and Universities', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Parties (Social)', 'Alcohol Abuse']
abstract: A nighttime alternative to frat parties could help improve safety on college campuses.
lead_paragraph: With campus sexual assault a major topic of national concern and conversation, universities are experimenting with ways to reduce sexual violence. One popular strategy is to crack down on fraternities. The University of Virginia, for instance, suspended frat activities after the publication of the now-discredited Rolling Stone story on the gang rape of a freshman; then it announced new safety measures, including a rule stipulating that at least three “sober and lucid” frat members monitor parties. Clemson, Emory and Johns Hopkins, among others, have also moved to curtail Greek mayhem.

headline: Cooking With Kimchi
abstract: Home cooks would do well to explore the preserved vegetable preparation. Kimchi is not just pickled vegetables; it’s Korean soul food.
lead_paragraph: Ask any native or transplanted Koreans about kimchi and you will be told that it is the very backbone of Korean cuisine. It is a cultural necessity, eaten enthusiastically at every meal, and daily life is unimaginable without it.

headline: ‘Guantánamo Diary,’ by Mohamedou Ould Slahi
abstract: “Guantánamo Diary” is a profound account by a current detainee of what it’s like to be collateral damage in the war against terror.
lead_paragraph: On or about Sept. 11, 2001, American character changed. What Americans had proudly flaunted as “our highest values” were now judged to be luxuries that in a new time of peril the country could ill afford. Justice, and its cardinal principle of innocent until proven guilty, became a risk, its indulgence a weakness. Asked recently about an innocent man who had been tortured to death in an American “black site” in Afghanistan, former Vice President Dick Cheney did not hesitate. “I’m more concerned,” he said, “with bad guys who got out and released than I am with a few that, in fact, were innocent.” In this new era in which all would be sacrificed to protect the country, torture and even murder of the innocent must be counted simply “collateral damage.”

headline: Modernism on a Religious Kick, Monolithic Egyptian Sculpture and More from the Art Calendar
abstract: Plus, work from Thailand, Syria and Iran, and more happenings to see in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: T’s list of happenings worth visiting in the week ahead.

headline: ‘Clinton the Musical’ Is Definitely Running Off Broadway
abstract: “Clinton the Musical,” which portrays Bill Clinton as mired in scandal and a politically ambitious Hillary Rodham Clinton, will begin performances in March.
lead_paragraph: For those who can’t get enough of Bill and Hillary Clinton – or want to see them lampooned in the tawdriest way possible – the stage satire “Clinton the Musical” is getting an open-ended commercial run at Off Broadway’s New World Stages complex, the producers announced on Tuesday. The show, which had a brief outing last summer in the New York Musical Theater Festival, focuses mostly on scandals in the Clinton administration (Monica Lewinsky features prominently) and splits the president into two characters – the diligent WJ and the roguish Billy – while portraying Mrs. Clinton’s character as politically ambitious.

headline: More Work to Be Done at Morgan Stanley
abstract: A dismal fourth quarter has exposed cracks that the chief of the Wall Street firm, James Gorman, still needs to fix, writes Antony Currie of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley has rained on its own parade. The Wall Street firm was progressing nicely in the first nine months of 2014. But a dismal fourth quarter exposed cracks that its boss, James P. Gorman, still needs to fix.

headline: Scaling El Capitan, for Your Browser
keywords: ['3-D Devices and Effects', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Photography', 'Rock Climbing']
abstract: Shan Carter, a graphics editor, details how researcher data was used to create a 3-D model of El Capitan for Times readers to view online.
lead_paragraph: Tommy Caldwell and Kevin Jorgeson, two highly skilled rock climbers, completed their trek to the top of El Capitan, in Yosemite National Park, last week.

headline: First Draft Focus: Back to the Capitol for Reid
abstract: The Senate minority leader, Harry Reid, walked to a Democratic luncheon on Tuesday as he returned to the Senate for the first time since suffering injuries in an exercise accident on Jan. 1.

headline: A Long Haul to the Top of El Capitan
keywords: ['Hikes and Hiking', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Rock Climbing', 'Text Messaging']
abstract: John Branch, a sports reporter, describes chronicling the 19-day climb of Tommy Caldwell and Kevin Jorgeson.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Tommy Caldwell and Kevin Jorgeson climbed to the summit of El Capitan, in Yosemite National Park, by way of the Dawn Wall, the rock formation’s most challenging route.

headline: ‘The Heart of Robin Hood’ Delays Plans for Broadway
abstract: The play will extend its run in Toronto; advance sales for a Broadway run have been sluggish.
lead_paragraph: The springtime Broadway production of the new play “The Heart of Robin Hood” has been postponed, its producers announced on Tuesday. The decision appears to have come down to ticket sales: The show, an athletic, spectacle-driven reimagining of the Robin Hood story, is selling well for its current Toronto production, but two New York group sales agents said that seats for the Broadway run haven’t been snatched up in droves. The two sales agents spoke on condition of anonymity to describe confidential sales information.

headline: From The Upshot: The State of the Union
abstract: The Upshot is offering its own take on the state of the union.
lead_paragraph: Better but Still Troubled: Our Take on the State of the Union

headline: My Very Educated Readers, Please Write Us a New Planet Mnemonic
abstract: If dwarf planets are considered actual planets, the mnemonic device for remembering their order will need to be rewritten. We are taking suggestions.
lead_paragraph: When Pluto was demoted from planethood, the trusty mnemonic “My Very Educated Mother Just Served Us Nine Pizzas” lost its main dish. Teachers and students across the world came up with adjustments. “My Very Educated Mother Just Served Us Noodles” was an easy tweak. Others revamped the mnemonic entirely — “Mean Very Evil Men Just Shortened Up Nature” was the offering of Caltech astronomy professor Mike Brown.

headline: A Sales Bump for ‘Honeymoon in Vegas’ on Broadway
abstract: Ticket sales for the new musical tripled over the weekend, after the show’s largely positive reviews came out.
lead_paragraph: It’s too soon to say if the new Broadway musical “Honeymoon in Vegas” will be able to capitalize on its mostly positive reviews last Thursday and turn around its lackluster ticket sales during recent weeks of preview performances. But ticket sales did almost triple last weekend, a spokesman for the producers said on Tuesday, though the producers declined to provide dollar amounts that would put that box-office jump in context. Meanwhile, according to ticket-sale data released on Tuesday, “Honeymoon in Vegas” – a musical adaptation of the 1992 film comedy of the same name – grossed a modest $440,476 last week, or 43 percent of the maximum possible amount.

headline: Whether Patriots Used Deflated Footballs Is a Question of Logistics
abstract: Gil Brandt, a former Cowboys executive and an analyst for N.F.L. Media, addressed how and why a team might deliberately deflate footballs for a competitive edge.
lead_paragraph: This season’s N.F.L. playoffs have had it all: overtime thrillers, disputed penalties, trick plays. But with one game remaining in the season, the league must now grapple with an odd question: Did the Patriots deflate some of their game balls in the A.F.C. championship game Sunday against the Indianapolis Colts?

headline: India’s Rebounding Tiger Population Grows 30 Percent in 4 Years
abstract: The increase, reported in a new census by the Indian government, comes after a decade-long effort to mitigate poaching.
lead_paragraph: India’s tiger population has rebounded, growing more than 30 percent over the last four years to 2,226, according to a new government census released on Tuesday.

headline: Palestinian Authority Gives Partial Salaries to Employees
abstract: The authority said it had taken out loans to cover a shortfall caused by Israel’s withholding tax revenue it collects on the Palestinians’ behalf.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Palestinian Authority has paid its employees 60 percent of their December salaries, using loans to make up for a shortfall caused by Israel’s withholding of $127 million in tax revenue it collects on the Palestinians’ behalf.

headline: Milan Street Style
abstract: Fashionable men and women flock to Milan for the men’s fall 2015 collection shows.
lead_paragraph: Fashionable men and women flock to Milan for the men’s fall 2015 collection shows.

headline: ‘Cinderella’ Sets: No Place for Pumpkins
abstract: A ballet’s classic roots evoked in an architectural backdrop right out of the Enlightenment.
lead_paragraph: When the Mariinsky Ballet brought Alexei Ratmansky’s “Cinderella” to the Brooklyn Academy of Music last weekend for its New York premiere, its arrival seemed like a homecoming. The drop curtain, painted with the silhouette of a jagged skyline that could be Manhattan or Downtown Brooklyn, rose to reveal a pair of three-story scaffolds recalling New York’s fire escapes. Two black columns punctuated the stage. The set was edgy and urban — no place for pumpkins.

headline: Zuma, Mixing East and West, Is Opening on Madison Avenue
abstract: A Japanese restaurant group introduces a New York branch; Masseria dei Vini is an uptown version of La Masseria; and other openings and chef switches.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: The Editorial Board’s State of the Union Wish List
abstract: There is even less suspense about this year’s address than usual. But here’s what we’d like to hear.
lead_paragraph: There is even less suspense about this year’s State of the Union than usual. The White House has been frantically briefing news organizations about the proposals President Obama is going to make tonight – and in any case it’s extremely likely (perhaps certain?) that his entire agenda will be dead on arrival in the Republican-controlled Congress. Sometimes I think that if Mr. Obama proposed repealing the Affordable Care Act the Republicans would reflexively reject him.

headline: L.R.A. Commander Ongwen Heads to Face Charges in Hague
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Dominic Ongwen, a senior commander in the Lord’s Resistance Army, was charged in 2005 with crimes against humanity and war crimes.
lead_paragraph: A notorious Ugandan rebel commander accused of kidnapping children and planning massacres is on his way to face charges of crimes against humanity at the International Criminal Court in The Hague, court officials announced Tuesday.

headline: 43 and Pregnant
abstract: My pregnancy’s viability is still very much in limbo. As am I. I am readying myself for whatever happens, but I am split in a way I have never felt before.
lead_paragraph: I was interrupted midthought, midword, midbreath. In that moment I was stunned into stasis, neither exhaling nor inhaling. I froze in place trying to process this unexpected news. Except the pink line persisted. So did my disbelief.

headline: In Philadelphia, Juniper Commons Offers Comfort Grub of the ’80s With a Soundtrack
abstract: A new restaurant from the chef Kevin Sbraga and Ben Fileccia is meant to be a flashback to the food, décor and music of that decade.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Imagine what might have happened if Wolfgang Puck, in the early days of Spago, had gotten his hands on a Golden Corral. That gives you a hint of how it feels to eat at Juniper Commons, a new restaurant here devoted to showcasing the food, décor and music of the 1980s.

headline: U.S. Charges Manhattan Man With Trying to Buy Ricin
abstract: A criminal complaint says Cheng Le suggested to an undercover F.B.I. employee that he had a client who wanted to use the highly toxic poison to kill someone who was hospitalized.
lead_paragraph: A man has been charged in Manhattan with trying to buy three to five lethal doses of the highly toxic poison ricin, seemingly for the purpose of reselling it, according to a criminal complaint unsealed on Tuesday in Federal District Court.

headline: By the Numbers: How State of the Union Addresses Stack Up

headline: President of New York Police Union Will Face Election Challenge
abstract: Patrick J. Lynch, who has openly clashed with Mayor Bill de Blasio in recent weeks, is facing rare opposition to his leadership from within his own union, the Patrolmen’s Benevolent Association.
lead_paragraph: Patrick J. Lynch, the president of New York City’s largest police union, who has openly clashed with the mayor in recent weeks, is facing a rare challenge to his leadership from a group within the union, the Patrolmen’s Benevolent Association.

headline: Japanese Detox Tips From a Geisha-Inspired Beauty Brand
abstract: Victoria Tsai, the founder of the beauty line Tatcha, offers a few suggestions for achieving flawless skin this time of year.
lead_paragraph: Japanese women, regarded for their porcelain-smooth complexions, often utilize a seven-step regimen to care for the skin. But for those too busy for such a meticulous approach, Victoria Tsai, the founder of the geisha-inspired beauty line Tatcha, offers a few smaller suggestions for achieving flawless skin. And there’s a good chance you’re already well on your way to a cleaner complexion this time of year: Like the body, the face requires a good detox because “skin is a mirror of your mental and physical health,” Tsai explains. “I start from the inside out.”

headline: For a Few Whirlwind Days, Davos Becomes the Deal Capital

lead_paragraph: Even before deal makers descended on Davos, Switzerland, for the World Economic Forum, they were making an important decision: how to protect their feet from the elements.

headline: From ArtsBeat: ‘Clinton the Musical’ Returns
abstract: For those who can’t get enough of Bill and Hillary Clinton – or want to see them lampooned in the tawdriest way possible – the stage satire “Clinton the Musical” is getting an open-ended commercial run at Off Broadway’s New World Stages complex, the producers announced on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: ‘Clinton the Musical’ Is Definitely Running Off Broadway

headline: Calpers Is Not in Danger of Breaking Up With Private Equity

lead_paragraph: Any investment decision by the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, the nation’s biggest pension fund with about $300 billion in assets, is closely watched by investors around the world.

headline: The Latest on Travel to Cuba
abstract: Wondering what is required if you want to go to Cuba? Here are some answers to frequently asked questions.
lead_paragraph: As the United States reopens its Embassy in Havana, here’s what you need to know about traveling to Cuba. Much has changed already since the publication of new regulations for travel to Cuba on Jan. 16, which losened some restrictions on travel for Americans, though some . travelers still cannot just hop on a plane and go.

headline: Super Bowl 2015: Patriots’ Red-Hot Offense Faces Seahawks’ Dominant Defense

lead_paragraph: Last year’s Super Bowl pitted one of the greatest single-season offenses in N.F.L. history against one of the greatest single-season defenses. Using slightly different time frames, this year’s Super Bowl can boast similar claims.

headline: IBM Revenue Slides as Revamping Takes Hold
abstract: New businesses are showing encouraging growth, but they are not yet large or profitable enough to offset challenges in the company’s traditional strengths.
lead_paragraph: IBM is in the midst of a challenging transition, and its fourth-quarter financial results reflected that reality.

headline: At the Fall/Winter 2015 Men’s Shows, A Crop of Pumpkin Pieces
abstract: There have been enough pops of burnt orange on the runway to inspire otherwise cautious men to take on the autumnal shade.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to the fall/winter 2015 men’s wear shows, to declare that “orange is the new black” would be to misrepresent most guys’ willingness to experiment with color. So far this season, though, there have been enough pops of burnt orange on the runway to inspire at least somewhat adventurous men to take on the autumnal shade, à la River Phoenix in the film “My Own Private Idaho.” In London at the Margaret Howell show, an orange jumper — worn on a red-headed model for extra oomph — brought new life to the British designer’s usually somber palette. In Milan, where the shows concluded today, the color continued to permeate some of the bigger collections. For Bottega Veneta, Tomas Maier played with a range of hues, from purple and kelly green to what he called “persimmon,” an orange shade that was deftly implemented in knits, outerwear and accessories like the above scarf. For Jil Sander’s men’s debut under the creative direction of Rodolfo Paglialunga, the designer also deployed accents of retro-inspired colors, including mustard and hunter green as well as a rusty shade seen in a covetable drop-shouldered textured polo. Though the copper-colored teddy-bear coat in No.21’s collection might be a stretch for some men, the matching sweater worn underneath is a much more palatable option to try next fall.

keywords: ['Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Traffic and Parking Violations', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The case has renewed debate about the extent to which states should regulate potential distractions.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — For something that merited a police stop, it does not sound like much: “eating while driving.” But that is what a police officer wrote on the citation he issued Jan. 10 after he pulled over the 2009 BMW that H. Madison Turner was driving through suburban Atlanta.

headline: Jury Selection Begins in Colorado Theater Shootings
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Aurora, Colo, Shooting (2012)']
abstract: The trial of James E. Holmes, who is accused of killing 12 people in an Aurora, Colo., movie theater, began with the first group of about 7,000 potential jurors filtering into a courthouse.
lead_paragraph: CENTENNIAL, Colo. — Two and a half years after a gunman killed 12 people inside a Colorado movie theater, jury selection in the case began Tuesday afternoon. More than 100 potential jurors filtered into the county courthouse here to fill out questionnaires and hear a judge’s introduction to one of the most complicated and emotionally charged criminal cases in this state’s history.

headline: Whoa, Girl, What Big Teeth You Have!
abstract: The three seasons of the BBC’s “Wolfblood,” about adolescent werewolves, are now available for streaming and on DVD.
lead_paragraph: How can you tell when a werewolf show is meant for young viewers? In “Wolfblood,” a charming series from the BBC’s children’s division, there’s one obvious sign: When the human-wolf hybrids change back into human form, they’re fully clothed. Where do their jackets and sneakers go when they’re running around in the woods? They don’t seem to care, so apparently we shouldn’t, either.

headline: Through Art and Forensics, Faces of Unidentified Victims Emerge
abstract: New York Academy of Art students, working with the city medical examiner’s office, are sculpting faces on the skulls of 11 unidentified crime victims.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who walked into Room 501 at the New York Academy of Art in TriBeCa the other day would have seen a roomful of sculpture students molding clay into faces that looked nearly alive.

headline: Mixing Shades of Gray Into a Chirpy Comedy and a Mother’s Anguish
abstract: Morningside Opera’s “Pergolesi Power Games,” at the Alchemical Theater Laboratory, seeks to upend Pergolesi’s Stabat Mater and “La Serva Padrona.”
lead_paragraph: Poor Pergolesi.

headline: In Vienna, a New Pass to See the Sights
abstract: The Vienna PASS lets travelers see more than 60 of the city’s sights with one purchase.
lead_paragraph: Travelers to Vienna can now see the city’s major attractions with a single purchase: Vienna PASS, which gives visitors entry into more than 60 sights, made its debut this week and can be purchased by visiting viennapass.com.

headline: Mark Ronson and Michael Chabon on the Making of ‘Uptown Special’
abstract: The new BFFs, who share writing credits on the infectious new album, discuss the origins of their unlikely collaboration.
lead_paragraph: Even amid the all-star lineup of guests that dot the liner notes of Mark Ronson’s latest album, “Uptown Special,” one name stands out among the rest: Michael Chabon. Ronson tapped the Pulitzer Prize winner to write lyrics for the album after realizing that the music — a mix of early R&B, funk and soul, and a departure from the up-tempo dance tracks of the longtime D.J.’s earlier efforts — called for a more cerebral approach to lyric writing than what he calls “the usual ‘heartache on the dance floor’ that we settle for sometimes.” Here, the Grammy-winning superproducer and the “The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay” author discuss the origins of their unlikely, if highly fruitful, collaboration.

headline: A Judicial Fund-Raising Case Causes Justices to Reflect on Their Own Jobs
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Campaign Finance', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Elections, Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Supreme Court justices reflected on the power and dignity of the judiciary in a case on whether Florida can ban judicial candidates from personally seeking donations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Supreme Court argument about how the First Amendment applies to judicial elections turned unusually personal on Tuesday, with several justices reflecting on the power and dignity of the judiciary.

abstract: Ethnic groups are fighting over representation, one candidate is wanted by Interpol, and one dropped out because he could not provide enough jobs to his would-be supporters.

lead_paragraph: On the face of it, so to speak, Holt v. Hobbs was not a difficult case.

headline: Iranian Commander Vows to Avenge Israeli Airstrike
abstract: The leader of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, Mohammad Ali Jafari, issued his condemnation of Israel after Gen. Mohammad Ali Allahdadi was killed in Syria.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s highest Revolutionary Guards commander issued a threat against Israel after the death of an Iranian general in an Israeli helicopter strike along the border with Syria, saying that “destructive thunderbolts” awaited.

headline: The Limits of a Mouth
abstract: Nate Wooley’s “For Kenneth Gaburo,” presented at the Wild Project, takes a sentence and manipulates it with odd vocalic positions and electronic sounds.
lead_paragraph: Nate Wooley’s new work “For Kenneth Gaburo” is a setting of a sentence by Mr. Gaburo (1926-93), a searching composer, conductor, pianist and language theorist. But its presentation of the words is extreme, to say the least.

headline: Italy Goes Global in Search for Museum Directors
abstract: The Italian Culture Ministry has begun its first international search for new museum directors, a move intended to make its art institutions more profit-driven.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Wanted: Directors for 20 of Italy’s leading museums, including the Uffizi in Florence, the Galleria Borghese in Rome and the Accademia in Venice. Strong art history background, management experience and an interest in improving visitor experience a must. Fluency in Italian a definite plus, but not a requirement.

headline: Led by a Tender Heart, Before It Is Ripped Out
abstract: “The Woodsman,” an ambitious production from James Ortiz, uses spare dialogue, omnipresent music and fanciful puppets to tell the Tin Man’s back story.
lead_paragraph: Using words is dangerous in this eastern corner of Oz, yet sound is everywhere: the mournful music of a violin, the rasp of a witch, the spooky wind of the woods.

headline: Ex-Union Leader Convicted in Philadelphia

lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — A former union leader was found guilty on Tuesday of extortion, racketeering and conspiracy for overseeing a campaign of violence and vandalism intended to force nonunion contractors to hire union members.

headline: Sit Down, Have a Beer and Don’t Forget Your Name Tag
abstract: Caps Lock Theater’s immersive, site-specific “Mrs. Mayfield’s Fifth-Grade Class of ’93 20-Year Reunion” enlists its audience members as classmates.
lead_paragraph: A show unlikely to please the shy, the claustrophobic or those with weak calf muscles, “Mrs. Mayfield’s Fifth-Grade Class of ’93 20-Year Reunion” takes place in an apartment on the fifth floor of an East Village walk-up. Whose apartment? Unclear, though certificates on the walls congratulate her on her mastery of ear candling and reiki.

headline: From Blissful Love to Homicidal Rage
abstract: The Broadway veteran Tom Hewitt plays a disarming psychopath in “Another Medea,” a monologue written by Aaron Mark.
lead_paragraph: For someone who murdered his own children, Marcus is really rather charming. Aggrieved, yes, and determined to tell his side of things, but not bad company. He understands that he’s committed a horror.

headline: ‘Coronation Street’ Was New, and Prince Charles Was a Boy
abstract: In “Modernity Britain: 1957-1962,” David Kynaston continues his exhaustive chronicle, looking at the Harold Macmillan years, when a young politician named Margaret Thatcher emerged and “Coronation Street” made its debut.
lead_paragraph: In 1957, when Americans took for granted electric ovens, hand-held mixers and finned cars, their British cousins were, comparatively speaking, just emerging from the cave. In a telling indicator, only 5 percent of working-class Britons owned a refrigerator, and only 12 percent over all. Yet this was the year that Harold Macmillan, the new prime minister, proclaimed, “Most of our people have never had it so good.”

headline: Photos Show American Held in Egypt Badly Bruised and Ill
abstract: Mohamed Soltan, who also holds Egyptian citizenship, has been held without charges for 16 months.
lead_paragraph: Photographs of an American holding a hunger strike in Cairo to protest his imprisonment without charges show him badly bruised and gravely ill, raising alarms about his deteriorating health and possible abuse.

lead_paragraph: Take your pick: Is God a huge floating head or a petulant little girl whose creations keep going wrong? Those are only two of the existential options on offer in “Sundance Film Festival Animated Shorts,” a diverse compendium of eight short films culled from past festival lineups.

headline: What America Thinks of the 2015 State of the Union Address
keywords: ['Community Colleges', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Tuition', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Watch the address and find out what observers are saying before, during, and afterward.
lead_paragraph: Updated at 11:11 PM. What’s unusual about this year’s State of the Union address, many have noted, is how much we know already. President Obama has revealed that he’ll call for a federal program to cover community college tuition and tax credits for middle-income Americans paid for by an increase in capital-gains taxes, among other changes. But, some say, that doesn’t mean we know everything about how Tuesday night’s speech will go. Below, watch the address and find out what observers are saying before, during and afterward — Op-Talk will be updating with reactions throughout the evening.

headline: Shareholders Face Quandary in Battle for Family Dollar
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Family Dollar shareholders have a tough decision: choose a higher, riskier bid from Dollar General or a lower, safer bid from Dollar Tree, writes Steven Davidoff Solomon in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: The Dollar Wars are coming to an end, but the question remains whether it was a takeover battle worth the effort.

headline: Cradle to Ivory Tower
abstract: College is crucial. So is all that leads up to it.
lead_paragraph: Leaving aside all of the other good arguments both for and against it, I have one big problem with the proposal for free community college that President Obama recently outlined and described anew in his State of the Union address on Tuesday night.

headline: 2 Yemeni Men Are Charged With Conspiring to Attack American Soldiers
abstract: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn said that Saddiq Al-Abbadi ambushed American convoys in Iraq, and that Ali Alvi fought for the Taliban in Afghanistan where American forces were stationed.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn have brought a case against two Yemeni men with suspected ties to Al Qaeda, accusing them of conspiring to attack American soldiers in the Middle East.

headline: Pope Amuses and Insults With Remark on Parenting
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: In saying that Roman Catholics should not feel compelled to breed “like rabbits,” the pope set a new standard for the papal vernacular, amusing to some and insulting to others.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Over the past two years, the world has become accustomed to Pope Francis’ folksy manner. Indeed, with his homespun anecdotes and off-the-cuff quips, the pope at times comes off more like a plainspoken uncle than the leader of the world’s 1.2 billion Roman Catholics.

headline: Obama’s Realistic Aim: Changing the Conversation, Not Minds
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Presidential speeches rarely alter people’s attitudes, studies show, but they can be effective in setting an agenda.
lead_paragraph: Despite the fact that more than 30 million people are expected to watch President Obama’s State of the Union address tonight, the speech is unlikely to change anyone’s mind about Mr. Obama or contemporary political issues. It’s not even a potential game-changer.

headline: 2 Teenagers Shot Near Brooklyn High School
abstract: A 17-year-old boy and a 14-year-old girl were struck shortly before 3 p.m. near Bushwick Avenue and Grand Street in Williamsburg; their injuries were not believed to be life-threatening.
lead_paragraph: Two teenagers were shot near a high school in Brooklyn on Tuesday, officials said.

headline: Reviving the Hogan Club Line and Returning It to Its Roots
abstract: Until Tuesday at the P.G.A. Merchandise Show, golfers had not seen new clubs bearing the Hogan name in seven years. But Terry Koehler, who grew up idolizing Ben Hogan, has resurrected the line.
lead_paragraph: In October 1953, after winning the Masters, the United States Open and the British Open in the same season, Ben Hogan wrote a letter to club pros, seeking their support for his fledgling line of golf clubs.

headline: Mourners Bear Flowers and Hopes for Unabridged Liberty
abstract: At sites honoring the 17 who were killed by terrorists almost two weeks ago, people of various nationalities and faiths have visited and expressed concerns about how European countries will react.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The light of a candle flickered across Silvana DiPonzeo’s face as she leaned down to read one of the hundreds of notes and cartoons strewn among heaps of flowers near the former offices of the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo.

headline: Smartphones Don’t Make Us Dumb
keywords: ['Smartphones', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Research', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: A significant change in our attention spans would happen over evolutionary time, not because you got a smartphone.
lead_paragraph: AS much as we love our digital devices, many of us have an uneasy sense that they are destroying our attention spans. We skitter from app to app, seldom alighting for long. Our ability to concentrate is shot, right?

headline: Traces of Montana Oil Spill Are Found in Drinking Water
abstract: Crews were working to clean up 50,000 gallons of oil that flowed into the Yellowstone River from a ruptured pipeline.
lead_paragraph: HELENA, Mont. — Work crews burrowed through thick ice and set up containment booms Tuesday in a struggle to vacuum up 50,000 gallons of oil that spilled into the Yellowstone River from a ruptured pipeline, contaminating drinking water.

headline: Rare Moment of Consensus for Senate on Keystone Pipeline
keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Buildings (Structures)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: An amendment to the Keystone XL bill that is aimed at improving energy efficiency in buildings was approved, 91 to 5.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved an amendment to the Keystone XL pipeline bill that is aimed at improving energy efficiency in buildings — a rare moment of bipartisan agreement in a tense debate that is nowhere near being settled.

headline: For States, $48 Million to Help Cut Emissions
abstract: A small group of wealthy philanthropists will give the money to various groups with a regional focus that will guide states in reducing warming gases from electricity generation.
lead_paragraph: Two charitable groups will spend $48 million over the next three years to help states figure out how to reduce emissions from electricity production, an effort to seize the possibilities that are opening up as the cost of clean power falls.

headline: Argentine Leader Criticizes Dead Official
abstract: President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner and her allies lashed out at Alberto Nisman, who was found dead in his home, questioning whether he had allied himself with forces seeking to weaken her government.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Facing a public outcry over the mysterious death of Alberto Nisman, the prosecutor leading the investigation into the 1994 bombing of a Jewish community center here, President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner and her allies lashed out at the dead man on Tuesday, questioning whether he had allied himself with forces seeking to weaken her government.

headline: Faith Seidenberg, 91, Dies; Took On McSorley’s, an All-Male Haven
abstract: Ms. Seidenberg, a civil rights lawyer, is best known for successfully suing McSorley’s Old Ale House in a case in which a judge found that sex discrimination in public accommodations is unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: One frigid January night in 1969, Faith Seidenberg vividly recalled a few years later, she and another woman, shivering “as much from fear as from the cold,” boldly swung open the double doors of McSorley’s Old Ale House in Manhattan, which “had withstood for 115 years the entry of female customers.”

headline: $447,000 Seized by Government Will Be Returned to Business
abstract: The United States attorney for New York’s Eastern District signed off on a settlement that would return $447,000 seized from a Long Island business under civil asset forfeiture.
lead_paragraph: Loretta E. Lynch, the United States attorney for New York’s Eastern District and President Obama’s nominee for attorney general, signed off on Tuesday to a settlement that would return $447,000 seized from a family-run Long Island business under a controversial area of federal law known as civil asset forfeiture. The business, Bi-County Distributors, was initially targeted because of a pattern of cash deposits under $10,000, but its owners, the Hirsch family, argued that the deposits were legitimate and, though more than two years passed after the money was seized, no criminal charges were filed. Lawyers from the Institute for Justice filed a motion demanding the return of the money. In the resulting settlement, neither side in the case admitted wrongdoing. Last Friday, the outgoing Attorney General, Eric H. Holder Jr., announced a policy change to rein in federal participation in civil asset forfeiture.

headline: Safety Unit Broadens Its Scrutiny of a Ford Recall
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s new administrator, Mark R. Rosekind, has ordered a review of a 2013 recall of Ford’s biggest pickup trucks.
lead_paragraph: A week after the nation’s top auto regulator warned automakers that he would be more vigilant on safety, his agency has taken the unusual move of revisiting the 2013 recall of Ford’s biggest pickup trucks.

headline: Say It Like It Is
abstract: You can’t dance around the topic of radical Islam.
lead_paragraph: I’ve never been a fan of global conferences to solve problems, but when I read that the Obama administration is organizing a Summit on Countering Violent Extremism for Feb. 18, in response to the Paris killings, I had a visceral reaction: Is there a box on my tax returns that I can check so my tax dollars won’t go to pay for this?

headline: Pope Francis’ September Visit to New York Is Expected to Be Just One Day
abstract: Stops at St. Patrick’s Cathedral and ground zero, as well as at Madison Square Garden for a Mass, could follow the pope’s address to the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis’ first visit to New York City, announced this week, will most likely last only a day, Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the Roman Catholic archbishop of New York, wrote on his blog Tuesday.

headline: Limits on Presidents Acting Alone
abstract: How a handful of presidential actions have been challenged in court, by Congress and by later presidents.
lead_paragraph: How a handful of presidential actions have been challenged in court, by Congress and by later presidents.

headline: Standard & Poor’s  Is Near  Costly  Settlements With U.S.
keywords: ['Attorneys General', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The credit rating agency has struck two tentative deals, one with state regulators and the Securities and Exchange Commission, and one for $1.37 billion with the Justice Department and state attorneys general.
lead_paragraph: Standard & Poor’s, the giant credit ratings agency, is closing in on a series of settlements with the government that will erode its profit and may damage its credibility as a major player on Wall Street.

headline: New Party Harnesses Discontent in Greece
abstract: With high unemployment and a struggling economy, the political field is fractured and includes a party formed just last March that is running third in the polls.
lead_paragraph: ILION, Greece — Harry Theoharis, whose relentless efforts as head of Greece’s tax collection agency prompted one newspaper last year to nickname him Little Stalin, was out campaigning recently in a smoky cafe in this working-class suburb of Athens.

headline: Reflections of a Student Protester Who Became a Police Sergeant
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Attacks on Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Cyress Smith proposes inviting the public to officers’ training sessions and other measures to improve relations between law enforcement and New Yorkers,
lead_paragraph: At age 23, Cyress Smith helped barricade buildings at City College, shutting down classes for a day in the spring of 1991 to protest tuition increases at the City University of New York, where he was a political science major.

headline: For Freshman Members of Congress, State of the Union Address Is a Rite of Passage
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: For longtime members of Congress, the address in the seventh year of a presidency can be a ho-hum affair, but for freshmen, it is a moment to savor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Carlos Curbelo, a freshman Republican of Florida, slipped into the Capitol on Monday night toting three freshly pressed dress shirts and a half a dozen ties. The building was quiet and nearly deserted; President Obama’s State of the Union address was still a whole day away.

headline: Bold Call to Action in Obama’s State of the Union, Even if No Action Is Likely
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Despite his party’s losses in the recent elections, President Obama laid out an expansive agenda as if he were the one who had triumphed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Near the end of his State of the Union address, President Obama noted, “I have no more campaigns to run.” A few Republicans in the audience cheekily applauded.

headline: C.I.A. Report Found Value of Brutal Interrogation Was Inflated
abstract: Years before a scathing Senate report, an internal review found that the C.I.A. had repeatedly overstated the value of intelligence gained from brutal interrogation techniques.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Years before the release in December of a Senate Intelligence Committee report detailing the C.I.A.’s use of torture and deceit in its detention program, an internal review by the agency found that the C.I.A. had repeatedly overstated the value of intelligence gained during the brutal interrogations of some of its detainees.

headline: The Personal and the Political Intersect
abstract: Carlos Vargas, who illegally immigrated with family members as a child, hopes to become a practicing lawyer in New York.

keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Vetoes (US)']
abstract: Republicans rejected most of the proposals in President Obama’s State of the Union address, saying he is unwilling to compromise.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “No” seems to be all anyone wants to say in this town anymore. In his State of the Union address on Tuesday, President Obama enumerated policies that he opposed, from rolling back Wall Street regulations to exempting more businesses from their obligation to provide health insurance under the Affordable Care Act.

keywords: ['Football', 'Coaches and Managers', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'Hiring and Promotion']

lead_paragraph: Todd Bowles had at least six interviews for N.F.L. head coaching jobs over the past five years. After each interview and rejection, he called an adviser to report who had been present, what questions had been asked, how long the interview had lasted and how he had performed.

lead_paragraph: State of the Union addresses — like most presidential speeches – rarely produce a bump in job approval ratings or bring around lawmakers of the opposite party. So why does tonight matter?

headline: Tournament’s Lawn Is a Place to Knock the Froth Off
abstract: Unlike the formal Wimbledon, the Australian Open features a spot for the average Joe and Josephine: a beer garden.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Wimbledon has Henman Hill, hallowed ground where thousands go to watch — nay, worship — Britain’s tennis greats. The Australian Open has a beer garden where many patrons barely noticed Tuesday night that Lleyton Hewitt, a local favorite, was battling to get into the tournament’s second round.

headline: Family Seeks Release of a Guantánamo Detainee Turned Author
keywords: ['Detainees', 'Books and Literature', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Mohamedou Ould Slahi, arrested in Mauritania and held at the prison in Cuba for 14 years, wrote an account of his detention that his family hopes will help a campaign to win his release.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On one of the roughest days in Mohamedou Ould Slahi’s 14 years of captivity at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, an American interrogator initially suggested that he pray out loud, then ridiculed him when he began reciting the Quran.

headline: U.S. Outpost in Cuba to Step Out of the Shadows
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: A building in Havana that has long been a center of intrigue and was once the American Embassy will again serve its diplomatic purpose amid the new détente with Cuba.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — Fidel Castro called the building a “nest of spies,” routinely marshaling tens of thousands of people to protest at its doorstep. His government even made a television mini-series with what it called images of American diplomats lurking in a forest nearby, dropping off suspicious bags and marking benches in acts of espionage.

headline: Obama: The State of the Union Is Strong
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: During his State of the Union address, the president said the economy was growing and “it’s now up to us” to choose where we go from here.
lead_paragraph: During his State of the Union address, the president said the economy was growing and “it’s now up to us” to choose where we go from here.

headline: Guyana: President Announces Date for Elections
abstract: President Donald Ramotar, who suspended Parliament in November to avoid a no-confidence vote, announced Tuesday that general elections would be held on May 11.
lead_paragraph: President Donald Ramotar, who suspended Parliament in November to avoid a no-confidence vote, announced Tuesday that general elections would be held on May 11. “I expect to win the election and win back a majority in Parliament,” Mr. Ramotar said. His People’s Progressive Party, dominated by Indo-Guyanese, has held power for more than 20 years but fell short of a majority in the assembly in 2011 with the rise of a multiethnic third party as a political force. The two main parties have traditionally hewed to racial lines: one drawing support from the descendants of Africans, the other from the descendants of Indians.

headline: Potential Buyers of New York City Opera Hold a Bidding War in Court
abstract: The board of the bankrupt opera must name its preferred choice by Thursday.
lead_paragraph: New York City Opera may have run out of money, filed for bankruptcy and sold its costumes and instruments, but two rival groups are so interested in trying to reinvent the company that they held a bidding war in court on Tuesday for its name and remaining assets.

headline: Britain: Man Pleads Guilty to Terrorism Charges
abstract: A British man who joined a jihadist group to fight in Syria and then returned to Britain after faking his death has pleaded guilty to four terrorism offenses, the London police said.
lead_paragraph: A British man who joined a jihadist group to fight in Syria and then returned to Britain after faking his death has pleaded guilty to four terrorism offenses, the London police said Tuesday. The man, Imran Khawaja, 27, of Southall in West London, left last January, joined a group called Rayat al-Tawheed and, with his face concealed, was featured in a grisly video in Syria in which he was described as “British ISIS fighter Abu Daigham al-Britani with government soldier’s head Syria,” the police said. Mr. Khawaja, who is to be sentenced next month, was arrested entering Britain at the port of Dover last June. He pleaded guilty last month to charges including attending a terrorism training camp and preparing terrorist acts, but restrictions on reporting his plea were lifted just Tuesday.

headline: Why the Guests? Because Heartwarming Stories Work
abstract: Experiments confirm a way that politicians can get citizens of the opposing party on their side, even if briefly.
lead_paragraph: Among the guests who will hear President Obama’s State of the Union speech in person – in the first lady’s box – are a police captain who helped reduce crime in Los Angeles by 50 percent and a college student from Dallas whose undocumented parents are eligible for the administration’s deferred action program for parents of lawful permanent residents.

headline: Coming Off the Bench, a Basketball Ambassador
abstract: Yuta Watanabe, a freshman at George Washington and the first Japanese-born player to earn a Division I basketball scholarship, said he hoped to inspire other Japanese players.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After Yuta Watanabe’s first workouts at George Washington University, his teammates recognized that he had the jump shot, the speed and the basketball intelligence to succeed at the Division I level.

headline: Michigan Governor Backs Measure Raising Sales Tax
keywords: ['Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Taxation']
abstract: Roads and bridges are seen as being in dire need of repair, so Gov. Rick Snyder, a Republican, used his State of the State address to support a generally unpopular way of raising revenue.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Snyder, a Republican, on Tuesday night urged Michigan voters to approve a sales tax increase to help pay for what he sees as long-needed repairs to roads and bridges, making him one of a small but growing number of governors to endorse raising taxes.

headline: Everyone Pays Their Own Way
abstract: Jim Hilger enjoys left-right symmetry, and gives us a good dose today.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — You’ll love this puzzle if you are the type who is vigilant about dotting your i’s and crossing your t’s. We’ll set aside the i’s for today, but Jim Hilger insists that you cross your t’s, and that you do it with the letter T.

headline: An Uneasy Rapport
abstract: “I’m Gonna Pray for You So Hard” explores the dynamics of the relationship between a playwright and his actress daughter.
lead_paragraph: Like father, like daughter. That sentimental notion, usually cooed to emphasize an endearing trait shared across the generation gap, takes on a bone-chilling dimension in “I’m Gonna Pray for You So Hard,” a potently acted but punishing drama by Halley Feiffer about the destructive relationship between a famous playwright and his daughter, an aspiring actress.

headline: Yankees to Return to WPIX-TV, 20 Times a Year
abstract: WPIX, which broadcast Yankees games from 1951 to 1998, will show 20 games a year under a multiyear deal.
lead_paragraph: WPIX-TV will carry about 20 Yankees games annually under a multiyear deal that brings the team back to the station, its longtime broadcast home in the New York area, a person familiar with the negotiations said. The Yankees were on WPIX from 1951 to 1998, from Mel Allen and Red Barber to Phil Rizzuto and Bobby Murcer.

lead_paragraph: At a raucous New York City Council hearing that pitted affordable housing advocates against proponents of the so-called sharing economy, city lawmakers on Tuesday railed against an expanding short-term rental market that they said was teeming with abuse and neglect and undermining low-income New Yorkers.

lead_paragraph: Key Democrats have reached agreement on a set of policies known as “inclusive capitalism”: a forceful market-oriented economic agenda intended to counter inequality, restrain the accrual of vast wealth at the top and provide the working and middle classes with improved economic opportunities.

headline: With Rick Nash Pacing Action, the Rangers Prevail in Overtime
abstract: Forward Carl Hagelin had a first-period assist and scored 2 minutes 55 seconds into the extra session as the Rangers rallied from a 2-1 third-period deficit.
lead_paragraph: Some critics believed Rick Nash was the reason the Rangers did not win the Stanley Cup last year.

headline: Century Later, the ‘Chinatown’ Water Feud Ebbs
abstract: Los Angeles began taking water from the Owens Valley nearly a century ago, inspiring the movie “Chinatown.” But the fight that ensued may soon be over.
lead_paragraph: OWENS LAKE, Calif. — For 24 years, traveling across the stark and dusty moonscape of what once was a glimmering 110-square-mile lake framed by snow-covered mountains, Ted Schade was a general in the Owens Valley water wars with Los Angeles. This was where Los Angeles began taking water for its own use nearly a century ago, leaving behind a dry lake bed that choked the valley with dust, turning it into one of the most polluted parts of the nation.

headline: Obama on Diplomacy and Iran
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president discussed the continuing negotiations to prevent a nuclear-armed Iran during his State of the Union address.
lead_paragraph: The president discussed the continuing negotiations to prevent a nuclear-armed Iran during his State of the Union address.

headline: At the State of the Union, a President Outgunned in Congress Is Still Combative
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Income Inequality', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: By raising the plight of the middle class in his State of the Union Message, President Obama firmly inserted issues of economic fairness into the political debate.
lead_paragraph: The circumstances facing President Obama as he delivered his State of the Union address Tuesday night could not have seemed less promising: a presidency with only two years left to get anything done in a Congress that is now totally in the control of a party that has routinely ignored his pleas for cooperation. So he chose wisely to send a simple, dramatic message about economic fairness, about the fact that the well-off — the top earners, the big banks, Silicon Valley — have done just great, while the middle and working classes remain dead in the water. His remedy: skim from the rich and redistribute to those below, while deploying other weapons to raise wages and increase jobs.

headline: Was Joni Ernst’s State of the Union Rebuttal Conciliatory, or Just More of the Same?
abstract: Republicans will be happy to compromise with President Obama, so long as he does everything they want.
lead_paragraph: Every year after the State of the Union address, the party in opposition to the president produces a “response” speech from one of its members that, of course, is written long before the president enters Congress for this annual ritual. It’s not a terribly difficult job.

keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Terrorism', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: Mayor Anne Hidalgo announced plans to take legal action against Fox News for inaccurate reports that areas of her city are Muslim-ruled enclaves.
lead_paragraph: Apparently unmoved by the Fox News channel’s on-air apology to “the people of France” for broadcasting the false claim that areas of Paris are Muslim-ruled enclaves — or “no-go zones” outside the control of the state — the city’s mayor announced Tuesday that she intended to take legal action against the network.

headline: R.V.s and Stolen Kidneys: Life on the Fringes in ‘Justified’
abstract: Interviews with Jere Burns, Damon Herriman, Mykelti Williamson and other actors who fill out the eccentric universe of the FX series, which began its final season on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The FX crime drama “Justified,” which began its sixth and final season on Tuesday, unfolds in a fictional version of Harlan County, Ky. — a place of cellphones and late-model sedans that nonetheless “may as well be wherever ‘Harry Potter’ takes place,” said Jere Burns, whose conniving Wynn Duffy is a fan favorite. “I don’t know what that’s called, but it may as well be that, because you have people there who would not seem to exist anywhere else.”

headline: Why Joni Ernst Talked About Her Tough Upbringing
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Politicians can win hearts on the left with stories about overcoming adversity in childhood, but there’s no evidence it affects their policy positions.
lead_paragraph: As she did in her stump speeches for Senate last fall, Joni Ernst of Iowa mentioned her upbringing in her response to the State of the Union speech Tuesday night. She talked about tough times walking to the school bus and her feelings about being different from the other families in her town. Politicians do this because they think it makes them relatable — it’s a shortcut to many people that says, “I understand you.”

headline: Joni Ernst Delivers Republican Response
abstract: Senator Joni Ernst, the newly elected Republican from Iowa, gave the official G.O.P. response to President Obama’s State of the Union address on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Senator Joni Ernst, the newly elected Republican from Iowa, gave the official G.O.P. response to President Obama’s State of the Union address on Tuesday.

headline: Resort Looks With a Masculine Twist
abstract: With men’s fashion week currently showing in Paris, now is a fitting time to borrow style cues from the boys.
lead_paragraph: With men’s fashion week currently showing in Paris, now is a fitting time to borrow style cues from the boys. J.W. Anderson’s resort offerings for ladies and gents were literally cut from the same cloth; his color-blocked bomber jacket for women combines an androgynous feel with a streamlined shape. Julien David, another young designer, added a tomboy touch to his women’s resort looks with his signature sneakers, styled with a baggy silhouette. A Peace Treaty’s graphic scarf, Comme des Garçons’s oxford shirt, Marni’s Mondrianesque backpack, Miu Miu’s retro-style shirt and MM6’s high-waisted jeans are similar in spirit: inspired by a man, tailored for a woman.

headline: A Sci-fi-Inspired Music Video From a Buzzy Indie Band
abstract: Viet Cong, founded by members of the art-rock band Women, released its eagerly anticipated first self-titled full-length LP this week.
lead_paragraph: For a few short years and just two albums, the Canadian band Women released some of the best art rock of the new millennium. Following the dissolution of the group in 2012 due to the death of the guitarist Christopher Reimer, the band members Matt Flegel and Mike Wallace enlisted their fellow Canadian musicians Scott Munro and Daniel Christiansen — of Lab Coast and Sharp Ends, respectively — to form Viet Cong, an indie-rock band with a shared penchant for charred, factious punk. “We all embrace all of our musical histories and wouldn’t be making the kind of music we make now if we hadn’t learned from all the music we’ve played in the past,” says Flegel, who plays bass and sings in the new outfit.
