headline: Shanghai Blames Local Officials and Police in Deadly New Year’s Stampede
abstract: The city dismissed two officials Wednesday after concluding that poor preparations and lax policing led to the panic that left 36 people dead.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Shanghai city government dismissed two officials on Wednesday after releasing a report that blamed poor preparations and lax policing for a stampede that killed 36 people at a popular tourist site on New Year’s Eve.

headline: Obama Says Family Leave Is an Economic Necessity, Not Just a Women’s Issue
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'Paid Time Off', 'Family Leaves', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The president said the government would provide $2.2 billion to reimburse states for paid family leave programs.
lead_paragraph: When the Labor Department recently gave states grants to expand paid family leave, the money came from the department’s Women’s Bureau. But in the State of the Union address on Tuesday, President Obama argued that paid leave is not just a women’s issue. “It’s time we stop treating child care as a side issue, or a women’s issue, and treat it like the national economic priority that it is for all of us,” he said. It’s often an economic necessity today for both parents in a household to work, he said.

headline: Line Drawn on Purported Corruption in Calligraphy
abstract: To judge from warnings by Chinese Communist Party officials, the calligraphy racket can be as sordid and ruthless as a rigged wrestling match.
lead_paragraph: In Chinese culture, calligraphy holds a hallowed status. In ancient times, emperors, mandarins and poets prized the skill of using ink and a brush to render words, texts and poems on paper with such vigor and grace that the complex characters of written Chinese become an art form of their own.

headline: China’s National Soccer Team Winning Games, and Fans
abstract: A history of failure has dogged China’s team, and deepened the fans’ gloom. But three wins at the Asian Cup could change all that.
lead_paragraph: CANBERRA, Australia — For Chinese soccer fans, the new year is already an unusual one. After years of frustration, disappointment and cynicism with the national team, the 2015 Asian Cup is becoming a big success, with China winning all three games so far and finishing first in Group B.

headline: Suspicious Death in Argentina
abstract: Did Alberto Nisman commit suicide, or was he murdered hours before he was to testify against the government?
lead_paragraph: Some Argentines are calling Alberto Nisman, the maverick prosecutor, the 86th casualty of one of the deadliest, unsolved terrorists attacks in modern history: the 1994 bombing of a Jewish community center in Buenos Aires. That seems fitting whether his death over the weekend turns out to be a suicide, as the government of President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner seems eager to establish, or the murder of a man who had learned too much.

headline: Stabbing on Tel Aviv Bus Breaks a Fragile Calm
abstract: The assailant, who attacked a bus driver as well as passengers during the morning rush, was shot and wounded by security forces as he tried to escape. At least three victims had serious injuries.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian man stabbed and wounded up to a dozen Israelis on Wednesday as he rampaged through a bus in central Tel Aviv during the morning rush, the police said. He then fled on foot but was shot and wounded by security forces.

headline: Test Yourself | Snapchat Stories
abstract: Here are the first several paragraphs from a Jan. 14 article, “Be the Star of Your Own Snapchat Story.” Can you choose the best word or phrase for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Here are the first several paragraphs from a Jan. 14 article, “Be the Star of Your Own Snapchat Story.”

headline: Obama, Citing China as Rival, Warns Lawmakers Over Inaction on Trade Measure
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: He warned lawmakers in his State of the Union address that failure to take action on trade legislation could be tantamount to ceding America’s leadership role to Beijing.
lead_paragraph: President Obama held up China as a formidable rival to the global influence of the United States in his annual State of the Union address on Tuesday, warning lawmakers that failure to take action on trade legislation could be tantamount to ceding America’s leadership role to Beijing.

headline: Why Is Binge Drinking So Common Among Young People in the United States?
abstract: What should colleges and communities do to decrease the amount of binge drinking among young people?
lead_paragraph: The drinking age in all 50 states is 21 years old, yet under-age drinking is widespread. According to the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism: “Although youth drink less often than adults do, when they do drink, they drink more. That is because young people consume more than 90 percent of their alcohol by binge drinking.”

headline: The Megyn Kelly Moment
keywords: ['Television', 'United States Politics and Government', 'News and News Media', 'Ratings (Audience Measurement)']
abstract: The anchor has brought Fox News a more unpredictable approach to red-meat politics. Can she draw a more unpredictable audience?
lead_paragraph: On a gray Wednesday in November, the Fox News anchor Megyn Kelly and four producers gathered around a conference table on the 17th floor of the News Corporation building in Manhattan. They were there to plan the 281st episode of “The Kelly File,” which would be shown live in a few hours, at 9 p.m. Kelly’s executive producer, Tom Lowell, a 25-year veteran of TV news, ticked through the program blocks, the between-commercial bits that are the basic unit of television programming. The A Block would contain a Fox News exclusive on the president’s plans to halt millions of deportations. The B and C Blocks would focus on the Obama health care adviser Jonathan Gruber’s declaration, caught on tape, that the Affordable Care Act passed in part because of “the stupidity of the American voter.” Slated for the D block was Jonathan Gilliam, a former Navy SEAL.

headline: An Immigrant’s Dream for a Better Life
keywords: ['Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'Photography']
abstract: Going behind the numbers and beyond the political debate, Mark Abramson got close to a young immigrant whose parents took her to California despite not having proper authorization.
lead_paragraph: The pictures of Blanca’s life in California look ordinary: relaxing with her parents on the banks of a river, dressed up for her quinceañera, studying at school, moving into her first off-campus apartment. Yet to her — and to thousands of other immigrants whose parents brought them to this country without authorization — the pictures represent lives that reach for the future, aware of the obstacles that could one day take it all away.

headline: France Vows Forceful Measures Against Terrorism
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Prime Minister Manuel Valls of France announced new security measures Wednesday in Paris, including proposals to add about 2,500 new jobs to fight terrorism and monitor potential threats.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French government promised a sweeping legislative response on Wednesday to this month’s terrorist attacks, setting out proposals to monitor potential threats more closely and wading deeper into an emerging debate over balancing security and civil liberties.

headline: Shakily, Rafael Nadal and Maria Sharapova Survive Upset Bids
abstract: Nadal overcame a stomach ailment and Sharapova fought back from match point to advance to the third round on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — His knees, back, wrist and appendix have all failed Rafael Nadal recently. On Wednesday, his stomach joined the list of ailments, but he gutted out a five-set victory, 6-2, 3-6, 6-7 (2), 6-3, 7-5, to reach the third round of the Australian Open.

headline: After a Tragedy, the Memorabilia

lead_paragraph: New year, new tragedy — new fashion statement?

headline: The State of Our Union, Tweeted
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Vetoes (US)']
abstract: Members of Congress (or their staffs) wrote more than a thousand tweets during President Obama’s address.
lead_paragraph: Members of Congress once had two primary means of responding to presidents while the yearly State of the Union address was delivered: stand and applaud, or sit on their hands and glare. Thanks to smartphones (or staff tucked away in offices with the passwords to official Twitter accounts), senators and representatives can now comment in real time to every word a president speaks. As they did in January 2014, the congressional audience wrote more than a thousand tweets during the approximately 65 minutes that President Obama spent delivering the State of the Union.

headline: New York Today: Snow, but Not Like Last Year’s
abstract: Wednesday: Remembering “plowgate,” some light evening snow, and the governor delivers the State of the State address.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this cloudy Wednesday.

headline: Champions League: How to Solve the Seeding Problem
abstract: It really isn’t hard to reward teams for performance in domestic leagues and also account for the relative strength of European leagues.
lead_paragraph: The governing body of European soccer, UEFA, is soon expected to ratify a revamping of the seeding system for the Champions League, one of the world’s most popular sporting events.

headline: Daily Report: Google Makes a Big Bet on SpaceX
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Private Spaceflight', 'Space and Astronomy']
abstract: Google has teamed up with Fidelity to invest in SpaceX, the rocketry company founded by Elon Musk, in part to further Google’s goal of extending the Internet’s reach through satellites.
lead_paragraph: Google likes its ambitions sky high. This time, it has gone a little further, Quentin Hardy and Conor Dougherty report.

headline: Helping an Island by Helping Hawks
abstract: A project on the Portuguese island of Madeira could help other hard-pressed native flora and fauna, and stoke local interest in conservation.
lead_paragraph: PAÚL DA SERRA, Portugal — It was warm and sunny when we started out from Funchal, the harbor town that is the capital of the Madeira archipelago of Portugal, on a recent morning. After a drive of about 45 minutes, we were high in the mountains. Thick fog was streaming across the rugged red and green landscape, and it was cold enough to make us want to put on hats and gloves.

headline: Today in Politics
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'State of the Union Message (US)']

headline: A Tale of Two Pegs
abstract: It’s all about the nagging.
lead_paragraph: I’m still in Hong Kong, and there’s a curious discussion here about the upward collapse of Switzerland’s peg to the euro. You see, by the numbers Switzerland’s monetary situation pre-collapse and Hong Kong’s now look remarkably similar. Both were pegged to the currency of a much larger economy; in both cases the monetary authorities had accumulated huge reserves. Both found themselves at the mercy of that larger economy’s monetary policies — much obsession here over when the Fed will raise rates, much discussion of how low rates and QE in the US fed housing prices. So is the Hong Kong dollar at risk of a franc-like event?

headline: Morning Agenda: Dollar Store Predicament
abstract: Shareholders are facing a quandary in the battle for Family Dollar. | President Obama sets agenda to help the middle class. | S.&P. is nearing costly settlements with the U.S. | Profit at Morgan Stanley disappoints.
lead_paragraph: Shareholders are facing a predicament in the battle for Family Dollar, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column. On Thursday, Family Dollar shareholders will vote on a proposed $8.5 billion acquisition by Dollar Tree, which is offering about $76 a share. If they vote yes, “it will be the death knell for a competing bid by Dollar General that is about $4 a share higher,” Mr. Davidoff Solomon writes.

headline: Battery Ventures Hires Intel Capital Executive
abstract: The venture capital firm Battery Ventures has hired Dharmesh Thakker, a former Intel Capital managing director, as a general partner.
lead_paragraph: Battery Ventures, a venture capital firm with offices in Boston, Menlo Park, Calif., and Israel, has hired Dharmesh Thakker, a former Intel Capital managing director, as a general partner.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Shazam, a smartphone application that can identify songs, announced on Wednesday that it had raised $30 million in new funding round that valued the company at roughly $1 billion.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Two Bank of England officials dropped their recent calls for higher interest rates and joined a unanimous vote this month to keep the benchmark rate unchanged, according to central bank minutes released on Wednesday.

headline: Mirror, Mirror
abstract: In a double bill of “Iolanta” and “Bluebeard’s Castle” at the Metropolitan Opera, Mariusz Trelinski charts a psychic bridge from innocence to knowledge.
lead_paragraph: Happy endings in opera are few and far between — especially for women. Outside of comic opera, it is rare for a heroine to survive the final act; the price for love is usually death. Tchaikovsky’s one-act opera, “Iolanta,” is an exception to this rule, a luscious setting of a fairy tale in which a blind princess finds love and the gift of sight.

headline: After Fire, 2 Brooklyn Families Linked by Work Are Now Bound by Grief

lead_paragraph: Decades before a Russian billionaire brought a pro basketball team to Downtown Brooklyn and a trendy doughnut shop opened down the block, two immigrant families saw nothing but opportunity in the humble stretch of Flatbush Avenue between St. Marks Avenue and Bergen Street.

headline: For Your Consideration

lead_paragraph: What if the Academy Awards were reimagined, and instead of best actor and other traditional categories, films were nominated according to what kind of viewer they appealed to? You might get a technophile category in which the contenders are the cinematography of “Mr. Turner,” the sound mix of “American Sniper” and the performance-capture technique of “Dawn of the Planet of the Apes.” To see the nominations remixed, start here.

headline: 1915: Murder From the Skies
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Anger at Germany’s Zeppelin raid on Britain in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Fierce indignation is the predominant sentiment in this country now that the full results of the cowardly Zeppelin raid on the undefended East Anglian towns are known to the public. For months past the enemy has threatened England with attack by airships, and the very fulfilment of his threat has done more than anything else could have done to dispel the bogey of his creation. Put briefly, all that the Germans have accomplished by their dastardly night attack is the murder of two women, one boy and a man, the injuring of a baby girl and thirty-one adults, nearly all non- combatants, and the destruction of some thousands of pounds’ worth of property. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 22, 1915

headline: Ways of Seeing
abstract: In this picture book, a cheerful first grader — who happens to be blind — navigates through her day with her friends at her side.
lead_paragraph: The first things we learn about Zulay, a first grader with pigtails like two fluffy pompoms on top of her head and a big, bright smile, are that she likes numbers, she likes symmetry and she likes being connected to her friends. In her classroom, she tells us, “there are 22 chairs and 22 desks,” along with 22 pencils, books, hooks, smocks and people. She in one of “four best friends who help each other, four best friends who help themselves — Maya, Nancy, Zulay, and Chyng.” We soon see this mutuality in action when Maya helps Zulay draw a pyramid, then Zulay helps Maya understand tens and ones.

headline: Have Photo Albums, Will Travel
abstract: The director Pawel Pawlikowski’s family snapshots from his boyhood in Poland were one source of inspiration for the film “Ida.”
lead_paragraph: Polish films about the Holocaust have been nominated for Oscars before, notably Agnieszka Holland’s “In Darkness” just three years ago, but strictly speaking, Pawel Pawlikowski’s “Ida,” a nominee this year, is a post-Holocaust movie. It takes place in the early 1960s, when the title character, an 18-year-old novitiate, learns that she is actually Jewish and meets up with her aunt Wanda, a disillusioned Communist prosecutor who guides the naïve teenager through the family’s grim, hidden history.

headline: All-Ohio Convention Year? Awaiting the Democrats’ Pick
abstract: Democrats are expected next month to choose the location of their 2016 convention, and if they pick Columbus, both parties will be meeting in the swing state of Ohio.

Cuomo, delivering his State of the State address along with a budget proposal heavy on infrastructure, laid out an ambitious social agenda on Wednesday that focuses on problems not so easily solved with cash: the erosion of confidence in the criminal justice system, public schools and teachers that he said were failing students, and a creeping sense that economic mobility is not what it once was.

headline: Philharmonic Outlines 2015-16 Season
abstract: Esa-Pekka Salonen will embark on three years as composer in residence at the New York Philharmonic, and series will be devoted to Rachmaninoff, Messiaen and new music.
lead_paragraph: The composer and conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen will begin a three-year stint as composer in residence, and the bass-baritone Eric Owens will be named artist in residence. A Rachmaninoff festival will feature the pianist Daniil Trifonov, a Messiaen week will explore the legacy of the French composer and organist, and the NY Phil Biennial of new music will live up to its name by returning two years after it made its debut.

headline: State of the Union, State of the Presidency
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama takes a stab at shaping the post-Obama era.
lead_paragraph: Last night’s State of the Union found President Obama in a somewhat better position politically than in the weeks immediately following his party’s big midterm defeat. The improving economy has finally boosted his poll numbers toward at least the mid-40s, probably because plunging gas prices have finally delivered an effective wage increase. His power grab on immigration also seems to have been a limited political success: The move was broadly unpopular but neither immigration nor executive power are top-of-mind issues for most voters, the president’s standing with Hispanics has clearly improved, a brief period of media chiding soon gave way (predictably) to media forgetfulness, and the Republican opposition has been (also predictably) divided and disorganized. And on foreign policy, while the days of presidential rhetoric about allegedly ending wars and routing Al Qaeda are over, there hasn’t been a return to the crisis atmosphere of last spring and summer, giving the president breathing room to claim (plausibly in the case of Russia, less so in the case of ISIS) that his strategies are working.

headline: Brigham and Women’s Surgeon Dies After Hospital Shooting
abstract: Dr. Michael Davidson was shot by a gunman who entered the Boston hospital Tuesday morning, opened fire and then killed himself, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — A cardiac surgeon who was shot when a man opened fire inside a Boston medical center Tuesday has died of his wounds, hospital and police officials said.

headline: Voices From the Front Lines
abstract: Ava DuVernay, Barbra Streisand, Jill Soloway, Kimberly Peirce and other film directors talk about the struggles women face in their field.
lead_paragraph: Manohla Dargis interviewed a number of women in the movie industry about the challenges they face. These are excerpts from those conversations.

headline: ‘Reeling Through Life’ and ‘Silver Screen Fiend’
abstract: Tara Ison’s essays and Patton Oswalt’s memoir offer personal accounts of intense movie fandom.
lead_paragraph: Are the movies entirely to be trusted as a design for living? “You can’t expect me to keep up that level of charm, I’d have a heart attack,” Woody Allen complains in “Play It Again, Sam,” the 1972 film in which he takes dating tips from Humphrey Bogart. He realizes reality must win in the end, although the fact that the scene that symbolizes this — his ex-wife shooting Bogart in the chest — is itself a re-­enactment of a scene from “They Drive by Night” tells you something about the elasticity of the medium, which, like Escher’s eternal stairwell, feeds even our dreams of escape from the movies. We all agree with Allen, on some level. A life lived at a constant pitch of screwball comedy is a recipe for exhaustion. The relationship of most movie couples would not last five minutes beyond the closing credits of the films in which they appear. And yet such is the movies’ unrivaled express train to the limbic brain, where Ingrid Bergman’s face appears projected the size of a mother as seen by an infant, that trying to see what the medium has done to the shape of our desires can be as difficult as trying to see the edges of the sky.

headline: How ‘Warmest Ever’ Headlines and Debates Can Obscure What Matters About Climate Change
abstract: The complex calculations behind federal scientists’ conclusion that 2014 was “easily” the warmest since records began in 1880.
lead_paragraph: If you track developments related to human-driven global warming, my guess is you’re aware that the federal agencies that analyze climate conditions released the final word on 2014’s climate on Friday.

headline: Fatal Blaze in Prospect Heights
abstract: A five-alarm fire tore through a Brooklyn building early Wednesday morning.
lead_paragraph: A five-alarm fire tore through a Brooklyn building early Wednesday morning.

headline: The Sorry State of In-Flight Wi-Fi
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Wireless Communications', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Business Travel']
abstract: Wi-Fi on commercial flights is slow, unreliable and expensive.
lead_paragraph: 35,000 FEET, SOMEWHERE OVER THE MIDWEST — I’ve finally found something on commercial flights that’s worse than airplane food: the Wi-Fi. It’s so slow and unreliable that it shouldn’t be allowed to call itself “Wi-Fi.” Renaming it Airplane Dial-Up would be unfair to dial-up.

headline: To Some in California, Founder of Church Missions Is Far From Saint
abstract: The Rev. Junipero Serra, a pious preacher from the late 1700s whom the pope plans to canonize, is accused by Indian historians of cultural sabotage.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For generations, fourth graders in California’s schools, often with a parent’s touch, built models of church missions out of poster board or sugar cubes to celebrate the Rev. Junipero Serra and the religious communities he established along the West Coast in the late 1700s.

headline: Tell Me Your Party and I’ll Tell You How You Feel
abstract: If you’re a Democrat, you probably feel pretty good about the economy.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a Democrat, you probably feel pretty good about the economy. If you’re a Republican, you probably don’t. At least that’s the take away from a new Washington Post-ABC News poll.

headline: 1940: Russians Abandon Positions
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The Russian Army struggles in Finland in 1940.
lead_paragraph: WITH FINLAND’S NORTHERN ARMY — The Russian forces that are still holding on to the village of Markajaervi, on the south Salla road, to which they retreated early in the week, abandoned strong defensive positions without a battle. They were forced out of their fortifications near Joutsijaervi, thirty miles away, by a series of rapier-like flank attacks that made their front line untenable. They picked up their baggage and moved slowly back along the highway that leads to Salla and the Soviet border without taking time to destroy their machine gun nests and dugouts. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 22, 1940

headline: Euro Style Bond Buying
abstract: The European Central Bank is expected to announce a broad bond-buying program, like the quantitative easing program that largely proved successful in the United States and Britain.
lead_paragraph: The European Central Bank is expected to announce a broad bond-buying program, like the quantitative easing program that largely proved successful in the United States and Britain.

headline: Lights, Camera, Taking Action
abstract: The American movie mainstream needs a revolution — and if some women have their way, it just might get one.
lead_paragraph: The American movie mainstream needs a revolution — and if some women have their way, it just might get one. It’s time. Not because Ava DuVernay wasn’t tapped as a best director in the recent Academy Award nominations, even though her acclaimed movie “Selma” received a best picture nod. There has been a lot of speculation about the snub, but the reasons are less crucial than the message that the largely white, male directors in the Academy sent: This woman doesn’t deserve credit for her own movie. Women in film are routinely denied jobs, credits, prizes and equal pay, so the rebuke was familiar. That’s because while individual men struggle in the industry, women struggle as a group.

headline: 36 Hours in Denver
abstract: The signs of Denver’s economic high times and progressiveness can be found in the city’s innovative art, nightlife, food and shopping scenes.
lead_paragraph: The signs of Denver’s economic high times and progressiveness can be found in the city’s innovative art, nightlife, food and shopping scenes.

headline: What to Do in Denver
abstract: Bagels, beignets, a history museum and a botanic garden are unexpected highlights in the mile-high city.
lead_paragraph: The signs of Denver’s economic high times as a pot boomtown and bastion of progressive urban policies are everywhere. There is the B-cycle bike-share program, among the most affordable and best-run systems in the country, and the newly renovated Union Station, which has taken a still-in-use 1881 train station and made it the focal point of the thriving LoDo neighborhood. And there are the inconspicuous marijuana dispensaries that dot nearly every neighborhood, and more stunning public spaces — from Washington Park to the Cherry Creek bike path — than one city has a right to.

headline: A Kinder, Gentler Investor Activism
abstract: Douglas L. Braunstein and James C. Woolery have started a fund to persuade companies to do value-enhancing deals. Richard Beales of Reuters Breakingviews questions whether there’s room for permanently well-mannered activism.
lead_paragraph: Can old dogs make money out of old tricks?

headline: Bond-Buying Programs: Simple in Theory but Complex in Eurozone
abstract: So-called quantitative easing was successful in the United States and Britain but will be much more complicated in a group of 19 countries.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank is widely expected to announce on Thursday that it will finally begin buying government bonds as part of a so-called quantitative easing program.

headline: Gucci Picks Alessandro Michele as Its Next Creative Director
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: The promotion of the brand’s accessories chief had been widely rumored within the industry and represents a gamble for the French luxury group Kering.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Hoping to reverse a prolonged sales slump at Gucci, its marquee brand, the French luxury group Kering said on Wednesday that it had promoted Alessandro Michele, Gucci’s head of accessories, to creative director.

headline: Dropbox Buys CloudOn, a Microsoft Document Start-Up
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']

lead_paragraph: In its quest to go global, the online file-sharing giant Dropbox has again turned to deal-making.

headline: Bitter ‘Chinatown’ Water Feud Ebbs
abstract: The stealing of the Owens Valley water was the inspiration for the movie “Chinatown.” But the fight may be over.
lead_paragraph: The stealing of the Owens Valley water was the inspiration for the movie “Chinatown.” But the fight may be over.

headline: Holding the Democratic Convention in Brooklyn? Fuhgeddaboudit.
abstract: The party should avoid the logistical and ethical minefield at Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: AT some point in the next few weeks, the Democratic National Committee will announce the location of its 2016 convention. Philadelphia and Columbus are in the running, but for many, the money is on Brooklyn. And the site does seem attractive: The convention would take place at the Barclays Center, a state-of-the-art arena in the hippest borough of the nation’s media capital.

headline: Jill Leovy’s ‘Ghettoside’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: In “Ghettoside,” Jill Leovy describes a homicide case in South Los Angeles to examine the epidemic of unsolved murders of African-American men in America.
lead_paragraph: In her timely new book, Jill Leovy examines one of the most disturbing facts about life in America: that African-American males are, as she puts it, “just 6 percent of the country’s population but nearly 40 percent of those murdered.” Leovy describes neighborhoods steeped in pain: A mother, dressed in a baggy T‑shirt adorned with her murdered son’s picture, spends all day indoors, too terrified to step outside; the brother of a homicide victim purposely meanders through violent streets in the hopes that he too will meet the same fate; grieving parents all wear the same haunted expression, the empty stare that one police chaplain calls “homicide eyes.” Leovy’s focus is South Los Angeles, though similar stories abound in many of the nation’s poorest communities.

headline: Animals Suffer in Meat Industry Profit Quest:  Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Michael Moss’s front-page article on farm animals’ welfare and the modern meat industry made some Times readers cry … and get angry.
lead_paragraph: Michael Moss wrote a front-page article on Tuesday about scientific efforts to re-engineer the farm animal to fit the needs of the modern meat industry.

headline: One by One, Protesters Interrupt Supreme Court
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Discrimination', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The justices were disrupted on the fifth anniversary of the Citizens United decision, which allowed unlimited political spending by corporations and unions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Supreme Court argument Wednesday about housing discrimination started with a disruption and included a surprise.

headline: A Cocktail Week for Paris
abstract: More than 30 bars in eight neighborhoods will be part of the first Paris Cocktail Week.
lead_paragraph: Paris bars were once known largely for mediocre mojitos, but in the last few years, places like Experimental Cocktail Club, Candelaria and Sherry Butt have won considerable acclaim.

headline: Bankers at Forum Say They Support Regulation, With Some Caveats
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: While the top bankers said they backed tougher regulations, they sounded alarmed about what might happen to global bond prices when central banks begin to wind down their stimulus policies.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland – Top bankers attending the World Economic Forum here are saying that they support the deluge of new regulations introduced since the financial crisis of 2008.

headline: Next Question, Please
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner seemed to express a bit of fashion fatigue on Wednesday when he was asked at a news conference about the pattern on his tie.
lead_paragraph: “It’s the right color, all right?”

headline: Prada and Armani Reassert the Power of Consistency
abstract: The elegant, dark clothing on several runways showed designers moving toward greater reserve and personal calm.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — One of the commonest sights outside fashion shows, in whatever city they’re held, is hordes of shutterbugs racing to snap pictures of what is loosely described as “street fashion.” Often the photographers form a phalanx, a kind of flying wedge, and back shoulder to shoulder into traffic snapping away as their quarry advances. They’re like crazy birders. Watch them long enough, though, or track their Instagram accounts and you will soon observe that they’re tracking just one kind of bird: the fashion cuckoo.

headline: The State of the Union: A View of the Economy From Ground Level
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: To hear President Obama tell it to Congress on Tuesday, the economy is “roaring back.” That’s true in some places; in others it is more of a putter.
lead_paragraph: The economy President Obama described Tuesday night during his State of the Union address sounded pretty good — with unemployment down and jobs added at the fastest past since 1999.

headline: Battle Rages With Rebels at Border Post in Ukraine
abstract: As violence flared in southeastern Ukraine, the president repeated his allegation that thousands of Russian forces had crossed the border to help separatists.
lead_paragraph: KRAMATORSK, Ukraine — Shelling from both Ukrainian military and rebel separatist positions continued Wednesday over a remote border checkpoint northwest of Luhansk that Ukraine said was seized Monday by Russian troops, a chief spokesman for the Ukrainian military said.

headline: Classical Playlist: Puccini, Mendelssohn, Wagner and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: PUCCINI: ‘Turandot’ Joan Sutherland, soprano; Luciano Pavarotti, tenor; Montserrat Caballé, soprano; Zubin Mehta, conductor; London Philharmonic Orchestra(Decca 478 7815; two CDs)Full disclosure: I am no audiophile. I’m still catching up with Blu-ray as a video technology. But now Decca has issued some classic opera recordings from its catalog remastered from the original tapes in what is called Blu-ray Pure Audio. I’m loath to apply the word “pure” to anything. Still, listening to this reissue of the landmark 1972 recording of Puccini’s “Turandot,” with the dynamic Zubin Mehta conducting the London Philharmonic Orchestra and a dream cast headed by Joan Sutherland and Luciano Pavarotti, I have to say the sound quality is clean, vivid and strikingly detailed. Ms. Sutherland, the reigning bel canto soprano of her day, was tempted into the studio to sing Turandot, a vocally weighty role she never performed in a house. Her voice is gleaming and penetrating, and Mr. Mehta draws surprising intensity from an artist who could be stolid. Mr. Pavarotti is in his prime as Calaf. With the sumptuous Montserrat Caballé as Liù, Nicolai Ghiaurov as Timur and, of all people, Peter Pears as the old emperor, this is quite the cast. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: A Plan for a Chapel in Chile Based on Designs by  Gaudí
abstract: Almost 90 years after the death of Antoní Gaudí, Chile plans to build a chapel based on his designs.
lead_paragraph: A new chapel based on the art nouveau architect Antoní Gaudí’s designs will be built in Chile, about 90 years after his death. When complete, the chapel — a modest building with a spire rendered in his signature neo-Baroque  style  — will be the only Gaudí-designed building outside of his native Spain.

headline: French Premier on Investment Plan
abstract: Manuel Valls, the French prime minister, announced new investment in the French intelligence services in the wake of the attack on Charlie Hebdo.
lead_paragraph: Manuel Valls, the French prime minister, announced new investment in the French intelligence services in the wake of the attack on Charlie Hebdo.

headline: In a Way, Todd Bowles and Mike Maccagnan Are Reuniting
abstract: The paths of Bowles and Maccagnan crossed when they were teenagers and again when they were with the Washington Redskins, and now they are reunited with the Jets.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — For preseason football, the Elizabeth High School team would travel about 40 miles south along the New Jersey Turnpike to the Peddie School in Hightstown, where a football-loving teenager named Mike Maccagnan would watch practice.

headline: Venture Capital Outpaces Buyouts in Investment Returns
abstract: Helped by deals like the Twitter I.P.O., the venture capital industry recorded a 25.9 percent internal rate of return in the 12 months through last June. Buyout funds turned in a 22.4 percent return.
lead_paragraph: In the years since the dot-com crash of 2000, Silicon Valley’s venture capital firms have generally lagged behind their Wall Street cousins that take companies private in leveraged buyouts.

headline: A New Paris Boutique Proves That Good Things Come in Small Packages
abstract: Small, an offshoot of the MAN/WOMAN trade shows, is a 500-square-foot space in the Marais district hosting a rotating cast of soon-to-be-cultish brands.
lead_paragraph: Since 2012, the MAN/WOMAN trade shows, where a tightly edited selection of fashion and lifestyle brands showcase their newest offerings, have been paramount for magazine editors and retail buyers seeking the next big thing. To bring that curatorial point of view to the public, MAN/WOMAN recently opened its first retail location in Paris’s trendy Marais district. The shop, called Small, invites international retailers and brands to install their visions on a monthly basis in a cozy retail venue measuring just under 500 square feet. “Small appears as a good and quite easy option for designers to target a new consumer and market,” says one of its founders, Antoine Floch. Traveling between Paris, New York, Tokyo and sometimes Los Angeles on what seems like a weekly basis, Floch, along with his partners Olivier Migda and Romain Bernardie James, has developed a keen eye for fashion’s soon-to-be-cultish brands. “We are lucky to work with the most creative and most well-produced brands right now, as well as the most beautifully designed and curated stores on the planet,” he says. “Some of them have been friends for a long time.”

headline: Cannes Winners Selected for New Directors/New Films
abstract: “The Tribe” and “White God” are among the first nine films announced for the annual series.
lead_paragraph: Myroslav Slaboshpytskiy’s silent film “The Tribe” is among the first nine selections for the annual New Directors/New Films series presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, those organizations announced Wednesday.

headline: How the Brain Stores Trivial Memories, Just in Case
abstract: The new research suggests that human memory keeps sights, sounds and observations in cold storage for a time in case they become useful later on.
lead_paragraph: The surge of emotion that makes memories of embarrassment, triumph and disappointment so vivid can also reach back in time, strengthening recall of seemingly mundane things that happened just beforehand and that, in retrospect, are relevant, a new study has found.

headline: Best Twitter Ad Practices Include Narrow Targets, Videos and Brevity
abstract: Small-business owners discuss the tactics that work on the social media network’s advertising platform.
lead_paragraph: More than four years after introducing advertising on its platform, Twitter has changed the way businesses create ads. And as with any game in which the rules have shifted, players adapt by developing new strategies.

headline: 36 Hours in Denver
abstract: Explore street view, find our points of interest and sign in to your Google account to save your map.
lead_paragraph: Explore street view, find our points of interest and sign in to your Google account to save your map.

headline: ‘Pretty Filthy,’ Musically Speaking
abstract: The Civilians are laying bare the lives of porn stars in their newest production.
lead_paragraph: The Civilians are laying bare the lives of porn stars in their newest production, “Pretty Filthy.” A behind-the-scenes musical about the adult entertainment industry, drawn as always from extensive interviews with players in the business itself, the new show features songs by the company’s go-to composer-lyricist, the supremely gifted Michael Friedman (known for “Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson,” among others); a book by Bess Wohl; and direction by Steve Cosson, the troupe’s founding artistic director.

headline: Scientists Work to Contain Modified Organisms to Labs
keywords: ['Bacteria', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Microbiology', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Synthetic Biology', 'E Coli (Bacteria)']
abstract: Scientists reported that they had developed a complex technique to prevent genetically modified bacteria from escaping a laboratory or tank.
lead_paragraph: Could genetically modified bacteria escape from a laboratory or fermentation tank and cause disease or ecological destruction?

headline: At Windows 10 Event, Microsoft Jumps Into Augmented Reality With HoloLens Headset
abstract: The HoloLens could help renew some of the luster Microsoft has lost in the last decade, when it reacted late to critical new technology trends.
lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash. — Microsoft wants back in the game, and it is using a little science fiction to get there.

headline: Chancellor Set to Centralize Management of New York City Schools
abstract: Chancellor Carmen Fariña is expected to announce that principals will report to district superintendents, dispensing with a core philosophy of the Bloomberg administration.
lead_paragraph: Chancellor Carmen Fariña is expected to announce changes on Thursday that will restore a centralized hierarchy to New York City’s schools, largely dispensing with one of the core management philosophies of the previous mayoral administration.

headline: App Smart | Unleash Your Inner Musician
abstract: Look no further than your smartphone to do everything from tuning your stringed instrument to storing sheet music.
lead_paragraph: Look no further than your smartphone to do everything from tuning your stringed instrument to storing sheet music.

headline: German Activist Against ‘Islamization’ Posed as Hitler for Facebook Photo
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: The anti-Islam activist Lutz Bachmann stepped down from his leadership role with the German group Pegida after an image of him as Hitler spread online.
lead_paragraph: A leading figure in a German protest movement against the supposed “Islamization” of Europe by Muslim immigrants stepped down Wednesday after the German tabloid Bild reported on its front page that he had posed as Adolf Hitler for a photograph posted on Facebook in September.

headline: Below the Line: Shooting ‘The Grand Budapest Hotel’
abstract: Robert Yeoman, the cinematographer for “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” discusses his work.
lead_paragraph: The cinematographer Robert Yeoman has long been helping to craft meticulous and precise images for Wes Anderson’s films. He has shot every one of the director’s live-action movies since “Bottle Rocket,” contributing to a motif that is instantly recognizable, frequently praised and sometimes parodied. With “The Grand Budapest Hotel” (Oscar-nominated for best cinematography), Mr. Yeoman and Mr. Anderson took the visuals a level further, shooting in multiple aspect ratios for the different time periods in which the film takes place.

headline: Video Feature: For Musicians, Apps for Tuning, Keeping Time and Organizing Charts
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Musical Instruments', 'Translation and Interpreters', 'Music', 'Guitars', 'iOS (Operating System)', 'Android (Operating System)']

lead_paragraph: SMARTPHONES and tablets are powerful music devices. You can listen to music, you can create music and, with the right app, you can get an assist when playing an instrument.

keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Semetric, based in Britain, is one of a growing number of companies that record labels and others consult for data on how music is consumed online.
lead_paragraph: Apple has acquired Semetric, a company that analyzes data about music online, a move that may hint at Apple’s ambitions as it prepares to revamp iTunes and Beats Music.

headline: Justices Rule Dismissal of Air Marshal Unlawful
abstract: The air marshal was dismissed for contacting an MSNBC reporter after overnight stays were halted in a cost-cutting move, which he contended would leave some flights unprotected.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday in favor of a fired air marshal, saying he was covered by a federal law protecting whistle-blowers.

headline: German Anti-Immigrant Figure Quits Post After Posing as Hitler
abstract: Lutz Bachmann, of Pegida, or Patriotic Europeans Against the Islamization of the West, had appeared as Adolf Hitler in an image on his Facebook page.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The leader of an anti-immigrant movement that has attracted tens of thousands of supporters and upended political debate in Germany stepped down on Wednesday after he was found to have posted an online image of himself as Adolf Hitler, after weeks of denying any Nazi sympathies.

headline: Rehabilitating 11 Acres on the Waterfront
abstract: A half-million square feet of space in the former Brooklyn Army Terminal will be renovated by the city in a $100 million project.
lead_paragraph: A half-million square feet of space in the former Brooklyn Army Terminal will be renovated by the city in a $100 million project.

lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Cuomo Delivers State of the State Address
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'State of the State Message (NYS)']
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo gave his State of the State address and presented his proposed budget for the coming year.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, whose State of the State speech was delayed after the Jan. 1 death of his father, former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, delivered his yearly address to members of the Legislature in Albany. He also introduced his budget proposal for the fiscal year that begins April 1. Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat beginning his second four-year term, has signaled in recent days that he has ambitious plans in education, job creation, criminal justice reform, income inequality, property taxes and infrastructure.

headline: Hamas and Israel React to Bus Attack
abstract: Hamas and Israeli government spokesmen reacted to the attack in which a Palestinian man stabbed up to a dozen Israelis on a bus in Tel Aviv. Tensions between the two sides are high.
lead_paragraph: Hamas and Israeli government spokesmen reacted to the attack in which a Palestinian man stabbed up to a dozen Israelis on a bus in Tel Aviv. Tensions between the two sides are high.

headline: Credit Suisse Previews Effect of Rise in Swiss Franc on Profit
abstract: The bank, which is based in Zurich, said it had not recorded any “material losses” in its trading since Switzerland abandoned a cap on its currency and that the rapid rise in the franc had not affected its capital ratios.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Credit Suisse on Wednesday gave investors a preview of the potential effect that the recent sharp rise in the value of the Swiss franc will have on its profit. The bank emphasized that it had not suffered any “material trading losses” since Switzerland eliminated a cap on its currency last week.

headline: Predictions, Pet Peeves and Random Musings From Davos
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Swiss Franc (Currency)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Bankers and other attendees at the World Economic Forum offer their thoughts on regulation, oil prices and quantitative easing by the European Central Bank, among other subjects.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — Finance-related panels at the World Economic Forum here on Wednesday focused on the impact of low oil prices, anticipation of the potential impact of the European Central Bank’s decision on Thursday to buy significant pools of sovereign bonds, liquidity concerns and the consequences of heavy-handed regulation.

headline: Players Drop Fight Against Turf at Women’s World Cup
abstract: Women’s soccer players pressing FIFA to play this summer’s Women’s World Cup on natural grass instead of artificial turf withdrew their complaint on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A group of prominent women’s soccer players pressing FIFA to install natural grass for matches at this summer’s Women’s World Cup withdrew its complaint Wednesday, grudgingly accepting that the event will be played entirely on artificial turf.

headline: Where Is the Governor of Georgia? His Office Won’t Say
abstract: People in Georgia are starting to wonder where Gov. Nathan Deal, who is on a secret economic development mission, has disappeared to.

headline: Canada’s Central Bank Cuts a Key Rate
abstract: The Canadian central bank reduced its overnight rate to 0.75 percent from 1 percent, in the first change since 2010.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Forecasting a major economic slowdown in the face of lower oil prices, the Bank of Canada unexpectedly cut its key lending rate on Wednesday.

headline: Flaunting Guns in the Washington Statehouse
abstract: Gun-rights activists came packing heat to protest a new state law approved by voter referendum mandating background checks,
lead_paragraph: A scene that played out in the Washington state legislature was fit for a Clint Eastwood movie. Last week, a group of angry citizens showed up in the House gallery openly waving pistols and high powered rifles as they looked down upon the debating chamber below.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 12:30 P.M. (Sundance) (500) DAYS OF SUMMER (2009) Tom Hansen (Joseph Gordon-Levitt) is an “unapologetic believer in true love, soul mates and other touchstones of greeting card mythology (and romantic comedy ideology),” A. O. Scott wrote in his review of this film in The New York Times. Summer Finn (Zooey Deschanel), Mr. Scott said, is “skeptical of such notions and refuses to promise commitment or even consistency, but she does seem to want more and more of Tom’s company, and this leads him to believe that her carefully maintained barriers to intimacy are beginning to fall.” That pretty much sums up this Marc Webb movie.

headline: Amid the Chattering of the Global Elite, a Silent Interlude
abstract: A mix of breathing instructions, management theory and personal reflection at a panel at the World Economic Forum.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland  – For 10 minutes at the World Economic Forum here on Wednesday afternoon, a conference room jammed with more than 100 high-powered delegates was entirely silent.

headline: Belgian Artist’s Painting Infringes Upon Photographer’s Work, Court Rules
abstract: The Belgian artist Luc Tuymans’s painting of a sweating politician infringes on a news photo of the politician Jean-Marie Dedecker, a court ruled.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Belgian artist Luc Tuymans faces fines of up to 500,000 euros (about $580,000), after a court ruled that his washed-out painting of a sweating politician is a copyright infringement that plagiarizes a photo taken by a news photographer.

headline: Loyal Knicks Fans May Deserve a Medal. But a Refund?
abstract: A Knicks fan says the team should lower ticket prices or learn from Broadway, where theatergoers are compensated when major stars cannot appear.
lead_paragraph: Loyal Knicks fans will not be surprised after this painful season when they learn that their ticket prices will not rise in 2015-16.

headline: Rikers Officers Who Hogtied and Beat an Inmate in 2012 Are Fired
keywords: ['Guards', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers']
abstract: The New York City correction commissioner, Joseph Ponte, announced that he was dismissing a captain and five guards involved in a violent encounter in a cellblock for men with mental illnesses.
lead_paragraph: The New York City correction commissioner announced on Wednesday that he was firing a captain and five Rikers Island guards who hogtied an inmate and then, while his hands were still cuffed behind him and his ankles shackled, savagely beat him in April 2012.

headline: A Delicate Operation
abstract: Maneuvering a sizable model of the ocean liner Queen Mary out of its Lower Manhattan home was one of the first challenges in getting it across the country.
lead_paragraph: Maneuvering a sizable model of the ocean liner Queen Mary out of its Lower Manhattan home was one of the first challenges in getting it across the country.

headline: It’s Not Easy to Steer the Queen Mary, Even a Model of It
abstract: A 21-foot-long scale model of the ocean liner started its journey from Lower Manhattan to California, where it will berth for a year.
lead_paragraph: The distance from a particular storefront in Lower Manhattan to Long Beach, Calif., is roughly 2,815 miles by truck, which is how this Queen Mary is going there — by truck. Not through the Panama Canal or around Cape Horn. Not this time. Not this Queen Mary.

headline: Have Questions About Winter Cooking?
abstract: Join New York Times Food reporter Melissa Clark for a Q. and A. about winter cooking on The New York Times Facebook Page.
lead_paragraph: Cold weather lends itself to bubbling baked dishes and hearty root vegetables. But the season also brings bright citrus to the table, as in this week’s recipe for lemon bars from Melissa Clark.

headline: A Theme in Davos: Fear of Financial Instability
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Swiss Franc (Currency)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Unsettling the participants at the World Economic Forum? Russia and Ukraine, cheap oil, volatile currency markets, deflation, terrorism, and even Switzerland.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — Fear is back in the valley of the privileged.

headline: The Investigation Into Whether the Patriots Used Deflated Footballs
abstract: N.F.L. officials are investigating whether the Patriots violated league rules by using footballs that were not properly inflated during the A.F.C. championship game against the Colts on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. officials are investigating whether the Patriots violated league rules by using footballs that were not properly inflated during the A.F.C. championship game against the Colts on Sunday.

headline: ‘Ben-Gurion: Father of Modern Israel,’ by Anita Shapira
abstract: The life of David Ben-Gurion, Israel’s first prime minister.
lead_paragraph: Recently, there was something of an ideological fistfight at the grave of Israel’s founding father. During a ceremony at Sde Boker in the Negev desert marking the 41 years since the death of David Ben-Gurion, the former and current presidents of Israel — Shimon Peres and Reuven Rivlin — slammed efforts to pass new legislation to enshrine Israel’s status as a Jewish state, a bill that many critics say will roll back Israel’s status as a democracy and turn the country’s Arabs, who are about 20 percent of the population, into second-class citizens. The chief sponsor of the so-called Jewish nation-state bill, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, sat stewing in the front row. When it was his turn to speak, he said that no one knows what Ben-Gurion would say were he alive today.

headline: Workers at Hunts Point Terminal Produce Market Approve Contract
abstract: A day before a threatened strike, an agreement was reached that grants more than 1,200 workers raises in each of three years.
lead_paragraph: Workers at the Hunts Point Terminal Produce Market in the Bronx voted on Wednesday to approve a three-year contract, ending a contentious dispute over wage increases and health benefits that had threatened to lead to their first strike in nearly three decades.

headline: Uber Closes $1.6 Billion in Financing
abstract: With the new investment, the company is valued at some $41.2 billion — one of the richest-ever valuations for a private start-up.
lead_paragraph: Uber, the popular ride-hailing start-up, has closed $1.6 billion in financing from clients of Goldman Sachs’s private wealth arm, the investment bank confirmed on Wednesday.

abstract: Snow fell in Washington on Wednesday.

headline: Ideas for E.L.L.s | Teaching About Weather and Seasons
abstract: The weather is a great topic for English Language Learners — it’s an issue that affects them every day. There are opportunities to discuss it all the time. Praising a nice day is nice, but who doesn’t love to complain about a bad one? And the topic provides easy reading, writing, speaking and listening opportunities

headline: Marissa Mayer’s Plan for Yahoo Takes Hold. The Question Now Is Time.
abstract: Marissa Mayer has made sharp acquisitions and rebuilt crucial products, but her future may depend on reaction to her plans for the Alibaba investment.
lead_paragraph: When Marissa Mayer was offered the chief executive job at Yahoo in the summer of 2012, she had a script for returning the pioneering Internet company to the tiny club of Silicon Valley powerhouses.

headline: U.S. Not Expected to Fault Officer in Ferguson Case
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Authorities have found no evidence to support charges against Darren Wilson, a former police officer in Ferguson, Mo., in the shooting death of Michael Brown, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Department lawyers will recommend that no civil rights charges be brought against the police officer who fatally shot an unarmed teenager in Ferguson, Mo., after an F.B.I. investigation found no evidence to support charges, law enforcement officials said Wednesday.

headline: Boehner Comments on Netanyahu Invitation
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner discusses his decision to ask Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to address Congress without consulting the White House, saying he is not “poking anyone in the eye.”
lead_paragraph: Speaker John A. Boehner discusses his decision to ask Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to address Congress without consulting the White House, saying he is not “poking anyone in the eye.”

headline: New Plays by Churchill, Shawn Will Be Part of National Theater Season
abstract: The shows will be part of Rufus Norris’s first season as the theater’s artistic director.
lead_paragraph: New plays by Caryl Churchill and Wallace Shawn, a new musical, “wonder.land,” by the Blur frontman Damon Albarn and the playwright Moira Buffini, and an updated version of the 15th-century English drama “Everyman,” starring Chiwetel Ejiofor, are among the highlights of next season’s programming at London’s National Theater.

headline: Young Players Give Signs of Australian Tennis Revival
abstract: After languishing as Lleyton Hewitt began to age, Australia has a new crop of young players, a sign that the country could revive its clout in men’s tennis.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — It was Rafael Nadal’s night at Melbourne Park on Wednesday, as he found a way to win when his body was sending him all the wrong signals.

lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio was a high-profile supporter of Mitt Romney’s 2012 bid for the presidency, campaigning with him repeatedly in the senator’s home state, Florida, a perennial battleground.

abstract: A daily cocktail may be associated with a lower risk for heart failure.
lead_paragraph: A daily cocktail may be associated with a lower risk for heart failure.

abstract: Senator Harry Reid to have surgery on right eye to recover vision; will remain off of Capitol Hill next week.

abstract: Google is investing in Elon Musk’s company, which is planning a broadband network of 4,000 satellites. The pioneering Teledesic tried something similar two decades ago but failed, notes Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk’s satellite dream is a throwback to the 1990s.

headline: Julianne Moore
abstract: A general feeling of “What can’t she do?” clings to the actress in her work and her fashion.
lead_paragraph: A general feeling of “What can’t she do?” clings to the actress in her work and her fashion.

headline: Decree Reflects Rift in Boston Over 2024 Olympics
abstract: On the day that the promoters of Boston’s plan to host the 2024 Summer Olympics finally made their bid public, it emerged that Mayor Martin J. Walsh had signed an agreement to prohibit city employees from speaking negatively about the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — On the day that the promoters of Boston’s plan to host the 2024 Summer Olympics finally made their bid public, a surprising bit of counterprogramming emerged from City Hall.

headline: A Most Unwelcome Return
abstract: In the play “Wyoming,” a family gets uncomfortable reminders when a son arrives for Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: Some plays are better staged after the holidays, when audience members are less likely to hyperventilate in sympathetic response. Here’s one: Brian Watkins’s “Wyoming,” in which a family’s Thanksgiving is jolted by the arrival of a surprise guest — the long-lost son who killed his father and has barely been mentioned since.

headline: Bronx Museum of the Arts Plans Art Exchange With Cuba
abstract: The Bronx Museum of the Arts and the National Museum of Fine Arts in Havana plan a major exchange of art that reflects a running conversation about their overlapping interests.
lead_paragraph: The Bronx Museum of the Arts and the National Museum of Fine Arts in Cuba announced Wednesday that a major exchange of works from their collections would take place this year and next in the most sweeping collaboration between the two countries’ museums in more than 50 years.

headline: Meghan Trainor Opens at No. 1
abstract: Ms. Trainor’s debut album, “Title,” topped the album chart, aided by her hit singles “All About That Bass” and “Lips Are Movin.”
lead_paragraph: Meghan Trainor’s debut album, “Title,” opened at the top of the Billboard chart this week, riding the momentum of her anthem “All About That Bass” and her latest hit single, “Lips Are Movin.”

headline: A Caustic Detective on the Beat
abstract: In the new Fox series “Backstrom,” Rainn Wilson (“The Office”) portrays a cigar-smoking investigator only somewhat in the Gregory House mold.
lead_paragraph: An annoying and offensive detective, Everett Backstrom (Rainn Wilson), is called to a wet, wooded campus crime scene where a student has been found dead, a possible suicide. “I’m a rich white senator’s pretty-boy son, I get up before the dawn in the pouring rain, and I hang myself from a bridge,” Backstrom asks aloud, puffing on a fat cigar. “Why?”

headline: Another Loss for Nice Guys; This One Wins Praise
abstract: Rafael Nadal defeated the qualifier Tim Smyczek in five sets, but what left Nadal most impressed was Smyczek’s sportsmanship after a fan disrupted Nadal’s serve late in the final set.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Tim Smyczek, a qualifier from Milwaukee ranked 112th, wielded his racket exceptionally well Wednesday night, striking 64 winners and coming within one game of upsetting third-ranked Rafael Nadal in the second round of the Australian Open.

headline: In Williamsburg, a Wedding Salon for Very Brooklyn Brides
abstract: Caitlin Mociun, whose custom jewelry is a favorite among the borough’s betrothed, is opening a wedding-oriented boutique that’s anything but traditional.
lead_paragraph: “I’m hoping to help brides feel more comfortable not wearing white to their weddings,” says Caitlin Mociun, gesturing toward a lemon-yellow gown. That’s not the only tradition the Brooklyn-based designer — noted among the betrothed for her sculptural fine jewelry and eponymous design shop — is looking to upend with today’s opening of Mociun White, her new wedding-oriented boutique. “It’s about a specific experience for a bride,” she says. “I wanted to create a space that redefined what a bridal salon is.” Mociun, who is returning to creating clothing after a three-year hiatus, has set her own not-so-bridal bridal collection — expertly cut Italian lace dresses, shirt-and-skirt combos and plenty of color — against a not-so-bridal interior: railings painted bright hues, intricate tile work, tables made with Archer Modern, a Bec Brittain chandelier and loop lights by Lucas Peet. Embellished pieces by Naeem Khan round out the assortment. The idea for the store came to her after time spent shopping at bridal salons with friends: “There were little vases of white flowers and rococo furniture, and it smelled like potpourri — it felt like a little girl’s dream, not the dream of an adult woman who’s really into design,” she recalls. Instead, she says, “I wanted a beautiful space that was cool architecturally.”

headline: Celebrating the Art of Song
abstract: Marilyn Horne presided over “The Song Continues,” a celebration of the art of song, at Zankel Hall on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Since her “retirement,” the mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne has been a mentor to young singers, offering guidance at festivals and workshops including “The Song Continues” at Carnegie Hall, a series of master classes that culminates in a public performance.

headline: EBay to Cut 2,400 Jobs, and Weighs 2nd Spinoff
abstract: The company plans a drastic restructuring in the face of slowing sales and intense competition.
lead_paragraph: EBay has made billions reinventing ways to sell items on the Internet. Now, in the face of declining growth, the company must reinvent itself once more.

headline: Belgium Offers Partial IDs of 2 Killed in Police Raid
abstract: The federal prosecutor’s office gave only first names for the two men who died in a firefight in Verviers, and said both had Belgian citizenship.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The Belgian authorities on Wednesday partly identified two men believed to be Islamic militants who died last week in a police raid, releasing the first names and nationalities — one Belgian, one Belgian-Moroccan — of the pair, who were suspected of belonging to a terrorist network and plotting an imminent attack.

headline: Protesters Stage ‘Die-In’ at Capitol
abstract: A few dozen protesters staged a “die-in” in a House cafeteria to raise awareness of the “Black Lives Matter” movement.
lead_paragraph: Never come between a hungry lawmaker and lunch. But a few dozen protesters tried to do just that on Wednesday, staging a “die-in” in a House cafeteria to raise awareness of the “Black Lives Matter” movement.

headline: Russia Presses Ahead With Plan for Gas Pipeline to Turkey
abstract: In the face of European Union opposition to the South Stream pipeline project, Gazprom is moving to an alternate route.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — President Vladimir V. Putin surprised the world in December when he aborted long-laid plans for a natural gas pipeline under the Black Sea to Europe, saying Russia would run pipes to Turkey instead.

headline: When Measles Spreads From Disneyland, It’s a Small World After All
abstract: A current measles outbreak, now at 48 confirmed cases, began with a visitor to Disneyland, and quickly spread beyond those directly exposed there.
lead_paragraph: The latest measles outbreak, which began at Disneyland in California between Dec. 17 and 20, is spreading. The seven confirmed cases first reported less than two weeks ago have quickly multiplied to 54 confirmed cases as of this writing. This includes two cases in Utah, two in Washington and one in Mexico. Some of the people infected were nowhere near Disneyland in December, suggesting that those infected in the park have begun infecting others. Most of those infected were “under-immunized,” which can mean they have been vaccinated against some illnesses but not others, or have not had all the recommended doses of a vaccine for their age.

headline: Reading The Times With Phil Klay
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Reading The Times with National Book Award winning writer Phil Klay
lead_paragraph: Phil Klay is a writer and a Marine Corps veteran of the Iraq war. His collection of short stories, “Redeployment,” received the 2014 National Book Award, and was recently named the recipient of the National Book Critics Circle’s John Leonard Prize.

headline: Anne Hathaway and Julie Taymor Team Up for ‘Grounded’
abstract: The play is a 70-minute monologue about a fighter pilot who is reassigned to operate drone strikes when she becomes pregnant.
lead_paragraph: The Academy Award winner Anne Hathaway (“Les Misérables”) and the Tony Award winner Julie Taymor (“The Lion King”) will team up this spring at the Public Theater on the prize-winning drama “Grounded,” a 70-minute monologue about a fighter pilot who is reassigned to operate drone strikes when she becomes pregnant, the Public announced on Wednesday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Syria and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Syria and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day

headline: Kinder Morgan to Buy Oil Pipeline Company From Harold Hamm for $3 Billion
abstract: The deal for Hiland Partners comes months after Mr. Hamm, an oil tycoon, was ordered to pay roughly $1 billion to his ex-wife, in one of the most expensive divorce settlements in history.
lead_paragraph: Kinder Morgan said on Wednesday that it had agreed to buy Hiland Partners, an oil pipeline and gathering company owned by the billionaire Harold Hamm, for about $3 billion, expanding its presence in the oil-rich Bakken rock formation in the northern United States.

headline: Executive Shake-Up at Procter & Gamble
abstract: David S. Taylor will take over the company’s beauty unit in a move interpreted to put him one step closer to succeeding the chief executive, A.G. Lafley.
lead_paragraph: Procter & Gamble announced a reshuffling of its top ranks on Wednesday in a move that might provide a clue to who will become the next leader of the consumer products giant.

headline: Free of Gluten, but Not of Arsenic (or of Guilt)
abstract: For gluten-free families, the increasing concerns about arsenic and rice are a source of worry and guilt. But how much should parents blame themselves?
lead_paragraph: Until last week, my children ate arsenic daily. Once used to poison royalty, arsenic (among other metals from the soil) is currently tainting rice, and I fed my daughters rice pasta for dinner, rice bread sandwiches for lunch, rice bagels for breakfast and rice cakes for snacks.

headline: Unlocking Prisons and Reopening Wounds
abstract: While Peter Carey’s “Amnesia” may be about a hacker, the novel has much less to do with computers than with Australian-American tensions during the 1942 Battle of Brisbane.
lead_paragraph: Peter Carey’s “Amnesia” has been received by some as an excitingly timely novel: “the story of WikiLeaks as if transmogrified by Dickens and turned into a thrilling fable for our post-Edward Snowden era,” as a writer in The Guardian has put it. But anyone expecting that kind of urgency can plow a long way into “Amnesia,” wondering when the fireworks start.

headline: The $210 Million Baseball Contract That Explains How Inflation Works
abstract: Both Max Scherzer and the Washington Nationals are effectively making a bet on the future path of prices.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Nationals have signed one of the best pitchers in the game to a blockbuster contract, bolstering an already excellent team. This is all very exciting news for baseball fans in Washington, as the $210 million contract for Max Scherzer gives the team perhaps the best pitching rotation in the sport.

headline: Jan. 21, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Syria, Pakistan, Israel and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Pakistan, Israel and the United States.

headline: Let Everyone Mingle, Awkward as It May Be
abstract: Part 2 of Taylor Mac’s sprawling adventure of culture(s) through music is a frolicsome romp from the 1930s to the 1950s.
lead_paragraph: “Everything you’re feeling is appropriate,” says Taylor Mac, repeatedly, as if to soothe anxious children, during the second three-hour installment of his opus in progress, “A 24-Decade History of Popular Music,” which is having its premiere at New York Live Arts as part of the Under the Radar festival. The assurance may well be needed for anyone in the audience uncomfortable with being uncomfortable — either physically, emotionally or politically.

headline: A Heart Broken and Dissected
abstract: Pop is not the point in “Vulnicura,” Björk’s new album.
lead_paragraph: The big news about Björk’s ninth studio album, “Vulnicura,” shouldn’t be the fact that she released it suddenly online, two months before its planned appearance, in response to having it leaked prematurely. It should be that in her latest songs, Björk leads as much with her heart as her brain.

headline: Disinherited Daughters Battle Their Father’s City Over Missing Artworks
keywords: ['Art', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes']
abstract: Barcelona officials claim the daughters of an industrialist who bequeathed his mansion to his native city covertly removed much of their father’s art collection from the property.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Núria Rivero, an art historian, gave a tour one recent day of a sumptuous mansion from Barcelona’s own bygone gilded age, one now owned by the city. But to her frustration, much of it was about what was not on the walls, instead of what was.

headline: Night Life
abstract: More than 670,000 photos have been posted on Instagram with the #nightshift hashtag, a window into a shadow world of workers.
lead_paragraph: More than 670,000 photos have been posted on Instagram with the #nightshift hashtag, a window into a shadow world of workers.

headline: With Each Star Turn, a Feeling of a Collective Force Begins to Brew
abstract: George Balanchine’s interplay between self and selflessness is on display in the New York City Ballet’s winter season opening performance.
lead_paragraph: As the curtain rises on George Balanchine’s “Serenade,” we’re plunged into a drama about selflessness. Seventeen young women are all facing front, all dressed alike, all slowly going through a ritual that strikingly resembles that of religious devotees. In what follows — as we watch loners; connections between individuals; kernel-like groups of three, four and five; and suggestions of love, loss, consolation and transcendence — we constantly see how lives are absorbed in something larger than private concerns.

headline: Twitter Now Helps You Catch Up on Missed Tweets
abstract: The social network is adding a feature called Recap that will show its users three top messages they missed since they last logged onto the service.
lead_paragraph: Twitter prides itself on being a real-time information service. If something big is going on right now, more and more people will post messages about it, and eventually the news will find its way into your Twitter feed.

headline: When Films and Facts Collide in Questions
abstract: The thorny question of historical accuracy, which continues to dog “Selma,” promises to be evergreen.
lead_paragraph: The issue of historical accuracy continues to dog “Selma,” though it’s hard to gauge how much the brouhaha contributed to the film’s inability to land best director and actor Oscar nods.

headline: New York Attorney General Adds to Lawsuit Over Barclays Dark Pool
abstract: Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York State attorney general, claimed that Barclays made a false statement in court documents and that it defied subpoenas seeking the testimony of two executives.
lead_paragraph: New York State’s top law enforcer has claimed that Barclays made a false statement in court documents and that it defied subpoenas seeking the testimony of two executives, a move that builds on a previous lawsuit over the bank’s private stock trading platform.

headline: This Is Your Grandmother
abstract: I saved her voice mails, realizing that any message could be the last.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR — I had two saved messages, and both began the same way: “Hello, Rebecca. This is your grandmother. In Florida.”

headline: Just Don’t ­Call Them Weeds
abstract: After years of being sold through Studio Drift’s website, the Dandelight is now available at the MoMA Store.
lead_paragraph: Studio Drift, a design group founded by Lonneke Gordijn and Ralph Nauta in Amsterdam, has built its reputation on fluff. A decade ago, Ms. Gordijn began gluing dandelion seeds to LEDs to produce lamps that softly filter light. The most ambitious versions take the form of chandeliers called Fragile Future, where the reconstituted dandelion heads are set in graceful bronze cages.

abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, in her first public speech of the year, denounced the recent attacks in Paris, weighed in President Obama’s State of the Union address and talked about ways to alleviate income inequality. She even impersonated Vladimir V. Putin.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Wednesday denounced the recent attacks by Muslim extremists in Paris, weighed in on the proposals President Obama outlined in his State of the Union address and talked about how the United States could alleviate income inequality. She even impersonated President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

lead_paragraph: Many people dread January’s subfreezing temperatures. But for those with a fireplace, like Ken Fulk, winter is something to look forward to.

headline: Look Closely Before You Sit
abstract: Aaron Scaturro recently introduced a variation on the Windsor chair that he calls a fan-back dining chair.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Scaturro, a 31-year-old self-taught woodworker, recently introduced a variation on the Windsor chair that he calls a fan-back dining chair. It takes two days to make, he said, and sells for $2,600. But that’s because of details the untrained eye may not notice: The legs are hand-turned and shaved, the spindles are hand-turned and scored, the tenons are tapered, and all the joints are wedged with ebony.
