lead_paragraph: Alabama Chanin’s first home collection in more than seven years includes throws, decorative pillows, napkins, candles, potholders and even drink cozies, almost all of it made in the company’s Florence, Ala., studio. And because it includes a combination of machine- and handmade items, the collection isn’t quite as pricey as the handmade quilts the company is known for.

headline: When Women Become Terrorists
abstract: Why does the West ignore the role they play in groups like ISIS?
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — SINCE the terror attacks in Paris two weeks ago, the French police have been on the hunt for Hayat Boumeddiene, the partner of Amedy Coulibaly, one of the slain gunmen. She is now suspected to be in Syria. Some news reports speculate that Ms. Boumeddiene, 26, may have been “the more radical of the two.” Yet one of the first questions that French authorities intend to ask her is, they say, “if she did this under influence, if she did it by ideology, if she did it to aid and abet.”

headline: Skiing Record Snow in Italy
abstract: A group of professional skiers traveled to Sella Nevea, Italy, to ski during the one of the snowiest winters in history.
lead_paragraph: A group of professional skiers traveled to Sella Nevea, Italy, to ski during the one of the snowiest winters in history.

headline: How Pink Is Your Floyd?
keywords: ['Light-Emitting Diodes', 'Electric Light Bulbs', 'Home Automation and Smart Homes']
abstract: With integrated stereo speakers, colors that pulse and other innovations, programmable LEDs are booming. But early adopters still pay a premium.
lead_paragraph: Get ready to dust off the old jokes about how many (fill in the blank) people it takes to change a light bulb. I just spent a week changing some of the bulbs in my house, and the complexity was enough to give me a migraine.

headline: At Home with Esther Freud
abstract: An old house on the coast of England inspired the novelist’s latest book, about Charles Rennie Mackintosh.

headline: They Stooped to Enter
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Writing and Writers', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A long-dreamed-of cottage in Walberswick, England, inspires the novelist Esther Freud’s latest book, about Charles Rennie Mackintosh.
lead_paragraph: Esther Freud first visited Walberswick, a village on the Suffolk coast in England, 30 years ago, when she was a young actress living in London and fed up with city life. She complained one day to her father, the painter Lucian Freud.

headline: A Manor of Family and Fiction
abstract: Andrea Chapin, an actress turned book editor, spent more than a decade helping writers publish their fiction before she embarked on a novel of her own.
lead_paragraph: ­Andrea Chapin, an actress turned book editor, spent more than a decade helping writers publish their fiction before she embarked on a novel of her own. Due out next month from Riverhead Books, “The Tutor” is the story of Katharine de L’Isle, muse of a gifted, honey-tongued young writer. With her guidance, Katharine’s protégé produces several sonnets and his first narrative poem, and goes on to a career as the actor and playwright we all know as William Shakespeare.

headline: Obama’s Bad Economic Ideas
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: We need a plan based on growth and work, not redistribution.
lead_paragraph: PRESIDENT OBAMA’S economic proposals in Tuesday’s State of the Union address were a disappointment. His ideas — free community college, an enhanced tax credit for child care and higher taxes on high-income earners and large financial institutions — failed to go beyond mere talking points. With no chance of engaging the Republicans, they will surely die without a hearing.

headline: Little House on the Alley
abstract: In Vancouver, a gift of land brings three generations closer.
lead_paragraph: In Vancouver, a gift of land brings three generations closer.

headline: At Home in the Out-Back
abstract: In Vancouver, a gift of land brings three generations closer.
lead_paragraph: For more than a year, Petto Chan refused to consider his wife’s idea of building a small, sustainable house in the backyard behind the large Vancouver home where he grew up with his extended family.

headline: Rare Alan Turing Document, Outlining Mathematical Thought, to be Auctioned
abstract: Auction house to sell notebook with writings by Alan Turing, the Enigma codebreaker.
lead_paragraph: It is short, just 56 pages long, and much of it consists of complicated mathematical musings written out in longhand. But it has never been seen before in public, and it provides an exciting insight into how Alan Turing, its author, formulated his theories about mathematical notation and computer science, according to Bonhams auction house.

headline: Off the Hook?
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Discrimination', 'Law and Legislation', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: One admires the chutzpah of party operatives whose platform opposes same-sex marriage hoping the justices will save them from having to choose sides in a fading culture war.
lead_paragraph: So the Republican establishment is breathing easy now that the Supreme Court is on the verge of issuing a ruling in favor of same-sex marriage, thus taking the question out of nasty old politics? “I think it’s probably going to be a relief,” a Republican committeeman from California told Jeremy W. Peters and Jonathan Martin of The New York Times, explaining that with such a ruling, “then it’s off the table.” Praise the Lord and thank the court.

headline: Cozy Onesies, Blanket Scarves and More for the Winter Chill
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Winter (Season)', 'Wool and Woolen Goods', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Onesies both comfortable and luxe; blanket scarves from the Andes; and a mohair and wool belted kimono coat.
lead_paragraph: In the face of punishing temperatures, going home on Friday and re-emerging on Monday may sound like a dream weekend. Think of it: binge-watching the first season of “The Fall” as you lounge in one of these luxe onesies. They will make you feel less guilty about having lunch delivered, and if you deign to leave the house, they can be layered up for a storm. You could even put on a nice pair of heels if there’s a party nearby.

headline: Recalling Romania’s Revolution
abstract: Joseph Rodriguez may be best known for his work in urban America, but his new book, “Romania,” shows him to be a photographer of the world.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Rodriguez may be best known for his work in urban America, but his new book, “Romania,” shows him to be a photographer of the world.

keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: With integrated stereo speakers, colors that pulse to the music and other innovations, programmable LEDs are booming.
lead_paragraph: With integrated stereo speakers, colors that pulse to the music and other innovations, programmable LEDs are booming.

headline: Power Lunches Are Out. Crumbs in the Keyboard Are In.
abstract: For the new-media generation, the three-martini lunch has gone the way of the manual Rolodex.
lead_paragraph: In early November, the television anchor Bryant Gumbel was standing in the middle of a sweaty crowd at the restaurant Michael’s, on West 55th Street. It was a little after 7 p.m., and Mr. Gumbel was shoulder-to-shoulder with other media luminaries, many of them household names for decades: Jann Wenner, Jay McInerney, Jeffrey Bewkes, Al Roker and Dr. Ruth Westheimer among them.

headline: Are You Man Enough for a Peel?
abstract: Dermatologists, facialists and skin-care companies say they are selling more facial peels to men every year to treat a variety of problems.
lead_paragraph: To prepare for important meetings, Robert Tomson, the owner of a women’s activewear company, has a secret weapon: an at-home two-step facial peel.

headline: Next-Generation Balms to Soothe Winter Lips
abstract: Come winter, with bracing winds and goth lipsticks, finding the perfect lip moisturizer takes on Monty Python proportions.
lead_paragraph: ­For most of the year, Chapstick will do. Come winter, with bracing winds and goth lipsticks, finding the perfect lip moisturizer takes on Monty Python proportions.

headline: Obama Unbowed: Grading the Speech
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Vetoes (US)']
abstract: Readers react to the State of the Union address.

headline: Jean-Claude Baker, ‘Son’ of Josephine Baker, Is Remembered
abstract: After Jean-Claude Baker, owner of Chez Josephine, was found dead last week, disbelieving friends summoned memories of his improbable life.
lead_paragraph: He told a few friends last week that he had finished his will, an impressive gesture even for the famously unbridled Jean-Claude Baker, irrepressible impresario of his own improbable life.

headline: Why Celebrities Are So Into the Artist Daniel Arsham
abstract: Mr. Arsham is not only a legitimate artist, but he has also collaborated with high-profile admirers, like James Franco, Hedi Slimane and Pharrell Williams.
lead_paragraph: Usher, the R&B star, discovered the artist Daniel Arsham the way most people find out about things: through friends. In this case, his friends happened to be Swizz Beatz, Jay Z and Pharrell Williams.

headline: A Look at Noteworthy Milan Men’s Collections
abstract: A cheat sheet to the reviews from the men’s wear shows at Milan Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Standing backstage after his Ermenegildo Zegna show on Saturday, the designer Stefano Pilati said functionality was one of the things on his mind as he created his fall 2015 collection. But the important function of anything Mr. Pilati produces is probably not to add a zippered elbow to an overcoat but to bring us his singular conception of beauty.

headline: Grand Jury Recommends Pennsylvania Attorney General Be Charged With Perjury
abstract: A state grand jury has recommended that Kathleen G. Kane be charged with perjury and other crimes in connection with her office’s disclosure of details about the secret investigation of a Philadelphia civil rights leader.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — A Pennsylvania grand jury has recommended that Kathleen G. Kane, the state’s attorney general, be charged with perjury and other crimes in connection with her office’s disclosure of details about the secret investigation of a Philadelphia civil rights leader, according to documents released Wednesday.

headline: Inequality in the Air We Breathe?
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Poverty', 'Discrimination']
abstract: It’s hard to imagine anyone, with a straight face, proposing to openly burn millions of pounds of explosives near, say, Manhattan or Seattle.
lead_paragraph: I grew up in the small town of Gibsland, in northern Louisiana. It is dirt poor, but proud. And it’s an overwhelmingly African-American community.

headline: Guy Bourdin’s Work Stands the Test of Time
abstract: A retrospective of the French fashion photographer at Somerset House.
lead_paragraph: London — The French fashion photographer Guy Bourdin died in 1991, but his influence can be felt in the pages of many of the fashion magazines that overwhelm the newsstands here.

headline: A Seamstress Who Handed Off to the N.F.L. for 48 Years
keywords: ['Football', 'Sporting Goods and Equipment', 'Leather and Leather Goods', 'Super Bowl']
abstract: Jane Helser recently retired from working at the Wilson Sporting Goods factory in Ada, Ohio, where employees accustomed to precise specifications see the Patriots’ deflation scandal as a distant issue.
lead_paragraph: ADA, Ohio — The first day Jane Helser went to work sewing footballs at the Wilson Sporting Goods factory in town, Lyndon Johnson was building his Great Society, Johnny Unitas was tossing passes for the Colts, and Apollo 11 was three years from landing on the moon.

headline: Hope Solo Is Suspended by U.S. Soccer for 30 Days
abstract: The suspension came after U.S. Soccer learned through news reports that Solo was present and reportedly arguing with the police when her husband was arrested for driving under the influence on Monday.
lead_paragraph: U.S. Soccer suspended goalkeeper Hope Solo for 30 days on Wednesday after learning through news reports that she was present and arguing with the police when her husband was arrested on suspicion of driving under the influence early Monday.

headline: Shannon’s Scouts vs. Sherman’s Armies
abstract: Unable to beat the Union general on the field, the Confederacy sent a small group of shock troops to slow down his progress through the Carolinas.
lead_paragraph: By late January 1865, the death knell was tolling loudly for the Confederacy. It was a month after the fall of Savannah, Ga., the finale to Union Gen. William T. Sherman’s March to the Sea. On Jan. 21, as his army rested in Savannah, Sherman penned a letter to Gen. James H. Wilson, commander of the federal cavalry. Using his typically brash and cocksure language, Sherman congratulated Wilson and himself on the success of the march. “I Knocked daylight through Georgia, and in retreating to s[outh] like a sensible man I gathered up some plunder and walked into this beautiful City,” Sherman wrote, “whilst you & Thomas gave Hood & Forest (sic) a taste of what they have to Expect by trying to meddle with our Conquered Territory.”

headline: Take-Along Chargers That Pack Power
abstract: The right external accessory can double the battery life of your mobile device and offer an option when an electrical outlet isn’t available.
lead_paragraph: SPEND any time in an airport, and you’ll witness the electrical outlet acting as the 21st century’s fire pit. Armed with their smartphones, travelers huddle around outlets, hoping to warm their portable devices with some extra power before flying.

headline: Where the Road Meets the Walrus
keywords: ['Gasoline Tax (US)', 'Roads and Traffic', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']
abstract: The gas tax might be a good topic to discuss when people ask you what you thought of President Obama’s State of the Union address.
lead_paragraph: Let’s raise the gas tax.

headline: Republicans Push Plan in Net Neutrality Debate
keywords: ['Net Neutrality', 'Law and Legislation', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Two hearings on Capitol Hill addressed a move by conservatives aimed at countering an imminent ruling by the telecommunications regulator.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The debate on Capitol Hill over the future of the Internet spilled into public view on Wednesday, as a pair of hearings took up a Republican proposal to put the issue in lawmakers’ hands.

headline: Senate Rejects Climate Measures
abstract: The Senate on Wednesday twice rejected measures declaring that humans are causing climate change.
lead_paragraph: The Senate on Wednesday twice rejected measures declaring that humans are causing climate change. But in the course of those votes, 15 Republicans, including Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky, voted yes. Mr. Paul, who is considered a likely presidential contender next year, was joined by Senators Bob Corker and Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire, Lisa Murkowski of Alaska and Jeff Flake of Arizona, among others. Two other potential Republican presidential candidates, Senators Marco Rubio of Florida and Ted Cruz of Texas, voted no. It was the first time in years that senators had voted on a climate change measure, and it came in the course of a debate on a bill forcing approval of the Keystone XL oil pipeline. President Obama is expected to veto the bill if it passes, as is likely, but lawmakers are using it to send their own political messages. Democrats had hoped to force Republicans on the record on the issue of climate change by introducing the two amendments.

headline: Microsoft HoloLens: A Sensational Vision of the PC’s Future
abstract: The device, which looks like ski goggles, superimposes holograms on reality and could have uses in communication, design, games, science and more.
lead_paragraph: IT’S generally wise to take demonstrations of new technologies with a grain of salt. That was especially true for the Microsoft HoloLens — the hologram-projecting glasses that the tech giant unveiled on Wednesday — which a small number of reporters were allowed to use for a few minutes.

headline: Turkey: 2 Officers Sentenced in Death
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Police']
abstract: The police officers were sentenced Wednesday to 10 years in prison for their role in the fatal beating of a university student.
lead_paragraph: Two Turkish police officers were sentenced Wednesday to 10 years in prison  for their role in the fatal beating of a university student during antigovernment protests in 2013, a case that has become a symbol of police violence. Four other people received lesser sentences in the death of the student, Ali Ismail Korkmaz, 19, who was hit in the head with clubs several times by men in civilian clothing in Eskisehir, a northwestern town. He died more than a month after falling into a coma. On Wednesday the police in Kayseri, a central Anatolian town where the hearing took place, used tear gas to disperse crowds that criticized the terms as too lenient, news reports said. The 2013 protests grew into nationwide riots against the authoritarian tendencies of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, now president, who called the protesters looters and terrorists seeking to overthrow his government.

headline: Inside a Wilson Football Factory
abstract: Jane Helser recently retired after working for nearly 50 years at the Wilson Sporting Goods factory, the source of the N.F.L.’s handmade footballs.
lead_paragraph: Jane Helser recently retired after working for nearly 50 years at the Wilson Sporting Goods factory, the source of the N.F.L.’s handmade footballs.

headline: Euroblunders
abstract: On doing everything wrong.
lead_paragraph: The contrast between the mood in the US and in Europe is amazing. Obama wasn’t exactly able to claim morning in America in this week’s SOTU, but he was able to talk about success and moving forward. Meanwhile Mario Draghi is doing what he can and should, but I don’t know anyone who really believes that it will be enough.

headline: Day After President’s Speech, Some Doubts Linger Over Nation’s Recovery
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'Income Inequality', 'Careers and Professions', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Retirement']
abstract: Despite President Obama’s call to help the middle class, unease lingered among those who said they were still earning less than before the recession.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — As a web developer benefiting from an 8 percent pay raise, Brad McLaughlin is looking good economically. He and his girlfriend are spending more money on natural groceries, ski weekends in Colorado’s mountains and vacations to England and Austin, Tex. Not that he credits President Obama for any of it.

headline: ‘Too Big to Fail’ on Financial Regulators’ Agenda Again
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Insurance']
abstract: Top financial regulators addressed the process of determining what companies are systemically important, shadowed by MetLife’s legal challenge to that designation.
lead_paragraph: Top financial regulators on Wednesday discussed ways to improve how so-called too-big-to-fail institutions are singled out for closer supervision, but they stopped well short of reversing any designations made so far.

headline: Once Incendiary, a Book Debuts Quietly in a Reshaped Nation
abstract: The book that spans Mrs. Gandhi’s life — from her birth in a small town to her ascent as the Congress Party matriarch — was released without fanfare in India.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Five years ago, the release in India of “The Red Sari,” about the president of the then-governing Indian National Congress Party, Sonia Gandhi, was unthinkable. Mrs. Gandhi was considered by some the de facto prime minister of the country, and her loyalists were incensed by the book’s contents, which they said was riddled with lies. They burned effigies of its Spanish author, Javier Moro, in Delhi’s streets, and according to the Spanish publisher, lawyers representing the Gandhi family threatened a lawsuit.

headline: Goldman Sachs Investments Test the Volcker Rule
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Goldman Sachs has found ways to put its money to work in formats that appear to comply with the Volcker Rule, but its investments have caused concern among some of its big clients.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs has been on a shopping spree with its own money, snapping up apartments in Spain, a mall in Utah and a European ink company, all of which the bank hopes eventually to sell for a profit.

headline: Measles Cases Linked to Disneyland Rise, and Debate Over Vaccinations Intensifies
abstract: As the number of diagnoses in California reached 59, some schools said students may be barred because they have not been inoculated.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A measles outbreak that began at Disneyland is spreading across California and beyond, prompting health officials to move aggressively to contain it — including by barring unvaccinated students from going to school in Orange County. The outbreak has increased concerns that a longstanding movement against childhood vaccinations has created a surge in a disease that was declared eliminated in the United States in 2000.

headline: For Former Assistants at Duke, Moving Up Means Moving Out
abstract: Steve Wojciechowski, whose Marquette team lost to St. John’s at the Garden, is among the many former assistants to Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski who are now head coaches elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Chris Carrawell knew he had to go far away when his time came. That was the way it was with all the former Duke players who had gone on to coaching roles at the university. Life in Durham, N.C., is so nice and cozy for the team’s assistant coaches — top talent, sustained national relevance and consistent job offers — that it is hard to find a reason to leave.

headline: Google Hopes to Take the Web Directly to Billions Lacking Access
abstract: The company believes it can use its growing collection of devices in the sky to spread the Internet to underserved areas around the world.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google has never shied from novelty or spending big to find ways to connect more people to the Internet. Over the last two years, its ideas have included fleets of little satellites, solar-powered drones that would fly around the world and balloons that float high into the stratosphere, beaming the Internet to those below.

headline: Gov. Cuomo Takes On Education
abstract: The governor’s undertaking for his second term is overdue and laudable, but he will face resistance from the state’s powerful teachers’ unions.
lead_paragraph: As presented in his State of the State address on Wednesday, Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s ambitious projects for his second term include a much-needed increase in the minimum wage, reform of the justice system, some forgiveness of student loans and a new commission to determine fair pay for legislators. At the top of his list is reforming the New York’s educational system. This is a laudable undertaking that has long needed addressing, Mr. Cuomo said, but also one that will put him directly at loggerheads with the powerful teachers’ unions.

headline: Obama: ‘Middle-Class Economics Works’

abstract: The president laid the groundwork for middle-class economics during his State of the Union address on Jan. 20.
lead_paragraph: The president laid the groundwork for middle-class economics during his State of the Union address on Jan. 20.

headline: Talk of Wealth Gap Prods the G.O.P. to Refocus
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Minimum Wage', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: With the economy on more solid ground, leading Republicans are tempering complaints about overall economic growth and refocusing on income disparity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s push for a new “middle-class economics” may go nowhere in Congress, but his ambitious array of proposals to raise stagnant incomes and provide more government support for struggling working families will frame his last two years in office and help make the politics of rich and poor a central issue in the campaign to succeed him.

headline: Argentine Phone Calls Detail Efforts to Shield Iran
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'International Relations', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: The intercepted telephone conversations, if proved accurate, describe an elaborate effort to reward Argentina for shipping food to Iran and for seeking to derail the investigation into a terrorist attack.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Intercepted conversations between representatives of the Iranian and Argentine governments point to a long pattern of secret negotiations to reach a deal in which Argentina would receive oil in exchange for shielding Iranian officials from charges that they orchestrated the bombing of a Jewish community center in 1994.

headline: Patriots Drag the N.F.L. Back Into Turbulence
abstract: Just when you think that the N.F.L. has temporarily halted its descent into the maelstrom, here comes an old reliable, the New England Patriots.
lead_paragraph: Just when you think that the N.F.L. has temporarily halted its descent into the maelstrom, here comes an old reliable, the New England Patriots.

headline: U.S. Seeking a Stronger World Media Voice
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Radio', 'Television', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Andrew Lack, the first chief executive of the Broadcasting Board of Governors, represents a sea change for the agency, which oversees United States government-supported civilian international news media.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Andrew Lack was sworn in this week as the first chief executive of the Broadcasting Board of Governors, putting him in charge of an agency with a $700 million budget and an outsize influence on shaping world opinion about the United States. Foreign policy experts and some critics say the appointment of Mr. Lack, the former president of NBC News and a prominent news media executive, represents a sea change for the often-criticized agency, which oversees United States government-supported civilian international news media such as Voice of America, Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, the Middle East Broadcasting Networks and Radio Free Asia.

headline: Reagan, Obama and Inequality
abstract: The average American has been stuck since the Reagan era in a predawn darkness of stagnation and inequality.
lead_paragraph: Since the end of the 1970s, something has gone profoundly wrong in America.

headline: U.S. and Cuba Set to Discuss Diplomatic Ties
abstract: The nations on Wednesday discussed migration, and a meeting on Thursday will cover matters like reopening embassies.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — Seeking to restore relations ruptured more than five decades ago, the United States and Cuba began talks here on Wednesday by agreeing to disagree on a central issue dividing them — the privilege of Cubans who arrive in the United States to automatically qualify for residency.

headline: Boston's 2024 Olympic Bid
abstract: The bid prepared by Boston 2024, a group of business leaders, construction magnates and politicians that was presented to the United States Olympic Committee in December. The committee chose Boston over Los Angeles, San Francisco and Washington on Jan. 8.
lead_paragraph: The bid prepared by Boston 2024, a group of business leaders, construction magnates and politicians that was presented to the United States Olympic Committee in December. The committee chose Boston over Los Angeles, San Francisco and Washington on Jan. 8.

headline: Gloom Lifts, and Obama Goes All Out
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy']
abstract: President Obama’s self-assured State of the Union address Tuesday reflected his sense of being liberated and emboldened, White House aides said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The morning after major Democratic losses in last year’s midterm elections, President Obama walked into the Roosevelt Room with a message for his despondent staff: I’m not done yet.

headline: Topless Photos Return to Page 3 of Britain’s Sun Tabloid
abstract: Its front page, posted online along with a preview of the topless woman, corrected other outlets’ reports that the paper was ending the feature.
lead_paragraph: The news swept the world, applauded as a sign of progress. After 40 years Britain’s Sun newspaper, according to news reports this week, would stop running photographs of topless women on its Page 3.

headline: Decoder Ring, for Short
abstract: A Timothy Polin puzzle that’s of solid construction.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — We’re building columns today, but they’re not the kind that hold up buildings. Timothy Polin is back, and he has hidden a group of subversives in our puzzle. We’re going to have to keep an eye on him.

headline: Queens Van Driver Accused of Fatally Shooting a Rival
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs']
abstract: A livery van driver was arrested on Wednesday in the fatal shooting of a second driver who the police believe was a competitor in the network of unlicensed dollar vans.
lead_paragraph: A livery van driver from Queens was charged on Wednesday in the fatal shooting of a second driver who the police believe was a rival in the shadow transportation network of unlicensed dollar vans.

headline: Rejecting a Life of Crime, and Hoping to Help Others
abstract: Gordon Raymond has sold drugs and spent time in prison, but he is determined to resist a return to the streets and instead earn a degree in social work.
lead_paragraph: Gordon Raymond is not proud when he talks about his past, and the various crimes he once carried out without a second thought. Today, at 53, Mr. Raymond is trying to atone; he wants to make a difference in the lives of others.

headline: When Digital Thieves Strike, Artists Act Quickly to Seize Opportunity
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Music']
abstract: Strategies are shifting for musical artists (including Madonna) and their labels when album tracks are hacked and released.
lead_paragraph: When nearly 30 new Madonna songs, many of them unfinished demos, surfaced online last month, the singer and her team reacted both emotionally and with a savvy business acumen tailored to the digital era.

headline: In Journal, Man Wrote of Creating Silk Road, an Online Black Market, Prosecutors Say
keywords: ['Black Markets', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: Reading from what they say is his diary, prosecutors in Federal District Court highlighted Ross W. Ulbricht’s ideas for starting and expanding the online black market.
lead_paragraph: Long before the website Silk Road became an online black market for drugs and other illicit goods, it began its life of underground commerce with the sale of homegrown hallucinogenic mushrooms, prosecutors have said.

headline: Edgewater Fire Drives Hundreds From Apartment Building
abstract: Flames from the blaze at Avalon at Edgewater in New Jersey could be seen across the Hudson River in Manhattan. No deaths or serious injuries had been reported, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A huge fire ripped through an apartment building near the Hudson River in New Jersey on Wednesday night, forcing the evacuation of hundreds of people and sending large plumes of black smoke billowing into the air.

headline: Tony Verna, Who Started Instant Replay and Remade Sports Television, Dies at 81
abstract: Before the Army-Navy football game of 1963, Mr. Verna, the inventor of instant replay, puzzled out a method to rewind videotape and immediately run it again.
lead_paragraph: The Army-Navy game of 1963 was an important one in that season’s college football landscape. With a Heisman Trophy winner and future pro star at quarterback, Roger Staubach, Navy, the No. 2 team in the nation, won by 21-15 and went on to face top-ranked Texas in the Cotton Bowl. (Texas won.)

headline: Melvin J. Gordon, Who Ran Tootsie Roll Industries, Dies at 95
abstract: Mr. Gordon expanded the product line, buying brands like Charleston Chew and Junior Mints, and running the company with an iron grip.
lead_paragraph: Melvin J. Gordon, who ran Tootsie Roll Industries for more than 50 years, died on Wednesday in Boston. He was 95.

headline: Facing 76ers, Knicks Earn a Win. Someone Had To.
abstract: In a game between two teams jockeying for the top pick in the N.B.A. draft, the Knicks, whether they liked it or not, took home the victory.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — What happens when an anemic force meets an infirm object? That premise was tested on Wednesday when the Knicks and the Philadelphia 76ers, who had combined for 14 wins, met at Wells Fargo Center.

headline: Alan J. Hirschfield, Who Led Film Studio Through Financial Scandal, Dies at 79
abstract: At Columbia Pictures, Mr. Hirschfield fought board members in an attempt to fire an executive who had embezzled money, and both were forced out.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Alan J. Hirschfield, an executive who ran two major film studios and saw Columbia Pictures through one of Hollywood’s most colorful and chronicled financial scandals, died on Jan. 15 at his home in Wilson, Wyo. He was 79.

headline: Serena and Venus Williams Advance in Straight Sets, With a Bit of Levity
abstract: Venus, seeded 18th, went first, beating fellow American Lauren Davis, 6-2, 6-3. Serena, the top seed, went next, beating Vera Zvonareva of Russia, 7-5, 6-0.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Venus and Serena Williams made their first long journey to the Australian Open in 1998 and played each other in the second round, with Venus, the big sister, coming out on top.

headline: John Bayley, Oxford Don Who Wrote of His Wife, Iris Murdoch, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Bayley was an Oxford don and literary critic who found an international readership with his memoir “Elegy for Iris,” a moving account of his life with the novelist Iris Murdoch, his wife.
lead_paragraph: John Bayley, an Oxford don and literary critic who found an international readership with his memoir “Elegy for Iris,” a moving account of his life with the novelist Iris Murdoch, his wife, after she was struck by Alzheimer’s disease, died on Jan. 12 at his home in Lanzarote, in the Canary Islands. He was 89.

headline: Romney and Jeb Bush to Meet in Utah
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The private meeting scheduled this week between Mitt Romney and Mr. Bush raises the possibility that the two former governors will find a way to avoid competing presidential campaigns.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jeb Bush and Mitt Romney are scheduled to meet privately this week in Utah, raising the possibility that the two former governors will find a way to avoid competing presidential campaigns that would split the Republican establishment next year, two prominent party members said Wednesday night.

headline: Faten Hamama, Actress Hailed as ‘Lady of the Arabic Screen,’ Dies at 83
abstract: Ms. Hamama appeared in nearly 100 films but was best known to American audiences as the wife of Omar Sharif, whose career she had helped start.
lead_paragraph: Faten Hamama, the Egyptian-born actress whose victory in a beauty contest when she was only 7 inspired a cinematic career that would span nearly 100 films and establish her as the unrivaled “Lady of the Arabic Screen,” died on Saturday in Cairo. She was 83.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Renowned Gay Mecca on Fire Island Goes to Auction
abstract: The owners of a commercial strip in Fire Island Pines, which they rebuilt after a devastating fire, have been trying to sell the property since the fall.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8:25 A.M. (Encore) BLUE JASMINE (2013) Cate Blanchett won an Oscar for her role as Jasmine French, a Park Avenue matron fallen on hard times after her husband, Hal (Alec Baldwin), lands in prison for bilking his clients out of millions, leaving her with little more than her pearls, white Chanel jacket, Hermès bag and monogrammed Louis Vuitton luggage. Destitute, in a manner of speaking, Jasmine flies first-class to San Francisco to begin life anew with her sister, Ginger (Sally Hawkins), whose scrappy existence and brutish men (Andrew Dice Clay and Bobby Cannavale) Jasmine can barely stomach without self-medicating with vodka and Xanax. Then she meets a diplomatic type (Peter Sarsgaard) with an appreciation for her decorating talents and designer threads and starts to see light at the end of her dark tunnel. With intimations of Ruth Madoff and Blanche DuBois, this shattered woman is “brilliantly brought to quivering life by Ms. Blanchett,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, in Woody Allen’s “most sustained, satisfying and resonant film since ‘Match Point.’ ”

headline: Lessons of the James Risen Case
keywords: ['Editorials', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: President Obama has taken two actions that are a refreshing departure from six years of aggressively attacking investigative journalism.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration has taken two actions that seem a refreshing departure from six years of aggressively attacking investigative journalism. The Justice Department abandoned an attempt to force James Risen, a New York Times reporter, to testify about a confidential source. And it tempered internal guidelines for trying to obtain records or testimony from the news media during leak investigations.

headline: Living With Cancer: Coming to Terms
abstract: The paucity of words at my disposal to talk about my cancer stymies me; I am grateful that patients have begun to create them.

The paucity of the language at my disposal stymies me, as does its obfuscations. I am grateful that patients , hungry for more fortifying formulations, have begun to create them.

headline: Parent and Child as Two Volcanoes Under One Roof
abstract: In Xavier Dolan’s “Mommy,” a mother and her troubled son confront each other when he returns home after a stint in group living.
lead_paragraph: The French-Canadian writer, director and actor Xavier Dolan is only 25, but “Mommy,” his fifth feature film in five years, seems like the work of an even younger filmmaker. I mean this, mostly, as a compliment. Stories of adolescence — young adult novels, coming-of-age movies, teenage-targeted television series — are usually the work of adults, and therefore often temper their emotional immediacy with nostalgia, condescension or grown-up wisdom. But “Mommy,” the story of a troubled young man and his mother, seethes and howls with unchecked feeling. Shot in the square, narrow dimensions of a cellphone video, it is a pocket opera of grandiose self-pity, a wild and uncompromising demand for attention, a cri de coeur from the selfie generation.

headline: The Orthodox Sex Guru
abstract: Bat Sheva Marcus tries to help Orthodox women find pleasure — without breaking the (Talmudic) law.
lead_paragraph: In one of her early sessions with the patient, Bat Sheva Marcus, an Orthodox Jewish sex counselor, drew up a list. The patient, who was in her 20s, wore the uniform of her rigidly devout sect: a dark suit with a shapeless skirt reaching well below the knee, dark stockings, a plain blouse buttoned up to the neck and both a wig and a crocheted hat covering her head. She had come to Marcus’s offices in Midtown Manhattan from a cloistered community in Borough Park, Brooklyn, because she had been recoiling from sex with her husband. There was pain, and, more problematic for Marcus, there was no desire. The pain, Marcus and her staff deduced right away, was a result of muscle constrictions stemming from childbirth; this could be treated effectively with dilators — and without objection from the patient’s rabbi. But the deeper aversion was more complex. Talking with the woman at a round table in a room decorated with still lifes of pears and berries, Marcus wrote a list of ways that the patient and her husband could make sex, for her, more appealing.

headline: Instagram’s Graveyard Shift
abstract: Alone together with the warehouse workers, soldiers and paramedics of late-night social media.
lead_paragraph: The photograph that Markisha McClenton posted on Instagram is a self-portrait, a close-up that is muted in dim light. She might be on her way to work. She might be coming home. Her workdays begin and end in the dark, and they are dark in between. She’s a lab technician in Jacksonville, Fla. Her specialty is blood. She has worked these dark hours since her son was 7. “Freedom,” she told me over the phone from her lab. That’s why she works these hours: The freedom to work at night and to raise her children during the days. To her, this is good fortune. She is smiling in this photo. But her eyes are midnight eyes, 3 a.m. eyes. Why take a photo at that hour? “People forget about us, the night shift,” she said. The #nightshift. That’s the hashtag she used. It’s how I found her.

headline: By the Fire
abstract: No mode of cooking is more ancient, simple or free.
lead_paragraph: To cook in fire is a lesson I learned from a wise man who was not a cook. The man was my father, and what he cooked in his fire were some of the finest and most original things I’ve ever eaten — original because they were original to me, to my earliest tastes, when my senses were new.

headline: Where Cervantes Once Lived in Madrid, Eclectic Boutiques Abound
abstract: In recent years, manageable rents in this artsy residential enclave, a short walk from the heart of the city, have encouraged locals to open equally artsy and eclectic shops.
lead_paragraph: The Madrid neighborhood of Barrio de las Letras is famous for the Spanish authors and poets who have lived here since the 14th century, including Cervantes. But, in recent years, the manageable rents in this artsy residential enclave, a short walk from the heart of the city, have encouraged locals to open equally artsy and eclectic shops. These affordable boutiques, selling everything including clothing, furniture, home goods and even guitars, are scattered along the charming crisscrossed streets lined with three- and four-story buildings, some dating back to the 18th century.

headline: ‘The Black Panthers, Revisited’
abstract: This short documentary explores what we can learn from the Black Panther Party in confronting police violence 50 years later.
lead_paragraph: When we think of the civil rights struggles of the 1960s, certain events tend to come to mind: the March on Washington, for example, or perhaps the Freedom Rides or sit-ins. Others, however, have faded from our collective memory. One of those is the story of the Black Panther Party, the subject of this Op-Doc video. Founded in 1966 in Oakland, Calif., to combat police violence, the Black Panther Party and its story are a key part of our nation’s still-complicated racial narrative.

abstract: The big question is whether the flood of new money will jolt Europe out its economic doldrums or merely create a short-term lift to financial markets.
lead_paragraph: The European Central Bank unleashed a surprisingly aggressive stimulus plan on Thursday that looked like the last, best hope to prevent the region from sliding toward another lost economic decade with the stagnant growth, high unemployment and political strains that it would mean.

headline: About Op-Docs
abstract: Op-Docs is the New York Times’ Oscar-nominated and Emmy-winning documentary film series, exploring the most important issues of our time.
lead_paragraph: Begun by the New York Times Opinion section in 2011, Op-Docs is the world’s premiere short documentary series, comprising nearly 300 short, interactive and virtual reality documentaries. Each film is produced with wide creative latitude by both renowned and emerging independent filmmakers, and premieres across Times online platforms. The goal of each Op-Doc is to present a unique story, character, argument or point of view — and to start a conversation among our global audience.

lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush, while boarding a plane at Reagan National Airport heading to Salt Lake City, responded to questions about whether he was going to meet with Mitt Romney in Utah.

headline: In a Shift, Argentine President Says Prosecutor’s Death Was Not a Suicide
abstract: President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner said she believed that the lead investigator of the 1994 bombing of a Jewish center did not commit suicide.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Confronted with a deepening scandal, the president of Argentina shifted position on Thursday, saying that the death of the lead prosecutor investigating the 1994 bombing of a Jewish center was not a suicide as she and other government officials had suggested.

headline: Chaotic Retreat Follows Ukrainians’ Withdrawal From Donetsk Airport
abstract: The airport has not been usable for months, but its loss carried powerful symbolic value for the government in Kiev.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — The ruins of the once gleaming and modern Donetsk airport, site of near relentless fighting in recent days, finally fell on Thursday to pro-Russian rebel forces who then paraded captured Ukrainian soldiers through the streets of the embattled city.

headline: E.C.B. Announces Stimulus Plan
keywords: ['Quantitative Easing', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Mario Draghi, the European Central Bank president, said Thursday that the governing council agreed to a quantitative easing program that will see it buy up to 60 billion euros’ worth of bonds.
lead_paragraph: Mario Draghi, the European Central Bank president, said Thursday that the governing council agreed to a quantitative easing program that will see it buy up to 60 billion euros’ worth of bonds.

headline: Al Pacino and Barry Levinson on Age, Accomplishments and ‘The Humbling’
abstract: The star and the director say they can identify — to a limited extent — with the actor at the heart of their new film.
lead_paragraph: Simon Axler, the fictional performer played by Al Pacino in “The Humbling,” is living a perpetual actor’s nightmare. In this dark comedy adapted from the 2009 Philip Roth novel, Axler finds his memory and stamina are failing him. He fears that his opportunities are drying up and that audiences no longer recognize him. He struggles with his sanity and fails at his attempt to commit suicide.

headline: Wider Chaos Threatens as Fighters Seize Branch of Libya’s Central Bank
abstract: The move, by one of the factions battling for control of the country, threatened to set off a scramble for the bank’s vast stores of money and gold.
lead_paragraph: BAYDA, Libya — The battle for control of Libya threatened to break open its central bank on Thursday as fighters with one of the country’s two warring factions seized control of its Benghazi branch, risking an armed scramble for its gold reserves that could cripple the last functioning institution in the country.

headline: Daniel Handler: By the Book
abstract: The author, most recently, of the novel “We Are Pirates” (and, as Lemony Snicket, numerous children’s books) likes to read Miss Manners.
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of the novel “We Are Pirates” (and, as Lemony Snicket, numerous children’s books) likes to read Miss Manners. “She’s an extremely useful philosopher, and I consult her frequently, in order to behave better.”

headline: Primavera Sound Announces Lineup for May Event in Barcelona
abstract: The annual music festival will features acts this year by the Strokes, the Black Keys, Interpol, Belle & Sebastian and Damien Rice.
lead_paragraph: The music festival Primavera Sound has announced its lineup for its 2015 event in Barcelona, with acts by the Strokes, the Black Keys, Interpol, Belle & Sebastian and Damien Rice. The 15th edition will run from May 28 to 30.

headline: We’re No.1
abstract: Record holders show why they’re on top.
lead_paragraph: Record holders show why they’re on top.

headline: In Davos, 3 Camps at Loggerheads Over a Cure for Europe’s Economic Funk
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']
abstract: Policy makers and specialists at the World Economic Forum were divided over the effect of the E.C.B.’s new stimulus program — and far apart on other measures aimed at bolstering growth in Europe.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — The World Economic Forum here is supposed to be a special place where people of differing viewpoints can learn from each other as they figure out solutions to the world’s problems.

headline: Defenders of Tradition in Keystone Pipeline Fight
abstract: Several farmers in Nebraska are in a personal fight to protect land that in many cases has been passed down through generations.
lead_paragraph: BRADSHAW, Neb. — An unpainted wooden barn sits in a snow-dusted cornfield along a gravel road, one of many that dot the rural horizon here.

headline: Rajiv Joseph Wins $150,000 Laurents/Hatcher Foundation Award
abstract: The playwright won the prize, which provides $50,000 to the winning playwright and an additional $100,000 to defray production costs, for his new play “The Guards at the Taj.”
lead_paragraph: The new play “The Guards at the Taj,” about life-shaking events in 1648 India as the sun rises on the just-completed Taj Mahal, is the recipient of the 2015 Laurents/Hatcher Foundation Award, which provides $50,000 to the winning playwright and an additional $100,000 to defray production costs for the play’s premiere. The playwright is Rajiv Joseph, a Pulitzer Prize finalist for “Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo,” which ran on Broadway in 2011 starring Robin Williams. And the production funds will go to Off Broadway’s Atlantic Theater Company, which will mount the play in May, with the award-winning actor Amy Morton directing.

headline: Data on Payments From Drugmakers to Doctors Is Marred by Error
abstract: Flaws in information submitted to Open Payments, a government database of financial relationships in the medical field, complicate analysis.
lead_paragraph: You’d think drug and medical device makers would know how to spell the names of their own products.

headline: Juilliard Receives $5 Million to Create Career Services Center
abstract: A $5 million gift will help Juilliard students prepare for their professional careers.
lead_paragraph: It is something of a given that the best conservatories, dance academies and drama schools can teach their students the craft, and sometimes the art, they need to master their fields. But teaching them how to make a living in those fields can be another matter.

headline: 1890: Violent Speeches by Anarchists
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Violent and bloodthirsty speeches were pronounced at the Anarchist Convention in London in 1890.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An International Convention of Anarchist and Revolutionary delegates was opened in London today at the International Socialist Club, Soho. Some very violent and bloodthirsty speeches were pronounced. Mr. Stone attended to represent the Chicago Anarchists. He was concerned in the riots and murders in that city, and was an intimate friend of the man Parsons, executed for throwing dynamite bombs at the police. He advised the extreme section to turn their attention to the kings of commerce, their banks, exchange bourses and other machinery for oppressing the workers. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 23, 1890

headline: Netanyahu Visit Delayed Until March
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was invited to address a joint meeting of Congress next month, but it looks as though he’ll be coming later than expected.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was invited to address a joint meeting of Congress next month, but it looks as though he’ll be coming later than expected.

headline: 4-Time Champ Jeff Gordon Will Exit Cup Series After 2015
abstract: Gordon, 43, who had 23 top-10 finishes in the Sprint Cup Series in 2014, said it was possible he would compete in select events after 2015, although he had no plans to do that.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Gordon was 13 when the longtime racing promoter Humpy Wheeler saw him compete in a race on a dirt track. Fools, Wheeler thought at the time. How could anyone put a kid that young out there?

headline: ‘American Sniper’ Writer Wrestled His Way Into Project
abstract: To persuade Navy buddies of Chris Kyle, the subject of the film, to work with him, the screenwriter Jason Hall had to literally pin them down first.
lead_paragraph: Can the Bagger rightly assume that Jason Hall is the only Hollywood screenwriter who wrestled multiple Navy Seals to prove he was the best guy to write a film about their buddy?

headline: What Do You Expect From Obama’s Visit to India?
abstract: The New York Times would like to hear from readers in India about what President Obama’s visit means to you.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times would like to hear from readers in India about what President Obama’s visit means to you.

lead_paragraph: A handcrafted letterpress printing pairs original text with lush color photos from the set of the 1963 adaptation of Lampedusa’s “The Leopard.”

lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: M.T.A. Is Raising Fares and Tolls; One Subway or Bus Ride Will Cost $2.75
abstract: Fare increases, the latest of which will take effect on March 22, are scheduled to occur every two years as part of the authority’s long-term revenue plans.
lead_paragraph: The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted on Thursday to raise the base fare on subways and buses by a quarter, to $2.75, and the cost of a 30-day MetroCard by $4.50, to $116.50.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Raf Simons Fall/Winter 2015

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Tom Brady and Bill Belichick Deny Knowledge of Deflated Footballs
abstract: Patriots Coach Bill Belichick said he had never talked to anyone about football air pressure, and quarterback Tom Brady said he was as shocked as Belichick by the accusations.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Coach Bill Belichick and quarterback Tom Brady said Thursday that they had no knowledge of how the New England Patriots came to use underinflated footballs in Sunday’s A.F.C. championship game against the Indianapolis Colts.

headline: Learning From My Oldest Patients
abstract: It is with a good deal of trepidation that I start any new medication in my patients who are very old, for fear of disrupting the myriad forces of genetics and environment that have allowed them to live so long.
lead_paragraph: It is with a good deal of trepidation that I start any new medication in my patients who are very old, for fear of disrupting the myriad forces of genetics and environment that have allowed them to live so long.

headline: Are Those Steel Drums I Hear?
abstract: The extemporaneous spirit of a Caribbean open-air barbecue joint is strong at LoLo’s Seafood Shack in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: There is no grill on a sawed-off oil drum, no lick of breeze or view of the sea in sun-shocked blue. But behind the frosted windows of LoLo’s Seafood Shack, which opened in Harlem in October, the extemporaneous spirit of the lolo — the kind of open-air barbecue joint found on the beaches and roadsides of St. Martin in the West Indies — is strong.

headline: Speaker Sheldon Silver Should Resign From New York Assembly
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Editorials', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: The charges are astounding, and so is the idea that the speaker would try to hold onto his post.
lead_paragraph: As astonishing as it was to see Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the New York Assembly, surrender to the F.B.I. on corruption charges Thursday morning, it is even more incredible that he can choose to go on serving in his job while he defends himself against bribery and kickback charges involving millions of dollars.

headline: LoLo’s Seafood Shack
abstract: A taste of the Caribbean in Harlem
lead_paragraph: A taste of the Caribbean in Harlem

headline: City Opera Board Still Prefers Lower Bid
abstract: The board of the bankrupt New York City Opera says it wants to sell its name and other assets to the bidder whose offer is lower than the competing bid.
lead_paragraph: The board for the bankrupt New York City Opera said Thursday that it still wanted to sell the company’s name and few remaining assets to its preferred suitor, even though another bidder offered $250,000 more for them at an auction in court earlier this week.

headline: Court Orders Release of Mubarak’s Sons Pending Retrial
abstract: The two imprisoned sons of the deposed president Hosni Mubarak came to symbolize self-dealing and corruption under their father’s three-decade rule.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An Egyptian court has ordered the release of the imprisoned sons of Hosni Mubarak, Egypt’s deposed president, pending their retrial on corruption charges, according to Al-Ahram, a state newspaper.

headline: Tumblr Taps Its Community to Work With Advertisers
abstract: It’s a way for Tumblr to benefit from the huge online followings of some of its most popular users.
lead_paragraph: Tumblr has long promoted itself as a hub for artists and creative entrepreneurs. Now, Tumblr wants to put those people to work.

headline: Shedding Their Secrets
keywords: ['ANIMALS', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Invasive Species', 'Animal Migration', 'Microbiology']
abstract: Scientists are relying more heavily on environmental DNA, shed in an animal’s habitat, to track rare or endangered species.
lead_paragraph: You wouldn’t think hellbenders would be hard to find: The huge salamanders, the biggest amphibians in North America, can grow up to 30 inches long. Yet hellbenders make themselves scarce, living on the bottoms of mountain streams, lurking under massive rocks.

headline: An Encouraging Day for Victoria Azarenka and for U.S. Women
abstract: Azarenka, coming back from an injury-plagued year, upset No. 8 Caroline Wozniacki to reach the third round, where she was joined by seven American women.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — For a former champion intent on becoming a future champion, Victoria Azarenka hardly had a welcome-back draw at this Australian Open: Sloane Stephens in the first round and Caroline Wozniacki in the second.

headline: First Draft Focus: Passing the Gavel
abstract: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, right, offered a tribute on Thursday to Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, who succeeded him as chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

headline: A Classic Novel of the Italian Aristocracy Returns in a Sumptuous New Edition
abstract: Lampedusa’s 1958 international best seller, “The Leopard,” was adapted into a Palme d’Or-winning film of the same name in 1963; a handcrafted letterpress printing pairs the original text with lush color photos from the set of the film.
lead_paragraph: Giuseppe Tomasi di Lampedusa’s internationally best-selling 1958 novel, “The Leopard,” is a satirically sad, lush tale of Italy’s lost, decadent aristocratic class. Set during Italian unification after the end of Napoleonic rule, when ancient feudal territories were merged and royal families were ruined, the novel is a meditation on revolutionary change. Luchino Visconti’s 1963 film adaptation of “The Leopard,” which won the Palme d’Or at Cannes, starred Alain Delon and Burt Lancaster and visualized in rich tones that same time period.

headline: Costumes Are in the Mix at Philippine Festival
abstract: This year’s Dinagyang Festival in Iloilo City in the Philippines will include an exhibition of costumes from across the country.
lead_paragraph: The Dinagyang Festival draws an estimated crowd of a million people to the streets of Iloilo City in the Philippines each year, and organizers say they hope the addition of the Philippine Festival Costume Expo will bring even more attention to the event.

headline: After Inspecting Private Equity Funds, S.E.C. Examiners to Broaden Focus
abstract: A specialized group of examiners is set to train its focus on hedge funds and other funds that invest in illiquid products like real estate, timber and energy assets, an S.E.C. official said on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Officials at the Securities and Exchange Commission have said they discovered numerous problems when examining private equity firms during a two-year review that ended recently.

headline: Text to Text | ‘Lord of the Flies’ and ‘A Fight Club for Flies’
abstract: In this Text to Text, we pair an excerpt from “Lord of the Flies” with a recent Science Times article and video on the study of aggression in fruit flies, and ask the question, “What is the relationship between aggression and gender?”
lead_paragraph: “Lord of the Flies” has been a classroom staple for decades, perhaps because the issues of bullying and male aggression remain central concerns in the lives of adolescents, even if they aren’t stranded on a desert island.

headline: Matching G.O.P. Presidential Candidates With Those Who Tried Before
abstract: Here are the closest historical parallels to the current Republican contenders and the implications for the “invisible primary.”
lead_paragraph: It’s audition time for presidential candidates in the “invisible primary” — the critical period before the state primaries and caucuses in which party elites help choose the eventual nominees.

headline: Russian, Argentine and Mauritanian Nominees Caught Up in Real-Life Turmoil
abstract: Politicians denounce “Leviathan”; a prosecutor’s death has echoes in “Wild Tales”; and “Timbuktu” has overtones of Nigeria’s current woes.
lead_paragraph: The Oscar process is meant to be hermetic, with the artistic merit of a movie as the sole criteria. But Academy voters do not live in a vacuum, and real life often seeps into their perceptions of the films they are being asked to honor.

headline: Soul in the Machine
abstract: We look back at some of the many shifting personae in Björk’s 20-year career, the subject of a major retrospective at MoMA in March.
lead_paragraph: We look back at some of the many shifting personae in Björk’s 20-year career, the subject of a major retrospective at MoMA in March.

headline: Draghi’s Bond Buying Plan Runs Counter to Eurozone Principles
abstract: The E.C.B.’s bond buying program is big enough to impress markets. But partial nationalization of losses risks undermining the eurozone’s foundations. Pierre Briançon of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Mario Draghi has compromised on principles for the sake of effectiveness. Mr. Draghi, the European Central Bank’s president, announced on Thursday a long-expected bond buying program that will be huge from the start and last until eurozone inflation gets back on track. But the eurozone’s version of quantitative easing runs contrary to the principles of a currency union.

headline: Former Iranian Official Gets Jail and $1 Million Fine in Corruption Case
abstract: Mohammad-Reza Rahimi, who was a first vice president under President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, is believed to have been involved in insurance fraud.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Signaling new efforts to halt what some officials have called out-of-control corruption, Iran’s judiciary announced this week that it had sentenced a former vice president to five years in jail and fined him the equivalent of $1 million after his recent conviction in a longstanding corruption case.

headline: Ayatollah Khamenei Appeals to Western Youth on Islam and Prejudice
abstract: Iran’s supreme leader released a letter and posted on Twitter after the attacks in Paris by militants who said they acted in the name of Islam.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — In a rare effort to reach out to the West, Iran’s supreme leader released a letter to youngsters in the United States and Europe imploring them to learn about Islam from original sources and not, as he said in a later posting on Twitter, have it “introduced to you by prejudices.”

headline: When Racism Can’t Be Ignored
abstract: “Rasheeda Speaking,” by the Chicago playwright Joel Drake Johnson, is a dark comedy about racism both covert and obvious, and stars Tonya Pinkins and Dianne Wiest.
lead_paragraph: Tonya Pinkins and Dianne Wiest sank into chairs at the back of the room after a recent rehearsal of the play “Rasheeda Speaking.” Ms. Pinkins sipped a mug of tea; Ms. Wiest wrapped herself in a gray cardigan. The antagonism of the last scene they’d worked lingered.

headline: Daughters in the Business
abstract: Halley Feiffer’s new play, “I’m Gonna Pray for You So Hard,” focuses on an actress and her better-known father, a situation she knows firsthand.
lead_paragraph: Betty Gilpin and Halley Feiffer suspect they must have crossed paths as infants, lolling in some green room or other. The actor Reed Birney has told them he remembers them as little girls. Ms. Gilpin, 28, and Ms. Feiffer, 30, grew up belonging to the same hothouse subculture: the children of theater people.

headline: Wendell Ford, 90, Dies; Kentucky Senator Pushed Voting Rights
abstract: Mr. Ford, who rose to become the Democratic whip in the Senate, was best known for defending the tobacco industry and for pushing voter-registration laws.
lead_paragraph: Wendell H. Ford, a political moderate from Kentucky who served as governor and then for four terms as a senator, rising to become the Democratic whip, or assistant leader, in the early 1990s, died on Thursday at his home in Owensboro, Ky. He was 90.

headline: High Rates of Opioid Prescriptions Among Women Raise Birth Defect Fears
keywords: ['Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Women and Girls', 'Birth Defects', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Babies and Infants']
abstract: A C.D.C. study found that nearly a third of women of reproductive age had had an opioid painkiller prescription filled each year from 2008 to 2012, a practice that carries high risks for birth defects.
lead_paragraph: The federal health authorities reported Thursday that nearly one-third of women of reproductive age had had an opioid painkiller prescription filled every year from 2008 to 2012. Experts said the practice carried considerable risks for birth defects.
