abstract: When Laurel Fantauzzo met a young woman and her bicycle in Manila, her relationship to the city was transformed.
lead_paragraph: When Laurel Fantauzzo met a young woman and her bicycle in Manila, her relationship to the city was transformed.

headline: Naming a Drone Lets Readers’ Imaginations Take Flight
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'News and News Media', 'Robots and Robotics']
abstract: If The Times ever gets a drone for news-gathering purposes, we’ll have to name it. We asked readers on Twitter what they’d name our hypothetical unmanned aerial journalist vehicle.
lead_paragraph: Drone journalism remains a hot topic, and as the prospect nears reality, the news media’s excitement increases, The Times’s included.

headline: Charges Filed Against Sheldon Silver
abstract: The criminal complaint filed against the speaker of the New York State Assembly, Sheldon Silver.
lead_paragraph: The criminal complaint filed against the speaker of the New York State Assembly, Sheldon Silver.

headline: 1940: Roosevelt Urges Better Schools
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: President Roosevelt says education is as important as adequate defense for national security in 1940.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Educated citizens are as important as adequate defense for national security, President Roosevelt declared last night in a radio address in connection with the White House conference on children in a democracy. He stressed the necessity of poor sections of the country finding means of taxation to pay for the education of children who don’t receive schooling. ‘‘Certainly our future is endangered when nearly a million children of elementary school age are not in school, when thousands of school districts and even some entire states do not pay for good schools,’’ he said. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 23, 1940

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Selma’
abstract: Ava DuVernay narrates a sequence from “Selma,” featuring David Oyelowo and Carmen Ejogo.
lead_paragraph: Ava DuVernay narrates a sequence from “Selma,” featuring David Oyelowo and Carmen Ejogo.

headline: Belichick Denies Knowing of Football Deflation
abstract: New England Patriots Coach Bill Belichick denied that he had any prior knowledge about the deflation of Patriots footballs in Sunday’s A.F.C. championship game against the Indianapolis Colts.
lead_paragraph: New England Patriots Coach Bill Belichick denied that he had any prior knowledge about the deflation of Patriots footballs in Sunday’s A.F.C. championship game against the Indianapolis Colts.

headline: As Construction Booms, Edgewater Fire Provides a Sobering Moment
abstract: A blaze at Avalon at Edgewater displaced more than 1,000 residents of the apartments and surrounding buildings and produced a spectacle rarely seen in an era of modern construction: a luxury development destroyed by fire.
lead_paragraph: EDGEWATER, N.J. — The complex of luxury apartments burned down 15 years ago, before it was even finished, in what fire officials here described then as the worst blaze they had seen in decades.

headline: Executives in Davos Express Worries Over More Disruptive Cyberattacks
abstract: Top executives, including Robert Smith of Vista Equity Partners and John Chambers of Cisco, say that not only are cyberattacks becoming more common, they are getting tougher to fight.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland – Executives from Target and Home Depot were not present at the World Economic Forum, where world leaders and corporate titans are rubbing shoulders and debating weighty issues.

headline: Harry Reid, Bruised but Emphatic: ‘I’m Fully Intending to Run’
abstract: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the minority leader, made his first on-camera appearance Thursday since his eye injury, dispelling rumors about his health and repeatedly asserting he planned to seek re-election in 2016.
lead_paragraph: With white gauze over his right eye and with deep purple bruising still visible along his jaw, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the minority leader, made his first on-camera appearance Thursday since suffering serious injuries three weeks ago in a fall, seeking to dispel worries about his health and repeatedly asserting that he planned to seek re-election in 2016.

headline: Assemblymen Respond to Silver Arrest
abstract: Members of the New York State Assembly respond to the arrest of Speaker Sheldon Silver on corruption charges Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Members of the New York State Assembly respond to the arrest of Speaker Sheldon Silver on corruption charges Thursday.

headline: Amazon to Buy Israeli Chip Developer
abstract: Amazon.com has agreed to buy Annapurna Labs, an Israeli chip developer, for about $350 million.
lead_paragraph: Amazon.com has agreed to buy Annapurna Labs, an Israeli chip developer, a spokeswoman for the American company said on Thursday.

headline: Anxiety and Division Flourish Amid Europe’s Struggle With Terrorism
abstract: Europe's problems with terror reach deep into national fabrics and will not be resolved by counterterrorism policing alone.
lead_paragraph: In Germany, opponents of immigration march on the streets of Dresden, decrying what they term the Islamization of Europe. In France, the prime minister, Manuel Valls, speaks of a kind of ethnic apartheid within his own society, an assessment mirrored by some British Muslims who accuse their government of setting them “inherently apart.”

headline: Silver’s Case May Have Vast Impact and Alter Entrenched Way of Governance
abstract: The corruption charges for Sheldon Silver are expected to be a major disruption in Albany, which has long believed he was untouchable.
lead_paragraph: His power unbending, his whims often unexplained, Sheldon Silver, in his two decades as speaker of the State Assembly, became a seemingly indestructible presence at the nucleus of the New York political world, a steady advocate for liberal causes and a master tactician in Albany’s closed and entrenched way of governance.

headline: White House, Citing Israeli Election, Says Obama and Netanyahu Won’t Meet
abstract: President Obama will not meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel when he travels to Washington in March to address a joint session of Congress.
lead_paragraph: LAWRENCE, Kan. — President Obama will not meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel when he travels to Washington in March to address a joint session of Congress, the White House said on Thursday, citing a policy against receiving foreign leaders close to their elections.

headline: A Monk’s Interests Captured on Camera
abstract: A camera used by the Trappist monk and writer Thomas Merton will appear in a centennial exhibition at Columbia University.
lead_paragraph: A forgotten camera said to have been used by the Trappist monk and writer Thomas Merton will appear in public for the first time on Feb. 2 in a Merton centennial exhibition at Columbia University’s Rare Book & Manuscript Library. Merton, who died in 1968, at 53, had taken vows at a Kentucky monastery that decreed he could own few possessions. With borrowed camera equipment, he took about 1,800 photos, creating meditative abstract compositions out of rocks, leaves, wagon wheels and barn siding.

headline: Nope. No Idea. Not Me. Next.
abstract: Coach Bill Belichick and quarterback Tom Brady both said they were utterly baffled as to how the Patriots came into possession of 11 underinflated footballs for the A.F.C. championship game.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — The monosyllabic New England Patriots coach Bill Belichick and his polysyllabic quarterback Tom Brady claimed to be united in mysterious unknowing.

headline: A New Nominee for Worst Tween Sitcom on TV
keywords: ['Athletics and Sports', 'Children and Childhood', 'Gender', 'Parenting', 'Television', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Instead of a show about the coed and girls’ teams our children have grown up with, Nickelodeon offers “Bella and the Bulldogs,” an ugly throwback to an era when girls who love sports are always odd girl out.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend, my daughter watched the first episode of Nickelodeon’s “Bella and the Bulldogs.” I was ranting two minutes after I walked into the room. Days later, the thought of it still infuriates me — and fills me with disbelief. In 1976, this would have been a reasonable plot to offer; even a clever take on changing gender expectations. In 2015, it’s an embarrassment to middle school students of both genders, imposing stereotypes more rigid and offensive than even the “Dukes of Hazzard” dreamed of.

headline: Objections by Women Open Rift in G.O.P.
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: After a revolt by Republican women on an abortion ban, the House instead passed a bill limiting the use of taxpayer funds to pay for abortions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans struggled on Thursday to mend another unwelcome rift that threatens to tarnish their party’s image with women and younger voters, shelving a contentious bill to outlaw most abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy.

headline: Hollywood Callback for Canadian Bank
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: After a retreat from the United States three years ago, Royal Bank of Canada is now paying City National a 26 percent premium that planned cost cuts don’t justify, writes Daniel Indiviglio of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Royal Bank of Canada is placing an expensive bet that the second time’s a charm for a foray south of the border. The Canadian titan is paying $5.4 billion for Beverly Hills-based City National little more than three years after it cut a painful retreat from  retail banking in the United States. This time around, RBC boss David McKay, who took the reins last August, has taken aim at a growing franchise in a coveted part of the market. But he’s also paying through the nose for it.

headline: Eurozone Nations Face Stronger Pressures to Lift Economies
abstract: With the European Central Bank now stretched to the limits of its powers, government spending may be a key variable in the prospects for growth.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — As the European Central Bank deploys its most powerful economic weapon, the onus for growth now lies with the 19 individual countries in the euro currency union, a fractious and highly political group.

headline: Videos Show Yemen’s Unfolding Crisis
abstract: Since Monday, videos have surfaced — both professional and amateur — showing the violence unfolding between the Yemeni Army and Houthi rebels in the capital, Sana.
lead_paragraph: Since Monday, videos have surfaced — both professional and amateur — showing the violence unfolding between the Yemeni Army and Houthi rebels in the capital, Sana.

headline: Ohio Councilman, 30, Will Challenge Portman for Senate Seat
abstract: Potential presidential candidates are not the only ones circling their wagons ahead of 2016.
lead_paragraph: Potential presidential candidates are not the only ones circling their wagons ahead of 2016.

headline: U.S. Attorney Announces Silver Charges
abstract: The United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, Preet Bharara, announces the charges against Sheldon Silver, the longtime Assembly speaker, who was arrested Thursday morning.
lead_paragraph: The United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, Preet Bharara, announces the charges against Sheldon Silver, the longtime Assembly speaker, who was arrested Thursday morning.

headline: Technology Leaders Define Digital Fault Lines
abstract: Panelists at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, discussed the benefits and challenges of a rapidly changing digital landscape.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — Trust, global consensus, government support for building infrastructure and inclusion are the main challenges of the digital future, a panel of technology leaders said here on Thursday at the World Economic Forum.

headline: Putting ‘Black Lives Matter’ Into Action
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: “Ghettoside: A True Story of Murder in America,” by Jill Leovy of The Los Angeles Times, follows the case of a gang-related killing.
lead_paragraph: The true-crime podcast “Serial” was a phenomenon, in part, because it was told in the first person. The narrator, Sarah Koenig, all but whispered the story into our ears, and her brainiac sensibility was as interesting as the killing at her story’s core. Her uncertainty was fetching on an existential level.

headline: ‘Mockingjay’ Beats Out ‘Guardians’ for  2014 Box Office Crown
abstract: The latest installment in the “Hunger Game” series beats out what had been considered the year’s No. 1 film, “Guardians of the Galaxy.”
lead_paragraph: Sorry, Groot: Katniss has taken your crown.

headline: The Uses and Abuses of Taboos
keywords: ['ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Discrimination', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Muslim Americans', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: More on blasphemy, racism and self-censorship in the light of the Hebdo tragedy.
lead_paragraph: In a post last week on the debate around the Charlie Hebdo killings, I explained why I’m not convinced by the argument that Muslims are facing an unusual (phobic?) level of provocations toward their religion in the West, and why I think a consistent standard of self-censorship around religion that excluded cartoon treatments of Muhammed would require a radical change in the way that religion generally, but especially Christianity, is treated in contemporary culture. Now, as promised, I want to take up the question of other cases, particularly around racism and anti-Semitism, where our culture more explicitly self-censors, and where the argument I made immediately following the killings about speech and violence deserves a qualification. Here’s part of what I originally wrote:

headline: Rubio, Cruz and Paul to Appear at Koch Donor Event
abstract: Three presidential contenders will appear on a panel moderated by Jonathan Karl of ABC News.
lead_paragraph: The annual donor event hosted by Charles and David Koch in California is among the most sought-after invitations in Republican politics — and one of the most difficult parties to crash.

headline: At Milan’s Food-Themed World’s Fair, U.S. Will Roll Out a Fleet
abstract: American food trucks will be a highlight of this year’s fair, from May through October.
lead_paragraph: American food trucks will serve lobster rolls and burgers at Expo Milano 2015, a world’s fair with nearly 150 countries participating. The theme of the fair, which will run May through October just outside Milan, is food — feeding the planet (an estimated nine billion people by 2050) — which is a first for a world’s fair.

headline: Obama Calls for Expanded Child Care
abstract: President Obama, speaking at the University of Kansas, called for an expanded child care program to lessen the financial strain on families.
lead_paragraph: President Obama, speaking at the University of Kansas, called for an expanded child care program to lessen the financial strain on families.

headline: Astronomy Night at the Intrepid Museum
abstract: On Friday, the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum will open its doors for a night of drinks and the search for other Earths around the galaxy.
lead_paragraph: Some childhood fantasies never go away. From time to time, the Miser pictures himself in a space shuttle’s cockpit or thinks about how much fun it would be to play in the underground fortress at the Louvre.

headline: Dries Van Noten: Fall 2015 Menswear
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Ava DuVernay Narrates a Scene From ‘Selma’
abstract: The director Ava DuVernay discusses a sequence from “Selma,” featuring David Oyelowo and Carmen Ejogo.
lead_paragraph: The Oscar-nominated film “Selma” shows the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s strategy going into the civil rights march in in Selma, Ala. But it also shows Dr. King (David Oyelowo) as a family man, in intimate moments with his wife, Coretta (Carmen Ejogo). In this video, the director Ava DuVernay discusses one of the calmer moments before the storm. Ms. DuVernay points out her interest in showing this relationship to give a more rounded sense of the activist and minister.

headline: The Top Five Fall/Winter 2015 Men’s Wear Collections From Milan
abstract: T’s men’s fashion editors share their favorites from the latest round of shows.
lead_paragraph: T’s men’s fashion editors share their favorites from the latest round of shows.

headline: Meet the Diplomats Leading the U.S.-Cuba Talks
abstract: Historic senior-level discussions kicked off this week in Havana.
lead_paragraph: Historic senior-level talks between the United States and Cuba kicked off this week in Havana with two formidable diplomats at the head of each delegation: Josefina Vidal, the longtime point-person in the Cuban government on American policy, and Roberta Jacobson, the Assistant Secretary of State who oversees the Western hemisphere.

headline: European Central Bank’s Bond-Buying Will Help U.S. Tourists and Investors
keywords: ['Euro (Currency)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'United States Economy', 'US Dollar (Currency)', 'Quantitative Easing']
abstract: “It wouldn’t surprise me in the least if the euro was even with the dollar by April,” one economist says.
lead_paragraph: For American investors and tourists especially, the long-awaited move by the European Central Bank on Thursday to help stimulate growth on the Continent is welcome news. For the rest of the American economy, it will not matter so much.

headline: White House Proposals on 529 College Savings Plans Would Reduce Benefits
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: As part of the Obama administration’s tax plan, money from 529 plans could no longer be withdrawn tax-free.
lead_paragraph: President Obama is proposing a radical change to the 529 college savings plans held by millions of families, which would require those who use them to rethink their approach to college savings.

headline: Paris Announces Plan to Promote Secular Values
abstract: The aftermath of the killings at Charlie Hebdo and a kosher market near Paris exposed serious cultural rifts, teachers say.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Officials in France announced new measures on Thursday aimed at reinforcing secular values at French schools, after the terrorist attacks in and around Paris exposed serious cultural rifts between children in heavily immigrant communities and others in classrooms throughout the country.

headline: More Footage Released From Romney Documentary
abstract: The director of the documentary “Mitt,” which was released last year and chronicled Mitt Romney’s two-time quest for the presidency, has made more footage available online.
lead_paragraph: A prank call from Arnold Schwarzenegger.

headline: When the Art Isn’t on the Walls
abstract: Performing artists are migrating from dance venues to the contemporary art world, and museums are welcoming the traffic.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Thursday evening at the New Museum in New York, the elevator door opened onto a fifth-floor gallery with a pole-dancing class in action. Some visitors looked confused and headed for the exit, but many more crowded around the edges of the floor watching the dance collaborators Brennan Gerard and Ryan Kelly learn strenuous and hypnotic moves — the kind more often practiced by strippers or teenage subway performers.

headline: Lovingly Layered With Slivers of Thrill
abstract: With its unusual seating plan and variety of tempos, the Budapest Festival Orchestra added excitement to Mozart and Brahms standards at Avery Fisher Hall.
lead_paragraph: Ivan Fischer and the Budapest Festival Orchestra stick to the repertoire when they come through New York. In that sense they are like any other ensemble, understandably eager to impress in the core of our music. But Mr. Fischer has a restless, inventive mind, and his players seem game for anything. So even in the ordinary, you can count on them for something extraordinary.

headline: Steyer Stands Down on California Senate Run
abstract: Tom Steyer, the billionaire environmentalist, said he would not run for the California Senate seat being vacated by Barbara Boxer.
lead_paragraph: Cross another name off the list of potential Senate candidates in California.

headline: On Set | Bjork
abstract: Bjork dances to “Becoming Chaina” by Dutch E Germ in a look from the spring 2015 Comme des Garçons collection.
lead_paragraph: Bjork dances to “Becoming Chaina” by Dutch E Germ in a look from the spring 2015 Comme des Garçons collection.

headline: Claiming Academic Fraud, Ex-Athletes Sue North Carolina and N.C.A.A.
keywords: ['College Athletics', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Scholarships and Fellowships']
abstract: A lawsuit was filed in state court just months after a report found that from 1993 to 2011, some 3,100 students took classes at North Carolina that sometimes did not take place or require any work.
lead_paragraph: Two former University of North Carolina athletes filed a lawsuit against their alma mater and the N.C.A.A. on Thursday, accusing them of academic fraud and failing to fulfill their stated missions of educating athletes. The athletes, Rashanda McCants, a former women’s basketball star, and Devon Ramsay, a former football player, are the named plaintiffs in the suit, filed in North Carolina state court.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Louis Vuitton Fall/Winter 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Danny Elfman’s Music for Tim Burton Films to Open Lincoln Center Festival
abstract: The festival will begin July 6 with an orchestra playing some of Danny Elfman’s film scores; the National Ballet of China and the Cleveland Orchestra will also perform.
lead_paragraph: The Lincoln Center Festival will mark its 20th anniversary this summer with return engagements by the Druid Theater Company of Ireland, the Cleveland Orchestra, the theater company Cheek by Jowl and the director Yukio Ninagawa, the festival announced Thursday.

headline: In Manila, Two Seasons, No Regrets
abstract: Coming out of hiding in Manila to risk falling in love.
lead_paragraph: The Philippines has just two seasons: raining and not raining. One September, the same month a typhoon wrecked the sea wall at Roxas Boulevard in Manila, a young woman walked into the room I was in and fell into a chair next to me. And I knew that from then on I would have just two seasons as well: before her and after her. Before I even knew her name, I thought: “Come with me. Take me with you.”

headline: Ripples of Muscle, Evoked Through Sound
abstract: Sufjan Stevens’s latest commission from the Brooklyn Academy of Music is “Round-Up,” inspired by one of the world’s largest rodeos.
lead_paragraph: “Let ’er buck” is the slogan of the Pendleton Round-Up in Oregon, founded in 1910 and now one of the world’s largest rodeos. Perhaps that brought out a contrarian side in the songwriter and composer Sufjan Stevens. His latest commission from the Brooklyn Academy of Music is “Round-Up,” a wordless, arty documentary with its score performed live for six nights at the BAM Harvey Theater, ending on Sunday. “Round-Up” was filmed in slow motion — 300 frames a second — and the music doesn’t buck; it’s steady and meditative, treating the rodeo as a ritual.

headline: The Case Against Sheldon Silver
abstract: Sheldon Silver, the former powerful speaker of the New York State Assembly, was found guilty on all counts in his corruption trial. The government said he used “the power and influence of his official position to obtain for himself millions of dollars of bribes and kickbacks.”
lead_paragraph: Sheldon Silver, the former powerful speaker of the New York State Assembly, was found guilty on all counts in his corruption trial. The government said he used “the power and influence of his official position to obtain for himself millions of dollars of bribes and kickbacks.”

headline: Race for Boxer’s Senate Seat Loses a High-Profile Hopeful
abstract: Tom Steyer, a billionaire environmentalist, bowed out of the race to succeed Senator Barbara Boxer, leaving the California attorney general, Kamala D. Harris, as the main candidate.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The supposedly crowded race to succeed Senator Barbara Boxer, the California Democrat who is not seeking re-election in 2016, just became less crowded.

headline: Amid Swords of Civil War, a President With a Pen
abstract: “Lincoln Speaks: Words That Transformed a Nation,” at the Morgan Library & Museum, shows how that president put his faith in the power of reason, without ranting.
lead_paragraph: Abraham Lincoln probably never envisioned the Internet, but he wouldn’t have been surprised by the tenor of the average Internet comment board. Among the documents that make up  “Lincoln Speaks: Words That Transformed a Nation,” an engrossing new exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum, is a letter not by Lincoln but to him, from a disgruntled Louisianian who signed himself “Pete Muggins.”

headline: A Toddler’s Inside Guide to New York City
abstract: Diego Acosta López wanted to document New York from his son’s perspective: inside a stroller. Thousands of pictures (including little feet and hands) ensued.
lead_paragraph: Diego Acosta López wanted to document New York from his son’s perspective: inside a stroller. Thousands of pictures (including little feet and hands) ensued.

headline: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
abstract: A look at McSorley’s Old Ale House, and the long time it stood increasingly alone on the wrong side of history. .
lead_paragraph: 78 YEARS AGO

headline: Eerie Self-Portraits Inspired by an Abandoned Vintage Suitcase
abstract: Anja Niemi began her series after finding a bag filled with the remnants of a woman named Darlene’s failed career as a beauty-sales representative.
lead_paragraph: Anja Niemi began her series after finding a bag filled with the remnants of a woman named Darlene’s failed career as a beauty-sales representative.

headline: Joachim Koester: ‘Body Electric’
abstract: The Danish artist Joachim Koester addresses a persistent anxiety of modern life: that we are all just cogs in a giant machine.
lead_paragraph: In the four absorbing but conceptually overbearing video and film works in this show, the Danish artist Joachim Koester addresses a persistent anxiety of modern life: that we are all just cogs in a giant machine.

headline: Shimmering Memories of a Mellow Collaborator
abstract: A roster of collaborators honored the guitarist Jeff Golub, who died Jan. 1 at 59, in a heartfelt musical tribute at the B. B. King Blues Club.
lead_paragraph: Entering the homestretch of the memorial concert “Friends of Jeff Golub,” which ran the better part of four hours at the B. B. King Blues Club on Wednesday night, the keyboardist Jason Miles offered an encomium, brief and to the point. “Whatever he did, whether it was smooth or it was blues, there was a commitment,” he said of Mr. Golub, a crisp and stylistically fluid guitarist who died on Jan. 1 at 59.

headline: Wells Fargo and JPMorgan Loan Officers Accused of Taking Kickbacks
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said that more than 100 former Wells Fargo loan officers and half a dozen from JPMorgan accepted kickbacks. The banks agreed to pay about $36 million.
lead_paragraph: More than 100 former Wells Fargo loan officers accepted kickbacks – including one former employee’s wife who collected tens of thousands of dollars in payments – as part of a scheme to steer business to a now defunct title insurance company, a federal regulator said on Thursday.

headline: Ann Toebbe: ‘Remarried’
abstract: Ann Toebbe uses collages to depict homes with significance in her adult life.
lead_paragraph: At once familiar and slightly bizarre, Ann Toebbe’s meticulous collages belong to the stay-at-home intimist tradition that begins with Édouard Vuillard’s Parisian interiors. For several years she has cut up bits of colored paper to recreate — with help from photographs and memory — the domestic interiors of her life and of the people around her. For her solo debut at this gallery in 2013, she recreated her childhood bedroom, and rooms inhabited by relatives and neighbors she knew growing up in Cincinnati.

headline: Verbatim: N.F.L. Must Punish Cheaters
abstract: Senator Dean Heller of Nevada is calling on the N.F.L. to take “decisive actions” to make sure teams play by the rules.
lead_paragraph: – Senator Dean Heller, Republican of Nevada, calling on the N.F.L. to take “decisive actions” to make sure teams play by the rules.

headline: People and Language, All at Sea
abstract: Caroline Bergvall’s installation takes its inspiration from an incident in which African immigrants were left to drift in the Mediterranean.
lead_paragraph: One of the blockbusters of Western art history, Théodore Géricault’s “The Raft of the Medusa” (1818-19), took as its impetus the true story of sailors left to die at sea, drifting on a raft off the coast of Senegal. Caroline Bergvall’s “Drift,” an installation of prints, sound works and a digital, algorithmic collage, was inspired by a similar tale, only set in the present day. In 2011, African migrants trying to reach the island of Lampedusa in the Mediterranean were left to drift at sea despite being sighted by officials; more than 60 people died.

headline: Gianna Commito
abstract: This solo show offers geometric painting on a small scale, increasingly elaborate compositions and historical references.
lead_paragraph: Gianna Commito is not alone in pursuing geometric painting on a small scale. (Tomma Abts is probably her best-known fellow traveler.) But in her second solo show at the Rachel Uffner Gallery, Ms. Commito continues to clarify her territory. She favors increasingly elaborate and compressed compositions of intersecting shards, bands and recurring stripes in medleys of softened related colors: The reds and pinks with gray and black of “Drisko,” for example, or the blues and greens with ocher of “Chestnut,” one of the show’s standouts.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Louis Vuitton Fall/Winter 2015
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Rosetta Finds Out Much About a Comet, Even With a Wayward Lander
abstract: Photographs and data from the European Space Agency craft have provided an unprecedented close-up examination of a comet, 67P.
lead_paragraph: Photographs and data from the European Space Agency’s Rosetta spacecraft have provided an unprecedented close-up examination of a comet, but there is one thing that has not shown up yet: the small lander that bounded to the surface in November.

headline: Citing Plunge in Oil Prices, Iraq Seeks Arms on Credit to Fight ISIS
abstract: Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi said the precipitous drop in prices posed a fresh challenge to his military’s efforts to push back Islamic State militants.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Battered by a sharp decline in oil prices, Iraq is asking Western allies to provide weapons on credit for its fight against the Islamic State until Baghdad is in a better position to pay.

headline: Fair City
abstract: Scenes from art and antiques fairs across New York City.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from art and antiques fairs across New York City.

headline: JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs Chiefs to Get a Sweeter Pay Package
abstract: Jamie Dimon’s pay stayed flat at $20 million, but he is receiving $7.4 million in easier-to-access cash instead of restricted stock. Lloyd Blankfein received a $1 million bump, to $24 million.
lead_paragraph: The two most-watched chief executives on Wall Street are receiving pay packages for 2014 that are a bit more attractive than the ones they received the year before.

headline: Tips for Surviving the Sundance Film Festival, From Adam Scott of “Parks and Recreation”
abstract: The actor, who has two comedies playing at this year’s festival, shares hints and tricks culled from years of movie- and party-going.
lead_paragraph: Adam Scott has made a career out of playing cool, self-deprecating men in television shows like the cult sitcom “Party Down” and the NBC comedy series “Parks and Recreation.” But as the Sundance Film Festival kicks off today in Park City, Utah, the real Adam Scott — a husband, father of two and as of late, film producer — is nervous. Though he’s a festival veteran, the stakes are especially high this year for the 41-year-old actor, who has two films debuting at Sundance: the romantic comedy “Sleeping With Other People,” in which he appears with Jason Sudekis and Alison Brie, and the in-competition comedy “The Overnight,” which he produced with his wife, and which he stars in alongside Taylor Schilling, Jason Schwartzman and Judith Godrèche. Scott took time out from his preparations to share with T his best tips for a successful Sundance.

headline: Judge Vacates Guilty Pleas of Men Charged With Insider Trading in I.B.M. Stock
abstract: A federal judge’s ruling on Thursday reflects the fallout from an appeals court decision in December that narrowed the definition of what constitutes insider trading.
lead_paragraph: The fallout from a federal appellate ruling in December that narrowed the definition of what constitutes insider trading continues to affect other cases.

headline: Pots and Pans Included
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: Fully furnished luxury homes appeal to buyers for whom time is an issue and money is not.
lead_paragraph: Fully furnished luxury homes appeal to buyers for whom time is an issue and money is not.

headline: Complaint Offers Motive for Silver’s Fight Against Corruption Panel
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: A federal prosecutor said the death of the Moreland Commission came as “a great relief” to the Assembly speaker, who actively fought its creation.
lead_paragraph: Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the New York Assembly and one of the most powerful politicians in Albany, did all he could to derail and undermine an anticorruption panel established by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline: Protest Art
abstract: A look at works in new shows at Smack Mellon Gallery and the Gray Art Gallery.
lead_paragraph: A look at works in new shows at Smack Mellon Gallery and the Gray Art Gallery.

headline: ‘Thomas Struth: Photographs’
abstract: Works from a new show focusing on a leading German photographer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Works from a new show focusing on a leading German photographer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Music Brings Out the Killer Instinct
abstract: In “Hear the Dance: Russia,” City Ballet offered four works set to the music of Rachmaninoff, Stravinsky, Tchaikovsky and Glazunov.
lead_paragraph: For its second program of the winter season, “Hear the Dance: Russia,” New York City Ballet offers four works set to the music of Rachmaninoff, Stravinsky, Tchaikovsky and Glazunov. Alas, music alone, no matter how sumptuous, doesn’t make a ballet. Despite the promise of debuts by several dancers on Wednesday night, Jerome Robbins’s “The Cage” and George Balanchine’s “Cortège Hongrois” eclipsed two other ballets with little effort.

headline: An Online Garage Sale, Culled From the Homes of Jeff Koons, Richard Phillips, Miuccia Prada and More
abstract: Other donors to the auction, organized by the hip Russian museum and magazine Garage, include Josephine Meckseper, James Franco, Carsten Holler and Joanna Lumley.
lead_paragraph: Leave it to the preternaturally hip Russian museum and magazine Garage to subvert that least glamorous of Sunday-afternoon routines: poking through garage sales. This Sunday, Garage will launch a digital sale (the proceeds of which will be split between CalArts and Garage Museum of Contemporary Art Education) that collects objects culled from the homes of 13 artists and creatives. According to the magazine’s editorial director, Michael Polsinelli, the concept was a natural fit for the organization. “It began as a simple editorial idea — we as readers always want better access to great creative contributors, and it’s pretty great access to know what’s collecting dust in their closets, attics and garages,” he says. “From our side, it’s also a neat callback to our roots: Garage — as a museum and subsequently a magazine – began in the famed bus garage designed by constructivist architect Konstantin Melnikov in Moscow.”

headline: Paul Pings Romney and Bush on Utah Meeting
abstract: Senator Rand Paul appears to be feeling a little left out of the mix, with potential Republican presidential rivals Jeb Bush and Mitt Romney holding an informal summit in Utah.
lead_paragraph: Senator Rand Paul appears to be feeling a little left out of the mix, with potential Republican presidential rivals Jeb Bush and Mitt Romney holding an informal summit in Utah on Thursday.

headline: The Rain Comes, but the Rescue Takes Longer
abstract: In “Against the Sun,” three World War II Navy airmen struggle to survive on a tiny raft after their plane crashes in the Pacific.
lead_paragraph: A three-men-in-a-raft movie that, like the raft, bobs around aimlessly for much of its running time, “Against the Sun” is a groaningly tedious survival story that will at least leave you with a renewed commitment to wearing sunscreen.

headline: Gift of Good Manners
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Kosher Foods and Products', 'Time-Sharing', 'Gifts']
abstract: Dealing with engagement gifts, observant guests, loud landlord and a story about a sister.
lead_paragraph: My fiancé and I were recently engaged. His mother gave us a week at her timeshare vacation home as an engagement present because she can’t afford to use it herself. I think this is inappropriate. The burden is on us to make all the other purchases necessary to use the present (flights, ground transport, food). It was clearly a gift of convenience. I want my fiancé to say something to her, but the gift doesn’t bother him. Am I wrong?

headline: A Film Star Finds His Folk Groove
abstract: John Reilly and Friends, a folk group led by the actor John C. Reilly that will perform in Lincoln Center’s Songbook series, was born of his abiding connection to American roots music.
lead_paragraph: In the 2007 satirical rock ’n’ roll biopic “Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story,” John C. Reilly plays a Johnny Cash-Ray Charles-Bob Dylan hybrid, hamming it up on parody songs like “There’s a Change A’ Happening (I Can Feel It).”

headline: Saints Owner Says Wife Will Inherit Control of Team
abstract: Tom Benson, the owner of the New Orleans Saints and the New Orleans Pelicans, said Thursday that his wife, Gayle, will take control of the teams when he dies.
lead_paragraph: Tom Benson, the 87-year-old owner of the New Orleans Saints and the N.B.A.’s New Orleans Pelicans, said Thursday that his wife, Gayle, 67, will take control of the teams when he dies.

headline: Setting New Standards
abstract: As it begins a 16th season, Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series has its most adventurous offerings yet.
lead_paragraph: When Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series began in 1999, it was a nostalgic program showcasing popular standards by the likes of Irving Berlin, the Gershwins and Cole Porter. While keeping one foot in the past, it has since become a progressive, increasingly multicultural program devoted to the new as much as to the old — the kind of program that can give you Richard Rodgers or rap, or even a concert sung entirely in Spanish.

headline: Brothers and Rivals in Gore
abstract: “Killers,” by the Mo Brothers, has a nihilistic yet mournful tone, following two murderers, one Japanese and one Indonesian.
lead_paragraph: Two nut cases, one Japanese and the other Indonesian, work out their psychoses on innocent women and despicable men in the aptly named “Killers,” the bludgeon-y sophomore feature from the Mo Brothers, Kimo Stamboel and Timo Tjahjanto.

headline: A Rum Crew Jettisons All Reason
abstract: In “Black Sea,” Jude Law stars as a sailor who seizes on a chance to explore for undersea gold with a rough and greedy crew.
lead_paragraph: The British submarine thriller “Black Sea” has an insistent political subtext that distinguishes it from earlier films in the undersea action genre. As its waterlogged treasure hunters brave fire and flood to find and bring back a cache of gold ingots from a sunken Nazi U-boat in the Black Sea, they grouse endlessly about paper-pushing rich guys who don’t know the meaning of real work.

headline: If a Car Is Going to Self-Drive, It Might as Well Self-Park, Too
keywords: ['Parking', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Automobiles', 'Mobile Applications', 'International Consumer Electronics Show']
abstract: BMW has created a system that actually obeys when a driver says to the car, “Go park yourself.” Other companies are also working on the technology.
lead_paragraph: TECHNOLOGY may soon render another skill superfluous: parking a car.

headline: Abortion Bill Bait-and-Switch
abstract: House Republican had planned to mark Thursday’s Roe v. Wade anniversary by pushing through a ban on almost all abortions 20 weeks after fertilization.
lead_paragraph: House Republican had planned to mark Thursday’s 42nd anniversary of the Supreme Court’s 1973 Roe v. Wade decision by pushing through a brazenly unconstitutional measure to prohibit almost all abortions 20 weeks after fertilization. That plan was abruptly abandoned when some female representatives objected to the bill’s callously narrow and politically tone-deaf rape and incest exceptions.

headline: Where to Get a FICO Credit Score
abstract: A list of lenders that provide free copies of FICO scores, three-digit numbers generally ranging from 300 to 850.
lead_paragraph: A list of lenders that provide free copies of FICO scores, three-digit numbers generally ranging from 300 to 850.

headline: Free FICO Credit Scores: Options Grow for Consumers
abstract: Nudging from federal officials, combined with an “open-access” program a leading credit score firm created in 2013, have pushed lenders to offer free scores.
lead_paragraph: It used to be that your credit score was a well-guarded secret, available only to lenders and banks, which used it to evaluate whether you were likely to pay back a loan. If you wanted to see your score, you typically had to buy it.

headline: Sparring in the Boxing Ring, in Politics and in Life
abstract: The documentary “Manny” is the story of Manny Pacquiao, a tiny Filipino boxer who emerged as a champion, a congressman and a natural showman.
lead_paragraph: Boxing loves an underdog story, and the hagiographic documentary “Manny” has a good one in Manny Pacquiao (below). According to the movie, this Filipino fighter grew up in extreme poverty, boxed for small purses to help his family and then became a superstar — amassing world titles in eight weight classes — after coming to the United States. He is revered in the Philippines, where he sits in Congress.

headline: Jockeying to Get Ahead by Cutting Corners
abstract: “Americons,” based on Beau Martin Williams’s personal experience, is a morality tale of high-flying, unscrupulous lenders.
lead_paragraph: The subprime mortgage disaster is treated as a muddled morality tale of glitzy corruption in Theo Avgerinos’s “Americons.” Mr. Avgerinos’s glossy, overripe take on high-flying, unscrupulous lenders — the wolves of Main Street — deteriorates into a hot mess of montages, trailer-ready one-liners and thudding drama.

headline: The People Most at Risk of Losing Insurance in the Supreme Court’s Health Ruling
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Those predominantly affected would be white, Southern, employed and middle-aged, according to an Urban Institute analysis.
lead_paragraph: The people who could lose their health insurance as a result of a Supreme Court decision this year are predominantly white, Southern, employed and middle-aged, according to an Urban Institute analysis.

headline: The Grief Spread Across the Road to Recovery
abstract: Jennifer Aniston plays a woman recovering from a horrific accident in “Cake,” a drama directed by Daniel Barnz.
lead_paragraph: The modestly scaled, sad-funny indie drama “Cake” centers on a woman and the kind of grief that’s so unbearable this movie can’t even handle it. Jennifer Aniston plays Claire, who, having survived a horrific accident, now lives in near isolation in Los Angeles in a midcentury magazine layout of a house. Its clean lines, drawn by an architect and embellished by a period-design obsessive, make a vivid contrast with the scars jaggedly slashed across Claire’s face and body. Her wounds have healed, but her grimace and the shadows darkening it announce that she’s far from whole.

headline: When Hunky Neighbor Becomes Homicidal Stalker
abstract: Jennifer Lopez plays a teacher who comes to regret a one-night stand in “The Boy Next Door.”
lead_paragraph: He can fix garage doors, beat up bullies and analyze “The Iliad,” but don’t be fooled: The new almost-20-year-old neighbor, Noah (Ryan Guzman), is a nightmare for an almost divorced schoolteacher, Claire Peterson (Jennifer Lopez), in “The Boy Next Door.” She succumbs to his flattery and his sculpted body one night, after walking out on a date, and the rest of the movie is devoted to showing how bad an idea that passionate mistake was.

headline: Details in Milan
abstract: Bags, shoes and other accessories at the men’s shows during Milan Fashion week.
lead_paragraph: Bags, shoes and other accessories at the men’s shows during Milan Fashion week.

headline: Emporiums of the Waggish and Weird
abstract: Metro Curates and the New York Ceramics and Glass Fair cater to antiques hunters with a yen for the droll or whimsical.
lead_paragraph: THIS year, as always, the Winter Antiques Show monopolizes the glamour and the glory, with top-end wares — at top-end prices — making it the trade-fair equivalent of a big Broadway musical. But there is an Off Broadway too, smaller-scale shows that accommodate the wayward, the whimsical and the downright weird.

headline: Flashbacks and Forecasts
abstract: A reporter’s look at how the art world has changed since 1991 and where it appears to be headed.
lead_paragraph: When I started covering the art world for The New York Times in 1991, the market was reeling from a worldwide recession. Gone were the Japanese who had been snapping up Impressionist and post-Impressionist paintings at a frenzied pace, spending huge sums for what one dealer described as “pretty pictures across a crowded room.” After the Japanese disappeared, sales at the auction giants Sotheby’s and Christie’s plummeted to about half of what they had been.

headline: Forgotten Creators, Memorable Works
abstract: The Winter Antiques Show at the Park Avenue Armory overflows with singular items from dozens of periods and genres.
lead_paragraph: Celebrated masterpieces are all well and good, but the less-well-lit nooks and crannies of art history are also needed to sustain a true art lover. That’s what a big fair like the Winter Antiques Show at the Park Avenue Armory is especially good for. With 73 purveyors of rare and remarkable objects, from ancient Egyptian sculpture to Modernist painting, it offers innumerable opportunities to encounter and learn about aspects of painting, decorative arts, furniture, jewelry or glass that might be new to even the best-informed visitors.

headline: Raging Against the Dying of the Stage Lights
abstract: Al Pacino plays a revered stage and screen actor who fears he is losing his mojo in “The Humbling.”
lead_paragraph: In his later fiction, Philip Roth has addressed the indignities of aging with a squirm-inducing candor. How many readers (or filmgoers) are eager to contemplate the loss of their powers until it is staring them in the face?

headline: A Backstage Genius at Bennington and Juilliard
abstract: Greg Vander Veer’s “Miss Hill: Making Dance Matter” is a documentary about Martha Hill, an educator whose influence may have been as great as any of the dance world’s better-known names.
lead_paragraph: Making a documentary about a well-known figure from the creative side of the performing arts — an actor, a singer, a writer — is easy, and common. Making one about any of the countless people who further the arts from behind the scenes is more difficult. “Miss Hill: Making Dance Matter” is such a documentary, advancing the idea that Martha Hill was as important a figure in modern dance in the last century as any of the art form’s better-known names.

headline: Raging at Racism, From Streets to Galleries
keywords: ['Art', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The deaths of Eric Garner and Michael Brown sparked angry protests in the streets that are now immortalized in art.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 3, a grand jury declined to indict a white New York City police officer for the chokehold death of an unarmed black Staten Island resident, Eric Garner. Anger at the verdict, particularly on the part of African-Americans, already stung by the police killing of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., was intense. Street protests flared across the country in perhaps the largest public display of resistance since the 1960s.

headline: Pocket-Size Picks for Photographers
abstract: Think small and lightweight accessories that attach to cellphones for newlyweds who want to record honeymoon memories.
lead_paragraph: Think small and lightweight accessories that attach to cellphones for newlyweds who want to record honeymoon memories.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Ukraine and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Ukraine and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: New York’s New Rentals
abstract: New rental buildings around the city.
lead_paragraph: New rental buildings around the city.

headline: A Sensual Utopia Driven by Ritual and Release
abstract: “The Duke of Burgundy,” by Peter Strickland, is an exquisite hothouse flower of high-toned eroticism, evoking the director’s unabashed love of old exploitation movies.
lead_paragraph: Here are two somewhat contradictory things I can tell you about “The Duke of Burgundy,” which takes its name from a species of butterfly. It is, I’m fairly certain, quite unlike any other Sapphic S-and-M lepidoptery-themed psychological romance you have ever seen. At the same time, though, its uniqueness rests on a passionate, you might say slavish, devotion to a particular cinematic style of the past.

headline: Not Quite Sure About Happily Ever After
abstract: In “We’ll Never Have Paris,” a florist on the cusp of proposing to his longtime girlfriend begins to wonder what it would be like to see other women.
lead_paragraph: If you think the characters played by Woody Allen seem insufficiently self-deprecating, “We’ll Never Have Paris” offers an even less likely romantic lead in Quinn (Simon Helberg, from “The Big Bang Theory”), a New York florist with unrealized musical ambitions. Now 28, Quinn plans to propose to Devon (Melanie Lynskey), his girlfriend since high school. But when he reveals his intentions to a co-worker and friend, Kelsey (Maggie Grace, in a ditsy turn), she confesses that she is in love with him.

headline: The Top Five Fall/Winter 2015 Men’s Wear Collections From Milan
keywords: ["Men's Fashion Week", 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Men and Boys', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: T’s men’s fashion editors share their favorites from the latest round of shows.
lead_paragraph: T’s men’s fashion editors share their favorites from the latest round of shows.

headline: Iowa Governor Issues an Ethanol Warning for 2016
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Ethanol', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Gov. Terry E. Branstad of Iowa is warning potential presidential candidates that they should support ethanol if they want to win the state’s caucuses.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Terry E. Branstad of Iowa is telling potential presidential candidates that if they want to win over the state’s voters next year, they should make clear now that they support ethanol production in a big way even as a powerful coalition of interest groups in Washington is working against it.

headline: Music as a Balm for a Grieving Soul
abstract: “Song One,” starring Anne Hathaway, offers a wispy meditation on the healing properties of a pretty folk song — especially when sung by a sensitive troubadour with bedroom eyes.
lead_paragraph: “Song One,” Kate Barker-Froyland’s anemic first feature, offers a wispy meditation on the healing properties of a pretty folk song — especially when sung by a shaggy-haired troubadour with bedroom eyes and a sensitive soul.

headline: Jan. 22, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Yemen, Malta and Nepal.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Yemen, Malta and Nepal.

headline: Spilling a Love Potion on a Fairy Princess
abstract: Gary Rydstrom’s animated “Strange Magic” is based on a story by George Lucas inspired by “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” and populated with fairies, elves and goblins.
lead_paragraph: “Strange Magic,” directed by the Oscar-winning sound designer Gary Rydstrom from a story by George Lucas, is set in a world of fairies, elves and goblins. The fluid digital animation tickles the eye with a sea of periwinkle, pockmarked creatures and diaphanous, detailed wings.

headline: He Loves Me, He Loves Me Not — Oh, Hi, Dad
abstract: Abdellah Taïa’s “Salvation Army” is the director’s story of growing up gay in Morocco, where homosexuality is illegal.
lead_paragraph: For a film rooted in a personal story, “Salvation Army” feels awfully remote. This disjointed movie is the directorial debut of the Moroccan author Abdellah Taïa, who caused a stir when he came out in his country, where homosexuality is illegal. Mr. Taïa adapted the screenplay from his autobiographical novel of the same name.

headline: Ford Opens Lab in Silicon Valley
abstract: Mark Fields, Ford’s chief executive, said the company wanted to be seen as part of Silicon Valley’s ecosystem.
lead_paragraph: In the latest sign that the distinctions between the auto and tech industries are becoming more blurry, Ford on Thursday celebrated the opening of a new research center in Palo Alto, Calif., in the heart of Silicon Valley.

headline: To Fight, Flee or Simply Join Them?
abstract: “Son of a Gun” teams a hardened criminal portrayed by Ewan McGregor with his 19-year-old protégé in a brutish Australian action-adventure fantasy.
lead_paragraph: “Some scientist discovered that all people are descended from two kinds of monkey: the chimpanzee and the bonobo,” declares Brendan Lynch (Ewan McGregor), a hardened criminal and chess whiz in Julius Avery’s grimly silly action-adventure fantasy, “Son of a Gun.”

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Dries Van Noten Fall/Winter 2015
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Small Protest Dispersed in Cairo Ahead of Revolt Anniversary
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Social Media']
abstract: Witnesses to a rare demonstration in central Cairo shared video and photographs of protesters clashing with the police.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of protesters staged a show of defiance against the authorities in downtown Cairo on Thursday, waving flares and chanting against military rule ahead of the fourth anniversary of the Egyptian revolution.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Li Ka-shing’s Hutchison Whampoa in Talks for British Mobile Firm O2
keywords: ['Cellular Telephones', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: If completed, the $15 billion deal between Three, Hutchison Whampoa’s British cellphone business, and O2 would be the latest in a transformation of Europe’s telecom sector.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Hutchison Whampoa, one of the flagship companies of the Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing, said on Friday it had agreed to enter exclusive talks to buy O2, the British cellphone carrier owned by the Spanish telecom giant Telefónica, in a deal worth roughly $15 billion.

abstract: A critical guide to movies playing in theaters, as well as a selected overview of film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

abstract: A selected, critical guide to performances of rock, pop, cabaret and more in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Pleasure, Dealt Painfully
abstract: In ‘R100,” by Hitoshi Matsumoto, a salaryman hires a sadism service to deliver dominatrixes wielding punishment on a regular basis.
lead_paragraph: Rivers of spit and acres of shiny fetish wear glisten in the Japanese fantasy “R100,” a gleeful gross-out in which a meek salaryman hires an army of dominatrixes to do their cruel worst. The S-&-M gear has been selected with conspicuous care, from the pointy heels (the better to kick bad boys down the stairs) to the suitcase of instruments that look modeled on those in David Cronenberg’s gynecological horror show, “Dead Ringers.” In that 1988 movie, the sinister tool kit was for “operating on mutant women”; here, it’s hauled out to dig deeper under the viewer’s skin.

headline: Sales Jump at Starbucks, at Outset of a Bold Push for Growth
abstract: The company used a mix of new products and promotions, including a new latte, Chestnut Praline, to attract consumers during the critical holiday season.
lead_paragraph: Starbucks, the company that turned legions of Americans into coffee cravers, on Thursday reported robust gains in sales and earnings during this past holiday quarter.

headline: King Abdullah, a Shrewd Force Who Reshaped Saudi Arabia, Dies at 90
abstract: Abdullah was one of the world’s wealthiest and most powerful men, but a cautious reformer amid great changes in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia, who came to the throne in old age and earned a reputation as a cautious reformer even as the Arab Spring revolts toppled heads of state and Islamic State militants threatened the Muslim establishment that he represented, died on Friday, according to a statement on state television. He was 90.

headline: Comes an Aristocrat, Mustache Flaring
abstract: In “Mortdecai,” Johnny Depp plays a rakish aristocrat who hopes to pay off an enormous tax debt by tracking down and selling a missing Goya painting.
lead_paragraph: “Mortdecai” might as well be called “The Johnny Depp Movie,” because its preening star, wearing an ascot and a walrus mustache that becomes a tiresome running joke, is the whole show. And what a frantically dull spectacle this vanity project is. “Mortdecai,” directed by David Koepp from a screenplay by Eric Aronson, would never have been made without Mr. Depp’s enthusiasm for the source material, the first of the 1970s trilogy of farcical novels by the British author Kyril Bonfiglioli, in the P. G. Wodehouse tradition of sophisticated silliness.

headline: In Egypt, Sowing Seeds of Gender Equality
abstract: A program has shown that mixing boys and girls together for discussions helps build empathy across the gender divide.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Sara was supposed to marry young. She was supposed to get a job teaching at the school a few minutes’ walk from her family’s apartment in Cairo so she’d always be close to home, safe from sexual harassment, keeping her reputation as a virtuous, Muslim woman intact.

headline: Why Adnan Syed of ‘Serial’ Should Have Pleaded Guilty
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Plea Bargaining', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: In his case, the injustice may lie not in the conviction, but in the failure to negotiate the charges.
lead_paragraph: OUR modern criminal justice system is designed to avoid jury trials. Through investigation and considered use of discretion, prosecutors are expected to charge only when there is sufficient evidence to convict. Once charged, defendants are encouraged to plead guilty in part to avoid a “trial penalty” — a longer sentence after a trial, often a much longer one. And 95 percent of them do just that. The Supreme Court acknowledged this reality in 2012 when it described our criminal process as “a system of pleas.”

headline: Online Storage Provider Box Prices I.P.O. at $14 a Share
abstract: Box will be valued at $1.7 billion when it begins trading on Friday, but concerns have been raised within Silicon Valley about the highflying valuations that some technology darlings have fetched recently.
lead_paragraph: After nearly a year of trying, the online file storage provider Box Inc. is finally set to become a public company. But it will begin trading amid questions about its future prospects.

headline: It’s How You Finish
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Football', 'United States Economy', 'Law and Legislation', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: A week of fourth-quarter heroics from the Seattle Seahawks and, if he has his way, President Obama.
lead_paragraph: As the world contemplates the deflated football scandal in Boston — ballghazi — please allow me one last moment of undiluted sports delirium. I live in Seattle, where this week the sky is always blue, trees are blossoming early, all children are not only above average but get into the college of their choice, free. We are a city transfixed, rhapsodically floating, after the most are-you-kidding-me experience my hometown has ever been through.

headline: Outrage: Cruelty at a U.S. Meat Lab
abstract: Sampling the outpouring of responses to front-page exposé.

headline: An Albany Powerhouse on the Edge of a Volcano
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'State Legislatures', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: In the past, Sheldon Silver, the New York State Assembly speaker who now faces graft charges, has rarely given quarter to other powerful people in distress.
lead_paragraph: Al Smith, the storied governor of New York in the 1920s who laid the groundwork for the New Deal, has been credited with making a famously cynical remark as he walked through a law school library. He spotted a student, bent over books and reading.

headline: Trying Youths as Adults
abstract: New York’s attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, calls for treating 16- and 17-year-olds as juveniles rather than adult defendants.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Insiders, Outsiders, and U.S. Monetary Policy
abstract: Worrying thoughts over breakfast.
lead_paragraph: I ran into Olivier Blanchard over breakfast the other day. This isn’t as prosaic as it sounds, because we were both in Hong Kong. On the other hand, that in turn isn’t as much of a coincidence as it might seem, because there was a big financial conference here, and the set of economists who get invited to such things isn’t that extensive. More broadly, many of the people who either make monetary policy or comment on it from fairly influential perches are members of what you might call the 1970s Cambridge mafia. Olivier, Ben Bernanke, Ken Rogoff, Mario Draghi, and yours truly all overlapped at MIT in the mid-70s; Larry Summers was at Harvard at the same time, taking courses at MIT; just about everyone was Stan Fischer’s student.

abstract: An official of Zero Waste Detroit says the environmental costs of burning waste should not be ignored.
