headline: Disparate Education Plans From Obama and Cuomo
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Community Colleges', 'Charter Schools', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Private and Sectarian Schools']
abstract: President Obama proposes to make community college free for two years for qualifying students. Education ideas that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo endorsed include a tax credit for charitable contributions to public, charter and parochial schools.
lead_paragraph: Since President Obama announced his proposal this month to make community college free for two years for qualifying students, arguments for and against the plan have been abundant. Some have assailed the initiative as futile, maintaining that federal Pell grants already cover the cost of community college for most poor and working-class students, and that the real obstacle comes not in tuition but in living expenses and the high price of textbooks. In actuality, tuition covered by the new subsidy would free up Pell grants to help alleviate those burdens.

headline: Spare Times for Jan. 23-29
abstract: A selected guide to readings, discussions, exhibitions, walking tours and other cultural events in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Note: With the snowstorm forcing cancellations across the city on Monday — including the postponement of a Tuesday night event at the Museum of Jewish Heritage to mark International Holocaust Remembrance Day — we advise that you check with venues before setting out to events scheduled for Monday or Tuesday.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Jan. 23-29
abstract: A selected guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Note: With the snowstorm forcing cancellations across the city on Monday, we advise that you check with venues before setting out to events scheduled for Monday or Tuesday.

headline: The Devotion Leap
keywords: ['Dating and Relationships', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Online Dating']
abstract: The ability to move from the self-centeredness of dating to the self-sacrifice of love requires one to lower the boundaries between self and self.
lead_paragraph: The online dating site OkCupid asks its clients to rate each other’s attractiveness on a scale of 1 to 5. When men rated the women, the median score was about 3 and the ratings followed a bell curve — a few really attractive women and an equal number of women rated as unattractive.

headline: Much Too Responsible
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression', 'American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (2009)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Deflation (Economics)', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: Why is the United States experiencing a solid recovery while Europe is sinking ever deeper into deflationary quicksand?
lead_paragraph: The United States and Europe have a lot in common. Both are multicultural and democratic; both are immensely wealthy; both possess currencies with global reach. Both, unfortunately, experienced giant housing and credit bubbles between 2000 and 2007, and suffered painful slumps when the bubbles burst.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Cuts Its Staff and Output
abstract: The studio said it had to lay off hundreds of employees and make fewer movies to “ensure the consistent and profitable delivery” of films.
lead_paragraph: DreamWorks Animation said on Thursday that it would reduce its movie output and lay off 500 employees, or roughly 19 percent of its staff, a retrenchment that follows a string of box-office misfires and two failed merger attempts.

headline: Senate Rejects Human Role in Climate Change
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Keystone Pipeline System', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senators are using the Keystone XL pipeline debate to argue over climate issues.
lead_paragraph: The Senate on Thursday again voted to reject two measures related to the Keystone XL pipeline that declared that humans are a cause of climate change — the second set of votes on the issue in two days.

headline: Fast Track on Drug for Ebola Has Faltered
abstract: Federal officials vowed to make more of an experimental drug that showed promise in treating Ebola, but that project has moved slowly.
lead_paragraph: As Ebola raged through West Africa last summer, an experimental drug was tried for the first time on two American aid workers in Liberia who were gravely ill with the virus. Both recovered, one of them rapidly.

headline: Conflict, and Smiles, as U.S. and Cuba Discuss Ties
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The sides met for several hours, mostly to iron out technical issues in converting their diplomatic outposts into full-fledged embassies.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — The United States and Cuba held talks on Thursday to re-establish diplomatic ties broken during the Cold War, aiming to put the countries on a path toward normal relations after decades of hostility, acrimony and mistrust.

headline: Brady Says League Has Not Contacted Him
abstract: “I thought we won the game fair and square,” Patriots quarterback Tom Brady said of Sunday’s A.F.C. championship game against the Indianapolis Colts. New England used underinflated balls.
lead_paragraph: “I thought we won the game fair and square,” Patriots quarterback Tom Brady said of Sunday’s A.F.C. championship game against the Indianapolis Colts. New England used underinflated balls.

headline: This Week’s Movies | Jan. 23, 2015
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Black Sea,” “Cake” and “Mommy.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Black Sea,” “Cake” and “Mommy.”

headline: European Central Bank Bets Big on Curing the Economy
abstract: With a $69 billion-a-month bond-buying program, Mario Draghi, the central bank president, is unleashing the bank’s full money-printing powers.
lead_paragraph: Mario Draghi has delivered — for now, at least.

headline: BMW and Volkswagen Team Up to Expand Network of High-Speed Charging Stations
abstract: The stations will be part of a fast-growing network run by ChargePoint, the nation’s largest, and will be compatible with nearly all electric vehicles on the road.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As sales of electric vehicles languish, automakers are starting to address one of the biggest obstacles to their wider acceptance: the lack of charging stations.

headline: Christie Uses Executive Order to Appoint an Emergency Manager in Atlantic City
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey said the move was not intended to “marginalize or minimize” the roles of the financially struggling city’s elected government, which had rejected the idea.
lead_paragraph: Moving to take greater control over Atlantic City, which is struggling financially as its casino industry shrinks, Gov. Chris Christie on Thursday appointed a corporate finance lawyer to be the city’s emergency manager.

headline: Searching for Answers in the 1961 Death of an Ayn Rand Follower
abstract: In 1961, Vivian Grant died after an unnecessary abortion. A woman who now lives in her apartment in Kips Bay is riveted by her story.
lead_paragraph: Joanne O’Connor keeps a three-ring binder as thick as a cinder block to contain the story that echoes through her head. It is stuffed with her research about a young woman she never met who died more than 50 years ago. She has trouble explaining why obsession gripped her so, but she does know: “I had to find out what happened.”

headline: In Tamir Rice Case, Many Errors by Cleveland Police, Then a Fatal One
abstract: Miscommunications, tactical errors and institutional failures by the Cleveland police cascaded into one irreversible mistake: the shooting of a 12-year-old boy.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — It began with a swap: one boy’s cellphone for another’s replica of a Colt pistol.

headline: A Scorsese Documentary on Bill Clinton Is Stalled
abstract: Martin Scorsese’s planned documentary on the 42nd president has been shelved over disagreements about control, people briefed on the project said.
lead_paragraph: Martin Scorsese has tackled the mob, the Dalai Lama and the real-life Wolf of Wall Street.

headline: Opening His Mother’s Clothing Shop, and Then Heading to Tel Aviv for a Rampage
abstract: A string of stabbings by a 23-year-old Palestinian exemplifies a new threat in Israel: spontaneous attacks by individuals.
lead_paragraph: AL JIB, West Bank — After the raid by Israeli security forces, details of the young Palestinian man’s life had been strewn haphazardly on the floor of one room of his family’s home: a mattress, a tangle of blankets and clothes, an ashtray of cigarette butts, an energy drink can and handwritten notes about electrical circuits — the young man had just received a diploma in electrical studies — and, chillingly in hindsight, a new-looking knife with a long, smooth blade.

headline: Peggy Charren, Children’s TV Crusader, Dies at 86
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Television', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Ms. Charren, whose work ultimately led to the Children’s Television Act, received a Peabody Award for public service and, later, a Presidential Medal of Freedom.
lead_paragraph: Peggy Charren, whose advocacy of higher-minded television programming for children took the issue to government agencies and the halls of Congress and led to landmark legislation, died on Thursday at her home in Dedham, Mass. She was 86.

headline: Conservative Gathering in Iowa Offers Platform to Several Possible 2016 Contenders
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: The largest assembly of potential Republican presidential candidates to date will offer those in a crowded field a chance to distinguish themselves from one another.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — The largest gathering of potential Republican presidential candidates so far will descend on Iowa on Saturday to test their messages at a forum shaping up as the informal starting gun for the 2016 campaign.

headline: Bush and Romney in ‘Gentlemanly’ Meeting
abstract: Jeb Bush and Mitt Romney did not emerge from a Salt Lake City meeting on Thursday with a proposal about how to reconcile their competing plans to run for the White House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jeb Bush and Mitt Romney did not reach an agreement during a Salt Lake City lunch meeting on Thursday on how to reconcile their competing plans to run for the White House next year, advisers to both men indicated after the talk.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Jan. 23
abstract: Photographs from the past week from New York City and the region include images from a City Council hearing on Airbnb and a protest of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s annual address.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week from New York City and the region include images from a City Council hearing on Airbnb and a protest of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s annual address.

headline: How Super Was Mario? (Wonkish)
abstract: The 0.2 percent solution?
lead_paragraph: Mario Draghi pulled off a political triumph on QE, coming in with a program that is bigger and more open-ended than anyone expected. The goal was to jolt expectations, to convince markets that there has been a fundamental shift toward aggressiveness. And markets certainly moved in the right direction. But how much was achieved? Inquiring minds want to know — or at least I do. So I’ve done some back-of-the-envelope calculations on the question of how much Draghi managed to move inflation expectations.

headline: Jean Lindenmann, Who Made Interferon His Life’s Work, Is Dead at 90
abstract: As a postdoctoral student working with Dr. Alick Isaacs in 1957, Dr. Lindenmann discovered interferon, the powerful antiviral substance used to treat some cancers, hepatitis C and multiple sclerosis.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Jean Lindenmann, a co-discoverer of interferon, the powerful antiviral substance used to treat some cancers as well as hepatitis C and multiple sclerosis, died on Jan. 15 in hospice care in Zurich. He was 90.

headline: A Year After Suing Their Landlord, Brooklyn Tenants Still Lack Heat
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Landlords', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Heating', 'Weather']
abstract: A group of Brooklyn tenants first complained about lacking heat last winter, but many trips to Housing Court later, the issue remains unresolved.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, a city housing inspector visited an apartment on the fourth floor of 940 Prospect Place in Brooklyn and issued a violation to the landlord for inadequate heat. The visit was nothing new — since December 2013, residents of 940 and the adjoining building at 930 Prospect Place have made more than 100 complaints about lack of heat or hot water.

headline: Knocked for Risks, League Plays Defense
abstract: The Texas Youth Football Association fueled a debate about youth football and parenting after it was featured on “Friday Night Tykes,” which has returned with some intensity toned down.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — On a Thursday night in December, Brian Morgan stood at the 50-yard line on a community football field as two teams from the Outlaws, a youth organization, practiced to his left and right. Both teams — one with 6- and 7-year-olds and the other with 10- and 11-year-olds — were preparing for championship games in a few days.

headline: Surveys Show Bias of Potential Jurors in Boston Bombing Trial
abstract: Lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who is accused of planting bombs at the Boston Marathon, cited juror prejudices in asking for a change of venue for the third time.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — One potential juror said she was biased against Dzhokhar Tsarnaev because he is Muslim. “I already feel that he’s guilty,” she said.

headline: Obama Not Planning to Meet With Israeli Premier
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: When Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel visits the United States to lobby Congress for new sanctions that President Obama opposes, the two leaders will not meet, the White House said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House said on Thursday that President Obama would not meet Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel when he comes here in March to speak to a joint meeting of Congress and to lobby for new sanctions on Iran that Mr. Obama opposes, the latest twist in a dispute that has marked a new low in relations between the two leaders and which now threatens the chances of a nuclear deal with Tehran.

abstract: Lottery numbersfor New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Inquiry Sought After Former Commissioner Accuses Gov. Rick Scott of Meddling

lead_paragraph: MIAMI — As Gov. Rick Scott faced mounting questions about the ouster of the top state law enforcement chief and allegations of improper political meddling, two influential fellow Republicans called for an inquiry on Thursday into the potentially damaging accusations.

headline: Baseball Lifer Leaves Office, but Not the Game
abstract: Commissioner Bud Selig leaves office on Sunday with a record of accomplishment, as well as some missteps, and an undeniable passion for baseball.
lead_paragraph: He has been honored in Arizona, Los Angeles and St. Louis, with a final farewell dinner set for Saturday night in Manhattan. In the middle of it all, back home in Milwaukee, 30 floors above his hometown, Bud Selig has somehow found time to pack his office.

headline: The Cat Is a Thinker; the Dog’s Unwell
abstract: Maggie Bofill’s domestic comedy “Winners” stars Grant Shaud and Florencia Lozano as a couple with relationship and peanut butter problems.
lead_paragraph: In Maggie Bofill’s domestic comedy “Winners,” co-produced by the Ensemble Studio Theater and the Radio Drama Network, the home fires have guttered. At the Mackeys’ suburban abode, the unemployed dad, Brian, slumps in his robe, cooking inedible meals. The overworked mom, Mabel, receives racy texts from her boss. Tommy, a teenager, loses his after-school job for smoking pot, and little Gabby’s proposal for the Christmas play involves an awful lot of stage blood.

headline: Political Intrigue in China, With Loyalties Uncertain
abstract: There is roiling tumult amid the shadows in Damon Chua’s play “Film Chinois,” an exercise in noir styling and political intrigue.
lead_paragraph: There is roiling tumult amid the shadows in Damon Chua’s uneven but beautifully staged “Film Chinois,” at the Beckett Theater. In this Pan Asian Repertory production, an exercise in noir styling and political intrigue, identities can be fluid and motivations suspect.

headline: Fewer Trees in a Fairy-Tale Forest
abstract: Fiasco Theater’s reworking of “Into the Woods” uncovers the aching, hopeful heart beneath the artifice.
lead_paragraph: These are the woods that you want to get lost in, a place you’ll find buried treasures that you didn’t even know existed. Fiasco Theater’s truly enchanting production of Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine’s “Into the Woods,” which opened on Thursday night at the Laura Pels Theater, makes the best case ever for a musical that interpreters have been trying to get right since the show was first staged in the mid-1980s.

headline: Measure of a Radio Band
abstract: Ed Sessa is back with a fun Friday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Deb Amlen Sighting Alert! Once again, the Ace Hotel and I will be gently waking up New York City with the Jan. 25 Sunday crossword, and we hope you can join us for trivia, coffee and crossword-solving fun. We invade, sorry, we start at 11 a.m. Sunday, January 25, in the beautifully appointed Ace lobby, located at 20 West 29th Street. See you there!

keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Legal Profession', 'State Legislatures', 'Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: ALBANY — When federal prosecutors subpoenaed a law firm to learn what exactly Sheldon Silver, the powerful leader of the State Assembly, had done to earn the hundreds of thousands of dollars the firm paid him each year, prosecutors received just one file.

headline: Nigeria: A Bird Flu Outbreak Spreads
abstract: An outbreak of avian flu that began in two states has spread to seven since last week and has infected more than 140,000 birds, Nigeria’s agriculture minister was quoted as saying by Nigerian news media on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: An outbreak of avian flu that began in two states has spread to seven since last week and has infected more than 140,000 birds, Nigeria’s agriculture minister was quoted as saying by Nigerian news media on Thursday. The minister, Akwinumi Adesina, sought to assure the public that the outbreak had not reached a crisis. “There is no cause for alarm,” he said, though at least one strain of the virus that causes the disease, H5N1, can infect humans. He also exhorted Nigerian consumers not to fear poultry consumption because the virus is spread only through contact between live birds and people who directly handle them, and the virus dies when cooked. “So, let Nigerians feel free to eat chicken and eggs,” Mr. Adesina was quoted as saying. Nigeria is Africa’s most populous country and leading poultry producer.

lead_paragraph: Bitcoin, the virtual currency that was once the talk of the financial world, has been taking a beating over the last year with the price tumbling downward.

abstract: A county prosecutor was temporarily stopped from filing charges against State Attorney General Kathleen Kane, who has been accused of perjury for disclosing an investigation to a newspaper.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Pennsylvania Supreme Court on Thursday temporarily blocked a county prosecutor from filing charges against the state attorney general, Kathleen G. Kane, who has been accused by a grand jury of perjury and other offenses in connection with the disclosure of an investigation to a Philadelphia newspaper.

abstract: Life has been hard for Pedro Martinez since he came to New York eight years ago at age 12. But that doesn’t mean he is ready to give up.

keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Terrorism', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: Khaled al-Fawwaz, charged in the attacks in Kenya and Tanzania, is one of the earliest and most senior alleged members of Al Qaeda to be tried in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen years after four men were convicted in a trial stemming from the deadly 1998 bombings of two United States Embassies in East Africa, a third trial in that attack began in Manhattan on Thursday.

headline: Bruised but Unbowed, Reid Plans for Future
abstract: Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, told reporters that injuries sustained three weeks ago during an exercise mishap would not keep him from seeking re-election in 2016.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With white gauze over his right eye and deep purple bruises visible along his jaw, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada on Thursday held his first on-camera news conference since suffering injuries in a fall three weeks ago, seeking to dispel worries about his health and repeatedly saying he would seek re-election in 2016.

lead_paragraph: A New York State watchdog agency overseeing jails and prisons has found that gross incompetence by medical personnel and correction officers at Rikers Island led to the death of a mentally ill inmate who was found naked and covered in feces after being locked in a cell for six days.

headline: Arkansas: Governor Seeks to Continue an Alternative to Medicaid
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid']
abstract: Gov. Asa Hutchinson asked lawmakers to keep the state’s alternative to Medicaid expansion under the Affordable Care Act in place for two more years.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Asa Hutchinson, a Republican, asked lawmakers Thursday to keep the state’s alternative to Medicaid expansion under the Affordable Care Act in place for two more years. In the meantime, he said, a task force will come up with recommendations for changing or replacing it. The program, known as the private option, has used federal funds to buy private insurance for more than 200,000 poor people through the HealthCare.gov marketplace instead of adding them to traditional Medicaid. The Republican-dominated Legislature has to reauthorize the program with a three-fourths vote every year, and a number of lawmakers, including some elected in November, oppose it. Mr. Hutchinson said he wanted to find a “compassionate, reasonable and cost-effective” way to provide health care for people currently benefiting from the private option.

headline: The First Woman Let Into McSorley’s Reminisces (Over an Ale, of Course)
abstract: McSorley’s Old Ale House, which opened in 1854, admitted Ms. Shaum as its first female patron, in 1970, after New York City barred discrimination against women in public places.
lead_paragraph: The low winter sun streamed into McSorley’s Old Ale House and a waiter lounged next to the saloon’s potbellied stove on Thursday afternoon, when an 85-year-old woman with a wooden cane and a mischievous look pushed her way through the double doors.

headline: Vice Uses Virtual Reality to Immerse Viewers in News

headline: At Mercy of the Draw, Players Often Hope for a Lucky Break
abstract: The opening rounds in Melbourne have demonstrated that a tennis player who might be on the verge of a breakout tournament can be stifled early on by a random draw.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Caroline Wozniacki did not lose her second-round match at the Australian Open on Thursday because of any moment of bad luck. There was no stray bounce on break point, no broken string on a crucial volley, no clipped net cord that swung the momentum.

headline: Weinstein Parts Ways With Press Agent for ‘Finding Neverland’
abstract: It’s a rare rupture in the image-conscious world of Broadway and another bump in the road for a highly anticipated musical.
lead_paragraph: The film producer Harvey Weinstein and the veteran Broadway press agent Rick Miramontez have parted ways on Mr. Weinstein’s forthcoming musical “Finding Neverland” after sharp words were said at their weekly planning meeting on Tuesday — a rare rupture in the image-conscious world of Broadway and another bump in the road for a highly anticipated musical.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 5:30 P.M. (FX Movie Channel) THE GIRL WITH THE DRAGON TATTOO (2011) Daniel Craig stars as a crusading Swedish journalist hired by a wealthy industrialist (Christopher Plummer) to investigate the disappearance of his niece 40 years earlier in this adaptation of the Stieg Larsson novel, directed by David Fincher. Rooney Mara, in an Oscar-nominated performance, is Lisbeth Salander, the vulnerable yet ruthlessly competent computer hacker who helps him solve the mystery. “She is a marvelous pop-culture character, stranger and more complex than the average superhero and more intriguing than the usual boy wizards and vampire brides,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about Lisbeth, first played by Noomi Rapace in the 2010 Swedish adaptation. “It has been her fate, unfortunately, to make her furious, uninspiring way through a series of plodding and ungainly stories.” And “despite the slick intensity of Mr. Fincher’s style, his movie is not immune to the same lumbering proceduralism,” Mr. Scott said, while acknowledging that “Mr. Fincher’s impressive skill is evident.”

headline: A Toddler’s View of New York City
abstract: Diego Acosta López wanted to document New York from his son’s perspective: inside a stroller. Thousands of pictures (including little feet and hands) ensued.
lead_paragraph: A lot has been said about embracing a child’s view of photography. That a child’s vision is innocent. That it is naïve. That above all, it is pure, unburdened by the rules of cynical grown-ups.

headline: Should a College Education Be Free?
abstract: Should students have a right to higher education, the way they now have a right to elementary and secondary education?
lead_paragraph: States offer children a free public school education until they complete 12th grade. After that, they have to pay tuition. President Obama recently announced his proposal to make community college free for many students. Is he onto something? Should students be able to get a free education after high school?

headline: Sony Postpones Earnings Announcement, Blaming Hacking Attacks

headline: In Targeting Ex-Premier, Thai Junta Takes a Risk

headline: Morning Agenda: Winklevosses Plan Bitcoin Exchange
abstract: The Winklevoss twins are planning to open a Bitcoin exchange. | Hutchison Whampoa is in talks to buy O2 of Britain. | Attractive pay packages for chiefs of JPMorgan and Goldman. | Markets respond to E.C.B. stimulus plan.
lead_paragraph: WINKLEVOSSES PLAN BITCOIN EXCHANGE | The Winklevoss twins, two of the biggest boosters of Bitcoin, are trying to firm up support for the virtual currency by creating the first regulated Bitcoin exchange for American customers, Nathaniel Popper and Sydney Ember write in DealBook. The brothers have hired engineers from top hedge funds, enlisted a bank and engaged regulators with the aim of opening their exchange, which they have financed themselves, in the coming months. They are calling the exchange Gemini ‒ Latin for twins.

headline: G.E. Profit Rises as It Puts a Stronger Focus on Its Industrial Business

If you want to know how the power set dress in the snow, this is the catwalk you need to watch.

headline: The Enemy as Hapless Clown
abstract: In “Timbuktu,” the filmmaker Abderrahmane Sissako casts the extremists who impose Muslim law on a desert city as contradictory buffoons.
lead_paragraph: To mock Adolf Hitler, Charlie Chaplin created Adenoid Hynkel, who sputtered gibberish and danced with a balloon in “The Great Dictator.” Woody Allen lampooned American relations with Cuba in “Bananas” by donning a glue-on beard and impersonating a fulminating Fidel Castro. Skewering Muammar el-Qaddafi in “The Dictator,” Sacha Baron Cohen wore a “Love Boat” cap and wandered cluelessly around Manhattan.

headline: New York’s New Rentals: Smaller Apartments, More Perks
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: More than 13,000 new rental apartments are expected to hit the market in New York City this year.
lead_paragraph: Developers of large rental buildings have stuck to a formula over the past several years: Keep apartments small; go big on amenities. Now, with a surge of rentals coming to market, some developers are pushing this formula to the max, tweaking apartment sizes and piling on the perks.

headline: A Small Batch From Life’s Work
abstract: The Russian filmmaker Aleksei German completed only a handful of features in a long career. His wife finished his final movie.
lead_paragraph: Aleksei German, who died last February at the age of 74 while putting the finishing touches on his most ambitious film, the long-awaited “Hard to Be a God,” was regarded by some as Russia’s greatest living director — despite, or perhaps because of, the fact that he managed to complete but a handful of features in a nearly half-century career.

headline: On the Paris Men’s Fall 2015 Runways, an Appetite for Destruction
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Knitting and Knit Goods', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)']
abstract: Designers this week are showing pieces in various states of deterioration: frayed, tattered or haphazardly stitched together.
lead_paragraph: A documentary on Kurt Cobain, produced by his daughter Frances, is set to premiere this weekend at the 2015 Sundance Film Festival as the first fully authorized film on the late grunge legend. Coincidentally, at the men’s fall/winter shows in Paris, tattered knits of the sort Cobain might have worn have surfaced on the runways. Raf Simons, whose collections always reflect on the rough-and-tumble energies of youth and music, presented a series of looks with pieces in various states of deterioration. There were floor-length vests with frayed edges, coats with ragged hems, trenches with their linings spilling out of the sleeves and the hole-ridden sweater vest seen above. Unraveling ribbed sweaters at Damir Doma were a nice contrast to the tailored suits and pleated high-waisted trousers in the collection. And Yohji Yamamoto showed a Frankenstein of a jumper — two different knits ripped and haphazardly sewn together down the front.

headline: In Far-Flung Myanmar, a Land of Contradictions
abstract: In the lush, primal jungles of the northern part of the country, where thoughts turn to orchids, not juntas.
lead_paragraph: It is strange how some of the world’s most retrograde authoritarian states end up being such inadvertent conservators of both their country’s architectural heritage and vast tracts of wild, unspoiled nature. Of course, it was not their leaders’ intention to distinguish themselves as environmentalists or conservationists, but by so abjectly failing to develop viable economic engines, they nonetheless had this providential effect.

headline: Sharing iTunes With the Whole Family
abstract: How to keep a passing interest from following you around on Google Now.

headline: Deciding Whether to Trust Your Senses. Or Not.
abstract: Two later-period Otto Preminger efforts come to disc: the Expressionistic thriller “Bunny Lake Is Missing” (1965) and the psychedelic comedy “Skidoo” (1968).
lead_paragraph: As much as he was a director or producer, Otto Preminger (1905-86) was an impresario. He was a master self-promoter as well, with a fondness for controversial subjects, presold properties and stunt casting — not least his own role as an on-set tyrant.

headline: In Silver’s Backyard, Views of the Case Against Him Are Split
abstract: Sheldon Silver is an outsize presence on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, which he has represented in the State Assembly for nearly 40 years and where he is also a polarizing figure.
lead_paragraph: When not in Albany, Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the New York State Assembly, has spent much of his life within a small pocket of the district that he has represented for almost four decades on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. It is an area bounded by the tenement building he grew up in, the synagogue he attends and the brown-brick co-op complex where he resides today.

headline: Track Changes
keywords: ['Gender', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Women and Girls', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: To protect myself, I found a simple way to hide.
lead_paragraph: I had just turned 20 the winter I passed as a man. I was backpacking through Europe alone. Others I knew at my study-abroad program in England had found travel companions, but I had decided to venture out by myself, armed with an unlimited train pass and a small amount of cash. My strategy was to sleep on the night trains to save money. It was both a brave and a stupid plan. (Mostly stupid.) It certainly didn’t occur to me in advance that I would need to alter my appearance.

headline: An Issue That Feta Can Solve
abstract: Adding feta cheese to a saltwater brine adds punch to a simple roast chicken. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: Brining a chicken before roasting it is an age-old technique. An overnight soak in brine seasons the bird through and through, and locks in moisture for tender flesh.

headline: The Case for Legalized Gambling on Sports
abstract: The more people invest in a market, the more they police it.
lead_paragraph: When the N.B.A. commissioner Adam Silver announced in November that he was in favor of legalizing sports betting in the United States, he shattered decades of genteel sporting tradition. For generations, major professional sports leagues in America have done their best to pretend sports gambling does not exist. But, as Silver wrote in an opinion column in The Times, illegal gambling is already everywhere. Urging legislators to contend with the reality that information technology has made it impossible to confine sports betting to Nevada, Silver argued for taking the market, worth an estimated $400 billion a year, into the realm of the licit.

lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — A top official with the European Central Bank on Friday defended its long-awaited economic stimulus program, saying it would be more effective than critics say because it coincides with other favorable developments, like the plunge in oil prices.

headline: Whose Tomb? Greece Wonders
abstract: A dig at an ancient tomb in Greece and a possible link to Alexander the Great have captured the nation’s imagination.
lead_paragraph: Call it “CSI: Alexander.” For months, the excavations at a large ancient tomb in northern Greece have gripped the country. First, a marble slab wall was unearthed. Then, through announcements and leaks from the Greek Culture Ministry meted out with the pacing of a good mystery series, headless sphinxes and other statues were found. Finally, bones! But whose?

headline: Two Cents, Too Late
keywords: ['Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Beggars', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Customer Relations', 'Philanthropy', 'Lying', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: The sound-financial-advice edition.
lead_paragraph: On public transportation, a young man entered my train car and made an announcement requesting money to pay for medication he needed. Three college-age men teamed up to contribute around $20. After the man left the car, a person sitting next to the trio told them that the man was actually a scammer who had used that pitch on a regular basis for a long time. Upon hearing this, the men looked crestfallen. Did the onlooker have the right to devalue their charity? Shouldn’t he have intervened while the money was being offered? Should he have stayed silent afterward? PATRICK BACHLER, CHICAGO

headline: The New Orleans Variations
abstract: Riffing on the classics — the Sazerac included.
lead_paragraph: Last Thanksgiving, some friends and I gathered in the Holy Cross section of New Orleans’s Lower Ninth Ward. The turkey was in the oven, the oyster dressing was prepped, the cranberry sauce was made with the juice of local satsumas and the green beans were trimmed and ready to be dropped into a pan with toasted pecans and brown butter. There was plenty of beer and wine, but not much to work with in the way of cocktail-making, and a cocktail certainly seemed in order.

headline: Why Is India So Crazy for World Records?
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Records and Achievements', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: An inquiry into the psyche of a mass-handshaking, fingernail-growing, motorcycle-pyramid-building nation.
lead_paragraph: The first time Nikhil Shukla adjudicated a Guinness world record, two million people turned up. Standing on a makeshift dais just before dawn in January 2012, Shukla gazed with bleary, incredulous eyes; he was 28, and he had never seen such a mammoth crowd in his life. Tolls on the national highway from the nearest city, Rajkot, had been suspended to accommodate the traffic, and Shukla had to trudge 20 minutes from his V.I.P. parking spot, squeezing through dense thickets of bodies, to approach the stage. The throng that gathered in this patch of dusty farmland in western India to watch the event came from villages and towns across the district. They had responded to a call from a Gujarati community organization that, with a vague aim of promoting public harmony, wanted people to pair off and shake hands with one another, setting a world record for the most simultaneous handshakes.

headline: Sundance 2015: ‘The Bronze’ Does Not Exactly Wow on Opening Night
abstract: In the same spot that “Whiplash” electrified last year, the first-night film is received tepidly.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah – John Cooper, Sundance’s director, was trying to introduce “The Bronze,” this year’s big opening-night feature, but members of the Eccles Theater audience were not done chatting. He finally stopped to shush them. But this crowd was not in a cooperative mood – right down to the reception of the film.

headline: Student Contest Winners | The 2014 Year in Rap
abstract: Announcing six winners and six runners-up in our December 2014 contest. Thank you teachers and students!
lead_paragraph: In December, we invited students to write raps about the very busy news year that was 2014, and we weren’t at all surprised when nearly every entry mentioned Ferguson, Eric Garner, Tamir Rice or the related protests that roiled the nation from August on. Not only did these events hit close to home for many teenagers, but the hip-hop community at large has been engaged from the very beginning.
