lead_paragraph: Pancakes for breakfast, lunch or dinner? By all means, but make mine savory, please. To me, sweet pancakes are dessert.

headline: 1940: Paderewski Vows Deliverance
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Ignace Jan Paderewski addressed the Polish National Council in 1940.
lead_paragraph: In words as resonant as the notes of Chopin’s “Polonaise Militaire,” which he has played thousands of times for encore-demanding audiences the world over, Ignace Jan Paderewski, seventy nine year old pianist-patriot, stood before his people yesterday at the Polish National Council and pledged the deliverance of his 35,000,000 countrymen. Although Paderewski was speaking not as a musician but as a Pole in the service of his nation, and although the voice of an aged man still weak from illness could not develop those crescendos that have never failed to thrill listeners as his long delicate fingers hit the keyboard, the nobility of his ideas and the dramatic turn of his phrases made the speech a series of forensic fortissimos. In the awareness that he might not live to see again the state of which he had the honor to be the first President, Paderewski stamped this discourse as the last will and testament to Poland of one of its servants. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 24, 1940

headline: Leaks and Ad-Libs: How to Cover the State of the Union Address
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Michael Shear, a White House correspondent, describes what it is like to cover the State of the Union address.
lead_paragraph: This week, reporters and editors in The Times’s Washington and New York offices prepared for President Obama’s State of the Union address, knowing that they would write, and rewrite, articles before, during and after the speech, all on tight deadlines.

headline: 1965: Smoking ‘Countess’ Convicted
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A “countess” was convicted in an assassination plot in 1965.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A pipe-smoking ‘‘countess,’’ who  was once an interpreter on Gen. Dwight  D. Eisenhower’s civilian staff, was sentenced to 18 years’ imprisonment for  plotting to assassinate President de  Gaulle. The State Security Court found  Mrs. Paule de Roussoulet, 56, who adopted the title ‘‘Countess of Liffiac,’’ guilty  of planning to shoot Gen. de Gaulle last  Feb. 15 when he visited the École Militaire here. Two other defendants were  also convicted. A civilian Jean Bichon,  51, was given 20 years and Capt. Robert  Poinard, 38, was sentenced to 15 years.  Security police uncovered the plot about  two weeks before it was to take place.  Bichon allegedly was the ringleader of  the group. Poinard and Mrs. de Roussoulet, a teacher of English at the École  Militaire, were accused of encouraging  the intended killers and planning to facilitate their entry to the school. Gen. de  Gaulle was to have been shot by a high- powered rifle equipped with a telescopic  sight as he crossed the École courtyard. —New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 24, 1965

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: PLATO AT THE GOOGLEPLEX: Why Philosophy Won’t Go Away,  by Rebecca Newberger Goldstein. (Vintage, $16.95.) Goldstein revives the art of the dialogue, bringing the Greek philosopher to life in 21st-­century America and sending him on a multi­city book tour. As he probes some of the deepest questions confronting us — from sexuality and child-rearing to morality and the meaning of life — “we hear authentic Platonic arguments brought nicely up to date,” Anthony Gottlieb wrote here.

headline: For Auschwitz Museum, a Time of Great Change
abstract: As the Auschwitz-Birkenau State Museum observes the 70th anniversary of the liberation of the concentration camps, it is focusing on new generations of visitors.
lead_paragraph: OSWIECIM, Poland — For what is likely to be the last time, a large number of the survivors of the Nazi concentration camps at Auschwitz will gather next week under an expansive tent, surrounded by royalty and heads of state, to commemorate the 70th anniversary of the liberation of those held there at the end of World War II.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: LEAVING BEFORE THE RAINS COME,  by Alexandra Fuller. (Penguin Press, $26.95.) Fuller, who described her idiosyncratic African childhood in “Don’t Let’s Go to the Dogs Tonight,” here offers an account of the collapse of her long marriage.

headline: Inequality as a Religious Issue: A Conversation With the Archbishop of Canterbury
abstract: The Most Rev. Justin Welby speaks about income inequality, the recent terrorist attacks in Paris, divisions in the Church of England and Pope Francis.
lead_paragraph: In the two years since the Most Rev. Justin Welby was installed as archbishop of Canterbury, he has traveled the world to talk with other church leaders, and his assessment of those visits has been, in many ways, grim.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Paula Hawkins, whose thriller “The Girl on the Train” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 2, previously wrote romantic comedies under a pseudonym.
lead_paragraph: Starting Over: When is a debut not a debut? When a writer changes names and genres, for one thing — as did the British author Paula Hawkins, whose “debut thriller,” “The Girl on the Train,” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 2. To judge from the Q. and A. at her publisher’s website, you’d never know that Hawkins, a financial journalist for 15 years, previously wrote romantic comedies under a pseudonym. “That was women’s fiction, I suppose,” Hawkins told NPR in a recent interview. “Much more lighthearted, not so much killing. . . . I did enjoy writing them, but they kept getting darker and darker. And once I started writing this book I knew this was what I was supposed to be doing. It just felt completely right for me. This sounds awful, but I’m not, you know, a joyful, romantic person. Well, I can be, but I’ve got a proper dark side and I enjoy indulging it.” She’s not kidding: “The Girl on the Train” is about an alcoholic commuter, fired from her job, who spins an obsessive fantasy about a couple along her train route and who may know something about the wife’s disappearance. (Comparisons to “Gone Girl” are not misplaced.) I had no luck unearthing Hawkins’s earlier pseudonym, but I did find a financial guide she published under her own name in Britain, “The Money Goddess,” which invents a group of “Sex and the City"-like friends as it dispenses advice about shopping for mortgages or planning for retirement. It’s the “Bridget Jones of finance,” according to one Amazon customer, who awarded it four out of five stars.

headline: Letters: David Bezmozgis Replies
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Rachel Cusk’s “Outline,” Richard Bernstein’s “China 1945” and more.
lead_paragraph: David Bezmozgis Replies

headline: A Solo Spotlight for a Powerful Voice
abstract: Rhiannon Giddens, celebrated on the folk circuit as the leader of the Carolina Chocolate Drops, releases a solo album that steps beyond the tradition of African-American string bands.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — At the Soundcheck rehearsal studio complex in Nashville, 18-wheeler trucks ready to haul equipment for country stars’ arena tours were backed up to loading bays. It’s probably a safe bet that on a recent Sunday afternoon, only Studio D held a band playing a replica of an 1858 fretless minstrel banjo and two sets of bones, the hand-held percussion instrument, clattering away in a medley of tunes at least 150 years old.

headline: King Abdullah Mourned by Saudis
abstract: Saudi Arabia’s King Salman led prayers for King Abdullah in Riyadh ahead of his burial Friday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia’s King Salman led prayers for King Abdullah in Riyadh ahead of his burial Friday afternoon.

headline: Reading the Tea Leaves: More Fund-Raisers by Clinton Allies
abstract: When will Hillary Clinton announce her long-awaited presidential campaign? One guess can be found in a new round of fund-raisers being organized by Ready for Hillary, the super PAC founded to organize grassroots supporters and potential donors for a potential Clinton campaign.
lead_paragraph: When will Hillary Rodham Clinton announce her long-awaited presidential campaign? One guess can be found in a new round of fund-raisers being organized by Ready for Hillary, the “super PAC” founded to organize grass-roots supporters and potential donors for a Clinton campaign.

headline: The View from Inside the Stroller
abstract: Diego Acosta López wanted to see what it was like when his son, Ignacio — just shy of 2 — visited New York City for the first time.
lead_paragraph: Diego Acosta López wanted to see what it was like when his son, Ignacio — just shy of 2 — visited New York City for the first time. Now, it wasn’t exactly a smart idea to let the toddler handle his big-boy DLSR. So he figured out the next best thing: mounting a GoPro camera to the boy’s stroller right behind his head, set it to take a picture every 10 seconds and go zipping around town.

headline: Diverse Israeli Arab Political Factions Join Forces to Keep Place in Parliament
abstract: Facing an electoral threshold that threatens to bar small parties from Parliament, the factions are forming a single ticket for the March elections.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Facing an increased electoral threshold that threatens to bar small parties from Parliament, Israel’s Arab political factions announced on Friday the formation of a single ticket for the March elections.

headline: The League, a Dating App for Would-Be Power Couples
abstract: A new dating app comes across as a boutique for mate-shopping, offering users only five potential matches a day.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — On a Saturday night just before the end of the year, single and single-ish professionals gathered for the Guardsmen Tree Lot Party, an annual fund-raiser for underprivileged children.

headline: Sundance 2015: A Lesson or Two From Sundance 2014
abstract: “Song One” arrived at last year’s festival amid a great deal of interest; it left without a buyer and is only now being released.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah – Every year, dozens of directors trek to this ski outpost in the mountains outside Salt Lake City hoping that a distributor will see promise in their film and make a deal to pump it out to the world. But the dream can get dicey in a hurry. Consider “Song One.”

headline: Clinton Opponents Hone New Barbs and Attacks as 2016 Campaign Nears
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance', 'Political Action Committees']
abstract: Once called a ’60s feminist, Hillary Rodham Clinton is now more often portrayed by her opponents as an out-of-touch elitist.
lead_paragraph: First, she was called the bra-burning feminist with a degree from Wellesley. Then, she was the aggressively political spouse from Arkansas who plotted behind closed doors. Today, she is the millionaire elitist who socializes in New York City and the Hamptons.

headline: War Is Exploding Anew in Ukraine; Rebels Vow More
abstract: Evidence is increasing that Russian troops and Russian equipment have been pouring into eastern Ukraine again.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Unexpectedly, at the height of the Ukrainian winter, war has exploded anew on a half-dozen battered fronts across eastern Ukraine, accompanied by increasing evidence that Russian troops and Russian equipment have been pouring into the region again.

headline: ‘The Wolfpack’ Tells of One New York Apartment With Seven Children Locked Inside
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: This documentary focuses on seven siblings who were rarely allowed outside their Lower East Side apartment, and spent years watching movies.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — It’s quite a tale: Seven children, all with waist-length hair, are raised on welfare in a messy four-bedroom apartment on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. And they are almost never allowed to leave the house. For years.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Jill Leovy’s ‘Ghettoside’
abstract: This week, Jill Leovy discusses “Ghettoside”; Patton Oswalt talks about his memoir “Silver Screen Fiend”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Anita Shapira discusses “Ben-Gurion: Father of Modern Israel”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Jill Leovy discusses “Ghettoside”; Patton Oswalt talks about his memoir “Silver Screen Fiend”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Anita Shapira discusses “Ben-Gurion: Father of Modern Israel”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Theaster Gates, Artes Mundi Recipient, to Share Prize money
abstract: The Chicago-based artist accepted the $60,000 prize in Wales, and announced that he would share the winnings with the nine other nominees.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Chicago-based artist Theaster Gates accepted the 40,000-pound Artes Mundi prize on Thursday night in Cardiff, Wales, offering up an expletive as he announced that he would share the winnings with the nine other nominees.

headline: Expedia Buys Travelocity for $280 Million in Cash
abstract: The acquisition will furnish Expedia — which already owns Hotels.com, Hotwire and CarRentals.com — another well-known name in the travel industry.
lead_paragraph: Expedia agreed on Friday to buy its fellow travel booking site Travelocity for $280 million in cash, nearly two years after the two forged a marketing and technology partnership.

headline: At the Fulcrum of Preventing Another Financial Crisis
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Mark Carney, the governor of the Bank of England, says the measures regulators have taken to strengthen the banking system will protect the global economy, but some skeptics remain.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — Perhaps more than any other financial figure, Mark Carney has the job of ensuring that the world’s largest banks are no longer a great danger to the economies in which they operate.

headline: Consumer Protection for Mortgage Seekers
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has introduced online tools to help in finding mortgages after a survey showed most borrowers don’t shop around.
lead_paragraph: Citing survey results showing that almost half of borrowers fail to shop around for a mortgage lender, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau wants to empower consumers to be more discerning when selecting a home loan.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Jill Leovy’s ‘Ghettoside’
abstract: This week, Jill Leovy, Patton Oswalt and Anita Shapira.
lead_paragraph: This week, Jill Leovy, Patton Oswalt and Anita Shapira.

headline: A Police Chief Turned Pastor, Working to Heal the Nation’s Racial Rifts
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Apologies', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Episcopal Church', 'Ministers (Protestant)', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: The Rev. David Couper, a former police chief turned Episcopal minister, believes an apology can close the gap between white police officers and the black communities they serve.
lead_paragraph: NORTH LAKE, Wis. — In the days leading up to Christmas, the aging pastor of a small Episcopal church set amid the glacial hills here began to write a parable. It came neither from Scripture nor from yuletide tradition, but rather from the priest’s very different earlier life.

headline: Bank of England Governor Backs E.C.B. Strategy
abstract: Mark Carney said he supported the European Central Bank’s decision to buy bonds to stimulate the European economy. At home, he faces a different situation.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — Mark Carney, the governor of the Bank of England, on Friday firmly backed the European Central Bank’s decision to buy bonds to stimulate the stagnant European economy.

headline: ‘If I Fall, if I Die,’ by Michael Christie
abstract: A debut novel about family, phobias and the high-flying freedoms of skateboarding.
lead_paragraph: The skateboard, that preferred mode of transportation for the alienated and disaffected — and also able to “black out the rest of the world,” as Tony Hawk put it in his 2000 autobiography, “Hawk. Occupation: Skateboarder” — appears midway through Michael Christie’s novel of a troubled childhood, “If I Fall, if I Die.” It’s a transformative object, this skateboard, redemptive and cathartic, and it helps the 11-year-old hero, Will Cardiel, convey himself, literally and figuratively, from what has been up to then a life of privation with his single mother.

headline: ‘The Forgotten Depression,’ by James Grant
abstract: Looking at the depression of 1921.
lead_paragraph: When the next big economic disaster hits, Washington will almost certainly choose to do something: cut taxes, increase spending, lower interest rates. There is another option, of course: do nothing. No fiscal or monetary stimulus. Let the fire burn the rot of excess from the system. From the ashes, goes this theory, a healthier, more balanced economy will emerge.

headline: Restoring a Park Slope Wreck
abstract: A building at the heart of Park Slope, Brooklyn, that had decayed in recent years is being restored and converted into spacious condominium apartments.
lead_paragraph: A building at the heart of Park Slope, Brooklyn, that had fallen into disrepair in recent years is being restored and converted into spacious condominium apartments.

headline: The Romance of Wine
abstract: Great wine by its nature is mysterious, unpredictable and perhaps ultimately unknowable.
lead_paragraph: I am a romantic about wine. I don’t mind saying it, even though some people may consider that soft and unrealistic, lacking the sort of rigor necessary to avoid being manipulated by fairy tales and marketers.

headline: The ‘Unofficial Start’ of the Presidential Campaign
abstract: Donors are sorting out candidates.
lead_paragraph: This is the period when overpaid political consultants talk about the “unofficial start” of the presidential campaign – a notion as meaningless as the “official start.” Candidates take advantage of this period to launch “exploratory committees” that allow them to raise money without the annoyance of disclosing donors, and to soak up news coverage.

headline: Kris Van Assch: Fall 2015 Menswear
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Finding a Nanny Who Fits With Your Family
abstract: One of the common mistakes made by those looking for in-home child care: failing to carefully consider the type of nanny who will best meet their needs.
lead_paragraph: IF you’re lucky enough to have a nanny like the one Shachar Scott has, one who was with her at the hospital when her twins were born more than three years ago, does everything she wants, keeps her informed when she travels and gets along brilliantly with the family, stop reading now.

headline: E.C.B.’s Bazooka Is a Water Pistol for Emerging Markets
abstract: Fading growth and falling prices will overwhelm the stimulus from central banks, says Andy Mukherjee of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: The European Central Bank has fired its bazooka. For emerging markets, it’s little more than a water pistol.

headline: ‘Marissa Mayer and the Fight to Save Yahoo!,’ by Nicholas Carlson
abstract: In 2012, Marissa Mayer was tasked with reversing the fortunes of a struggling Internet pioneer.
lead_paragraph: One day in 2012, Marissa Mayer was whirling around Yahoo’s office in Sunnyvale, Calif., directing a redesign of the home page and the company’s uncool but still widely used email application. The next, she was the proud mother of her first child, who was nicknamed BBBB in the hospital, for Big Baby Boy Bogue (her husband’s last name). This would hardly be considered extraordinary if it weren’t for the fact that she had recently been named the company’s C.E.O. Female chief executives typically live in glass boxes where every move they make is held up for intense public scrutiny, and most get themselves there through brutal amounts of work and by avoiding anything that draws attention to the fact that they’re women. Yet right after starting her job running a troubled $30 billion technology giant, Mayer announced that she would be taking a maternity leave, albeit a stunningly short one. (She took two weeks.) The audacity of the move — accepting a top executive job knowing that she was five months pregnant and then taking so little time off — prompted an Internet outcry (“The Pregnant C.E.O.: Should You Hate Marissa Mayer?” Forbes asked in one representative example), in which even progressives grumbled about the privilege involved, including Mayer’s household staff and in-office nursery. And so it was that her upsetting of the women’s­-issues industrial complex became all that most people know about Mayer. Yet there is much more to the picture.

headline: Doulas, Who Usher in New Life, Find Mission in Support for the Dying
abstract: Services vary from volunteers who simply make visits, to those who charge for helping with arrangements like caregivers or organizing papers.
lead_paragraph: MARY HILBURN spent the last three years watching her partner of 17 years, Jo Allison Bennett, die of brain cancer. Their families weren’t supportive, and many of their friends found the experience too emotionally wrenching to become very involved.

headline: Nets’ Mirza Teletovic Is Sidelined for Season by Blood Clots
abstract: Teletovic, a forward, is in a Los Angeles hospital with blood clots in his lungs and will miss the rest of the season, the Nets said Friday.
lead_paragraph: Mirza Teletovic of the Nets will miss the rest of the season after being diagnosed with bilateral pulmonary embolus, a formation of blood clots in the lungs.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Jill Leovy’s ‘Ghettoside’
abstract: Ms. Leovy discusses “Ghettoside,” Patton Oswalt talks about his new memoir and Anita Shapira discusses “Ben-Gurion: Father of Modern Israel.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Jennifer Gonnerman reviews Jill Leovy’s “Ghettoside: A True Story of Murder in America.” Ms. Gonnerman writes:

headline: What I Love | Dr. Patricia Wexler
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The dermatologist Patricia Wexler and her husband, Dr. Eugene Wexler, retreat to their Upper East Side apartment.
lead_paragraph: The dermatologist Patricia Wexler and her husband, Dr. Eugene Wexler, retreat to their Upper East Side apartment.

headline: Sometimes Golden Oldies Means the Band, Not the Music
abstract: Baby boomers are often picking up an instrument they put down decades ago, and some are starting a new career as their main one is coming to an end.
lead_paragraph: A 4-YEAR-OLD GIRL twirled and jumped in what is normally a parking lot to the music of Monko, telling her mother it was her favorite band.

headline: 700,000 Homeowners Could Still Benefit From U.S. HARP Refinancing
abstract: People with little or no equity in their homes could be helped by the Home Affordable Refinance Program, which is scheduled to end this year.
lead_paragraph: ALTHOUGH the housing market is increasingly on the mend, hundreds of thousands of homeowners still have little or no equity in their homes and could benefit from a federal mortgage refinancing program that is scheduled to end this year.

headline: Her Prescription for Home: Color
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: A flood gave Dr. Patricia Wexler the opportunity to redecorate her New York apartment.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Patricia Wexler and her husband, Eugene, were at their house in the Hamptons on a July weekend a few years ago when the call came from the superintendent of their Upper East Side condominium: You’ve got to get home immediately.

headline: Childless, With Regret and Advice: Don’t Wait for the Perfect Picture
abstract: I didn’t want to become my mother, so I actively avoided becoming a mother at all until it was too late.
lead_paragraph: Growing up, I rebelled against my beautiful redheaded mother, a domestic goddess. A feisty orphan from the Lower East Side, she had revered the four older siblings who took care of her. She married my father at 19, planning to start her own big family. After working as a secretary and office manager to put him through medical school in the Midwest, she became a proud stay-at-home mom. She had me at 27, then my carrot-top brothers arrived, 17 months apart (called “Yiddish twins”), followed by a third boy. As the oldest and only girl, I was “mommy’s little helper,” which I resented. She was always cooking, feeding, cleaning. I felt born in the wrong role, resolved to escape taking care of babies.

headline: The Democratic Convention: When? July 2016. Where? T.B.D.
abstract: The Democrats don’t have a city yet, but they now have a date for their nominating convention.
lead_paragraph: The Democrats don’t have a city yet, but they now have a date for their nominating convention.

headline: Privilege Is a Privilege, and a Responsibility
abstract: Tony Schwartz, in the Life@Work column, asks the wealthiest: Are you comfortable having more than you will ever spend, while those around you barely earn what they need to survive?
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, I walked into a local delicatessen to get a sandwich for lunch. The man behind the counter looked to be in his early 30s, and we struck up a conversation. I asked how he was feeling about the upcoming year, and the one that just passed. It’s amazing what people will tell you if they sense you are genuinely interested.

headline: ‘Where the Dead Pause, and the Japanese Say Goodbye,’ by Marie Mutsuki Mockett
abstract: Mourning her father’s death, the author undertakes a pilgrimage to Japan’s great Buddhist temples.
lead_paragraph: Among the many shocking things about tsunamis — along with their suddenness, violence and indiscriminate destruction of life and community — is how little there is to say about them. Man-made catastrophes, like wars or nuclear accidents, provide infinite opportunities for blame, recrimination and lessons learned. But natural disasters have no politics. One can quibble about the height of sea walls, the promptness of warnings and the quality of aid given to survivors. But such events have always occurred in countries like Japan, and always will. When the wave has receded, the dead have been counted and the slow work of recovery has begun, the pundits sheepishly quit the field and abandon it to the theologians, the spiritualists and the priests.

headline: ‘Once Upon a Time,’ by Marina Warner
abstract: Marina Warner explores the history and enduring power of fairy tales.
lead_paragraph: In her new and vigorous book on fairy tales, “Once Upon a Time,” the scholar Marina Warner explains a crucial stage of story pollination. Discussing early versions of “Puss in Boots” and “Rapunzel,” written by the Italians Straparola and Basile, she notes,“It’s no accident that these two authors created their story cycles in great seaports, where cultures, languages and ideas — and above all travelers — met one another.”

headline: ‘There Was and There Was Not,’ by Meline Toumani
abstract: An Armenian-American moves to Turkey to investigate a history of tense relations.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, Meline Toumani, an Armenian-American, went to live in Turkey — the country that, in its former incarnation as the Ottoman Empire, killed more than one million Armenians beginning in 1915, in mass deportations most historians regard as genocide. Fellow Armenians considered her decision perverse, not least because she, like them, had imbibed stories of Turkish plunder and murder along with her mother’s milk. But Toumani is an idealistic, somewhat contrary soul. Although in no doubt of Turkish culpability, she was convinced of the need for reconciliation on a basic, human level.

headline: SkyMall’s Parent Files for Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: The in-flight catalog’s parent, Xhibit, attributed some of its troubles to changes in in-flight entertainment and retail competition.
lead_paragraph: The parent of the in-flight shopping magazine SkyMall said on Friday that it had filed for bankruptcy protection, citing in-flight Wi-Fi access as one of the factors luring shoppers away from its quirky catalog of travel products, pet toys and garden gnomes.

headline: ‘Sophia: Princess, Suffragette, Revolutionary,’ by Anita Anand
abstract: The life of a suffragist daughter of an exiled maharajah.
lead_paragraph: Part of a biographer’s job is to rescue forgotten figures, and in “Sophia: Princess, Suffragette, Revolutionary” Anita Anand has salvaged an extraordinary one. Sophia Duleep Singh was a Punjabi princess and Queen Victoria’s goddaughter, a bucktoothed “docile little thing” who went on to become a celebrated London fashion plate and then a steely suffragist.

headline: ‘The Match Girl and the Heiress,’ by Seth Koven
abstract: A story of activists and unlikely soulmates in Victorian London.
lead_paragraph: Faith-based social policies have gotten a bad name lately, but not long ago they formed the core of many admirable progressive movements. Some late Victorian Christians arguably stood between London’s poorest and the Dickensian horrors suffered by the likes of Oliver Twist.

headline: ‘When Books Went to War,’ by Molly Guptill Manning
abstract: In World War II, books helped lift the spirits of the troops.
lead_paragraph: “From the Airborne Infantry of the front lines to the chair-borne Finance Corps of the rear,” an American soldier observed from an English hospital in the midst of World War II, “you can find the boys reading as they never have before.” He was referring to the ubiquitous presence, among troops stationed abroad, of Armed Services Editions, or A.S.E.s: disposable pocket-size paperback reprints of a wide range of current and classic titles paid for by the United States government and produced by a consortium of the nation’s publishers. The editions, as the soldier’s remark suggests, met the demand for print among American military personnel overseas while opening up possibilities for greater consumption of books in the postwar period.

headline: Pigalle’s Night at the Opéra
abstract: The gilt surroundings of the streetwear label’s show reflected its evolution into more tailored pieces and outerwear.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For Pigalle, the streetwear label born and raised in the not-fully-gentrified neighborhood that inspired its name, the Beaux-Arts splendor of the Palais Garnier, traditional home of the Paris Opéra, seems a world apart — although, as the fan of the label and fellow Pigalle resident Caroline de Maigret pointed out, they both are technically in the 9th Arrondissement.

headline: See Baja on a Ship With a Past
abstract: AdventureSmith Explorations is offering a Baja Peninsula cruise on a ship that launched in 1924.
lead_paragraph: The small-ship cruise company AdventureSmith Explorations has added a historic yacht to its inventory of ships exploring the Baja Peninsula.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Black Sea,’ ‘Cake’ and ‘Mommy’
abstract: Times critics review “Black Sea,” “Cake” and “Mommy.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Black Sea,” “Cake” and “Mommy.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Somebody’s Watching Us
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Today, Richard Hofstadter, who wrote “The Paranoid Style in American Politics,” might target not just right-wing radio hosts but also the aggrieved left.
lead_paragraph: About fifty years ago, the Pulitzer Prize-winning historian Richard Hofstadter exposed a dark recess of the American psyche with an essay in Harper’s Magazine, “The Paranoid Style in American Politics.” Hofstadter was writing about the peculiar tendency of the political right to indulge in paranoid theories, but he was careful to stipulate that the left could just as easily be infected. “American politics has often been an arena for angry minds,” he wrote.

headline: Casey Walker’s ‘Last Days in Shanghai’
abstract: In this first novel, a young congressional aide navigates a minefield of graft and corruption in present-day China.
lead_paragraph: In the lobby of an apartment building in the Chinese factory city of Dongguan, I once saw this sign: “for the peace of residents, renovation will stop on jan. 1. it will resume on jan. 2.”

headline: ‘Offcomer,’ by Jo Baker
abstract: The protagonist of Jo Baker’s first novel is an Oxford graduate working at a Belfast pub.
lead_paragraph: “Offcomer” is the Lancashire word for an outsider, a person from somewhere else who will never quite fit in. It’s the perfect term for the underachieving and dispirited Claire Thomas, the central character in Jo Baker’s first novel — published only last month in the United States, 12 years after it appeared in Britain and 11 years before the spectacular success of Baker’s fifth novel, “Longbourn,” in 2013.

headline: ‘Van Gogh,’ by Julian Bell
abstract: Julian Bell looks at van Gogh’s brief, explosively creative life.
lead_paragraph: As a fledgling artist, Vincent van Gogh hired a carpenter to build a perspective frame: a wire-grid window. He used it to draw the Dutch countryside, his eyes darting between his pencil and the views through the frame. A few years later, van Gogh suffered a spate of psychiatric crises that sent him to an asylum in Saint Rémy, France. There his bedroom’s barred window doubled as a new perspective frame, albeit one with only verticals, through which he sketched the wheat field below.

headline: ‘The Season of Migration,’ by Nellie Hermann
abstract: A novel of van Gogh’s anguished time in Belgium.
lead_paragraph: Poor van Gogh. Impossibly tenderhearted yet forbiddingly irascible. Push-pulled by scorching genius and helpless servitude to his own morality. Before becoming a painter, he put in a disastrous stint at an evangelical school, his failure there due in part to his obstinacy. As one of his classmates put it, “he did not know what submission was.” But to the clarity and purity of his vision he submitted in full, to the point of madness, to the point of utter self-abnegation.

headline: Get Your Freekeh On
abstract: Chefs are coming up with all sorts of inspiring ideas for grains.
lead_paragraph: Chefs are coming up with all sorts of inspiring ideas for grains, and I was lucky enough to learn about some of them at last November’s Whole Grains: Breaking Barriers conference organized in Boston by Oldways and the Whole Grains Counsel. I moderated a panel of three local chefs: Ana Sortun of Oleana and Sarma, Jason Bond of Bondir, and Barry Maiden of Hungry Mother, as well as Liz l’Etoile of Four Stars Farms, a small Massachusetts farm that is producing and milling wheat, corn, rye, barley and hops. Boston area chefs are delighted that they can now get local grains, milled only days before delivery.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Junya Watanabe Fall/Winter 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Maison Margiela Fall/Winter 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Junya Watanabe Fall/Winter 2015
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: Baldfaced Hornet: A Selfless Builder That Stings
abstract: The baldfaced hornet (Dolichovespula maculata) is a valuable predator of flies, caterpillars and other crop pests. It is also a valuable pollinator.
lead_paragraph: Winter is not generally the time of year to search for insects, but then the baldfaced hornet is not an insect most are excited to see. Winter is simply the time of year when this wasp’s handiwork is most safely admired.

headline: New Saudi King and U.S. Face Crucial Point in the Relationship
abstract: Saudi Arabia’s new king, Salman, inherits both the policies put in place by the more assertive brother he is succeeding and the conflicts that in recent years have characterized relations with Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Almost a decade ago, an Arab diplomat famously likened the relationship between the United States and Saudi Arabia to a Catholic marriage “where you can have no divorce.”

headline: Ben Metcalf’s ‘Against the Country’
abstract: Ben Metcalf’s novel, set in Virginia, takes issue with the American idealization of the back-to-the-land life.
lead_paragraph: A remarkable thing about the novel is that it can incorporate almost anything — essays, short stories, mock memoirs, screenplays, emails — and remain a novel. This elasticity is also a sign that unlike, say, the epic or the ode, the novel is a living, evolving form. But if its outer limits are virtually nonexistent, the minimum requirement is generally that there be a narrator telling us something. In this way, any manner of book can find a way to justify calling itself a novel. But the label should not be worn lightly, since it invites scrutiny of the highest and most exacting kind.

headline: Esther Freud’s ‘Mr. Mac and Me’
abstract: In Esther Freud’s novel, an artistic boy befriends the architect Charles Rennie Mackintosh in 1914.
lead_paragraph: “See everything. Hear everything. Say nothing,” reads a poster outside the town hall in Esther Freud’s evocative eighth novel, “Mr. Mac and Me.” It’s 1914, at the dawn of World War I, and the coastal Suffolk village of Walberswick is on high alert, its citizens patrolling the beaches and casting suspicious glances at newcomers, since anyone might be a spy. Our guide through this world is Thomas Maggs, age 13 when the book begins. The son of a drunk who runs the local pub, Thomas loves to draw (mostly ships) and dreams of being a sailor, though a pronounced limp, an overprotective mother and a controlling father conspire to keep him close to home.

headline: British History
abstract: New books about the Plantagenets and the Tudors, Thomas Cromwell and more.
lead_paragraph: THE GREATEST KNIGHT  The Remarkable Life of William Marshal, the Power Behind Five English Thrones  By Thomas Asbridge  Ecco/HarperCollins, $27.99.

headline: Immersive History
abstract: David Kynaston’s method of recapturing Britain’s past includes quoting from the diaries and letters of average citizens.
lead_paragraph: David Kynaston’s “Modernity Britain,” reviewed this week by Richard Aldous, is the third volume of a planned series covering British history from 1945 to 1979.

headline: ‘Modernity Britain: 1957-1962,’ by David Kynaston
abstract: David Kynaston’s multivolume history of postwar Britain continues in this tapestry of political, socioeconomic and cultural change.
lead_paragraph: On May 25, 1962, two decades after the original medieval building had been bombed by the Germans, the new Coventry Cathedral was consecrated. Alas, the service was a fiasco. Queen Elizabeth’s yellow outfit clashed with the canary-hued cope worn by the bishop of Coventry. The city’s lord mayor, whether overawed or overheated, fainted in a cacophony of metal regalia and had to be revived by the bishop of Birmingham. An unfortunate sidesman dropped the overflowing collection plate right in front of Her Majesty. Even the building, designed by Sir Basil Spence, failed for some to live up to the occasion: “The worst setback to English church architecture for a very long time,” the ultramodernist critic Reyner Banham sniffed.

headline: Leaders in Davos Urge Quick Action to Alter the Effects of Climate Change
abstract: Business and political leaders called on governments to set clear goals so companies are prompted to act before the problems of climate change become irreversible.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland – On the heels of data showing that last year was the hottest on earth since record keeping began, business leaders, politicians and scientists at the World Economic Forum redoubled their calls to combat climate change.

headline: In Rain and Snow, It’s Clear That Patriots Are a Good Bet
abstract: Covers, the betting website, found the Patriots beat the spread 80 percent of the time in wet weather over the past 12 seasons compared with 56 percent in dry conditions.
lead_paragraph: Over the past 12 seasons, the New England Patriots have played so well in wet conditions that their margin of victory in those games has exceeded the betting spread — set by a global market that tries to take all known advantages into account — 80 percent of the time, according to an analysis by Covers, a sports betting information website.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Raise Fund to Buy Energy Sector Debt
abstract: The private equity giant, seeking to capitalize on the recent collapse in oil prices, is aiming to raise money on an unusually compressed timeline, according to a confidential email.
lead_paragraph: Apollo Global Management is sprinting to raise a new fund to buy the debt of troubled energy companies, as the private equity giant seeks to capitalize on the recent collapse in oil prices.

headline: Verbatim: A White House Jab at Tom Brady
abstract: The White House on the Patriots scandal.
lead_paragraph: — Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, poking fun at Tom Brady’s performance at a news conference about the use of deflated footballs in the A.F.C. championship game.

headline: Historic Charleston Makes Room for New Construction
abstract: Long accustomed to basing its reputation on the grandeur of its old buildings, the city now finds it almost impossible to agree on how to build any new ones.
lead_paragraph: Long accustomed to basing its reputation on the grandeur of its old buildings, the city now finds it almost impossible to agree on how to build any new ones.

headline: In Stately Old Charleston, the New Buildings on the Block Are Struggling to Fit In
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Accustomed to basing its identity on its grand old buildings, the South Carolina city now finds it almost impossible to agree on how to build new ones as its economy and its population grow.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The elegant buildings from different eras strut across Charleston’s downtown neighborhoods like notes on a major scale: the Gothic churches, the Greek Revival storefronts, the homes in vivid pastels exuding Queen Anne grace, Georgian symmetry and Italianate grandeur.

headline: $100.4 Million Sale at One57
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: The duplex penthouse shattered the record for the highest price ever paid for a single residence in New York City and was the most expensive sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A duplex penthouse at the pinnacle of One57, the vitreous skyscraper with nonpareil vistas of Central Park, the Hudson and East Rivers and almost every landmark on the horizon, sold for $100,471,452.77 to a mystery buyer, shattering the record for the highest price ever paid for a single residence in New York City, and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Goldman Executive Says Falling Oil Prices Will Help Firm’s Business
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Goldman Sachs has calculated that falling oil prices will push well over a trillion dollars into other industries around the world, said Gary Cohn, the investment bank’s president and chief operating officer.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland – The sudden plunge in oil prices has been a boon for consumers, and could be a boon for Goldman Sachs, too, according to Gary D. Cohn, the investment bank’s president and chief operating officer.

headline: Footage Shows Damage at Donetsk Airport
abstract: Footage produced by “Army SOS,” a group linked to the Ukrainian army, apparently shot on Jan.15, shows aerial views of the damage to Donetsk airport after recent fighting.
lead_paragraph: Footage produced by “Army SOS,” a group linked to the Ukrainian army, apparently shot on Jan.15, shows aerial views of the damage to Donetsk airport after recent fighting.

abstract: Plus, Rick Owens’s ballsy runway move, Obama’s right to shoes and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Stuff We Liked: End of an Era for Baby Boomers
abstract: A weekly roundup of web gems, including a demographic shift and a look at where the president eats.
lead_paragraph: Here are a few things we found elsewhere this week that tickled us.

headline: Fort Hood Could Not Have Foreseen 2014 Gun Attack, Army Says
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Fort Hood Shooting (2014)']
abstract: Officials at the base in central Texas could not have predicted a shooting rampage last year in part because the troubled soldier behind the attack gave no clear warning that he posed a threat, according to an Army report.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Officials at the Fort Hood Army base in central Texas could not have prevented a shooting rampage last year in part because the troubled soldier behind the attack gave no clear warning that he posed a threat, according to an Army report released Friday.

headline: ‘Degenerate Art’ to Koons’s ‘Made and Heaven’ and Much in Between
abstract: The art world has always operated on the herd instinct. But over the years it has morphed into a visible playpen of power and privilege.
lead_paragraph: The art world has always operated on the herd instinct. But over the years it has morphed into a visible playpen of power and privilege.

headline: Letter From the Editor: 2015’s Big Question
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: What’s happening with wages will be vital for determining the national mood, the relative strength of Mr. Obama and Congress, and the 2016 election.
lead_paragraph: “Wages are finally starting to rise again,” President Obama said, during his recitation of good economic news in this week’s State of the Union address. Many of the other trends he listed were undeniable: unemployment and the deficit down, health insurance and educational attainment up. But his statement about wages left more room for debate.

headline: Doctor in the House? Not After Sunday
abstract: An Off Broadway production of the bio-musical about Shlomo Carlebach will close on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: “Shlomo’s back!” was the triumphant slogan when “Soul Doctor,” the Broadway musical about the guitar-strumming rabbi Shlomo Carlebach, reopened Off Broadway in December. But the show, which lasted not quite three months on Broadway in 2013, won’t make it to the two-month mark at the Actors Temple Theater, where its last performance is Sunday.

headline: At Casting Awards, Nina Arianda’s Headshots, Christine Baranski’s Surprise Numbers
abstract: The actors were on hand to present the Artios.
lead_paragraph: A lot of actors would surely love the opportunity to appear before a room full of powerful casting directors, and when Nina Arianda did just that, she took advantage of the situation and passed out copies of her headshot. It was a joke, of course, one well-suited to the occasion: Ms. Arianda was a presenter at the Casting Society of America’s 30th annual Artios Awards, honoring achievement by casting directors, a decidedly less widely appreciated bunch than actors and directors.

headline: Polish Group Demands ‘Ida’ Add Context About German Occupation
abstract: The Polish Anti-Defamation League has started a petition for additional language at the start of the tale of a novitiate who finds out her parents were Jewish and killed by a Polish family hiding them from the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: Pawel Pawlikowski’s Oscar-nominated film “Ida” is under fire, accused by the Polish Anti-Defamation League of failing to acknowledge the German occupation of Poland. The league has addressed its concerns to the Polish Film Institute, which provided some of the financial backing for “Ida.”

abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

lead_paragraph: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss two connectors with keen ears, who died last week.

abstract: Today, the city’s Museum of Contemporary Art opens “Laugh-in,” a show featuring artists who incorporate comedic elements into their work.

headline: N.F.L. Ends Silence on Underinflated Footballs to Say It Is Investigating
abstract: The N.F.L. said on Friday that it had interviewed nearly 40 people and hired a firm with forensic expertise to determine if the underinflated footballs used during the A.F.C. championship game were a result of deliberate action.
lead_paragraph: After days of silence and no comments, the N.F.L. confirmed Friday that game balls used by the New England Patriots during the first half of Sunday’s A.F.C. championship game against the Indianapolis Colts were underinflated, and the league said it was continuing to investigate why and how that came to be.

headline: As Last Paid Editors Depart, Modern Farmer’s Future in Doubt
abstract: The remaining paid editorial staff members of the 100,000-circulation quarterly and website have resigned.
lead_paragraph: Modern Farmer, the quirky 100,000-circulation quarterly and website that tried to link effete urban farmers’ market culture with the practicalities of actual farming, became a magazine without an editorial staff on Friday, when its remaining paid editors walked out its doors.

headline: Hint for Investors in Rise in Cash for Wall St. Chiefs’ Pay
abstract: With stock gains at the big banks slowing, cash bonuses may seem relatively more appealing to bank bosses. Investors should keep that in mind, Antony Currie of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Shareholders may want to take a hint from this week’s news on compensation for Wall Street chief executives. JPMorgan Chase is paying a portion of Jamie Dimon’s bonus in cash for the first time since 2011. And Goldman Sachs is bolstering how much cash Lloyd Blankfein gets. Meanwhile, bank stock gains are slowing.

headline: Protesters in Iran Condemn Charlie Hebdo Over Muhammad Cartoon
abstract: In cities across Iran, tens of thousands of people took to the streets to protest against the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo for its cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iranian protesters, encouraged by state-sanctioned Friday Prayer leaders, condemned the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo for publishing a cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad.

headline: Catching up with Danielle Steel, Couture Week Icon
abstract: On the eve of the Paris shows (and the release of her next novel), the author shares the details of her fashionable life there with T.
lead_paragraph: As familiar a sight at the Paris couture shows as models and gowns is Danielle Steel: author of 139 books that have sold 650 million copies; member of the Ordre des Arts et des Lettres and Chevalier of the Légion d’honneur; Guinness world record holder for longest time spent on The New York Times best-seller list; mother of nine and all-around avatar of elegance. Though Steel, who divides her time between San Francisco and Paris, keeps busy writing several books per year, if there’s one thing that will tear her away from her desk, it’s fashion. “I grew up going to haute couture shows, and began taking my daughters when they were very little girls,” she says. “Couture is an extraordinary experience and a dying art; each show is a thrill. It is art in one of its finest and most magical forms.” Here, on the eve of couture week (and the release of her next novel, “Prodigal Son,” out Feb. 24 from Random House), Steel shared the details of her fashionable life in Paris (written, of course, in an email).

headline: Officials Say Ebola Cases Are Falling In West Africa
abstract: Officials said that there had been a substantial reduction in new cases, but that dwindling funds and the approaching rainy season were a problem.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The number of people falling victim to the Ebola virus in West Africa has dropped to the lowest level in months, the World Health Organization said on Friday, but dwindling funds and a looming rainy season threaten to hamper efforts to control the disease.

abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Maintains His Support for Speaker Silver
abstract: Asked by reporters about his belief in the integrity of Sheldon Silver, who was arrested on corruption charges on Thursday, Mayor Bill de Blasio characterized him as a staunch ally.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio is not wavering in his support for Sheldon Silver.

headline: Hit the High Seas
abstract: Designers are riding a wave of rope detailing and sailor stripes.
lead_paragraph: Designers are riding a wave of rope detailing and sailor stripes.

headline: A Toddler’s Inside Guide to New York City
abstract: Diego Acosta López wanted to document New York from his son’s perspective: inside a stroller. Thousands of pictures (including little feet and hands) ensued.
lead_paragraph: Diego Acosta López wanted to document New York from his son’s perspective: inside a stroller. Thousands of pictures (including little feet and hands) ensued.

headline: Faith Hope Consolo: At Brunch, at a Museum, Always at Work
abstract: On Sundays, Ms. Consolo, the chairwoman of Douglas Elliman’s retail leasing and sales division, does her best to take advantage of what New York City offers.
lead_paragraph: Faith Hope Consolo, the chairwoman of Douglas Elliman’s retail leasing and sales division, likes to leverage her name. It can be seen plastered onto dozens of vacant shop windows along Madison Avenue, and a tag line, “You Need Faith,” is tattooed to pink pens and nail files that she sends to clients during the holidays. Ms. Consolo, one of the city’s most prolific retail brokers, has clients that include Cartier, Fendi and Yves Saint Laurent. A widow who says she is “sexy and 60-something,” she lives in a two-bedroom on Fifth Avenue with a wraparound terrace and views of Central Park.

headline: New Saudi King Addresses the Nation
abstract: King Salman of Saudi Arabia addressed the nation after the death of King Abdullah yesterday. He pledged continuity and unity in the country and the Arab world.
lead_paragraph: King Salman of Saudi Arabia addressed the nation after the death of King Abdullah yesterday. He pledged continuity and unity in the country and the Arab world.

headline: Judge Rules Tommie Rae Hynie Brown Was Married to James Brown
abstract: The dispute over whether the woman James Brown long treated as his wife was also his legal spouse neared its conclusion, as a South Carolina judge found that the couple had been legally married.
lead_paragraph: In a decision likely to significantly affect the long-running dispute over James Brown’s estate, a judge in South Carolina has ruled that Tommie Rae Hynie Brown is the widow of the singer, known as the Godfather of Soul.

headline: Compromise and Persuasion Won Grudging Support for E.C.B. Bond Buying
abstract: There was predictable criticism from German economists, but for the most part Mario Draghi, the central bank chief, was able to win support from Europe’s leaders for his stimulus plan.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — The economist Hans Werner-Sinn, guru of German inflation militants, accused the European Central Bank of illegal money printing. The Frankfurter Allgemeine newspaper said the central bank was destroying trust in the euro. And a German citizens’ group threatened to sue.

headline: New Issue for One City Opera Bidder: A Borrowed Name
abstract: A group bidding for the assets of the bankrupt New York City Opera is using a name that already belongs to another opera company.
lead_paragraph: What’s in a name? Apparently quite a lot, when it comes to opera companies.

headline: Answers to Questions About Snowplows, De-Icing Sidewalks and Parking Meters
abstract: Readers ask winter weather-related questions, and about meter-feeding.
lead_paragraph: Q.Why do city snowplows always push the snow to the right?

headline: A Singing Duo for 50 Years, a Married Couple Are Talent Scouts, Too
abstract: Billy Shepard and Judi Jourdan are a married couple with a 50-year career as a singing duo and a longstanding interest in finding, training and promoting vocalists.
lead_paragraph: Standing back by the bar in a Manhattan nightclub, Billy Shepard and Judi Jourdan watched the jazz singer, then the rap duo, then the show-tune crooner boning up for his upcoming gig at the Best Western in Morristown, N.J.

headline: Playing Politics on Iran
abstract: House Speaker John Boehner’s invitation to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel defies diplomatic norms and common sense.
lead_paragraph: Normally, the visit of a world leader to the United States would be arranged by the White House. But in a breach of sense and diplomacy, House Speaker John Boehner and Ron Dermer, Israel’s ambassador to Washington, have taken it upon themselves to invite Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to Congress to challenge President Obama’s approach to achieving a nuclear agreement with Iran.

headline: Jorge Ramos, Voice of Latino Voters on Univision, Sends Shiver Through G.O.P.
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Mr. Ramos, the influential Univision and Fusion anchor, has begun criticizing Republicans over their immigration stance, posing a challenge to their 2016 hopes.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — Jorge Ramos, the Univision and Fusion television anchor who is often called the Walter Cronkite of Latino America, was in his suburban Miami broadcast studio when he all but pounced on the chairman of the Republican Party, Reince Priebus, who was appearing from Washington. The Republicans’ immigration policy is “deportations, deportations, deportations,” Mr. Ramos said. “Why?”

headline: Michigan’s New Strategy: ‘Embrace the Adversity’
abstract: Michigan, which lost to N.J.I.T. and Eastern Michigan last month and lost Caris LeVert, a top player, this month, will continue to try to salvage its season on Saturday against Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — The only place for John Beilein, the men’s basketball coach at Michigan, to sit in the hallway of the Rutgers athletic center on Tuesday night was on a medical table with a cushion held together with duct tape. He hoisted himself up, pored over the box score from his team’s victory over Rutgers and accepted pats on the back and congratulations from alumni.

headline: In San Diego, Art Is a Laughing Matter
abstract: Today, the city’s Museum of Contemporary Art opens “Laugh-in,” a show featuring artists who incorporate comedic elements into their work.
lead_paragraph: If the intersection of comedy, contemporary art and San Diego sounds like a strange brew, then brace yourself: Today the Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego in La Jolla opens an exhibition called “Laugh-in,” gathering 20 artists whose work utilizes humor in all its modes.

headline: Euphorically Embracing a Long-Missing Soloist
abstract: The violinist Maxim Vengerov played Tchaikovsky with the New York Philharmonic after a long hiatus, as Long Yu made his conducting debut at Avery Fisher Hall.
lead_paragraph: A debut and a comeback were on offer at Thursday’s New York Philharmonic concert at Avery Fisher Hall. A majority of the vocal, near-capacity audience was clearly there for the comeback: After an absence of almost nine years resulting partly from a shoulder injury, the Siberian-born star violinist Maxim Vengerov was returning to this stage with one of his signature pieces, Tchaikovsky’s Violin Concerto. He received a hero’s welcome. There were bravos and smattered applause between movements and a protracted ovation at the end of the piece. Isolated whoops of the weak-kneed kind usually reserved for rock stars greeted his announcement of an encore. After the intermission, clusters of seats remained empty.

headline: Tasty Cozy Cool
abstract: Equal parts Left Bank bistro and Harlem Renaissance speakeasy, Chez Oskar in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, has remained relevant by staying true to its original aesthetic.
lead_paragraph: Equal parts Left Bank bistro and Harlem Renaissance speakeasy, Chez Oskar in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, has remained relevant by staying true to its original aesthetic.

headline: Popcast: ASAP Yams and Kim Fowley, Departed Tastemakers
abstract: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss ASAP Yams and Kim Fowley, connectors, motivators and talent scouts with keen ears, who died last week.
lead_paragraph: The future of pop doesn’t only rest on great singers or musicians or signature-sound producers. It also, sometimes, rests on people who understand opportunity, the movement of taste, fashion, sound, visual style, the way the wind is blowing. They’re not primarily artists or merchants. They’re not necessarily back-room forces — sometimes they are very public — but their roles and strengths remain in flux.

headline: Fort Greene Changes. Chez Oskar Doesn’t.
abstract: Chez Oskar, in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, has stayed true to its original aesthetic in a changing neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: On a frigid Brooklyn night, a deep-red facade on the corner of DeKalb Avenue and Adelphi Street in Fort Greene’s historic district glows invitingly. A worn wooden door awaits under the weathered sign of Chez Oskar, and those who enter will join a convivial scene that has been in steady swing for 17 years.

headline: New York Alternate-Side Parking Rules Suspended Saturday
abstract: To facilitate snow removal, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: To facilitate snow removal, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Saturday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Pirate Ships, the Wall Street of the High Seas
abstract: The Starz series “Black Sails” returns for a second season and is already down for a third.
lead_paragraph: The best pirate series introduced in 2014 that wasn’t canceled returns Saturday night, its gnarly men still gnarly, its brothel still doing a booming business, and its allegiances and morality still ever-shifting.

abstract: Among Todd Bowles’s choices on Friday were Kacy Rodgers as defensive coordinator and Bobby April Jr. as special teams coordinator.
lead_paragraph: Todd Bowles, the Jets’ new head coach, appointed two coordinators and seven assistants Friday as he continued to fill out his staff.

headline: Growing Scrutiny for an Allergy Trigger Used in Personal Care Products
abstract: While some consumer products companies are removing the chemical, methylisothiazolinone, others are adding it to offerings including mouthwash.
lead_paragraph: Because she has an eczema condition, Michelle Kirn intently reads ingredient labels on baby wipes, soaps and other household items to avoid allergic reactions that she says were caused by a commonly used preservative.

headline: Is the Defendant White or Not?
abstract: The answer can vary with a juror’s political outlook.
lead_paragraph: AS jury selection continues in the trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the defendant in the Boston Marathon bombings, so does debate about what would constitute a fair and impartial jury. Questions have been raised about the race, gender, age and religiosity of prospective jurors; about the effect of holding the trial in Boston; and about the legal requirement that the jurors be open to the possibility of sentencing the defendant to death.

headline: ‘Finding Neverland’ Publicist Resigns After Dispute
abstract: Rick Miramontez, the publicist for “Finding Neverland,” has left after a spat with the show’s producer, Harvey Weinstein.
lead_paragraph: The bare-knuckled tactics of the film producer Harvey Weinstein have slammed into the more genteel sensibilities of Broadway, where he is bringing his first musical, “Finding Neverland.” After the show’s publicist resigned — apparently in reaction to criticism from Mr. Weinstein — the producer on Thursday night ripped into the strategy to promote the musical, then changed his tone on Friday and said he had made a “rookie” mistake with the criticisms.

headline: Door to Emancipation; Decades of Decay
abstract: A book by a Columbia University historian on New York’s integral role in the Underground Railroad, and another which invokes artistic expression to vividly recreate a gritty and pivotal era of urban tumult.
lead_paragraph: Eric Foner, the Pulitzer Prize-winning Columbia University historian, has mined a 19th-century manuscript brought to his attention by a graduate student (who doubled as his dog walker) to produce a consummate narrative about New York’s ambiguous relationship with the antebellum South and the fugitive slaves who fled it.

headline: Honoring Orson Welles in Wisconsin
abstract: Kenosha, Wis., the hometown of Orson Welles, will observe the centennial of his birth in May with a month of events, including live performances and screenings.
lead_paragraph: Though he streaked to fame on New York stages and Hollywood sets, the actor and director Orson Welles was born in a city far away from show business capitals —  Kenosha, Wis., about 40 miles south of Milwaukee.

headline: A Shadow of His Old Self? For Roger Federer, Maybe Not Yet
abstract: Despite falling to the unheralded Italian Andreas Seppi in the third round of the Australian Open, Federer was coming off a grueling, but successful, 2014.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — In darker moments for Roger Federer, a loss like Friday’s, to Andreas Seppi, could have restarted the doomsday chatter that Federer likes just about as much as a certain Spanish left-hander’s forehand.

headline: Justices to Hear Case Over Drugs Used in Executions
abstract: The Supreme Court agreed to rule on three Oklahoma inmates’ contention that a new chemical combination poses a significant risk of terrible suffering.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to decide a case on the constitutionality of the new combinations of drugs that some states are using to execute prisoners and that critics say cause intense suffering.

headline: Ale and Muskets Frame Revolt
abstract: “Sons of Liberty,” a mini-series on History, is a prequel of sorts to the American Revolution.
lead_paragraph: There is no shame in not knowing why Boston boasts a beer called “Samuel Adams,” or why it’s the New England Patriots, not the New England Panthers or the New England Pistols.

headline: Young Performers Spreading Their Wings
abstract: The Mariinsky Ballet shrewdly paired Oxana Skorik and Xander Paris toward the end of its run of “Swan Lake” in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The Mariinsky Ballet’s production of “Swan Lake” is a strange bird. There have been frosty Odettes, tawdry Odiles, uncharismatic Siegfrieds and a frequently irritating Joker. Yet the luminosity of the staging, a 1950 revision of the celebrated 1895 version choreographed by Marius Petipa and Lev Ivanov, manages to shine in its sets, lighting and costumes. To see swans — they’re not real, but they look it — glide across the lake at the start of the second scene is heart-stopping. (Even the third time around.) The swan maidens, this time real women, are bewilderingly gorgeous as they skim across the stage or frame it, poised like statues.

headline: Hooked on Novocain? Call This Number
abstract: The comedy troupe Parallel Exit evokes “Rowan & Martin’s Laugh-In” in its new show, “Everybody Gets Cake!”
lead_paragraph: In its humor, “Everybody Gets Cake!,” the comedy troupe Parallel Exit’s new show at 59E59 Theaters, is a throwback. Specifically, it’s a throwback to 1968.

headline: Women Fighting for Their Land and Opportunity
abstract: In a hard-to-reach corner of Myanmar, Adriane Ohanesian searched for the young female fighters of the Kachin Independence Army, which has waged a long civil war.
lead_paragraph: In a hard-to-reach corner of Myanmar, Adriane Ohanesian searched for the young female fighters of the Kachin Independence Army, which has waged a long civil war.

lead_paragraph: Lori Levine and Jan van Arsdale were married Jan. 1, at ABC Kitchen in New York.

headline: Balanchine as Shape-Shifter, Concealing Surprises in Familiarity
abstract: New York City Ballet stages another collection of Balanchine works in its new season at the David H. Koch Theater.
lead_paragraph: Thursday was the 111th birthday of George Balanchine, the most revelatory, influential and protean ballet master in history. New York City Ballet, the company he founded with Lincoln Kirstein in 1948, celebrated the occasion by bringing three Balanchine ballets back to the repertory: “Donizetti Variations” (1960), “La Valse” (1951) and “Chaconne” (1976).

headline: Meeting Each Other Halfway, and Then Some
abstract: A couple find that a relationship is like making custard: “If you cook it too fast, you end up with scrambled eggs.”
lead_paragraph: ­When Lori Levine goes out for a night on the town, she is often in the company of famous men like George Clooney, Chris Noth or Adrien Brody. But that’s her job.

headline: Gorman at Morgan Stanley to Receive $4.4 Million Stock Bonus
abstract: The investment bank will also most likely pay its chief executive a cash bonus and another stock bonus tied to the bank’s future performance, in addition to a $1.5 million salary.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley’s chief executive, James Gorman, is receiving a $4.4 million stock bonus for 2014 in addition to his $1.5 million salary.

headline: Berluti: Fall 2015 Menswear
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: A Moviemaking Couple Takes on Sundance, Together and Separately
abstract: The married indie filmmakers Joe and Kris Swanberg each have new projects playing at the festival this year.
lead_paragraph: For a pair of Chicagoans who operate far outside the Hollywood bubble, Joe and Kris Swanberg are finding filmmaking a surprisingly fruitful family business. The low-key couple made waves last month when it was announced that Joe and Kris would each separately premiere a film at the Sundance Film Festival — an anomaly in the event’s 31-year history. “Kris found out a few hours before I did,” Joe says. “I had sort of made my peace with the idea that I wasn’t going to get in, so there was a part of me that was really thrilled to just go and be Kris’s husband for the whole festival.”

headline: What We’re Reading
