headline: Bill Cunningham | Fashion-Forward Lads
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Fur', 'Hats and Caps', 'Men and Boys', 'Sneakers']
abstract: Young men are pushing the style envelope with felt hats, winged sneakers and fur-collared coats.
lead_paragraph: Young men are pushing the style envelope with felt hats, winged sneakers and fur-collared coats.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Fashion-Forward Lads
abstract: Young men are pushing the style envelope with felt hats, winged sneakers and fur-collared coats.
lead_paragraph: Young men are pushing the style envelope with felt hats, winged sneakers and fur-collared coats. These are not the fashion professionals attending the European men’s shows; they are New Yorkers. A newer look: dress coats in patterns, colors or with embroidered shoulders. Many of the men who never had a chance to experience rakish hats are into them this season. Even the hairstyles are interesting, the sides of the head shaven close and topped with a comb-over or a sleek, finlike mohawk. Torn trousers have been around for decades, but they now have embroidery, stencils or a dozen miniature pockets.

headline: Daily Kos Founder Considering Run For Congress
abstract: Representative Barbara Lee of California may not wind up as our woman in Havana, but when she does leave Congress, there may be a nationally known liberal waiting to run for her seat: Markos Moulitsas.
lead_paragraph: Representative Barbara Lee of California may not wind up as our woman in Havana — disputing reports that she was seeking the nomination to be ambassador — but when she does leave Congress, there may be a nationally known liberal waiting to run for her seat: Markos Moulitsas.

headline: Evening Hours | The Weight of History
abstract: Honoring the past and the arts.
lead_paragraph: Honoring the past and the arts.

headline: U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara Challenges Insider Trading Ruling
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Insider Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: Federal prosecutors are mounting a challenge to an appellate court’s verdict in an effort to reverse it, or at least narrow it.
lead_paragraph: When an appeals court overturned the convictions of two hedge fund managers last month, the ruling reverberated throughout the legal world and rewrote the government’s insider trading playbook.

headline: Sarah Silverman Gets Serious at Sundance
keywords: ['Movies', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Books and Literature', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: What will the film festival attendees think of the unlikely star of a harrowing film, “I Smile Back”?
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — The harrowing drama “I Smile Back,” making its debut on Sunday at the Sundance Film Festival, opens with a drawn-out shot of a naked, forlorn woman. She is an alcoholic suburban mom having a cocaine-fueled affair and wrestling with mental illness. At one point she gets beaten bloody in an alley.

headline: Martin Short’s Night Out With Matthew Broderick
abstract: The co-stars in the Broadway meta-comedy, “It’s Only a Play,” dine with their co-star Katie Finneran.
lead_paragraph: Martin Short has so much going on these days, he can’t afford to get the sniffles.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: A Stage for Nurturing New Works
abstract: Established and fledgling playwrights can test out their productions in staged readings at the John Drew Theater Lab at Guild Hall in East Hampton.
lead_paragraph: Established and fledgling playwrights can test out their productions in staged readings at the John Drew Theater Lab at Guild Hall in East Hampton.

headline: Where New Works Go to Be Nurtured: John Drew Theater Lab in East Hampton
abstract: The John Drew Theater Lab in East Hampton is a place for established and fledgling playwrights to present staged readings of their new works.
lead_paragraph: Joe Brondo started writing a play last June — a first for him — and after two weeks showed his first draft to Josh Gladstone, the artistic director of the John Drew Theater Lab at Guild Hall in East Hampton, where Mr. Brondo is assistant technical director. Mr. Gladstone had started the theater lab in February 2014 to develop and present staged readings of new plays and other one-night showcases for creative work.

headline: Eddie Redmayne and Emma Stone on Acting, Fame and Protecting Their Privacy
abstract: Emma Stone and Eddie Redmayne knew early on that they wanted to act. Convincing their parents? Well, that was another story.
lead_paragraph: Emma Stone was delighted to grant Eddie Redmayne a retroactive wish on his birthday candle, since he forgot to make one when he blew it out.

headline: Libyan Peace Talks to Resume, U.N. Says
abstract: The United Nations said that most of Libya’s feuding factions had agreed to meet in Geneva next week to resume talks on ending their conflict.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations said Friday that most of Libya’s feuding factions had agreed to meet in Geneva next week to resume talks on ending a conflict that has put the country at risk of economic and social collapse.

headline: Blackstone Is Said to Raise $4.5 Billion for Energy Fund
abstract: The Blackstone vehicle is among several efforts by big private equity firms to find investment bargains among oil and gas companies, many of which have been strained by the fall in oil prices.
lead_paragraph: The Blackstone Group has finished raising $4.5 billion for a new fund dedicated to investments in the energy sector, as the private equity giant seeks to profit on the rout in oil prices, a person with knowledge of the matter said on Friday.

headline: Tumblr 466 — 469
abstract: Tumblr 466 — 469
lead_paragraph: Tumblr 466 — 469

headline: Congressional Republicans Call on F.C.C. to Release Internal Net Neutrality Document
abstract: Congressional Republicans are urging the F.C.C. to publicly release an internal draft of its net neutrality proposal. They are concerned the commission is poised to pursue heavy-handed regulation.
lead_paragraph: Congressional Republicans took a tactical step this week in their brewing confrontation with the Federal Communications Commission over who sets the rules for the future of the Internet.

headline: SkyMall Is Going Bankrupt, and It’s All Your Fault
abstract: The leading journal of the stupid stuff people buy, no longer made viable through actual sales of stupid stuff.
lead_paragraph: The first time I met Felix Salmon, the financial journalist, was on a United flight from Newark to Kansas City. Throughout the flight, he would tap my shoulder and excitedly point out increasingly ridiculous items in the SkyMall catalog.

headline: Staying Put and Bearing Witness to the Holocaust
abstract: Rather than flee to safe havens in America or Israel, some 2,700 Jews who survived Auschwitz returned to their European town in what is now Romania.
lead_paragraph: Rather than flee to safe havens in America or Israel, some 2,700 Jews who survived Auschwitz returned to their European town in what is now Romania.

headline: From a Fount of Grief, Endless Invention
abstract: The Martha Graham Dance Company will celebrate the 85th anniversary of “Lamentation” with four new variations on the piece.
lead_paragraph: As America’s oldest modern dance troupe, the Martha Graham Dance Company devotes much effort to maintaining traditions. A project called “Lamentation Variations” was not supposed to be one of them. The opening night of the company’s 2007 New York season happened to fall on Sept. 11. To commemorate the anniversary of the 9/11 attacks, the group’s artistic director, Janet Eilber, decided to invite three choreographers to contribute pieces inspired by a film of “Lamentation,” Graham’s canonical 1930 dance of grief.

headline: In Westchester, a 130-Year-Old Theater Primps for Its Next Act
abstract: With a combination of public and private funds, the oldest operating theater in Westchester County, the Tarrytown Music Hall, positions itself to keep hosting performances.
lead_paragraph: In all likelihood, few of the 80,000 people who attend events at the Tarrytown Music Hall each year noticed that the floor near the north end of the east wall had become slightly spongy underfoot. But Bjorn Olsson, executive director of the hall, had. And he knew why: Poor drainage outside had allowed water to gather, erode the wood-on-stone foundation and seep in under the hall.

headline: More Than Tools: Sometimes Instruments Inspire
abstract: Noveller, Remmy Valenzuela, Jason Nelson, Allegra Levy and Jeremy Pelt have released new music.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Pelt

headline: From Valiant Prince to Smoldering Rebel
abstract: Ben Barnes discusses his role as Samuel Adams in the History channel’s “Sons of Liberty.”
lead_paragraph: These are not your history professor’s founding fathers. With their chiseled jawlines and devil-may-care gazes, History’s “Sons of Liberty” — John Hancock (Rafe Spall), John Adams (Henry Thomas), Paul Revere (Michael Raymond-James) and Joseph Warren (Ryan Eggold) — skew more Versace model than early American revolutionary. Then there’s Sam Adams, the Harvard-educated statesman, master of propaganda and Boston Tea Party champion. In real life Adams was a stout 50-something in the 1770s; here he’s played by Ben Barnes, 33, a dashing London-born actor.

headline: Tracee Ellis Ross Is Big on Big Hair
abstract: The ‘black-ish’ star on how the Internet built a community around natural hair.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, I interviewed the actress Tracee Ellis Ross about her role on “Black-ish” (her new hit show on ABC), her playful presence on social media and her childhood as a daughter of the legendary singer Diana Ross. You can read an excerpt from our conversation in this week’s Talk column. Throughout the hourlong phone call, however, we kept drifting back to one subject: Ross’s trademark curly cloud of hair and the way Instagram and Pinterest have contributed to the expansion of mainstream beauty standards online and in Hollywood. Much of that discussion didn’t make it into the print version of the interview, but it felt worth sharing — and worth adding to. Jenna Wortham

headline: Mining Life’s Complications for Laughs
abstract: Alan Ayckbourn’s “Absurd Person Singular,” in Red Bank, is set during three successive Christmas gatherings and tells the story of how three British couples deal with the gradual change in status.
lead_paragraph: “Spinning Wheel,” the Blood, Sweat & Tears pop classic, introduces each of the three acts of Alan Ayckbourn’s “Absurd Person Singular.”

headline: This Cold House
abstract: My experiment with daily life at 45 degrees — indoors.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — OVER the summer, I moved into a house in rural Nebraska where, for the first time ever, I had full control of the thermostat. It was a drafty 4,000-square-foot palace of cold-to-the touch cinder-blocks that had long stood empty. As fall approached, I started to think about heating. Keeping that whole place at 70 degrees with natural gas, for just one person, seemed like a waste. I wondered: How cold could I let my house get, while remaining comfortable?

headline: Ocwen Reaches Settlement With California Regulator
abstract: The embattled subprime mortgage servicer agreed to pay $2.5 million in penalties and pay for a third-party auditor to ensure that the firm complies with regulators’ requests for information.
lead_paragraph: The embattled subprime mortgage servicer Ocwen Financial on Friday reached a settlement with a California regulator that will allow it to continue operating in the state.

headline: I Love You. I Hate You. It’s Complicated.
abstract: With “Private Lives,” now in Hartford, Noël Coward wrote about ex-spouses who are reminded how the “ex-” got there.
lead_paragraph: If Noël Coward’s “Private Lives” is to be believed — and with this shiny, new, perfectly polished production at Hartford Stage, how can it not be? — sexual mores in England changed a great deal between 1924 and 1930. There is poor Lady Mary in the recent episode of “Downton Abbey,” an elegant young widow being preached to by her grandmother because she has spent the night in a hotel with a man to whom she is not married. Then there is the rather cavalier Amanda Chase Prynne, the heroine of “Private Lives,” casually informing her ex-husband, Elyot Chase, of the men she has had affairs with since their divorce five years ago.

headline: Who Will Rule the Oil Market?
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Natural Gas', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Oil Sands']
abstract: Economic forces, not OPEC, now set prices.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A HISTORIC change of roles is at the heart of the clamor and turmoil over the collapse of oil prices, which have plummeted by 50 percent since September. For decades, Saudi Arabia, backed by the Persian Gulf emirates, was described as the “swing producer.” With its immense production capacity, it could raise or lower its output to help the global market adjust to shortages or surpluses.

headline: Snapchat Plans to Offer Original Media Content
abstract: The photo messaging start-up is joining with a group of media companies to offer users original editorial content for the first time.
lead_paragraph: Snapchat, the photo messaging start-up, is joining with a select group of media companies to offer users original editorial content, according to three people briefed on the matter.

headline: Inventiveness With a Hot Plate
abstract: In a shoebox-size space in New Haven, August: Upscale Bar and Eatery’s owners offer a small menu with rustic, elegant dishes.
lead_paragraph: Even for veteran chefs working in state-of-the-art kitchens, it can be taxing to consistently whip up sophisticated, satisfying meals for a parade of discriminating patrons. So when a self-taught cook manages to pull it off using only a hot plate, a plug-in stew pot and a panini press, the results can seem like feats of culinary magic.

headline: Syrian Airstrike Hits Damascus Suburb, Killing Dozens
abstract: The government attack targeted an insurgent-held area, as Lebanon’s army fought militants near the border.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A Syrian government airstrike on Friday hit a market square in an insurgent-held suburb of Damascus, the capital, killing several dozen people, antigovernment activists in the area said, while five Lebanese soldiers were killed in clashes with militants who crisscross the Syrian border, in one of the worst recent cases of spillover violence.

headline: Cuomo Cites School Crisis in New York; Data Suggest Otherwise
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo says New York’s education system “needs dramatic reform.” How bad is New York, really? Relative to others states, experts say, not that bad. But not that good, either.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, in his State of the State address this week, exhorted lawmakers to make significant changes to New York State’s education system. He painted a picture of a system in crisis: only a third of students reaching proficiency on state math and English tests, less than 40 percent of high school students prepared for college, hundreds of thousands of mostly minority students condemned to failing schools.

headline: A Move to More Casual Fare
abstract: Ariane Duarte, the chef of Ariane Kitchen & Bar, in Verona, said she opened a less expensive place because she wanted “to make a burger” and “have fun.”
lead_paragraph: A meal at Ariane Kitchen & Bar begins with croissants. They are everything croissants should be: buttery and flaky; their ends just the slightest bit crisp. But they are small, and shouldn’t stop you from enjoying the rest of the meal, you think, as you reach for a second one.

headline: After an Anxiety-Filled Campaign, Greek Voters Consider a Turn to the Left
abstract: Battered by years of economic trouble, Greeks may turn to the leftist Alexis Tsipras and his party when they go to the polls on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: GLYFADA, Greece — Katerina Georgiou, 64, who used to own a private school, says that she will probably act out of fear when she decides who to vote for in Sunday’s general election.

headline: V.A.’s Treatment of Veterans’ Trauma
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: Readers react to a Marine’s description of his therapy.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Bridge Big Hosts Online World Cup
abstract: Internet bridge continues to gain in popularity.
lead_paragraph: Internet bridge continues to gain in popularity. The first World Cup of Online Bridge has been organized by Bridge Big (bridgebig.com). Players can enter directly or qualify through preliminary events, which run until next Saturday. The final will take place on Feb. 1.

headline: Health Care and Prosperity
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Two doctors write that universal health care is a major contributor to a country’s economic well-being.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Intimate, Casual and Classical, in a Club Setting
abstract: Beethoven, Liszt and Debussy were on the bill Wednesday when Anne Sofie von Otter and Angela Hewitt appeared at Le Poisson Rouge in Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: “It’s wonderful to be here in the Red Fish,” the Swedish mezzo-soprano Anne Sofie von Otter said on Wednesday evening. And it was wonderful to have her there.

headline: How to Test North Korea
abstract: Jerome A. Cohen of the N.Y.U. School of Law recommends a “broadened approach,” with new contacts in business, education, cultural exchange and other areas.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Pennsylvania’s Governor Breaks Through a G.O.P. Tide
abstract: Gov. Tom Wolf, a Democrat, emerges against a Republican tide and faces a $2 billion budget gap.
lead_paragraph: HARRISBURG, Pa. — Standing outside the Capitol here — an ornate jewel wedged in the center of this recession-beaten industrial city — the businessman and political neophyte Tom Wolf told the gathered crowd this week, “I’m going to be an unconventional governor.”

headline: Disciplining Police Officers
abstract: The executive director of the A.C.L.U. of New Jersey says review boards that address misconduct should have the power to impose punishments.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Gay Couple Awaits the Justices’ Decision
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Personal Finances', 'Financial Planners']
abstract: Couples have had to navigate byzantine laws as same-sex marriage rights have progressed state by state. A Supreme Court ruling may change everything.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — It may have been a coincidence that the United States Supreme Court announced its intent to hear another same-sex marriage case the same week as the holiday honoring Martin Luther King’s Birthday, but it was hard not to notice the connection. The gay marriage question is one that has civil rights at its center, after all.

headline: Why Tolerate Terrorist Publications?
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Terrorism', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: The First Amendment should not apply to our sworn enemies.
lead_paragraph: WHILE most of us would agree that religious fundamentalists, foreign and domestic, sometimes do serious harm to our society, there are other kinds of fundamentalists who are also dangerous: I refer to legal fundamentalists.

headline: Mobile Monitoring of Blood Glucose Is Approved
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved a set of mobile applications that allow people with diabetes to share information with doctors using an iPhone.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved a set of mobile medical applications that allow people with diabetes to share information about the level of glucose in their blood with doctors in real time using an iPhone. Such apps have existed but were not in broad use, in part because they had not met regulatory requirements. Dr. K. M. Venkat Narayan, professor of medicine and epidemiology at Emory University, said that the apps would be useful for certain patients, for example those with extreme fluctuations in glucose levels, but would not fundamentally change diabetes monitoring.

headline: Archaeologists Want Egyptian Officials Charged for Damage to Tutankhamen’s Burial Mask
abstract: A group of Egyptian archaeologists said that they planned to file charges against officials at the state-run Egyptian Museum in Cairo.
lead_paragraph: Outraged over what appears to be serious damage to one of Egypt’s ancient treasures — scratches and a layer of glue on the golden burial mask of Tutankhamen — a group of Egyptian archaeologists said on Friday that they planned to file charges against officials at the state-run Egyptian Museum in Cairo.

headline: Dishes So Complex the Waiters Use Crib Sheets
abstract: Hopscotch, in Croton-on-Hudson, not for the timid, spoils its patrons with personal touches and fancy footwork in the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: On a winter’s night at the four-month-old Hopscotch in Croton-on-Hudson, I asked our waiter to tell me about the quenelle-shaped oval that adorned a dish called oxtail strudel. He blushed a bit and backed up in the direction of the kitchen, saying, “I just need to check my notes.” That the waiters at Hopscotch — who are very quick and personable — rely on crib sheets says a lot about the complexity of the dishes with which Kenyon Hart, the chef de cuisine, is spoiling patrons.

headline: U.S. Army Report of the Investigation Into 2014 Fort Hood Shooting
abstract: The Army’s report, which has been redacted in places, says that no clear warnings existed about Specialist Ivan A. Lopez’s mental state, and that no single factor prompted the episode.
lead_paragraph: The Army’s report, which has been redacted in places, says that no clear warnings existed about Specialist Ivan A. Lopez’s mental state, and that no single factor prompted the episode.

headline: For Obama’s Visit, India Takes a Broom to Stray Monkeys and Cows
abstract: With President Obama arriving Sunday, India faces a special challenge in trying to chase troublesome but venerated animals like cows and rhesus macaque monkeys out of view.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — When an important guest is on his way over, it is common practice to sweep up one’s odds and ends and hide them all in the back room. So it was in New Delhi this week.

headline: Japanese Dishes, With a Side Order of Kitsch
abstract: Teinei Ya, a Japanese restaurant in Little Neck, Queens, that opened last May, more than holds its own in a neighborhood rife with cheap and interesting international food.
lead_paragraph: To enjoy Teinei Ya (pronounced TAY-nay YA), a Japanese restaurant in Little Neck that opened last May, you have to like your food served with a rather large dollop of kitsch. Diners who can get past this — or better yet, learn to embrace it — are in for a culinary treat. On a stretch of Northern Boulevard on the Queens side of the Nassau County border in a neighborhood that is rife with cheap and interesting international food, this is a restaurant that holds its own, and then some.

headline: In Brooklyn, Spotlight Recedes From Site of Fatal Ambush of 2 Officers
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: The road has been reopened and the memorial has been removed at the corner of Myrtle and Tomkins Avenues, where Officers Wenjian Liu and Rafael Ramos were killed on Dec. 20.
lead_paragraph: For years, the stretch of curb outside the back door of Mike’s Pizza, on the corner of Myrtle and Tompkins Avenues in Brooklyn, belonged, unofficially, to a man known to neighbors as Mr. Wallace. They knew he always parked his Cadillac there to keep his walk home to the Tompkins Houses across the street short.

headline: Former Party Official Says Spain’s Leader Knew of Slush Fund
abstract: The former treasurer at the heart of a slush-fund scandal has accused Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of knowing “from the beginning” about the party’s illegal payments.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The former treasurer at the heart of a slush-fund scandal that has undermined Spain’s governing Popular Party accused Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy on Friday of knowing “from the beginning” about the party’s illegal payments.

headline: Jeb Bush Sounds Sympathetic Note for Immigrants
abstract: The speech was the first offered by Jeb Bush since he announced he was actively exploring a run for the presidency, and it focused on traditional conservative positions and avoided specifics.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In a sweeping speech that leaned heavily on economic policy, former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida on Friday described immigrants as the “engine of economic vitality” before calling for a more welcoming immigration policy that could put him at odds with some in the more conservative wing of his party.

headline: For SkyMall, It All Seemed So Cool at Six Miles High
abstract: With its kitsch appeal, SkyMall became a kind of cultural reference point, a one-word inside joke that everyone could share.
lead_paragraph: For years, it was something of a ritual. You had made it through airport security, survived the lengthy delays and even crammed your carry-on into an overhead bin. Then you could settle in, buckle up and reach into the seat-back pocket in front of you. There, pressed up against the motion-sickness bag or the laminated emergency instruction card, you would find the latest edition of SkyMall.

headline: Gamesmanship vs. Cheating
abstract: The “Deflategate” inquiry involving the Patriots is a reminder that athletes in almost every pursuit cheat or practice its fraternal twin, gamesmanship.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, Derek Jeter developed a tic at the plate that gave him an advantage. Or was it a trick? Whenever a pitch darted inside, Jeter bent over, stuck out his backside, held back his bat, and watched as the ball went by. It was his way of signaling to the umpire that the pitch was a ball, and often he got the call.

headline: Kerry, at Davos, Urges Multipronged Fight Against Violent Extremism
abstract: The secretary of state called for efforts to reduce unemployment and other programs that could dissuade young people from joining militant causes, even if such initiatives were costly.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — Secretary of State John Kerry on Friday called for an ambitious campaign to combat the root causes of violent extremism, which he said represented one of the most grave threats to international order since the end of World War II.

headline: Microsoft’s Holographic Vision Triggers a Flashback
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)', 'Xbox One (Video Game System)']
abstract: The introduction of the HoloLens by Microsoft brought back memories of the history of its Kinect device.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — This week, Microsoft did what it usually does when it has an intriguing new technology that isn’t fully baked: It released a video.

headline: The Plunder of Myanmar
abstract: China’s desire for everything from tiger parts to copper is threatening the environment and political stability.
lead_paragraph: China’s exploding appetites have unleashed a wholesale looting of Myanmar’s valuable natural resources. While this often involves outright theft, it also comes in the form of crony capitalism. Myanmar’s military elite has deals with Chinese companies that are eager to exploit the land, with little concern for the environment or people. The Kachin Independence Army, a rebel group that controls part of northeastern Myanmar, also takes a cut of some of this trade with China, especially jade hacked out of the earth by impoverished, heroin-addicted laborers.

headline: Raced to Death at the Big A
abstract: New emergency measures are in place at Aqueduct Racetrack. More may be needed.
lead_paragraph: The tragic degradation of thoroughbred racing continues at New York’s Aqueduct Racetrack, where the fatality rate for horses — 7.8 per 1,000 horses — has reached more than four times the national average as heedless owners put unproven horses at risk for lucrative purses. Twelve horses broke down in competition and had to be put to death in just 22 days in the track’s current winter meet.

headline: In Spectacle of Biggest Stars, a Modest Center Stands Out
abstract: Zemgus Girgensons, a center for the Buffalo Sabres, earned a spot in the N.H.L. All-Star Game because of the support he received in the league’s fan voting competition, provided largely by Latvia, his home country.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Reporters and photographers at the N.H.L. All-Star Game media day thronged around Zemgus Girgensons, a modest second-year center for one of the league’s worst teams who obliterated a list of hockey superstars in fan voting dominated by his home country, Latvia, where he is a national hero.

headline: Crusading for Israel in a Way Some Say Is Misguided
abstract: To show, as she put it, “there is a price to Jewish blood,” Nitsana Darshan-Leitner sues nations, terrorist organizations and others that have harmed Israelis — angering some on the left in Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — She is a crusading lawyer who serially sues rogue nations, terror groups and international banks to show, as she put it, “there is a price to Jewish blood.” She is a mother of six who, while seven months pregnant with triplets, astonished an Israeli court with a motion requesting that a hearing be moved to her home. (It was denied.).

headline: The Greeks Head to the Polls, Many Saying ‘Enough’
abstract: The only surprise in the rise of the left-wing Syriza party is that it has taken so long for an anti-austerity party to come to the fore.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Driving along a broad avenue lined with restaurants, the Greek man at the wheel points to the trash cans. Every night, he says, people rummage through them for scraps of food. His two well-educated daughters cannot find jobs; more than half of Greek youths have no work, and the jobs that do appear are often short-term and lacking in benefits.

headline: Long Led by Silver, Assembly Democrats Face Uncertainty on a Successor
abstract: Sheldon Silver, who has served as Assembly speaker for more than two decades, has given no indication that he plans to resign. But as Democrats look for a potential heir, they are finding few options.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — With New York Democrats still reeling on Friday from the arrest of their powerful Assembly leader, Sheldon Silver, on federal graft charges, the state’s political corridors were abuzz with one question: Who could take his place?

headline: Don’t Blame Nafta
keywords: ['Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Over the two decades since the trade deal, manufacturing jobs have vanished. But it isn’t clear that there’s a link.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, the day after President Obama’s State of the Union address, a handful of Democratic House members, along with one senator, Bernie Sanders of Vermont, held a news conference to denounce one of the very few proposals the president put forward that actually has a chance of passage. The objects of their displeasure were the new trade agreements currently being negotiated by the administration.

headline: Amid Times Square’s Bright Lights, Murders in the Shadows
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Authorities are investigating two murders that happened in the shadows beyond the bright lights surrounding Times Square in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A major in the United States Marine Corps spent this week in and around Times Square on a business trip, a stranger marveling at the sights.

headline: And Now: Air Republicans
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Sex Crimes', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: So much for the House passing that bill banning abortions after 20 weeks. Didn’t work out as planned.
lead_paragraph: Tough week for the House Republicans. Speaker John Boehner’s high point must have been not clapping when President Obama talked about job growth in the State of the Union.

headline: Sounds Like a Plan
abstract: Kevin G. Der offers us a stunningly good Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Deb Amlen Sighting Alert! Once again, the Ace Hotel and I will be gently waking up New York City with the Jan. 25 Sunday crossword, and we hope you can join us for trivia, coffee and crossword-solving fun. We invade, sorry, we start at 11 a.m. Sunday, Jan. 25, in the beautifully appointed Ace lobby, located at 20 West 29th Street. See you there!

headline: Argentina Points to Spy After Lawyer’s Eerie Death
abstract: Argentina’s government asserted that a former intelligence official was involved in the murky events around the death of Alberto Nisman, the prosecutor found dead from a gunshot wound on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Argentina’s government asserted on Friday that an ousted spymaster was involved in the murky events around the death of the prosecutor investigating the 1994 bombing of a Jewish center, with President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner’s chief of staff claiming that the prosecutor did not even write a complaint accusing her and top aides of subverting his inquiry.

headline: Jackie Selebi, South Africa Police Head Convicted in Bribery Case, Dies at 64
abstract: Mr. Selebi, South Africa’s first black national police commissioner, was found guilty of taking bribes from a drug trafficker in a trial that drew immense international attention.
lead_paragraph: Jackie Selebi, South Africa’s first black national police commissioner, who in 2010 was convicted of taking bribes from a drug trafficker in a trial that drew immense international attention, died on Friday in a Pretoria hospital. He was 64.

headline: Washington Post Reporter, Jailed in Tehran, Is Said to Be Out of Solitary Confinement
abstract: While Jason Rezaian’s prison conditions appeared to have eased, it was unclear if that signaled some movement in Iran’s mysterious prosecution.
lead_paragraph: Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post’s Iran correspondent, who was imprisoned and placed in solitary confinement six months ago for unspecified reasons, has been moved recently and has a cellmate, his brother said Friday.

headline: After a Deal, British Chocolates Won’t Cross the Pond
abstract: As a result of a settlement with the Hershey’s Company, Let’s Buy British Imports, or L.B.B., agreed this week to stop importing all Cadbury’s chocolate made overseas.
lead_paragraph: “Have you tried Hershey’s chocolate?” asked Nicky Perry, a longtime British expatriate living in New York.

headline: Vince Camuto Dies at 78; Shoe Mogul Founded Nine West
abstract: Colleagues say Mr. Camuto was tuned in to the ever-changing tastes of his customers.
lead_paragraph: Vince Camuto, a quiet titan of retail and founder of the footwear behemoth Nine West, whose specialty was the midpriced but stylish shoe, died on Wednesday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 78.

headline: Adaptability Aids in a Driver’s Evolution
abstract: Scott Pruett has driven modified Mustangs and Mazdas and prototypes from Jaguar and Ford that go 200 miles per hour, but he has found his niche in endurance racing and will seek a record sixth victory in this weekend’s Rolex 24.
lead_paragraph: Scott Pruett’s success as a racecar driver comes down to adaptability.

headline: Columbia Doctor, Player in Sheldon Silver Investigation, Is Leaving Post
abstract: Dr. Robert N. Taub, accused of accepting grants from the Assembly speaker in exchange for referrals, will step down from the Columbia University Mesothelioma Center, which is being disbanded.
lead_paragraph: Robert N. Taub, a doctor and government witness in the federal corruption case against the State Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, is leaving his position as the head of a Columbia University cancer center, and the center is being disbanded, a university spokesman said Friday.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 23, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: In Unraveling Season, the Knicks String Together Reasons for Hope
abstract: The Knicks become the owners of a three-game winning streak by knocking off the Magic at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Milestones for the Knicks this season have been nothing but negative, but finally, 44 games in, they can attach their names to something of relatively reasonable acclaim: The Knicks, for the first time this season, have won three in a row.

headline: Ralph Morse, Photographer, Dies at 97
abstract: Mr. Morse’s images peppered the glossy pages of Life and Time magazines during a 50-year career.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Morse’s images peppered the glossy pages of Life and Time magazines during a 50-year career.

headline: Ralph Morse, Life Photographer of Big Events, Is Dead at 97
abstract: Mr. Morse, a Bronx native, was, at 24, the weekly magazine’s youngest war photographer and later covered the Mercury space program.
lead_paragraph: Everybody can point to some lucky break that advanced his career. For Ralph Morse, it was a serendipitous visit to Jones Beach with friends the weekend after he had been hired as a darkroom assistant for a photo sales agency. His impromptu shots of a father bouncing his child in the air so captivated his boss that Mr. Morse was promoted to full-time photographer.

headline: Dallas Taylor, Drummer for Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young, Dies at 66
abstract: Mr. Taylor, who later became a drug counselor, was ejected from the band because of his drinking and drug use.
lead_paragraph: Dallas Taylor, a rock ’n’ roll drummer who played behind David Crosby, Stephen Stills and Graham Nash, among other big names, and who overcame desperate addictions to drugs and alcohol to become a counselor for other addicts, died on Jan. 18 in Los Angeles. He was 66.

headline: Ward Swingle, Who Made Classical Music Jazzy, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Swingle was a conductor and arranger whose group, the Swingle Singers, combined scat vocals with classical music.
lead_paragraph: Ward Swingle, an American jazz vocalist, conductor and arranger whose Swingle Singers brought classical music into the Qiana Age with best-selling Bach that bubbled and bounced, died on Jan. 19 in Eastbourne, England. He was 87.

headline: Newly Energetic, Venus Williams Battles Her Way Into the Fourth Round
abstract: Williams, 34, looked strong and quick as she rallied to defeat Camila Giorgi of Italy after losing the first set. She will face Agnieszka Radwanska in the fourth round.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — For the first time in nearly four years, Venus Williams is back in the second week of a Grand Slam singles tournament.

headline: Ernie Banks, the Eternally Hopeful Mr. Cub, Dies at 83
abstract: Banks, known for his sunny mantra, “Let’s play two,” hit 512 home runs in 19 seasons and won consecutive M.V.P. awards, but he never reached the postseason.
lead_paragraph: Ernie Banks, the greatest power-hitting shortstop of the 20th century and an unconquerable optimist whose sunny disposition never dimmed in 19 seasons with the perennially stumbling Chicago Cubs, died on Friday in Chicago. He was 83.

headline: Baseball’s Eternal Optimist
abstract: Ernie Banks, the greatest power-hitting shortstop of the 20th century, maintained his sunny disposition in 19 seasons with the perennially stumbling Chicago Cubs.
lead_paragraph: Ernie Banks, the greatest power-hitting shortstop of the 20th century, maintained his sunny disposition in 19 seasons with the perennially stumbling Chicago Cubs.

headline: Sheldon Silver’s Arrest Leaves Governor Cuomo in Difficult Spot
abstract: The arrest of the New York State Assembly speaker is threatening to upend the order that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo spent his first term in the capital working to restore.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo unleashed a lengthy and aspirational oration laying out an ambitious social agenda for his second term. In 84 minutes, he devoted only about 40 seconds to the issue of cleaning up Albany.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 24, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “It was pure illusion that peace could be achieved now. None of the sides has yet achieved its goals. The only real surprise is that the fighting started in the winter instead of the spring.”

headline: Corrections: January 24, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, January 24, 2015.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) THE ESSENTIALS: RAGS TO RICHES Robert Osborne and Drew Barrymore explain why Michael Apted’s “Coal Miner’s Daughter” (1980), starring Sissy Spacek in an Oscar-winning portrayal of the country legend Loretta Lynn — a role for which she did all the singing — is required viewing. A “gentle touch” gives “this movie its distinctive sweetness,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times, adding that the film “risks understating its story to make Loretta Lynn’s biography part of a larger fabric, and the gamble pays off.”

headline: 1965: Commons Honors Churchill at His Death
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: the British House of Commons paid tribute to Winston Churchill in 1965.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Mother of Parliaments paid tribute today [Jan. 25] to her most famous son.

headline: 1915: An Interview With Winston Churchill
abstract: In 1915, the New York Herald, European Edition, published an interview with a young Winston Churchill, then First Lord of the Admiralty.
lead_paragraph: Winston Churchill, wartime prime minister of Britain, died 50 years ago today, on Jan. 24, 1965. Here is an interview published in the New York Herald, European Edition, in 1915, when he was the first lord of the Admiralty:

headline: Obama Will End India Trip Early to Visit Saudi Arabia
abstract: The president will cancel a tour of the Taj Mahal and instead fly to Saudi Arabia, where he will meet with the late King Abdullah’s successor, White House officials said Saturday.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — President Obama has decided to cut short his planned three-day trip to India and visit Saudi Arabia, where he will pay his respects to the royal family after the death of King Abdullah and meet with the king’s successor, White House officials said Saturday.

headline: 27 Are Killed by Rockets in Ukraine
abstract: Rockets struck homes and a market in the Azov Sea port city of Mariupol on Saturday, the latest indication that the war has flared up again in eastern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — A barrage of rockets struck homes and a market in the Azov Sea port city of Mariupol in eastern Ukraine on Saturday, killing 27 people and wounding 97 others, the Interior Ministry said.

headline: Sundance 2015: Documentaries Suddenly Made Timely
abstract: News events have made four nonfiction entries in the festival very relevant.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah – If timing is everything, then four documentary filmmakers are about to have a very good run in this resort town.

headline: In Africa, Mosquito Nets Are Putting Fish at Risk
abstract: Across the continent, mosquito-net fishing is an unintended consequence of a campaign to eradicate malaria.

headline: A Tragic Choice: Fight Malaria or Starve
abstract: Millions of mosquito nets are given out fight to malaria in Africa, yet many faced with hunger use them as fish nets, creating potential environmental problems.
lead_paragraph: Millions of mosquito nets are given out fight to malaria in Africa, yet many faced with hunger use them as fish nets, creating potential environmental problems.

headline: Meant to Keep Malaria Out, Mosquito Nets Are Used to Haul Fish In
abstract: The nets, with holes smaller than mosquitoes, trap much more than traditional fishing nets do and could wipe out stressed fish populations in Africa.

lead_paragraph: As a job seeker at the vice president or director level, I have noticed that almost every application process includes at least some online component. But in my most recent search, I am starting to wonder about privacy protection.

headline: Rifts Between U.S. and Nigeria Impeding Fight Against Boko Haram
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The militants are charging through northern Nigeria, razing villages, abducting children and forcing tens of thousands of people to flee.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Relations between American military trainers and specialists advising the Nigerian military in the fight against Boko Haram are so strained that the Pentagon often bypasses the Nigerians altogether, choosing to work instead with security officials in the neighboring countries of Chad, Cameroon and Niger, according to defense officials and diplomats.

headline: One Couple’s Unanticipated Journey to Center of Landmark Gay Rights Case
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'States (US)', 'Child Custody and Support', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: April DeBoer and Jayne Rowse of Hazel Park, Mich., were concerned about custody of their children if either parent died. Their efforts have evolved into a Supreme Court challenge of state bans on same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: HAZEL PARK, Mich. — On a snowy night in 2011, April DeBoer, Jayne Rowse and their three children were driving in their minivan down a rural road when a truck, attempting to pass another vehicle, came barreling toward them.

lead_paragraph: In the criminal complaint against Sheldon Silver, he is identified simply as “Doctor-1.”

headline: New to U.S., Sisters Help School Return to Dominance in a Flash
abstract: Thanks to two sisters from Mexico, the tradition-rich Levelland High School girls’ basketball team, which has not won a Texas state title since 1997, is an up-tempo, high-scoring contender.
lead_paragraph: LEVELLAND, Tex. — A large sign greets visitors to this small, windswept city in West Texas. Planted on the side of State Highway 114, about 30 miles west of Lubbock, beyond the oil rigs that rise from fallow cotton fields, the sign has borne the brunt of harsh winters and searing summers.

headline: Experts See Signs of Moderation Despite Houthis’ Harsh Slogans
abstract: Experts and analysts say it would be premature to dismiss the Houthis as Yemen’s Hezbollah, despite their alliance with Iran.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — At first glance the official slogan and emblem of the Houthis, who are now the dominant force in Yemen, does not offer much hope to American policy makers.

headline: What We’re Watching: Sunday Shows
abstract: The turmoil in the Middle East will dominate the conversations on the Sunday shows.
lead_paragraph: The Yemeni president, prime minister and cabinet all resigned on Friday, but rebel militia leaders have not made an official claim of power. In Saudi Arabia, King Abdullah died, and was succeeded by his half brother, Salman. This turmoil in the Middle East will dominate conversations on the Sunday shows, when Denis McDonough, the White House chief of staff, will discuss the administration’s foreign policy. He will appear on all five network shows.

headline: An Uncertain Future for Dodd-Frank
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Editorials', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Weak rules, political setbacks and budget constraints threaten proper implementation of the law.
lead_paragraph: There have been powerful reminders in recent days that the financial system needs more regulatory vigilance, not less. But they come just as Republicans are setting their agenda in Congress, complete with vows to weaken the Dodd-Frank reform law.

headline: De Blasio, Obama and a Flawed Vision of Liberalism
abstract: The mayor favored identity groups over economic populism.
lead_paragraph: MAYOR BILL DE BLASIO recently got some good news in his standoff with the Police Department. In the first major poll conducted after the high-profile murder of two patrolmen, 69 percent of New Yorkers said they objected to police officers’ turning their backs on the mayor at their colleagues’ funerals, while 77 percent rejected a union boss’s accusation that the mayor shared blame for the deaths. Over all, more than half of New Yorkers said that they believed that discipline had “broken down” among police.

headline: Climate and Our Future
abstract: Readers discuss the peril that global warming poses for life on earth, and what can be done.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss the peril that global warming poses for life on earth, and what can be done.

headline: What’s Worse Than Sad
keywords: ['English Language', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Terrorism', 'Books and Literature', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: We toss the term around carelessly, but tragedy should teach us something.
lead_paragraph: EVERY news broadcaster, commentator and writer has proclaimed the massacre of the French satirical cartoonists and editorialists to be a tragedy. And perhaps it was. But then, so we are told, was the death of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo.

headline: How Auschwitz Is Misunderstood
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Concentration Camps', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Emphasizing its technological aspects overlooks its true significance.
lead_paragraph: AUSCHWITZ was liberated 70 years ago, on Jan. 27, 1945, and news of its existence shocked the world. With its principal killing center at one of its main camps, Auschwitz-Birkenau, becoming fully operational in 1942, it was Germany’s largest and the most notorious extermination site. There the Germans slaughtered approximately 1.1 million people, a million of whom were Jews. Its mention evokes notions of evil and instant horror. Auschwitz was a death factory, an oxymoron that would have made no sense before the Holocaust, but that now is effortlessly comprehensible.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Running for Daylight (Obama, Not Brady)
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Buoyant in defeat, President Obama ascends to the mountaintop to throw thunderbolts at Republicans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE talk up in Boston is all about deflation while the talk down here is all about inflation.

headline: The Growing Shadow of Political Money
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Editorials', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: Toxic campaign spending has been on the rise, and not only because of Citizens United. But needed reforms are going nowhere.
lead_paragraph: Like bettors checking Las Vegas odds on the Super Bowl, specialists in the nation’s booming campaign finance industry are tracking the action in the 2016 elections, not so much to assess the candidates as to see how much of a payout is likely this time around in the grand casino of American politics.

headline: Be Fruitful, Not Bananas
abstract: St. Francis was said to preach to birds. Pope Francis just said the darnedest thing about bunnies.
lead_paragraph: MY mother always believed that when you signed up for a regimen, you owed it your best shot.

headline: Generous Republican Benefits

abstract: The G.O.P. should help all parents, not just its own.
lead_paragraph: LAST week, President Obama signed a memorandum that would allow employees at federal agencies to take up to six weeks of paid parental leave, and he has made it clear that he thinks Congress should extend paid leave to employees in the private sector, too.

headline: When Calculus of Loss Doesn’t Add Up
abstract: What makes one atrocity more newsworthy than another? An attack in Paris that was covered heavily, and one in Nigeria that got less attention, raise the question anew.
lead_paragraph: IF you start from the premise that every human life is of equal importance, then the judgments of news organizations will often be confounding.

headline: Prisoners of the Saudis
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: A monarch is dead, but our relationship with his gangster family is not.
lead_paragraph: THE Western response to the death of Abdullah bin Abdul Aziz al-Saud, king of Saudi Arabia and custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, followed two paths. Along one, various officials and luminaries offered the gestures — half-mast flags, public obsequies — expected when a great statesman enters the hereafter. John Kerry described the late monarch as “a man of wisdom and vision” and a “revered leader.” Tony Blair called him a “modernizer of his country” and a “staunch advocate of interfaith relations,” who was “loved by his people and will be deeply missed.”

headline: Nazanin Boniadi
abstract: The actress on Amnesty International, Dire Straits and dark chocolate.
lead_paragraph: Nazanin Boniadi is an Iranian-born actress best known for her role as the C.I.A. analyst Fara Sherazi on the television series “Homeland.” She has been cast as Esther in the remake of the film “Ben-Hur.”

headline: Shifting Realities in Syria
abstract: The greater threat is the Islamic State, not President Bashar al-Assad. America will have to live with him, at least for now.
lead_paragraph: As recently as October, Secretary of State John Kerry argued that there will never be peace in Syria as long as President Bashar al-Assad “remains the focus of power” there. Even now, American officials continue to insist that any lasting political solution will require Mr. Assad’s exit. But the unsettling truth is that the brutal dictator is still clinging to power and the United States and its allies are going to have to live with him, at least for now.

headline: Where’s the Empathy?
abstract: My old running buddy Kevin couldn’t get a good job. Now he’s dead at age 54.
lead_paragraph: YAMHILL, Ore. — THE funeral for my high school buddy Kevin Green is Saturday, near this town where we both grew up.

headline: Adding Innovations, the Pro Bowl is Trying to Be Relevant. Stop Laughing.
abstract: The N.F.L. has come up with changes to the format of the Pro Bowl to keep fans interested in a game that has been akin to a pickup game.
lead_paragraph: Given the N.F.L.’s obsession with rules, protocols and procedures, the Pro Bowl is the equivalent of the league letting its hair down. Players chuckle with one another on the field, wear wacky uniforms and talk openly about how the game, which is often played in Hawaii, is a vacation.

abstract: “The Witch” proves a breakout despite trying to maintain an air of mystery.

keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: As President Obama visits India to improve the strained relationship between the two countries, some human rights groups hope their concerns are not swept under the rug.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A year after the arrest of an Indian diplomat accused of exploiting a domestic worker in New York ruptured relations, India and the United States have put the episode behind them, and President Obama arrived here Sunday to hail a new era of cooperation.

headline: For N.B.A. Teams, Nonentities on Offense Can Fill Important Roles
abstract: In his N.B.A. career Charles Jones had little to do on the offensive end of the court, but he unexpectedly played a key role in the Rockets’ 1995 championship run.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks have won each of the three games the well-traveled Lou Amundson has started, but not because of anything he is doing on offense. In Friday night’s win over the Orlando Magic, Amundson took a pass from Tim Hardaway Jr. and dunked it for his only 2 points of the game.

headline: Sundance 2015: Duplass Brothers, Netflix Make a Deal
abstract: The pact calls for the Internet company to finance four films by the siblings.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah – Jay and Mark Duplass have so many projects going that at least among some Sundance festivalgoers here, their hyper-productivity is becoming a bit of a punch line.

headline: Moments in Time With Schubert
abstract: A program at the 92nd Street Y offers works by Schubert and by contemporary composers he influenced.
lead_paragraph: Schubert’s music, in which a single moment can blissfully expand into a spacious, contemplative arc, offers an ideal forum to explore the concept of time. When devising the program for his two coming concerts at the 92nd Street Y, the pianist Shai Wosner was inspired by differing notions of time — comparing the multitasking, contemporary 140-character attention span with Schubert’s era, when a seven-minute piece was deemed short.

headline: The Meaning of Being Alone
abstract: Five performers offer kinetic explorations, both subtle and athletic, of what it means to be alone.
lead_paragraph: In “Solitudes solo,” the Montreal choreographer Daniel Léveillé highlights five performers — Mathieu Campeau, Esther Gaudette, Justin Gionet, Jason Martin and Emmanuel Proulx — who offer kinetic explorations, both subtle and athletic, of what it means to be alone. This grouping of spare, elegant dances, performed in silence and to Bach, also introduces a new performance series at Abrons Arts Center: Travelogues, organized by Laurie Uprichard, formerly the director of Danspace Project and the Dublin Dance Festival. During Ms. Uprichard’s tenure at Danspace Project, Mr. Léveillé’s unadorned choreography was regularly on display; his 2012 production, which features Marc Parent’s austere lighting, is a chance to revisit Mr. Léveillé’s unaffected choreographic voice. The series will continue in May with a shared program by Kimberly Bartosik and Dylan Crossman, as well as in October with separate engagements by the Irish company ponydance and the Los Angeles choreographer Lionel Popkin.   (Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m., Sunday at 3 p.m., Abrons Arts Center, 466 Grand Street, at Pitt Street, Lower East Side; 212-352-3101, abronsartscenter.org).

headline: Run the Jewels to Join Jack White
abstract: Remember when Jack White used to hate hip-hop? It was 2003 — more innocent, genre-segregated times! — when he gave an interview to Rolling Stone and more or less tried to bury the whole genre. Rock purists cheered; most everyone else shrugged and sighed. He’s made tentative steps toward reconciliation over the years, but maybe none as convincing as inviting the agit-noise post-backpack rap duo Run the Jewels to open for him Friday at Madison Square Garden. Granted, Run the Jewels — the partnership of Killer Mike and El-P — are a favorite of those who might malign hip-hop’s center. But there will be no mistaking, once they’re on stage, their bona fides. And like Mr. White, they’re brash and not terribly concerned with who they step on with their words. (Friday at 8 p.m. at Madison Square Garden; thegarden.com.)

headline: A Buddy Movie, With a Crime Spree
abstract: Just what makes Ridley Scott’s 1991 feminist neo-western “Thelma & Louise” so timeless? Find out Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Just what elements make Ridley Scott’s 1991 feminist neo-western “Thelma & Louise” so timeless? For one thing, its unfaded relevance. But you can find out on Thursday at the Chelsea Cinemas, where the drag queen Hedda Lettuce is to introduce the film — about two modern-day outlaws (Susan Sarandon and Geena Davis) on the run after killing a would-be rapist — as part of her classics series. Certainly, there are the gorgeous desert vistas shot by the cinematographer Adrian Biddle. And the leading actresses, both at career peaks. And, as a seductive sociopath, a young Brad Pitt, arriving at stardom fully formed, like a he-Venus on the half-shell.

abstract: “Suits” has long been an underrated guilty pleasure, and is back for Season 4.

headline: As Vatican Revisits Divorce, Many Catholics Long for Acceptance
abstract: Pope Francis has begun a debate about the church’s treatment of divorced Catholics, and in October, a group of bishops will decide whether to recommend changes to him.
lead_paragraph: Mark Garren does not take communion when he goes to church. Sometimes he walks up to the priest, crosses his arms over his chest and touches his shoulders to signal that he is seeking a blessing. More often, mindful of his divorce years ago, Mr. Garren, a 64-year-old Illinoisan, remains in his pew, watching with slight embarrassment as the rest of the row moves to the front of the church.

headline: North Korea’s Forbidden Love? Smuggled, Illegal Soap Operas
abstract: Despite a crackdown on smugglers, South Korean soap operas are sneaking visions of a comfortable lifestyle into North Korea, causing some to defect.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — As a math professor in North Korea, Jang Se-yul was among the nation’s relatively privileged classes; he got to sit in special seats in restaurants and on crowded trains, and more important in a country where many go hungry, was given priority for government food rations. Then he risked it all — for a soap opera from South Korea.

lead_paragraph: His green raincoat pulled tight against the wet morning cold, Antonio Ciccarello, a Midtown Manhattan porter known as Tony, trudged through the Lower East Side on his way to work near Times Square.

headline: Belgium Confronts the Jihadist Danger Within
abstract: The recent thwarting of a terrorist operation highlights the dangers posed by a well-developed underground pipeline that has made Belgium the biggest per capita contributor in Europe of fighters to Syria.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — When Abdelhamid Abaaoud, the Belgian-born son of an immigrant shopkeeper from Morocco, went to Syria a year ago to wage jihad, nobody paid much attention. He was just one of more than two dozen angry young men from the grimy Molenbeek district in Brussels who, lured by the promise of adventure and reward from God, have taken up the fight for Islam.

headline: Joe Franklin, a Talk Show Institution in New York, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Franklin, a pioneer of local talk shows, was on the air in New York from 1951 to 1993 as the host of a compellingly low-rent parade of has-beens and yet-to-bes.
lead_paragraph: Joe Franklin, who became a New York institution by presiding over one of the most compellingly low-rent television programs in history, one that even he acknowledged was an oddly long-running parade of has-beens and yet-to-bes interrupted from time to time by surprisingly famous guests, died on Saturday in a hospice in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: When Mango Mania Was Revolutionary
abstract: Mango madness pervaded Chinese culture in 1968.
lead_paragraph: In 1968, two years after he began the Cultural Revolution, Mao Zedong wrested it from the hands of avid but unruly students and handed it over to a more worshipful working class. During the transition, he happened to receive, as an ambassadorial gift from Pakistan, a basket of fresh mangoes. And as a symbolic act of largess, he had the exotic fruit delivered to a group of workers. In doing so, he created an instant cult. Not only was the fruit not eaten, but it was also revered as an emblem of the leader’s godlike love. The mangoes were preserved and became objects of worship. Wax and plastic duplicates were created and enshrined. Mango madness pervaded the culture: Images of the yellow fruit appeared in posters, on porcelain and in textile designs. “Mao’s Golden Mangoes and the Cultural Revolution,” a China Institute exhibition organized by the art historian Alfreda Murck, perfectly captures the devotional fervor of that moment. And a mere moment it was. Within a year, the fad was over. Mango memorabilia went into closets and then to flea markets, from which Ms. Murck, who lived many years in Beijing, rescued choice examples to tell this fascinating tale of consumerist infatuation. (Through April 26, 125 East 65th Street, 212-744-8181, chinainstitute.org.)

headline: What’s on TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (History) SONS OF LIBERTY This fictionalized prequel to the American Revolution follows hunkier, more youthful versions of the founding fathers — Sam Adams (Ben Barnes), John Hancock (Rafe Spall), John Adams (Henry Thomas), Dr. Joseph Warren (Ryan Eggold) and Paul Revere (Michael Raymond-James) — as they lead the revolt against the British crown. “ 'Sons of Liberty’ is fun and engaging, a better option than a much more ambitious, highfalutin series on AMC last year, ‘Turn,’ which followed a ring of spies working for Gen. lead_paragraph: LONDON — In his many victories coaching teams in four countries, we have too often seen the arrogant side of José Mourinho. A bigger, more humble Mourinho emerged Saturday after the most shocking defeat of his coaching career.

headline: Tech Giants Invest in New Dreams of Grandeur
abstract: A series of investments by some of the tech industry’s biggest companies may sound odd, but they point to larger ambitions in moving giant amounts of data.
lead_paragraph: In the last two weeks, investments from some of the biggest technology companies have raised an important question: Have they gone crazy?

headline: Greece Chooses Anti-Austerity Party in Major Shift
abstract: Syriza’s victory, which positions Alexis Tsipras as prime minister, comes as Europe’s economic crisis has stirred populist anger.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Greece rejected the harsh economics of austerity on Sunday and sent a warning to the rest of Europe as the left-wing Syriza party won a decisive victory in national elections, positioning its tough-talking leader, Alexis Tsipras, to become the next prime minister.

headline: In Bold Push Forward, Islamist Militants Attack a Major Nigerian City
abstract: Maiduguri, the major city in Nigeria’s northeast, was attacked from at least two directions by the Islamist militants, and initial reports suggested that casualties were substantial.
lead_paragraph: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — Maiduguri, the major city in Nigeria’s northeast, came under sustained attack from Boko Haram terrorists on Sunday, and officials here called it the group’s most audacious assault on the city to date.

headline: ‘Birdman’ Takes Producers Guild Award
abstract: The film beats out “Boyhood” for an award that is seen as a predictor of the best picture Oscar.
lead_paragraph: In something of a surprise, “Birdman” captured the Producers Guild equivalent of best picture on Saturday, beating out another awards-season front-runner, “Boyhood.”

headline: Rebels Tied to Blackout Across Most of Pakistan
abstract: Even with a partial restoration of power in the capital, Islamabad, and the most populous city, Karachi, 80 percent of the country remained without power after an apparent militant attack.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Towns and cities across Pakistan plunged into darkness early Sunday when what officials said was an attack by militants on a transmission line short-circuited the national electricity grid, presenting a new indictment of the government’s faltering efforts to solve the country’s chronic power crisis.

headline: Kerry Meets With Nigerian Leaders to Encourage Peaceful Election
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Lagos hoping to encourage an orderly vote amid the continuing fight against the militant group Boko Haram.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — Concerned that Nigeria could face postelection turmoil, Secretary of State John Kerry on Sunday urged President Goodluck Jonathan and his principal political rival to respect the results of next month’s presidential vote and to discourage their supporters from carrying out violent protests.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — After weeks of political wrangling and tension, Edgar Lungu was sworn in on Sunday as Zambia’s new president, overcoming a close political challenge and divisions within his own Patriotic Front party to secure a narrow majority in an election called after the death of his predecessor in October.

headline: From Inside Prison, a Terrorism Suspect Shares His Diary
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Detainees', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Mohamedou Ould Slahi’s memoir, “Guantánamo Diary,” was published after a seven-year legal battle and with heavy redactions from military censors.
lead_paragraph: There’s a revealing moment in Mohamedou Ould Slahi’s gripping and depressing “Guantánamo Diary” when a new interrogator is assigned to question him. By this point, Mr. Slahi has been asked the same questions and given the same answers for years. But the new military interrogator, a woman he describes as “quiet and polite,” surprises him with a novel inquiry about what he knows of another terrorism suspect’s travel to Iraq in 2003.

headline: A Pianist, Duly Smitten, Mines a Prolific Master
abstract: Jonathan Biss’s recital on Saturday delved deeply into Beethoven, the subject of a recording series by Mr. Biss.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Biss has become an authority on Beethoven. First there was “Beethoven’s Shadow,” an eloquent volume on his relationship with that composer’s music that would be slim if it were available for more than your Kindle. A volume of his ongoing recording series of the complete sonatas has emerged every year of the past few, and the fourth is out this week on his new label, JB Recordings. And his innovative online course, in association with Coursera and the Curtis Institute, is in its third season. So far, over 60,000 students have learned about everything from expositions and recapitulations to the metaphysics of slow movements.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Clippers at Spurs
abstract: San Antonio and Los Angeles each got off to a bumpier start than expected. The Spurs can blame Kawhi Leonard’s absence. The Clippers have no such excuse.
lead_paragraph: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

abstract: Films with something to prove have their premieres.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah – Three movies, each with something to prove, or at least a question to answer, had back-to-back premieres on Saturday night at Sundance.

headline: An Unblinking Look at Sexual Assaults on Campus
keywords: ['Movies', 'Sex Crimes', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'College Athletics', 'Football']
abstract: “The Hunting Ground,” a documentary about sexual assaults on college campuses, drew gasps at a Sundance Film Festival viewing.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — “The Hunting Ground,” set for release in theaters and broadcast on CNN, was billed by the Sundance Film Festival as a “piercing, monumental exposé of rape culture on campuses.” Judging by viewer reaction at the film’s premiere and the comments of two United States senators afterward, festival programmers might have undersold it.

headline: A Valiant Cub Goes on the Hunt
abstract: Set in a dystopian future in which corporations are more powerful than governments, “Lionboy” focuses on a young hero who comes home one day to find that his parents have disappeared.
lead_paragraph: The Disney feline that has bestrode Broadway for well over a decade has a lot going for it, obviously, but at “Lionboy,” playing a few blocks south at the New Victory Theater on West 42nd Street, the audience gets to do something it doesn’t at “The Lion King,” namely let out a big, gutsy roar in the middle of the show.

headline: Moving, Sometimes at a Snail’s Pace, to Music and Shakespeare
abstract: The choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker’s new “Golden Hours” is loosely structured around Shakespeare’s “As You Like It” and set to music by Brian Eno.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — There is a lot riding on Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker’s new “Golden Hours (As you like it),” set to music by Brian Eno, which opened at the Kaaitheater here on Friday. In December, the Brussels opera house, the Théâtre Royal de la Monnaie, which co-produced the work, and with which Ms. De Keersmaeker has had a 23-year association, announced it would have to remove all dance from its programming if projected budget cuts by the federal government go ahead.

headline: A Rising Star and a Master, Inspiring Each Other
abstract: Daniil Trifonov, the young Russian pianist hailed for his technique, joined the Latvian violinist Gidon Kremer for a duo recital at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: In a way, by joining the esteemed Latvian violinist Gidon Kremer for a duo recital at Carnegie Hall on Friday, the dazzling Russian pianist Daniil Trifonov was taking a bigger risk than when he played all of Liszt’s torturously difficult “Transcendental Études” in a recital last month on the same stage.

headline: Recalling a Film From the Liberation of the Camps
abstract: In 1945, filmmakers accompanied Allied troops as they liberated concentration camps. The documentary “Night Will Fall” samples their footage and offers eyewitness accounts.
lead_paragraph: The HBO documentary “Night Will Fall” is a movie about the Holocaust, a movie about remembering the Holocaust and primarily, at least in formal terms, a movie about a movie. It may not do full justice to all these subjects in its tight 78 minutes, but it’s not a film you’re likely to forget.

lead_paragraph: An armed employee walked into a Manhattan Home Depot on Sunday and fatally shot his manager before killing himself amid scores of horrified colleagues and shoppers, the authorities said.
