headline: It’s a Picture That’s Worth a Thousand Triumphs
abstract: Mike Krzyzewski, who already had the mark for wins by an N.C.A.A. Division I men’s coach, reached a milestone as the freshman Jahlil Okafor helped the Blue Devils rally against St. John’s.
lead_paragraph: No record was at stake Sunday afternoon. Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski had already taken care of that, eclipsing Bob Knight’s mark for wins by an N.C.A.A. Division I men’s basketball coach, 902, in 2011 and chugging steadily onward.

headline: Larry David Racks Up a Big Broadway Advance
abstract: Larry David’s stage debut, “Fish in the Dark,” has set a Broadway record for advance ticket sales for a play.
lead_paragraph: Larry David’s stage debut, “Fish in the Dark,” has set a Broadway record for advance ticket sales for a play before performances begin, taking in $13.5 million. It’s an extraordinary number driven by audience demand and a willingness to pay high ticket prices of up to $425, an amount that few plays have charged before. Plays with popular stars (Bradley Cooper in “The Elephant Man,” Bryan Cranston in “All the Way”) often have advance sales of several million dollars, while even many musicals — which tend to be bigger sellers than plays — often struggle to build an eight-figure advance. A spokesman for the play’s lead producer, Scott Rudin, confirmed the figure on Sunday. It beats the previous record for a play, $13.05 million for the 2013 revival of Harold Pinter’s “Betrayal,” another Rudin production, starring the real-life couple Daniel Craig and Rachel Weisz. Mr. David (above) is widely known as the star of HBO’s “Curb Your Enthusiasm” and co-creator and head writer of “Seinfeld.” He is both the author and star of “Fish in the Dark,” his first play, a comedy about a death in the family. “Fish in the Dark,” directed by Anna D. Shapiro (a Tony winner for “August: Osage County”), is scheduled to begin performances on Feb. 2 at the Cort Theater.

headline: Fallen Journalist Finds Solace and Success in Poetry
abstract: Patricia Smith, an award-winning poet and English professor, has moved past her troubled career as a journalist and found a new life in verse.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, the words come to her on the Garden State Parkway or on the Outerbridge Crossing, snippets of verse that capture a flash of light, an eruption of color, a piercing cry.

headline: Evolution for Libraries in Brooklyn
keywords: ['Libraries and Librarians', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Mixed-Use Developments', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: Proposals to sell and develop library sites in Brooklyn are being met with the usual arguments, but the plans actually look promising.
lead_paragraph: Two proposals to sell and develop local library sites are wending through the Brooklyn Public Library pipeline, and, predictably, opponents have manned the barricades, citing the usual arguments about selling off public land to rapacious developers.

headline: Distilling Japanese Sound From a Varied Catalog
abstract: Focus! Festival by the New Juilliard Ensemble and conducted by Joel Sachs features works of contemporary Japanese music since 1945.
lead_paragraph: Chinese contemporary music has attained considerable visibility and influence in the West in recent decades. Chinese-born composers, some of them scarred by the Cultural Revolution, have made major inroads in the classical music scene in the United States and elsewhere.

headline: A Choreographer Who Wrote and Drew
abstract: “Remy Charlip: I Love You,” at the 92nd Street Y, celebrated a beloved choreographer and children’s book author who died in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Whether or not you personally knew Remy Charlip, the choreographer and children’s book author who died in 2012 at 83, he’s easy to love. On Friday, as part of its Fridays at Noon series, the 92nd Street Y presented “Remy Charlip: I Love You,” a program of readings, performances and film screenings commemorating his whimsical life and work.

headline: Verizon’s Mobile ‘Supercookies’ Seen as Threat to Privacy
keywords: ['Privacy', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Wireless Communications', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: Advertisers, and possibly other third parties, are finding ways to exploit a hidden tracking mechanism that Verizon Wireless users cannot delete.
lead_paragraph: For the last several months, cybersecurity experts have been warning Verizon Wireless that it was putting the privacy of its customers at risk. The computer codes the company uses to tag and follow its mobile subscribers around the web, they said, could make those consumers vulnerable to covert tracking and profiling.

headline: Live Arts Aims High
abstract: The lineup of music, dance, lectures and film screenings is set for the 2015 Live Ideas Festival, organizers said on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The lineup of music, dance, lectures and film screenings is set for the 2015 Live Ideas Festival, organizers said on Sunday. This multidisciplinary festival of arts and ideas was founded in 2013 by New York Live Arts, a Chelsea group. Each year has a different theme, with previous festivals focusing on the works of the neurologist Oliver Sacks and the playwright and author James Baldwin. This year’s edition, assembled by the visual artist and performer Laurie Anderson, is themed “S K Y — Force and Wisdom in America Today.” “The sky — a multidimensional symbol of aspiration, vastness, change, threat and now information storage — is a fitting image for this year’s festival,” Bill T. Jones, New York Live Arts’ artistic director, said in a statement. Highlights of the festival, taking place April 15-19, include a new commission by the Bessie Award-winning choreographer Beth Gill and screenings of films by Julian Schnabel. Tickets range from free to $65. Information is at newyorklivearts.org.

headline: Six Urban Characters in Search of a Retreat
abstract: A new play about six strangers who leave the city for a silent retreat in the woods will open the 2015 season at the Manhattan nonprofit Ars Nova.
lead_paragraph: A new play about six strangers who leave the city for a silent retreat in the woods will open the 2015 season at the Manhattan nonprofit Ars Nova, organizers said on Sunday. The production, “Small Mouth Sounds,” by Bess Wohl (“American Hero”), is directed by Rachel Chavkin (“Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812”) and developed through Ars Nova’s Play Group. It opens March 10 and runs through April 11. Other season highlights include “Bridget Everett” (the full title is unprintable) ” (April 9), a concert by the alt-cabaret performer Bridget Everett and various Ars Nova emerging artists; and the annual ANT Fest in June. Fall will bring “Futurity,” a new musical with book and lyrics by César Alvarez.

headline: New Beginning
abstract: Ian Livengood starts off our solving week.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — If you ever have the opportunity to meet Ian Livengood in person, you might note his quiet demeanor, his friendly smile, his self-deprecating sense of humor. It’s not until you get to know him a lot better that the FRESH part of him starts to emerge, and when that happens, I advise you to run like heck. Or have a beer with him, which is much more fun.

headline: Greek Leftists Adopt Patti Smith Anthem ‘People Have the Power’ as Their Own
abstract: An American rock song has become something of an unofficial anthem for Greek populists.
lead_paragraph: Two minutes after the polls closed in Greece on Sunday night, activists for the left-wing Syriza party celebrated projections of a decisive victory by posting a link on Twitter to “People Have the Power,” a song by the American poet and singer Patti Smith that has become something of an unofficial anthem for the populist movement.

lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Sunday that the storm approaching on Monday was likely to be one of the biggest to ever strike New York City, and he urged people to stay indoors to avoid powerful winds, low visibility and “treacherous” road conditions.

headline: British Start-Up TransferWise Raises $58 Million

headline: Bloomberg Shakes Up Newsroom Side of His Company

lead_paragraph: Things have changed at Bloomberg since its founder, Michael R. Bloomberg, returned to the office.

headline: Unease for What Microsoft’s HoloLens Will Mean for Our Screen-Obsessed Lives
abstract: Something about Microsoft’s new HoloLens technology feels unnerving, especially when considered against the dark television series “Black Mirror.”
lead_paragraph: Microsoft made a big announcement last week, revealing that Windows, a lucrative legacy franchise, was about to be unleashed into the physical environment through a set of goggles called the HoloLens that superimposes the operating system on the actual world. In one sense, it was heartening. Business reporters are frequently hung up on the new and the insurgent, but seeing mature companies adapt to a changed world is equally interesting.

headline: Chitresh Das, Influential Performer and Educator of Indian Dance, Dies at 70
abstract: Mr. Das helped popularize kathak, one of the most prominent forms of classical Indian dance and the only one that has roots in both Muslim and Hindu traditions.
lead_paragraph: Chitresh Das, a teacher and performer who widely disseminated the north Indian classical dance form kathak in the United States, died on Jan. 4 in San Rafael, Calif. He was 70.

headline: Navajo Heavy Metal
abstract: In addition to playing in a heavy metal band with his son, Darius, Edmund Yazzie is also a delegate to the Navajo legislature.
lead_paragraph: In addition to playing in a heavy metal band with his son, Darius, Edmund Yazzie is also a delegate to the Navajo legislature.

headline: Navajo ‘Rez Metal’
abstract: A veteran lawmaker spends his days in meetings with the Navajo Nation Council and his nights behind a drum set.
lead_paragraph: A veteran lawmaker spends his days in meetings with the Navajo Nation Council and his nights behind a drum set.

headline: Looking to Uplift, With Navajo ‘Rez Metal’
abstract: As a veteran lawmaker on the Navajo reservation, Edmund Yazzie is an integral part of the establishment. He is also the drummer for the metal band Testify.
lead_paragraph: FARMINGTON, N.M. — Edmund Yazzie is not the type of guy you expect to see at a heavy metal concert. He is 46, well past the age of youthful angst. As a veteran lawmaker on the Navajo reservation, he is also an integral part of the establishment, known for his starched shirts, polite manner and ardent anti-marijuana stance.

headline: Two Japanese Hostages, as Different as Can Be, Linked by Fate in Syria
abstract: The surviving hostage is a respected journalist, while the other man was a lost soul who had attempted suicide and seemed to become unhinged by setbacks in life.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In the public’s mind, the two Japanese hostages held by Islamic State militants have become inextricably linked: a pair of grim-faced figures who appeared last week in a video kneeling in orange jumpsuits next to a masked militant demanding a ransom for their lives.

headline: Worry for Solar Projects After End of Tax Credits
keywords: ['Solar Energy', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: New solar-plant technology can store and use the sun’s heat for energy even after sunset, but the coming expiration of federal tax credits has put further construction of such facilities in doubt.
lead_paragraph: For more than a year now, an enormous solar thermal power plant has been humming along in the Arizona desert, sending out power as needed, even well after sunset. The plant, called Solana, was developed by the Spanish energy and technology company Abengoa and has succeeded in meeting an elusive solar goal — producing electricity when the sun is not shining — and displacing fossil-fuel-based power in the grid.

headline: For Olympic Hopefuls, Antidoping Rules Will Be an Adjustment
abstract: In advance of golf’s return to the Olympics next year in Rio de Janeiro, the antidoping program golfers are set to join is considerably less predictable and more invasive.
lead_paragraph: After closing with a 62 at the Tournament of Champions this month, Chris Kirk showed up at the site of his next start and learned he had been randomly selected for out-of-competition testing as part of the PGA Tour’s antidoping program.

headline: Defense in Long-Awaited Trial Will Argue Another Man Killed Etan Patz
abstract: For years after 6-year-old Etan Patz vanished in 1979, his family considered Jose A. Ramos to be the killer, but a different man, Pedro Hernandez, will be on trial.
lead_paragraph: He sits in a jail cell in Brooklyn, waiting for a trial that prosecutors promise will finally deliver justice for the murder of 6-year-old Etan Patz — a child-abduction case that panicked parents and gripped New York City through the summer of 1979.

headline: By Blocking View of the Brooklyn Bridge, a Building Incites a Battle

abstract: A development in Brooklyn Bridge Park has affected the view of the Brooklyn Bridge from the Brooklyn Heights Promenade, causing controversy in the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: To many people, it might not make much difference. Looking toward the Brooklyn Bridge from a point on the Brooklyn Heights Promenade roughly between Clark and Pierrepont Streets, pedestrians used to be able to watch cars flow along the bridge’s roadbed, and see the Chrysler Building behind the bridge’s intricate web of cables.

headline: Uneven Progress for 3 Chicagoans Janet Yellen Held Up as Symbols

headline: ‘Mass Mob’ Fills a Manhattan Church With Hopes of Saving It

headline: W.H.O. Members Endorse Resolution to Improve Response to Health Emergencies

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) DIRECTED BY LUIS BUÑUEL This five-film tribute to Buñuel (1900-1983), known as the father of Surrealist cinema, begins with “Belle de Jour” (1968), starring Catherine Deneuve (above right, with Geneviève Page) as a frigid young housewife able to achieve sexual satisfaction only after becoming a prostitute. Writing in The New York Times, Renata Adler called “Belle de Jour” “a really beautiful movie, and somehow, letting the color in — this is Buñuel’s first color film — has changed the emotional quality of his obsessions in a completely unpredictable way.” In “The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie” (1972), an Oscar-winner for best foreign film, at 10, six upwardly mobile friends try to have dinner together — but find they can’t. “In addition to being extraordinarily funny and perfectly acted,” Vincent Canby wrote, “ ‘The Discreet Charm’ moves with the breathtaking speed and self-assurance that only a man of Buñuel’s experience can achieve without resorting to awkward ellipsis.” The lineup continues with “Diary of a Chambermaid” (1964), an adaptation of the novel by Octave Mirbeau about the foibles and hypocrisy of the landed gentry as seen through the eyes of a worldly domestic (Jeanne Moreau), at midnight; “Viridiana” (1962), in which a young nun (Silvia Pinal) tries to help the poor after inheriting a fortune, at 2 a.m.; and “The Exterminating Angel” (1962), where guests at a lavish dinner party in an elegant home in Mexico City find themselves unable to leave the parlor for several days, during which the social order begins to break down, at 3:45.

According to Preet Bharara, the federal prosecutor who brought the charges, the once seemingly untouchable Mr. Silver took millions of dollars for legal work he did not do. In exchange, he used his official power to steer business to a law firm that specialized in getting tax breaks for real estate developers, and he directed state funds to a doctor who referred cases to another law firm that paid Mr. Silver fees.

headline: Spy Agency in Britain Falls Victim to a Prankster
abstract: An unidentified caller secured a private cellphone number for a top intelligence chief and apparently made a separate phone call to the prime minister in his name, British officials acknowledged.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — At a time when Western leaders are clamoring for greater powers to conduct covert surveillance, a prankster in Britain has turned the tables, obtaining a private cellphone number for a top intelligence chief and apparently telephoning the prime minister in his name, British officials acknowledged on Monday.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: Judgments are hardening about which Republican presidential hopefuls picked up momentum, and which didn’t, after this weekend’s Iowa Freedom Summit.
lead_paragraph: Winning Weekend in Iowa for Walker, Christie, Cruz and Fiorina

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 26, 2015
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why. A live discussion is offered from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Jan. 27, 2015

headline: Daily Report: Why Messaging Apps Are So Hot
abstract: People are spending more time on messaging apps, which many say allow for multimedia exchanges and commerce in a more intimate setting than on older social media sites.
lead_paragraph: Some publishers, game makers and e-commerce companies are using personal messaging apps like Instagram, WeChat and Snapchat as a new distribution and moneymaking platform, Mike Isaac and Michael J. de la Merced report.

headline: Democrats Set Record in 2014, in Fund-Raising Anyway
abstract: The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee raised more than $4 million after the party’s big losses in November. The total capped off a record year.
lead_paragraph: Democrats raised $4.1 million in December after their bruising losses in the midterm elections. That put their 2014 total at a record $131 million and helped them shave their debt to $10 million, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee said on Monday.

headline: Those Radical VSPs
abstract: Syriza is more mainstream than Brussels.
lead_paragraph: As we head for the big Greek face-off, Francesco Saraceno makes a point I’ve also made on a number of occasions: although many of the press reports describe Syriza as “far-left”, it’s actually preaching fairly conventional economics, while the supposedly responsible officials of Brussels and Berlin have been relying on radical doctrines like expansionary austerity and a growth cliff at 90 percent. The same has to a certain extent been true in the US context.

headline: Morning Agenda: U.S. Challenges Insider Trading Ruling
abstract: Federal prosecutors seek to reverse a crucial insider trading ruling. | Markets shake off Greek election results. | An obscure law has its day. | PartnerRe and Axis Capital Holdings agree to merge.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are seeking to reverse, or at least narrow, a crucial insider trading ruling that overturned the convictions of two hedge fund managers last month, DealBook’s Matthew Goldstein and Ben Protess report. Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, is asking the same three-judge panel that issued the ruling to revisit its decision, according to a filing on Friday. As an alternative, Mr. Bharara’s filing proposes the legal equivalent of a do-over in a process known as en banc.

headline: Internal Devaluation in Greece
abstract: It’s immensely costly, but the costs have been paid.
lead_paragraph: One point that seems relevant to talk about Grexit (Greek exit from the euro) and all that: at this point it’s not clear that Greece needs a big boost to competitiveness. “Internal devaluation” via falling wages is incredibly costly — but Greece has been paying incredible costs, and has achieved a sharp fall in relative wages:

headline: Perry Finds an Admiring Audience on the Road in Iowa
abstract: Former Gov. Rick Perry of Texas wasted no time after leaving office to make a presidential pitch to voters in Iowa.
lead_paragraph: Five days after leaving behind the pomp of the Texas governor’s office, Rick Perry stood before 30 Iowans at a Pizza Ranch in Indianola, Iowa, on Sunday trying to convince them that the humble mortal just inches away was fit to occupy the Oval Office.

headline: China to Force Authors to Provide Real Names When Publishing Online
keywords: ['Censorship', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Linking the offline identities of authors with their online writings, new guidelines say, will encourage writers to “better take responsibility” for their works and bolster “moral education and training.”
lead_paragraph: Zhou Shuren is widely regarded as one of China’s most influential 20th-century writers. But to most readers, he is known as Lu Xun, one of the more than 100 pen names the author used, often to evade the repercussions of provocative political views.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Journalist Who Reported on Argentine Prosecutor’s Death Flees to Israel
abstract: Damián Pachter, who broke the story of the death of an official investigating the bombing of a Jewish center, said he was being followed.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Damián Pachter, the first journalist to report the suspicious death of an Argentine prosecutor, has fled to Israel, saying that he feared for his life in Argentina.

headline: GrandVision Plans to Raise Up to $1.2 Billion in Amsterdam I.P.O.
abstract: The Dutch operator of Vision Express in Britain and Générale d’Optique in France said it expected to price its stock at €17.50 to €21.50 a share, valuing it at up to about $6 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – GrandVision, the Dutch operator of the optical retailers Vision Express in Britain and Générale d’Optique in France, plans to raise as much as 1.1 billion euros, or about $1.2 billion, in an initial public offering on Euronext in Amsterdam next month.

headline: Ocwen and Bondholders Clash Over Mortgage Services
abstract: Ocwen Financial is accusing a group of mortgage-bond investors of pushing for fast foreclosure and objecting to principal reductions on billions of dollars in mortgages.
lead_paragraph: The embattled subprime mortgage servicer Ocwen Financial is accusing a group of mortgage-bond investors of pushing for fast foreclosure and objecting to principal reductions on billions of dollars in mortgages.

headline: Saint-Gobain Suffers Setback in Bid for Control of Swiss Chemical Maker
abstract: Sika said that it would restrict the voting rights of the Burkhard family, which controls the company’s voting rights and has agreed to sell its controlling stake to the French conglomerate.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The French conglomerate Saint-Gobain suffered a setback on Monday in its bid to take control of Sika, the Swiss specialty chemical maker.

headline: Revisiting ‘Andrea Chénier’ at the Royal Opera House
abstract: A new production at Covent Garden in London attempts to give Umberto Giordano’s opera grandeur without the clutter.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Andrea Chénier” is one of those operas that most major companies do every 20 years or so: often enough for it to count as “repertory” but not for anyone to remember if it was worth the effort the last time around. And as the last Covent Garden staging was in fact 30 years ago — a generation past — it was a curious, inquisitive audience that came to Tuesday’s opening of a big new international production that is scheduled for Beijing and San Francisco after London.

headline: Shakeups in Best Picture and Best Actor Races
abstract: The SAG and Producers Guild awards over the weekend pushed “Birdman” to the fore, while Eddie Redmayne appears to be nosing ahead of Michael Keaton.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — As potential nominees for next year’s Oscars were making the rounds at Sundance, with the requisite publicists and strategists at their sides, this year’s race delivered a shakeup over the weekend, courtesy of the Producers Guild and Screen Actors Guild awards.

headline: New York City Is Spared the Worst Effects of Snowstorm
abstract: Although driving bans were in effect and transit was suspended, the dire warnings that it could be one of the worst blizzards in the city’s history failed to materialize.
lead_paragraph: For the latest on the winter storm affecting the New York region, click here.

headline: A Radio Host’s Strategy for Christie: Let Him Rant
abstract: First Draft sat down with the host of Gov. Chris Christie’s radio call-in program, Eric Scott, recently. What follows are edited excerpts from that conversation.
lead_paragraph: Over five years and 58 hours, Eric Scott has sat across the table from Gov. Chris Christie inside the studios of WKXW-FM (101.5), hosting a call-in program that captures the many moods of New Jersey’s mercurial chief executive.

headline: Blizzard Questions, Including Why a European Weather Model (Usually) Excels at U.S. Forecasts
abstract: Three questions about the great Northeast blizzard.
lead_paragraph: | Needless to say, there’s plenty of day-after cogitation and finger pointing over the New York side of snowfall forecasts, which the European model did poorly at — along with many meteorologists. Read Henry Fountain’s news story and Eric Holthaus’s great Slate piece on how only the Weather Channel got snow forecasts right.

headline: Packaging Giants RockTenn and MeadWestvaco to Merge
abstract: Together, the two will create a stronger competitor to International Paper, with a combined market value of about $16 billion.
lead_paragraph: Two big makers of packaging materials, RockTenn and MeadWestvaco, agreed on Monday to merge, creating a $16 billion manufacturer of cardboard cartons and other types of boxes.

headline: Kanye West Is a Visionary, and He Has a B.E.T. Award to Prove It
abstract: Mr. West was among those given B.E.T. Honors this weekend. Other award winners included Usher and Phylicia Rashad.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kanye West took home the Visionary Award at the B.E.T. Honors on Saturday during an evening of surprise freestyles at the Warner Theater near the White House.

headline: Scenes From India’s Republic Day Parade
abstract: President Obama and the first lady attended India’s Republic Day Parade on Monday and watched a grand display of military hardware, marching bands, helicopters and elaborately dressed camels.
lead_paragraph: President Obama and the first lady attended India’s Republic Day Parade on Monday and watched a grand display of military hardware, marching bands, helicopters and elaborately dressed camels.

headline: At Universities, a Push for Data-Driven Career Services
abstract: LinkedIn data on college graduates is a goldmine for schools seeking to identify alumni willing to mentor students or recruit them for jobs.
lead_paragraph: Officials at the University of California, San Diego, had sparse information on the career success of their graduates until they set up a branded page for the university on LinkedIn a couple of years ago.

headline: Who Gets a Raise?
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Women and Girls', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: Some say wages could rise this year — but even a large-scale increase in pay might not benefit everybody equally.
lead_paragraph: Is it time to ask for a raise? Neil Irwin at The Upshot writes that this could (finally) be a good year for wages, with small businesses, and a big health insurer, planning to increase pay. And The Billfold titled a recent post “The Year America Gets a Raise” (though its author, Mike Dang, also cautioned that “we can only watch and wait” to see if wages really rise).

headline: Video Review: The 2015 Nissan Murano, Dressed Up and Looking Good
abstract: The company doesn’t tend to play it safe with design, and the new Murano has elements, like its flowing brightwork, that are bold and refreshing.
lead_paragraph: LEAF, Juke, Quest and Cube are proof that Nissan doesn’t play it safe with design. This could be because of its alliance with the French automaker Renault. If not, the French curves Nissan uses must come directly from the mother country.

headline: Driven | 2015 Nissan Murano
abstract: A crossover that never fit in with the flannel shirt crowd leans farther toward the fashion scene.
lead_paragraph: A crossover that never fit in with the flannel shirt crowd leans farther toward the fashion scene.

headline: U.S. Envoy Urges Thailand to Lift Martial Law
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Daniel Russel, assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, said in an interview that he had told the junta it was losing credibility.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The most senior United States diplomat to visit Thailand since the military seized power in May called on Monday for the lifting of martial law and delivered harsh words to the junta.

headline: 1915: Attack on Egypt Imminent
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Turkish army is expected to advance upon Suez region in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A despatch from Cairo to the ‘‘Daily News and Leader’’ says that air scouts report that everything is ready for the advance of the Turkish army upon the Suez Canal excepting the arrangements for the transport of heavy guns, for which a system of tramways is being laid with the utmost speed on the soft desert soil. A general survey of the situation seems to point to the delivery of the blow immediately north of the Bitter Lakes, but the movements of the invading army are likely to be greatly impeded in many directions by flooded areas. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 27, 1915

headline: Streetwear, a Little Older and Wiser at OAMC
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Paris Fashion Week', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: The men’s wear designers intend to make clothes more tailored, more luxurious and more expensive.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On a recent afternoon, the Balenciaga showroom was buzzing with buyers from international stores pawing through blazers and eyeballing leather knapsacks. A pair at one table in the center caught the eye. One wore a shirt with the oversize graphic logo of Off-White, Virgil Abloh’s line; the other, the oversize graphic logo of Palace, the London-based skate-wear brand.

headline: Mubarak Sons Released From Egyptian Jail
abstract: The release of Alaa and Gamal Mubarak came one day after the fourth anniversary of the revolt that cast them down from the pinnacle of power.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The two adult sons of former President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt were released from jail early Monday, just one day after the fourth anniversary of the revolt that cast them down from the pinnacle of power.

abstract: Downtown Phoenix will be transformed for the Super Bowl, and there is great food and art throughout the city.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of football fans are flying into Phoenix this week for the Super Bowl on Sunday, but will locals be joining in the festivities? Are they embracing their roles as hosts, or just bracing themselves?

headline: ‘Midnight Three & Six’
abstract: This short documentary shows a mother’s efforts to manage her daughter’s daily struggle with a life-threatening condition: Type 1 diabetes.
lead_paragraph: For the past eight years, the Chamberlain family in Fort Worth, Tex., has been coping with a nightmare all parents fear: In 2006, their daughter, Grace, was given a diagnosis of a life-threatening disease. Grace has Type 1 diabetes, for which there is no cure. Now 15 years old, she has endured approximately 34,000 blood tests, 5,550 shots and 1,660 medical tubing injections to keep her alive.

headline: ScienceTake | The Smell of Rain
abstract: Raindrops capture tiny bubbles which then release that fresh, earthy scent into the air.
lead_paragraph: Raindrops capture tiny bubbles which then release that fresh, earthy scent into the air.

headline: How the Smell of Rain Bubbles From the Ground
abstract: Two M.I.T. scientists found that the right velocity of a raindrop on the right kind of soil can create the smell, known as petrichor.
lead_paragraph: A familiar scent fills the air after a dry stretch is broken by a summer rain. There is even a word for this fresh, earthy smell: petrichor. The term was coined in the 1960s when scientists reported that the smell came from chemicals in the surface that the rain landed on.

headline: Millions Paid by X Prize Foundation for Progress Toward Trip to Moon
keywords: ['Moon', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Contests and Prizes', 'Rocket Science and Propulsion']
abstract: The X Prize Foundation paid more than $5 million to several groups for advances in landing, moving on the lunar surface and imaging.
lead_paragraph: In 2004, the X Prize Foundation celebrated the culmination of its first prize competition, awarding $10 million for successful flights of SpaceShipOne, the first privately financed reusable spacecraft to take a pilot to space, defined as 62 miles above the Earth’s surface.

lead_paragraph: Panos Kammenos, left, the leader of the Independent Greeks, announced a new coalition government on Monday after meeting with Alexis Tsipras, who swept to power on Sunday in Greece.

headline: Eddie Redmayne on Ignoring the Odds
abstract: The actor says his father, who works in finance, pointed out that only one in 100 actors finds success.
lead_paragraph: Newly minted SAG Award winner Eddie Redmayne  (“The Theory of Everything”) set his sights on being an actor when he was 12 and was cast in a London production of “Oliver!” directed by Sam Mendes. He was Workhouse Boy No. 40. Mr. Redmayne tells the Bagger’s colleague Philip Galanes that his parents were supportive — to a point: “My dad works in finance, so he kept giving me the stats: only one in a hundred actors makes it. He’d ask, ‘Have you thought about producing?'”

headline: Christian Dior: Spring 2015 Couture
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Seattle Running Back Joins List of N.F.L.’s Defiant Ones
abstract: Like Bears quarterback Jim McMahon in 1986, the Seahawks’ Marshawn Lynch has excelled at drawing the N.F.L.’s ire in the time leading up to the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — One chooses not to speak with the news media, while the other was often accused of talking too much. But Marshawn Lynch, the embattled Seattle Seahawks running back, and Jim McMahon, the quarterback of the 1985 Chicago Bears, have a lot in common in terms of drawing the N.F.L.’s ire in the time leading up to a Super Bowl.

headline: New Leader in Greece Now Faces Creditors
abstract: The new prime minister’s promise to end austerity, renegotiate Greece’s bailout and reduce the country’s debt burden may be hard to fulfill.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — As the new Greek prime minister turns to fulfilling his campaign pledge of renegotiating his country’s bailout loans and reducing its staggering debt burden, he may find that Greece’s international creditors will be harder to persuade than the country’s voters.

headline: More Differences Than Similarities Are Found in Autistic Siblings
abstract: Most siblings with a diagnosis do not share the same genetic risk factors for the disorder and are as distinct in their behaviors as any brothers and sisters, scientists reported.
lead_paragraph: Most siblings with a diagnosis of autism do not share the same genetic risk factors for the disorder and are as distinct in their behaviors as any brothers and sisters, scientists reported on Monday in a study that came as a surprise to many doctors, if not to parents.

headline: Sundance 2015: Scientology Documentary Draws Crush of Festgoers
abstract: Hundreds lined up for the film by Alex Gibney, who said he was quietly pleased that Scientologists had taken out ads decrying the film.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — Any doubts that anticipation was high for Oscar winner Alex Gibney’s latest documentary, “Going Clear,” an exposé about the Church of Scientology, were allayed Sunday afternoon at the packed premiere at Sundance.

headline: White House Says Device Poses No Threat
abstract: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, says that a small electronic device found on the White House lawn overnight is not thought to pose a threat to anyone within the building.
lead_paragraph: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, says that a small electronic device found on the White House lawn overnight is not thought to pose a threat to anyone within the building.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Donald Trump, Border-Fence Builder
abstract: At the Freedom Summit in Iowa, he said he’d build a fence to keep out crooks, criminals and Islamic terrorists.
lead_paragraph: At the Freedom Summit in Iowa on Saturday, Donald Trump said that if he runs for president, and is elected president, he will build a border fence to keep out criminals, crooks and Islamic terrorists.

headline: Sundance 2015: A Buying Spree Propelled by Video on Demand
abstract: Many films are selling as indie film’s economics start to make sense again.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah – Distributors are snapping up Sundance movies with a ferocity not seen in years, a reflection of the quality of this year’s lineup and independent film’s improving economics, fueled by video on demand.

headline: AT&T to Buy Nextel Mexico for $1.9 Billion
abstract: The deal, if completed, would be the second AT&T acquisition in Mexico since November, when the company bought the big wireless service provider Iusacell for $2.5 billion.
lead_paragraph: AT&T continued its southward expansion on Monday, agreeing to buy Nextel Mexico for nearly $1.9 billion as part of its campaign to expand its Latin American presence.

headline: After a Bad Decision, Avoid the Shame and the Blame
abstract: When talking about money, couples should make the commitment to avoid blaming each other for past decisions that went awry.
lead_paragraph: About 10 years ago, my wife and I were driving around Park City during one of our annual summer trips to Utah. We knew that at some point we wanted to live there, so we were excited when we discovered a new housing development. Only a handful of lots had been sold, and the developer offered us a great discount off an already low price in an attempt to reel us in.

headline: Tom Brady Cannot Stop
abstract: A season in the charmed, cutthroat life of the N.F.L.’s most enigmatic quarterback.
lead_paragraph: Last July, a few weeks before the New England Patriots started training camp, I got a call from Donald Yee, the agent in Los Angeles who has represented Tom Brady since he entered the N.F.L. in 2000. It had been four years since I first told Yee that I was interested in writing about Brady, even though I typically cover politics. I grew up in the Boston suburbs, rooted for the Patriots as a kid and even possessed vague memories of watching the team play at Fenway Park, one of their homes before they settled into the nowhereland of Foxborough, Mass., in 1971. My friend Josh and I once wrote a letter to the team’s young quarterback, Jim Plunkett, inviting him to dinner at Josh’s house. (Plunkett never responded.) Their teams were mostly bad, their owner was an embarrassment, their stadium a dump. Yet the Patriots always retained a lovable haplessness about them, with their cute minuteman logos, their A.F.L. lineage and the identity crisis that comes from being named after an entire region instead of a city or state. (The Seattle Seahawks are not the Pacific Northwest Seahawks.)

headline: George Sicherman’s Pool Puzzles
abstract: Bend both sides of your brain with these billiards challenges from George Sicherman.

headline: On the Men’s Fall/Winter 2015 Runways, a Collection of Vinyl
abstract: The slick material made a comeback last week on the runways of Calvin Klein, Raf Simons and Pigalle.
lead_paragraph: Black vinyl has been associated with fetishists’ attire, the ’70s punk scene, Hype Williams’s music videos of the late ’90s and, more recently, installations by the artist Urs Fischer. And the slick plastic made a comeback in the fall/winter men’s collections last week, giving an alluring, glossy finish to some of the looks. Calvin Klein’s  Italo Zucchelli deployed the fabric — in both gray and black — in a range of familiar men’s silhouettes including baggy trousers, parkas, and shrunken pilot jackets. The model wearing a structured black PVC raincoat in Raf Simons’s recent collection proved that the shiny material can seem approachable when worn as part of a monochromatic look. And for his first appearance on the Paris fashion calendar, Stéphane Ashpool orchestrated a theatrical presentation inside a classic opera house for his street-wear-cum-high-fashion brand Pigalle. Among the nubby knits, track suits, puffers and shearlings was the black vinyl bomber jacket seen above.

headline: Learning From Animal Friendships
abstract: Interspecies interactions are all over YouTube. Yes, they’re cute, but are they useful to scientists?
lead_paragraph: A goat frolics with a baby rhinoceros.  A pig nestles up to a house cat. A rat snake makes nice with the dwarf hamster originally intended as its lunch.

headline: 1965: Fiery Suicide in Vietnam
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Buddhist protester self-immolates in Vietnam in 1965.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — A 17-year-old girl drenched herself with gasoline and burned herself to death today [Jan. 26] as a political protest against the government of Premier Tran Van Huong. The protest suicide — the first of its kind in South Vietnam since October, 1963 — took place at Nha Trang, a coastal city 200 miles north of Saigon, during an antigovernment demonstration. The suicide occurred shortly after two terrorist bombs had exploded at an annex of the American military advisory headquarters in Saigon, injuring one Army officer but causing little damage. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 27, 1965

headline: Facebook Is Said to Block Pages Critical of Muhammad to Avoid Shutdown in Turkey
keywords: ['Censorship', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media']
abstract: An employee said the company had acted to comply with an order from a court in Turkey, whose government has not hesitated to cut access to services like Twitter and YouTube for political reasons.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — To avoid being banned throughout Turkey, Facebook has blocked Turkish users’ access to a number of pages containing content that the authorities had deemed insulting to the Prophet Muhammad, according to a company employee with direct knowledge of the matter and a report by the state broadcaster TRT.

headline: The Surprise Isn’t That an Extreme Party Won in Greece. It’s That It Took This Long.
abstract: The election of an anti-austerity party has been met with remarkable calm in Europe, with most European markets up.
lead_paragraph: When I was last in Greece, for a reporting trip in May 2012, Syriza, a political party whose name is an acronym for “coalition of the radical left,” had recorded shockingly strong results in a recent election. The centrist, mainstream sources I was meeting with — such as bankers and ex-politicians — were nervous about what Syriza supporters, whom they viewed as wackos, meant for their country.

headline: How Much Snow Has Fallen
abstract: Inches of snow and time of measurement as reported by the National Weather Service.

headline: On a Big Stage, Hoping to Beat Her Inspiration
abstract: Madison Keys was 4 when she started swinging a racket after seeing Venus Williams on TV. Now 19, she will face Williams, 34, for the first time in a Grand Slam tournament.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Whatever the outcome, it will be a full-circle moment Wednesday when Venus Williams and Madison Keys meet in the quarterfinals of the Australian Open.

headline: Snow Day Approaches
abstract: Cookie baking. Board game playing. Snow shoveling. What will you do with your snow day?
lead_paragraph: Bread. Milk. Bottled water. Flashlights, batteries, etcetera, etcetera. Normal storm preparations, check. But who’s prepared for the children to be home from school tomorrow and maybe for a day or two thereafter? A number of schools across the East Coast have already canceled for Tuesday, Jan. 27, 2015, in anticipation of heavy snow and hazardous travel conditions, and many are dismissing early today as well.

lead_paragraph: A look back at some of the house’s recent feats of interior design.

abstract: On Monday morning, New Yorkers prepared for a powerful blizzard that was set to sweep across the region.
lead_paragraph: On Monday morning, New Yorkers prepared for a powerful blizzard that was set to sweep across the region.

headline: Supreme Court Rules Against Retirees in Union Health Benefits Case
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Organized Labor', 'Collective Bargaining', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The unanimous decision reversed a lower-court ruling that found the benefits had vested for life.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday ruled that a chemical company may be able to cut the health benefits of its retired workers, unanimously reversing an appeals court ruling that said the benefits had vested for life.

headline: SkyMall Stumbles as Airlines Hone Their Sales Pitches
abstract: More fliers are reaching for their tablets than the catalog of the quirky, and airlines are improving their magazines to reach more advertisers.
lead_paragraph: WE might get a little more knee room in coach, now that the familiar SkyMall catalog is disappearing from that thick stash of printed material the airlines cram into seat-back pockets.

headline: Even in Affluent Towns, Rising Tax Bills Mean Angst, and Appeals
abstract: Scarsdale, N.Y., re-examined the values of all its property last year, the first such assessment in 45 years. Taxes for some owners more than doubled.
lead_paragraph: SCARSDALE, N.Y. — It is hard, homeowners in this emblem of affluence agree, to feel sorry for the tax problems of people who live in 6,000-square-foot homes set on two or three manicured acres with swimming pools and tennis courts.

headline: Anatomy of a Health Care Mess
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Steven Brill has written a comprehensive chronicle of the politicking behind the Affordable Care Act, spiced by personal insights stemming from his own surgery.
lead_paragraph: Never sign up for a tour of the sausage factory, not if you want to keep eating sausage. In the case of health care, unfortunately, no one gets to abstain. Journalists and legislators, doctors and nurses, reformers and reformed alike, all eventually land on the conveyor belt that feeds those grinding gears.

headline: Study Suggests Earlier Use of Tools by Hominids
abstract: Human ancestors developed hands that were better suited to holding tools than climbing trees up to 600,000 years earlier than previously thought.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere along the journey from ape to human, our ancestors developed hands that were better suited to holding tools than climbing trees. A new study suggests the transition took place as much as 3.2 million years ago — about 600,000 years earlier than previously thought.

headline: The Bee Solution to Winter
abstract: Do bees hibernate, especially where temperatures are below freezing for extended periods? Why don’t they just freeze?
lead_paragraph: Q. Do bees hibernate, especially where temperatures are below freezing for extended periods? Why don’t they just freeze?

headline: Ukrainian Forces Struggle as Fighting Flares in East
abstract: Regular attacks by pro-Russian separatist forces have the Ukrainian military struggling to rebound from losses at the Donetsk airport last week.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — The shattered remains of a tank bearing a tattered Ukrainian flag sat beside the main highway to Mariupol on Monday afternoon, a remnant of what pro-Russian rebel forces said was a failed attempt by Ukrainian forces to push into rebel-held territory a few days after a shelling attack left 30 dead in that port city.

headline: Paul Singer’s Fund, Elliott, Takes a Stake in Informatica
abstract: The hedge fund appears likely to push its newest investment into selling itself.
lead_paragraph: Over the past two years, Paul Singer’s hedge fund, Elliott Management, has successfully pushed a number of technology companies to sell themselves. Now, it appears that the $25 billion hedge fund has set its sights on a new target.

headline: For First Time, Church of England Consecrates a Woman to Serve as a Bishop
abstract: The Rev. Libby Lane is the new bishop of Stockport.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Centuries of tradition were overturned in the Church of England on Monday when it consecrated the first woman to serve as one of its bishops at a service in York Minister.

headline: Iowa Governor Is Hospitalized After Falling Ill at Event
abstract: Gov. Terry Branstad of Iowa fell ill at an event on Monday and was rushed by ambulance to the hospital, according to a statement form his office.

headline: Why Your Workout Should Be High-Intensity
abstract: Studies suggest that a more demanding approach to exercise is not only safe for most patients but also more effective at preventing and reversing the problems of many ailments.
lead_paragraph: Many people with chronic health problems resign themselves to lives of modest activity or no activity at all, thinking vigorous exercise is unsafe or that they lack the stamina for it. But recent studies are proving just the opposite.

headline: Momofuku Milk Bar Pops Up
abstract: A couple of new hot, sweet drinks will make their debut in Madison Square Park; a kettle for pour-over coffee; Eneko Atxa’s guest appearance; and more.
lead_paragraph: To Sip: New Hot Drinks From a Pop-Up

headline: Storm Shelves Home Games for the Knicks and the Nets
abstract: The Knicks’ game against Sacramento was rescheduled for March 3. The Nets’ game against Portland was postponed until April 6.
lead_paragraph: With a powerful snowstorm heading toward the Northeast, the N.B.A. postponed two games scheduled for Monday night in New York.

headline: African Mosquitoes, Toxic Nets
abstract: The Times’ East Africa bureau chief, Jeffrey Gettleman provides insight into inadvertent trouble that resulted from mosquito nets intended to defend against malaria.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s East Africa bureau chief, Jeffrey Gettleman, wrote on Sunday about one of the continent’s biggest recent public health campaigns — and its surprising unintended consequences. He explains his personal experience with mosquito nets and provides insight, and empathy, into inadvertent trouble that results from mosquito nets intended to defend against malaria.

headline: U.S. Drone Kills 3 Qaeda Operatives in Yemen, Continuing Policy on Strikes
abstract: The drone strike was a signal that the United States will continue its targeted killing operations in Yemen despite the apparent takeover in the country by Houthi fighters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A C.I.A. drone strike in Yemen, the first since the resignation of President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi, killed three suspected Qaeda fighters on Monday, American officials said, in a signal that the United States will continue its counterterrorism operations there despite the apparent takeover by Houthi fighters.

headline: A Friendly but Willful Old Spirit, Pouring Tea
abstract: “Da,” Hugh Leonard’s semi-autobiographical work, is a memory play with a spectral turn as a son is visited by his father’s ghost.
lead_paragraph: If you have to be haunted, you really couldn’t ask for a nicer sort of ghost. The specter at the heart of Hugh Leonard’s semi-autobiographical play “Da,” revived by the Irish Repertory Theater, pours piping cups of tea and proffers packs of cigarettes. Most of the time he lounges in his favorite armchair, singing snatches of songs and telling jokes.

headline: A New Face for Violet
keywords: ['Cleft Palate and Clefts', 'Skull (Body Part)', '3-D Printers', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'Face']
abstract: Violet Pietrok was born with a Tessier Cleft, a rare defect that left a fissure in her skull. Surgeons at Boston Children’s Hospital, aided by 3-D prints of her skull, hope to repair the damage.
lead_paragraph: Violet Pietrok was born with a Tessier Cleft, a rare defect that left a fissure in her skull. Surgeons at Boston Children’s Hospital, aided by 3-D prints of her skull, hope to repair the damage.

headline: A Snowless Snow Day
abstract: There’s no snow in Washington, but the House has canceled votes tonight.

headline: Seeking Contrasts, Finding Similarities
abstract: Separate recitals by the violinists Miranda Cuckson and Paul Huang revealed no stark separation of classic and modern but a sustained reflection on Romanticism and its reverberations.
lead_paragraph: The violinist Miranda Cuckson started to play Mario Davidovsky’s “Synchronisms No. 9” (1988) just after 3 p.m. on Sunday at Spectrum on the Lower East Side. While the piece is a duet with electronics, it begins with a plaintive solo line, lonely yet warm, like the glow of firelight spied across a snowy plain by night.

headline: Republicans Pretend to Care About Inequality
abstract: John Boehner and Mitch McConnell blamed President Obama for a “top of the income recovery.”
lead_paragraph: Every time I think the Republican Party’s political spin can’t get more brazen, House Speaker John Boehner and the new Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell show me that I’ve just succumbed to the soft bigotry of low expectations.

headline: A Literary Agent Writes His Own Novel
abstract: Bill Clegg, the literary agent, faced a different pressure when seeking a publisher for his debut work of fiction.
lead_paragraph: The literary agent Bill Clegg is renowned in the publishing world as a ruthless negotiator who routinely wrings fat six- and seven-figure advances out of editors for experimental debut novels from unknown authors.

headline: Off the 3-D Printer, Practice Parts for the Surgeon
keywords: ['3-D Printers', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'Cleft Palate and Clefts', 'Skull (Body Part)', 'Face', 'Eyes and Eyesight']
abstract: Three-dimensional printing allows surgeons to foresee issues, not stumble into them.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The surgeon held a translucent white plastic eye socket in each hand. Gently moving them away from each other, Dr. John Meara showed the distance between Violet Pietrok’s eyes at birth. He slid the sockets closer to demonstrate their positions 19 months later, after he had operated on her.

headline: Sundance Veterans Winona Ryder and Peter Sarsgaard on College Psych Experiments, “Beetlejuice 2” and the Lure of TV
keywords: ['ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Movies', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)']
abstract: The pair star in “Experimenter,” Michael Almereyda’s film about Stanley Milgram’s controversial behavioral experiments in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Winona Ryder and Peter Sarsgaard seem ambivalent, if amused, by their roles as elder statespeople of the Sundance Film Festival. The actors, both 43, have become synonymous with the kind of quirky indie fare that has come to epitomize Sundance over the years: Ryder, as the breakout star of “Beetlejuice” and with her roles in the cult films “Heathers” and “Edward Scissorhands” in the late ’80s and early ’90s; and Sarsgaard with celebrated turns in the Sundance films “The Dying Gaul,” “An Education” and “Garden State,” among others. This week, they star alongside one another for the first time in “Experimenter,” the director Michael Almereyda’s drama about the social psychologist Stanley Milgram and his controversial experiments on obedience in the 1960s. It’s a peculiar film — as Milgram, Sarsgaard routinely breaks the fourth wall by speaking directly to the camera; at several points an elephant appears from seemingly nowhere to hint at the deeper meaning behind Milgram’s experiments — and yet it never crumbles under its own weight, thanks to the steady talents of Sarsgaard and Ryder, who plays Milgram’s wife, Sasha. (Ryder is also a jury member at this year’s festival.) T sat down with the actors prior to Sunday’s premiere to discuss ambiguous audience reactions, the allure of television and the rising specter of a “Beetlejuice” sequel.

headline: Former Lord’s Resistance Army Commander Appears at War Crimes Court
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The appearance of the former Ugandan rebel commander, Dominic Ongwen, gave the world its first long look at a suspect that rights groups called a marauding murderer.
lead_paragraph: A captured Ugandan rebel commander made his first public appearance Monday at a hearing before the International Criminal Court, where he stands accused of crimes including murder and enslavement.

headline: Grieg, Extended
abstract: The Amphion ensemble performed Grieg’s one complete string quartet as part of its program on Sunday presented by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: One of the most striking features of Grieg’s String Quartet in G minor is the textural richness created by techniques including double stopping, in which two notes are played simultaneously. Given the work’s allure, it receives surprisingly infrequent airings. But listeners had a chance to admire the score’s many charms during a passionate performance by the Amphion String Quartet at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday evening, in a concert presented by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center.

headline: In Push for Change, Finra Is Opposed by the Wall St. Firms It Regulates
abstract: The self-regulator is facing criticism over a proposal to require brokers to share information about clients’ accounts.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street has pulled out all the stops in opposing a plan by its own self-regulator to require brokers to share extensive information about their clients’ accounts.

headline: Cuomo Tells New Yorkers to Stay Home
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Monday urged New Yorkers to stay indoors and avoid hazardous conditions during the snowstorm.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Monday urged New Yorkers to stay indoors and avoid hazardous conditions during the snowstorm.

headline: Dress Blues
abstract: From double-breasted jean jackets to starched culottes, tailored denim is the next big thing.
lead_paragraph: From double-breasted jean jackets to starched culottes, tailored denim is the next big thing.

headline: De Blasio: No Food Takeout During Storm
abstract: New York City banned non-emergency vehicles after 11 p.m. When asked about food delivery, Mayor Bill de Blasio said, “A food delivery bicycle is not an emergency vehicle.”
lead_paragraph: New York City banned non-emergency vehicles after 11 p.m. When asked about food delivery, Mayor Bill de Blasio said, “A food delivery bicycle is not an emergency vehicle.”

headline: Snowed In? Here’s What to Watch, Read or Listen To
abstract: Streaming TV, movies, music and books to help you through a winter storm.
lead_paragraph: It’s too cold to go out. Your remote is working, but forget flipping though the channels: let us guide you. Your stereo is searching for something better than what you’re listening to now? You need a new book? We hear you. Here are our recommendations for what’s streaming on TV, what should be rocking your apartment and great reads to curl up with.

headline: Christie on New Jersey’s Preparations
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey spoke about the preparations he was taking ahead of the snowstorm.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey spoke about the preparations he was taking ahead of the snowstorm.

abstract: Pluralsight, an online training platform for technology professionals, acquires Code School, a skills site for beginning coders.
lead_paragraph: Pluralsight, an online service that provides advanced training courses for technology professionals, is on a shopping spree.

headline: De Blasio Declares State of Emergency
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced a state of emergency and said that only emergency vehicles would be allowed on New York City streets after 11 p.m. Monday.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced a state of emergency and said that only emergency vehicles would be allowed on New York City streets after 11 p.m. Monday.

headline: Behind the Poster: ‘The Visit’
abstract: The moody poster art for the musical “The Visit” shows the Tony Award-winning actress Chita Rivera looking regal.
lead_paragraph: The moody poster art for the musical “The Visit” shows the Tony Award-winning actress Chita Rivera looking regal in a crisp white maxi-coat, with bright red lips and a sparkling necklace adding bold accents to the scene. She stands with a cane before a shadowy recess that hints at the show’s dark tale about a wealthy widow who seeks revenge on a former lover. (In his review for the production at the Williamstown Theater Festival, Ben Brantley wrote that Scott Pask’s set “suggests a long-abandoned train station where you can buy a ticket straight to hell.”) The long-gestating musical, from the songwriters John Kander and Fred Ebb (“Chicago”) and the playwright Terrence McNally, arrives on Broadway this spring.

headline: Translating, if Not Analyzing, Gender Dynamics
abstract: The South African artist Robyn Orlin and the dancers of Compagnie Jant-Bi explore issues surrounding gender and homophobia in African life, at Montclair State University.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — Some choreographers build up to audience participation, or infiltration, during the course of an evening, but not the South African artist Robyn Orlin. Within the first five minutes of her expansively titled “At the same time we were pointing a finger at you, we realized we were pointing three at ourselves,” her fluorescent-clad dancers clamber into the audience, swatting at the seats and the people in them with rubber flip-flops.

headline: Post Holdings Buying MOM Brands for $1.15 Billion
abstract: The cereal maker is acquiring a portfolio of products free of additives and preservatives.
lead_paragraph: Post Holdings, maker of classic cereals like Grape-Nuts, Honeycomb and Post Raisin Bran, said on Monday that was spending $1.15 billion to buy MOM Brands, the family-owned maker of Malt-O-Meal.

abstract: An offbeat naïveté is informing fashion this spring, from eyelet nightshirts to textured tights.
lead_paragraph: An offbeat naïveté is informing fashion this spring, from eyelet nightshirts to textured tights.

lead_paragraph: The snowstorm forced the Metropolitan Opera to cancel one of the highlights of its season: Monday night’s planned premiere of a new production of a double bill of Tchaikovsky’s “Iolanta,” starring Anna Netrebko, and Bartok’s “Bluebeard’s Castle.”

headline: 3 Men Are Charged With Serving as Secret Agents for Russia in New York
abstract: Two of the men were posing as official representatives of Russia, but they gave assignments to a third man, federal officials say.
lead_paragraph: The three men would typically agree to meet outside, where one might tell another that he had a book, umbrella or hat to pass on. Then, at the appointed time and place, the secret handoff would occur: a bag, magazine or slip of paper changing hands.

headline: The Uniquely Modern Grandeur of Dior’s Couture Stage Sets
abstract: A look back at some of the house’s recent feats of interior design.
lead_paragraph: Since Raf Simons debuted as Dior’s creative director in 2012, his romantic yet futuristic collections have remained a high point of couture week. And the same is true of the sets on which they have been presented. Today, at the Musée Rodin, Simons showed printed transparent vinyl coats, structured cutout gowns and graphic jumpsuits amidst an elaborate network of scaffolding with pink-carpeted stairs — as per usual, an immersive installation that deepened the clothes’ sense of drama. Here, a look at the structure and the house’s other recent feats of set design.

headline: In ‘Selma,’ Trench Coats Amid Protests
abstract: Ruth E. Carter, the costume designer for “Selma,” explains how a heightened collar, colorful suits and coat pockets help transport viewers back to the violent but hopeful days of 1965.
lead_paragraph: Ruth E. Carter, the costume designer for “Selma,” explains how a heightened collar, colorful suits and coat pockets help transport viewers back to the violent but hopeful days of 1965.

lead_paragraph: Mr. Donahoe in a scene from “Every Brilliant Thing,” a solo show about a man who creates a list of life’s pleasures for his suicidal mother. The play is at the Barrow Street Theater through March 29.

headline: C.I.A. Officer Is Found Guilty in Leak Tied to Times Reporter
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jeffrey A. Sterling, a former Central Intelligence Agency officer, was convicted of espionage Monday on charges that he told a reporter for The New York Times about a secret operation to disrupt Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: Merger of Packaging Makers Can Face Cultural Challenges
abstract: Mergers that look equal can still provoke business and cultural upheaval, writes Kevin Allison of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Delivering on the promise of a $16 billion paper merger may require some precision. Stockholders in the packaging giants Rock-Tenn and MeadWestvaco will share their combined company evenly, with a roughly balanced board.

headline: Readers Respond: On Taking Dating Advice From David Brooks
abstract: With David Brooks’s column “The Devotion Leap,” some readers wondered if it is a good idea to take dating advice from a columnist, conservative or otherwise.
lead_paragraph: As David Brooks picked up the topic of online dating, he must have known he was displaying the very vulnerability he cited as a prerequisite for love.

headline: Mariinsky Ballet
abstract: Yevgeny Ivanchenko and Yekaterina Kondaurova in Jerome Robbins’s “In the Night” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Yevgeny Ivanchenko and Yekaterina Kondaurova in Jerome Robbins’s “In the Night” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Tweaking an Illustrious Tradition to Incorporate Western Notions
abstract: After wrapping up a Chopin weekend at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Mariinsky Ballet is bringing a program of late-19th- and early-20th-century choreography to the Kennedy Center.
lead_paragraph: A reader recently left a voice mail message telling me, “The Russians invented ballet!” No, they certainly didn’t, but you can see why many people believe that they must have — especially the Mariinsky Ballet of St. Petersburg. Last weekend, the company ended a two-week season of three different programs at the Brooklyn Academy of Music; this week it moves on to the Kennedy Center in Washington with a program of late-19th- and early-20th-century choreography.

headline: Wright Foundation Names Architecture Dean
abstract: After a period of turmoil over the fate of its architecture school, the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation has selected Aaron Betsky as its new dean.
lead_paragraph: After a period of turmoil over the fate of its architecture school, the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation has selected Aaron Betsky as its new dean. Mr. Betsky, who last year stepped down as the director of the Cincinnati Art Museum, said he would start next month, succeeding Victor Sidy, who has led the school since 2005. “The school does have to grow, not just in terms of student numbers, but also in terms of its capacity and its academic excellence,” Mr. Betsky said in a telephone interview. “We have to keep proving that this is the best experimental-architecture school in the world.” Facing the loss of its accreditation, the foundation in October approved a possible path toward independent incorporation of its architecture school — provided fund-raising targets are met. Mr. Betsky, who has taught and written extensively about architecture, said he was undaunted, having raised more than $80 million in his eight years at the Cincinnati Art Museum. The architecture school’s main campus is in Scottsdale, Ariz., with a campus for summer terms in Spring Green, Wis.

headline: High Cholesterol Takes Its Toll Over Time
abstract: Researchers found that the longer cholesterol remained, elevated the greater the likelihood for cardiovascular disease.
lead_paragraph: Having high cholesterol in your 30s and 40s increases your risk for heart disease, and the longer it stays elevated, the greater the risk, a new study reports.

headline: Push Over, Cornish Pasty: Balti Curry Seeks a Place in British Culinary Lore
abstract: Some say Balti curry, adapted from Pakistan for British tastes, should gain European recognition alongside other iconic foods.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, England — The year after opening a small restaurant here in 1977, Mohammed Arif spent two weeks in his native Pakistan, where he saw spicy, aromatic curries being cooked and served, sizzling, in the same dish.

headline: A Mobile Umbilical Cord, Off the Table, but Still Connected
abstract: Those of us who keep our phones nearby all the time — just in case — run the risk of 24/7 distractedness, of never being fully there for our work, ourselves, or our non-offspring companions.
lead_paragraph: “I’m sorry, looks like you’re getting a text. Gosh, I should probably have my phone out too!” We were two women, meeting for the first time, seated across from each other in a cozy coffee shop. She was squeezing in our date between more-than-full-time work and two children, and I sandwiched the visit between shuttling my three kids, working from home, and a key board meeting for my start-up nonprofit. We had just 40 minutes to get to know each other and see if we could support each other in our growing careers.

headline: Hold the Drug, Go Straight to the Source
abstract: The ground-up plants from which the anti-malaria drug artemisinin is derived appear to work better that the drug itself, new research shows.
lead_paragraph: Ground-up artemisia plants, from which the anti-malaria drug artemisinin is derived, appear to work much better than the refined drug does by itself, according to research at the University of Massachusetts.

abstract: The goal, announced at the billionaire brothers’ annual winter retreat, is an unparalleled effort by outside groups to shape a presidential election.
lead_paragraph: The political network overseen by the conservative billionaires Charles G. and David H. Koch plans to spend close to $900 million on the 2016 campaign, an unparalleled effort by coordinated outside groups to shape a presidential election that is already on track to be the most expensive in history.

headline: Cleaning Up Water by Running It Through Dirt
abstract: Storm runoff can be toxic to aquatic life, but a study suggests that filtering the water through dirt before it enters streams, rivers or the ocean is a solution.
lead_paragraph: Storm runoff can be toxic to aquatic life, but a new study suggests a simple and relatively inexpensive solution: Filter the water through dirt before it enters streams, rivers or the ocean.

headline: Strong Sales for ‘Hedwig’ on Broadway
abstract: John Cameron Mitchell returned to the role he created in “Hedwig and the Angry Inch,” sparking strong sales. “Honeymoon in Vegas” saw modest sales after strong reviews.
lead_paragraph: Fans of the 1990s downtown musical “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” and its 2001 movie version turned out in strong numbers last week to see the original Hedwig, John Cameron Mitchell, play the role for the first time on Broadway in the hit production there. According to box office data released on Monday, “Hedwig” had one of the highest average ticket prices on Broadway last week — $115.72 — and grossed $609,617 for six performances, or 93 percent of the maximum possible amount. “Hedwig” is the creation of Mr. Mitchell (who wrote the book) and Stephen Trask (who wrote the music and lyrics), and won the Tony Award for best musical revival in June (as well as a best actor Tony for its star at the time, Neil Patrick Harris). Mr. Mitchell is scheduled to play Hedwig on Broadway through March 14.

headline: One Pioneer’s Attempt to Rescue Another
abstract: Nicholas Carlson’s “Marissa Mayer and the Fight to Save Yahoo!” is a breezy retelling of the company’s hiring of Ms. Mayer as part of its efforts to recapture its former glory.
lead_paragraph: To the list of books about transformative technology companies and their visionary leaders we can now add one about Silicon Valley’s wayward soul and would-be savior: Yahoo’s Marissa Mayer.

headline: Flawed Case Contributes to Acquittals in Murder of Costa Rican Turtle Guardian
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Environment', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Smuggling', 'Turtles and Tortoises']
abstract: Seven men charged in the killing of a Costa Rican turtle conservationist are acquitted of murder charges.
lead_paragraph: A Costa Rican judge today acquitted seven men of murder charges in the May, 2013, slaying of Jairo Mora, a young sea turtle conservationist, citing faults in handling of evidence and other problems with the investigation. Below you can read courtroom details as reported for the Tico Times by Lindsay Fendt, whose fine coverage of this case was cited here in 2013.

headline: Deep Into That Darkness Peering
abstract: Jonathan Christenson’s “Nevermore: The Imaginary Life and Mysterious Death of Edgar Allan Poe” opens at New World Stages.
lead_paragraph: Exquisitely stylish and excessively bleak, the new musical “Nevermore: The Imaginary Life and Mysterious Death of Edgar Allan Poe,” at New World Stages, takes the sad facts of Poe’s life and makes them gloomier still.

headline: A Versatile Pianist Grounded in Groove, His Collaborators in Tow
abstract: Marc Cary, the jazz musician, and his collaborators played two nights in Harlem ahead of the release of his latest album.
lead_paragraph: There isn’t much in the modern-jazz-musician tool kit that Marc Cary hasn’t mastered, but he has a particular subspecialty in the area of groove. A pianist who came up the old-school way, with mentors like Abbey Lincoln and Betty Carter, Mr. Cary has always been adept with a range of rhythmic strategies, from a deep-house pulse to a swinging churn.

headline: Shaping His Genius to Transform Everyday Life
abstract: Historians and other experts examine the life of Thomas A. Edison in Tuesday’s “American Experience” on PBS.
lead_paragraph: Plenty of lives are admirable or eventful, but only a very few are so influential that it’s difficult to wrap your head around just how much they meant to the world. Thomas A. Edison lived such a life, and it receives a thorough two-hour examination in Tuesday’s “American Experience” on PBS.

headline: Budget Forecast Sees End to Sharp Deficit Declines
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Baby Boomers', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Congressional Budget Office sees a rise in Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security spending as baby boomers age.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal budget deficit will continue to inch downward through next year, but even with the economy on an upward trajectory, the government’s red ink will begin to rise in 2017 and expand with an aging population, the Congressional Budget Office said Monday.

headline: Kurd Militia Says ISIS Is Expelled From Kobani
abstract: Some activists said clearing the northern Syrian town was no great victory, given that it took nearly 700 airstrikes by the American-led coalition to do it.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Kurdish militias regained full control of the northern Syrian town of Kobani on Monday, driving Islamic State militants out with the help of American-led airstrikes, Kurdish activists on the scene said.

headline: Greece’s Agonized Cry to Europe
abstract: European leaders must hear the unambiguous message from voters: Greeks will not continue to abide by the austerity regime.
lead_paragraph: The message from Sunday’s elections in Greece was unambiguous: The Greeks cannot and will not continue to abide by the austerity regime that has brought their economy to its knees. It was a message the Germans and other Europeans who continue to insist that Greece pay off its mountainous debt, no matter what the damage, must hear. Persisting on their dogmatic course is not only wrong for Greece but dangerous for the entire European Union.

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Just about every June, on the anniversary of his company’s founding, Richard Liu dons a big motorcycle helmet and red uniform, hops on a three-wheeled electric bike and makes home deliveries for his e-commerce company JD.com.

abstract: The Planetary Society announced that it would send the first of two small spacecraft testing the technology of solar sails into orbit in May.
lead_paragraph: To sail on winds of sunlight has long been a dream of rocket scientists.

headline: Weekend Scrambles Top Oscar Prospects
abstract: “Birdman” has shown surprising strength in winning guild awards, while “The Imitation Game” tried a new strategy to promote its chances for best picture.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — An unexpected double win for Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s “Birdman,” at the expense of Richard Linklater’s “Boyhood,” jolted the Oscar race over the weekend, even as Harvey Weinstein made a bid to enhance his own contender, “The Imitation Game,” as a filmic standard-bearer against past injustices directed at gays.
