lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft has conjured up some attention-grabbing new products lately to help it restart growth. The company’s results over the holidays show how badly it needs them to work.

headline: My Very Educated Readers Just Served Us Some New Planet Mnemonics
abstract: We asked our readers to submit their own mnemonics, including the dwarf planets. Here are some of our favorites:
lead_paragraph: When Pluto was demoted from planethood, the trusty mnemonic “My Very Educated Mother Just Served Us Nine Pizzas” had to be retooled. But there are still those who are rooting for the dwarf planets to be considered actual planets, which would require a new mnemonic. It’s not just that P - for Pluto — would be added back but also C for Ceres, E for Eris, H for Haumea and M for Makemake, creating the new order: M-V-E-M-C-J-S-U-N-P-H-M-E. We asked our readers to submit their own mnemonics. Here are some of our favorites:

headline: Reid Recuperating at Home After Surgery
abstract: Senator Harry Reid made it home after surgery for injuries sustained in an exercise accident on Jan. 1.
lead_paragraph: Senator Harry Reid was back at his home in Washington on Monday after having surgery for injuries sustained in an exercise accident on Jan. 1.

headline: At Dior’s Spring 2015 Couture Presentation, a Perfect Storm of Pattern and Texture
abstract: One of the strongest looks Raf Simons showed was a plastic floral-print cape layered over a crystal-embellished minidress and printed bodysuit.
lead_paragraph: The tent at the Musée Rodin for today’s Dior spring 2015 haute couture show was transformed by mirrored walls and a bilevel mass of white scaffolding that felt a bit like the inside of a kaleidoscope. The effect upon entering was jarring — which also seemed to be the intention of Raf Simons’s collection, a mash-up of various historical references from the ’50s and ’60s taken for a futuristic spin. One of the best looks was a plastic floral-print cape worn over a crystal-embellished minidress and a floral-tattoo-print bodysuit and paired with high-gloss short boots. Just like the show’s venue, the look was multifaceted, but somehow harmonious all the same.

headline: Rand Paul Challenges Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz on Iran
abstract: He asked his fellow senators if they were ready to send ground troops.
lead_paragraph: Politicians who oppose President Obama can bluster all they want, grab headlines and curry favor with donors yet don’t have to be responsible for their (too often) irresponsible critiques and prescriptions on foreign policy. So it was refreshing to hear Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky split with some of his fellow Republicans on Iran during a presidential forum on Saturday organized by Freedom Partners.

headline: Greek Election Reflects a Deep Divide in Europe
abstract: Beneath the austerity debate that propelled a left-wing party to victory in Greece is a conflict of wills between Greek voters and those in Germany, Finland and the Netherlands.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The Greek election not only strengthened opponents of austerity, it also highlighted a fundamental tension at the heart of Europe’s six-decade-long push to forge a closer union of democratic states: what to do when voters in different countries have different, even opposite, demands.

headline: Greece: Think Flows, Not Stocks
abstract: Greek debt is a fiction, Greek surpluses are real.
lead_paragraph: How should we think about the bargaining that may or may not now take place between the new Greek government and the troika? (No bargaining if the troika basically says no concessions.) Most discussion is framed in terms of what happens to the debt. But as both Daniel Davies and James Galbraith point out — with very different de facto value judgments, but never mind for now — at this point Greek debt, measured as a stock, is not a very meaningful number. After all, the great bulk of the debt is now officially held, the interest rate bears little relationship to market prices, and the interest payments come in part out of funds lent by the creditors. In a sense the debt is an accounting fiction; it’s whatever the governments trying to dictate terms to Greece decide to say it is.

headline: Not Dressed to Impress, and Running Into a High School Classmate
abstract: Denise Colella, chief executive of Maxifier, recalls a flight where, traveling in a “ridiculous” outfit, she found herself seated next to an old acquaintance.
lead_paragraph: I’M lucky enough to have a lot of friends all around the world, which makes business travel kind of fun. I’ve been flying my entire career, and now as chief executive of Maxifier, an advertising technology company, I’m traveling as much as ever.

headline: For Students (and Some Adults), School Cancellation in New York Comes as Welcome News
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced that city schools would be closed on Tuesday because of the snowstorm, giving some students a reprieve from pending exams.
lead_paragraph: They are perhaps the three sweetest words to a young person’s ear: School is canceled. And this week, students in New York City were able to savor the cheerful news further in advance than usual.

headline: Oklahoma Asks Supreme Court to Delay Executions
abstract: Legal officials in Oklahoma are seeking a delay by the United States Supreme Court until it decides whether the state’s combination of lethal drugs used in executions is constitutional.
lead_paragraph: Oklahoma officials asked the United States Supreme Court on Monday to stay the execution of three inmates on death row until the court rules on the constitutionality of the state’s lethal injection process. The court agreed on Friday to decide a case on the constitutionality of the new combinations of drugs that some states are using to execute prisoners, which critics say cause intense suffering.

headline: His Heart and a Coach’s Advice Take a World Cup Star Abroad

lead_paragraph: LONDON — DeAndre Yedlin had modest plans for New Year’s Eve 2013. He went to his mother’s house in Seattle. He watched some fireworks on television. He went to sleep.

keywords: ['Female Genital Mutilation', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Officials said it was Egypt’s first criminal conviction for the practice of female genital mutilation, and related to the death of a 13-year-old girl.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A court on Monday handed down what officials said was Egypt’s first criminal conviction for the practice of female genital mutilation, sentencing a doctor to more than two years of hard labor for committing manslaughter while performing the procedure on a 13-year-old girl.

headline: Marcus Borg, Liberal Scholar on Historical Jesus, Dies at 72
abstract: Professor Borg was among a group of scholars, known as the Jesus Seminar, who set out to discern which of Jesus’ acts and utterances could be confirmed as historically true, and which were merely myths.
lead_paragraph: Marcus J. Borg, a scholar who popularized a liberal intellectual approach to Christianity with his lectures and books about Jesus as a historical figure, died on Wednesday at his home in Powell Butte, Ore. He was 72.

lead_paragraph: The Rangers’ oft-derided power play — a source of frustration through the regime of their former coach John Tortorella and during Alain Vigneault’s first season behind the bench — is now a source of confidence as the team heads into the second half of the season.

headline: Israel: Dissident Reservists Dismissed
abstract: The military on Monday terminated the service of 43 reservists who in September signed a letter refusing to participate in “actions against Palestinians” for moral reasons.
lead_paragraph: The military on Monday terminated the service of 43 reservists from an elite intelligence unit who in September signed a letter refusing to participate in “actions against Palestinians” for moral reasons. The letter by veterans of the clandestine Unit 8200 claimed that its work harmed innocent people, amounted to “political persecution,” and made it more difficult to resolve the underlying conflict. The military said that the refusal violated its “standards and morals,” and questioned why the complaint was aired publicly rather than through the chain of command. The military “views with great severity any attempt to elude mandatory military service especially when the act is intended to make a political statement,” its statement said. A leader of the reservists’ group, speaking on the condition of anonymity because the military prohibits members of 8200 from being identified publicly, said “the army is trying to make the issues that we were trying to raise go away by making us go away.”

keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'News and News Media']

lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — With her government badly shaken over the mysterious death of a prosecutor investigating the 1994 bombing of a Jewish center, President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner said in a televised speech on Monday night that she would immediately send a bill to Congress to dissolve the nation’s premier intelligence agency.

headline: WikiLeaks Assails Google and the U.S.
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Lawyers acting for WikiLeaks said Monday that they were exploring possible legal action against the American government and Google over the seizure of emails.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers acting for WikiLeaks and its fugitive editor, Julian Assange, said Monday that they were exploring possible legal action against the American government and Google over the seizure of emails and other data belonging to three of the whistle-blowing organization’s journalists. A lawyer for WikiLeaks, Michael Ratner, told journalists in Geneva that the group had written on Monday to Google’s chairman, Eric Schmidt, and to American officials demanding details and explanations for “search and seizure” warrants issued to Google by the Department of Justice in March 2012. In response to the warrants, Google turned over to law enforcement authorities all data associated with the accounts of the journalists, Mr. Ratner said. WikiLeaks said it was “astonished and disturbed” that Google had waited more than two and a half years to notify the journalists that the authorities had issued the warrants, denying them the opportunity to oppose them in court. A Google spokesman said that its policy was to inform people about government requests for their data “except in limited cases, like when we are gagged by a court order, which sadly happens quite often.”

headline: Reid Is Home After Surgery for Injuries
abstract: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada was back at his home in Washington on Monday after surgery for injuries sustained in an exercise accident on Jan. 1.
lead_paragraph: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada was back at his home in Washington on Monday after surgery for injuries sustained in an exercise accident on Jan. 1. Mr. Reid, the Senate’s Democratic leader, was “sitting in his living room with Mrs. Reid, cracking jokes and asking about the whip count for this evening’s vote on the Keystone pipeline legislation,” his office said. Doctors removed a blood clot from Mr. Reid’s right eye and repaired bones in his face, his office said. The surgery took three and a half hours, and Mr. Reid was under full anesthesia. Doctors say they are hopeful that he will regain sight in the eye. Mr. Reid is expected to monitor Senate business from home this week.

headline: White House to Propose Allowing Oil Drilling Off Atlantic Coast

headline: Edgar Froese, Adventurous Leader of Tangerine Dream, Dies at 70
abstract: In Tangerine Dream, a band that evolved through many incarnations and spanned decades, Mr. Froese is the musician who stayed the longest.
lead_paragraph: Edgar Froese, the leader of the long-running and prolific German group Tangerine Dream — first an improvising avant-garde rock band, then an ambient electronic-music project, and finally an arena-filling machine of smooth and heroic synthesizer pulsations — died on Jan. 20 in Vienna. He was 70.

headline: Government Declassifies 2007 Surveillance Court Rulings
keywords: ['Freedom of Information Act', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'USA PATRIOT Act']
abstract: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit, the government has declassified two previously Top Secret rulings from May and August 2007 by Judge Roger Vinson of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court. The disclosure filled in a missing link in the history of the evolving legality of the Bush administration’s warrantless surveillance program. The government previously declassified key rulings from January 2007 and April 2007revealing an internal dispute on the court as the Bush administration struggled to put the program on a firmer legal footing. Congress legalized the program with the Protect America Act in August 2007, ending the efforts to fit it into the existing Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act.
lead_paragraph: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit, the government has declassified two previously Top Secret rulings from May and August 2007 by Judge Roger Vinson of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court. The disclosure filled in a missing link in the history of the evolving legality of the Bush administration’s warrantless surveillance program. headline: Robert Kraft Defends Patriots Amid Uproar Over Deflated Footballs

headline: Documents Show N.S.A.’s Wiretap Moves Before Congress’s Approval
keywords: ['USA PATRIOT Act', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Freedom of Information Act']
abstract: A federal judge allowed the agency cull foreigners’ emails and phone calls without judicial preapproval before Congress authorized the spying, newly declassified papers show.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge ruled in 2007 that the U.S.A. Patriot Act empowered the National Security Agency to collect foreigners’ emails and phone calls from domestic networks without prior judicial approval, newly declassified documents show.

headline: Amazon Investigated in Japan Over Child Pornography
abstract: The police have raided Amazon’s Tokyo headquarters, a distribution center and the offices of an affiliate, according to Japanese news reports.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Amazon.com’s Japan unit has said that it is cooperating with the local authorities in an investigation into whether child pornography has been sold on its website.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7:30 P.M. (Starz Cinema) IN DARKNESS (2011) A Polish sewer worker and sometime thief (Robert Wieckiewicz) and his young sidekick (Krzysztof Skonieczny) discover a group of Jews who have taken refuge from the Nazis in the underground waterways of Lvov and decide to help them — first as a business proposition, and then out of moral obligation — in this dramatization of real-life events by the director Agnieszka Holland. “The visual contrast between the worlds above and below ground is handled beautifully and evocatively, and it gives ‘In Darkness’ the dreamlike quality of a fairy tale,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this Oscar nominee for best foreign-language film. “It is not a bad movie,” he added. “It is touching, warm and dramatically satisfying. But that, given the subject matter, is exactly the problem.”

headline: Tomas Berdych Keeps Nerve in Lopsided Win Over Rafael Nadal
abstract: With a quarterfinal victory at the Australian Open on Tuesday, Tomas Berdych snapped a 17-match losing streak against Rafael Nadal.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Rafael Nadal has always seemed to enjoy the chase more than the trophy, which may be why he is always biting his trophies.

lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — After some unflinching words from her family, Maria Sharapova has been relentless on her opponents.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Offering new details after years of official silence, a public inquiry into the death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer and vitriolic critic of the Kremlin, opened on Tuesday with a lawyer for his widow saying that the trail of evidence would lead “directly to the door” of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

headline: Is Vaping Worse Than Smoking?
abstract: You wouldn’t discover the correct answer from reading the latest study on e-cigarettes.
lead_paragraph: So I suppose you heard about the latest e-cigarette study, the one that said that the vapors e-cigarette users inhale contain multiple forms of formaldehyde. It was much in the news last week, after its authors, five scientists from Portland State University, published a peer-reviewed letter outlining their findings in the prestigious New England Journal of Medicine.

headline: How to Leave a Mark
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Social Impact Bonds']
abstract: Impact investing is perhaps the most promising new development tool. Young people just getting started and older business gurus alike should consider it.
lead_paragraph: The big debate during the 20th century was about the relationship between the market and the state. Both those institutions are now tarnished. The market is prone to devastating crashes and seems to be producing widening inequality. Government is gridlocked, sclerotic or captured by special interests. Government is an ever more rigid and ineffective tool to address market failures.

headline: President Obama Protects a Valued Wilderness
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Land Use Policies', 'Editorials', 'Wilderness Areas', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Conservation of Resources']
abstract: A new proposal would protect 1.5 million acres of coastal plain in the Arctic by barring oil-and-gas exploration.
lead_paragraph: The Arctic National Wildlife Refuge covers only a small part of Alaska. Smaller still is the coastal plain of the refuge, a narrow, 1.5 million-acre strip flanking the Beaufort Sea. The plain is an ecological and biological wonder, the hunting grounds for Alaskan natives and home to caribou, polar bears, all manner of marine life and countless bird species. It may also contain one of the biggest unexploited oil fields in America.

headline: The Humane Death Penalty Charade
abstract: It is time to dispense with the pretense of the state carrying out a pain-free execution.
lead_paragraph: When the United States at last abandons the abhorrent practice of capital punishment, the early years of the 21st century will stand out as a peculiar period during which otherwise reasonable people hotly debated how to kill other people while inflicting the least amount of constitutionally acceptable pain.

headline: Investing in Our Future at Community Colleges
abstract: Readers discuss a column by David Brooks about President Obama’s plan for free tuition.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Save the New Ukraine
abstract: The pro-European reformers desperately need financial aid to survive Russia’s assault.
lead_paragraph: A NEW Ukraine was born a year ago in the pro-European protests that helped to drive President Viktor F. Yanukovych from power. And today, the spirit that inspired hundreds of thousands to gather in the Maidan, Kiev’s Independence Square, is stronger than ever, even as it is under direct military assault from Russian forces supporting separatists in eastern Ukraine.

headline: Q. and A.: Luigi Tomba on Privatized Housing and Political Legitimacy in China
abstract: Mr. Tomba, a China expert based in Australia, talks about how the privatization of housing in China appears to be strengthening the grip of the Communist Party.
lead_paragraph: Luigi Tomba, 49, is the associate director of the Australian Center on China in the World at the Australian National University in Canberra. In his new book, “The Government Next Door: Neighborhood Politics in Urban China,” Mr. Tomba, a native of Italy who first went to China in 1988, challenges the conventional wisdom that a property-owning middle class is helping to foster civil society in China. Instead, his research leads him to conclude that the privatization of housing has strengthened the grip of the Communist Party.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Learning from Animal Friendships
abstract: Have you watched any of these videos of interspecies relationships? Have you ever witnessed a cross-species interaction? What do you think these relationships show?
lead_paragraph: In “Learning From Animal Friendships,” Erica Goode writes about how some interspecies relationships might merit scientific research.

headline: Who Was Really Flying That Drone?
abstract: Twitter has a little fun with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. over the drone that landed at the White House early Monday.

headline: Facebook Briefly Falters After Malfunction
abstract: Facebook said the cause was an internal malfunction rather than a cyberattack.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Facebook and Instagram were inaccessible for about an hour Tuesday, but after a brief mystery, Facebook said the cause had been an internal malfunction rather than a cyberattack.

abstract: The new firm, with more than 6,500 lawyers in more than 50 countries, aims to take advantage of China’s growing economic heft and the increasing number of deals being made overseas by its companies.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The multinational law firm Dentons announced on Tuesday that it would merge with the Dacheng Law Offices of China, creating a firm with the world’s largest number of lawyers.

headline: French Police Arrest 5 in Hunt for Terrorism Recruiters
abstract: The arrests were part of a continuing effort to combat terrorism after the deadly attacks this month in and near Paris that left 17 dead, the police said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French counterterrorism police on Tuesday raided the southern town of Lunel and arrested five people in an operation aimed at rooting out a suspected jihadist network, a senior police official said.

headline: Aer Lingus Receptive to Latest Offer From Parent of British Airways
abstract: The Irish carrier Aer Lingus had rejected two takeover offers late last year from the International Consolidated Airlines Group.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Aer Lingus said on Tuesday that its board of directors would be willing to recommend that shareholders accept the latest takeover bid from the parent of British Airways, valued at about $1.5 billion, if certain conditions were met, paving the way for potential deal.

headline: Siemens Profit Down 25% on Weak Economy and Lower Oil Prices
abstract: The German engineering company said profit in its first quarter fell to $1.23 billion, and that it may have to cut jobs to reduce costs.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Siemens, the German engineering and electronics company, said on Tuesday that profit fell 25 percent in its first quarter as sales to the energy industry slumped, a sign of falling fuel prices’ having repercussions beyond the main oil-producing countries.

headline: As Visit Ends, Obama Presses India on Human Rights and Climate Change
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Human Trafficking', 'Global Warming', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Child Labor', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Obama pressed India on Tuesday to do more to curb emissions, as he wrapped up a trip that failed to achieve a meaningful breakthrough on the issue.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — President Obama concluded his three-day trip here Tuesday with a tough-love message to his hosts, as he vowed to be “India’s best partner” in taking its place in the ranks of the world’s great powers but urged it to do more to protect human rights and fight climate change.

headline: I.P.O. Could Value Sunrise Communications of Switzerland at $3.7 Billion
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: The telecommunications provider is expected to price its I.P.O. at between $65 and $88 a share, and to begin trading on the Swiss exchange in the coming weeks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Sunrise Communications, one of the largest telecommunications companies in Switzerland, said on Tuesday that an initial public offering this year could value its recently formed holding company at up to 3.3 billion Swiss francs, or about $3.7 billion.

headline: What Would You Do on a Snow Day?
abstract: Do you have any snow day rituals? Do you like to play in the snow? Would you go sledding or have a snowball fight? Or would you rather stay inside and keep warm?
lead_paragraph: Officials from New York City warned that the winter storm bearing down on the region this week could be one of the most powerful blizzards ever recorded. That might well mean a snow day for millions of students from New Jersey to Maine.

headline: Staying Put and Bearing Witness to the Holocaust
abstract: Rather than flee to safe havens in America or Israel, some 2,700 Jews who survived Auschwitz returned to their European town in what is now Romania.
lead_paragraph: While recent terror attacks and anti-Semitism have led a growing number of French Jews to flee to Israel, another European Jewish community is determined to stay put, and has been for a long time.

headline: Psychotherapy as a Kind of Art
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: Like my novels, it enabled me to make sense of a world that often seemed senseless.
lead_paragraph: On the day, some decades ago, that I sent off the manuscript of what would become my sixth published book, I was suddenly possessed — there is no other word — by the desire to leave this world, and to do so by stepping in front of an oncoming bus. I walked to the edge of the sidewalk, stepped down, hesitated, let the bus go by, and decided to go home, where, if one of my children, then ages 4, 2 and 1, defied me in any way, I imagined picking that child up and throwing the child against a wall or through a window.

lead_paragraph: Left-wing party Syriza has promised to renegotiate Greece’s debt.

lead_paragraph: It was an unprecedented step for what became, in New York City, a common storm: For the first time in its 110-year history, the subway system was shut down because of snow.

headline: ‘Gomorrah’: Italy’s Criminally Great TV Show
abstract: Will the international success of "Gomorrah" help or hurt the country's image?
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Italy — “Gomorrah,” which recounts the exploits of the fictional Savastanos crime family, is Italy’s all-time most popular TV series. And it is starting to go global: Twelve of the first episodes have already been sold for broadcast in 50 countries. “Gomorrah” will tell world viewers a great story. But what will it tell them about Italy itself?

lead_paragraph: PARIS — It was day two at Haute Couture, and Natalie Portman was beaming. She was sitting in the front row at the Dior show, on the grounds of the Musée Rodin in Paris.

lead_paragraph: Long overshadowed by its rival Alibaba, JD.com has emerged as China’s other online goliath by carving out its own distinct identity, David Barboza reports.

headline: Apologies All Around After Watch Is Presented as Gift in Taiwan
abstract: In a cultural faux pas, Susan Kramer, the British minister of state for transport, gave a large pocket watch to the mayor of Taipei, Ko Wen-je, during a visit to Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: Guides to Chinese business etiquette often carry a reminder to never give a timepiece as a gift. The phrase “giving a clock,” or 送鐘, sounds in Mandarin too much like “paying one’s last respects” to the deceased, and the act of it is one of a few taboos based on Chinese pronunciation.

headline: In Reprieve to Obama, Senate Democrats Agree to Wait on Iran Sanctions
abstract: While the House of Representatives weighs whether to impose new sanctions on Tehran, the Iranian Parliament is working on a resolution of its own.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ten Senate Democrats who have advocated putting more sanctions on Iran gave the White House a two-month reprieve on Tuesday, saying they would wait until after the late-March deadline for completing the outlines of a deal to restrain Tehran’s nuclear program before voting for a bill that President Obama has said would undermine any chance of reaching an agreement.

headline: Morning Agenda: Subprime Auto Loans Spun Into Gold
abstract: Investors are fueling the boom in subprime auto lending. | Snow blankets the New York region. | A Dodd-Frank provision on disclosing pay ratios has stalled. | Helena Morrissey is the face of women’s advancement in business in Britain.
lead_paragraph: Across the country, there is a booming business in lending to poor people with bad credit who need cars to get to work. But this market is “as much about Wall Street’s perpetual demand for high returns as it is about used cars,” DealBook’s Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report. “An influx of investor money is making more loans possible, but all that money may also be enabling excessive risk-taking that could have repercussions throughout the financial system.”

lead_paragraph: A police officer shot a man at an apartment in Lower Manhattan early on Tuesday after the man threatened a woman with a knife, officials said.

headline: Storm That Glanced at Region Hit Hard in New England
abstract: High winds and whiteout conditions swept across New England as the storm moved up the East Coast, leaving the island of Nantucket without power.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The projected epic storm that failed to deliver in New York City instead turned its full fury on eastern New England on Tuesday, unleashing howling winds that created whiteout conditions across the region and upended life on Nantucket, where virtually everyone lost power as well as all methods of modern communications.

Muammar el-Qaddafi more than three years ago.

headline: Close but Not Quite
abstract: Sometimes on deadline we seem to grab the first word we think of, not necessarily the best. With language as with facts, precision should be our hallmark.
lead_paragraph: As a colleague said in pointing out a couple of these recent lapses in word choice, sometimes on deadline we seem to grab the first word we think of, not necessarily the best. With language as with facts, precision should be our hallmark.

headline: In Performance: Jonny Donahoe of ‘Every Brilliant Thing’
abstract: The British comic performs a scene from the solo show at the Barrow Street Theater.
lead_paragraph: This week’s video features a scene from “Every Brilliant Thing,” a solo show starring the British comic Jonny Donahoe as a son who comes up with a huge list of reasons why his depressed and suicidal mother should continue living. The show, written by Duncan Macmillan (with Mr. Donahoe) and directed by George Perrin, continues through March 29 at the Barrow Street Theater.

headline: Remembering Auschwitz
abstract: As Holocaust survivors traveled to the concentration camp in Poland for the 70th anniversary of its liberation, a look back at the moments after its liberation.
lead_paragraph: As Holocaust survivors traveled to the concentration camp in Poland for the 70th anniversary of its liberation, a look back at the moments after its liberation.

lead_paragraph: Until recently, the development march of office and apartment towers that displaced warehouses and refineries along the Brooklyn waterfront largely spared Red Hook.

headline: Indonesian Military Halts Search for Victims of AirAsia Crash
abstract: A civilian agency will continue searching for the bodies of those who were on Flight 8501, but the armed forces were the mainstay of the operation that found 70 of the 162 people onboard.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesia’s armed forces on Tuesday officially halted the search for passengers on the AirAsia plane that crashed into the Java Sea last month, killing all 162 people aboard.

headline: The Debt Non-Spiral
abstract: Is the deficit scare coming back? No.
lead_paragraph: Amid all the other economic news, the CBO has issued its latest budget projections. According to the projections, the US deficit will soon stop shrinking and begin to rise again. Cue the Very Serious People, who are deeply distressed at the failure of the promised fiscal crisis to materialize; I’m sure we’ll see editorials and op-eds in the next few days warning us that the deficit is still public enemy #1.

headline: 1965 U.K. Says Farewell to Churchill
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1965 Britain Says Farewell to Churchill
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain began its long and sad farewell to Sir Winston Churchill today. Just as Big Ben pealed 11 a.m., the great door of St. Stephen at Westminster hall swung wide.

headline: Paris Takes Pains to Reassure Tourists
abstract: Less than a month after 17 people were killed in terror attacks on France, the government is assuring travelers that the City of Light is safe.
lead_paragraph: A throng of visitors huddled outside L’As du Fallafel on the Rue des Rosiers, braving the cold for a taste of the legendary restaurant’s takeout shawarma and chickpea fritters. Around them, people jammed onto the narrow cobbled street, dressed in bright scarves, arms loaded with shopping bags and cameras.

headline: Roman Architecture, Beyond the Colosseum
abstract: Contemporary structures, from museums to stadiums to churches, in the city’s outskirts.
lead_paragraph: For people who love contemporary architecture, trying to find striking new buildings in the historic center of Rome is about as easy as trying to go gluten-free there. But if you move a little farther out — or a lot — there are stunning treasures to find, from museums to stadiums to churches, not to mention animated new neighborhoods that you probably would have never explored in the first place.

headline: Twitter Adds Group Messaging and Video Recording
keywords: ['Instant Messaging', 'Mobile Applications', 'Social Media', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: In an effort to catch up to rival services like Facebook, Twitter will now allow people to shoot, edit and post video directly from its mobile apps. Also, private messages on the service can now be sent to as many as 20 people.
lead_paragraph: Faced with slow growth in new users and usage by existing users, Twitter executives repeatedly promised improvements to make the social network more inviting.

headline: The Tyranny of Greece Over Germany
abstract: Did bad luck produce perverse policy?
lead_paragraph: No, I haven’t lost my mind. That’s the title of a classic book by Eliza Marian Butler arguing that German culture was warped by an obsession with ancient Greece, which has nothing at all to do with the current problems of macroeconomic policy. But the title came to mind when I read Simon Wren-Lewis’s meditation on two different hypotheses about the disastrous 2010 turn to austerity. One hypothesis, as he says, is that it was just bad luck: Greece blew up at the end of 2009, and false analogies with Greece soon dominated policy debate; you can call this Hellenization of discourse the tyranny of Greece, not so much over Germany, as over the OECD as a whole.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Jan. 20-26, 2015
abstract: Have you been following the news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more, and look for a new edition each week on Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: Have you been following the news?

headline: Totally Prepared. Still Freaking Out.
abstract: One would think that we’d be more ready for her; after all, we had been waiting for this moment for over three years. But “ready” and “get your car seat” are two very different things.
lead_paragraph: When my wife, Rachel, got off the phone with the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) on Jan. 19, after her usual morning check in on how Evy was doing — we visit her in the afternoons to be clear of doctors’ rounds, which would keep us in the hallway and not by Evy’s side — her voice had a mixture of amazement, pride and fear, the verbal equivalent of turning white when scared.

headline: S.E.C. Faces Challenges Over the Constitutionality of Some of Its Court Proceedings
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Defense lawyers say the Securities and Exchange Commission’s push to bring more cases before its administrative law judges rather than in federal district courts is not just unfair but also unconstitutional, Peter J. Henning writes in White Collar Watch.
lead_paragraph: It is probably not a stretch to say that the Securities and Exchange Commission likes to win every case that it decides to bring.

headline: Marriage of Convenience
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: How does the new gay rights case before the Supreme Court play into John Roberts’s long game?
lead_paragraph: Of the many gay and lesbian couples fighting for the right to marry in the courts, April DeBoer and Jayne Rowse are listed first in the case that the Supreme Court will hear this spring. DeBoer and Rowse, who live in Hazel Park, Mich., want to marry so they can both be adoptive parents to the four children they are raising together. The women, both nurses, stagger their hospital shifts so they can take turns at home with the kids, ages 2 to 6, two of whom have special needs.

headline: Lyft, Now in Talks for More Funding, Pushes Growth Strategy
abstract: Lyft must persuade its backers that the company has a fighting chance against Uber, which operates in hundreds of cities globally and has raised many times more money.
lead_paragraph: Lyft, the popular ride-hailing start-up, is nowhere near as large as Uber, its top competitor. That certainly has not stopped Lyft from trying to catch up.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Her Detractors: Reporter’s Notebook
keywords: ['Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Amy Chozick describes the challenges of fairly reporting the shift in tone of the ire that is directed at Hillary Rodham Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presumed 2016 presidential campaign is already drawing a lot of criticism. That may not be a surprise. But Amy Chozick, a political reporter, is finding that the attacks against Mrs. Clinton have a new angle. She describes the challenge of reporting fairly on this subtle shift and what it may mean.

headline: A Snowstorm in the Northeast
abstract: The region was unusually quiet overnight, with some drivers ordered to stay off the roads, the New York City subways shut down, and bridges and tunnels closed.
lead_paragraph: The region was unusually quiet overnight, with some drivers ordered to stay off the roads, the New York City subways shut down, and bridges and tunnels closed.

headline: Sundance 2015: A Role Worth Dying For
abstract: The star of “The Diary of a Teenage Girl” says that after she read the script, she felt for the first time that she would die if she didn’t get the part.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah – Mighty was the praise for “The Diary of a Teenage Girl” after its premiere here on Sunday, especially after word got out that Sony Pictures Classics had picked it up.

headline: Photographing the Border: The Landscape Behind the Politics

headline: Outliving Horror for 70 Years and Never Forgetting

lead_paragraph: OSWIECIM, Poland — More than 3,000 guests, including Holocaust survivors and foreign dignitaries, gathered on Tuesday at a site marking one of history’s biggest horrors, the Auschwitz-Birkenau death camps in Poland, which were liberated by Soviet troops 70 years ago in the closing months of World War II.

headline: A Data-Science Lender Takes on Student Debt
abstract: Earnest, a start-up lender, is moving into the student debt market. Using data-science tools, Earnest says it can offer lower, tailored rates and flexible repayment schedules.
lead_paragraph: Louis Beryl insists that financially responsible young people are the borrowers most disadvantaged by the traditional math of consumer lending. The standard scoring of creditworthiness relies largely on a person’s credit history, and that’s a blunt instrument. Since young people have slender credit histories, he said, they pay higher rates than they should.

headline: Snow Fell, but Food Deliverymen Got the Chicken Curry Through

Cheeks shedding steam, eyebrows still thawing, he had just come in from a nearby chicken curry run in Williamsburg. Now he was headed out again — with chicken madras, chicken poori and an order of lemon rice — on a longer trip to Greenpoint.

headline: Most New York Theaters and Concert Halls Will Reopen Tuesday

With this week’s snowstorm a bust (at least in most of New York City), Broadway producers and theater owners announced that most plays and musicals would hold their regularly scheduled Tuesday evening performances. Disney’s two Broadway musicals, “The Lion King” and “Aladdin,” have been canceled, a decision producers made on Monday amid grim weather forecasts and the state of emergency declared by government officials. Both shows are offering refunds for Tuesday night’s shows.

headline: 1915: Indian Receives Victoria Cross
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: King George conferred the Victoria Cross to an Indian soldier in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — At Buckingham Palace, yesterday, King George conferred the Victoria Cross on Sepoy Khudadad Khan, the first Indian soldier to earn the coveted distinction. Khudadad Khan, or the 129th Duke of Connaught’s Own Baluchis, was the sole survivor of a gallant machine-gun team, who on October 30 heroically fought to the last, every man being bayoneted at his post. Though badly wounded, Khudadad Khan managed some time afterward to rejoin his company, but never left his gun until he had rendered it useless to the enemy. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 28, 1915

headline: Did New York Overreact to the 2015 Blizzard?
abstract: With less snow than predicted falling on New York City, some are arguing that precautions were excessive. Can over-preparing for storms have its own dangers?
lead_paragraph: The winter storm once predicted to drop two feet or more of snow on New York City actually left only around eight inches as of early Tuesday morning, leading some to wonder if precautions like shutting down the New York subways were misplaced. Is preparing too much for such storms better than preparing too little — or are some kinds of preparations themselves dangerous?

He dreamed of being a magician. “Then, I wanted to be a professional skateboarder,” the artist, 28, said from a folding chair set atop the barren rooftop of his Los Angeles studio in the El Sereno neighborhood. It was a few weeks before his new, knotty multimedia show, “A Lil Taste of Cheeto in the Night,” would open in a 7,800-square-foot warehouse in Downtown Los Angeles, adjacent to Château Shatto, the gallery co-owned by Ito’s girlfriend and art dealer, Liv Barrett.

lead_paragraph: On Friday, Patrick Healy, The Times’s theater reporter, wrote about a dispute between the film producer Harvey Weinstein and the “Finding Neverland” theater publicist Rick Miramontez. He describes the delicate business of getting both sides of a hot-button story.

headline: New York’s Sanitation Commissioner Faced First Major Test
abstract: Kathryn Garcia confronted the threat of a major snowstorm armed with an emailed pep talk from her predecessor.
lead_paragraph: Kathryn Garcia stopped by Sanitation Department garages to check on her workers. She stood with Mayor Bill de Blasio to take questions about storm preparations. And she prepared herself for the snow that was threatening New York and would be the first big test of her tenure as the city’s sanitation commissioner.

lead_paragraph: The age-old mystery has at last been solved: Benjamin Franklin was Jack the Ripper.

headline: Navigating a Cold War, at Work and at Home
abstract: Season 3 of “The Americans,” about Soviet spies posing as suburban parents in Reagan-era America, begins on Wednesday on FX.
lead_paragraph: “The Americans” has a deep and discerning sense of irony, which is probably a prerequisite for a series about Soviet spies posing as suburban parents in Reagan-era America. Season 3 of this espionage drama begins on Wednesday on FX, and it may be the most provocative one yet.

lead_paragraph: Immigration is heating up (yet again) on Capitol Hill.

headline: Firefight Kills 4 in Kashmir
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: A counterterrorism raid ended in the death of an Indian colonel.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A colonel in India’s army, a police officer and two militants died Tuesday in a gun battle in Kashmir, the police said. Indian forces had surrounded a house where militants were thought to be visiting, in the Pulwama district of India-administered Kashmir, when the troops were attacked with grenades and Kalashnikov fire. Col. Munindra Nath Rai, a highly decorated officer and commander of the local Indian Army unit, led the operation and was killed. He had been awarded a gallantry medal the day before, Indian news media reported.

headline: Convincing and Conniving, a Law Firm’s Specialty
abstract: “Suits” returns on Wednesday with the ever-circling pool of sharks at Pearson Specter again looking for ways to cover for their brilliant young colleague.
lead_paragraph: When “Suits” started three and a half years ago, its premise didn’t seem built for the long haul. An entire show built around the idea of a lawyer who has to pretend that he went to Harvard Law School? Something like that worked for Michael J. Fox in “The Secret of My Success,” but for not quite two hours.

headline: Trailer: ‘The Dam Keeper’

lead_paragraph: A preview of the film.

lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York stressed the importance of heeding warnings though a snowstorm affected the city much less than had been anticipated.

headline: A Bolero of Blooms at Chanel’s Spring/Summer 2015 Couture Presentation
abstract: A standout look today was a two-piece cobalt ensemble topped with an elaborate floral shrug.
lead_paragraph: Chanel’s couture shows are known for their elaborate sets, and at this morning’s presentation Karl Lagerfeld staged a man-made botanical garden complete with male-model “gardeners” who watered the set to help the flowers “grow.” It wasn’t surprising, then, that many of the looks that followed incorporated fantastical flora. The collection opened with solid tangerine-and-green skirt suits and blossomed into an exquisite bouquet of embroidered dresses and separates. Some of the girls donned lace eye masks and others grunge-style beanies that lent themselves to the laid-back ease of this bold collection. A standout of the day was this two-piece cobalt look topped with a floral bolero and grounded by flat black leather boots.

headline: Yahoo to Spin Off Its Stake in Alibaba
abstract: Shedding its 15 percent stake in the Chinese e-commerce site turns the spotlight to Yahoo’s plans to revamp its core Internet advertising business.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Marissa Mayer, chief executive of Yahoo, said on Tuesday that the Internet company would spin off its 15.4 percent stake in Alibaba, China’s leading e-commerce company, into a separate company.

lead_paragraph: What can a pregnant photojournalist cover? Everything.

headline: Smithsonian Considers Opening London Location
abstract: The Smithsonian Institution has announced that it is considering a new 40,000-square-foot exhibition space in London, to open in 2021.
lead_paragraph: The Smithsonian Institution said on Tuesday that it was considering opening a new 40,000-square-foot exhibition space in London in 2021. The move, if it goes ahead, will be the first time in the Smithsonian’s 168-year history that it has opened a permanent exhibition space outside the United States.

headline: In Paris, Reality Collides With Fashion
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Paris Fashion Week', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: In several collections in Paris, there was a return to clothes that could make the difficult passage between the runway world and the real world.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — What looked to be the worst snowstorm in years was heading toward the Northeast as the men’s season drew to a close in Paris. Outside it was a balmy 48 degrees, but the last uncanceled flight to New York on Monday left around 10.

lead_paragraph: Yahoo finally announced what it will do with its $39 billion stake in the Alibaba Group: spin it off to investors. As I noted earlier, it’s the simplest way of dealing with shareholder pressure to sell those shares in a tax-efficient manner.

headline: A Fury Arrives. Hypocrisy, Too.
abstract: An unflinching exploration of jihadists is the focus of Abderrahmane Sissako’s film “Timbuktu.”
lead_paragraph: This month, Abderrahmane Sissako’s “Timbuktu,” an official selection in Cannes last year and a current nominee for the best foreign-language film Oscar, was caught up in the aftermath of the Charlie Hebdo murders, when the mayor of a Paris suburb briefly succeeded in banning it from a local cinema. Coming amid an outpouring of public and official support for freedom of speech, this act of censorship was both dismaying and ridiculous.

headline: A Multiplicity of Voices in High-Energy Movement
abstract: Parsons Dance, performing at the Joyce Theater, has unveiled a world premiere by the former company member Natalie Lomonte, alongside new and old works.
lead_paragraph: When his troupe turned 30 last year, David Parsons established GenerationNOW, a fellowship for up-and-coming choreographers. On Thursday at the Joyce Theater, Parsons Dance unveiled the first result of that admirable initiative, a world premiere by the former company member Natalie Lomonte, alongside new and old works by Mr. Parsons, Trey McIntyre and another Parsons alumnus, Robert Battle.

abstract: I have visited camps before, but this time the pain left me speechless.
lead_paragraph: KHANKE, Iraq — I HAVE visited Iraq five times since 2007, and I have seen nothing like the suffering I’m witnessing now.

headline: Los Angeles Opera Season to Open With Domingo Singing ‘Gianni Schicchi’
abstract: To open the season, Plácido Domingo will sing the title role in Puccini’s one-act opera “Gianni Schicchi” and then, after the intermission, move down to the orchestra pit to conduct Leoncavallo’s “Pagliacci.”
lead_paragraph: Plácido Domingo, the general director of the Los Angeles Opera, plans to open the company’s 30th anniversary season in September with a feat few other impresarios could attempt: He will sing the title role in Puccini’s one-act opera “Gianni Schicchi” and then, after the intermission, move down to the orchestra pit to conduct Leoncavallo’s “Pagliacci.”

headline: Obama Relents on Proposal to End ‘529’ College Savings Plans
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Savings', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Tuition']
abstract: The president, facing pressure from both parties, dropped from his budget a proposal to effectively end college savings accounts known as 529s.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, facing angry reprisals from parents and from lawmakers of both parties, will drop his proposal to effectively end the popular college savings accounts known as 529s, but will keep an expanded tuition tax credit at the center of his college access plan, White House officials said Tuesday.

headline: Young, French and Desperate for a Ride Out of Town
abstract: “My Name Is Hmmm ...” tells the story of an 11-year-old girl running away from a sexually abusive father.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy for filmmakers and critics alike to confuse artiness with art. As I watched “My Name Is Hmmm ...,” the feature directing debut of the French fashion designer agnès b. (identified here as Agnès Troublé), I kept wondering why the story about Céline (Lou-Lélia Demerliac), a glum 11-year-old who escapes her sexually abusive father by hiding out in the back of a truck, insists on changing style and texture every few minutes.

lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — In an unusually critical statement, a senior Pakistani official said that Pakistan remained opposed to India’s inclusion in the Nuclear Suppliers Group and feared that the country’s growing nuclear cooperation with the United States could harm deterrence efforts in South Asia.

lead_paragraph: Three masked robbers smashed a stolen sport utility vehicle into the entrance of Wells Fargo’s corporate museum in the heart of San Francisco’s financial district on Tuesday, then held a security guard at gunpoint and made off with gold nuggets from a display case, the San Francisco police said.

keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Income', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'United States Economy', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes']
abstract: In 2013, the concentration of income among the richest Americans remained at levels last seen nearly a century ago.
lead_paragraph: It’s the economic statistic that spawned the Occupy protest movement (“We are the 99 percent”), reshaped President Obama’s domestic program (“middle-class economics”), and most recently led the eternal Republican presidential hopeful Mitt Romney to bemoan that “the rich have gotten richer.”

headline: Report Sheds Light on Transgender Sex Workers in China
abstract: The report, “My Life Is Too Dark to See the Light,” draws on interviews with 70 people, most of whom left their rural hometowns to live in more liberal-minded cities, like Beijing and Shanghai, where they engage in sex work to make a living.
lead_paragraph: When Piao Piao, 26, who was born a boy in Shandong Province, arrived in Beijing in 2008 to live a life as the woman she felt she truly was, she faced innumerable problems. After she began dressing as a woman, while still using official documents that identified her as male, it was difficult for her to find a mainstream job. So she became an entertainer in bars, and supplemented her income as a sex worker.

lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — For 123 consecutive days, the AAA motor club reported a daily drop in national gasoline prices, bringing hundreds of dollars of savings to almost every American family. But that streak has now come to an end.

headline: Botswana Doctor Is Named to Lead W.H.O. in Africa
abstract: The much-praised appointee, Dr. Matshidiso Moeti, promised to overhaul the regional office, which has faced criticism for its slow response to the Ebola crisis.
lead_paragraph: A defining moment in the life of Dr. Matshidiso Moeti, the World Health Organization’s new regional director for Africa, came when she was 9 and her father realized that her little sister’s mathematics textbook was below even the level he had studied as a poor child on a South African farm.

headline: The Lasting Impacts of Football
abstract: The docudrama play “X’s and O’s (A Football Love Story)” looks at how a sport damages its players.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, CALIF. — As the youngest of Chuck Mercein’s four children, the actress Jenny Mercein had at least two things going for her. She received constant reminders — an indoctrination, really — that the children of anyone who had played football for Vince Lombardi’s Green Bay Packers would never, ever quit at anything. And she was Daddy’s little girl.

lead_paragraph: Shareholder activism is in full roar as hedge funds prowl and companies retreat, but Nelson Peltz’s campaign to replace four directors at DuPont may just be where corporate America finally draws the line and tries to stem the activist tide.

headline: Life of Italian Nobility for Sale, Complete With Regulations and Taxes
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Property Taxes', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Palaces and Castles', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes']
abstract: Italy’s long heritage of inherited wealth and property has withered thanks to cuts in government subsidies and high maintenance costs, among other factors.
lead_paragraph: PONTASSIEVE, Italy — Nestled on a gentle Tuscan hill near this town just east of Florence, and caressed by the morning fog, sits a medieval castle that was once home to the few prominent noble families who plotted against the Medicis’ rule during the Renaissance, some of whom are believed to have taken refuge here.

lead_paragraph: As New York City shut down in anticipation of a fearful snowstorm, a resourceful if hungry gray whippet named Burt approached a pile of canned dog food that rose like a mirage in the snowy expanse of Randalls Island.

headline: Health Care Enrollment Appears to Be Near Goal
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: As a Feb. 15 deadline approaches, the Obama administration said 9.5 million people had signed up for insurance this year through public marketplaces set up under the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Tuesday that 9.5 million people had signed up to receive health coverage through public marketplaces in 2015, with less than a month to go before the enrollment deadline.

headline: Ukraine: E.U. Sends Aid to East
abstract: The European Union delivered three planeloads of aid to eastern Ukraine on Tuesday, including blankets, tents, heaters and warm clothing.
lead_paragraph: The European Union delivered three planeloads of aid to eastern Ukraine on Tuesday, including blankets, tents, heaters and warm clothing, as part of a stepped-up effort to help the nearly one million people who have fled their homes in the war-torn region. The planes landed in Dnipropetrovsk, outside the area where pro-Russian separatists are battling the Ukrainian military. The assistance is being delivered by a coalition including Unicef, Save the Children, the World Food Program and People in Need, and is part of more than $53 million in aid pledged by European Union countries. The effort contrasted sharply with Russia’s unilateral dispatch of convoys to eastern Ukraine in recent months, which drew criticism from the Ukrainian government and the Red Cross over a lack of inspections and participation of international groups. “We have not forgotten the population of Ukraine,” said Christos Stylianides, the European commissioner for humanitarian assistance, who oversaw the planes’ arrival. “We’re in there big time,” he added. “It is our job to minimize the pain.”

headline: An Overflow of Memories From Joe Franklin’s Storied Career
abstract: The legendary New York TV talk show host who died last week kept an office packed to the gills with ephemera from his long career.
lead_paragraph: “Joe Franklin’s Memory Lane,” read the sign nearly buried in an avalanche of ephemera in Room 305, off a nondescript hallway in a Times Square building.

headline: Mexico Officially Declares Missing Students Dead
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Missing Persons']
abstract: Four months after the students were abducted, Mexico’s attorney general said confessions and forensic evidence supported the theory that their bodies were incinerated near a garbage dump.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Four months after the abduction of 43 rural college students shook the nation and set off a political crisis, Mexico’s attorney general on Tuesday officially declared the students dead, saying confessions and forensic evidence supported the theory that their bodies were incinerated near a garbage dump.

lead_paragraph: Myriad Genetics has essentially given up trying to stop other companies from offering tests for increased risk of breast cancer, ending a dispute that was the subject of a landmark Supreme Court ruling that human genes cannot be patented.

lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The State of Georgia executed a convicted murderer, Warren Lee Hill, on Tuesday night, ending a prolonged legal fight that led to a series of court-ordered reprieves and frequently tested the state’s standards for capital punishment.

headline: Russian Movie ‘Leviathan’ Gets Applause in Hollywood but Scorn at Home
abstract: The film has admirers and won a Golden Globe, but some Russian detractors want it banned and accuse its director of acting under Western orders.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In many ways, the movie “Leviathan” is Russia’s greatest cinematic accomplishment in years, maybe decades. The Golden Globe winner this month for best foreign film, it provides an unrelenting, vodka-soaked portrait of small-town corruption that has been praised by critics and filmmakers throughout the world — everywhere, it seems, but Russia.

headline: ‘Empire’ May Provide Fox the Big Hit It Needs

headline: Bill Monbouquette, 78, Dies; Pitching Ace When Red Sox Struggled

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Leon Brittan, a British politician who rose fast and far in the Margaret Thatcher government, only to see his career crash over a leaked letter in a dispute over a helicopter company, died on Jan. 21 at his home here. He was 75.

headline: On Tour, the Stories Keep Getting Weirder

headline: Civil War Submarines
abstract: How the conflict shaped the future of underwater warfare.
lead_paragraph: In the darkness of Feb. 17, 1864, off the coast of Charleston, S.C., the Union warship Housatonic’s crew clung to her rigging and masts that thrust up from the shallow water, awaiting rescue. Despite the fact that Housatonic’s attacker, the Confederate submarine Hunley, would not return from her mission and remain missing for over 150 years, her victory proved the viability of submarines as a weapon. The North and South would approach that knowledge in different ways.

headline: Uganda: Agency Cuts Refugees’ Rations
abstract: Faced with a funding shortfall, the World Food Program, the lead United Nations relief agency for fighting hunger, halved rations on Tuesday to nearly 150,000 South Sudanese refugees in Uganda.
lead_paragraph: Faced with a funding shortfall, the World Food Program, the lead United Nations relief agency for fighting hunger, halved rations on Tuesday to nearly 150,000 refugees in Uganda, a majority of them from the Democratic Republic of Congo. The cuts, announced by the agency’s Uganda director, Alice Martin-Daihirou, come as the program struggles to raise $30 million to fund the Uganda operation for the next six months. Ms. Martin-Daihirou called the step “a last resort to ensure we can continue providing lifesaving support” to the 150,000 refugees, nearly half of all refugees receiving the agency’s assistance in Uganda. Their arrival predated the December 2013 outbreak of fighting in South Sudan, which caused a flight of 138,000 South Sudanese to Uganda, who are not affected by the cuts. The agency’s recurrent funding problems have forced it to cut or halt food-aid distribution. Last month, it suspended a voucher program that had helped nearly 1.7 million Syrian refugees, but resumed it after an emergency fund-raising appeal.

headline: A$AP Rocky on His Sundance Hit, Mourning A$AP Yams and Why He Rejects Those Tupac Comparisons
abstract: The 26-year-old rapper’s first film, “Dope,” a hip-hop-driven comedy in which he plays a drug dealer named Dom, is an early favorite to win the festival’s audience award.
lead_paragraph: It’s been an up-and-down couple of weeks for A$AP Rocky. On Saturday, the 26-year-old rapper attended the world premiere of his new film, “Dope,” a hip-hop-driven comedy in which he plays a drug dealer named Dom. (Also featured are Keith Stanfield, Zoë Kravitz and Rocky’s ex-girlfriend, the model Chanel Iman.) The movie — Rocky’s first — has been a Sundance hit, drawing rave reviews and becoming an early favorite to win the festival’s audience award. But Rocky, né Rakim Mayers, was in little mood to celebrate. Just six days earlier, on Jan. 18, his close friend and collaborator Steven “A$AP Yams” Rodriguez died suddenly of still-undisclosed causes. On Sunday morning, Rocky would have to fly to New York City for the funeral.

headline: Opening Ceremony Brings Vivienne Westwood’s Worlds End Shop Stateside
abstract: A 20-piece collection of the timeless “clothes for heroes” found at the designer’s fabled London store launches at the boutique Feb. 9.
lead_paragraph: Opening Ceremony’s latest co-conspirator is Vivienne Westwood, who has designed for the boutique a 20-piece collection based on the timeless “clothes for heroes” found at her fabled Worlds End shop in London. “We’d been wanting to do something with Vivienne for a while,” says Humberto Leon, the store’s cofounder with Carol Lim. “Growing up, I remember being excited about her brand’s messages and its relevancy to culture — and I wanted to share this incredible story that I revere, if people don’t already know about it.” The resulting capsule, priced from $95 for a T-shirt to $1,500 for a bomber jacket, includes reissued garments dating back to the ’70s — and transcends gender. “It plays on this idea of unisex that we’ve been working on for many years,” says Andreas Kronthaler, Westwood’s design partner and creative director (and husband). “We know a woman looks great in a man’s shirt, but can a man look great in a woman’s dress? It could be the case — it’s about pushing boundaries and experimenting.” Asked to select a standout item, Kronthaler mentions the Pirate Trouser, originally from Westwood’s 1981 Pirate collection, for its “muscly, active-looking, dynamic leg shape”; Leon, however, declined to choose just one. “It’s hard to pick specifics because it’s about telling the whole story,” he says.

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (13, 49) PENGUIN POST OFFICE Every summer in the Southern Hemisphere, a British post office at Port Lockroy, above, becomes the most popular tourist attraction for cruise ships to the Antarctic Peninsula, as some 3,000 gentoo penguins take up residence alongside the other seasonal inhabitants: volunteers from the United Kingdom Antarctic Heritage Trust, who run the remote outpost. There, each November, after a bout of intensive deep-sea fishing, the gentoos find their mates, build their nests, raise their young — and pose for pictures, as long as the photographer stays 15 feet away. This “Nature” episode ventures to Antarctica to film the four-month ritual. In “Sinkholes — Buried Alive,” at 10, “Nova” investigates what happens when the ground opens up beneath your feet.

headline: Czar Putin’s Next Moves
abstract: Is anyone paying attention to the awful things President Vladimir Putin of Russia is doing to Ukraine, not to mention his own country?
lead_paragraph: ZURICH — Last March, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton was quoted as saying that Russian President Vladimir Putin’s attack on Ukraine, supposedly in defense of Russian-speakers there, was just like “what Hitler did back in the ‘30s“ — using ethnic Germans to justify his invasion of neighboring lands. At the time, I thought such a comparison was over the top. I don’t think so anymore. I’d endorse Mrs. Clinton’s comparison purely for the shock value: It draws attention to the awful things Putin is doing to Ukraine, not to mention his own country, whose credit rating was just reduced to junk status.

headline: Reducing Our Obscene Level of Child Poverty
abstract: A new report on our nation’s “moral disgrace” reminds us that allowing child poverty to remain this widespread costs more than eliminating it would.
lead_paragraph: I’m not someone who believes that poverty can ever truly be ended — I’m one of those “the poor will always be with you” types — but I do believe that the ranks of the poor can and must be shrunk and that the effects of poverty can and must be ameliorated.

headline: The Fraud of the Student-Athlete Claim
abstract: A lawsuit from two former University of North Carolina athletes raises the question of whether getting a meaningful education is part of college sports.
lead_paragraph: Two former athletes at the University of North Carolina have filed a lawsuit against their alma mater and the National Collegiate Athletic Association, accusing them of academic fraud. College athletes who sue for compensation is an old story. But, in this instance, Rashanda McCants, a former women’s basketball player, and Devon Ramsay, who played football, are suing because, they say, they didn’t receive a meaningful education. They are seeking class-action status, damages for some athletes and changes in academic oversight.

headline: How Did Politics Get So Personal?
abstract: One study shows that from 1960 to 2010 the percentage of Republicans and Democrats who would be upset if their children married across party lines shot up.
lead_paragraph: Political hostility in the United States is more and more becoming personal hostility. New findings suggest that the sources of dispute in contemporary life go far beyond ideological differences or mere polarization. They have become elemental, almost tribal, tapping into in-group loyalty and out-group enmity.

headline: Morning Agenda: Yahoo’s Alibaba Split
abstract: Yahoo plans to spin off its stake in Alibaba. | The outcome of the fight over DuPont could define shareholder activism. | U.S. strengths are hurting American multinational corporations. | Thieves steal gold nuggets from Wells Fargo museum.
lead_paragraph: Marissa Mayer, the chief executive of Yahoo, said on Tuesday that the Internet company would spin off its 15.4 percent stake in Alibaba, China’s leading e-commerce company, into a separate company, Vindu Goel and Michael J. de la Merced report in The New York Times. Shareholders will directly reap all the remaining profit from Yahoo’s investment, which cost almost nothing a decade ago but is now worth about $39.5 billion. The Alibaba stake alone now makes up nearly 85 percent of Yahoo’s market value. Shares of Yahoo rose about 7 percent in after-hours trading after disclosure of the plan.

headline: ‘Gateway to Freedom,’ by Eric Foner
abstract: Mr. Foner, a historian, explores the network of blacks and whites who helped slaves escape to freedom.
lead_paragraph: “I dreaded the approach of summer, when snakes and slaveholders made their appearance,” wrote Harriet Jacobs, author, educator, servant, mother of two — and escaped slave.

headline: Yasmina Reza’s ‘Happy Are the Happy’
abstract: Yasmina Reza’s novel tells interlinked stories of yearning.
lead_paragraph: Like a handful of the 18 people who populate her latest novel, “Happy Are the Happy,” Yasmina Reza is formidably accomplished. A prolific novelist and playwright — two of her works for the stage, “Art” and “God of Carnage,” won Tony Awards for best play — as well as a screenwriter and actress, she haunts the halls of power in her native France. “Happy Are the Happy” is another coup, a quick and delicate book that’s as funny as it is humane. Each of its short chapters, titled with the name of the character speaking, is told in the first person and concerns, for the most part, other characters in the book soon to introduce themselves if they haven’t already. Everyone gets a word in, and the style is feathery as gossip. Characters chime with one another in ways they never realize, a conviviality that is bittersweet. Their voices are self-aware, a little jaundiced, vulnerable, sometimes plaintive, and entirely authentic. Accomplishment, Reza suggests, is no hedge against yearning or regret. Status, wealth, celebrity, sex appeal and good health are unevenly distributed and ­underappreciated, until they are in decline. Life isn’t sparkly, it’s a slog: “People, practically oldsters, lurching around Paris, bearing their lives.” Perhaps chasing the impractical is simply a way to stay in motion.

headline: Kehinde Wiley Puts a Classical Spin on His Contemporary Subjects
abstract: The painter Kehinde Wiley, the subject of a coming Brooklyn Museum retrospective, is known for vibrant, photo-based portraits of young black men in poses culled from art history.
lead_paragraph: Kehinde Wiley began thinking about the stereotypes that shadow black men long before events in Ferguson, Mo., pushed the phrase “unarmed black man” back into the headlines and inaugurated a new wave of the civil rights movement.

Colombian bakeries, Mexican taquerias and Dominican lunch counters dot commercial areas. Spanish conversations fill the streets. And sporting goods stores are more likely to display Ecuadorean national soccer jerseys than fan gear from the Jets and Giants.

The first is to stop and identify yourself as a journalist and hope that you are respected as a neutral observer. The second is to blow past the checkpoint and hope the soldiers guarding it don’t open fire on you.

headline: A Chicago Neighborhood Follows a Latin Beat
abstract: Pilsen, a Mexican-American enclave in the city’s Lower West Side, now draws tourists thanks to new shops, breweries and restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Pilsen, about a dozen blocks south of downtown Chicago, got its name from 19th-century Czech settlers who long ago gave way to more recent waves of Mexican immigrants. The enclave’s reputation seemed to bottom out in 2005, when the doll company American Girl introduced Marisol Luna, whose family leaves gritty Pilsen for the suburbs. But even then, a mix of Latino cafes and attractions including the National Museum of Mexican Art was drawing visitors and artists. Now new breweries, restaurants and the relocation of the popular Redmoon Theater have rooted Pilsen on Chicago’s tourism map.

headline: 36 Hours in Belfast, Northern Ireland
abstract: A more sophisticated city has emerged with a sleek new cultural center, a vibrant dining scene and plenty of friendly pubs in which to while away the hours.
lead_paragraph: Avoided, underrated or just plain forgotten, Belfast is a city that’s been fighting a bad reputation for half a century. A visit today, however, is an eye-opening experience in the best possible way. Belfast has been coming into its own in the last few years, developing a vibrant restaurant scene, award-winning architecture — the Royal Institute of British Architects gave the MAC, a sleek arts venue, a National Award in 2013 — and a new cosmopolitanism, although fried breakfasts and a heightened awareness of sectarian conflict are still an integral part of most residents’ days. The friendliness of the people is what’s most appealing in this small and very walkable city, from smiling servers to talkative bartenders to helpful strangers on the street. Visit Belfast to soak up good vibes, to eat well and to drink unstintingly. It’s a city that’s at its best when enjoyed from behind a pint glass.

headline: Reader Idea | Student Opinion Questions as E.L.L. Writing Prompts
abstract: We’re thrilled that our daily Student Opinion questions attract such a variety of kinds of students to engage with current events and ideas, but we hope that English Language Learners worldwide know that we are especially impressed by their contributions. This lesson plan shows how to tailor the feature to the challenges and rewards of expressing opinions in a non-native language.
lead_paragraph: This week we’ll be publishing three more great Reader Ideas, and hoping you’ll write in with your own.

headline: From Buzz to Bombs: A Dispatch From the Sundance Film Festival
keywords: ['Festivals', 'Movies', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)']
abstract: Brooks Barnes tells of how he learned to cover the Sundance Film Festival, and what mistakes he will never make again.
lead_paragraph: Brooks Barnes covers show business for The Times. Last week he attended the Sundance Film Festival. For a reporter, the festival is probably less glamorous than it seems. He describes the highs and lows of covering the screenings, and how he avoided the festival’s public relations hype.

headline: Suspicion Is Cast on Aide in Death of Argentine Prosecutor
abstract: Investigators say Diego Lagomarsino, who worked with the prosecutor, Alberto Nisman, lent Mr. Nisman the pistol used in his death.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Argentina’s government on Wednesday cast greater suspicion on an aide to Alberto Nisman, the prosecutor whose mysterious death this month has shaken the country, by describing the aide as an intelligence operative — adding to its assertions that rogue spies were involved in the events around Mr. Nisman’s death.

headline: Whitewashing the Crazy, Fed Edition
abstract: What the anti-Fed people have really been saying.
lead_paragraph: How does one report on politics when a significant wing of the political spectrum is, not to put too fine a point on it, stark raving mad? I appreciate that it’s hard to do without attracting accusations of bias; on the other hand, there’s a temptation to soft-pedal the crazy, to make it seem as if politicians were less out there than they really are.

headline: Moriah Evans’s ‘Social Dance 1-8: Index’ at Issue Project Room
abstract: The choreographer Moriah Evans plays with the paradoxical ratios of intimacy and proximity in contemporary social dance in an Issue Project Room performance.
lead_paragraph: Before each performance of “Social Dance 1-8: Index,” the choreographer Moriah Evans personally escorts audience members to seats of her choosing. It’s the action of a hostess, though Ms. Evans isn’t cordial. As a cold abstraction of a social gesture, and as an indication of Ms. Evans’s close control over every part of her work, this is an apt introduction to what follows.

headline: OK Go Video and Volcano Journey Make the Cut for Drone Film Festival
abstract: The festival aims to show what kind of art drones can help make.
lead_paragraph: Superman flying with a GoPro, an intricately choreographed OK Go music video and a trip inside a volcano will  all be part of  the first New York City Drone Film Festival, organizers announced Wednesday.
