lead_paragraph: While he is shooting and filing images for print and the web, Stephen Crowley, a photographer for The Times, is also sharing photos on his Instagram account, @crowleygraph.

headline: Federal Reserve Won’t Raise Interest Rates Before June, at Earliest
abstract: The Federal Reserve gave its most upbeat economic assessment since the recession, though it did say inflation remains sluggish.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve kept its options open on Wednesday, signaling that it would not raise short-term interest rates any earlier than June, while leaving unresolved how much longer it might be willing to wait before lifting its benchmark rate from near zero, where the central bank has held it for more than six years.

headline: At Silk Road Trial, Lawyers Fight to Include Evidence They Call Vital: Emoji
keywords: ['Black Markets', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Emojis and Emoticons', 'Symbols']
abstract: How chats and other messages and their symbols should be presented in court has become a subplot in the trial of a California man charged with running the online black market.
lead_paragraph: The trial of Ross W. Ulbricht, a California man charged with running an online black-market bazaar called Silk Road, had barely begun when an unusual objection was lodged.

headline: Dabbling in Romantic Chemistry
abstract: Martin Starr, best known for nerdy or acerbic roles, plays the romantic lead in the film “Amira & Sam.”
lead_paragraph: Since playing one of the geeks on the short-lived TV series “Freaks and Geeks,” Martin Starr — variously bearded, bespectacled, acerbic, nerdy or all of the above — has been part of many memorable comic ensembles, from the films “Knocked Up” and “Adventureland” to HBO’s current series “Silicon Valley.” But for his latest film, he did his most surprising thing to date for a role: clean up.

headline: Workers at London’s National Gallery Plan Five-Day Strike
abstract: About 250 union workers at the museum are planning a five-day strike to protest the privatization of visitor and security services. The museum’s management has said there will be no layoffs.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Employees at the National Gallery here have voted in favor of a five-day strike in response to the museum’s decision to outsource visitor and security services to a private company. The change would affect approximately 400 of the 600 staff members. About 250 employees who are members of the Public and Commercial Services union voted in favor of the strike, which is planned for Feb. 3 to 7. Mark Serwotka, the general secretary of the union, said in a statement that the museum’s plan “risks damaging the worldwide reputation of what is one of the U.K.’s greatest cultural assets.”

headline: Perfectly Reasonable Question: Gender of Letter Writers
abstract: The letters editor explains how choices are made and who makes them
lead_paragraph: From time to time, I take up questions that have come to me from readers, pose them to Times editors, and publish the questions and answers without providing further commentary. I’ll do a few of those over the next few days.

headline: 1890: Horrible Sufferings at Sea
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The crew of the Arethusa suffered a terrible fate in 1890.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Sufferings at sea have seldom taken a more horrible form than those undergone by the crew of the ship Arethusa of Liverpool. The Arethusa was bound from the Tyne to Valparaiso, and on September 29 her cargo of coal took fire. On October 2, the crew of twenty-three men took to two boats, and at that time they were only twenty six miles from Falkland Islands, when the weather became dirty and during the night the boats parted company. Seven days later the boat, with the captain and ten men, arrived at Port Stanley, the crew being in a pitiable condition. The barque Lady Octavia picked up the other boat. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 29, 1890

lead_paragraph: A federal bankruptcy judge in Delaware said on Wednesday that Caesars Entertainment, the troubled casino operator, could proceed with a Chapter 11 bankruptcy of its largest unit in its preferred jurisdiction of Chicago, handing an incremental but important victory to the company and its private equity backers.

headline: Colombia Calls for Release of Venezuelan Political Prisoner
abstract: Latin American governments typically refrain from criticizing the domestic policies of their neighbors.
lead_paragraph: Latin American governments typically refrain from criticizing the domestic policies of their neighbors. But Colombia broke with that unwritten rule this week by calling on Venezuela to free the political prisoner Leopoldo López.

headline: Justices Stay Executions of 3 in Oklahoma, Pending Decision on Lethal Drug Protocol
abstract: The Supreme Court was asked by state officials to allow it to put off the executions until the justices ruled on a new combination of drugs to be used in the state’s executions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday stayed the executions of three Oklahoma inmates who were challenging the state’s lethal injection protocol on the grounds that it might cause intense suffering.

Wonder flagship store opening on Spring Street one chilly night in October as Solange Knowles spun records on a console in the middle of a party-packed room. It was 2011, and J. Christopher Burch hovered nearby, surveying guests who had come to celebrate the opening of his new candy-colored emporium.

headline: We Can’t Blame a Few Rich People for Global Poverty
abstract: The world’s richest 80 people hold as much wealth as the poorest half of the entire planet, but that says more about the poor than the rich.

It’s the centerpiece of Oxfam’s latest campaign, timed to coincide with the touching down of several of those billionaires in Davos for the World Economic Forum last week.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (13, 49) GRANTCHESTER James Norton (“Happy Valley”), above, portrays Sidney Chambers, a small-town vicar with a love of jazz, whiskey and complicated women who discovers an enthusiasm for sleuthing after a concerned parishioner compels him to investigate a grisly suicide in this new “Masterpiece Mystery!” series, based on the mysteries by James Runcie. “ ‘Grantchester’ will be breezy fun for fans of the form, though the more discerning will be put off by how rudimentary the actual murder mysteries are after being squeezed into 50 minutes (half the norm for this type of show),” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times about what he called “cozy mysteries.” And while “it benefits from the presence of the veteran Robson Green (‘Wire in the Blood,’ ‘Touching Evil’) as Sidney’s sidekick, Inspector Keating,” Mr. Hale added, he found Mr. Norton, though amiable and good to look at, “a little dim”: “As religiously inclined young British sleuths go — and I apologize for a reference that only my fellow British-mystery zealots will understand — he’s no Hathaway.” In “Downton Abbey,” which leads in at 9, Lady Mary (Michelle Dockery) and Lord Gillingham (Tom Cullen) check into a Liverpool hotel — the better to check out their love. The art historian Simon Bricker (Richard E. Grant) turns his attention from a Piero della Francesca painting to its owner, Lady Cora (Elizabeth McGovern). A secret from the past of the Dowager Countess (Maggie Smith) resurfaces. And the police continue to investigate the death of Lord Gillingham’s valet.

headline: The Camera Is On: Now Go Create
abstract: The documentary “Ballet 422,” directed by Jody Lee Lipes, follows the choreographer Justin Peck.
lead_paragraph: Justin Peck is not a lonely guy. He has a girlfriend, close colleagues, a loving family. But you wouldn’t necessarily know this from watching him in “Ballet 422,” the documentary that chronicles his third piece of choreography for New York City Ballet from creation to performance. In the film, to be released on Feb. 6, Mr. Peck is so intensely focused, so singular of purpose, that you wonder whether he has anything left for a personal life.

headline: ‘King Charles III,’ a Hit in London, Is Aiming at Broadway

lead_paragraph: Broadway is getting Queen Elizabeth II this spring in “The Audience,” a play starring Helen Mirren as the monarch, and in all probability Broadway will get her son soon afterward with “King Charles III,” Mike Bartlett’s future-history play that has earned critical acclaim in London.

headline: This Just In: Local Newscasters Play Themselves on TV
abstract: “Breaking Greenville,” on TruTV, is a reality show tracking the competition between two news stations in Mississippi.

Something to counteract all the earnestness, all the impossibly sharp newsroom dialogue about earthshaking issues. Five minutes of “Breaking Greenville” should do the trick.

headline: Ulyana Sergeenko, Couture’s Russian Ambassador, on How to Look Relaxed and Gorgeous (Even When You’re Stressed Out)
abstract: The designer, who showed her fifth couture collection earlier this week, shares her beauty secrets.
lead_paragraph: If Ulyana Sergeenko is having a hectic couture season, it certainly doesn’t show. However uncertain the Russian presence in fashion may be at the moment, the designer, who presented her fifth collection earlier this week, has become the face of it — and deservedly so, given her flawless grooming and porcelain complexion. (Perhaps her more low-key approach — forgoing the typical runway format, she instead hosted one-on-one appointments at Le Bristol in Paris — hasn’t hurt.) Here, Sergeenko shares her secrets to maintaining a relaxed look and immaculate skin, even when under pressure.

headline: Bringing Warm Exuberance to a Series of Character Studies
abstract: Alexandre Tharaud, the French pianist, performed a program of Mozart, Beethoven, Schubert and Couperin, among others, at Zankel Hall.
lead_paragraph: “Scarlatti,” announced the French pianist Alexandre Tharaud before his second encore at Zankel Hall on Tuesday night, emphatically pronouncing the name of a composer he has championed live and on disc. He offered Scarlatti’s Sonata in D Minor (K. 141), decisively rendering the percussive effects and guitarlike inflections in a rendition notable for its articulation and wild exuberance.

headline: Fiery Odes Dedicated to a Love Still Burning
abstract: Many of the martial soul-pop songs in the Swedish singer Seinabo Sey’s short set at Le Poisson Rouge were inspired by a doomed romance.

But without the struggle, countless pop songs would never exist. Seinabo Sey (pronounced SAY-na-bo See) joins the fray with the sadder-but-stronger songs she brought to Le Poisson Rouge on Tuesday night.

headline: A Looker Who Lives for Laughs
abstract: Nick Hornby’s “Funny Girl” traces a pivotal time in British comedy through the lens of a beauty queen who abandons her title to make her name on TV in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: In “Funny Girl,” Nick Hornby uses the story of a reluctant beauty queen from Blackpool as the hook for a rambunctious cultural history of British television comedy 50 years ago. As befits a novel about a popular sitcom, this novel packs in lots of laughs, but it’s also got more heft than Mr. Hornby’s readers may expect. Its story begins in 1964, when the standards for everything that Britain found funny, familiar, thrilling and off limits were drastically changing. And its characters create the biggest hit on the BBC with a show that’s a sign of its times.

headline: A Street-Style Trick That Works IRL and More
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Coats and Jackets', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Handbags and Purses']
abstract: How to wear layers of outerwear and still look chic; long chains make low necklines look ladylike; and other shopping news.
lead_paragraph: Piling on outerwear to stay warm is a street-style trick that works IRL. And there are ways to pull off the stratagem without looking like a coat lady. The stylist Kusum Lynn suggests wearing a leather jacket or puffer under a classic men’s wear coat, adding an oversize scarf for color. For an undone yet still chic ensemble, she likes a relaxed-fit robe coat (preferably with an exaggerated collar) worn atop a chunky cardigan. To counter the proportions of slouchy outerwear, wear tailored trousers. “You can be at work with the worst hangover and feel like you’re still getting cozy in bed under the covers,” Ms. Lynn said.

headline: An Inventive Postwar Japanese Painter Has His Moment
abstract: Four exhibitions in New York and Dallas this winter and spring will showcase the work of Kazuo Shiraga, known as the “foot painter” of the underrepresented Gutai Art Association.
lead_paragraph: Ironically, Kazuo Shiraga’s feet were nearly his feet of clay. The breakout star of the Gutai Art Association, Shiraga became colloquially known as the “foot painter”; the Japanese postwar movement’s founder, Jiro Yoshihara, even dismissed Shiraga as a “nobody, if he didn’t paint with his feet.” After his 1955 performance “Challenging Mud,” in which the artist wrestled a mixture of cement, gravel, clay, plaster, pebbles and twigs into a “formless form,” Shiraga devised an entirely new painting technique. From 1959 onward, he suspended himself from his studio ceiling and manipulated the paint exclusively with his ten toes to create a range of textures from the slinky and supple to the protruding and violent. Almost 60 years later, Shiraga, whose dynamic contributions blend painting and performance, is still a misunderstood radical who is only now receiving the sort of American institutional and gallery attention that properly contextualizes the depth and reach of his practice.

headline: To Allay Fears, N.F.L. Huddles With Mothers
abstract: Through a nonprofit group, USA Football, the N.F.L. has tried to reassure mothers, many of whom decide which sports their children play, that football can be played safely.
lead_paragraph: KISSIMMEE, Fla. — Rebecca Morgan squared her feet, bent her knees, raised her hands and tried to connect with her inner linebacker. Beside her, two dozen other mothers did the same as they listened to Mike Haynes, a former N.F.L. defensive lineman, teach them how to tackle safely.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — “To defy circumstance and live with joie de vivre!” one Congolese dandy said, explaining his philosophy in a 2014 documentary about Les Sapeurs, or le Société des Ambianceurs et des Personnes Élégantes (Society of Ambiance-Makers and Elegant Persons), and incidentally describing a fundamental purpose of fashion.

headline: The Book Ends, and the Story Begins
abstract: Jason Hall, the screenwriter of “American Sniper,” created a more complex character than the one in the book of the same name.
lead_paragraph: In “American Sniper,” Chris Kyle (Bradley Cooper) peers through the scope of a high-powered rifle, finger on the trigger, preparing to shoot a young boy. A Navy SEAL on his first tour of duty in Iraq, he has been tasked with protecting the lives of the Marines under his watch, and the boy is running full speed at a convoy of them, his hands wrapped around an enormous Russian-made grenade.

headline: All-but-Forgotten Prisoner in Jordan Is at Center of Swap Demand by ISIS
abstract: The Islamic State has said that if a failed suicide bomber, Sajida al-Rishawi, is not released by Jordan, it will kill a Japanese and a Jordanian hostage.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — During the nine years that Sajida al-Rishawi, 46, has been sitting in self-imposed solitary confinement in her cell at the Juweidah Women’s Prison in Jordan, refusing to mix with other prisoners, she has had hardly any visitors, other than her court-appointed lawyer.

headline: Zaha Hadid Settles Libel Suit Against New York Review of Books
abstract: The architect Zaha Hadid has settled a libel suit she had filed against the New York Review of Books.
lead_paragraph: The architect Zaha Hadid has settled her case against the New York Review of Books and critic Martin Filler, and donated the settlement money to an undisclosed charity that “protects and champions labor rights,” dezeen magazine reported on Tuesday.

headline: Sick Child’s Father Seeks Vaccination Requirement in California
abstract: Carl Krawitt, of Marin County, argued that parents who refused to have their children vaccinated against diseases like measles were putting his son at risk.
lead_paragraph: In the latest salvo in the vaccination wars that have shaken California since a measles outbreak originated at Disneyland last month, the father of a 6-year-old boy with leukemia has asked the superintendent of his Marin County school district to keep unvaccinated children out of school.

headline: ‘American Sniper’ Fuels a War on the Home Front
abstract: After earning more than $250 million and six Oscar nominations, the movie has spawned diatribes from both hand-wringing lefties and chest-thumping righties.
lead_paragraph: As “American Sniper” continues to spawn think pieces, internecine celebrity squabbles and diatribes from hand-wringing lefties and chest-thumping righties, it’s interesting to remember the naysaying about the film’s prospects that swirled just last month.

headline: Scholars at Odds on Ukraine
abstract: After members of an association supporting post-Soviet studies object to fellowships linked to a controversial Russia scholar, some academics accuse them of censorship.
lead_paragraph: Since the crisis in Ukraine began, the Russia scholar Stephen F. Cohen has cast himself in the role of the unbowed dissenter, whose sharp criticisms of America’s foreign policy in the region have earned him denunciations as “Putin’s American toady,” as The New Republic put it, and worse.

headline: First Draft Focus: Obama Bids Farewell to Hagel
abstract: President Obama embraced Chuck Hagel, the outgoing defense secretary, at a farewell ceremony in Fort Myer, Va., on Wednesday.

headline: Adrian Grenier Pitches Whale Movie With Sundance Party
keywords: ['Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Parties (Social)', 'Movies', 'Whales and Whaling', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: The “Entourage” star is making a documentary about what’s been called “the loneliest whale on the planet.”
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — While the Sundance Film Festival crowd was wondering last Saturday about which films to see and which gifting suites had the best swag, the actor Adrian Grenier had gathered about 100 friends for a candlelit dinner at a private home in Deer Valley, Utah. The occasion was not the coming “Entourage” movie in which he stars, but a passion project about a whale.

headline: Not Just Telling a Joke, but Showing It, Too
abstract: What distinguishes acts like Sebastian Maniscalco’s is a full-bodied commitment to the act-out: stand-up jargon describing a shift from narrating a joke to acting it.
lead_paragraph: The choreography of stand-up comedy is usually pretty simple: Walk onstage, grab the microphone and tell a joke. Lean forward, look one way and tell another.

headline: Friendship 9 Convictions Thrown Out
abstract: A judge in Rock Hill, S.C., vacated the convictions of nine black men who were arrested in 1961 for sitting at a whites-only lunch counter.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Rock Hill, S.C., vacated the convictions of nine black men who were arrested in 1961 for sitting at a whites-only lunch counter.

headline: Ice, Polar Bears and Death, but It’s Not Global Warming
abstract: An exotic setting provides gorgeous backdrops for the murder mystery “Fortitude” on Pivot. But does the story live up to its surroundings?
lead_paragraph: “Fortitude,” an ambitious 12-episode murder mystery beginning on Thursday night, takes place in two unusual locales. One is its slightly fantastical far-far-north setting, a fictional Arctic island — based on the Norwegian archipelago of Svalbard — where a small international community is outnumbered by polar bears; crime is thought to be nonexistent; and anyone near death is exiled to the mainland, because bodies can’t be buried in the permafrost.

headline: Amazon’s Got Mail
abstract: Amazon’s latest foray: back-end email systems.
lead_paragraph: Amazon Web Services on Wednesday announced Amazon WorkMail, an email service that adds a new front to the fierce competition in the cloud. WorkMail, which works behind existing interfaces like Microsoft Outlook, is being promoted as safer and cheaper than other systems.

headline: 54 Years Later, South Carolina Court Clears ‘Friendship Nine’
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: A prosecutor in Rock Hill said the misdemeanor trespassing charges against the nine black students should never have been filed.
lead_paragraph: ROCK HILL, S.C. — Fifty-four years after they went to jail for an anti-segregation protest in this former mill town, the African-American men who came to be known as the Friendship Nine returned to court Wednesday dressed in their sober Sunday best, as though a judge might sentence them again.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Finding a Path to Making 4 Spades in Florida
abstract: Zeke Jabbour, an eight-time national champion, hosts an annual charity pro-am tournament to benefit the National Parkinson Foundation.
lead_paragraph: Zeke Jabbour, an eight-time national champion, hosts an annual charity pro-am tournament to benefit the National Parkinson Foundation. Chaired by Joanne Weingold and Molly O’Neill, this year’s event — with 196 players, the biggest yet — was held on Sunday at St. Andrews Country Club in Boca Raton, Fla. Anyone could have played the same deals simultaneously at the Common Game website. Combined with sponsorship from Netjets, about $100,000 was raised.

headline: Shopping Sales and Events in New York City
abstract: A collection of shopping suggestions and sales.
lead_paragraph: ­Attention sneakerheads: Beginning Thursday, the athletic-shoe-inspired Alexander Wang spring collection will be available at Bergdorf Goodman in a pop-up on 5F. The installation is made from the same black-and-gray speckled performance rubber used for the set of the runway show. Get in the game with a graphic mesh tee dress ($950) or a striped poplin romper ($1,450); spend $500 and you’ll receive a USB playlist by Jesse Marco, a D.J. who collaborates with Mr. Wang. ­

headline: ‘This.’ Has People Clamoring for an Invite
abstract: An invitation-only social network whose exclusivity has media insiders jockeying to be invited to participate has generated hunger for its streamlined platform.
lead_paragraph: “This” is now more than a pronoun. In the online realm of social media, “this” is a statement, a proclamation, a call to action. Written often in caps, or as a hashtag (#THIS), “this” means “I second this sentiment,” “This is great” or “Read this.”

headline: Newly Released Books
abstract: Boualem Sansal, Magda Szabo, S. M. Hulse, Yasmina Reza, Michael Crummey and Megan Mayhew Bergman publish new books.
lead_paragraph: HARRAGA

headline: This Bed Keeps No Secrets
abstract: Aaron Poritz’s new bed design reveals how it’s held together, something traditional techniques seek to hide.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Poritz’s new bed was originally designed as a custom piece for a buyer from Design Within Reach, who commissioned it after seeing a daybed Mr. Poritz was showing at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair.

headline: Great Ideas Just Down the Road
abstract: The collection of furniture, lighting, textiles and accessories was designed by students from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago.
lead_paragraph: One of CB2’s newest lines, a 15-piece collection of furniture, lighting, textiles and accessories, was created by design students from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago. Conceived for small-space living, it is filled with clever ideas, among them a mirrored wall-mounted jewelry cabinet and a set of tables with a big presence but a small profile (Paradox nesting tables, $249). Prices range from $3.50 for a plate to $699 for a rug.

headline: Loretta Lynch Revisits an Ultra-Long Prison Sentence
abstract: The national political conversation has progressed since the reflexive “tough on crime” days.
lead_paragraph: Loretta Lynch fielded mostly predictable questions at her confirmation hearing on Wednesday. Senators weighing her nomination to be the next attorney general wondered: Does she believe President Obama has the legal authority to grant amnesty to five million undocumented immigrants? Will she just be another Eric Holder? Duke or UNC? And so on.

headline: Full Bloom in a World of White
abstract: Rebecca Louise Law’s art installations are constructed from cut flowers, often threaded on wire and suspended overhead.
lead_paragraph: ­There were thistles, Kangaroo Paw, ranunculus and peonies, hydrangeas, delphiniums and over 40 varieties of roses. In all, 14 species of 16,000 individual flowers lay in sweet-smelling drifts on lunch tables set up last weekend at the Viacom building in Times Square, home of MTV. There, more than 200 volunteers threaded blooms onto lengths of copper wire that were then gathered into bundles and hung above the building’s two entrances and in the visitors’ center. Standing under them and looking up, you were caught in a different sort of blizzard than the one that was expected this week. It was spring, abstracted, designed and orchestrated by Rebecca Louise Law, a British artist whose medium is flowers.

headline: I Don’t Want to Spend Much on Window Treatments. What Are the Most Appealing Options?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Windows']
abstract: Try buying premade curtain panels and hanging them from a track rather than a rod.
lead_paragraph: Q. I don’t want to spend too much on window treatments, because I’ll leave them behind when I sell. What are some affordable but attractive options?

headline: A Tip of the Cap
abstract: In preparation for the Super Bowl, a search for bottle openers.
lead_paragraph: On any given night, bartenders at Spuyten Duyvil, a craft beer bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, open about 200 bottles of beer. Joe Carroll, who owns the bar (as well as Fette Sau, St. Anselm, Gotham Artisanal and Lake Trout), doesn’t tend bar anymore — his role is strictly managerial now — but he did for three years. And he has strong opinions about bottle openers.

headline: Coming Full Circle
abstract: A Texan moves back into his family home, but not before making room for his boyhood hobby.
lead_paragraph: When Glen Rosenbaum was a teenager, his parents commissioned a midcentury architect named Arthur Steinberg to design a house in the Meyerland neighborhood in Houston. “My parents, Max and Helen, were really proud of it,” said Mr. Rosenbaum, who is now 66, a tax lawyer and the former board chairman at the Houston Grand Opera Association. “I was, too.”

headline: As Sales Dip, McDonald’s Is Replacing Don Thompson as Chief
abstract: Steve Easterbrook, chief branding officer, will take over from Don Thompson after one of the chain’s worst financial performances in years.
lead_paragraph: McDonald’s announced on Wednesday that its chief executive would step down, just days after the fast-food restaurant chain posted one of its worst financial performances in years.

headline: A Potluck for Product Development
abstract: FirstBuild, a subsidiary of GE, fast-tracks home products developed with input from a community of makers and hackers.
lead_paragraph: FirstBuild, a subsidiary of GE, operates like an in-house start-up. Its home products are designed with input from a community of makers and hackers, produced in low quantities and fast-tracked to the marketplace. The misses quietly fade away; the hits can then be manufactured on a larger scale.

headline: After Three Years, It’s Time to Turn on the Lights
keywords: ['Lamps and Lampshades', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Ceramics and Pottery']
abstract: Julian Peploe and David Ryan’s lamp designs, inspired by 20th century American and Scandinavian ceramics, have been a long time coming.
lead_paragraph: How long does it take to create a lighting collection? Three years, apparently — at least if you’re self-described “super type-A creatives,” like Julian Peploe, an art director, and David Ryan, a painter and sculptor.

headline: Swing, Sit and Sleep for Less
keywords: ['Porches, Patios and Decks', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Sales on furniture, bedding, porch swings and home accessories.
lead_paragraph: In-stock duvets are 20 percent off, and all orders of beds, mattresses, wardrobes, furniture and linen sets are 15 percent off at Flou in January (the narrow Biss trundle bed, originally $4,086, is about $3,473); 42 Greene Street (Broome Street), 212-941-9101, flou.com.

headline: Faulty Hood and Fire Hazard Lead to Twin Recalls for Nissan
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: The carmaker’s actions, which cover 640,000 vehicles, came on the same day as smaller recalls by Toyota and Ford.
lead_paragraph: Nissan is recalling almost 640,000 vehicles in two actions for a fire hazard and because the hood could open while the vehicle is moving, the automaker has informed federal regulators.

headline: Keira Knightley
abstract: The actress received her first Oscar nomination for “Pride and Prejudice.” Her second is for her role in “The Imitation Game.”
lead_paragraph: The actress received her first Oscar nomination for “Pride and Prejudice.” Her second is for her role in “The Imitation Game.”

headline: Beyond Luxurious
abstract: New York developers are redefining the meaning of “amenity.” Once it was a steam room. Now it’s a hamam.
lead_paragraph: New York developers are redefining the meaning of “amenity.” Once it was a steam room. Now it’s a hamam.

headline: Over-the-Top Amenities: Sweating the Details
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Saunas and Sweat Lodges', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Swimming Pools']
abstract: Developers of super-luxury apartments in New York are redefining the meaning of “amenity.” Once it was a steam room. Now it’s a hamam.
lead_paragraph: At the Cast Iron House, a late-19th-century landmark in TriBeCa reimagined by Shigeru Ban, the Pritzker Prize-winning architect, into 13 shiny white condos, you will find another flourish designed by Mr. Ban: a Turkish-style hamam, complete with a plunge pool and a “deluge” shower. (We’ll circle back to that deluge later.)

headline: French Video Tries to Blunt Jihad’s Allure Among Youth
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Youth', 'Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Hate Crimes', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: The video, showing clips of executions, wounded children and crucifixions, is aimed at countering recruitment efforts by the Islamic State and other terrorist groups.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In a bid to stop the flow of disaffected youth to the battlefields of Syria and Iraq, the French government on Wednesday released a graphic two-minute video showing clips of executions, wounded children and crucifixions that tells potential recruits that the glory promised to them is a lie.

headline: Swept Away by a Love for Dust
abstract: Klaus Pichler went looking for something most people want to avoid: dust.
lead_paragraph: Klaus Pichler went looking for something most people want to avoid: dust.

headline: Five Minutes to Moonflower
keywords: ['Flowers and Plants', 'Watches and Clocks', 'Gardens and Gardening']
abstract: The idea of a garden that blooms like clockwork has been around for centuries. But how well does it work?
lead_paragraph: The professionals said it could not be done. They had never tried it, and they didn’t know any public garden that had tried it, and they wouldn’t recommend anyone else give it a try.

headline: Study Finds H.I.V. Drugs Priced Out of Reach
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: The study found evidence of “adverse tiering,” or placing all of the drugs used to treat H.I.V. in a specialty tier, where consumers are required to pay at least 30 percent of the cost of the drug.
lead_paragraph: Drugs to treat H.I.V. and AIDS are being priced out of reach for many patients enrolled in insurance plans through the new health care exchanges, despite warnings that such practices are illegal under the Obama administration’s health care law, according to a new analysis by Harvard researchers.

headline: As Profit Slows, Ikea Notes Need to Move Online
abstract: Peter Agnefjall, Ikea’s chief executive, said, “We realized this is not a trend, it’s a megashift.”
lead_paragraph: When Ikea burst onto the American retail scene in 1985, it was a trailblazer. Ikea, the Swedish retailer, had mastered a clean, simple aesthetic long before Apple opened its sleek stores. It figured out how shoppers would flock to buy hip, if not very durable, products at low prices, long before H&M or Zara made that their business model.

headline: New York City’s First Lady Shares Family History as She Unveils Push on Mental Health Care
abstract: After describing her experiences with loved ones’ mental illnesses, Chirlane McCray announced plans for a review of the problems affecting New Yorkers to help the city address their care.
lead_paragraph: Chirlane McCray, the wife of Mayor Bill de Blasio, revealed on Wednesday that she had been surrounded by mental illness most of her life — first as a child of parents who had depression and later as a mother of a daughter who is recovering from depression, anxiety and substance abuse.

headline: The People vs. Boko Haram
abstract: How a band of vigilantes helped defend a Nigerian city from Islamist militants.
lead_paragraph: Through the fall and winter, the Islamist militant group Boko Haram has seemed nearly unstoppable. It has captured town after town in northeastern Nigeria and laid siege to the fishing hamlet Baga and nearby villages, killing hundreds of people. But over the weekend, the group finally suffered a significant setback. The militants tried to invade Maiduguri, a city of two million in the northeast, as well as two towns in the area, Monguno and Konduga. While Monguno — which is 80 miles north of Maiduguri and houses a military base — fell under Boko Haram control on Sunday, Maiduguri and Konduga held their ground, in no small part because of vigilantes who fought alongside the Nigerian military.

headline: Bill Belichick Wore Flip-Flops
abstract: On (not) covering the Super Bowl media circus.
lead_paragraph: Bill Belichick wore flip-flops.*

headline: Alan J. Hirschfield, 79, Hollywood Executive, Is Dead
abstract: At Columbia Pictures, Mr. Hirschfield fought board members in an attempt to fire an executive who had embezzled money, and both were forced out.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Alan J. Hirschfield, an executive who ran two major film studios and saw Columbia Pictures through one of Hollywood’s most colorful and chronicled financial scandals, died on Jan. 15 at his home in Wilson, Wyo. He was 79.

headline: Michelle Obama Praised for Bold Stand She Didn’t Take in Saudi Arabia
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'First Ladies (US)', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The first lady observed longstanding diplomatic protocol by not covering her hair during a visit with the new Saudi leader this week.
lead_paragraph: As images of President Obama and the first lady, Michelle Obama, with the new Saudi leader, King Salman, circulated online after their brief visit to Riyadh on Tuesday, commentators, observers watching from afar, seized on the fact that Mrs. Obama had not covered her hair during the audience with the new monarch.

headline: Oil Company Sasol Delays Huge Louisiana Project as Prices Slide
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: The $14 billion project, which had not received final approval from Sasol, was to begin production in 2018, creating some 1,200 permanent jobs.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — In the biggest retrenchment in the United States as oil prices fall, Sasol has delayed an expansive $14 billion project in southwestern Louisiana to make diesel out of natural gas.

headline: In Pakistan, a Charity Project Points to Official Tolerance of Militants
abstract: On Monday, Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, the founder of Lashkar-e-Taiba, the group that waged the deadly 2008 Mumbai attacks, inaugurated an ambulance service run by the group’s charity wing, Jamaat-ud-Dawa, in Karachi.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — Violence and mayhem are the hallmarks of Lashkar-e-Taiba, the Pakistani group that waged the deadly 2008 Mumbai attacks. But this week, the group publicly expanded its operations in an entirely different domain: health care.

headline: As New Leadership Takes Over in Washington, Fiscal Battles Resurface
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy']
abstract: While both sides say they are trying to help the squeezed middle class, the divide between the two parties on fiscal policy may be as stark as at any time since Bill Clinton’s first term.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the era of falling budget deficits coming to an end, President Obama and Congress are hurtling toward a clash over spending as the White House and Democrats press for an easing of fiscal austerity just as Republicans redouble efforts to balance the budget.

headline: Homeowners in Poland Borrowed in Swiss Francs, and Now Pay Dearly
abstract: Switzerland’s move to untie its currency from the euro has caused the franc to soar, along with hundreds of thousands of mortgage payments in Poland.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Piotr Szczepaniak, an apartment manager here, had just finished work, checking faucets and making sure rents were paid. After making himself a coffee, he logged on to a Polish social network and noticed that someone had posted the current exchange rate of the Swiss franc.

headline: Harvard’s Endowment Remains Biggest of All
abstract: Some things do not change: Harvard’s $36 billion endowment is still the largest of any university, according to the 2014 NACUBO-Commonfund Study of Endowments.
lead_paragraph: Some things do not change: Harvard’s $36 billion endowment is still the largest of any university, according to the 2014 NACUBO-Commonfund Study of Endowments. The University of Texas System endowment, at $25 billion, was in second place, edging last year’s No. 2, Yale, at $24 billion. The average market value of college and university endowments increased 15.5 percent in the 2014 fiscal year, the study found, compared with 11.7 in 2013. A separate survey, by the Council for Aid for Education, found that charitable contributions to colleges and universities in the United States increased 10.8 percent in 2014, the largest increase since 2000. The five institutions that raised the most money took in more than 10 percent of the $37.45 billion in charitable contributions to higher education. In that study, too, Harvard led the pack, taking in $1.16 billion. Stanford was second, at $928 million.

headline: Ukraine Clamps Down on Travel to and From Rebel Areas
abstract: After new border restrictions were put in place, a policy of isolating and frustrating rebel-held regions has taken a major and maddening turn.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — For Larisa Horlova, a cashier, making the trip from rebel-held territory to Ukraine proper had been a routine matter, despite the shells that sometimes pounded into fields near the road as she drove. She did it every week or so to get money from her Ukrainian bank account, since A.T.M.s are no longer functioning in Donetsk.

headline: Motorcyclist Pleads Guilty to Assault in 2013 Attack on S.U.V. Driver in Manhattan
keywords: ['Assaults', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: Christopher Cruz, 29, will serve four months in jail for his role in a confrontation along the Henry Hudson Parkway that ended with the beating of a motorist.
lead_paragraph: In the widely viewed confrontation between a swarm of motorcyclists and a family in a Range Rover on the Henry Hudson Parkway, Christopher Cruz played a minor but key role.

headline: The New Pleasures of Photo Printing
abstract: The Canon Pixma Pro-100 sells for around half the price of a top-of-the-line model and still delivers luscious color photos.
lead_paragraph: NOT long ago I donned a vest and a top hat, gathered my pocketwatch and monocle, and rode my penny-farthing to the general store. The get-up seemed appropriate because I was on the hunt for one of the old-timiest machines still floating about our digital world: A photo printer.

headline: Robert Pirie, 80, Lawyer and Banker in Mergers and Takeovers, Dies
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Legal Profession', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Mr. Pirie was a combative lawyer when the risky but lucrative field of mergers and acquisitions was emerging and later a prominent investment banker on Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: Robert S Pirie, a combative corporate lawyer when the risky but lucrative field of mergers and acquisitions was emerging and later a prominent investment banker on Wall Street, died on Jan. 15 in Manhattan. He was 80.

headline: After Alibaba Spinoff, Yahoo May Become a Takeover Target
abstract: By spinning off the stake into a separate company, Yahoo will be judged by its core Internet businesses.
lead_paragraph: The real Yahoo can now stand up.

headline: Rev. Richard McBrien, Dissenting Catholic Theologian, Dies at 78
abstract: Father McBrien was a champion of Vatican II reforms and often criticized the Roman Catholic Church for its stances on birth control, celibacy and the infallibility of the pope.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Richard P. McBrien, a theologian and professor at Notre Dame who unflinchingly challenged orthodoxy in the Roman Catholic Church for five decades and popularized and perpetuated the reforms of the Second Vatican Council, died on Sunday at his home in Farmington, Conn. He was 78.

headline: Patriots Mix Things Up to Gain Cohesion in Their Running Game
abstract: New England has played a deft game of musical chairs to find balance for the offense each week while showing allegiance to no one.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — There are patterns to be found in chaos, but anyone who claims to know how effectively the New England Patriots will run the ball in Super Bowl XLIX on Sunday has not been paying attention to the team this season.

headline: The Virtual Reality Content Race
abstract: Now that the Oculus Rift has some competition, the virtual reality content race has begun.
lead_paragraph: Now that the Oculus Rift has some competition, the virtual reality content race has begun.

headline: Video Feature: Signs That Virtual Reality Is on the Verge of Taking Off
keywords: ['Virtual Reality (Computers)', 'Wearable Computing', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Smartphones', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Major technology and media companies are investing heavily in virtual reality, a signal that the experience may soon be ready for mass consumption.
lead_paragraph: READY or not, here comes virtual reality.

headline: Don Harron, Actor on Broadway and in ‘Hee Haw,’ Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Harron, a busy stage actor in the 1950s and 1960s, became best known for playing Charlie Farquharson, a wisecracking hayseed on “Hee Haw.”
lead_paragraph: Don Harron, a Shakespearean actor who became a star on Canadian television and a familiar face on “Hee Haw” as the country bumpkin Charlie Farquharson, died on Jan. 17 at his home in Toronto. He was 90.

headline: Xu Shilin, a Young Chinese Player, Tries to Step Into the Void Left by Li Na
abstract: Xu, 17, was the first Chinese player to be seeded No. 1 in a Grand Slam singles event when she got the top spot in the junior girls’ draw at the Australian Open.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Xu Shilin might become the next great Chinese tennis player, but her path to success has only recently led her back to China.

headline: Chevron and BP in Deal to Search for Oil Deep Beneath the Gulf of Mexico
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)']
abstract: The joint effort is a reflection of the pressure on oil companies to hold down spending and share risk as oil prices continue to drop.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Chevron and BP said on Wednesday that they would work together to explore, appraise and, possibly, develop 24 offshore leases in a deepwater part of the Gulf of Mexico known as the lower tertiary.

headline: Judged by Their Covers, Atlanta Hawks Fascinate Bettors
abstract: The Hawks (38-8) have covered the spread 33 times, more than any other team through 46 games in at least a quarter-century, according to the odds tracker Covers.
lead_paragraph: As the Atlanta Hawks exceed the most pie-in-the-sky expectations in the N.B.A. standings this season, with a 38-8 record after Wednesday night’s home win over the Nets, their ledger against the spread is equally astonishing.

headline: Margaret Bloy Graham, ‘Harry the Dirty Dog’ Illustrator, Dies at 94
abstract: Two other works that Ms. Graham illustrated were named Caldecott Honor Books by the American Library Association.
lead_paragraph: Margaret Bloy Graham, a picture-book illustrator best known for “Harry the Dirty Dog,” a cautionary ablutionary tale from 1956 that remains a staple of childhood, died on Jan. 22 in Belmont, Mass. She was 94.

headline: Blizzard Warnings
abstract: How New York City’s no-show snow turned into a story about the relationship between the governor and the mayor.
lead_paragraph: There is no point in second-guessing the decisions that were made from Sunday to Monday involving the New York City megablizzard that never arrived, including the one to shut down the city subways — the first time in 110 years that the system stopped because of a snow forecast.

headline: Happy to Air Their Views
abstract: The Patriots have been tight-lipped over the N.F.L.’s inquiry into their use of underinflated footballs, but there are plenty of experts with extensive knowledge of inflation and deflation.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Not far from where the Super Bowl will be played Sunday, at a party store called Dulceria La Nueva Pico Rico, Norma Rios, an employee, stood next to a tank of helium. The store sells hundreds of balloons each week, and underinflation can ruin a child’s day. Rios pointed to the ceiling.

headline: Administration Official Criticizes Israeli Ambassador Over Netanyahu Visit
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: A senior official said the Israeli envoy, who orchestrated a visit in which Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will address Congress, had repeatedly put politics above diplomacy.

Two former Vanderbilt University football players are facing the possibility of decades in prison after it took a jury less than four hours to convict them for their roles in a 2013 sexual assault of an unconscious woman. Two more former football players await trial.

Snowden indicates.

headline: Iran: Washington Post Reporter’s Trial to Be ‘Soon,’ but Charges Are Unclear
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'Political Prisoners', 'News and News Media', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post’s Tehran correspondent, who has been incarcerated since July 22, “will be tried soon,” Iran’s state-run Islamic Republic News Agency said Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Jason Rezaian, The Washington Post’s Tehran correspondent, who has been incarcerated for unexplained reasons since July 22, “will be tried soon,” Iran’s state-run Islamic Republic News Agency said Wednesday, but there was still no word on the charges he faces. The agency’s report came two weeks after it announced that Mr. Rezaian, 38, had been formally charged and that his case would be heard by Iran’s Revolutionary Court. Mr. Rezaian’s family, American officials and The Post have all urged Iran to free him and have questioned why the charges have not been made public. Mr. Rezaian, a dual Iranian-American citizen, has been denied access to a lawyer. Martin Baron, The Post’s executive editor, said in a statement this month, “It is appalling and outrageous that Jason remains behind bars.”

headline: Russia: Court Rules for Rights Group
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Russia’s Supreme Court on Thursday dismissed a government effort to shut down Memorial, the country’s oldest human rights advocacy group.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s Supreme Court on Wednesday dismissed a government effort to shut down Memorial, the country’s oldest human rights advocacy group, which has been singled out for its investigations of Soviet-era and current civil violations. The Ministry of Justice had accused Memorial of structuring its organization in violation of its own charter. The judge threw out the lawsuit on Thursday after the Justice Ministry said Memorial had rectified the charter violation. In a separate case, Memorial is challenging a decision by the ministry to register it as a foreign agent, a term defined under a 2012 law as a nongovernmental organization that receives foreign funds and engages in politics.

headline: Cuba: Party Paper Reports on Meeting of Fidel Castro and Brazilian Author
abstract: Cuba’s former leader Fidel Castro met with Frei Betto, a Brazilian intellectual, this week, the first such meeting reported in the state-run Cuban news media since a recent swell of rumors that he was dead.
lead_paragraph: Cuba’s former leader Fidel Castro met with Frei Betto, a Brazilian intellectual, this week, the first such meeting reported in the state-run Cuban news media since a recent swell of rumors that Mr. Castro was dead. A brief article in Granma, the Communist Party’s official newspaper, reported late Tuesday that Mr. Castro had had a “friendly conversation” that day with Frei Betto, a leftist Dominican friar who wrote a book in the 1980s on Mr. Castro’s views on Christianity, “Fidel and Religion.” Granma did not publish a photograph of the meeting. On Monday Granma published Mr. Castro’s first remarks on the restoration of diplomatic relations with the United States, which was announced in December. His lack of comment then fueled intense speculation that he was dead or so mentally frail that he could not comment.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (HBO2) THE COUNSELOR (2013) In this thriller directed by Ridley Scott from a screenplay by Cormac McCarthy, Michael Fassbender portrays the title character — a corrupt, high-flying Texas lawyer who gets in over his head in a drug deal with Reiner (Javier Bardem), a nightclub owner involved with a Mexican cartel promising an astronomical return. Brad Pitt is the Counselor’s wary business associate, Cameron Diaz is Reiner’s predatory girlfriend, and Penélope Cruz is the woman the Counselor intends to marry. “From all the ellipses, as well as the eccentric, mesmerizing poetry of his dialogue, Mr. McCarthy appears to have never read a screenwriting manual in his life. (That’s a compliment; this is his first produced film script.),” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times.

lead_paragraph: The release of Canadian diplomatic cables from 1989 has offered new detail on the deadly crackdown on protesters in Beijing that year. headline: Why Are Cubans So Special?
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Cuban-Americans', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: For a fair immigration policy, end laws favoring one group over the others.
lead_paragraph: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. — Every Cuban knows the “wet foot, dry foot” drill: Risk fleeing to the United States and get caught at sea, and you will be sent back to the island; but if you wangle just one toe onto dry land, you’re home free. From there, typically, it’s a fast track to permanent residency, and eligibility for all manner of benefits, from green cards to welfare, then citizenship — all compliments of the Cuban Adjustment Act of 1966. Indeed, for almost a half century, Cubans have been the most privileged immigrants in the United States.
