headline: Race Relations on the Family Tree
abstract: In “Black or White,” Kevin Costner and Octavia Spencer battle each other for custody of their biracial granddaughter.
lead_paragraph: “Black or White,” Mike Binder’s steady, well-intentioned exploration of the racial tensions affecting two branches of a Southern California family, is notable for what it doesn’t try to do. It doesn’t assess America’s racial attitudes based on the headlines of the day or use its story, which revolves around custody of a biracial child, to placate or to inflame.

headline: Blackstone’s Falling Earnings Still Beat Forecasts
abstract: Economic net income from private equity nearly doubled, but the firm reported declines in its real estate and credit businesses.
lead_paragraph: The Blackstone Group reported lower fourth-quarter earnings on Thursday that, despite a decline in its credit business and less robust returns on real estate, exceeded analysts’ expectations.

headline: Showtime Plans a Global Push, Starting With a Canadian Deal
abstract: It will be the first time Showtime’s programming will be distributed and marketed under the Showtime umbrella outside the United States.
lead_paragraph: Showtime is crossing the border.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Alibaba Profit Surges, but a Revenue Gain of 40% Still Misses Forecasts
abstract: The company, which had a huge initial public offering in September, is now facing trouble with China’s government regulators and an economic slowdown.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Just a day after a surprisingly blunt exchange with a Chinese regulator that unnerved investors, the e-commerce giant Alibaba Group on Thursday reported a 40 percent revenue increase in its final quarter of 2014, though the total was weaker than expected.

headline: In Berlin, History Squares Off Against Hip
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Cold War Era', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: On a trip with her 21-year-old daughter, a mother finds a divided city. Not between East and West, of course, but between serious and fun.
lead_paragraph: Berlin is a divided city.

headline: Life in the Garment District
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A former resident of an illegal loft recalled the district’s rough beauty and some of its peculiarities, like the screaming giraffe’s head.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: E.C.B. Warns Lenders Over Dividends and Executive Pay
abstract: Asserting its new role as the eurozone’s banking supervisor, the European Central Bank advised lenders to prepare for a challenging economic environment.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank, asserting its new role as the eurozone’s chief bank supervisor, advised lenders on Thursday not to dispense too much of their profits in dividends to shareholders or in pay packages to executives, in order to gird themselves for global financial stress.

headline: The Fire on the 57 Bus in Oakland
abstract: One teenager flicked a lighter, and two families’ lives were changed forever.
lead_paragraph: It was close to 5 o’clock on the afternoon of Nov. 4, 2013, and Sasha Fleischman was riding the 57 bus home from school. An 18-year-old senior at a small private high school, Sasha wore a T-shirt, a black fleece jacket, a gray newsboy cap and a gauzy white skirt. For much of the long bus ride through Oakland, Calif., Sasha — who identifies as agender, neither male nor female — had been reading a paperback copy of “Anna Karenina,” but eventually the teenager drifted into sleep, skirt draped over the edge of the bus seat.

headline: In Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, One Roof for Two Households
abstract: Two sisters and their husbands discovered that an equally split two-family house can be difficult to come by. They bought a place in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Expecting twins, Elizabeth Clark-Garvey and her husband, Mathew Sullivan, needed a larger place.

headline: A Trove of Vintage Counterculture Photographs Sees the Light of Day
abstract: “The Family Acid,” debuting at this weekend’s L.A. Art Book Fair, compiles decades’ worth of psychedelic shots and features such figures as Peter Tosh and Ron Kovic.
lead_paragraph: For most of their lives, Kate and Devon Steffens thought of their father not as a photographer, but simply as someone who always had a camera in one hand. (And, likely, a joint in the other.) But when Roger Steffens hired Devon to spend a year scanning some 40,000 slides he’d shot over the last 40-plus years — many of which are now collected in a new book, “The Family Acid,” debuting from Sun at this weekend’s L.A. Art Book Fair — a bigger picture emerged.

headline: Dartmouth Cites Student Misconduct in Its Ban on Hard Liquor
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Fraternities and Sororities', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Hazing', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: The college’s president announced the prohibition as part of a far-ranging overhaul of campus life, but experts say few universities are likely to follow his lead.
lead_paragraph: With colleges under growing pressure to reduce alcohol-soaked student misbehavior, Dartmouth College said Thursday that it would ban hard liquor on campus, going beyond the changes that all but a few of its peers have been willing to make.

headline: Ford Earnings Plummet, Weighed by Expenses
abstract: International costs and new-model introductions were challenging for the automaker, which said it expected stronger results this year.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — After several years as the leader in profits and performance among American automakers, the Ford Motor Company hit a speed bump in 2014.

headline: In Etan Patz Case, High Hurdles for Prosecutors and Defense
abstract: The prosecution must convict Pedro Hernandez of the 6-year-old’s 1979 murder almost entirely on his own words, and the defense must convince a jury that his videotaped confessions were fiction.
lead_paragraph: In a typical murder trial, a videotape of a defendant calmly describing how he throttled a young boy — an admission repeated more than once — would be nearly impossible evidence for the defense to overcome, defense lawyers say.

headline: After Semifinal Win, Murray Puts Focus on New Coach, Not His Old One
abstract: After overhearing a passing remark from Berdych, Andy Murray took offense and proceeded to blitz the Czech player and reach the men’s final.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — What began as a battle against a former coach turned into a tribute to a new one as Andy Murray reached a Grand Slam final for the first time since 2013.

headline: 1915: Princess Is Awarded Damages
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1915: Lida Eleanor, Princess of Thurn and Taxis, was awarded £250 damages.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Lida Eleanor, Princess of Thurn and Taxis, was awarded £250 damages in Mr. Justice Darling’s Court yesterday [Jan. 28] against Messrs. E. Hulton and Co., proprietors of the ‘‘Daily Sketch,’’ for libel, trespass, and breach of copyright.

headline: Colleen McCullough, Author of ‘The Thorn Birds,’ Dies at 77
abstract: Ms. McCullough’s novel, set against the sweeping panorama of her native Australia, became one of the most-watched mini-series of all time.
lead_paragraph: Colleen McCullough, a former neurophysiological researcher at Yale who, deciding to write novels in her spare time, produced “The Thorn Birds,” a multigenerational Australian romance that became an international best seller and inspired a hugely popular television mini-series, died on Thursday on Norfolk Island in the South Pacific, where she had made her home for more than 30 years. She was 77.

headline: Jordan Lets Islamic State’s Deadline for a Prisoner Exchange Pass
abstract: Jordan, which is willing to release an imprisoned militant, apparently has not received proof that its captured air force pilot, being held with a Japanese journalist, is still alive.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Jordan refused to release an imprisoned female militant on Thursday to meet a deadline set by the Islamic State, demanding that it first needed proof that a captured Jordanian pilot was still alive.

headline: Unicef, Seeking More Aid, Points to Children Touched by Armed Conflict
abstract: The agency is asking for $3.1 billion, one-third more than it did last year, with the goal of helping 62 million children in 71 countries.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — With more than one in 10 of the world’s children living in areas affected by armed conflict, the United Nations children’s agency said Thursday that it is struggling to deal with “a new generation of emergencies.”

headline: There’s Something Funny in This Saloon
abstract: “The Iceman Cometh,” directed by Robert Falls and starring Nathan Lane and Brian Dennehy, prepares to come to New York.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Nathan Lane is making people laugh in a rehearsal room here, ribbing a fellow actor about his guttural delivery of one of Eugene O’Neill’s simpler exclamations.

headline: ‘Foxcatcher’ Postscript: A Wrestler’s Widow Still Goes to Meets
abstract: Nancy Schultz, whose husband was killed by the wealthy John E. du Pont, says the athletes often felt sorry for their sponsor.

headline: Politicizing U.S.-Israel Ties? In 1996, Accuser Was Netanyahu
abstract: In 1996, it was Benjamin Netanyahu who accused an Israeli prime minister of politicizing relations with the United States on the eve of his country’s elections.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli prime minister stood accused of politicizing relations with the United States on the eve of his country’s elections.

headline: Malaysia Declares Flight 370 an Accident
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']
abstract: Azharuddin Abdul Rahman, the director general of Malaysia’s Department of Civil Aviation, proclaimed the crash of Flight 370 an accident, paving the way for compensation claims.
lead_paragraph: Azharuddin Abdul Rahman, the director general of Malaysia’s Department of Civil Aviation, proclaimed the crash of Flight 370 an accident, paving the way for compensation claims.

headline: Is College Sexual Assault a Fraternity Problem?
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Fraternities and Sororities', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Some say that focusing entirely on sanctioning frats may be misguided, and that fraternity members could be an important part of assault prevention efforts.
lead_paragraph: As colleges and universities continue to struggle with the issue of sexual assault on their campuses, fraternities remain a subject of intense focus.

headline: Why You Should Tell Your Children How Much You Make
abstract: Discussions about family finances can start early and fit a child’s age and ability to understand, but they shouldn’t be avoided.
lead_paragraph: When Scott Parker wanted his six offspring to know more about the value of money, he decided to do something that many parents would consider radical: show them exactly what he earned.

headline: Reader Idea | Using an Op-Doc Video to Teach Argumentative Writing
abstract: In addition to serving as a great conversation piece for discussing technology and social media, the Op-Doc “China’s Web Junkies” also serves as a tool for introducing students to the language of argumentation — specifically to the types of evidence writers use to support a position.
lead_paragraph: Below we share an idea from Allison Marchetti, an English teacher at Trinity Episcopal School in Richmond, Va., who uses an Op-Doc video about the problem of Internet addiction among China’s youth to teach argumentative writing to her ninth graders. This lesson is part of a larger unit of study on editorial and commentary writing.

headline: Nickelodeon to Offer a Streaming Service as Viacom Steps Up Digital Efforts
abstract: The subscription service to be offered by the children’s programming group joins a growing number of similar offerings from other television groups.
lead_paragraph: Nickelodeon, the entertainment group focused on children’s programming, said on Thursday that it would start a new subscription streaming service in March that will be available outside traditional cable or satellite television packages.

headline: Jordan on Hostage Talks With ISIS
abstract: The Jordanian information minister, Mohammad al-Momani, said Jordan was still waiting for ISIS to give proof of life for the Jordanian pilot it captured in order to carry out a prisoner exchange.
lead_paragraph: The Jordanian information minister, Mohammad al-Momani, said Jordan was still waiting for ISIS to give proof of life for the Jordanian pilot it captured in order to carry out a prisoner exchange.

headline: Long Lines, and Odds, for New York’s Subsidized Housing Lotteries
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Atlantic Yards (Brooklyn)']
abstract: Amid record-high demand for affordable housing in New York City, the odds of securing a unit have become daunting.
lead_paragraph: Sitting in the back pew of a packed church in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, William Jamieson hoped to learn winning tips from a workshop on how to play New York City’s housing lotteries.

headline: Gas Explosion at Mexico City Hospital Kills 3 and Wounds Dozens
abstract: At least three people were killed and dozens wounded in an explosion at a maternity and children’s hospital in Mexico City.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A gas refueling truck exploded outside a maternity and children’s hospital here on Thursday, killing three people, two of them babies, and leaving dozens injured in the destruction of nearly the entire building.

headline: Connecting the Dots on the Art Map
abstract: An interesting crop of group shows will take art-lovers to the East Side, West Side, all around Chelsea and SoHo and more.
lead_paragraph: An interesting crop of group shows will take art-lovers to the East Side, West Side, all around Chelsea and SoHo and more.

headline: 15 Group Shows Not to Miss
abstract: Current art-gallery group shows cover a dizzying array of subjects and styles, including judo, erotic haiku in giant letters and unusual self-portraits.
lead_paragraph: Group shows are a staple of the New York gallery scene, but right now they are not only more plentiful than usual, they are especially good. The 15 group shows reviewed or mentioned here form a welcome antidote to the deluge of monolithic, big-name, single-artist shows that have drawn most of the air in the art world over the last year. They take us to a place where money is not king and give us small snapshots from the gigantic disorderly sprawl that is contemporary art. These shows often represent dealers, their gallery directors or invited curators — usually artists or critics — thinking slightly or very outside the box, putting together disparate works often by younger or lesser-known artists, in new and illuminating combinations. The dizzying bounty here reveals not only the elastic nature of the words “art” and “artist” but also of the group-show format itself.

headline: Helping a Perfectionist Child Worry Less and Do More
abstract: Perfectionism can take a high toll on children who see it as the only route to living up to their own and their parents’ high standards.
lead_paragraph: A question I’ve been getting a lot recently, both via email and in person, is this: How can I help my perfectionist child worry less, and understand that it’s normal to make mistakes?

headline: Sam Waterston to Star in ‘The Tempest’ in Central Park
abstract: The Public Theater’s free Shakespeare in the Park program will offer “The Tempest” and “Cymbeline” in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: The Public Theater on Thursday announced the lineup for its free Shakespeare in the Park program this summer: Sam Waterston will star as Prospero in “The Tempest” at the Delacorte Theater, followed by the Tony Award-winning director Daniel Sullivan’s staging of “Cymbeline.”

headline: Clothes and Character: ‘Theory,’ ‘Selma’ and ‘Hobbit’
abstract: Talking with costume designers about how their choices affected actors and their films.
lead_paragraph: Though the Academy may have overlooked their costume designs, three films competing in other categories have made strong cases this season for the impact a character’s clothing can have on the actor, the film and finally, the audience.

headline: Lotte Hass, Pioneering Diver Known for Beauty and Bravery, Dies at 86
abstract: Often called the first lady of diving, Ms. Hass helped shatter the glass floor that had long kept women from the ocean’s depths.
lead_paragraph: Lotte Hass, an Austrian diver and underwater filmmaker who at midcentury helped shatter the glass floor that had long kept women from the ocean’s depths, died on Jan. 14 in Vienna. She was 86.

headline: Will the Next Attorney General Crack Down on Marijuana?
abstract: At her confirmation hearing, Loretta Lynch said she disagreed with the view that marijuana is less dangerous than alcohol.
lead_paragraph: Despite substantial scientific evidence that marijuana is not as harmful as alcohol, many law enforcement officials continue to pretend otherwise. Add to that list Loretta Lynch, President Obama’s nominee for attorney general.

headline: A Long Run in Goal
abstract: A look at the career of goaltender Martin Brodeur, a son of Montreal who won three Stanley Cups in his 22-season N.H.L. career, almost all of it with the New Jersey Devils.
lead_paragraph: A look at the career of goaltender Martin Brodeur, a son of Montreal who won three Stanley Cups in his 22-season N.H.L. career, almost all of it with the New Jersey Devils.

headline: A New York Icon Who Shone Just Outside the Bright Lights
abstract: Martin Brodeur, who retired Thursday after a brief stint with the Blues, earned a spot alongside other New York sports icons despite playing across the Hudson River for the Devils.
lead_paragraph: Martin Brodeur is a New York icon who belongs in the same company as Jeter and Seaver, Clyde and Broadway Joe, L. T. and Jackie Robinson and the Babe.

headline: Airbus Shakes Up Its Military Aircraft Unit
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Delays (Transportation)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Delays in delivery of the A400M cargo plane have prompted a restructuring of the division and a change in leadership.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Faced with mounting criticism from European governments over production problems with its newest military transport plane, the Airbus Group on Thursday announced a management shake-up at its military aircraft unit and promised a restructuring of the business to address what it said were “unacceptable” delivery delays.

headline: Sariling Atin in Elmhurst, Queens
abstract: Filipino specialties on a block once dominated by furniture showrooms.
lead_paragraph: Filipino specialties on a block once dominated by furniture showrooms.

headline: A Buffet of Filipino Specialties
abstract: Sariling Atin, whose name in Tagalog means “our own,” opened in April in Elmhurst, Queens, on a block once dominated by furniture showrooms.
lead_paragraph: Fish are stacked on the glass over the steam table, fried whole without interfering batter, all crackly veneer and quick-tearing flesh. There are galunggong, like swollen cigars with the flavor of a shyer mackerel; pompano in puckering silver; and, best of all, bangus (pronounced ban-GOOSE), or milkfish, flaky and sweet, stripped of bones and butterflied flat, but with the brittle fletch of a tail intact.

headline: Temple St. Clair Carr’s Jeweled Creatures
abstract: The jewelry designer introduced her nine newest creations during Paris Couture Week.
lead_paragraph: The jewelry designer introduced her nine newest creations during Paris Couture Week.

headline: Graham Is Latest Republican to Explore Presidential Run
abstract: Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina has been hinting that he might throw his hat in the ring for the Republican presidential nomination and on Thursday he came a step closer to putting it in writing.
lead_paragraph: Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina has been hinting that he might vie for the Republican presidential nomination, and on Thursday he came a step closer to putting it in writing.

headline: Jim Parsons to Play the Title Role in ‘An Act of God’ on Broadway
abstract: Mr. Parsons will star in the new comedy “An Act of God” by David Javerbaum.
lead_paragraph: Jim Parsons is God – and not just to fans of his character, Sheldon Cooper, on the hit CBS series “The Big Bang Theory,” for which he has won four best actor Emmy Awards. No, Mr. Parsons is actually going to play the Almighty on Broadway beginning May 5 in the new comedy “An Act of God” by David Javerbaum, a former head writer and executive producer of “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart,” the play’s producer announced on Thursday.

headline: French Police Question Boy, 8, After Remarks on Paris Attacks
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: The authorities said the boy was questioned after he refused to observe a minute of silence for victims and later defended the men who attacked the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Police officials in the southern French city of Nice questioned an 8-year-old boy who is believed to have made comments in school defending the gunmen who killed 17 people in terrorist attacks in and near Paris this month, a senior regional police official confirmed on Thursday.

headline: At Reed Krakoff’s New SoHo Boutique, the Art and Design Are as Compelling as the Fashion
abstract: From lamps that appear to have burst through the walls to an installation by the Bouroullec brothers, the space is no ordinary luxury flagship.
lead_paragraph: From the moment a customer enters Reed Krakoff’s new SoHo boutique to find lamps that appear to have burst in right through the sheetrock, it’s clear that the store is no ordinary luxury flagship. “It’s surprising,” Krakoff says, referring to both the site-specific lighting installation by Nick Allman and the 2,700-square-foot storefront, his second in New York, which opens Sunday. “The idea was to have a space that combines art and fashion and design in a way that is sort of un-self-conscious and natural.” Krakoff’s well-documented affinity for art and design informed many other elements of the marble-floored interior: Also present are an opalescent table by Mattia Bonetti, which Krakoff says “reads almost like a sculpture”; a custom Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec “Clouds” installation rendered in felt, one of Krakoff’s favorite materials; and a wall installation of chairs created by Krakoff and his wife Delphine that was originally exhibited at Salon 94 and will double as shelving for merchandise. Steven Sebring’s 360-degree photographs of Krakoff’s designs — the same signature technique utilized in the photographer’s recent book featuring Coco Rocha, “Study of Pose” — will also be on prominent display. “The juxtaposition of these things tells a story,” Krakoff says. “It’s different than the typical shopping experience.”

headline: The Top Five Fall/Winter 2015 Men’s Wear Collections in Paris
keywords: ["Men's Fashion Week", 'Paris Fashion Week', 'Men and Boys', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: T’s men’s fashion editors share their favorites from the latest round of shows.
lead_paragraph: T’s men’s fashion editors share their favorites from the latest round of shows.

headline: Online Political Ads Have Been Slow to Catch On as TV Reigns
abstract: Digital advertising is a work in progress, because targeting voters with online ads is complicated.
lead_paragraph: After being hit with a television advertisement attacking his position on women’s issues, Mike Coffman, a Colorado Republican running for re-election in 2014 to the House of Representatives, did the natural thing: His campaign responded with an ad of its own.

headline: U.S. Textbook Skews History, Prime Minister of Japan Says
abstract: Shinzo Abe, the conservative prime minister of Japan, opened a new front in a battle to sway American views of the country’s wartime history.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan on Thursday criticized an American textbook that he said inaccurately depicted Japan’s actions during World War II, opening a new front in a battle to sway American views of the country’s wartime history.

headline: At Bocuse d’Or, Americans Take 2nd
abstract: The United States’ highest finish in the biennial international culinary competition in Lyon, France, had been sixth place.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, the culinary team from the United States placed second out of 24 teams in the biennial Bocuse d’Or international culinary competition in Lyon, France. It’s the first time the Americans have earned a medal. Their highest finish had been sixth place.

headline: Alibaba’s Lesson in Government Relations
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Alibaba’s run-in with a Chinese regulator serves as a reminder that there is no such thing as a good relationship with China’s government, John Foley of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Alibaba is teaching its shareholders a useful lesson about Chinese business: There is no such thing as having a good relationship with the government. The company’s shares fell 4.4 percent on Wednesday after a regulator lambasted its sales habits. Alibaba says the State Administration for Industry and Commerce is being irrational. That is little comfort to investors who, on paper, are now $11 billion worse off.

headline: For Athletes, the Time of an Event Can Affect Performance
abstract: Researchers studying a small group of athletes found that those used to rising early perform best at midday, while late risers do best in the evening.
lead_paragraph: Athletes have long sought ways to gain even a small edge that can make the difference between getting a medal and finishing in the middle of the pack, like altitude training or even performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Houthis Reach Out as They Cement Power in Yemen
abstract: The Houthis see themselves now as having evolved from rebels into a broad-based voice against government oppression, corruption and incompetence.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — Abu Raad strutted through the streets of the Yemeni capital as if he owned them. His obvious glee, at a time of crisis in the country, bordered on naïveté. But he had his reasons to be happy.

headline: China Further Tightens Grip on the Internet
abstract: The Chinese authorities are no longer tolerating the workarounds used by millions of people who rely heavily on less-fettered access to the Internet.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Jing Yuechen, the founder of an Internet start-up here in the Chinese capital, has no interest in overthrowing the Communist Party. But these days she finds herself cursing the nation’s smothering cyberpolice as she tries — and fails — to browse photo-sharing websites like Flickr and struggles to stay in touch with the Facebook friends she has made during trips to France, India and Singapore.

headline: A Quirky Car Collection on the Cape, in Red and Mostly British
abstract: An innkeeper fell in love with the classic sports cars that thrilled postwar Americans and now keeps 45 of them out back.
lead_paragraph: HYANNIS PORT, Mass. — BILL PUTMAN is a collector, and no ordinary one. Step behind the doors of his Simmons Homestead Inn here on Cape Cod, and a visitor is allowed a glimpse into the quirky mind of its 78-year-old proprietor.

headline: 1940: Daladier Addresses Civilians
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1940: Premier Edouard Daladier told civilians that their lives must undergo a complete transformation.
lead_paragraph: In an earnest radio talk to the French nation last night [Jan. 28], Premier Edouard Daladier told civilians that their lives must undergo as complete a transformation as those of the men in the front line if a powerful, destructive and unscrupulous enemy is to be defeated in the ‘‘total war which will not be long now in being let loose. When they left for the frontier, our sons accepted a total transformation of their lives,’’ he said. ‘‘Those who have stayed behind and do not have to put up with the same sufferings and dangers must also agree to transform their lives.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 30, 1940

headline: A Digital Upgrade at the Tower of David Museum
abstract: At the Tower of David Museum in Jerusalem, a digital initiative is designed to enhance visitors’ experiences.
lead_paragraph: When the Tower of David Museum opened in Jerusalem’s Old City in 1989, with video models, dioramas and even a rainbow-hued hologram among its offerings, its technology was considered cutting-edge.

headline: A Dark, Delicate New Track From Elvis Perkins
abstract: “I Came for Fire,” from the singer-songwriter’s upcoming third LP, contains a subtle tribute to his late mother, the photographer Berry Berenson, who died in the Sept. 11 attacks.
lead_paragraph: “It’s a record that’s been in the offing for a while,” says the songwriter Elvis Perkins about his forthcoming third LP, “I Aubade,” which sees its release on his own MIR label on Feb. 24. “It’s a culmination of past visions, present inclinations and a lot of guesswork. And a lot of accidents.”

headline: F.C.C. Sharply Revises Definition of Broadband
abstract: The new broadband benchmark sets downloads at a speed of 25 megabits per second and uploads of 3 megabits per second. The standard is used to guide policy in some areas.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday sharply revised its benchmark definition of broadband Internet service. The new definition increases download speeds to more than six times faster than the previous standard, set more than four years ago.

headline: David Landau, Mideast Journalist and Biographer of Sharon, Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. Landau was affiliated with The Jerusalem Post, Haaretz and The Economist, and wrote a recent biography of former Prime Minister Ariel Sharon.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — David Landau, a prominent British-Israeli reporter, newspaper editor and author who practiced an unusual mix of religious Orthodoxy, ardent Zionism and leftist politics, died on Tuesday at a hospital here. He was 67.

headline: Reddit Issues First Transparency Report
abstract: The popular message board gives insight into how often government agencies request data on Reddit users.
lead_paragraph: Reddit, the hugely popular Internet message board, released its first transparency report Thursday afternoon, giving its 174 million regular visitors a closer look into how often outside agencies request user information.

headline: The College Partying Crackdown
abstract: Dartmouth wants to ban hard liquor at parties. Could that possibly work?
lead_paragraph: Sick of bad press about dangerous parties and concerned that young people can’t handle the social freedoms offered by college, will universities retake the in loco parentis role they abandoned long ago and impose stricter rules? It’s starting to look that way.

headline: Senate Approves Keystone XL Pipeline Bill, Testing Obama
keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: As expected, the Senate passed the bill forcing approval of the oil pipeline from Canada to the Gulf Coast — a measure President Obama has promised to veto.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate passed a bill on Thursday to force approval of the Keystone XL oil pipeline, which President Obama is certain to veto in his first official clash with the new Republican-majority Congress.

headline: Greece Steps Back Into Line With European Union Policy on Russia Sanctions
abstract: On Thursday, Greece backed away from strong statements denouncing sanctions, calming worries that the election of a far-left government in Greece could upend Europe’s policy toward Moscow.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Gathering in Brussels, European foreign ministers scrambled on Thursday to hold a united front against Russia over Ukraine, calming worries that the election of a far-left government in Greece hostile to sanctions could upend Europe’s policy toward Moscow.

headline: Bipartisan Praise for Lynch as Confirmation Hearings End
abstract: Testimony in the confirmation hearings of Loretta E. Lynch wrapped up Thursday with members of both parties praising her performance as she won her first declared Republican supporter, Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah.
lead_paragraph: Testimony in the confirmation hearings of Loretta E. Lynch wrapped up Thursday with members of both parties praising her performance and with her winning her first declared Republican supporter, Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah.

headline: The Top Five Fall/Winter 2015 Men’s Wear Collections in Paris
abstract: T’s men’s fashion editors share their favorites from the latest round of shows.
lead_paragraph: T’s men’s fashion editors share their favorites from the latest round of shows.

headline: Chaos in Paris Commute as RER Train Drivers Go on Strike Over Assault
abstract: Passengers were unable to take the RER A, a line that runs through central Paris and carries a million passengers a day, as drivers protested the assault of a colleague.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Railway traffic on Europe’s busiest commuter line came to a near standstill in Paris and its suburbs on Thursday as train drivers went on strike to protest the assault of a driver on Wednesday night.

headline: Treasury Fight Is Over, but Wall Street Animosity Lingers
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: The drive to derail the Treasury post nomination of Antonio Weiss highlights a vitriol toward bankers that risks becoming counterproductive, William D. Cohan writes in the Street Scene column.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Antonio Weiss, the 48-year-old former global head of investment banking at Lazard, took up his new position as counselor to Jacob J. Lew, the Treasury secretary. In a note to his friends and Lazard colleagues, Mr. Weiss explained that he will be advising Mr. Lew on financial markets, regulatory reform, job creation and on “fostering broad-based” economic growth. It sounds like a full plate, and a job worth giving up his high-powered career at Lazard to take.

headline: Do Your Children Know How Much It Costs to Support Your Family?
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Children and Childhood', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: If you want your children to have any idea what it takes financially to take care of a family, or of themselves, it starts by letting them in on what it takes to support the family they’re a part of now.
lead_paragraph: The excerpt from Ron Lieber’s book “The Opposite of Spoiled” opens with a bang — or at least, with a dramatic thump: the sound of one parent’s entire month’s salary, in bills, sliding out of an unmarked bag onto the dining room table.

headline: In the Way Cancer Cells Work Together, a Possible Tool for Their Demise
abstract: Research on the cooperation that goes on in a cancerous tumor could point to a new strategy for fighting the disease.
lead_paragraph: A tumor, as strange as it may sound, is a little society. The cancer cells that make it up cooperate with one another, and together they thrive.

headline: A Climatologist Answers Questions on Weather Forecasts
abstract: Mark W. Wysocki, the New York State climatologist, answered a selection of readers’ questions about meteorology.
lead_paragraph: After the blizzard that wasn’t in New York City, many people have been wondering about weather forecasts and meteorology.

headline: I Do Not Think That Number Means What You Think It Means
abstract: Tis the gift to be simplistic, tis the gift to be free.
lead_paragraph: Steve Rattner has a very puzzling piece in today’s Times. Leave aside the dismissal of the austerity debate — which has, if nothing else, been a dramatic illustration of the immense relevance of macroeconomic analysis — as “simplistic”; Dean Baker has that one covered. What really gets me is this chart:

headline: By Breaking Mold of Receiver, Edelman Fits In With Patriots
abstract: A little defense, some kick returns, a lot of receptions and one critical pass make wide receiver Julian Edelman invaluable to the Patriots.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — In professional sports, being listed as 6 feet tall often means you are somewhere between 5-8 and 5-11. The rounding up is considered a courtesy, since being undersize carries something of a stigma. Julian Edelman, New England’s jack-of-all-trades wide receiver, freely admits that he is 5 feet 10 even if the Patriots’ website used to give him a couple of extra inches.

headline: From Steep Hillsides, a Depth of Flavor
abstract: A primary strength of the St.-Joseph region is the granite slopes on which the best vineyards are planted.
lead_paragraph: The reds of the northern Rhône Valley are some of my favorite wines in the world. When not wrapped in the homogenizing influence of new oak aromas and textures, the wines radiate a combination of savory intensity, freshness and nuance I find almost unrivaled.

headline: More Than 1,000 in Arizona Are Watched for Measles
abstract: State health officials are tracking hundreds of people, including at least 195 children, who might have been exposed in an outbreak that began at Disneyland.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Arizona health officials on Thursday were tracking more than 1,000 people, including at least 195 children, who might have been exposed to measles as part of an outbreak that began at Disneyland in Southern California and has grown to 67 cases in seven states.

headline: Counting by Chickens
abstract: Researchers demonstrated that chickens naturally order numbers left to right. When the number five is in the middle, chickens naturally go left for lower numbers and to the right for higher numbers.
lead_paragraph: Researchers demonstrated that chickens naturally order numbers left to right. When the number five is in the middle, chickens naturally go left for lower numbers and to the right for higher numbers.

headline: Chickens Agree: Left Means Less; Right Means More
abstract: Scientists found that newborn chicks, like people, seem to map numbers spatially, associating smaller amounts with the left and larger ones with the right.
lead_paragraph: Asked to picture the numbers from one to 10, most people will imagine a straight line with one at the left end and 10 at the right.

headline: With a Few Bits of Data, Researchers Identify ‘Anonymous’ People
abstract: Knowing just four random pieces of information was enough to reidentify 90 percent of the shoppers as unique individuals and to uncover their records, researchers calculated.
lead_paragraph: Even when real names and other personal information are stripped from big data sets, it is often possible to use just a few pieces of the information to identify a specific person, according to a study to be published Friday in the journal Science.

headline: Your Next Lesson: Langhe Nebbiolo
abstract: The wine comes from the same general area as Barolo and Barbaresco, but it is usually softer and more accessible.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a Wine School problem for you: Barolo and Barbaresco are among the world’s most beautiful wines, made from the nebbiolo grape, which is known partly for a tannic austerity that can take years of aging to soften. The young Barolos and Barbarescos available in most wine shops won’t be ready to drink for several more years, while older examples are expensive and hard to find. How should we approach these wines?

headline: At Valentino’s Spring 2015 Couture Presentation, a Shimmering Ode to Love
abstract: A standout look was a golden dress with sentences of rapturous prose sparkling across the skirt.
lead_paragraph: Valentino’s couture presentation was an homage to romance. Words like “Amore” were emblazoned across the busts of dresses and seen in poetry verses swirled in cursive around the sheer, full skirts of gowns. Less literal takes on the theme came in the form of Russian folkloric embroidered vests and jackets, garnet velvet dresses and ethereal, pale lace gowns. The standout that this editor loved: a golden dress constructed like armor on top, with hand-beaded sentences of rapturous prose sparkling across the skirt.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Valentino Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Schohaja.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: Sheldon Silver’s Departure Creates Rare Opportunity in Albany
abstract: The Times editorial board member Eleanor Randolph reflects on Sheldon Silver’s downfall and what it could mean for New York State politics.
lead_paragraph: Sheldon Silver, the New York State Assembly speaker, was arrested last week on charges he exploited his office for personal gain. As The Times reported Thursday, an idealistic new wave of Assembly members forced him to resign his post. The Times editorial board member Eleanor Randolph, who has covered Albany and New York politics for nearly 20 years, reflects on what she sees as an opportune moment.

headline: Man Lost Contact With Drone Before It Sped to White House, Friend Says
abstract: The man was flying the drone outside his apartment window when it shot off toward the White House, the friend who owned the device said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In retrospect, flying the drone out the apartment window at 3 a.m. might not have been the best idea.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Boyhood’
abstract: Richard Linklater discusses a sequence from his drama “Boyhood,” with Ellar Coltrane and Ethan Hawke.
lead_paragraph: Richard Linklater discusses a sequence from his drama “Boyhood,” with Ellar Coltrane and Ethan Hawke.

headline: Marshawn Lynch Has Some Words for Reporters, and a Few Stares
abstract: “I don’t know what story you’re all trying to get out of me,” Lynch, a running back for Seattle, said Thursday as he completed his Super Bowl media obligations.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The smiling Marshawn Lynch from media day was officially gone Thursday when the Seattle Seahawks running back faced the news media for the final time before the Super Bowl. No longer content to answer every question with a stock answer like “I’m just here so I don’t get fined,” Lynch briefly addressed the large crowd and tried to explain his point of view.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Zuhair Murad Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Lawyers in Anti-Police Video Knew of Violent Tone, Inquiry Finds
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Music', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The public defenders were aware that a music video they agreed to appear in encouraged retribution for the death of Eric Garner, according to New York City’s Department of Investigation.
lead_paragraph: The music video opens with symbols of the police protest movement that gained traction last fall: images of Eric Garner being wrestled to a sidewalk on Staten Island and of black men with their arms raised in a pose of surrender.

headline: In a Time of Racial Turmoil, Why Change Course on Covering Race?
abstract: Editors explain that they want to broaden the approach across departments.
lead_paragraph: To state the obvious, it seems like an odd time to discontinue the one Times beat devoted solely to race and ethnicity. (A few words of reminder: Michael Brown of Ferguson, Eric Garner of Staten Island, Tamir Rice of Cleveland.)

headline: Maria Sharapova vs. Serena Williams: A One-Sided Rivalry
abstract: Saturday’s Australian Open women’s final, between Maria Sharapova and Serena Williams, will be their 19th meeting, and Williams has won the last 15.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The un-rivalry is back with Maria Sharapova facing Serena Williams in the Australian Open final.

headline: Government Allies Are Said to Have Slaughtered Dozens of Sunnis in Iraq
abstract: Dozens of people from a mostly Sunni village in eastern Iraq were methodically singled out for slaughter this week, witnesses and local Sunni leaders say.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Some of the men were shot on their doorsteps, their bodies left crumpled in the streets. Others were lined up, led to a field and killed there. Their relatives, ordered to stay in their homes, heard the gunfire.

headline: Uber Accused of Lax Safety Practices by Delhi Woman
abstract: The woman who says she was sexually assaulted by an Uber driver says in a lawsuit filed in California that the company does not adequately screen its drivers, risking the safety of Uber customers.
lead_paragraph: A woman who says she was sexually assaulted by an Uber driver last month in New Delhi has filed a lawsuit against the company, arguing that Uber’s “hollow” safety and driver screening practices put her in an unsafe situation.

headline: Blackstone Courts Wealthy Individuals With New Private Equity Fund
abstract: Blackstone has raised about $700 million from wealthy individuals for a new fund intended expressly for this class of investors, a new and largely untapped source of capital for buyout firms.
lead_paragraph: The Blackstone Group, the biggest alternative investment firm, which typically relies on pension funds and other institutions to amass capital for deals, has begun an effort to raise more of that capital from individuals.

headline: Richard Linklater Narrates a Scene From ‘Boyhood’
abstract: The writer and director of “Boyhood” discusses a sequence.
lead_paragraph: A road trip turns melancholy in this scene from Richard Linklater’s Oscar-nominated film “Boyhood.” Here, the writer and director narrates a sequence in which  Mason (Ellar Coltrane) has a talk with his dad (Ethan Hawke) about the Pontiac GTO his dad owned but has since sold and replaced with a minivan.

headline: Tim Ryan’s Switch on Abortion Rights
abstract: The Democratic representative from Ohio now supports the cause of reproductive freedom.
lead_paragraph: Representative Tim Ryan, an Ohio Democrat who previously opposed abortion rights, has officially changed sides. He’s very welcome in the pro-choice camp. With reproductive freedom under attack in the Republican-led Congress and in G.O.P.-controlled state legislatures around the country, the embattled cause needs all the new supporters it can get.

headline: A Road Map of Home Values and Street Names
abstract: Streets named for trees, presidents and more, and how they compare.
lead_paragraph: Streets named for trees, presidents and more, and how they compare.

headline: How to Avoid Frauds in Investments, and Personnel Hires
abstract: Hiring people is a lot like picking stocks, and in both situations, even smart investors can be blindsided by fraud, Carson Block writes in an Another View column.
lead_paragraph: Carson C. Block is the director of research for Muddy Waters, a research and investment firm. He is on Twitter at @muddywatersre

headline: As New Leadership Takes Over in Washington, a Major Fiscal Clash Takes Shape
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy']
abstract: While both sides say they are trying to help the squeezed middle class, the divide between the two parties on fiscal policy may be as stark as at any time since President Clinton’s first term.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will propose breaching statutory spending caps in the fiscal year that begins in October, putting out a budget Monday that raises spending at Congress’s discretion by $74 billion — or 7 percent, the White House announced Thursday.

headline: David Kochel, Romney’s Iowa Strategist, Jumps to Bush
abstract: David Kochel, an Iowa-based Republican strategist who worked on both of Mitt Romney’s presidential campaigns, is joining Jeb Bush’s political action committee as a senior strategist and is in line to serve as Mr. Bush’s national campaign manager.
lead_paragraph: David Kochel, a Republican strategist based in Iowa who worked on both of Mitt Romney’s presidential campaigns, is joining Jeb Bush’s political action committee as a senior strategist and is in line to serve as Mr. Bush’s national campaign manager.

headline: SoundExchange Says It Paid $773 Million in Music Royalties Last Year
abstract: The nonprofit agency pays performing artists when their material is heard on Internet and satellite radio services.
lead_paragraph: As streaming music becomes more popular with consumers, the agency that processes much of the licensing income behind outlets like Pandora and Sirius XM has quickly grown to be one of the music industry’s biggest sources of royalties.

headline: A Bloom in TV’s Asian-American Desert
abstract: “Fresh Off the Boat,” based on a memoir by the chef Eddie Huang, is the first sitcom about an Asian-American family since Margaret Cho’s short-lived show of the 1990s. Much is riding on it.
lead_paragraph: On “Fresh Off the Boat,” the new ABC family sitcom based on the memoir of the same name by the rowdy, bawdy chef Eddie Huang, the young Eddie is played by Hudson Yang, an amiable 11-year-old with an air of preternatural chill. In the book, Eddie is a bit of a rabble-rouser, but on the show, he’s a fast-learning fish out of water with a gift for comic self-presentation.

headline: Front Seat to an Escalating Global Conflict
abstract: “The Road to Damascus” traces the United States government’s diplomatic maneuvering after a pair of domestic attacks lead — accurately or not — to Syria.
lead_paragraph: The “not so distant future” looks a lot like the recent past in “The Road to Damascus,” a serious and mostly satisfying new political thriller at 59E59 Theaters.

headline: Eurozone Takes on Quantitative Easing, and Its Risks
abstract: The European Central Bank’s bond buying should benefit 18.4 million people without jobs. But there is a chance it will help only a privileged few.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — As central banks have injected cash into their nations’ economies, a question has raged over whether they have helped average people or simply made the rich even richer.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Valentino Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Schohaja.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: McCain Calls Hecklers ‘Low-Life Scum’
abstract: Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, admonished members of an antiwar group who were heckling former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger during a committee hearing.
lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, admonished members of an antiwar group who were heckling former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger during a committee hearing.

headline: A New York Movie Marathon
abstract: Scenes at some of the 12 theaters and museums that a reporter visited on a two-day movie binge.
lead_paragraph: Scenes at some of the 12 theaters and museums that a reporter visited on a two-day movie binge.

headline: Video: McCain Calls Hecklers ‘Low-Life Scum’
abstract: Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, admonished members of an antiwar group who were heckling former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger during a committee hearing.

headline: 12 Theaters, Two Days, One Kick in the Head
abstract: A reporter indulges a longtime fancy, and spends a Friday — and a Saturday — at the movies, from “Blackhat” to an Altman festival.
lead_paragraph: I try to keep it quiet, but what I really want to do is go to the movies. Not for the same reasons as Binx Bolling in “The Moviegoer” — he wants to escape the sadness of daily life — but because so much is going on that sometimes I need to get out of my head, and I like to do it in a cinema instead of in front of a computer.

headline: Super Bowl Parties at Bars, No Cover Required
abstract: The Bell House in Brooklyn and Posh in Manhattan are offering free football festivities.
lead_paragraph: Football isn’t for everyone, but it sure is for a lot of people: It’s America’s most popular sport. Last year’s Super Bowl on Fox averaged 111.5 million viewers — the most for any single broadcast in American television history.

headline: Department of Investigation Report on the Bronx Defenders
abstract: An inquiry into a government-funded legal organization’s involvement in a music video with song lyrics that included “For Mike Brown and Sean Bell, a cop got to get killed.”
lead_paragraph: An inquiry into a government-funded legal organization’s involvement in a music video with song lyrics that included “For Mike Brown and Sean Bell, a cop got to get killed.”

headline: Rand Paul Pushes Buttons, in a New Medium
abstract: Rand Paul posted a faux-phone call featuring two voice actors pretending to be Hillary Rodham Clinton and Jeb Bush, arguing over whose turn it is to be president.
lead_paragraph: Senator Rand Paul has been quite the pot stirrer on Twitter and Facebook recently, poking fun at Mitt Romney and Jeb Bush’s lunch meeting last week in Salt Lake City, going after Senator Marco Rubio on Cuba policy and having some fun with the “Seinfeld” holiday Festivus.

headline: In Los Angeles, a Crop of Art Fairs to Suit All Tastes
abstract: The city’s biggest art week of the year finds happenings all over town, from Santa Monica Airport to far-off Agoura Hills.
lead_paragraph: As the dust has settled on Snowpocalypse, the sun is shining in California and increasingly international factions of the art world are making their way to Los Angeles for the city’s biggest art week of the year. Three fairs that could not be more different (or far away) from each other converge this weekend, along with a host of collateral events and exhibitions organized by Angelenos and visitors alike.

headline: Medicare Payments Surge for Stents to Unblock Blood Vessels in Limbs
abstract: Some cardiologists are reaping huge reimbursements for operating to relieve blockages in peripheral veins and arteries, a treatment many may not need.
lead_paragraph: At a time of increasing scrutiny of procedures to open blocked heart arteries, cardiologists are turning to — and reaping huge payments from -- controversial techniques that relieve blockages in the arms and legs.

headline: Amazon Reports a Profit, Citing Prime as the Key
abstract: The company delivered better earnings than expected in the fourth quarter, breaking a recent pattern of disappointments.
lead_paragraph: Amazon’s profits fell in the fourth quarter. Revenue did not meet expectations. The company said it might lose money in the current quarter.

headline: Points of Interest
abstract: Reflective metal hardware turns otherwise architecturally simple shoes and bags into modern art.
lead_paragraph: Reflective metal hardware turns otherwise architecturally simple shoes and bags into modern art.

headline: Murder Trial Begins for Former Patriot
abstract: Aaron Hernandez is charged with orchestrating the killing of a friend, Odin Lloyd, who was found in a pit at an industrial park near Mr. Hernandez’s home in North Attleboro, Mass.
lead_paragraph: FALL RIVER, Mass. — Aaron Hernandez wore a dark suit on Thursday, just as his former teammates with the New England Patriots had worn coats and ties earlier in the week. The difference was that they were flying to the Super Bowl and he was walking into his trial on a charge of first-degree murder.

headline: Temple St. Clair Carr’s Jeweled Creatures
abstract: The jewelry designer introduced her nine newest creations, on view here, during Paris Couture Week.
lead_paragraph: “What began as an errand to find an ancient coin to make into a necklace for my mother turned into a lifelong passion,” says the New York-based jewelry designer Temple St. Clair Carr. Since she began her line, Temple St. Clair, in 1986, St. Clair Carr’s designs have evolved from mostly gold pieces — featuring antique amulets and cabochon stones and crafted with historic techniques — into the elaborate fine-jewelry treasures she unveiled today at the Musée des Arts Décoratifs during Paris Couture Week. Called “Mythical Creatures from the Golden Menagerie,” the collection includes nine pieces: Great Horned Owl, Sleeping Fox, Flying Fish, Medusa Moon Jellyfish, Phoenix Chicks, Frog Prince, Sea Dragon, Secret Garden Serpent and Turtles on the Rocks (which, to St. Clair Carr, evoke swimming in country ponds with her family). “This is slow jewelry!” declares St. Clair Carr, who worked on the collection for three years, flying back and forth to Florence as her Italian craftsmen came across “anything particularly beautiful or rare.” The whole set, as seen in the above slideshow, remains on view at Chahan Gallery (by appointment only) until Feb. 6.

headline: Google Revenue Is Higher, but Profit Misses Expectations
abstract: The company’s results were squeezed by a number of temporary factors, including a strong dollar that ate into overseas sales.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Everybody knows Google is working on a lot of things besides search. Wall Street wants to know when all those projects will start making a lot of money.

headline: Harvard Art Museums Director to Step Down
abstract: Thomas W. Lentz, who directed the Harvard Art Museums for more than a decade, will step down on July 1.
lead_paragraph: Thomas W. Lentz, who directed the Harvard Art Museums for more than a decade and shepherded them through a long and sometimes contentious $350 million renovation and expansion that was completed last November, has announced that he will step down on July 1, the university announced.

headline: Notes On A Scandale
abstract: For years, France’s leaders have been caught up in a sex farce of their own making, proving that bedfellows make for very strange politics.
lead_paragraph: For years, France’s leaders have been caught up in a sex farce of their own making, proving that bedfellows make for very strange politics.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Zuhair Murad Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Celebrating Images of a Long-Gone Florida
abstract: An exhibition in Daytona Beach will showcase artists who began documenting the state’s vanishing landscape more than a century ago.
lead_paragraph: As soon as 19th-century developers started carving Florida’s swampland and palm groves into resorts and subdivisions, colonies of artists formed there to document the vanishing landscape. On Feb. 8, a new building devoted to the art of the region opens at the Museum of Arts and Sciences in Daytona Beach.

headline: Noguchi Show Is Planned for Brooklyn Botanic Garden
abstract: Brooklyn Botanic Garden will host a show of Isamu Noguchi’s sculptures at its Japanese garden, starting in September.
lead_paragraph: Gardens have been formative playgrounds for great artists at least since Michelangelo spent his teenage years poring over antiquities in the Medici gardens in Florence. But few artists have made gardens as central to their work as Isamu Noguchi, whose museum and sculpture garden in Long Island City, Queens, turns 30 this year.

headline: Should Unvaccinated Children Stay Home to Protect a Vulnerable Classmate?
abstract: For a student unable to be vaccinated in California, the risk of measles exposure isn’t as small as his family believes it ought to be.
lead_paragraph: The father of a 6-year-old boy with leukemia in Marin County, Calif., has asked the superintendent of his school district to keep unvaccinated children out of school.

headline: From the White House to the Super Bowl
abstract: A sampling of Doug Mills’s work.
lead_paragraph: A sampling of Doug Mills’s work.

headline: Beautiful Unrest
abstract: Vivid botanical prints lose their ladylike sweetness when paired with utilitarian samples.
lead_paragraph: Vivid botanical prints lose their ladylike sweetness when paired with utilitarian samples.

headline: From the White House to the Super Bowl, With a Times Photographer
abstract: Doug Mills, a veteran staff photographer with The New York Times, talks about the differences between covering the White House and the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: Doug Mills, a staff photographer for The New York Times based in the Washington bureau for the better part of two decades, has seen it all: from presidential inaugurations to Super Bowls, from the campaign trail to court-side champions.

headline: No Detail Goes Unnoticed When Art Is a Click Away
abstract: Art museum websites have become more useful, with entire collections online, some accompanied by essays and videos.
lead_paragraph: The construction of new art museum buildings like that of the Whitney Museum of American Art in Manhattan’s meatpacking district naturally receives a lot of attention. But there’s another kind of construction going on that tells more about where museums are at and where they are going than any shiny new edifice: their websites. That might sound surprising to anyone not professionally involved in museum work, but if you want to know how museums are changing their philosophies and programs in a time of increasing financial pressure and the continuing rise of private museums like Eli Broad’s in Los Angeles, websites are the most visible and informative places to look.

headline: A Long, Strange Trip Indeed
abstract: “The Golden Toad,” by the experimental troupe the Talking Band, unfolds over several locations and 27 years.
lead_paragraph: “The Golden Toad,” the latest work by the experimental troupe the Talking Band, is a long, often amusing journey of discovery, but its characters do most of the discovering.

headline: A Deep, Dark Fight for Dignity
abstract: James Green’s history of the coal-mining uprisings in West Virginia in the 1920s and ’30s drives home the misery of working conditions and the violence of the confrontations in that era.
lead_paragraph: The story James Green has to tell in “The Devil Is Here in These Hills: West Virginia’s Coal Miners and Their Battle for Freedom” is among the best and largely forgotten American stories. It’s about property rights versus human rights, about hard men and women and about violent conflict. It’s a tale about a working-class insurgency that’s as piney as an Appalachian ballad.

headline: Marshawn Lynch Has Only One Answer
abstract: The Seattle Seahawks running back replied to every question at a Super Bowl news conference with a variation of “you know why I’m here.”
lead_paragraph: The Seattle Seahawks running back replied to every question at a Super Bowl news conference with a variation of “you know why I’m here.”

headline: On the Margins, but Moving Toward the Center
abstract: The Outsider Art Fair, organized this year by Andrew Edlin, has grown up but holds fast to its roots.
lead_paragraph: Outsider art has changed significantly over the last decade. Where it used to come with a story and a diagnosis (the work was found in an attic or a Dumpster and made by a person with schizophrenia), it has now been included in the 2013 Venice Biennale, Rosemarie Trockel’s 2012 retrospective at the New Museum and acquired by the Museum of Modern Art. Quibbles over whether it should be called outsider, folk or self-taught are less prominent, and there has been somewhat of a shift to supporting living artists.

headline: A Brush With Fame, Long Before His Life in Art
abstract: Jerry Torre, who is having his first solo show at the Outsider Art Fair, has an offbeat back story that begins with the Beales of Grey Gardens.
lead_paragraph: DEALERS tend to be fond of an artist with a story. Jerry Torre has a doozy. Several, in fact.

headline: Jim Woodring: ‘You Drive!’
abstract: “You Drive!,” Jim Woodring’s show at Scott Eder Gallery, shows off his talent for wordless, comic narratives.
lead_paragraph: While barely if at all known in the high-art realm, Jim Woodring is a giant in the world of comics and graphic novels. Scott Eder Gallery, which specializes in comic art, here presents an assortment of recent drawings and paintings that display Mr. Woodring’s extraordinary gifts as a draftsman, storyteller and creator of hilarious characters and hallucinatory situations.

headline: Has the Measles Outbreak Changed Your Views on Vaccination? Describe Your Experience
abstract: New York Times journalists would like to hear from parents, particularly those in California and Arizona, who have chosen not to vaccinate their children against measles and other diseases.
lead_paragraph: New York Times journalists would like to hear from parents, particularly those in California and Arizona, who have chosen not to vaccinate their children against measles and other diseases.

headline: A Snowstorm Passes Over, but Leaves Stravinsky Scrambling in Its Wake
abstract: After the New York Philharmonic’s rehearsals were disrupted by the weather, the orchestra played a revised program on Wednesday evening.
lead_paragraph: There is an ineffable, unmistakable quality at the core of great live performances. Call it energy; call it joy. And it doesn’t require the material to be happy: It is possible for a rendition of a symphony to be joyful, even if the work is weighty.

headline: ‘Sing’s Millennium Mart’ at Interstate Projects
abstract: This exhibition, organized by Seung-Min Lee, envisions the deli of the future.
lead_paragraph: The Korean market is a relatively new institution in New York, but it has precedents in older corner stores, bodegas and delis where various cultures have mingled and clashed. “Sing’s Millennium Mart,” organized by Seung-Min Lee, is billed as “the corner deli of the future,” rather than any particular type — although Ms. Lee was born in Korea and her family has worked in the food business in New York.

headline: Sri Lanka to Free Tamils and Return Their Land
abstract: The promises represent the most significant efforts yet announced by the new government to heal the still-festering wounds of a decades-long civil war.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — The Sri Lankan government pledged Thursday to free hundreds of minority Tamil detainees and return much of the Tamil land in the north and east that the military seized and continues to hold years after the end of the country’s bitter civil war.

headline: What I Love | Valerie Steele
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The director of the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology lives with her husband, John S. Major, in a Chelsea loft.
lead_paragraph: The director of the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology lives with her husband, John S. Major, in a Chelsea loft.

headline: Diana Thater: ‘Science, Fiction’
abstract: The video artist Diana Thater’s “Science, Fiction,” considers the implications of starless nights.
lead_paragraph: Entering this spectacular exhibition by the West Coast video artist Diana Thater, you might think you’ve walked onto the set of a Stanley Kubrick sci-fi movie. The whole show is flooded by an intense blue glow cast by lights beaming from the floor in all corners. In the center of the gallery is a mysterious, room-size box, which appears to hover a few inches off the floor over a band of bright yellow light. A grainy video is projected on the ceiling directly above the box. It shows large beetles — dung beetles — slowly burrowing into the earth and moving about in thicket of brown grass.

headline: Björk Gets Personal
abstract: Jon Pareles tells Ben Ratliff about club-hopping with Björk in Iceland and listening to her new album, “Vulnerica,” which was released last week.
lead_paragraph: Jon Pareles tells Ben Ratliff about club-hopping with Björk in Iceland and listening to her new album, “Vulnerica,” which was released last week.

headline: Pictures of the Day — Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Ukraine and More: Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Ukraine and More: Pictures of the Day

headline: Uche Okeke: ‘Works on Paper, 1958-1993’
abstract: The Nigerian Modernist artist Uche Okeke has a show of drawings at the Skoto Gallery.
lead_paragraph: Histories of Modernism are constantly changing as scholars come to realize its global breadth and local particularities. The marketplace is slower on the uptake. Although New York has a few galleries specializing in early-to-mid-20th-century Asian work, Skoto Gallery in Chelsea remains, more than two decades after it opened, the sole full-time outlet for comparable work from Africa. And it gives us some Modernism-merging-into-contemporary basics in a thumbnail survey of works on paper by the influential West African artist Uche Okeke.

headline: How, and Why, Apple Overtook Microsoft
abstract: With the latest earnings reports from Microsoft and Apple, the once-unthinkable became reality: Apple’s market capitalization hit $683 billion, more than double Microsoft’s $338 billion.
lead_paragraph: When Microsoft stock was at a record high in 1999, and its market capitalization was nearly $620 billion, the notion that Apple Computer would ever be bigger — let alone twice as big — was laughable. Apple was teetering on bankruptcy. And Microsoft’s operating system was so dominant in personal computers, then the center of the technology universe, that the government deemed the company an unlawful monopoly.

headline: Three Americans Are Killed in a Shooting at Kabul Airport
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Defense Contracts', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Some reports said the Americans, who were military contractors, were killed by a man wearing an Afghan military uniform.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Three American military contractors were killed in a shooting on the military side of Kabul’s international airport on Thursday, military officials said.

headline: A Flower Delivery That Brought More Pain Than Pleasure
keywords: ['Modern Love (Times Column)', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Love (Emotion)', 'Dating and Relationships']
abstract: When a simple gift becomes flowergate.
lead_paragraph: With the best of intentions, I once did something regrettable.

headline: Oscar Nominated Shorts
abstract: Images of films in the program.
lead_paragraph: Images of films in the program.

headline: Hershey to Buy Krave, a Maker of Jerky
abstract: The company plans to buy Krave, which is intent on turning jerky into the next upscale snack food.
lead_paragraph: Chocolate-covered jerky? It’s no longer a wild idea, with Hershey’s on Thursday announcing plans to buy a tiny, trendy jerky company.

headline: Jan. 29, 2015  — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Israel, Australia and France.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Israel, Australia and France.

headline: Martin Brodeur Retires With Most Wins and ‘a Smile’
abstract: Brodeur, the longtime face of the Devils, said he was leaving hockey “with a smile on my face” and would become an adviser to St. Louis Blues General Manager Doug Armstrong.
lead_paragraph: Martin Brodeur acknowledged on Thursday that he could have found other opportunities to continue to play goaltender in the N.H.L.

headline: An Eyeful Next Door
abstract: Questions about spying on neighbors, sibling disputes, vegan dilemmas and tipping in the age of Groupon.
lead_paragraph: The man next door cut down his bamboo trees and exposed his backyard to us (and 20 others in our building). Our young son loves reporting on the doings in the newly visible yard, especially “the man in the pool.” Our neighbor uses his hot tub most mornings, stark naked and in full view of our building. May I speak with him about a compromise? (p.s. He is not European. The gossip is that he is 30, and his parents bought him the house. Yes, I am judging.)

headline: And to the Point
abstract: Academy Award nominees in the short film, short documentary and short animated film categories are everything Oscar nominees should and could be but rarely are.
lead_paragraph: At Oscar time, short films are both an afterthought and a corrective. Office-pool hustlers will hope for a lucky break or an inside line (Is there a Pixar cartoon? Something with cute kids? A Holocaust theme?), while more casual observers will brace themselves for disproportionately long, achingly sincere speeches from filmmakers nobody has ever heard of. But if the shorts are inevitably upstaged by the main show, they also offer a vision of what the Academy Awards should and could be but very rarely are: eclectic, cosmopolitan, scrappy and surprising.

headline: Bomb Attacks at Security Sites in Sinai Kill at Least 26
abstract: The bombings suggest that Egypt’s campaign of home demolitions, nighttime curfews and geographic isolation has failed to head off the budding insurgency there.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A series of simultaneous bombings targeting security facilities in the Sinai killed at least 26 people Thursday night, prompting fears that the Egyptian government’s campaign of home demolitions, curfews and sweeping arrests has failed to choke off a budding insurgency there.

headline: In Montreal, a Week for Poutine
abstract: La Poutine Week in Montreal and other cities is a culinary competition (cheese curds included).
lead_paragraph: With a food scene as diverse as Montreal’s, tourists often don’t know where to start eating.

headline: In Fashion
abstract: Athletic sportswear has come a long way from the track and the field. High fashion sounds a call to action with all-American lettered jerseys, motocross stripes and high-tech mesh.
lead_paragraph: Athletic sportswear has come a long way from the track and the field. High fashion sounds a call to action with all-American lettered jerseys, motocross stripes and high-tech mesh.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Manitowoc to Split in Two After Pressure From Activists
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: In a victory for Carl Icahn and Ralph Whitworth’s Relational Investors, Manitowoc said it would separate its crane manufacturing and food service businesses, betting that the two would be more valuable as independent companies.
lead_paragraph: The Manitowoc Company, a manufacturer in Wisconsin, plans to spit itself in two after pressure from powerful activist investors.

headline: Theater Listings for Jan. 30-Feb. 5
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Greece’s Feisty Finance Minister Tries a More Moderate Message
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Euro (Currency)', 'Credit and Debt', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Yanis Varoufakis, a self-described “erratic Marxist,” says that renegotiating Greek debt needn’t be a “yes or no, take it or leave it” situation.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — In the first days after the election victory of the leftist party Syriza in Greece, Yanis Varoufakis, the new finance minister, has lobbed some rhetorical grenades, referring to his country’s foreign-imposed austerity budgets as “fiscal waterboarding” and calling Greece’s international bailout deals “a toxic mistake.”

headline: The Thrum of Thrill-Seeking
abstract: From the drama “The Diary of a Teenage Girl” to the unsettling documentary “Prophet’s Prey,” the offerings at this year’s Sundance Film Festival underline why the event remains a draw.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — Every January at the Sundance Film Festival, a movie or two will pop, exciting a cinematic congregation that descends on this resort town praying for the next big thing and at times finding it. Last year the festival got the party started with “Whiplash,” one of its opening selections, and then sent attendees into raptures with “Boyhood.” No single title has dominated this year’s event, yet after a slow start that had some writing off the event before it really got going, good and great movies — from coming-of-age tales like “The Diary of a Teenage Girl” and “Me and Earl and the Dying Girl” to documentaries like “Prophet’s Prey” and “Welcome to Leith” — affirmed that, once again, this was the place to be.

headline: Oil Cash Waning, Venezuelan Shelves Lie Bare
keywords: ['Rationing and Allocation of Resources', 'Shortages', 'Series', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Because Venezuela is so dependent on oil sales to buy imports of food, medicine and many other basics, the drop in oil prices means that there is even less hard currency to buy what the country needs.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Mary Noriega heard there would be chicken.

lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Positive Science on ART Babies
abstract: The healthy outcomes of babies born through assisted reproduction technology, or fertility treatments, are rising, a large study shows.
lead_paragraph: A large study has found that assisted reproduction technology, or ART, has markedly improved over the past 20 years, with the outcomes of these fertility treatments now better than ever.
