headline: Spurning Placidity for the Fire Within
abstract: The Mariinsky Orchestra displayed a gnashing intensity in performances of two all-Russian programs at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Other ensembles may play more consistently with technical prowess and exacting coordination than the Mariinsky Orchestra. But at its best, this ensemble, the house band of the Mariinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, Russia, brings dark, rich sound; vivid character; and emotional depth to its performances, especially in Russian repertory. The orchestra was not quite at its best for the two all-Russian programs that Valery Gergiev, its longtime music director, conducted at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday and Wednesday nights.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for Jan. 30-Feb. 5
abstract: A selected, critical guide to the visual arts in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Bernice Gordon, Prolific Crossword Constructor,  Dies at 101
abstract: Ms. Gordon began building puzzles in her 30s, and continued assembling a grid a day until just recently.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — Bernice Gordon, who reinvented herself as an artist and a crossword-puzzle constructor after raising three children, died this morning at her home in Philadelphia. She was 101.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Jan. 30-Feb. 5
abstract: A selected guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families in New York City.
lead_paragraph: ‘Hello From Japan!’

headline: A Mother’s Illness, a Daughter’s Duty
abstract: After Nancy Borowick’s father died of cancer, she wasted no moments as she chronicled her mother’s illness.
lead_paragraph: After Nancy Borowick’s father died of cancer, she wasted no moments as she chronicled her mother’s illness.

headline: Spare Times for Jan. 30-Feb. 5
abstract: A selected guide to readings, discussions, exhibitions, walking tours and other cultural events in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Museums and Sites

headline: Abstracted Moves
abstract: The choreographer Moriah Evans plays with the paradoxical ratios of intimacy and proximity in contemporary social dance in an Issue Project Room performance.
lead_paragraph: Before each performance of “Social Dance 1-8: Index,” the choreographer Moriah Evans personally escorts audience members to seats of her choosing. It’s the action of a hostess, though Ms. Evans isn’t cordial. As a cold abstraction of a social gesture, and as an indication of Ms. Evans’s close control over every part of her work, this is an apt introduction to what follows.

headline: Joe Biden: A Plan for Central America
keywords: ['Foreign Aid', 'United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Taxation']
abstract: If we don’t act, the region’s problems will arrive at our door.
lead_paragraph: AS we were reminded last summer when thousands of unaccompanied children showed up on our southwestern border, the security and prosperity of Central America are inextricably linked with our own.

headline: At Halftime, Hear Her Roar
abstract: This year’s Super Bowl headliner has had nine No. 1 hits on the Billboard Hot 100 since 2008.
lead_paragraph: More cartoon character than gridiron warrior, Katy Perry will bring some whimsy to the Super Bowl this weekend.

headline: Exploring the Limits in a Man’s World
abstract: In “Girlhood,” Céline Sciamma revels in the risky, reckless exuberance of adolescence and in the sheer joy of filming it.
lead_paragraph: Céline Sciamma’s “Girlhood” can be described (like so many movies these days) as a coming-of-age story, and it honors the genre, and its main character, with exemplary sensitivity and sympathy. But even as she stops at familiar stations on the road to maturity — problems at home and school, new friendships and first love — Ms. Sciamma revels in the risky, reckless exuberance of adolescence and in the sheer joy of filming it.

headline: On Film, the Dance Hidden in Hands, Poetry and Parkinson’s
abstract: Choreography pops up in unexpected places as the film festival Dance on Camera, at Lincoln Center, proves.
lead_paragraph: It’s time for a new kind of dance film, one that forces you to see the art form differently, that even makes you breathe a little differently. This season’s Dance on Camera festival, now in its 43rd year, presents several unconventional offerings that aim spotlights at the choreographic rigor of hand-clapping games and competitive cheerleading or reveal how Parkinson’s patients can dance with hypnotic purity.

headline: Concussions Are Down, N.F.L. Says
abstract: The league said that 202 concussions were diagnosed in the preseason and regular season in practices as well as games, down from 229 last season.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The N.F.L. said that the number of concussions fell 11.8 percent this season compared to 2013 as players adjust to new, stricter rules on helmet-to-helmet tackles.

headline: Embracing a Fantasy From Their Pixar Past
abstract: Two former Pixar artists have landed an Oscar nomination for “The Dam Keeper,” the first animated short they have written and directed.
lead_paragraph: This year’s nominees for the Oscar for animated short film cover a variety of subjects and styles. But the film that has generated the most excitement among professional animators is “The Dam Keeper,” a painterly short by Daisuke Tsutsumi and Robert Kondo, former Pixar art directors who have started their own studio.

headline: Katy Perry Touches Down in Football Fandom
abstract: Perry, a pop superstar, will perform the halftime show at the Super Bowl, but she got her first taste of the sport with a memorable stint as a guest picker on ESPNs “College GameDay.”
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — As the final seconds ticked off the clock on the first Saturday in October, capping a hectic but exhilarating day, a University of Mississippi student turned to his neighbor and planted a kiss on her lips. This was no ordinary seatmate, though: It was the pop superstar Katy Perry. And this was no ordinary game; Ole Miss had just upset Alabama.

headline: Katy Perry Teases Her Halftime Show
abstract: The singer dropped hints at a news conference about her appearance at the Super Bowl on Sunday with Lenny Kravitz and an unnamed guest performer.
lead_paragraph: The singer dropped hints at a news conference about her appearance at the Super Bowl on Sunday with Lenny Kravitz and an unnamed guest performer.

headline: A Medieval Time on a Planet Far Away
abstract: “Hard to Be a God,” the last movie by the Russian filmmaker Aleksei German, is set on another planet still in the throes of the Middle Ages.
lead_paragraph: The future is mired in the muddy, muddy past in “Hard to Be a God,” Aleksei German’s full-contact, madly outré adaptation of the 1964 science-fiction novel by Arkady and Boris Strugatsky. The film’s helter-skelter action takes place on another planet, but not some gleamingly advanced version of our own. On the parallel world of Arkanar, it’s still the Middle Ages, and the rabble spend their lives tramping through muck, surviving warring factions (or not), and apparently delighting in the total lack of sanitation.

headline: Italy Opens Voting for New President. Let the Intrigue Begin.
abstract: In a process expected to take at least three days, the candidate of Prime Minister Matteo Renzi has already been turned away.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Shortly before voting began in Parliament on Thursday to elect Italy’s new president, a flash mob gathered in the cold rain outside the Quirinale, as the presidential residence is called.

headline: ConocoPhillips and Occidental Post Losses, Reflecting Oil Price Plunge
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Company Reports', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: After years of the industry making record profits both companies said that they lost money in the fourth quarter.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — After years of making record profits as oil prices soared, America’s oil giants are beginning to lose money.

headline: Deflation Experiments Show Patriots May Have a Point After All
abstract: Thomas Healy, a graduate student in mechanical engineering at Carnegie Mellon, has detailed data on how atmospheric conditions might have reduced the pressure in footballs in the A.F.C. title game.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Healy does not have tickets to the Super Bowl, but he plans to fly to Phoenix with something that is even harder to come by than seats at Sunday’s game: the first detailed, experimental data on how atmospheric conditions might have reduced the air pressure in footballs used by the New England Patriots in their victory over the Indianapolis Colts nearly two weeks ago.

headline: More Special-Needs Students Remain at Charter Schools, Report Finds
abstract: New York City’s Independent Budget Office found that 53 percent of charter school kindergartners with disabilities were still in the same schools four years later, compared with 49 percent in traditional schools.
lead_paragraph: In the continuing battle over the growth of charter schools, critics often say that many New York charter schools push out students with special needs.

headline: Offshore Wind Farm Leases Draw Few Bids From Wary Industry
abstract: Wind Farm projects off the coast of New England, New Jersey and Delaware are dead, moribund or struggling.
lead_paragraph: Not too long ago, in 2013, the Obama administration began auctioning off leases for offshore wind farms up and down the Eastern Seaboard, hoping to spur a nascent industry.

headline: Law Firm Founds Project to Fight ‘Revenge Porn’
keywords: ['Cyberharassment', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Law and Legislation', 'Pornography', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: K&L Gates has set up the Cyber Civil Rights Legal Project to fight the shame-posting of sexual photos and videos online by jilted lovers.
lead_paragraph: A California law student and a Virginia man dated for about six months after meeting through an online dating service. The fallout from the breakup, however, has gone on far longer, as the former boyfriend faces federal criminal charges over posting nude selfies and a sexually explicit video of the woman on pornographic websites.

headline: Take My Iraqi Niece, Please
abstract: In Sean Mullin’s “Amira & Sam,” an Army veteran and aspiring comedian becomes the protector of his old Iraqi translator’s beautiful relative.
lead_paragraph: Stripped of the beard, glasses and unwashed curtain of hair that transform him into Gilfoyle on HBO’s “Silicon Valley,” the actor Martin Starr is unrecognizable in the prickly love story “Amira & Sam.” His blank-eyed impassivity and deadpan line delivery, though, are exactly the same; and while they work beautifully to play a testy techie on a comedy show, they make him an unpersuasive lover and an unappealing leading man.

headline: Group of Senators Seeks to Lift Cuba Travel Limits
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: A bipartisan group of lawmakers has taken the first step in a looming congressional battle over how far to expand trade and tourism with the Castro government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan group of senators introduced legislation on Thursday to permanently lift all restrictions on American travel to Cuba, the first step in what will be a pitched congressional battle over how far the United States should go in expanding trade and tourism with the Communist island nation.

headline: A Boy Praises the Principal of His Brooklyn School, and a Fund-Raising Campaign Takes Off
abstract: The efforts of Mott Hall Bridges Academy, in Brownsville, Brooklyn, to educate low-income children have inspired people and spurred a campaign that has raised more than $1 million for the students.
lead_paragraph: The fat yellow package was addressed to the principal, students and staff of Mott Hall Bridges Academy in Brownsville, Brooklyn. Inside were hundreds of red business cards printed with a single message: “You Matter.”

headline: Senators Introduce Cuba Travel Bill
abstract: A bipartisan group of senators spoke in support of a bill that would remove a ban on Americans traveling to Cuba, in light of President Obama’s restoration of diplomatic relations.
lead_paragraph: A bipartisan group of senators spoke in support of a bill that would remove a ban on Americans traveling to Cuba, in light of President Obama’s restoration of diplomatic relations.

headline: A Musician Who Was a Player, Too
abstract: “The Devil’s Violinist” is about the 19th-century Italian violinist Niccolò Paganini.
lead_paragraph: Even if, like me, you’re a sucker for men with tossable hair and precision eyeliner, you can’t help noticing that “The Devil’s Violinist” is hysterical — and possibly historical — hooey. More bodice-ripper than biopic, this German-Austrian coproduction about the life of the Italian violinist Niccolò Paganini is so magnificently misjudged that it almost defies description.

headline: Spotify to Raise $500 Million; Move Could Delay an I.P.O.
abstract: The move would increase the firm’s valuation to at least $6 billion, according to a person briefed on the company’s plans.
lead_paragraph: Spotify, the popular streaming music service, has retained Goldman Sachs to raise $500 million in private investment, a move that would probably delay the possibility of an initial public stock offering in the near future.

headline: With Ability to Script Success, What Could Go Wrong?
abstract: “Project Almanac,” portrayed as if the film’s footage were shot by the characters, traces a group of friends as they try to manipulate their lives through time travel.
lead_paragraph: “Project Almanac,” a teenage time-travel fable, begins with its hero delivering a college admissions essay to the camera and continues to pretend that everything we see was filmed by the characters. It’s the latest example of the “found-footage” conceit, which apparently reflects a misperception among screenwriters that the filmmakers have to be part of the story, or else the movie doesn’t happen.

headline: Civil Lawsuit on Revenge Porn
abstract: The former boyfriend of a California law student posted nude selfies and a sexually explicit video of her on pornographic websites.
lead_paragraph: The former boyfriend of a California law student posted nude selfies and a sexually explicit video of her on pornographic websites.

headline: For Special-Care Residents, New York State Policy Means Leaving Home
abstract: John Cosentino has spent 36 years at a Brooklyn institution. Now the state is moving disabled residents out. The change is wrenching.
lead_paragraph: Long after lunchtime one recent afternoon, John Cosentino sat at his usual table, eating his usual snacks. On this day, he was the only resident of the Brooklyn Developmental Center in its cavernous cafeteria, drafty and lit with the bleakness of an earlier era.

headline: N.B.A. Signs Deal With Chinese Internet Giant
abstract: The N.B.A. announced a five-year deal said to be worth at least $500 million with Tencent Holdings to carry games, highlights and other league content.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. announced a five-year deal Thursday with the Chinese Internet giant Tencent Holdings Limited to carry games, highlights and other league content on its digital platforms. The deal is worth at least $500 million, said a person briefed on the details of the agreement who was not authorized to speak publicly about it. The deal will start on July 1.

headline: Back When They Were Fab
abstract: In “Backstreet Boys: Show ’Em What You’re Made Of,” members of that boy band reminisce, relax and occasionally rehearse.
lead_paragraph: “Backstreet Boys: Show ‘Em What You’re Made Of” is a film that only fans who are seriously overinvested in that once formidable boy band could love.

headline: Drones Spotted, but Not Halted, Raise Concerns
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Super Bowl', 'Terrorism', 'White House Building (Washington, DC)']
abstract: Thwarting drones is increasingly becoming a challenge for law enforcement and security officials who are charged with protecting large-scale events like the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Major League Baseball’s top players took the field at the All-Star Game in Minneapolis in July, a covert radar system scanned the sky above the 40,000-seat stadium for what security experts said was an emerging threat to public safety: drones.

headline: Crash Death May Be Tied to a Takata Airbag
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Honda Motor is investigating the fatal crash of a driver on Jan. 19 as a possible sixth death linked to Takata airbags that can rupture.
lead_paragraph: Honda Motor is investigating a possible sixth death linked to Takata airbags that can rupture, the automaker and lawyers said on Thursday, as a new estimate put the number of those injured by the defective airbags as high as 64.

headline: Events in New Jersey for Feb. 1-7, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Embedded With the E. T. Fighters
abstract: The low-budget “Alien Outpost” is shaped like a boots-on-the-ground documentary but is more akin to a futuristic war movie.
lead_paragraph: “Alien Outpost,” the first feature from Jabbar Raisani, should really be called “Alien Out of Sight,” as the few, mostly distant glimpses we’re allowed of the movie’s extraterrestrials tell us very little. What we do learn — from a flurry of opening title cards — is that these so-called Heavies invaded Earth in 2021 and were chased off a year later, inexplicably leaving thousands of their kind behind. Probably just to annoy us.

headline: Jewish American Pilots Fighting for Israel
abstract: The documentary “Above and Beyond” recounts the story of Jewish American pilots who secretly fought for Israel during its War of Independence.
lead_paragraph: Produced by Nancy Spielberg (sister of Steven Spielberg), the documentary “Above and Beyond” recounts the story of Jewish American pilots who, beginning in 1948, secretly fought for Israel in its war of independence, when the Israeli military was nascent.

headline: Los Angeles to Build Housing for Veterans
abstract: The Department of Veterans Affairs has agreed to settle a three-year-old lawsuit brought on behalf of homeless veterans by pledging to build permanent and transitional “bridge” housing.
lead_paragraph: Even as Los Angeles became home to the country’s largest population of homeless military veterans, the Department of Veterans Affairs for years has used much of its 387-acre tract near the city’s exclusive Brentwood neighborhood for other purposes, including leasing property to a car rental agency and the laundry facilities of a major hotel chain. This happened over the objections of veterans advocates who thought that the tract, which had been deeded to the government in 1888 for the purpose of housing disabled veterans, should be used to house some of Los Angeles’s 4,000 homeless veterans.

headline: Plane Crashes Near Aruba After Pursuit by Military Jets
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Smuggling', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: A small civilian aircraft, suspected of carrying drugs and pursued by Venezuelan military jets, crashed Thursday into the Caribbean Sea near the island of Aruba, officials said.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — A small civilian aircraft, pursued by Venezuelan military jets, crashed Thursday into the Caribbean Sea near the island of Aruba, officials on the island said.

headline: Rod McKuen, Poet and Lyricist With Vast Following, Dies at 81
abstract: The author of dozens of books whose work met with immense commercial success if little critical esteem, Mr. McKuen was once described as “the unofficial poet laureate of America.”
lead_paragraph: Rod McKuen, a ubiquitous poet, lyricist and songwriter whose work met with immense commercial success if little critical esteem, died on Thursday in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 81.

headline: Events on Long Island for Feb. 1-7, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Hostages of Racism
abstract: In “Supremacy,” directed by Deon Taylor, a white supremacist just released from prison invades a black family’s farmhouse.
lead_paragraph: Feeding over-the-top language to underdeveloped characters, Deon Taylor’s “Supremacy” dramatizes racism with an unvarying intensity that quickly becomes wearing. The furnace at its center is Tully (Joe Anderson), a white supremacist newly released from prison after serving 15 years for armed robbery. With a swastika on his cheek and hate in his heart, Tully hits the road with Doreen (Dawn Olivieri), a coked-up Aryan floozy, before robbing a convenience store and shooting a police officer. All this, and we’ve barely cleared the opening credits.

headline: Netanyahu Is Talking to Leading Democrats to Little Effect So Far
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The Israeli prime minister has been reaching out to leading Capitol Hill Democrats, including Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, to try to ease criticism over his coming address to Congress, but has made little progress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has been reaching out to leading Capitol Hill Democrats to try to ease criticism over his coming address to Congress, but has made little progress.

headline: Shake Shack, Born in a Park, Is Going Public With Big Dreams
abstract: Shake Shack is part of fast-food movement that has emphasized fresh food and friendliness, a tack that will value the company at around $745 million.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 14 years ago, on something of a lark, the restaurateur Danny Meyer opened a Chicago-style hot dog cart in Manhattan’s Madison Square Park, hoping to draw crowds to the park and give summer jobs to the staff at one of his nearby high-end restaurants.

headline: A Small Plane, Sputtering, Gently Merges Into a Northbound Lane on a New Jersey Highway
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: A pilot landed the failing Cessna 150 on Route 23 in West Milford, N.J., managing to avoid injuring himself or any motorists.
lead_paragraph: A small airplane was cruising about 3,500 feet over the northwest corner of New Jersey on Thursday afternoon when its single engine sputtered out, rendering it powerless as it descended miles from a landing strip.

headline: Course Gives Tiger Woods Some Problems, but Fans Don’t
abstract: Woods stood at five over par after his first 11 holes at the Phoenix Open, at which point the gap separating him and the early leader, Keegan Bradley, who posted a six-under 65, was a gulf.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — Tiger Woods took a lemon and squeezed a two-over-par 73 out of it Thursday, proving there is nothing wrong with his mental game. After nearly six months away from full-field competition, Woods’s golf remains a little green. If it were a piece of fruit, he would let it ripen a few months before picking it.

headline: House Democrats, Facing Long Odds, Take Inspiration From the Top

lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — President Obama sought to buck up House Democrats on retreat here, even as Republicans back in Washington proved the value of being in the majority by pushing through the Senate a bill to approve the Keystone XL pipeline.

headline: Marked for Death After Helping a Friend
abstract: “Wild Card,” a remake of William Goldman’s “Heat,” stars Jason Stratham as a security consultant caught up in violent confrontations in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: Set in the underbelly of Las Vegas and full of dull existential timeouts, “Wild Card” is about second chances. For the “security consultant” played by Jason Statham, that would mean finally escaping the (violent) grind. For the film’s storied screenwriter, William Goldman, it’s the rare privilege of re-adapting his novel “Heat” after its first incarnation in 1986 with Burt Reynolds.

abstract: In addition to his musical career, Mr. Roussos was a passenger on TWA Flight 847, from Athens to Rome, which was hijacked to Beirut in 1985.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Demis Roussos, an internationally famous Greek singer known for both his heartfelt pop songs and his flamboyant clothes, died here on Sunday. He was 68.

lead_paragraph: As he made his way through immigration at Kennedy International Airport after returning to New York from Barbados, Michael Waithe was stopped.

abstract: Mr. Laxman’s comic strip, featuring a character he called the Common Man, appeared daily on the front page of The Times of India for more than five decades.
lead_paragraph: R. K. Laxman, a fixture of Indian society whose satirical comic strip featuring a character he called the Common Man appeared daily on the front page of The Times of India for more than five decades, died on Jan. 26 in the western Indian city of Pune. He was 93.

headline: A Fragile Circle of Love, Doomed at Every Turn
abstract: The Classic Stage Company’s production of “A Month in the Country,” Ivan Turgenev’s melancholy romantic comedy, stars two performers currently riding high on television fame.
lead_paragraph: “A Month in the Country” feels like a week in the gulag — or perhaps I should say a stint in a minimum-security prison? — in the Classic Stage Company’s listless staging of Ivan Turgenev’s melancholy comedy of romantic misalliances and infatuations. The production, which opened on Thursday night, stars two performers riding high on television fame: Taylor Schilling, the jailed Piper Chapman of “Orange Is the New Black,” portrays the restless, disaffected heroine, Natalya, and Peter Dinklage, from “Game of Thrones,” is her ardent admirer, Rakitin.

headline: What’s the Point of an Eating Utensil?
abstract: A fun Friday puzzle by David Phillips.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — David Phillips is back with a 66-worder that definitely shows how younger constructors can bring us the freshest puzzles. He has some interesting points to make about this puzzle, so I’ll briefly talk about some of the highlights and then skedaddle out of his way.

headline: Saudi King Hands Out Pink Slips and Bonuses
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Government Employees', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Despite concern that a steep decline in oil prices would restrict the country’s finances, King Salman also decreed a cash bonus worth two months' salary to government employees, students and pensioners.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Less than a week after ascending the throne, King Salman of Saudi Arabia issued an array of royal decrees on Thursday — abolishing government bodies, changing ministers, dismissing the chief of intelligence and further consolidating his own authority.

headline: What to Wear? First Ladies Are Steeped in Protocol
abstract: Photographs of Michelle Obama without a head scarf led to headlines and Internet chatter about whether she had broken with tradition.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The first lady, Michelle Obama, bared her head in Saudi Arabia, but covered it at the Vatican and at an Indonesian mosque. Laura Bush wore a head scarf only briefly in Saudi Arabia and to tour the Dome of the Rock in Jerusalem. Hillary Rodham Clinton covered her head in Eritrea, the West Bank and Pakistan, but did not in Saudi Arabia.

headline: Field Thins Quickly in Contest for New Assembly Speaker
abstract: By Thursday afternoon, what had been a four-person race among Democrats to succeed Sheldon Silver as Assembly speaker had been winnowed to three contenders.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The magic number is 76. And on Thursday, State Assemblyman Carl E. Heastie appeared to be tantalizingly close to, or past, that threshold and thus on the precipice of ascending to the soon-to-be-vacant speakership of the New York Assembly.

headline: Race for Assembly Speaker Is a Fight Until the End
abstract: As the competition to succeed the disgraced Sheldon Silver narrowed, Catherine Nolan, an assemblywoman for 30 years, said she had no intention of dropping out.
lead_paragraph: As fast as Assemblywoman Catherine Nolan speaks — and there are few in public life who can, like her, reel off complete, properly punctuated sentences with dependent clauses at 60 miles per hour — she could not keep up with the call-waiting beep on her phone on Thursday afternoon.

headline: Two Infants Die in New York in Unrelated Episodes
abstract: A 5-month-old boy was found dead in Washington Heights in Manhattan on Thursday morning, and 2-week-old girl was found dead in the Kensington section of Brooklyn at about the same time, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Two infants died on Thursday morning in separate episodes in Manhattan and Brooklyn, the authorities said.

headline: Behind the Scenes, Network Production Crews Find a Friendlier Belichick
abstract: Bill Belichick’s funereal demeanor is rooted in the public imagination, but as one N.F.L. network analyst said, meetings with him can be illuminating, even fun.
lead_paragraph: Bill Belichick’s funereal demeanor is so rooted in the public imagination that any smile or moment of loquaciousness is like finding a great prize in a Cracker Jack box. You cherish little diversions like the one at Super Bowl media day on Tuesday when he talked about a hand-held monkey puppet.

headline: The Worst 4th-Down Decisions in Super Bowl History
abstract: In the biggest game of all, coaches have frequently made decisions that damaged their teams’ chances to win a championship.
lead_paragraph: Tom Landry made the mistake in two different Super Bowls. Marv Levy, the longtime Bills coach, made it in an excruciating loss to the Giants in 1991. Mike Tomlin, Mike Martz and Lovie Smith have all done it, too. Perhaps most surprisingly, Bill Belichick has done it multiple times in his Super Bowl appearances.

headline: Lundqvist’s Lone Mistake Is One Too Many as Rangers Fall to Canadiens
abstract: Max Pacioretty scored the game’s only goal, and the Canadiens dealt the Rangers a 1-0 loss at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: For much of Thursday night’s Rangers-Canadiens game, two of the N.H.L.’s best goaltenders showed just how good they are.

headline: Martha A. Derthick, Analyst Who Untangled Public Policy, Dies at 81
abstract: Dr. Derthick’s work on Social Security, federalism, deregulation and welfare was said to vividly bring life to impenetrable subjects.
lead_paragraph: Martha A. Derthick, a political scientist whose trenchant analyses of typically impenetrable subjects like Social Security, federalism, deregulation and tobacco litigation were praised as “masterful” and “definitive,” died on Jan. 12 at a hospital in Charlottesville, Va. She was 81.

headline: Recipes From a Chef Beloved by Artists
abstract: Mina Stone, who cooks regularly for Urs Fischer and other big names in the art world, shares dishes from her new cookbook.
lead_paragraph: Mina Stone just wants to be able to feed everyone. “Every menu is sort of structured around everybody, whether they’re vegetarian or vegan or meat eaters, being able to be satisfied by a dish,” says the Brooklyn-based personal chef who, for the past nine years, has made a name for herself in the New York art scene. She prepares lunch three days a week for the artist Urs Fischer and his staff at his Red Hook studio, serves post-opening dinners for the gallerist Gavin Brown and cooks for the painter Elizabeth Peyton. Fittingly, Stone also admits to developing recipes based on color: “When you look at your plate,” she says, “I feel like all those items should be really beautiful together.”

lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department on Friday morning questioned Marion Knight, the hip-hop music executive known as Suge, who was believed to have been involved in a hit-and-run that left one pedestrian dead and another hospitalized in Compton, Calif., a day earlier.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13); 10 P.M. (49) SHAKESPEARE UNCOVERED Actors and directors tour some of Shakespeare’s greatest works in this series, which begins a second season. Hugh Bonneville, who began his career at the Open Air Theater in Regent’s Park in London understudying Ralph Fiennes as Lysander in “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” goes to see the play on Midsummer Night at the Globe Theater. There he speaks with the artistic director, Dominic Dromgoole, and the actor David Walliams; looks back at performances by James Cagney and Helen Mirren and settings by the directors Peter Brook and Julie Taymor; and offers some musings of his own. At 10, Christopher Plummer takes on “King Lear,” a role he has played to acclaim under the direction of Jonathan Miller, by delving into the play’s history, pondering how the storm scenes might have been produced at Shakespeare’s own theater and looking at some alternate endings. Ian McKellen and Simon Russell Beale share their insights as well.

headline: China to Tally Suicides by Civil Servants
abstract: A spate of suicides last year has raised questions about the effects of the country’s continuing campaign to root out corruption.
lead_paragraph: China will begin tabulating deaths of officials after a spate of suicides last year raised questions about the effects of the country’s continuing anticorruption campaign.

headline: Can Students Have Too Much Tech?
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Income Inequality', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Research']
abstract: The wired classroom may actually widen the learning gap.
lead_paragraph: PRESIDENT OBAMA’s domestic agenda, which he announced in his State of the Union address this month, has a lot to like: health care, maternity leave, affordable college. But there was one thing he got wrong. As part of his promise to educate American children for an increasingly competitive world, he vowed to “protect a free and open Internet” and “extend its reach to every classroom and every community.”

headline: A Huge Victory for Homeless Veterans
abstract: Credit the new secretary of veterans affairs for embracing, in Los Angeles, the once radical-sounding idea that the sick and the troubled need housing first.
lead_paragraph: The Veterans Affairs Department is going to provide housing for disabled homeless veterans on the vast property it owns in Los Angeles. On Wednesday, it announced an agreement with plaintiffs in a lawsuit “that restores the West Los Angeles V.A. campus to serving veterans in need,” by housing them there, and by ending the practice of leasing parts of the 387-acre property to outside parties in deals “that do not meet the goal of serving veterans.”

headline: Rabbits and Rebels
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: My ever-pregnant mother, a devout Catholic, agonized over what to do. If only Pope Francis had been around then.
lead_paragraph: The babies came one after the other in my family, six in eight years’ time, then a miscarriage, a seventh, and finally a dire medical warning: An eighth child might leave the rest without the young woman who had brought us into this world. My mother went to her general practitioner first, then the Roman Catholic bishop. The doctor said stop. The cleric said shame if you do.

headline: Europe’s Greek Test
abstract: Can Europe get past the myths and moralizing, and deal with reality in a way that respects the Continents core values?
lead_paragraph: In the five years (!) that have passed since the euro crisis began, clear thinking has been in notably short supply. But that fuzziness must now end. Recent events in Greece pose a fundamental challenge for Europe: Can it get past the myths and the moralizing, and deal with reality in a way that respects the Continent’s core values? If not, the whole European project — the attempt to build peace and democracy through shared prosperity — will suffer a terrible, perhaps mortal blow.

headline: Being Who We Are
abstract: We should stop trying to play chess in the Middle East and simply keep our promises.
lead_paragraph: In the middle of 2013, the United States began supporting moderate rebels in Syria. We gave them just enough support to betray them.

headline: No Case for Killing the Medical Device Tax
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medical Devices', 'Editorials', 'Taxation', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Affordable Care Act opponents are taking aim at a component that would raise some $29 billion. President Obama ought to veto any bill that eliminates it.
lead_paragraph: In seeking to dismantle the Affordable Care Act piece by piece, congressional Republicans have placed a high priority on repealing a tax on medical devices that would raise some $29 billion over the next 10 years to help ensure that health reform will not increase the deficit. Repealing the tax is a terrible idea that has been given a veneer of respectability by support from liberal Democrats in states with large concentrations of device manufacturers. They include Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, Senators Amy Klobuchar and Al Franken of Minnesota and Representative Ron Kind of Wisconsin, among others. President Obama ought to veto any bill that eliminates the tax.

headline: Requiem for a Friend, and for Empathy
abstract: Readers respond to columns by Nicholas Kristof.

headline: Washington and Havana Break the Ice
abstract: American and Cuban officials will need to be pragmatic and patient as they untangle a relationship laden with five decades of acrimony, resentment and mistrust.
lead_paragraph: A couple of years after America’s attempted invasion of Cuba in 1961, the disastrous intervention known as the Bay of Pigs, an envoy President John F. Kennedy secretly dispatched to Havana posed an odd question to the Cuban leader, Fidel Castro.

headline: For V.A. Hospitals (and Patients), a Major Health Victory
abstract: One in 25 patients who goes into the hospital without an infection will get one there. The V.A. is leading the way in bringing those numbers under control.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced that the United States is making modest progress in bringing down rates of hospital-acquired infections.

headline: Qatar Airways Acquires 9.99% Stake in British Airways Parent
abstract: The stake in the International Airlines Group, also the parent of the Spanish carried Iberia, deepens a commercial partnership with the group.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Qatar Airways said on Friday that it had acquired a 9.99 percent stake in the International Airlines Group, the parent company of British Airways and Iberia of Spain, deepening an existing commercial partnership with the group and further extending the emirate's push into Europe.

headline: The Lessons of the Michelle Obama Head Scarf Hoo-Ha
abstract: Public figures, and politicians in particular, should communicate their clothing and hair choices before the public does it for them.
lead_paragraph: Leave the real world to enter the alternate fashion-verse (a.k.a. the couture shows) for a few days, and what happens? A faux fashion scandal! Such is the irony of this life. Still, it contains an important lesson.

abstract: Some nutrition scientists are concerned that with the profusion of fortified foods, beverages and supplements, many people may be ingesting levels of vitamins and other nutrients that are not only unnecessary, but potentially harmful.
lead_paragraph: Companies are increasingly adding vitamins and minerals to juices, sports drinks and bottled water, responding to a growing consumer demand for these products. Even though the amounts of added nutrients in these drinks are typically small, some nutrition scientists are concerned that through their overall diets, many people may be ingesting levels of vitamins and other nutrients that are not only unnecessary, but potentially harmful.

lead_paragraph: In law school at Peking University in the late 1970s, Li Keqiang, now China’s premier, was an avid student of English and helped translate texts that gave his generation its first, exhilarating exposure to Western legal ideals after the death of Mao.

headline: Daily Report: How Apple Surpassed Microsoft
abstract: With the latest earnings reports from Microsoft and Apple, the once-unthinkable became reality: Apple’s market capitalization hit $683 billion, more than double Microsoft’s $338 billion.
lead_paragraph: When Microsoft stock was at a record high in 1999, and its market capitalization was nearly $620 billion, the notion that Apple Computer would ever be bigger — let alone twice as big — was laughable. Apple was teetering on bankruptcy. And Microsoft’s operating system was so dominant in personal computers, then the center of the technology universe, that the government deemed the company an unlawful monopoly, James B. Stewart writes in his Common Sense column.

headline: Q. and A.: Roderick MacFarquhar on Xi Jinping’s High-Risk Campaign to Save the Communist Party
abstract: The Chinese leader is determined to shield the country from the fate of the Soviet Union, but his approach is fraught with danger, according to the Harvard scholar.
lead_paragraph: Two years into Xi Jinping’s tenure as China’s president, many analysts consider him to be the most powerful leader since Deng Xiaoping, the man who oversaw China’s opening to the world and its market-oriented policies after the chaos of the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution. Roderick MacFarquhar, a scholar of elite Communist Party politics at Harvard University, goes one step further. Mr. Xi, he says, is the most powerful Chinese leader since Chairman Mao Zedong, the “Great Helmsman” who declared the founding of the People’s Republic in 1949 and was worshiped almost as a god by millions of fanatical Red Guards.

headline: Jay Z Bids for a Swedish Streaming Company to Expand His Empire
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Music', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The rapper and entrepreneur made a $56 million offer for Aspiro, which offers high-fidelity audio streaming through WiMP in Europe and Tidal in the United States
lead_paragraph: Jay Z, the rap star and entrepreneur, has made a $56 million offer for the Swedish company Aspiro, the owner of two digital music services, in a deal that would give him a foothold in the rapidly expanding world of streaming music and put him in competition with major players like Apple and Spotify.

headline: Morning Agenda: Crackdown on Car Title Loans
abstract: Car title loans are drawing scrutiny from regulators. | Law firm founds a project to fight “revenge porn.” | Shake Shack is going public with big dreams. | How Apple beat Microsoft.
lead_paragraph: CRACKDOWN ON LOANS LINKED TO CARS | Car title loans, which allow owners to borrow money against their cars, are under fire, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery report in DealBook. On Friday, the Federal Trade Commission is expected to announce that it has reached a settlement with two car title lenders, First American Title Lending and Finance Select, over suspicions that they misled borrowers by failing to accurately disclose the terms and costs of the loans, according to people briefed on the action. The agreement will require the companies, both based in Georgia, to overhaul how they advertise and promote their loans, the people said.

headline: Neither Rain Nor Snow Nor Lack of Transit …

lead_paragraph: Kyle Massey is an assistant news editor. He has worked at The Times since 1999.

headline: Fallen Hip-Hop Mogul Is Charged With Killing a Man He Struck With His Vehicle
abstract: Marion Knight, who helped found Death Row Records and is better known as Suge, was arrested and charged with murder after the police said he struck two men with his truck.
lead_paragraph: Marion Knight, the former chief executive of Death Row Records, who is better known as Suge, was arrested in West Hollywood on Friday on suspicion of murder after the authorities said the vehicle he was driving struck two men in the parking lot of a fast-food restaurant.

headline: Popcast: Björk Gets Personal
abstract: Jon Pareles discusses club-hopping with Björk in Iceland and her new album, “Vulnerica,” which explores the singer’s breakup with Matthew Barney.
lead_paragraph: Björk’s new album “Vulnicura,” released two months ahead of schedule last week as an emergency response to a leak, is a record about heartbreak and estrangement, and based in real events. But the string arrangements are astringent and intense, the beats spacious or chopped-up, and her lyrics refuse to default in revenge or self-pity. She’s looking for safety, clarity, and the right way to mourn the end of one family construct and to build another. “Don’t remove my pain,” she sings in “Notget.” “It is my chance to heal.”

headline: Perfectly Reasonable Question: Why the Signed Editorials?

headline: Gunman Who Killed 3 Americans Was Said to Wear Afghan Military Uniform
abstract: The attacker who killed three military contractors at the airport in Kabul is believed to have been a member of the security forces, official said.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The gunman who killed three American military contractors at Kabul’s international airport on Thursday was wearing an Afghan military uniform, the authorities said on Friday. The Taliban hailed the attack, but it was not clear whether they were claiming direct responsibility for it.

headline: Sometimes Heartbreak Takes a Hostage
abstract: Björk prepares for the release of her new album, “Vulnicura,” and a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: REYKJAVIK, ICELAND — It wasn’t exactly a beach day. It was a chilly, damp November morning with a drizzle that turned intermittently to rain. Björk called it “sniffle weather”; she and a video crew were at Grotta, a lighthouse on a spit of land on the coast here that she has often rented for stretches of isolated songwriting.

headline: Litchi Toxin May Have Caused Mysterious Epidemic in India, Inquiry Finds
abstract: An investigation of an illness that caused thousands of children to suffer convulsions, lapse into comas and die has found that a toxin found in litchi fruit may be the cause.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — An intensive investigation of a mysterious annual epidemic in northern India in which thousands of young children suffer convulsions, lapse into comas and die has concluded that a toxin found in litchi fruit may be the cause.

lead_paragraph: African leaders are stepping up their response to Boko Haram, with Chadian soldiers chasing the militants from a northern Nigerian town and the African Union calling for a 7,500-member regional force to tackle what it called “a serious threat” to the continent.

headline: On Slavery’s Doorstep in Ghana
abstract: Descendants of Venture Smith, a famous slave who won freedom and success in America, return to the roots of his captivity.
lead_paragraph: Mandred Henry was a health care sales rep from Hartford whom people often stopped on the street, saying he was a dead ringer for Morgan Freeman. Throughout his life he identified strongly with his African-American background. He was president of the local N.A.A.C.P. chapter. He remembered his mother keeping her grandmother’s slavery manumission papers in her top drawer.

headline: Growth Rate Put at 2.6% as Economy Pulls Ahead

lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — An explosion ripped through a Shiite mosque in southern Pakistan during Friday Prayer, killing at least 55 people and wounding at least 59 in an apparent suicide bombing, the police said.

headline: Most Republicans Say They Back Climate Action, Poll Finds
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: A poll found that about half of Republicans would favor a presidential candidate who supports fighting climate change.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An overwhelming majority of the American public, including half of Republicans, support government action to curb global warming, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times, Stanford University and the nonpartisan environmental research group Resources for the Future.

headline: The Los Feliz Neighborhood of Los Angeles Gets its First Boutique Hotel
abstract: In a creative-class enclave not known for its lodging options, Hotel Covell is opening above the beloved hangout Bar Covell.
lead_paragraph: The east side of Los Angeles has long been established as the stomping ground of the city’s creative class, but a lack of appealing hotels has posed a bit of a challenge for out-of-towners looking to bed down there. That is changing, however, with the arrival of Hotel Covell, a boutique establishment from the hospitality entrepreneur Dustin Lancaster and the interior designer Sally Breer, which opens this weekend above Lancaster’s beloved Los Feliz hangout Bar Covell.

headline: 1940: Finns Engage Russian Army
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1940: Finns engage the Red Army in the Winter War.
lead_paragraph: On the north central front — One of the great battles of the war is being fought in the Kushmov sector. The battle began before dawn yesterday [Jan. 29] in an area where there had been relative peace since December 30. The Finns engaged the 54th Red Army Division, which is the only Russian force on the entire northern front still on Finnish territory.

headline: Look at This World (Not All of It’s Nice)
abstract: A look at one image from “Jupiter Ascending,” with commentary from the film’s directors, the Wachowskis.
lead_paragraph: With “The Matrix” (1999), the Wachowskis made their mark in Hollywood by building a complex and intricate science-fiction universe that operated on its own terms. Their latest film, “Jupiter Ascending,” due Feb. 6, is a return to that kind of world-building, an adventure film with political undertones and a distinct visual style.

headline: Life in Memory and Real Time
abstract: Richard Linklater revisited a cast over 12 years to make his Oscar-nominated “Boyhood”; Guy Maddin used montage for his hometown valentine “My Winnipeg.”
lead_paragraph: Richard Linklater’s “Boyhood” — now available in a dual Blu-ray DVD edition from Paramount — may or may not win the Academy Award for best picture in February, but it’s a safe bet that no movie released in 2014 received more passionate approval.

headline: 1890: Dupré’s Paintings Are Sold
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Paintings by Jules Dupré are auctioned in 1890.
lead_paragraph: One of the most important picture sales  of the season thus far took place yesterday [Jan. 30] afternoon at the Petit Gallery. It was the art collection of the late  Jules Dupré, the father of the French  landscape painting, and the predecessor  of Corot and Rousseau in the natural or  realistic school of modern art. The handsome galleries were crowded with  artists and prominent Parisian amateurs, among whom were noticed and  admired a goodly number of the fair sex.

headline: In Alzheimer’s Cases, Financial Ruin and Abuse Are Always Lurking
keywords: ["Alzheimer's Disease", 'Personal Finances', 'Movies', 'Families and Family Life', 'Elder Care']

lead_paragraph: MIDWAY through the film “Still Alice,” which tracks the growing grip of Alzheimer’s on a 50-something Columbia University professor, that professor, played by Julianne Moore, stands at a lectern to address an Alzheimer’s conference. She is holding a yellow highlighter and a copy of her speech.

headline: ‘Black Mirror’ and the Horrors and Delights of Technology
abstract: A brilliant British TV show reflects a modern-day dystopia, made in America.
lead_paragraph: One of the most disturbing moments in the British TV series “Black Mirror” is what appears to be a passionate love scene. The episode takes place in a version of the future where most people have had small devices, called “grains,” surgically implanted in their heads that can record and replay their memories on demand. As the encounter progresses, it is revealed that the couple are actually having dull and mechanical sex, their eyes grayed out as they both tune into their grains to watch memories of their previous trysts, from an earlier, steamier time in their relationship.

headline: His Qualifications — and Mine
abstract: Reference points; pledge allegiances.
lead_paragraph: While volunteering at a local charity, I became friends with a fellow worker. I considered recommending him for membership to a local service club. The club requires vetting, so I checked him out and discovered that he had been convicted of tax fraud, disbarred from practicing law and sentenced to three years in prison. That ended the possibility of club sponsorship. But our friendship continued. He has now asked me for letters of reference. Would it be unethical for me to write these letters, even with careful wording that my recommendation applies only to the time I have known him? NAME WITHHELD, VANCOUVER, BRITISH COLUMBIA

headline: David Duchovny: ‘I Like Fooling Around With Words’
abstract: The actor on his first novel and fan fiction.
lead_paragraph: The actor talks to Taffy Brodesser-Akner about steamy “X-Files” fan fiction and his new novel, not suitable for Disney.

headline: Dive Nights
abstract: What was treasure and what was trash.
lead_paragraph: One evening in the fall of 1993, when I was 9, my father climbed into a Dumpster. This was in a Connecticut college town — a place totally unlike Chongqing, the sooty, cacophonous Chinese city where I grew up — that was almost as strange to me as my father was. I had known him for only half a year, which was how long my mother and I had been in the United States; he moved here shortly after I was born.

headline: Shake Shack More Than Doubles Its I.P.O. Price in Market Debut
abstract: Shares of Shake Shack began trading at $47 on Friday after being priced at $21, valuing the company at more than $1.6 billion.
lead_paragraph: Customers have been known to line up for close to an hour to order a burger and some crinkle-cut fries at Shake Shack. On Friday, investors showed an equal amount of enthusiasm for the company’s stock.

headline: The Economic Benefits of Paid Parental Leave
abstract: Three states are providing real-life experiments on the impact of paid leave on new parents and employers.
lead_paragraph: When Larisa Casillas gave birth to a boy two years ago, the Bay Area nonprofit organization where she worked gave her only four weeks of paid leave. But she took more than that, including 12 weeks paid by California’s state family leave program, one of the few of its kind in the nation.

headline: Israel Takes New Step to Expand West Bank Housing
abstract: The government published bids for the construction of 450 units, a move that angered the Palestinians and came amid growing tensions with the Obama administration.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel on Friday published bids for the building of 450 new housing units in West Bank settlements, deepening Palestinian anger and eliciting blunt criticism from the United States, which called the move illegitimate, counterproductive and likely to worsen Israel's isolation.

headline: Scene from “Girlhood”
abstract: The French director Céline Sciamma’s coming-of-age story features Marieme, a 16-year-old girl who joins a gang in the Paris suburbs.

headline: Support Waning, Romney Decides Against 2016 Bid
abstract: By not pursuing a third presidential bid, Mitt Romney frees up scores of donors and operatives who had been awaiting his decision.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a ski lift high above the powdery slopes of Deer Valley, Utah, Mitt Romney made it clear: His quest for the White House, which had dominated nearly a decade of his life, was coming to a close.

headline: The Tricky Calculus of Picking Jameis Winston
abstract: The downtrodden Tampa Bay Buccaneers need a quarterback, and they will draft first, but Winston’s checkered past has presented the team with a quandary.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — At a downtown park here on April 26, the Sexual Violence Task Force of Tampa Bay will host a “Take Back the Night” rally, a candlelight vigil and silent march to raise sexual assault awareness.

headline: A Clip from the Anticipated New French Film ‘Girlhood’
abstract: Céline Sciamma discusses her portrait of a young inhabitant of Paris’s tough banlieues — and shares a scene with T.
lead_paragraph: In an Oscar season in which the Best Picture frontrunner is named “Boyhood,” it might seem too easy to give the English-language title of “Girlhood” to “Bande de Filles” (“Gang of Girls”), the third feature, premiering in New York on Friday, from the ascendant French director Céline Sciamma. But in fairness, Sciamma’s luminously twisty coming-of-age story — that of Marieme, a 16-year-old girl with limited options growing up in the drab towers of one of the tough banlieues that ring Paris — shares with Linklater’s film both a fierce specificity to its time and place and the universal heft of a classic bildungsroman.

headline: Tweet of the Week
abstract: Neil Patrick Harris suggests changing the ceremony slightly.
lead_paragraph: Every year, the Oscar races are likened to political campaigns. Neil Patrick Harris, host of the Feb. 22 Academy Awards ceremony, takes that comparison to its logical conclusion:

headline: Lining Up to Receive Aid in Ukraine, Crowd Is Devastated by a Mortar Attack
abstract: Some of the victims were killed as they waited in line for humanitarian aid intended for children and the elderly.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Seven people were killed and at least three wounded in a pair of mortar attacks on the city’s west side Friday, including one that hit a crowd of people waiting in line to receive humanitarian aid as fighting raged outside of town.

headline: An Internationally Renowned Sculptor Returns to His Down Home Roots
abstract: Patrick Dougherty created his newest piece on the grounds of the botanical garden in Chapel Hill, just down the way from his home — a log cabin he also built with his own two hands.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Dougherty created his newest piece on the grounds of the botanical garden in Chapel Hill, just down the way from his home — a log cabin he also built with his own two hands.

headline: Reversing Course, Russia Cuts Interest Rate
abstract: The central bank’s move, prompted by the country’s economic weakness, weighed on the ruble.
lead_paragraph: Facing the economic stings of falling oil prices and Western sanctions, the Central Bank of Russia unexpectedly reversed course on Friday, lowering its crucial interest rate after a year of increases.

headline: Daughter to Disney: I’ll Take the Tiara, You Keep the Prince
abstract: Answering questions from the Fairy-Godmothers-in-Training at the Bibbidi Bobbidi Boutique, a tiny princess reveals that a tiara and hair extensions didn’t change the kid underneath.
lead_paragraph: Our hotel room seemed to radiate with pink glitter. The Disney World staff knew it was my daughter’s fifth birthday and that she loves everything princess, so they filled our room with princess galore. There was a Rapunzel balloon and a Little Mermaid coloring book and a Cinderella Barbie doll — as if Cinderella could get any skinnier. On the bed was a piece of paper announcing that the next day, my daughter Willa had an appointment at something called The Bibbidi Bobbidi Boutique. Beyond that was a giant pile of sugary confections, like a hyped-up mountain surveying the scene. I reached over and bit off the head of a chocolate Mickey.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Black or White,’ ‘Girlhood’ and ‘Hard to Be a God’
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Black or White,” “Girlhood” and “Hard to Be a God.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Black or White,” “Girlhood” and “Hard to Be a God.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Don't Trade Away Our Health
keywords: ['Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'Generic Brands and Products', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The efforts to raise drug prices in the so-called Trans-Pacific Partnership take us in the wrong direction.
lead_paragraph: A secretive group met behind closed doors in New York this week. What they decided may lead to higher drug prices for you and hundreds of millions around the world.

headline: Bleak Report For Quarter From Mattel
abstract: The toymaker, whose chief executive resigned last weekend, said net income fell nearly 60 percent in the fourth quarter.
lead_paragraph: The toymaker Mattel on Friday promised to take swift action to reverse years of sales declines as it released grim earnings, just days after the abrupt resignation of its chief executive.

headline: Does Political Correctness Work?
keywords: ['ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: On Jonathan Chait, his critics, and the effectiveness of ideological taboos.
lead_paragraph: I’ve spent a few days traveling, so I’ve had time to mull over what kind of intervention might be useful in the debate kicked off by Jonathan Chait’s big New York Magazine essay on the alleged return of a speech-policing, debate-squelching, illiberal P.C. left. The critical response has ranged from the spluttering to the dismissive, with the latter being seemingly the sophisticated left-wing take: There is no such thing as political correctness, the term is just a tool used by privileged white men to marginalize the legitimate arguments of the less-privileged, Chait’s lament is the latest iteration in a long tradition of internet-era complaints from prominent columnists confronted with tough criticism from outside their comfort zone, except now the criticism making him uncomfortable is coming from Twitterers instead of netroots types, etc.

headline: Verizon Wireless to Allow Complete Opt Out of Mobile ‘Supercookies’
abstract: The wireless carrier is under pressure from privacy groups after it introduced tracking code that can’t be deleted by consumers.
lead_paragraph: Verizon Wireless, which has been under fire by privacy advocates since late last year, has decided to make a major revision to its mobile ad-targeting program. Users who do not want to be tracked with an identifier that Verizon uses for ad-targeting purposes will soon be able to completely opt out, the company said on Friday.

headline: Aftermath of Pakistan Mosque Explosion
abstract: More than 40 people were killed and scores wounded after a suicide attack at a Shiite mosque in Shikarpur, Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: More than 40 people were killed and scores wounded after a suicide attack at a Shiite mosque in Shikarpur, Pakistan.

headline: Biden Says G.O.P. Will Try to ‘Steal’ Credit for Better Economy
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden warned Democrats on Friday that if they did not speak up and take credit for the economic recovery, Republicans would try to “steal” the credit for themselves.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Friday warned Democrats that if they did not speak up and take credit for the economic recovery, Republicans would try to “steal” the credit for themselves.

headline: Islamic Militants Surprise Kurds in Iraq, Killing a Commander in a Day of Attacks
abstract: The assault was repelled but it underscored the ability of the Islamic State to strike at Iraq’s cities, despite the American-backed campaign to dislodge the group.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Exploiting a foggy night as cover, Islamic State militants launched a surprise attack on Iraqi Kurdish positions on the outskirts of Kirkuk early Friday, killing a senior Kurdish commander and at least five of his men, security officials in the city said.

headline: Reader Mailbag: Why Does Josh Barro Hate the Merely Affluent?
abstract: Readers weigh in on the heated question of who can be considered rich.
lead_paragraph: In my article Thursday on President Obama’s failed plan to curtail tax preferences for college savings accounts, which benefit mostly people with higher incomes, I called out the “merely affluent” — people with family incomes of, say, $175,000 — for pleading poverty and putting themselves off limits for tax increases.

headline: Mortgage Shopping and Credit Scores
abstract: The notion that a flurry of credit inquiries from mortgage lenders will lower a borrower’s score is a common misconception.
lead_paragraph: Borrowers need not avoid shopping around for the best mortgage deal out of fear that allowing multiple lenders to “pull,” or check, their credit will chip away at their score.

headline: Historians Sift the Ruins for Ferguson’s Legacy
abstract: Business owners are determined to move forward after protests destroyed storefronts, and the Missouri History Museum wants to keep reminders of what happened.
lead_paragraph: DELLWOOD, Mo. — Amid the ashes and the shards of glass, Juanita Morris found remnants of her life before Nov. 24. There was the foam mannequin head that once showcased hats, now charred from the fire. A leopard-print blouse still clung to a melted hanger. And the sewing machine she used for alterations lay buried and crumpled in the wreckage of her store, Fashions R Boutique.

headline: Letter From the Editor: Who’s Really Middle Class?
abstract: Obama’s retreat on college tax breaks starts a debate on who’s affluent and who’s not.
lead_paragraph: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Oscar Shorts in Theaters
abstract: This year’s Oscar nominated shorts come to theaters in three distinct programs.
lead_paragraph: It’s that time in the season when you can get ahead of your Oscar ballot competitors by seeing all the nominated shorts. Those shorts open in theaters nationwide  Friday in three feature-length compilations: animated, live-action and documentary.

headline: Churchill’s Funeral, and the Perils of Staying Home
abstract: Lyndon Johnson’s decision to skip the ceremony, and also to not send his vice president, raised questions on both sides of the Atlantic.
lead_paragraph: Sir Winston Churchill — who, as Franklin Roosevelt’s partner during World War II, was the most consequential British ally in American history – was honored and buried in England 50 years ago today, but neither the American president nor vice president was present.

headline: Chevron to Abandon Shale Natural Gas Venture in Poland
abstract: The decision was perhaps the biggest setback yet to fledgling efforts to start a European shale oil and gas industry.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Chevron said on Friday that it would abandon efforts to find and produce natural gas from shale rock in Poland, in perhaps the biggest setback yet to fledgling efforts to start a European shale oil and gas industry that might help replace the region’s dwindling fuel resources.
