headline: Many G.M.O.-Free Labels, Little Clarity Over Rules
keywords: ['Labeling and Labels', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Food', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: Products described as not containing genetically modified organisms, whether that statement has been verified or not, are increasingly appearing in stores.
lead_paragraph: Few industry debates are as heated these days as the one about labeling foods that contain genetically modified ingredients.

headline: $33 Million Penthouse on Central Park West
abstract: A fully renovated, nine-room home near the top of the Trump International Hotel and Tower on Central Park West was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A fully renovated penthouse near the top of the Trump International Hotel and Tower, with picture-book park, river or cityscape views from each of its oversize windows, sold for $33,000,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Alexandra Fuller’s third memoir, “Leaving Before the Rains Come,” is also her third best seller.
lead_paragraph: Children of Divorce: Alexandra Fuller’s third memoir, “Leaving Before the Rains Come” — No. 10 on the hardcover nonfiction list — is also her third best seller, following “Don’t Let’s Go to the Dogs Tonight” (about her childhood in war-torn Rhodesia) and “Cocktail Hour Under the Tree of Forgetfulness” (about her indomitable mother). Fuller’s new book describes the collapse of her marriage, and in a recent interview with the Times reporter Penelope Green she bristled at the idea that she would have shown a draft to her ex-husband. “There’s almost this expectation you need to get approval,” she said. “I doubt Ernest Hemingway was asked what his ex-wives thought of his writing. I think women have to stop asking for permission.” She didn’t say, though, whether she had shared the memoir with her children, who are 21, 17 and 9. So I asked. “There’s a very fine line,” she said by phone from Washington, D.C., where she was on book tour, “between protecting your children, as you should, and smothering them to the point that they don’t know what’s going down in the world.” She had offered to show relevant passages to her older two, and Sarah, the 21-year-old, took her up on it. “She’s a fantastic writer in her own way,” Fuller said. “At the same time I was working on this book, she wrote an essay about the divorce for her student magazine. It was so poignant. My ex-husband read it and said, That’s not what happened. But of course it was totally from her perspective. It’s another prism. We’re reading each other’s stuff now not just as people who were personally involved, but as writers able to appreciate each other’s talent.” And her 17-year-old son? Fuller laughed. “He has better boundaries than anyone I know. He said, Mum, I lived it. I don’t need to read it.”

headline: German and British Regulators Examining Deutsche Bank’s Controls and Reporting
keywords: ['Fines (Penalties)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: A year after the New York Fed raised questions, the inquiries are the latest to examine reporting procedures at one of Europe’s largest lenders.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – German and British regulators are examining Deutsche Bank’s systems and controls as questions have again arisen about the German lender’s reporting procedures.

headline: A Daughter’s Promise, a Mother’s Story
abstract: “Mia, a Dancer’s Journey,” having its New York premiere at the Walter Reade Theater, is part of the Dance on Camera festival.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before Mia Slavenska died in 2002, Maria Ramas, her daughter, made a promise: to tell her story. “She had spent many years feeling, as many artists do who outlive their fame and their time of creativity, that the dance world wouldn’t remember her and her contribution,” Ms. Ramas said in an interview. “It was really difficult for her to make peace with that.”

headline: As Measles Cases Spread in U.S., So Does Anxiety
abstract: New cases have emerged in California, Nebraska and Minnesota, while Arizona officials warned that at least 1,000 people may have been exposed.
lead_paragraph: The measles outbreak tied to Disneyland continued to spread anxiety Friday as two new cases emerged overnight in Marin County in California — along with at least one in Nebraska — while Arizona officials warned that at least 1,000 people may have been exposed to the virus through seven others in that state.

headline: Anne Enright Is Ireland’s First Fiction Laureate
abstract: The novelist Anne Enright is the first person chosen as fiction laureate for Ireland.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Irish Arts Council has announced that the Man Booker prize-winning novelist Anne Enright will serve as Ireland’s first laureate for fiction.

headline: Former London Trader Sentenced to Seven Years in Investment Scheme
abstract: Alex Hope was convicted of a single count of fraud in London this month in a $7.55 million investment scam after pleading guilty in April 2014 to operating a collective investment scheme without authorization
lead_paragraph: LONDON – A trader who reportedly once spent more than $300,000 on drinks on a single night out was sentenced to seven years in prison after he was convicted of fraud in an investment scheme that authorities say took in 5 million pounds, or about $7.55 million, from investors.

headline: In Berlin, a New Shop That Offers Much More Than Shopping
abstract: The Store, a retail space at Soho House opening this weekend, includes dining, co-working spaces, a library, photography studios and screening rooms.
lead_paragraph: Spanning the lower levels of the private club Soho House Berlin in the city’s Mitte district, a new space officially opening this weekend — called, simply, the Store — offers just about everything a creative professional might want under one roof: a place to work, to play and to indulge in a bit of spending.

headline: Law Creates Special Savings Accounts for Disabled People
abstract: A new law enables the creation of special accounts, modeled after the popular Section 529 education plans that many families use to save for college.
lead_paragraph: People with disabilities, and their families, will soon have a tax-favored way to save money for a range of expenses.

headline: ‘Hall of Small Mammals,’ by Thomas Pierce
abstract: The characters of Thomas Pierce’s stories inhabit a strange world where reality meets irreality.
lead_paragraph: There was that moment starting in the late 1980s when the culture was seized with so-called recovered memories. Some were clearly real, but a surprising number couldn’t have been; they were too fantastic — elephants butchered in church basements, ordinary suburban parents gathered on the outskirts of town, in forests, to perform satanic rituals (though really, who wouldn’t thrill at the idea of one’s mother doing that while one slept?). A lot of the stories came from children, so one hesitated to call them “lies.” They were fictions. They were the great outrageous stories made up to express the more regular feelings of loss or disenchantment or anger.

headline: Jenny Uglow’s ‘In These Times’
abstract: Jenny Uglow’s multifaceted history of the British home front during the Napoleonic wars.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans probably have an indistinct idea of the warfare between Britain and France at the turn of the 19th century. So far as Britain is concerned, we are likely to recall that Admiral Nelson won a great victory in 1805 at Trafalgar, off the coast of Spain, and was mortally wounded during the battle. In words that became famous, he had signaled to his fleet, “England expects that every man will do his duty.” We are likelier to remember the Duke of Wellington’s triumph at Waterloo 10 years later, which ended Napoleon’s sensational career. A comment Wellington supposedly made afterward is also frequently quoted, that the engagement had been “a damned close-run thing.” And as a sidelight to the international conflict there was our own American War of 1812, during which Francis Scott Key was inspired to write his verses about the rockets’ red glare and bombs bursting in air.

headline: ‘A Theory of the Drone,’ by Grégoire Chamayou
abstract: A French philosopher asks what drones mean for the moral basis of war.
lead_paragraph: For thousands of years, the outstanding characteristic of war was the violent interaction known as fighting. It was the fighters’ willingness and ability to cope with and overcome danger that distinguished them from assassins and often made them into heroes — alive or dead — deserving of the highest rewards society could bestow.

headline: Trespassers, Beware!
abstract: Every last one of the gaudy characters in Tom Cooper’s first novel, “The Marauders,” has a story to tell about life on the Gulf Coast.
lead_paragraph: It’s always the voice, the singular sound of a place like none other, that draws you into a regional mystery. In Tom Cooper’s first novel, THE MARAUDERS (Crown, $26), that beguiling music comes out of the Louisiana bayous, where a raucous chorus of shrimp fishermen, marijuana growers, treasure hunters, professional crooks and common thieves fight to be heard.

headline: ‘Only One Thing Can Save Us,’ by Thomas Geoghegan
abstract: How the labor movement could survive and thrive.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Geoghegan, a veteran labor lawyer, wants his book read by upscale liberals who worry about income inequality and the vanishing middle class but who turn up their noses at all those stolid unions still clinging to life in urban America. Properly reconstituted, Geoghegan insists, the labor movement can save us, and by “us” he means the country as a vibrant democracy, and a Democratic Party that has lost millions of working-class voters either to apathy or to the Republicans.

headline: Letters: ‘Among the Disrupted’
abstract: Readers respond to a recent essay by Leon Wieseltier.
lead_paragraph: ‘Among the Disrupted’

headline: ‘The Girl on the Train,’ by Paula Hawkins
abstract: A psychological thriller of intersecting lives and betrayals.
lead_paragraph: Alfred Hitchcock may have said all there is to say about the fallibility of making assumptions about what you see through a window, but, like most important lessons, this one can bear some repeating. To the limited scope of a window frame, the former London journalist Paula Hawkins, in her debut thriller, “The Girl on the Train,” offers a few additional obfuscations. First, her novel’s protagonist, Rachel, looks out through the window of a moving train on her daily commute. Second, Rachel is your basic hot mess: depressed, unemployed, still in mourning for the death of her marriage and prone to alcoholic blackouts that coincide with critical moments in the tale of a missing woman later found dead. Rachel might as well be wearing a sign that reads “Unreliable Narrator.”

headline: ‘They Eat ­Horses, Don’t They?’ by Piu Marie Eatwell
abstract: Debunking the myths and stereotypes about France.
lead_paragraph: French women do get fat. Their children do throw food. And they don’t look the other way when their husbands cheat.

headline: ‘The Girl From Human Street,’ by Roger Cohen
abstract: From Lithuania to South Africa, England, America and Israel, a journalist chronicles his family’s story of repeated upheaval.
lead_paragraph: In the years around the turn of the 20th century, Roger Cohen’s family joined the mass exodus of Jews out of their long, mostly dismal residency in the Pale of Settlement. Like thousands of their Lithuanian landsmen, Cohen’s relatives headed for the sunny, still-undeveloped, resource-­rich country of South Africa. In this new world they began with nothing, worked hard and achieved much. As is often true of successful immigrant families, their grandchildren could live as though the old world had never been. Cohen’s father became a doctor, his mother was college educated. Both were raised with the comforts that only numerous servants can provide: “They never had to boil an egg,” Cohen writes. Being a Jew in South Africa was not unlike being a Jew in the American South: Anti-Semitism was not absent, but it was greatly mitigated by a segregated black underclass all but legally enslaved.

headline: ‘The Sacrifice,’ by Joyce Carol Oates
abstract: In Joyce Carol Oates’s novel, a teenage girl is the alleged victim of a brutal rape.
lead_paragraph: Writing difference is a challenge, particularly in fiction. How do men write women and vice versa? How do writers of one race or ethnicity write about people of another race or ethnicity? More important, how do writers tackle difference without reducing their characters to caricatures or stereotypes? Some handle the challenge with aplomb. Bill Cheng’s “Southern Cross the Dog” and Louise Erdrich’s “The Round House” come to mind. Others fail: At one point in Kathryn Stockett’s “The Help,” a black woman compares her skin color with that of a cockroach. To write difference well demands empathy, an ability to respect the humanity of those you mean to represent.

headline: Scott Blackwood’s ‘See How Small’
abstract: Inspired by real events, Scott Blackwood’s novel imagines the aftermath of the murder of three teenage girls.
lead_paragraph: On the busy corner of Rockwood and West Anderson Lanes in north Austin, Tex., stands a beige-bricked strip mall. At first glance, nothing about it is remarkable. The usual suspects — Jimmy John’s, a pet grooming shop — line the row of one-story facades. Near one end, Classy Nails Spa is wedged between a hair salon and a furniture showroom. In a bed of white granite rocks shaded by an oak, a bronze plaque commemorates the lives of four young women — Amy Ayers, Eliza Thomas, and Sarah and Jennifer Harbison.

headline: David Adam’s ‘The Man Who Couldn’t Stop’
abstract: A guide to the science of obsessive-compulsive disorder, offered by a sufferer.
lead_paragraph: One cold Northern England evening in November 1990, when David Adam was a first-year college student in Leeds, he enjoyed an encouraging first date with a young woman that culminated in a bit of physical intimacy ending somewhere short of intercourse. The next day when a friend asked Adam if he had sex with the woman, he lied in the traditional manner of boastful, insecure young men everywhere and said that he had, without a condom. “You could have AIDS,” the friend said. That wasn’t true — or was, at most, exceedingly unlikely. Nevertheless, the idea lodged in Adam’s mind, where it set about establishing permanent residency. By the following summer, the fear that he might already have AIDS, or would someday contract it, had hijacked his brain. The “snowflake” of a single intrusive thought, as he puts it, had become a “blizzard” that “blew the snow into every corner of my mind, and laid down a blanket that muffled every surface.” For the next 20 years, Adam was consumed by the fear that he had contracted, or would contract, H.I.V.: He called the National AIDS Helpline so many times daily that the half-dozen staffers there came to recognize his voice; he got blood tests; he compulsively examined and re-examined every red stain he ever came across to determine whether it might be AIDS-tainted blood, and whether it might somehow have contaminated him. He knew this to be irrational — he was a science writer! — yet he couldn’t resist his compulsions. He had developed obsessive-compulsive disorder, or O.C.D.

headline: Reading in Transit
abstract: The photographer Reinier Gerritsen captures the reading habits of New York’s subway riders.
lead_paragraph: Peeking at what your fellow passengers are reading is a time-honored sport on the New York subway. The Amsterdam-based photographer Reinier Gerritsen captures his peeks for posterity in “The Last Book,” a collection of candid photos of subterranean readers. Gerritsen comes to New York for two weeks three times a year and spent 13 weeks shooting straphangers for the project. No e-readers were allowed. “I read only printed books,” Gerritsen said via email, though he owned up to having an iPad.

headline: ‘Ideas of Order,’ by Neil L. Rudenstine
abstract: A guide to Shakespeare’s 154 sonnets, and an argument that they contain an underlying narrative.
lead_paragraph: Time has formed its judgment on the 154 poems that make up what we call “Shakespeare’s sonnets.” Most are known to some and some are known to all. Eight or 10 are probably here for as long as we are, two or three perhaps longer, lighting out for deep space in binary code, beyond praise or burial. Any critical word a living poet might say about them now would necessitate the wearing of a jester’s motley — with first-person “I” as one’s little stick to shake — so excuse me while I don this costume, leaf haplessly hither and thither through all 154 and cry that I would take the least of the plays over the whole blooming thing.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: GHETTOSIDE: A True Story of Murder in America, by Jill Leovy. (Spiegel & Grau, $28.) Focusing on South Los Angeles, Leovy examines the circumstances of the country’s disturbingly high rate of murders of African-American men.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: PRISCILLA: The Hidden Life of an Englishwoman in Wartime France,  by Nicholas Shakespeare. (Harper Perennial, $15.99.) Shakespeare knew that Priscilla Thompson, his glamorous but enigmatic aunt, had lived in Vichy France, and family lore even had her jailed by the Gestapo for her work in the Resistance. But long after her death in 1982, the author has pieced together a far more intriguing story: that of a femme fatale who made painful compromises to survive the Nazi occupation.

headline: Yannick Nézet-Séguin Extends Philadelphia Orchestra Contract
abstract: Mr. Nézet-Séguin, 39, began his tenure with the orchestra in 2012 and has won critical praise since then for his exuberant style.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Orchestra extended the contract of its dynamic music director, Yannick Nézet-Séguin, through the 2021-22 season, the orchestra announced Friday.

headline: Short Stories
abstract: New books by Katherine Heiny, Megan Mayhew Bergman, Mark Kurlansky and Shelly Oria.
lead_paragraph: SINGLE, CAREFREE, MELLOW  Stories  By Katherine Heiny  Knopf, $23.95.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom house in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and a three-bedroom condo in Weehawken, N.J.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom house in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and a three-bedroom condo in Weehawken, N.J.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This weeks properties include co-ops in Carnegie Hill, on the Upper East Side and in Brooklyn Heights.
lead_paragraph: This weeks properties include co-ops in Carnegie Hill, on the Upper East Side and in Brooklyn Heights.

headline: Every Year Is the Year of the Dumpling
abstract: For the Chinese New Year, celebrate with homemade won tons packed with shrimp and scallops, seasoned simply with ginger, scallions, hot pepper and sesame oil.
lead_paragraph: Dumplings are said to bring good fortune, and eating them is a time-honored traditional way to celebrate the Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 19 this year. So why not rally a few friends for a little homemade dumpling feast?

headline: When Consumers Give Up Their Right to Trial in Financial Disputes
keywords: ['ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Constitution (US)', 'Consumer Protection', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: If you have a credit card or cellphone, there’s a good chance you’ve agreed to settle claims through arbitration. And businesses have the advantage in arbitration, Jeff Sovern writes in the Another View column.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Sovern is a professor of law at St. John’s University School of Law and co-coordinator of the Consumer Law and Policy Blog.

headline: She’s the Johnny Appleseed of Pickling
abstract: Referring to her cross-country travels as Fermentation on Wheels, Tara Whitsitt motors around the United States in a bus, earning a living largely by holding workshops in which she teaches old-fashioned methods of food preservation.
lead_paragraph: If you find yourself wandering near Whale Creek, in an industrial stretch of Long Island City, Queens, and you come across a dilapidated 1986 International Harvester school bus emitting a faint smell of decay, no need to call the authorities.

headline: Speaker Candidate Drew Ethics Panel’s Notice
abstract: Carl E. Heastie, a lawmaker from the Bronx who has emerged as the favorite to succeed Sheldon Silver, attracted the attention of the now-defunct Moreland Commission on corruption in Albany.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Over $10,000 for car repairs. Hundreds of dollars in interest and finance charges on credit-card balances. Thousands of dollars in expenses for which no explanation was given.

headline: Let Them Bake Baguettes
abstract: A report by the Citizens Committee for Children of New York presents a bleak picture for Hunts Point in the Bronx compared with other neighborhoods in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appeared at a new employment center in the South Bronx to announce an initiative called the Hunts Point Vision Plan, aimed at expanding economic opportunity in an area that although markedly improved from the dereliction of the 1970s, was still not a place distinguished by tasting menus and other signifiers of urban prosperity.

headline: Same-Sex Interfaith Couples Face Roadblock to Marriage in Judaism
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Religion and Belief', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: While same-sex marriage is largely accepted in the religion, most rabbis refuse to marry interfaith couples, even as they publicly recognize their love.
lead_paragraph: SOMERVILLE, Mass. — When Julia Spiegelman and Erina Donnelly, two teachers who met as undergraduates at Bryn Mawr, became engaged, they were looking forward to planning a wedding that included elements from both of their religions.

headline: Mitt Romney Drops Out
abstract: He’s already gone 360. Meanwhile the Democrats are waiting around for Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: There are a couple of remarkable aspects to Mitt Romney’s announcement that he will not run for president, after all.

headline: Ratings Now Cut Both Ways, So Don’t Sass Your Uber Driver
keywords: ['Customer Relations', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Consumer Reviews']
abstract: Companies from Uber to Airbnb are rating their customers on degrees of promptness and politeness, but who owns the data that details good and bad behavior?
lead_paragraph: People routinely use the Internet to review services from plumbers to hairdressers. Now the tables are turned. Companies are rating their customers, shunning those who do not make the grade.

headline: An App, Happy, Offers Discounts for Drinkers
abstract: Happy, known on Android phones as Happy Any Hour, is a new app that allows users to drink on the cheap at participating bars in Brooklyn and downtown Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Happy, known on Android phones as Happy Any Hour, is a new app that allows users to drink on the cheap at participating bars in Brooklyn and downtown Manhattan. Download the app, and suddenly it is as if you have joined a club: A flash of your phone screen suddenly gets you $2 off the Smuttynose I.P.A. that you have been craving.

headline: Stuff We Liked: Parking the Car in Harvard Yard (With 11 Permits)
abstract: Web gems this week include articles on Boston’s parking problems and on vaccination rates across the country.
lead_paragraph: What we liked elsewhere on the web this week:

headline: Sheldon Silver and New York’s ‘Caldron of Corruption’
abstract: The arrest of the Assembly speaker doesn’t let the governor and lawmakers off the hook. Here’s how they can start the cleanup.
lead_paragraph: Now that Sheldon Silver has been pressured into agreeing to resign as speaker of New York’s Assembly after his arrest on corruption charges, the governor and the lawmakers who so poorly represent the state should not kid themselves into thinking they have made real progress on cleaning up what the federal prosecutor who indicted Mr. Silver called the “caldron of corruption” in Albany.

headline: Sundance 2015 Video: Festival in Slo-Mo
abstract: Actors, directors and others step into a slow-motion booth.
lead_paragraph: At the Sundance Film Festival this week in Park City, Utah, we asked actors, directors and others to step into our slow-motion booth and perform a 5-section action either from their movie or representative of it. Here’s what happened.

headline: Chanel vs. the Costume Institute, Amal Clooney’s Gown and Naomi Campbell on the Instagirls
abstract: Plus, Taylor Swift is trademark-happy, the truth about tightie-whities and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Etan Patz Trial Starts, 35 Years After Boy Disappeared on SoHo Street
abstract: Pedro Hernandez, who is accused of the murder, confessed that he had killed a child to a church group and others in the early 1980s, a prosecutor said during opening statements on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The murder trial against a man accused of killing Etan Patz got underway on Friday, with opening statements made in a proceeding that prosecutors hope will finally lay to rest a question that for decades has tormented the Patz family and, in a sense, all of New York City: What really happened to the 6-year-old boy?

headline: An Original Seahawk by Way of New England
abstract: Neil Graff, a financial adviser in Sioux Falls, S.D., was the starting quarterback for two Patriots games in 1975 and the first preseason game in Seahawks history, in 1976.
lead_paragraph: There is a man in South Dakota who, on occasion, will stump people with a trivia question: Can you name the original starting quarterback of the Seattle Seahawks?

headline: New Walking Tours in Japan and China
abstract: Country Walkers is offering new multi-day itineraries in China and Japan.
lead_paragraph: Country Walkers, the Vermont walking tour company, will amble east this year, with new trips in Japan and China.

headline: Butterflies, Rain, Shelter
abstract: The Times Science reporter John Schwartz answers the question, “Where do butterflies go when it rains?”
lead_paragraph: Draw on Times staff members’ expertise.

headline: Remembering the Neediest: An Inside Look
abstract: Michael McElroy, a Metro editor, tells the story of The Times’s Neediest Cases Fund and the people it helps.
lead_paragraph: For over 100 years, The Times has provided direct assistance to struggling New Yorkers through the Neediest Cases Fund. Michael McElroy, a copy editor on the Metro desk, led the effort to tell the stories of those whom it helped last year.

headline: Harry Reid Won’t Take Some Things Lying Down. Like Rest.
abstract: While recovering from an exercise accident, Senator Harry Reid is conducting policy from his well-appointed condominium.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some of the biggest decisions in Washington these days are being made not at either end of Pennsylvania Avenue, but in a well-appointed one-bedroom condominium at the Ritz-Carlton on M Street.

headline: Romney’s Withdrawal Is a Reflection of Bush’s Strength
abstract: It is now clear that Mr. Bush, despite some drawbacks as a candidate, has attracted much of the support that Mr. Romney wanted.
lead_paragraph: In renouncing a new run for president Friday, Mitt Romney becomes the first big casualty of the invisible primary — the behind-the-scenes competition for donors, endorsements and campaign operatives.

headline: Auditioning for ‘School of Rock’
abstract: An open casting call for “School of Rock,” the new Broadway musical from Andrew Lloyd Webber, was held recently at the Winter Garden Theater.
lead_paragraph: An open casting call for “School of Rock,” the new Broadway musical from Andrew Lloyd Webber, was held recently at the Winter Garden Theater.

headline: Video: Vying for a Seat in ‘School of Rock’
abstract: Scenes from an open casting call for the coming Broadway musical “School of Rock.”
lead_paragraph: Early in the morning on Jan. 24, hundreds of kids and their tired-looking parents trekked through winter slush to the Winter Garden Theater on Broadway for an open casting call for the musical “School of Rock.”

headline: Managing Health Costs With Crowdfunding
abstract: Asking friends and family, and even strangers, to help with bills is becoming more accepted on crowdfunding websites.
lead_paragraph: SOMETIMES paying for a loved one’s health care expenses literally takes a crowd.

headline: Miami Tourists to New York City: Let It Snow
abstract: After an unexpected extra day in New York City as a result of a storm, a couple takes some time to be tourists near Central Park, at the Stone Rose Lounge.
lead_paragraph: For many New Yorkers this week, as the blizzard panic lifted from the city, the pressing culinary question on Tuesday was, “Now what do I do with all this Dinty Moore?” One answer was just to walk away, perhaps to find a table someplace where the snow outside maintained its fleeting Currier & Ives majesties. Why not? With Tavern on the Green shuttered because of the weather, scenic duty fell to the slight remove of the restaurants of the Time Warner Center at Columbus Circle, where the trees of Central Park displayed dustings of white thingamajigs suspended perilously above their inevitable future as unloved street slush. Quiet descended on the city, cocktails and Pat LaFrieda beef products descended on the polished black tables of the Stone Rose Lounge, and stranded tourists consoled themselves for having to spend an extra night in the world’s greatest city. Poor babies.

headline: Jack Leggett, Who Cultivated Writers in Iowa, Dies at 97
abstract: Mr. Leggett was a longtime director of the University of Iowa Writers’ Workshop and a mentor to many well-known authors.
lead_paragraph: Jack Leggett, who nourished a generation of poets and novelists as director of the University of Iowa Writers’ Workshop, perhaps the nation’s pre-eminent graduate program in creative writing, died on Sunday in Napa, Calif. He was 97.

headline: Kerry to Meet with Ukrainian Leaders in Kiev
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry’s trip will highlight the United States’ support for Ukraine, the State Department said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry plans to travel to Ukraine next week and will meet with President Petro O. Poroshenko and other senior Ukrainian leaders, the State Department announced Friday.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
abstract: A look back at the week in politics.
lead_paragraph: A look back at the week in politics.

headline: An Internationally Renowned Sculptor Returns to His Down-Home Roots
abstract: Patrick Dougherty created his newest piece on the grounds of the botanical garden in Chapel Hill, N.C., just down the way from his home — a log cabin he also built with his own two hands.
lead_paragraph: In this series, the photographer Rinne Allen documents harvests across the South, exploring the many uses of nature’s seasonal yield.

abstract: Melissa Clark bakes fried cauliflower smothered in tomato sauce, Parmesan and fresh mozzarella.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark bakes fried cauliflower smothered in tomato sauce, Parmesan and fresh mozzarella.

abstract: A look back at the week in politics.

headline: Conductor Dies After Collapsing on Stage
abstract: The renowned Israeli conductor Israel Yinon died after collapsing during a concert in Switzerland.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The Israeli conductor Israel Yinon collapsed during a youth concert at a Swiss university on Thursday evening and died, a member of the university staff reported.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Hard to Be a God’
abstract: The Times critic Nicolas Rapold reviews “Hard to Be a God.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Nicolas Rapold reviews “Hard to Be a God.”

headline: Romney Out, Scott Walker Makes His (Anti-Washington) Case
abstract: Less than two hours after Mitt Romney announced that he was not going to make another run at the White House, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin made a case for why he could be the man for the job.
lead_paragraph: Less than two hours after Mitt Romney announced that he was not going to make another run at the White House, Gov. Scott Walker, Republican of Wisconsin, made a case for why he might be the man for the job.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Black or White’
abstract: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Black or White.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Black or White.”

headline: For Manoush Zomorodi, Time for Some Conscious Unplugging
abstract: On Sundays, Ms. Zomorodi, the host and managing editor of WNYC public radio’s New Tech City, spends time outside and with her children, hoping to inspire their minds to drift creatively.
lead_paragraph: Manoush Zomorodi, the host and managing editor of WNYC public radio’s New Tech City, a podcast that explores how technology affects the way we live, hasn’t been bored in seven years. She traces her condition to 2007, when the iPhone was introduced. Concerned that she’s not alone, and that letting the mind wander spurs creativity, Ms. Zomorodi, 41, is spearheading “Bored and Brilliant,” a seven-day challenge that asks participants to minimize device use and enjoy idle time — with the help of an app. “We’re trying to embrace the ridiculousness of it,” she said. Ms. Zomorodi lives in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, with her husband, Josh Robin, 38, a reporter for NY1, and their son, Kai, 7, and daughter, Soraya, 4.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Girlhood’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Girlhood.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Girlhood.”

abstract: Delayed by a storm, new productions of “Bluebeard’s Castle” and “Iolanta” made their debut at the Metropolitan Opera, with Valery Gergiev conducting.
lead_paragraph: A new production at the Metropolitan Opera involves weeks of concentrated work, leading to a dress rehearsal and then, usually after a couple of days off, the opening night.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
abstract: Food news from Australia to Kansas.
lead_paragraph: One year ago next week, President Obama signed the 2014 Farm Bill into law, a piece of legislation that will cut $8.7 billion in food stamp benefits over the next decade. (If that number sounds monstrously high, consider the fact that the Republicans’ plan would have cut benefits by between $20.5 billion and $39 billion.)

headline: Parmigiana Dishes to Warm Weary Souls
abstract: When carefully and lovingly cooked with excellent ingredients, parmigiana is a fantastic dish, one worth learning how to make just right. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: It’s been nearly a half-century since veal parmigiana anchored menus of the fanciest Italian restaurants in America, the kinds of places where tuxedoed waiters were as likely to burst into a Verdi aria as they were to light your cigarette.

headline: Daily Mail Buys Site Targeting Millennials
abstract: The British tabloid paid a reported $40 million to $50 million for Elite Daily, which specializes in articles and videos intended to be shared online.
lead_paragraph: The Daily Mail, a British tabloid that became an online behemoth with fast, salacious stories, announced on Friday that it had bought Elite Daily, a website aimed at millennials, as part of a plan to become a larger media conglomerate.

headline: Brooding, Nostalgia and Wacky Humor
abstract: “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike” will run at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport through March 8.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Durang saves the best speech for last in “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike,” the comedic mash-up in which the playwright mixes bits of Anton Chekhov with large doses of his own brand of wacky humor. The play is running at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport through March 8.

headline: The Surprising Power of Blue-State Republicans
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Endorsements', 'Republican National Convention', 'Campaign Finance', 'States (US)', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Elections (US)']
abstract: Why it’s very hard for a far-right conservative to win the G.O.P. nomination.
lead_paragraph: There is a basic mystery at the heart of modern Republican presidential politics. The party’s voters, despite electing conservatives to the House and Senate, have repeatedly chosen relatively moderate nominees, like Mitt Romney and John McCain, in the primaries.

headline: Insider Tips: Wine in 2015
abstract: Eric Asimov, chief wine critic, provides a list of bottles to drink in the new year.
lead_paragraph: A New Year’s gift for Times Insiders: a series of inside tips from Times editors and reporters. Eric Asimov, chief wine critic, provides a list of bottles to drink in the new year.

headline: The Theater Is His Church
abstract: Billy Porter fuses Broadway, pop and gospel in his performances at the Appel Room, part of the American Songbook series.
lead_paragraph: As Billy Porter transformed “Take the Moment,” an obscure song from the Richard Rodgers-Stephen Sondheim musical “Do I Hear a Waltz?,” into a pop-gospel plea at the Appel Room on Wednesday evening, his performance created the kind of epiphany that a great voice can conjure out of thin air. The key lay not only in Mr. Porter’s innate vocal power but also in his commitment to shoot the moon, no matter the consequences. His go-for-broke approach recalled singers like Patti LaBelle, for whom there are no halfways and who risk drowning in emotional intensity.

headline: Alison Brie on the State of the Rom-Com and the End of ‘Mad Men’
abstract: The actress stars in Leslye Headland’s romantic comedy “Sleeping with Other People,” which the director has described as a kind of “When Harry Met Sally” for jerks.
lead_paragraph: In the director Leslye Headland’s “Sleeping With Other People,” which premiered at Sundance last week, Alison Brie plays Lainey, a serial cheater whose longing for a stable relationship is constantly railroaded by an obsession with her college crush (Adam Scott). She meets her match when she strikes up a friendship with Jake (Jason Sudeikis), a good-natured womanizer who just happens to have taken her virginity 12 years earlier. At the premiere, Headland described the film as “When Harry Met Sally” for jerks (though she used a slightly stronger word), which is to say that, like the director’s previous effort, “Bachelorette,” it is more than a little naughty and twisted (and, it follows, a perfect starring vehicle for Brie). The 32-year-old L.A. native has been stealing scenes for the better part of a decade playing type-A characters on “Mad Men” and “Community,” and she viewed Headland’s film — and its many sex scenes — as an opportunity to try out a new direction. T sat down with the actress in Park City to discuss high-school sweethearts, “Sleepless in Seattle” and the highly secretive world of “Mad Men.”

headline: True Grits
abstract: Most life-changing food experiences involve exotic or high-end foods like truffles. But my latest life-changing food experience involved humble grits and polenta – cornmeal mush.
lead_paragraph: Most life-changing food experiences involve exotic or high-end foods like truffles. But my latest life-changing food experience involved humble grits and polenta – cornmeal mush.

headline: A High Court Check on Insider Trading
abstract: The judiciary’s interest in narrowing the scope of insider trading cases could provide some much needed clarity, Reynolds Holding writes for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: United States insider trading enforcers are making enemies in high places. Their aggressive view of the law has already irked appeals judges, and the Supreme Court may be next. Justice Antonin Scalia may get his long-sought opportunity to rein in Wall Street watchdogs.

headline: Till Death Parts Them
abstract: Rob Lowe and Paz Vega star as a hotel heir and the stripper he married.
lead_paragraph: Some of you have probably been worried about what has become of Rob Lowe since he left the quirky comforts of Pawnee and “Parks and Recreation” last year. You have good reason to be. Turns out, he married a stripper who had him brutally murdered.

headline: Their Picture Finally Comes Into Focus
abstract: Kristine Mattson and Kevin McCauley were high school sweethearts who overcame individual setbacks before reuniting.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Kevin McCauley received a Christmas card sent by Kristine Mattson, a woman he dated in high school and college before each took a separate path in the late 1980s, when he went to medical school on the East Coast, and she was married in their native California.

headline: A Tom Brady Sneak Is the Patriots’ Unstoppable Play
abstract: On third or fourth down with two yards or less to go, quarterback Tom Brady converts 91.3 percent of the time, thanks in part to preparation and tremendous leg strength.
lead_paragraph: CHANDLER, Ariz. — The most automatic play in the Patriots’ offensive playbook over the last 14 seasons involves Tom Brady, but it is not a pass. It is having Brady tuck the ball and lower his shoulder and shimmy into a narrow gap, gaining inch after bruising inch, the quarterback with a fullback’s mentality.

headline: Taxing 529 College Savings Plans: A Plan That Went Awry
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Personal Finances', 'Savings']
abstract: A White House plan to remove a tax break for saving money for college in 529 plans goes awry, and the reason includes money and feelings.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, we were treated to a truly odd Washington spectacle. Just over a week after making a set of pointed policy proposals that had little chance of getting to Congress and surviving intact, President Obama made front-page news by changing his mind about one of the smaller ones.

lead_paragraph: I’ve been tracking various reactions to the updated assessment of “planetary boundaries” —  nine physical or biological parameters that define “a safe operating space for humanity.”

lead_paragraph: A duplex penthouse with four terraces perched in one of the majestic twin towers of the Eldorado, an Art Deco landmark at 300 Central Park West, is poised to enter the market for $29 million.

lead_paragraph: The Occupy Wall Street protesters are long gone from Lower Manhattan. But on Friday morning, fanatics of a different sort mobbed a block of Broad Street outside the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Economist’s Advice on Super Bowl Pick: Follow the Money
abstract: Once you’ve seen the bookmakers’ odds, you’ve effectively summarized the thousands of pieces of data about the relative merits of the teams.
lead_paragraph: So, you want to be a football expert, but can’t actually be bothered devoting the hours required to understand the intricacies of the game? Let me help. Like you, I know that I’m never going to be the most knowledgeable football fan — I’ve never played the game, and grew up watching Australian rules football instead — but equally, I don’t want to be excluded from water cooler conversations.

headline: Roger Goodell Acknowledges ‘Tough Year’ but Says He Won’t Resign
abstract: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell added that if team owners decided to cut his pay, he would not object.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — N.F.L Commissioner Roger Goodell said on Friday that he had been chastened by a season of embarrassing scandals, contentious battles and growing distrust, but that he had no intention of resigning.

headline: Republican Rivals Shower Praise on Romney Upon His Exit

headline: The Myth of the Harmless Wrong
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: It’s logically possible but psychologically rare.
lead_paragraph: SOCIAL conservatives who bemoan the immorality of same-sex marriage typically also decry the harm it wreaks on society. The pundit Alan Keyes calls gay marriage a “social weapon of mass destruction,” while the North Carolina pastor Michael Barrett argues that widespread gay marriage would be “equivalent to a nuclear holocaust.”

headline: It’s 2 A.M. and You Need Tonkatsu
abstract: Ichibantei, in the East Village, can satisfy not just those who crave Japanese home cooking but those who crave it very late at night.
lead_paragraph: Ichibantei has carved out a very particular niche in the East Village, offering the unlikely pairing of home-style Japanese comfort food with a nonstop playlist of roots reggae. A loyal following is drawn to its heartfelt take on classic dishes that include donburi (rice bowls), tonkatsu (deep-fried pork cutlets) and kara-age (Japanese-style fried chicken), as well as $5 beers served in frosted mugs and a variety of sakes.

keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Compensation for Damages (Law)']

lead_paragraph: With a midnight Saturday deadline looming, hundreds of death and injury claims have been pouring into General Motors’ compensation program for victims of accidents caused by a defective ignition switch in millions of small cars.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Snow Day
keywords: ['Snow and Snowstorms', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: Hoods made a fashion statement.
lead_paragraph: With the schools closed, Tuesday was a day in the park for parents, children and dogs. A young mother brought her 10-month-old baby , who looked like an upside-down radish in a green jacket and red hat, and put the child into a plastic bucket for a first sleigh ride. Pedestrians leapt like ballet dancers over slushy curbsides. Tourists ventured into the south end of Central Park. The fountain in Bryant Park was newly frozen, and a group of youngsters had a snow fight using cafeteria trays. A young man built a snowman, chilled wine bottles inside of it, then poured himself a glass. He said it was his birthday.

headline: Argentine Leader Pleads For Unity During Inquiry
abstract: President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, in her second public appearance after the mysterious death of a prosecutor, blamed outside forces for provoking upheaval.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — In a veiled reference to the fallout from the mysterious death of a federal prosecutor this month, President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of Argentina blamed unspecified forces on Friday for provoking upheaval, pleading with Argentines to remain united and to “not let them bring conflicts here that are causing desolation, death and strain on other countries.”

headline: Senate Democrats to Try to Block Funding Bill Over Immigration
abstract: Senator Richard J. Durbin said Friday that Democrats would seek to block debate on a bill that would cancel President Obama’s actions protecting millions of unauthorized immigrants from deportation.
lead_paragraph: Senator Richard J. Durbin, the chamber’s No. 2 Democrat, said Friday that Senate Democrats would seek to block debate on a House-passed bill to fund the Department of Homeland Security that would cancel President Obama’s actions protecting millions of unauthorized immigrants from deportation.

headline: How to Get Through Cold-and-Flu Season Without Making Enemies
abstract: The etiquette of sick season.
lead_paragraph: Good manners and cold-and-flu season share an uneasy relationship, like spell-check and Chaucer. Consider, for instance, the pale, disheveled gentleman — “a guy in that sweet spot of the hipster/homeless Venn diagram” — that the artist Andrew Pope said he and about 15 other straphangers stood next to on the F train a few winters ago.

headline: Sundance Courts a New Celebrity Crowd
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Social Media', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Movies']
abstract: Stars of social media, not Hollywood, now have the attention of merchandisers.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — There was a love fest going on inside the publicist Kari Feinstein’s Sundance Style Lounge. Like the dozens of gifting suites that popped up along Main Street during the Sundance Film Festival last week, this one was filled with freebies: leather boots, knitted hats, portable cellphone chargers and, perhaps most outlandishly, a three-night, all-expenses-paid trip to Aruba, valued at $10,000.

headline: Greece Signals Unwillingness to Cooperate With Auditors
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The new finance minister said his country would no longer cooperate with international auditors sent to negotiate its bailout.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The new Greek finance minister used a joint appearance with a top eurozone official on Friday to insist that Greece would no longer cooperate with auditors representing its international creditors and would not seek an extension to the country’s bailout program.

headline: Schubert, Then and Now
abstract: In the series “The Schubert Effect,” Shai Wosner pairs that composer’s works with contemporary ones.
lead_paragraph: The pianist Shai Wosner is probably sick of hearing that he bears a certain physical resemblance to Schubert (though his choice of eyeglasses only fosters the notion). His identification with the composer, however, clearly runs much deeper, as he showed in a superb rendition of the late Sonata in A (D. 959) at the 92nd Street Y on Wednesday evening. The performance was part of a two-concert series, “The Schubert Effect,” which Mr. Wosner, its curator, is sharing with the Parker Quartet.

lead_paragraph: Guest cooking stints by high-profile chefs at upscale hotels is a certifiable trend, and the Bulgari Hotel Milan has upped the ante with Epicurea, a seven-month food festival.

headline: Larry Clark Explores the Subject of Misspent Youths
abstract: The filmmaker discusses “Marfa Girl,” which follows a group of aimless teenagers in West Texas and will open in theaters in March.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve had many, many vices,” said Larry Clark, who has made a career of filming and photographing wayward adolescents shuffling through life in a haze of heroin, marijuana and random sex. He may well have been referring to his own errant youth. But now, if a vice remains, it is the occasional tipple.

lead_paragraph: MADRID — When Jordan Casey took to the stage to present his technology business, he jumped onto the platform rather than walking up the access ramp.

headline: Grab Bag of Wit and Pathos
abstract: Cora Dance is presenting a diverse program at the Brooklyn Academy of Music that reflects how it has expanded its mission.
lead_paragraph: Shannon Hummel founded Cora Dance in 1997 as a dance company, but in recent years her organization has branched out in its aims and activities. Committed to increasing access to dance, she has opened a pay-what-you-can community-center studio in Red Hook, Brooklyn, and taken her choreography and workshops to parks and public housing developments. “Stories,” the program that opened at BAM Fisher on Thursday, is designed as a “container,” as she put it, for all that Cora Dance now is.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Sometimes it seems as if the first month of the new year is one giant runway show — and that’s before you even get to the official collections.

headline: Work in Progress, Stormy and Insistent
abstract: Savages, a rock band from London, has spent three weeks in New York clubs working on fresh material.
lead_paragraph: It’s tempting to want to watch Savages from a distance. As a unit, this London band works on a grand scale, making a post-punk squall that’s streamlined but not skeletal. From its earliest shows, it’s been adept at filling a space with a sound that’s imposing, urgent and mildly gloomy.

headline: Welcoming the Dark Twist in Her Career
abstract: Paula Hawkins, author of the best seller “The Girl on the Train,” says the book was born of a realization that she prefers tragedy to humor.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In retrospect, Paula Hawkins realizes that sending her half-finished thriller to publishers before she’d written the crucial, explosive final scenes might seem like a brazen act of overconfidence. At the time, though, she badly needed the money.

abstract: The ride-hailing start-up responds to criticism from privacy hawks.
lead_paragraph: Uber, the popular ride-hailing start-up, on Friday said it would strengthen its data privacy practices, responding to months of criticism that the company had taken a lackadaisical approach to guarding the customer information.

headline: Christie’s Hosts an Online Auction With Some Fresh Names in Fine Jewelry
abstract: The house is teaming up with Dalia Oberlander of the e-commerce site Latest Revival to sell seven original designs next week.
lead_paragraph: Though Christie’s is renowned for its antique jewelry offerings, next week the auction house is turning its eye toward new design — the type of pieces favored by the client who’d rather submit bids with a click of a mouse than with a paddle. The auction house has tapped Dalia Oberlander, a former Sotheby’s employee and founder of the fashionable fine jewelry site Latest Revival, to curate a limited-edition, seven-piece collection to be sold exclusively online. The assortment includes Monique Péan’s diamond pavé ring with a fossilized dinosaur bone; Deborah Pagani’s chandelier earrings with gray and black diamonds; and custom necklaces, earrings and rings by influential brands such as Maiyet, Pamela Love and Completedworks. Each piece also comes with a signed sketch from the designer. “It’s jewelry that can be passed down through generations and will remain as relevant and fresh in the future as it is now,” Oberlander says.

headline: Incursion Wasn’t a First for a Protester
abstract: The man who leapt onto the stage during the Metropolitan Opera’s “Iolanta” to protest Russian actions in Ukraine had done something similar at a Russian violinist’s performance at Harvard.

headline: Does Censorship Make Us Safer?

keywords: ['Savings', 'Personal Finances', 'Families and Family Life', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Poverty']
abstract: Most households have only a paltry amount in easily accessible accounts, but some simple steps can help many set money aside for use in an emergency.
lead_paragraph: MORE than half of American households have less than one month of income available in readily accessible savings to use in case of an emergency, a new report from the Pew Charitable Trusts finds.

headline: Presidents Can Be So Romantic
abstract: This year Valentine’s and Presidents’ Day fall on the same weekend, and hotels around the country are offering packages that celebrate both occasions.
lead_paragraph: Valentine’s-themed getaways are all about romance; Presidents’ Day weekend tends to be more straightforward. But this year the holidays fall on the same weekend, and hotels around the country are offering packages that celebrate both occasions.

lead_paragraph: In a partial retreat from drug prosecutions that spurred a national debate over possible entrapment and racial profiling, the federal prosecutor in Chicago has dropped the most serious charges against 27 defendants who were caught in so-called stash-house stings.
