headline: East End Bread from East End Wheat
abstract: Farmers are bringing back commercial grain production, with the notion that bread has a distinctive connection to the soil.
lead_paragraph: Farmers are bringing back commercial grain production, with the notion that bread has a distinctive connection to the soil.

headline: On the East End of Long Island, Embracing Local Wheat
abstract: East End farmers are bringing commercial grain production back to local agriculture.
lead_paragraph: Wines have their Tuscan countryside; cheeses, their hillside caves in southern France. So wouldn’t it make sense that bread, too, might hold a connection to the place where the wheat is grown and the dough kneaded? That’s the goal in Amagansett, where farmers and bakers work the bounty of the land, encouraged by the idea of terroir: that the soil and the elements combine to create a distinct flavor bound to place.

headline: Spy vs. Nonspy in Putin’s Russia
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'News and News Media', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: The ring of suspected intelligence operatives’ use of journalists tells you everything you need to know about the Kremlin’s paranoia.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, F.B.I. agents in New York arrested a 39-year-old Russian man named Evgeny Buryakov, whom federal prosecutors accused of participating in a spy ring gathering economic intelligence on the United States. There were three spies in all, according to the criminal complaint federal prosecutors filed on Monday, all agents of the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (S.V.R.), who had been posing for several years as civilians. Buryakov worked at the New York branch of the Russian state-owned Vnesheconombank; his suspected accomplices worked as a Russian trade representative and diplomatic attaché.

headline: Lowcountry Cooking Travels North
abstract: Sarah Gresko, raised in New Jersey, absorbed enough traditional Lowcountry cooking while working in restaurants in Charleston, S.C., that she felt the urge to sell some grits in Hopewell, at SweetGrass, her first restaurant as owner and chef.
lead_paragraph: Who says you have to grow up with grits to love them — or to cook them? Sarah Gresko, raised in New Jersey, absorbed enough traditional Lowcountry cooking while working in restaurants in Charleston, S.C., that she got the itch to sell some grits in Hopewell, at SweetGrass, her first restaurant as owner and chef.

headline: Federal Construction Projects Must Plan for Flood Risks From Climate Change
abstract: President Obama issued an executive order requiring that all federally funded construction projects take into account the flood risks linked to global warming.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday continued to push his aggressive climate change agenda, signing an executive order requiring that all federally funded construction projects take into account the flood risks linked to global warming.

headline: U.N. Rights Chief Says He’ll Shine a Light on Countries Big and Small
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations']
abstract: Four months into his new job, Prince Zeid Ra’ad Zeid al-Hussein of Jordan is resisting the efforts of some nations to hold his office to a narrow interpretation of its mandate.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — IN a 20-year career at the United Nations, Prince Zeid Ra’ad Zeid al-Hussein has had more than a few opportunities to witness the human capacity for cruelty, but nothing seared his memory quite like two scenes from the Balkan wars of the 1990s.

headline: Holding Soccer Drive and Devotion to a Certain Standard
abstract: In her years of conducting soccer clinics, Yael Averbuch writes, one thing has become clear: There is a need for standards of development at various age levels.
lead_paragraph: It’s encouraging to witness first-hand how soccer is taking off in the United States. According to a recent survey, youth soccer participation rates increased roughly 300 percent from 1974 to 2014. During my current off-season, I have conducted a number of clinics for some of these youth players. Typically, a club will invite me in for a day, and I work with boys and (mostly) girls on and off the field. Ages and ability levels vary greatly, but I am always astounded and moved by the level of enthusiasm and eagerness I see in the players.

headline: Chinese Agency Softens Criticism of Alibaba on Sales of Fake Goods
keywords: ['E-Commerce', 'Counterfeit Merchandise', 'Consumer Protection', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Two days after a government regulator harshly criticized the company, the two showed signs of moving quickly to cooperate.
lead_paragraph: It was only two days ago that a Chinese government regulator chastised the Alibaba Group, the e-commerce giant, for failing to curb the sale of fake goods on its sites.

headline: I See Very Serious Dead People
abstract: Sometimes, the responsible and brave thing is to focus on the short run.
lead_paragraph: In the long run, of course, when we’re all dead.

headline: Friday Night Music: Carolina Chocolate Drops, Up In The Air
abstract: Taking their music to new, slightly strange heights.
lead_paragraph: I spent 12 days tromping around Asia, so of course I found myself listening to a lot of Americana — Civil Wars (sigh), Sarah Jarosz, and Carolina Chocolate Drops. I’m not sure exactly why you’d want them playing in a gondola, but never mind — still great.

headline: When a Rivalry Was Young, Maria Sharapova Held Her Own
abstract: While Serena Williams holds a 16-2 advantage in their head-to-head record, in 2004 a 17-year-old Sharapova beat her in two of their first three meetings.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — As strange as it might seem considering their lifetime head-to-head results, Maria Sharapova had a winning record against Serena Williams until their burgeoning rivalry shifted to Australia.

headline: Oil Prices Surge 8% After Long Slide Down
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Energy experts said the sudden increase could be explained by various factors, including reports that the Islamic State terrorist group was advancing in an offensive near Iraq’s northern oil fields.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Oil prices suddenly spiked more than 8 percent on Friday, in the biggest one-day price move for the volatile commodity in nearly three years. But most energy experts said it was too soon to say whether any meaningful shift was underway.

headline: Nevada: Soccer Stadium Foes’ Petition Drive Rejected
abstract: A petition drive for a referendum on using public money to help pay for construction of a soccer stadium in downtown Las Vegas did not gather enough valid signatures.
lead_paragraph: A petition drive for a referendum on using public money to help pay for construction of a soccer stadium in downtown Las Vegas did not gather enough valid signatures, Clark County officials said Friday. Opponents of the stadium subsidy submitted more than 9,800 signatures to the county Elections Department. After randomly sampling 500 signatures, elections officials said that only 6,966 were valid, less than the 8,258 they say are required to put the question on the June 2 ballot. Opponents say the state Constitution requires only 2,306 signatures, and have asked a district court judge to order the county to accept fewer signatures. A hearing is scheduled on Feb. 10.

headline: Odd Photo Choice for Venezuela Promotional Effort
abstract: Jim Wyss, a reporter for The Miami Herald, was surprised to see a picture of himself after his release from Venezuelan detention being used in a campaign for national pride.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Not long ago, Jim Wyss, a South America correspondent for The Miami Herald, was detained by Venezuelan authorities for 48 hours and questioned by military intelligence. This week, he briefly became a poster boy for Venezuelan national pride.

headline: Trinity Guardrail Test
abstract: A sequence from video footage of the eighth crash test of a Trinity’s ET-Plus guardrail, which shows a car colliding with a guardrail.
lead_paragraph: A sequence from video footage of the eighth crash test of a Trinity’s ET-Plus guardrail, which shows a car colliding with a guardrail.

headline: For Tourists Seeking Drugs, an Experience That’s Less Than Authentic
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Counterfeit Merchandise', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine']
abstract: Preying on out-of-towners with money to burn, street hustlers on Seventh Avenue in Manhattan are selling cold medicine in place of cocaine.
lead_paragraph: P. T. Barnum declared over 100 years ago that there is one born every minute. But where, when they grow up to become adults who visit New York, do they go to buy cocaine?

headline: Pilots Union Approves Contract With Airline
keywords: ['Pilots', 'Organized Labor', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The deal provides a substantial salary increase, though some union members have criticized it for failing to match the terms offered by Delta Air Lines.
lead_paragraph: American Airlines pilots approved a new five-year contract with the airline, clearing a big internal hurdle toward integrating operations from the merger of American Airlines and US Airways.

headline: Assessment of Guardrails May Hinge on Final Crash Test
abstract: The test, the last in a series ordered by the Federal Highway Administration, appeared to be the first to shed doubt on the widely used barrier system.
lead_paragraph: As a debate swirls over whether a widely used guardrail system is safe, more than 30 states have been waiting for the results of crash tests before deciding whether to continue to use the guardrails or, possibly, have them removed.

headline: Venezuela: Military Says It Downed Plane Near Aruba
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Venezuela’s defense minister said Friday that Venezuelan military aircraft had shot down a small plane that crashed a day earlier in the waters near the island of Aruba.
lead_paragraph: Venezuela’s defense minister said Friday that Venezuelan military aircraft had shot down a small plane that crashed a day earlier in the waters near the island of Aruba. Officials in Aruba said Thursday that the plane had gone down after being pursued by Venezuelan jets, but it was not immediately known if they had fired on it. The Venezuelan defense minister, Vladimir Padrino, said that the plane had taken off from the southern state of Apure, which is a regular loading point for drug flights. “Our aircraft intercepted and it did not follow orders and, well, it was disabled,” he said, adding that the encounter took place over Venezuela’s territorial waters. The Aruban authorities said that the craft crashed in waters belonging to the island, which lies just off Venezuela’s coast. Officials in Aruba said that body parts and about 400 packages that appeared to contain drugs were found in the wreckage. A Justice Ministry official in Aruba said Friday that the plane was registered in the United States.

headline: Speck of Interstellar Dust Obscures Glimpse of Big Bang
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Gravitation and Gravity', 'Microwaves (Electromagnetic Waves)']
abstract: A team of astronomers, after saying last spring that they had found long-sought evidence for what kicked off the big bang, now concede that more work is needed.
lead_paragraph: Scientists will have to wait a while longer to find out what kicked off the Big Bang.

headline: Newcomers Buy Ad Time at the Super Bowl
abstract: A tiny start-up in Silicon Valley is one of 15 first-time advertisers that will compete for attention on Sunday against the usual lineup of deep-pocketed brands.
lead_paragraph: About a month after advertising on television for the first time, the makers of the free mobile game Heroes Charge decided at the last minute that they wanted to make a much bigger splash: a commercial during television’s biggest advertising event, the Super Bowl.

headline: Slipping Into Darkness in South Africa
abstract: “Sizwe Banzi Is Dead,” in Princeton, translates the repressive horror of apartheid into human terms through the use of easygoing humor in its early passages, then shifts into graver tones as the play progresses.
lead_paragraph: The Kafkaesque existence that millions of people suffered through under South Africa’s apartheid laws is rendered with powerful simplicity in “Sizwe Banzi Is Dead.”

headline: Oswald’s Coffin Belongs to His Brother, Not Funeral Home, a Judge Rules
abstract: The coffin that held the body of Lee Harvey Oswald belongs to his brother and not a Fort Worth funeral home, a Texas judge ruled Friday.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — The wood coffin that held the body of Lee Harvey Oswald belongs to his brother and not a Fort Worth funeral home that sought to sell it for more than $87,000, a Texas judge ruled Friday.

headline: Bernice Gordon, Crossword Creator for The Times, Dies at 101
abstract: For more than six decades, Ms. Gordon created crossword puzzles known for their wit and finesse.
lead_paragraph: Bernice Gordon, a self-described ⬜ ⬜ ⬜ ⬜ ⬜ ⬜ ⬜ ⬜ ⬜ ⬜ ⬜ ⬜ ⬜ ⬜ who over the last six decades contributed some 150 crossword puzzles to The New York Times, died on Thursday at her home in Philadelphia. She was 101.

headline: Vague Job Outline Leads to Defining Role With Seahawks
abstract: As the Seahawks’ defensive passing game specialist, Rocky Seto deals with the minutiae of the game as the “detail guy.”
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Rocky Seto is the Seattle Seahawks’ defensive passing game coordinator.

headline: Buyers of Used Cars Are Left to Find Recalls on Their Own
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Consumer Protection', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Buying a used car in the United States can be a dangerous proposition if the vehicle has an unadvertised safety defect.
lead_paragraph: Buying a used car in the United States can be a dangerous proposition — if the vehicle has an unadvertised safety defect.

headline: Canada Seeks to Strengthen Spy Agency After Attacks
abstract: Prime Minister Stephen Harper introduced legislation that would greatly expand the role of the spy service, allowing courts to remove online postings and increasing police detention powers.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Citing the attacks by radical Islamists that killed two Canadian soldiers in October and the more recent assaults in France, Prime Minister Stephen Harper introduced sweeping legislation on Friday that would greatly expand the role of Canada’s spy service, allowing courts to remove online postings and increasing police detention powers.

headline: A Strained Alliance: Obama-Netanyahu Rift Grew Over Years
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Palestinians', 'Israeli Settlements']
abstract: The diplomatic break touched off by Benjamin Netanyahu’s decision to negotiate an address to Congress without first telling President Obama reflects their fundamentally different world views.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For six years, the pattern has been the same. A dispute between American and Israeli leaders spills out into the open. Analysts declare the relationship in crisis. Then the two sides try to tamp down emotions and argue that the rupture is not as dire as it looks.

headline: Japanese Comfort Food in the Wee Hours
abstract: In a neighborhood teeming with Japanese food offerings, Ichibantei has its own niche.
lead_paragraph: In a neighborhood teeming with Japanese food offerings, Ichibantei has its own niche.

headline: Vaccine Critics Turn Defensive Over Measles
abstract: As officials in 14 states grapple with a measles outbreak, the parents at the heart of America’s anti-vaccine movement are being blamed for a public-health crisis.
lead_paragraph: HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif. — Their children have been sent home from school. Their families are barred from birthday parties and neighborhood play dates. Online, people call them negligent and criminal. And as officials in 14 states grapple to contain a spreading measles outbreak that began near here at Disneyland, the parents at the heart of America’s anti-vaccine movement are being blamed for incubating an otherwise preventable public-health crisis.

headline: Judge Rules for Warner Bros. in Dispute Over ‘Gravity’
abstract: The author Tess Gerritsen had claimed that Warner breached a contract with her when it made the film.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — While viewers work through this year’s Oscar films, a court here is still working its way through one of last year’s nominees, “Gravity.” On Friday, Judge Margaret M. Morrow of the United States District Court for the Central District of California in Los Angeles dismissed a complaint by the author Tess Gerritsen, who had claimed that Warner Bros. breached a contract with her when it made “Gravity” without giving her credit or 2.5 percent of the film’s net profit.

headline: Mitt Quits. Again. Probably.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Maybe we can get a squirrel theme going for 2016 because, without Candidate Mitt, we won’t have the dog on the roof to talk about.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney is out! And we hardly had time to adjust to the idea that he was in.

headline: A Fading Titan, Cheered On With Pity
abstract: Fans expressed pity as Tiger Woods stumbled through the worst round of his professional career, an 82 at the Phoenix Open. At 23 strokes back after 36 holes, he missed the cut.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — Watching Tiger Woods launch wildly errant drives was hard. Watching his ground-ball chip shots was harder. But the hardest part of watching Woods’s career-worst round Friday at the Phoenix Open was seeing the greatest golfer of his generation turn into the lovable last-place straggler.

headline: Rematch in the Final, but Only the Names Are the Same
abstract: Novak Djokovic will face Andy Murray in the men’s final at the Australian Open on Sunday, but much has changed since they last played in the final here, in 2013.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Once more, it will be Novak Djokovic versus Andy Murray with the Norman Brookes Challenge Cup and the Australian Open title at stake.

headline: Was Abolitionism a Failure?
abstract: The movement didn’t end slavery; the Civil War did.
lead_paragraph: ON Jan. 31, 1865, Congress passed the 13th Amendment, banning slavery in America. It was an achievement that abolitionists had spent decades fighting for — and one for which their movement has been lauded ever since.

headline: Loyalist Forsakes Gandhis’ Fraying Party
abstract: Jayanthi Natarajan, breaking from the Indian National Congress, accused Sonia Gandhi and her son of making her a scapegoat for their government’s failings.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A longtime and prominent loyalist of the Indian National Congress party publicly broke with the party’s president, Sonia Gandhi, and her son, Rahul, on Friday. The loyalist accused the Gandhis of interfering with her decisions when she was environment minister, forcing her to resign without explanation, then making her a scapegoat for their government’s failings.

headline: A Hearty Visit to Germany
abstract: With its casually retro ambience and filling meals, Jennifer’s Restaurant, in Yorktown Heights, evokes a trip to the old country.
lead_paragraph: I must have passed Jennifer’s Restaurant hundreds of times over the years. Set on a remote stretch along the Croton Reservoir, the modest roadside German restaurant has been operating — with a brief interlude in the ’90s (and with one other name) — since 1979.

headline: Store Steps Onto New Turf To Aid 2 Officers’ Families
abstract: Modell’s Sporting Goods is selling T-shirts that pledge support for the Police Department in hopes of raising money for the families of two slain officers.
lead_paragraph: The Super Bowl is familiar territory for Modell’s Sporting Goods, the New York retail institution: Every year, racks at almost all of its locations hang heavy with N.F.L. T-shirts and jerseys, and this year is no exception — Modell’s stores are crowded with clothing displaying loyalty to the New England Patriots, the Seattle Seahawks or simply the game itself.

headline: Near Collision in the Skies Is Recounted by Passengers
abstract: Passengers described a near collision of two planes near Westchester County Airport on Sunday, which the Federal Aviation Administration is investigating.
lead_paragraph: To her left, Kay Germano noticed a small silvery speck hurtling toward her airplane. Maybe it was a bird, she thought, lost in the clouds. She paid it no heed.

headline: Higher Pay for New York City’s Managers
abstract: The senior-most members of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration will receive about a 6 percent raise over the next three years, city officials said.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Mayor Bill de Blasio made good on a pledge to raise the pay of tens of thousands of unionized New York City employees, granting higher wages to teachers, nurses and other rank-and-file workers who had gone without contracts for years.

headline: Give It a Go
abstract: There’s some pretty chewy stuff in Tim Croce’s Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is the kind of crossword puzzle that has enough verbalization clues and entries that I could almost write today’s entire blog post in all cap answers. I’ll leave that fun to the commenters.

headline: Yves Chauvin, ‘Green’ Chemist and Nobel Laureate, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Chauvin helped unlock the secret of “green chemistry” to produce less hazardous waste in manufacturing.
lead_paragraph: Yves Chauvin, who shared the 2005 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for deciphering a “green chemistry” reaction now used to make pharmaceuticals and plastics more efficiently while generating less hazardous waste, died on Tuesday in Tours, France. He was 84.

headline: The Bahamas Tightens Immigration
abstract: Raids on places where Haitians live have swept up hundreds of people since a new policy took effect, requiring everyone to hold a passport.
lead_paragraph: Raids on places where Haitians live have swept up hundreds of people since a new policy took effect, requiring everyone to hold a passport.

headline: Immigration Rules in Bahamas Sweep Up Haitians
abstract: A fiercely debated new immigration policy in the Bahamas requires everyone to hold a passport, a rule that human rights groups say unfairly targets people of Haitian descent.
lead_paragraph: NASSAU, Bahamas — Kenson Timothee was walking down the street when a uniformed officer asked him a question that sends Bahamians of Haitian descent like him into a panic these days: Do you have a passport?

headline: Wadsworth Atheneum’s New Spaces for Contemporary Art
abstract: The Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art, in Hartford, is opening two permanent galleries dedicated to contemporary art, and the galleries have been refurbished and reinstalled with significant objects from the museum’s collection.
lead_paragraph: In 1844, the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art’s inaugural exhibition included Thomas Cole’s “Mt. Etna From Taormina,” completed the year before. Two years later, the fledgling institution purchased Frederic Edwin Church’s first painting, the brand-new “Hooker and Company Journeying Through the Wilderness From Plymouth to Hartford, in 1636.”

headline: Service Restored, but Still No Empty Seats
abstract: Aude Back de Surany was among the C train passengers in Manhattan on Friday after uptown service on the line was restored. A power failure downtown had interrupted service.
lead_paragraph: Aude Back de Surany, center, of France, was among the C train passengers in Manhattan on Friday after uptown service on the line was restored. Early in the morning, a power failure at Chambers Street cause a brief halt in uptown service on the A, C and E lines.

headline: A Call to Raise Tipped Workers’ Wages in New York
abstract: The state’s Wage Board recommended a rate of $7.50 an hour before gratuities for workers who rely on tips. The current rate is $5.
lead_paragraph: A New York State board on Friday recommended an increase in the hourly wage for tipped workers like restaurant servers, proposing a rate of $7.50 an hour before gratuities. The current wage, which has not increased since 2011, is $5.

headline: China’s Self-Destructive Tech Crackdown
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Censorship', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Computer Security']
abstract: President Xi Jinping’s rules for foreign technology companies will create a major rift between his country and the rest of the world.
lead_paragraph: Under the guise of improving security, the Chinese government is clamping down on technology companies and further limiting the access its citizens have to information that is not sanitized by the Communist Party. These moves will hurt the Chinese economy and create a major rift between China and the rest of the world.

headline: With Oil Revenue Dropping, Mexico Announces Budget Cuts
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'High-Speed Rail Projects']
abstract: The government said it would cut $8.3 billion, sharply reducing the budget of the state oil company and effectively canceling a bullet train project at the center of a conflict-of-interest scandal.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Faced with declining prices for its oil exports, Mexico’s government announced $8.3 billion in budget cuts, slashing the budget of the state oil company. It also effectively canceled a bullet train project at the center of a conflict-of-interest scandal that has weakened Enrique Peña Nieto’s presidency.

headline: Rooting Out Brutality at Rikers Island
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Guards']
abstract: The disciplinary process at the Correction Department desperately needs to be strengthened and repaired.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s correction commissioner did the right thing this month when he fired a captain and five guards who tied up and savagely beat an inmate at the Rikers Island jail complex in the spring of 2012. But the fact that it took nearly three years to dismiss the officers reveals — again — a disciplinary process badly in need of repair. It also underscores the need for the full-scale reforms that the Justice Department is seeking in federal court.

headline: New York’s Real Scandal
abstract: The Sheldon Silver affair shows that some corruption can be perfectly legal.
lead_paragraph: Editors' Note:

headline: Civil War Mural, Obscured for Decades, Resurfaces on a Shelf
abstract: A painting that was mislabeled and moved among museums for decades has been identified. But its owners are pondering where it can be displayed.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — A historic Civil War mural that bounced, mislabeled, from museum to museum for several decades has emerged from storage, its identity reclaimed. But because of its size, its owners are still pondering where it can be displayed.

headline: Survivors of 1998 U.S. Embassy Bombings Can Testify in Trial, Judge Rules
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Lawyers representing Khaled al-Fawwaz had argued that testimony from victims of the bombings would add nothing more than “dramatics” and “emotions” to the proceedings.
lead_paragraph: In terrorism trials in Manhattan in recent years, perhaps no testimony has been as riveting as that offered by the survivors of the 1998 bombings by Al Qaeda of the United States embassies in Nairobi, Kenya, and Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, which killed 224 people and wounded thousands.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 30, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: New York to Pay $3.9 Million to End Suit Over Police Killing of Teenager
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The agreement to settle the case comes nearly three years after the Feb. 2, 2012, shooting of the Bronx teenager, Ramarley Graham.
lead_paragraph: The family of a Bronx teenager who was fatally shot by a police officer who had barged into his apartment after suspecting him of taking part in a drug deal has agreed to settle a wrongful-death lawsuit against the city for $3.9 million.

headline: With Eye on Harvard, Basketball Player Has 2 Careers on His Mind
abstract: Chris Lewis, a power forward who has been receiving scholarship offers since he was in middle school, has chosen to play for Harvard, following advice from his father, Mo Lewis, the former Jets linebacker.
lead_paragraph: On a family trip to Boston two years ago, the former Jets linebacker Mo Lewis and his son Chris toured the Massachusetts Institute of Technology’s campus. Chris Lewis, a ninth-grader at the time, had already received basketball scholarship offers from Memphis and New Mexico. Still, he had always dreamed of becoming an engineer, and few colleges had a better engineering program than M.I.T.

headline: Charlie Williams, a Met Traded for Mays, Dies at 67
abstract: Williams played eight seasons in the majors, but was best known as the trade bait that brought Willie Mays back to New York.
lead_paragraph: Charlie Williams, a pitcher best known as the trade bait the Mets used to land Willie Mays in the twilight of his career, died on Tuesday in Daytona Beach, Fla. He was 67.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 31, 2015
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 31, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “I said, ‘I’d rather you miss an entire semester than you get the shot.’”

headline: Craig Ramini, Whose Heart Led to Buffalo Mozzarella, Dies at 57
abstract: Mr. Ramini, a software consultant, stopped to ask himself what he really wanted to do, then doggedly pursued the answer despite great odds.
lead_paragraph: Craig Ramini, a 52-year-old Silicon Valley software consultant at the time, didn’t know his curds from his wheys or a bison from a paesan (and maybe even whether buffaloes had wings or originated in western New York) when he confronted a midlife crisis early in 2009.

headline: Edward J. Saylor, 94, Dies; Took Fight to Japan With Doolittle Raiders
abstract: Mr. Saylor was a member of a band of World War II airmen who bombed Japan in early 1942, stunning the enemy at a time when its army and navy were racking up victories across Asia.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Edward J. Saylor, one of the last surviving members of the Doolittle Raiders, a band of World War II airmen who bombed Japan in early 1942, stunning the Japanese at a time when their army and navy were racking up victories across Asia, died on Wednesday at his home near here. He was 94.

headline: A Mere 112 Million? The Super Bowl’s Audience Is Tough to Gauge
abstract: The Super Bowl is a ratings blockbuster, but the people who televise it continue to try to learn how many people watch it without being counted.
lead_paragraph: The Super Bowl may sometimes disappoint as a competitive game, but never as an audience grabber. Witness Seattle’s 43-8 drubbing of Denver last year. Despite being a blowout, it was the fourth straight Super Bowl to draw 100 million viewers, generating a record 112.8 million.

headline: Stig Bergling, a Cold War Spy Known for His Escape, Dies at 77
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Cold War Era', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Prison Escapes']
abstract: Mr. Bergling, sentenced to life in prison in 1979 for selling military secrets to the Soviet Union, fled from custody during a conjugal visit with his wife.
lead_paragraph: Stig Bergling, one of Sweden’s most notorious Cold War spies, who in 1987 escaped from prison during a conjugal visit, died on Jan. 24 in Stockholm. He was 77.

headline: Love, the Other Letdown
abstract: These poems about Monday evening’s storm and its relationship to romance (or the lack thereof) were found in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org.
lead_paragraph: Blizzards — or feared blizzards, like this week’s storm — tear us from our daily lives. In that, they are like love. They also tend to be fickle, blowing in quickly and dissipating just as fast. These poems about Monday evening’s storm and its relationship to romance (or the lack thereof) were found in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.

headline: Bobby Shmurda Posts $2 Million Bail
abstract: The Brooklyn rapper has spent more than six weeks in jail on gun and drug charges related to allegations of a gang conspiracy.
lead_paragraph: Bobby Shmurda, the spark-plug Brooklyn rapper, has posted $2 million bail after spending more than six weeks in jail on gun and drug charges related to allegations of a gang conspiracy, his lawyer said on Friday.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) BAD WORDS (2014) Guy Trilby (Jason Bateman, who also directed), a 40-year-old bully who has wormed his way onto the spelling-bee circuit, mows down the small-fry competition with one expletive after another until he reaches the nationals. And then he encounters Chaitanya Chopra (Rohan Chand), a socially awkward 10-year-old sorely in need of a friend. “It would be something to see Mr. Bateman go authentically dark (perhaps not that dark), but it’s also enough just to watch him as he widens his eyes, furrows his brow and shows off his excellent timing,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “It’s a fluid feature-directing debut, and he pulls the ensemble together smoothly,” she added. “The performances are funny, appealing and, in the case of Allison Janney, as a spelling bee official, wonderful. A dowdied-down Kathryn Hahn has it tougher as Jenny, a reporter who’s chasing Guy for his story and occasional sex. It’s a pathetic role, largely because she’s a sad piñata made for the whacking simply because, it seems, the only thing worse than making kids cry is being a journalist.”

headline: Corrections: January 31, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, January 31, 2015.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Serena Williams Wins Australian Open With Coughs, Guts and Aces
abstract: Williams won her 19th Grand Slam singles title on Saturday, defeating Sharapova, 6-3, 7-6 (5) to become the oldest woman to win the singles title in the Open era.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The record still shows that Maria Sharapova is a pushover for Serena Williams: her muse, her matchup made in tennis heaven.

headline: Super Bowls Are Getting More Interesting
abstract: Blowouts, once the norm, no longer are. This is the seventh straight Super Bowl projected to be a close game, and most have lived up to expectations.
lead_paragraph: Any football fans old enough to remember the 1980s are old enough to remember the idea that Super Bowls were lousy football games. Blowouts were the norm for much of the 1980s and 1990s, with scores like 38-9, 46-10, 55-10 and 52-17.

headline: Shots Fired at Kabul Protest Against French Newspaper
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Attacks on Police', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Witnesses said at least eight people were wounded on Saturday at a demonstration against the French newspaper’s publication of cartoons depicting the Prophet Muhammad.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Gunfire erupted on Saturday at a demonstration in Kabul where several hundred people had gathered to protest the publication of cartoons depicting the Prophet Muhammad in the satirical French newspaper Charlie Hebdo, witnesses said.

headline: Andrew Filev of Wrike: Check Your Ego at the Door
abstract: The chief executive of a software company says that anyone who makes a decision in a company should be able to explain it and give reasons for it.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Andrew Filev, chief executive of Wrike, a provider of project management software, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Two Judges Who Get It About Banks
abstract: A Missouri judge ordered Wells Fargo to pay over $3 million for abusing a borrower, and a federal judge in New York said there was evidence the bank had forged documents.
lead_paragraph: Big banks hold great sway in Washington these days, far more than troubled homeowners do. But outside the Beltway, many people remain caught in the maw of the financial giants, which is why it is heartening when some judges step into the fray.

headline: A Focus on Fitness, and a Passion for the Packers
abstract: Hoyt Harper says it is refreshing to come into his Stamford, Conn., office and see Long Island Sound, but he doesn’t get to spend much time looking at it.
lead_paragraph: Hoyt Harper is senior vice president and global brand leader of Sheraton Hotels and Resorts Group in Stamford, Conn.

headline: The Case of the Disappearing Diamond Ring
abstract: As repairs on an engagement ring stretch into months, the owner gets apologies, but no ring or explanation, from a jewelry chain.
lead_paragraph: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

headline: Few Smiles for These Cameras
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Cameras', 'Landlords', 'Condominiums']
abstract: Surveillance in hallways and through peepholes, and restrictions on renting out condos are this week’s subjects.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: G.O.P. Campaigns Scramble to Add Romney Donors
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida are in all-out battle this weekend to tap into the billion-dollar donor network once harnessed by Mitt Romney.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida plunged into all-out battle this weekend for the biggest unclaimed prize in American politics and the decisive advantage that could go with it: the billion-dollar donor network once harnessed by Mitt Romney.

headline: Climate Change’s Bottom Line
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'United States Economy', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Risky Business Project’s well-known business and policy leaders hope its research will persuade companies to prepare for, and help mitigate, climate change.
lead_paragraph: It was 8 degrees in Minneapolis on a recent January day, and out on Interstate 394, snow whipped against the windshields of drivers on their morning commutes. But inside the offices of Cargill, the food conglomerate, Greg Page, the company’s executive chairman, felt compelled to talk about global warming.

headline: Cunard Ships Will Travel Back in Time
abstract: This summer, in honor of its 175th anniversary, Cunard plans to recreate its original voyage, from Liverpool, England, to Boston, aboard the Queen Mary 2.
lead_paragraph: Cunard, the British cruise line, made its inaugural trans-Atlantic voyage in the summer of 1840, ferrying passengers from Liverpool, England, to Boston aboard the Britannia, the first ship the company built for its first fleet, all paddleboat steamers. This summer, in honor of its 175th anniversary, Cunard plans to recreate that original voyage, but this time on the Queen Mary 2, one of its modern ocean liners.

headline: The Vaccine Lunacy
abstract: For the sake of children’s health, let’s face facts and repudiate fiction.
lead_paragraph: A FEW years back, an acerbic friend of mine who was a recent transplant to Los Angeles told me that she itched to write a satirical novel with the following narrative:

headline: Papers Fuel a 7-Alarm Fire at a Warehouse in Brooklyn
abstract: More than 200 firefighters worked to control a blaze at the CitiStorage building in Williamsburg on Saturday. Smoke was visible as far away as New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A seven-alarm fire engulfed a warehouse crammed with official documents near the waterfront in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Saturday morning, sending plumes of brown, acrid smoke into the air that were visible as far away as New Jersey.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: Daniel Raymon returns with a delightful cryptic crossword.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Daniel Raymon is well known to New York Times solvers as a crossword puzzle constructor and has had four cryptic crosswords published here as well.

headline: Cars With Faulty Airbags Are Recalled Second Time, but Fix May Take a Year
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Toyota, Chrysler and Honda previously recalled the 2.1 million cars, but the fix administered was not effective, United States officials said.
lead_paragraph: Toyota, Chrysler and Honda are recalling about 2.1 million vehicles with airbags that might suddenly deploy even when the vehicle is not in a crash after earlier recalls did not sufficiently address the problem. Federal regulators said replacement parts might not be fully available until the end of the year.

headline: Fire on Williamsburg Waterfront
abstract: The seven-alarm fire on North 11th Street began on Saturday morning.
lead_paragraph: The seven-alarm fire on North 11th Street began on Saturday morning.

headline: White House Seeks to Limit Health Law’s Tax Troubles
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Tax Preparers and Preparation', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: Obama administration officials say they worry that the tax-filing season will generate new anger as uninsured consumers learn that they must pay tax penalties.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Obama administration officials and other supporters of the Affordable Care Act say they worry that the tax-filing season will generate new anger as uninsured consumers learn that they must pay tax penalties and as many people struggle with complex forms needed to justify tax credits they received in 2014 to pay for health insurance.

headline: An Expressive, Propulsive Voice
abstract: The Miller Theater’s Composer Portraits series shines a bright spotlight on female composers.
lead_paragraph: The Miller Theater’s Composer Portraits series has long been an invaluable new-music series, offering a carefully curated anthology of works by a single author that allows audiences to immerse themselves in one compositional voice.

headline: Do-It-Yourself Mining in Eastern Ukraine
abstract: The rebel government has lifted a ban on private coal mining, a widespread practice in the financially struggling region.
lead_paragraph: The rebel government has lifted a ban on private coal mining, a widespread practice in the financially struggling region.

headline: A Silver Lining Coated in Coal Dust in Eastern Ukraine
abstract: The rebel government has lifted a ban on private coal mining, a widespread practice in the financially struggling region.
lead_paragraph: SNIZHNE, Ukraine — Outside Vladimir Moroz’s snug little brick home, winter and hardship grip war-stricken eastern Ukraine. Money is scarce, the store shelves are bare and an icy wind whips over the snowy steppe.

headline: Losing Mobility and Gaining a Work Life
abstract: Permanently paralyzed when he was a teenager, an author says that programs offering summer jobs to high school students with disabilities gave him a strong sense of purpose.
lead_paragraph: I always cringe a little when I hear people say that affirmative action doesn’t work or isn’t fair. That’s because I know I wouldn’t be where I am today without it. I also know that very few people see the issue from the same perspective that I do.

headline: Bad Tayloring
abstract: If the rule doesn’t fit, you must admit … that you were wrong.
lead_paragraph: Since they aren’t currently able to demand a return to the gold standard — and maybe a ban on paper money? — Republicans are pushing to mandate that the Fed follow the so-called Taylor rule, which relates short-term interest rates to unemployment (and/or the output gap) and inflation. John Taylor, not surprisingly, likes this idea. But it’s a really terrible idea, and not just for the reasons Tony Yates describes.

headline: Blue Dot for Obama Prompts Red Nebraska to Revisit Electoral College Rules
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidential Election of 2008', 'Electoral College', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Elections (US)']
abstract: Nebraska is one of just two states, along with Maine, that do not award all their electoral voters to the statewide winner.
lead_paragraph: LINCOLN, Neb. — If this state had an official color, it would most certainly be red. Football fans here don scarlet sweatshirts each game day, red meat is a dietary staple and, for decades, Republican presidential candidates filled Nebraska’s borders on the electoral map with their party’s hue.

headline: The Voice Mail Oracle Speaks (Silly)
abstract: What is technology trying to tell me?
lead_paragraph: Princeton has Microsoft speech recognition on its voice mail; I’ve used Google for other purposes. The Google versions tend to be funny but decipherable; the Microsoft versions, well.

headline: Carl Djerassi, 91, a Creator of the Birth Control Pill, Dies
abstract: Dr. Djerassi was one of two chemists working with a student assistant who in 1951 first synthesized a hormone that became the key ingredient of the contraceptive pill.
lead_paragraph: Carl Djerassi, an eminent chemist who 63 years ago synthesized a hormone that changed the world by creating the key ingredient for the oral contraceptive known as “the pill,” died on Friday at his home in San Francisco. He was 91.

headline: Bait and Switch, a Common Ploy of Patriots and Seahawks
abstract: The Patriots and the Seahawks share a knack for the trick play. They make it look like something that the defense recognizes, but it is something entirely different.
lead_paragraph: The Patriots and the Seahawks share a knack for the trick play. They make it look like something that the defense recognizes, but it is something entirely different.

headline: Italy Elects President, While Mulling a Change in Role
abstract: Sergio Mattarella, a veteran politician and constitutional court judge, will be Italy’s next president, a post that is expected to be redefined during his tenure.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italian lawmakers on Saturday elected Sergio Mattarella, a veteran politician and constitutional court judge, as the country’s president, a post that is expected to be redefined during his tenure.

headline: Thousands March in Spain to Support Left-Wing Party
abstract: Saturday’s march was the most important rally organized by Podemos since it emerged as a newcomer in Spanish politics last May.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — At least 100,000 supporters of Podemos, the left-wing party that is threatening to overhaul Spain’s bipartisan party system, marched in downtown Madrid on Saturday in a show of force at the beginning of a busy year of elections.

headline: At Age XLIX, Super Bowl Has No Sense of Place
abstract: Super Bowl week is following the trend of uniformity in the N.F.L., where players and teams and stadiums have been slowly dulled of personality.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Most of what makes the setting of this Super Bowl different from all the rest is a climbing wall meant to evoke the Grand Canyon. In a downtown parking lot, visible from the raised set of the N.F.L. Network and near a giant light-up cutout of letters reading XLIX, the wall, made of fake rock, has an enormous video screen in the middle that plays commercials.

headline: Sampling From Music’s Buffet to Find New Arenas
abstract: Pete Wentz and Patrick Stump of Fall Out Boy talk about what went into making their new album.
lead_paragraph: With their second act as a band, the members of Fall Out Boy have pulled off what once seemed at least highly unlikely: not only outlasting their emo peers from the early aughts but also transcending them all the way to the top of the Billboard charts — and with real guitars, too, a rare sound on pop radio today. After a five-year hiatus, the band returned in 2013 with “Save Rock and Roll,” a typically irreverent album that made its debut at No. 1; now, its new single, “Centuries,” is hovering in the Top 20 and scoring sporting events on TVs and in stadiums across the country.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Young Talent, Taking New Steps
abstract: Since its founding in 1959, Nederlands Dans Theater has been remarkably venturesome.
lead_paragraph: Since its founding in 1959, Nederlands Dans Theater has been remarkably venturesome, assembling an impressive contemporary repertory. In 1978, it established Nederlands Dans Theater 2 (NDT2, for short) for dancers between 17 and 22 years old. More than a training ground, NDT2 has a distinct repertory, several pieces from which will be shown in its first season here in five years, including some unusual examples of collaborative choreography. Paul Lightfoot, NDT2’s director, and Sol León, its artistic adviser, teamed up for the highly emotional “Subject to Change” and the eccentric “Shutters Shut,” which unites choreographic play with wordplay as dancers interpret a poem by Gertrude Stein. Working together, the Israeli choreographers Sharon Eyal and Gai Behar created “Sara,” an exploration of memories and dreams.

headline: Folk Works Known as Fraktur
abstract: The Pennsylvania Germans produced the handsome, lavishly embellished documents called fraktur, 200 outstanding examples of which are at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: The Pennsylvania Germans produced the handsome ceramics known as redware and vibrantly painted furniture. They also made lavishly embellished documents called fraktur, 200 outstanding examples of which are in “Drawn With Spirit: Pennsylvania German Fraktur From the Joan and Victor Johnson Collection” opening on Sunday at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

headline: Promethean Fire, Smoldering Still
abstract: An enormous wildfire in August 1910 in the northern Rockies is the focus of an episode of “American Experience.”
lead_paragraph: The great fires in American history are generally identified with a city or a building: Chicago in 1871, Boston in 1872, the Iroquois Theater in 1903, the Triangle shirtwaist factory in 1911. But a wildfire in August 1910 in the northern Rockies dwarfed all of those in geographic scope. An episode of “American Experience” on Tuesday on PBS that examines that blaze borrows one of its nicknames for its title: “The Big Burn.”

headline: Back in Town With Tricky Tunes
abstract: Guillermo Klein, the singer Rebecca Martin, the bassist Larry Grenadier and the drummer Jeff Ballard will play at Rockwood Music Hall.
lead_paragraph: A composer doesn’t necessarily mean a songwriter, especially in jazz. Guillermo Klein, originally from Argentina, who has written brilliantly for his jazz groups in New York and Barcelona since the mid-’90s, never made a distinction. He creates pieces full of tricky counterpoint and canon, but he also writes emotionally direct, harmonically complex, circular songs to be sung by himself and others, including Liliana Herrero and Luciana Souza.

headline: It’s Safe to Look Back
abstract: A Brooklyn Academy of Music retrospective offers John Carpenter’s 1978 classic “Halloween” on Friday.
lead_paragraph: It’s amazing what you can do with ingenuity, a microbudget, a butcher knife and a Captain Kirk mask. Take “Halloween,” John Carpenter’s 1978 classic, which unleashed the killer Michael Myers (not to mention Jamie Lee Curtis) on the world. “John Carpenter: Master of Fear,” a Brooklyn Academy of Music retrospective Thursday through Feb. 22, offers “Halloween” on Friday; other screenings include Mr. Carpenter’s tribute to Hong Kong cinema, “Big Trouble in Little China” (1986); his remake of “The Thing” (1982); and his Reagan-era parable “They Live” (1988).

headline: After Many Milestones, Karrie Webb Returns to Where It All Began
abstract: Webb opened the 2015 L.P.G.A. season at the Golden Ocala Golf and Equestrian Club last week, the site of her first victory in the United States in 1995.
lead_paragraph: OCALA, Fla. — Karrie Webb said she was caught by surprise last week when she arrived at the Golden Ocala Golf and Equestrian Club for the L.P.G.A.’s 2015 season opener and realized she had come full circle.

headline: Richard von Weizsäcker, 94, Dies: First President of Reunited Germany
abstract: Mr. Weizsäcker became West Germany’s head of state in 1984 and served through the merger of East Germany into the Federal Republic of Germany before stepping down in 1994.
lead_paragraph: Richard von Weizsäcker, the patrician first president of the reunited Germany and a guardian of his nation’s moral conscience, has died, the president’s office in Berlin announced on Saturday. He was 94.

headline: Closing the Math Gap for Boys
abstract: An intensive tutoring and mentoring program in Chicago has produced big improvements for kids.
lead_paragraph: ON a recent afternoon, the banter of boisterous adolescents at Edwin G. Foreman High School, in a poor, racially and ethnically mixed Chicago neighborhood, echoed off the corridor walls. But Room 214 was as silent as a meditation retreat. Inside, 16 ninth- and 10th-grade African-American and Latino boys were working, two-on-one, with a tutor. They’re among 1,326 boys in 12 public schools in this city who are sweating over math for an hour every day.

headline: Louisiana Squeezed as Oil Prices Drop
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Shale']
abstract: Every downturn is a little bit different, and every downturn falls unevenly — even within the oil industry, as Louisiana’s complicated place in the current price collapse shows.
lead_paragraph: CUT OFF, La. — “The first thing you hear is, ‘Can you cut 10 percent?’ ” explained Jimmy Lafont, whose towboat operation is one of the countless oil-field service companies spread across south Louisiana. “Cajuns normally have a habit of cutting the price quick like.”

headline: Armenia and Azerbaijan Clash With Increasing Ferocity Over Disputed Land
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: An armed conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan over the territory of Nagorno-Karabakh has escalated with deadly consequences in recent months.
lead_paragraph: An armed conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan over the territory of Nagorno-Karabakh has escalated with deadly consequences in recent months.

headline: Australian Open Intent on Leading the World in Pampering Players
abstract: The Australian Open cafeteria offers goji berries and sushi, the child-care center has a staff of sitters, and the event provides stipends for travel and expenses.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — For decades, professional tennis players struggled with tournament organizers to get more money and better services, and while that battle is far from over, the level of player pampering at the Australian Open suggests a historic victory.

headline: The Only Baby Book You’ll Ever Need
abstract: As anthropology shows, the kids will be all right.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH PORTLAND, Me. — LIKE many parents, I have a particular book I like to give to friends when they announce they’re pregnant for the first time. It is the book I read early in my wife’s pregnancy, blurting out passages about everything from birth, baby minding and child rearing to education, work and discipline. But you probably won’t find it in the baby section of your local bookstore. “The Anthropology of Childhood: Cherubs, Chattel, Changelings,” by David F. Lancy, is an academic title — but it’s possibly the only book that new parents will ever need.

headline: Clashes Intensify Between Armenia and Azerbaijan Over Disputed Land
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Dozens of soldiers on each side have been killed and the countries are perilously close to open war.
lead_paragraph: AGDAM, Azerbaijan — Overshadowed by the fighting in Ukraine, another armed conflict in the former Soviet Union — between Armenia and Azerbaijan over the territory of Nagorno-Karabakh — has escalated with deadly ferocity in recent months, killing dozens of soldiers on each side and pushing the countries perilously close to open war.

headline: Dying Shouldn’t Be So Brutal
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospice Care']
abstract: Where is the public outrage over needless suffering at the end of life?
lead_paragraph: “Travel safe!” It has become a nearly reflexive wish I give to friends who are coming or going. This fall, I noticed myself holding back from saying it to Michael, a dear friend who was wrestling with incurable cancer. The journey metaphor was too poignant.

headline: Michel Nischan
abstract: The chef on the Dalai Lama, Alaskan reality TV shows and playing pétanque with Jacques Pépin.
lead_paragraph: Michel Nischan is a two-time James Beard Award-winning chef who co-founded and now runs Wholesome Wave, a nonprofit sustainable food advocacy group that has forged partnerships with health care providers nationwide to prescribe and make farm-fresh produce available in low-income communities.

headline: Heroes and Bystanders
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Armenians', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: The best way to honor past victims of genocide is to fight it everywhere that it exists today.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the great heroes of the 20th century was Auschwitz prisoner No. 4859, who volunteered to be there.

headline: Our Loud, Proud Left
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'News and News Media', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: What is fueling the cultural activism of the later Obama years?
lead_paragraph: FOR the last week, liberal journalists have been furiously debating whether a new political correctness has swept over the American left. The instigator of this argument was New York magazine’s Jonathan Chait, normally a scourge of Republicans, whose essay on what he dubbed “the new P.C.” critiqued left-wing activists for their zeal to play language cop, shout down arguments and shut down debate outright.

headline: Forty Years of Servitude, and Counting
abstract: A federal judge’s decision on the labeling of aides for the elderly and disabled “companions” means an even longer wait for labor protections.
lead_paragraph: An enduring injustice was supposed to end on Jan. 1. That was the effective date for new rules by the Labor Department that would have required employers of home care aides for the elderly and disabled to pay at least the federal minimum wage and time and a half for overtime. Specifically, the new rules would have ended a federal regulation from 1974 that labeled home care aides “companions,” a designation that lets their employers — generally, for-profit agencies — ignore basic labor protections.

headline: Questions in the Church
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Birth Control and Family Planning']
abstract: Readers share their experiences of divorce, and discuss the Catholic Church’s stand against birth control.
lead_paragraph: Readers share experiences of divorce, and discuss the stand against birth control.

headline: Fighting Racial Isolation in Hartford
abstract: The city’s desegregation program, built on a voluntary school transfer plan and a vibrant system of magnet schools, should inspire politicians in New York.
lead_paragraph: The fact that New York has the most segregated public schools in the nation does not bode well for the state’s future. It is a disaster for poor and minority children, who are disproportionately trapped in schools that will not prepare them for the new economy. And it is harming children of all races and economic levels who are in demographically homogeneous schools that do not reflect society or expose them to fresh perspectives.

headline: Mitt’s White Horse Pulls Up Lame
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Movies']
abstract: How real Mitt fell in love with reel Mitt.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — WHEN the Mitt Romney documentary premiered here at the Sundance Film Festival last year, one member of the audience was especially charmed by the candidate up on the screen.

headline: Retroactively Authorizing War
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Editorials']
abstract: An expansive mandate would leave President Obama and his successors with broad authority to use military force in perpetuity. There are better ideas.
lead_paragraph: They went largely unnoticed, four words President Obama ad-libbed during the State of the Union address last month as he asked lawmakers to provide legal cover for America’s military intervention in Iraq and Syria.

headline: Flexing to Embrace a Flip Side
abstract: Projects at the Park Avenue Armory and New York Live Arts suggest how far flex dancing has traveled from the streets of East New York.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, Jay Donn, a pioneer of the Brooklyn street-dance form known as flex, was stopped by police officers in a subway station. This wasn’t part of the crackdown on dancing in trains: The police were concerned about the wires protruding from the bags he carried. What the officers found inside must have surprised them. This heavily tattooed dancer was transporting tutus.

headline: Whitney Houston’s Daughter Found Unresponsive in Tub
abstract: Bobbi Kristina Brown, the daughter of Whitney Houston and Bobby Brown, was taken to a hospital and was alive on Saturday, a police spokeswoman said.
lead_paragraph: The daughter of the singer Whitney Houston was found unresponsive in a bathtub at her home outside Atlanta on Saturday morning and taken to a hospital, officials said.

headline: Politics Is Personal, and Professional
abstract: Lisa Batiashvili is baffled by the West’s fondness for Valery Gergiev, and by violinists’ obsession with “Strads.”
lead_paragraph: Lisa Batiashvili, the 35-year-old Georgian violinist who is this season’s artist in residence with the New York Philharmonic and will perform Barber’s Violin Concerto with that orchestra this week, is an eloquent musician. In concert and on award-winning recordings, she has captivated critics and audiences with her natural elegance, silky sound and the meticulous grace of her articulation. There is a laserlike directness to her playing that enables her to transmit concentrated emotions without a trace of affectation or theatrics: the musical equivalent to laparoscopic surgery.

headline: Ukraine Fighting Continues as Talks Stall
abstract: Envoys representing Ukraine, Russia and a European monitoring group opened a new round of cease-fire talks in Belarus on Saturday, but without leaders of the Russian-backed separatists.
lead_paragraph: ARTEMOVSK, Ukraine — Envoys representing Ukraine, Russia and a European monitoring group opened a new round of cease-fire talks on Saturday aimed at ending a two-week-old flare-up in violence in the Ukraine war.

headline: What We’re Watching: Sunday Shows
abstract: Mitt Romney said he would not be running for president for a third time, but there are still many 2016 hopefuls who will appear on the Sunday shows.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate in 2012, ended speculation of a third bid for the White House on Friday, but other 2016 Republican hopefuls are still gearing up for a long campaign season. Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin will appear on ABC’s “This Week,” and Mike Huckabee, the former governor of Arkansas, will be on CNN’s “State of the Union.” Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, who just formed an exploratory committee for the presidency, will talk about this move on CBS’s “Face the Nation.”

headline: President of China Minsheng Bank Steps Down
abstract: The China Minsheng Banking Corporation gave no explanation for the resignation of Mao Xiaofeng and no indication whether he had been questioned or was assisting investigators.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The China Minsheng Banking Corporation, one of China’s biggest financial institutions, said on Saturday that its president, Mao Xiaofeng, had resigned for personal reasons unrelated to the bank’s operation, after published reports that he had been taken away to assist the country’s anti-corruption investigators.

headline: When Coaching Is the Family Business
abstract: The sons of coaches Bill Belichick and Pete Carroll are valuable assets to their teams as assistants and have high aspirations in the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — During Super Bowl week, coaches named Belichick and Carroll set about preparing for one of the biggest games of their lives.

headline: Lights Out in Nigeria
abstract: Bulbs dim. Fans slow. Once, my air-conditioner caught on fire.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — WE call it light; “electricity” is too sterile a word, and “power” too stiff, for this Nigerian phenomenon that can buoy spirits and smother dreams. Whenever I have been away from home for a while, my first question upon returning is always: “How has light been?” The response, from my gateman, comes in mournful degrees of a head shake.

headline: The Death of the Dinosaurs
abstract: Maybe an asteroid didn’t wipe them out.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — BY now the image of the demise of the dinosaurs has become iconic: a luckless tyrannosaur looking over its shoulder as a colossal fireball from heaven bears down on the horizon, the monster’s death by vaporization imminent.

headline: ISIS Says It Has Killed 2nd Japanese Hostage
abstract: A video showed the beheading of a journalist, Kenji Goto, killed a week after ISIS announced the killing of another Japanese hostage.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — The Islamic State claimed to have beheaded a Japanese journalist in a video released Saturday night, the culmination of a two-week-long drama that appears to have cost the lives of two Japanese men.

headline: Super Bowl Coaches’ Mutual Respect
abstract: Pete Carroll, coach of the Seattle Seahawks, and Bill Belichick, coach of the New England Patriots, praised each other’s team before they meet in the Super Bowl on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Pete Carroll, coach of the Seattle Seahawks, and Bill Belichick, coach of the New England Patriots, praised each other’s team before they meet in the Super Bowl on Sunday.

headline: Chasing Ghosts, Sleight of Hand and Naked Defensive Backs
abstract: Bill Belichick of the New England Patriots and Pete Carroll of the Seattle Seahawks have both played mind games in the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — So you put the questions to the offensive and defensive coordinators whose fate it was to have spent the two weeks before Super Bowl XLIX in a more or less constant state of sleepless agitation:

headline: Why Judges Tilt to the Right
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Legal Profession', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: Politics shape the bench, even though most lawyers are liberal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — LAWYERS on average are much more liberal than the general population, a new study has found. But judges are more conservative than the average lawyer, to say nothing of the graduates of top law schools.

headline: Onward, Christian Health Care?
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: In our new Gilded Age, mutual aid societies revive.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Theresa Bixby, 63, learned that she had breast cancer four years ago, she reacted as many Americans do. “One of my first thoughts was, ‘will they pay?’ ” she said. But she wasn’t talking about a conventional insurance plan. She lost hers when she left her full-time position for part-time work at her church in Greenville, S.C. She was worried about the program that she had joined six months earlier: Christian Healthcare Ministries.

headline: Super Bowl 2015: Seahawks vs. Patriots Preview
abstract: The Seahawks should be able to put points on the board, which may not be true for Tom Brady and the New England offense, unless the Patriots commit to running the ball and succeed.
lead_paragraph: Patriots vs. Seahawks

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Sports readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L.’s Safety Lessons Run Afoul of Reality

headline: Kel Nagle, Who Staved Off Palmer to Win ’60 British Open, Dies at 94
abstract: Nagle, an Australian, staved off a rally at St. Andrews in Scotland to deny Arnold Palmer’s attempt to capture his third straight major title, and lost to Gary Player in a memorable playoff at the 1965 United States Open.
lead_paragraph: Kel Nagle, one of Australia’s greatest golfers, who denied Arnold Palmer’s attempt to win his third straight major tournament when he staved off Palmer’s rally to capture the 1960 British Open, died on Thursday in Sydney. He was 94.

headline: New York City to Pay $5 Million in ‘Mafia Cops’ Case
keywords: ['Organized Crime', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Twenty-eight years after Nicholas Guido was killed, mistaken for a mobster with the same name by two detectives who were later convicted of moonlighting as hit men, New York City has reached a settlement with Mr. Guido’s family.
lead_paragraph: On Christmas Day in 1986, Nicholas Guido was sitting outside his mother’s Brooklyn home in his bright red Nissan Maxima, wearing the clean white jacket he had just gotten as a gift.

headline: Exams in Years Before Death
abstract: Florida’s seniors lead the nation in the cost of diagnostic tests and imaging during their final two years of life.
lead_paragraph: Florida’s seniors lead the nation in the cost of diagnostic tests and imaging during their final two years of life.

headline: Medical Costs Rise as Retirees Winter in Florida
abstract: Data suggests that many doctors, especially those in states known as winter getaways, increase their revenues by expanding the volume of diagnostic exams.
lead_paragraph: Like many retirees, one couple from upstate New York visit doctors in their winter getaway in Florida. But on a recent routine checkup of a pacemaker, a cardiologist there insisted on scheduling several expensive tests even though the 91-year-old husband had no symptoms.

headline: To Unlock Deflation Puzzle, Mind Your PV = nRT’s
abstract: “Gas physics” might explain the low pressure found in some balls used for the A.F.C. championship game. And then again, maybe not.
lead_paragraph: Yep, it’s for real. The law firm representing the N.F.L. (Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison) has reached out to Columbia University’s department of physics to recruit an expert on “gas physics” to help determine, as has been reported, the “environmental impacts on inflated footballs.”

headline: Taliban Justice Gains Favor as Official Afghan Courts Fail
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: After paying bribes and enduring long delays while pursuing resolution in Afghanistan’s government courts, a growing number of citizens are turning to an informal justice system that includes tribal elders and the Taliban insurgents.
lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Matiullah Khan and Muhammad Aywaz were each dug in, their property dispute in southern Afghanistan at an impasse.

headline: 127-Year-Old Rivalry of Celtic and Rangers Resumes in Scotland
abstract: Rangers and Celtic will end a three-year hiatus when they meet in the semifinals of Scotland’s League Cup.
lead_paragraph: GLASGOW — Rangers and Celtic will renew one of the fiercest feuds in soccer on Sunday when they meet — for the first time in nearly three years — in the semifinals of Scotland’s League Cup. The rivalry, which has spanned 127 years, surely has seen better days.

headline: In Newark, a Youth Hockey Explosion on the Ice
abstract: Many children in Newark do not have the prototypical background of a hockey player, but the sport, once seen as inaccessible, is catching on among the boys and the girls.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — On a recent Saturday morning, an overnight snowstorm had coated the streets of the Ironbound neighborhood. The soccer fields and basketball courts, usually populated by the city’s youth, were empty.

headline: This ‘n’ That
abstract: David Steinberg cracks me up.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — At the end of this post, I’m going to direct you to a very touching tribute to our own Bernice Gordon, who died on Thursday at the age of 101. It was written by today’s constructor, David Steinberg, who collaborated with Ms. Gordon on these two puzzles. Besides being delightful to solve, theirs was a collaboration that covered multiple generations and was the basis of an incredible friendship. I highly encourage you to give it a read.

headline: Potential Premier League Showdown Ends Up Reinforcing the Status Quo
abstract: In a match that was promoted as a global event, the two leading teams in the Premier League fought to a draw in the soccer equivalent of a lukewarm hot chocolate.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With only a few minutes remaining on the clock at Stamford Bridge, Manchester City’s James Milner lashed the ball across the face of Chelsea’s goal, a tantalizing cross that could have been turned in by a stray foot, a sliding knee, a wayward ankle. If one of Milner’s teammates had been in the right spot at the right time, this match — and perhaps this Premier League season — would have felt altogether different.

headline: Warehouse Fire in Brooklyn
abstract: Smoke continued to billow from a seven-alarm fire in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, late Saturday afternoon. The fire, which started around 6:20 AM Saturday, engulfed a warehouse housing official documents.
lead_paragraph: Smoke continued to billow from a seven-alarm fire in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, late Saturday afternoon. The fire, which started around 6:20 AM Saturday, engulfed a warehouse housing official documents.

headline: West Bank: Israeli Forces Fatally Shoot a Palestinian
abstract: Israeli forces fatally shot one Palestinian and wounded another after they were spotted throwing a firebomb onto a road that is also used by Israeli settlers, the Israeli military said.
lead_paragraph: Israeli forces fatally shot one Palestinian and wounded another on Saturday in the West Bank after they were spotted throwing a firebomb onto a road near Nablus that is also used by Israeli settlers, the Israeli military said. Wafa, the official Palestinian news agency, said the dead Palestinian was Ahmed Ibrahim al-Najar, 19. The military said that the soldiers had fired at the suspects’ legs and that the episode was under investigation. In October, Israeli forces fatally shot a 14-year-old Palestinian who also held American citizenship in what the military said were similar circumstances. In December, an Israeli girl, 11, was severely injured when a firebomb hit the car in which she was traveling near her home in a West Bank settlement.
